column2: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Federal assistance to needy transients, long a troublesome problem in many cities, neared its end, as a separate activity, when the FERA, on Sept. 20, closed its shelters and camps to new applicants. Existing facilities will continue to operate until November, when all transient activities will be liquidated.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- The expenditure of millions of dollars of Federal relief funds on Eastern waterways development has "contributed substantially to the relief of unemployment and the revival of industry," President Roosevelt wrote in a letter to Mayor J. Hampton Moore of this city, president of the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 5. -- A strong Williams eleven defeated Middlebury today, by 40 to 0. Williams' aerial attack functioned perfectly and with a heavy fast line the gains through the centre were outstanding.

LOYSTON, Tenn., Oct. 5. - Old-timers who spent all or part of their lives in this 100-year-old village will gather here Sunday for a final reunion before backwaters from the government's new dam cover the countryside more than 100 feet deep.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Search for an extortioner who for two weeks has been sending threatening letters demanding $30,000 from Harold F. McCormick, chairman of the board of the International Harvester Company, was being conducted today among former employes of the Harvester Company.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- A new high in attendance and receipts for the current world series was reached today as the Cubs' fading chances dipped lower under the masterful pitching of General Alvin Crowder on Wrigley Field.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- The play-by-play description of the fourth game of the world series today follows:

SINCE it originates in London, this bulletin should come directly thence. Instead, it arrives via the West Coast, and it announces, briefly and with authority, the nature of the play which Sir James M. Barrie is writing for Elisabeth Bergner: it will present her in the role of the young David against the background of the biblical story.

A bitter conflict between retailer and producer groups as to what constitutes "legal" fair trade practices was seen here yesterday as the aftermath of the announcement during the week of the filing by the National Retail Dry Goods Association of charges with the Federal Trade Commission against alleged "price fixing, monopolistic and collusive practices in violation of the anti-trust laws" by six manufacturing groups.

MARY PICKFORD'S new booklet is comparable with her previous one, "Why Not Try God?" in the simplicity and practical quality of its message and in the directness and gentle sweetness of nature with which it urges its viewpoint upon the reader.

The seventeenth monthly survey on world travel conducted by the American Express Company, made public yesterday, shows that the European war crisis has done little to alter plans for a record season in Fall and Winter travel.

THE Summer was marked by three important events in the Dutch museum world. On July 13 the Rijksmuseum at Amsterdam celebrated its fiftieth anniversary by the opening of another Rembrandt exhibition, to which European and American galleries have contributed works, some famous and some less well known.

JOHN BUCHAN has locked his top drawer and gone away to succeed Lord Bessborough as Governor General of Canada. First-class passengers in the London-Oxford trains will no longer find him buried in a corner of the carriage writing a novel on his knee as the train roars along.

Between 2,000,000 and 3,000,000 Americans saw the President in the last ten days as he crossed the nation on his Western trip; in addition to the large crowds that turned out in the cities (in Los Angeles alone perhaps 1,000,000) there were sizable groups whenever his train stopped for service, which was about every two hours; even at crossroads people waited in the hope of catching a glimpse of him as the special passed by.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4. -- An increasingly liberal policy on the part of the Soviet government toward collective farmers is seen in the decree of Sept. 30 reorganizing the entire system of consumers' cooperatives in the villages, a reform that, the government tells the peasants, assures them in the immediate future a bountiful supply of much-needed goods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Heads of leading aviation agencies and societies were named today by Secretary Roper to serve on a committee to plan suitable activities during the week of Oct. 14-21 in observance of Air Navigation Week, proclaimed by President Roosevelt.
OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 5. -- The text of former President Hoover's speech before the Young Republicans of eleven Western States here this evening was as follows:

Which has the more patrons, the street car, bus and subway or the telephone? In the cities, the street car or its modern counterpart appears still to have the advantage. In New York, for example, where presumably more telephone calls per capita are made than anywhere else in the world, the total number of such calls last year was 2,548,000,000.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 5. -- As dusk and an Autumn mist settled over Locust Valley late this afternoon, the judges of the thirty-third annual Piping Rock Horse Show selected as the grand hunter champion of the notable exhibition the 5-year-old chestnut gelding, Chatter Chat, owned by Mrs. Ellsworth H. Augustus of Willoughby, Ohio.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 5. -- A band of -football animal tamers from Michigan State College, who clipped the Wolverines' claws a year ago to set off the University of Michigan's most disastrous season, did it again today. The score was 25 to 6.

AMERICA cannot develop an enlightened foreign policy unless her college students learn to read the daily newspaper intelligently. That, in substance, is the conclusion of Dr. Karl Polanyi, a political scientist of Vienna, who last Spring was sent by the Institute of International Education on a tour of twenty-four of our Southern colleges.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 5. -- The twentieth anniversary of the opening of Connecticut College will be celebrated during Alumnae Week-end, starting Friday. A feature of the celebration will be the presentation of the Pageant of the Tree, portraying the beginnings of education for women in Connecticut, Saturday afternoon in the Outdoor Theatre under the direction of Miss Catherine Oakes, Assistant Professor of English and the author of the pageant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All over the country Safety Month has recently been observed. State departments, automobile associations and women's clubs have joined to promote education for safety on our highways. It was a most commendable and necessary, movement, but it seems to me that some one has missed a trick.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The Army Air Corps chief gave today to the United States a third-place ranking in air strength among the world's leading powers.

The city's anti-noise drive was launched on Tuesday night. By the end of the week more than 5,000 noisemakers had been warned by police, about ten others arrested and an indeterminate but significant number of decibels had been chopped off the city's nightly quota of noise.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 5. -- The show grounds of the Piping Rock Club today drew a throng for the third day program, including the annual Piping Rock horse show. The children's hacks and hunter classes were featured.

WALL STREET has a strange kind of boss in James McCauley Landis, the new 36-year-old chairman of the Securities and Exchange commission. The man who now regulates the bulls and bears has never invested a penny in stocks or bonds. He earned his last capitalistic cent in a commercial way when he cashed in on his scholastic solidity by peddling "trots" to wealthier, duller and lazier fellow-students at Princeton University.

The first anti-Nazi meeting to be held in Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, located in a neighborhood populated largely by German-Americans, took place last night, with about 150 persons in attendance. Several meetings of Nazi sympathizers have previously been held there.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will head a group of women leaders in education, aviation, religion, the theatre, and other fields, who will contribute to a broadcast Wednesday evening on the theme, "Women Want Peace." Under auspices of the National Council for Prevention of War, the symposium will originate in the NBC studios in Rockefeller Center except for two addresses to come from Chicago, and be heard from 10 to 11 o'clock, through WJZ.

CAMERA and water-color came to the fore in gallery exhibitions of the week, with some outstanding work in both fields. No less than four exhibitions for devotees of photography and three of water-colors are on the calendar.

Mrs. H. Thurston W. Huntting heads a group of women aiding in the plans for a luncheon and fashion show in behalf of Stony Wold Sanitarium Auxiliary No. 6, to be held on Oct. 15 in the new Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza. Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins in the fashion showing of costumes for Autumn and Winter wear, which will be a feature of the entertainment.

MANY miles of fine mountain scenery have been made accessible to the general public by the construction of scenic highways to summits in the Appalachian ranges. Time was when one needed strong legs and a steady heart to scramble to the top of a mountain and experience that deep thrill which comes of standing so near to heaven, with the world all at one's feet.

The annual memorial services of the New York City Fire Department for members who have died during the year will be held this afternoon at the Firemen's Monument, 100th Street and Riverside Drive, with Mayor La Guardia and Fire Commissioner McElligott as the principal speakers.

ROME, Oct. 5. -- The Italians are overjoyed by the development of the past twenty-four hours. While on one hand their army in East Africa has won several early successes that have inflamed their patriotism and swollen their national pride, the threat of sanctions and serious European complications on the other hand is regarded as receding into the distance.

The results of the recent effort of the Appellate Division to clear the congested calendars of the Supreme Court in New York and Bronx counties of dormant cases were announced yesterday by Presiding Justice Martin of the Appellate bench.

We have at our service in these days far more numerous statistical indices of business conditions than were available in any other period of industrial recovery. The industrial trend will be ascertained by comparing with a preceding week or month the loadings of railway freight, the production of steel, coal and other industrial commodities, the sale of motor cars, factory employment, building construction contracts, mill consumption of cotton, output of electric power, nation-wide retail purchases.

GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- The Italo-Ethiopian conflict has brought two big surprises. First, it has brought the question of applying sanctions out of the clouds into the realm of practical discussion. Second, this discussion is going on under conditions that seemed even more incredible beforehand.
VISITORS to the New England coast are frequently amused by the odd fishing expressions more or less peculiar to the locale. One never hears a native say, "It is thick with fog today."

The modern educational system, with its overcrowded and complex curricula, is failing to produce men and women of culture and character, according to Sir Alfred T. Davies, British educator, who for eighteen years was Permanent Secretary of Education for Wales.

ITALIAN troops pour into East Africa, spurred on in the fight against heat, rough terrain and tropical pestilence by memories of the old Roman legions. No less inspired, the Ethiopians await the issue -- the independence of their royal line and religious culture which trace descent from King Solomon and early Christian proselytizers forming the background for their valor.

ANOTHER of the films to be done in the grand manner was launched this week when the cameras began turning on Metro's most elaborate musical, "The Great Ziegfeld," scheduled to cost $1,500,000. While the studio press department was unable to find any adjectives that had not been used on previous epics, the lads did adduce evidence indicating that this might become one of the more distinguished offerings of the season.

The transaction consummated by the Van Sweringen interests last week, when, through $3,121,000 put up by friendly associates, they regained control of a railroad system with $3,000,000,000 of assets, was described in Wall Street as possibly one of the most extreme uses to which the holding company principle has been applied.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 5 (AP). -- A powerhouse of speed and drive on the ground and a menace in the air, Marquette's football team achieved today what eleven of its predecessors failed to do -- defeat Wisconsin. It did the trick by the score of 33 to 0, outplaying the Badgers in every department of the game.

The Children's Welfare Federation will be aided by a series of six children's plays to be presented by the Clare Tree Major Children's Theatre on Saturday mornings at the Barbizon Plaza Theatre, the first of which, "Robin Hood," will be given on Oct. 19. Subsequent plays include "Hans Brinker," "Alice in Wonderland," "Beauty and the Beast," "Heidi" and "Secret Garden."

Textile, Curtis and John Adams were the winners in the first of the annual series of P.S.A.L. group cross-country runs at Van Cortland Park yesterday. Textile, the Manhattan P.S.A.L. champion last year, was an easy victor with 36 points over Stuyvesant in Group Three. Curtis, the Richmond titleholder, won in Group One with 33 points, while John Adams took first place in Group Two with 55 points.

Profiting by the harrowing experience it had in its opening game of the season against Franklin and Marshall last week, a greatly improved Fordham eleven swung into action early in yesterday's contest with Boston College at the Polo Grounds and evened the twenty-game series with the Eagles.

HELEN HAYES, now appearing in her first regular radio series, admits that she has almost completely overcome her early inherent fear of the microphone and now looks upon broadcasting as stimulating, ever-changing and always refreshingly new.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- A pageant honoring the memory of John Howard Payne, the Union College alumnus who wrote "Home, Sweet Home," will be the outstanding event of the annual college week-end program on the campus from next Friday to Sunday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Farthest North" discoveries by the Russian Government of an ancient Siberian civilization in Yamal peninsula, reported in THE TIMES, draw attention to the Siberian Samoyede tribe, which occupies the peninsula seven months of the year, living mainly by reindeer-herding, aided by their Samoyede dogs.

New York has joined London in declaring war upon noise, and no doubt other big cities will follow. As some day it may happen that the world runs out of undesirable sounds to suppress, we might draw up a little list of pestilential noises that never will be missed.

ONCE the discovery is made that indoor gardening is not entirely earthbound, numerous attractive arrangements suggest themselves for varying the material of the window garden and adding to its gayety. Growing plants in water makes possible the use of many a bright pottery bowl or delicate treasured vase.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 5. -- The University of Georgia defeated the University of Chattanooga, 40 -- 0, today before a crowd of 4,500 fans in the first game between the two schools since 1915, when the teams tied, 6 to 6.

Politicians in the United States have only to look across the northern border to be reminded again that politics is almost as uncertain as the weather and political prophecy often mere bluffing. A few weeks ago victory of the Canadian Liberals in the Federal elections of Oct. 14 seemed as sure as anything can be.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Loosing all the fury that has been bottled up since its surprise tie with little Howard College a week ago, Alabama's Crimson Tide came back to the football heights today with a relentless attack that crushed George Washington University, 39 to 0.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 5. -- Dartmouth scored successive touchdowns on the first two running plays of the game today, and Vermont was buried under a 47-0 score as the Indians romped at will. The Big Green showed a fine forward and lateral passing attack during the first period, making 33 points in this quarter.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area made marked gains last week, with increases up to 12 per cent or more noted for leading department stores here. While purchasing of Fall apparel tended to vary with weather conditions, consumer demand for many types of home furnishings was excellent.

THE cars of 1936, according to advance information, promise smoother riding, better brakeing ability and greater ease of handling coupled with lower upkeep cost. While some new models have been shown to the public, many companies will withhold display of their new products until the opening of the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace Nov. 2.

Five men, two of them arrested in New York by Secret Service agents, were held at police headquarters in Passaic last night, charged with financing beer-drinking forays in that part of New Jersey with counterfeit $20 bills.
Surf fishermen may be divided roughly into two classes.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- The new "pouff veils" of tulle, chenille or lace are veils in name only; they do not even shade the eyes or forehead, but are posed like a chou atop the crown of the hat and spread out round the head in supple, cloudy aureole.

A total of $50,342 was netted by the first art auction of the season to be held by the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. The sale, which opened Thursday, was completed yesterday afternoon. It consisted of furniture, plate, Oriental rugs and other art objects from the collections of Charles Robertson of London, Augustus Lukeman, A.N.A.; Mrs. George R. Van Reed and other owners.

RETURNING from London and Paris to Italy was like entering another world. At the moment when England and France were thoroughly worked up over Italian defiance, were united as Northern Europe has not been for years by a complex of alarms and anger -- primarily the anger against the war-maker of people who remember war -- to cross the Alps was to break through a canvas to the other side of the picture.
GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- Ethiopia's plea in a note to the League of Nations today said:

The United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md., will celebrate the ninetieth anniversary of its founding on Thursday with simple exercises which will be attended by many graduates prominent in naval and civilian life.

The flight of capital from Europe has been primarily a flight from the pound sterling, and the great influx of gold to this country, coming apparently from the gold-bloc countries, has, in fact, come chiefly out of the hidden gold reserves of]the British Exchange Equalization Fund, according to bankers whose international connections enable them to see beneath the surface of important monetary movements like those of the last few weeks.

Representatives of the city and the security groups of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company will sign a "memorandum of understanding" this week, covering the city's acquisition of the rapid transit lines of both companies, it was indicated yesterday.

Eight transfers of detectives, regarded at police headquarters as a minor shake-up, were made known yesterday through an order issued by Assistant Chief Inspector Henry E. Bruckman, in command of the detective division.
HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Rice opened its home season today with a 27-to-7 victory over a hard-fighting eleven from Duquesne University before a crowd estimated at 10,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP). -- In a hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C., far from the hue and cry of world series battle, Mrs. Alvin Crowder will be getting much better tonight because her husband won himself a ball game today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Is the King James version of the Bible, which is in most general use in English-speaking lands, the only and original "Authorized Bible"?
CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- A marked change in sentiment occurred overnight in the domestic and foreign grain trade and today there was a noticeable lack of pressure on the markets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Two New England States were reported by the Home Owners Loan Corporation today among the six highest in the country in foreclosure actions resulting from delinquent payment of home owners.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 5. -- The Meadow Brook Hunt opened its Autumn fox hunting season this morning with a meet at the stables on the estate here of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney. Harvey Dow Gibson of Locust Valley and Harry T. Peters of Islip, co-masters, led a field of almost 100 subscribers to the hunt, and a few guests, all of whom wore formal livery for the first time this year.

HOLLYWOOD. DURING those months of agitation when the cinema worked itself into a state believing that the wily agents of Moscow were about to descend upon California and tax the practically destitute producers, stars and directors to death, the industry declared that the day of the location was over and that, with improved technical effects and the universal use of the process shot, movies might just as well be made in New York.

WHILE on a recent visit to Schenectady, Henry Ford, automobile manufacturer, was fascinated by a demonstration of the power of radio to link the automobile on a city street or country highway with cities far across the horizon.
MEXICO, No., Oct. 5 (AP). -- With tears and then ejaculations of happiness, Mrs. Nellie Tipton Muench received today a jury verdict acquitting her of kidnapping conspiracy charges.

CIVILIAN Conservation Corps youths, hewing a rugged single-track road through twenty-four miles of mountain country, finally have brought North America's deepest canyon within reach of the skillful traveler. The driver willing to negotiate the narrow upland road connecting Imnaha, Ore., and the Hat Point lookout station can now gaze downward more than 7,000 feet to where the Snake River surges through Hell's Canyon, a gorge of almost unbelievable depth.

THE Little Singers of Paris, who will he heard in recital here tomorrow, are officially known as Les Petits Chanteurs a la Croix de Bois. The organization is the result of the efforts of a few French students who some twenty-seven years ago grouped the children of the Faubourgs and started choir rehearsals.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5 (AP). -- A fighting band of Auburn Plainsmen gave Tulane's Green Wave a setback today, winning 10 to 0, before 18,000 spectators, and broke up what the fans had believed was another conference winner.

WHAT oftenest is asked concerning a contemporary portrait amounts merely to the question of likeness. And all portraits are more or less likenesses in representing the idea the artist has of him, which quite possibly is unlike the idea any one else has of him.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 5. -- Postmaster General Farley today assailed the outcry against any change in the Constitution, declaring that from the beginning of the Republic "the financial power" has always "stooped to the cheap demagogy of pretending that to Suggest an amendment is to attack the fundamental law."

CITY'S FREEDOM: In the Summer of 1887 Andrew Carnegie was in Scotland with his young bride, the former Louise Whitfield of Connecticut. They stopped off at Edinburgh, where the Scottish-American steel magnate laid the cornerstone of the Free Library and gave the city $250,000.

Long after the depression has ended, said Gerard Swope, chairman of the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs, which is making a drive for funds to support private welfare organizations in the United States, the bills for it will be coming in, the bills for "repair of damage wrought."

The National Munitions Control Board recently created by act of Congress grew naturally out of the development of modern arms. As long as war machines were simple and secondary to manpower, the nations paid little attention to control measures.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- The Boulder Brook Club here will have a reception and tea tomorrow in honor of new members. Mrs. Christopher T. Chenery and Mrs. Joseph Carreau will preside at the tea table. Christopher T. Chenery is president of the club.

A national alarm for Daniel J. Driscoll, 63-year-old subway contractor, who has been missing from his home, 52-15 189th Street, Flushing, Queens, since Sept. 3, was issued yesterday by the Missing Persons Bureau of the Police Department.

CARRYING on the story begun in his earlier book, "Peacock's Feather," this new novel by Mr. Hellman tells what happened to Croesus and to the most beautiful of women, Delarai, after Aesop perished at the hands of the Grecian mob.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 5. -- North Carolina's fast backs and superb line crushed the University of Tennessee eleven today, 38 to 13. The defeat was the worst the Vols have suffered in many years.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 5. -- Twenty-five thousand persons thronged the streets of Greenwich this afternoon to witness the largest and most colorful parade in the town's history, held in observance of the Connecticut tercentenary, in which scenes of the early days in the State were recalled.

HOWEVER much we may disagree as to the specific merit of this or that canvas by Fernand Leger, we are not likely to quarrel with the scope of the artist's present one-man show at the Museum of Modern Art, which will remain through Oct. 24.

THE operatic cycle, impelled by the success of the Grace Moore films, begins to be upon us. What is more, some of the operatic cyclists who were busily engaged in filmic endeavors during the hot and weary Summer months have pedaled their way back across the continent from Hollywood and even now are in the city recuperating from their labors.

Receiverships and bankruptcies destroy neither the assets nor the earning power of railroads, it is pointed out in an analysis of defaulted railway bonds by Pask Walbridge. The analysis maintains that securities issued in the reorganizations of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas in 1922, the Wabash in 1915 and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific in 1927 later showed considerable appreciation.

ON a single day recently, one of New York's leading travel agencies had, in addition to its normal business, applications for passage to Zululand, in the interior of Africa; to the Edie Creek gold fields, in the interior of New Guinea; to Baghdad, in Mesopotamia; to Tashkent, far in the interior of Asia to the south and east of the Sea of Aral, and to Great Bear Lake in Arctic Canada.

For the first time this Fall, the executive board of the National Society of New England Women will convene Tuesday at the Hotel Lexington. Mrs. Parlan Semple Jr. of Montclair, elected to the presidency at the close of the last club season, will officiate.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 5. -- Two long runs of 70 yards each by Nick Kotys and Andy Stopper featured Villanova's 20-to-0 victory over Western Maryland on the main line gridiron today.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 5 (Reuters). -- Adowa, Italy's main objective at the moment, remains in Ethiopian hands despite a three-day battering by bombing planes and artillery.

THE Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, Eugene Goossens conductor, has issued a twenty- eight-page booklet on the orchestra's forty-first season, to open on Oct. 18 and close on April 25. There will be sixteen pairs of events in the symphony series, given Friday afternoons and Saturday evenings, with soloists appearing at ten pair, the University of Cincinnati Oratorio Chorus participating in one pair and the May Festival Chorus in another pair.

A REPRESENTATIVE committee of AE's admirers and personal friends has begun work in Dublin toward the erection there of a public monument to his memory. At the moment the proposal is to erect in Stephens Green a wall with a sculptured plaque which may represent the varied activities of the dead poet, critic, economist, prose-writer, and philosopher.

The most astonishing thing about "Death at Dayton's Folly" is the weather. California weather. California weather which is overwhelmingly, all-conqueringly, unremittingly bad. To the knowledge of the present reviewer, such a thing has never before been met with in writing or speech, however common it may be in nature; and in this book it is a feature of the story.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Crisp Fall weather and an unusually successful furniture week promotion combined to give the city the best week's retail trade in at least two months. Dollar totals passed 1934 for the first time this Fall. Furniture sales were in excess of expectations, while the demands for featured carpetings drew on the reserves of local warehouse stocks.
OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 5. -- In a fighting speech studded with sarcasm, Herbert Hoover delivered tonight a sharp and comprehensive attack against the fiscal policies of the Roosevelt administration.

HARRAR, Ethiopia, Sept. 20 (By mail). -- At a table in the corner of a Greek pension, Wehib Pasha directs the organization of 150,000 Ethiopians as he checks from an ordinary pocket map the positions which this country is fortifying against Italian attack.

Ethiopia is one of the great natural fortresses of the world, and the problem facing the Italian Army is graphically shown by the map, on which are traced the outlines of the great plateau, split by deep valleys, which makes up the bulk of the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Presidential commission as General and Chief of Staff of the Army was today formally presented by Harry H. Woodring, Acting Secretary of War, to Major Gen. Malin D. Craig, who was appointed to the office this week. The presentation was at a brief ceremony in the office of the Secretary.
LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The most violent attacks on Italy that could be heard in Britain today continued to come from English churchmen, from the Archbishop of Canterbury down.

IF college enrolments are a reliable barometer, prosperity's sun shines warmer this Fall than last on the United States from coast to coast. And it beams brightest not on the purlieus of Wall Street but on the wide-open spaces of the West, where people cut corn instead of coupons.

ABOARD S.S. ROTTERDAM, Oct. 5. -- Less than six days after the Holland-America liner Rotterdam, while on a cruise in the Caribbean Sea ran on Southwest Reef off Cays Morant, the vessel was floated at 5:30 this afternoon. Apparently the stanchly built ship came off undamaged.

A demand for immediate action in increasing the force of packers and openers employed at the Appraiser's Stores building, where imported merchandise is examined for duty assessment, will be carried to Washington this week by a special committee of five importers, it was announced yesterday.

The scooping out of Sixth Avenue for a new link of the city independent subway will soon begin. On last Friday bids were opened for building the section between Fortieth and Forty-seventh Streets, and the successful contractor is required to start work within the next thirty days.

The League of Nations was no happy-go-lucky or overnight creation. It was the result of long years of study and effort and tentative approach. It was, in fact, the outgrowth of a world movement, the intention of which, as recently defined by an English writer, was to prescribe "open, just and honorable relations between nations."

The first intersectional National Football League game to be staged in the East this season will take place at Ebbets Field this afternoon as the Brooklyn Dodgers engage the Detroit Lions in their home debut. Game time is set for 2:30 o'clock.

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 5. -- A sturdy Kent School eleven which marched 61 yards for a touchdown after taking the opening kick-off and never relinquished the lead conquered Loomis School, 18 to 6, today on the latter's field in the season's opening football game for both.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5. -- For a time today it seemed that the Pittsburgh jinx over Notre Dame was as effective as it had been during the last three years. By virtue of a beautiful placement kick by Coleman Kopcsak from the 37-yard line just before the close of the second period, Carnegie Tech jumped into a lead over the Ramblers and sent 35,000 local fans into hysteria.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- As a climax to the sesquicentennial of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, the cornerstone of the new Trinity Cathedral was laid here today at West State and Overbrook Avenues.

NOW that you have read and heard about all the big excitements in the new styles, it is high time to pay some attention to the little ones. They are worth plenty of consideration. Creative genius has taken quite a fling at the et ceteras.

Columbia opened its season with a victory over Virginia Military Institute yesterday, but it was not the kind of a triumph that would influence old grads to pull down the goal posts in wild jubilation. Instead, some 14,000 Lion well-wishers silently filed out of Baker Field wondering why the Blue could administer no better than a setback to a team that had been routed 44 -- 0 by Tulane the week before.

Taking advantage of a break in the third quarter to score the only tally of the game, Curtis High of Staten Island conquered Flushing, 7 -- 0, in a hard-fought contest yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field. A crowd of 6,000 saw the victors give the Red Devils their first setback in eighteen games, two of which resulted in ties, since the start of 1933.
The average Hunter College girl of the class of '39 is 17 years old, has a cosmopolitan background and wants to be a teacher.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- President Roosevelt shortly after 11 o'clock tonight issued a proclamation declaring an arms embargo against Italy and Ethiopia as required by the Joint Neutrality Resolution adopted in the closing days of the recent session.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct 5. -- With water-borne commerce of San Francisco at the point of complete paralysis, A.B. Sloss, Federal arbitrator, today delivered another blow at longshoremen, insisting that they abandon their continued boycott on the "hot" steamer Point Clear and go to work.

WHEN Hollywood embroils itself in the drama of controversy and ideas, it is well for the judicious to get out of the way. Like the small boy with an air rifle, the studios are likely to hit almost anything but the target.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Continuing on the beaten path, Cornell's football eleven sustained its second defeat of the season on Schoellkopf Field today as Western Reserve's heavy team outran and outpassed the Ithacans for a 33-19 victory.

GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- Ethiopia invoked Article XVI's sanctions, non-military and military, against Italy today. Never before in League of Nations history has this grave stage been reached, and the Council left the decision until Monday after naming a committee of six to prepare meanwhile to name the aggressor.

Interest centred in the coffee futures market yesterday with the sugar market continuing its Saturday holidays during October. Offices of refiners and brokers for raw and refined sugars will continue to operate on a five-day week.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- As the strike of dairy farmers spread today with increasing curtailment of Chicago's milk supply, it was marked by a first death.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- Leopold Stokowski, who has reprimanded more than one Philadelphia orchestra audience for applauding between movements of a symphony, congratulated an audience tonight for "breaking all the rules" by doing just that.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- With Premier Mussolini's legions on the march and his bombing planes dropping "civilization" upon Ethiopian villages the British Government has at last come face to face with the events it has dreaded for the past six months or more.
AT Annapolis, where "Severn joins the tide," the United States Naval Academy celebrates next Thursday the ninetieth anniversary of its founding.

CAIRO. -- In less than fifty hours after leaving London I was in Cairo. The first person to receive me on Egyptian soil, at the Heliopolis Airdrome, was a little black newsboy. One of his magazines caught my eye. Judging by its format it was a humorous paper with Arab jokes reading from right to left, and although I naturally could not understand them, the cover attracted my attention.
GUATEMALA. -- No great increase in trade may be expected from recent tariff and immigration concessions obtained by Japan from Guatemala as a result of negotiations by Minister Yoshiatsu Hori.

FEW laymen, and probably no true gardener, will dispute the statement that daffodils are the most beloved of all Spring's offerings. More assured than crocuses, more friendly and simple than tulips, they seem to embody the very spirit of the young year.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday net assets on Sept. 30 of $100.64 a share on the 682,700 no-par shares of capital stock, excluding treasury shares. This is the first quarterly report issued by the trust since its formation in 1929 showing a liquidating value of more than $100 a share, the amount which it realized on the offering of its common stock to the public.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The declaration that the budget cannot be balanced next year, nor a balance even approached, unless PWA and WPA allocations and rivers and harbors programs are abandoned, was made today by Representative Chester C. Bolton, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee.

VIENNA, Oct. 5. -- The Austrian Nazis have played a trick on the Ostmaerkischen, Sturmscharen, the clerical armed organization, by printing and distributing leaflets in which an appeal was made in the name of that organization "to all good Austrians" to join a corps of volunteers for the Italian expeditionary force in Ethiopia.

AS a result of President Roosevelt's decision to make culture a white-collar project the Federal Government is about to become a patron of the arts on a scale unequaled in the palmy days of Greece, Rome, Renaissance Italy, republican France or pre-war Vienna.

THE Indians of Canada, thanks to science, are increasing. Schools, health education, regular inspection by government doctors, vocational training, are some of the means whereby the Indian population has been saved from extinction and tuberculosis and trachoma have been checked.

The two-hour trading period for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was marked by the sudden flurry in the local traction issues in response to the announcement that a tentative agreement has been reached between city officials and representatives of the rapid transit companies on a price for the properties in unification proceedings.

Many steel authorities believe that the largest part of our steel output will be in some form of stainless steel "in the not too distant future," according to a pamphlet entitled "The Stainless Prince of Steels," made public yesterday by the Chemical Foundation, Inc.
ROME, Oct. 5. -- Don Alfonso de Bourbon, Duke of Toledo and the one-time King of Spain, has no intention of relinquishing his claim to the throne to the Infante Don Juan, friends said today.
OAKLAND Calif., Oct. 5. -- Here are some highlights from Herbert Hoover's address at the Republican convention tonight:
EXETER, N.H., Oct. 5. -- By opening a fast attack in the second period Exeter came from behind to defeat the Yale freshmen, 7 to 6, today.

New York City, the second largest governmental spending agency in the United States (the Federal Government alone exceeding it in annual expenditures), is now in the throes of preparing its budget for the coming year.

ROME, Oct. 5. -- Since dawn the Italian troops have been heavily engaged in the big mountains that bar access to Adowa, according to frequent reports to the War Office here from the front. Over a barren, rocky inferno, made up of narrow gorges, treacherous passes, impassable ravines and almost unscalable peaks the battle has been raging all day.

IN this column's first-night review of Mr. Anderson's verse tragedy those lines were described as "formal and prolix." They are not. They are as hard and cutting as emerald dust, and a fair token of the philosophy and style of a fine American drama which ought to be produced.

TORONTO, Oct 4 (Canadian Press). -- Representatives of Toronto business and financial firms at a meeting tonight formed a Toronto Better Business Bureau, to be linked with bureaus in Montreal, Winnipeg and the United States. The bureau aims to give protection against fraud, misrepresentation and general malpractice in business.

Cocos Island, which President Roosevelt intends to visit on his voyage from California to Panama, is one of the most fascinating small islands in the world. It is a lonely dot on the sea, 300 miles from the coast of Costa Rica, and for a good part of the year is shrouded in rain-clouds and beaten by tempests.
Today's front page topics are also today's club program themes, with disturbance in Africa and the balancing of the city budget alike waking echoes in conference rooms and on the rostrum.

THE Hydrographic Office of the navy is constantly alert to guard airmen. It issues, over the signature of Rear Admiral W. R. Gherardi, many timely warnings on the conditions of airports and landing areas, new obstructions and the like.

Applications for the principalships of Tottenville High School, Bayside High School and the Manhattan Evening Trade School for Girls should be submitted not later than Friday on forms obtainable in Room 507 at the Board of Education, according to an announcement by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 5. -- A report was adopted by the National Conference of Labor Legislation today stating that government in America, both national and local, was destined to engage not only in slum reclamation projects but in providing low-rental housing and "an adequate supply of good dwellings for the whole population."

CARMEL, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Tribute to the memory of Daniel Drew, philanthropist, will mark the observance of the seventieth anniversary of the dedication of the Daniel Drew Methodist Episcopal Church in this village next week. This church was built in the community where he was born and was dedicated Oct. 10, 1865.

The Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., will advise its members, with the exception of the few high style houses, against preparing special collections for the Palm Beach and Southern resort seasons, Samuel Klein, executive director, said yesterday.

MR. SEABURY'S title is an adjuration to his readers not to allow themselves to become shallow, silly, unthinking persons, what he calls "dormorons," but to train their minds and keep them vigorous in creative activity, independent thinking, personal and not imitative expression.

As a stylist Bertrand Russell's qualities are an almost naive simplicity, crystal clarity, a calm Olympian irony, and a gift for compressed, epigrammatic statement. As a thinker he is distinguished for the acuteness of his logic and a scientific detachment that makes him look habitually for the evidential basis for opinions which most of us accept on emotional grounds.

The d'Aulaires are not ordinary travelers. On their journeys to Norway and Lapland they have looked about them with the clear-eyed pleasure that children take in new sights and strange lands, and into their book has gone the magic of the North and the romance of snow-covered countries.
The City College eleven gained its second victory of the season by subduing St. Francis of Brooklyn, 14-0, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

Garden enthusiasts from the metropolitan district and from New Jersey will meet Sunday, Oct. 13, for the Radio Garden Club Field Day to be held at the New York Botanical Garden. The garden's 700-foot dahlia border, now at the height of its bloom; early flowering outdoor chrysanthemums, late blooming roses, and a wide variety of Fall annuals will be included in the tour of inspection which has been planned for the afternoon.
OTTAWA, Oct. 5. -- Canada has never known a general election campaign like that which will culiminate on Oct. 14. There are five parties, some 900 candidates and no one clear-cut issue.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 5. -- Duke University's Blue Devils conquered the husky Washington and Lee eleven today by the score of 26 to 0. Clarence (Ace) Parker, Portsmouth (Va.) star, was Wallace Wade's trump card as the Devils blasted the Generals' hopes for a successful defense of their Southern Conference championship.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 5, -- Navy defeated Mercer, 27 to 0, in its second game before 8,000 today. The Middies did all the scoring in the first half.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 5. -- With most of the varsity watching the game from the sidelines, Holy Cross crushed the University of Maine eleven this afternoon in a one-sided football game, 47 to 0.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Success of the $140,000,000 refunding program of the Sanitary District of Chicago became assured today when deposits of old bonds exceeded 85 per cent, the amount required under the plan F.B. Hall, vice president of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, reported that the five local banks acting as refunding agents had received about $120,000,000 of the outstanding bonds. Engraving of new bonds was ordered started at once.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Oct. 5 (AP). -- The Panthers of Pittsburgh, showing the power, brawn and speed traditional of Jock Sutherland's football machines, overwhelmed Washington and Jefferson, 35 to 0, today in the teams' thirty-third annual meeting.

An acceleration of the rise that had been resumed on Thursday and extended on Friday was evident yesterday in the financial markets. Almost overnight, the war scare was converted into ammunition suitable for speculators committed to the rise.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5. -- A unique experiment is being worked out by the School of Architecture at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to bring to first-year students the stimulating realities of planning and supervising the construction of a modern house.

The first four days of the city's anti-noise campaign have shown clearly, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday, that the citizens of the community are almost unanimously in favor of his drive to make New York a quieter place in which to live.

Before a cheering crowd of 1,000 persons at Fifty-fifth Avenue and Queens Boulevard yesterday, Mayor La Guardia announced that the last barrier to the removal of the tracks of the Manhattan Queens Traction Company, long an obstacle to the improvement of that thoroughfare, had been disposed of.
In a report from Vienna I read the following concerning our "Parcifal" performance:

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- Britain has refused even to answer Premier Mussolini's suggestion that there should be a simultaneous Anglo-Italian cancellation of precautionary measures in the Mediterranean and Red Sea areas.

AMES, Iowa, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Nebraska's scarlet-clad football giants brought their power and cunning to State Field today to crush Iowa State by 20 to 7 in their opening bid for the Big Six Conference championship. About 12,000 saw the game.

Firethorn found himself in the $21,330 Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday and ran the greatest race of his career to encompass the defeat of Count Arthur, one of the shortest-priced favorites on an afternoon which saw form knocked galley west once more.

ROME, Oct. 5. -- The might of Premier Benito Mussolini's modern African army was hurled against ancient Ethiopia today in a three-sided attack. Infantry, tanks, cavalry and aerial squadrons went into action.

ANEW social pattern is being woven into the daily routine at Mount Holyoke College with an eye to the integrating more successfully of students' intellectual and social development during the coming year. The design, worked out by the trustees and members of the administration after a study of other "house plans," features the enrichment of cultural life.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 3. -- Although the speech of President Roosevelt at Fremont on the farm policies of his administration has had a good reception generally throughout the Western staple growing States, including the Northwest, elements of weakness which may easily assume importance are detectable from the reactions in this territory.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 5. -- An improved Rutgers team defeated Marietta 26 -- 9 today in the first intersectional game ever played on Neilson Field.

Important events in important organizations top the women's club schedule for the week in Manhattan. Conventions, seasonal openings and programs, and conferences are the order of the next several days.

When the spectacular career of Arnold Rothstein was ended in a hotel room by pistol shots seven years ago, it was suggested immediately, and almost universally believed, that his estate would come to high figures, possibly as much as $3,000,000.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 5. -- Dessye, 175 miles northeast of this city, around which the main Ethiopian Army is gathered, was bombed at 8 o'clock this morning and probably will be evacuated.

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- Reports regarding the activity of various German societies in America have irritated officials here, and the Foreign Office in a communique takes special objection to information obtained in other quarters and reported to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

AN anthropologist, an experimental psychologist and an artist, after an expedition in the jungles of human behavior, have just returned with a bagful of gestures as their sole prize. An odd capture, surely, but then their quest was a curious one: to determine whether immigrants, under the influence of an American environment, lose their gesture habits.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3. -- No phase of the general return of soft coal miners to work under the new joint and district contracts signed between the operators and the United Mine Workers of America attracted more attention here than the promptness with which the great "captive mine" companies joined the procession.

A seven-point policy emphasizing retailer participation in many of the activities of the Federal Housing Administration has been adopted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, following the recommendations of its housing committee, headed by Saul Cohn, vice president of the City Stores Company, it was announced yesterday.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 5. -- Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., in an interim report covering operations for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 shows net profit of $2,355,695 after all charges, equivalent to 49 cents a share. In the year the company treated 383,958 tons of ore, retreated 40,290 tons of tailings and recovered bullion, less Federal bullion tax, of $4,750,956, or $11.20 a ton milled.

All Jackson Durant's old friends cut him: he was no longer invited even to church weddings in the Park Avenue set; and although it was true that he had gone to bed in a state of alcoholic coma every night for six months and was finding his recreation in the company of chorus girls, that was not the reason for his disgrace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was interested in the discussion in Topics of The Times of the words "sanctions," "implement" and "unilateral.'' Ask the average newspaper reader what these constantly used terms mean, and nine times out of ten he will have only the vaguest notion.

UP in the high Sierra country, 200 miles from San Francisco, lies the only community of its kind in the country -- a lumber camp in which every one is earning an interest for which no worker has paid out a cent, and where every worker receives the same wage, though paydays are unknown.

HOW did the murderer get out of the locked room? An old question, that. But John Dickson Carr has a new answer for it. And he has another new and even more puzzling twist to give to the always interesting problem of the "invisible" murderer.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 5. -- Middlebury, town and college, commemorated yesterday the 400th anniversary of the publishing of the Coverdale Bible, with more than fifty Bibles tracing the history of printing from the fifteenth century, on display at the newly reopened Sheldon Museum. The exhibit included several loans from private collections.

The war started last week. In Rome on Wednesday Premier Mussolini dispatched a telegram ordering his men on the march into Ethiopia. In Addis Ababa on Thursday Emperor Haile Selassie also sent a message to his people, by a method far older than the telegraph.

Declaring that further business recovery hinges upon expansion of the demand for better merchandise, P.A. O'Connell, president of the E.T. Slattery Company, Boston, warned yesterday that with the current upward trend in prices of raw materials the temptation would be strong for producers to use lower grade, less-serviceable materials in order to keep the selling prices of their finished products unchanged.

ROBERT RAYNOLDS'S third novel moves with the generous sweep of youth and the obvious intention of taking time and space in its stride. It would seem to indicate once again that our young writers are moving away from objective realism toward a new romance.

Rare Chinese textiles, some from the former imperial palaces, forming the collection of Williamson C. Moore, collector, of this city and Peiping, China, will be offered at auction next Friday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

A GLANCE into the newspaper files of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch of last July 23 reveals two nonpareil lines, down at the bottom of the first report of the first performance of "Venus in Silk" in America, that are high praise indeed: "Stolz's music, peculiarly enough, is not a rewrite of Strauss waltzes."

BETHAYRES, Pa., Oct. 5. -- A crowd of 8,000 watched a nose finish in the feature race at the Huntington Valley hunt races held at Justa Farm today. Three racers came thundering down the stretch neck and neck in the two-mile brush test, the King's Oak Steeplechase, for which George Horace Lorimer presented the third renewal plate valued $1,000.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The French note in reply to the British inquiry regarding assistance which France could provide in the Mediterranean should the British fleet be attacked by Italy was presented to the Foreign Office this morning by Charles Corbin, the French Ambassador.

In the heart of Ethiopia lies Lake Tana. Great Britain's chief Ethiopian interest is embodied in that sheet of water, about an eighth the size of Lake Erie. For Lake Tana feeds the Blue Nile, and the Blue Nile supplies 70 per cent of the water that flows into the Nile at Khartoum, center of the rich, irrigated, cotton-growing region of the Sudan and Egypt.

A woman from the Bronx won the prize for "the best layer cake in America" yesterday afternoon at the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Hotel Astor. She is Mrs. Anthony Rubano of 1,963 Benedict Avenue, and not only has she never cooked professionally, but she never has cooked with controlled heat.

WHEN Nathalia Crane was 10 years old, the newspapers were filled with enthusiastic appreciation of her verse and her small book, "The Janitor's Boy and Other Poems," went into eight editions in two years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The temporary agreement now being concluded between the United States and Japan covering cotton textile exports to the Philippines will run for two years and will mean an increase in United States exports to the islands during the period, the State Department said today.

Discouraged by several developments in the last week, trade association executives yesterday predicted that the voluntary code movement appeared destined to collapse unless the government simplified and centralized the procedure necessary for obtaining approval of such pacts.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Great Britain has approximately 150 fighting ships in strategic points in the Mediterranean and Red Seas, it was estimated today. They comprise virtually all the newest type.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- A mild-mannered fellow of thirty-four Summers and Winters pitched baseball of a sort on this wintry afternoon that brought him back, as if by magic, to the Summer of his career, while a crowd of 50,000 congealed spectators looked on spell-bound and as helpless as those who desperately were trying to thwart him.

GLEN HEAD, L.I. Oct. 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. James Robbins, the Pine Valley qualifiers in the mixed foursome tournament at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club, will meet another famous husband-and- wife team when they play Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Vare of Philadelphia in the upper semi-final bracket tomorrow morning.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Two hundred members and guests attending the sixth annual conference of the Federation of Bar Associations of the Sixth Judicial District today heard former Governor Charles S. Whitman sound the call for a campaign of optimism in regard to the outlook for the country and the crime situation.
