EVERY Saturday during the next two months throngs of merrymakers will take part in a vast one-day migration to local and national football games. Modishly dressed girls, intent only on having a gay time, youths to whom victory over the rival team is far more important than mere gayety, will crowd the railroad and bus terminals or speed over the highways in fast cars.

An appeal for funds to aid the Ethiopian cause in the Italian invasion was issued last night by Dr. Willis N. Huggins, a prominent Negro educator and author, who recently returned from London, where he was received by Dr. Azaz Wahrneck Martin, the Ethiopian Minister.

The criticism probably most frequently heard along the waterfront from liner passengers is against the system of handling personal baggage. Many feel the system amounts to racketeering, but it is of old standing and difficult to change.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Following is the text of the proclamation issued by President Roosevelt through the State Department tonight declaring an embargo against arms to Italy and Ethiopia:

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- The City Council is studying a proposal to place this city on daylight-saving time the year around. Proponents of the movement point out that many economic benefits would result from sharing Eastern standard time with New York and other business centres of the East.

MADRID, Sept. 20, 1935. THE problem of national opera is at present traversing another of the acute stages that recur periodically in Madrid, owing to the lack of a permanent operatic institution in this city. It is now a decade since the ex-Teatro Real (platonically rechristened the Teatro de la Opera) has been out of commission.

WHEN, in 1806, John Cary, celebrated London cartographer, published a "New Map of North America," the section of what is now the United States between the Mississippi and the Pacific Coast was left blank because its topography was largely unknown.

Marked gains in student registration in schools devoted to education for teaching and business were reported by New York University yesterday as registration neared its close. Total registration in all divisions was 27,113 students.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Following a conference with Supreme Court Justice Clarence E. Case and members of the Board of Freeholders, it was announced today that no permit had been issued for a public meeting before the court house at Elizabeth, planned as a protest over the death of Mrs. John Crempa.

Brisk activity was maintained throughout last week in nearly all retail departments, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Greater stress than usual is being placed on style and quality rather than price appeal in fashion promotions, and buyers are concentrating their purchases in higher price brackets, particularly in dresses and furs.

A portrait of the late Professor Charles Frederick Chandler, one of the founders of the American Chemical Society and first dean of the School of Mines, Columbia University, has been presented to the university by a group of older engineering graduates. The work, by Michael de Santis, will hang in the Egleston Library as a companion portrait to that of Thomas Egleston Jr., founder of the School of Mines.

IT takes a good sense of color and impeccable taste to see a woman through the purchase of accessories in this season of blues, reds and greens in gloves, shoes, belts, hats, bags, scarfs, vanities and the rest. More than two brightly colored matching accessories can be too much of a good thing.

A demand that the United States Government maintain a position of "armed neutrality" in its international relations and that education be used to combat the influx of communistic propaganda into this country was embodied in resolutions passed by the Children of the American Revolution, junior auxiliary of the D.A.R., at its seventeenth annual convention at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 5. -- Two powerful columns of Ethiopian regular troops advanced to a new position late this aternoon in the vicinity of Adowa as Italian military sources announced the imminence of a major battle. Some Italian officers said they believed the occupation of Adowa would be "only a matter of hours."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Living up to its promise of a fast attack, Syracuse opened its football season today with a 33-0 victory over Clarkson. Vic Hanson's Orange eleven roiled up fifteen first downs to Clarkson's one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Far behind in their schedule of getting 3,500,000 persons on work relief jobs by Nov. 1 and faced with the task of providing 90,000 jobs a day, government officials were understood to be worrying today about the slowness with which Controller General McCarl is making funds available for projects approved by President Roosevelt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a pleasure to read P.W. Wilson's contribution to THE NEW YORK TIMES concerning the Bible. One passage in his article deserves a place in every history of literature -- "The Bible is the literary miracle of all time and all countries."

THIS is not the first time that the name of Grete von Urbanitzky appears in these columns. One cannot help admiring the broad scope of this woman's interests, her intellectual vitality and her rich creative power.

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- More than a million words from almost a thousand experts flowed forth in Albany during the past week on the subject of crime and from these Governor Lehman will frame a definite legislative program for the coming year to translate the many proposals into terms of action.

FROM Vienna comes this book for teachers, parents, any one interested in training children who are delinquent or difficult because of neurotic tenden cies. August Aichhorn has had remarkable practical success in dealing with such children according to methods he seems to have developed himself.

APPLE-PICKING, in full swing as the season began, reveals a crop but once exceeded since the Autumn before the economic slump. Orchards, in fact, have shared in recovery from depression to such an extent that their production is two-thirds of that of the standard prosperity year of 1926.

THIS novel opens with a situation which, for the degree of interest and curiosity it immediately arouses in the reader, could hardly have been bettered. Though -- and this is as it should be -- the full drama implicit in it is disclosed very gradually.

THE collapse of the gold standard in the last three countries in which it survives is the grand climax to which the world's monetary drama is rushing. So we are told at any rate; and those who tell us may easily be right.

VIENNA, Oct. 4. -- "We do not want to bring in a Trojan horse," was the Austrian Government's answer to recent rumors about an alleged understanding reached between Berlin and Vienna on the Nazis' participation in the government, in return for which Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler was said to have promised to drop hostile propaganda and tolerate Austria's independence "within certain limits."

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Using power and tricky laterals, Colgate's Red Raiders swamped St. Lawrence, 31 -- 0, but met subborn opposition in Amherst, winning by only 12 -- 0, in the triangular competition today which was played to honor Dr. Ellery G. Huntington, father of Colgate athletics.

MONTREAL. STEPS are being taken in the Province of Quebec -- where old-time customs prevail to a greater extent than anywhere else hi Canada -- to abolish seigniorial rights. The Quebec Government has appointed a commission, with T.D. Bouchard, Minister of Municipal Affairs, as Chairman, and the commission already has issued a questionnaire to the seigneurs and their agents.

LONDON (AP). -- World ship tonnage is shrinking and sailing cargo vessels have almost disappeared, it is revealed by Lloyd's Register Book for 1935-36, containing records of 31,000 ships of every description.

GAR WOOD, internationally known builder of speed boats, has embarked in the motor bus production field. His company will produce modernized buses and coaches from designs developed by William B. Stout, president of the Society of Automotive Engineers, who has started production of a rear-engined, streamlined passenger car.

ONE cold and blustery day during the Winter of 1914 five little girls trooped into the old Rehearsal Club for luncheon. They were all under 12, all somewhat precocious and all blithely unconcerned with the drama then playing its first act in Central Europe.

FOR this strange, romantic story -- which is more in the mood of "Dewer Rides" than any of his other novels -- Mr. Strong has excelled himself in finding a wild and primitive setting. His scene is the Land of the Seven Arms, a rocky peninsula on the Atlantic coast of Scotland which is thickly wooded and slashed by winding sea lochs.

The movements of the British Navy indicate that Great Britain is preparing for a war with Italy by concentrating ships in strategic positions in the Mediterranean, Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., commandant of the Third United States Naval District, said last night in a speech at the annual dinner of the Association of Military Surgeons at the Waldorf-Astoria.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Ky Laffoon, brilliant Chicago golfer, ripped par today with a 68 round l over a par-70 course to take the lead in the Indianapolis 85,000 open tournament at the halfway mark of: the seventy-two-hole event.

When Mrs. Alfred Robie Driscoil of Haddonfield, recently elected president of the New Jersey Federation Of Women's Clubs, raises her gavel to convene the Fall conference at Convention Hall, Asbury Park, on Thursday, she will have under her jurisdiction 296 clubs and seven State organizations.

NOT many years ago among the ruins of a once famous monastic establishment on the slopes of Nanking's Purple Mountain there walked and talked General Chiang Kai-shek, Mme. Chiang and an American architect.

REJOICINGS will fill the hearts of many readers when they learn of this new book by Leonard Woolf on current quackery. For everybody knows with what intellectual fearlessness he faces the obsessions and the fetishes of the crowd and with what skill and success his scathing pen can flay the preachers of shams and falsities.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 5. -- The question whether a newspaper publisher or editor should hold political office, elective or appointive, is discussed by executives of important newspapers in different parts of the country in a symposium which The Chattanooga Times will print tomorrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5. -- Mobilization of five billions of dollars of union wages annually for union label goods and services was a project discussed here today by Matthew Woll, president, and I. M. Ornburn, secretary-treasurer, of the union label trades department of the American Federation of Labor.

IN a few notable cases, working the vein of personal experience has met with sensational success. But the fortune makers in this department must be in a small minority. We all know, many too well, that "every man has one good book in him," but things being as they are, whether this takes the form of a sad biographical novel or an episodic autobiography, though all are called, few are ultimately elected.
Quite liberal hedging operations, usual for a Saturday at this season of the year, supplied contracts on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed the list 2 to 8 points lower than on Friday.

The problems of old New York in the days just preceding the Revolution were brought home to the Finance Department yesterday afternoon when five certificates of varied denominations calling for payment on demand of a total of 21 shillings were presented for payment.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Mrs. Hans Glogau, 52 years old, of New Rochelle, bequeathed her head to science, according to her will filed for probate in Westchester County Surrogate's office today. She had been operated upon four times for a brain tumor since 1927.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 5. -- Bryn Mawr College expects to play host on Nov. 1 and 2 to 1,000 or more educators at a celebration marking the fiftieth anniversary of the institution's founding. The delegates will include presidents of universities and colleges east of the Mississippi River, representatives of various societies of learning and of 934 schools which have prepared students for Bryn Mawr College.

Optimistic reports from most of the leading centres throughout the country last week continued to indicate rising trade and industrial activity and improved economic conditions as the nation enters the final quarter of the year. With the drop in temperatures in various sections, retail buying of Fall merchandise, which slackened somewhat during the previous week, again spurted ahead, with the wholesale markets also benefiting.

The importance of the potato as an economic factor has been reemphasized by the action of Congress in placing the 1936 crop under AAA control. The potato has often played an important role in history, has saved whole nations from starvation and has been the basis of a war.

IT is from this ancient adage that Robert Coffin takes the title for his finely etched Maine novel of descendants of America's famous days of sail. With those days long since over, the descendants of the Vikings that trod the decks of clippers, unless gone into steam, have either become fisher folk or taken to landward paths.

Answering criticism of the report of a committee of the Board of Education which recommended a program of "uninterrupted continuity'' in the advancement of pupils from kindergarten to college, Dr. Stephen F. Bayne, associate superintendent, who headed the committee, has denied that "100 per cent promotion" was contemplated under the plan.

With the war in Ethiopia already affecting a wide area, fear that the conflict will spread to Europe shortly prompted export executives here yesterday to lay plans for meeting conditions similar to those which arose twenty years ago when the World War got under way.
Charles M. Griffith, medical director of the Veterans' Administration, was elected president of the association at the closing business session and will serve one year.

Appeals for a rebirth of religious zeal in America were voiced yesterday afternoon by speakers representing the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths during a radio program under the sponsorship of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery.

UNANIMOUS DECISION: Tomorrow the Supreme Court will move into its new home. Everything in the $10,000,000 structure is new except the chairs of the Justices; they are retaining the ones they used in their former quarters in the Capitol. It's a matter of sentiment.

THE Drs. Stone, who are partners in medicine, marriage and parenthood, have had extensive experience in the advising of married persons and those contemplating marriage and have made many special studies of the subjects they deal with in this book.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Mrs. Dorothy Watson Elsworth, 21 years old, a bride of six weeks and socially prominent in Montclair, was fatally injured here at 1:30 A.M. today when her husband, Joseph W. Elsworth, also 21, fell asleep at the steering wheel of their car, which crashed into a telephone pole on Wyoming Avenue, near Woodhill Drive.

The extension of margin credit to stock traders by banks on terms under which brokers cannot compete because of restraints in the Federal Reserve Board's Regulation T, was the subject of complaint last week by member firms of the New York Stock Exchange.
YACHTSMEN, young and old, who devote themselves entirely to model boats are having a gay time these days at ponds and pools in the city parks.

WITH Otto Klemperer conducting for the second of his thirteen weeks with the Philharmonic- Symphony, the music of Sibelius will make an early appearance in the season's lists, the Fifth symphony of the Finnish master being announced for Thursday night and Friday afternoon concerts of the week.

THE story of "Porgy and Bess" had its beginnings nine years ago. George Gershwin, tired from a day of rehearsals, tumbled into bed and picked up a copy of DuBose Heyward's novel "Porgy," to read himself to sleep. Instead, he read himself very much awake.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The flow of aliens away from the United States, begun in 1931 after a continuous influx for more than 300 years, has been checked.

GROWTH is so rare a thing among the younger novelists that when it unmistakably appears there is a temptation to be overgenerous in praise. The history of the American novel for twenty years back is littered with promising first books which have never been bettered by their authors, and us often as not, the curve has been a descending one. Morley Callaghan has proved himself one

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection with the President's listing of arms, ammunition and implements of war within the meaning of the registration and licensing provisions of the Neutrality Act, it is interesting to note that, as far as I have been able to find after an exhaustive search, the only known use of the phrase in an American treaty was in Jay's treaty of 1794 with England.

Two hundred children watched various athletic contests usher out the city's outdoor recreation season yesterday at the Sutton Place Playground, East River and Fifty-fourth Street. The contests, which included shuffle board, paddle tennis and playground baseball, were the culmination of city-wide tournaments held during the Summer at the four Community Councils playgrounds and in the seventy play streets.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- With the Philadelphia Mayoralty election less than five weeks away it has become apparent that Republican strategy will call for the party's campaign orators to hammer away at the New Deal and national issues, in spite of the fact that City Controller S. Davis Wilson, the Republican nominee, announced a few days ago a nine-point program dealing only with local questions.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy a few days ago received the German Ambassador to Rome, lately returned from a visit to Berlin, and had a long conversation with him which, it was noted afterward, seemed to afford II Duce great satisfaction.

License Commissioner Paul Moss climbed to the stage of a portable theatre on the Mall in Central Park shortly before dusk yesterday and made a grave decision that sent a troupe of young actors from Jackson Heights home happy.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Playing its second game of the season today Lawrenceville was defeated by the Lafayette freshman eleven, 29 -- 0.

" PRYNTED in the years of cure Lord MD XXXV. and fynished the fourth daye of October." Thus runs the colophon, the simple last sentence of the first complete Bible printed in English, the 400th anniversary of which has just been celebrated.

IT really isn't fair to the other eleven to put the cunning mulatto into the place of honor. For several of the others are quite as worthy of it as he. The corpse in the creek, for instance, is even more complicated, ingenious and resourceful.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- New York's $50,000,000 postal savings jam may be broken next week, possibly with a legal opinion that postal savings are exempt from the rules of the State Banking Commission.

Dean Roswell C. McCrea of the Columbia University School of Business, in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, declares that although the "cross currents" are perplexing, the general trend of business in this country is upward.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT ABOARD ESCORT CRUISER PORTLAND, Oct. 5. -- In the blazing sunshine of Lower California Bay, President Roosevelt spent this morning acting on Washington works and approved $26,000,000 of Works Progress projects in Pennsylvania.

WHILE it is legal to transport liquor in wet States, there is risk of grave charges if the motorist gets into an accident when carrying liquor in his car, it is pointed out in Public Safety, publication of the National Safety Council. In dry States, transporting liquor may bring a fine, jail sentence or confiscation of the car.

The dean's honor list of the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken was announced yesterday by Dean Franklin DeRonde Furman. It consists of fourteen seniors, fifteen juniors and twenty-four sophomores whose work was consistently excellent during the second and supplementary terms of the last college year.
ROME, Oct. 4. -- Nobody who is in Italy these days can fail to note the spirit with which this country is waging war. The Italians have no illusions about the campaign in East Africa.

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler s Minister for Church Affairs, Hanns Kerrl, assumed supreme command of the established Protestant Church in Germany today, creating by decree a Protestant directorate with dictatorial powers that he will appoint to administer the affairs of the "Reich Evangelical Church."

Accused of swindling more than seventy store owners in the last three months, Joseph Bibeau, 47 years old, of 201 East Fourteenth Street, appeared in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday morning charged with extortion and impersonating a Department of Health officer.

REGINALD GARDNER, whom several thousand-watt spots search out nightly on the stage of the Winter Garden -- which "At Home Abroad" calls "home" -- was born in the prosperous London suburb of Wimbledon, a place where the trajectory of a tennis ball is of greater importance that that of a cultivated voice in flight over the footlights.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Two substitutes accounted for the surprising climax in today's Union College game to give Hobart a 7-0 victory in the twenty-seventh battle of their thirty-nine-year-old series.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- There is improvement in the textile situation in New England but it is a distinctly lop-sided improvement. In woolen textiles the upslant is marked. In cotton it is barely perceptible and many of the ablest operators fail to see it at all.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- The Hedgerow Theatre closed its 1935 season at Rose Valley tonight with a performance of the Dreiser-Piscater play, "An American Tragedy," and the company, directed by Jasper Deeter, prepared to start on its second national road tour.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 3. -- Government, the farm problem, the New Deal and their relation to one another have been very much on the Corn Belt mind. Wheat growers have been completing signing up for a 1936 program; corn-hog producers are being importuned to vote on whether they want a program next year, while a steady stream of benefit checks on this year's program is flowing in weekly.

BROADCAST showmen are wondering if they have found a new index by which to measure the popularity of programs. Revelation of the increased electrical consumption in homes during the Louis-Baer prizefight and other events of national interest has caused the broadcasters to investigate the possibilities of gauging their comedians, symphonies and other shows by keeping tabs on the electrical output meters.

PARIS. PARIS is putting on her Autumn make-up. The dying bronze-and-copper tints of leaves that fall from the trees live again in the chic costumes of smart women and in the bronzed skins that have not yet had time to be bleached by city light, and also in copper-colored tresses -- almost every one is going a bit Titian these days!

IN the Golden Book of the Hotel de la Cite at Carcassonne -- a book which must be worth a considerable sum as a collection of autographs -- an American a few years ago set down his name and habitation in a not unusual way: he wrote his name, and then, "Chicago, Illinois, U.S.A."

WITH the rapid approach of the days when the cry of the hunter will he heard in the land, it is fitting here to remark that if the cry of the hunter is for suggestions for hunting clothes, there are clothiers in town who can answer his every call.

THE Viking Press this week is ten years old. They've been looking over what people always used to say Al Smith always called the record. These are their ten ten-strikes: "Power," "Ask Me Another," "Rasputin, the Holy Devil," "The Case of Sergeant Grishcha," "The Lives of a Bengal Lancer," Education of a Princess," "Boners," "Marie Antoinette,' "While Rome Burns," and "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh."

SELDOM before has the American Southwest, land of historical romance and natural beauty, been visited by more Eastern tourists than during this year. And, with the number of sightseers growing constantly, the probability of a permanent resort at the end of the Old Santa Fe Trail becomes greater.

A list of 157 students who completed work for degrees during the Summer session was announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College. Six of them finished graduate courses leading to the degree of Master of Science in Education and Master of Business Administration.

FOUR years of highly successful flying have now been completed by the pioneer aviation company of the Philippines. This is the Philippine Aerial Taxi Company, which operates a daily mail and passenger service between this city and Baguio, 130 miles to the north.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- If quantity was the theme of bankers in the last decade, "quality" must be the watchword in the next few years, S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, said here tonight to bankers of Western New York.

The Port of New York Authority was notified yesterday that the "port equalization" provisions of the intercoastal steamship tariff schedules had been upheld by the Shipping Board Bureau against the protests of the Baltimore Association of Commerce.

BOSTON, Oct. 5. -- Jockey Sam Renick thrilled 26,000 spectators today when he rode the Calumet Farm's Some Pomp to a nose victory over Percy M. Pike's Time Flight in the $5,000 added Pilgrim Handicap, six-furlong feature at Suffolk Downs.

MADRID, Oct. 5. -- Disdaining the official automobiles with which the Spanish Government wished to usher him into Spain, Henry Morgenthau Jr., United States Secretary of the Treasury, finally reached Salamanca from Northern Portugal today on the European holiday which he is so anxious to conduct with his wife as a private citizen and simple tourist.

BRADFORD, Pa., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Two long-time employes of the Commercial National Bank, which failed to open Monday after discovery of a shortage estimated by Federal officials at $1,000,000, were arrested today and held for grand jury action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Completely aware, extremely cautious and somewhat worried. Such might be said to summarize the feeling of this government as Benito Mussolini's troops this week began their long-advertised invasion of Ethiopia.
TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 5. -- Senator Arthur Capper, long a leader among the nation's drys, predicted tonight the country would swing back to prohibition.

THE opening of the century marked the beginning of a revolution in biology. The Dutch botanist, de Vries, had discovered that Lamarck's Evening Primrose was throwing off new varieties and that evolution was not the gradual, continuous process that Darwin supposed, but sudden and discontinuous.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, former Controller and Republican-Fusion candidate for District Attorney in Kings County, charged in a speech last night that thirteen of the fifteen assistant district attorneys under District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan were engaged in the private practice of law on the side.
State and Federal authorities joined yesterday in a campaign to stop the sale of misbranded wines and liquors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Members of his race were advised today by Representative Arthur W. Mitchell of Illinois, the only Negro member of Congress, not to demonstrate against Italians in this country because of the Ethiopian situation.

MARY PICKFORD stepped in last week to put an end to the conflicting reports about the schedule of her new producing unit. Not one, not six and not twelve pictures will be made by Mary Pickford-Jesse Lasky Productions next year, she said, but three -- or possibly four.

With the outbreak of war between Italy and Ethiopia, two vastly different armies meet in bloody combat. In equipment and appearance it is as if a military juggernaut of the twentieth century were seeking to annihilate an army arising miraculously out of a page of ancient history.

ST. LOUIS, in cooperation with the Missouri State Highway Department, is aiming to have a system of traffic arteries in and near the city second to none in any municipal district. Already a wide belt line highway encircles the city five miles from the city limits and wide superhighways extend in all directions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Catholic University's football Cardinals snapped La Salle College's nine- game winning streak today, swamping Marry Brill's Explorers from Philadelphia under a 41-to-7 score.

A "School of Politics," or political conference, will be staged by the Nassau County Federation of Republican Women Thursday in the Garden City Casino to study the issues which are to be voted upon this Fall, affecting town, county and State.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 5. -- The action of the University of Virginia's board of visitors in refusing to admit Miss Alice Jackson, daughter of a Richmond Negro druggist and former graduate student at Smith College, to the graduate school was criticized today by the National Students League of the university.

HAVERFORD. Pa.. Oct. 5. -- Taking advantage of two early breaks, Lehigh University scored twice in the opening minutes of play and again in the second quarter to defeat Haverford, 21 -- 0, today. Bill Tiernan, loser's quarterback, was the individual star of the game, his off-tackle plunges and end runs being largely responsible for Haverford's seven first downs.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5. -- The Soviet Government cannot tolerate proposals for a protectorate of powers over Ethiopia although it "will do everything it can to aid a genuine peaceful solution of the conflict," according to a leading editorial in Pravda today.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 4. -- Wrapped in the genial embrace of frontier hospitality last Monday, when he dedicated Boulder Dam, President Roosevelt increased the already strong hold he has enjoyed on the affections of Nevada and the adjoining Southwest States.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- The thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Princeton University Press will be celebrated at a reception to be held in its building next Saturday afternoon. The occasion is also the twenty-fifth anniversary of the incorporation of The Press as a non-profit-making organization.

WHAT shall be the balance between old music and new, in the programs given by our symphony orchestras? Mr. Klemperer, returned to conduct the opening Philharmonic-Symphony concert of the season, answered these questions in his own way.

A FILM record of the exodus of Britons from the slum areas of Hulme, a district in Manchester, to the model housing estates of Wythenshawe in Lancashire, was recently completed. The scenario was written and the action "shot" by the Rev. A.D. Wing, curate in charge of the St. George's mission at Atherton.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5. -- Efforts by the government to bring out testimony that Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., proposed settlement of the "movie war" between St. Louis theatre interests on condition that Attorney General Cummings dismiss criminal charges now being tried caused heated words today in the Anti-Trust Law trial in Federal Judge Moore's court.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- The strain is over for the Tigers. They are looking forward to tomorrow and the end of the series. Beating the Cubs, 2 to 1, and gaining a three-to-one edge in the world series on the pitching of the veteran Alvin Crowder, the Bengals cast aside restraint as they trooped into the clubhouse and became a, frolicking group of schoolboys.

AUTUMNS, like Springs, vary greatly from year to year in the opportunities they present the gardener for getting his work done under favorable conditions. So far this Fall season has been ideal for planting. Cool nights have matured foliage and new growth, sunny days have been keeping the soil temperature sufficiently high to stimulate root growth and rains have supplied adequate moisture.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. WITH a theatric blast of six consecutive premieres, taps was sounded for one of this city's dullest Summer seasons within my memory. Nothing but playbacks of rosy fluff, a collation for transients and the yokel.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3 -- Yale's celebration of the 400th anniversary of the Coverdale translation of the complete English Bible will include an exhibition of Hebrew, Oriental, Greek and Latin manuscripts and Bibles and the Gulfberg Bible presented by Mrs. Edward S. Harkness. It will continue for a month.

SYDNEY, Australia. WHILE wild tropical parrots screeched from banyan trees and naked aborigines stood about, Australia's strangest court case recently moved to its conclusion. This was the official investigation into the killing of two natives during an inter-tribal battle in which 200 men were engaged.

THIS is a curiously pleasant little tale with its mildly Gallic mockery, its gentle, objective, slightly malicious probing and its ironic gesture of raised eyebrows. Like young Clarence Jordan who rooms at Madame Bonnard's, Joseph Vogel seems to be devoted to "The Principal of Mild Surprise" or, perhaps better, to a belief in the poses and postures of mild surprise as a way of extracting from life the most amusement.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 5 (AP). -- George D. Widener's great weight-carrying sprinter, Sation, easily captured the $5,000 added capital handicap today with a brilliant display of form.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., Oct. 5. -- The East Stroudsburg State Teachers College opened their home grid season here today by handing a decisive defeat to the Panzer College eleven by a score of 26 -- 0. The Panzer line offered little resistance to the plunging warriors of East Stroudsburg, who after the first period scored in every session.

CONCORD, Mass., Oct. 5 (AP). -- A guard was critically wounded when shot today as five prisoners at the Concord Reformatory, armed with home-made weapons, seized the keys from another guard and fled from the institution, only to be captured as they sought to drive off in a commandeered car.

GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- Following is the text of the conclusions reached in the Ethiopian clash by the Council of the League of Nations, acting as a committee of thirteen under Paragraph 4 of Article XV of the covenant:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The question of constitutionality of another New Deal venture -- loans and grants to towns and cities for municipal power and water projects -- will be placed before the District of Columbia Court of Appeals on Monday.

With colorful contrasts of flags and uniforms, New York State's fortieth annual conference of the Daughters of the American Revolution will open tomorrow morning at the Hotel Roosevelt. Several hundred delegates will be in attendance during the three days.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- One of the most exciting and best played opening games any football season has ever seen went to Princeton today by the slimmest margin a winner may have in football, 1 point.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity continued in large volume, many of them for substantial amounts. The calls were principally for November, only some small lots of foreign and industrial bonds being posted for October. This month's redemptions now total $369,992,000, compared with $350,304,000 in September, and $47,867,000 in October, 1934, in the corresponding weeks.

EXPERIMENT in the theatre is made difficult and expensive by the fact that a play must find an audience at once or have no chance of finding one later. There is no instance in the theatre of a writer who left behind him a body of unappreciated work which slowly found its public, as, for example, the work of Shelley and Keats found a belated public after they had left the scene.

Both the Council and the Assembly of the League of Nations have now concerned themselves with the Ethiopian dispute. A division of labor between the two League bodies has been established more or less by custom. The relation of the Assembly to the Council is somewhat analogous to the relation of Parliament to the Cabinet chosen from its ranks.

Rigoletto, condensed for an hour broadcast as the first of a Verdi operatic cycle performed by a seventy-five piece orchestra and chorus. Soloists of this "Music Hall of the Air" presentation include Rosemarie Brancato, soprano; Bruna Castagna, contralto; John Gurney, bass, and Martino Rossi, baritone: WJZ, 12:30 P.M.

EXENSIVE preparations are being made throughout South Africa for the Empire Exhibition, which is to take place in Johannesburg next year. The nucleus of the exhibition grounds is to be a tract of 100 acres of the Witwatersand Agricultural Society, at least thirteen acres of which will be roofed over for the show.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Various attempts have been made to link the extraordinary number of automobile fatalities to faulty eyesight. To men whose lifework is the study of problems of human vision the wonder is that a greater number of accidents do not occur from this cause alone.

While the whole world watched the East African struggle French, British and other European statesmen nervously kept their eyes on Central Europe and especially on Berlin. In the back of their minds was one question of vast importance: Would Adolf Hitler attempt to take Austria and realize his dream of a "Greater Germany" while Benito Mussolini's men were on the march in Ethiopia?

LONDON, Oct. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Defeats inflicted on Manchester City and Middlesbrough in English soccer today resulted in Sunderland and Derby County drawing into a tie for second place, one point behind Huddersf{eld Town, which drew 2 -- 2, with Leeds United.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5. -- Playing its initial game under its first non-graduate coach, the Harvard football team made an auspicious season's beginning by defeating a stubborn Springfield College eleven today, 20 to 0.

Many reservations have been made for the premiere showing of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," the Warner Brothers production, in behalf of the English-Speaking Union of the United States to be held on Wednesday night at the Hollywood Theatre.

LONDON, Sept. 13. CLIFFORD BAX, chiefly known as the author of "The Venetian" and of a study of Henry VII's Katharine Howard, called "The Rose Without a Thorn," is among our least predictable and, therefore, our most interesting dramatists. He has produced now a play called "The House of Borgia."

Faced with another session of the United States Supreme Court, which is scheduled to convene in Washington tomorrow, the financial and industrial communities are awaiting rulings on the constitutionality of the processing taxes of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and other New Deal legislation with much more confidence than they showed last Winter when the court began a similar session, according to bankers and brokers in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Each family pocketbook is beginning to feel again the once-familiar pinch of increased living costs, and the impersonal statistics of the Department of Labor confirm the housewives' plaint. It takes more money now than it did two years ago, or even last year, to keep food on the table, new clothes in the closet and coal in the Cellar. Prices are on the way up.

The December ball given annually under the auspices of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House is to be known this year as the Tropical Ball. It will be held on Dec. 12 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, and the net proceeds will aid the beneficiary in meeting its yearly maintenance budget.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Camel trains, a military failure in the Southwest, will be revived to carry the mail between Fort Tejon and Los Angeles next month.

A sudden wave of copper buying abroad yesterday sent the price of the metal to the equivalent of 9.05 cents a pound at European base ports, a gain of 20 points from the high on Friday and the highest for the current move. The price now is 85 points above that of Sept. 1 and the highest since July 11, 1933, when quotations went up sharply on the currency inflation talk at that time.

TOKYO, Oct. 5. -- More mystery was added today to the murder on Aug. 12 of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, director of the Military Affairs Bureau, when Colonel Chozaburo Yamada, one of the slain officer's principal assistants, killed himself with an army sword.

Loyalty Sunday will be observed today by churches of all faiths at the request of the Committee on Religion and Welfare Recovery. The committee has issued a call "for the strengthening and under-girding of the moral and spiritual forces of the nation," the special plea being that every one attend his own church services.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 5. -- Arrangements have been made by the Wednesday Singing Club for the presentation of the American Ballet at the High School auditorium on Oct. 15. The ballet will present "Alma Mater," "Mozartiana," and "Serenade." The music for "Alma Mater" was written by Kay Swift and arranged by Morgan Gould.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Purdue conquered Northwestern, 7 to 0, tonight in the opening battle of the Western Conference football season. It was the first contest played under lights in the history of the Big Ten. Purdue's margin came early in the second period on a 52-yard touchdown dash by Tom McGannon.
AMHERST, Oct. 5. -- Massachusetts State College faces many problems of organization and administration as it enters its seventy-second year.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 5. -- Connecticut will conclude its tercentenary celebration next week with various activities depicting the history and accomplishments of the Connecticut Yankee and other racial groups which have shared in the building of the State.

American business, to be successful in the future, must encourage the development of American creative art instead of continuing the present practice of turning to Europe for such work, Ira A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, declared last night in an address at the opening of the fourth season of the Talk of the Town Club, held in the Hotel des Artistes, 1 West Sixty-seventh Street.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association announced yesterday that it had called a strike of radio operators against the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company. The union asserted that the strike was so effective at some stations that it had paralyzed communications across both the Atlantic and Pacific.

A flood of orders released by retailers, reflecting the fear of rising prices, following the recent advances in commodities, poured in on the wholesale food markets here last week and brought predictions that distribution during the Fall season will reach the highest levels since 1929.

FORTY years ago, perhaps a little longer, two brothers out in Ohio began reading about flying. To their reading they added a few experiments. From thin sheet metal they constructed plane surfaces of many different shapes.

Wall Streeters were inclined to have a hearty laugh on A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, yesterday morning when they read of the tentative agreement between representatives of the lnterborough Rapid Transit and Manhattan stockholders and the city on the purchase of the stock equities of these two traction companies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- In the campaign against rackets and racketeers now being planned G-men of the Department of Justice Bureau of Investigation will find themselves hampered by even greater restrictions than those which handicapped them in the successful campaign against gangsters and kidnappers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- A plan for holding a national conference in Chicago or Washington of Republicans, Democrats and independents opposed to New Deal principles and for the outlining of policies of the Republican party in advance of the national convention, is under consideration by members of the Republican National Committee.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Scoring on the wings of opportunity, the Illinois football team launched a challenge to Southern California, its foe at Los Angeles next week, by passing and running its way to a 28-6 victory over Washington University today before 15,000 spectators.

A blaze which started in the celar of an apartment house at 22 "East Seventy-sixth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, route about fifty residents of the four story structure shortly after 7:00 o'clock last night until firemen under Deputy Battalion Chief Hug Halligan brought the flames under control.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Cold blew the biting blast coming in off Lake Michigan as the world series went into the fourth reel at Wrigley Field today. The first show of real enthusiasm of the afternoon came when Umpire Majority appeared on the diamond just before game time. The Cubs' rooters greeted him with an avalanche of jeers which he did not acknowledge. It was too cold for him to lift his cap.

OWING to a spell of piercingly cold weather last May, grouse shooting on most of the Scottish moors began very late this year. Legally it began on Aug. 12, a date which sticks out in the British and American sporting and social calendar.

SOON the day will come when seasoned gardeners will exclaim, "Frost tonight!" They will base their forecast mainly on a steady fall in temperature from late afternoon until the thermometer is in the thirties by 9 in the evening.

KUDA BUX, the Kashmir magician, managed last month to compete with Halle Selassie, Mussolini and President Roosevelt in making front-page news. In Surrey, England, he had walked barefooted through fire, coming out of the ordeal unharmed.

About 53,504,000 pounds of Federal surplus foods, with a retail value of $5,572,189, were distributed to more than 220,000 families on relief and thousands of other needy individuals in New York City between Jan. 1 and Aug. 31, 1935, the Commodities Distribution Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau reported yesterday to Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the ERB.

Market quotations here on Italian dollar bonds are from 30 to more than 50 per cent below the prices set by the conversion decree of the Mussolini Government, and investment firms active in the foreign field report that a large number of the securities held in this country has been turned in for repatriation.

WITH somewhat more fanfare than would attend the signing of a peace pact between Italy and Ethiopia, the Brothers Warner will present their film of Shakespeare's "A Mid-summer Night's Dream" at the Hollywood Theatre on Wednesday night. To say that the eyes of the world will be on the Hollywood that night would be going a bit strong.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Unable to appear as a speaker at the conference of Republicans in Oakland, Governor Hoffman sent today a message of greeting in which he hailed the meeting as "another advance in the determined march to victory in 1936 for the preservation of American institutions and American liberties."

According to advices received yesterday from Clydebank, the steel work on the Queen Mary is nearly completed and when the hull is ready a start will be made on the interior decorations. All the furniture and equipment for the cabins are ready to be installed.

Father Knickerbocker's most ambitious offensive against noise was launched last week. It began with a night attack; before a barrage of warnings and a few arrests the enemy retreated many decibels in all sectors. For instance: In Times Square engineers found noises 35 per cent less on Wednesday than on Tuesday when the campaign began.

LIKE most native races elsewhere, the Maoris of New Zealand declined as the white settlers increased in their country. So steadily did the Maoris decrease that many a chieftain predicted the complete passing of his race before many years.

When an arrest is made in the Holloway murder case the prisoner is changed with three murders and with murderous attempts upon two other men. But this first prisoner is not the guilty man. And acts of violence still follow. It becomes evident very early in the course of the story that some one is trying to get rid of almost all the heirs of the rich and eccentric Leander Holloway.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 5. -- There was further fighting reported on the southern Ogaden front, facing Italian Somaliland, today, with 2,000 Ethiopian casualities.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 5. -- Richard F. Cobb, 20, of Cleveland, a senior at Yale, died at St. Vincent's Hospital today from a fractured skull suffered in a two-car collision in which six persons were injured at North and Madison Avenues early this morning.

BOOKS for children describing other countries have changed markedly in character during the last twenty-five years. "Boomba Lives in Africa" reminds us how far away we are not only from the highly informational little books of our grandfathers but from the stereotype geographical series that were so plentiful during the early years of the twentieth century.
Barnard College has announced the addition of new members to the teaching staff of several departments. They include:

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- Early clarification of the international diplomatic situation resulting from the Italo-Ethiopian war is not looked for in Berlin official and political circles. Today's press warns against premature conclusions, especially with respect to impending decisions in Geneva.

NEW YORK and London seem to be marching along into the new season pretty much together. At least the cable takes pains this week to point out that Shaftesbury Avenue is "in earnest," a phrase not unknown on Broadway north of Forty-second Street.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Another phase in the aerial conquest of the Pacific was undertaken today by the Pan American Clipper in taking off here on a projected three-stop flight to Guam, 6,600 miles away.

The Rev. Aloysius C. Dineen, pastor of the Church of the Holy Innocents, 128 West Thirty-seventh Street, and archdiocesan managing director of Calvary and Allied Cemeteries, will observe the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood this week, according to an announcement yesterday.

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 4. -- It was a cheerful President who boarded the cruiser Houston on Wednesday for a long deferred vacation to be devoted principally to fishing in the waters off the Mexican coast and in the Bay of Panama. Elated would hardly be too strong a word to describe his feelings over the receptions he had received on his rapid but eventful journey from Washington to this semi-tropical port of the Pacific.

Dusk this evening will bring to Jews throughout the world the beginning of the most solemn day of their calendar. Once again they will observe Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, of which they were reminded on Rosh ha-Shanah, the New Year, by the blowing of the shofar, the ram's horn.

Representatives of women's organizations in all forty-eight States and in foreign countries will attend the fifth annual Forum on Current Problems, to be held Oct. 15, 16 and 17 at the Waldorf-Astoria by The New York Herald Tribune. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will make the first address on "The American Woman's Place in the World Today."

IT is the nature of a story to require a certain amount of time for its action to unfold and to culminate, and any attempt to impose tricky temporal limitations inevitably smacks of decadence. The forcible curtailing of the time element may be a confession that the novelist is afraid to entrust himself to the logic of character, to destiny.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP). -- An inspired University of California football team rose today to defeat St. Mary's Gaels, 10 to 0, in an upset victory that thrilled 55,000 fans at Memorial Stadium.

BOOKS for children seem to be acquiring a higher status. Charles Lamb, it is true, did not think it beneath him to write for boys and girls, nor did Charles Kingsley, but as a rule our most distinguished men of letters have sought none but adult readers.

STRATFORD - ON - THE - POTOMAC, cradle of the Lee family in this country and outstanding among America's historic homes, will be dedicated next Saturday as a national shrine in ceremonies reflecting-the traditions of Colonial Virginia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- After a 55-minute conference in which both sides told their stories of yesterday's run-in between Umpire George Moriarty and members of the Cub team, Baseball Commissioner K.M. Landis announced today that he would take no action until the conclusion of the world series.
Seventh Avenue in South Brooklyn, between Fourteenth and Twentieth Streets, has been "borrowed" by the residents of the district, it was discovered yesterday.

AIR transportation lines in the United States are this year making an all-time record for carrying passengers and express, and along with this progress in aviation comes the announcement of a $50,000,000 program of airport expansion and development sponsored by the Federal Government.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 5. -- Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner of Euclid Avenue Temple tonight urged that Pope Pius lead a new crusade to stop war by molding world public opinion against war. In a Yom Kippur message, broadcast over a national hook-up through radio station WGAR here, Rabbi Brickner said:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 5. -- Ohio State's football team, touted as a likely winner of the Big Ten and national championships, failed today to display the coordination which featured its play last season, but had enough power to defeat a scrappy University of Kentucky eleven, 19 to 6.

RADIO industrialists are happier than they have been since the days before their business hit rock bottom in March, 1931. At present they are enjoying what is described as "a small boom," which has all the earmarks of spreading over into 1936 as a real boom.

WITH "The Victorians and Their Reading" Miss Cruse has hit on a phrase as descriptive as The Augustans and Their Coffee Houses and Salons, or The Elizabethans and Their Taverns and Theatres, or, perhaps, as Our Contemporaries and Their Cocktail Parties.
Seventh Avenue in South Brooklyn, between Fourteenth and Twentieth Streets, has been "borrowed" by the residents of the district, it was discovered yesterday.

AIR transportation lines in the United States are this year making an all-time record for carrying passengers and express, and along with this progress in aviation comes the announcement of a $50,000,000 program of airport expansion and development sponsored by the Federal Government.

Registration for the general election in November will begin this year on Tuesday instead of Monday and will close Tuesday night of next week. The change in the registration period for New York City was authorized because tomorrow will be Yom Kippur, a Jewish holy day.

About five minutes after an unidentified Negro had committed a $32 hold-up in Harlem last night, he was shot and killed in the first floor hallway of a tenement at 167 West 133d Street by Patrolman Leo Steiner of the West 135th Street Station.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Army opened its football season today, defeating William and Mary, 14 to 0, in a hotly contested game. Perfect football weather prevailed. Ten thousand saw the contest, which was played in Michie Stadium.

OLD FORT NIAGARA, N.Y., Oct. 5 (AP). -- A bust of Samuel de Champlain, who explored for the French much of what is now Eastern Canada, was unveiled here today in the old fort built by the French when Niagara was the key to the "West."

Failure of the construction industry to abandon traditional methods and to make a broad-scaled attempt to capture the mass market will retard to a great extent the building boom next year, so confidently predicted by many authorities, W.A. McDermid, head of the company that bears his name, sales consultants and engineers and closely allied with the building field, declared here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- While a commission appointed by Governor Horner is studying the public school problem in Illinois, John A. Wieland, State Superintendent of Public Instruction, furnishes from his records significant figures indicating the decline in educational opportunities which has resulted from the depression.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Facing what physicians say will be total and incurable blindness within three years, Ralph W. Klix of this city, aged 27, confessed in county court today to four burglaries here and was sentenced to serve ten years in Attica prison.

While the sleek-flanked prize performers of Colonel W.T. Johnson's rodeo fretted comfortably in their hay-lined stalls in the basement of Madison Square Garden last night, the colonel relaxed in an armchair in his room at the Hotel Forrest and allowed himself to become annoyed at a would-be cowboy radio crooner.

GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- Figures in the International Labor Office's quarterly report on world unemployment, issued today, indicate that it is roughly 1,000,000 less than a year ago, but nearly all of this improvement comes from Italy and Germany, where war business is most active.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5. -- Striking members of the International Longshoremen's Association in New Orleans, focal point in the Gulf port strike, and steamship men looked today to the visit of Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, to settle the dock strife here.

In an impressive exhibition of scoring power, Manhattan's rising football team crushed a fighting but outmanned Brooklyn College eleven, 59 to 7, at Ebbets Field yesterday. Using straightaway tactics for the most part, the Jaspers scored nine touchdowns, the majority of them from long range.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 5. -- Bill Cooper's two touchdowns in the last ten minutes today enabled Penn State to defeat a Lebanon Valley team, 12 -- 6, before an opening game crowd of 7,000 at New Beaver Field.

BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- On the Bueckeberg near Hamelin, the town of Pied Piper fame, National Socialist Germany will celebrate Sunday its harvest thanksgiving day with all the display of pomp and power that is now a fixed part of all Nazi festivals, including the massing of huge crowds, sham battles by the new army and speeches by Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler and other Nazi rulers.

TYLER, Texas, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Bounding Vince Renzo, a tap dancer by avocation, beat a merry patter today to give Pop Warner's Temple University Owls a 14-0 victory over Texas A. and M. in a bitter intersectional game.

Registration for the general election in November will begin this year on Tuesday instead of Monday and will close Tuesday night of next week. The change in the registration period for New York City was authorized because tomorrow will be Yom Kippur, a Jewish holy day.

About five minutes after an unidentified Negro had committed a $32 hold-up in Harlem last night, he was shot and killed in the first floor hallway of a tenement at 167 West 133d Street by Patrolman Leo Steiner of the West 135th Street Station.

TYLER, Texas, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Bounding Vince Renzo, a tap dancer by avocation, beat a merry patter today to give Pop Warner's Temple University Owls a 14-0 victory over Texas A. and M. in a bitter intersectional game.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 6. -- More than 1,000 citizens of Newark, including many prominent in the official, professional and business life of the city, gathered today at the Newark Museum to observe John Cotton Dana Day, set aside by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein to honor the memory of the founder of the museum.

Early last Summer the Research and Planning Division of the NRA, under the direction of LEON HENDERSON, published a report intended to show that labor had suffered much more comparatively from the depression than capital. The Department of Commerce figures published in mid-August showed such a contention to be without substance.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 6. -- Driven back by every mechanical war device the Italians could employ, the Ethiopians surrendered Adowa today to the Second National Army Corps, which, although suffering from continual sniping, was celebrating tonight its avenging of the massacre of Italian forces there in 1896.

Building costs in the metropolitan area have about reached rock bottom and are slated for an upward swing, Myron L. Matthews declares in the current Dow Service Building Reports. The main basis for this forecast is the fact that construction volume here has been improving steadily for the past year.

The Long Island Lighting Company has completed negotiations for the private sale to three insurance companies of $5,992,000 first refunding mortgage gold bonds, Series C, 4 per cent, dated June 1, 1935, and maturing on June 1, 1960, at par and accrued interest, Ellis L. Phillips, president, announced yesterday.

A chaotic world's need for a Day of Atonement was the theme of sermons addressed to 2,000,000 members of the Jewish community of New York City yesterday, the eve of Yom Kippur, Jewish Day of Atonement. The twenty-four-hour period of fasting and prayer ends a ten-day period of spiritual contemplation that began with Rosh ha-Shanah, the opening of the year 5696 in the Jewish calendar.

In line with the promise of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, to pay interest in dollars on the Dawes and Young Plan bonds, as announced on Sept. 13, the Hamburg-American Line and the North German Lloyd are offering to buy from holders in the United States the coupons of the Dawes Loan falling due on Oct. 15 and the Young Plan Loan falling due on Dec. 1.

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- Bankers and financiers here predict a prolonged period of international unrest, punctuated by recurring threats of an extension of the territorial scope of the war. If the League of Nations decrees economic sanctions it is believed here they will be ineffective against Italy unless backed up by a formal blockade, for it is considered certain that Mussolini counts on a brief war, and for such he has adequate supplies.

If this country is to be kept "free and unentangled" from the danger of foreign war, we must curb every would-be war profiteer, not only by legislation but by force of public opinion, the Rev. Dr. Howard Chandler Robbins of the General Theological Seminary said in a sermon yesterday morning. He spoke at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

In the most active trading in more than a year prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed last week at net gains of 42 to 54 points. At the high point they were up almost 1 cent a pound from the level at the middle of September and not far below the quotations prevailing before the government reduced the loan value on the current crop.

Replying to a query from this column, Deputy Commissioner John T. Gibbs of the Conservation Department voices optimism regarding the outlook for the coming hunting season in New York State, basing his opinion on information gathered from game protectors, sportsmen's organizations and landowners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The American Red Cross has queried both the Italian and Ethiopian Red Cross societies on whether American assistance is desired in the present situation, Admiral Cary T. Grayson, Red Cross national chairman, revealed in a statement today.

New Jersey deals reported over the week-end included, the sale of the former Perkins residence at 302 South Street, Morristown, for the Morris County Savings Bank to Endicott Fiske. Eugene V. Welsh was the broker. The property consists of a plot of three acres and a brick residence of eighteen rooms and three baths. It is one of the oldest

SHOUPE, Idaho, Oct. 6 (AP).--Down a tumbling mountain stream with current so swift and banks so steep it has been called the "River of No Return," a party of scientists launched today a thirty-day expedition in a radio-equipped scow. The river has claimed the lives of scores of adventurers in twenty years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Al Espinosa of Akron, Ohio, veteran of many golf wars, won the $5,000 Indianapolis Open tourney today as some of the world's greatest exponents of money play fell by the wayside in the seventy-two-hole event.

Taking up his permanent pastorate yesterday morning at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, the Rev. Dr. John S. Bonnell told a congregation of more than 1,300 that a makeshift life as a frail raft to bear one on the seas substituted disillusion for idealism and faith.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Right at world series harvest time, the big Cub "lemon" turned into a juicy "peach." The Cubs paid $125,000 for Chuck Klein and he was a sour "lemon" to them until today when he hit that home run.

ROME, Oct. 6 (AP). -- The Italian Government officially announced tonight the capture of Adowa from its Ethiopian defenders. That scene of Italy's defeat in 1896 was captured at 10:30 A.M. by troops of the Second Army Corps, the announcement said.

New York City provides more than half of the entire national output of twelve different manufactured products, according to results of an analysis of the 1933 cenus of manufactures of the Census Bureau, made public yesterday by the Merchants Association.

More than 300 members and officers of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution registered for the New York State Conference of the organization will be officially welcomed by Mayor La Guardia at the Hotel Roosevelt this morning.

CORNING, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Joe Costa, the 26-year-old airplane pilot who plans to fly to Portugal "to surprise his mother," had $150 toward expenses today, but he had to go to his first dance to get it.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6. -- The world's largest steel mill is planned for the Pittsburgh district by the United States Steel Corporation. Engineering details now being completed call for a wide-strip mill, the first major one to be installed in this area by any producer of steel and one which will put Pittsburgh directly into the fight for a large percentage of the all-important automobile-body tonnage.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 6. -- Pennsylvania's goosebone prophets have spoken -- it's going to be a long, blustery Winter.

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- The revenue of the German Government for the first five months of the current fiscal year amounted to 3,657,000,000 marks, compared with 3,207,000,000 in the corresponding period in 1934. Since March, 1933, the indebtedness of business undertakings owned by the Reich and the States increased by 1,000,000,000 marks to 5,780,000,000 marks.

The Republican State Committee will begin today an intensive drive to recapture the Assembly, as a preliminary step toward regaining control of the State government and in the hope that success will be construed as a defeat for President Roosevelt in his home State.

With the city's $200,000,000 voluntary hospital system "nearing the point of operating insolvency," the United Hospital Fund completed plans last night for a campaign under the chairmanship of Gates W. McGarrah, banker, to seek a minimum of $2,000,000 this Fall.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross gave aid or instruction to more than 125,000 persons in the year ended June 30, according to the annual report made public yesterday. The report, made by General Robert C. Davis as executive director of the chapter, stated that 11,943 veterans and their families were cared for, 850,000 received nutrition instruction, 8,288 books and booklets were Brailled and distributed to the blind.

Cooler weather stimulated buying in the wholesale markets here last week, the gain being extended to nearly all divisions in the form of reorders or fresh commitments. The demand for street dresses was less active, although considerable interest was shown in the formal types, including the "bar" and double-duty styles.
One week after publication, Doubleday, Doran reports a fifth printing of "Seven Pillars of Wisdom, which brings the total number of copies printed to 102,000 and exceeds the English sale.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 6. -- The Berkshire Hills are alive with color and are expected to continue to be so for about two weeks. Many reservations have been made at the leading hotels.

The hospitals of this city face a financial condition "rapidly becoming more desperate," as Mr. GATES W. MCGARRAH, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign Committee, announces today. The municipal hospitals, maintained for the care of the destitute sick, are overcrowded.

Three young boys, who had a brief but exciting adventure in a rowboat on the East River yesterday afternoon and were rescued by having a life line shot to them, lost their taste for thrills when after landing safely on shore they were sternly reprimanded and sent home without a heroes' reception.

Operations of the American Smelting and Refining Company in the first six months of this year resulted in a net income of $5,062,850 after deduction of expenses, depreciation, interest, taxes and other charges, and including $740,882 profit on inventories in excess of normal.
ATLANTA, Oct. 6. (AP). -- Dixie's football experts, left groggy by a succession of setbacks for the favored Southeastern Conference elevens, literally received a knockout punch Saturday.

Our city administration is about to embark upon a very worthy campaign of noise abatement. It is long overdue, hence the more reason why some thought should be given to preventive measures as well as curative. With the advent of the radio, the automobile horn and other noise makers, the time has come to soundproof our dwellings, offices and other buildings where human beings congregate.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 6. -- Emperor Haile Selassie appealed today for volunteer American doctors and nurses and gifts of hospital supplies. He made his appeal in a letter handed to this correspondent for transmission through THE NEW YORK TIMES to Robert Harris of the committee for Ethiopia, 228 East Forty-fifth Street, New York.

Columbia turns its football attention to Rutgers today considerably more experienced as a result of its unexpectedly close victory over Virginia Military Institute on Saturday. In spite of the 12 -- 0 score and the fact that they were outplayed in the second half, the Lions believe they have the makings of a strong team before the season ends.

Staid business, professional and civic leaders, who, as trigger-nerved youngsters, volunteered for ambulance service with the French Army prior to our entry into the World War, will hold a reunion here next Saturday and Sunday to mark the twentieth anniversary of the organization of the American Ambulance Field Service.

Faulty intelligence service and confusion of names were largely responsible for the debacle of General Baratieri's troops at the battle of Adowa in 1896. The fateful events of Feb. 29, 1896, are described by Major Bernard Smith of the Corps of Engineers, U.S.A., in the current issue of the Infantry Journal.
