GENEVA, Oct. 6. -- The League Council's committee of six, reduced to five by Chile's absence, agreed tonight on its report to the Council meeting tomorrow afternoon, but pledged its members to secrecy on it.

A solemn mass of thanksgiving was offered yesterday morning in honor of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the priesthood of the Rev. Aloysius C. Dineen, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents, Thirty-seventh Street near Broadway, and managing director of Calvary and Allied Cemeteries.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Miss Myrtle Weller, 30, daughter of Mrs. Minnie Weller of Hudson Falls, jumped into the Glens Falls feeder canal in a suicide attempt this morning, but was rescued by Albert Labarge after she had gone under for the second time.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The fall of Adowa scarcely more than three days after the Italian armies had invaded Ethiopia has been received here with little surprise, because descriptions of the almost unprecedented care with which Italy had planned her invasion had prepared the British public for swift results.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- For six years under Andy Kerr, Colgate has stood as one of the bright jewels of the gridiron firmament.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT ABOARD THE CRUISER PORTLAND, Oct. 6 (AP). -- President Roosevelt headed over the rolling swells of the Pacific Ocean today for an ideal fishing place, Cocos Island, off Costa Rica.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- With five cases on its docket vitally affecting the fate of the New Deal and thus the destiny of the Roosevelt administration, the Supreme Court will meet in its magnificent new white marble temple for the first time tomorrow to start a term regarded as one of the most important in the nation's history.

With New York City registration for the general election on Nov. 5 beginning tomorrow, William Ziegler Jr., chairman of the Progressive Republican State Committee, sent out letters yesterday urging all members of the committee to get Republicans to register so that they might enroll as party members and participate in the Spring and Fall primary elections next year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Emerging from the Penn game with no injuries, the Princeton football team will devote the major part of the coming week's drill to a thorough review of some of the fundamentals of play that were lacking against the Quakers yesterday.
Gramercy Park, where quiet is so intense that the bounce of a rubber ball is considered reverberating clamor, enlisted aggressively yesterday in the campaign for abatement of noise.

ROME, Oct. 6--The Italian troops brought to a close today the first phase of their advance into Ethiopia at 10:30 this morning when they captured the town of Adowa after driving the defending warriors into the hills in four hours of stiff fighting.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 6. -- Wilfred Courtenay Barber, correspondent of The Chicago Tribune, who came to Ethiopia to report the present conflict, died of malaria this afternoon.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Purdue's Boilermakers are off in front in the Big Ten football title chase, and even if they don't stay there probably will cause a lot of trouble for all comers.

More than 10,000 persons participated as contestants or spectators yesterday in the third annual Feis, or folk festival, held at the Bronx Coliseum under the auspices of the United Irish Counties Association.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Miss Fredericka Fry's True Mark, a 4-year-old chestnut mare, was awarded the hunter championship after a day of spirited competition in the eighth annual Soldiers and Sailors Club horse show, held on the spacious Rockwood Hall Country Club grounds today.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Centering its curriculum on the technical training of peace officers, an eight-week "crime school" will open tomorrow at Hobart College as a part of the State's drive on crime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the filing of thirteen additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 involving a total of $13,553,333.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- The market here for hogs was nervous last week. Supplies were ample but the demand was irregular. The top price on Friday was $11.15 a hundredweight, compared with $11.65 a week before and $12 three weeks ago. The average for the week was $10.30. Conditions in the provision trade are holding close attention.

With the season in the local galleries only just getting under way, the calendar of exhibitions has already begun to assume formidable proportions, and this week includes several of outstanding interest. The Newark Museum announces its long-planned exhibition of work by Pop Hart, with a press view tomorrow and opening to the public on Thursday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Corn traders are confronted with conditions that have not prevailed in recent years. Prospects are for a good crop, although conditions have been somewhat reduced by recent cold weather with some frost at a few points. Taking the crop on the whole, however, latest reports indicate that little damage was done last week by the low temperatures except in isolated sections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- A further shrinkage of the favorable merchandise trade balance to $29,000,000, net gold imports of $804,000,000 and a net inflow of short-term and long-term capital funds of about $660,000,000 were the outstanding features of the United States balance of international payments in the first six months of 1935, according to a summary made public today by Amos E. Taylor, assistant chief of the Finance Division of the Department of Commerce.

Football's first full-fledged Saturday followed the familiar pattern. There were the usual upsets, the usual unexpected scores and the usual evidences of early-season awkwardness. In short, very little was decided by the first Saturday in which all hands joined in the festivities. There are several first impressions, but these will have to be backed by further laboratory experiments before lasting opinions may be formed.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 6. -- A forty-yard free shot from the mallet of Raymond Guest in the second overtime period gave the Templeton poloists a thrilling 7-to-6 victory over the Aiken Knights in the weekly high-goal match at Bostwick Field today.

Activity increased last week in the commodity futures markets here, with most prices making substantial advances over the previous week. In the cash markets, all of the grains, coffee, cocoa, raw sugar, tin, cotton, printcloth, silk, wool tops, rubber and hides were higher, while only lard showed losses.

More than 15,000 men and women of German origin assembled in Madison Square Garden last night to commemorate the first German settlers in the United States in 1683. They brought up to date the sentiments of "German Day," which has been celebrated by the United German Societies for more than thirty years, by approving of present day Germany.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Three California airmen disappeared on a flight over the Great Salt Lake today and fear was expressed that they had perished in the brine.

Debutantes of this season will be manikins in the fashion show which will be given in conjunction with a luncheon tomorrow in the new Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza for the benefit of the Social Service Committee of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary.

How could good leadership have reduced our unemployment in the past two years? The answer to this question, very difficult three years ago, has since been worked out by the Australian and British Governments in a way so practical, plain and definite that the economic tricks and theories peddled around in this country look like kindergarten nonsense by comparison.

In his letter to THE TIMES Edward C. Wiley objects to the statement in Governor Lehman's Constitution Day proclamation that New York became a member of the new Federated Republic by ratifying the Constitution. Mr. Wiley says: "New York became a member of the Federated Republic when the Articles of Confederation went into effect in 1781.

The roll of a muffled drum beat a last tattoo for each of the eight city firemen killed in line of duty and for the twenty-nine other firemen who died during the past year, at the annual memorial services for deceased members of the New York City Fire Department yesterday afternoon at the Firemen's Monument, 100th Street and Riverside Drive.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,327,042,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Considerable shifting about of high ranking army officers is in prospect following the appointment of General Malin D. Craig as chief of staff.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP). -- The scene of the greatest show in baseball shifted to Detroit tonight, with the return of the Tigers and the Chicago Cubs for the final game, or games, of the 1935 world series.

From far and near, myriad friends, relatives and neighbors are ready to swarm to the stand to attest the veracity and high character of the skipper of the ferryboat Paunpeck of the Yonkers-Alpine Line, wherefore it must be assumed that in relating the following narrative Captain John New is entitled to at least a show of credulity.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- The New York Giants moved into first place in the Eastern division of the National Football League by defeating the Boston Redskins today, 20 to 12. A speedy, alert series of attacks in the first half, during which they made all their points, gave the Giants an advantage which the Redskins were unable to overcome.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Unfair competition in the sale of cleaning fluids is alleged in three Federal Trade Commission complaints issued against companies having headquarters in New York City and in Newark and Jersey City.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Charles Herber Klein, the Hoosier boy who became the National League's leading all-around batsman and homerun swatter only to lose in a mystifying way this gifted knack, regained his magic touch today.

Even those who live in the city and give thought now and then to the reasons for its supremacy are often content to dwell on its commercial facilities and financial institutions and let it go at that.

The Chase National Bank and the National City Bank, in their statements of condition on Sept. 30, report large gains in deposits and total resources compared with three months and a year ago.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 6. -- Administrators of the new unemployment insurance programs must guard against making "so many demands upon employers that their operating efficiency is impaired," Elmer F. Andrews, New York Industrial Commissioner, warned today in a speech before the International Association of Public Employment Services.
PARIS, Oct. 5. -- The uncertainty of the foreign situation does not augur well for the complete success of the domestic economic recovery program that has been undertaken by the French Government.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Oct. 6. -- An approach shot that landed fifteen feet from the pin on the nineteenth green combined with a first putt that stopped less than two inches from the cup gave Miss Charlotte Glutting and Rudolph Knepper victory over Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Vare in the final round of the mixed foursome tourney at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 6. -- Delegates to an agrarian congress in Cuautla, Morelos, demanded today that the government guarantee to protect the lives off rural school teachers. The demand was prompted by the killing of Professors Silvestre Gonzales and Gilberto Mendes near Cuernavaca Sept. 30 and by the murder and mutilation of two other professors near Cuautla a few days later.

New York City and other communities in the nation will face an emergency situation after Nov. 1, when Federal funds for the relief of transients will no longer be available, according to a statement yesterday by Stanley P. Davies, general director of the Charity Organization Society.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The American Federation of Labor's committee on racketeering in New York reported to the executive council today that its members were in complete accord with Assistant United States Attorney Thomas E. Dewey "that racketeering in labor unions, where it exists, must be stamped out."

In your recent editorial "Employment Rises" you speak of a "cheerful picture" because certain figures showed a decrease in unemployment amounting to 220,000 persons from July to August of this year. Inasmuch as the same authority says there were 9,900,000 unemployed in August, is it not plain that it would take nearly four years to clear up unemployment at this "cheerful" rate, even if it kept on improving this way every month?

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- Nazi Germany and all German colonies throughout the world celebrated today the National Socialist harvest thanksgiving festival as a demonstration that, following her regained "armament freedom," Germany is also determined to regain her "food freedom," to make herself independent of the world.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 6. -- Although they played throughout the full session of five hours at the Military Casino tonight, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of this city, challenger, failed to reach a decision in the second of their series of thirty games for the chess championship of the world.

A call to all Americans of all creeds and races to contribute to the United Jewish Appeal was made public yesterday over the signatures of 200 persons, many of them bishops, deans of theological schools, leaders of Christian organizations, university presidents and other notable laymen.

This evening's first-night business, at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, is "Macbeth," or Croshy Gaige's second gift to the season's Shakespearean doings. The four principals seen lately in "Othello" continue in this one -- Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper co-starred as Macbeth and his lady, Kenneth MacKenna and Alexandra Carlisle featured as Macduff and Lady Macduff.

MILWAUKIEE, Oct. 6 (AP). -- The American Public Health Association made public tonight a report on a new vaccine for the common cold, which indicates that the blood of many, though at present not all persons, can be immunized against catching colds to the extent that susceptible sufferers become as free as the hardy persons who have one cold a year, or now and then none.

The world production of cotton for the current season is tentatively estimated by the New York Cotton Exchange Service at 25,362,000 bales, compared with the sharply curtailed production of 22,605,000 bales last season and 25,885,000 two seasons ago.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 6. -- Partisanship in the Italo-Ethiopian hostilities nearly resulted in a riot in a theatre here last night when pictures of Mussolini, flashed on the screen in a news reel, were hissed by two residents of a fashionable colony in Islip.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- Norman Thomas of New York told a gathering in the Quincy Labor Church today that President Roosevelt cannot be termed a Socialist even though he has espoused ideas conceived and sponsored by Socialists.

HONOLULU, Oct. 6. -- Completing her fourth flight from Alameda Airport in San Francisco Bay to Honolulu, the Pan American Clipper landed at Pearl Harbor at 5:35 A.M. [11:05 A.M. New York time] today. Waiting to meet the airliner were only the ground crew and a dozen or so onlookers.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Four leading Southern Conference contenders took another hitch in their belts today and pressed onward to next Saturday's far-flung elimination tournament, with Duke and North Carolina carrying the favorites' banner.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6. -- Trading was active in the cotton market here last week and prices advanced rather sharply notwithstanding increased hedge selling and intermittent profit-taking. The main cause of the activity was a fear that war in Europe would grow out of the Ethiopian affair. This caused rather liberal buying by foreign interests and moreover stimulated trade buying in the belief that European complications would cause a further advance in prices.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 6. -- Everett C. Applegate, runner-up for the position of Nassau County Commander of the American Legion last Summer, was arrested here today on a charge of criminal assault on Ruth Creighton, 15 years old, as the result of disclosures during an investigation of the death of Applegate's wife, Ada, from arsenical poisoning.

That a major shake-up in personnel between seasons has been of immense profit to the Brooklyn Dodgers was proved yesterday when the rejuvenated Brooklynites turned about and shook up the vaunted Detroit Lions before the startled gaze of a gathering of 10,000 at Ebbets Field.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman proposed today to "modernize" the Constitution by enactment of a constitutional amendment requiring that all laws enacted by Congress be submitted to the Supreme Court for a decision on their constitutionality before they become effective.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Five investigators of the Federal Alcohol Administration will be sent into the country with sealed orders this week to renew the government's enforcement of "fair trade practices" in the liquor industry.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6. -- The Soviet Government will join the League of Nations steps to curb Italy, but will not collaborate in or recognize a mandate or protectorate over Ethiopia even under the League's flag, Moscow newspapers stress today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- The celebrating was done in the Cubs' clubhouse today, and with unmistakable fervor. Manager Charlie Grimm and his athletes were a riotous crew as they hustled through packing to make the 5 o'clock train for Detroit.
A two-day campaign to increase church attendance throughout the country in a demonstration of "loyalty day." was linked last night to a movement of the churches for the preservation of world peace.

ROME, Oct. 6. -- All Italy was galvanized this evening by the announcement of the capture of Adowa. The news was communicated by radio to the population by Dino Alfieri, Under-Secretary for Press and Propaganda, and a few minutes later huge crowds began to gather in the Piazza Colonna.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Asserting that foodstuffs have risen in price an average of 32 per cent under the AAA, the American Liberty League charged today that "the consumer is the forgotten man of this administration."

The conference in regard to crime held at Albany has adjourned. It is surprising that the moving picture industry was not urged to give real service by leading a movement which would demonstrate that crime never pays. The owners of this industry should remember that as citizens and taxpayers they are paying the cost of the maintenance of reformatories and prisons.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6. -- J.B. Greeson, district supervisor of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics, said today that Federal under-cover agents had for months made regular "buys" from the men arrested last night as members of an alleged "dope" ring.

Now that the 1935 scholastic football procession is virtually in full swing, inasmuch as numerous teams marched into action during the past week-end, schoolboy fans are beginning to take stock of their favorites as regards their chances for the season and for the traditional battles later.

Staging a brilliant rally in the second half to overcome a four-goal handicap, the Governors Island polo team routed the First Division riders of Fort Hamilton, 10 -- 5, in the fourth contest of their five-game series for the Colonel Joseph H. Colyer Trophy yesterday.

MADRID, Oct. 6. -- The first anniversary of the "proletarian" revolt launched by the Spanish Socialists throughout the country, which was particularly sanguinary in Asturias, passed with order in all provinces, it was announced tonight by the Ministry of the Interior.

A world war on leprosy, to determine its cause and cure, is to be waged with the cooperation of governments and scientific agencies in all countries where the disease persists, according to an announcement made yesterday by Henry L. Stimson, chairman, and Perry Burgess, president of the Leonard Wood Memorial.

The whaleboat representing the Twenty-seventh Fleet Division of Eighth Battalion of the United States Naval Reserve, pulled by five oarsmen in red crew shirts, won the third annual race for the R.A.C. Smith Memorial Trophy yesterday afternoon over a mile and a quarter course in the Hudson River.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 6. -- Dr. Robert A. Millikan, president of California Institute of Technology, in an address today at the Pacific International Exposition commemorating the 400th anniversary of the printing of the first complete Bible, expressed the belief that "the future progress of mankind will bear some intimate relation to the future circulation of the Bible."

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, today visioned country colleges, residential units of large universities, as a new trend in higher education.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Scoring three touchdowns in the second period and another in the fourth, the Green Bay Packers routed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 27 to 0, today in a National Football League game before 5,000 persons.

Even with due allowance for the strange things that winey Autumn air can do to boyish minds, the police of the Alexander Avenue station in the Bronx could not quite make head or tail yesterday of the strange odyssey of Robert Lane, the brothers Mirra and the brothers Segall.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct, 6. -- The eight annual horse show for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, held here today on the grounds of the Rockwood Hall Country Club, attracted a large gathering from Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- With war already under way in Africa, a European-American campaign to obtain 50,000,000 signatures to a people's mandate against war is making rapid headway, it was announced today at the headquarters of the Women's International League for Peace, which is directing the drive.

The Rev. Dr. J. Wilson Sutton, for the last twenty-one years vicar of Trinity Episcopal Chapel, announced yesterday that he would decline the office of Bishop of Vermont, to which he was recently elected, and remain in his present post. He revealed his decision at yesterday morning's service at Trinity Chapel, Twenty-fifth Street west of Broadway.

An issue of $6,000,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts 1 1/2 per cent public works bonds, due $1,200,000 annually on Sept. 15, 1936 to 1940, inclusive, will be offered today by an underwriting group at prices to yield 0.25 per cent to $1.50 according to maturity.

THE State of Connecticut, which is now celebrating its tercentenary year with displays of model salt box houses on village greens, might pause to drop an official tear for the subject of the late Thomas Boyd's biography, "Poor John Fitch" (Putnam, $3). For it was Fitch, a Connecticut Yankee inventor from Windsor, and not Robert Fulton, who devised the first successful steamboat.

A "campus" in its modern "U.S." use is defined as "the principal grounds "of a college or school between the "buildings or within the main en-"closure." According to the report of Mr. FRANK E. HILL, who has been making for the American Association for Adult Education a study of the educational work carried on by the CCC camps, they have become "campuses."

Denunciations of Italy and its current rulers for the outbreak of war in Ethiopia was sounded yesterday in numerous pulpits throughout the metropolitan area, while preachers voiced the hope that some way might be found to bring a speedy end to the suffering it is causing.

Unification of the city's rapid transit lines has proved a long-drawn-out process. The first official report, "Statement and Outline of Plan of "Readjustment, New York City Street "Railroads," carrying the names of GEORGE MCANENY, LE ROY T. HARKNESS and JOHN F. O'RYAN, was published Sept. 29, 1921, fourteen years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Protestant Episcopal parishes and missions throughout the diocese of Pennsylvania observed today the 150th anniversary of the convention, held in old Christ Church here, which laid the foundations for the communion in this country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- American leaders have all looked to the Bible for inspiration, President Roosevelt declared in a message delivered for him today by Secretary Hull over the National Broadcasting Company's network.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

As the site for a seven-story apartment house to contain sixty-five suites, the southwest corner of East 164th and 165th Streets has been purchased by Joseph Sager from Edward C. Baumert. The plot is 131 by 246 feet, a half block east of the Grand Concourse, where 164th Street turns north and runs into 165th Street. The new apartment

ADOWA, Ethiopia, Oct. 6. -- Italy's forty-year-old goal of vengeance fell into the hands of Il Duce's army today. Military headquarters announced officially that the city fell at 10:30 A.M. [2:30 A.M. Eastern standard time].
The Theatre Alliance, which Elmer Rice and associates were to have launched this Fall on a repertory basis, has been postponed for a full season, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- The play-by-play description of the fifth game of the world series today follows:

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 53 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the two weeks preceding and the highest rate this year excepting that in the two weeks ended on Feb. 9, when the automobile industry and other consumers were stocking steel.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 6.--After considering the recent orders of the Communist International in Moscow, which directed its adherents in the United States to join the American Federation of Labor in order to seize control of the labor movement, the executive council of the federation has decided, it was announced today, on a drastic step to purge the unions of Communists or of any persons advocating the violent overthrow of American institutions.

ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- The eastern end of Long Island and Fire Island are free from ragweed, the State Department of Health announced today in a summary of a survey to guide hay fever sufferers in the State in selecting those parts of the State which are free from this weed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Government attorneys checked their notes today in preparation for final arguments tomorrow in the case of twelve packing companies charged with combining to control retail prices of meat from 1927 to 1933.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The defiance of the League of Nations by Premier Mussolini of Italy has raised a situation which is considered here to be fraught with grave possibilities. However, the Stock Exchange was calm when hostilities in Ethiopia actually began.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Ramsay MacDonald, Lord President of the Council and former Prime Minister, in a speech tonight criticized Italy's case against Ethiopia and condemned dictatorships as "an unsettling element among civilized nations."

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Speculative trade in lard is attracting fair attention, but there is no enthusiasm on the part of most interests. Stocks are light and consumption is said to be about the usual level. Erratic hog and grain prices create uneasiness and liberal selling on all sharp bulges, largely by packing interests, while consumptive trade is fair.

Impartial, comprehensive and judicial are the right words to use of the report of the League's special committee on the whole Italo-Ethiopian controversy. From it but one conclusion can honestly be drawn. The careful and minute survey of the dispute from its beginnings shows that the Ethiopian Government has always been ready to submit its case to the judgment of the League, and to follow in every detail the prescriptions of the Covenant.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- The opposition is general in France to the application of severe sanctions against Italy, and as Great Britain will not undertake to apply them alone, it is thought here that the French argument in favor of moderate sanctions limited to the financial sphere will finally prevail.

The responsibility of the church in national and world affairs was emphasized yesterday morning in the sermon of the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx.

While more than 800 Polish-American residents of New Jersey gathered in Jersey City yesterday afternoon to protest the recent shooting at the home of John Crempa at Scotch Plains, N.J., Abe J. David, prosecutor of Union County, made plans to discuss the case today or tomorrow with Samuel Leibowitz, New York attorney, who will represent the family.

Mayor La Guardia's transit unification experts hope to present to the Transit Commission before the end of this month a comprehensive plan embracing the B.M.T., Interborough and Manhattan Railway properties and calling for a gross price of approximately $432,500,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6.--United States citizens were warned by President Roosevelt in a proclamation today against traveling except at their own risk on the ships of Italy and Ethiopia because of the war between those countries.

GENEVA, Oct. 6. -- President Roosevelt's neutrality proclamation made an extremely deep impression here as today's major development -- so much so that it brought a number of important League officials to their desks for work upon it today despite its being Sunday.

The Italian Teatro d'Arte opened its sixth consecutive season at Longacre Theatre yesterday afternoon and evening with an impressive rendering of an episodic play drawn from Sienkiewicz's widely-read, dramatized and filmed novel, "Quo Vadis," entitled; like other plays in thirty languages and the films inspired by it, "The Sign of the Cross."

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 6. -- Indictment of the Roosevelt administration "for a gross betrayal of the American people" was voted by Young Republican leaders from eleven Western States in closing today their convention, sponsored by the California Republican Assembly.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 7. -- Jose Iturbi, Spanish pianist and conductor, received one of the greatest ovations in the history of the Colon Theatre here last night when he directed the theatre's orchestra and played as piano soloist at the same time.
Prisons seem to have some strange attraction for Wayne Miller, 60 years old, a meek, thin little man with thinning gray hair, who was arrested yesterday on a charge of possessing heroin.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- Connection of New England ports with Philadelphia and other ports on the Delaware River through a modern ship canal across New Jersey and a plan to build an "auxiliary navy" through government subsidy for the American merchant marine, were primary issues at the annual convention of the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association which opened here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Greetings from the Archbishop of Canterbury to the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States were read here today at the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the first general convention of the communion in this country.

Retail plans now being developed for the Christmas selling period indicate that many stores are giving increased consideration to launching their holiday promotions from a week to ten days earlier than is usually the case. Ordinarily, showings of Christmas merchandise are not featured until the passing of Thanksgiving Day.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 7. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin refused to elaborate today on a statement he made during his Sunday sermon that he might resign his pastorate of the Shrine of the Little Flower unless parishioners contributed more generously to support of the church.

Directors of the Spiegel, May, Stern Company, Inc., voted yesterday to resume payment of dividends on the common stock with the declaration of 75 cents a share. The last payment was a similar amount in May, 1930. Two regular dividends of $1.62 1/2 each a share on the 6 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock also were declared yesterday, payable at different dates.

Opposition to pending State legislation which would force cities in this State to meet all their expenditures by a 2 per cent tax on the true value in money of real estate was expressed in a resolution adopted yesterday by the advisory council of the New York State Conference of Mayors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP). -- Restoration by President Roosevelt of a $6,000,000 allotment for extending the Shenandoah-Great Smoky Mountains National Parkway in Virginia and North Carolina was announced today by the Public Works Administration.

Virginia and Mary Drane, duo violinists, will appear tonight at the historical program to be given at the Hotel Roosevelt in conjunction with the fortieth New York State Conference of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

Rolling up the largest sales total for any Saturday in the last five years, outside of the Christmas shopping period, Fall retail trade in the metropolitan area showed heavy gains at the week-end, it was reported yesterday by department-store executives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The United States intends to do nothing to interfere with any program of economic and financial sanctions voted against Italy by the League of Nations, but officials said today that President Roosevelt could do no more than he has done, in his series of proclamations and the statement issued over the week-end providing for our neutrality.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 7 (AP). -- Miney Myerson, George W. Ogle's 5-year-old bay gelding, set a new track record at Agawam Park today in winning the five-and-one-half furlongs feature in 1:06 1-5.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 7. -- The Victorian Council Against War and Fascism sent a deputation today to the Italian Consul, Cavalier Anzelotti, protesting against Italy's "murderous attack upon helpless Abyssinians." The consul previously refused to see the deputation but agreed to see one representative. Two others forced their way into the room.

Industrial and housing properties were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday. Six Manhattan properties and one Bronx holding were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales.

Before New Jersey showed herself unworthy of the sales tax Governor HOFFMAN was sometimes spoken of as the Young Hope of the Republicans in '36. It is not, however, as a Governor, a leader, but as a Republican voter that he offers to Chairman FLETCHER and the Republican party a positive, prime, constructive and necessary issue that will make everything right for the American people, their Government and their business.
"The End of St. Petersburg" and "Days With Tolstoi" will be revived tomorrow night by the Cinema Guild of the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7. -- The Social Security Act offers an unparalleled opportunity to develop public health services into tremendous benefit to the nation, the convention of the American Public Health Association was told tonight by the president of the association, Dr. E.L. Bishop, health director for the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Mr. and Mrs. Silas B. Mason, on the eve of departing for the West, saw the latter's Mid Victorian run one of her best races to capture the Blue Girl Purse, feature yesterday at Belmont Park. Charles Kurtsinger, who has done so well this year aboard Mrs. Mason's racers, rode in his old-time form to get the daughter of Victorian home first by three lengths.

It would be a pleasant privilege to write cheerfully of Philip Merivale's "Macbeth," which was put on at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. He is an excellent actor who has kept the stage in high esteem whenever he has been on it. Although we are less familiar with Gladys Cooper on this side of the Atlantic, we once had a taste of her mettlesome quality in "The Shining Hour."

Horace G. Knowles, real estate broker of 45 East Fifty-fifth Street, is sorry for Ethiopia. However, he does not want to keep on receiving checks and appeals for medical and nursing jobs in the African empire. He has no connection with Ethiopia.

DETROIT, Oct. 7. -- Scenes of the wildest disorder prevailed tonight as Tigertown, fairly beside itself in its joy, embarked on what promised to be a twenty-four-hour celebration commemorating Detroit's first baseball championship of the world.

Not much attention appears to have been given, other than in the Albany newspapers, to the meeting of the State Trails Conference, held Oct. 4-5 in Albany, which developed into earnest opposition to projects now under way in the State forest preserve by the Civilian Conservation Corps under the direction of the Conservation Department.

The 1,485 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $42,671,487,291 par value on Oct. 1, had a total market value of $38,374,693,665, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Sept. 1, there were 1,493 issues aggregating $43,144,670,444 par value, which had a total market value of $39,061,593,570.

In its massive new building, occupied for the first time yesterday, the Supreme Court of the United States will find its dignity as well as its convenience better served than in the contracted quarters where it had long sat. The project for a more stately edifice was agitated and maturely considered for many years.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The State of New Jersey should suppress a feeling of inferiority and develop a "superiority complex," Governor Harold G. Hoffman declared here today at the fourteenth annual institute of the New Jersey Press Association at Rutgers University.
Dwellings and plots were among the Westchester items in the market reports yesterday.

When Dominick Tassone, 19 years old, finishes the sentence in Elmira Reformatory recently imposed by Supreme Court Justice McCook on his plea of guilty in the first racketeering case developed by the Dewey inquiry, he will receive another sentence as a parole violator.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 7. -- Floyd B. Odlum of New York was divorced at Minden today by Hortense McQuarrie Odlum. The decree involved two figures active in the business world.
Three bankers and two diplomats who arrived from Europe yesterday on the French liner Normandie expressed the opinion that the fighting in Ethiopia would not lead to a war in Europe.

The concert given by "The Little Singers of the Wooden Cross" last night in the Town Hall was an entertainment of the most refreshing originality and charm. The performers are for the greater part young boys, from the faubourgs of Paris and neighboring places.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Two combinations finished in a tie for first place in the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Westchester P.G.A., which was played over the 6,152-yard course of the Mount Kisco Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Acting Secretary of the Treasury Coolidge announced tonight that the tenders for Treasury bills, to be dated Oct. 9, which were offered on Oct. 4, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today. Tenders were invited for two series to the aggregate amount of $100,000,000, and $315,724,000 was applied for, of which $100,031,000 was accepted.
ADOWA, Oct. 7 (Reuters). -- Ethiopian casualties in the whole action before Adowa were estimated by the Italian headquarters today at 600 dead and wounded. Many prisoners were taken.
ROME, Oct. 7. -- The decisions of the League of Nations Council felt like a cold douche to Italy.

I have had so many occasions recently to defend the American Civil Liberties Union from the charge of communism that perhaps you will permit me to point out to Messrs. Baldwin, Hays and Ward, whose letter appears in your issue of today, the basis for that charge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7. -- Although expressing the opinion that the Teachers' Oath Bill is "an unnecessary and unwise piece of legislation" and offering the hope that it will be repealed, Dr. James B. Conant of Harvard University, declared today that every Harvard faculty member must take the oath if he is to hold his present position.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- Having ostracized the Jews legally, socially and professionally, the National Socialist regime is undertaking the final step in its solution of the Jewish question -- namely, economic "liquidation" of the Jews.

Registration for the general election will begin today and the leaders of both major parties will bend their efforts to overcome customary "off-year" apathy to bring out a big vote for their respective Assembly candidates.

Yesterday was the coldest Oct. 7 on record in New York City. The thermometer at the United States Weather Bureau touched 39 degrees at 2 A.M., one degree below the previous mark of 40 degrees, set in 1904. The high for the date, reached in 1912, is 79, and the average over a forty-six-year period is 60.

The "truck trails" to which Mr. RAYMOND TORREY refers in his letter, published in an adjoining column, have become a lively topic of debate among local conservationists. They are substantial roads, twelve to sixteen feet wide, built by CCC labor along the course of old logging roads in some of the more remote parts of the Adirondacks and designed for fire protection.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Abraham Epstein of New York, executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security, told the New Jersey Social Security Commission here today that the Social Security Law recently enacted by Congress was "a damnable sales-tax scheme."

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 7. -- To the delight of his countrymen, who had lamented his poor start and the loss of the first game, Dr. Max Euwe of this city today succeeded in equalizing the score in his match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris for the chess championship of the world.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- The Reich Brotherhood Council of Confessional Synods met here tonight to consider the government's offer to place two of its leaders on the three-man church directorate just created by a decree of Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- The Boerse was firm and quiet today. Heavy industrials were stronger, Hoesch gaining 2 points. Machines were somewhat more active, and Niuag gained 1, points. Chemicals were firmer throughout. Electricals rose, Siemens Halske gaining I point.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 7. -- Charley Caldwell will be heading south to his alma mater, Princeton, at the end of this week and he'll be taking with him the fastest Williams College football team he has developed in his eight years in the Berkshires.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The "relatively favorable" pace of recent months was maintained by domestic business in September, the Department of Commerce said today in its Survey of Current Business for October.

ROME, Oct. 7. -- While comparative calm reigned along most of the Italian Eritrean front, heavy fighting was reported at the extreme left of the Italian line, where General Ruggero Santini is still in contact with Ethiopian forces that are attempting an outflanking movement.

Sailing tomorrow on the Normandie will be Arthur Schwartz, bound for London and work on a new C.B. Cochran revue that is destined later for New York. Mr. Schwartz will furnish the entire score for the show, which is due in London about Christmas time, with some of its lyrics by Howard Dietz, sketches possibly by Edward Knoblock, and with a Hollywood star heading an otherwise all-English cast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Better collections and a "greatly reduced" demand for emergency loans are clear indications that "the economic sky is brightening," W.I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, today told the presidents of the twelve Federal Land Banks, here for a conference on their business problems.
Quotations for all classes of money were carried forward without change. Demand for funds was light.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- At least six men were killed and thirty-eight injured today in an explosion which demolished the five-story plant of the Glidden Soya Products Company. Policemen and firemen were searching the ruins tonight for other bodies.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7. -- Colonel Snowden Fahnestock won a divorce from Mrs. Helen Moran Fahnestock in the Superior Court here today on the ground of desertion. Judge Alberic Archambault heard the case in less than a half hour on depositions. None of the principals was present.

The flight of capital from Europe, sped by the fear of war, slackened perceptibly yesterday, giving the British Exchange Equalization Account an opportunity to bolster up the pound sterling, which in turn helped to lift other currencies.

The Conference on Port Development of the City of New York sent a protest yesterday to President Roosevelt asking him to rescind his warning against American use of ships of belligerents in the Italo-Ethiopian war on the grounds that it was "ill-advised" and a "serious blow" to the commerce of the port.

Automobile fatalities in New York State during the first eight months of this year totaled 1,725, an increase of twenty-one over the corresponding period of 1934, according to data issued yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Coincident with a report by Chief Justice Hughes that there are 2,991 more criminal cases on Federal Court dockets than at this time last year, a recommendation of the Conference of Federal Circuit Judges proposed the creation of eight additional district judgeships.

The Department of Commerce published yesterday its estimated "balance of international payments" for the first half of 1935. This computation, which attempts to provide an accurate ledger of all our transactions with other nations, shows in the present case a striking contrast with the record of pre-depression days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP). -- An intensive effort to develop gasoline substitutes and a big increase in oil imports were disclosed today as part of Italy's war preparations.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 (AP). -- America's beer-brewing industry has "come back" from near extinction to about 70 per cent of the peak production of pre-prohibition days, the Master Brewers Association was told today.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The text of the French reply to Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's inquiry of two weeks ago regarding the probable attitude of France to an attack by Italy on the British fleet in consequence of naval preparations in the Mediterranean was made public here and in Paris tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7. -- For the first time this year Coach Dick Harlow took his Harvard varsity behind the secret practice fence today to begin the grind necessary to whip the eleven into shape for Holy Cross. Mondays were easy days on Soldiers Field in the past, but today the coaches ordered a short scrimmage between the regulars and the scrubs.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 7. -- Ethiopians felt Italian troops had failed to penetrate Ethiopia at any vital point today as the war entered its fifth day. They pointed out the line of defense had been pushed back only in the extreme northeast, where the Fascisti advanced in the Adowa and Adigrat sections.

TOKYO, Oct. 7. -- With the support of the army and the navy the Foreign Office is taking steps to curb a tendency of officers in China to make unauthorized statements on policy. Goro Morishima, Foreign Office Major General; Niejl Okamura, army general staff captain, and Tadao Honda of the naval general staff have been ordered to China for an inspection tour.

Prices of commodity futures were easier yesterday in quiet trading, although several of the metals were firm and hides were active and strong. In the cash markets tin, cotton, lead and zinc advanced and all the grains, rubber and silk declined.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Attacks on the New Deal policies of President Roosevelt, the alleged extravagance of the administration of Governor Lehman and the dictatorship claimed to have been exerted on members of the State Legislature by Postmaster General James A. Farley characterized speeches by members of the Republican Assembly caravan in opening their campaign for the election of a Republican Assembly in Westchester County today.

The Rev. F. George Makowski of the Garden City Country Club, who last Monday teamed with another amateur, Johnny Hines, to win the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association on his home course, yesterday collaborated with Al Brosch, Bethpage Park pro, to lead a field of thirty-four teams with a dazzling 68.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The New Jersey women's golf team routed the Westchester squad, 11 1/2 to 3 1/2, in their annual team match for the J.J. Thompson Trophy at the Westchester Country Club today. The victors took eleven of the fifteen encounters, one match being tied.
PARIS, Oct. 7. -- The following is the text of the French note to Great Britain, delivered in the form of a letter from the French Ambassador to the British Foreign Secretary:

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 7. -- Inspector Harold R. King, in charge of Nassau County detectives, announced here today that he was convinced that Mrs. Ada Applegate, wife of an American Legion official, had been murdered. He added, however, that unless there were unforeseen developments he did not expect any arrests on a murder charge.

Details of salaries of executives of the Spiegel, May, Stern Company, Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission confidentially, were released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange upon order of the commission.

The Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls at 440 East Fifty-seventh Street will open its forty-seventh season on Friday by offering its members, the majority of whom are young business woman of Greater New York, an augmented program of classes in business, cultural and domestic subjects, and of social activities.

DETROIT, Oct. 7. -- "We want Goose! Yea, Goose!" The cry echoed over Navin Field today as the greatest crowd the park ever held thrilled to the spectacle of Goose Goslin driving the single that gave Detroit's Tigers the first world series championship the club has ever won.

DUBLIN, Oct. 7. -- William T. Cosgrave, former President of the United Ireland Party, was faced tonight with a crisis within his own ranks precipitated by Frank MacDermott, one of the party's vice presidents, who addressed a strong letter of protest to him against recent criticisms of Eamon de Valera by some of the party's stalwarts.

Samuel R. Rosoff, subway contractor, protested yesterday the expected award by the Board of Transportation to one of his competitors of the contract for the construction of the first section of the Sixth Avenue subway. The Board opened the bids last Friday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Publication of the Westchester Government Commission's recommendations for revision of the government of Westchester County and its political subdivisions as soon as possible after election day was asked today in a resolution adopted by the county Board of Supervisors.

Scandinavian countries are reaping in growing tourist trade the benefits of their traditional aloofness from European political wrangles, according to William C. Neven, passenger traffic manager of the American Scantic Line. Mr. Neven returned to his office yesterday after an eight-week business trip in Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Poland and Russia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Arguments on the appeal of the Oklahoma Utilities Company from a District of Columbia Supreme Court ruling which refused to enjoin Secretary Ickes, PWA Administrator, from allocating Federal funds for the construction of a municipally owned power plant in Hominy, Okla., were heard today in the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

The Alaska Juneau Gold Mining Company reported for the nine months ended Sept. 30 an estimated profit after operating expenses and development charges, but before depreciation, depletion and Federal taxes of $1,420,800, compared with $1,725,850 in the same period last year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct, 7. -- With most of the men who played against Penn Saturday excused from the drill, the Princeton football squad resumed work today in preparation for the Williams game here Saturday.

"Heaven on Earth," the musical play with which the Public Theatre, Second Avenue and Fifth Street, formally began its season ten days ago, resuming regular performances last night, follows pretty much the same pattern as the shows exhibited at that house in previous years. That is to say, it affords a pleasant, innocuous evening for uncritical minds.
The formation of an Insurance Arbitration Council to promote a greater use of arbitration in settling insurance disputes was announced yesterday by the American Arbitration Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Treasury's refunding of $1,250,000,000 of called Fourth Liberty loan bonds will end on Friday night, Acting Secretary Coolidge announced today.

GENEVA, Oct. 7. -- The League of Nations has acted. Thirteen member nations of the League Council have found guilty of war "the Italian Government" -- not Italy, but her Fascist dictatorship. A jury chosen from every continent unanimously pronounced this verdict: ...

Following is the text of the report of the Committee of Six of the Council of the League of Nations on aggressions in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, as broadcast from the League's wireless station at Geneva:

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 7. -- Twelve persons, several of them prominent in business or banking, were killed early today in an unexplained crash of a United Air Lines transport plane into a hill fifteen miles west of here.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 7. -- A golfers' dinner was given this evening for those entered in the Fall golf tournament here. Among those present were Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pell, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Richards, Mr. and Mrs. Morin S. Hare, Mr. and Mrs. Bedell H. Harned, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Jarrett, Fay Ingalls, H.G. Hornfeck, Martin M. Foss, John Stewart, Paul King, Dr. S.L. Craig and E.G. Herendeen.

A memorial service for Jacob H. Schiff, Jewish philanthropist, was held yesterday in the original building of Congregation Ohab Zedek, 18 West 116th Street, the cornerstone of which was laid by Mr. Schiff in 1906. A tribute by Morris Engelman, chairman of the congregation, embodied a plea for the establishment of a Schiff Memorial Fund to aid Jewish social, educational and religious institutions throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Trade practice rules for the juvenile wheel goods industry, adopted by that industry and submitted to the Federal Trade Commission for consideration and approval, were made public by that commission today. In making public the proposed rules, the commission issued the following statement:

Executive offices of the New York Stock Exchange will be centralized as the result of a four-month study of methods of coordination, Charles R. Gary, president, announced yesterday to the membership. His letter was the first direct report from a president of the Exchange since the annual report of Richard Whitney for the fiscal year 1931-1932.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion nominee for District Attorney of Kings County, charged last night before a Brooklyn audience that "murder is safe" in that borough.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 7. -- Labor policies proposed in the "new line" adopted by the Communist International were denounced as an attempt to coerce the American Federation of Labor in an address by President William Green on opening the fifty-fifth annual convention of the federation today.

Perhaps I can give a word of comfort to "Frightened Lady" who relates an experience in visiting a church where preference was given to members only. She wishes to know "whether one can enter the home of the Lord in New York with the serene grace country people have -- the certainty of being welcomed there."

Mrs. Alicia Maddox Glendening Llewellyn, foster daughter of Alfred du Pont, began proceedings yesterday before Supreme Court Referee Gavegan for the custody of her 12-year-old son, Alan Sanford Glendening, son of Harold S. Glendening, New York lawyer. The care and custody of the boy have been the subject of litigation at intervals since he was born in Paris in 1923.

DETROIT, Oct. 7. -- The hit that won the world series almost sent Goose Goslin to the hospital. His team-mates broke out in a physical demonstration of joy as he tore into the dugout after chasing Manager Mickey Cochrane home with the winning run, and they didn't stop until they were nearly exhausted in the clubhouse and Goslin's nose was bleeding from a scratch from an excited Detroit player.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- Three modified plans for reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company, the top holding concern of the former Insull utilities empire, were filed in the Federal Court here today under Section 77B of the amended Bankruptcy Law.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 7. -- Mrs. Betty Peck Thomas obtained a divorce here today from Richard W. Thomas, columnist on The Brooklyn Daily Eagle; She charged nonsupport and cruelty.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Two Newark detectives, waiting in a darkened theatre box office for burglars, were wounded here early today when a uniformed policeman mistook them for their quarry and opened fire.

The trial of three of eleven former officers and directors of the New York Title and Mortgage Company on indictments handed up more than a year ago was tentatively set for Oct. 21 by General Sessions Judge Freschi yesterday. The indictments charge they misrepresented the financial status of the corporation as of Dee. 31, 1932.
Fordham's football forces moved ahead with increased speed yesterday in preparation for their first intersectional contest of the season against Purdue at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

DETROIT, Oct. 7. -- The goose hangs high once more in the world of baseball, and tonight all Detroit is madly dancing through the streets and rending the air with a mighty chant, "Yea, Goose! Yea, Goose! Yea, Goose!"

John Anderson, rugged Swedish light heavyweight, was returned the victor over Fanis Tzanetopoulos, Greek battler, in the feature eight-rounder before 3,000 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

A call to all patriots to combat the forces undermining our national foundations was the keynote of an address delivered by Mrs. William A. Becker, president general of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, at the opening session of the fortieth annual New York State conference of the organization yesterday morning at the Hotel Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Administration officials were disclosed today to be working on plans for a new work relief program for next year.
DETROIT, Oct. 7. -- The play-by-play description of the sixth and final game of the world series today follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- An innovation in educational methods, which will enable school pupils at widely scattered points to listen to illustrated radio lectures, was demonstrated privately today under the sponsorship of the Pennsylvania Arts and Sciences Society.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 7. -- The British motorship Pronto, her decks awash, was being towed here tonight after wallowing in the high seas since last night twenty-five miles south of Montauk Point, after a collision yesterday with the Coast Guard patrol boat Argo.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 7. -- Members of the diplomatic and consular corps following a conference here sent identical telegrams today to their respective governments asking them to obtain assurances from the Italian Government that neither Addis Ababa, where the foreign population is 6,000, nor Diredawa, where there are 200 foreigners, would be attacked from the air.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Potato Program Development Committee, a non-governmental group, after studying the testimony taken at the Potato Control Law hearing last week, made public today proposed amendments to the law which Secretary Wallace was requested to submit to Congress when it convenes in January.

NEWARK; N.J., Oct. 7. -- The New Jersey Association of the Amateur Athletic Union took a definite stand tonight against the participation of American athletes in the Olympic Games scheduled to be held in Berlin, Germany, next Spring.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- While Italy was being branded as a treaty-breaker at Geneva today it became known that the Italian Government had accepted Great Britain's invitation to a naval conference this Autumn in accordance with the Washington treaty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Women of both political parties went into action here today.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- Advice to Italy is plentiful in the French press today -- now that Italy has had the satisfaction of avenging her defeat at Adowa and before the application of the Geneva decision -- to begin to seek by every means a diplomatic settlement of her claims against Ethiopia.
BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 7 (AP). -- A warning that the United States must guard against "subtle ways of propagandists" in striving to stay out of war was given tonight by Senator William E. Borah of Idaho.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Instead of ending the "dole" on Nov. 1, the deadline set by President Roosevelt, the government will continue direct relief in full force during the first half of November, spending at least $30,000,000, it was declared officially at WPA headquarters today.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7 (AP). -- The shattered ranks of the political administration left by the late Senator Huey P. Long were rallied tonight by Lieut. Gov. James A. Noe's announcement of his withdrawal as a candidate for Governor in the January primary.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES IN THE FIELD, Adowa, Ethiopia, Oct. 7. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's troops fortified their new-won lines and held their eager armies in leash on the Northern Ethiopian front tonight.

DETROIT, Oct. 7. -- Weather clear, track fast. The mercury moved up in the thermometer and Flea Clifton moved up in the Tiger batting order. Both changes were favorably received by the Detroit fans. The crowd packed the park and the streets around the park. Fire engines clanged past the main entrance and went on up the street at full tilt.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Possibility that Admiral Richard E. Byrd may return to Antarctica for the third time is seen in his first report of the second expedition's work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Supreme Court today held its first session in its splendid new ten-million-dollar home, devoting a 1-hour-and-20-minute session to the admission of 113 lawyers to practice before the bar and the hearing of motions.

Steel ingot production in September was 123 per cent higher than in the same month last year, although 3 per cent less than in August, 1935. The daily average production last month, however, was 4.7 per cent higher than in August owing to two less working days in September, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

A State-wide campaign to reduce highway accidents was initiated at the thirty-second annual convention of the New York State Automobile Association yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 100 delegates from automobile clubs affiliated with the association attended the convention, which will conclude today.

Favorable dividend actions announced yesterday and over the week-end did much to offset the effects of the war news and the slight let-up noted in industrial recovery, especially in steel production. The decline in steel operations, however, is viewed as entirely temporary, and it is the consensus that the upward trend, checked last week, will be resumed as soon as the automotive manufacturers extend production of their new models.

It is not a subject for regret that the Chicago and Detroit papers put the Ethiopian war in second place while the world series was under way. We need by no means blush for the fact that fully as many people have been listening to the play-by-play account over the radio as listened to MUSSOLINI'S radio call to arms.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Rejection of New Jersey's argument that dumping at sea of "sludge," the residue from chemically treated garbage, is a violation of the Supreme Court's decree of December, 1933, against garbage dumping was urged upon the Supreme Court today by New York City, through Mayor La Guardia.

Mrs. Robert Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador in London, and Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others include Edgar Selwyn, producer; Mme. Helena Rubinstein, Sidney Kent, president of Fox films; Professor Emil Ludwig, and:

I read with interest and appreciation the letter from "Frightened Lady." Some years ago when I was studying for the ministry in a theological school in an Eastern city I had a similar experience to that which she describes in her letter.

Killing frosts in parts of the Cotton Belt over Sunday, following a general lowering of private crop estimates last week, sent prices up one-fourth cent a pound yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and carried May and July contracts to new high levels.
Business buildings, several flats and various dwellings were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- A fresh outburst of speculative buying took place today in iron, steel, aircraft and shipbuilding issues in the stock markets here in anticipation of large orders following probable increased expenditure for armaments. British funds recovered further on fresh investment support.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The leading packers of the country, against whom complaints charging combinations to control prices, apportion sales and eliminate competition in Texas, Tennessee, Alabama, Mississippi and Arkansas, are pending in the Department of Agriculture, made a blanket denial of all charges at a hearing today before Secretary Wallace.

The belief that dictatorships now threatening civilization ultimately will work their own destruction was voiced in a number of sermons addressed to the 2,000,000 members of New York City's Jewish community, celebrating Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 7. -- A Pittsburgh society girl and a banker were among those killed in the air accident near Cheyenne, Wyo., today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Commenting upon former President Hoover's speech of Saturday, Senator Robinson, majority leader of the Senate, characterized the utterances as those of a man who "was seeking return to power," and added:

A story of an Ohio woman's month-long siege to find a place for herself among the American volunteers going to Ethiopia to administer medical and other aid to the native troops was told yesterday by Miss Lila Coon of Cincinnati after she had won her cause at the offices of the Committee for Ethiopia, located at 228 East Forty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- A special meeting of the Labor party tomorrow to consider its own leadership and a Cabinet meeting the next day will conjointly have a definite bearing on the next British general election, in which the outstanding issue will be the Italian war.

After a conference with Victor F. Ridder, publisher, who will succeed him on or before Oct. 15, General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator here, announced yesterday the addition of 10,000 workers to the WPA payroll within the last fortnight.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 7. -- Reports of ill treatment of Colonel Damian Veltcheff and other arrested persons in connection with the recent coup d'etat "plot" reached such dimensions today that several doctors, journalists and relatives of the arrested men were taken by the police to visit the prisoners. The reports have aroused resentment in the army.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Oct. 2, issued by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows decreases for the week of $46,000,000 in total loans and investments, $79,000,000 in net demand deposits and $37,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and an increase of $20,000,000 in time deposits.

When the work-relief program was first outlined some pointed out that it would have to steer its way between two dangers: either projects of the leaf-raking variety or projects of permanent value which would require not only a heavy outlay for materials but a special type of skilled work to which only a small proportion of the jobless had been trained.

The transit unification negotiations now being concluded with the Interborough interests may result in saving interest charges that were in prospect under the tentative memorandum of understanding with the B.M.T., it was indicated yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 7. -- The government asserted today that the Italian occupation of Adowa and Adigrat had been accomplished without resistance and that the Ethiopians had evacuated the towns in an orderly fashion in accordance with a preconceived program.

Columbia University, which last Spring abolished the fee collected from students for the support of undergraduate activities, announced yesterday a new policy of supporting these activities from general income, except in the case of undergraduate publications, for which a gradual withdrawal of support was provided.

HARTFORD, Oct. 7. -- Elections for local offices in 149 of the 169 towns in Connecticut today indicated a trend toward Republicanism. Several towns which have been Democratic in local elections and went Democratic in the last State and national elections, today elected Republican Selectmen and tax collectors.
Mayor La Guardia said last night that he was well pleased with the result of his anti-noise drive, which completed its first week last midnight.

Danno O'Mahoney successfully repulsed Joe Savoldi's bid for the world's heavyweight wrestling championship at Madison Square Garden last night. The Irish grappler threw the former Notre Dame football star in 26 minutes and two seconds of a finish match before a crowd of 8,000.
Antique collecting is not strictly a parlor game, it appears from exhibits at the seventh New York Antiques Exposition, which opened last night at the Hotel Commodore.

No bids were reported yesterday to have been received by the Board of Supervisors of Alameda County, Calif., for a new issue of $1,060,000 tax-anticipation notes of the Oakland-Berkeley school and high school districts. The offer was made last week.

A new issue of $10,000,000 of Pacific Lighting Corporation 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures, due in 1945, will be offered to the public today at par by a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc. Others in the group are Dean Witter Co., Brown Harriman Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers, Lazard Freres Co., Inc., Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., and Elworthy Co.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 7. -- Mrs. Alice Speed Stoll told for the first time this afternoon the story of her kidnapping by Thomas H. Robinson Jr. when she was called as a government witness in the trial of Mrs. Frances Robinson, the kidnapper's wife, and Thomas H. Robinson Sr., both of Nashville, Tenn., on charges of complicity in the abduction and subsequent ransoming for $50,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Although Head Coach Ducky Pond plans no Yale shake-up until after the Pennsylvania football game next Saturday gives the men their first real test, Bernie Rankin, reserve halfback in 1934, today was promoted to right halfback, displacing Al Hessberg, last year's freshman co-captain. Rankin is likely to start against Penn.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7 (AP). -- Safe and Sound, H.W. Young's 4-year-old gelding, came through to an unexpected victory today in the one and one-sixteenth miles of the Tuscarora Purse at Laurel.

ALBANY, Oct. 7 (AP). -- Federal approval of twenty-seven New York State Works Progress Administration projects calling for an expenditure of $141,755.52 and immediate employment of 785 men was announced today by Lester W. Herzog, up-State administrator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Henry Ford is reported here to be favorable to a conference of independent citizens to formulate a declaration of principles in opposition to the New Deal policies. Republicans who have advocated a meeting of Republicans and Democrats to define a platform acceptable to conservatives have been informed that Mr. Ford is reacting well to the proposal.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

HONOLULU, Oct. 7. -- Hawaii's first formal hearing on the matter of statehood for the territory opened today in historic Iolani Palace before five members of Congress who arrived four days ago to conduct forums on all the islands. Witnesses of both chief political parties testified that sentiment in Hawaii was overwhelmingly in favor of complete State's rights here.

PRAGUE, Oct. 7. -- Significant speeches couched in terms of friendship were made today at a reception in honor of Russian journalists now visiting Czechoslovakia by Foreign Minister Eduard Banes and the Soviet Minister, S.S. Alexandrovsky.
State Liquor Authority inspectors unexpectedly visited restaurants and night clubs in the midtown and East Side area yesterday afternoon, where they seized champagne, still wine and liquor.

In THE TIMES report of the fortieth anniversary celebration program at Teaneck, N.J., mention is made of the supposed derivation of the name of the township from two Dutch words, "tea," meaning "bordering a stream," and "neck," meaning a curved piece of land.

Norman Thomas was the chief speaker at the opening of the Socialist party's campaign in Queens at four meetings last night. The principal meeting was in the Jamaica Town Hall, Parsons Boulevard and Jamaica Avenue. The others were at party headquarters in Astoria and Ridgewood and the Woodside Labor Temple.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- The New Deal, however sound its principles and projects may be, could not be made workable "within the lifetime of the youngest prospective voter now living," according to Robert Moses, New York City Park Commissioner, writing in this week's issue of The Saturday Evening Post, out tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- Small receipts and firmness in the market for fresh pork were reflected today in a stronger market for hogs, with prices steady to 10 cents a hundred weight higher than on Saturday. The clearance was reported as the best for a Monday in some time.

For nearly two years the College Art Association has been publishing, in monthly instalments, an Index of Twentieth Century Artists. This project has resulted and continues to result in the compilation of much very valuable reference material. It deserves to be called one of the College Art Association's most important activities.
The Pennsylvania Board of Game Commissioners has declared a three-day open season on antlerless deer in fourteen counties of the State. The dates are Dec. 12, 13 and 14.

Interest in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was confined principally to the market for United States Government loans and further substantial gains were marked up in the group on a moderate turnover. Final quotations showed advances of 2-32 to 20-32 point, with the new Treasury 2 3/4s reaching a new high at 100 8-32, while the Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s rose 5-32 to 100 14-32.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- In response to a request of Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, Governor Lehman tonight named a committee to advise with the department on a policy of building additional "fire truck trails" in the forest preserve.

Apparently content to await a more definite course in industrial recovery and confused by the mixed war news, trading on the Stock Exchange fell off yesterday although prices generally moved higher. Trading in bonds was dull, although government obligations and some foreign issues were stronger.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- Small receipts and firmness in the market for fresh pork were reflected today in a stronger market for hogs, with prices steady to 10 cents a hundred weight higher than on Saturday. The clearance was reported as the best for a Monday in some time.

With exchanges of the called liberty Fourth 4 1/4s into the new Treasury 2 3/4 per cent bonds having come virtually to a standstill of late, the decision of the Treasury Department to set this Friday as the final date on which the exchange can be made, caused only a ripple of interest yesterday in Government bond circles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Striking dairy farmers of Northern Illinois and Southern Wisconsin late today rejected the proposal of Governor Horner for a thirty-day truce in the strike which has curtailed Chicago's milk supply and announced plans to develop a new marketing agency.

Revamping Manhattan's offense for the intersectional battle with Louisiana State at Ebbets Field next Saturday, Coach Chick Meehan yesterday ordered secret practice for the Manhattan football squad for the second successive day.

ROME, Oct. 8. -- The effects so far of the League of Nations decisions on Premier Mussolini have been to increase his determination to go ahead on the road he has chosen for himself and to defy the powers that are sitting in judgment on him in Geneva.

ROME, Wednesday, Oct. 9. -- Dispatches from Italian correspondents at Asmara early today said that a strong column of the Second Army Corps left Adowa yesterday in the direction of Aksum and was last reported fifteen kilometers [about nine miles] from that objective.

Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, was asked yesterday by Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley to explain why she had failed to restore Major Wilfred E. Boughton to his position in the occupational bureau of the ERB.

With the woodcock season opening next Tuesday, the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission reminds hunters that a special license, in addition to the regular State permit, is required to shoot these migratory birds. Licenses may be obtained from game wardens or from the commission's offices in Trenton.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- Curtailment of Federal revenue was advocated today by Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia as "the only way to stop government spending." He recommended specifically that the Federal Government be deprived of the power to collect income taxes through repeal of the Sixteenth Amendment.
THERE were times during the recent world series when an onlooker might have been puzzled as to whether it was Chicago vs. Detroit or the Cubs vs. Umpire Moriarty for the big baseball title.
Mayor La Guardia repeated yesterday his warning that commissioners and appointive officers in his administration must sever their political ties and inform him that they had done so.

New York, which for several days has been vaguely aware of an impending rodeo because of a profusion of ten-gallon hats along Eighth Avenue and a sign in a beauty parlor, "Welcome, Cowgirls," will see the real thing this morning.

The sincerity of Governor Lehman in fostering a conference on crime at Albany last week was questioned last night by Walter J. Mahoney, president of the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs. He spoke over WEAF and a State-wide network of radio stations.
