Depressing influences continued yesterday in many of the commodity futures markets, but rubber, silk, wool tops and lead futures were firmer. Spot copper advanced to 9 1/4 cents a pound, the highest since April, 1931. Rubber gained, while all the grains, cotton and silk eased on the cash markets.

Leonard Weisman, accused in Federal court of being "an outstanding swindler" who in the last seven months had mulcted three prominent business men of $250,000, was taken to the Federal House of Detention yesterday when he was unable to post a bond of $25,000.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 8. -- Navy's last hard work in preparation for the Virginia contest on Thursday took place today. The third team was the only one which did any regular scrimmaging against the B squad, however.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8. -- The Federal Government today began the trial of A. L. Shushan, president of the Orleans Parish Levee Board and close friend of Senator Long, on charges of attempting to evade and defeat income tax payments.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- Prices on the Boerse fell slightly today in trading activity under that of yesterday. German investors and speculators have been somewhat frightened by the possible consequences of the Geneva decision that Italy is the aggressor in the African operations.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 8. -- The famous duplex residence at 21 Massasoit Street, long the home of the late President Calvin Coolidge, is being transformed into a tea room and gift shop.

LYNN, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Eight-yearold Carleton B. Nichols Jr., who has refused to salute the Stars and Stripes because of religious scruples, was expelled from school tonight by a unanimous vote of the Lynn school committee.

Three witnesses were questioned yesterday at District Attorney Dodge's office in the inquiry on suspected tampering with questions in advance of their use last April 22 by the board of examiners of the Education Department in a test of applicants for licenses as high school teachers of health education.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Plans for administration of the Motor Carrier Act under the Bureau of Motor Carriers headed by John L. Rogers of Tennessee as director, with a staff of 600 employes, were announced today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 8 (AP). -- The featured sixth race at one mile and seventy yards for fillies and mares 3 years old and upward was won easily by A. J. Sackett's Tabitha, a chestnut filly, today.
Myrna Loy will be co-starred with William Powell and Luise Rainer in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's production of "The Great Ziegfeld." She will appear as Billie Burke, the late producer's wife.

The Italo-Ethiopian conflict will be ended within a few weeks, with Ethiopia under an Italian mandate or some similar arrangement satisfactory to Premier Mussolini, according to Emil Ludwig, the biographer, who arrived here yesterday for a two-month lecture tour.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8. -- Eight world glider records, three of them by women, were hung up recently in the eleventh all-Soviet glider meet, according to official figures issued today.

After battling for sixteen months to bring about an involuntary reorganization of the $600,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act, counsel for the petitioning creditors buried the hatchet, for the time being at least, by joining attorneys for the company yesterday in a petition for adjournment of proceedings until Nov. 6.

About 100 judges and lawyers, including Protestant and Jewish members of the bench and bar, attended yesterday morning the eighth annual "Red Mass" sponsored by the Guild of Catholic Lawyers to mark the opening of the Fall term of court.

While awaiting the report of the WPA intelligence department on Communist activities among workers on relief, General Hugh S. Johnson, works progress administrator, struck the first blow yesterday at such activities by promulgating an order setting forth the manner in which the WPA in the future would deal with employes' complaints.

The movement of gold to the United States from Europe, which showed signs of abating as the week opened, was increased again yesterday. Engagements of the metal abroad for shipment here were reported as $18,185,000, compared with $11,300,000 on the preceding day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Receipts of hogs at leading Western packing points so far this week show a reduction of around 33 per cent compared with the same period last week. The local market, however, has fared better than those in the more Western territory with the result that sellers have been able to secure better prices, especially as there has been a keen demand from Eastern buyers.

The Daughters of the American Revolution were warned at the second session of the New York State conference in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday that the "misnamed" Child Labor Amendment is an attempt on the part of the Federal Government to have "Federal guardians displace the parents and rear America's children."

MOSCOW, Oct. 8. -- Found guilty of deliberately smashing three airplanes "to revenge the exile of his wealthy kulak father," Pilot Arefiev, member of the Young Communist organization, was executed today by a Soviet firing squad.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Important decisions both in the field of foreign policy and in domestic matters will be taken by the British Cabinet at its meeting tomorrow. Developments of internal politics -- discussed in another dispatch -- confront the Cabinet with the necessity of deciding whether it shall ask the electorate to renew the present government's mandate by calling a general election a few weeks hence.

Men in Nazi uniforms cheering Hitler and urging Americans to "awake" caused a near-riot just after noon yesterday among 3,000 garment workers in Thirty-seventh Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. Radio patrols, mounted policemen and an emergency squad charged the crowd, restoring order, and arrested three men.

The Whitney Museum of American Art is about to begin its fifth season and, by way of marking this anniversary milestone, will open next Tuesday an exhibition of works of art acquired since Nov. 18, 1931. The total number of items added to the permanent collection in this period is 330.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- The transit monopoly built up in Philadelphia by the late Thomas E. Mitten, through which taxicabs, street cars, buses and subway and elevated lines have been operated under a common ownership, appeared today to be almost at an end.

HONOLULU, Oct. 8. -- Hawaii's Statehood hearing entered its second day with discussions of the loyalty of Japanese-American citizens and opposition to so-called discriminatory legislation by the United States Congress as chief topics of the forum.
WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES ON THE NORTHERN ETHIOPIAN FRONT, Oct. 8. -- A rich region of northern Ethiopia, along a sixty-mile front, was completely under the domination of Italy's armed legions today.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Winston Churchill, who was First Lord of the Admiralty at the outbreak of the World War, told a mass meeting of his constituents at Chingford tonight that Britain stands by all her obligations under the covenant of the League of Nations.

The nation is headed for a period of prosperity and will be out of the depression within six months, Roger W. Babson, statistician and economist, told the annual New York Babson Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. But the period of prosperity, though marked by business and stock-market activity and re-employment, would be accompanied by a declining standard of living, Mr. Babson predicted.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- A final showdown on next Saturday on all plans submitted thus far to the Federal court for reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company was promised today by Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson. He told the various litigants that he would hold an exhaustive hearing on all proposals, modified plans and amended plans that had been filed.

LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 8 (AP). -Luckite, a sleek black gelding, entered by J. W. Y. Martin of Glyndon, Md., today captured the Rolling Rock Hunt Cup in a three-mile run over the brushlands of Loyolhanna Valley in the inaugural of a new national steeplechasing meet at the Rolling Rock Country Club's course.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today concluded hearings on the appointment of trustees for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railway and said he was hopeful he would be able to reach a decision on the appointment by 11 A.M. Saturday.

BANFF, Alberta, Oct. 8. -- Two young Doukhobor gunmen from near Arran, Sask., are dead, and a third is dying from bullet wounds after they had killed two Royal Canadian Mounted policemen and two municipal constables.

War correspondents in modern times are under increasingly rigid restrictions. They are not permitted to see all that they would like to witness, and their reports are necessarily subject to military censorship. This would be true today, of course, with regard to all the dispatches from Italian headquarters in Eritrea or in Adowa.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The United States has already acted for the protection of Americans in Addis Ababa through what is tantamount to a request to Italy to avoid striking American buildings in any bombing of the Ethiopian capital.

Confining the subject-matter to docks, bridges and waterways of New York, the Roerich Museum is currently showing (until Nov. 4) oils, water-colors and prints by more than sixty artists of the metropolitan area. All but a few of these are painters identified with the younger contemporary movement, and there is a distinct note of "modernism" which, perhaps even more than the subject-matter, binds the show together.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,719,600 barrels, compared with 2,763,200 in the preceding week, a drop of 43,600, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 22,100 and 16,700 barrels, respectively in Texas and Oklahoma were the principal changes.

Eight eligibles for Saturday's $100,000 Futurity were on view at Belmont Park yesterday in two divisions of the Nursery Handicap, and now that they are history, the outlook for the week-end special, and the mythical juvenile championship, appears more of a muddle than ever.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- Edward Warwick, Penn's fast-running left halfback, who scored the touchdown against Princeton, gave way today to Gene Sweeney of Shamokin, a sophomore, as the Red and Blue prepared for Yale's first visit to Philadelphia since 1889.

The Columbia Spectator, in a front-page editorial yesterday entitled "Our Trustees Hate Censorship," criticized the action of the university board, which voted Monday to discontinue subsidies to the undergraduate publications after June 30, 1938.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- While passive and almost mute neutrality continues to distinguish the German official attitude toward the ItaloEthiopian armed conflict, the press is most emphatic in praise of President Roosevelt's neutrality proclamations, which it hails as an impressive exhibition of "moral politics" and also as plain talk uttered just at the right moment.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were generally firm today in quieter trading. Armament stocks were mostly easier owing to profit-taking. Talk of a general election before 1936 also was a cause of dullness in British funds as well as in other parts of the market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- A cotton crop this year of 11,464,000 bales was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture on the basis of Oct. 1 conditions averaging 64 per cent of normal. The forecast was 25,000 bales under the estimate of Sept. 1 and 1,828,000 more than the 1934 crop, but 3,202,000 less than the 1928-32 average.

Because of information that efforts may be made in Washington to cut the allotments for WPA projects in this city, General Hugh S. Johnson warned in a press interview yesterday that any substantial reduction of these funds would produce a "catastrophe."
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 8. -- Officials here emphasize that Ethiopian tactics at present consist of retreating gradually and harassing the invader -- tactics at which the Ethiopians are past masters.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 8. -Driven by a 600-horsepower Diesel electric engine, operating on common fuel oil, the Mark Twain, a four-car stainless-steel train built for the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, completed here this afternoon the first leg of its trip to the Midwest.

John Hay Whitney, president of the Museum of Modern Art Film Library, announced yesterday the library's acquisition of two groups of motion picture films from Harold Lloyd and Warner Brothers Pictures. The Lloyd films cover the work of the comedian from his earliest days into his later dialogue pictures.

Shippers of the metropolitan area realized savings in excess of $1,000,000 in the three years during which Manhattan's first inland freight terminal has been in operation, it was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. During this period almost 360,000,000 pounds of package freight passed through the station.

L. A. G. STRONG'S "The Seven Arms" (Knopf, $2.50) makes an appeal to the past of a sort that is fast becoming the stock in trade of scores of our lesser writers. But instead of picking the Maine seaboard, or the North Carolina mountain coves, or the Aran Islands, Mr. Strong has chosen a self-contained peninsula on the Atlantic coast of Scotland.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The bull movement in wheat which carried all deliveries in the world's leading markets to a new high level for the season late last week, appeared today to have run its course, and steady selling credited to small and large operators who were aggressive buyers recently carried prices on the Board of Trade off 1 5/8 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish, with the December leading.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The members of the Republican Assembly caravan, headed by Minority Leader Irving M. Ives, made little headway today in their campaign to recapture the Assembly but found that their services were in great demand tonight.

Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine, it was learned yesterday, are working on a plan to modify the use of loudspeakers on trucks in the coming political campaign, it was learned yesterday. Neither would indicate what steps were contemplated in this phase of the drive against noise, but it was said at City Hall that a definite plan was being devised.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8. -Unsatisfactory form in the centre of the Yale line today led Coach Ducky Pond and Line Coach Denny Myers to shift the veteran Tommy Wilson to left guard, replacing Web Davis.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 9. -The Duchess of Kent gave birth to a son at her London home, 3 Belgrave Square, early today. The son ranks seventh in succession to the throne. The Duchess's doctors, Dr. W. Gilliat and Dr. A. E. Gow, were summoned by the Duchess late last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Although President Roosevelt has authorized WPA projects which would cost $1,900,000,000 to complete and probably will approve projects estimated to cost $3,000,000,000, the amount which will actually be spent for the WPA program has been limited for the time being to $1,140,000,000, it was stated officially today.

ATHENS, Wednesday, Oct. 9. -Immediate restoration of the monarchy by Parliament is acceptable to former King George, according to Royalist leaders who received his decision through Jean Pipinellis, leading Greek diplomat, just returned from a secret mission to London.

Two Federal grand juries, in Brooklyn and Manhattan, voted indictments yesterday against four men, one an attorney formerly employed by the Department of Labor, accusing them of immigration and naturalization frauds.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The Union County (N.J.) October grand jury was discharged here today by Supreme Court Justice Clarence E. Case on the ground that Sheriff John J. Fitzpatrick, who drew the jury, was no longer a disinterested party, because he and several of his deputies have had criminal charges brought against them as the result of the wounding of John Crempa of Scotch Plains, N.J., and the killing of his wife.
Participants Put in Technical State of War Against Nation Found Violator.

The "Marquis" Edmond Raoul de Castellot Rousselot, 47 years old, son of a French peasant family, who, in the twenty-three years of his stay in this country, posed as an intimate of royalty with much influence in foreign governmental affairs, was sent to Sing Sing yesterday for two and one-half years.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 8. -- Emperor Haile Selassie, heartened by the prospect of League of Nations' sanctions against Italy, tonight urged all Ethiopians to evacuate the Italian colony of Eritrea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The remarks of Secretary of State Hull on our foreign policy, made before the executive committee of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, were as follows:

Ted Allen, the contribution of Alhambra, Calif., to the roster of world champions in sport, demonstrated the remarkable proficiency which has enabled him to keep the world's horseshoe-pitching crown since 1933 with an exhibition yesterday afternoon of plain and fancy tossing in the Crystal Health Club in the basement of the Woolworth Building.

GENEVA, Oct. 8. -- Concrete planning of non-military sanctions against the Italian Government was started here today in a long meeting of economic, financial and diplomatic experts of the British and French Governments.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- The Times of London editorially invokes the small nations that are members of the League of Nations to stand firm behind the covenant in the forthcoming test when the Assembly decides on sanctions against Italy.

Having temporarily exhausted the speculative possibilities of war talk, financial markets gave evidence yesterday of selling "ex war scare." Stocks, bonds and commodities declined on realizing sales in generally dull trading. The turnover for the day on the New York Stock Exchange was 1,182,110 shares, while THE NEW YORK TIMES combined index for fifty stocks declined .85 point.

The commodities distribution division of the Emergency Relief Bureau reported yesterday to Miss Charlotte Carr, director of the bureau, that more than 220,000 relief families in this city and thousands of other needy individuals received more than 53,504,000 pounds of Federal surplus foods, valued at $5,572,189.93 at retail prices, from Jan. 1 to Aug. 31, 1935.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Oct. 8. -- Guarded by a company of Ethiopian infantry men, the last twentyeight Italians in Ethiopia, except for diplomatic officials, arrived today at the frontier station of Duanle.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 8. -- Problems attending the use of vaccines designed to prevent infantile paralysis occupied delegates at the convention of the American Public Health Association here today, with Dr. Thomas M. Rivers of the Rockefeller Institute, New York, expressing doubt that a vaccine made by Dr. John A. Kolmer of Philadelphia was safe.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Ambassador Robert W. Bingham of the United States called on Sir Samuel Hoare at the Foreign Office today for conversations on the Roosevelt arms embargo proclamation and statements to the effect that American citizens traveling on ships of the belligerent powers would do so at their own risk.

A second-hand bottle dealer in Brooklyn became yesterday the first person in the country to be convicted of violating a Federal regulation by possessing empty liquor bottles of the type which should be destroyed when emptied.

Debutantes of this season acted as manikins in the fashion show which was a feature of the entertainment at the luncheon in behalf of the Social Service Auxiliary of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary held yesterday in the new Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Supreme Court Justice Steinbrink in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that Gerald Smith, 23 years old, must wait until he is 35 before he may have the bulk of the $2,225,000 estate which he inherited from his father, Ormond G. Smith, publisher, and his mother, Mrs. Grace Smith.

John Volpe misrepresents me in his letter to you. He writes of my approval of the idea of abolishing our slum tenements by government subsidy to private enterprise. I have never advocated anything of the kind.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 8 (AP). -- Three government witnesses scored today for Thomas H. Robinson Sr., Nashville engineer who is on trial in Federal court here with his daughterin-law, Mrs. Frances Robinson, for the $50,000-ransom kidnapping of Mrs. Alice Speed Stoll, Louisville society matron.

DETROIT, Oct. 8. -- Following a night of celebration unparalleled in connection with any previous baseball event, the citizens of Detroit, whose Tigers now reign as new world champions, strove hard today to return to their normal conduct of life.

NORFOLK, Conn., Oct. 8. -- Mrs. Louis Graham Smith of New York and Norfolk will inherit the bulk of the estate of her father, Dr. Michael I. Pupin, according to a decision made known today in the Probate Court by Acting Judge J. Sedgwick Tracy of Canaan.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Following in the footsteps of Elisabeth Bergner and Lucie Mannheim, Grete Mosheim, another German-Jewish actress exiled from Germany, made a brilliant debut at the St. James Theatre tonight in Alice Campbell's drama of dual personality, "Two Share a Dwelling."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Gains made by Republicans in yesterday's voting in 149 Connecticut towns indicate a decided drift away from New Deal policies, Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee declared today as telegrams were received at headquarters stating that the "increased local taxes caused by the communities matching Federal appropriations" was the chief issue in the elections.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- George Lansbury, adhering to his principles of "Christian pacifism," today resigned the parliamentary leadership of the British Labor party because it is committed to sanctions against Italy. Sanctions, in his opinion, merely mean an approach to another war.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 8. -- A new track record for pacing was set at the Danbury Fair today when Betty Signal, owned by J. W. Porteous of Middletown, Conn., stepped the mile in 2:05 1/2, clipping a quarter second from the mark established five years ago when Mimzy, owned in Hartford, Conn., went over the half-mile track in 2:05 3/4.

After a tour novel in the history of American sport, members of the first United States women's lacrosse team to invade England and Ireland returned yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8. -- Expecting stiff opposition from Williams Saturday, Coach Fritz Crisler sent the Princeton football squad through an unusually hard drill on University Field today. A scrimmage between a Black and White eleven featured the work.

The Queens political tangle was further complicated last night when John T. O'Connell, Democratic State Committeeman in the Fourth Assembly District and former Alderman, filed petitions to run independently for Representative in the Second Congressional District.

A genuine harvest moon shone mistily over the Mall in Central Park last night, where 4,500 persons joined with the Park Department, the Works Progress Administration and several folk-dancing societies in one of the oldest ceremonies known to man -- a harvest festival.

Officials of Weehawken Township, N.J., have arranged for a private sale of a new issue of $775,000 general refunding bonds to H. L. Schwamm Co. The bank took $195,000 that will mature from 1937 to 1941 as 3 1/4s and $580,000 due on Oct. 1, 1942 to 1953, as 4s.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Oct. 8. -- The advance of three Italian columns toward their expected and eventual convergence on the central plateau in Ethiopia has convinced European officials here, including the French, that the Frenchowned railway connecting Addis Ababa with the sea will be cut and the Ethiopian capital isolated.

The discharge of one WPA official for irregularity and the suspension of five employes was announced yesterday by General Hugh S. Johnson, local Works Progress Administrator, as part of a program "to clean things up" before he quits his post next week.

Coach Lou Little ordered the Columbia football squad out on Baker Field yesterday for a three-hour session in preparation for the Lions' encounter with Rutgers on Saturday. For the second day in succession offensive formations occupied most of the time, with backs and running guards striving for perfection in blocking assignments.
The Rockefeller gift to the people of the City of New York of the Fort Tryon Park suggests several matters of historic interest.

The New York Stock Exchange committee on stock list announced yesterday that dealings would be suspended today in American-La France and Foamite Corporation 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock because the number of shares undeposited under the company's plan of reorganization is small.

Orders placed here by Italian or Ethiopian buyers will be accepted by exporters in spite of the Presidential neutrality proclamation, export executives declared when questioned yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SALEM, N.J., Oct. 8. -- Judge Frank T. Neutze halted abruptly today the Dolbow murder trial and sent the wife of one of the jurors to jail. As a result Mrs. Marguerite Fox Dolbow and her childhood sweetheart, Norman Driscoll, will not go on trial again until Jan. 6 for the murder of the woman's husband, Harry Dolbow, 39 years old, a farmer who was beaten to death last Aug. 2.

All complaints indicating retailers are seeking volume discounts or secret rebates on apparel purchases will be acted upon by the Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives on behalf of the individual organizations, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the council at the offices of the National Dress Manufacturers Association.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- A sharp discussion of France's financial situation developed today when the Chamber of Deputies Finance Committee discussed 1936 budget plans. Marcel Regnier, Minister of Finance, had to face the committee alone, since Premier Laval, who had been slated to appear with him, was detained at Geneva.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 8. -Three men captured the next to last polo tournament of the season at the Meadow Brook Club today when Old Westbury, with a goal scored after the bell had rung to end the final period, defeated the Hurricanes, 11 to 10, in the final event of the sixteen-goal division of the Autumn plates.

Real estate interests are actively engaged in a campaign in support of an amendment to the State Constitution imposing a tax limit of 2 per cent on real estate for all purposes. A concurrent resolution to that effect was introduced in the Legislature last year, with the support of the New York State Economic Council, but it did not get very far.

Trading in most sections of the bond market yesterday was routine, with only minor price fluctuations recorded despite a moderate increase in volume. Trading in United States Government loans was somewhat heavier, and that group continued to move irregularly higher.

While Alfred E. Smith was sounding in Cleveland his solemn warning against communism and fascism, and the American Legion was doing the same thing at St. Louis, a condition of affairs was discovered by patriotic women in this section of Ohio which indicates that subversive doctrines are spreading rapidly among our local farmers.

Jesse Isidor Straus, Ambassador to France, and Mrs. Straus and John F. Montgomery, Minister to Hungary, are among those sailing today for the Channel ports on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. Other passengers include:

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 8. -- Emperor Haile Selassie received a telegram today saying that the Italian commercial agent at Magalo had arrived at Ginir, south of the Chercher Range in Bale Province. The journey from Ginir to the railway is expected to take three or four days, and Count Luigi Vinci-Gigliucci, the Italian Minister, is sending a courier down the line in today's train to meet the attache.

I have noticed of late that huge crowds gather to watch and listen to the antics and songs of street urchins. The crowds are highly amused and toss coins for the pleasure they have received. I have noted, too, a street musician who played Schubert's "Serenade" on his violin is in the recesses of a darkened building entrance.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 8. -- A football game of the "canvas jacketstocking cap" era, before forward and lateral passes were thought of, will be played at the Naval Academy Thursday between the halves of the regular Navy-Virginia game.

The major producers of copper raised the price of the metal 1/4 cent a pound in the domestic market yesterday morning, thus bringing it to 9 1/4 cents. This is the highest price since April, 1931. The advance was the third one made since the price was cut to 8 cents on June 28 last following the dropping of the NRA Copper Code.

The Tri-Continental Corporation and affiliated investment trusts -- Selected Industries, Inc., Capital Administration Company, Ltd., and Broad Street Investing Company, Inc. -- reported yesterday gains in their net assets for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, and for the first nine months.

The Appellate Division heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on the city's appeal from the decision of Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore barring from the November ballot a referendum on Mayor La Guardia's proposal for a municipal power plant.

Joseph Schildkraut has long been looking for a co-producer of "Tomorrow Is a Holiday," and apparently he has found one. It will be John Golden, who yesterday signed a contract by which he would be associated with the actor in this production.

Hope was expressed that a "New York festival" would be held under the direction of Max Reinhardt in connection with the forthcoming world's fair to be held in this city, at a dinner last night at which Mayor La Guardia and Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch extended their official welcome to the producer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Plans for pushing the American Legion's Bonus Payment Bill through Congress ahead of the Patman bonusinflation measure were tentatively laid at an informal meeting of the newly elected national commander, Ray Murphy, with Legion legislative representatives here today.
Miss Marion H. Duval, 32 years old, of 76 East Fifty-sixth Street, was killed by a hit-and-run automobile at 4:15 A.M. yesterday as she was crossing Fifth Avenue just north of Fifty-sixth Street.

The Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, largest of the thirty-four district groups of the national organization, refused to go on record last night in favor of a boycott of the 1936 Olympic Games by the A.A.U. The national action is to come up at the annual convention in December.

Forward passing was stressed by Coach Jim Crowley as the Fordham football squad quickened its pace in the drill yesterday for the invasion of Purdue at the Polo Grounds Saturday. All phases of the Rams' aerial attack were polished in a two-hour workout at Fordham Field.
The first day of registration brought 186,565 persons to the booths in New York City yesterday, a compilation of the figures showed early this morning.

Strange doings, you may say, when you have to think the Elephant into a Camel as the Republican Assembly Caravan makes its way over our fair States. Why Caravan ? A caravan is a body of traders. Republican Legislatures never trade. The name in its present use may be thought to represent a care-free rollicking band of men carrying among other treasures the boom, boom, boom of GEORGE HARVEY of Queens for Governor.

Due to the religious holiday the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday fell under the figures for the preceding week. The total was also well below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

When the deadline for filing independent petitions for nominations in the Fall elections was reached at last midnight the City Fusion party had named complete tickets in both Kings and Queens Counties. In all, 134 individual candidates were named by independent petitions filed with the Board of Elections during the eight-day period for such designations.

National leaders of the pro-Nazi Friends of the New Germany declared last night a virtual state of war on the United German Societies, the Steuben Society and other German-American groups hostile to the Friends because of the conduct of the German Day exercises at Madison Square Garden on Sunday and the exclusion of the Friends from the celebration.

BUFFALO, Oct. 8. -- "Start with the high chair and you won't need the electric chair," said Mrs. Francis H. Blake, president of the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers, tonight in announcing that the organization would give strong support to the crime prevention work which may emerge from the recent conference held in Albany.

The Conversion Office for German Foreign Debts is offering holders of certain matured serial bonds of German obligors the option of exchange for a like principal amount of bonds of unmatured series, or payment in "blocked" reichsmark, it was announced here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Liquor distillers were urged in a letter today from James M. Doran, Administrator of Distilled Spirits, Inc., to "refrain from advertising on Sunday.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- There is more disquiet than satisfaction in Paris today over yesterday's decision at Geneva in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, and every effort will be made by France to restrict the sanctions applied against the aggressor.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Three years ago Lloyd Jordan arrived at Amherst College to find interest in football apathetic among an undergraduate body that went in for the classics and prized a Phi Beta Kappa key far above a varsity letter.

Whoopee and O.K. and other current American colloquialisms have a deep, dark past, which patient research is disclosing, Sir William A. Craigie, joint editor of the Oxford English Dictionary and Professor of English at Chicago University, said yesterday when he arrived on the Cunard liner Laconia.
GENEVA, Oct. 8 (AP). -- The League of Nations was informed today that the Ethiopian Government had asked the Italian Minister to Addis Ababa and his entire staff to leave Ethiopia immediately.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, told 500 members of the freshman class at their weekly orientation lecture yesterday that the greatest enemy of progress today was the self-centred individual who scorned the "common denominator" through which men understand their fellows.

Considerable grumbling at the President's neutrality proclamations has been heard. Some critics call them too sweeping. It is thought a little absurd that the President should warn Americans against sailing on ships of either belligerent, when only one belligerent has ships at sea.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8. -- A demonstration of Holy Cross offensive plays by the second freshman team and a rugged stationary scrimmage against the junior varsity comprised Harvard's workout today as preparation for the coming of the Crusaders continued.

The report of the Saratoga Association on attendance, gross receipts, purse distribution and taxes paid shows increases all along the line, according to an announcement made yesterday at Belmont Park by Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP). -- Former President Hoover regards the farm problem as a prime potential issue of the 1936 campaign, but will offer no suggestions for a Republican plank until the fate of the AAA has been settled, members of his traveling party said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. $.--A reproduction of the ."perfect banquet"that 'as tendered to AdmiralGeorge Dewey in 1906 by the NewYork Lotus Club was served tomembers of the National Restaurant Association tonight at $25 aplate.

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- A proposed new milk pact in the New York-New Jersey market was revealed today by Peter G. Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, representing the Seven States Governors' Committee, of which he is the head.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 8. -- Playing with the same spirit of adventure that marked the first two games of their match for the chess championship of the world, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, champion, and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the challenger, started another lively session when they engaged in the third contest at the Hotel Carlton tonight.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 8. -- Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau of Suffolk County has reserved decision on the application of Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers of Manhattan and Southampton for an order directing the temporary administrators of the estate of her husband. Colonel Henry H. Rogers, to pay her $6,000 a month from the estate for her support.

Dr. John McCabe, a physician who specialized in internal medicine, died of a cerebral hemorrhage at Midtown Hospital on Monday after a two months' illness. He was executive physician of that hospital, which he had done much to build up.

In your editorial on Mussolini's latest war speech and its aftermath you call attention to the fact that he is "for the old order." Even Mussolini was not ever thus, as witness the following editorial written by him in the Italian labor daily, Avanti, for Jan. 1, 1912:

Had General LEONARD WOOD lived out his seeming "expectancy," he would have been 75 years old today. So strong was he that he could even match the Basques in the game of jai alai. And with his strength there was an "infinite charm" that made him, as one saw him in the days of Santiago and later in Havana, a man whom one would choose as an ideal American.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 8. -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled today that the Secretary of Labor, under the Act of Congress of March 3, 1931, had the power to determine the prevailing wage in the event of disputes on Federal jobs, but could not determine when the decision should be made effective.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Retail prices of food rose one-tenth of 1 per cent in the two weeks ended on Sept. 24, Commissioner Lubin of the United States Department of Labor announced today.

The General Motors Corporation's monthly figures of sales, issued yesterday, showed a decline for September, reflecting the effect of the introduction of new models two months earlier than usual. Most of the corporation's models for 1936 will be exhibited at the annual show to be held at the beginning of next month, whereas in former years the show has been held in January.

Courage born of desperation conquered an attack of vertigo for Lawrence Jurgenson, 8 years old, while other boys and passing motorists held their breath at 5:20 P.M. yesterday at Harlem River Speedway opposite 176th Street.

A special committee of five Senators, authorized to hold hearings while Congress stands adjourned, is to begin this week an investigation of the Treasury's administration of the Silver Purchase Act of 1934. It is also authorized to inquire into "the economic and commercial effect" of this legislation, both in the United States and elsewhere, and to report back to the Senate any recommendations it may choose to make.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today launched its administration of the Public Utility Act of 1935 by laying down the requirements which holding companies and subsidiaries must meet if they file preliminary regulations or if they seek exemption from registration.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 8. -- Miss Alice Rutherfurd of Baltusrol won low gross with 88, and Miss Cecelia Einstein of Jackson Heights took low net with 101 -- 22 -79 in a one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Upper Montclair Country Club today.

In a dispatch from London, Frederick T. Birchall stated two days ago that the British Government has decided to send troops to occupy the Lake Tana region should the present Italian advance in Ethiopia progress any further. No denial of this extraordinary piece of news has been published since.

A reorganization plan for General Theatres Equipment, Inc., was filed yesterday in the Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del., by the committee representing holders of ten-year 6 per cent convertible debentures due in 1940, which is constituted a reorganization committee under the plan.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 8. -- Announcing to the convention of the American Federation of Labor that the principal indices of production, employment and wages were rising. Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, declared today that latest reports of her department left no doubt that the durable goods industries "have actually made the turn."

The first jail commitment in the racket investigation by the special New York County grand jury took place yesterday afternoon when Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook imposed a sentence of fifteen days in the Tombs on a witness who had failed to produce subpoenaed books.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 8. -- Mrs. Mary Creighton, 36 years old, who was acquitted of two arsenic murders in Newark, N.J., twelve years ago, admitted tonight, according to District Attorney Martin W. Littleton, that she alone had poisoned Mrs. Ada Applegate.

The New York University varsity football squad commenced preparations yesterday at Ohio Field for its second engagement of the season next Saturday when it faces Carnegie Tech at the Yankee Stadium. Assistant Coach Leo Collins scouted the Skibos and reported the Violet will have to be at its best to defeat the Tartans.

Looking at the pictures of the United States Supreme Court's new $10,000,000 home one must not yield, to temptation and read into it any kind of disturbing significance. It would be so easy, for instance, to say that this magnificent new court house is a sufficient answer to hostile murmurs being raised against the august tribunal in certain quarters.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Mrs. Edwin T. Rice had forty guests at a tea reception this afternoon at her cottage in Stockbridge. Mrs. Henry Hudson Kitson, wife of the sculptor, and Miss Grace Nettleton poured. Miss Helen Rice assisted.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 9. -- The Naval Academy tomorrow will oppose the football team of the University of Virginia, one of its oldest opponents in the sport, in a game which will be a part of the celebration of the academy's ninetieth anniversary.

PARIS, Oct. 9. -- In Paris, Marseilles and throughout France services and commemorative ceremonies were held today in honor of King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Foreign Minister Barthou of France, who was assassinated with him in Marseilles a year ago.
Arguments for equalization of salaries in the city service featured the first of four public hearings on the 1936 budget held yesterday by the Board of Estimate at City Hall.

Many of your readers undoubtedly perused with bewilderment some of the contents of Dr. Alexis Carrel's new book, "Man, the Unknown," as presented in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review recently. Dr. Carrel claims that prayer can cure cancer and other ailments in a period of time varying from a few minutes to two hours.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Prices were irregular on the London Stock Exchange today, profit-taking having effect and business slackening as developments in Geneva were awaited. A sharp rally took place in British funds, however, under the lead of the war loan.

RICHMOND, Va., Thursday, Oct. 10. -- The group of Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation stockholders headed by George S. Kemp, Richmond broker, won a long battle of proxies at 1:15 o'clock this morning and named their slate of directors for the $30,000,000 company.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 9. -- Authorities seemed convinced today that Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton's revised confession concerning the fatal poisoning of Mrs. Ada Applegate, her friend and neighbor, has cleared up all the mystery in the case.

Mrs. Alicia Maddox Glendening Llewellyn, adopted daughter of the late Alfred I. du Pont, told Official Referee Edward J. Gavegan in Supreme Court yesterday that she had been "harassed" by her first husband for four years after their separation and divorce, and later had sent letters to her son in care of the governess so her first husband could not prevent their delivery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Details of the reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Colombia, announced today at the State Department, revealed that the South American republic had agreed to reduce duties on more than 50 per cent of this country's exports to her in exchange for little more than a promise that the United States would keep Colombia's coffee, bananas and minor commodities on the free list, where they always have been.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Declaring an intention to "keep my tents at the front where they have always been," Waizeru Shamerga Gaby, who inherited 10,000 servants, vast fields and great herds of mules and ponies from her father, prepared to leave Addis Ababa Thursday to head her own army of 15,000 men.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who directs also the operation of WPA park projects, representing the largest single part of the entire WPA program, made public a notice to all park project superintendents, foremen and employes yesterday informing them that all work now under way must be completed by July 1, 1936.

Benjamin B. Tilt, who as early as 1912 had found Manhattan's noisiness so unbearable that he brought suit in the Supreme Court against a railroad doing construction work at night near his residence, committed suicide early yesterday, according to a police report.

The directors of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad studied the company's financial requirements at a meeting here yesterday, and, it was reported, considered borrowing again from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Howard S. Palmer, president of the New Haven, declined to comment on this report.

The text of the unanimcus opinion of the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals on the appeal of Bruno Richard Hauptmann from his conviction of the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., written by Justice Charles W. Parker, follows:
BERLIN. Oct. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmark:
The text of the address of James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, before the American Management Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Apparently because preliminary reports showed only a small amount of additional employment, the WPA today canceled an announcement, scheduled for tomorrow, of employment figures.

Neither profit-taking nor hedge selling caused much pressure yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, and prices steadied to end unchanged to 4 points higher. At one time, active demand from trade quarters brought a recovery of 15 points, but above 11 cents a pound for near months growers continued to offer cotton and much of the early gain disappeared before the close.

GENEVA, Oct. 9. -- The League of Nations Assembly opened this afternoon its hearing of the case of the Council against the Italian Government as an aggressor subject to sanctions with only two of the fifty-nine League members favoring the defense.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 9. -- Taking the third game of the series for the chess championship of the world at the Hotel Carlton today, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris now has a lead of two games to one over Dr. Max Euwe of this city, the challenger.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- A mild flurry was created in diplomatic circles here today by what at first seemed to be an announcement by Secretary Swanson of the Navy Department that an international naval conference was to be held soon and that Admiral Standley, Chief of Naval Operations, would represent this government.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Professional operations dominated the wheat market on the Board of Trade today, with prices holding within a range of around a cent. Closing of spreads between the December and the May deliveries credited to a local operator stood out in an otherwise dull day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- The mother of Senator Bronson M. Cutting, Democrat, New Mexico, has informed Vice President Garner that she would "not be justified" in accepting the $10,000 appropriation ordinarily made by the Senate to next of kin of dead Senators.

BOSTON, Oct. 9. -- Mrs. A. A. Baroni's Ann O'Ruley, chestnut daughter of Man of War, drove to a neck victory over Whopper in the mile and sixteenth of the Yankee Stakes, :5,000 added feature, before 15,000 at Suffolk Downs today.
"The Gay Deception," starring Francis Lederer and Frances Dee, opens today at the Radio City Music Hall.

The President's warning that he desires it "to be understood that any of our people who voluntarily engage in transactions of any character with either of the belligerents do so at their own risk" recalls vividly the incident of the British passenger steamer Falaba.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Responsibility for curbing lawless acts of striking dairy farmers, even to the extent of declaring martial law, was put np to State law enforcement agencies in a ruling made today by Judge John P. Barnes in Federal Court.
Democratic leaders laid out plans yesterday or an intensive campaign in twenty-five up-State counties in their drive to retain control of the Assembly.

On Oct. 4 you published a letter signed by Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, and others, in which he undertakes to correct a statement made by me carried in your issue of Sept. 17, complaining that I "implied" that their organization was communistic.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

The University of Pennsylvania Club of New York City, for the past thirteen years in East Fiftieth Street, will move to the Murray Hill section, where it has leased a building adjoining the Morgan Library and abutting the Union League Club in the rear.

Under the impetus of the AmericanRussian trade agreement, Soviet buying in the United States this year will attain a $50,000,000 level, exporters predicted yesterday following the announcement by the Amtorg Trading Corporation that purchases up to the end of last month had reached $33,000,000.

United States Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange became moderately reactionary yesterday on a slightly reduced turnover. With the exception of the Treasury 3 3/8s due from 1940 to 1943, which closed 3-32 point higher, losses ranging from 1-32 to 9-32 point ruled throughout the Federal list at the close.

Ed Danowskl, former Fordham back field ace, will make his dbut as a quarterback when the New York Giants, National Football League champions, meet the Brooklyn Dodgers on Sunday in their first appearance of the season at the Polo Grounds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Loans and discounts of all banks in Chicago are at the lowest point since the present system of reporting was inaugurated fifteen years ago, it was shown by quarterly statements of condition made public today. All State banks issued reports of their position in response to the quarterly call made by the State auditor, Edward J. Barrett.

Heads of operating companies of the Standard Gas and Electric System were elected yesterday to the board of directors of the Byllesby Engineering and Management Corporation, which supplies management, engineering and other services to the operating companies.

Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted kidnapper and murderer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., learned yesterday in the death house of Trenton prison that his main hope for life had gone glimmering. Even his iron nerve was shaken.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The British Parliament, which adjourned in the middle of the Summer until Oct. 29, will be summoned to reassemble a week earlier than that because of the war emergency and this country's prospective participation in League of Nations sanctions against Italy.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 9. -Mrs. Giraud Van Nest Foster was a luncheon hostess today at Bellefontaine, Lenox, to Miss Ellen T. Bullard, who is at the Lenox Club; Mrs. Nina L. Duryea, Mrs. R. J. Flick, Mrs. William A. Herron, Mrs. Robert S. Hibbard, Mrs. Ramsey Hoguet, Mrs. Chauncey C. Loomis, Mrs. Charles Astor Bristed, Mrs. Lowell M. Clucas, Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease, Mrs. Owen Johnson and Mrs. George Higginson.

A slight increase is expected in retail butter prices because of government purchases, it was said yesterday by the Food Guide issued by the Department of Public Markets. Prices again advanced on fresh and refrigerated poultry.

Charging that the proposed municipal electric plant would cost at least $10,000,000 more than the maximum estimates of city engineers, Frank W. Smith, president of the Consolidated Gas Company and the New York Edison Company, said yesterday that it would result in an annual deficit of from $3,000,000 to $3,500,000 if operated at the rates proposed by Mayor La Guardia.

PARIS, Oct. 9. -- Dispatches to the Paris-Soir from the Eritrean front stated today that fighting was gen eral throughout the Northern Ethiopian sector, with 300,000 troops engaged in a quadrangle formed by Adi Ugri and Adi Caieh, in Eritrea, and Adigrat and Aksum, in Ethiopia.

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- Professor Karl has been arrested at a theological has been arrested at the theological conference at Barmen in the Rhineland and expelled from Germany. He was accompanied by a German police officer to the Swiss border at Basle after his arrest and released at noon today.

With fiery oral attacks on the Washington administration for its sponsorship of the Public Utility Act of 1935 and on Congress for passing the measure, stockholders of the Electric Bond and Share Company at their annual meeting yesterday approved the action of the management in lobbying against the regulatory act and urged their officers and directors to continue the fight against what was called this "destructive legislation."

ATHENS, Oct. 9. -- Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris faced tonight a royalist Parliament which is expected at tomorrow's session to vote for the return of former King George or create a regency and wipe out the last vestiges of the republic.

The city of Buffalo, N.Y., will enter the market on Oct. 22 with a new issue of $4,000,000 refunding bonds, officers of the city announced yesterday. The bonds will be dated Nov. 15, 1935, and will mature serially from Nov. 15, 1936 to 1955.

HONOLULU, Oct. 9. -- Statehood for Hawaii is not a partisan issue here, it was clearly shown today as Democratic leaders of the islands, testifying before the Congressional Committee holding forums in Iolani Palace, restated arguments offered by Republican Witnesses in the first two days of hearings this week.

Lacking a new speculative impulse, the financial markets were dull yesterday. Stocks closed slightly higher, while bonds were irregularly lower. Wheat declined a fraction of a cent and cotton advanced a trifle. Transactions in the New York Stock Exchange aggregated 882,910 shares, compared with 1,182,110 shares on the previous day.

ZAGREB, Oct. 9. -- In the presence of 100,000 people a memorial tablet to King Alexander was unveiled today at the main railway station on the spot where his body lay in state last year. A meeting to celebrate the memory of the late King took place later on Alexander Square.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. (AP). -- The two Stoll kidnapping defendants failed to obtain a directed verdict of acquittal late today after the government had completed its evidence.

The rate of production of steel ingots has declined this week a half point to 52 per cent of the industry's plant capacity despite a moderate improvement in the automotive demand for steel, according to The Iron Age.
Money market was featureless. New business was at a minimum, and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

Word that a pledge of full cooperation with the Mexican Government in the solution of the nation's social problems had been given in a collective pastoral letter, signed by the entire Catholic hierarchy of Mexico, was received here yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 9. -- A decline in the size of families is largely responsible for a decline of 57 per cent in the last ten years in deaths from measles and for a reduction of 53 per cent in whooping cough deaths, the convention of the American Public Health Association was told today by Dr. Haven Emerson, Professor of Public Health Practice at Columbia University.

IN two spicy, irreverent, not unbearably consistent books called "The New Dealers" and "American Messiahs," the "Unofficial Observer," who is supposedly John ("Jay Franklin") Carter, has blown the gaff and tipped his mitt on the personalities behind the New Deal and behind such native Amurrican radical movements as the National Union for Social Justice and the Share-Our-Wealth plan.

A committee representing twentyfour nations was nominated yesterday at Geneva to consider the grave question of sanctions against Italy. In addition to the thirteen nations which are members of the League Council, it includes eleven others -- among them, Austria, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, Switzerland and Greece.

The National Exhibition Company, owner of the Polo Grounds and the New York Giants, which for many years has opposed the broadcasting of its baseball games, filed an injunction suit yesterday to restrain alleged "bootleg" broadcasts of baseball games and other sporting events from the Polo Grounds.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9. -Five changes were made in the Yale eleven today because of the continued ineffectiveness of the defense and the nearness of the struggle with Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. Line unsteadiness was reflected in the dropping of Tiger Taylor from left tackle and Tommy Wilson and Jack Castle, who yesterday received tryouts at guard.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Great Britain's new-born "sixth gentleman of the land" was still nameless tonight, but the child whose arrival at 2:05 A. M. thrilled the nation will in all likelihood be known as "Prince of Kent."

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 9. -- The Ogaden roads lack soldiery now where, last week, every red rut through this green paradise bristled with arms. It is necessary to use a sharp eye to find troops now. They lurk like quail, invisible beneath the underbrush.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 9. -The Michigan formula for winning football, as carried out by Fielding H. (Hurry Up) Yost, stresses the development of a centre, a kicker and a passer, and the first two are of primary consideration.

The flow of gold from Europe to the United States, carried here by the flight of capital before the threat of war, continued to rise yesterday when $21,765,000 was engaged in London and Paris for shipment here, compared with $18,185,000 on Tuesday and $11,300,000 on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Seeking to speed construction on WPA projects, eleven engineers loaned to the Works Progress Administration by the army are in the field making a nation-wide study of engineering difficulties and procedure on construction.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 9 (AP). -The prospect of League of Nations sanctions against Italy led today to definite suspension of negotiations to sell that nation 22,000 tons of Brazilian meat for her troops in East Africa.

BUFFALO, Oct. 9 (AP). -- The statement that many nations are making homes "recruiting stations for the State" was made by Rabbi Joseph L. Fink of Buffalo at the State Congress of Parents and Teachers here tonight.

The urgent need for funds to continue support of the city's voluntary hospitals was called to public attention yesterday at luncheon meetings in Manhattan and Brooklyn under the auspices of the United Hospital Campaign Committee of 14 Wall Street.

Out of the control of the driver, an automobile mounted the curb at the southwest corner of Thirty-first Street and Second Avenue soon after 5 o'clock last night, striking two girls, killing one and injuring the other seriously. The car then crashed into a plate glass window and stopped.

Directors of the Fletcher Joint Stock Land Bank, Indianapolis, have called for retirement on Nov. 1 the remaining $461,500 of the series of 5 per cent bonds of the bank due on May 1, 1952, and optional on May 1, 1932, according to an announcement by William B. Schiltges, president.

Members of the Daughters of the American Revolution, closing their fortieth State convention at the Hotel Roosevelt, were enjoined yesterday to increase their activity among children and thus help "insure the future of the country."

Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, yesterday stated the board's position concerning the recent proposal made at Washington for a "flying squadron" to assist the racing commissions in stumping out the alleged drugging evil and in running narcotic traffickers from the country's race tracks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Gold fleeing from war-scared Europe and continued imports of silver purchased by the Treasury forced the United States' total monetary stocks up to a new record of $15,489,276,690 in September, the Treasury Department reported today.

LYNN, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP). -- A fine of $25 for disturbing a school was imposed upon Carleton Nichols today a few hours after his son Carleton, Jr., 8, had been expelled from the Lynn schools for refusing, on religious grounds, to salute the flag.

The data submitted to the Labor Convention by Secretary PERKINS of the Labor Department, covering as they did the country's actual increase in manufacturing employment since the low level of 1933, provide a more accurate measure of the change than could possibly be derived from the much-discussed figures of "unemployed on relief."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The National Bituminous Coal Commission, created under the Guffey Law which establishes a miniature NRA for the soft coal industry, swung rapidly into action today.

The Park Department has decided to go into the furniture business to equip the 165 new playground recreation buildings it will have when the WPA program is completed next July 1 it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Twentytwo offering sheets of various oil interests were received in the week ended on Oct. 5, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. It added that the act of filing did not give to the security the commission's approval or indicate that it had passed on the merits o the issue, or that the material filed was correct.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- Reinforced by State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton, the Republican Assembly caravan moved today into Greene County in an attempt to recapture a seat now held by a Democrat, and into Dutchess, home county of President Roosevelt, where the reelection of Assemblyman Emerson D. Fite is believed to be somewhat endangered by the candidacy of John E. Mack Jr., Democratic candidate and son of a close friend of the President.
The Board of Elections made public yesterday the final group of independent nominations filed by the previous midnight but held back from the former list because of the last-minute rush. They follow:
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP). -- Muriel Hall, 18 years old and high school student, was found strangled to death tonight in the living room of her home in a wellto-do section here.

Day before yesterday The World-Telegram said our and present feeling about neutrality shows that the American people have learned the lesson of the Lusitania. In the course of its argument it cites the Gore-McLemore resolution of January, 1916, which would have discouraged American citizens from traveling on armed belligerent ships.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- Negradus Yesus, Ethiopian Charge d'Affaires in Rome, who was instructed to get his passports and leave this country as soon as possible, said today he would depart on the first available ship.

ROME, Oct. 9. -- With Adowa occupied, every sign points to a short war. Italy is engaged in battle on three fronts-military, diplomatic and economic-and all three are now concentrating on one objective, which is to make the conflict as brief as possible.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 9. -- The Ethiopian Government now expects a military pause, in the north at least, which may be used by the Italian Government for diplomatic negotiations.

Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia brought his attack on the Roosevelt administration to New York yesterday, tracing the origin of the New Deal to the "Russian primer" and implying an alliance between the present Washington government and communism.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9. -Following the loss of Fullback Don Jackson on Saturday, there was another break in Harvard's firstteam ranks today when it was found that Bob Jones had suffered a severe shoulder injury in yesterday's scrimmage.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 9. -- That The Netherlands intends to fulfill her obligations resulting from membership in the League of Nations was indicated by the passage today in the upper house of the States General of a bill empowering the government to promulgate export prohibitions and to take all measures necessary for the promotion of international cooperation.

"Porgy and Bess" opens this evening at the Alvin Theatre, throwing the entire Broadway amusement field into confusion; is it drama or opera? George Gershwin, who has written the score, calls it a "folk opera," but the show is based on 1927's "Porgy."
Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein accused Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday of considering the work of the Crime Prevention Bureau a "lollypop job" instead of a "cop's job."

Former Governor Nathan L. Miller, testifying yesterday before the Congressional committee investigating real estate bond reorganizations, said that mortgage bond issues and reorganization committees should be controlled by State law.

The felicitous term "statistical recovery" used in your editorial "Nazi Sleight-of-Hand" fills a great need in present-day economics. It ought to be accepted as a standard term to remind economists that statistics and human welfare are two different things that often move ih diametrically opposite directions.
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 9 (AP). -- F. A. Seiberling, president of the Seiberling Tire and Rubber Company, said today concerning reports of a tire price war in New York:

ALBANY, Oct. 9. -- An upward tendency in factory employment and payrolls in the State was evident from the middle of August to the middle of September, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9. -- Ray Murphy, newly elected National Commander of the American Legion, today invited the American Federation of Labor to form a united front with his organization to fight "communism and all subversive influences."
The opinion by Justice Parker in the Hauptmann case included a syllabus of twenty-one points. They were:
Your comment on the passing of Francis Wilson recalls a personal incident which will remind his many friends of that ready wit which endeared him to all.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 9. -- The Court of Errors and Appeals held today as constitutional the law of 1993 authorizing banks to reorganize by paying 50 per cent of their deposits in preferred stock.

ROME, Oct. 9. -- Since Italy and Ethiopia have not yet been officially at war, Count Luigi VhiciGigliucci, the Italian Minister at Addis Ababa, was authorized to abandon his post only today. He was to leave the Ethiopian capital either tonight or tomorrow morning.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 9. -- Assured of success because of one of the largest entries in the history of the event, the fifty-second annual dog show given by the Danbury Agricultural Society began its twoday stand at the Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Sept. 28 amounted to 305,050,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. Compared with the previous week, this is a decline of 1,587,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 1,572,000 and 15,000 barrels, respectively, in stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum.
The noise abatement drive was momentarily subordinated yesterday to two other municipal campaigns -those for street safety and fire prevention.

Yesterday, the second day for registration for the November election, continued to show the number of persons qualifying themselves to vote to be far in excess of 1931, the last comparable year. The total for the first two days was 410,356, as compared with 320,542 in 1931.

"Pop" Hart, widely known and abundantly loved American artist, died on Sept. 9, 1933. The Newark Museum, always thorough in its undertakings, has prepared a splendid memorial showing of his work in all the mediums he used. The exhibition will open at the museum with a preview this evening and to the public tomorrow, remaining until Dec. 5.
Pointing toward the intersectional battle with Purdue on Saturday at the Polo Grounds, the Fordham football squad went through an intensive practice session yesterday at Fordham Field.

A candor in discussing current financial conditions remarkable in a president of the New York Stock Exchange was observed last night in the address of Charles R. Gay before the American Management Association. Coming directly to the point, Mr. Gay admitted that the Exchange is deeply concerned over the possibilities of inflation, fearing that another great speculative orgy might mean its ruin.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 9 (AP). -The government, through two of its "key" witnesses, charged today at the income tax trial of Abraham L. Shushan that he received thousands of dollars from a New Orleans lake front development under a "rebate" agreement, and did not report this in his income tax returns.

ROME, Oct. 9. -- Official circles refused to comment on today's proceedings at Geneva except to express Italy's gratitude to Austria and Hungary for the speeches against sanctions by the League of Nations.

MONTEVIDEO, Oct. 9. -- With the bottom scraped and painted, the Wyatt Earp slipped from the drydock yesterday and is now anchored in the harbor here to remain until Monday, when she will be tied alongside the wharf to take on the last of the expedition supplies to come aboard.

The Appellate Division heard argument yesterday on the appeal by Mrs. Margaret Alexandria Alexander of London from the order by Surrogate Foley probating the will of her sister, Mrs. Florence Adelaide Pratt. The sister left more than $3,000,000 of her $5,000,000 estate to a Scotland Yard man who had befriended her, Parisian saleswomen and other acquaintances.

Plaintiffs took over eleven properties in Manhattan at auction sales yesterday. The leading foreclosure involved the thirty-one-story Hotel Shelton, at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, which was bid in by the New York Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 9.-Dolores Costello, who forsook her film career seven years ago to marry John Barrymore, today received a divorce from the noted favorite of the stage and screen. The belief is expressed that she may now attempt to regain the fame she once enjoyed in motion pictures.

One traditional element of "Jersey justice" has been its speed. This was not outstanding in the trial of the man charged with kidnapping and slaying the Lindbergh baby, nor in the action of the Court of Errors and Appeals, which has devoted months to the study of his appeal to it.

Jewelry valued at $50,000 was recovered yesterday by the police as the result of the arrest on Tuesday evening of Murray Jacobson, 25 years old, a jeweler of 130 East Forty-seventh Street, who said that he bought it from a man he did not know for $800.
In commenting on "The Fabric of Good Faith" editorially last Sunday you had this to say:
DAi'BUIY, Conn., Oct. 9. Atrack record at the Danbury Fairwas equaled today when HanoverPeter, owned and driven by P. H.Stuart of Mechanic Falls, Me.,trotted the mile in 2:06.
COCOS ISLAND, Oct. 9. -- The British treasure hunters now here visited President Roosevelt aboard the cruiser Houston today, although he has yet to land on the island where a welcome awaits him.

Led by Colonel W. T. Johnson, who wore a pearl-gray sombrero, a pink satin blouse trimmed with green, heavy black trousers and spinning silver spurs, the tenth annual rodeo thundered into Madison Square Garden last night.

The New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Miss Antonia Brico, opened a drive yesterday afternoon in Steinway Hall, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street, for the support of a series of six monthly concerts which it will start Nov. 12 in Carnegie Hall.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation reported yesterday that its net asset value on Aug. 31, the end of its fiscal year, was $7,041,500. This was equivalent to $91.03 a share on its preferred stock and after providing for this issue at the liquidating price. $50 a share, to $3.71 a share on the common stock.
TOKYO, Oct. 9. -- The Japanese Navy refuses to accept even a twoyear naval agreement, as suggested in the latest British proposal, the newspaper Asahi reports.

BERLIN, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler blended today a plea for idealism and a denunciation of bolshevism into a successful appeal for funds at the opening of the Nazis' third relief drive.

In spite of Governor CROSS, who may be forgiven as a sort of institution or an exceptional favorite that has given the voters medicines, Connecticut is a land of steady Republican habits. The result of the elections in the small towns Monday shows a rising remorse among the comparatively few that had strayed from the beaten path.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 9. -- A charge of buckshot fired at her automobile will not stop Mrs. Sheldon S. Wells from her self-appointed task of attempting to bring about the arrest of those who pass the red light on the Boston Post Road In Greens Farms, she said tonight.

P. A. S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, said yesterday before sailing for Europe on the United States liner Manhattan that officials of the company would file plans for a third new cabin liner with the United States Shipping Board Bureau in Washington either today or tomorrow.

The public offering of $10,000,000 of Pacific Lighting Corporation 4 1/2 per cent debentures by a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., ended yesterday and the syndicate books were closed, according to the group manager.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Oct. 9. -Police Recorder William R. Buckley issued here tonight warrants charging first-degree murder to seven deputy sheriffs of Union County who took part in a raid Sept. 26 on the farmhouse of John Crempa on Terrell Road here, when Crempa's wife, Sophie, 41 years old, was shot dead and the farmer wounded.

Three generations of Broadway's great, near-great and never-great filled the Church of the Transfiguration at noon yesterday at funeral services for Francis Wilson, first president of the Actors Equity Association, who coupled a genius for comedy with a life-long concern for the welfare of the less fortunate in his profession.

Navy vs. Virginia. One formal vote for Navy. That opens and closes the balloting for the day. Perhaps football is getting so popular that they will be playing games every day in the week sooner or later. And by night as well as day. Well, it's a short season at best and the football followers will only add to the cheering if they pack the game a little closer together.

Dr. William E. Geyer, Professor Emeritus of Physics at the Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken, N.J., and last surviving member of the original faculty of 1870 there, died on Tuesday at his residence at Boonton, N.J., according to word received yesterday by officials of the college.

In and out among East River traffic, now submerging like a Uboat, now skimming the water like a seasled, Leander, the amphibian, bull calf, nearly'took the heart out of the marine division of the police yesterday morning.

Arthur (Dutch chultz) Flegenheimer, New York racketeer, whowas acquitted recently in Malone,N. Y., of income-tax fraud, andthus thwarted government agentswho had sworn to put him in jail,stood in ieopardy again yesterday.

The executive committee of the Conference on Port Development of the City of New York will hold a meeting at the Hotel Astor at 4 o'clock this afternoon to consider a conference of all manufacturers, importers, exporters and steamship lines affected by President Roosevelt's recent proclamation withdrawing government protection from all trade and travel between United States ports and Italy and Ethiopia.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 9. -John D. Rockefeller Sr., his niece, his secretary and twelve employes will leave Golf House, his estate here, tomorrow morning for Ormond Beach, Fla., where the 96year-old philanthropist has his Winter home.
]PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 tau).ThePhiladelphia liagleq of the NationalFootball League pushed the Pittsburgh Pirates into the league cellartonight and avenged an earlier defeat with a l?to6 victory.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- The Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company announced today that it had received a loan of $5,000,000 from local banks in participation with the Federal Reserve Bank here.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9. -- A little more than eight years after he flew the "Spirit of St. Louis" from New York to Paris and blazed the trail for ocean air travel, Colonel Lindbergh saw here today the transfer from the Glenn L. Martin Company to Pan American Airways of the China Clipper, the largest transport plane ever developed in the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Criticizing "individuals with limited vision" who assert that American business has collapsed, Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, declared here today that it "is the most successful instrument for the production and distribution of goods that the world has yet seen."
CATANIA, Sicily, Oct. 9. -- Judging by the display of submarines and aircraft at Sicilian ports, Italy is ready to strike hard if called upon to use her naval forces in the Mediterranean.

Jascha Heifetz, who appeared in recital at Carnegie Hall last night, is the first of the established virtuosos to greet the new season. He was received by a capacity audience with a warmth born of long acquaintance and appreciation. The applause seemed to imply that Mr. Heifetz's admirers felt he could do no wrong.

Retailers yesterday developed plans to follow closely the future functioning of the Social Security Board and the setting up of State legislation in conformity with the Federal Social Security Act. Announcement was made by the National Retail Dry Goods Association that arrangements were being made for handling work relative to the administration of the social security program through its taxation committee and committees of the controllers congress and the store management group of the association.
Columbia's varsity football team faced the husky freshman array in an hour and a half scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the meeting with Rutgers here on Saturday.
