Three men arrested following the disturbance that greeted the appearance of a truck carrying men in Nazi uniforms in the garment district on Tuesday were found guilty of disorderly conduct in Jefferson Market Court yesterday. Each received a suspended sentence.
ROME, Oct. 9. -- The Giornale d'Italia's Asmara correspondent, Ferdinando Chiarelli, gives the following account of a visit to the headquarters of General Ruggero Santini in Adigrat, Ethiopia:
Mrs. Anna Hauptmann, wife of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, was stunned yesterday when she learned that the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals had upheld the death sentence of her husband.

Marked emphasis will be accorded dresses for the Winter social season, according to the results of a survey completed yesterday by the Dress Creators League of America, Inc. The survey showed seventeen firms will stress lines of so-called "Sunday-night" dresses very strongly for the period directly ahead, against one firm which indicated it would not do so.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 9. -- The 4,000 persons who escaped scars by a new kind of smallpox vaccine were cited at the American Public Health Association today as reasons for health officials to reconsider the entire smallpox vaccination technique.

In reading over a summation of Mayor La Guardia's proposed budget for 1936 I notice his allowance to the Police Department is $54,527,803 for 1936, compared with $57,455,574, which was estimated by Police Commissioner Valentine as necessary; also Mayor La Guardia's comment that he is increasing the police force by 600 men.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 9. -- The statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Sept. 30 shows the following changes, in paper pesos, for the month:

Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney, announced yesterday that he would submit evidence on Tuesday to the grand jury in the inquiry requested by the board of examiners of the Education Department. The request followed a report that questions asked 880 applicants for licenses as high school health education teachers had been obtained by one of them in advance.

At a little before 9 o'clock last night, the particular art known as ballet returned to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House, from which it had been pretty effectively banished for the last decade or so. The occasion was the opening of the third American season of Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe, and its first appearance here in a suitable theatrical atmosphere.
Prices of commodity futures were generally lower yesterday, only copper and wool tops advancing. All grains and lard were lower in the cash markets while tin, wool tops and rubber were higher.

James M. Landis, new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, promised yesterday to continue administration of the Securities Exchange Act so as to relieve corporate financing of unnecessary burdens and expense. He spoke at the opening session of a two-day conference of the American Management Association in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Responsible officials made it clear today that American exporters might take whatever risks they please in shipping to Italy and Ethiopia goods not specifically covered by President Roosevelt's munitions embargo.

I heartily agree with a letter from Estelle H. Ries, regretting the fact that discussion of personal ailments forms so large a part of the conversation between friends when they meet. The habit of harping on health, sickness or disaster is deplorable when considered only as a topic.

ROME, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Italy stands to lose several billion lire yearly in exports by isolation from other League of Nations members if the League imposes economic and financial sanctions against her. But Italy believes this loss will be made up in exports to other countries, Italian economists insist.

Class 1 railroads, numbering 149, reported to the Interstate Commerce Commission that they had suffered a net loss of $78,025,038 in the first seven months of the year, against a net loss of $29,897,250 in the same period last year. The statement for July and the seven months follow:

WASHTNGTON, Oct. 9. -- A tablet inscribed to the memory of George Bancroft who, as Secretary of the Navy under President Polk, was credited with establishing the Naval Academy at Annapolis, was accepted for the government today by Henry L. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

A distinguished audience of about 1,400 persons filled the Hollywood Theatre to capacity last night, providing an incidental field day for scores of autograph seekers and knotting pedestrian traffic in the upper reaches of Times Square as the Warner Brothers presented the first public showing of their film of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream."
East Side apartment rentals predominated in the lists furnished by brokers yesterday. The upper West Side, the Bronx and Queens also were centres of activity. The lessees included the following:
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 9. -The University of Michigan has completed a study of the fat boy and found him wanting -- in zeal and ambition.

VIENNA, Oct. 9. -- One of civil war's inevitable tragedies was revealed in a Vienna court yesterday when Rudolf Frieml, chauffeur and former commandant in the Socialist Republican Defense Corps, was sentenced to three and one-half years' imprisonment.

Forward pass defense was stressed yesterday as the Manhattan football team entered the final stages of its preparations for the intersectional battle with Louisiana State at Ebbets Field Saturday. In the course of a two-hour drill at Innisfail Park Coach Chick Meehan emphasized the necessity of checking the powerful overhead attack the Tigers are expected to rely upon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -Launching a war budget campaign for the first time since the World War, the American Red Cross appealed today to the American public for money for the Ethiopian Red Cross.

ATLANTA, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Louisiana State University's football squad of thirty-four players, en route to New York to play Manhattan, stopped off here today for a two-hour workout on Georgia Tech's gridiron.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The British Cabinet was in session for two hours today, but it did not raise the embargo against supplying arms, for which the Ethiopian Government is begging so that its people can defend themselves against the Italian attack.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Snug and safe after nearly three days of peril and hardship, the crew of twentyseven of the Gloucester schooner Hesperus told tonight how the big fisherman foundered almost beneath their feet and of their own desperate battle for life.

Earnings of the United Fruit Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 have been estimated by the company's controller at $7,350,000 before taxes, compared with $10,621,000 in the first nine months of 1934.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- Bill Goldbeck, professional, and James Rushin, amateur, both of Lawrence Farms, today captured the laurels in the Westchester P.G.A.'s first Scotch foursome tourney of the season.

Scribners have decided to keep four of their major books out of the Fall rush. They are "A Life of John Galsworthy," by H. V. Marrot; "Freedom in the Modern World," by Jacques Maritain; "Soviet Communism," by Sidney and Beatrice Webb, and "Jesus Manifest," by Dmitri Merejowski.

La Maisonette Russe, the restaurant and night club in the Hotel St. Regis which will be opened tonight, was blessed yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Vasily Kurdiumoff, rector of the Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church of Jesus Christ the Saviour, Madison Avenue and 121st Street.

Expressing confidence that the present interest rate of 2 per cent paid by savings banks, which was set earlier this year by the State Banking Board, would not be reduced further, Harold Stone, the new president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, predicted yesterday that "within a reasonable length of time" regulation of savings bank interest rates would be abolished.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Choice hogs advanced 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight here today, but packing sows and heavy kinds, after showing strength in the early trading, weakened and closed generally 10 cents lower than yesterday. A break in lard had some effect on the demand.
Resales of housing properties featured trading in the Bronx yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Oct. 9. -- The Nayal Academy is prepared to celebrate tomorrow the ninetieth anniversary of its founding. Thousands of graduates are expected to attend.

New York City's infant death rate dropped to a new low of 31.9 per 1,000 live births last week, the Health Department reported yesterday. This figure is .6 point less than the previous record established three weeks ago. Before that the lowest figure was 33.5 for the week ended July 8, 1933.

The American Rolling Mill Company will exchange 72,500 shares of its common stock, having a par value of $1,812,500, for all the assets of Calco Iron Pipe, Ltd., it disclosed yesterday in an application to the New York Stock Exchange to list the block of additional stock.

Count Arthur took the Manhattan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday to cap the climax in what was Reigh Count's greatest day as a sire since he was retired to the stud after conquests on both sides of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Government expenditures for a little over three months of the current fiscal year passed the two billion mark on Monday, breaking all previous records in the country's peacetime history, the Treasury disclosed today.

VIENNA, Oct. 9. -- Politicians and the press are occupied with the dilemma confronting Austria as a result of Italy's invasion of Ethiopia and the prospect of sanctions. It is suddenly realized that Austria's position has become highly important, for if she evades the application of sanctions by refusing on the League's demand, to close her frontier with Italy, she will make the sanctions largely ineffective.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP). -- W. A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, tonight denied as "ridiculous and vicious" charges made today by President John Fitzpatrick of the Chicago Federation of Labor that labor trouble might have figured in the possible causes of the fatal crash of a plane near Cheyenne Monday.
A dispatch received yesterday from the Maine Tuna Club at Ogunquit describes the capture of three tuna, weighing 183, 157 and 97 pounds, last week-end.

BOSTON, Oct. 9. -- James and John Roosevelt, eldest and youngest sons of the President, escaped with a shaking-up at 8:10 o'clock tonight when a train of the Boston. Revere Beach Lynn Railroad was hit by the sport roadster which John was driving and which was wedged against a post of a gate through which the auto had crashed at the Maverick Street crossing in East Boston.

VIENNA, Oct. 9. -- From reliable information received from South Tyrol it appears that the prohibition of the exportation of war material to Italy has been considerably more effective than has generally been supposed.

Fourteen charitable and civic institutions receive bequests totaling $177,000 and the residuary estate of undetermined value in the will of Mrs. Mary T. Sheldon, widow of James O. Sheldon, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mrs. Sheldon died on Sept. 19, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than $10,000."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Profits from future sales of securities purchased under stock-option plans by directors, officers and employes of corporations, when such plans were entered into before the passage of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 were exempted from the provisions of Section 16b. of the act by a rule announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Former President Herbert Hoover arrived in New York City yesterday fresh from new attacks on the policies of President Roosevelt and prepared to deliver an address tonight in which he may touch on broad social aspects of current political problems.

In the first full-fledged song recital of the young season, Maria Silveira, a soprano who appeared here seven or eight years ago with Rosing's American Opera Company, held the interest and evoked the applause of an audience of encouraging size at the Town Hall last night.

Engineers of the United States Steel Corporation have been examining for several weeks the iron ore mines of the Warren Foundry and Pipe Company near Dover, N.J. These mines constitute one of the largest ore bodies in the Eastern part of this country.

ATHENS, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Greece ended her eleven-year-old republic tonight in a swift royalist coup d'etat, capped by a rousing vote of Parliament restoring the monarchy. Amid scenes of wild rejoicing in the Parliament building -- once the royal palace -- the nation's lawmakers decreed the return of King George II from exile in England.
The searchlight will be turned upon Harvard and Yale tomorrow by two of the power houses of the East.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 254,995.6 shares of no-par value $4.50 series preferred stock, having a maximum offering price of $102 a share and aggregating $26,009,571.60.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- As a hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning the defaulted bonds of the Republic of El Salvador proceeded today it developed that Douglas Bradford, secretary of the protective committee for the bondholders, had disappeared on the eve of the opening session, apparently headed for El Salvador.

OTTAWA, Oct. 10 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $2,370,769 in the week ended yesterday, said the weekly statement of the bank today. Deposits by chartered banks declined by $4,808,991.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -In the first game it has played in Philadelphia in forty-six years, Yale will present against Penn on Saturday the line-up which the coaches selected after a drastic shake-up yesterday. Four newcomers will be regulars and Captain Kim Whitehead will abandon the defensive back role for the offensive task at left halfback, it was determined today.
ADOWA, Ethiopia, Oct. 10 (Reuters). -- Italian soldiers today buried the last defenders of Governor Ras Seyoum's palace, shot dead while resisting to the last the entry of the invaders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A sharp warning to Americans against engaging in transactions of any character either with Italy or Ethiopia, even though they may do so legally and at their own risk, was issued by Secretary Hull in a statement today.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- The entire German press and other organs of governmental opinion surrendered themselves today to a celebration of the German election victory in Memel Territory and to laying down the terms on which Lithuania may "normalize" her relations with Germany.

The West Side took the lead in the apartment renting reported yesterday. The Greenwich Village section was particularly active. Various leases in Westchester houses also were listed. The tenants included the following:

Carl O. Schniewind has been appointed librarian and curator of prints of the Brooklyn Museum, succeeding Miss Susan A. Hutchinson, whose resignation became effective on Oct. 1. Miss Hutchinson had been with the museum for thirty-five years.

After eight years of savory memories, "Porgy" has acquired a score, a band, a choir of singers and a new title, "Porgy and Bess." which the Theatre Guild put on at the Alvin last evening. Du Bose and Dorothy Heyward wrote the original lithograph of Catfish Row, which Rouben Mamoulian translated into a memorable work of theatre dynamics.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (;P).--The executive committee of the Communist International published today a call to transport workers throughout the world to tie up the shipment of goods to Italy in an effort to force suspension of the war with Ethiopia.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Glenn Brasser, 22-year-old son of a Rochester dairy operator, confessed tonight. Corporal William Waldron of the State Police said, that he strangled 18-year-old Muriel Hall of Rochester because she refused to marry him.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The Treasury will do no further financing in the near future except possibly to issue $100,000,000 of shortterm bills each week, Acting Secretary Coolidge hinted today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad pleaded poverty today in its application for a writ of certiorari for review of the valu ations placed on its property by the town of Mamaroneck. It asks that they be reduced by $160,135 from the present figure of $974,200.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 10. -- Despite the formal approval of President William Green and the official endorsement of the executive council, the powerful bloc of building unions now in official control of the building trades department received a setback today in its attempt to seat J. W. Williams, the department president, as a delegate to the federation's annual convention here.

Directors of the Netherland-America Foundation, which was established in 1921 to deepen understanding and friendship between the Netherlands and the United States, were entertained at a tea and reception yesterday afternoon in the new club quarters of the foundation on Stuyvesant Square North.

The obtaining of another loan by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was seen yesterday as depending on the willingness of the Pennsylvania Railroad to guarantee the obligation.

Saying that he could neither confirm nor deny reports of his appointment until he had received instructions from Washington, Mr. Rice declined last night to discuss relief plans for actors in this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The economic factor will be largely determinative for Italy in her East African campaign, military experts here believe. The utmost importance, therefore, is placed on the collective action of sanctions against Italy through the League of Nations, and particularly on the firm stand taken by Great Britain.

In the International-Cosmopolitan for November Mr. DAMON RUNYON, who has been studying Governor LANDON in Topeka, records the habits and history of that statesman, now high on the roll of the "favorably mentioned" as potential Republican candidates for President.

Captain Jens Nilsen, master of the liner Santa Barbara, was charged with negligence yesterday in the crash last month of the Santa Barbara and the Ambrose Lightship. William A. Mitchell, Sandy Hook pilot of the passenger liner, which collided with the light vessel off the Quarantine dock as the result of mixed signals, was also charged with negligence in findings reported yesterday and based on testimony taken last month before the Steamboat Inspection Service.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10. -- The Russians hold the view that Germany is taking advantage of Italy's involvement in Ethiopia to strengthen her position in Central Europe, particularly in the Danube Basin. The official Soviet press asserts the German rapprochement with Hungary, signalized by Premier Julius Goemboes's visit to Berlin, means the beginning of the end of the Little Entente.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A slight recession marked the trend of wholesale prices during the week ended on Oct. 5, according to an announcement today by Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The composite index for the week was 80.5 per cent of the 1926 average, compared with 81 the week of Sept. 28, and 76.6 a year ago.

Secretary HULL has been trading jackknives again. With the Minister of Colombia he has concluded a reciprocal trade treaty which needs only approval by President ROOSEVELT and ratification by the Colombian Congress to make it effective. Under the terms of this agreement Colombia is to grant tariff concessions, ranging from 16 to 90 per cent, on more than half the goods we sell her.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10. -Coach Dick Harlow tonight named Harvard's starting line-up for the game with Holy Cross in the stadium on Saturday. There are several changes as compared with the starting team of a week ago against Springfield.

Retail package deliveries for the week ended Oct. 5 showed a rise of 14 per cent over the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. For the four weeks ended on that date there was a gain of 20 per cent in deliveries, made for about 250 stores in the metropolitan and suburban areas.

Modifying the ban on the participation of members of the Association of Junior Leagues of America in political activities, the board of directors, meeting at the Waldorf Astoria yesterday, urged the members to take part as individuals in civic affairs and legislative campaigns.
COCOS ISLAND, Oct. 10. -- In the shade of a palm tree on a strip of rocky shore, President Roosevelt ate lunch today with a group of Pacific adventurers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The new National Labor Relations Board issued its first complaint today when it cited the Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines, Inc., and the Greyhound Management Corporation, Inc., to appear on Oct. 22 to answer charges that they seek to restrain their employes from joining the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes of America.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 10. -- A brush fire got out of the control of the man who had obtained a permit to start it here this afternoon and burned over an area two miles long by half a mile wide on the outskirts of this village.
Cause for reflection is furnished by the following brief communication sent by the Commissioner of Public Welfare to the old-age pensioners:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 10 (AP). -Thomas H. Robinson Sr., father of the fugitive hunted as the kidnapper of Mrs. Alice Speed Stoll, testified in his own defense today that he offered to go from Nashville to Indianapolis to liberate Mrs. Stoll without payment of ransom.

Industrial recovery in this country has elicited two opposite views of the probable sequel. One is, that this may turn out to be only another of the several "false starts" which have occurred since the Spring of 1933, each of which ended in more or less discouraging reaction.

An advance of 1.5 points in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices placed it at 130.2 on Tuesday, against 128.7 the week before. This is the highest point in five years, with prices of 1913 figured as 100.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES ON THE NORTHERN ETHIOPIAN FRONT, Oct. 10. -- The population of Adowa was returning to its normal routine today as Italian engineers pushed forward in their strenuous efforts to run roads into the town. The roads will be used to provide the troops who occupied

An offer of $5,700,000 for assets of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company, which is being reorganized under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, was heard yesterday at a session in the proceedings before Federal Judge John Knight.

Mayor La Guardia taxed the Board of Education yesterday with lacking the courage to get rid of its "rotten, dishonest custodial service" when the department's budget allowance for next year was under discussion before the Board of Estimate at City Hall.
Quotations were unchanged for all classes of credit. The turnover was small and in the main represented replacement of expiring obligations.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Britain's big minelaying submarine Porpoise, 2,060 tons, normally stationed with the fifth submarine flotilla at Portsmouth, has arrived in the Straits of Gibraltar.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 10. -- Hordes of savage warriors marched out of the mountains and deserts of Ethiopia tonight to throw a wall of fighting men about this capital.

The Flying Ebony filly Vicaress ran one of her good races in the Ladies' Handicap, which had its sixty-fourth renewal at Belmont yesterday, and led from start to finish to score by three lengths at 7 to 1 in a field of seven.

BEING a stenographic report of a conversation between two fluent gentlemen who seemed to know what they were talking about, to wit: The game of professional football that has been making long gains in popular favor with each passing season. "They tell me Potsy Clark is still in a daze. He thought" -
ROME, Oct. 10. -- Premier Mussolini's army in Northern Ethiopia has captured a number of small towns in a slow but steady advance on a widening front, dispatches from Asmara, Eritrea, said today.
KAMENZ, Germany, Oct. 10. -The worn and aged mother of Bruno Richard Hauptmann burst into tears tonight when she talked of "American justice."

The Union League Club delivered a sharp attack on President Roosevelt and his administration last night, charging the President and the Democratic majority in Congress with attacking fundamental rights of citizens as guaranteed under the Constitution.

Leading the business recovery parade by a substantial margin, practically all branches of the textile industry are surging forward to new high records for the depression period and in some instances, to all-time peaks, a survey disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Although business on the London Stock Exchange today was affected by the settlements prices were firmer, the industrials being particularly good. Investment buying brought a further upward movement in British funds although the best levels were not maintained.
LONDON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 10. -Harry Brusie, veteran driver, piloted Louis Guy to a new trotting mark for the Danbury 'Fair track today in the first heat of the 2:08 trot. The gelding, owned by W. H. Bird of Windsor, Conn., went the mile in 2:04 3/4, bettering the time of 2:06 1/2 made only yesterday by Hanover Peter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- A vast airport improvement program, nation-wide in scope, was taking shape today at the Works Progress Administration.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 10. -- After three games at Amsterdam, the world's championship chess match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam was continued at the Hotel Witte Brug here tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- A world premiere of a new opera by Ethel Leginska, with John Charles Thomas, internationally famous baritone, in the leading role, will be given the last week in November at the Chicago Civic Opera House.

The Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin will arrive today from Hamburg, Bremen and Channel ports. Among her passengers is Matthew E. Hanna, United States Minister to Guatemala, accompanied by Mrs. Hanna. Others on board include:

The city will build three new stream-lined ferryboats for service on the Battery-Staten Island run, F. J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, announced yesterday. Construction of the boats was made possible by an allotment of $3,000,000 in PWA funds under a loan-and-grant arrangement.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis, a reproduction of the Maisonette Russe in the Rue du MontThabor in Paris, was opened formally last night, attracting a large attendance of members of society, who gave dinners and supper parties.

An appeal will be carried to the Supreme Court against the decision last week of Federal District Court Judge Elwood Hamilton at Louisville, Ky., holding unconstitutional the provisions of the Ashurst-Sumners Law which prohibit interstate shipment of convict-made goods, according to information received here yesterday by Mortimer Fishel, counsel for work clothing groups.

Awards of medals and cash were made yesterday at police headquarters to thirty-four members of the Police Department for rescuing persons from drowning in the waters surrounding New York City. The awards were made by the Life Saving Benevolent Association, founded eighty-six years ago by merchants and shippers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Manager Bill Terry of the Giants today said he had refused an offer by the Cardinals to trade First Baseman Jim (Rip) Collins and Outfielder Joe Medwick for Pitcher Carl Hubbell and Outfielder Mel Ott, Giant stars.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 10. -Further reform of the nation's banking structure and banking practices is necessary because the New Deal reforms "fall short of going to the root of the problem," Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, said here today in an address before the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Emergence of the Middle West Utilities Company as a corporation with one class of stock and no stock-purchase warrants was indicated today as the result of the second of two all-day conferences of organizations representing creditors and stockholders.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- A thorough drill in fundamentals occupied the Princeton football squad today on University Field in preparation for the Williams encounter.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday at the formal opening of the Caprice Room of the Weylin, when a percentage of the proceeds were turned over to the directors of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., to further the work of that organization.

EVERY year, in the old Liveright catalogues, it used to be announced that Katherine Anne Porter was about to finish a book to be called "The Devil and Cotton Mather." But, like Burton Rascoe's novel, "The Devil and Cotton Mather" never was finished. And Katherine Anne Porter went on keeping her scrupulously sensitive and miraculously pure prose style to herself.

Bankers have been invited to submit bids on Oct. 21 for a new issue of $150,000 Floral Park N.Y. municipal building and signal system bonds, the interest rate not to exceed 5 per cent. The bonds are to be dated Nov. 1, 1935, and will mature from Nov. 1, 1937, to 1955.
Registration in the city rose yesterday to a total of 664,557 for the first three days, a figure regarded as exceedingly high for an off year.

VIENNA, Oct. 10. -- Sensational claims that his nomination as an honorary citizen of Austrian villages and towns amounts to an invitation to return and take power was made by Archduke Otto in a letter read by Archduke Eugene in Otto's name yesterday to the Burgomaster of Waidhofen on the Ybbs.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- Monsignor Peter Legge, Catholic Bishop of Meissen, is now in prison awaiting trial on charges of exchange smuggling, the government announced today. He was arrested yesterday and brought to Moabit Prison here, where he has been placed at the disposal of the judicial authorities.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 10. -Many luncheon parties were given at the Cascades Club between rounds of the men's Autumn golf tournament today. Mr. and Mrs. Hector Suyker entertained for Mr. and Mrs. J. L. Lindquist and L. S. Walworth. Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hicks Kerr had as luncheon guests Dr. Stewart L. Craig, Dr. R. O. Jones and William H. Jones, Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pell were luncheon hosts.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Seven deputy sheriffs who took part in a raid on the farmhouse of John Crempa on Terrell Road here last Sept. 26, when the farmer's wife, Sophie, 41, was shot dead and her husband wounded, were held without bail for the grand jury when arraigned before Recorder William R. Buckley here today on charges of first-degree murder.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 10 (AP). -Bloodroot, second only to Black Helen in E. R. Bradley's stable, turned in her first winning effort since the Saratoga meeting when she took the measure of three high class rivals in the mile and seventy yards of the Wye Mill Purse at Laurel today.

Prices on the Liverpool. New Orleans and New York Cotton Exchanges eased slightly yesterday because the action taken at Geneva was construed in foreign cotton circles as a further restriction on an already handicapped international trade situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 9, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,480,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week and $25,000,000 above the corresponding week in 1934.

A jury which has been hearing evidence intermittently since last Sept. 10 in the government's case against promoters of Atlas Tack stock, was taken to the Hotel McAlpin for the night at 10:30 o'clock last night when no agreement was in sight.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 10 (AP). -- An old heathen custom, revived with scientific improvements at Boston, was credited by speakers before the American Public Health Association today with preventing measles in a surprisingly large number of cases.

GENEVA, Oct. 10. -- Fifty-one governments representing four-fifths of mankind joined today through the League of Nations Assembly here in a verdict that "the Italian Government has resorted to war in disregard of its covenants under Article XII of the League's covenant."
GENEVA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Baron Pompeo Aloisi defended Italy's activities in Ethiopia before the League of Nations Assembly today.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 10. -- It was officially announced today that the Italians were advancing from Gerlogubi toward Gorahai on the southern front, while the Italian Legation declared that Gorahai had already been taken. This is possible since the defenses of Gorahai are centred in a small gully on an open plain which is open to a mechanized attack, especially on the north side, where the road leaves toward Gabridihari.
"I Live My Life," featuring Joan Crawford and Brian Aherne, begins an engagement today at the Capitol.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- The demand for hogs was much less aggressive here today and the heaviest receipts for a Thursday in some weeks provided supplies somewhat in excess of requirements. The market was off around 10 cents a hundredweight at the start but steadily weakened with packing sows and heavy lard types hogs off as much as 50 cents at the last.

Idyllic, no less, is life at the Italian front around Adigrat, as sung in Virgilian cadences by the correspondent of the Giornale d'Italia of Rome. Among other things, the arrival of the Italians has been a "godsend" to the people of Adigrat.

A big, impressive group of softspoken country boys, the thirtyfour members of Louisiana State University's football squad, arrived last night for their game with Manhattan at Ebbets Field tomorrow. The Tigers apparently suffered no ill effects from their 1,500-mile journey from Baton Rouge and were all enthusiasm at their first glimpse of New York, whose attractions they immediately started to investigate.

Herbert Robinson, City College undergraduate, suspended last week by Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men, following an altercation with Professor Warren G. Hubert of the Mathematics Department, was reinstated by the faculty student discipline committee, it was learned yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 (AP). -The defense revealed today at the trial of Abraham L. Shushan for alleged Federal income tax evasions its endeavor to show that certain funds which the government charges flowed into the defendant's hands as "rebate or graft" from Orleans Levee Board contracts, actually were "political contributions."
PARIS, Oct. 10 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

DETROIT, Oct. 10. -- In a quarterly statement issued today, B. C. Schram, receiver of the First National Bank, reported that the earnings of the institution since its suspension in February, 1933, had exceeded the expense of the receivership by $9,139,372.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 10. -An appeal to the voters of Clinton County to vote for the re-election of Assemblyman McKenzie B. Stewart as the only way they can vote this year against the Roosevelt New Deal was made tonight by Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, and the members of the Republican Assembly Caravan at a well-attended meeting in the court house here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- New York City was placed in the forefront today of arrangements to put thousands of jobless actors to work as the WPA revealed the setting-up of the framework of a nation-wide arts organization to provide work relief not only in the threatre but also in painting and sculpture, music and literature through a $27,000,000 cultural program.

A design piracy controversy similar to that which marked the efforts of the former Dress Code Authority to include a provision against pirating of designs developed yesterday in the dress industry with the announcement by manufacturers of $4.75 dresses that they will not accept orders rubberstamped by retailers to the effect that the garments may be returned if they are "copies."

Forty-nine fellowships have been awarded to students from eighteen States for study at the Juilliard Graduate School of Music during the 1935-36 season, Ernest Hutcheson, dean of the school, announced yesterday.

Mademoiselle, a magazine for women, has leased offices in the RKO Building, Rockefeller Center, to which the publishing firm is moving from smaller quarters in 485 Madison Avenue. Other business leases reported yesterday included firms taking larger space.

Italy's arraignment before the world by the League of Nations is now complete. By the unanimous vote of the Council and by the decision of all but two or three members of the Assembly she has been declared guilty of resorting to war in violation of her own solemn agreement not to do so.

DIREDAWA, Ethiopia, Oct. 10. -Italy's invasion of Southern Ethiopia is still fighting for water rather than territory. The advance of General Rodolfo Graziani's European and native mechanized army through Ogaden Province continues slowly and methodically from well to well.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 10. -- American missionaries in Ethiopia remained at their posts today, ignoring advice from Washington that they leave.

More than $30,000 already has been pledged toward the goal of $111,770 which the Irvington House, an institution to care for children with heart disease, is seeking to establish in an intensive program of research for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease, it was announced last night.

International cooperation, to be inaugurated by the United States and Great Britain, in the gradual elimination of trade barriers toward ultimate free trade, was advocated by George Macaulay Booth, a British shipper and a director of the Bank of England, in an address before members and guests of the New York Bond Club at a luncheon yesterday at the Bankers' Club.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The governments report on this year's grain crop, issued today after the Board of Trade had ceased business, was in line with the trade's expectations and with the private figures given out earlier in the month, and therefore it attracted little attention from operators.

A better tone prevailed in the commodity markets yesterday, with most futures above the levels of the previous day. Wheat, rye, tin, hides and rubber were higher in the cash markets, while corn and silk declined.
ROME, Oct. 10. -- It may be doubted whether Italians were really convinced of the inevitability of sanctions until today.
BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- The Boerse was firmer today, although activity, as in most recent sessions, was rather limited.

Financial markets resumed their advance yesterday on a broad front. Stocks made their best gains since June. Wheat closed up almost a cent a bushel, while cotton was slightly lower. The bond market was irregularly higher.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- There is a possibility of the early inauguration of transatlantic air service between the United States and Europe as aircraft especially designed for it are nearing completion.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 10. -- After their unsuccessful effort to oust George S. Kemp and associates from control of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation here early today, minority holders of prior-preference stock informally prepared to force a special meeting of the prior-preference group to resume the battle of proxies.

The attorneys for Bruno Richard Hauptmann made plans yesterday to carry his appeal to the United States Supreme Court, while the prisoner observed his tenth wedding anniversary with a one-hour conversation with his wife in his death cell at Trenton, N.J.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Governor Hoffman predicted the sales tax would be repealed at the January session of the Legislature in a talk today to 200 members and guests of the Red Bank Rotary and Lions Clubs in the Elks Club here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Department store sales throughout the country reached in September their highest point in four years, the index of the Federal Reserve' Board showed today. The index, not adjusted to allow for seasonal variations, jumped from 62 per cent of the 1923-25 average in August to 86 per cent during September, the board announced.

VIENNA, Oct. 10. -- While the government controlled press naturally was filled today with plaudits for Austrian opposition at Geneva to sanctions against Italy, public opinion expressed surprise and disapproval.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 10. -John D. Rockefeller Sr. departed today for the Casements, his estate at Ormond Beach, Fla., varying slightly and unexpectedly the usual routine that marks his annual departure for the South from his estate here.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 10. -Navy's football squad put the finishing touches today on the celebration of the ninetieth anniversary of the founding of the United States Naval Academy.

The formation of a nation-wide committee on fair play in sports to oppose the participation of American athletes in the Olympic Games in Berlin next Spring was announced yesterday from headquarters of the new organization at 20 Vesey Street.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 10. -- Ten seconds before the game's close Stewart Iglehart smashed a fortyyard free hit between the opposition's goal posts to give the Vipers a 5-to-4 victory over The Nuts today in the twelve-goal division final of the Autumn Plates polo competition at the Meadow Brook Club.
GENEVA, Friday, Oct. 11. -- Great Britain put the first sanction on Italy early today, shutting off a speech intended by Il Duce's envoy at Geneva for the ears of America's radio audience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Liquidation of eighteen national bank receiverships was completed in September, J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today. This brought to 144 the number closed since Oct. 31, 1934. Dividends paid to unsecured depositors in these banks, exclusive of eleven banks which were restored to complete solvency, amounted to 61 cents on the dollar.

J. P. Morgan Co. sent yesterday to holders in this country of Dawes and Young Plan dollar loans and to the banks and dealers which participated under Morgan leadership in the flotation of those issues here an account of the latest offer of the German Government with respect to payments of interest on these bonds.

CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Fearing "close control of education by the government," Hamilton College let it be known today through the current issue of the publication Hamiltion Life that it had declined to accept financial aid for its students, offered by the new National Youth Administration.

Bunk clearings for the week ended on Wednesday increased 25 per cent from the corresponding week in 1934, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The total for the twenty-two leading cities in the United States was $5,025,048,000, against $4,021,619,000. For the preceding week, the advance was 37.1 per cent.

While this country and a few others "are still calm and collected, we can and should direct all our energies and efforts toward peace," former Governor Alfred E. Smith said last night. He spoke over a Columbia coast-to-coast network at 9:30 P.M.

"Howard Burton, 22, of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, attempted to load his shotgun with an oversized shell. The explosion blew out the breach of the gun and physicians fear Howard may lose the sight of one eye."

Music by Aaron Copland will feature the first of a series of five one-man concerts of contemporary American music tonight at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. Mr. Copland's music will include his piano variations, "As It Fell Upon a Day," "Symphonic Ode," "Three Songs," "Vitebsk" and "El Salon Mexico."

BUFFALO, Oct. 10. -- The sevenpoint program of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers was adopted as the major objective of the New York State congress at the session here today. The body pledged itself to work for the principles of the program in behalf of every child in the State.

District Attorney Dodge began an investigation yesterday of the charge made by Patrick E. Gorman, president of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workers of America, in a letter to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, that a confidential report by one of Mr. Dodge's aides on the results of an inquiry into alleged racketeering was in the files of a national labor headquarters in Chicago.

The private detective license of the Bergoff Detective Service, Inc., 551 Fifth Avenue, of which Pearl L. Bergoff, strike-breaker extraordinary, is president, was revoked yesterday by Miss Grace A. Reavy, Deputy Secretary of State and chief of the Division of Licenses of New York State.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 10. -Mrs. Harry C. Holloway was a luncheon hostess today at Tyringham in honor of Miss Betsey Paddock of Pittsfield, who is to be married here Saturday to Mrs. Holloway's son, George Allen Holloway.

Mr. and Mrs. Elon Huntington Hooker gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for Baron and Baroness Ino Dan of Tokyo, Japan. Among their other guests were Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, and Mrs. MacCracken; Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Barr, Mrs. Harold Coolidge, Miss Adelaide Ferry Hooker, Henry Goddard Leach and George Brownell.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Carrying forward its poll of American business on the trend of the New Deal, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today addressed questionnaires to its 1,500 constituent bodies, representing more than 750,000 firms and individuals.

The reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $106,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday in response to the continued influx of gold from foreign countries plus an excess of disbursements by the Treasury over its receipts, according to the weekly Federal Reserve report, published yesterday.

It is known that the virus of infantile paralysis enters by way of the nose and throat, passes on to the brain, lodges in the spinal cord and thus affects the nerves that control muscular movement. Human beings and monkeys that have recovered from the disease never contract it again because they set up antibodies that fight off new onslaughts of the virus.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The Austrian Ambassador to London, Georg Frankenstein, is a man of letters, art and music -- the sort of cultured gentleman whom the English associate with the Austria they know best. They have taken him to their hearts and make much of him as they did of an earlier Ambassador of a greater nation, Walter Hines Page of the United States.

The observance of Leiv Eiriksson Day as proclaimed by the President was a fit preface for the celebration of Columbus Day. It takes naught from the glory of COLUMBUS that half a thousand years before he came LEIV may have come "rowing up the "Charles in the sea-battered dragon "ships," as HERVEY ALLEN in "Earth Moods" has pictured him with his "golden bearded earls."

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- If the refusal of the Austrian and Hungarian Governments to support the League's economic boycott of Italy affords the Reich government occasion for gratification, such gratification is not receiving a demonstrative expression in official quarters, and authoritative comment on the procedure of the two Danube powers is wholly lacking.

The reorganization of the Paramount Publix Corporation, now Paramount Pictures, Inc., was marked by "collusion, fraud and conspiracy," Representative A. J. Sabath, chairman of the Congressional committee investigating real estate bond reorganizations, declared at yesterday's hearing in the Federal Building at 641 Washington Street.

Mixed trends marked trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with United States obligations closing slightly lower. Appreciable declines were registered in Italian issues. The total sales were $9,325,900, against $10,053,700 on the previous day.
Transactions announced yesterday indicated a continuance of the demand for dwellings and multifamily buildings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn. Operators were the leading traders.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The bulk of WPA projects approved by President Roosevelt for New York State, totaling $7,535,365, were made public today by the Division of Applications and Information.

HADDON HEIGHTS, N.J., Oct. 10. -- While a fire raged in a cellar of his home the Rev. George A. Palmer, pastor of the Haddon Heights Baptist Church and sponsor of a daily radio program over a Philadelphia station, continued his broadcast today, interspersing the program with a description of the fire and progress in fighting it.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 10. -Champion Milson o' Boy, handsome Irish setter owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York City and handled by Harry Hartnett of Harrison, N.Y., was named the best in show as the fifty-second annual dog show given by the Danbury Agricultural Society came to a close on the fair grounds today.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Low yields to the acre for many fields of late potatoes, beans and buckwheat in New York State are forecast in a State-Federal report issued tonight by the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets.
The appointment of W. O. Loomis. formerly secretary of the stock list committee, as an assistant secretary of the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday by Charles R. Gay. president.
Kuhn, Loeb Co., as fiscal agents have notified holders of city of Prague 7 1/2 per cent mortgage loan bonds of 1922, due in 1952, that $111,500 of the bonds has been drawn for redemption on Nov. 1.

In a final effort to complete its preparations for the invasion of the formidable Purdue eleven, the Fordham football squad staged one of the longest drills it has had at Fordham Field yesterday. The two teams will meet tomorrow in their intersectional contest at the Polo Grounds.

Public bequests totaling $902,553 were made in the will of Mrs. Margaret I. Howe, who died in Brooklyn on Jan. 8, 1935, it was disclosed yesterday when a transfer tax report on her estate was filed in Brooklyn. The report listed her net estate at $961,892, of which the bulk comprised stocks and bonds, amounting to $909,108.

Competition for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup for contract bridge teams of four will be held Nov. 6 to 12 at the Park Lane Hotel, it was announced yesterday by the cup committee, headed by Douglas W. Paige.

A collection of 1,500 fossil bones of small mammals of the paleocene age, about 50,000,000 years ago, have been brought from the Crazy Mountains in Montana to the American Museum of Natural History by Dr. George Gaylord Simpson, assistant curator of vertebrate palaeontology.

Issuing yesterday the best report for any half-year period in its history, the Collins Aikman Corporation and subsidiaries showed a net profit of $1,755,739 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges for the twenty-six weeks ended on Aug. 31.

ATHENS, Oct. 10. -- By a military coup d'etat today the republic was abolished in Greece and a monarchy instituted. Martial law was proclaimed; all communications, by telegraph and telephone with foreign countries were cut; public buildings were occupied by troops, and Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris was forced to resign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Electrochemists boasting about achieving temperatures of a few thousand degrees in electric furnaces were confronted today by an estimate that the interior temperature of ordinary stars is close to 2,000,000,000 degrees.

Issuing yesterday the best report for any half-year period in its history, the Collins Aikman Corporation and subsidiaries showed a net profit of $1,755,739 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges for the twenty-six weeks ended on Aug. 31.

ATHENS, Oct. 10. -- By a military coup d'etat today the republic was abolished in Greece and a monarchy instituted. Martial law was proclaimed; all communications, by telegraph and telephone with foreign countries were cut; public buildings were occupied by troops, and Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris was forced to resign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Conversations looking to a possible adjustment of German-American trade relations in order to avoid a rupture of unconditional mostfavored-nation treatment have been conducted with Secretary Hull and other State Department officials by Dr. Karl Ritter, chief of the economic section of the Berlin Foreign Office, but without any definite progress being made.

Appointment to the United Textile Industrial Committee for Exports has been accepted by the president of three important associations in the cotton goods field, Frank S. Bruyn, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, made known yesterday.

The continued flight of capital from Europe because of the threat of war was reflected yesterday in the engagement of another $16,928,000 of gold for shipment here and in renewed weakness in the pound sterling, following two days of resistance to the decline.

BOSTON, Friday, Oct. 11. -- The passenger liner City of Montgomery, bound from Boston to New York and Savannah, ran aground at midnight on Lovell's Island, near the Narrows, in the outer edge of Boston Harbor. Early today tugboats went to her assistance.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 10. -Celebrating its ninetieth anniversary today, the Naval Academy honored the fathers of the navy and of naval education in the United States, displayed to thousands of alumni and interested visitors many of the most precious relics of the old navy and illustrated the growth and development of naval training during the nearcentury of the academy's life.

The 443d anniversary of the discovery of America will be widely celebrated here tomorrow, Columbus Day. Patriotic societies, fraternal groups, civic associations, governmental officials and the public will unite to do honor to Christopher Columbus, the intrepid sailor who found the New World.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- How British sympathy lies in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict is demonstrated at reels in British movie houses. Pictures of Premier Mussolini, General Emilia de Bono and other Italians are greeted with boos and hisses, while there is fervent applause for Emperor Halle Selassie and the Ethiopians.

Sturdy of substance and in most respects of communicative vitality in performance, Otto Klemperer's second program for the PhilharmonicSymphony's new season, as played in Carnegie Hall last night, was definitely more interesting than his first, of the Thursday preceding.
BUDAPEST, Oct. 10. -- Premier Goemboes, addressing the constituent assembly of the government party's committee, explained today Hungary's support of Austrian opposition to sanctions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Holding that twenty-seven officials of various communications lines who had filed applications for permission of the commission to engage in their respective duties were not subject to the Communications Act of 1934, the Federal Communications Commission today dismissed the applicants on the ground that "they are not seeking to holding positions as officer or director in more than one carrier subject to the act."

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. (AP). -- Political ghosts of the "mauve decade" walked once more today as 79-yearold Oberlin M. Carter seized the first opportunity given him in thirty-seven years to present officially his charge that he was railroaded out of a promising army career by a corrupt court-martial.
TULSA, Okla., Oct. 10 (AP). -Funds of the Presbyterian Church Pension Board are at a pre-depression high, its members said today, due to advice from prominent lay members on stock market operations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). -Secretary of Agriculture Wallace said today that the anticipated 29,000,000bushel greater corn production, lifting the total to 2,213,319,000 bushels, and the 7,000,000bushel expected decrease in potato production would have no material effect on agricultural prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A combined wheat crop of 598,935,000 bushels this year, an increase of 4,320,000 from the estimate made for Sept. 1, was forecast today by the crop reporting board of the Department of Agriculture, based on reports supplied by agents as of Oct. 1.

Preparatory to his departure as Works Progress Administrator General Hugh S. Johnson announced yesterday that he hoped to have 200,000 unemployed at work before he leaves. Yesterday's figure stood at 185,000, a gain of 13,000 over last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Lehman Brothers of New York, today purchased a $2,756,000 bond issue of Newark, N.J., from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, paying $1,081.77 for each $1,000 face value of the bonds.

Columbia concluded its heavy work yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the renewal of its football rivalry with Rutgers here tomorrow. Coach Lou Little again turned loose the varsity eleven on the stalwart group of freshmen and, for the second day in succession, the big eleven found the going difficult.

Efforts to extort yesterday from James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, an admission that M. J. Meehan and other prominent traders had been interrogated by the SEC in connection with recent stock transactions proved futile.

Our present national policies, especially in fiscal and currency problems, have brought an increase in the cost of living and at the same time are depreciating the purchasing power of the income from trustee securities, such as make up the endowments of universities and other institutions, Herbert Hoover charged last night at an address at the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Partial identification of Mandeville W. Zenge as the man who ran away from the automobile in which Dr. Walter J. Bauer was found mutilated and dying July 31 in a South Side filling station was the opening evidence in the murder trial of the young Missouri carpenter today.

Mayor La Guardia was asked yesterday by a committee of pharmacists and dealers in drugs to postpone for one month public hearings on a proposed amendment to the Sanitary Code requiring an initial registration fee of $25 and an annual renewal fee of $10 for the sale of patent medicines.

"Sweet Mystery of Life is tonight's incoming guest at the Shubert, and if its title were complete it would add "Insurance." The comedy's authors are George Haight, Richard Malbaum and Michael Wallach; the producer is Herman Shumlin, stepping forth for the first time since "The Children's Hour."

Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title of actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30, 1934.

Columbia's oldest football rivalry will be renewed at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon at Baker Field when the Lions meet Rutgers University. It was the New Brunswick institution that introduced the Blue and White to football back in 1870 and their last meeting was in 1902.

Four New York Lutheran clergymen will speak at the third Lutheran World Convention at the Lutheran Church of St. Jean, 147 Rue de Grenelle, Paris, France, which begins tomorrow and continues a week. The delegates will represent 80,000,000 of that communion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Weakness in foreign markets, a forecast of rains in Argentina and general evening-up on the part of scattered longs on the Board of Trade here for the double holiday more than offset today any buying induced by war or inflation talk, except for a brief period early.

Sales and leases over a wide area were reported yesterday. In Manhattan the activity extended from the downtown section to Harlem and the Dyckman Street district. Scattering deals were closed in the Bronx and Brooklyn.

Acquisition of an additional 392 acres of land in the Flushing Meadows, Queens, to provide an adequate site for the 1939-40 World's Fair was urged on the Board of Estimate yesterday by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner.

Attention was called a few days ago to the fate of the jobless homeless, hopeless "transients." Citizens at large of the country, they have no permanent abiding place anywhere within it. During the last few years they have been provided for by the Federal allowances made to the States and through them to the localities.

Two indictments were reported to have been voted yesterday by the New York County grand jury against John J. Kemp, insurance broker with a theatrical clientele, charging the theft from Donald Brian, actor, and Clarence (Little Billy) Bliss, midget performer, of money obtained on insurance policies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- The Treasury said today that Elaine Barrie, 19-year-old admirer of John Barrymore, had paid the government $3,200 for failing to declare a diamond ring she brought into this country after a trip to Cuba on the actor's yacht.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11. -- Fair weather tomorrow will help attract a crowd of 45,000 to the Harvard-Holy Cross game. Scheduled each season almost since the World War, the battle will be the last in the Stadium for several years.

"Barbary Coast," a Samuel Goldwyn production of the goldrush era of old San Francisco, opens this morning at the Rivoli. Miriam Hopkins, Edward G. Robinson and Joel McCrea appear in the principal roles.

Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, accused Democratic members of the Board yesterday of urging a 50 per cent reduction in water rates for political reasons on the eve of elections next Month.

GENEVA, Oct. 11. -- With "Proposal No. 1" the League of Nations began this afternoon applying sanctions against the Italian Government. This sanction, number one in history, applies to Italy alone precisely the same arms embargo the United States proclaimed against both Italy and Ethiopia, except to add powder and explosives to the list President Roosevelt gave.

The second bill of the De Basil Ballet Russe season at the Metropolitan Opera House was presented last night, with variety as its outstanding characteristic. It consisted of the compositions of three choreographers whose styles are as widely different as the locales in which these particular ballets are set.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- King George II of Greece was officially informed today by Charalambos Simopoulos, Greek Minister to London, that his throne had been restored to him. On instructions from his government the Minister called this afternoon on George II at his London hotel to acquaint him with the resolutions adopted by the Greek Parliament and at the same time to present to him the respects of the Greek Government.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- For the first time since 1889, a Yale University eleven will meet Pennsylvania on Philadelphia soil when the two old-time rivals clash at Franklin Field tomorrow.

Members of the Sabath Congressional committee investigating reorganizations of defaulted bond issues freely criticized Federal judges yesterday for the way in which they have handled large bankruptcies and reorganizations, charging the judges favored the large financial interests and ignored the small bondholders.

A tentative agreement between the city's negotiators for transit unification and those representing the various security interests of the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company failed to materialize yesterday when City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. was unable to come to terms with spokesmen for two committees of holders of Interborough 6 per cent unsecured notes.

Steady improvement in retail distribution was the most significant feature of the trend of business this week, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. With ideal shopping weather prevailing in most districts, the agency states, sales increased as much as 5 to 15 per cent as compared with the previous week and were 6 to 12 per cent over the totals for the corresponding period last year.

The text of the resolution adopted by the committee of fifty of the League of Nations regarding arms embargoes against Italy and the lifting of such embargoes against Ethiopia was received here yesterday from the League wireless station at Geneva. It follows:
Registration for the November election fell off somewhat yesterday. In the course of the day and evening 236,810 persons registered, bringing the total for the first four days up to 901,367.

A temporary injunction which had restrained the American Hide and Leather Company from consummating a reorganization plan that involved the reduction of its capital structure from $11,115,000 to $6,115,000 was vacated yesterday by Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder in Chancery Court, Jersey City, following announcements by counsel for the company and the complainant that the differences had been settled.

Striking with sudden success early in the second half after being on the defensive for the most part of the first two quarters, the Hill School football team of Pottstown, Pa., registered a 7-to-0 triumph over Poly Prep yesterday on the latter's field in Brooklyn in the fourth annual game between the schools.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 11. -- With news of the bombardment yesterday of Gorahai, Tafere Katama and Helabo, it is evident that the Italian southern offensive has begun in earnest. The Ethiopians, however, deny that Gorahai has fallen, saying a message from the radio station there was received yesterday afternoon.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Jack Sabol, pro at the Westchester Hills Country Club in White Plains, figured prominently in both morning and afternoon rounds of the Westchester P.G.A. one-day tournament over the links of the Mount Vernon Country Club today.

Steamship men who have been looking ahead to the Winter cruise program to European ports are anxious about the effect of the Italo-Ethiopian war on American travel to Europe, and particularly over the fate of an unusually large Mediterranean program of six cruises planned at great expense for January and February.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- An impression prevails here that, despite the speed Geneva is unexpectedly manifesting in providing for sanctions against Italy and help for Ethiopia, it will be some time before either can come into effect.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Connecticut Power and Light Company of Hartford became today the first utility company to apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission for exemption from the terms of the Public Utility Act of 1935, passed in the last Congress after a bitter fight.

The body of a gangster, the latest victim of the long-raging gang war in Brownsville, Brooklyn, was found at 9:15 o'clock last night in a large, new trunk lying on the cobblestones twenty-five feet from the East River waterfront at Roosevelt and South Streets, directly under the Brooklyn Bridge.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced here today that he was in Europe on a special mission from President Roosevelt to make an economic investigation.
ALBRIGHT vs. Lafayette -- No electioneering within 100 yards of the polling booth, by order of the Sheriff. Stand back, men! One fluttering vote for Lafayette.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 11.Dr. and Mrs. Harold Willis Dodds were hosts to the 630 members of the freshman class of Princeton University and 178 feminine guests from New York, Philadelphia and New Jersey at the annual freshman reception this afternoon at Prospect, their home.

Plans of three Brooklyn structures to house a total of 125 families, at an estimated cost of $367,000, were filed yesterday. A $1,200,000 public school project for the borough also was submitted. The Queens filings included a $150,000 parochial school and $45,000 rectory for Flushing, a $500,000 public school for Long Island City and a $49,000 group of dwellings in Hollis.
May I as assistant to Dr. Euler of the Adult Education Project submit some facts about our work for the information of the taxpayers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Louis McHenry Howe, explaining that he spoke not as the secretary to President Roosevelt but as one connected with Democratic headquarters in the last four elections, did a little guessing today on the 1936 campaign from his room in the Naval Hospital.

ROME, Oct. 11. -- The war bulletin which is issued in Rome every day by the Ministry of Press and Propaganda contained three statements today that are regarded by Italians as highly important for any one wishing to form a clear idea of the way in which operations in East Africa are likely to develop.
Apartments were rented in large numbers yesterday on the East Side. Suites in Park Avenue houses proved especially attractive to families seeking new living quarters for Fall occupancy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Bids for the largest merchant vessel ever constructed in this country have been invited by the United States Lines for a ship to take the place of the Leviathan as a sister ship to the Manhattan and Washington. The bids were asked, Secretary Roper said, in conformity with an order issued by the Department of Commerce on Sept. 14.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 11. -- After six months of diversified observance of Connecticut's 300th birthday, including pageants, parades and expositions in every one of the 169 towns, the State Tercentenary Commission moved into Hartford today for the final exercises of the celebration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The government will begin tomorrow the construction near Berwyn Heights, Md., in the suburban area of Washington, of a modern low-cost housing town, a community of cottages and apartment houses, with all modern conveniences.
An alleged hold-up man who keeps his money on deposit in banks, and a Bowery sporting goods store owner were arrested yesterday.

Speaking of sudden death, there are other causes besides drink and recklessness. Just above Woodlawn, the Bronx River Parkway forks out into one-way drives before it tops a hill. There is no sign, or at least there has not been for weeks, to indicate that the left fork is a one-way road.
P.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade condition and wholesale prices in New York.

On the eve of another hunting season, gunners of New York State are concentrating on such important preliminary chores as the inspection of their firearms, clothing and equipment, and careful perusal of the syllabus of laws issued by the Conservation Department.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 11. -- After three days' debate the House of Representatives defeated today by a vote of 27 to 21 the Lang Labor party's resolution expressing "unflinching determination not to allow Australia to become involved in a second world war developing out of a conflict of imperial trading interests, notwithstanding any decision recorded by the League of Nations."
GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Pickets, many armed with clubs, patrolled Texas and Louisiana waterfronts tonight in a walkout of 3,000 longshoremen. There were scattered reports of violence.

A crew of Water Department sewer swabbers, accustomed to such petty prizes as rubber balls and odd dimes, quivered with excitement when they scooped up a jimmied strong-box packed with handsomely engraved bonds and other documents yesterday in a sewer at Park Avenue and 109th Street.

The New York University varsity football team will play its second game of the season today when it meets the Carnegie Tech eleven at the Yankee Stadium. This will be the tenth meeting between the two elevens, and a crowd of 20,000 is expected to be present.

Although earning assets (securities and loans) in the banks of this country are about $13,000,000,000 less than in 1929, the average held by each bank is $607,812 higher than in 1929, according to the final 1935 edition of the Rand McNally Bankers Directory, just published.

A warning was given to bird and animal lovers by the Humane Society of New York yesterday that a poison had been spread on the ground in Central Park in the vicinity of Eightieth Street and Fifth Avenue, causing the death of at least twelve pigeons.

SWATOW, China, Saturday, Oct. 12. -- With Japanese cruisers and a destroyer squadron stubbornly remaining in Swatow harbor and with Chinese armies reported to be feverishly entrenching on a stretch of more than fifty miles, from Swatow northward to the city of Ungking, near the Fukien border, the Chino-Japanese dispute in the Far Southeast is approaching a crisis.

DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 11. -- The Ford Motor Company has not aided two relatives of Henry Ford seeking the office of Mayor and has given its active support to John L. Carey, a manufacturer of automobile accessories.

With the future football fate of Manhattan more or less hanging in the balance, a Jasper eleven which stormed impressively through three preliminary games will risk its undefeated record against mighty Louisiana State at Ebbets Field today at 2:30 o'clock.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 11. -- Matthew Woll, chairman of the Chest for the Liberation of Workers of Europe, formed to assist victims of Nazism and Fascism in Germany, Austria and Italy, told the American Federation of Labor convention today that unpublished reports just brought to this country by a member of his committee indicated that persecution of trade union leaders was increasing.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Scoring a sparkling 67, T. Suffern Tailer Jr. of Piping Rock and Joseph J. Dowling of the home club today captured the top honors in the qualifying round of the annual best-ball invitation tournament over the Meadow Brook links.

Responding chiefly to domestic trends, industrial and public utility stocks were bought heavily in active trading yesterday, while the railroad issues were in supply throughout the day. Speculative enthusiasm, coupled with investment buying, carried the security markets upward, while wheat and cotton declined.

PONTIAC, Mich., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Ferrin Rowland hanged himself with an improvised rope in his cell here today a few minutes before he was to have been arraigned for the confessed murder of his two small stepdaughters, and six hours afterward authorities at Harrison, Mich., announced that his wife had admitted complicity in the plot to kill her children, who were born of a previous marriage.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES IN NORTHERN ETHIOPIA, Oct. 10 (Delayed in Transmission). -- A slight advance has been made on the southern front from Somaliland, the Italian field headquarters announced today, "in order to rectify the frontier."

Influenced by improved weather, absence of the threatened frost and a dock strike at several ports on the Gulf of Mexico, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased 6 to 10 points yesterday and closed at the bottom.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 11. -- With a 98-cent nickel-plated watch in his pocket and large assortment of socks in his bag to choose from for his audience with the Emperor of Japan, Vice President Garner passed through this city today en route from his home in Uvalde, Texas, to Seattle, where he will sail Wednesday for the Orient aboard the liner President Grant. Mrs. Garner accompanied him.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 11. -- Shackled to detectives, Glenn Brasser, 22, former choir boy, was brought back here tonight as the confessed slayer of Miss Muriel Hall, 18 years old, who spurned his love.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Members of the faculty and student body of Nassau College-Hofstra Memorial have an opportunity to help in the "much-needed recasting" of liberal education in this country, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, declared this afternoon at exercises dedicating the institution.

The business community launched a movement to provide jobs on private payrolls yesterday at a conference of trade association representatives with General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for New York City.
Governor Hoffman's proposal of an amendment to permit the Supreme Court to render advisory opinions on laws passed by the Congress is open to several objections.

The New York Stock Exchange and other security and commodity markets throughout the United States, together with the banks, will be closed today in observance of Columbus Day. All Canadian markets will be open for trading.

BURTON J. HENDRICK'S "The Lees of Virginia" (Little, Brown, $3.75) illuminates the history of 200 years. The material dealt with in this biography of a family is extremely rich and complex. But the book is an artful triumph of hidden short-cuts. With the stories of whole generations of Lees to be told, Mr. Hendrick has accomplished his task within the limits of a medium-sized volume and without either hurry or skimping.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The government's new Consumers Division, the mission of which is to assist the administration in getting the buying public "more for its money," announced today the appointment of a "consumers' cabinet."

The State of New Jersey made yesterday the moves necessary to bring about a new sentence of death for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted of having kidnapped and murdered the son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

Baron Pompeo Aloisi, Italy's chief delegate to the League of Nations Council, whose scheduled broadcast to the United States Thursday night was canceled because of British refusal of radio facilities, has been invited to speak via other sources, it was announced by the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday.

ADOWA, Oct. 11 (Reuters). -- The chief problem confronting the Italians at the moment is one of communications. A vivid impression of their difficulties was obtained by following the line of advance of the central column of the Italian army that took Adowa.

Broadway will fling itself into the Imperial Theatre tonight for them city's first look at "Jubilee," a history of a mythical kingdom. That is the show written by Cole Porter and Moss Hart, as they went around the world last Winter, taking pictures of themselves and the Fiji Islanders.

A bid for the services of Joe Louis was made by the Madison Square Garden Corporation yesterday. James J. Johnston, in charge of boxing at the Eighth Avenue arena, telegraphed John Roxborough in Detroit and Julian Black in Chicago, offering the Brown Bomber a chance in June at the world's heavyweight championship held by James J. Braddock.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- With one of the most sensational forward and lateral passing plays seen in Philadelphia in many years, Temple University kept its record clean tonight by defeating Vanderbilt University in a driving rainstorm at the Owls' stadium, 6 to 3.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Unemployment in Europe, "both relatively and absolutely," is considerably lower than in the United States, according to B. Charney Vladeck, a member of the New York City Housing Authority, who addressed the opening session tonight of a two-day meeting of the Labor Housing Forum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Fees aggregating $80,250 were received by members of the Bondholders Protective Committee for Republic of El Salvador, from March 1, 1932, to March 1, 1935, according to evidence submitted today by Irving B.
