Brunstrom, an examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission at the hearing concerning the $7,000,000 of defaulted bonds of the republic.

ATHENS, Oct. 11. -- King George and all the scattered members of his many-branched family became Greek citizens today under a Cabinet decree issued by Regent Kondylis. The repatriation of the banished sovereign was the first act of the new Cabinet, which flouted President Zaimis during the night by taking individual oaths to "guard the fatherland and perform their duty in the name of the blessed Trinity."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Special funds have been allocated to the Federal Power Commission to continue the power and rate surveys that will give it information for carrying out the long-controverted Utilities Act.

The sense of futility of a single voice protesting against a manifest wrong being perpetrated by a selfish group almost stills this writer in advance. How many cries of "No!" have so diminished to uneasy waiting helplessness!

Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn, usually a stanch supporter of Mayor La Guardia, swung away from him yesterday and voted against a Board of Estimate resolution which would give preference to American manufacturers of supplies bought by the city.
BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- The Boerse was slightly weaker and relatively inactive today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The United States will not follow the lead of the League of Nations and lift its arms embargo against Ethiopia because it is held that President Roosevelt has no power to discriminate in this respect between the belligerents.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Oct. 11. -- The movement of Italian troops and workmen through the Suez Canal for the present campaign now exceeds 200,000.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 11. -- Major Gen. Rensuke Isogaye, Japanese Military Attache in China, today challenged the beneficial effects of the financial mission which the British Government sent to Shanghai under the leadership of Sir Frederick Leith-Rose.
Governor Philip La Follette of Wisconsin is sailing today on the American Legion of the Munson Line to join his brother, Senator Robert La Follette. Both will return to New York on Oct. 24.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 11. -- Dorothy Gish, stage and screen actress, and Vaughn de Leath, known as the original woman radio singer, obtained divorces here today. Miss Gish, suing under her full name of Dorothy Elizabeth Gish Rennie, charged James R. Rennie, New York actor, with intolerable cruelty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today announced the final sale of thirty-two out of the thirty-five municipal bond issues upon which it received bids yesterday. A premium of $724,236.61 was realized by the RFC on the thirty-two sales, which involved bonds with a face value of $5,447,500.

After an extended hearing yesterday, Supreme Court Justice Valente rejected the bid of $8,000,000 made by Nasurco, Inc. as well as all other bids for stock of the National Surety Corporation which was organized to take over the insurance business of the Old National Surety Company when the latter was put into liquidation in 1933 by the State Insurance Department.

New bond financing this week again dropped well below the average for the year to date with a total of $19,740,000 placed on the market. This compares with $15,637,000 in new offerings made last week, and with only $5,440,000 appearing in the corresponding week a year ago.

The refusal of the trustees of Hamilton College to authorize the acceptance of financial aid from the Government deserved a better comment than it had at the hands of the "Administration spokesman." It is distinctly not "the loss" of an independent private institution to meet its obligations out of its private resources, which Hamilton College has found itself able to do.

Any one who has inadvertently encountered a life insurance agent will relish the knockabout humors of "Sweet Mystery of Life," which was put on at the Shubert last evening. The authors, who come in triplicate, like official insurance receipts, are Richard Maibaum, Michael Wallach and George Height.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- The action of a special committee which investigated and supported the dismissal of Lienhard Bergel, an instructor in German at the New Jersey College for Women here, was upheld today by the board of trustees of Rutgers University, of which the women's college is a unit.

Good citizens everywhere will endeavor to observe Columbus Day in the spirit of President ROOSEVELT'S neutrality proclamation. Our duty goes beyond refusing to engage passage on Ethiopian or Italian ships.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of the Baltusrol Golf Club, a semi-finalist the past two years in New Jersey State Women's championships, led a field of seventy-five in a one-day tourney at the Essex County Country Club today with an 88.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 11. -- The October grand jury, sworn in at 10:30 o'clock this morning, filed this afternoon indictments charging Everett Applegate and Mrs. Mary Creighton with murder in the first degree in the death from arsenic poisoning of Applegate's wife, Ada.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- After repeated failures, another attempt is being made by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to obtain the entire output of Russian oil products in the export markets of the world.

The Mayor has recently launched an anti-noise campaign about which many things have been said, some in earnest endorsement, but many of them facetious. The published articles cover all parts of the city and mention every kind of noise from auto horns, jazz, fire sirens and cats and drunken singers, but nowhere have I seen a word about the heavy trucks that still come down Broadway in the night.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 11 (AP). -- A driving back field that twice went across for touchdowns and a line that held when the opposition threatened gave Marquette University a 14-to-0 victory over Kansas State tonight before a crowd of 12,000.

Any one who started out at the beginning of this passing week with the intention of catching every transpiring "event" on the nocturnal call-board -- and did -- should be bodering upon collapse this grayish morning. For the past week was fairly loaded with flashy first-night affairs.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty-two municipalities totals $12,507,902. This compares with $14,452,766 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date stands at $24,980,716.

BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- The Reich Brotherhood Council of Confessional Synods closed its Berlin meetting today without being able to adopt any definite policy toward the offer of Hanns Kerrl, Minister of Church Affairs, to appoint a church directorate with a representation of opposition church pastors.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11. -- Holding to a slight lead in a stirring stretch drive over a slippery track, J.W.Y. Martin's Luckite, the favorite, won the International Gold Cup at the Rolling Rock Country Club today. A stumble at the last jump nearly cost him the honors.

The discovery by radio of a hitherto unknown and still inexplicable cosmic phenomenon is reported in the current issue of Science, official publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Prince Charming II, the famous bay gelding now owned by Mrs. Lewis L. Breden of Grossepointe, Mich., romped off with the blue in the lightweight hunters' class, the featured event on the opening day's program of the fifteenth annual Orange Horse Show today on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- The cost of the "dole," which the government is struggling to abandon still amounts to millions of dollars each month.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- As expected, Parliament will reassemble Oct. 22, a week earlier than the day set when it adjourned in August. An announcement to that effect was issued at 10 Downing Street today. The official explanation is that "the government consider that the public interest requires it."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 11. -- Unverified reports that Ethiopian warriors had swept down on Adowa under cover of darkness, recapturing that historic battle site and seizing Italian cannon, arms and ammunition, reached this capital today.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt suffered another defeat yesterday in her long fight to gain complete custody of her 11-year-old daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt. The Appellate Division unanimously refused permission to Mrs. Vanderbilt to appeal to the Court of Appeals from rulings giving custody of the child to her paternal aunt, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney.

Plans for the Winter dinghy racing on Long Island Sound had materialized yesterday to the extent that forty Class B one-design sailing craft, designated as the B-O boats, were assured for competition. There will be eighteen at Larchmont, twelve at Indian Harbor, Greenwich, and ten at Manhasset Bay.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 11. -- With the football eyes of the nation focused on Nebraska's capital city, the University of Minnesota's 1934 national champions and the Cornhuskers of Nebraska will meet in Memorial Stadium tomorrow before a capacity crowd of 35,000 fans.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11. -- Governor Martin L. Davey pictured football today as "the supreme purpose of higher education" and declared that most of the Ohio State University gridiron squad is on the State payroll.

The Appellate Division affirmed unanimously yesterday the recent decision by Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore, enjoining the city from submitting to the voters in the coming election a referendum on Mayor La Guardia's proposed municipal "yardstick" power plant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Registration statements for new security issues involving $33,600,000, of series about $2,000,000 is for purposes other than refunding, were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two utility companies.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 11. -- Whether the League of Nations had sounded Brazil out in to regard sanctions against Italy could not be learned today, but diplomatic groups believed that the League would strive to the utmost to win Brazil, called during the World War, the world's granary.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 11. -President Angell criticized in his speech tonight what he termed oppressive taxation "invoked to finance grandiose programs of social reform." He charged also that "reasonable individual liberty is gravely and repeatedly invaded."

With twenty-one entered for the $93,400 Futurity, to be run this afternoon at Belmont Park, interest waxes hotter than ever in this forty-six-year-old classic which usually decides the juvenile championship. The largest crowd of the season is expected to turn out for the closing-day program of seven races, featured by three stakes, of which The Futurity is the richest and the greatest.

Federal Judge John Knight of Buffalo, who is sitting in this district temporarily, reproached a jury when it reported yesterday that although it had been deliberating since noon last Thursday it was still unable to arrive at a verdict in the Atlas Tack mail fraud case.

Despite continued weaknes in some of the rails, the bond market maintained a firm undertone in trading yesterday and prices moved forward with advances scattered throughout the list. Sales amounted to $10,086,100, as compared with $9,325,900 on Thursday.
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were generally firm today, with buying of tin and copper shares heavy, although armament issues were less active.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 11 (By Wireless). -- "The Italians have gassed our troops around Gorahai and I doubt that we can continue to offer resistance to such warfare successfully."

Mayor La Guardia's arbitrary cut of the tax reserve fund in his executive budget for 1936 from the $17,000,000 called for in the bankers' agreement to $10,500,000 would, if approved by the Board of Estimate, create the danger of a shortage of city funds next year, it was learned yesterday.

MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Irving M. Ives, minority leader, heading the Republican Assembly caravan, split his forces tonight and sent speakers to eight meetings in Franklin County to urge the reelection of Assemblyman John H. Black of Tupper Lake.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 11. -- The four-day light-harness meeting in connection with the Danbury Fair came to a close this afternoon, with three events carded.

Trading was at a slackened pace in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Closing prices were mixed. The grains, coffee and cotton were lower in the cash markets and cocoa, silk and tin moved up, the latter to a new high level for the year.

The recently announced WPA theatre project will be started here about Nov. 1, with thousands of unemployed theatrical workers, the majority of whom are now on relief rolls, placed in "dignified, professional jobs," Elmer Rice, playwright and head of the New York City program, said yesterday in an interview at TERA headquarters, 69 Madison Avenue.

Engagements reported yesterday of $20,167,000 more gold abroad for shipment here reflected the continued flight of capital from Europe, moved by the threat of war. Except for the lira, however, the foreign exchanges were quiet and firm.

Mayor LA GUARDIA'S plan to submit to a referendum next month a bill to construct a city power plant got a second judicial blow yesterday. Previously Supreme Court Justice DORE had decided that the local law proposed was invalid because it was in direct conflict with the recent State legislation on the same subject.

The Alias Corporation and the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers have purchased a part of the Radio Corporation of America's controlling interest in the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation and have an option to buy the remainder of the holdings, it was announced jointly yesterday by David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation, and Floyd Odlum, president of Atlas.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 11. -- Alvin (Butch) Krueger, semi-pro baseball pitcher of Beloit, Wis., knocked three strokes off par on the second nine today for a 33 and an eighteen-hole total of 67 to tie with Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., at the end of the first eighteen holes of the Louisville open championship.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Ellis Knowles of Apawamis was re-elected president of the Westchester County Golf Association at the annual meeting held at the Bonnie Briar Country Club tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Declaring that it was unable to obtain funds from any other source, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $5,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with which to meet tax payments in several States and municipalities, and to pay instalments of principal on equipment trust certificates falling due during the remainder of the present year.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Delegates from thirty States, meeting here today in the first session of an interstate conference on crime, unanimously adopted a resolution to establish an Interstate Crime Commission to be composed of one member from each of the forty-eight States.

The Conference on Port Development of the City of New York yesterday announced plans for a meeting of exporters, shippers, manufacturers and other groups next Friday to consider the neutrality proclamation of President Roosevelt.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- About $8,000,000. representing the share turned over to localities from alcoholic beverage taxes collected by the late for the quarter ended Sept. 30, has been distributed, State Controller Morris S. Tremaine announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP). -- William Leinnert, taxi driver, took the spotlight today in the trial of Mandeville W. Zenge for the mutilation slaying of Dr. Walter J. Bauer with his story of hearing the defendant admit the crime.

Early United States coins brought spirited bidding at the sale of the Richard De Silva Santos and other collections at the J.C. Morgenthau Galleries, 1 West Forty-seventh Street. For a brilliant proof specimen of the $4 gold coin popularly known as the "Stella" 1879, $127.50 was paid.

Football in the scholastic ranks today settles down to a month of abundant and widespread activity. More than 100 high school games are carded in the metropolitan district and there will be numerous others involving Eastern prep school elevens.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Don Manuel tripped home in front with a nose to spare over Midshipman in the Great Waltz, mile and 70-yard principal offering today at Suffolk Downs before an estimated crowd of 15,000.
Quotations for day loans, maturity reduced from 2 per cent, in effect money and business paper were since Oct. 20, 1933. unchanged. Business was small in Bankers* Acceptances. m. ll departments.

COCOS ISLAND, Oct. 11. -- The visit by President Roosevelt has been the greatest adventure yet achieved by the British treasure hunters who have been searching for pirate gold on this island for more than four months.

By 1939 New York City will be in much better shape to handle the automobile traffic attracted by a World's Fair than it would have been even a decade ago. Consider first the important new facilities already available: the Holland Tunnel, the George Washington Bridge, the West Side Motor Highway and the three Staten Island bridges.

With the Mayor's anti-noise drive so well on its way and the resultant benefits so generally apparent, hope for the permanent establishment of a condition that is really a blessing to so many is assured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Treasury's last bond refunding until 1940 closed at midnight tonight when the conversion offer on $1,250,000,000 of 4 1/4 per cent Fourth Liberty loan bonds, called for Oct. 15, expired.

The pianists' season had a serious beginning at the Town Hall last night, when Willard MacGregor, Boston-born and a pupil of Artur Schnabel and Isidor Philipp, gave his first New York recital after considerable playing abroad. Earnestness was a cardinal characteristic of Mr. MacGregor's approach to a weighty list of Schumann, Bach, Bach-Liszt and Beethoven compositions, lightened only at the close by a group that bracketed Schubert with Chopin.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- With thirteen cruising craft entered, the New Rochelle Yacht Club tonight started its annual Fall distance race around Stratford Shoal and over to Northport, L.I. The turning point is the lighthouse known as Middle Ground, out in Long Island Sound, east of Bridgeport, Conn.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the New York County racket investigation, made five appointments yesterday, rounding out his staff. Three will serve on salary. They are Sewell T. Tyng, 40 year old; Charles P. Grimes, 31, and Jacob Grumet, 35.

Mr. FRANK C. WALKER, director of the National Emergency Council, is close enough to the inner councils of the Roosevelt Administration to warrant special interest in his remarks, made in the course of an address this week, on the chief problem with which the Administration is confronted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Government officials read with deep interest today the letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, commenting on the neutrality policy of the government. They expressed pleasure over its nonpartisan tone and what they construed as an endorsement of policies thus far adopted.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Declines in business in several Latin-American countries were reported today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey of conditions abroad.

With general expectations that consumer response to merchandise offerings on the holiday today will be notably favorable, retail trade in the metropolitan area made substantial gains during the week. An average increase of 10 per cent over a year ago was estimated for leading department stores here, with several stores running well ahead of this figure.
So much having been told of Francis Wilson the actor, the author, the man, would it not be fitting for one who knew and loved him in his later years to write of Francis Wilson the friend?

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 11 (AP). -- After several Nashville citizens had supported the testimony of Thomas H. Robinson Sr. and Mrs. Frances A. Robinson that they played no part in the $50,000 Stoll kidnapping, both the defense and the government rested in Federal court late today.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Oct. 11. -- The joint Anglo-Egyptian naval and military parade through Alexandria today proved a most popular event.

Net profit of the General Baking Company for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Sept. 28 was announced yesterday as $1,383,910 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on 87,883 shares of $8 preferred stock, the profit is equivalent to 54 cents a share on 1,588,697 shares of $5 par common stock.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- With one of the strongest Williams teams of recent years as its opponent, the Princeton eleven will attempt to win its second encounter of the year in Palmer Stadium tomorrow. The kick-off is scheduled for 2:30.

The Holland-America liner Volendam docked at Fifth Street, Hoboken, yesterday with 450 passengers and members of the crew who were on the liner Rotterdam when it went aground on a clear night a week ago Monday. The Rotterdam, which struck Morent Cays as she was steaming for Kingston, Jamaica, sailed from Kingston yesterday for New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Moves to punish brokers for alleged market rigging were taken for the first time by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

PARIS, Oct. 11. -- Queen Mother Marie of Yugoslavia has dropped her complaint against the three men held in Marseilles as accomplices of the assassin of her husband, King Alexander. This announcement, made there today by Joseph Paul-Boncour, lawyer for Marie, means that the case will be prosecuted by the French Government alone.

In the widespread group of games of major importance in this weekend of football, the City of New York finds itself with a set of contests that holds as much promise of keen action as any other centre.
Seventeen city officials notified Mayor La Guardia yesterday that they had complied with his order against political activity by appointive members of the Fusion administration.

Looking as fit and as hardy as their sobriquet implies, the Boilermakers of Purdue University arrived in New York yesterday ready and eager for their gridiron battle with Fordham at the Polo Grounds today.

VIENNA, Oct. 11. -- Public order in Greece following the Royalist coup d'etat yesterday remained undisturbed today. The strictest censorship of messages sent abroad was maintained, and all messages published abroad should be read in this light.

A year ago last September Germany put into effect her "new policy," which gave the Government absolute control of the volume of imports by setting up twenty-five control boards and requiring importers to secure "exchange certificates" for everything they brought in.
THE big season is on again and coaches are grooming their favorites to kick a goal. And smart girls are grooming themselves to make a hit at the big games.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- Sea Rig, owned by John Strawbridge, won the Pennsylvania Hunt Cup, feature event at the Whitemarsh Hunt Club's fall meeting today before a large crowd, defeating Coq Bruyere by three-quarters of a length.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 12. -- Alvin (Butch) Krueger, Beloit, Wis., semi-pro baseball player, beat par by three strokes on the second nine today to card a 33, and turned in an 18-hole total of 69 to nose out Paul Runyan, national P.G.A. champion, for the lead in the $5,000 Louisville open golf tournament.

An analysis of the geographical distribution of stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation shows that stock owned abroad is about one-third of the foreign holdings when the World War started in 1914. The figures are of interest to Wall Street because if the war in Africa should spread to Europe, the selling of European investments in this market would be stimulated, as it was in 1914.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- An experiment in the broad field of financial ethics has been proposed by J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency. He has circularized all national bankers outlining fourteen points, many of them frankly idealistic in trend, designed to make of banking a profession.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- All was quiet on the milk strike front today as striking dairy farmers and city dealers remained deadlocked on the price issue.

THE middle of October finds Paris becoming animated again. In the brilliant Fall season, racing, the theatres, opera and the art shows are drawing the vacationists back from the beaches and mountains. For the racegoers the feature event is the Prix du Conseil Municipal, to be run at Longchamps on Oct. 20.

BARCELONA. -- The Catalan revolution, the first anniversary of which occurred on Oct. 6, is revealed in a new light by a book just published from the pen of Manuel Azana, the former Prime Minister of Spain. The book is a recital of his own political odyssey since leaving the Ministry in September, 1933, and deals ruthlessly with the manoeuvres and seeming intrigues of those whom he considers the republic's enemies -- and his own.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 12. -- Dartmouth's entire football squad of forty-one players took part in a 59-to-7 rout of Bates today, the visitors not being able to muster any opposition at any stage of the game.

WAR has a curious uneventfulness when it has been waged for a long time. Young Andromache, Hector's 15-year-old bride, saw little of it when she came to Ilion, the marvelous city with paved streets, and the luxurious long-house of old King Priam, who added a new wife to his harem every year.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 12. -- Dixie Howell's University of Mexico football team took a decisive beating from Lamar College of Beaumont, Texas, in the first international game of the season today. The score was 32 -- 0. The University of Mexico threatened in the first quarter, but after that it was almost all Lamar.
A trout is a smart fish. Any fly fisherman can attest to that.

FOR the gardener who cares particularly for wild flowers there can be no more thrilling discovery than a colony of Silene (pennsylvanica caroliniana), the Wild-pink or Peat-pink. Here is a real find, for not only is this flower lovely in its natural setting but, with careful transplanting, it will settle down contentedly in the home garden.

OMAHA, Oct. 10. -- With the cornhog referendum only two weeks away, the campaign to get out the vote passed from the stage of State and regional instruction meetings and "pep talks" for workers to county and township rallies for the farmers.

DUBLIN. -- Control of the dance in the Irish Free State has become more than a minor problem. It is generally conceded that in the rural areas the tune has been altogether too merry a one. The government has enacted legislation giving local authorities power to license and control public dance halls.

GUAM (via Pan American Airways Radio), Sunday, Oct. 13 (AP). -- Completing a 6,500-mile experimental flight with several stops from Alameda, Calif., the Pan American Airways' Clipper landed here at 5:40 P.M. today [12:10 A.M. Eastern standard time].

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 12. -- South American members of the League of Nations are hedging on sanctions. They are perfectly willing to give their moral support to League measures as long as it does not cost anything.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 12. -- The NewI York University varsity cross coun-[ try team defeated the Lafayettel harriers over a four-and-four-fifth-I mile course today by 24 -- 31 and theI Violet freshman squad conquered the Lafayette yearlings, 17 -- 38.

As its most ambitious project of the current season, the College Women's Club of Essex County is sponsoring a benefit concert by Kirsten Flagstad, Metropolitan Opera star, at the Mosque Theatre in Newark Tuesday night.

Establishment of a special force of park police is being given serious consideration by city authorities. Park Commissioner Robert Moses confirms the report that he and his aides have conferred with Police Commissioner Valentine on the matter but says it is too early to discuss details.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey renewed last night his plea for a constitutional amendment to make all laws subject to Supreme Court approval before they become effective. He spoke over the station WJZ and a nationwide hook-up.

ONE of the busiest radio stations in the world right now is a small transmitter at Addis Ababa known on the air by its call letters, ETA, ETB or ETC. The power is only three kilowatts, which is "just a drop in the ether" compared to the fifty kilowatts used by many of America's leading broadcasters.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The names of the 110 men heading Princeton University campus organizations, publications and activity clubs for the coming academic year were announced today by William K. Selden, assistant to the dean of the college.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 10. -- The statistical and economic picture of the Southern coal industry which is now being painted impressively for the Southern public in the course of labor troubles is so inartistic and unhappy that it may eventually draw miners and operators together in the company which misery is said to love.
The New Deal involves a new system of mathematics as exemplified by the following story of a recent Cabinet meeting:

THE new Italian Army, on which the Fascist regime has lavished its most assiduous care for the last thirteen years, has received its baptism of fire. The road to Addis Ababa has provided a test for the efficiency of the whole Italian military machine.

VIENNA, Oct. 12. -- Reports reaching here indicate Athens is completely cut off from the rest of the country. News from Saloniki takes thirty-six hours to reach the capital. There is every evidence that the army and civil servants are monarchical in an overwhelming majority so far as Athens is concerned, but nothing is known regarding the feeling in the provinces.

President Roosevelt likes to talk about being a good neighbor. He seems to be fond of the phrase. It fits the mouth and sounds rather noble. We all have our pet phrases that we use often even if we do not always understand their real meaning.

The signs of recent recovery are found in many fields. Far from the least interesting is the increased demand for luxuries, particularly for those most luxurious of all luxuries -- diamonds. Though they are still at only about 65 per cent of their 1929 price level, their price has risen about 15 per cent, even within the last three months, and now stands about 50 per cent above their low price of 1932.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 12. -- Doc C.W. Spears rallied his tired and weary Wisconsin Badgers for five thrilling minutes today, but they wound up with another sick headache as one of the strongest Notre Dame football squads in years smashed and buried them under an avalanche of points, 27 to 0.

CURTIS BROWN pioneered as a literary agent. As such he came in for many an icy stare, but caught a lot of big game, too. In the old days many publishers thought the term literary agent synonymous with road agent and scoundrel.

ROME, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Bearing the blessing of Pope Pius XI, Prince Juan of Bourbon, son of former King Alfonso of Spain, and his bride, a Princess of the House of Bourbon, are on a honeymoon tonight that may take them to the United States.

SAN SALVADOR. -- The field of honor is not entirely deserted in Latin America, although dueling is forbidden by law in most of the republics. Challenges, however, are more frequent than actual conflicts at sunrise. Aversion to early rising may have something to do with this.

Mrs. Virginia L. Bacon in a letter to THE TIMES attacks the American Civil Liberties Union. When she made her original assault several weeks ago I wrote and asked her to attend one of the union's directors' luncheons and make a first-hand investigation. She failed to accept this, charging in return that the union encourages unbridled free speech.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- Chicago, Cleveland and Indianapolis presented invitations for the 1936 convention of the Socialist party to its national executive committee, in session here today.

With woolen goods the chief beneficiary of heavier advance buying, executives of chains selling general merchandise lines indicated during the week they are completing purchasing plans for next Spring based on a further gain in retail sales during that period.

ADOLF HITLER wanted in his youth to be an architect and in fact studied as a draftsman in Munich. But the only architecture he has ever achieved has consisted in the improvements and additions to his chalet high up in the Bavarian Alps above Berchtesgaden.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Justification for an early Parliamentary election, despite the fact that the present Parliament is fully supporting the Cabinet's League of Nations policy, is offered by Scrutator in The Sunday Times on the assumption that sanctions against Italy may fail, necessitating a complete revision of the British foreign program.

A CYNOSURE of interest this Fall at Yale is the new course in "World Problems" under the auspices of the Department of Education. Syllabus and textbook for its sixty-five students are the daily newspapers; current events are the source material from which a perspective of contemporary history is drawn.

Police yesterday were seeking members of the Amberg gang of Brownsville, Brooklyn, for questioning in the murder of Frank (Little Frankie) Teitlebaum, racketeer, whose body, locked in a trunk, was dropped under the Manhattan end of Brooklyn Bridge late Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Customs officials said today that any large munitions shipments that might be made to neutral countries while Italy and Ethiopia were at war would be scrutinized most carefully.

OF these twelve sea stories a cycle of four with the same chief characters -- two whaling mariners, long retired, but now forced back into their old calling by commonly suffered adversity -- comprises nearly half the contents of the book.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12. -- Shipping men of San Francisco, who have been harassed by months of labor unrest and loss through idle cargoes, have been cheered by the announcement of the Pacific Steamship Lines that resumption of their coastwise Admiral Line freighter service would become effective at once.
Would it not be wise to develop a tradition of permanent public service before we attempt to usher in an economic millennium by Presidential decree?
C.C.N.Y.'s football team proved unequal to the task of subduing its first major opponent yesterday, the Beavers bowing to the Providence College eleven, 14 -- 0, at Lewisohn Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Receipts from sales of principal farm products were 4 per cent higher in August this year than for the corresponding month in 1934 and for the first eight months of 1935 were 9 per cent higher than the corresponding period of 1934, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- St. Joseph's defeated St. Francis College of Brooklyn today by a score of 26 to 6.

Curtis High of Staten Island scored two victories while Newtown was the other winner in the second series of the annual P.S.A.L. cross-country group runs at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. It was the first time in several years that one school has won in more than one group the same day.

The final quarter of each year brings its avalanche of football on the wireless. The two NBC stations at San Francisco -- KPO and KGO -- and the CBS station, KFRC, which are the three really important stations of Central California, appear to have devoted themselves almost exclusively to this phase of entertainment at the outset.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 10. -- James Aloysius Farley came to Kentucky last week and saw the evidences of revolt in the Democratic camp, but he did not conquer the disaffection which has seized upon a considerable portion of the still-functioning Rhea-Laffoon machine.

MR. O'BRIEN'S biography of Will Rogers is just the kind of book about him that his hundreds of thousands of followers would wish to have, and its author is to be congratulated on having so aptly met their desires. For it comes as near being a paper-and-print incarnation of their beloved humorist as they are likely ever to see.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Ken Cotton was outstanding today as the University of California football team opened its coast conference schedule with a 6-to-0 victory over the University of Oregon.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES, ADOWA, Ethiopia, Oct. 12. -- General Emilio de Bono, commander of the Italian armies in this sector, will formally annex Adowa, capital of the valuable Tigre Province, tomorrow in the name of Italy.

CHESTER, Ill., Oct. 12. -- Seizing a commissary truck in the yard of the Menard State prison in a surprise attack today, four convicts made a spectacular escape by ramming the machine at high speed through the locked main gates of the prison.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Membership in the Honor School was awarded to eighty-seven students in the College of Arts and Sciences of Rutgers University, Dr. Walter T. Marvin, dean of the college, announced today. Maintenance of a high scholarship average during the previous semester is the basis of the selection.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12. -- The Soviet Union has no intention of halting wheat shipments to Italy unless the League of Nations votes sanctions covering this type of trade, your correspondent learned from well informed Soviet sources today.

WITHIN a year of each other two manifestations of The Great American Novel had been published. Hawthorne's masterpiece was issued in a drab little volume in Boston in 1850. The following year there appeared in London over the imprint of Richard Bentley a three-decker described on its title-page as "The Whale. By Herman Melville."

THE thirty-eight-story International Building, newest of the Rockefeller Center group of skyscrapers in New York, is as much of a history-maker as was the first street car or the first street-gas system. And this not only because air-conditioning is provided for but because the method is what its designers call selective and flexible.

BOONESBORO, Ky., Oct. 12. -- On the site of the gigantic elm tree which cast its shade over the first Kentucky Legislature 160 years ago, a monument commemorating Kentucky's founders was unveiled today.

With an exceptionally heavy Columbus Day trade reported yesterday by most stores here, retail trade in the metropolitan area made substantial gains during the week. Estimates indicated an average increase for the week of about 10 per cent for leading department stores here, although several individual establishments had gains considerably in excess of this figure.

Isaac Don Levine in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES charges that the officers of the American Civil Liberties Union have themselves contributed to a common misunderstanding of the union's purposes by partiality toward Soviet Russia and violations of civil liberties by Communists.

Specimens of coins in use in Ethiopia were among the exhibits in the coin display opened to the public yesterday in the British Empire Building of the Rockefeller Center, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street. It will be open again today from 11 to 6 o'clock.

"SMITH" follows "Smith."In preparation is "Smire." That's the line-up of Branch Cabell's new trilogy, which seems to carry on from where his alter ego left off in those eighteen faerily ironic tomes of the fair and wondrous land of Poictesme.

IT requires a wide grasp to encompass within the pages of an average size novel the story of a big family, including members of four generations. This is a particularly ambitious effort when most of the members of the family are interesting and unusual people.

The rollicking strains of "Madelon" and the French military march, "Sambre et Meuse" rolled across the ballroom of the Hotel Biltmore last night as 450 men who brought the wounded back from Verdun, Compiegne, Soissons, and a dozen other World War battles celebrated the twentieth anniversary of the American Ambulance Field Service.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12. -- Illinois unleashed an amazing display of football pyrotechnics to defeat Southern California today, 19 to 0, in the West's first big intersectional encounter of the season.
MANLIUS, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The Manlius School football team defeated a strong Ithaca College freshman eleven, 13 to 0, on Kallet Field this afternoon.

A FEW years ago I happened to be on a jury of selection for a print exhibition. There were a great many etchings among the competitors, almost as many lithographs, a few engravings and a very few aquatints. I was rather surprised to discover after a wearisome day that the prints lingering most pleasantly in my mind were the aquatints.

Admiral Richard E. Byrd gave a persqnal account of the explorations and research conducted on his second expedition into the bleak Antarctic for the first time in New York yesterday at Carnegie Hall, illustrating his story with motion pictures.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 12. -- The Automobile Safety League of America has been incorporated as a non-profit organization designed to promote safer driving on the streets and highways.

In Geneva early Friday morning a diplomat and a newspaper man rehearsed a radio act that never reached the air. The broadcast was to have been an interview (questions by Edgar Mowrer, answers by Baron Pompeo Aloisi, Italian delegate to the League of Nations), which was designed to present Italy's case for war to the American public.

PATIENCE has often been recommended as the chief virtue to be cultivated by international negotiators. It has certainly been displayed abundantly by those who in the past few weeks have been striving to prevent Italy from invading Ethiopia.

FOR THE first time since the depression there is talk on the street corners about new producing concerns. In the old days when the Alexandria Hotel was the gathering place for the industry, a large Oriental carpet in the centre of the lobby was known as "the million dollar rug," for on it million after million was spent, mergers were effected and conversations about what I told DeMille today" were common.

To those who thought that whoopee was a pure bit of American slang, a product of the gay white lights, there came disillusionment last week. The disillusioner was Sir William A. Craigie, lexicographer of American English and joint editor of the Oxford Dictionary. Whoopee, he said, was used 300 years ago by startled Britons as an exclamation.

MOULTONBORO NECK, N.H., Oct. 12. -- Roger Tyzzer, 26 years old, the youngest son of Professor Ernest E. Tyzzer of the Harvard Medical School, died in a small motor boat on Lake Winnepesaukee near here this afternoon.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 12. -- Springfield scored its second triumph over Brown today in thirty-three years of battling. The score was 20 to 0.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- All good National Socialist Germans everywhere will observe tomorrow, the first of the six one-dish Sundays decreed for this Winter season as one means of raising money for the National Socialist Winter relief campaign, which holds a monopoly on charity work in German.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Washington College, undefeated since 1933, recovered from a slow start to defeat Swarthmore, 13 -- 6, today.

After two years of drifting Johnny Malone and his old side-kick, Rawhide Mullins, headed back for the only home they had ever known, Sandy Carter's Bar 5 Ranch. They had been happy there. They were sure of a friendly welcome, and anticipation of Ma Carter's fried chicken and real biscuits and mince pie made their mouths water.

IT looked for a time as though Jean Muir wouldn't be out of the doghouse by Christmas. But now that she has her "Workshop," she has ceased being the studio pest. Directors may come and go without stern admonitions, pleas and rebukes.

SYRACUSE, Oct.12 (AP). -- Demand for a meeting as soon as possible of Young Republican leaders from all States was voiced in a resolution adopted by the board of governors of the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs here today.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 12 (AP). -- Senator Glass, held one of the most outspoken Democratic opponent of many of President Roosevelt's policies, said today that the President would be renominated without great opposition.

I.A. Hirschmann, chairman of the board of trustees of the University in Exile, composed of German scholars who refused to subscribe to Nazi doctrines, announced yesterday that preliminary pledges of $115,000 had been received toward a $375,000 fund to continue the project for five years.

Refunding operations showed a decided shrinkage in volume last week, when announcements of bonds called for redemption before maturity and flotations of new offerings, for proceeds to redeem bonds, declined. Of the new calls, most of them were for November, only some small lots of municipals being added for October.

The annual Miami Biltmore fashion show and supper dance will be held on Nov. 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Centre. The board of directors of the centre will meet tomorrow at the home of Airs. George L. Shearer, 63 East Sixty-sixth Street, to form committees for the event, which is being given under their auspices in association with Henry L. Doherty, president of the Florida Year-Round Clubs.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12. -- Colder weather, many conventions and a general industrial quickening has speeded business appreciably in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week, especially in the St. Louis territory.

THE orbit of the Autumn holt-day is wider than ever this year. From Atlantic City to Santa Fe a boom is reported in Fall travel. Traditionally October opens the "season" in the Virginias and North Carolina, November extends it to South Carolina resorts, but, while these popular centres are reporting the liveliest patronage in years.

Entertainments have been arranged for the near future for members of the committees planning the Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillion in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 25. On Tuesday Mrs. Joseph Feder will give a reception at her home, 973 Fifth Avenue, for debutantes of the season who are participating in the cotillion at the ball.

Five hundred horseshoe pitching fans watched the Park Department's champion team defeat the best entrants Paterson, N.J., had to offer yesterday at Heekscher Playground in Central Park. The match was the first in a series to be played each Saturday between the New Yorkers and other contestants from the metropolitan area.

A plea for Catholics to broaden and strengthen the faith of their children so that they will carry it into their mature lives and defeat the purposes of communistic teaching in this country was made by the Most Rev. William J. Hafey, Bishop of Raleigh, N.C., at a memorial luncheon of the New York Assembly, Catholic Daughters of America, at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

Stirred by their modern Caesar and his soldiers marching into battle, Italians are once again dreaming of empire. While Italian legions fight their way forward in the attempt to plant their banner over large portions of Ethiopia, visions of the grandeur that was Rome fascinate Italian minds. Never before has the modern Italian turned the pages of ancient history with so much pride as he does today.

IT is right and proper that there should be at least some elementary book about music addressed to a higher level than that of the abecedarians, who have so much done for them. Readers on that higher level are well provided for in this admirable volume.

OUR ENVOY: While the State Department at home takes steps to avoid American involvement in the complications arising from the Ethiopian war, our interests in Addis Ababa are in the experienced hands of Cornelius Van H. Engert, Charge d'Affaires and Consul General in Haile Selassie's capital.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- The so-called Balbo medal, pinned or Amelia Earhart, flier, May 23, by Dr. Giuseppe Castruccio, then Royal Italian consul general to Chicago, has been returned to him, Miss Earhart disclosed here tonight.

WELL timed to support remarks made in this department recently, in Masterworks Albums 221 and 223 Columbia presents two contemporary Americans, one by birth, the other by adoption, in works of their own composition.

EXPERIMENT is the rule of the day in almost every known field. In an art which is making such rapid progress as that of flower arrangement, it is fitting that the old timeworn conventions should make place for the more intelligent use of such essential mediums as color and texture.
"Broadway shopping for the busy collegian" might well be the motto of Hunter College's newly organized Theatre Alcove.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Events revolving around the Italo-Ethiopian unpleasantness, as they occurred during the last week on this side of the water, left a clear indication with official Washington of the possible difficulties ahead in our attempt to wear the tailor-made mantle of neutrality which a tired Congress cut out, altered slightly and pieced together in the closing hours of the last session.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Williams College gave to the Department of Agriculture today 1,500 acres of woodland in the northwest corner of Massachusetts, adjoining the Vermont and New York lines, with the stipulation that it would be known as the Lawrence Hopkins Memorial Experimental Forest.

In spite of its glittering title, "All Is Not Gold" is not a flashy yarn but a sound, smoothly told romance of the better class of popular-magazine fiction. The good old theme that love rates higher than riches is pleasantly decked out in fresh, young, mid-depression trimmings.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 12. -- Experience with would-be extortionists, kidnappers and other criminals has caused Hollywood's famous movie colony to surround itself with every safeguard human ingenuity can devise.
The largest school construction program here since the depression began, involving the expenditure of about $25,000,000 in Federal funds, will be completely under way before Christmas.

BARELY fifty yards apart, two natural springs in Western Queensland, Australia, give entirely different streams of water. A clear and tepid flow gushes from one; from the other bubbles an ice-cold, jet-black stream.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- After a 1,200-mile journey by horseback and afoot across Western Canada, about 1,000 miles of it through unmapped country in British Columbia, Mrs. J. Norman Henry, wife of Philadelphia's Director of Public Health, and her daughter, Josephine, have returned home with more than 600 plant specimens for the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, the Royal Botanical Gardens of Edinburgh and the Arbold Arboretum of Harvard University.

WITH killing frosts "just around the corner," gardeners are busy these days seeing to it that nothing which needs protection will be caught. The last of the house plants are brought indoors, or at least placed in the shelter of an enclosed porch.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 10. -- With the lines tightly drawn for the first time between two systems of publicly-owned light and power service, the Tennessee Valley Authority is awaiting the outcome of a decision by three West Tennessee towns to determine whether their taxpayers want low taxes or cheap power.
Mayor La Guardia sounded the tocsin yesterday for a "fight to the finish" against the public utilities, to the end that the city may build its "yardstick" power plant system.

SELINSGROVE, Pa., Oct. 12. -- Amos Alonzo Stagg Jr. opened his coaching regime at Susquehanna University today with his team gaining a 19-16 victory over a stubborn Haverford College eleven.
THE first visit of the Philadelphia Orchestra, a number of debuts and the return of familiar artists like Paul Robeson will mark the current week of concerts.
LANSING, Mich., Oct. 12. -- Michigan State defeated Kansas University by a score of 42 to 0 on Macklin Field today.

Members of the New York Wellesley Club will have a double celebration on Wednesday, the club's forty-fifth anniversary and its formal opening of new quarters at 106 East Fifty-second Street. There will be a cocktail party in the redecorated club lounge on the eighth floor and a buffet supper and dance in the ballroom of the Women's University Club.

ATHENS, Oct. 12. -- Regent Kondylis today received directors of Athens newspapers and told them former Premier Tsaldaris had been overthrown because "the uncertainty of the situation had exhausted the patience of the armed forces."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- A spinner play which continually caught the Union team off balance was the effective weapon used by Amherst to win today, 23 to 0, before several thousand Union alumni at the annual home-coming celebration.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- Retail trade continued at the sharply improved pace of a week earlier, with sales of the larger department stores averaging substantially ahead of last year. The week-end closed with a further pick-up due to the start of a heavily advertised department store anniversary sale.

BEVERLY FARMS, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Gayest of all affairs on the North Shore since the boom days of 1929, the dinner dance given tonight by Mrs. Joseph Leiter of du Pont Circle, Washington, and her son, Thomas Leiter, as a coming-out party for Miss Nancy Leiter, was attended by more than 200 guests from all of the neighboring colonies, and from New York, Washington and Chicago.

FORT TRYON PARK, which was formally opened yesterday is the latest of the completed public works of Robert Moses, Park Commissioner at large and Bridge Authority in duplicate, so to speak. It commemorates directly one of the three principal northern defenses of New York from which General Washington was dislodged by the British in 1776.

A WOMAN who hasn't the tall, lissom figure of the designer's model often thinks herself hard to fit in ready-made clothes conceived for figures quite different from hers. Tall, large women and short, plump ones are well taken care of in shops which make a special effort to supply ready-made clothes for other than the standard sizes.

The story of that adventure is one which deserves to take its place beside the great books of Arctic exploration, and that it may fail to do so will be only because of its arrangement and not because of its subject.

The Hospital Department, as its contribution to the celebration next year of the 200th anniversary of the establishment of the first public hospital in New York City, hopes to raise the city hospital system to the front rank of the world's medical centres, Commissioner S.S. Goldwater said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Aubrey Williams, Acting Works Progess Administrator, said today that persons who are sympathetic with President Roosevelt's program have obtained most positions on WPA administrative staffs over the country.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 11. -- Time must cast its patina over the gleaming surface of the Supreme Court's superb $10,000,000 home before its newness wears away, but time too must work its spell upon the building's occupants before they can shake off a present uneasy sense of strangeness.

ROME, Oct. 12. -- Premier Mussolini has moved to strengthen his naval defenses in the Mediterranean so that he would be able to meet Great Britain with her own weapons if necessary, it became known tonight.

Shipping men who have been waging a slow battle during the last five years to rejuvenate a business virtually ruined by the depression, face one of their greatest problems in the dangers to travel and commerce caused by the war in Africa.

A CALL to artists for a congress to be held in New York City early in the Winter has been issued by more than a hundred painters, critics and others in associated fields. All sections of the United States are represented. Stuart Davis, 52 West Eighth Street, is secretary.

ACCORDING to present plans, there will be two outstanding features during Air Navigation Week, which begins tomorrow. The first involves the overnight flight from San Francisco to Newark over the Department of Commerce midcontinental airway by a regular United Air Lines passenger plane with the pilots under hoods the entire way except for take-offs and landings at the regular scheduled stops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Improvement of the relationship between employes and management, with a speedier settlement of issues when strikes are called, was reported today by Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor.

TRADE moved smartly during the week under the influence of favorable weather. The last week-end furnished a spurt that brought the best totals in four or five years. Apparel demand finally came to life and excellent business was also done on dress accessories.

PARIS. THE dull, sleepy days of Summer are over. Shops are opening again; Parisians who went away a month ago and left the city to the American tourists are returning in flocks, and the movie houses along the Grands Boulevards and the Champs Elysees have taken down their signs of "Fermeture Annuelle" (annual closing).
Registration in the city for the November election has run, for the first four days, at 92 per cent of the figures for the first four days of last year, informal computation showed yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 12. -- The government will retain its hold on $75,000 in Liberty bonds filed as bail for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer last Winter under a decision made by Federal Judge Frank Cooper today.

Competition from Japanese and German sources, the main obstacle to American trade expansion in Latin America less than a year ago. is crumbling under pressure of improved economic conditions there, R.C. Thompson, president of the Overseas Automotive Club and export manager of the Prest-O-Lite Battery Company, Inc., said here yesterday on his return from an airplane trip to major markets of South America.

A DELEGATION of the Socialist Cinema Centre has waited on the Minister of Justice to protest against the severity with which film censorship is carried out in this country and especially against the rule that any embrace that lasts more than six yards of film should be cut out.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 12. -- Ceremonies to rival those of October, 1930, when the River Campus of the University of Rochester was dedicated, are being planned for the inaugural of President Alan Valentine Nov. 14 and 15 in the Eastman Theatre.

"We must act," said Captain EDEN at Geneva on Wednesday. The Assembly did act, following the lead of the Council, and in a way deeply to impress the whole world. Even from Italy the censorship has allowed dispatches to pass explaining that the decision of the League against the Italian Government is causing "uneasiness" among the people.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 12. -- An intercepted forward led to a 2-0 defeat for Western Maryland at the hands of Penn State today.

THE year 1793, which for some cause, probably Victor Hugo, is always taken as the numerical symbol and the climax of the French Revolution, almost saw, as a matter of fact, that revolution's sudden end. It was an annee terrible for the revolutionaries themselves as well as for their royalist victims.
OTTAWA, Oct. 12. -- Political authorities estimated tonight that 6,000,000 votes would be cast in Monday's election for the next government of Canada.

With but a few weeks remaining before the debutante season gets under way, younger members of society are looking forward to the various subscription dances which form part of the entertaining in society during the Autumn and Winter.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Enthusiastic scenes were witnessed outside the Ethiopian legation in London today when some 2,000 men and women who had attended a Chelsea mass meeting of the organized London workers, intellectuals and friends of peace marched to present the Ethiopian Minister, Warqnex Martin, with an address assuring him of their support.

SO wrote Chaucer six centuries ago of his Clerk of Oxenford and Canterbury Pilgrim. And down through all the intervening years there have been schoolmasters, and professors, to whom these words applied more fittingly than any others.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- Terra cotta dice used in gambling operations at Tepe Gawra nearly fifty centuries ago furnish evidence that international commerce flourished to a hitherto unsuspected degree in ancient Mesopotamia, according to Dr. E.A. Speiser, University of Pennsylvania archaeologist.

The Conference on Port Development of the City of New York announced last night that it would present its attitude on foreign trade in a series of nation-wide broadcasts "in an effort to have the Roosevelt administration bare its plans and clarify its policies."

LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- A survey of the munitions position of principal European exporting countries indicated today that the League of Nations' arms embargo might help Ethiopia but would not work much harm on Italy.

Fort Tryon Park, at the northern tip of Washington Heights, widely known for its natural beauties and its historic part in the Revolutionary War, was formally given to the city yesterday by John D. Rockefeller Jr. before a gathering of distinguished citizens, officials and 3,000 near-by residents.

Dr. Edgar J. Goodspeed in considerably better known in the world of classic scholarship than among detective story fans. And it had better be explained here and now that this university professor is an authority on dead tongues, ancient manuscripts and the secrets of treasures hidden in tombs of thousands of years ago.

Determined to end vicious price cutting in the retail drug industry, pharmacists in all sections of the State, through their organizations and acting independently, will launch an organized movement this week in an effort to force the cooperation of manufacturers of trade-marked lines of medicines, cosmetics and other toilet articles.

AT 26, James Whitall was living in a Philadelphia suburb and working in his father's office. His labors were uncongenial and existence offered none of the mental stimulation he needed. The prospect of a business career filled him with dismay.

Retail trade during the last ten days has exceeded the expectations of the most optimistic merchants, with both apparel and home wares in strong demand, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Numerous reports from all parts of the country, the buying office said, indicated substantial increases in volume.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- Fascism would not come to this country with an outward appearance of revolution, and no American President ever would set himself up as an avowed dictator, Gilbert H. Montague, New York attorney, declared here today.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Affording practical radio work to students interested in broadcasting as a profession and as a hobby, the reorganized Tufts College Radio Society went on the air this week with a transmitter rated at 500 watts, one of the most powerful amateur stations in the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- Marking a departure in college glee club work, an opportunity will be given to student members of choral societies at the University of Pennsylvania to become acquainted with the great music of all periods through undergraduate activities planned for this year.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Oct. 12. -- The fate of several thousand Finnish-born Ingrian peasants who were recently deported from homesteads around Leningrad was revealed by an Ingrian farmer, Simo Lavonen, on his arrival here after an adventurous flight from inner Russia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Allegations that the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., was unreliable, incompetent and unsatisfactory in its work were made before the Securities and Exchange Commission by F.J. Lisman, chairman of the Bondholders Protective Committee, Republic of El Salvador, at a continuance of the commission's hearings into the defaulted bonds of the Latin-American republic today.

Before sailing yesterday for Bermuda, Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin, said there was no doubt in his mind that President Roosevelt would be re-elected if his opposition was reactionary. Governor La Follette left on the American Legion of the Munson Line for a twelve-day vacation.

Continued improvement is shown in the room business of transient hotels here, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by Harris Kerr, Forster Co., accountants. Statistics compiled for the month of September indicate that of the 27,836 rooms in twenty-nine representative hotels 63.08 per cent were occupied, an increase of 6.4 per cent over the corresponding period last year.

ROME, Oct. 12. -- For the capital of a country at war against Ethiopia and against the world, Rome is strangely apathetic. Premier Benito Mussolini's new Italy is very old, after all, and it never seemed older than in these high-tension hours.
New York University will open tomorrow at its Washington Square Centre the first unit of a museum designed to show that ideas like the machine gun and mass production are at least 2,000 years old.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12. -- In an exciting match, Rudolph Knepper of the Garden City Golf Club and John R. Fell of the home club gained the semi-finals of the annual invitation best-ball tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

A CRISP Autumn day. The maples are scarlet and gold, the ash trees are a deep bronzy purple and the euonymus bush is afire with its flame-colored leaves and orange berries. A snowy trumpet-lily is swinging at the tip of a high stem thickly covered with leaves.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh is a man of letters -- 100,000 of them.

With a flippant "Good-bye Old Bright Eyes," General Hugh S. Johnson, retiring Works Progress Administrator for New York, bade farewell last night to the city and its officialdom in a nation-wide radio address devoted to a biting attack on the "Tory barrage against WPA."

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 12. -- Dr. Florence Rena Sabin, a staff member of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research since 1925, was announced today as the third recipient of the M. Carey Thomas Prize of $5,000, which is given at intervals to an American woman in recognition of eminent achievement.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- Such events as the opening of the Automobile Show and the first Autumn gala dinner at the Ritz usually coincide with the return en masse of society folk to the capital. The motor salon, as it is called, starts tomorrow at the Grand Palais and attracts, especially on Fridays, a fashionable throng.

BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler brought to an abrupt conclusion four centuries of confusion in Germany in the relations between the State and the Protestant Church, when on Sept. 24 he decreed State supremacy over the Evangelical Church.

Like the word boon-doogle which came out of the New York City relief investigation to sweep the nation only a few months ago, a new word is being popularized by our current campaign against unnecessary noise -- the decibel. In decibels engineers will finally measure the degree of success scored by the Mayor in the attempt to silence auto horns, brakes, radios, and people who are merely vociferous.

The accurate passes of Arthur Schillig enabled the Grover Cleveland High School Eleven of Ridgewood, Queens, to vanquish Jamaica High, 18 to 6, at Dexter Park yesterday. A crowd of 6,000 watched Schillig throw three passes for touchdowns.

James Madison High School's eleven scored a crushing 28-0 victory over Erasmus Hall at Ebbets Field yesterday. A crowd of more than 6,000 saw the twelfth gridiron meeting of the traditional rivals. Madison assumed the lead in the series, with five victories against four for the Buff and Blue.

ON the stage, perhaps, the play's the thing; in the world of sports it's the player. The Babe Ruths of baseball and the Red Granges of football have helped materially to turn mere pastimes into stupendous spectacles that are followed, directly or indirectly, by half the nation.

French eighteenth century furniture and decorations, Queen Anne and Georgian silver, Chinese porcelains, jewelry, paintings of the French school, tapestries, and other art objects, from the estate of Mary Strong Shattuck of New York and Lenox, Mass., will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Now that the epidemic of opening meetings has passed its peak in the club world, the calendar reveals an impending outbreak of jubilee celebrations. Since such festivities veer away from routine organization programs, lending both variety and color to the year's activities, they will be as welcome in October as the flowers in May.

SHAMOKIN, Pa., Oct. 12 (AP). -- A suspected automobile thief shot it out with State Troopers on a Shamokin street tonight, killing one of his five sisters and critically wounding a State police crack-shot. Then he fled in an automobile which he is alleged to have stolen, with authorities in pursuit.

ALMOST any night in the week you chance to be passing along Constitution Avenue near the new building of the Department of Labor you may observe lights in windows on the third floor. About midnight the lights will go out and a few minutes later there will emerge from the building a neatly dressed man with a military bearing who has just ended a fifteen or sixteen hour day.

Harold G. Hathaway, a former law associate of John W. Davis, Democratic nominee for President in 1924, was found dead in bed yesterday at the University Club. Detectives said he had strangled himself with the silken cord of his dressing gown by tying one end of it to a bed post and knotting the other about his throat.

PANTOMIME has taken never root in this country as it did in England, where to this day it flourishes like the proverbial green bay tree, after more than two centuries of exceedingly varied history. But Americans have never cared for it, although they have delighted in some of the features that have been transferred by British managers to pantomime from other forms of entertainment.

Bernard McNabb Jr., 10 years old, of 1,819 Woodbine Street, Ridgewood, died early yesterday morning in the Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn, of injuries received Friday evening when he was struck by a Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens Transit Company trolley car while crossing Woodbine Street near Onderdonk Avenue, Ridgewood.

Students are enrolling in increasing numbers for the Social science, technology, and business degrees to the neglect of arts, science and education courses at City College, it was shown in an enrolment report released yesterday by President Frederick B. Robinson.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Honorary scholarships in memory of Mark Hopkins, Williams College president, who was inaugurated nearly a century ago, will be awarded to students of high rank who are not necessarily in financial need, under a plan just presented to the trustees.

ON BOARD S.S. CAIRO CITY, Oct. 12. -- The Mediterranean region has become a hotbed of rumors and minor Anglo-Italian incidents. At sea in the Mediterranean there is a feeling of tension, even uneasiness, among passengers and crews of all ships.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Robert H. Moore's green-hulled 10-meter sloop Lilu, which he had used for cruising all Summer, came out of racing retirement to win the New Rochelle Yacht Club's annual Fall contest out around Stratford Shoal lighthouse today .

No person was better qualified than the late Sir J. Arthur Thomson to write a biology book that would capture and hold the interest of adult readers and which, at the same time, would be a thorough review of the entire field of biology and a competent presentation of its most important concepts.

A recently perfected device to warn mariners of near-by obstacles of any kind has been successfully tried out on the French liner Normandie on several trips. Before he sailed for Plymouth and Havre last week Captain Rene Pugnet, master of the liner, said experts hoped the new apparatus would be the fog-proof, storm-proof safety invention for which seamen had searched and experimented for many years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12. -- The Holy Cross steam roller battered through to its third straight triumph of the season by defeating Harvard today. But the Crusaders from Worcester encountered stronger opposition than they anticipated from the sturdy Crimson eleven and had to fight their way without relenting for a moment before tucking away a 13-to-0 triumph.

IN the agricultural Province of Alberta a new government has received an overwhelming electoral mandate to attempt to apply for the first time a financial doctrine which has remained obscure to many of those, including specialists, who have studied it.

Evelyn Hubbell of New York, who is a member of the Imperial Society of London, as well as of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., will illustrate at the latter's October meeting in the Hotel Astor this morning "The Flicker," newest and most popular ballroom dance in the smart dancing places of London, and will also demonstrate the chief steps in vogue among New York society and college dancers.

COLONEL W. DE BASIL'S Ballet Russe do Monte Carlo will present four novelties during the week at the Metropolitan Opera House First will be "The Midnight Sun," the first ballet created by Leonide Massine, which was given in New York by the Diaghileff company in 1916.

HARTFORD, Oct. 12. -- With examinations by fifty Hartford specialists Trinity College freshmen closed their preliminary activities. So that the college will have a health report of all students, these specialists each year contribute their time to the tests.

GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Pistol and brickbat fighting today at New Orleans, in which two men were shot, marked the first serious outbreak of violence in the strike of 3,000 Gulf ports union longshoremen.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Oct. 12. -- Chartered before its most prominent citizen, George Washington, was born, Fredericksburg is to lose one of the things that may give it claim to being a typical American town. It no longer is to have a Main Street.

With one of the best conceived aerial attacks seen in these parts for a long time, a brilliant Louisiana State eleven yesterday completely smothered a hard-fighting Manhattan team that was able to cope with everything the foe from the bayous had except passes.

ROME, Oct. 12. -- The attention of most Italians focuses so intently on East Africa that they have not been particularly impressed by the first sanctions being proposed in Geneva. They are believed to leave things very much as they wore because Italy does not need to import war materials in any considerable quantities to carry on her campaign, while Ethiopia lacks money and credit to make purchases abroad on a large scale.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- Helene Rouff, "making many Schiaparelli gadgets," has designed the season's most amusing jewelry, literally speaking. Her puzzle bracelets are something to play with when one is trying to give up smoking.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The Westchester County Recreation Commision, in its second annual exposition which opens Tuesday at the County Centre, will demonstrate how the residents of this suburban community pass their leisure time. The exposition will continue until the following Monday.
New Jersey is the horticultural centre of the nation this week, with three major events to back its claim to the distinction.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Harvard's freshman football team opened its 1935 season with a 6-to-0 victory over Phillips Exeter Academy on the Crimson's freshman field today.

Although seldom mentioned among the Stock Exchange's assets, the Exchange Luncheon Club's collection of historic pictures of New York City is regarded as among the most complete and valuable in existence. One of the Exchange's greatest treasures, however, does not adorn the club's walls.

KENT, Conn., Oct. 12. -- Off to the lead at the very start via the oldfashioned sleeper pass play, Kent School's wideawake football team defeated Hotchkiss, 20 to 0, today on Alumni Field in the seventeenth [gridiron meeting, thereby checking i the supremacy that the Lakeville School had maintained for three successive years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The question anxiously propounded by every European statesman today is, "What will the United States do if and when sanctions are applied against Italy by members of the League?"

DALLAS, Oct. 12. -- Southwestern business took a tremendous upward leap early in October and all lines of endeavor are showing gains over the same period of last year, the first week in September and over the preceding week.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 12. -- After years in the background, Iowa swept back into national football prominence today, defeating Colgate, 12 to 6. A fast-charging, strong line smothered Colgate's lateral passers. Crayne's punting and the amazing open field running of Oze Simmons were Iowa's chief weapons.

WITH potentially interesting material and an evident gift for penetrating characterizations, Mr. Heth commite two blunders serious enough to offset much that is good in his first novel. His manner, possibly intended to be excessively simple, a kind of authoriah I'll-let-you-in-on-this simplicity, becomes, instead, almost patronizing.

While the volume of chain and mail order trade continued to show an increase during September, the pace was not as rapid as in preceding months. The first twenty-five chains and mail-order concerns to report for September did an aggregate business of $172,583,614, as against $161,722,817 in September a year ago, an increase of 6.7 per cent, according to a compilation issued yesterday by Hammons Co., Inc., and Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- Eugen Hadamovsky, director of the German radio system, announced today that henceforth jazz would be barred from German radio programs in favor of German dance music, to do away with the last remnants of the "culture-destroying activities of the culture-Bolshevistic Jew."

HERE is another of those small, thoughtful, evaluating books that contain the lectures delivered annually by eminent men at Milton Academy on the permanent foundation provided as a memorial to the alumni of the school who lost their lives in the World War.
