The effort to laugh is commendable at any time, and what we call laughter through tears may be always interpreted as an indication of humanity asserting itself in the face of tragedy, of pathos, or of Sheer tedium.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Before 25,000 spectators in Michie Stadium today Army overwhelmed Gettysburg College, 54 to 0. The Cadets registered eight touchdowns, tossing many substitutes into the fray and using nearly everybody on the squad before the game ended.

Since returning to this country after seven years' residence in Persia I have found a great many people who were unaware of the fact that last Spring Persia changed its name to Iran. This was a nationalistic move on the part of the country, which has awakened from centuries of sleep and is anxious to be a modern world power.

IN ORDER to make Grand Central Palace more realistic as a setting for the National Automobile Show, Nov. 2-9, murals depicting scenes at the motor factories will hang on many of the walls. Many of the aisles will thus be galleries along which visitors will be able to visualize the operations that made possible the automotive creations displayed on the floor.

ROME, Oct. 12 (AP). -- An Ethiopian fort at Dagnerrei, near Mustahil, on the Italian Somaliland front, was destroyed yesterday by an aerial bombardment, according to advices from La Tribuna's correspondent today. The bombardment, he said, fired the near-by village of Degabonka, which burned for two hours.

IN this biography, admirable from beginning to end, Paul Cezanne is at last brought convincingly to life. Working with material often scanty, still more often recalcitrant, Gerstle Mack has produced a full-length portrait which may be accepted as authentic.

The final meeting of the Jockey Club season, that at Empire City, will get under way tomorrow to run fifteen days until the end of the month. It will be featured by five stakes. James Butler, head of the Empire City Racing Association, has increased the value of the features, with the purpose in view of keeping good horses in this area.
Purdue's big, fast and hard-running football squad -- thirty-five players got into the game -- finally wore down and beat Fordham at the Polo Grounds yesterday by a score of 20 to 0.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican candidate for District Attorney of Kings County, issued another attack yesterday on his opponent, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan.

The steady drumbeat of Tintagel's hoofs down the Widener chute at Belmont Park yesterday shot that colt of Marshall Field's right back into contention for the juvenile championship when he charged on gamely to win the $90,420 Futurity by a length as 25,000 persons watched the favored racers finish out of the money.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 12. -- The big Brown team of Lehigh University crashed through for its third straight victory of the season with a 26-to-0 triumph over Dickinson in Taylor Stadium today. The game was witnessed by a crowd of 5,000.
LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 12. -- Franklin and Marshall easily defeated Moravian College of Bethlehem today, 28 to 0.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Striking early with a powerful rushing attack, coupled with a daring aerial barrage, North Carolina's Tarheels routed the Old Liners of Maryland today, 33 to 0, to cover another long stride in their ambitious march toward Dixie's football championship.

The first murder took place just as the oil well was gushing, and there is the smell of oil and the breathlessness of Southern Summer throughout this Texas tale. There is, also, the atmosphere of a singularly unpleasant small town, and, particularly, of the small town's newspaper office, whose society editor is the novel's heroine.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- With the comment that the company would "belong to the lawyers" if an early settlement in the case were not reached, Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson continued today the hearings on the reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company until Oct. 23.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- It has taken an economic depression to convince officials of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company that continuance of this city's experiment in transit monopoly is unwise, but the decision finally has been made.

MEXICO, D.F. SPANISH, or adobe, silver furnaces are again working in old Mexico. They are patterned after the furnaces that the Spaniards of the sixteenth century used in smelting their ore. Throughout the silver-mining area these furnaces have sprung up or have been rebuilt in tiny pueblos or near mines.
The text of General Hugh S. Johnson's nation-wide radio address delivered last night, as a farewell to the post of WPA Administrator for New York City, follows:

LONDON, Sept. 20. ANOTHER foreign actress, Lucie Mannheim, is this week advertised as having "taken London by storm." The English are a dogged race; they recover with healthy speed from these frequent invasions; St. Paul's stands where it did; the Thames is not on fire.

Suddenly springing into action by land and by air, Columbia defeated Rutgers, 20 -- 6, yesterday before 20,000 spectators at Baker Field. It was a brilliant performance in the second period that brought victory to the Lions, for all of its points came in that session and provided a comfortable but none-to-secure lead for the men of Morningside.

AFTER many of the mountain and shore resorts have been shuttered for the Winter and before those of the South have come into their own, the Southwest wedges in its tourist season. October and November, dull nearly everywhere else, are busier than any other part of the year, from the touring standpoint, in Texas and New Mexico.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Whopper, Hal Price Headley's bay colt, won the $10,000 added Agawam Handicap at Agawam Park today before a crowd of 25,000.

STOCKHOLM. A LITTLE Japanese tea ceremony house, unique in Europe and indeed in the West, has just become a part of the collections of the State Ethnographical Museum in Stockholm as a joint gift of Douglas Lundgren, a Swedish tea importer of Gothenburg, and Ginjiro Fujihara, a paper manufacturer of Tokyo.

GRANGER, Iowa, Oct. 12 (AP). -- In the heart of Central Iowa's coal fields fifty families of part-time workers will soon start a New Deal social experiment -- a subsistence homestead. The fifty modern houses are finished and two to eight acre plots are waiting for the plow.

BUCHAREST, capital of Rumania, was recently startled by a true crime story stranger than fiction. The city's public prosecutor, Luca Georghiade, who brought many rogues to justice in his official capacity, himself committed eleven major burglaries and many small ones which yielded more than $1,250,000. He was sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment in the salt mines.

While in no way desiring to detract from the credit due the American Field Service for the splendid part it played in the World War, I must take exception to your statement in a recent article that it was "the first unit of United States citizens to take active part in field operations during the war."
"CONTROLLED output" of automobile manufacturing, as it began to be known in 1931, and which Was another name for curtailment of production, is reversing itself as the companies go into 1936.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 12. -- Stanford's two-year reign as Pacific Coast Conference champion apparently came to an end today as the mighty Warriors coached by Tiny Thornhill went down to a 7-6 defeat before an alert band of Bruins from the University of California at Los Angeles.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Glenn Brasser, 20 years old, a former choir boy, charged with slaying Muriel Hall, his 17-year-old high school sweetheart, made a formal plea of not guilty to a charge of murder, first degree, in City Court here today.

BECAUSE anchors lie at the bottom of the sea, an Annapolis student who graduates at the bottom of his class is "Anchor Man." John Cobb was the most popular anchor man who ever got a diploma. He had the makings of a fine officer, but he also had a way of getting into jams.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The Federal plans to regulate bus and truck traffic have been endorsed by motor vehicle administrators of thirty-four States.

The "Portrait of a Boy in Gray," attributed to Thomas Gainsborough, went under the hammer for $220 at a public sale at the Anderson Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday. Another oil, portraying a landscape with figures, said to be the work of Claude le Lorrain, sold for $280.

IN turning to a consideration of Pop Hart's work it would be difficult indeed to know how much corresponds to a lovable, exuberant personality, and how much, on a strict count, to the art itself that was produced in those prodigious journeyings up and down the world.

WHAT high school studies form the most effective preparation for college work? A recent poll of 132 members of the Hunter College faculty on this question showed the majority of the doctors agreeing on the basic importance of nine subjects: English (by unanimous vote), French and German (tied for second place), ancient history, English literature, American history, modern history and elementary algebra (tied) and physics.

AN American traveler in Paris looking for his familiar hamburger-and-apple-pie fare will have a tedious quest. His search is not hopeless, but it will be a long one, for a tiny shop on the Place de l'Opera is likely to be the only salvation of the casual tourist.

THE headline "A Fortune Waiting" would catch the eye of the most careless newspaper reader. It appeared on the editorial page of The News-Chronicle over the report of a talk with a well-informed book publisher.

LESLIE HOWARD, star of the stage and screen, asked a friend to buy him a chocolate bar; then, smiling, he stepped into the elevator for a lift to the lofty studios, where he found a staff of production men, announcers and co-actors waiting to swing into rehearsal of the opening episode in his initial radio serial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- In a race to the Nov. 1 deadline, the date set by President Roosevelt for ending the "dole," WPA this week speeded up its drive to create jobs for 3,500,000 employables who have been on public relief rolls. The work-relief program has lagged behind expectations, but WPA officials still hope they can win the race.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Another series of transactions through which Abraham L. Shushan, on trial in Federal Court for alleged income tax evasion, was asserted to have exchanged more than $50,000 in cash for personal checks of his New York associate was presented today in the government's efforts to trace his income.

With the sensational score of 100 straight targets, R.H. Helsel won the twenty-second annual Cosmopolitan Championship over the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. The shoot, the first important one of the new season, brought forty-one gunners to the firing line.

PARIS. PIONEERS of the needle," such as Army Blatt are undoubtedly responsible for the established place occupied at the moment by hand-knitted clothes and accessories in the Paris couture. They have developed the technique of tricot to such a high point that knitted materials can successfully compete with woven fabrics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Secretary Hull has no intention of enter ing into a protracted discussion with American exporters over the wisdom or justice of President Roosevelt's warning to our business men to engage in transactions with Italy and Ethiopia only at their own risk.

IN the first quarter of the eighteenth century Maine was one of the focal points in the long-drawn-out struggle between the French and English for control of the frontier, with each faction making use of the Indians as grim allies. In a stirring and vigorous story for readers from 12 to 16, which shows a marked improvement over his earlier story.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Two of three Boston brokers indicted for conspiracy to steal $38,000 from a Newton woman, were arrested today and police continued search for the third man. Henry P. Fielding, Assistant District Attorney, said the woman was one of several investors who had turned over thousands of dollars to the brokers to finance search for sunken treasure.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11. -- Proposals that the American Federation of Labor endorse creation of an American Labor party have been attended with livelier interest at the present annual convention than at any federation meeting in many years.
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- One of the daily inquiries at the source whence official British information emanates always concerns Franco-British relations. Are the two still cooperating?

A new formula for the award of the Pulitzer Prize in reporting was announced last night by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia School of Journalism, who said it had been approved by the advisory board of the school.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 12. -- With 190-pound Halfback George Roscoe showing the way behind the Gophers' great forward wall, Minnesota defeated the Nebraska football team today, 12 to 7, before a capacity crowd of 35,000.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Boston University won its first game from a Tufts football team by beating the Jumboes 13 to 7 at the Tufts Oval today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Work relief figures gave hints today of a double failure of objectives originally set for the $4,000,000,000 drive.

Mrs. Ruth Hailer Ottoway of New York and Port Huron, Mich., will be elected as president of the National Council of Women, advance reports indicate, succeeding Miss Lena Madesin Phillips, at the biennial convention opening tomorrow at the Vanderbilt Hotel.

JOSE ITURBI is making a habit of organizing orchestras. Several years ago he launched his public career as a conductor in Mexico, D.F., and an ensemble known as the Orquesta Iturbi was formed as a result of his ministrations. Several weeks ago he went to Lima, Peru, for a piano recital, gave several and ended by organizing an orchestra.

In The New England Quarterly Review Mr. ALLEN MACDONALD of Dartmouth makes us hear once more the most vital and famous once of Boston preachers, minister of the Seaman's Bethel in North Square. Father TAYLOR has become a literary memory. "A Sailor among Transcendentalists," Mr. MACDONALD calls him.

Mayor La Guardia's chief transit guides, Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., are prepared to recommend soon to the Board of Estimate a "tentative" plan for rapid transit unification. It is based upon nearly two years of intensive negotiation with spokesmen for various interests in the traction companies.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- With an uprising in the last quarter, Kenyon College gave the University of Rochester Yellow Jackets their first defeat of the season, 18 to 6, at the river campus today.

A runaway team, drawing an ash cart, was stopped by a patrolman last evening after the horses, going in the reverse direction of a one-way street in East Flatbush, had galloped seven blocks without a driver, sometimes in the street and sometimes on the sidewalk, endangering pedestrians and sideswiping two automobiles.

For a few seething moments at Columbus Circle yesterday the 443d anniversary of the day when the prows of the Christopher Columbus fleet washed through New World surf took on rather violent aspects. That was when Fascists and anti-Fascists came into collision.

SIX works by as many American composers have been commissioned by the League of Composers, each to be performed by a different organization. With the seven works similarly commissioned last season when the League inaugurated its "commission plan," the League now has a total of thirteen such commissions to its credit.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, declared last week that a strong representation of American Jewish athletes at the next Olympic games in Berlin would "gain greater glory both for our own country and for the Jewish people of the world."

FORTY years ago, when George Bernard Shaw was a dramatic critic and still believed in fairies, he penned a savage indictment of an Augustin Daly production of "A Mid-summer Night's Dream," which had just arrived in London.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 12. -- With every section of Connecticut offering an outstanding contribution of allegory or personnel, 400,000 spectators viewed 15,000 marchers in a two-mile parade here today marking the climax of the celebration of the State's 300th birthday.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12. -- Pittsburgh had little trouble downing West Virginia, 24 to 6, in their twenty-eighth annual game at Pitt Stadium today.

ALEXANDRIA. -- British warships come steaming daily into Egyptian waters -- British cruisers, British destroyers, British aircraft carriers, British hospital ships. At the Royal Air Force airdrome at Aboukir British planes and British bombing machines are arriving by hundreds; parts are being assembled to augment largely the number of British aircraft in Egypt.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 12. -- Hard running backs carried Villanova to an imposing 25-0 victory over Bucknell in the homecoming-day game at the Main Line Stadium today before a crowd of 10,000.

VIENNA, Sept. 22, 1935. THE beginning of the Vienna season and the end of the Salzburg festival overlapped, the Staatsoper opening the same night the Festspielhaus closed. The first three weeks have been mainly a chronicle of small beer. For better or worse, the effort to bag some new singers has been resumed in a succession of guest per formances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Government authorities said today that the British monopoly of the best radio circuit between Europe and the United States which prevented broadcasting in America of a speech by Baron Pompeo Aloisi, Italian delegate to the League of Nations, would soon be broken.

ALL of us have, at one time or another, had the experience of groping mentally for some recollection which seemed to be lurking on the borderland of consciousness, a recollection we felt was almost within our grasp, yet which continually eluded us.
TOKYO, Oct. 12. -- "Japan will not obstruct the League of Nations. While not playing an active role, she will not adopt a policy that would tend to conflict with or nullify the League's efforts.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 12 (AP). -- After the foreman had reported that the jury which tried Thomas H. Robinson Sr. and Mrs. Frances A. Robinson for the $50,000 kidnapping of Mrs. Alice Speed Stool could not reach a verdict, Federal Judge Elwood Hamilton late tonight ordered a recess until 9 A.M. tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- A new system of handling juveniles charged with law violation has been adopted by the Chicago Police Department on the recommendation of an advisory committee appointed by Mayor Kelly to study the problem of juvenile delinquency.

SYDNEY, Australia. THE island home of Robert Louis Stevenson, and Vaea Hill, on the summit of which the famous author was buried, form the central design of the sixpence denomination of a picturesque issue of stamps being made by British Samoa.

In addition to placing reorders on apparel and accessories to fill in current stocks, arrivals of a large number of buyers are expected here shortly to cover initial requirements of gift, novelty merchandise and toys for the Christmas holiday season. Optimism on prospects for the holiday trade is running high and retail buyers will back up their confidence with orders ranging 15 per cent or more above last year's totals, according to estimates here yesterday.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Staging a stirring sprint in the last hundred yards, Leslie Pawson of the Fairlawn A.C. of Pawtucket, R.I., finished twenty yards ahead of Pat Dengis of Baltimore, national marathon champion and defending titleholder, to win the eleventh annual New York to Port Chester National Marathon today.

SIDNEY KINGSLEY, that playwright who won the Pulitzer Prize (1934) and did not bounce back ten minutes later with another play, is staging his first professional show. It is "Dead End," by himself, and he came out of a rehearsal at the Belasco Theatre the other day to call it "an experiment in technique, a step toward increased realism in writing and production."

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Victory in the championship hunter sweepstakes went to the nationally known French thoroughbred Prince Charming II, Mrs. Lewis L. Bredin's bay gelding, as the fifteenth annual Orange horse show came to a close today on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 12. -- The United States Army observation plane U.S.W.V. 14 crashed on the E.R. Swope farm, four and a half miles north of Chillicothe, this morning, after the pilot, Captain Rafael Baez of Scott Field. Belleville, Ill., had bailed out while his ship was 6,000 feet in the air.

Arabella was spirited and beautiful, but she was unhappy. She was plagued by the wanderlust, and being a merry-go-round horse, there seemed little chance of her dreams of seeing the world coming true Then came the day when Judy and John, two understanding children took her with them on their rounds of the amusement park.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Syracuse gained its third straight victory of its modern series with Cornell today, 21 -- 14, in a thrill-studded game.

ARRANGING rooms for children -- a specialized field for the professional decorator and an ever-demanding one for the homemaker -- is being made easier and more interesting. Builders of furniture are each year devising new chairs, tables, beds and chests of drawers especially adapted to start youngsters in life and help them along the way of growth.
ARE too many of our young people going to college? The answer to that question depends on what one expects a college to do, on what one supposes that a college ought to be.

BIRDS are the world's greatest travelers. With that mysterious instinct which guides them, they fly hundreds -- sometimes thousands -- of mites to their destination during the seasons of migration. Their schedule is marvelously accurate; they arrive or depart from a place almost exactly on the same date year after year.

KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Hundreds of war veterans who died in the tropical hurricane sweeping the Florida Keys Sept. 2 could and should have been saved, American Legion investigators were told today.

THE shade of William Shakespeare is wandering abroad. No longer is the Bard of Avon content with that most legitimate of theatres built by public subscription near his tomb at Stratford. Shakespeare braves the vasty deep and, at Hollywood, goes into the movies.

HOLLYWOOD. CONTRIBUTING to the cheerier aspects of the picture business, Central Casting -- the bureau that employs all the extras used in Hollywood -- has installed a machine which reduces the hopes, the achievements and the personalities of the cinema's would-be's to the cold impersonality of a multi-punched card.

THE chief film items of the new week stem from such widely separated points as the Antarctic, Paris, England, Pompeii (before its last days), the Naval Academy at Annapolis and a Hollywood model of the Metropolitan Opera.

The New York University football team filled the air with forward passes, supported the aerial bombardment with a splendid ground attack and before so potent an offensive combination Carnegie Tech's eleven crumbled at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

When an innocent girl from Smackover, Texas, makes her mark as a model in New York and Paris it isn't a plain pushover. There's a reason. In Nellie Downes's case, her blond prettiness, her youth and a marvelous pair of legs won her a trip to New York.

TWO four-man bridge teams representing the United States and the Argentine are scheduled to meet "over a bridge table 6,000 miles across" on the night of Nov. 1. An American four, which is expected to include Ely Culbertson, will engage a team representing the Jockey Club of Buenos Aires, with short-wave radio stations in North and South America carrying the bidding and playing back and forth between the two extremes as the contest progresses.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- In a blood and thunder thriller ending in a riotous free-for-all fight around the goal posts, a game, superbly conditioned Yale team turned on Pennsylvania's giants on Franklin Field today to salvage an apparently lost cause with an unexpected 31 -- 20 victory.

The theory behind the spectacular moves for railroad consolidation in the 1929 boom period may stand or fall on the outcome of problems now faced by the New York, New Haven Hartford and the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroads, in the view of some financial observers.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be the initial speaker Tuesday morning at the first session of the fifth annual Forum on Current Problems, conducted at the Waldorf-Astoria under the sponsorship of The New York Herald Tribune. Six sessions will be held, terminating Thursday evening with a message to be sent by President Roosevelt to the audience of club leaders from many States.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- There is good reason to suppose that German rearmament is less formidable and less developed than is generally believed. To no small degree it has been a bluff, which owes its success, at least temporarily, to the fact that it was not only a bluff but a bogy.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The Rice Owls, one of the most feared gridiron units in the South, ended their pre-Conference schedule today with a 14-0 victory over Creighton, co-leader of the Missouri Valley Conference. The defending champions of the Southwest have dropped only one of their last fifteen contests.

IN 1935, as in 1860, cotton is king in the South. Now, as then, the welfare of millions of people depends upon cotton crops and prices. From the delta of the Mississippi, northward, eastward and westward for hundreds of miles, the cotton-crop estimate is a portentous symbol of prosperity or adversity.

Plans for an educational campaign to acquaint high school and college students with a knowledge of how to recognize propaganda and combat its effects have been detailed by Professor Clyde R. Miller of Teachers College, Columbia University, and a member of the board of executives of the Progressive Education Association.

Hundreds of model boats, including every type from home-made contraptions to sleek and expensive racing craft, dotted the surface of Conservatory Lake in Central Park yesterday morning as the semi-annual model sail and motor boat regatta was held.

The Giants, titleholders in the National Football League, will raise their pennant this afternoon at 2:15 when they make their first 1935 appearance at the Polo Grounds. Fifteen minutes after the ceremonies the champions will meet the strong Brooklyn Dodgers eleven.

ONLY one thing more fantastical than the thought of Arnold Schonberg in Hollywood is possible, and that thing has happened. Since arriving there about a year ago Schonberg has composed in a melodic manner and in recognizable keys. That is what Hollywood has done to Schonberg. We may now expect atonal fugues by Shirley Temple.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Gorford Greyskin, a blue roan dog by Whoopee of Ware -- Wild Rose of Pitchford, today was awarded first honors in the open Non-Winners Stake, featured event of the fourth annual field trial meeting of the Albany Cocker Spaniel Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Former President Hoover plans to strengthen his position as titular leader of his party by a high-pressure campaign against the New Deal. This, according to opinion here, aims to make him a possible compromise candidate for the Republican nomination for President.

IN his two novels. "Bredon and Sons" and "The Son of Richard Carden," Neil Bell proved that he could turn out a powerful story of character and incident. But with each of these books the tale was so predominantly localized within English counties not intimately known to Americans that the tale necessarily lost some thing in interest for those on this side of the Atlantic.

THE Trio Italiano, Alfred Casella, pianist; Alberto Poltronieri, violinist, and Arturo Bonucci, 'cellist, will arrive early in February for its first American concert tour. The trio was introduced to this country last Autumn in programs at the Berkshire Festival in Pittsfield and the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., under the sponsorship of Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge.

BRIDGES, docks and waterways in and near New York have stimulated many artists. The Roerich Museum has assembled more than three score works, chiefly by the younger generation of painters with modern sympathies.

DELFT, The Netherlands, Oct. 12. -- The first draw recorded in the series of games for the chess championship of the world between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, titleholder, and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the challenger, was played tonight at the rooms of the Delft Chess Club.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Connecticut State's reputedly strong defense faded before a varied attack by Massachusetts State and the Nutmeggers were handed a 25-12 defeat before a large Dads' Day crowd on Alumni Field today.

PARIS, Oct. 11. -- After sixteen years of diplomatic effort to get everybody into the same net, France is just now having the disagreeable experience of finding herself caught in that net and not being the one to hold the strings. What is even perhaps more irksome is that the net is being used against a different government and people from the one for which, in French opinion, it should have been uniquely reserved.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- The ominous shadow of impending martial law falls across the highways of Illinois as more than 1,000 regular police officers and special deputies endeavor to keep open the channels for Chicago's milk supply. The milk strike is nearing the end of its second week, and neither side has yet shown a sign of yielding.

GREAT BRITAIN, distanced, according to the contentions of her own experts, in the international air armament race, is planning to have a fleet of 2,000 new combat planes by 1937. This does not mean that her present equipment will be written off by that time.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- At the closing session of the two-day Interstate Crime Conference here today, resolutions were adopted endorsing universal fingerprinting, and creation in each State of a bureau of criminal identification and a unit of criminal intelligence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Married three weeks ago, Mrs. Willie Mae Wood, wife of Herbert R. Wood, a Virginia Highway Department employe, was found dead here today in a small hotel. Her throat had been cut. In the same room, with his wrists and arms cut, was W.H. Reaguer of Culpeper, Va.; an undertaker, 50 years old.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 12. -- Away on his toes and going easily over a muddy track, Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Speed to Spare raced to victory in the Maryland Futurity today without so much as a challenge from seven other 2-year-olds.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 12. -- The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported this week increased production of gold, silver and copper in July and reduced output of nickel and lead, compared with the same month last year.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 12. -- Mercersburg lost its first game of the season today, bowing to the Princeton freshmen, 6-0, on Academy Field. The contest was one of the features of the Fall alumni reunion.

THE prevailing tone of this book of short stories duplicates that of the Studs Lonigan trilogy. Mr. Farrell can, and does, handle other types -- to wit, Irish priests, Greek immigrants, and expatriate Americans -- but for the most part he is still concerned with the group of young men who graduated, like Studs, from Saint Stanislaus High School.

If and when AAA is dismantled by the Supreme Court, those sections of agriculture now enjoying the benefits of anti-social legislation intend to continue their privileges, just as organized labor for some time has consecutively demanded and received uneconomic, almost unbearable gains at the expense and sacrifice of the majority.

TRUMANSBURG, Oct. 12. -- This town of 1,100 inhabitants celebrated today the reopening of a public library closed for ninety-six years with 100 of the original books on the shelves for loaning. The interesting event has been made possible by the financial interest of Miss Kate Stone, former secretary to the late Adolph Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and TERA labor directed by Mrs. Keith Sears, president of the new library board.

More than 250 former members of Company G of the 107th National Guard Regiment, the old Seventh, attended a review and dinner last night in the regiment armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, in honor of the ll0th anniversary of the founding of the company.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 12. -- After three games of non-conference competition, the University of Kentucky Wildcats made their 1935 debut in the Southeastern Conference this afternoon by halting the undefeated Georgia Tech eleven, 25 to 6.

FRANCES WOODHOUSE, in this first novel, makes neither pretension nor fuss. She is content with the technique of straight-forward, slow-pacing narrative and plain dialogue, and she does not seek to arrest our attention by the presentation of bizarre characters or extraordinary happenings.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12. -- The Yale 150-pound football team today halted the Hopkins School eleven, 18 -- 7, scoring three touchdowns in quick succession during the first half.

GEORGE JOEL announces that the Heritage Press, 551 Fifth Avenue, which will release its opening series of finely made and illustrated classics on Nov. 1, is the first American publishing house organized with the active participation of booksellers and with their ideas primarily in mind.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The three leaders of the English Football League were defeated in today's games, but the standing at the top of the first division remained unchanged. Middlesbrough gained a 4-2 decision over Huddersfield Town, Shieffield Wednesday won, 1 -- 0, from Derby County, while the last-place Grimsby Town squad swamped Sunderland, 4 -- 0.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- President Roosevelt, his Cabinet and the New Deal agencies get the bulk of the national news in the daily newspapers of the country, according to a survey by Princeton University students.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 12. -- Employing a varied assortment of forward and lateral passes, Bowdoin defeated Wesleyan, 33 to 0, on Whittier Field today.

One of the largest industrial bond issues of the year will be placed on the market on Tuesday morning when public offering is made of a new issue of $55,000,000 of Anaconda Copper Mining Company 4 1/2 per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1950, it became known in Wall Street last week.

The military coup d' etat in Athens last Thursday, in which Field Marshal George Kondylis abolished the republic of Greece and restored the monarchy, grew out of a longstanding conflict in which three principal elements figured. The coup was the work of army and navy officers, who had gained the upper hand over their republican colleagues.

THE bicycle is rolling into public favor again. Ten factories in this country are reported busier than they have been in twenty-five years turning out the two-wheeled machines, and from the riders come cries for cycle paths along highways and in parks where they can be safe from speeding motorists.
A plucky Great Neck High eleven, which showed fine defensive strength, turned in a surprise victory by topping Flushing High, 6 -- 0, yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field before a crowd of 6,000.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 12. -- A member of the 1932 United States Olympic squad, Eino Pentti of the Millrose A.A., gave an impressive performance in capturing the 15,000-meter Metropolitan A.A.U. championship today and leading home a field of thirty starters in the fast time of 47:02.

A HIGHWAY project believed to be without precedent in the history of road Construction will be started this week or next in New Jersey when work begins on the moving of an eight-mile stretch of concrete roadway twelve feet to one side.

The first book sale of the season at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., will take place on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons, when the library of the late Philip Greely Brown of Portland, Me., will be offered.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 12. -- A brief urging the Federal court to direct trustees of the American States Public Service Company to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the terms of the Public Utility Holding Act of 1935 was filed with Judge William C. Coleman today by Ralph P. Buell and D. Heyward Hamilton Jr., counsel for Burco, Inc.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 12. -- Count Luigi Orazio Vinci-Gigliucci, Italian Minister, who subjected himself today to a self-imposed state of siege in the Italian Legation following his rejection of Ethiopia's demand to leave the country this morning, found himself tonight in the home of Ras Desta Demtu, Emperor Haile Selassie's son-in-law.

For those who are interested in what happens to football heroes after their days of glory on the gridiron are over, one plausible explanation is offered in "While the Crowd Cheers." The author, obviously a football enthusiast, is burned up about the problem.

BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- Although the presidents of Harvard, Boston University, and other Massachusetts institutions of higher learning have temporarily retreated before the forces of compulsory patriotism, seven children, members of a religious sect known as the Witnesses of Jehovah, are perplexing the school authorities of Lynn and Saugus by their refusal to salute the American flag.

BOSTON, Oct. 12. -- Hal Price Headley's Tinkling Brook beat an excellent field of 2-year-olds in the Santa Maria, $3,000 added holiday feature, over the six-furlong distance before a crowd of 35,000 at Suffolk Downs today. The victor covered the route in 1:12 3-5.

The leading New York banks showed an average increase of 8.8 per cent in deposits and 7.5 per cent in total resources in the third quarter of this year, on the basis of reports issued by seventeen clearing house banks. Most of this increase in bank funds was left in the form of cash or its equivalent.

Archibald Rutledge has written nearly a dozen books of nature studies of the South Carolina lowlands, and this collection is one more proof of his skill in fixing in words the fleeting beauty of those moments which are the privilege of those who roam the woods with the seeing eye and the understanding heart.
ALBANY, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Drastic action to curb reckless driving was considered by New York State officials tonight as they surveyed the mounting list of automobile fatalities.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 12. -- The University of Michigan chalked up its first Western Conference victory in two years today by defeating Indiana, 7 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Secrets usually are not secrets long in Washington, but the government has managed to keep one phase of its activities generally relegated to the realm of mystery. This is the operation of the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund, by which the Treasury seeks to keep the foreign value of the dollar at such levels as seem best for American business.

IT was just as well for Mickey Cochrane that the world series ended when it did. If it had gone to a seventh game, Manager Mike would have been behind the plate tastefully attired in a strait-jacket. He is the worrying kind and he was putting on a championship worrying fit for the championship series.

WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, BAHIA HONDA, Panama, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The cruiser Houston dropped anchor in this protected bay early this afternoon in time for President Roosevelt to organize his first fishing expedition in surrounding waters.

Two policemen beat a gunman to the draw, killed him and arrested his two unarmed companions at 4:40 P.M. yesterday outside a delicatessen store and lunch room at 428 Hudson Street, between Leroy and Barrow Streets, in Greenwich Village.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- A home-coming day crowd of 2,500 watched Hobart come from behind in the second half to defeat Hamilton 9 to 7, today.

AZTEC, N.M., Oct. 12 (AP). -- The State rested its case today against ten Spanish-Americans accused of the riot-slaying of a Sheriff at Gallup, N.M., after a star witness had identified nine of the defendants as members of the mob.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 12. -- In expectation of adverse decisions by the Supreme Court on all New Deal social and economic legislation, important labor groups are demanding that the American Federation of Labor go on record as favoring an amendment to the Constitution that would give Congress the right to make specific provision for such legislation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Amendments to the newspaper prospectus which specifies information which must be contained in advertisements by seasoned corporations registering issues on Form A-2 under the Securities Act of 1933, intended to simplify and clarify earlier rules, were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LEISURELY old Astoria, quiet backwater of New York City, is at last yielding to the ebb and flow of change. Out of Washington ripples the disturbance, borne on the crest of a $20,000,000 Federal appropriation to clear away the dilapidated homes between Rainey and Astoria Parks, fronting the East River opposite Welfare Island, and to replace them with model apartments.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Providing to students related work closely connected with either their studies or their avocational interests is considered the main problem in the distribution of funds made available to New Jersey College for Women through the National Youth Administration.

A HEARTY welcome, once more, to Father Brown! He has come back to us, and none too soon; for he has been sadly missed during this period since the last Chesterton stories appeared. Father Brown is unique. He not only stands high among the very small list of really great detectives of fiction but he is himself so interesting and so lovable that he becomes an actual friend.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Williams caught Princeton on the rebound from last week's bitter battle with Penn, but the Purple could not quite hold on to the catch. By the relatively narrow margin of Homer Spofford's 56-yard touchdown gallop in the third period, the Nassau powerhouse slipped through to a 14-7 victory over its spirited and ambitious foe in Palmer Stadium today.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the pre-opening performance of "Jumbo," the new musical circus, which has been taken over by the directors of the Maternity Centre Association for Oct. 24 at the Hippodrome to raise funds for the organization.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 12. -- Prices of wheat at the close of today's listless session on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange were 7/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel lower than yesterday. This made the decline 3 cents for the week on Canadian wheat. Today's closing prices were:

THOSE sounds of revelry by night emanating from the depths of the New Amsterdam Theatre are neither the ticket brokers' annual libation to the incoming season nor yet the ululations of the dramatic critics in vinous revolt against the seven-night week.

LONDON. -- It is considered probable here that Great Britain soon will adopt the greatest naval expansion program she has launched since the war, perhaps by means of a loan which would form part of an expansionist program of industrial reconstruction in the interests of the depressed areas and the unemployed (who still number nearly 2,000,000).

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW has attained his seventy-ninth birthday and sneered at it. "I am not distinguished by having birthdays," he said. The attitude of the most exciting author of his day is characteristic of many intelligent men who are far past 60.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Japan will hold her exports of cotton piece goods to the Philippines to 45,000,000 square meters annually, provided there is no increase in the Philippine tariff on such goods, under the terms of her agreement with the United States for voluntarily limiting shipments.

The appointment of a committee, headed by Herbert W. Smith, headmaster of the Fieldston School, to investigate methods of promoting the amateur spirit in school athletics was announced yesterday by the Athletic Association of Private Schools.

This is the second Western tale by the minister of the South Congregational Church of Braintree, Mass., and it is a good one, mixing mystery with adventure and romance. Below the jagged peaks of the Squawtooth Mountains "King" Saul Rangdon was not satisfied even with his mighty Circle-R ranch, but sought to hog the whole range of many miles of rolling grassland.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 12. -- A series of twenty-eight or more minor earthquakes shook sections of Montana early today, causing considerable property damage and causing hundreds of persons to flee from their homes.

While not desirous of having the government formulate rules, prescribing inflexible methods of operation, the woolen industry is anxious for some Federal power to force the "small uncooperative minority" to abide by proposals adopted by a majority of an industry, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, declared yesterday in a letter to George L. Berry, coordinator for industrial cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- "Balance the budget," the watchword that was dinned up and down the country during the Hoover administration, is returning like an errant echo. Since the middle of the year it has been heard in increasing volume.

A WORKABLE tabloid headline for this one would be PLAYBOY PREFERS PROLETARIAN PORTRAYALS, and the subhead might very well read, "Franchot Tone, screen sophisticate, would abandon broadcloth for homespun."

Business continued to move vigorously toward higher levels in the Federal Reserve districts throughout the country last week, the most significant gains being recorded in retail distribution. Under the influence of ideal weather conditions, sales mounted sharply in nearly all sections, with all lines of wearing apparel and home furnishings participating in the upward trend.

ROME, Oct. 12. -- News from Asmara indicates that the defections to the Italian cause of General Haile Selassie Gugsa and General Kassa Araia have had the effect of deciding General Emilio de Bono, commander-in-chief of the operations on the Eritrean front, to hasten the resumption of the Italian advance in Northern Ethiopia and push it in a single forward rush considerably further than was originally intended.

GOLD, and diamonds, and orchids -- -things for which men pay large sum of money; things for which other men may risk their lives; but more than that: gold and diamonds and orchids beckon not only with the promise of riches and the excitement of danger but with the glamour of actual exploration, the lure of the unknown.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Spokesmen for the Cotton Belt today gave added testimonials for the government's acreage reduction program as the cure for the economic ailments of the cotton producer. They were heard as the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's public inquiry into Southern sentiment was concluded.

Some time ago, I believe it was in January of this year, Yehudi Menuhin gave a performance of Mozart's G major violin concerto, K. 216. The young violinist startled people at the time by using a mute in the adagio and, when questioned, defended his action by saying that the score called for it.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12. -- The Yale freshmen defeated Andover Academy's eleven today, 18 to 0, before 800 spectators in the Yale Bowl.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 10. -- Those close to cotton are more cheerful than they have been at any time during the last two years, and, despite Secretary Wallace's warning that a boom in the cotton market was not to be expected, the Southwest is inclined to a cautiously opposite view.

BUFFALO, Oct. 12. -- The Republican Assembly Caravan arrived at Buffalo tonight and its members at once started an intensive campaign to recapture two of the Erie County Assembly seats now held by Democrats.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 12. -- The position of Count Luigi Orazio Vinci-Gigliucci, Italian Minister, was obscure tonight. Although Emperor Haile Selassie delivered an ultimatum demanding that the Minister leave 7 A.M. tomorrow, it appeared possible he might relent and allow him to stay.

A joint recital by Lotte Lehmann, of the Metropolitan Opera, and Harold Bauer, pianist, on the night of Nov. 27 at the Waldorf-Astoria will further the work of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind and its auxiliaries, the Community Workers and the Vacation Camp and Dormitory.

HARTFORD, Oct. 10. -- Surprising even the Republicans, who had been hopeful their campaign against the New Deal would be endorsed, town elections in Connecticut this month resulted in defeats for just half of the Democratic administration seeking to retain control.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- Herbert Hoover, dodging political discussion, had lunch with a group of Stanford University alumni today and attended the Yale-Pennsylvania football game, where he was cheered and applauded by the crowd at Franklin Field.

Economic penalties that the League of Nations may vote against Italy for violation of the covenant will be met by that nation, Premier Mussolini has announced, with discipline and frugality. These devices Italy has become used to. For a generation she has seldom known a year with a favorable balance of trade.

Under the enthusiastic supervision of Mrs. Alexander Lamport of Mount Vernon, N.Y., the 300 chapters of Hadassah will launch on Tuesday a far-flung membership campaign designed to raise the national total for the organization to 50,000 women.

Having demonstrated one type of prefabricated house to more than a million people in exhibitions in the East, Foster Gunnison, president of Houses, Inc., leading factor in the new industry, declared yesterday that "all doubts have been removed" as to the public's receptiveness to these modern homes.

ST. LOUIS. Oct. 10. -- Missouri's old-age pension law, which went into effect Aug. 27 with high hopes that the needy eligibles would receive their monthly stipends of $30 each immediately, has failed to function to date, and the prospects are that payments will not be made before Jan. 1, next, and then only in part.

Business executives from a score of major companies will be among the guest speakers participating in a two-day conference for sales executives at the Hotel Biltmore on Thursday and Friday. The meeting, sponsored by the International Association of Sales Executives and conducted with the cooperation of more than a half dozen other sales organizations, will be devoted to consideration of current trends in business and the outlook for sales expansion next year.

IT is unlikely that any war play or novel could be written without some element of missionary motive. One must be out either to sell Liberty bonds or to annoy Mr. Hearst and his sisters of the D.A.R. You are left to draw your own conclusions regarding the motives which prompted the writing of this play.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Philadelphia lawyers have decided that unless the brakes are applied their numbers are likely to become too large for the good of the profession, from the standpoints of both economics and ethics.

BOSTON, Oct. 11. IN these later years the season in Boston follows a curiously consistent pattern. First there are the elaborate musical shows on their way to New York, dazzling the natives with a display of splendor. When they have departed and the pace slackens, plays of the spoken word begin to put in a modest appearance as they try their wings.

A NEW and smaller Cadillac, a Cadillac-Fleetwood series and a group of La Salle cars were announced last week by the Cadillac Motor Car Company as comprising its 1936 line. In all series prices are said to be lower, while the newcomer, designated the Cadillac Series Sixty, with a list price of $1,645, is said to be the lowest-priced car offered by the company since the four-cylinder models of 1908.

Early last week large advertisements appeared in the newspapers, paid for by the City of New York, informing the electorate of a referendum to be held Nov. 5 on Mayor La Guardia's proposed 140,000-kilowatt $45,000,000 municipal electric power plant to compete with the New York Edison-Consolidated Gas system.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Duke's mighty Blue Devils unleashed their vaunted running attack today, varied with effective aerial thrusts, to blast Clemsen's husky, fighting Tigers from the Southern Conference championship race, 38 to 12.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Duke's mighty Blue Devils unleashed their vaunted running attack today, varied with effective aerial thrusts, to blast Clemsen's husky, fighting Tigers from the Southern Conference championship race, 38 to 12.

ROSE WILDER LANE has written in "Old Home Town" a book which is thoroughly conventional in style and rather unconventional in structure. It would be easiest, perhaps, to regard it as a collection of short stories. The nine sections of which it is composed are complete in themselves; and most, if not all of them, have already been published separately.

More than 2,000 persons, representing nearly 300 business and civic groups of New York City, are expected, to attend a luncheon at the Hotel Astor on Tuesday in honor of Grover A. Whalen as a testimonial of appreciation of his services to business as chairman of the Retail Code Authority, chairman of the Sales Tax Committee of 1,000 and in other capacities.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12. -- One of the most hectic and confused general election campaigns in Canada's history closed tonight in eight of the Dominion's nine Provinces. In the ninth, Quebec, rival candidates will go at it again tomorrow, hammer and tongs, on 100 platforms as soon as church is out, for in Quebec politics, theatres and other "amusements" are allowed on the Sabbath.
GENEVA, Oct. 12. -- The League of Nations reached today the drafting stage on Proposal 2 -- financial sanctions -- against the Italian Government.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 12. -- The position of Count Luigi Orazio Vinci-Gigliucci, Italian Minister, was obscure tonight. Although Emperor Haile Selassie delivered an ultimatum demanding that the Minister leave 7 A.M. tomorrow, it appeared possible he might relent and allow him to stay.

A joint recital by Lotte Lehmann, of the Metropolitan Opera, and Harold Bauer, pianist, on the night of Nov. 27 at the Waldorf-Astoria will further the work of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind and its auxiliaries, the Community Workers and the Vacation Camp and Dormitory.

THAT is exactly what you are likely to do, according to Mr. Malmberg's investigations, unless you are skeptical about anti-fat fakers. If you are bent on dying, he shows that you can easily accomplish your purpose, not only by the "diet" of his effective title but also by a variety of other quack methods whose number, humbuggery and frequent danger make one gasp with surprise.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 12. -- The Amherst freshmen defeated the Roxbury School eleven, 14 -- 0, today in the victors' first game of the season. The initial score came late in the first period when a pass from in Pattengill and two laterals gained 46 yards. Smart crossing the line.

Quite apart from any difficulties that may be created by the application of League sanctions, Italy faces a formidable problem in obtaining the supplies necessary for her East African campaign if it is to be long sustained. It is a familiar fact that, lacking adequate natural resources of their own, the Italian people are heavily dependent upon foreign sources for coal, cotton, fuel oils and the chief metals.
BIRMINGHAM, Oct. 12. -- Auburn bowed today to the University of Tennesse team, 13 -- 6.

WARSAW, Oct. 12. -- A significant turn in the internal political situation in Poland occurred today when President Ignaz Moscicki appointed as Premier Marjan Zyndram Koscialkowski after Colonel Walery Slawek had resigned with his Cabinet this morning.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Quick, accurate aerial thrusts, coming as a surprise attack, brought realization today to a 20-year dream of a scrappy Mississippi State football team as it defeated Alabama, 20 to 7.

The immense audience that welcomed Fritz Kreisler yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall testified again to the power of a name which is consequent upon the power of an artist. The program contained five Kreisler compositions, of which three were taken from the group believed until last January to be the works of various classic masters, as arranged by Kreisler.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 12. -- Connecticut College, the first college for women in the State, celebrated the twentieth anniversary of its opening today with ceremonies which recalled the events leading up to its founding and also the beginnings of "female education" in the State.

Whatever the week may bring forth in Ethiopia, it is already evident that Italy has before her one of the most difficult foreign wars ever attempted. Like China, Ethiopia has been overrun several times before but has always absorbed or thrown off her conquorers.

Five children representing the Seward Park playground and the borough of Manhattan yesterday presented a fast-stepping skit entitled "The Three Bears" and won the day's honors at the finals of the interborough one-act play contest sponsored this year by the recreation department of the Park Department.

PRISONS undoubtedly have a fascination for those who are not in them, and a public execution would fill the Yankee Stadium fuller than it was filled by the recent exhibition of the manly art of self-defense in which Mr. Joe Louis played such a prominent part.

In spite of the "off" season, the liners Manhattan and Washington, fast cabin ships of the United States Lines, continue to substantiate the contentions of the company that they are the ideal type of vessel for American trade, as opposed to the large express liners.

Dickinson High upset the previously unbeaten Perth Amboy eleven at Jersey City yesterday, 13 to 0. A pass from Bill Quinn to Charles Steidel, who ran 25 yards, gave the victors their first touchdown in the third period. Vincent DeMatto intercepted a pass and ran 52 yards for another tally in the fourth period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- A general 5 per cent wage increase, retroactive to Aug. 29, was ordered today by the board of arbitration named by President Roosevelt to adjust the long-standing labor dispute at the Camden yards of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation.

Members of forty-six women's organizations of neighboring communities have been invited to attend a meeting tomorrow afternoon at the Woman's Club of New Rochelle, under the auspices of the civic, education and the intermediate membership of the club.
BROOKFIELD, Mo., Oct. 12 (AP). -- In the cryptic last words of 18-year-old Thelma Wolfe and a note she left behind, authorities sought tonight to read the true story of her death in a pool.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Officials at the district offices of the Works Progress Administration were notified today that 900 workers employed on the Bear Mountain Park project in Orange County would not return to work Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Members of the CCC will have the opportunity to become Civil Service employes of the Federal Government under a recent order of President Roosevelt. The order marks a step of the government toward bringing members of the New Deal agencies into Civil Service.

A smart Evander Childs eleven, displaying an unyielding line, furnished an upset by conquering DeWitt Clinton, 6 -- 0, in the feature contest of a schoolboy double-header yesterday at Dyckman Oval before 8,000 persons.

You have been so kind in your appreciation, with reservations, of "If This Be Treason" that I make bold to submit herewith a statement about certain aspects of the play which I trust may be of interest to you and to your readers. Many of the reviewers, like yourself, found, almost in spite of themselves, that they were "terribly persuaded" by the play; some others, however, felt it to be incredible.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Great Britain is on the eve of a general parliamentary election, the result of which will undoubtedly be to continue the present Conservative Government in power for another five years. Its only opponents at the polls will be the Labor party, which is handicapped by temporary and ineffective stop-gap leadership.

The Fortnightly Club of Rockville Centre, Mrs. Edwin Giles Wright, president, will open its season's program on Tuesday afternoon at the Masonic Temple. The music department, of which Mrs. Leonard H. Calvert is chairman, will present Miss Martha Whittemore in a costume recital of 'cello and viola de gamba numbers.

The sermons today in virtually all the city's churches will mark Columbus Day. Pastors will include petitions that the Italo-Ethiopian conflict may be speedily settled. By direction of Cardinal .Hayes a prayer for peace will be added to all masses in the 456 churches commencing today and continuing "until further notice."
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 12. -- In a hard-fought game today, Lawrenceville battled Franklin and Marshall Academy to a 0-0 tie. Although strong on the defense, both teams were weak offensively.

Britain's power is being displayed at Alexandria to impress and reassure Egyptians who may fear Italian invasion. Britain now has more fighting ships and aircraft assembled at the Egyptian city than at any time since the World War.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 12. -- State and local taxation for unemployment relief is the chief issue in Oregon. It is likely to have a large influence on how the State goes in the Presidential election next year.

OF the German writers who enjoy an international reputation well over half can no longer publish the German editions of their books within Germany, but only in Holland, Switzerland, Czechoslovakia or France. Lion Feuchtwanger, Stefan Zweig, Arnold Zweig, Thomas Mann, Heinrich Mann, Emil Ludwig, , the repositories of the humanist and liberal tradition of the German Goethe period, have had their books burnt or proscribed in Germany.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 28 (By mail) -- We stepped off the Graf Zeppelin at Rio de Janeiro after a four-day flight from Germany, and a day later found us en route by airplane into the heart of Brazil -- into what is known as the Matto Grosso (big forest), 1,200 miles from civilization.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Southern Methodist University's Mustangs, showing the bombing attack that has placed them among the South's leading aerial troupes, smothered Washington University today, 35 to 6, before 10,000 persons.

NOT unnaturally, the deplorable crash near Cheyenne last week serves to focus attention on the risks of flying. That there is some hazard in this newest mode of transportation no sensible person will deny. The spectacular nature of the medium and its speed tend, however, to lend emphasis to the failures rather than to the impressive record of safe performance.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Thirty-five Wellesley students from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will take part in the ambitious dramatic program outlined by the Barnswallows Association for the coming year. As active members, they will gain experience in the production as well as histrionic phases of the theatre.

STRATFORD, Va., Oct. 12. -- Stratford Hall, birthplace of General Robert E. Lee, and the home for generations of a family which has given many famous men to the nation, is now a part of the national heritage.

PRINCETON, N.J. Oct. 13. -- The announcement of the finding of the complete skull of a primitive carnivora, a flesh-eating animal about the size of a cat, which lived in the lower Paleocene Epoch, about ninety million years ago, was made here today by Dr. Glenn L. Jepsen of the Princeton University Department of Geology.

Senator Carter Glass of Virginia will be the featured speaker at the sixty-first annual convention of the American Bankers Association, to be held in New Orleans from Nov. 11 to 14, it was announced here yesterday.
ROME, Oct. 13. -- There were hopes in high quarters tonight for a relatively peaceful settlement of the Ethiopian war. An authoritative personage said:

Although the demand from the automobile and building industries increased, production of steel last week declined 1 1/2 points to 52 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. The decline was caused mainly by lower tin-plate production, and a decrease in railroad orders.

PARKS, Oct. 12. -- The money market here still is narrow. Call money is at 2 per cent and thirty-day loans are at 3 per cent, but the latter are not easy to obtain except from the Bank of France, as shown by the increase in such special loans in the last return.

Apartment rentals reported over the week-end were about equally divided between the East and West Sides. Several Park Avenue suites were included in the East Side rentals. Washington Heights and Greenwich Village were among the active areas.

The cotton mills of the country consumed the staple at a much higher rate in the first two months of this season, August and September, than in the same months the year before, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

The finding of a special committee, which the American Committee on Religious Rights and Minorities sent to Mexico last Summer to inquire into the status of religious liberty in that country, was made public yesterday.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Oct. 13 (AP). -- The Italian Army under General Rodolfo Graziani on the southeastern Ethiopian front has made a total advance of thirty miles from their original starting place in the desert, covered by 250 tanks and 200 airplanes.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13. -- Limiting the increase in the price of newsprint to its customers for 1936 by the Great Northern Paper Company to $1 has created a new problem for the Canadian newsprint industry, according to views expressed here.

Observing the thirty-fifth anniversary of the First Presbyterian Church of Williamsbridge, 730 East 225th Street, the Bronx, the Rev. Albert Dale Gantz, the pastor for nearly twenty-five years, delivered a historical sermon detailing the origin and development of the church up to the present.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- Red Pollock, former Penn Military captain and fullback, performed brilliantly as the Chicago Bears easily defeated the Philadelphia Eagles at Baker Bowl in a National Football League game today, 39 to 0. Pollock scored three touchdowns, all in a big second period when the former league champions made 27 points.

Any thoughtful person reading the letter of former Secretary Stimson must be convinced that the neutrality resolution lately passed by Congress and the ensuing proclamation of the President leaves the United States in a position similar to that of the man who locked the front door to keep out thieves, but left the back door and the windows wide open.

A State-wide registration act for building contf'aotors will be recommended this week by the Research and Planning Committee of the Building Construction Industry, Myron L. Matthews says in the curPent Dow Service Daily Building l Reports.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- Lord Dickinson, president of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches, appealed tonight to the Pope and Roman Catholics of the United States and other countries to take an immediate stand against the Italian aggression in Ethiopia.

VIENNA, Oct. 13. -- The case of Ladislaus Benes, proprietor of the Anglo-American News Service, who was arrested Saturday morning and is to be expelled on the completion of any sentence which may be passed upon him, is attracting a great deal of notice among English and American correspondents in Vienna.

Twelve new playgrounds will be opened at 4 P.M. today by the Department of Parks, making ninety-eight to be opened since January, 1934. Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Robert Moses, James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx; General Hugh S. Johnson and Victor Ridder will speak at the opening of the Macomb's Dam Playground, Sedgwick and Jerome Avenues, the Bronx.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- Germany will be unable permanently to pursue a policy of disinterestedness in the conflict between the League of Nations and Italy. Her neutrality, already announced, can apply no more than to hostilities between Italy and Ethiopia, and to naval operations in the event the League later imposes a blockade.

DUMAS MALONE, the editor of the Dictionary of American Biography, has gleaned from the fifteen volumes of that monumental work, which is now approaching completion, significant data relating to the contributions of the various national and social strains of the foreign-born to the intellectual life of America.

A SPECTATOR, who saw Purdue defeat Fordham at the Polo Grounds, said that Fordham never got started. Nothing like that could be said for the Yale-Penn encounter at Franklin Field. Both teams got started and, for a time, it seemed that neither one would ever stop.

As thousands cheer, "Jubilee" has finally hung its hat in the Imperial Theatre, where it had a tumultuous premiere Saturday evening. It is a rapturous masquerade. By this time every student of the theatre and of navigation must know that "Jubilee" is the musical show Moss Hart and Cole Porter wrote last Spring -- or say that they wrote -- while they were blandly steaming around the world in the Franconia.

Arthur Andresen of the Dragon Club, junior national 220-yard free style champion staved off a closing bid by Harry Tresnak of the Lenox Hill A.A., metropolitan mile titleholder, to win the 100-yard free style event of the weekly A.A.U. swimming meet at the Park Central Hotel pool yesterday.

Francis Hackett, author of the historical biographies, "Francis I" and "Henry VIII," arrived here from Ireland yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Britannic, bringing the manuscript of the first book of a trilogy about the Irish revolution and its background.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- An advance in prices of hogs early last week brought increased receipts, which had a depressing influence, with most of the early gains lost.

When news came from London of how KUDA BUX, a native of Kashmir, had walked barefoot over trenches of living coals having a temperature of 800 degrees this column was perhaps frivolous. It suggested that a couple of regiments of such fire-walkers would greatly help the Ethiopian defense against the corrosive acids scattered by the Italians.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 13 (Reuters). -- Thirty-six Ethiopian infantrymen were buried alive in a dug-

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Endorsed by international unions of the American Federation of Labor with a membership of 500, 000, organized labor's first venture into the field of the theatre was announced today in the formation of Labor Stage, Inc., which will present plays dealing with labor's social and cultural ideals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The Public Works Administration's report today that school construction comprised more than half the 3,965 projects in its part of the work relief program recalled the New Deal's unprecedented subsidization of education, literature and the arts from relief funds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- B. Howell Griswold Jr., chairman of the Investment Bankers' Conference Committee, has sent a letter to all investment bankers and securities dealers informing them of negotiations carried on with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and seeking their cooperation in setting up a nation-wide self-regulating organization to work with the commission in the regulation of the over-the-counter markets and in handling other problems.

One event out of town and another in New York head the list in a varied and full week off art exhibitions. In Pittsburgh the annual Carnegie International will open on Thursday -- always one of the outstanding occasions of the season. On Tuesday the Whitney Museum of American Art will reopen, putting on display works added to its permanent collection since November, 1931 -- about 330 items.

ALBANY, Oct. 13. -- Gaining a brilliant local victory, the black bitch Craigden Consolation today gained the highest honors in the fourth annual field trials of the Albany Cocker Club, which were completed on the hillsides of the Northrup Farm at Feura Bush west of the capital.

In Mrs. Edward B. Huling's address before delegates of the D.A.R. last Tuesday one phrase deserves to be singled out for attention. Mrs. Huling spoke of children's "God-given right to work when and where they please."

This is the Hunter's Moon we have all seen glowing in the night sky. Dogs are as restless as their masters; guns are itching on the wall. The deer season opens tomorrow in the Adirondacks, where the quarry is said to be more plentiful than ever. Partridges, after lean years, are again in full cycle.

Buying continued brisk in most divisions of the wholesale markets here last week, with a heavy volume of reorders for all types of women's apparel featuring trade activity. Manufacturers experienced an unusually strong demand for sports coats, which have been outselling the dressy types, and as a result, merchandise for spot delivery was scarce in the market.

With exchange conditions better and many controls modified, American trade with Latin-American and other Southern countries is showing a steady improvement, according to a report issued yesterday by Harry Tipper, executive vice president of the American Manufacturers Export Association.

For her first New York song recital, given in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, Lola Monti-Gorsey contrived a program that escaped the familiar routine of such events. Instead of the usual classic Italian airs, she began with two troubadour lays and an early French dancing song, all, of course, in modern arrangements.

A defense of the Christian church as something more than an ancient institution, something more than a social club or a place where people may go to seek salvation from sin, was made by Professor William Adams Brown in his sermon yesterday morning in the James Memorial Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary, Claremont Avenue between 120th and 122d Streets.

On the principle that imitation is the sincerest flattery, MUSSOLINI is paying a marked tribute to Japan. What she did in North China he apparently hopes to do in Ethiopia. It is announced in Rome that Italy will promptly annex Adowa and the adjoining territory. Then it is expected that the Ethiopian province of Tigre will be set up as a pretended independent State, after the example of Manchukuo.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13. -- A new outbreak of guerrilla warfare on the Manchurian-Soviet border, with engagements on Oct. 6, Oct. 8 and yesterday that resulted in losses in killed and wounded on both sides, is reported in a communique today from Tass, the Soviet official news agency.

I wish to endorse ex-Senator Walter E. Edge's plan for a national conference of Democrats, Republicans, Independents, et al., who are opposed to the New Deal policies of the present administration. I feel that this is an outstanding and constructive contribution to the present situation, and in the interest of a coalition party.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 12. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85.8, which compares with 85.6 the week before, 85.5 two weeks before, 85.2 three weeks before and 85.1 four weeks before.

After studying reports of game research investigators and other field men of the New York Conservation Department, Commissioner Lithgow Osborne is predicting that when the deer-hunting season opens in the northern counties tomorrow the licensed gunners will find conditions as favorable as they were last year.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Oct. 14. -- A denial that there is any basically new Japanese policy toward China was expressed by Goro Morishima, special Japanese Foreign Office representative, yesterday on his arrival in Shanghai to clarify for Japanese officials in China the present attitude of the Tokyo Government toward the Chinese situation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Camera enthusiasts are up in arms as the result of a decision by the Princeton University Athletic Association that their activities at football games are a menace, or at least a nuisance, to their neighbors.

Columbia University is the recipient of gifts amounting to $325,700, it was announced yesterday by Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university. Of this amount $200,000 was given by William S. Barstow of the class of '87, the income of which is to be used for scholarships.

The De Basil Ballet Russe gave the first performance of "La Boutique Fantasque" in its present season at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon, and in it introduced Alexandra Danilova in her season's debut. Both events were greeted with enthusiasm by the audience, and Mme. Danilova's famous can-can with Massine fairly stopped the show.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Settlement of the bitter rivalry which has split the American Federation of Labor building unions into two warring camps was in sight tonight. Unless unforeseen contingencies arise an early announcement of the results of the last four days of conference may be expected.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Two paintings, one by Robert Henri and the other by George Luks. disappeared yesterday while being taken from New York City to Germantown, Pa., it was reported here today to the South Orange police.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13. -- Forged bonds worth $25,000 have been found among a $550,000 block of genuine securities retired by the Western Pipe and Steel Company, authorities here disclosed today. They have traced the forgeries to New York City.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Hunters, one of whom the State Police believe to be an expert marksman, shot and wounded a game warden near here early this morning when he surprised them "jacking" deer with electric torches and the headlights of their car.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Contending that the financing of the New Deal recovery program represented a "briliant achievement," and that the government's credit has never before "been in a sounder position," Representative Joseph W. Byrns, Speaker of the House, struck back today at critical statements recently made against the administration policies.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Cash interests on the Board of Trade bought December oats last week on all recessions, while tired holders liquidated.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 14 (AP).--Constantin Yureneff, the Soviet Ambassador, visited the Foreign Office today to lodge a vigorous protest over a clash near the Russian-Manchurian border Saturday night in which Soviet guards and members of a Japanese-Manchurian detachment were slain.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 13. -- Before leaving by plane for the United States yesterday Dr. Ernest Gruening of the Department of the Interior accepted the resignation of Mrs. Dorothy D. Bourne from the directorship of the social investigation bureau of the Puerto Rican Reconstruction Administration.

Too many politicians talk too much and so invite the wrath of the Anti-Noise Society.
