To hear from Mr. LOUIS MCHENRY HOWE, one of the most expert and surely the most unselfish of the tribe, is a pleasure. He is rather a glutton of silence than of speech. It is a sign, one hopes, of gaining health and strength, that he consented last week to say a little about next year's campaign.

Notwithstanding the tense situation in Europe growing out of the Italo-Ethiopian crisis, business in the foreign exchange market here last week was quiet and rate fluctuations in the major units confined to narrow range. The only exception to the upward trend was shown in the Italian Jira, which was under pressure and at a decline. Business was on a modest scale so far as volume was concerned.

VALETTA, Malta, Oct. 13 (AP). -- The fears of British naval officers attached to the mighty British armada in the Mediterranean that Malta may become a zone of acute danger was reflected today in the fact that many wives of these officers have received wireless messages from their absent husbands urging them to leave.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT IN PACIFIC, U.S.S. HOUSTON, Oct. 13 (AP). -- President Roosevelt circled the Panama coast tonight, proceeding toward the Gulf of Panama after a Sabbath devoted to attendance at church service and complete relaxation.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- A lightly regarded Canisius eleven enjoyed a field day against Brooklyn College today, winning by a 52-6 count before 4,000 fans.

Five compositions by American composers and a new work by the English composer, Vaughan Williams, will be presented by Hans Lange and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra during Mr. Lange's appearances as conductor in February, March and April. Mr. Lange plans to add other contemporary works to his programs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13. -- Yale's football team has been transformed by the 31-20 victory over Penn from one of uneasy uncertainty to a belligerent self-confident eleven. The team's rally after trailing 20 -- 6, has made the squad from first string players to third string aspirants, jauntly assertive.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71.2 on Oct. 9. This compares with 69.9 a fortnight before, 68.4 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 13. -- With the seven-goal Cyril Harrison turning in one of his finest performances of the season, the Aiken Knights brought the high-goal campaign on Long Island to a close with a well-earned 9-to-7 victory over the Templeton riders on Bostwick Field today.

The Amateur Fencers League of America released its national rankings for 1935-36 yesterday, with the three national champions in each weapon topping the lists. The ranking system, started a year ago in order to give tournament directors a proper line on seeding the duelists, returns two fencers to the No. 1 positions.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- A dispatch to The Times of London from Cairo aid a man who left Massaua at the end of last month gave a vivid description of congestion at Italy's chief seaport in Eritrea. When he left there seventy steamers were lying outside the harbor awaiting their turn to discharge cargo, the informant said.

A collection of the paintings of Vincent van Gogh, the Dutch artist, arrived yesterday from Holland on the liner Statendam for a tour of American art galleries. An estimated valuation of $1,000,000 is placed upon these works of the mad painter, whose entire revenue from his art during his lifetime is said to have been little more than $100.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The firmness of the financial markets here this week is believed by many to reflect the widespread expectation that weak economic sanctions will be applied against Italy and that the League of Nations intends to take only mild measures to uphold the covenant, thus saving its face.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 13. -- The Knickerbocker field hockey team won both of its games in the interclub round robin series at the Greenwich Academy field today, defeating Westchester, 9 -- 0, and Blind Brook, 3 -- 1. A third match scheduled between Blind Brook and Westchester was called off.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Country-wide subscription of funds for a Will Rogers memorial will begin on Nov. 4, the fifty-sixth anniversary of the humorist's birth, and continue until Nov. 27, Eddie Rickenbacker, director of the Will Rogers Memorial Commission, said today.

Using a dexterous, well-timed passing attack as its most effective weapon, the New York Rugby Club subdued the French Rugby Club, 27 -- 0, on the Travers Island grounds of the New York A.C. yesterday.

Europe, tottering on the brink of world war, has adopted an attitude of fatalism that expresses itself in fear and horror of the approaching cataclysm, the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise said yesterday in his sermon at the Free Synagogue, Carnegie Hall.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13. -- The cotton market here was nervous and erratic last week, with alternating periods of activity and comparative quiet. Price fluctuations were frequent, but comparatively narrow, the extreme spread being less than $1.50 a bale.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on display this morning in its Room of Recent Accessions four miniatures from the famous J.P. Morgan collection, which was dispersed at auction in London last June.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 13. -- Today's weather made out-of-door sports popular among the late-staying members of the Summer colony and their guests. It was a busy day on the tennis courts of the Newport Casino, on the links of the Newport Country Club and on the sand at Bailey's Beach.

The suggestion made by United States Senator William E. Borah to Colonel Theodore Roosevelt that the Republican campaign in 1936 be based on the "trust-busting" issue so popular with the late President Theodore Roosevelt was answered here yesterday by Colonel Roosevelt.

ALBANY, Oct. 13. -- In the first nine months of this year 14,031 new stock corporations were chartered in this State, the Division of Corporations of the Department of State reported today. This compares with 14,127 in the first nine months of 1934.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- A presession campaign to prevent Congress from going to new extremes in the matter of relief and public works when it meets again in January was seen here as the motive of publication today by the National Economy League of an analysis emphasizing the apparent ineffectiveness of the present program.

An offering to the public will be made today of a new issue of $20,000,000 first and refunding mort gage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1960, of the Dayton Power and Light Company, by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. The bonds are priced at 99 1/2 and accrued interest.

The American Olympic Committee will be assenting to race discrimination if it allows American athletes to take part in Olympic contests held in Nazi Germany, Dr. Charles S. Macfarland, clergyman and author, declared last night in a talk broadcast over station WEVD.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 13. -- The Chicago Cardinals made it two in a row over the Green Bay Packers before a record crowd of 17,000 today, winning by 3 to 0 to hold undisputed possession of first place in the Western division of the National Football League.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Mayor Herbert W. Jenkins of Englewood Cliffs announced tonight that he had married Joan Crawford, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer screen star, and Franchot Tone, a featured player of the same studio, at 10 A.M. Friday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13. -- Soviet Russia directed today a "resolute" protest to the Japanese Government against a reported new invasion of the Soviet frontier, in which Russian guards and members of a Japanese-Manchurian detachment were slain last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- With a lack of new speculative buying and with liquidation by those who had been bullish, prices of grains generally declined last week. Detailed prices on the Board of Trade here for the week follow:

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Ethiopia is diverting general attention from the internal troubles of the gold bloc countries, and it is reported that Spanish authorities are sounding out the possibilities of external credit for supporting exchange. The French franc is interwoven with internal politics and the situation might precipitate a fresh Cabinet crisis, resulting in a capital flight toward the United States when the unsatisfactory results of Premier Laval's deflationary experiment have been recognized.

The promising young Giant recruit, Jim Ripple of the Montreal Royals, stole the show from Dizzy Dean and his major league all-stars at the Yankee Stadium yesterday as he drove in all the runs that gave the big leaguers two victories over a Negro all-star combination in a double-header.

Behind a six-foot sign saying "No dumping allowed," the body of Timothy Curran, 25 years old, a paroled convict wanted for murder here and in Philadelphia, was found at dusk yesterday in a vacant lot on West Twenty-ninth Street, midway between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 13. -- Count Luigi Orazio Vinci-Gigliucci, Italy's Minister to Addis Ababa, told The Associated Press today "nothing will stop Premier Mussolini from conquering Ethiopia."

Surviving two or three games without defeat is rapidly becoming an enviable accomplishment among the Eastern prep school football teams. Undoubtedly it is largely because their usual six-game schedules are not lengthy enough to prevent the booking of several, breathers and consequently the prep elevens face keen competition virtually every week.

The refunding operation under the final call for the Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s as of date Oct. 15 will leave a balance to be met from the Treasury's cash tomorrow. On that date, except in cases where investors have overlooked the redemption notice, all bonds of that issue and all other United States bonds put out in wartime will have been redeemed in cash or exchanged into other obligations at a lower rate.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- With six teams engaging in a trio of championship conflicts, the scramble for the Western Conference gridiron championship will take definite shape next Saturday for the first time this season.
You might give F.R. Batchelder this explanation of the barring of cameras from the Bronx Zoo.

BUFFALO, Oct. 13. -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, here with the Republican Assembly caravan, predicted tonight that the Republicans would regain control of the Assembly by a sizable majority.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 13. -- Count Luigi Orazio Vinci-Gigliucci, the Italian Minister, refused again today to leave Ethiopia although a special train ordered by the Ethiopian Government waited for him two hours. The train was sidetracked when word was telephoned from the palace that the Minister would not depart.

The State Charities Aid Association, at the request of Governor Lehman, has begun a campaign of public information in behalf of the adoption of the $55,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief which will be submitted to the voters on Election Day.
VIENNA, Oct. 13. -- Sensational allegations of complicity in the great Hungarian "franc forgery plot of 1925 to 1926" are made by Prince Louis Windisch-Graetz in a forthcoming book.

Approval of 310 and disapproval of twenty-four WPA white-collar projects now in operation or being contemplated was expressed in a report submitted yesterday to General Hugh S. Johnson. retiring Works Progress Administrator, by a committee headed by Major Benjamin H. Namm of Brooklyn.
BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- The Detroit Lions beat the Boston Redskins, 17 to 7, in a National Football League game at Fenway Park before 20,000 spectators today.

The Governors Island polo team rode off with the Colonel Joseph H. Colyer Trophy for the third successive year when it repulsed the First Division mallet-swingers of Fort Hamilton in the fifth and final game of the annual series between the teams at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The New Rochelle Bulldogs and the Clifton (N.J.) Wessingtons played to a 7-7 tie in an exciting football game today. Each team scored in the second period, with the visitors crashing across with the first touchdown.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 13. -- Carding a sub-par 70 on the final eighteen, Paul Runyan, White Plains, N.Y., pro golf star, overhauled Alvin Krueger of Beloit, Wis., leader at the fifty-four-hole mark, to win the $5,000 Louisville open tournament today.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- The British equalization fund again intervened at the beginning of the week in support of the pound, but the stering market was steadier later. The dollar, moreover, weakened. Gold entries will doubtless, therefore, make a smaller showing in the next return.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- About the same number of non-Federal PWA projects will be undertaken with work relief funds as under the original PWA program, although the amounts to be spent upon the projects will be considerably smaller, it was revealed today.

Although December sugar contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange last week were commanding premiums of 35 points over the January, 1936, deliveries, the long-expected tightness in the contracts is proving to be much less acute than feared, owing in part to the possibility that the AAA system of financing curtailed production through processing taxes soon may be declared invalid by the United States Supreme Court.
Edna St. Vincent Millay, American poet, arrived yesterday from Europe on the Holland America liner Statendam, accompanied by her husband, Eugene Boissevain.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 13. -- I was awakened by lamplight streaming into my quarters, and in the doorway stood an Ethiopian Colonel. He begged me to arise and to tell the world that the Italians were bombing a Webbe Shibeli village, killing not troops but women and children.

The Succoth festival was celebrated yesterday in many of the city's synagogues with sermons on the significance of the celebration. Several rabbis appealed for a return to the ancient religious truths and pointed out that the new Palestine was more than a mere homeland but a source of spiritual and cultural influence as well.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The number of fatalities in which automobiles were involved rose to a new high in 1934 when 33,980 persons were killed in or by motor cars, a death rate of 26.9 per 100,000 of estimated population, while 1,789 additional persons were killed in collisions between automobiles, railroad trains and street cars, according to a preliminary survey issued today by W.L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- There is no need for a reduction in current food prices since factory wages have increased in equal proportion to the rise in the cost of food, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration declared today in a report prepared by L.H. Bean, its economic adviser.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- Germany's attitude toward the League of Nations was vigorously expressed today by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, in a speech at Saarbruecken when he asserted that there was not a German living who was not happy over Germany's withdrawal from the League two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP). -- Fresh speculation on William E. Borah's plans for 1936 stirred the Capital today upon publication of the Idaho Senator's view that the "question of monopoly lies at the base" of campaign issue-making.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 13. -- Two goals late in the first half by Miss Jo Van Ness enabled the North Jersey Field Hockey Association to down Long Island, 2 -- 0, at the Hempstead Lake State Park today in the first major field hockey game in the metropolitan area this season.

The Walter Scott Free Industrial School for Crippled Children at 55 West Sixty-eighth Street and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Crippled and Delicate Children in Claverack, N.Y., will be the joint beneficiaries of a card party to be held on the afternoon of Nov. 14 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 13. -- The British and French Ministers undoubtedly regard the resistance of Count Luigi Orazio VinciGigliucci, the Italian Minister, as a piece of theatricality that is contrary to all rules of international diplomatic practice.

While commendable efforts are being made to preserve some tracts of our primitive Northern wilderness, down in Kentucky they have just been celebrating the opening to "civilization" of its sometime "trackless, howling wilderness," as CHATEAUBRIAND imaginatively described it in his "Atala."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- The New Deal is to be satirized with animated cartoon movies and then denounced by prominent speakers here this week at a "Safeguard the Constitution" exhibition organized by the "Sentinels of the Republic," the organization which led the successful fight against the "pink slip" amendment to last year's Income Tax Law.

ROME, Oct. 13.--Italy is organizing to withstand the hard times that are expected as soon as the plan of sanctions that Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, is so strenuously advocating in Geneva comes into general application. The Fascist party has taken it upon itself to exercise a strict supervision over prices and to curb profiteering to prevent speculation causing an unwarranted rise in the cost of living.

A faint pop greeted the morning at Governors Island today. And tonight, an equally distressing sound will salute the sunset, while wisps of smoke curl from the once militant muzzle of Fort Jay's saluting gun.
OTTAWA, Oct. 13. -- The Canadian general election will be held tomorrow after a campaign which closed last night on a belligerent note.
LONDON, Monday, Oct. 14. -- A mile beneath the surface of the earth, in the depths of a Welsh coal mine, seventy-one men are fighting the strangest strike in British industrial history.

The immediate and exceptional opportunities offered by available WPA funds for planning public improvements on a county basis were emphasized by the Regional Plan Association in a statement sent yesterday to municipal and other officials.

With five horses entered in each of the two featured races on the card, the Empire City Racing Association will begin its fifteen-day meeting at the Yonkers course today. None of the five stakes scheduled during the session is down for decision on the inaugural program, but Handicapper Jack Campbell appears to have gotten well-balanced fields unless scratches alter the outlook.

A young pianist with a tongue-twisting name, Zbigniew Gniadowski, who was born in Detroit of Polish parents, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night and made it clear that his is a genuine talent. Not a finished artist by any means, Mr. Gniadowski nevertheless revealed qualities that should mark him for significant development: a musical poetic nature, a sense of line and color and an instinct for the piano.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- The German Government announced today that it would open a great National Socialist exposition in conjunction with the Olympic Games in Berlin next year. The official party newspaper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, asserts the exhibition will "present a concrete demonstration of National Socialist principles and program.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Nearly 140,000 men took part today in eleven New Jersey communities in the annual parades of the Holy Name Society of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark. During the afternoon the Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of the Diocese, who reviewed the parade in Bayonne, received the Apostolic benediction of Pope Pius XI for the society.

A net profit of $2,125,020 is reported by the United Corporation for the third quarter of 1935, equal, after preferred dividends, to 1.8 cents a share on 14,529,324 common shares, compared with $2,147,004, or 1.9 cents a share, in the preceding quarter, and with $2,575,083, or 4.9 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1934.

Mayor La Guardia, Governor Lehman and the Consolidated Gas system are criticized for some of their acts in connection with municipal power plants in a pamphlet issued yesterday by the Socialist Party, and written by Dr. Harry W. Laidler.

In the face of world-wide criticism and President Roosevelt's proclamation warning Americans against the use of ships of belligerent nations, the Italian Government has launched a campaign in the United States to urge tourists to visit "the new Italy" and convince them that conditions in Italy have not been altered by the country's preparations for war.

The young in all countries are marching toward "spiritual disillusionment and cynicism" because they are accepting "with adolescent enthusiasm" ideals which have never before been tried and which are destined to disappoint them, the Rev. Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, Dean of the Drew Theological Seminary, said yesterday in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

" Achilles Had a Heel," which was put on at the Forty-fourth Street last evening, is the play in which Walter Hampden appears in black face. After associating with the grandees of classical drama, Mr. Hampden would not emerge as the Moorish-visaged keeper of the elephant in a crack-brained zoo if he did not perceive some great truth in Martin Flavin's play.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 13. -- Setting the pace throughout, T. Suffern Taller Jr. of Piping Rock and Joseph J. Dowling of the home club today defeated Edmund H. Driggs Jr. of the Garden City Golf Club and Maxwell Stevenson of Meadow Brook, 6 and 5, in the final round of the annual invitation best-ball tournament at the Meadow Brook Club.

Neither in this country nor abroad were financial markets perturbed by last Monday's decision of the League to apply to Italy punitive "sanctions." or by the progress of Italy's Ethiopian campaign. Our own stock market "averages" rose last week 3 3/8 points, reaching on Friday a figure 6 points above the month's low level.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Emphasizing a desire to become a part of a farmer-labor party when and if such a group becomes strong enough to represent a real factor in American politics, the executive committee of the Socialist party in session here today decided that no such prospect is in sight and, accordingly, to enter every State in next year's Presidential and Congressional elections.
A call to students in high schools and colleges throughout the country to unite in a demonstration for peace at 11 A.M. on Armistice Day was sounded yesterday by eight national youth organizations.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 52 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the preceding week. Outstanding in the general situation in steel is the steadiness of demand in the last eight weeks following a sharp rise, by approximately one-half, from the early days of July.

Trading in commodity futures was mixed last week, with hides, rubber, zinc and tin among the stronger staples, while sugar, coffee, cocoa and cottonseed oil were depressed. The volume of trading was not large in any of the commodities. In the cash markets, new high marks were reached by antimony, copper, tin, zinc and hides, and rubber advanced, while all the grains, cotton, coffee, cocoa, lard and print-cloths declined.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Machinery for fixing the method of adjusting tonnage and day wage rate differentials among 326,000 bituminous coal miners in the Appalachian field was created today at a joint committee meeting of miners and operators.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- German Jewry will soon be informed of the complete regulations governing the enforcement of the "laws of Nuremberg," but on one point at least clarification by an authoritative source came today.
Scoring ten points against West Virginia on Saturday, Frank Patrick, Pittsburgh fullback, increased his total to 41 and is first in the Eastern intercollegiate scoring.

Restrictive building ordinances to become effective early next Spring were urged last week by Richard S. Childs, president of the City Club of New York, in a letter to Mayor La Guardia released yesterday. Delay in the application of more restrictive ordinances would cause a rush of speculative plans to head off the restrictions, Mr. Childs pointed out.
With renewed hope as a result of the improvement displayed in the Rutgers contest, Columbia will start preparation today for its game with Penn in Philadelphia on Saturday.

Net income of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $7,893,976, equal to $6.58 a share earned on 1,200,000 common shares, compared with $6,085,476, or $5.07 a share, earned in the preceding year.

Hundreds who attended the first field day of the Radio Garden Club at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park yesterday were interested in a rare wild Mexican dahlia, blooming for the first time in the dahlia border near the western rim of the grounds.

In its current state of flux and mutation, with the trend toward flying trapeze, flea flicker and other aerial brain-children serving as an equalizer between the giants and small fry, the football pack has become stacked so full of jokers and wild dark-horses that nothing surprises any more.

With today and tomorrow the last days for registration in the city for the November election, both political parties were prepared yesterday for last minute drives to bring out the largest number of voters possible.

PARIS, Oct. 13. -- In an effort to check the violence of the press criticism on the actions of the British Government at Geneva and in the Mediterranean and also with a view to strengthening his own position, Premier Pierre Laval thought fit last evening at Clermont-Ferrand to issue a statement through the Havas News Agency protesting that Franco-British collaboration at Geneva had been entirely cordial and in the interests of peace.

The Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard, rector of the French Church du Saint Esprit, 229 East Sixty-first Street, in his sermon yesterday morning made a plea in behalf of Italy in her present struggle in Ethiopia and criticized both nations and individuals who call Italy an "outlaw" nation.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct 13.--Three armed bandits ransacked the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Rowse, 457 South Ocean Avenue, at 10:30 o'clock last night after slugging Mr. Rowse, a retired business man, with the butts of their revolvers and binding and gagging Mrs. Rowse with adhesive tape.

Elizabeth Miele, who has offered Broadway no show since the season before last, will do something about it tonight. "Triumph," by one George Austin, a Nevada newspaper man, is the play. The Fulton and 8:40 o'clock are the place and time. And the cast: Ruth Matteson, Gladys Griswold, Douglas Gregory, Zamah Cunningham, Howard Miller and Leslie Bingham are among the important people in it, Priestly Morrison being their director.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- An effort to interest industry in increasing the possessions and standard of living of the masses by taking advantage of technological progress to lower prices will be made by the Brookings Institution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Industrial activity in the first week of October was maintained at the September level, the Department of Commerce said in its weekly survey of domestic business. The index of steel and automobile production for the week ended on Oct. 5 advanced, while the index of electric power output changed slightly.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 13.--After deliberating seven hours and thirty-five minutes, a jury in Federal Court today acquitted Mrs. Thomas H. Robinson Jr., and her father-in-law Thomas H. Robinson Sr., of complicity with her fugitive husband in the kidnapping of Mrs. Berry V. Stoll, Oct. 10, 1934.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 13. -- The week-end was one of the busiest of the season with many entertainments. Hotels and clubs were filled to capacity.

A dwelling and apartment project for eighty city lots in the Greenville section of Jersey City, owned by the Henderson family, seed merchants, for more than a century, was announced yesterday. The buyer and prospective builder is the Dorsey Realty Syndicate, Inc., represented by the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

ROME, Oct. 13. -- Baron Pompeo Aloisi, chief Geneva envoy of Italy, made a radio plea for fairness tonight direct to the United States -- a plea that Great Britain's postoffice refused to relay last week.

I read with interest the letter appearing in THE TIMES, written by Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, on the dangers of neutrality. I concur with Mr. Stimson's views for two principal reasons. The first is that there is woven into the question of neutrality a moral feature which cannot be ignored.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP). -- William Miles Taylor of Bear Mountain, N.Y., today was named coach of the American Olympic speed skating team which will compete at Garmisch-Partenkirken, Germany, Feb. 1-16.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 14. -- The visit to Japan of George H. Dern, United States Secretary of War, began this morning when at 8 o'clock the cruiser Chester anchored at Yokohama. Mr. Dern was welcomed by Edwin L. Neville, United States Charge d'Affaires; the Governor and the Mayor of Yokohama and representatives of the Navy, Army and Foreign Offices.

A plea for unification of Christian denominations was made yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Herbert L. Willett of Chicago in a sermon commemorating the 125th anniversary of the founding of the Central Church of the Disciples of Christ, 142 West Eighty-first Street.

Mrs. Cornelius E. O'Connor Jr. will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at 720 Park Avenue for a large group of matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "On Stage" the night of Oct. 31 at the Mansfield Theatre for the benefit of the Vocational Service for Juniors.
LONDON, Oct. 12. -- The necessarily slow proceedings in Geneva provide a breathing space in which one may turn to the progress of events in Africa.

GENEVA, Oct. 13. -- Working hard through Sunday, the League of Nations subcommittee of eight on financial sanctions against the Italian Government agreed tonight after five hours of steady discussion on the text of Proposal No. 2. It will be milled over tomorrow by the committee of eighteen.

A field goal by Ken Strong in the final quarter won the opening home game of the professional football season for the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday when they turned back the Brooklyn Dodgers, 10 to 7, in a hard-fought contest before a crowd of 30,000.

Despite the recent fear of war in Europe, foreign holdings of the preferred and common stocks of the United States Steel Corporation increased in the three months ended on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday.

THIS is Mark Twain's centenary year. To commemorate it, Albert Bigelow Paine has prepared for publication "Mark Twain's Notebook" (Harper, $4). Those who have read the Paine biography of Twain, those who are steeped in Twain's own books (which provide the man's own autobiography in large measure), and those who have followed the Brooks-de Voto controversy will discover nothing of great import in the "Notebook."

The familiar landmark at 810 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn, erected by the late Ludwig Nissen on the model of Kaiser Wilhelm's residence at Potsdam, today houses a Soviet elementary school for thirty-five young Russian boys and girls.

Former Supreme Court Justice John M. Tierney, the senior judicial officer of New York State, who was made an official judiciary referee for a life term in 1930, celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday yesterday. A birthday party, attended by leaders of the political, business and theatrical world, was given in his honor last night by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Murray at their apartment, 91 Central Park West.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 14. -- Governor Hoffman of New Jersey called upon the 7,000 delegates to the National Safety Council at its convention here today to set for each State in the nation the goal of reduction of 35 per cent in motor vehicle deaths by 1940.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Fourteen teams played in the final one-day tournament on the New Jersey P.G.A. schedule today at the Summit Golf Club, with Mrs. F.A. Neuberg of Hackensack and Jack Forrester, pro at the same club, winning a Scotch foursome with 73, two over par.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Asserting that processing taxes and tariffs are "full of peril," Secretary Wallace tonight contended that such levies would be necessary until high tariff groups are compelled to "behave" as the nation's "creditor position requires."

MASSAUA, Eritrea, Oct. 14. -- Two thousand men were added to the greatest colonial army in modern history when the transport Gange, formerly the liner Presidente Wilson, arrived here today. Though the

Officials of the National Youth Administration conceded yesterday that they had given up hope of finding any kind of employment for most of the 11,000 high school students in this city who are to receive $3 to $6 monthly from the Federal fund.
WITH THE ITALIAN FORCES AT ADOWA, Ethiopia, Sunday, Oct. 13 (4 P.M.). -- Aksum, the holy city of ancient Ethiopia, fell into the hands of Italy's armies today without so much as a single gun shot.

Making their fourth consecutive advance yesterday, stocks generally reached their best level since the middle of last month. Government and foreign dollar bonds were in demand. Wheat and cotton were lower. Wall Street continued to ascribe the rise of stocks to the domestic improvement in business and attributed the weakness of grains on the lessened fear of a European war.

If we may say it again and live, the last day and the last night of registration are here. When the count is made everybody will be satisfied, as usual. Mr. EATON will rejoice to see that the people have shown their determination to wipe out the New Deal, protect the rights of States, put the pulmotor to the exhausted Constitution, restore liberty and prosperity to an oppressed nation.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14. -- Two hundred children trooped to classes today in the glass and garden rooms of a "test tube" schoolhouse in which the modern architecture is bent to the latest educational methods.

Cooperative action by medicine manufacturers to get Congress to enact a satisfactory pure food and drug law at its session opening in January was urged yesterday by Charles L. Huisking, president of the United Medicine Manufacturers of America, Inc., in opening the organization's fourteenth annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

TORONTO, Oct. 14. -- Ontario saved some seats for the Conservative party in the general election but at the same time swung sharply to the Liberal side. Liberals captured fifty-five of the Province's eighty-two seats, but the twenty-six Conservatives elected assured the continuance of the Conservative party as a fighting force in Parliament.

The official census figures on automobile fatalities do not greatly differ from the earlier estimates. They indicate that 35,769 people were killed in the United States last year as compared with 30,760 the year before. In 1933 a community the size of New London was destroyed; in 1934 this City of the Dead had swollen to the size of White Plains.

ROME, Oct. 14. -- The Vatican takes a grave view of the situation. In Vatican City, that extraordinary 150-acre kingdom embedded in Rome, the developments in Geneva are regarded with misgivings and as heading toward general war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed in September totaled 449,126 bales of lint and 61,127 of linters, compared with 408,410 and 57,866, respectively, in August, and 294,414 and 53,913 in September, 1934. The Census Bureau reported today cotton on band on Sept. 30 showed an increase over the month before, but a decrease from September, 1934.
Fashion invaded the Wall Street district yesterday when a group of society maids and matrons appeared as manikins at a Fall fashion show at the Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street.

DEDHAM, Mass., Oct. 14. -- On the recommendation of Chief of Police William Fleming of Wellesley, bail of $10,000 each was asked for Albert Berger of Cleveland and Alvin Barton of the Bronx when they were arraigned in the district police court here this afternoon.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers is offering today $2,756,000 ctiy of Newark, N.J., 4 1/2 per cent bonds, which were purchased last week from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The bonds, which are dated Aug. 1, 1933, and mature from 1936 to 1983, are priced to yield from 1 to 4 per cent

Tension, as Mrs. Malaprop would have said, has once more broken loose on the Russo-Japanese border. Moscow complains of Japanese raids. But is it really a quarrel, or is it only Moscow's way of applying sanctions to MUSSOLINI?

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 14. -- If Colonel Henry H. Rogers of Manhattan and Southampton had not exercised his power of appointment over a trust fund, amounting to about $10,000,000 at the time of his death, July 25 last, his estate would have been saved more than $4,000,000 in Federal estate taxes and New York State transfer taxes.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Bertha Weinman, who died Jan. 22, showed that Mount Sinai Hospital would receive more than $1,300,000. Miss Weinman left an estate of $1,830,002 gross and $1,703,453 net. The hospital bequest is one of ten public gifts provided for in the will and is to establish a fund for the care of convalescents in memory of her brother, Moses Weinman.

The Superheater Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $371,957 after expenses, depreciation, provision for Federal taxes and other charges. In the corresponding period of last year the company had a net income of $378,120, equal to 43 cents a share on 874,554 shares then outstanding.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 (AP). -- The cash register at the Yale Athletic Association jingled a post- depression tune today as it picked up the echo of the Elis' victory over Pennsylvania.

The problem of preserving American neutrality in the midst of conflict abroad will be discussed today at the opening session of the fifth annual forum on current problems at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of The New York Herald Tribune.

ATHENS, Oct. 14. -- Cautious diplomatic soundings are being made here and at Angora to determine whether Greece and Turkey, which are bound together by a mutual defense pact and are already taking armed precautions against a possible Mediterranean conflict, would be willing to join Britain in military sanctions against Italy.

On its second visit to Manhattan, the Chicago A Cappella Choir presented an unaccompanied program of generous proportions in Carnegie Hall last night. The fifty men and women singers of the chorus were clad in vestments but not such as to suggest a church service.

Despite the assurances given by bankers and lawyers during two sessions of the Congressional committee investigating bond reorganizations, that the Paramount Publix Corporation's reorganization was entirely in the interest of all creditors and bondholders, A.J. Sabath, chairman of the committee, told his investigators yesterday to "get the lowdown on the whole situation."

The investment market demonstrated again yesterday its eagerness for new high-grade corporate bonds with its reception of the issue of $20,000,000 of Dayton Power and Light Company 3 1/2s. Offered at 99 1/2 by a banking group headed by Morgan, Stanley Co., Inc., the bonds went to a premium of 1 1/2 points by mid-afternoon and were quoted in over-the-counter trading at about 100 1/2 at the close of the day.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14. -- How a young Communist girl made a living torch of herself and burned to death in protest against mistreatment by her husband was related at the first Congress of Young Eastern Women recently held in Baku, according to today's Izvestia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The "opportunity and plain duty" of the republics of the Americas to "keep the peace," even perhaps assuming the responsibility of preserving together the benefits of civilization in a war-torn world, was urged today by Secretary Hull at the opening here of the second general assembly of the Pan American Institute of Geography and History.

Evidence in the alleged tampering with the Education Department's examination last April for licenses as public health education teachers will not be submitted to the New York County grand jury today as had been expected. Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the indictment bureau, announced the grand jury inquiry had to be put off because of the illness of the mother of the principal witness.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14. -- Bringing in one of the greatest wheat crops in Russia's history, estimated at between 100,000,000 and 110,000,000 tons, and delivering it to the State grain elevators a month earlier than last year, Soviet farmers were hailed today throughout the capital's press as having mastered the modern machinery of agriculture.
Brokers reported sales of apartment houses in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday, with most of the trading in the latter borough. Savings banks and operators figured in several of the deals.

The Board of Health opened hearings yesterday in the aldermanic chamber, scheduled to last three days and to clear the way for new regulations having the force of law to protect the public in this city against dangerous patent medicines land cosmetics.

Mail reorders received here yesterday by the resident buying offices were extremely heavy, with the volume as large, if not larger, than that noted last Monday. While Columbus Day trade here did not show the heavy gains expected, volume in other sections was notably good, according to reports.

Victor J. Sudman, president of the Black Diamond Steamship Company, operator of a fleet of freight ships between New York and Rotterdam and Antwerp, announced yesterday that effective immediately all officers on the line's eight ships would receive annual two-week vacations with full pay.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- Contending that the government's policy of financing itself by deficits meant the possibility of a collapse of the national credit and "some sort of dictatorship," Lewis W. Douglas, former director of the budget, declared in an address here tonight that the danger could be avoided by "giving evidence of a grim determination to stop spending the country into bankruptcy and to bring the budget into balance."

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Receipts of livestock here today were the heaviest of the season, and the supplies were too much for the markets to readily absorb. Prices of hogs dropped 10 to 25 cents a hundred-weight, with packing sows showing the most loss in sympathy with a further recession in lard.

With more than one-third of the public health work in the United States supported by contributions to community chests and other private services, only $1 per capita from both public and private funds is being spent for public health work in the nation, it was pointed out yesterday by Gerard Swope, chairman of the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs.

Colonel de Basil's Ballet Russe devoted its performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night to the presentation of three ballets all listed as "after" the choreography of Michel Fokine. They were "Les Sylphides," "Petrushka" and the Polovetsian dances from "Prince Igor," none of which had previously been given this season.

The many and varied cash registers, adding machines and other business devices displayed yesterday at the opening of the thirty-second National Business Show at Commerce Hall, Port Authority Building, are recording six-year sales peaks for the office-equipment industry, according to officials of many of the seventy-six exhibiting manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Six injunction suits on file in the District of Columbia Supreme Court to restrain Secretary Ickes, PWA Administrator, from allocating funds for the construction of municipally owned lighting plants in twelve Southern towns were hastened on their way to a final determination in the Court of Appeals today.

With scores of youngsters almost mobbing Mayor La Guardia in their effort to get their pictures taken with him, twelve new playgrounds built by relief workers in four boroughs were officially opened yesterday by the City Department of Parks.

A controversy which has vexed Wall Street for many months was ended yesterday when arbitrators appointed by the American Arbitration Association announced that trades in the $2.50 prior preferred stock of the Alleghany Corporation when issued were valid.

Bitterly denouncing the power and utility interests as having grown and prospered "by bribery and corruption," Mayor La Guardia said last night that they had provided just the issue he desired in his fight for a municipal power plant to serve as a "yardstick."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York said here today in an interview that "it is possible I will enter the Ohio primaries next May and carry the issue to the people, present facts and challenge all other Presidential candidates to do the same thing.

The message of Martin Van Buren during the depression of 1837, more serious than the one said to exist now, deserves attention. President Van Buren was almost as good a politician as President Roosevelt. His message, however, lost him the Presidency. Instead of weeping sentimentally and offering everybody the help of the government, he said:

The number of persons placed in jobs under the WPA has passed the 200,000 mark, General Hugh S. Johnson, Work Progress Administrator for this city, announced yesterday on the eve of his retirement, to be succeeded by Victor F. Ridder, publisher.

The possibility that many poor families in the city may soon be unable to purchase kerosene for heating and illumination was seen yesterday in the disclosure that the price of kerosene "safety" cans, required by the Fire Department on and after Nov. 1, will be from $3 to $3.50 apiece.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 14. -- Two teams shared the leading scoring honors today in the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association over the 6,404-yard links of the Sands Point Club.

Only through "continued public pressure" will New York get general Sunday shows, Dr. Henry Moskowitz, executive adviser of the League of New York Theatres, said yesterday afternoon in making his annual report. The league met in its offices in the Paramount Building.

Dr. Raymond Ditmars, curator of mammals at the Bronx Zoo, returned from Trinidad on the liner Nerissa yesterday with seven specimens as notable for their rarity as for their appetites. The specimens included four leaf-nosed bats -- Vampyrus spectrum -- the first ever to be brought back alive, according to Dr. Ditmars.

There was a sort of lull before a practice storm at Baker Field yesterday as Columbia started preparations for its game with Penn in Philadelphia on Saturday. The Lions drilled for two hours and there was nothing intensive about the session, but Coach Lou Little let it be known that starting today there will be long and hard workouts in store for the Blue and White.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Head Coach Ducky Pond told the Yale varsity football squad today, in outlining practice plans for the Navy game Saturday, that in that contest it will meet stiffer competition than Penn provided last Saturday.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 14. -- Official news from the various fronts is absolutely unobtainable here. The frontier lords, though mostly loyalist, seem to have reverted to the feudal system, shaking themselves free from the control of the general staff.

Constructive operations in the market for United States Government obligations on a somewhat heavier turnover were a feature of an otherwise listless trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Foreign government loans, with the exception of Italian issues, also were in good demand at advancing prices.

A servant who had just left the employ of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Goldsmith of 575 Park Avenue was arrested last night as the accomplice of the burglar who robbed the penthouse apartment of the Goldsmiths of $51,000 in jewelry on Dec. 8.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14. -- By a rising vote, to the accompaniment of an enthusiastic outburst of applause, the delegates of the American Federation of Labor convention approved today the terms of settlement for ending the long struggle that has divided the building unions into rival camps.

The rotation system of shifting city magistrates from one court to another each week probably will be discontinued, according to Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., who said last night that the abuses that were responsible for the rotation had been virtually wiped out.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, announced today the appointment of an eight-man church directorate with dictatorial powers. Seven of the eight directors are opponents of Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller and the Nazi German Christian movement that brought him to power.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Trading in daily indemnities and a change in the basis of margin requirements were voted today by members of the Chicago Board of Trade. The final poll showed 880 for the changes and 57 against.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, will reopen for the season today, not to close again -- save for a fortnight in mid-Winter before the biennial -- until next August. The hours are 1 to 5 o'clock every afternoon except Monday.
One of the most important exhibitions of armorial bookbindings ever assembled was opened yesterday afternoon at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street.

An order directing the American Hide and Leather Company to show cause why it and its officers should not be restrained from effecting a plan of recapitalization pending a final hearing on a bill of complaint was issued yesterday by Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder in Chancery Court, Jersey City. The order is returnable on Oct. 28.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- As the first sequel to the Geneva decree, supported by this country, lifting the embargo on the export of arms to Ethiopia, two applications for licenses to make such shipments were filed today with the British Board of Trade.

Michael J. Hogan, former Representative from Brooklyn, who is on trial in Federal court on a charge of having accepted bribes from aliens in 1933 when he was confidential clerk to Philip Elting, then Collector of the Port, took the witness stand yesterday and flatly repudiated statements that the government contends he made in June, 1934, in the presence of a stenographer.
OTTAWA, Tuesday, Oct. 15. -- In the Liberal sweep of yesterday Cabinet Ministers toppled all along the front. Early today the following had gone down:

May I rise to a question of personal privilege in replying to a letter from Mrs. Virginia M. Bacon published in your issue of Oct. 10 in which she endeavors to portray me as a defender of murder and assassination and the American Civil Liberties Union as a 90 per cent Communist organization?
BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler has formed a "brain trust" to coordinate all the various Nazi plans for a better Reich and to see that they are carried out effectively.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

The stock market yesterday reflected the widespread belief that consummation of the Atlas Corporation-Lehman Brothers acquisition of the Radio Corporation's controlling interest in the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation would facilitate the elimination of arrears of dividends on the Radio Corporation Class B preferred stock, which were $15,350,500, or $20 a share, on Oct. 1, 1935.

There are definite signs of recovery, especially in retail trade, although the heavy industries have considerable ground to regain, J.M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad said yesterday in an address before the Hoboken Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the filing of nine more registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, for a total value of $6,399,625 in proposed issues. They were listed as follows:

Head Coach Mal Stevens gave his New York University football squad a rest yesterday following its victory over Carnegie Tech last Saturday. The Violet will return to Ohio Field today to resume training for its third game -- against Pennsylvania Military College at the Yankee Stadium -- next Saturday.

In outlining the objectives of the American Wildlife Institute, J.N. Darling, chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, maintained that the field of influence of the organization in accomplishing the international restoration of game, fish and other wildlife was almost unlimited.

ALBANY, Oct. 14. -- Governor Lehman, in a statement tonight, urged citizens of the State to register for the election next month. He called attention to the referendum on the county home rule amendment to the Constitution which would permit the reorganization of county governments if the voters so determine.

Changes in the authorized capitalization of the Tung-Sol Lamp Works have been approved by the stockholders of the company, it was announced yesterday. The new capitalization will consist of 210,000 shares of no-par preference stock, bearing cumulative dividends of 80 cents a share, and 500.000 shares of $1-par value common stock.

WARSAW, Oct. 14. -- Poland's new deal premier, Marjan Zyndram Koscialskowski, broke the rule of secrecy and isolation of his predecessors when he called a press conference tonight, the first in eight years, immediately after the first session of the new cabinet.

Ragweed pollen in the New York atmosphere, said to cause most hay-fever cases, was 20 per cent more prevalent this year than last year, according to the results of the seventh annual collection of ragweed pollen made at the New York Meteorological Observatory in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Positive assurance that the constitutionality of the Agricultural Adjustment Act and the Tennessee Valley Authority Act, keystones of the New Deal, will be passed upon by the highest court in the land came today when the Supreme Court, through written orders, consented to review two cases involving the basic merits of these statutes.

In a recent issue of your paper you noted the appointment of a new head of the Rockefeller Institute. This man and his associates, along with a great many other men of the same kind, have accomplished untold good for the relief of the sick and the afflicted. Millions and millions of dollars have been poured into this one endeavor and the unending praise and appreciation of the people of the world should continue.

Mayor La Guardia served notice on the rest of the country yesterday that New York's business men were tired of bearing single-handed the burden of promoting recovery through higher industrial standards.

The chief significance of Senator BORAH'S letter to Colonel THEODORE ROOSEVELT, who had invited him to address the Republican Club in this city, is that it shows the Senator's intention to be serious as well as, of course, honorable. He is evidently ready to write the Republican platform for next year.
BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador to the United States, defended the policy of his country in Ethiopia as he spoke tonight at a dinner of the Order of the Sons of Italy.
The women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies opened its campaign for $650,000 at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

The $55,000,000 financing operation for the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, in the form of an offering of 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures, due on Oct. 1, 1950, will be carried out today through a nation-wide underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The British Cabinet will hold its adjourned meeting tomorrow to complete the unfinished business of last week and on Wednesday will meet again in regular session. Both conferences will be concerned chiefly with the Ethiopian war and with preparing the government's presentation of its case next week when Parliament is to reconvene for a debate on foreign affairs.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- New York State sportsmen oiled their guns and scanned the skies tonight preparatory to the opening of the 1935 hunting season with the assurance of the Conservation Department of an "abundant" supply of game.

Registration in the city rose to a new high for an off political year, and surpassed the figure for last year, a Gubernatorial year, by more than 150,000, when the total registration for the first five days was tabulated early this morning.

GENEVA, Oct. 14. -- The Secretary General of the League of Nations has made public on behalf of the Committee for Coordination of Measures Under Article XVI of the Covenant the following text adopted by the committee at its meeting today:

Returns gathered by The Associated Press and The Canadian Press showed the following candidates had won in Canada's parliamentary elections [Liberal candidates are designated (L), the Conservatives ( C ), the Reconstructionists (R), the Social Credit party (S), the Liberal Progressives (P), the Independebt Liberals (I) and those of the Cooperative Federation (F)]:

The casual visitor at any of the numerous projects under supervision of our army and navy is oftentimes amazed by the perfect coordination of every detail and marvels at a system which enables such housekeeping. The pivotal centre from which this coordination functions is, in the army, the provost sergeant; in the navy, the master-at-arms.
Paul Green, the Pulitzer Prize winning playwright, has a novel on the Harper list. It is called "This Body the Earth," and is about poor whites in the South. Harpers will publish it on Oct. 22.

At a meeting of the trustees of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club at Oyster Bay, L.I., last night, a letter from Algernon Maudsley, honorary secretary for the British Yacht Clubs, was read on the 6-meter situation for next year.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Lloyd's and other big British insurance companies are ready to close the British insurance market completely to all Italian applicants whenever the government gives the word. It was said tonight the companies were standing by, awaiting government instructions to apply the financial sanction which would deprive Italy of her main source of insurance protection for her shipping and other forms of reinsurances taken out abroad.

With another intersectional foe to be met next Saturday, Fordham's football squad came in for a drastic shuffling yesterday at Fordham Field, resulting in more changes than ever have been effected in a first-string line-up on Rose Hill.
Everett Meyer has resigned as vice president and director of the P. Lorillard Company. He was with the company for twenty-three years.

Harry Newman has signed a contract with the New York Football Giants and will join the team tomorrow to prepare for the clash with the Boston Redskins at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. Earlier in the Fall the former All-America quarterback at Michigan had announced his retirement from active competition.

The trading in commodity futures here yesterday was mixed. A feature was a sharp advance in silk and another was the virtual halting of trading in sugar. On the cash markets new high prices for 1935 were set by tin, antimony and silk, while declines occurred in all the grains, mess pork, printcloths and rubber.

TOKYO, Oct. 14. -- Foreign Minister Koki Hirota proposed today to Constantin Yureneff, the Russian Ambassador, the formation of a joint commission to fix the border between Manchurian and Russian territory. The proposal being entirely new, Mr. Yureneff referred it to Moscow.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,377,052,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The $4,750,000 loan extended by the Chase National Bank to the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad has been extended to Jan. 2, according to the application of the carrier for a $5,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Despite the outward calm in the foreign exchange market, uneasiness over the future stability of the lira increased yesterday to a point where the market almost reached a standstill. Concern over the future of the Italian currency was heightened as the first definite measure in the sanctions program of the League of Nations was passed with only two dissenting votes at Geneva.
GENEVA, Oct. 14 -- The delegates of fifty governments agreed tonight on a complete credit blockade of Italy.

Hirsch Jacobs, who has saddled more winners than any other trainer for the past two years and is well ahead this season, sent out the victors in both divisions of the Dunwoodie Handicap, featured races, as Empire City Began its Fall meeting yesterday.

Several card parties will be held in the near future for the benefit of charitable organizations. The annual luncheon and card party in behalf of the Junior Catholic Big Sisters will take place next Saturday at the Central Park Casino. A feature of the entertainment will be a fashion show.

Contracts for residential construction amounting to $41,810,800 were let in thirty-seven States in the East last month, as contrasted with $40,528,300 in August and only $17,8553,600 in September, 1934, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation, which reports that during the first nine months of this year the contract total was $338,907,500, as compared with only $188,080,100 for the corresponding period of 1934.

The Colon Oil Corporation, holding company for the Colon Development Company, Ltd., which owns petroleum concessions in Venezuela, filed a petition yesterday in Federal court asking permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Maude Adams made an unheralded appearance yesterday before half a dozen persons in the Supreme Court to defend a suit brought against her by John D. Williams, former stage director, who is suing her for $200,000 for services in inducing her to return to the stage.

MEMEL, Oct. 14. -- The victory of the German element in the recent elections for the Memel Diet was officially confirmed today when the election commission announced the final figures simultaneously with reports from Kaunas that Vladas Kurkauskas, Governor of the territory, had resigned.
LONDON, Oct. 14. -- For the first time in many years Great Britain's exports in September were less than in August, the month when midsummer slackness usually is at its worst.

The work of building a pass defense, in anticipation of the aerial barrage expected when undefeated, untied and unscored upon Holy Cross comes to Ebbets Field next Saturday to meet Manhattan College, was started yesterday by Coach Chick Meehan.

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- Clinging steadfastly to his role of peacemaker and intermediary between Great Britain and Italy, Premier Laval received both the British and Italian Ambassadors to France today and tried once more to throw a bridge across the widening gulf between the governments of their countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Federal Department of Justice agents revealed the arrest tonight of a 23-year-old youth in an alleged extortion plot which carried a threat to sear the face of a Philadelphia debutante with acid.

The Supreme Court agreed yesterday to pronounce judgment on the constitutionality of two famous New Deal agencies -- TVA and AAA. The opinions it hands down will have a profound effect on the plans of the Roosevelt Administration, a great influence in defining the present limits of Federal authority and possibly a decisive voice in determining whether the question of amending the Constitution will become a political issue in next year's national election.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 14. -- Ethiopia is opening her war chest along the southern front and is dishing out gold and silver to the hill chiefs, thus assuring the allegiance of the home guards.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Alex Watson, veteran Hudson River pro, led home a field of seventeen with a score of 145 in the Westchester P.G.A. open tournament, a 36-hole test over the difficult Bonnie Briar course today. Adding a 74 in the afternoon to his brilliant 71 in the morning, Watson captured first prize by the margin of two strokes.

There are several ways of measuring the relative welfare of labor at different periods. One is by a comparison of the number of unemployed or employed, another by a comparison of hourly wage rates, a third by average weekly wages and a fourth by total payrolls.

The eulogy of Mrs. H.E. Talbott in THE TIMES of Oct. 4 dwelt with reason and truth upon the philanthropies and the sponsorship of the Westminster Choir, which made her name familiar both here and abroad. But those of us who for many years have enjoyed the privilege of close contact with Katherine Talbott feel an irreparable loss.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Oct. 9, issued by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows a decrease for the week of $37,000,000 in total loans and investments and increases of $48,000,000 in net demand deposits, $21,000,000 in time deposits and $89,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Contracts providing for supervision of the Cities Service Company, a $1,270,000,000 holding company, by Henry L. Doherty Co., have been canceled by the latter company, it was announced last night by Ernest H. Johnston, vice president of Cities Service.

ROME, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Ethiopian resistance to the Italian advance from the north appeared to be crumbling today and there were strong indications at home that Premier Mussolini might be willing to talk about peace.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Half of the alleged $448,000 gross income which the government charges Abraham L. Shushan, New Orleans merchant and State political leader, failed to report in his income returns for 1929-33 inclusive, was in deposits in four New Orleans banks and one New York bank, the government asserted at his trial today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Liquidation by scattered longs in wheat developed today on the Board of Trade anl kept prices on the down grade from the opening. Weakness in prices at Winnipeg and Liverpool over the double holiday and further highly beneficial rains in Northern Argentina brought in persistent selling and at no time did the market show a disposition to rally.

ROME, Oct. 14. -- The period of stagnation into which the military operations in East Africa have fallen while preparations are being made for the next advance has caused many Italians to turn their minds more toward the political and diplomatic aspects of their controversy with Ethiopia.

Walter A. Rathbourne, 41 years old, a patient in the Veterans Hospital on Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, was arrested there yesterday afternoon on charges of forgery and grand larceny a few minutes before he was to have been discharged as a patient. Rathbourne, who described himself as a salesman and real estate broker, is accused in a $25,750 bond fraud.

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- Although in Paris only "accidentally" on his way home, since a return voyage on an Italian ship was made impossible for him by the American neutrality stand, Henry Morgenthau Jr., United States Secretary of the Treasury, paid a visit this morning to the French Finance Minister, Marcel Regnier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Army engineers have privately informed the Works Progress Administration that, due to technical difficulties, peak employment in their part of the $145,000,000 work relief program cannot be reached by the Nov. 1 deadline and that maximum employment on their 104 projects will probably not be attained until Spring.

MONTREAL, Oct. 14. -- Quebec voters all but returned to the solid-bloc days of 1921 in today's general election by sending fifty-five Liberals to the House of Commons, and adding four others of Liberal leaning who lack official party support.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- A total of $995,000,000 of the $1,246,000,000 in Fourth Liberty Loan 4 1/4 per cent bonds called for redemption tomorrow has been refunded, thus bringing to a successful climax the Treasury Department's $8,200,000,000 refinancing program which began two years ago, Acting Secretary Coolidge announced today.

The introduction of the artificial eyebrow and of hair "coloring" as a euphemistic verbal substitute for dye marked the opening of the tenth annual convention and exhibition of the National Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Supreme Court refused again today to interfere in the case of Tom Mooney, California prisoner, now fighting in the State courts to prove that he was unlawfully convicted in connection with the bombing during the 1916 Preparedness Day parade.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 14. -- Urged on by the coaches, who saw Yale and Penn in action at Philadelphia last Saturday, the Navy team today began its preparations for the contest with the Elis in New Haven. Highly impressed with the work of Yale, particularly its gallant comeback in the second half, the coaches told their charges that they had a hard job ahead of them.
The Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, the first railroad to report earnings for September, showed yesterday a net Loss. Its statement follows:

SYRACUSE, Oct. 14. -- While 2,000 registered nurses of the State were assembling for a four-day convention, officers and directors discussed suggestions for radical changes in the Nurses Practice Act. It will be submitted to a convention vote tomorrow.

OTTAWA, Tuesday, Oct. 15. -- The Conservative Government of Prime Minister Richard Bedford Bennett was swept out of office in yesterday's general election by a Liberal landslide which will give the new government to be headed by William Lyon Mackenzie King, leader of the Opposition, the largest representation any party has ever had in the Dominion Parliament.

I find myself at variance with the dominant thought of the country -- which is not unusual -- with respect to our part in the impending world exigency. In the first place, I have but scant sympathy with the idea that we should accept the benefits of civilization and avoid its responsibilities.

The need for recognizing housing as an emergency in itself and not merely as a make-work program in the unemployment emergency was emphasized yesterday by Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, and head of the New York Housing Authority.

Aside from a fair amount of activity at the opening of the Cotton Exchange and again toward the close, trading in cotton here yesterday was comparatively quiet, with early advances followed by moderate reactions under Southern selling combined with some scattered realizing or liquidation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Italo-Ethiopian war and generally unsettled conditions in Europe have not materially affected United States cotton shipments to Europe, according to a report of the Commerce Department made public today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Emperor Hirohito received in audience today George H. Dern, United States Secretary of War. He was accompanied by Edwin L. Neville, the United States Charge d'Affaires here. The nature of Mr. Dern's talk with the Emperor was not disclosed.

A DIPLOMAT once said of the Russia of the old days that it was despotism tempered by assassination. Too bad the beribboned gent didn't live long enough to have a look at football this current season. He would have found a phrase for it. To a dazed bystander, it looks like prosperity surrounded by revolution.

Tonight, at the Empire, Philip Barry's "Bright Star" offers itself to Broadway, and this time it seems to mean it. Largely rewritten and recast since its out-of-town tryout last season, it brings Lee Tracy and Julie Haydon as its stars, and with Jean Dixon, Louis Jean Heydt, Rosalie Norman and Katherine Grey as others in its cast of eight.
The Philadelphia Orchestra, under the direction of Leopold Stokowski, will pay its first visit of the season to New York in a concert at Carnegie Hall tonight.

MANILA, Oct. 14. -- The Philippine Islands ostensibly are peacefully and joyfully awaiting inauguration of the new Commonwealth government, but actually, according to many observers, they are a seething volcano of political and social unrest, promising explosion upon slight provocation.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- The campaign for control of the next State Assembly centred tonight in Erie County.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- The Boerse was weak today. Heavy industrials fell, Hoesch losing 2 1/2 points and Rheinstahl 2. Potashes were inactive and Aschesleben lost 1/2 point. Machines fell, Schubert Salzer losing 2 points and Orenstein Koppel 1.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- The economic "liquidation" of Jews in Germany, already under way through National Socialist party pressure and other "unofficial" methods, has become a part of the German Government's official policy.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 (AP). -- The filing today of a deed disclosed that Andrew W. Mellon has given over $10,000,000 more for construction of an art gallery at the national capital.

About 2,000 persons from every State in the Union except Nevada have enrolled in the Council for Moderation in the last two weeks, according to a statement issued yesterday by Everett Colby, its president. The membership drive was opened recently with experimental one-day campaigns in New York, Newark and Bridgeport, Conn.

It was the privilege of the customers at the Fulton last evening, when "Triumph" was produced, to peer into some of the graver affairs of politics and jurisprudence. George Austin, alleged to be a newspaper man, was exposing the interior of Gloria Kendall's law office, where justice and hair-pulling consumed most of the time.

BUCHAREST, Oct. 14. -- Rumors of forthcoming events affecting Rumania's domestic situation, current during the last few days, seem to have been confirmed by Alexandre Avarescu, leader of the People's party. Today at a meeting of his party he proposed to postpone discussion of political problems for a couple of weeks because "I have every reason to believe an event may occur very soon which will modify Rumania's internal situation."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Because the Oil Ridge Oil and Refining Company, Las Vegas, Nev., wished to advertise that its stock offered "speculative stock-profit possibilities with a bond feature," the Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today the effectiveness of the company's registration under the Securities Act of 1933.
Four playwrights, Emmet Lavery, Gladys Hurlbut, Richard Maibum and Allen Boretz, have been engaged by Sam Marx, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer scenario editor.

FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 14. -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt charged tonight that President Roosevelt, his cousin, was backing subversive schemes modeled after European dictatorships that would spell ruin for the nation.

MIAMI, Oct. 14 (AP). -- An American Legion committee investigating the death of several hundred veterans in Florida keys camps in the hurricane of Sept. 2 was told today by A.J. Wheeler, adjutant of the Spanish-American War Veterans post here, that "the officers deserted when the storm approached and left the men to their fate."

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Oct. 15. -- Important discussions of domestic and international policy loomed in Nanking today following the arrival at the capital yesterday of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. He came by plane from Taiyuan in Shansi Province, where he conferred with General Yen Hsi-shan concerning the anti-communist campaign.

The American Canoe Association's executive committee has voted unanimously to support the American Olympic Committee in preparations for the 1936 Olympics at Berlin, it was announced yesterday. The A.C.A., governing canoeing body in the United States, will stage its Olympic tryouts late next June or early next July.

B. Charney Vladeck, general manager of The Jewish Daily Forward and president of the American ORT, was a guest of honor last night at a dinner of the ORT board of directors at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue. Mr. Vladeck recently returned from a tour of Europe on which he visited nine countries.

Representatives of 3,000,000 American clubwomen were urged yesterday to turn their attention to the family relations of young men and women as the "most important phase" of the problem of social security in the depression.
Details of the play in the first game between Alexandre Alekhine and Dr. Max Euwe in their match for the chess championship of the world, contested at Amsterdam, were received here by mail yesterday.

J.P. Morgan Co., as sinking fund administrators, reported yesterday that $2,054,200 Government of the French Republic external loan of 1924 25-year sinking fund 7 per cent bonds had been drawn for redemption at 105 on Dec. 1.

I notice with some interest the editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES in which Mayor La Guardia is commended upon his stand regarding politics in the city administration. Unfortunately, the logic used does not hold.

Ranking football teams at mid-October may be as futile an undertaking as picking baseball pennant winners on the Fourth of July, but it can be no more prejudicial to the intrepid prophets' reputation for sound judgment than was the selection of the Giants to win the gonfalon in the National League for the past two years.

After a fortnight's refusal to produce them, the Metropolitan Restaurant and Cafeteria Owners Association yielded yesterday its books and records to the New York County grand jury investigating rackets.
George Salvatore, Houston (Texas) welterweight, outpointed Jackie Davis of Cleveland in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Four men and two women, among thirty-one persons indicted last Spring in the investigation of bail bond frauds in the criminal courts, pleaded guilty to various irregularities yesterday before Judge William Allen in General Sessions. The court continued their bail until Oct. 30, when they will be sentenced.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Upon a petition of the Securities and Exchange Commission Federal Judge William Clarke here issued today an order requiring the Whealton Company, Inc., of Philadelphia, its officers, dealers and salesmen to show cause why they should not be restrained from alleged fraudulent practices in connection with the sales of Trusteed Diversified Royalty Trust Certificates and Davis-Stinnett units.
Business in money continued along routine lines -- volume was small and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

The visitor to the national business show in New York cannot fail to be impressed by the constant improvement and refinement of office appliances -- of adding, calculating, bookkeeping, and addressing machines, envelope sealers, dictaphones, typewriters that return the carriage electrically, cash registers, check signers, water coolers and what-not.
