PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Foregoing the usual Monday rest for players who saw action in the previous Saturday's game, Coach Fritz Crisler sent his entire Princeton football squad through a long drill on University Field today. Timing and speedy execution of assignments were stressed.

HARRINGTON PARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- A dog that lost one limb last week saving its master from being run over by a truck will be entered in the Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden in January, it was learned here today.

DOUGLAS, Ariz., Tuesday, Oct. 15. -- Word that five United States bankers are missing in the wilds of Eastern Sonora, Mexico, after being captured by rebels who confiscated their guns and ammuntion, was brought here early today.

Because American builders and manufacturers are admitted to be "well in advance" of British groups in the use of residential equipment and some types of labor-saving devices, an official of a large London building organization is in New York studying our construction methods and materials with a view to making use of some of these ideas in an extensive housing program for the coming year in various parts of Great Britain.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- Possibilities of a shake-up in the Pennsylvania varsity line-up were indicated today as the coaches discussed plans for the coming game with Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- The Washington Post said tonight that Senator Borah has declared his intention to do "everything he could to rally public sentiment against Eastern domination" of the Republican party in the campaign next year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Fred Moseley ran through signals in Johnny Adzigian's halfback place in today's Harvard practice and Bobby Jones, first-string centre, who is ready to play again, filled in at tackle for Jim Maser.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Welcomed by Secretaries Roper and Wallace "in a genuinely friendly spirit," eleven aviation leaders from as many Latin-American countries expressed amazement today at the picture of modern aviation which Eugene I. Vidal, director of air commerce, and his assistants drew for them from charts, figures and actual demonstration of new aids to navigation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Of especial importance to the Roosevelt administration, in the ruling of the Supreme Court today was the high court's formal "consented" by which it agreed to pass on the constitutionality of the AAA's legally harried processing taxes.

Changing its previous tactics in enforcing its sales tax, the La Guardia administration has dealt its first effective blow at merchants who have been ignoring the tax and failing to collect for Controller Taylor the tax money to which the city is entitled, it was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company of Milwaukee filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for a $15,000,000 issue of ten-year convertible debentures.

TORONTO, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Holders of bonds of the Great Lakes Paper Company voted today to accept an offer for the assets of the company submitted by Lynn E. Aldrich and John E. Gaefell on behalf of some twenty-five newspaper publishers in the United States.

Following is a list, compiled by the Canadian Press, of members elected Monday to the Canadian House of Commons [Liberals are designated (L.) , Conservatives (C.), Independents (Ind.), Independent Liberals (Ind. L.), Liberal Progressives (L.P.), Social Credit Party (S.C.), Reconstructionists (R.), United Farmers of Ontario Labor Party (U.F.), Independent Conservative (Ind. C.) and Cooperative Commonwealth Federation (C.F.)]:

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- There was a serious spread today in the "stay down strike" among coal miners along the border of England and Wales in sympathy with the sixty-eight men who have imprisoned themselves in the Nine-Mile-Point colliery since Saturday in protest against continued employment of non-union men.

On June 15, 1927, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, at a luncheon of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, predicted that the air service would defend New York City against an attack by battleships by the use of bombing planes which would destroy the enemy ships.

Election of a Republican Assembly to end a "little new deal" at Albany serving as a brake on recovery in the State was urged last night by George R. Fearon, Republican Senate leader, in a State-wide radio broadcast arranged by the Republican State Committee.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Costumes of fifty years ago, contrasted with styles of today, formed a colorful pageant at Hollow Hall Farm, home of Mrs. Paul Moore at Convent, this afternoon, in celebration of the golden jubilee of the Morristown Woman's Work and Art Exchange.

Louis (Lepke) Buckhouse and Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, who are said to have gross incomes of more than $1,000,000 a year each from the activities of their private army of 250 "strong arm" men in the garment, trucking and baking industries, are under investigation by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Pope Pius XI has intervened in the dispute between Italy and Ethiopia, it became evident today. Accounts received here of yesterday's interview in Paris between Premier Pierre Laval and Mgr. Luigi Maglione, the Papal Nuncio, show that they referred to a compromise suggested a fortnight ago by the Holy See.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Strength in the wheat markets in Liverpool and Buenos Aires and removal of the Canadian election as a market factor turned operators and commission houses on the Board of Trade here to the buying side of wheat today and resulted in prices advancing 1 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel, with the close well toward the top.

After tracing the influence of the United States in the formation of the League of Nations, Colonel Edward M. House, wartime adviser of President Wilson and co-author of the League covenant, appealed to this country inferentially last night to become a member of the League and thus make the application of sanctions against Italy "100 per cent effective."

A good demand for retail shopping locations in scattered sections of the city was indicated in the large volume of business leases reported by brokers and renting agents yesterday. Contracts for various units of office, loft and showroom space also were signed.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Oct. 15. -- Admiral Sir William Fisher, commander of Egypt's 'first line of defense, directed today the biggest naval manoeuvres yet held off the shores of this ancient kingdom as Egyptian politicians intensified their violent protests against being "tied to Great Britain's apron strings."

GENEVA, Oct. 15. -- The League of Nations committee on economic sanctions agreed today, subject to a second reading later, to a French proposal to cut off all shipments to Italy of specified raw materials used for war. The fourteen States on this committee control nearly all the world's production of the key materials listed.

Another large audience assembled at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the De Basil Ballet Russe, whose program on this occasion contained by way of novelty the first American performance of Massine's ballet, "The Good-Humored Ladies."

ROME, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Italian airplanes bombarded and dispersed Ethiopian troops yesterday in camps south of Makale, on the northern front, according to an official communique today, which confirmed that General Emilio de Bono, commander-in-chief of the Italian forces in East Africa, visited Adowa and "took possession of the region in the name of His Majesty the King."

Cotton moved rather irregularly within a range of 8 or 10 points in yesterday's trading on the Cotton Exchange, with orders about evenly divided between continued hedge selling from the South and demand from the trade. December contracts, after selling up from 10.82 to 10.89 cents a pound, or 9 points above Monday's closing quotation, closed at 10.82 cents, with the general market ending barely steady at net advance of 1 to 3 points.

In the broadest and most active market in more than a month, stocks registered yesterday their fifth consecutive advance. What had hitherto been a highly selective rise developed into a general upturn, with rails, steels and other recently neglected issues leading the movement. Wheat regained more than half of Monday's losses.

PARIS, Oct. 15. -- Premier Pierre Laval has not given up his efforts at conciliation of the Ethiopian conflict. Having yielded at Geneva and supported, at least formally, the League of Nations' policy of sanctions and having returned to Paris in time to quell an outbreak of fury in the press against Britain, the Premier has again opened negotiations in Paris, London and Rome for a renewed attempt at a tripartite settlement.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller is becoming an embarrassing problem for the Nazi Government. He will not resign, with the pleadings of government agents and hostility of opposition pastors equally ineffective.

Moving forward under a renewed demand for high-grade investments, with trading at a greatly quickened pace, the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange made impressive gains in all sections yesterday. Sales amounted to $13,181,600, compared with Monday's total of $9,856,900.

Net profit of the Masonite Corporation, manufacturer of hard board for insulation, for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 was $1,004,271 after depreciation, amortization of patents, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. After annual dividend requirements on 13,477 shares of $100 par, 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, the earnings are equivalent to $3.41 a share on 266,689 shares of no par common stock.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The sense of the members of the British Cabinet at today's session was reported to have been in favor not only of a general election next month but also of the earliest day possible for the polling, which would be Nov. 14.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Under present population trends the United States will be converted within twenty-five years into a country populated and ruled largely by elderly people, and youth will be on the wane as to both numbers and influence, the National Resources Committee has concluded on the basis of a preliminary analysis of findings of planning boards of several States.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15. -- The Harvard coaches who had hoped for a hard scrimmage today for the players they count on as starters at West Point on Saturday, again met disappointment. While Johnny Adzigian and Jim Maser reported, neither took part in the contact work.

The American Flag colt Patriotic, which races for the Geneseo Stable, was first in the Inverness Handicap at Empire City yesterday as public choices bowed with a discouraging regularity to send the favorite players in full flight under a deluge of long shots.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 15 -- After squadrons of Italian reconnaissance planes had flown over this city Ethiopian residents and foreign newspaper men and photographers fled today to the neighboring hills or to Diredawa, about thirty miles away.
Three adventurous Brooklyn boys were languishing last night in city institutions, convinced that this is not the best possible world. And with good cause, too, if one puts faith in their story.

Last Winter President Roosevelt called upon the nation to help solve the crime problem. What is that problem if it be not that in this nation there is relatively more crime than in other comparable countries?

Mixed movements prevailed again yesterday in the commodity futures markets. In the cash markets prices of all the grains and cotton were higher, with silk, antimony and hides at new high marks for the year. Tin was lower and raw sugar fell 5 points to 3.60 cents, the first change since Oct. 2.

With photographs of her dead husband, herself and her 9-year-old son, Lawrence, smiling gayly at her from the top of a desk a few feet away, Mrs. Isabelle Carlin Parker, 36-year-old stenographer, committed suicide by gas yesterday in her furnished room at 144 West Seventy-sixth Street.

An amendment to the State Constitution to permit the temporary assignment of Supreme Court Justices, County Judges, Judges of the Court of General Sessions, and Surrogates from one judicial department to another to relieve calendar congestion was approved last night by the Association of the Bar of the State of New York.
Colonel Roosevelt joins in the present vociferousness of the limelight Republicans in replying to Senator Borah, who talks measures.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Residential building during September totaled $42,000,000, an increase of 134 per cent over September, 1934, although far behind similar building in pre-depression years, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Carrying his attack on the "old guard" to the floor of the American Federation of Labor convention today, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, forced the immediate resignation of Matthew Woll, vice president of the A.F. of L., from the acting presidency of the National Civic Federation, a post he had held since the death of Samuel Gompers in 1924.

Once more the American Federation of Labor has declared in favor of the thirty-hour week. This is now its "paramount objective." It will support the Black-Connery Thirty-Hour Bill at the next Congressional session. Mr. GREEN asserts that "we are going "to fight for this as we have never "fought before."
Dr. Richard Gottheil, Professor of Semitic Languages at Columbia University, returned on the French liner Ile de France yesterday after attending the International Congress of Orientalists in Rome.

Two young thugs invaded a slipper factory a few blocks from police headquarters yesterday afternoon, wrested a payroll from a frightened girl, threw her to the floor and escaped with $2,000 after seriously wounding the head of the concern when he started after them.
Dr. Modesto Aloo, conductor of the New York Civic Orchestra, will give the second of the free symphonic concerts tonight in the Great Hall of City College.

An audience, large and "brilliant," welcomed Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra in their first New York concert of the season, last night in Carnegie Hall. They welcomed the magnificent orchestra, with its warm and vivid tone, its superb flexibility and nicety of balance, and the eloquent solo performance of various players of the ranks.

With a warning against interference with the work-relief machinery set up under his administration and a plea against the injection of politics into relief, General Hugh S. Johnson ended his duties yesterday as Works Progress Administrator or this city and turned over the office to his successor, Victor F. Ridder, newspaper publisher.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Garry LeVan and Homer Spofford, Princeton's first-string halfbacks, be lost to the Tiger football squad for at least two weeks as a result of injuries suffered today in a scrimmage session.

Their longest session in a fortnight, featured almost exclusively by work on aerials, kept the Fordham football players busy for more than three hours yesterday at Fordham Field. Following the wholesale revisions in the regular line-up on Monday more changes were effected so that the varsity barely resembled that which had held sway since the season began.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Whitehall officials are skeptical about the timeliness of the reported negotiations between Premier Laval of France and Mgr. Luigi Maglione, Papal Nuncio in Paris, for a settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian war at the present time.

Mrs. Marguerite Phillips, 48 years old, of 37 West Forty-sixth Street, was held under bail of $100 yesterday by Magistrate H. Stanley Renaud in West Side Court to await trial in Special Sessions on a charge of violating the Sullivan Law. She pleaded not guilty.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- "War on the Soho Front" was one of the banners carried in yesterday's demonstration by British cooks and waiters against the employment of Italians in London hotels and restaurants.

Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan returned last night on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania from a three months' tour of Europe. He denied reports that he would run for the Republican Presidential nomination and that he had "a surprise announcement" on the 1936 campaign issues.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 15. -- There were a number of dinner parties in Newport last night, the larger given by Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hill at Roselawn and Mr. and Mrs. Maxim Karolik. The guests later attended the piano recital given by Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead.

The members of the American Ballet and its symphony orchestra set out from New York yesterday in two buses that will take them on a transcontinental tour. The company, headed by George Balanchine, maitre de ballet, will not return until January, when it will take part in performances at the Metropolitan Opera House.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15. -- Joseph Fernandez, an orphan of 23, who was captured last night after he apparently had succeeded in extorting $500 from the parents of a sub-debutante under threat of marring the girl's features with acid, was held in $5,000 bail today for the Federal grand jury by Commissioner William S. Wacker.

TOKYO, Oct. 15. -- Japan's reply to the British invitation to a naval conference Sept. 30 under the terms of the Washington treaty was approved by the Cabinet today and was telegraphed to Keinosuke Fujii, the Charge d'Affaires in London.
ADOWA, Oct. 15 (Reuters). -- Reports reached Italian miltary headquarters today that a revolt had broken out in Gojjam province.

While Sears, Roebuck Co.'s volume of business has increased from $350,000,000 annually in 1930 to an estimated $380,000,000 in 1935, or 8.5 per cent, the company's taxes have jumped from $4,000,000 to $8,333,000, or more than 100 per cent, it was disclosed yesterday by Lessing J. Rosenwald, chairman of the board.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday exceeded those of the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 1,083, the highest since the week of Sept. 4, when 1,240 buyers were listed, and compared with 559 reported in the previous week and 726 in the same period last year.

TOKYO, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Addressing an audience which included famous Japanese proponents of an aggressive imperial policy, Secretary of War George H. Dern of the United States declared today that "President Roosevelt's good-neighbor policy is in force in regard to our relations with Japan and other countries of the Far East, as elsewhere."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Oct. 5 totaled 304,595,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. Compared with the previous week, this represented a decline of 455,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 370,000 and 85,000 barrels, respectively, in stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum.

ROME, Oct. 15. -- Italian troops are again on the march in East Africa, moving out from Adowa, Adigrat and Entiscio and massing in the mountain passes that are the gateways to Makale and the Takkaze River Valley. The imminence of the resumption of the advance into Ethiopia acts like wine on the Italians and makes them forget the League of Nations and all international complications the future may hold in store.

The Anti-Racket Bureau of the State Attorney General's office announced yesterday that it had obtained indictments against two Chinese who are alleged to have been attempting to "shake down" Chinese laundry owners. The case was said to have been the first involving racketeering by Chinese to be reported to State officials by persons of that nationality.

All types of products handled by the average drug store, from foot plasters to the most important ingredients entering into the preparation of prescriptions, are on display at the fourth annual Drug Trades Exposition, which opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace.

Daily average production of gross crude oil in the United States last week was 2,781,750 barrels, compared with 2,719,600 in the preceding week, an increase of 62,150, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Increases of 41,150 and of 14,700 barrels, respectively, in Oklahoma and California were the principal changes.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Al Robertson, veteran contract rider for C.V. Whitney, scored his eleventh victory of the current Suffolk Downs meeting today when he turned in a handy performance on Synod in the mile feature for 3-year-olds.

The dismissal of a score of Communists, leaders of Communist "cells" in various parts of the WPA organization in this city, may be expected shortly as a beginning of a drive to stop subversive activity and the fanning of discontent among WPA employes, it was learned yesterday.

Orders received by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in the third quarter of 1935 amounted to $30,497,620, an increase of 21 per cent over orders of $25,213,271 received in the third quarter last year. Orders in the second quarter of 1935 were $34,222,014 and in the first quarter $30,762,901.

The New York University varsity football squad resumed work yesterday at Ohio Field following its holiday on Monday. Coach Mal Stevens drove the Violet through an extended session in preparation for the third contest of the season on Saturday when N.Y.U. faces the Pennsylvania Military College at the Yankee Stadium.

A thrill is in store for any one who pays a visit these days to the Jones Beach State Bird Sanctuary, situtated about a mile and a half northeast of the No. 9 parking field; for here is one of the most famous resting places of migratory waterfowl on the Eastern seaboard.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Ten men, women and children were held up here today in the home of a well-to-do New York manufacturer by three armed thugs, polite and well dressed, who joked about "movie stick-ups," were careful not to harm the children, and who escaped with about $10,000 in jewelry and cash.

Grover A. Whalen's services to business and trade interests were rewarded yesterday at a testimonial luncheon at the Hotel Astor attended by 2,000 representatives of about 300 organizations and of 100,000 business houses in the city.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

ITALIAN GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, NEAR ADOWA, (via Rome), Oct. 15 (AP). -- New Italian advances from the Somaliland front were reported yesterday to General Emilio de Bono, commander of the Northern Army. These reports said troops that had occupied Gerlogubi several days ago had moved on to Gorahai, in a drive toward the strategic city of Harar.

ADOWA, Ethiopia, Oct. 14 (via Rome, delayed since 9:45 A.M., Monday). -- Many Ethiopians who surrendered to Italy in this region are still loyal to Emperor Haile Selassie, an independent survey disclosed today.

Maude Adams, stage star, played the role of spectator for a second day in Supreme Court yesterday. She listened while John D. Williams, former stage director, told the court how a play is "pingponged," how Otis Skinner was picked for Shylock's role because of the shape of his back, and how a stage director can go "pretty nearly broke" in the process of persuading a star to return to the stage.

OTTAWA, Oct. 15. -- With nearly complete election returns showing that the Liberals, holding officially 167 seats, had achieved the greatest political sweep Canada has ever known, attention over the Dominion turned today to the probable Cabinet line-up of the victorious Mackenzie King government and its policies.

ATHENS, Oct. 15. -- General Papagos, Minister of War, today announced a nation-wide review of the entire army, navy, air force, constabulary and municipal police on Oct. 26, at which time all members of the service and police will be required to swear allegiance to George II.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15. -- While the varsity regulars rested again, the Penn second varsity scrimmaged with the jayvees today. Captain Paul Stofko and Bob McNamara, first-string guards, were the only regulars on Franklin Field in uniform, but neither was permitted to take part in any of the heavy work.

Louis Waldman, Socialist leader, who returned Monday from Panama where he defended Nelson Rounsevell, publisher of The Panama American, in a suit for criminal libel brought by two army ofcers, announced yesterday that he would submit to President Roosevelt a report on conditions at army posts in the Canal Zone.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Mess call had sounded tonight before Army's football squad quit the gridiron in its preparations for the Harvard game Saturday. The cadets' workout was once more designed with a view of stiffening the defenses.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP). -A new type of naval seaplane roared into port today from Panama, setting what was believed to be a new distance record for craft of its kind -- 3,387 miles without a stop.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- Generally fair weather over most of New York State brought out thousands of sportsmen for the opening of the hunting season today -- and a subsequent report of no first-day fatalities.

" Strip Girl" will not have its premiere this evening at the Longacre. Instead the first of this season's proposed plays about burlesque will make its official bow on Saturday. The postponement is attributed to scenic difficulties.

Brokers were undecided yesterday how to feel about the stock market's sudden advance and the increase in the public's interest in the market. They recalled the warning of a runaway market and a subsequent crash, issued last week by Charles R. Gay, president of the Stock Exchange.

The banking firm of J.P. Morgan Co. is again in a position to exercise some control of the Alleghany Corporation, it developed yesterday, as a result of the refusal by the United States Supreme Court on Monday to review an action brought to prevent the corporation from consummating its reorganization plan.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 (AP). -- The Works Progress Administration today released $913,188 in Federal funds to start immediate work on forty-two WPA projects in nineteen New York counties. Lester W. Herzog, administrator said, however, he had not yet received notification from Washington that the funds are available.

The Railroad Credit Corporation, which for more than two years has been collecting gradually the loans that it extended to needy railroads in 1932 and 1933, is about to invoke "intensive" efforts to liquidate advances made to certain debtors which are reorganizing, E.G. Buckland, president of the corporation, said in his annual report issued yesterday.
Registration in the city set a new record for an off-political year, reaching phenomenal heights when the Assembly district totals were tabulated at 3:30 o'clock this morning.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 15. -- According to Ethiopian information, the advance of the Italian Northern Army from Adowa, Entiscio and Adigrat has already progressed half way to Makale, its goal. It is felt here that this advance has been made with surprising speed.

Ira H. Holley, Democratic Assemblyman from the Ninth Assembly District, who apparently was defeated in the Democratic primaries in September by Louis Rittenberg, was declared the winner of the nomination in a recount that was finished yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 15. -- Following his visit yesterday with Finance Minister Marcel Regnier, Henry Morgenthau Jr., United States Secretary of the Treasury, paid a call on Premier Laval this morning, accompanied by Theodore Marriner, United States Charge d'Affaires.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 15. -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the first attempt to span the Atlantic Ocean in a dirigible was observed here today when navy blimps from Lakehurst flew over this resort and the chamber of commerce issued a special cachet commemorating the famous flight of Walter Wellman and the crew of the America.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 15. -- With Yale's passing attack feared more than anything else, Navy backs and ends were drilled during the whole

Warning that conflict abroad touches the United States closely and "dangerously," Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, declared yesterday that this country not only was collaborating with other nations to enforce world peace but was prepared to enforce the domestic policies designed to insure its own neutrality.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Major Norman E. Fiske, now stationed at Philadelphia, will sail tomorrow for Rome with the possible objective of serving as the United States military observer with the Italian armies in Ethiopia.

The State of Minnesota awarded yesterday a new issue of $4,500,000 highway bonds, maturing from 1937 to 1951, to a banking group headed by the Chase National Bank, on a bid of 100.4799 for 2%s. Other members of the syndicate are Harris Trust and Savings Bank, R.W. Pressprich Co., Thrall, West Co., Kean, Taylor Co., L.F. Rothschild Co., Northwestern National Bank and Trust Company and R.H. Moulton Co.
The text of the address by Grover A. Whalen at a luncheon given in his honor yesterday by representatives of business, trades an civic organizations at the Hotel Astor, follows:
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

A suit of Mrs. Isabel D. Curtis of Litchfield, Conn., against the brokerage firm of Morgan, Davis Co., for an accounting of $500,000, which she asserts was taken from her account with the firm and transferred to the account of her son, Ellicott D. Curtis, was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday when Mrs. Curtis applies to strike out part of the brokers answer.

Count Ludwig Salm of Vienna, first husband of Millicent Rogers Ramos and father of Peter Salm, one of the chief heirs under the will of his grandfather, Colonel Henry H. Rogers, applied in the Supreme Court yesterday for the appointment of a guardian for the child's estate because of the large bequests made to the 11-year-old boy in the Rogers will
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Where are Army's football stars of other years?

At the opening book sale of the season yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., a copy of the first issue of the first edition of Bret Harte's "The Luck of Roaring Camp, and Other Sketches," was sold to W.H. Woods for $400.

The charge that school children were "punished" for absences caused by illness was made in a report yesterday by a committee of the United Parents Associations. School officials, however, declared that such practices were against the policy of the education department.

While the retail and manufacturing divisions showed decline in failures during the week ended Oct. 10, as compared with the previous week, there was an increase in the number of defaults in the wholesale group, according to the detailed report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Defensive work against Holy Cross running and passing plays was the principal occupation of the Manhattan football squad yesterday. The varsity scrimmaged for two hours at Innisfail Park against a scrub eleven equipped with the formations of the undefeated, untied and unscored on Crusaders who come to Ebbets Field Saturday.

The fear of a violent death which had been torturing Herman Niemeier, German-born portrait painter, for the last ten years became a reality yesterday. The Brooklyn police found his body crumpled on the ground beneath his kitchen studio in the attic of a four-story apartment house at 396 Butler Street.

PARIS, Oct. 15. -- The Eritrea correspondent of Paris-Soir reported today that final plans for a slashing offensive by Italy in Southern Ethiopia had been completed by the commanders of the northern and southern armies. The plans were made in a conference made possible by an airplane flight covering virtually the whole length of Ethiopia.

The China Clipper of Pan American Airways, outranking all existing flying boats in load-carrying and range and the largest airplane to visit New York since the DO-X, flew from Baltimore yesterday morning and made two circuits of Manhattan.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Oct. 15. -- If reports are correct, Italy's adventure in Ogaden Province in Ethiopia in the last three days has yielded nothing to justify the jubilation of the expectant Italian people, much less to encourage the troops lodged in that arid waste.

An unofficial tabulation of a nation-wide poll of the American Newspaper Guild on the question of affiliation with the American Federation of Labor indicated that affiliation had failed of passage by a margin of 1 per cent under the required two-thirds, according to a report published in The Guild Reporter, organ of the guild.

Irving (Red) Blauner, 27 years old of 264 East 180th Street, the Bronx, described by detectives as an understrapper or general handy-man for the band of bank robbers led by the late Leonard carnici was found gravely wounded last night near the Metropolitan Museum of Art at Eighty-second Street.

THE communication from State Camp 82, Waterville, Pa., included notice to write soon and answer all questions, the implied hint being that work couldn't go on until word came on these important matters. It must be queer work they are doing out there when they dig up a bundle of questions like the following:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -Solicitor General Stanley Reed said tonight that the government would move within a day or so for a speedy decision on the constitutionality of agricultural processing taxes. The Supreme Court agreed yesterday to review a Boston Circuit Court decision which held the taxes invalid in the Hoosac Mills case.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15. -- Everything is in readiness for the 1935 Carnegie international exhibition of paintings, which opens tomorrow at Carnegie Institute in this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Secretary Morgenthau reiterated a policy already announced by this government when he declared in Paris that America was ready to discuss stabilization, Treasury officials said here today.

Although gold continued yesterday to leave Europe for this country in response to the flight of capital provoked by war fears, the European currencies were generally stronger. The pound sterling rose 3/8 cent to $4.90 7/8, the franc recovered 1/8 point to 6.59 1/4 cents and the Italian lira rallied smartly under official support to close at 8.14 cents, up 3 1/2 points.

When Harvard comes into the picturesque little stadium that stands on the cliff behind West Point this Saturday for its game with Army, the Crimson will be protecting something of a record, for a Harvard team has never been defeated at West Point.

The real aim of those responsible for the movement for new Federal drug legislation is the immediate curtailment and final destruction of the right of self-medication by the public, Clinton Robb, consulting counsel, warned members of the United Medicine Manufacturers of America, Inc., yesterday.

The great need of New York City's voluntary hospitals for financial assistance was stressed yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Mid-Day Club, 25 Broad Street. The luncheon was given by Charles Hayden, chairman of the finance section of the $2,000,000 drive to be started some time next month by the United Hospital Campaign Committee.

William T. Crawford of Scarsdale, commodore of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association, last night became the first chairman of the New York region's board of directors of the American Power Boat Association at the annual meeting and election held at the Hotel Lexington.

The Radio Corporation of America is applying part of the proceeds of the sale of a portion of its interest in the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation to the retirement of $4,000,000 outstanding 5 per cent debentures due from 1936 to 1942.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- One change in the line was made by Head Coach Ducky Pond of Yale today and the entire back field was shifted in the football practice for next Saturday's Navy game. Tiger Taylor regained the left tackle berth, which had been turned over to several other candidates during the past week.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Chrysler gave a luncheon in the Tangerine Room at the Greenbrier Casino today for Mr. and Mrs. William Cutler, Mrs. Lyttleton Fox, Mrs. Theodore W. Stenler and Joseph B. Long. Others entertaining there included Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Harjes, Mrs. Henry von Elm and Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey C. Woodworth.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Prices of new crop hogs dropped 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight in the early trading today to a new low since July, but a good demand developed later, with the close steady to 5 cents lower. Packing sows and heavy lard hogs were slightly better than Monday's average at the finish.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has made an informal investigation of the recent market activity in the common stock of the Chrysler Corporation, it announced yesterday in issuing a further denial that any of its representatives had, as stated in published reports, urged E.F. Hutton Co. to sell some of the stock in order to avert a "technical corner."

Fifteen properties in Manhattan were offered by auctioneers at foreclosure sales yesterday. The auction selling involved realty extending from the downtown section to Riverside Drive and 139th Street. All the holdings were bought in by the plaintiffs.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company reported yesterday a net profit of 25,595,478 for the first nine months of this year, after deducting expenses, taxes and other charges. This equals $2.21 a share on 2,526,553 shares of capital stock and compares with a net profit of $2,819,068, or $1.11 a share on 2,537,053 shares, in the preceding nine months.

Revision of the city water rates to reduce water taxes for 1936 by $5,900,000, which would throw Mayor La Guardia's tentative budget for 1936 out of balance by that sum, was voted unanimously yesterday by the Board of Aldermen.

" What is the record of this Government?" asked Prime Minister BENNETT on the eve of the election. Monday he got the opinion of the electors. It had been foreshadowed by the Liberal triumphs in Provincial elections. Their verdict had been obscured by the confusion caused by the noise of so many captains and the shouting.
Young people who yearn for the glamour of the stage may think that actors are born and not made, and that they are natural, if unrecognized, geniuses. But even a born actor has to have training.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Simon Bolivar, revolutionary hero of more than 200 battles in his successful campaigns to free six countries from Spanish rule, was pictured today as the precursor of Woodrow Wilson in advocacy of a league of nations.

In one of the largest Lexington Avenue deals closed recently, a syndicate organized by Henry Mandel and represented by Crawford W. Hawkins of Satterlee Canfield, lawyers, has purchased the Rhinelander, an apartment property occupying the easterly Lexington Avenue block front between Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth Streets.

The party of United States bankers reported disarmed by Mexican revolutionaries while on a hunting trip in the Sierra Madre region of Sonora, Mexico, are safe at a ranch in the Sonora Mountains, communications received here yesterday from several sources indicated.

Captain Johan van Dulken, master of the Holland-America liner Rotterdam, brought his ship to her Hoboken dock yesterday afternoon and stepped ashore a few minutes later for his first feel of land since the ship went aground on Morant Cays on Sept. 30.

The only country in the world whose shipbuilding increased in the third quarter of the year was Germany, according to the quarterly survey of world production made public yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Thirty-five municipal, county and school district bond issues having a face value of $5,007,300 were offered for sale to the highest bidders today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Bids will be opened in the RFC headquarters here at noon on Oct. 29.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Oct. 16. -- Chinese troops are moving into the Lower Yangtse provinces, ostensibly for large-scale land and air manoeuvres to be held next month. Japanese officials here regard the movements, however, as "training to repel foreign invasion."

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, and Dr. Frank B. Jewett, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and president of the Bell Laboratories, testified yesterday before the patent committee of the House of Representatives that they saw no particular objection to the registration with the Patent Office of patent pool and cross licensing agreements.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Germany's rapid progress in building up a new fleet was revealed today in the Naval Gazette, which discloses that twenty-one submarines already have been launched, although their building was announced only last March. They all are of the 250-ton class, but 600-ton submarines will be constructed later.

The new Paramount Pictures, Inc. is a mere pawn in the struggle of huge rival industrial and finance interests to dominate American industry, in the opinion of members of the Sabath committee investigating bond reorganizations.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 15. -- A statement that government guardianship of health is the most urgent need of the present time was made by Misses Annie Warburton Goodrich, dean emeritus of the Yale School of Nursing and head of the University of Pennsylvania's new School of Nursing, in an address here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Westchester's second annual recreation exposition opened in the County Centre this afternoon with exhibits of almost every kind of leisure activity. The exposition will continue through Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Clad in a long black robe, large white starched collar and wearing a white wig, a man who signed his name as "Francis J. Cahill, Esq., The Bronx," caused a minor stir today at the Supreme Court.
Quick public acceptance of canned beer has induced can makers to plan an output of 1,500,000,000 beer cans or next year, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

BASLE, Oct. 15. -- The governors of the leading European Central Banks have returned to their capitals after the monthly meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements less concerned, it seems, over the Italian situation than over its possible repercussions in Europe and the particular strength of the dollar in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Renewed efforts to speed up negotiation of the proposed Canadian-American reciprocal trade pact were predicted today, since the Canadian elections have been removed as an element of uncertainty.

A consolidated statement of earnings of the Bell System for the first eight months of 1935, accompanying quarterly dividend checks mailed to stockholders yesterday, shows consolidated net income equal to $4.28 a share earned on 18,662,275 shares of capital stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, compared with $3.85 a share for the first eight months of 1934.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Another season came to an end today for the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association as its final one-day tourney was held at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

Several large apartments in houses on the East Side were rented to tenants yesterday when brokers were kept busy with a continuance of the demand for suites. The activity included rentals of furnished apartments.

BALBOA, Panama, Oct. 15. -- President Roosevelt will pay his second visit to Panama when the cruisers Houston and Portland tie up at the Pacific entrance to the Panama Canal tomorrow. He was bound in the opposite direction on his visit in July, 1934, but now he is headed homeward, after two weeks' cruising and fishing in the Pacific.

NANKING, Oct. 15 (AP). -- The United States Embassy requested the Chinese Government today to exert every effort to apprehend the persons responsible for the death of Dr. Susan Waddell, a former resident of Berkeley, Calif., who police said had been slain.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 15. -- Gathering in this city tonight was a party of forty-seven members of Congress, with Vice President Garner at their head, and nineteen newspaper editors and publishers from throughout the United States to sail tomorrow to witness the inauguration of the Philippine Commonwealth Nov. 15.

In 1932 the people of this State voted in favor of a bond issue of $30,000,000 for unemployment relief. In 1933 they approved a second bond issue of $60,000,000. Last year, in recommending a $40,000,000 issue for the same purpose, Governor LEHMAN suggested a change in policy.

By their adherence to "Proposal No. 2," the delegates of fifty nations represented at Geneva have agreed to apply financial sanctions against Italy. In the first instance these will prohibit direct loans to the Italian Government. It is interesting to note, in passing, that such loans are already prohibited by the United States.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 15. -- As Mussolini's modern legions advance from Italian Somaliland, penetrating Southern Ethiopia on a line extending from the Webbe Shibeli River on the west to the border of British Somaliland on the east, it is apparent that the Ethiopians' strategy is to put up a desperate fight at every important waterhole in Ogaden and Harar Provinces.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 15. -- Ethiopia today received the first arms allowed by the rescinding of embargoes as a result of League of Nations action when 30,000 foreign rifles arrived at Jijiga. Additional shipments are expected from Berbera, British Somaliland, leading to fear that Italian airmen will attempt to bomb the Berbera-Jijiga road.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The history of aviation was traced today for aviation leaders from eleven Latin-American countries and J.A. Wilson, Controller of Aviation for Canada, when they visited the Smithsonian Institution on the second day of the Observance of Air Navigation Week, proclaimed by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Works Progress Administration State heads have been instructed to approve no further projects calling for the expenditure of Federal funds to enhance the value of private property or for the production of articles which might be put into ordinary trade, WPA officials disclosed today.

Award of the Michael Friedsam Medal for 1935 by the Architectural League of New York to Professor CHARLES R. RICHARDS gives public as well as professional recognition to the varied service of this teacher and leader in the industrial arts to this community and to the nation.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Ramsay MacDonald, Lord President of the Council, opened formally today the Imperial Chemical Industries coal hydrogenation plant at Billingham, near Stockton-on-Tees, where gasoline on a commercial scale will be made by the hydrogenation of bituminous coal.

Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis 3d, the former Grace Vanderbilt, daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, sailed for Europe last night on the Europa with her daughter, Cornelia, and her mother.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Notice that the German general staff has been formally reconstituted and therewith another provision of the Treaty of Versailles abrogated was served on the world today with elaborate military ceremonies officially designated as the celebration of the 125th anniversary of the founding of the German War Academy.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- With the campaign on in full force up-State for control of the Assembly in the November election, Governor Lehman today issued a call for a conference tomorrow at the Executive Mansion of all up-State Democratic candidates.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- After a dull opening today prices on the London Stock Exchange rallied under the lead of British funds. Renewed buying of Brazilian securities marked the foreign section of the market, but European issues were idle and dull.

Considerably disappointed by the agreement negotiated by the State Department, confining exports of Japanese cotton goods to the Philippines to 45,000,000 square meters annually, local exporters are seriously considering a united protest to Washington on the pact, it was learned here yesterday.
Senator Borah's letter to Colonel Theodore Roosevelt is a very unusual statement for this astute statesman to write. It is remarkable both for what it says and what it does not say.
OTTAWA, Oct. 15. -- Prime Minister Bennett and Prime Minister-elect King conferred for two hours this evening.

After an interval of nearly two seasons, Philip Barry is back in the theatre with a new play, "Bright Star," which was put on at the Empire last evening. It is the spiritual tragedy of a loveless marriage, written with all the scruple and devotion to principle that characterize Mr. Barry's work.

John Charles Thomas, the American baritone, who was absent from the Metropolitan Opera last season, has been re-engaged to sing in leading roles with the Metropolitan Opera Association for the coming season, Edward Johnson, general manager of the company, announced yesterday.

TRENTON, Oct. 15. -- The Court of Errors and Appeals, which recently affirmed unanimously the conviction of Bruno Richard Hauptmann in the Lindbergh baby murder, today granted his counsel thirty days to apply to the United States Supreme Court for a review of the case.

The destroyer Mahan, newest of the nation's men-of-war, got her first taste of the salt in the quiet waters of the Kill van Kull yesterday when she slid gracefully down the Staten Island ways of the United Dry Docks Corporation.

Since becoming First Lady and a centre of public notice wherever she goes, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has found that "you must become oblivious of people looking at you, so I have developed the self-protective habit of looking over people's heads."

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- A Federal ban on radio news flashes broadcast under sponsorship of advertisers was urged on the Federal Communications Commission in a resolution adopted today by the Inland Daily Press Association.

Michael J. Hogan, Republican politician, of Brooklyn, who served for two years as a Representative during the administration of the late President Harding, was sentenced yesterday to serve a year and a day in a Federal penitentiary.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -Five grower-meetings were scheduled by the Farm Administration today to speed a $5,000,000 program for raising quickly the price of potatoes.
The text of the address of Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, by radio from Washington to the Forum on Current Affairs, follows:

Their white horses turning gray under a fine rain of soot from neighboring utility plants along the East River ("We always get it when the wind blows from the south," an interne explained) the members of Colonel W.T. Johnson's Rodeo went through their paces yesterday for about 1,500 child patients at Bellevue Hospital.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Oct. 15. -Strikers and strike sympathizers of the Consumers Research, Inc., stoned the plant at Boyerstown, near here, late today. A half dozen or more automobiles were damaged and fifty panes of glass in the building shattered.
Beyond renewing expiring commitments little new credit was arranged in the day's money market. Quotations remained steady and unchanged.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Republicans opened their drive to rout the New Deal in the West today as party leaders gathered to map their strategy.

The two-day lose Tree hunt race meeting will open at Media, Pa., today with five races scheduled for the initial card. The first event is scheduled to start at 2:30 P.M. Two of the races will be steeplechases, two will be on the flat and one will be cross-country.

In its first financial statement issued since the refunding operation in March, the Port of New York Authority revealed yesterday a gross income of $9,007,400 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, against $8,218,592 for the same period last year.

Mrs. Julia Dennis, 22 years old, created an uproar in the corridors of the Criminal Courts Building yesterday afternoon when, screaming hysterically, she tried to fling herself over the interior balcony railing outside Judge Morris Koenig's part of General Sessions to the marble floor two stories below.

With not much to show for their 3,000 mile journey but still cheerful as when they arrived, the members of the British Ryder Cup team returned to the city yesterday from Louisville to await the departure of the Aquitania of the Cunard White Star Line at midnight tomorrow.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that, under a new ruling of the Securities and Exchange Commission, securities of three railroads which were to have been suspended from dealings today would be retained on the list until Nov. 1 or longer.

The franchise, rights and players of the St. Louis Eagles hockey team, controlled by Redmond Quain's Ottawa syndicate, were purchased by the National Hockey League yesterday, it was announced by President Frank Calder following an emergency meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel

With not much to show for their 3,000 mile journey but still cheerful as when they arrived, the members of the British Ryder Cup team returned to the city yesterday from Louisville to await the departure of the Aquitania of the Cunard White Star Line at midnight tomorrow.
A thorough rehearsal of offensive tactics in preparation for its encounter with Penn on Saturday featured Columbia's long and intensive drill yesterday at Baker Field.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- The Boerse was quiet but today. Heavy industrial issues showed a trend towkrd firmness, with Vereinig[estahl gaining a point. Potash shares were inactive. Orenstein and Koppel lost . point each in the slightly weaker machine list.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- American motion picture interests were seriously alarmed by a report published here today that the French Government was preparing to issue a decree before the end of this month establishing drastic restrictions on the importation and release of American films.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- The martial "anniversary" ceremony at the German War Academy yesterday, which was marked by announcement of the reconstitution of the German general staff, was also featured by an official admission that the German general staff had been in existence ever since 1920, although forbidden by the Treaty of Versailles.
OTTAWA, Oct. 16. -- W.D. Heridge, Canadian Minister to the United States, has tendered his resignation, it was announced today.

The Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Utica, N.Y., was called unanimously to the pastorate of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, at a congregational meeting last night.
Army and Navy shove off on the big push Saturday, beginning major operations against two of the oldest and most ivy-coated powers of the gridiron.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Characterizing the Roosevelt administration as "the first in all recorded history to go into partnership with drought to manufacture famine and call it a new deal," Colonel Henry Breckinridge of New York said tonight that this country needed no war "to suffer most of the dire economic consequences that flow from war."

An example of loose thinking arising out of the failure to appreciate the true nature of exchange is found in the idea that it is a good thing to sell goods to persons living outside one's own community, but a bad thing to buy from them.

The proposal that the Constitution be amended to give the Federal Government power to regulate the nation's economic life was debated yesterday by Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania and Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, before 2,500 women delegates to The Herald Tribune's Forum on Current Problems at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- A defense of its first "satellite city," a project for expending $5,500,000 in low-cost housing at Berwyn, Md., just outside the nation's capital, against the attacks of local officials and criticism in the Washington press, was issued by the Resettlement Administration today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Strong liquidation developed today in the wheat market, induced by unconfirmed rumors, apparently from the East, that the Canadian Government would reduce or abandon its guarantee minimum of 87 1/2 cents a bushel for No. 1 Northern cash grain delivered at Fort William, Ont., or Vancouver, B.C.

Attorneys for John D. Williams, former stage director, accused defendants yesterday in his $200,000 suit against Maude Adams, former Supreme Court Justice Mitchell L. Erlanger and others of utilizing "superfine technicalities" to defeat a "meritorious cause of action."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Monopolistic practices and restraint of competition in interstate, coastwise and foreign trade were charged against the California Packing Corporation of San Francisco and three subsidiaries by the Federal Trade Commission in a complaint today.

Combining well executed iron shots with superb putting, Mrs. Belle C. Rosenberg of Salisbury yesterday captured the low gross prize in the women's annual invitation tournament of the Old Country Club in Flushing with a card of 85.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 16. -The Medical Society of the County of Westchester, unincorporated for 138 years and said to be the oldest county medical society in the United States, has been incorporated to enable its more than 600 members to undertake several projects in medical economics, it was announced today.

Bidding for a copy of the exceedingly rare first English edition of "The Whale" by Herman Melville enlivened the auction sale of the library of the late Philip Greeley Brown of Portland, Me., yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., and finally was knocked down at $1,575 to Charles Sessler.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- German Jews, forced by the National Socialist campaign against them to liquidate their capital holdings in Germany, are beginning to transfer these holdings to foreign owners with results which the Nazis had not foreseen and do not welcome.

Mr. and Mrs. Kenelm Winslow gave a tea yesterday at their home, 17 East Ninety-seventh Street, for Miss Dorothy Pratt Williams, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herschel U. Williams of New Orleans, who will be formally introduced at a dinner dance in December.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 16. -- Emperor Haile Selassie asserted today that his warriors were undefeated and that no decisive battle would be fought until the Italians reached Ethiopia's strongholds in the lofty mountains of the interior. He said that the Ethiopians had withdrawn from the northern towns of Adowa and Aksum for strategic reasons and that their occupation by the Italians had no military importance.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 16. -Fear of far-reaching effects as a result of the refusal of seamen at Sydney to man the Union Company's steamship Niagera unless guaranteed that non-union labor would not be employed at Vancouver to unload the vessel may cause a review of this decision.

The American Newspaper Guild announced yesterday that the final tabulation of votes in its recent referendum had resulted in defeat for the proposal to apply for affiliation with the American Federation of Labor. Instead of the two-thirds vote required by the Guild convention, which authorized the referendum, the proposal received a favorable vote of slightly more than 65.4 per cent.

ROTTERDAM, Oct. 16. -- A desperate struggle against heavy odds finally enabled Dr. Max Euwe, Holland's leading chess master, to overcome the disadvantage of an inferior position today and to draw the sixth game of his match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, world champion.

Senator VANDENBERG the moving waters at their priestlike task of pure ablution have washed clean of terrestrial ambition. He is "not a candidate for anything on earth." He is not alone in this heavenly or millennial frame of mind. National Committeeman SPANGLER of Iowa, who has just opened at Chicago the Western headquarters of that committee and the Grass Rooters, has a strong touch of millennarianism.

The registration of 1,966,882 voters for the November election left many political leaders mystified, and others uncertain, as to the reasons that brought that number of voters to the registration booths this year -- an off year on the political calendar.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP). -- A Home Owners Loan Corporation announcement of foreclosure proceedings against 2,105 residential properties today plunged the government more deeply into the real estate business.

Continued trade recovery in this country is assured if the government will abandon interference with business men and let "nature do its job of economic healing," H. Gordon Selfridge said in an interview yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Receipts of gold from Europe continued yesterday to exceed new engagements abroad, and the foreign exchange market maintained its quiet tone, indicating, apparently, that the flight of capital to this country from Europe, which had been set in motion by the fear of war, was tapering off.

Before sailing yesterday for Bermuda in the Furness Line Queen of Bermuda. E.P. Rees, the general manager of the company, announced that a cablegram had been received from Glasgow saying that the Red Cross Line's new oil-burning turbo liner, the Fort Amherst, constructed for the Newfoundland route, had been launched in the Clyde yesterday morning.

Italy's invasion of Ethiopia is apparently about to raise an important question of policy for the United States. It is stated that England and France, seeking to explore the ground before further action is taken at Geneva, intend to ask our Government whether this country will agree to restrict its imports from Italy in case sanctions of this kind are applied by the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The "rugged individualism" of the United States in dealing with the crisis in Europe and Africa was stressed again today in answer to published reports from Paris that France and Great Britain were planning to ask the United States if it would be willing to restrict imports from Italy in the effort to curb that nation's war activities.

Steady progress in the plans for the world's fair to be held here in 1939 was reported by George McAneny, chairman of the preliminary committee sponsoring the project, at a luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Sanitation Department employes were formally "invited" by Commissioner Thomas W. Hammond, it was learned yesterday, to attend last Monday night's city power plant mass meeting in the Hotel Commodore. At this meeting Mayor La Guardia and other city officals opened a "finish fight" against the local power companies in behalf of a city plant.

Shipments of pneumatic casings in August amounted to 4,739,259 units, compared with 5,447,109 in July and 4,308,270 in August, last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc. Production of pneumatic casings in August amounted to 3,992,800 units, 3,531,834 in July and 3,532,631 in August, 1934.

CANTON, Oct. 16. -- More than two months ago the Canton government was officially warned by a high Japanese spokesman that "Japan's military arm must necessarily penetrate very deeply into South China." Therefore, Cantonese spokesmen say they realize settlement of the Swatow crisis merely affords a breathing spell.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 16. -Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Schmidlapp gave a luncheon at the Cascades Club today for Mr. and Mrs. Courtlandt Nicoll, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Winmill and Mrs. J. Allen Townsend. Dr. and Mrs. Stewart L. Craig's guests there were Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Bissell.

The city's negotiations for inclusion of the Interborough Rapid Transit system in its unification project moved forward yesterday because of a tentative agreement by one of the two committees representing holders of Interborough 6 per cent notes.
As a reward for her comeback conquest at Wimbledon Mrs. Helen Wills Moody once again has been designated the foremost woman tennis player of the world.

In its last heavy workout before the Holy Cross game Saturday the Manhattan eleven staged a long scrimmage, its third in as many days, at Innisfail Park yesterday. Coach Chick Meehan again emphasized pass defense.

Indications of a real business recovery were outlined yesterday by Fred W. Sargent, president of the Chicago North Western Railway, who was here to attend a meeting of the company's directors. He said reorganization of the company, which is in bankruptcy, should be delayed until the results of the Railway Pension and Social Security Laws were determined.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16. -- Prizes awarded in the 1935 Carnegie International Exhibition, which will open to the public tomorrow, were announced here this evening. The fortunate artists represent seven nationalities.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 16. -- It was the Yale second squad that was scrimmaging with the scrub reserves in the chilly twilight. The Blues and the Grays. The varsity lads -- the aristocrats of the Autumn pastime around these parts -- wear the blue jerseys. The scrubs wear the gray jerseys. They are the peasants taking the lordly thumps from the peerage.

NOGALES, Mexico, Oct. 16 (AP). -Authoritative sources said here tonight that ammunition had been purchased in Tucson, Ariz., yesterday and brought into the State of Sonora, where a rebel band has slain several town officials in the last ten days.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced early yesterday as a result of trade buying, but reacted because of realizing and increased hedging in the late trading. December deliveries after selling up to 10.92 cents a pound, or 10 points net higher, closed at 10.84, compared with 10.82 on Tuesday, with the general market ending barely steady at the bottom, net unchanged to 2 points higher.

Going and coming: "If This Be Treason," the Theatre Guild's opening show of the season, will close a week from Saturday night at the Music Box. Run: five weeks. . . . The next attraction at the Music Box will be Max Gordon's production of "Pride and Prejudice," possibly on Oct. 29.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The Court of Appeals will determine before it recesses on Oct. 25 whether New York City election officials may submit the question of municipal ownership of a power plant at a referendum at the November election. The case was before the court this afternoon, and the arguments lasted nearly two hours.

The vast problem inherent in the nation's unemployed and socially unoriented youths was described yesterday by Aubrey Williams, executive director of the National Youth Administration, at a meeting of the Welfare Council of New York City in the Hotel Astor.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Premier Pierre Level's last-minute efforts to halt the march of events toward an extension of the Italo-Etiopian war into, at the very least, economic and financial outlawry of Italy are having no better success than his earlier ones to prevent the war from beginning.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 16. -- Evidence that the Hungarian Government's pro-Italian policy -- as shown in its refusal at Geneva to take part in sanctions -- is not popular was forthcoming today in interpellations put down for Parliament by Deputy Rupert of the Kossuth party.

SEATTLE, Oct. 19. -- A plea for the United States to keep out of "foreign troubles" marked the departure today of a Congressional party to attend the inauguration of Manuel Quezon as the Philippine Commonwealth's first President.

Internal revenue agents here have begun a drive on tax delinquents among beer and liquor wholesalers, it became known yesterday. John H. Flynn, district supervisor of the alcohol tax unit of the Internal Revenue Bureau, said that inspections by his men had disclosed that more than 1,000 of the 2,200 distributers in the city never had obtained a Federal tax stamp.

Although the desired support from the automotive industry is beginning to appear, steel production this week is unchanged at 52 per cent of capacity, the level it has held to within half a point in the last six weeks, according to The Iron Age.

Homer S. Cummings, Attorney General of the United States; Homer M. Byington, United States Consul General at Antwerp, with Mrs. Byington; Willem van Hoogstraten, conductor, and Kermit Roosevelt are among the passengers due tonight from Europe on the Washington of the United States Lines.

The former quarters of the Manhattan Congregational Church in the Manhattan Towers Hotel at Broadway and Seventy-sixth Street will be converted into a motion-picture theatre or restaurant with cabaret, Donald W. Stewart, the new manager, reported yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 16. -- Loss of standards by the youth of today was discussed by Dr. Sarah M. Sturtevant, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, before a round-table session on the third day of the annual convention of three State nursing organizations.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. George M. Dallas of Chestnut Hill introduced their niece, Miss Hope Stoever, daughter of Philip F. Stoever and the late Mrs. Stoever, at tea this afternoon at their home, where Miss Stoever lives with her uncle and aunt.

The hunting season is still too young to hazard an opinion on whether the ruffed grouse shooting in this State will come up to advance predictions. Scattered reports received from the hill sections in the past two days indicate that these great game birds are fairly plentiful, but it will be a week or more before an accurate picture of the State-wide situation can be obtained.
Merging of the activities of Flower Hospital with those of Fifth Avenue Hospital was voted yesterday at a meeting of the boards of trustees of the two institutions.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The British Cabinet flatly refused today to withdraw a single warship from the Mediterranean, where a fleet of 150 vessels stands guard over Gibraltar, Malta and the gateway to the Suez Canal.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Without the flourish of ceremony, trading in privileges in grain futures was resumed today on the Board of Trade.

A general election in Great Britain has been for some time regarded as imminent. There would have to be one next year, in any case, and the political seers have been saying that it would not be later than January and probably might come in December. Now the Government seems to have fixed upon an earlier date.

I read with interest this morning's editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES "What Is It All About" That is exactly what many simple persons have been asking and will continue to ask between now and election day.

The fifth consecutive victory for Little Miracle was scored at Empire City yesterday where one of the largest mid-week crowds of the entire season saw the daughter of Bud Lerner take the Autumn Days Stakes by three lengths.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP). -The Montana, Wyoming Southern Railroad will have to pay additional Federal income taxes on $15,168 which the Commissioner of Internal Revenue held represented profit on the purchase of bonds which the board issued to acquire the Yellowstone Park Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Criticism of what he termed the "pan-scientific attack upon the Maya" was voiced this morning by Dr. A.V. Kidder of the Carnegie Institution at the morning session of the Pan American Institute of Geography and History, held in the Pan American Union.
The Richmond Symphony Orchestra, a WPA unit under the direction of Eugene Plotnikoff, will give the first of a series of Thursday evening concerts tonight at Curtis High School.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 16. -- Two leaders of a band of wandering musicians, who for years had entertained the peasants on collective farms, today were sentenced to death as counter-revolutionary plotters.

TORONTO, Oct. 16. -- To ascertain if anything can be done to protect their investments, a committee of holders of bonds of four power companies whose contracts with the Ontario Hydroelectric Commission are threatened with cancellation was authorized today by a meeting of the shareholders to confer with officials of the Ontario Government and the power companies involved.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- With imports throttled under the "new plan" of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, and exports continuing to rise ever since the 1,000,000,000-mark subsidy scheme went into effect in June, Germany is successfully, pulling herself out of the red ink in her foreign trade.

The large United States oil companies have been approached on the question of ceasing oil shipments to Italy to curb war activities in line with the sanctions recently imposed by the League of Nations. Because the United States Government is not a member of the League this question is considered a rather delicate one for the oil companies, especially those with large investments in Italy.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins handed down a decision yesterday in the suit brought by the City Fusion party for a liberal construction of the amendment to the election law passed last Spring relating to the disqualification of signers of independent nominating petitions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Tentative regulations to control lobbying by public utility companies have been drawn up by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Ignoring small items of disturbing news, the stock market yesterday continued its steady advance during the greater part of the trading session, but in the final hour it reacted from the best levels of the day under a mild wave of profit-taking. Grains prices also broke sharply.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16. -Charging the General Federation of Women's Clubs with "being un-American in forcing an issue which is contrary to the dictates of the conscience of hundreds of its members," the Catholic Woman's Club withdrew from the Federation today.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 16 (AP). -- E.R. Bradley's Black Helen won the featured fifth race at Laurel Park today. The 3-year-old black filly started in front, held the lead all the way and finished first with a length and a quarter to spare.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP). -- A free defense of the constitutional rights of any citizen unable to pay legal fees was offered tonight by a spokesman of the American Liberty League.

Massine's much-discussed ballet, "Choreartium," a setting of Brahms's Fourth Symphony, constituted the principal item on the program of the De Basil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House, where it received its first New York performance last night.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16. -Coach Dick Harlow of Harvard tonight announced a playing squad of thirty-five who will make the West Point trip and also picked his starting eleven.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- A suggestion for a British Empire Parliament in London, with aviation the real connecting link between Britain and the dominions, was made yesterday by Captain Norman MacMillan, president of the National League of Airmen.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The Rev. Dr. William Braman Tower, 63 years old, secretary of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church and treasurer of the Motion Picture National Board of Review, died of pneumonia at 2:10 P.M. today in Mount Vernon Hospital.

An institute founded to "debunk the ancient myth" that all mothers are good mothers opened its doors yesterday at 132 MacDougal Street, in the presence of a distinguished group of men and women. Dedicated to the proper training of women with children, the unit will be known by its registered title, "Mothers of Today," and will operate by the clinic and lecture method.

GENEVA, Oct. 16. -- Anthony Eden, British Minister for League Affairs, diplomatically and substantially stiffened today his demand that loyal League members completely boycott Italian goods, and he gained more support for it. There was no decision, but adoption of this sanction now seems certain this week, possibly in a day or two.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The Daughters of the American Revolution will not enter the Women's Patriotic Conference unless delegates to the Continental Congress of the D.A.R. rescind a resolution adopted last year, declaring that under its charter the national society cannot legally affiliate with any other organization.

MADRID, Oct. 16. -- Spain and Portugal will stand side by side in the League of Nations on whatever sanctions may be agreed upon against Italy. This was decided today after a conference between the Spanish Foreign Minister Alejandro Lerroux and the Portuguese Foreign Minister Dr. Armando R. Monteiro.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 16. -- A prediction that much of the steel industry's future progress would lie in new or radically changed markets was made today to the American Institute of Steel Construction by E.L. Shaner, editor of the magazine Steel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The Irving Trust Company of New York, as trustee in bankruptcy for four utility companies, today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to declare that it is not a utility holding company and is not required to register under the Public Utility Act of 1935.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 16. -- Sid Hirst, although riding with a broken hand which he sustained in the recent Meadowbrook Hunt Cup race, piloted Fighting Cock, owned by Mrs. William C. Hinneman Jr., to victory in the Foxcatcher Plate, a two-mile brush race as the Rose Tree Hunt Club meet opened today.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- George Reis today smashed the world's record for Gold Cup boats by more than ten miles an hour as he sent his 13-year-old El Lagarto, three-time Gold Cup winner, over a one-mile straightaway in the averaged time of 49.25 seconds.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange remained quiet but generally firm today. The best group was that of British funds, in which the war loan was strong. European issues improved in the foreign department. Home rail stocks were steady.

Mount Sinai Hospital was named residuary legatee and received remainder and contingent interests in $830,000 under the will of Edward J. King, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Twelve other charitable institutions receive bequests totaling $33,000, and relatives, friends and employes get legacies totaling more than $1,000,000.

BALBOA, Oct. 16. -- President Roosevelt, tanned by sea and sun was a picture of vigorous health when he landed from the cruiser Houston here today after a fortnight's cruising and fishing in the Pacific. There was vigor in his handclasp and he is evidently well rested and unworried.

Price movements of commodity futures here yesterday were mixed. Continued strength was seen in silk and rubber futures and wool tops were moderately higher. On the cash markets silk and antimony again sold at new high prices and spot rubber advanced, while all the grains, lard, tin and cocoa declined.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild, in its effort to secure a sustaining membership similar to that enjoyed by other great art and cultural institutions, started from the conviction that if grand opera is to survive, the many must become interested in its conduct and development rather than merely the few.
