LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The ugliest mine rioting in many years flared up today in the coal field along the South Wales-England border, where 2,000 men have remained underground, many since last Saturday, in defiance of the colliery owners.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 16. -- Alaji, 300 miles north of Addis Ababa, was heavily bombed today without inflicting any casualties upon Ethiopian troops, who were officially stated to have moved beyond that position.

BOSTON, Oct. 16. -- Despite a seven-pound shift in weights, A.A. Baroni's tiny but gallant Top Row, a 4-year-old son of Peanuts, gained his second straight triumph over Discovery, the champion of the handicap division, in the $25,000-added Massachusetts Handicap today before a crowd of 40,000 persons at Suffolk Downs.

Although Arthur Bryant's work on Samuel Pepys was originally planned for only two volumes, the author has discovered so much hitherto unknown Pepysian material at Cambridge, at Oxford, and in the British Museum, that he is now engaged on a third volume, Cambridge University Press anounces.

An improvement in the business of transient hotels in New York was shown in a survey made yesterday. The management of many of the leading hotels, where inquiry was made, reported a substantial increase in the number of rooms occupied and in sales of food and beverages over last year.

A campaign to prevent juvenile delinquency and crime through religious training was outlined yesterday at a luncheon conference in the Lawyers Club, sponsored by the Religious Education Foundation "in the interest of a united Protestant program" among "unchurched and underprivileged" children.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- The heaviest receipts of hogs here since May 6 and for a Wednesday since Jan. 23 failed today to have a material effect on the market because of the aggressive buying by local packers. A good part of the arrivals were from the new crop and weighed 180 to 230 pounds.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 16. -- Emperor Haile Selassie's journey to the front to fulfill the traditional obligation to lead his troops personally in battle will begin in a few days, it is learned unofficially from a high source. Empress Quizzero Menen will accompany him, as did Menelik's Empress when he and she exposed themselves to Italian fire at Adowa in 1896.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Advocates of industrial unionism were overwhelmingly defeated tonight at the fifty-fifth annual convention of the American Federation of Labor by the "old guard" among the craft unions at the conclusion of one of the bitterest debates in the history of the federation.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 16. -- Many luncheons were given in the Tangerine Room at the Casino today and at Kate's Mountain Lodge. At the Casino, between rounds of the conference golf tournament, Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Hence gave a luncheon for Mr. and Mrs. Carl L. Kurtz.

Mrs. George F. Baker gave a dinner last night at the St. Regis for Mrs. Allan A. Ryan Jr., Lord Dudley, William Rhinelander Stewart, Lytle Hull and Charles Munn. A luncheon was given at that hotel by Mrs. John Morgan Lee for Mrs. William Warren Barbour, Mrs. George F. Lee, Mrs. L. Sidney Carrere and Mrs. Lewis Buckman.

Georges Miquelle, a 'cellist of ripe musicianship and well-fortified technique, made his entry in the season's musical lists at the Town Hall last night. Mr. Miquelle, whose name has been associated with the Detroit Symphony, which has announced him as a soloist this year, and with some of the last concerts of Dame Melba, was fortunate in having the collaboration last night of an able pianist, Joseph Brinkman.

Twenty-five years from now there will be in this country twice as many persons over the age of 60, and the National Resources Committee at Washington speculates on the changes that will follow. The influence of youth will be on the wane and we shall be ruled "largely" by elderly people.

I was beginning to regain my former enthusiasm for the League of Nations, but I fear your editorial today "The Japanese Model" has again put the brakes on. You call attention to Mussolini's attempt to imitate Japan's tactics of setting up a dummy State and emperor in Manchuria, which, however, would not go unchallenged in Ethiopia.
The House Committee on Patents, which is holding hearings in the Fifth Avenue Hotel on patent pools and cross licensing, discussed with its witnesses yesterday a variety of subjects which included:

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Oct. 16 (AP). -- The golfers who are good enough to make the game a business were ready tonight for their annual competition to determine who is the best professional player of the game.

A long, intensive workout yesterday at Baker Field marked the end of Columbia's heavy preparation for its encounter with Pennsylvania in Philadelphia on Saturday. The Lions took stock of their offensive and defensive assets in a scrimmage against the stalwart freshman outfit, and again the yearlings gave the varsity quite a tussle.

ROME, Oct. 16. -- The European situation is considered here to have become critical again in consequence of the British Cabinet's decision today not to accept France's suggestion for easing the tension between Italy and Britain by a simultaneous withdrawal of reinforcements sent to the British Mediterranean fleet and to Italian troops in Libya.

Albert N. Shapiro, 37 years old, a stocky, neatly dressed man, walked into the Criminal Courts Building yesterday afternoon and announced he wanted to surrender on a charge of grand larceny, on which he had jumped $2,500 bail four years ago.
LAKE MAHOPAC, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The annual conference of the clergy of the Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New York opened this noon with 225 clergymen registered for the sessions.

Issuing reports which were among the first to be released for September, two Van Sweringen lines disclosed yesterday increased earnings for the month. The companies, the Chesapeake Ohio and the New York, Chicago St. Louis, reported as follows:
Store, office and showroom space in buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan was leased in transactions announced by brokers and renting agents yesterday.

Although advices from the office of Major Henry H. Curran, commissioner of the city's unofficial Anti-Noise Department, indicated that all was quiet yesterday afternoon, other sources reported skirmishes in which the Forces of Silence emerged victorious.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16. -- The two leaders of a band of minstrels who drew from their guitars music about "the downfall of the Soviet Union" and "the end of the world" as they wandered among collective farms in the Kiev district were sentenced to death today in the Kiev Regional Court as counter-revolutionaries.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Emerging from the retirement of an "elder statesman," Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw unexpectedly lashed at the government today with the same bitter invective he hurled at the Labor party four years ago.

SOFIA, Oct. 16. -- Former Premier Kimon Gueorgieff was released today from the prison to which he had been sent a fortnight ago on the charge of participation in the abortive coup headed by Colonel Damian Veltcheff. At the same time many of Mr. Gueorgieff's friends were also set free, so that only Colonel Veltcheff, former Finance Minister Peter Todoroff, about fifteen officers and a few civilians remain in prison.

Rolf A. Christensen, Norwegian Consul General in New York, criticized national merchant marine subsidies last night and warned that many governments today were ruining sea commerce by overbuilding in a trade already over-tonnaged.

The names of 133 members of the freshman class who have accepted invitations to join Columbia College fraternities were made public yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes. The total represents a gain of twenty-six over last year.

With retailers calling for immediate replacements of all types of electrical appliances, manufacturers are enjoying the most active October business in six years. Demand, for the first time since the depression started, has outdistanced production in the majority of appliance factories, and deliveries are now three to four weeks behind.

More than 300 leaders of every branch of the cotton textile industry, from grower to garment manufacturer, meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania, called upon Secretary of Agriculture Wallace for a $15,000,000 allotment to revive the industry's export trade, as provided for under section 32 of the AAA amendments.

Always have a good fund of funny stories or ones that strike you as funny if you want to live long. So says John Carl Fast Deer Hill, a Mohawk Indian whose age is recorded by the old age security division of the Welfare Department as 105.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- The annual race meet of the Rose Tree Hunt Club started today at the Rose Tree course near Media. It will continue on Saturday.

Prices of bonds moved upward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange under the leadership of second-grade railroad lines and United States Government loans. Trading continued at a fairly active pace, transactions amounting to $12,290,400, compared with $14,181,600 on Tuesday.

Sales billed by the General Electric Company in the first nine months of 1935 amounted to $149,173,275, compared with $121,735,123 in the corresponding period in 1934, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday.

Stephen Callaghan, former Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn and a director of Paramount Pictures, Inc., was one of two trustees of the Prudence Company, Inc., who leased two theatres in Florida to Paramount last September although a better offer had been submitted, the Sabath committee investigating bond reorganizations was told yesterday.

Net earnings of the Schenley Distillers Corporation and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 were reported yesterday as $1,724,913 after provision for interest, depreciation, contingencies and Federal income and capital stock taxes. They were equivalent to $1.64 a share on 1,050,000 shares of common stock.

A Negro was elected to the executive committee of Tammany Hall last night for the first time in the history of that organization at a meeting of county committeemen of the Twenty-first Assembly District in Harlem at the Teachers Training School, St. Nicholas Terrace and 135th Street.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, Inc., launched yesterday afternoon a new drive for $150,000 at a luncheon at the Hotel St. Regis. Mrs. Vincent Astor, chairman of the women's division of the fund, who made the announcement, emphasized the need of the campaign "to help re-establish talented and accomplished musicians in self-supporting work."

Books have been opened in Argentina for public subscription to a 4 1/2 per cent long-term internal bond issue of 50,000,000 pesos ($16,850,000) at the official rate of exchange) of the Argentine Government by a banking syndicate headed by Credito Industrial y Commercial Argentino (Bembery group) and Bracht Co., according to the Argentine Information Bureau here.

Although the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies, with a membership of 6,500, agreed to call off today's stoppage of employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau, which serves 150,000 home relief clients, 5,000 members of the association served notice last night that the stoppage would go into effect next week unless their demands were granted.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., Oct. 16. -- Eleven Latin-American aviation officials and one Canadian official visiting the United States to take part in the observance of Air Navigation Week, ended today a three-day inspection of aircraft in and about Washington with a tour of Langley Field, the General Headquarters Air Force Base, and the laboratories of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics here.

Preliminary plans were filed yesterday for a nine-story apartment house to take the place of the Hotel Brevoort, long a lower Fifth Avenue landmark, which has sheltered royalty and many other famous persons and is a rendezvous for epicures.

Several large apartments on and adjacent to Park Avenue were included in the new tenancies reported by brokers yesterday. In addition to the East Side activity, numerous rentals on the upper West Side also were listed.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 16. -- A revolution in concrete, which foreshadows significant improvement in the construction of dams, bridges, piers, roads, foundations and tall buildings, was demonstrated today at the Yale University laboratories before a representative gathering of experts.

Business showed a substantial improvement in September, according to The Annalist index of business activity, which rose to the highest level since July, 1933. The preliminary figure is 84.1, compared with 82.7 for August, 80.7 for July and 83.6 for January, the previous high mark for the year.

The hearings by examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission on the application of the Albany Port Commission for lower rate differentials on import and export freight for the port of Albany closed yesterday after representatives of several more Eastern ports voiced their opposition to the Albany plan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- An increase of a cent a loaf in the price of bread is not justified at this time, because costs to bakers have not risen above half a cent to the loaf, Secretary Wallace said today.

Dr. Fred B. Smith, leader of the World Alliance for International Friendship, urged members of the Sisterhood of the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun to aid this cause, at the annual harvest festival held yesterday at the community house of the congregation, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 16. -Dr. Tyler W. Dennett, president of Williams College, and Mrs. Dennett were the honored guests at a dinner which the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John F. Nichols gave tonight at the Williams Inn, Williamstown. The other guests included Colonel and Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice, the Rev. and Mrs. William R. Bennett, Professor and Mrs. James B. Pratt and Charles Bulkley Hubbell.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- A committee of thirty experts in the field of criminology was named by Governor Lehman today to help frame a detailed program of anti-crime legislation to be presented to the next Legislature for action.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- Governor Lehman announced tonight the appointment of Frederick I. Daniels as new chairman of the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration to succeed Alfred H. Schoellkopf, who will remain a member of the body.
The purchase of a corner in the Dyckman Street section by a syndicate of realty interests headed by Clarke G. Dailey was announced yesterday. Other activity centred in the Washington Heights section.

Few organists attain the fluid ductility and elasticity of tone in cantilena which graced the playing put forth by Pietro Yon last night at his Carnegie Hall recital. Whenever a selection or movement in slow tempo was the offering, one settled back contentedly, satisfied that by means of this uncanny command of cantabile the ear would be caressed by dulcet sounds.
John Block of Kirby, Block Co., was re-elected president of the Association of Buying Offices at the annual meeting yesterday.

WARSAW, Oct. 16. -- Foreign Minister Josef Beck is still confined to his home as a result of having caught a severe cold while hurrying from Geneva by airplane, and complications in the illness are feared.

A new first-string Fordham football team, drawn from the ranks of the reserves, substitutes and scrubs, and with only two regulars retaining positions, was tested against the freshmen yesterday at Fordham Field. This shake-up by Coach Jim Crowley was the most drastic thus far on Rose Hill and was made in an effort to bolster the Maroon eleven for the invasion of Vanderbilt at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 16. -- Alcohol, fatigue and sluggishness were presented as leading causes of fatalities on the highways in tests before the American Safety Congress here today. Accurate measurement of intoxication and testing of the drivers were urged as curbs for the mounting traffic death toll.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Franklin C. Hoyt, the new Federal Alcohol Administrator, tried his hand today at answering the question, "What is whisky?" which has bothered distillers and government officials for sixty years.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 16. -- The time has arrived for the imperial Japanese Army to give active consideration to plans for blocking possible cooperation of the Chinese Communist Army with the Soviet-controlled troops of Outer Mongolia and the Red Army of the Soviet Union.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 16. -- Amid the flurry of claims and counter-claims made for political effect, this correspondent learns that the Italian forces are making definite progress under the alert General Rodolfo Graziani on the southern front.

Arguments for and against segregation of the functions of brokers and dealers in stocks will be presented next month to the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. Informal invitations have already been extended to several Wall Street groups and individuals to attend the hearings.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 16. -- Opposition to selling below cost and sectional price cutting to suppress competitors was expressed in resolutions adopted at the closing session of the second annual convention of the Food and Grocery Chain Stores of America in the Hotel Traymore here today.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 16. -- The wheat trade is apparently convinced, according to interpretation here, that the new government will change the wheat policy to fit more accurately the ideals of unrestricted marketing and trading.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 16. -- An enthusiastic audience acclaimed the premiere here of "Tonight at Seven-Thirty," Noel Coward's first triple bill, short plays he has written for himself and Gertrude Lawrence. Each is entirely different yet typical of Coward's versatility.

Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago newspaper publisher, who is an active aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1936, arrived in New York yesterday for a three-day stay, during which he will endeavor to gain support from Eastern Republican leaders for his boom.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- A Democratic victory in the Assembly election was predicted today by Governor Lehman after a long conference with more than sixty up-State party candidates and organization leaders.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Tuesday, Oct. 15 (Delayed). -- Two strong Ethiopian raiding parties swept into Italian Somaliland today and claimed marked successes, while an Ethiopian army of 100,000 warriors advanced toward the left flank of Italy's Southern Army.

On the ground that there was "an odor of fraud" in the canvass of the primary election returns in the Fifth Election District of the Nineteenth Assembly District, Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy yesterday ordered that the ballot boxes in that election district be opened and the returns recanvassed by the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- For the first time in American history, it is said, the President and Vice President today were out of the United States at the same time. President Roosevelt was in the Panama Canal Zone, while Vice President Garner sailed today from Seattle for Japan and the Philippines, leaving Secretary Hull as ranking official in this country.

Those of us who believe that a proper solution of the problems of crime calls for something more than an improved program of apprehension appreciate fully the informed and effective handling of the recent crime conference at Trenton by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Notice was served yesterday upon religious, charitable and educational organizations by the Sinking Fund Commission, with Mayor La Guardia as spokesman, that the commission in the future would reject all applications for abatement of assessments on local improvements or for cancellation of unpaid water rents.

Schlater, Noyes Gardner, Inc., and Colyer, Robinson Co., Inc., of Newark will offer today an issue of $183,000 of town of Kearny, N.J., 4 per cent serial funding bonds dated Feb. 1, 1935, and due on Dec. 1, 1943 to 1945, at prices to yield from 3.45 to 3.55 per cent, according to maturity.

ONCE upon a time, in the dear innocent days of 1920, good folk shook their heads over the antics of the boys and girls of F. Scott Fitzgerald's "jazz age." Yet how idyllic, how positively sylvan and dewy, those far-off days seem when one reads John O'Hara's second novel, "Butterfield 8" (Harcourt, Brace, $2,50). Here, at last, is the ultra-ultra in fictional depiction of the willful degradation of sex.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The question arose today as to whether the Federal Government will be forced to assume responsibility for administration of billions passed out for direct relief or will be able to shunt off on the States the investigation of irregularities.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- The Boerse was weaker today, although activity was limited. Heavy industrial shares showed average losses of 1/4 to 1/2 point. Machine issues were mixed in prices at the end. Chemical stocks fell slightly, Farben receding 5/8 point.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16. -That Yale will face Navy Saturday with every man fit was assured by Head Coach Ducky Pond and Trainer Frank Wandle today. The Yale starting line-up, however, remained a puzzle as Pond again called Clint Frank and Jerry Roscoe into the back-field quartet with Al Hessberg and Captain Kim Whitehead.

Counsel for Mrs. Millicent Rogers Ramos opposed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Collins the application by Count Ludwig Salm, her former husband, for the appointment of a guardian of the property of their son, Peter Salm, to the exclusion of both parents.

Testimony yesterday in the hearing before Edward J. Gavegan, Supreme Court referee in the proceeding by Mrs. Alicia Maddox Llewellyn to get part-time custody of her 12-year-old son, Alan Sanford Glendening, from her divorced husband, Harold Sanford Glendening, lawyer, disclosed that her present husband, Victor R. Llewellyn of London, former member of the Welsh Guards, is suing her in London to annul their marriage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Augusto Rosso, the Italian Ambassador, conferred with William Phillips, Under Secretary of State, for forty-five minutes late today. It was assumed by observers that they discussed the Italo-Ethiopian and general European situations, but the Ambassador insisted to reporters that only routine affairs had been considered.

VICTORIA, B.C., Oct. 16. -- Two nations feted the departing delegation of forty-eight members of Congress and nineteen publishers or editors of American newspapers led by Vice President Garner today to speed them on their way to the inauguration of Manuel Quezon as the first President of the Philippines.

The doctrine that short hair is here to stay was formally admitted into the dogma of the beauty industry yesterday by a council of hierarchs deliberating at the annual convention of the National Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Defense preparations along the northern coast of Egypt continued at top speed today, unaffected by an Egyptian governmental crisis.

When the various crop-control and subsidy plans were introduced, their sponsors referred to them as emergency measures. They are more and more being discussed as if they were permanent. The tendency has been for an increasing number of crops to be controlled and subsidized.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Election of a Republican Assembly for the effect which a reversal of the New Deal policies in the home State of President Roosevelt would have throughout the country was urged today by James W. Wadsworth, former United States Senator, in welcoming the Republican Assembly Caravan at Geneseo.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 16 (AP). -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., 21-year-old son of the President, finally rid himself today of a charge of speeding sixty-five miles an hour on the Lafayette Highway at Hampton Sept. 18.
TOKYO, Oct. 17. -- The visit here of George H. Dern, Secretary of War of the United States, which ended tonight, left pleasant impressions on both sides.

JIJIGA, Ethiopia, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Italian troops appeared today to be pursuing a slow and cautious campaign, but steadily advancing in this sector. Airplanes were clearing the way for the operations of the main army.

ST. THOMAS, V.I, Oct. 17. -- Albert Levitt, former special assistant to Attorney General Homer S. Cummings, today took the oath of office as judge of the Federal District Court for the Virgin Islands, Judge T. Webber Wilson having resigned during the Congressional investigation of the administration of former Governor Paul M. Pearson.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Development of a State-wide employment system for the nursing profession to end "the present chaotic scheme of placements in private fields" will be started without delay, Miss Alice Snyder, director of the Nursing Bureau in New York City, stated today at the convention of the New York State Nurses Association.

Controller Frank J. Taylor yesterday advised J.P. Morgan Co., agents for this city's bankers, that he would redeem $5,000,000 of revenue bills, due on or before Dec. 31, on Oct. 22. The bills, which bear a 2 1/2 per cent interest rate, were issued on Sept. 4.

Governor Lehman refused yesterday to supersede District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County or to impanel an extraordinary term of the Supreme Court for another investigation of a Williamsburg garage murder. The request had been made by Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion candidate for the office now held by Mr. Geoghan.

A petition asking the abrogation of the law by which Mexico plans nationalization of church property, signed by fourteen Archbishops and Bishops in behalf of the entire hierarchy in that country, has been presented to President Lazaro Cardenas, according to announcement yesterday by the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

The first executive meeting of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra was held yesterday afternoon in the apartment of Mrs. Alma Clayburgh, Ritz Tower. Mrs. Clayburgh and Mrs. Raynal C. Bolling presided at the meeting, which was devoted to the organization of various committees.

MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- With the nationality of a young pig as the issue, United States Commissioner Hubert C. Genaway held a night hearing here which resulted yesterday in the holding of Thomas McNierney, 58-year-old border farmer, on a charge of smuggling from Canada what he contends was his own porker, born and raised on the American side of the line.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Secretary Wallace was accused today of trying to "keep consumer attacks off his doorstep" by Henry Stude, president of the American Bakers Association.

The Federal deficit for the current fiscal year has just passed the billion dollar mark -- having reached this unwelcome milestone some two weeks earlier than was the case last year. The figure at this point is $1,069,754,359, compared with $707,033,182 a year ago.

I read with great interest Mr. R.L. Duffus's review of Nicolson's "Dwight Morrow" in the Oct. 6 issue of THE TIMES Book Review. Mr. Duffus enjoys so deserved a reputation for command of his facts that perhaps I am taking a great liberty in seriously questioning certain of his general utterances.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Denunciation of the Nazi Government for stamping out "in blood and fire" the powerful German trade union movement was accompanied today by a resolution adopted at the American Federation of Labor convention urging that "all American sport organizations be prevailed upon not to participate in the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin."

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17. -- The drought condition is by no means ended and the next ten years may be the driest decade we have had in a century and a half, according to Halbert Powers Gillette, prominent Chicago mining engineer.

The New York University varsity football squad concluded preparations at Ohio Field yesterday for its third game of the season tomorrow against the Pennsylvania Military College eleven at the Yankee Stadium. The Violet will go through a brief drill on the Stadium turf this afternoon.

Many excited and febrile statements are reported out of Italy. There was the story of MUSSOLINI sending for some of his Admirals and asking them if they were prepared to go against the British fleet. Their answer was, "You will be sending us to our death." That did not mean that they would hesitate to obey orders, but that they would welcome the opportunity to die a glorious death for their country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- If alleged Communist agitators are dismissed from WPA jobs in New York City it will be on the sole responsibility of Victor Ridder, Works Progress Administrator for the city, it was said here today.

Lured by the hope of picking up imported wines and liquor at bargain prices, a large number of consumers was present yesterday at the United States Customs semi-annual auction of unclaimed goods. The result was that small lots of liquor were bid in for what Peter F. Bradley, deputy collector and auctioneer, described as "extraordinarily high prices."

The Appellate Division was asked yesterday to decide the opposing claims to the bulk of the $10,000,000 estate left by Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick. One of the claimants is her daughter, Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard, and the others are assignees of Edward W. Krenn, Swiss architect and close friend of Mrs. McCormick.

A capacity throng representative of society and artistic circles attended last night the formal opening of the Caprice Room of the Weylin for its season of dinner and supper dancing. The opening fete was featured by a special entertainment. Many in society gave dinners and supper parties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Problems involved in the redistribution of populations and proposals to make the subject one of intensive study by each of the Pan-American republics were considered today by the delegates to the Institute of Geography and History.

Bank clearings in twenty-two leading cities for the week ended on Wednesday showed a decline of $56,994,000 from the preceding week, in contrast with a gain of $97,219,000 in the same period last year, although New York and several other centres showed large gains, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Five groups of Federal narcotic agents, working together last night and early this morning rounded up a Broadway narcotics gang of eleven members, six of them women, and seized one of the most elaborate drug-cutting plants ever discovered in the midtown sector, as well as $20,000 worth of heroin and other narcotics.
Fencing skillfully with legal-minded lawyers, Maude Adams played a real-life Portia in her own behalf yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee and a jury.
Lady Murasaki's "Tale of Genji," which Houghton Mifflin will publish Nov. 1 in a two-volume edition, will be distributed to its members by the Literary Guild.

Sugar, cocoa and rubber futures were strong in moderate trading on local commodity markets yesterday, but the other staples with the exception of some members of the metal group were irregular. In the cash markets cotton and corn declined, but wheat, rye, oats, flour, cocoa, butter, tin and rubber were stronger.

Major Gen. Lucius R. Holbrook, commanding the First Division of the Regular Army, who will sail soon to assume command of the Philippine Department, received a soldier's farewell at Governors Island yesterday from officers and men of the Sixteenth Infantry, which has been part of his command for the last five years.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations on candidates for judicial office in New York City. Supreme Court Justices Ferdinand Pecora and Harry E. Lewis and General Sessions Judge James Garrett Wallace were among these endorsed. The recommendations follow:
ROME, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Enemy forces were reported officially by Italy tonight to be massing around Makale, where military experts have predicted a "big battle" would be fought.
SUEZ, Egypt, Oct. 17. -- The vital base of Port Massaua is rapidly being converted into a formidable stronghold by the Italians, according to reports reaching here.

The ninety-ninth winner this season for Trainer Hirsch Jacobs was saddled yesterday at Empire City when he sent out the Man o' War gelding War Stripes to take the featured Woodlawn Handicap in easy fashion. The former Glen Riddle Farm racer carried the colors of the B.B. Stable and was the seventh victor handled in four days by Jacobs.

If Premier Mussolini had believed that sanctions would be applied by a united League of Nations he would never have dared to go forward with his war plans in Ethiopia, Sir Norman Angell, winner of the Nobel Peace Award for 1933, declared yesterday in a lecture delivered at the Finch School, 61 East Seventy-seventh Street.

Ellsworth Vines and Lester Stoefen, tennis professionals, who have been playing in matches abroad, are returning today from Europe on the Deutschland of the Hamburg-American Line. Others coming on the ship from the Channel ports include Hans Clemens, opera singer, and:

EISENACH, Germany, Oct. 17. -- Probably the last solemn ceremony in the colorful history of Germany's famous duelling fraternities will take place in the great hall of the historic Wartburg Castle above the old town of Eisenach when the so-called Boerschenshaften gather tomorrow to surrender their independence and become part of the Nazi Student League.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Wholesale prices advanced slightly during the week ended on Oct. 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today, bringing the index, based on the 1926 average as 100, from 80.5 on Oct. 5 to 80.7. The index a year ago was 76.4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Final figures on the Treasury conversion of $1,246,000,000 in Fourth Liberty Loan bonds, which ended on last Friday, show that $998,090,050 of the bonds was turned in for new Treasury securities, T.J. Coolidge, Acting Secretary, announced today.
Money market was at a standstill in the matter of business and rate variations. Turnover was small, at prevailing quotations.

Spectators at the National Horse Show, which opens in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 6, will be treated to the unique demonstration of a spirited former race horse being guided through his paces only by two slender silken threads attached to the bit in place of the usual strong reins.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17. -- A warning that the country may accept a temporary "peace" in its social welfare work was sounded tonight by the Very Rev. Robert F. Keegan of New York, president of the National Conference of Social Work, at the convention of the Ohio Welfare Conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The Federal Government's tax collections for the current fiscal year are now smaller than they were a year ago despite a recent prediction by President Roosevelt that this fiscal year would end with a $670,000,000 increase in receipts, the Treasury disclosed today.

One of the reasons for selecting Flushing Bay as the site of the projected New York World's Fair in 1939 is that the bay is deep and the river which enters it capable of being made navigable for boats of substantial draught. From all points of the compass people will be able to travel to the fair by water.

Leasing of private houses for late Fall occupancy and of a business building on Fifth Avenue featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday. Apartment houses and a site for a new apartment building were sold in the Bronx.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 17. -- Emperor Haile Selassie pledged himself never to discuss peace "while a single Italian soldier remains on my soil," and then received a barbaric but impressive demonstration of loyalty today from thousands of frenzied warriors.

The United States Government took formal steps yesterday to enforce its neutrality regulations by ordering a grand jury inquiry to prosecute individuals and corporations accused of shipping airplanes and munitions of war to Bolivia and Paraguay last Spring.
LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The Hurlingham Polo Club today selected a squad of six players to represent England against the United States here next June in an international series for the Westchester Cup.

The navies of the world are looking toward the East, where "ton for ton, Japanese designs show a greater all-round value than those of any other country," Oscar Parkes, former editor of the British publication, Jane's Fighting Ships, declares in an article in the November issue of Scientific American, published today.

Plans were filed yesterday by the Third Avenue Railway Company for altering its car barns at 789-803 Tenth Avenue, between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets, at a cost of $200,000. The changes will consist of the removal of part of the superstructure, installation of new columns, retaining walls and steel girders to support the first floor.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Flamenco, great English colt, went down to defeat today in his American debut at Agawam Park.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- The team Dick Harlow is striving so hard to have in top physical condition for Harvard's game with the Army at West Point on Saturday was withheld from contact work today. However, there was a driving drill for two hours, with complete rehearsal of plays, including several not used in earlier games, and another intensive session on forward-pass defense.

Ranking officials in aviation in a dozen Latin-American countries and Canada, who are in the United States as part of the celebration of Air Navigation Week, were welcomed at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. They had flown to the municipal airport from Camden in two navy transports.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Reports that the Canadian Wheat Board had embarked on a policy of liquidation of its holdings, which led to a 3-cent break in prices on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange yesterday, were called false today by the board, which said:

Through direct intimidation and by reason of its position as a controller of franchises and patents, the Western Electric Company through its by-product subsidiary, Electrical Research Products Inc., has driven independent electrical companies to the wall, witnesses charged yesterday at a hearing of the House Patent Committee.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York Bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Controller of the Currency and the receiver and president of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company for an order permitting depositions to be taken from more than 100 witnesses in seventeen cities in support of the plaintiffs' lawsuit to compel ten Clearing House banks to make good losses suffered by Harriman depositors.

CARDIFF, Wales, Friday, Oct. 18. -- The "stay-down strike" of coal miners in the region along the Wales-England border took a serious turn early this morning as 15,000 miners in the Tredegar Valley decided to walk out in sympathy with the seventy-three men remaining down in the Nine Mile Point pit.

A group of twenty-six oils by Albert Pinkham Ryder has just opened at the Kleemann Galleries, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until Nov. 2. Although, of course, the work of this great American artist frequently makes its appearance in miscellaneous exhibitions, rare indeed is the show composed entirely of Ryder paintings.
President Roosevelt reiterated last night his plea for the support of American opinion for his policy of neutrality in threatened conflicts abroad.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- John Gielgud, certainly the youngest -- he is 31 -- if not also the most brilliant actor-manager of the contemporary English stage, again captivated London with "a new play by Shakespeare, 'Romeo and Juliet,'" presented at the New Theatre tonight. It was an outstanding success in the same way as his vividly original "Hamlet" last season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The Italo-Ethiopian crisis was discussed with Secretary of State Cordell Hull today by Andre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador, who said later, however, that he did not touch upon the question of sanctions or the attitude of the United States toward imposing an embargo on Italian imports, in collaboration with the League of Nations.

ZEILA, British Somaliland, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Fearing a threat to their left flank, the Italians since Monday have been hurrying reinforcements from Italian Somaliland into Southern Ogaden, where the army of Ras Desta Demtu was reported continuing its movement down the Webbe Shibeli River valley.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Newspaper circulation figures, considered one of the best barometers of business, showed "healthy increases" in the United States and Canada this year, O.C. Harn, managing director of the Audit Bureau of Circulations, said today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 17 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada decreased $1,536,271, deposits by chartered banks increased $6,077,293, and notes in circulation rose $4,372,502 in the week ended yesterday.

A resolution was adopted at an after-theatre meeting of the Actors Forum, held last night and early this morning at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street, calling for measures designed to protect the Actors Equity Association and uphold wage standards on the new WPA theatre projects.

VIENNA, Oct. 17. -- While all Vienna was quietly going about its ordinary occupations, Austria's fate passed out of the hands of one dictatorship and into those of another tonight without any one in the country learning that it had acquired a fresh set of rulers until all was over.

Selectivity ruled in yesterday's share market, with a renewal of war fears tending to hold trading down to a minimum. Stocks generally failed to extend their gains, and none of the averages broke through to new high levels. In the final hour prices eased, and they closed irregularly lower but only after individual issues had reached new high figures.

Two reorganized back-field units held the spotlight yesterday as the Fordham football squad went through its final heavy drill in preparation for the invasion of Vanderbilt at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were generally dull again today. Prices weakened in the absence of fresh buying. British funds declined as a result of demand slackening. Foreign bonds were quiet and unchanged.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 17. -- Gene Tunney, retired heavyweight champion squired by Professor William Lyon Phelps, gave a Waterbury audience a little bit of history, a dash of philosophy and some personal opinions from the platform of the Women's Club tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- The world's wheat markets rallied strongly today and while some uneasiness was shown as a result of the heavy decline yesterday in North America, many longs who had sold out then were active today in reinstating their holdings because of the strength in Liverpool and Buenos Aires and of the more serious construction placed upon the European political situation.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 17 (AP). -- A bungled attempt was made early today to drug two horses in their stalls, and the Maryland Racing Commission launched an immediate investigation.

GENEVA, Oct. 17. -- The planetarium of League of Nations committees preparing sanctions against Italy whirled today at faster speed and for a longer time. New minor stars, called drafting committees, appeared and, more naturally for stars than for League committees, they shone on into the night.

Columbia applied the finishing touches to its tactics yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its football encounter with Penn at Philadelphia tomorrow. The Blue and White squad of thirty-eight players, coaches, trainers and managers will leave Pennsylvania Station at 10 o'clock this morning, hold a light practice drill on Franklin Field this afternoon and then move on to Green Hill Farms in Overbrook, Pa., for the night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Coach Fritz Crisler sent the Princeton football squad through a hard defensive workout on University Field today in preparation for Saturday's encounter with Rutgers in Palmer Stadium.
R.B. MacDermott has retired as a general partner in J.H. Brooks Co.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The Canadian stable of E.R. Seagram scored a popular victory in the mile and a sixteenth claiming handicap, feature of today's Suffolk Downs card, when the bay gelding Biography romped home in front of a ten-horse field.

It was definitely decided yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs, secretary of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, to stage Joe Louis's next fight on Dec. 3 in the New York Coliseum. But although the time and place have been agreed upon, no opponent has yet been selected to face the Brown Bomber.

Miss E. Victoria Swartwout gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Her guests were her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Swartwout; Mr. and Mrs. William Bowden, the Misses Constance Terhune, Elizabeth Grant, Mary A. Vietor, Anne S. Richardson and Mary E. Scott; Duncan Van Norden, Richard B. Whitney, John Graham, H. Rollinson Peck Jr., Charles Tucker and John DeWitt Peltz.

William H. Lange, director for New York State of the National Re-employment Service, announced yesterday that there was a shortage of about 800 skilled engineers for WPA openings. He said that calls upon large contracting companies, the General Contractors Association, engineering societies, college placement bureaus, the Building Congress and consulting engineers showed all these agencies facing a similar situation.

UTRECHT, The Netherlands, Oct. 17. -- Unless the unforeseen happens, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, is due to score still another victory in his match with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam as a result of the seventh game commenced here tonight and which, adjourned unfinished after forty moves, will be played to a finish tomorrow.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct 17. -- An annual scholarship in memory of Richard G. and Henry Russell Ames, who lost their lives in June in a heroic attempt to rescue their father, Robert R. Ames, when he was swept overboard from the yacht Hamrah during a transocean race from Newport to Norway, was announced today by the Harvard University Student Council.

Cotton, after holding fairly steady in the early trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, eased later under Southern selling and pressure from liquidation of old long accounts. Prices broke below recent points of resistance, the December delivery easing to 10.74 cents a pound, making a decline of 49 points from the high price touched just before the publication of the government crop report last week.
LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
DETROIT, Oct. 17. -- It was revealed today that the Ford Motor Company had discontinued the shipment of trucks to Italian Africa and had so informed the Senate Munitions Committee in Washington.

The necessity for early construction of the proposed Thirty-eighth Street vehicular tunnel under the East River to "complete" transportation facilities for New York's world's fair in 1939 was impressed upon business men yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in a luncheon address at the Advertising Club.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The bitterness against France for its pro-Italian leanings threatened to burst all bounds in London today, while tension in the Mediterranean grew worse every hour and another brigade of 3,000 British infantrymen was ordered to Egypt to guard the Libyan frontier.

T.O.M. Sopwith, who failed to capture the America's Cup last year with his yacht Endeavour, planned to have the Royal Yacht Squadron send a challenge for a match next year, and had that in mind when he ordered an Endeavour II from Charles E. Nicholson, English designer and builder of the last three challengers.

A shortage of skilled laborers, attributed to their preference for the comparatively greater security of WPA jobs in the Winter, is slowing down an important repaving project in the Bronx, Borough President James J. Lyons disclosed last night.

Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange turned mildly reactionary yesterday on a somewhat smaller turnover. Trading in most sections was of a routine character and price changes, with but few exceptions, were restricted within narrow limits.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 17. -- Minister of War Mulougheta took leave of Emperor Haile Selassie before Parliament House today after an impressive force of about 80,000 warriors had marched past in a review lasting from 10:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M.
ROME, Oct. 17. -- The situation between Italy and Great Britain continues to absorb almost the whole interest of the people here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- A serious rift in the White Plains Republican organization was disclosed today when The Daily Reporter, a Republican newspaper, published a front-page editorial endorsing Mortimer C. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, and Archibald F. Coons, Democratic candidate for City Council.
BERLIN, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- Never since the Fashoda incident in the days before the Entente Cordiale have France and Britain been so far apart in policy and outlook as they are today. There is not the same direct conflict in this argument and there is not so much open bitterness, but every other factor of principle, of pride and of policy that serves to divide nations is entering into play.

Mayor La Guardia is to blame for the action of the Board of Aldermen in cutting water rates by $5,900,000, the Real Estate Board of New York declared in a statement issued yesterday, which recalled the Mayor's campaign promise to repeal the 50 per cent increase in water rates.

Autumn has laid her hand on hills and valleys. An automobile trip at this time of year presents unusual attractions. The Henry Hudson Drive, appealing at all seasons, is exceptionally lovely now. At each turn in the road new glories unfold.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 17. -- The stockholders of the Maine Central Railroad approved today changes authorized by the directors at an immediately prior meeting in plans for refunding of $20,000,000 of the road's bonds.

It is becoming increasingly common to blame the numerous automobile accidents with which we are plagued on excess speed, as was done by the letter in THE TIMES yesterday. The writer pointed out that at certain high speeds it requires much greater space in which to stop a car.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The few members of Congress here today who are familiar with aviation, and particularly those of the House Naval Affairs Committee, were filled with satisfaction over the exploit of the flying boat XP3Y-1, flown by Commander Knefler McGinnis and a crew of five in a nonstop test of 3,387 miles from Panama to Alameda, Calif.
The entire economic picture as it appears to the Department of Commerce was described here yesterday by Secretary Daniel C. Roper as "the most encouraging since 1929."

TRENTON, Oct. 17. -- Governor Hoffman let it be known today that he was willing to call a special session of the 1935 Legislature to repeal the Sales Tax. At the same time it was said that he would do so only if the Republican faction which advocates financing emergency relief by economies took the initiative and requested him to act.
Substantial improvement was shown in the financial statements of two steel organizations which yesterday reported earnings for the first nine months of this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- As a result of court action taken by the Securities and Exchange Commission, more than $50,000 will be returned to persons who were persuaded to invest in stock of the Eurydice Gold Mining Company, the commission announced today.

More than a score of stocks were sold yesterday on a "seller thirty-day" basis. This means that the seller has thirty days to make delivery of the stock that he has sold. The use of this method of trading usually indicates that the seller is in a distant country.

Three changes in the proposed Copeland Food, Drug and Cosmetics Bill were recommended in a resolution adopted by members of the National Hairdressers' and Cosmetologists Association, who held the final business section of their five-day convention yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
PARIS, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17. -- Yale's varsity football squad today refrained from contact work and held strictly a defensive workout against Navy plays which were run off by the scrubs. Close attention was paid to Navy's effective triple lateral and double-wing formation.
In a letter to THE TIMES, Edward P. Doyle, attacking by implication the New Deal, states that the depression of 1837 was "more serious than the one said to exist now."
GENOA, Italy, Oct. 17. -- Guglielmo Marconi, Italian inventor, and his micro-wave, which he believes will be a new and extremely useful weapon of war, will soon be on the African front.

A series of public hearings in this and adjoining States to investigate the mortgage certificate situation was announced yesterday by the Federal Bar Association Committee on Mortgage Certificates and Bond Racketeering.
The test of President Roosevelt's message to the Fifth Annual Women's Conference on Current Problems, as read by Mrs. Roosevelt at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night follows:

Manhattan climaxed its preparations for the game with Holy Cross at Ebbets Field tomorrow by thoroughly reviewing its offensive repertoire in a long dummy scrimmage at Innisfall Park yesterday. Coach Chick Meehan emphasized speed and timing in the drill and the Jaspers snapped through their plays with smoothness and precision.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden, women's metropolitan champion, shot a sparkling 83 over the long course of the Tamarack Country Club today to lead a field of seventy-nine who competed in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association.
THE TIMES is giving admirable publicity to the automobile safety campaign, but there is one point that seems to be overlooked -- namely, the types of cars themselves.

Secretary Wallace's statement in Washington on Wednesday that an increase in the price of bread is not justified at this time was ridiculed yesterday by flour millers and bakers here, who said that a general movement was on to raise the cost of bread to New York consumers within the next fortnight.

A proposal to establish a world centre for women's archives was submitted yesterday to a small group of woman leaders at the A.W.A. clubhouse. Originated by Mme. Rosika Schwimmer and presented by Mrs. Mary A. Beard, the proposal was greeted enthusiastically even though all realized the obstacles involved.

Plans for a campaign to raise $2,636,000 to meet a deficit caused by a "sharp slump" in income were announced last night at a dinner meeting of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at the Hotel Plaza. The present financial situation of the federation was described as "precarious" by Lawrence Marx, who will lead the drive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. l7. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 16, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,489,000,000, an increase of $9,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $32,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

The rowing try-outs for the 1936 Olympic Games will be held on Lake Carnegie, Princeton, N.J., it was decided yesterday by the American Olympic Rowing Committee. The trials will be held from July 2 to July 4.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- More than 2,000 fans saw South River High's eleven score a 21-6 victory over Good Counsel High tonight in Newark's first scholastic night football game.
East Side apartments drew the majority of tenancies reported yesterday. Several Park Avenue suites were among those taken. The lessees included the following:

A hostelry ninety years old would be considered venerable even in London. When the Hotel Brevoort goes the way of all brick and mortar next year the city's oldest inn will have passed into history. The Brevoort was only seven years the junior of the Astor House, but has outlived it by many years.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Oct. 17. -- The navy's Panama-to-Alameda non-stop flight by Commander Knefler McGinnis this week was just a forerunner of American naval might in the sky, according to Rear Admiral E.J. King, chief of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- While receipts of hogs were again fairly liberal and most of the run was of 175 to 225 pound new crop hogs, the market showed a firmer undertone and sales were generally 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than on Wednesday, with packers taking a good part of the offers.

Holdings of 8,041 shares of its common stock and 66,113 of its preferred in the company's treasury were disclosed yesterday by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in its first report of reacquired stock to the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The volume of business handled through the Federal Housing Administration, including loans for modernization, new building and refinancing of existing long-term home mortgages, has passed the $400,000,000 mark and is now clipping along at nearly $2,000,000 a day, Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, announced today.

After long and faithful service as chairman of the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration of this State, Mr. SCHOELLKOPF of Buffalo has resigned, though he will remain a member of the board. As head of this relief agency he has won universal praise for his ability, energy, tact and devotion in the work laid upon him.

TACOMA, Oct. 17. -- The historic Tacoma Hotel, one of the famous hostelries of the Pacific Northwest, was destroyed by fire today with a loss of $500,000. The building was designed by Stanford White and was erected under his supervision in 1884 during the railroad boom days.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Disgruntled at a lack of spectators, Dizzy Dean, temperamental hurler for the St. Louis Cardinals, walked out on a scheduled amateur exhibition game today announcing, "I can pick up more money playing poker on the train."

The frailties, fetishes and idiosyncrasies of big-game anglers were satirized with more or less subtlety, mostly less, at the annual dinner of the Beach Haven Tuna Club at the Hotel New Yorker Wednesday night.

A vigorous attack on President Roosevelt and the policies of the New Deal was voiced last night by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., who was the chief speaker at a Republican rally conducted by the County Committee of the Sixth Assembly District at Public School 93, at Forest Avenue and Woodbine Street, in the Ridgewood section of Queens.

The Sabath Congressional committee, concluding an eight-day series of hearings on bond reorganizations, conferred yesterday with the Federal judges of the Southern District in the chambers of Judge John C. Knox in the Woolworth Building.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The Reich Church Directorate of compromise men appointed by Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, over the head of Reichsbishop Mueller to "bring order into the German Protestant Church" today issued a proclamation laying down a program for the settlement of the church struggle which has rent the German people ever since the National Socialists came into power, despite censorship and concentration camps for opposition pastors.

The present threat of war in the Mediterranean is the direct result of the collapse of Italy's economic life under a system of regimentation which has forced Mussolini to resort to "the final adventure -- war," Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, said last night.

Leaders in the construction industry criticized governmental relief policies and engaged in a debate on the question of State registration of contractors at the opening sessions of the annual convention of the New York State Association of Builders here yesterday.

Victor F. Ridder, successor to General Hugh S. Johnson as Works Progress Administrator for this city, demonstrated yesterday his announced determination to run the WPA in his own way when he appointed Major Wilfred E. Boughton to a committee of three to promote the transfer of persons on work relief to jobs in private industry.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Irving M. Ives, minority leader in the State Assembly and head of the Republican Assembly caravan, hit back tonight at Governor Lehman for instructing Democratic candidates to emphasize State issues in this campaign and not to stress defense of the New Deal at the expense of discussion of the record of the Democratic party in the State.

HARAR, Oct. 17. -- Italian airplanes are dropping chlorine gas bombs on Ethiopian troops in Ogaden province, bordering Italian Somaliland, according to Dr. Robert W. Hockman, medical missionary of Wheaton, Ill.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Oct. 18. -- While Shanghai continues seething with rumors of prospective Japanese aggression against China, the government leaders at Nanking yesterday carried on protracted discussion guarded with the greatest secrecy but believed to be concentrated primarily on the problems of the Kuomintang Central Executive Committee plenum now set for Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- A daily check on financial transactions between United States banks and Italy and Ethiopia was reported tonight to have been instituted by the New York Federal Reserve Bank, fiscal agent for the Treasury.

ATHENS, Oct. 17. -- Alexander Papanastassiou, republican leader, has given your correspondent the first interview he has granted since the lifting of the constabulary guard at his house following the coup d'etat of Oct. 10 which abolished the republic and re-established the monarchy.

Football now reaches the part of the season where there is so much going on it is difficult to do justice to it all. The unfortunate football follower is in the position of the small boy at his first three-ring circus. This week, in this section, a great deal of attention has been focused on the games of the two service elevens, Navy at New Haven with Yale and Harvard's visit to West Point.

GEORGE BRITT'S "Forty Years -- Forty Millions: The Career of Frank A. Munsey" (Farrar Rinehart, $3) is the story of the life that didn't make sense. It is the story of a poor Maine farm boy who wanted to be rich. But when the poor boy had accumulated his millions, he didn't know what to do with them. He had been too busy to marry when young.

H.G. Seidel, a former director of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and now with that company in London, was. disclosed yesterday as the principal negotiator on behalf of the international oil companies for the purchase of the entire output of Russian oil products in the export markets.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler handed down yesterday a decision on an application by holders of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company for a ruling as to how their claims should be made to the State Insurance Department as liquidator of the mortgage company.

Retail package deliveries rose 11 per cent for the week ended Oct. 12, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain is smaller than was anticipated and reflects the fact that Columbus Day trade did not register the marked increases expected.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Italian Occupied Territory in Northern Ethiopia, Oct. 17. -- Italian military authorities prescribed today a cautious advance on their next objective of Makale. Officers said the impending push out of Adowa on the strategic caravan route centre sixty miles to the south, deep in Ethiopian territory, would be carried out gradually.

Every bosom in which there is the faintest spark of the collector's spirit must swell with pride at the reappearance of the Democratic Council of the District of Columbia, more affectionately called the "Collection Club." The Council's Finance Committee performs as an unselfish amateur the duties entrusted by Tammany to that official of high name, the Wiskinkie.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Reluctance on the part of investors and speculators to take their profits in the stock market because of the Federal income taxes on capital appreciation was cited tonight by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, as a contributing factor in the current rise of security prices.

ALBANY, Oct 17. -- The average American is no longer "committed against all reason" to old theories of rugged individualism, but the danger now is that the masses will accept "any half-plausible panacea," whether economically unsound or socially disastrous, Edward A. Filene of Boston, merchant, declared tonight in a speech read for him before the seventy-first convocation of the University of the State of New York.
SANDS POINT, L.I., Oct. 17. -- Two men were killed at 3:45 P.M. today when their airplane plunged into Manhasset Bay and sank about half a mile off Siegelman's dock at Barker's Point, near here.

The kidnapping of a policy banker operating in Westchester County, never reported to the police but followed by the slaying of three men and the shooting of another, all believed to have been connected with the crime, was disclosed yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court.

SEATTLE, Oct. 71. -- Master Sergeant Stanley R. Morgan, who sent to a stunned world the first word of the airplane crash near Point Barrow which killed Will Rogers and Wiley Post, began today his first vacation in seven years away from the "top of the world" community, where he is by way of being a sort of king.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Gifts of 127,000 shares of the common stock of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., with an aggregate value of about $5,620,000, at the time the donations were made in August by Percy S. Straus, officer, director and beneficial owner, and Jesse Isidor Straus, beneficial owner, according to supplemental reports of officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations for the month which were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 17. -- In view of the establishment of a temporary base for the Mediterranean fleet at Alexandria and also the substantial increase in Italian military forces in Libya, it has been decided by agreement with the Egyptian Government provisionally to strengthen the British garrison in Egypt by one brigade of infantry, which will arrive soon. The brigade will be stationed at Alexandria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- In an effort to solve the potato-price problem in line with the Potato Act of 1935, which, the Agricultural Department says, cannot be enforced because of the failure of Congress to appropriate funds, the AAA today proposed a series of meetings with growers to obtain their approval of a two-phase plan designed to increase the income of growers from the 1935 crop.

The national executive board of the Boy Scouts of America voted last night, at a meeting in the Union Club, Sixty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, to hold a national Scout jamboree in the Summer of 1937, "if practicable," to take the place of the jamboree which had been scheduled for last August but which was canceled by President Roosevelt because of the prevalence of infantile paralysis around Washington.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose to a new high record of $2,910,000, 000 on Wednesday (Oct. 16), according to the weekly report of the system, published yesterday. This compared with reserves of $2,272, 000,000 in excess of legal requirements reported last week and with a previous high record of $2,820, 000,000, reported on Sept. 11 last.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose to a new high record of $2,910,000, 000 on Wednesday (Oct. 16), according to the weekly report of the system, published yesterday. This compared with reserves of $2,272, 000,000 in excess of legal requirements reported last week and with a previous high record of $2,820, 000,000, reported on Sept. 11 last.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- A challenge by Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, charging that Federal Judge William Clark was disqualified to consider his case because of "personal bias and prejudice," caused a further postponement today, at least until next Tuesday, of the Federal court hearing on an application to remove the racketeer to New York to face trial on an indictment charging conspiracy to evade income tax payment.

ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- Formation of a nonpartisan committee to press for passage of the proposed county home rule amendment to the Constitution, which will be before the voters in the November election, was announced today by Governor Lehman, who will be honorary chairman.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 17. -- Steps were taken today by Connecticut's largest electric light and power interests to merge a holding company into its operating corporation to escape control by the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- There is every good reason to hope that before the hands of the clock go round twice the British Government again will reaffirm for the whole world to know its peaceful intentions in the present crisis in Europe.

Swift Co. have declared a special dividend of 25 cents and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents, placing the capital stock on an annual basis of $1 a share. The stock had been on a 12 1/2 cents quarterly basis, but the company disbursed a total of $1 a share this year, as a special dividend of 25 cents a share was paid also in January.
Football teams of this and other sections of the country were discussed at the weekly luncheon of the Touchdown Club, held yesterday at the Lawyers Club.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17. -- "General mismanagement" was charged against St. Mary's College today as a bandholders' committee sought to protect its $1,370,000 investment in the school.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Colonel Robert R. McCormick, Chicago publisher, tonight warned the Sentinels of the Republic against "a movement financed by billions of dollars from the Federal Treasury that seeks to replace our Republic with a dictatorship, our Constitution with the whims of an officeholder."

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- Everywhere in the United States there is great encouragement except in "that small, circumscribed district called Wall Street," Ambassador Jesse I. Straus said today, addressing the American Club on his return here from his visit home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, would be included with President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner in a heroic bronze statuary group for which Floridans will be asked to subscribe money, according to reports reaching Washington.

THE tall, distinguished alumnus of Lafayette came by to report a gross affront. An impudent scoundrel came up to him and said: "Hey, I just met a guy who must be the oldest man in the world. He remembers when Lafayette had a football team." The scoundrel, according to the distinguished alumnus, then made his escape but the police have a clue and an arrest is expected momentarily.

A General Sessions jury convicted James Graham, 22 years old, of 246 West Twentieth Street, yesterday of manslaughter in the first degree. Graham stabbed John Dennis, 24, his brother-in-law and father of two small children, on Aug. 4, 1934, in front of Dennis's home, 248 West Twentieth Street, in a row over 50 cents.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The Boerse was again listless and weak today, due in part to the continued liquidation of Jewish capital holdings. The losses, however, rarely exceeded 1 point, and some values have begun to show certain powers of resistance.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 17. -- Walter Hagen, who was "too old" for championship play, according to some observers, to all appearances was medalist tonight in the eighteenth annual Professional Golfers Association tournament.

If ever arid intellectualism and emptiness were put on the spot and exposed for the useless things that they are, this occurred at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert directed by Otto Klemperer last night in Carnegie Hall when Arnold Schoenberg's new "Suite for String Orchestra" was given its first New York performance.

The three-day invitation tournament of the Nassau Country Club at Glen Head, L.I., listed to start on Thursday, will open the season for the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, it was announced yesterday by officials of the association.

VIENNA, Oct. l7. -- Political observers tonight expressed the opinion that the increase of power granted to Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg in today's governmental reorganization probably would mean closer cooperation between Italy and Austria.

The Richmond Symphony Orchestra, a WPA unit, under the direction of Eugene Plotnikoff, will appear tonight at the Bronx County Building. The Bronx Symphony Orchestra will be heard on Sundays at 3 P.M.
Reports of railroad earnings in September and the first nine months of the year were issued yesterday as follows:

If ever arid intellectualism and emptiness were put on the spot and exposed for the useless things that they are, this occurred at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert directed by Otto Klemperer last night in Carnegie Hall when Arnold Schoenberg's new "Suite for String Orchestra" was given its first New York performance.

The three-day invitation tournament of the Nassau Country Club at Glen Head, L.I., listed to start on Thursday, will open the season for the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, it was announced yesterday by officials of the association.

VIENNA, Oct. l7. -- Political observers tonight expressed the opinion that the increase of power granted to Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg in today's governmental reorganization probably would mean closer cooperation between Italy and Austria.

The ten members of the British Ryder Cup team and their manager, Commander Robert Charles Roe, R.N. (retired), sailed yesterday for home on board the Cunard-White Star liner Aquitania. Departing on the same ship were four members of the British Wightman Cup team and their manager, D.M. Horn.

The Richmond Symphony Orchestra, a WPA unit, under the direction of Eugene Plotnikoff, will appear tonight at the Bronx County Building. The Bronx Symphony Orchestra will be heard on Sundays at 3 P.M.
Reports of railroad earnings in September and the first nine months of the year were issued yesterday as follows:
BOSTON College vs. Michigan State -- On information and belief, one vote for Michigan State.

Warm weather checked expansion of retail trade in the metropolitan area during the week. Increases over a year ago were not generally obtained by department stores, although some stores showed gains of from 5 to 9 per cent.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT ABOARD U.S.S. HOUSTON, San Blas Islands, Panama, Oct. 18 (AP). -- President Roosevelt exchanged a gift of several cartons of cigarettes for another of spears and shark teeth today in a meeting with a chieftain of these palm-covered, thickly populated islands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Because the 1935 rye crop, estimated at 52,000,000 bushels, is so far in excess of the 1934 crop of only 16,000,000 bushels, and also above the 1928-32 average of 39,000,000 bushels, Secretary Wallace today approved a four-year adjustment program to curtail production of rye during the years 1936-39 inclusive.

Housing properties again formed the bulk of realty activity in the city yesterday. Trading was featured by sales of dwellings in Manhattan and Brooklyn that had been held in seller's family for thirty or more years.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- The "beautiful standards" of education, in which there is little or no provision for meeting the problem of individuality among young students, have contributed to the wave of juvenile crime, Dr. Max McConn, dean of Lehigh University, told the convocation of the University of the State of New York here today.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 18. -The United States has become a nation weakened by the "excesses and follies" of its government and uncertain whether it can avoid bankruptcy, it was said here today by Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State.

Silk and rubber futures continued strong in yesterday's market for commodities here, despite irregularity in other staples. The market was active. In the cash markets silk made a new high price and cotton and rubber advanced, while corn, coffee and tin declined.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- The protests by various groups of Americans against participation by the United States in the Berlin Olympic Games next year appear to be making an impression in Germany, and German Olympic authorities are seeking means to counteract this aspect of the American response to the policies of the Hitler regime.

Rameses VI, the lusty ram which is the inspiration of Fordham University's football enthusiasts, has been mentally upset ever since his team lost to Purdue a week ago, according to those close to him. But it was not until yesterday, the eve of today's game with Vanderbilt, that he so far forgot himself as to bowl over a woman who was quietly picking dandelions.

Manhattan and Holy Cross will meet on the gridiron for the fifth time today at Ebbets Field. The battle between the powerful Crusaders, undefeated, untied and unscored on in four games to date, and the improved Jaspers is expected to attract a crowd of 20,000 persons.

The Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, tomorrow will begin the celebration of its 150th anniversary. The time also will mark the completion of ten years in the pastorate of the Rev. Benjamin F. Farber.

David Glassford, character actor appearing with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in "The Taming of the Shrew" at the Guild Theatre, died of pleurisy in the French Hospital on Thursday night. He was in his seventieth year.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- The Boerse was irregular today, but prices showed signs of recovery, led by rayons, electric and machine issues. Heavy industrial shares opened weak, but ended with gains of fractions. Among the rayons Aku rose 4 3/4 points and Bemberg 3 1/8.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, a Canadian, for the last six years pastor of the Westminster United Church, Winnipeg, Canada, was formally installed by the Presbytery of New York last evening as the pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 18 (AP). -With $5,000 in added money and Kentucky Derby prestige as the prize, eleven of the turf's firstflight 2-year-olds are entered to go postward in the sixteenth running of the Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes at Churchill Downs tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Unheralded, a train rolled quietly into the Dearborn Street station late last night to hang up a new speed record. Powered by a 3,600-horsepower Diesel locomotive, the Santa Fe train of nine standard steel passenger cars came to a halt 39 hours 34 minutes from Los Angeles.
