A provision in the Social Security Act calling for investment of the security fund only in Federal or Federally guaranteed obligations is likely to "revolutionize the entire system of government borrowing," M. L. Seidman, public accountant, forecast yesterday in a speech before the annual convention of the New York State Association of Builders.

In well-lighted, newly decorated quarters, the Carl Fischer Art Gallery opened yesterday with an exhibition of paintings and drawings at 61 East Fifty-seventh Street. Its near neighbors are the Marie Harriman and the Ferargil, but its function is apparently to be quite different from these.

Cotton more than recovered Thursday's losses yesterday as a result of continued buying from foreign and domestic sources, which absorbed Southern hedging and sent prices about 8 to 12 points above yesterday's closing quotations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- A "diplomatic incident" involving the Ministers of Paraguay and Bolivia was narrowly averted at the sessions of the second general assembly of the Pan American Institute of Geography and History this morning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- George Washington University's Colonials defeated the West Virginia Mountaineers by 15 -- 7 tonight in a game which had two features.

After two hours of quarreling in the Federal court in Brooklyn among lawyers for various groups of bondholders of the Prudence Company, Inc., now in reorganization, Judge Moscowitz adjourned the hearing and announced that all the lawyers' charges and countercharges would be referred to the Federal Bar Grievance Committee.

While consumer buying continued to expand and most of the wholesale markets turned more active this week, the most sustained elements of strength for progress were provided by the durable goods industries, which accounted for the largest percentage of employment increase, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- The "Church of the Coming Generation" was the subject of an address today by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler of New York City at the third Lutheran World Convention in the Lutheran Church of St. Jean here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 (AP). -A surprise witness, breaking nineteen years of silence, testified today that he was with Tom Mooney, convicted 1916 Preparedness Day bomber, a mile from the scene of the blast at the hour prosecution witnesses swore he was near by.

In your editorial "The Thirty-Hour Mirage" you have attacked the American Federation of Labor upon its declaration in favor of the thirty-hour week. As a constant reader of THE TIMES, its attitude toward labor, especially in questions of hours and wages, is very well known to me and therefore this editorial did not surprise me in the least.

GENEVA, Oct. 18. -- Working from 9.30 A.M. to 9.30 P.M. today, the sanctions subcommittees of the League of Nations had the texts of three more proposals in shape tonight for discussion by the Committee of Eighteen tomorrow morning.

At a two-day conference attended by more than 500 sales executives of enterprises throughout the country which ended yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel, speakers declared unanimously their belief that the long upswing of recovery was definitely under way.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- Columbia's undefeated eleven, outweighed ten pounds to the man, meets a determined Pennsylvania team on Franklin Field tomorrow in the twenty-first game of the series. The crowd will probably reach 30,000, including Columbia's cheering delegation of 500 and the students band.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Three horse players collected $2,151 each at Agawam Park today, as K. Daingerfield's Moll and Robert Robertson's Venetian won the daily double.

SWATOW, China, Oct. 18. -- For the first time in recent years Japan seems to have met a setback in a dispute with China, for the settlement of the Swatow dispute gained Japan none of her major objectives. After more than a month of menacing Swatow harbor, the Japanese flagship Tatsuta and all except one ship of the destroyer squadron have sailed away.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -Chuckles greeted word today that President Roosevelt in his recent letter to clergymen had asked Representative Eaton of New Jersey, an outspoken Republican opponent of the New Deal, for his advice on governmental affairs.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 18. -- A violent earthquake shook Western Montana tonight, tearing at the mountainous backbone of the Continental Divide and spending its full force in Helena, where one death, several injuries and widespread damage resulted.

The undergraduate members of thePrinceton Scott Fund Expedition, whichhas returned from the Big Horn Basinof Wyoming with added rich paleontological finds, must feel themselves privileged to have shared in such a searchinto the long past of America. Theirmost prized recovery is the part of askull of "the oldest known primate"to whose species the tentative name"Plesiolestes Problematicus" has beengiven.

Lest it soon find itself dragging along about two weeks behind the parade -- so fast does the present company step -- this column is devoted this morning to a hasty resume of the recent and manifold nocturnal events which come under the heading of news. For the moment, then, the critical eye is closed; the reporter's ear drags the ground.

An exchange of Interborough Rapid Transit 6 per cent notes, par for par, for the 4 per cent second mortgage bonds of a Board of Transit Control, as part of a unification plan, is unfair to the noteholders, according to a statement issued yesterday by the independent noteholders' committee headed by Dwight F. Faulkner Jr.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Daily newspaper publishers won a greater share today in the control of the Audit Bureau of Circulation, an agency which certifies newspaper and other circulation figures to advertisers.

Seagulls dropping skimmers and clams upon the concrete and steel base of the Atlantic Beach Bridge between Lawrence and Atlantic Beach during the last week have been causing motorists many frights, it was revealed yesterday.
GENEVA, Oct. 18. -- Automatic machinery to prevent "sanctions profiteering" was approved by a League of Nations subcommittee tonight.

Mayor La Guardia's efforts to keep the 1936 budget from becoming further out of balance met a setback yesterday when the Board of Estimate sanctioned increases in expenditures aggregating $195,571.85.

New York University's varsity football team, undefeated in its first two games, will face its third opponent of the season this afternoon when it meets the Pennsylvania Military College eleven at the Yankee Stadium. A crowd of 15,000 fans is anticipated, with the start set for 2:30 P.M.
The West Side gained the lead in the volume of apartment rentals reported yesterday. East Side leases included several large suites. The following were among the tenants listed:

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Wheat made a strong start and an irregular finish today on the Board of Trade. Strength in Liverpool, an official denial of rumors concerning the operations of the Canadian Wheat Board, and the tense political situation abroad brought in fairly general commission-house buying of futures early, but the upturn was lost quickly on concentrated selling by houses with Eastern connections.

New bonds and notes amounting to $15,481,486 are to be offered by thirty-two states and municipalities next week at public sales by competitive bidding. This compares with a revised total of $12,507,902 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date now is $25,278,524.
The Adelphi Academy football squad submerged Woodmere Academy under a barrage of touchdowns to win by 39 -- 0 yesterday at Adelphi Field, Queens Village.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- George Gershwin, the composer, will appear this season with the Philadelphia Orchestra in the course of a "festival series" of special events, announced today by Alfred Reginald Allen, the orchestra manager.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Irving M. Ives, minority leader of the Assembly and head of the Republican Assembly caravan, replied today to the challenge of Speaker Irwin Steingut to name one act, passed by the Democratic Legislature at its last session, which the Republicans would repeal.
ON BOARD S.S. WYATT EARP, Oct. 18. -- The Wyatt Earp left Montevideo today and headed south across the light-brown, muddy waters of the River Platte, bound for the Weddell Sea in the Antarctic.

ISTANBUL, Oct. 18. -- The announcement yesterday of the discovery of a plot against President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is causing great excitement. The first arrest in connection with it took place two months ago, but it was kept secret pending an inquiry.

The Actors Equity Association went on record yesterday as endorsing "wholeheartedly" the WPA relief scheme -- which, in part, affects the theatre -- but asked that it be consulted on all points where its members are involved. The chances are that the association will hold a special meeting in the near future so that the entire membership may consider the subject.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Receipts of hogs here today were the second largest for a Friday since last March, and combined with a relatively slow demand to bring about a decline of 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight in prices. So far this week the local market has received 65,000 hogs, the largest in more than seven months.

" We who are about to die salute you!" We hear much these days of leagues of youth in various countries. Why not a league of old age, named after the great Ulysses, composed of those tired reformers who fifty or sixty years ago sought eagerly to remold the world's sorry scheme of things entire?

Three Catholic organizations share the residuary estate of Mrs. Mary MacMahon Crane, widow of Major John Crane, who died in Allenhurst, N.J., on June 10, last, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

Informed through police channels that various groups planned to stage demonstrations at the pier of the Italian liner Rex before she sails at noon today from the foot of West Eighteenth Street, Police Commissioner Valentine issued orders yesterday for a strong police guard to be on hand to prevent disorders.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Revocation of the appointment of Charles E. Callahan of Medina as a special deputy superintendent of banks was announced today in the department's bulletin. He had been assisting in the liquidation of the Community Trust Company of Middleport, the Central Bank of Medina, the Union Bank of Medina and the Peoples State Bank of East Randolph.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 18. -- Many persons from the North today joined the Autumn colony at the Greenbrier. Mrs. Sidney Z. Mitchell of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Mrs. G. B. Maxwell of New York are here for their annual visit.

Not only less noise but also the assurance of greater safety and more courteous manners are important objectives of the city-wide drive, according to Major Henry H. Curran, Mayor La Guardia's noiseabatement commissioner, who addressed a large audience yesterday morning at a meeting of the Woman's Forum in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad has experienced a general increase in all kinds of traffic, according to I. B. Tigrett, president. He said that the company's September gross was about $575,000, up $178,000 from September, 1934, and the road's gross for the eight months was $3,950,808 to Aug. 31 against $3,496,010 in the same period last year.

Gold continues to drift out of Italy. The present exodus began in June, following a period of stability lasting throughout the Winter and Spring. Since June 1 the loss of gold has amounted to 1,467,000,000 lire, or about one-fourth of the total reserve existing at the end of May.

ROME, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Italy's big war machine in Northern Ethiopia was about ready tonight to roll south again in its next big push. Correspondents with the army reported that many thousands of laborers and engineers were working desperately to smooth the way for an attack.

Dr. Frank B. Jewett, a leader of industrial research, president of Bell Telephone Laboratories and vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was elected president of the New York Museum of Science and Industry by the trustees at their annual meeting yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18.--Milton Miller crashed through the Yale Jayvee line for the winning touchdown, giving the New York University junior varsity a 13-7 triumph today in the last minute of play. Joe Sivak scored the first touchdown in the opening period and Miller place-kicked the additional point.

VIENNA, Oct. 18. -- The new Austrian Government continued unobtrusively today strengthening its position against possible trouble with the Vienna Heimwehr of Major Emil Fey by bringing up the Lower Austrian Heimwehr fully armed and equipped with ammunition and distributing them among the various military barracks in Vienna.

The test of whether or not George D. Widener's Sation can carry his great speed for more than a mile will be afforded this afternoon at Empire City when the son of Galetian goes to the post in the Scarsdale Handicap at a mile and seventy yards.

MANCHESTER N.H., Oct. 18. -The eighteenth annual conference of New England museums held its sessions today at the Currier Gallery of Art. Delegates representing many New England museums and other organizations attended.

Operators of steamship lines aided by the Federal Government expressed indignation yesterday over criticism of the merchant marine subsidy system voiced by Rolf A. Christensen, Norwegian Consul General, who told the Foreign Commerce Club at its monthly meeting that the Norwegian merchant marine was so successful because it was eager to serve "trade always and everywhere."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- A branch office for the Treasury's special study of income tax returns probably will be opened in New York, it was announced officially today.

Henry L. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, in accepting the tablet inscribed to the memory of George Bancroft, founder of the Naval Academy, alluded also to Mr. Bancroft as the Secretary of War who "dispatched General Zachary Taylor, with an army, into the debatable region between Texas and Mexico along the Rio Grande."

Getting the jump in the opening quarter and never allowing the opposition to progress within the 25yard mark, the alert eleven of the Horace Mann School for Boys blanked Blair Academy, 9 to 0, yesterday at Horace Mann Field to give the Maroon and White its eleventh successive football triumph since midway in the 1933 campaign.
Mrs. Richard Stahl, widow of the late composer, will give a musical and buffet supper tonight at her home, 60 Gramercy Park, North.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 18. -Walter Hagen, casual, stocky Detroit golf veteran, his medalist crown still glowing brightly, lost today in the first-round eighteen-hole match of the P.G.A. national tournament to a fellow member of the Ryder Cup team, Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 18. -Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol, a former runner-up in the women's national championship, turned in one of her best rounds of the season today at the Montclair Golf Club to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association oneday tournament.

Ray Morrison and a band of husky Vanderbilt football players came out of the Southland into a New York climate which was almost as warm yesterday, physically fit and ready for the whistle which will start their battle with Fordham at the Polo Grounds at 2:30 this afternoon.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18. -The oldest intercollegiate football rivalry in the country will be resumed in Palmer Stadium tomorrow when the teams of Princeton and Rutgers meet.

Intensifying their campaign to keep control of the Assembly in the final two weeks before election, the Democrats expect to have an array of speakers to aid them in their cause headed by Governor Lehman.
BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- Nearly 6,000 Massachusetts teachers cheered to day as the new law requiring an oath of allegiance from all educators was attacked and ridiculed by several speakers.

The Clare Tree Major Players will give a performance of "Robin Hood" this morning at the Barbizon Plaza Theatre as the first in a series of six plays being presented by the Children's Theatre for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- A memorandum outlining Japan's views with reference to naval limitation, identical in terms with the one delivered to the British Foreign Office by K. Fujii, the Japanese Charge d'Affaires in London, was given to the State Department today for its information by Hirosi Saito, the Japanese Ambassador.

The first of the season's purposed shows about one of the theatre's major arts -- burlesque -- will have its official opening this evening at the Longacre. It was due last Wednesday and then scenic difficulties got in their unpleasant work and it was postponed.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- A great nationwide coal strike on the eve of the general election loomed as a possibility tonight following the decision of Miners Federation delegates at a conference in London to take a ballot in all coal fields on the question of whether to strike to enforce the demand for a 50-centsa-day wage increase.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP). -- High blood pressure, one of the maladies attributed to the increased tempo of modern life, apparently is yielding to the surgeon's scalpel, Dr. George Crile said today at one of the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Interstate Postgraduate Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- A warning to government civil service employes that they need make no contributions to wipe out the $500,000 deficit of the Democratic National Committee will be issued by the National Federation of Federal Officeholders, an official of the organization said today in commenting on the appeal for funds sent out by Joseph J. Cotter, chairman of the Democratic finance committee.

Advocates of increased aid for child welfare work and directors of agencies in this field joined yesterday in a campaign to provide adequate care for about 500,000 children throughout the country whose needs outside their homes have become known through recent surveys by various organizations.

The day before her eighty-fourth birthday, Mrs. Josephine Wuppermann, the world's first woman president of a large corporation, completed arrangements for increasing her company's stock from 200,000 to 300,000 shares. Mrs. Wuppermann, who celebrated her birthday on Wednesday, has been a business executive for twenty years and still directs the company's policy and presides at directors' and stockholders' meetings.

A feature of the market for new securities this week was the resumption of corporate financing on a substantial scale, resulting in $131,724,000 of bonds reaching the market, of which S120,000,000 was for public utility and industrial companies.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Chancefield Flush of Earlsmore, capable liver and white springer, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York City, won the puppy stake today at the opening session of the twelfth annual meet of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association.

SUEZ, Oct. 18 (Reuters). -- Italy's most formidable foe at present in the war area is lack of water. Many wells recently dug along the coast and in the hills give water only fit for washing, as it is slightly salt. Therefore, every troopship going to East Africa from Italy has to carry as much water as possible for drinking.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- In the first case in which the Federal Power Commission has acted under the highly controversial Public Utilities Act, the commission today granted permission for the Monongahela West Penn Service Company to merge with the Kanawha Traction and Electric Company "in the public interest."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission amended today its rules to make clear that security dealers receiving only a usual and customary seller's commission from an underwriter do not incur underwriting liability, although they might appear to do so because of an inter-relationship between the actual underwriter and the issuer.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Quicker court action in criminal cases and a Federal law requiring regulation of firearms are necessary to improved law enforcement in America, Attorney General Cummings said today. He has just returned from a tour of police and judicial agencies in England, France and Belgium.

Counsel for Mrs. Muriel Sisman Dodge, who is suing her husband, Horace E. Dodge, Detroit speedboat manufacturer, to settle financial differences between them, told Supreme Court Justice Collins yesterday that it would be unfair if she were compelled to litigate her claim to a trust fund in the courts of Michigan.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 18. -- General Jan Christian Smuts tonight expressed the deepest misgivings over the possible consequences of the Italian conquest of Ethiopia, either by diplomatic or military means.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- British iron and steel plants operated at near the 1929 peak record during the first six months of 1935 and the total British output for the year is expected to be 99 1/2 per cent of the 1929 record year, the Department of Commerce was informed today by James Somerville Jr., commercial attache at London.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18. -Before 60,000 fans, the largest crowd in the Bowl in four years, Yale will meet Navy tomorrow in the resumption of their football rivalry after a thirty-four-year intermission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Reports reaching here today indicated that Italian forces in Libya now number 50,000, all regular divisions. According to this information, Italy has sent reinforcements to Libya, not primarily to attack, but to defend an air base from which planes could be sent over Alexandria, the British base, and over the Mediterranean to attack war vessels.

THIS is about a couple of fat, good-natured books. Neither of them ever will cause much of a stir, but they are hardy and solid and will be around for a long time. They are Rose Macaulay's "The Minor Pleasures of Life" (Harper, $3.50) and "Annals of the Poets: Their Private Lives and Personalities," by Chard Powers Smith (Scribner, $3).

A simplified method of financing sales of General Motors cars was announced yesterday by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. It will be inaugurated on Monday with a national advertising campaign.

With increasing frequency, as the "mechanical age" engulfs us in its iron maw, we may expect to encounter the type of artistry displayed by Rosalyn Tureck, a true child of her generation, who negotiated her debut recital at the Town Hall last night before a sizable and responsive gathering.

The National Aviation Corporation, an investment trust, reported yesterday that the liquidating value of its capital stock on Sept. 30 last was $12.58 a share, compared with $12.16 a share on June 30 and with $12.24 a share on Dec. 31, 1934.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 18. -- Election of Frank Swift Gibson of Baltimore as president of the VirginiaCarolina Chemical Corporation at a directors' meeting here today was followed by the resignation of M. S. Purvis, vice president in charge of sales, and H. E. Perry, treasurer in charge of credits and collections, as a protest to the ousting of A. L. Ivey of Richmond from the presidency.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The Lone Star Stable's Dorothy B. held off the belated rush of Don Manuel to score by a neck in the six-furlong claiming race for platers of a better grade at Suffolk Downs today before 15,000 spectators. To win before the concerted stretch drive of the gelded brown son of Bostonian, Dorothy B. had to travel the distance in 1:11 2-5, a fraction off the track mark.
" Red Army Days," a Russian film based on the activities of the War Tank Division of the Soviet Army, opens today at the Cameo.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- New York State will cooperate heartily with other States in raising and improving labor standards, but it will enter into no alliances "if there is the slightest likelihood" that these will be used as "an excuse or pretext for leveling down our own labor standards to those existing in some of our competing States," Governor Lehman stated in an address here tonight.

The flight of capital from Europe, which had shown signs of tapering off earlier in the week, increased yesterday under the pressure of renewed fears of a European war. The rising flow was revealed in a declining movement of foreign exchanges and in larger engagements of gold abroad for shipment here.

The first ballet by Bronislava Nijinska to be seen in New York had its local premiere last night, when "The Hundred Kisses" was presented by the De Basil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House. First produced in London during the last Summer, it is the company's latest addition to its repertoire, but how long it is destined to remain there is a question.

ZEILA, British Somaliland, Oct.18 (!P).--Somali runners arrivingfrom the frontier said today thatrains still were holding up theItalian advance on the southernfront from neighboring ItalianSomaliland into Ethiopia.

CANTON, China, Oct. 18. -- "If Japan attempts an invasion or penetration into the southeast, Canton's armies will resist with force," declared Marshal Chen Chia-tang today in a frank discussion of foreign and domestic problems.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were dull again today and prices continued weak. British funds were affected by the resumption of scattered selling, but rallied later. Austrian securities were lower following political developments, while German and French loans hardened.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The fight for a new State Nurse Practice Law had hit a snag today and more than 2,000 nurses who attended their annual convention in Syracuse during the last four days departed for home without reaching an agreement.
MOSCOW, Oct. 18. -- Joseph Stalin went back to Tiflis, Georgia, his home town, yesterday and had a cup of tea with his mother, the Moscow Press reports today.

For most of the East's major prep school elevens, the current football campaign reaches the halfway juncture today, and in observance of the midseason mark there will be important games on every hand, a number of them being renewals of annual rivalries involving unbeaten teams.
JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Oct. 18 (Havas). -- An Italian column isolated in the Ethiopian desert north of French Somaliland regained Eritrea today after hard fighting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Trade in Canada in September, although large in volume, was somewhat retarded by the political campaign that ended on Monday and by a full realization of the damage done to the wheat crop by rust and frost, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of the business situation abroad.

HAVANA, Oct. 18. -- President Carlos Mendieta informed the Cabinet today that he had declared vacant the office of Secretary of Communications occupied by Dr. Pelayo Cuervo and had accepted the resignation of Dr. Antonio Beruff Mendieta, his nephew, as Secretary of Commerce.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator for New York City, announced yesterday that he had ordered the discontinuance of five of the twenty-four white-collar projects disapproved by the committee headed by Major Benjamin H. Namm of Brooklyn.

HARRISBURG, Oct. 18. -- State Senator William H. Clark, oldline Republican of Chester County, convicted of bribery and extortion, asked the Dauphin County Court for a new trial today in an appeal which attacked the State's "mechanical witness" and made accusations against a juror.

Many hunters in New York, unable to leave their desks for the week-day opening, will have their first opportunity today to fare forth into fields and woodlands. While those who confine their gunning to the metropolitan area do not anticipate much action until the taking of pheasants becomes legal on Oct. 28, considerable numbers will be found trekking to the Catskills and more northerly points in search of grouse, deer, bear and squirrels.

Net income of the Continental Can Company, Inc., for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, as reported yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange, was $16,231,650, which, after providing $4,966,165 for depreciation and Federal taxes, left net earnings available for the common stock of $11,265,485, equivalent to $4.23 a share on 2,665,191 common shares of $20 par value outstanding.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Japan today indicated her willingness to attend a new naval conference in London as called for by the Washington Treaty although she has not receded from her stand which led her to denounce the treaty at the end of last year.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 19. -The Duke of Buccleuch, father of Lady Alice Scott, whose wedding to the Duke of Gloucester had been arranged for Nov. 6, died early today at Bowhill, Selkirk, Scotland, after a long illness, at the age of 71. He is succeeded by his eldest son, the Earl of Dalkeith, who served in the World War and afterward was aide de camp to the Duke of Devonshire, Governor General of Canada.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 18. -- "Satisfactory relations with the leaders of the present Nanking regime are not impossible," Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Japanese Military Attache of the Peiping Embassy, told this correspondent in an interview today.

H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, said yesterday that 90 per cent of the American seagoing tonnage was "rapidly approaching obsolescence," and that replacement building must be begun immediately if the United States is to continue to carry its percentage of foreign trade.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- An employment drop of 1.1 per cent in the construction industry in New York State from August to September was reported today by the State Industrial Commissioner, Elmer F. Andrews.

Headed by Leonard Dauenhauer of Syracuse Central High, national interscholastic champion, more than 400 schoolboy harriers from approximately forty schools will compete in Manhattan College's thirteenth annual interscholastic cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park this morning.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 18. -- The army of Ras Mulugeta, the War Minister, is moving toward Dessye in small parties and the camp near here is now almost unoccupied except for the Ras's own hut, roofed with corrugated iron, where he sat this morning administering justice to two of his soldiers who had come before him with mutual complaints.

A hold-up that was a model in technique netted three robbers the $2,800 payroll of Keystone Silver, Inc., hollowware manufacturers, of 460 West Thirty-fourth Street, at 3 P.M. yesterday, according to a report to the police.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 18. -William Green was elected unanimously president of the American Federation of Labor for the eleventh consecutive term today.

Another actress took the stand yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee and a jury to challenge part of the testimony given by Maude Adams in the $200,000 suit brought by John D. Williams, former stage director, against Miss Adams and the Erlanger theatrical interests.

The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices declined 0.5 point to 129.7 in the week ended on Tuesday, reflecting lower prices for grains, flour, livestock, meats and cotton, partly offset by higher tin, rubber, hides and the textile group except raw cotton.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18. -- Duquesne downed Washington University of St. Louis, 13 to 6, at Forbes Field tonight in a hardfought battle. The local team scored in the first and third periods and the Mound City team in the third.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- A sub-par 70 gave William Goldbeck, Lawrence Farms pro, the victory in a special eighteen-hole medal play tournament held at the Leewood Country Club today under the sponsorship of the Westchester Police Golf Association.

The address of the president of the New York Stock Exchange, Charles R. Gay, in Springfield, Ill., yesterday struck a most responsive chord in the financial community. Since the institution that he heads is regarded popularly as a citadel of conservatism, the fact that he used this word as the title of his address brought his talk all the closer to Wall Street.

Reactionary trends again dominated trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading continued more or less professional in character as the turnover was further reduced to $10,328,700, as compared with $11,518,900 on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -Financial reports of the country's largest cities revealed today that a majority had cut their debts as well as their operating costs in 1934.

The League of Nations Committee goes on adding to the list of raw materials shipment of which to Italy it proposes to embargo. Reports have it that the Washington Government has been approached with a request to cooperate with the League, or at least to do nothing to hamper its collective action against an aggressor nation.

A new and deeper interest in the power of the spirit can be spread through the people of this country by inspired women workers of the Oxford Group, according to Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman, the founder and leader of the Oxford Movement, who was a speaker yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the group in the Hotel Pierre.

The football battlefront today presents the most formidable marshaling of the campaign, with first-class powers drawn up against each other in every sector and unbeaten entries coming to grips in many instances.

Prices of stocks receded moderately yesterday in the smallest trading in more than a week. Wheat was irregularly lower, while cotton was slightly higher. In the bond market, United States Government issues were lower and other bonds were irregular.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The black war clouds which have hung over the Mediterranean all week were blown apart today by simultaneous action in London, Paris and Rome and patches of blue again appeared in the sky.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- With minority objectors injecting a discordant note into the proceeding, creditors and stockholders of the Middle West Utilities Company presented today to Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson their plan for reorganization of the company, whose affairs have been in the hands of the court since April, 1932.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 18 (AP). -- A mother who said Pearl Buck's "The Good Earth" was a type of book which in her childhood days "you went behind the barn to read," brought about a sweeping investigation tonight of high school reading lists in Kansas City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- With the deadline for putting 3,500,000 unemployed at work thirteen days away, the Works Progress Administration released a report today which showed that the total now employed is 1,310,733, leaving 2,189,267 still to be placed if the Nov. 1 goal is to be attained.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 18. -- After months of negotiation, the assets and business of the Libbey Glass Manufacturing Company, reputed to be the world's largest producer of thin-blown glass, have been purchased by the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, William E. Levis, president of the latter, announced tonight.

High officials in civil aviation in nearly a dozen Latin-American countries and Canada, here in celebration of Air Navigation Week, were called heralds of a better international understanding by Mayor La Guardia at a luncheon at the Advertising Club of New York yesterday.

W. C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, in a statement yesterday said that he saw no reason under existing conditions to interfere with the regular commercial business which his company has been carrying on with Italy.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Oct. 18. -Sailors on British warships in the harbor here went to the rescue of the passengers and crew of the Italian liner Ausonia this morning and saved many lives in a fire which killed seven of the crew and left the vessel a blackened, smoking hulk.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 18. -- Seventynine army officers were dismissed today by a decree signed by King Boris. The action was officially called a "purge of the army in the interest of its discipline." Among the officers were one general, Zaimeff; an inspector of artillery, fourteen colonels and twentyfive lieutenant colonels, the remainder being of lesser rank.

The New York Queens Electric Light and Power Company applied yesterday to the Public Service Commission of New York for permission to issue $25,000,000 of 30year 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1965, and 135,000 shares of no par capital stock.

The possible course of business in the coming Presidential election year, forces which may produce a set-back in the current recovery wave and the possibility of inflation were among the subjects discussed yesterday on the first day of a two-day, tri-State conference of the National Association of Credit Men in the Hotel Commodore.

In one of the amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act Congress provided that 30 per cent of our customs receipts should be set aside in a separate fund to be used by the Secretary of Agriculture for several purposes, one of which was to subsidize exports of agricultural commodities and products made from them.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Mandeville Zenge, a young Missouri farmer, was found guilty tonight by a jury of the murder by mutilation of Dr. Walter J. Bauer, a chemistry teacher of Kirksville, Mo. His punishment was fixed by the verdict at life imprisonment.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 18 (AP). -Hurling pennies at their household god Tecumseh and defiance at their foes, 1,000 blue-clad Midshipmen entrained tonight for New Haven, Conn., where they will cheer the Navy football team in its game with Yale.
ROME, Oct. 18. -- Sir Eric Drummond, British Ambassador to Italy, was received by Premier Mussolini early this morning and remained in conversation with him for more than an hour.

The second or the third week of October is apt to be the period in which distribution of merchandise from first to second hands reaches the high mark of the year. Comparison of the movement at that time with the corresponding period in other years will always picture the actual increase or decrease of the volume of trade in motion.

A dividend of $3 a share was declared on the first preferred stock of Associated Dry Goods Corporation yesterday, payable on Dec. 2 to stock of record Nov. 8. In the three previous quarters similar amounts were paid on account of accumulations, which were $10.50 a share on Sept. 3.

A luncheon will be tendered on Oct. 30 to H. Gordon Selfridge, noted London merchant, by the Association of Buying Offices in conjunction with the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York, it was announced Thursday by John Block, president of the Buying Office group.

What may be termed a "life speedometer" for measuring the rate or tempo at which one lives was discussed yesterday by Professor Franz Boas of Columbia University, at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Association of Life Insurance Medical Directors of America at the WaldorfAstoria

If there was ever any doubt that the less government the better, it has been removed by the enchanting weather of recent days. President ROOSEVELT is out of the country, somewhere in the Gulf of Panama, Vice President GARNER is on the bounding Pacific.
Your Moscow correspondent, in his dispatch "Anti-Soviet Songs Doom Two Minstrels," stated that General Petlura was a "white Russian leader."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Dr. John B. (Jock) Sutherland, Pittsburgh's football coach and a very cautious man about making predictions, said today that the Panthers have an "even chance" of defeating Notre Dame tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Farm Administration fixed today an Oct. 31 deadline for receipt here of 1935 corn-hog contracts.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 18 (AP) -Machines themselves are harmless, misuse of them by operators causes the havoc, the final session of the National Safety Conference was told today by H. W. Heinrich of the Travelers Insurance Company.

In reference to the article in THE TIMES of Oct. 15 regarding so-called "safety cans" to be used for the storage of kerosene, as required by the Fire Department after Nov. 1, may I say that I am among those forced to live in one of the rat-trap tenements which have been such a lucrative source of profit to the landlords of New York?
At its meeting in City Hall yesterday the Board of Estimate adopted a resolution authorizing the expenditure of $200,000 for preliminary work on the Flushing meadows site of the World's Fair in 1939.

The House Committee on Patents, investigating pooling and cross licensing, turned its attention yesterday to the moving-picture industry. Among the witnesses at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Fifth Avenue at Ninth Street, where the committee is holding its hearings, was Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America, Inc.

UTRECHT, The Netherlands, Oct.l$.--By winning the seventh gameof the world championship chessmatch today, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, tifieholder, drew stillfurther away from his challenger,Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam,whom he now leads by 5--2.

The Flatbush School eleven staged a hard drive in the last half to triumph over McBurney, 13 -- 0, yesterday at Rice Stadium, Pelham Bay Park. The contest was held in conjunction with McBurney's annual field day.
EISENACH, Oct. 18. -- The closing scene in the long and colorful history of Germany's student dueling corps was played today in the courtyard of the Wartburg Castle.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 18. -The stringent control which the Federal Government has clamped on business is operating as a positive check on investment and is causing a continued depression in the heavy-goods industries, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, asserted here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Treasury today certified an income tax assessment of $120,000 against Al Capone and fourteen confederates. In connection with the action, the Department of Justice revealed details of the investigation on the basis of which it recommended the assessment a month ago.

The Board of Estimate adopted the 1936 proposed city budget unanimously yesterday. There was no bickering and none of the grand-stand plays familiar to another political generation. While there have been differences of opinion in the board, it is heartening to note that the minority members have in the main cooperated with the Fusion members in this labor.

The New York Zoological Society fully understands and sympathizes with the desire of many lovers of animals and beautiful scenery, including your recent correspondents, F. R. Batchelder and Dorothy Marie Johnson, to take photographs in the park.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 18. -Harvard's football squad, which meets Army in Michie Stadium tomorrow, arrived here at 3:30 this afternoon. The Crimson players and coaches got into Beacon, N.Y., by rail shortly afternoon, crossed the river and were driven directly to West Point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Export-Import Bank concluded an agreement with Cuba today to sell her silver bullion sufficient to coin 10,000,000 standard pesos which will be minted at the United States Mint in Philadelphia.

The National Labor Relations Board has started the first action under the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act in this district against the United Fruit Company for the alleged discharge of three employes for their union activities, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Regional Director of the Labor Board.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its recommendations on the candidates for the Assembly in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond. The committee on local candidates based its comments on experience, capability and training of the aspirants.

A FLOOD of new books is appearing to celebrate the centenary of the birth in Florida of Samuel L. Clemens, beloved the world over as Mark Twain. Harpers are publishing his translation in jingles, made for the amusement of his children; of Dr. Hoffman's "Slovenly Peter," as well as his notebooks, which are a mine of witty and picturesque ideas.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- After deliberating more than sixteen hours a jury in the Westchester County Court returned a verdict at 5:30 this morning acquitting the three men who were accused of second-degree manslaughter in connection with the Ossining bus disaster which cost twenty lives July 22, 1934.

DOWN the steps of a modest business district hotel and into the Autumn sunshine strolls an angular, bushy-haired man. He nods to the bellboy as he leaves the building. A dilapidated hat is perched jauntily on his head.
REDECORATED and with a very effective new lighting system installed, the Whitney Museum of American Art opened up for the current season last Tuesday afternoon.

ROME. -- Italy is generally classed with Germany and Japan as a country in which the problem of overpopulation has become so acute as to represent a danger for the peace of the world. It is felt that these peoples must either expand or explode.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Bucknell, its attack unable to function against a stubborn Western Maryland defense, eked out a narrow 3-to-0 victory today. Walter Dobie, Bison guard, drop-kicked a field goal for the score late in the third period.

A comprehensive series of classes in sociology, economics, political science and psychology, called "Social Planning -- Basic Concepts," and designed to give a basis for scientific understanding of contemporary society, will begin tomorrow as a part of the adult education project of the Board of Education and the WPA.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Commerce Department trade experts disclosed today from official figures that the United States had been supplying a major part of a large increase in Italian imports of four classes of products easily made into munitions.

IN his presidential address to the annual conference of the Association of Special Libraries, Sir Richard Gregory, the distinguished scientist and editor of Nature, discussed the relation of literature, especially poetry, to science.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 19 (AP). -- With a call for "broad-minded Democrats" to join them in ousting the Roosevelt administration, and an appeal for support of the nation's youth, Republican leaders of eight intermountain States closed a two-day conference today.

THE optimists who were making things hum before the depression left the country so well equipped with business buildings that, according to seemingly trustworthy figures more than one-fourth of the space so lavishly provided for this purpose is vacant today.
The following letter was written by William Randolph Hearst in reply to questions submitted to him by Paul Mallon, Washington correspondent of the North American Newspaper Alliance:

For the liras time this season, members of the Woman's Club of Garden City will gather tomorrow for a general meeting, with Mrs. Andrew H. Boardman, who was reelected as president, directing the program.

THOSE who have come to find in the startling poetic genius of Robinson Jeffers something not akin either to the elder poets or to the general run of poetry turned out today will not be disappointed in this new collection. True, it is a little more scattering than is usual with this Californian.

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 19. -- The Montana earthquake is just another evidence that mountain building is going on in the Rockies of that region, it was declared today at the seismological station of the Carnegie Institution of Washington here.
MORE than $100,000 will be spent by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to provide classes for its members, in the second season of its enlarged educational program, which began last week.

HOLLYWOOD. A BOWL is only as big as a bowl; a stage is only as big as a stage; but a screen is as big as the director's imagination." Max Reinhardt unloosed this profound observation when he settled himself in his office in the Warner Brothers' drama mill in Burbank a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Attorney General Cummings bade "God-speed" today to twenty-three police officers who will return to their beats with the first diplomas of the Federal Police Training School.

The executive committee of the New York State Bar Association, meeting yesterday afternoon at the Bar Association Building, adopted resolutions advocating measures to speed up, simplify and otherwise reform the administration of the law in this State.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Fugitive proved too hard to catch in the tenth running of the Monmouth County Hunt Gold Cup today and Mrs. G.H. Bostwick's racer made a runaway affair of the three-mile steeplechase.

THE 1936 "Standard Catalogue of Air Post Stamps" illustrates, by the large number of varieties listed from more than 100 countries, the rapid development within recent years of air mail transportation and the eagerness of many countries whose facilities for such service are limited to issue many varieties which have been chiefly used to fill several pages of collectors' albums.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 19. -- State Senator J. Dryden Kuser of New Jersey and Mrs. Louise Mattei Farry will be married here Monday at the home of Judge and Mrs. Clyde D. Souter.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 19 (AP). -- A dazzling Southern Methodist team shot the vaunted Rice Institute Owl from its high perch in the national football picture today, winning by 10 -- 0 before 25,000 spectators. The largest throng in Southern Methodist's home game history cheered wildly as Coach Matty Bell's powerful machine stamped itself as one of the nation's leading teams.
PARIS, Oct. 19. -- A ten-day breathing space for negotiation has been obtained, in French opinion, as a result of the diplomatic activity of the past few days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A Winter work program calling for 2,427 CCC camps and the employment of 500,000 enrolled young men was announced today by Robert Fechner, director of the emergency conservation work. As a result, Mr. Fechner said, more men will be available during the period than any previous six months since the CCC camps were organized on April 5, 1933.

TONY and Maria Torchiani came to America from Sicily, honest and God-fearing peasant folk following the dream of getting ahead. They settle in Chicago's Little Italy among people of their own kind, race and background.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Talk was current here today that Senator Vandenberg of Michigan might become the compromise Republican candidate for President, if plans tacitly agreed upon by Western leaders succeeded.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 19. -- The Northeastern freshmen defeated the Anover eleven by 7 -- 6 today in a game marred by fumbles.

IMPROVED spring suspension, easier steering and a "ride levelator" are among the outstanding features of the new Dodge cars. Seven body types are presented -- four-door sedan, four-door touring sedan, two-door sedan, two-door touring sedan, coupe, coupe with rumble seat, and convertible coupe.

Although the stock market has had a substantial rise, there is lacking the flavor and dash of the old-fashioned bull market. Where, for example, are the cherished cliches of yesteryear? No commentator, so far as can be discovered, has revived that fine old metaphor to the effect that "constructive forces are in the saddle."
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 19 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg said today that "uninstructed delegates" should be sent to the conventions to choose the Presidential candidates in 1936.

EPERNON, the cantankerous old Gascon Kingfish who started his fantastic career as a mignon of Henry III, could, just to be modish, faint at the sight of a leveret, but infinitely preferred a life ignorant of such subtleties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Federal Finance Committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today began a comprehensive study of the Federal tax structure, seeking to frame a simplified and equitable tax program which could command the united support of American business men.

MADRID, Oct. 19. -- The recent resignation of the Lerroux Cabinet, which was expected to remain in office for the rest of this year, if not longer, has caused much uneasy speculation in this capital as to whether another political upheaval in Spain might occur on the first anniversary of last year's October rebellion.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 19. -- The chapel problem at Williams College, which once was of considerable difficulty to the administration, owing to the persistent protest from undergraduates opposing compulsory daily attendance, has been solved in the last three weeks.

THE turbulent, intriguing Italy of the quattrocento, glittering, luxurious, treacherous and cruel, forms a rich background for the chivalrous figure of Rafael Sabatini's latest hero, Colombo da Siena. Colombo was of a noble house; but his father had been hanged, and justly hanged, as a traitor, and that sinister fact influenced all his life.

IN this case the semi-divinity that doth hedge a prince detracts considerably from what otherwise might have been a quite enjoyable account of two hunting expeditious to British East Africa. The more recent trip took place five years ago, and is scarcely news.

IN a benevolent address at Northampton Andrew Carnegie endorsed dancing as a proper diversion for the young, and the Kaiser Wilhelm sailed with his fleet from Corfu for Italy. The roar of Russian guns was heard in the China Sea, and four horses hitched to an empty hearse ran away in Times Square.

EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 19 (AP). -- A hard-driving University of Oregon football team defeated a fast, tricky University of Idaho eleven, 14 to 0, in their Pacific Coast Conference contest today before 6,000 fans. Halfback Braddock made both touchdowns.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 19. -- The Montclair Academy eleven proved much too strong for Rutgers Prep today and won by a score of 27 to 6. Murphy at quarterback played a particularly good game and scored two of the touchdowns for the winners.

The furniture, tapestries, paintings, silver and other art objects auctioned during the last three days by the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, realized $37,905, it was announced yesterday at the close of the sale. The collection consisted of property of the late Edward L. Norton of 1,010 Fifth Avenue, property of Ethel Leary of 940 Park Avenue and additions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19. -- The outstanding astronomical achievements of 1935 were outlined tonight by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, in an address before the American Association of Variable Star Observers tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Current statistics indicate continuation of the relatively favorable trend of business activity during the first half of October, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of the domestic situation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- Counteraction against a decrease in the purchase of bread is planned at the annual convention of the American Bakers Association, which opens here Sunday. A plan for cooperative advertising in local newspapers is in preparation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Insisting that processing taxes had justified no more than a rise of half a cent a loaf in the price of bread, Donald E. Montgomery, consumers' counsel for the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, sent a letter today to Henry Stude, president of the American Bakers Association, asking him to give "a complete and accurate explanation of the facts behind the price increases that have been made or now proposed."

THE crisp October weather seems to have frozen the film-shipment channels between Hollywood and New York. Breaking through the ice barrier are four new films, but only two are reasonably sure of reaching their Times Square destinations this week.

Before the largest crowd ever to jam the Empire City Race Track since its era as a trotting oval, Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Psychic Bid yesterday left in his wake the doughty Sation and a new track record as he sped to victory in the Scarsdale Handicap.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 (AP). -- After nineteen years of trying, Oregon State defeated the Southern California football team today, 13 to 7, in a thrilling encounter.

Bonds were bid up sharply on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in response to the decidedly more favorable news from Europe on the war situation. Almost all classifications participated in the upward movement, a feature of which was the sharp rise in Italian loans, and quiet strength in United States Government obligations.

Every seat in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor is expected to be occupied on Friday for the October convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs. One explanation is the enthusiasm for the progressive policy of the organization, which brings to the platform a nonpartisan discussion of the philosophies and policies of major political parties.

In a recent visit to New York I had the pleasure of seeing Maxwell Anderson's "Winterset," and I was surprised to find in reading the dramatic criticisms that it did not seem to be understood. While the response in general was favorable, many of the critics were bothered by the rhythmic mode in which the play was written.

IN many of their earlier works the Gestalt psychologists seemed to be centring all their attention on the field of sense perception, and there appeared to be the danger that, like Fechner, their interest would not extend much beyond these limits, nor bring them to correlate this research with the other domains of psychology.

The first sizable demonstration aimed at Victor F. Ridder since he succeeded General Hugh S. Johnson as Works Progress Administrator for New York City last Tuesday was staged yesterday by some 200 unemployed teachers, members of the Unemployed Teachers Association, a left-wing organization.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 18. -- Louisiana faces a period of political uncertainty. With full State and parish tickets placed in the field by the machine created by the late Senator Huey P. Long, and by the factions opposed to him, the results of the January Democratic primary are hard to predict.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19. -- Although the Socialist International in its Paris conference yesterday turned down the projected union of Socialists and Communists to boycott "Italy's invasion of Abyssinia," the Socialist action was taken in friendly fashion.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Two hundred students are equipping themselves for careers as artists or art teachers this Fall at Georgian Terrace, the former home of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Tyler in Elkins Park. The nine-acre estate with its fifty-room mansion, through a gift of its former occupants, has become the Stella Elkins Tyler School of Fine Arts of Temple University.

DOUGLAS, Ariz., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Churchmen were blamed by two government authorities tonight for the bloody Northern Sonora "revolt" which reputedly has come to an end satisfactory to the Mexican rebel raiders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Building permits issued in September declined 15.8 per cent from the August value, but were 88.1 per cent above a year ago, the Bureau of Labor Statistics stated today on the basis of reports from 770 cities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The program of the housing division of the Public Works Administration entered the construction phase today when bids were asked on twenty-one projects involving a construction cost of $70,000,000.

THE second number of The Dolphin has just appeared and it is a worthy successor to the first volume. This annual is closely patterned after the late lamented Fleuron -- the most distinguished in scholarly content and typographic beauty of any periodical devoted to printing.

ONE rubber plant," sang T.R. Ybarra, when rubber plants were rife, "can never make a home." Neither does a happy title always make a book. But this book, embracing the rubber-plant era, and written by New York's self-devoted historiographer, is precisely as good as the title; just as capaciously discursive and at the same time as complacently local as that compendious grouping of words would imply.

ROME, Oct. 18. -- While the League of Nations subcommittees labor overtime on the unprecedented task of coordinating and implementing economic and financial sanctions, developments of major importance are in genesis elsewhere. At the front of the stage, in the heat and light of Geneva, Mr. Eden works to harmonize a fifty-piece orchestra.

The Loose-Wiles Biscuit Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $1,022,247, after Federal taxes, depreciation, interest and other charges, for the first nine months of this year. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the profit is equivalent to $1.60 a share on 522,476 shares of $25 par common stock.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19. -- Not without some satisfaction, the newspaper Pravda reports "the disappearance of Premier Bennett" from the Canadian political scene and foresees low tariffs and hence renewed trade relations between Canada and foreign countries with the advent of the new Liberal government.

TURIN, Sept. 25, 1935. IN the Rome Cabinet meeting held yesterday it was deliberated, among other centralizing measures, to place all Italian radio (and future television) activities under State control, the organization and broadcasting of programs being taken over by the recently created Ministry of Press and Propaganda, while the technical and administrative departments fall under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Communications (Costanzo Ciano).

THE musical season in Stockholm, which formally opened in the Concert House of the Swedish capital during the past week, presents an array of singers who for the most part are known in this country, among them the American tenor, Richard Crooks.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18. -- The rattle of rifle fire on an open steppe near Pogranichnaya, where three times in the last month troops from Manchukuo under Japanese officership have crashed across the Soviet frontier, has again called the world's attention to what a year or two ago was generally believed to be one of the worst danger spots to international peace.

Despite the apparently rapid price advances of many textile lines in recent months, they still have some distance to go before levels of a year ago will be reached, according to a survey made yesterday in the primary market. Selling agents stressed this point to show that the market has not been a "runaway" one.

HARDY souls who endured chilled hands and feet at football games last year will find plenty of garments and accessories in the shops this year to protect them against the cold blasts that sweep through the stands.

An inspired Brooklyn Prep team that struck with speed and deception in the last half after being outplayed held a favored Fordham Prep eleven to a 6-to-6 tie yesterday at the Maroon's field in the Bronx.

The recent publication of "Historical Opinions of the United States Supreme Court" (Doskow) recalls an article in THE TIMES in the early Summer tracing the influence of Chief Justice John Marshall to the present time. Both have suggested two striking coincidences:

The window cleaners' strike called last Wednesday to enforce the demands of the Window Cleaners Union, Local 2, for higher wages was accompanied yesterday by violence and vandalism. Plate glass in the show windows of four shops was ruined by acid and a non-striking window cleaner in the Bronx received a beating.

THE American School of the Air, presented coast-to-coast by WABC and affiliated stations, begins its sixth year tomorrow at 2:30 o'clock. The daily Monday to Friday program schedule is designed "to stimulate and vitalize education and encourage enterprise and individual initiative on the part of pupils."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Victor Ridder, Works Progress Administrator for New York City, discussed the work-relief problem here today with Acting WPA Administrator Aubrey Williams. Mr. Williams said charges that Communists had attempted to sabotage the New York City WPA program had been mentioned but not seriously considered.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- Premier Pierre Laval will be a candidate on Sunday in two departments of France for election to the Senate. For the past nine years he has sat in the upper house as Senator for the Seine Department, representing the district of Aubervilliers, of which he is Mayor.

PLANTS that have been made ready for Winter bloom indoors and have been undergoing a preliminary period of getting "established" on the porch or in a sheltered nook out of doors are now being brought inside that there may be no danger of Jack Frost's catching them unawares.

WITH the delivery of the world's premier aircraft for range and load-carrying, the China Clipper, 25 1/2-ton Martin flying boat, to Pan American Airways scheduled transpacific and transatlantic air service draws very close.

Every employed person of the United States designated by a number, their careers of employment traced and recorded by the largest bureau ever set up in Washington and the threat of an avalanche of paper work of unprecedented size were aspects of the Federal Social Security Act discussed and considered yesterday by credit men in convention at the Hotel Commodore.

The annual Horse Show Ball, the feature of a week of entertaining in connection with the forthcoming National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, will be one of the important functions of the late Autumn. The event will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 11, the night before "International Night," which brings the horse show to a close.

In the Magazine Section of THE TIMES today Mr. CHARLES WARREN discusses problems of American neutrality. Formerly Assistant Attorney General of the United States, in charge of all matters relating to war and neutrality which came to the Department of Justice between 1914 and 1917, he has thought and written extensively on these questions.

OF paramount importance to any garden is the path. It is a main artery. It may lead to a bench in a peaceful corner, to a pool or sundial, or merely to the cutting borders; but without it the garden lacks a vital point of interest.

United Neighborhood Houses, comprising forty-six settlement houses in the city, will be the beneficiary of the second night's performance of "First Lady," a new play by George S. Kaufman, which is scheduled to open the week of Nov. 22 at a theatre yet to be announced.
The long string of twenty-eight triumphs compiled in the past three years by Morgan College was extended when Lincoln University was routed, 26 -- 0, before 10,000 persons at Dyckman Oval yesterday.

IN the World War this country as a neutral was faced with new conditions of warfare, unusual problems and acts of hostility here and on the high seas from belligerents which could not have been anticipated. Consequently, policies had to be initiated, often suddenly and rapidly, to meet these conditions.
AMARILLO, Texas, Oct. 19 (AP). -- An idea and a dime, combined to rehabilitate Amarillo's delinquent boys, have affected the lives of more than 2,250 youths of three races in two States.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 19. -- California's Golden Bears, as scrappy and alert as any band to carry the Blue and Gold colors in many a year, retained an unblemished football record today with a 6-to-0 victory over the University of Santa Clara Broncos.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19. -- Serious rumors of a plan for a Fascist coup, in which a group led by Joseph Kostich, forty Yugoslav Fascist leaders, former Premier Yeftitch's National party and former Dictator Zhivkovitch, would overthrow the Stoyadinovitch government and seize dictatorial power, were heard in well-informed political circles of Belgrade today.

Led by Miss Margaret McAghon, who tallied three goals, the Carroll Club first team routed the German-American Club, 5-0, in one of the three New York Field Hockey Association interclub games played at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

SOFIA. -- The Sofia municipality, anxious to beautify the capital, is planning to order all business houses overlooking main streets to provide themselves with green window boxes. The municipal authorities will then fill them with earth and plant flowers.
MAX BEERBOHM once said that Sir Hall Caine always wrote at the top of his voice. The Unofficial Observer sometimes raises Caine's ghost. He shouts his warnings -- and he has many warnings to shout.

ON a few rocky islands off the Pacific Coast, near Vancouver, the raucous roar of sea lions can be heard over the pounding of the surf. Here the flippery family make their home, scrambling on finny arms up and down the rocks and sliding into the white foaming waters. And here came the Canadian Government ship Givenchy in the Summer just past to count sea lions and control their numbers.

FURTHER advances in the safety and reliability of flight may be expected from developments successfully carried on by Captain C.J. Crane of the Air Corps in cooperation with the Sperry Gyroscope Company to connect the gyropilot with the radio compass.

Long years after Tonopah had flourished as a mining town it became a mecca for outlaws. Blaze Tremaine made it his headquarters and gathered about him a wild crew of lawless scavengers that scourged the State. But Tremaine was a cautious leader and confined his depredations mostly to stealing cattle.

Rising retail prices and a stronger demand for better-grade merchandise are forcing a rise in the size of the average retail sale, department store executives reported here yesterday. The gain is slow and thus far this Fall has not exceeded 5 per cent or so, according to estimates, following a practically stationary or slightly smaller unit sale during the first six months of this year.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 19. -- Scoring a touchdown in every period, Alabama defeated Tennessee, 25 to 0, at football today before a homecoming crowd of 25,000.

For entertaining the farmers with ballads singing "the downfall of the Soviet Union," and for other acts of counter-revolution, Titschenko Tishkovetz Golub and Zlotnik Zlotnitsky were sentenced to death last week in Kiev Regional Court. Twenty-two members of their minstrel band received prison sentences.

CANTON, Oct. 19. -- Although convinced that the Southern Chinese provinces have been selected as the next field for Japanese attempts at economic, political and probably military penetration, Cantonese leaders do not despair. Instead they profess a virile determination to resist, although the present policy of Nanking seems to be to continue conciliation, and despite the preoccupation of the rest of the world with events in Africa and Europe.

Colonial and later American furniture, decorative objects of New England and Pennsylvania origin ranging from the turn of the eighteenth to the early nineteenth century, early American silver, including examples of the work of Paul Revere Sr. and Jr., and William Cowell, will compose the second part of the collection formed by Hyman Kaufman of Boston, to be sold at auction Friday and Saturday afternoons at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The Mediterranean situation as between Britain and Italy had developed beyond the naval stage to land preparations by Britain to meet the challenge of troops that Premier Mussolini has poured into Libya, which borders on Egypt.

LOGICIANS, if they wish to preserve their tempers, should avoid this book, for Mr. Hitchcock thumbs his nose at all their cherished laws. His short stories are, quite simply, mad. Written with an airy casualness, with a studied naivete as of one addressing small children, they have a faint flavor of early Benchley plus a fine irrationality all their own.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- While his fiancee was dressing in her wedding gown, Frederick Wiegman, 25 years old, hurried from her home in South Philadelphia today on a last-minute errand, and was injured fatally in an automobile accident.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Single mortgages not exceeding $16,000 insured by the Federal Housing Administrator as well as trust instruments covering such single mortgages were exempted today from registration by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the authority with which the commission is endowed to grant such exemption to issues offered in amounts not in excess of $100,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- The smooth-functioning Curtis High football machine eliminated another obstacle in its path toward an unbeaten and untied season by running roughshod over White Plains, 1934 Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association champion, today.
PARIS, Oct. 19. -- Senatorial elections will be held tomorrow in thirty-two departments of France, and 107 Senators will be elected or re-elected.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Senator Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware termed President Roosevelt's administration "the era of deception" today and said there was danger it would become "the debacle" of 1933-41 unless ended in 1937.

THE mysterious fading on high frequencies which has been the cause of annoyance to short-wave listeners during the past six months has assumed such proportions that Dr. J.H. Dellinger, in charge of the radio laboratories of the United States Bureau of Standards in Washington, has asked the broadcasters and listeners throughout the United States to report any unusual fading or atmospheric inconsistencies.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Italian sources were advised today that the Ethiopians south of the area now held by the Italian expeditionary force are preparing actively for a counter-offensive.

Riding by Wild Plum Creek School late in the afternoon, young Bob Hall took a look inside and saw the pretty new teacher tied in a chair on the rostrum and two ugly bums threatening to torture her to obtain a map of Aspen Canyon. Bob gave the curs the worst thrashing they ever had, rescued the girl -- and lost his heart to her on the spot.

MR. SACKLER has seized for his novel a very difficult theme, and on the whole he has done a skillful job. He has generously helped himself to real characters out of real history -- not unmixed with concomitant legend -- and woven them into a novel which, oddly enough, considering the circumstances, does not suffer too much either as history or as fic-

It is to be regretted that Mr. Margolies, writing of The New Film Alliance, Inc., in THE TIMES of Sunday, Sept. 29, did not approach the subject with a more open mind. If he had, his commentaries would have been far more constructive and helpful, as, perhaps, they were intended to be.

A new venture in club activities be the conference on Tuesday at the Bethpage Country Club at Farmingdale when delegates from about sixty Nassau County clubs will be present. The event is sponsored jointly by the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs and the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs, participating organizations being affiliated with one or both.

NOTWITHSTANDING all the books about bees with which libraries are already densely populated, room and a welcome await this new one by Julie Closson Kenly because it is written with dramatic feeling, with a fresh viewpoint that much increases the inherent interest of the story.
An article in THE TIMES Magazine, "How Old Is Old?" touched my funny-bone. I plead guilty. I do not know.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 19. -- The increasing number of students eager to enjoy music from the platform instead of from the audience has given Wellesley College the largest choir in its history. Rigorous elimination tryouts, under the direction of the conductor, Edward B. Greene of Passaic, N.J., could only reduce the number of applicants to 188, an increase of sixty-five over last year's membership.
Mussolini's spell over the Italian people has been broken by recent events, declares M.E. Ravage in an article captioned "Italy Doubts Mussolini," in November Current History.

CHEMNITZ, Saxony, Oct. 19. -- Professor Leffler, high functionary of the racial-political bureau of the National Socialist party, publishes a statement today to the effect that any assertion that the racial character of the recipient of alien blood through transfusion can be changed by transfusion is sheer nonsense.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- When President Roosevelt and Secretary Wallace told the country in recent public addresses that benefit payments under the Agricultural Adjustment Act would be continued, regardless of the Supreme Court's decision as to legality of processing taxes, they were outlining a practical political situation as well as stating an administration intention.

VIENNA, Oct. 19. -- A decision of greatest importance to all foreign newspapers represented in Austria was handed down today when Ladislaus Benes, editor of the American-European Press Service, was sentenced to five days' imprisonment and was ordered expelled from the country for "publishing alarming and untrue rumors calculated to damage the Austrian State."

The Cunningham syndicate's twelve-meter Cantitoe, S.C. Pirie's thirty-footer, Oriole, I.O. Griffiths's' interclub Kenboy and Ted Clark's Victory Reveille were among the winners of championships in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound's series, according to final standings announced yesterday by Secretary Briggs S. Cunningham.

IF the man who wrote "Sandford and Merton" could have known, as he finished that famous book, that almost a century and a half later men and women would be interested in his life, personality and ideas and would be still reading about them, he might, for the fraction of a second, have been surprised, even startled.

BLACK EARTH" is a pretty rough, tough story of the Alabama coal mining country. It is nothing like as good a tale as Rowan's first novel, "Stormy Road," which last year gave us a moving picture of the Alabama hill people.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17. -- Andrew W. Mellon's dream of years for the establishment in Washington of a national art gallery was disclosed in completed outline here this week. Its total cost or value in gifts from the retired Pittsburgh banker and former Secretary of the Treasury is estimated up to $50,000,000.

To a book published this year, "The Foreign Policy of the Powers," the Italian Ambassador in London, DINO GRANDI, contributed a chapter. In a footnote he referred to the attempted seizure of the Island of Corfu by MUSSOLINI in 1923, and said that this should have been "a warning gun" to Europe.

From the high priests of the political tribes, from the Fletchers and the Farleys, come day after day predictions of the utmost certainty about the results of the Fall elections of 1936. Wonderful achievements of the Administration are catalogued by distinguished Democratic politicians.

TOKYO. -- Disappointment with the economic results of Japanese policy in Manchukuo is expressed in Chugai Shogyo (Home and Foreign Commerce), the leading financial daily of Tokyo. Investments have failed to give satisfactory results, says this journal, and Japanese financial and industrial leaders are unwilling to find more capital at present.
