New York University's varsity football forces put on another air raid yesterday, this time to the dismay of the Pennsylvania Military College eleven. The Chester cadets, like Bates and Carnegie Tech before them, came to the Yankee Stadium inadequately equipped to spike the Violet hurling ace, Full-back Ed Smith.

WITHIN a few months, it is anticipated, passengers will be crossing the Pacific Ocean in airplanes. The skyway is about ready. Stations have been established at Honolulu, Midway Islands, Wake Island and Guam.

MADRID, Oct. 19. -- Discussion of the administrative scandal alleged in the denunciation by Daniel Straus, a Mexican citizen, who admits he tried to obtain a gambling concession at the San Sebastian Casino by bribery, today took precedence in Spain over the international situation and all internal problems.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 19. -- Six points of attack against legalized liquor were urged by Mrs. Ida B. Wise Smith, president of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union, in a statement today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- A serious battle for control of the strong Republican organization of the county seat of Westchester was started Thursday when The White Plains Daily Reporter, a Republican newspaper, endorsed two Democratic city candidates in a front-page editorial. Observers believe the fight will be both bitter and long.

Gases backing up through an underground conduit in front of the Long Island Waste Paper Company's warehouse at 44-21 Tenth Street, Long Island City, at 7:30 o'clock last night were believed responsible for an explosion that injured one fireman seriously and six others slightly.
Pedestrians who cross streets against the traffic lights or in the middle of blocks are to be curbed by the police as a part of the city's anti-noise campaign, it was announced yesterday.

SOMETHING of a setback was suffered by trade in the week. The chief blame was laid upon warm weather, although there are increased reports of consumer resistance to higher prices. Information on the week's retail sales disclosed very spotty results.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- With the prevention of disease as the major objective, Red Cross public health nurses took care of 214,444 cases, involving 156,003 individual visits, in 1934, Admiral Cary T. Grayson said in his annual report to the society today.

A statistical defense of the Federal parole system is contributed by Sanford Bates, director of the Federal bureau of prisons, to the 1935 Year Book of the National Probation Association, 50 West Fiftieth Street.

Repercussions of the war in Africa are making themselves felt in Asia. Mussolini has immobilized the Western powers between the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean, thus conferring on Japan a free hand in the Far East. The mounting number of "incidents" in the Far East in the last few weeks is indication that Japan is aware of the opportunity and may be making ready to use it.

CLEMENCE DANE, whose versatility is a matter for marvel, has ventured on a romantic holiday in this new book of short stories. There are nine tales in "Fate Cries Out," and only one of them has the slightest connection with contemporary reality. Waving such drab stuff aside, Miss Dane has devoted herself mostly

Magistrate Michael A. Ford in Washington Heights Court yesterday postponed until next Tuesday the hearing of nine members of the American Newspaper Guild who were arrested Friday on charges of disorderly conduct while picketing in front of the plant of The Amsterdam News, Negro weekly, at 2,293 Seventh Avenue.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- After a prolonged lapse of news from Ethiopia that could be treated as a trustworthy basis for a military analysis, a trickle has at last filtered through. While it suggests there has been little actual change in the situation since the fortnight-old capture of Adowa, it foreshadows certain lines of development.

Five outstanding speakers will contribute to a symposium on Friday afternoon on the opening program of the Westchester Federation of Women's Clubs at the Contemporary Club of White Plains. Mrs. Kenneth Norton, president, will direct the activities, including a business session in the morning and the addresses during the afternoon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- Sharply lower prices of wheat abroad and press reports indicating a much less strained political situation in Europe brought in general selling of wheat futures at the opening of the Chicago Board of Trade today and disclosed a lack of aggressive support.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 19. -- While a large Ethiopian army is rapidly assembling to resist the Italians -- Emperor Haile Selassie reviewed 10,000 or more Gofa warriors this morning -- the Ethiopian general staff believes it has successfully carried out the first phase of its strategy.

The scrapping of the White Star liner Olympic has caused considerable comment in this city. She was regarded by P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine, and other ship owners as one of the finest ships afloat. She has a double skin throughout and is the last hand-riveted liner in the North Atlantic trade.

A PARTICULARLY benignant star must have presided over the birth hour of Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of the President, in such generous measure have the good and pleasant things of life been poured into her lap.

There are so many characters and so much plot in "New Ground" that it wants careful reading. And this, most of the time, hardly seems worth while. Anne Audinrid, a poor little rich girl who lives in a rococo palace in Sutton Place, is the centre of all the turmoil.

The conference that has been going on here for about a week among leading executives of United States and European oil companies in connection with the possibility of controlling the oil supplies available for the various European countries is considered by those following the discussions to be the most important meeting in the history of the oil industry.

The surrender of the Holy City of Aksum, in Ethiopia, recalled the tradition that this city was the home of Macheda, the Queen of Sheba. The legend persists it was to Aksum that she returned after the historic visit to Solomon, as twice described in the Old Testament.

THE sound of a phonograph needle, skipping with a screech across the grooves of a revolving disk, ended with a thud across 8,000 miles from Johannesburg, South Africa. The announcer apologized for the "minor accident" that marred the music, which otherwise was exceptionally clear.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 19. -- King Ranch's 2-year-old black filly Split Second took the lead in the back stretch of the $10,000 added Selima Stakes today and won by a four-length margin in the mile feature.

OMAHA, Oct. 17. -- When Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas came through as the one conspicuous Republican survivor of the election of 1934 political observers in his neighborhood began to take note of him. "Keep your eyes on Landon," they said.

Domestic troubles and foreign uncertainties continue to prey upon the peace of Austria. Last Thursday the government was reshuffled in such a way as to strengthen the pro-Italian orientation and to eliminate the leader of the faction supposed to be ready for a compromise with the German Reich.

DAME LAURA KNIGHT of England and Otto Dix of Germany have sent to the just opened 1935 Carnegie International at Pittsburgh paintings that in about every respect I can think of appear to be poles asunder.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19. -Sixty-eight students are included in the roster of the Princeton University choir, as announced here today by Francis Pangrac, acting choirmaster and vocal soloist of New York City.

Whether or not county government should endure in its present form is a question now pressing for an answer. In Chicago recently it was discussed in detail by the American County Association, composed of county officials from all parts of the United States.

This is the story of a girl who was so generous and sweet-natured that her friends were always imposing upon her. Caroline was beautiful and blond, but the man she was in love with regarded her as just a good companion because she never condescended to use the wiles of women on him.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Yale's remarkable football team came through the hardest sort of fight today to score a 1-point victory over Navy, 7 to 6. In figures, that is the story of the game. But there was far more to this sunlit spectacle that drew the biggest crowd in four years to the huge Yale sport centre.

Some 800,000 children are included in the 550,000 families dependent upon unemployment relief in New York State, it was disclosed by Frederick I. Daniels, who succeeded Alfred H. Schoellkopf as State Temporary Emergency Relief Administrator, in an address broadcast last evening over WEAF.

MR. LUCAS has finished his tremendous undertaking with the appearance of having enjoyed every moment of it. It is a pleasure only second to the reading of the letters to follow his scrupulous notes and to read between the lines his loving regard for every word Lamb put on a friendly paper.

WITH a personnel of ninety-one players and with Karl Krueger again the conductor, the Kansas City Philharmonic will given ten pairs of subscription concerts on Thursday and Friday evenings in the new season, beginning on Nov. 21 and 22 and closing on April 2 and 3.

MOST of this book was written by Mr. Bridges, who accompanied the holiday jaunt to Trinidad and British Guiana as a representative of The New York Sun. The introductory pages and a concluding chapter are all that Dr. Dittmars supplied.

In churches of every faith pastors will preach today anti-war sermons and prayers will be offered that the Italo-Ethiopian conflict will be speedily settled. Pleas will be made that America stay out of the trouble. In Episcopal churches peace prayers will be included in the the regular ritual according to the request of the Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop.

THE TIMES reports that the League of Nations Committee on Economic sanctions has tentatively agreed to cut off all shipments to Italy of specified raw materials used for war, and that two categories of such raw materials have been developed. The first contains the materials produced almost exclusively by the States represented on the committee; the second includes items obtainable mainly from the United States and Germany.

Fifteen thousand poor, crippled or orphaned children from the metropolitan area left their cares behind them yesterday to attend a special free performance of the Tenth Annual World Series Rodeo at Madison Square Garden. The treat was made possible by Colonel John R. Kilpatrick, director of the Garden, and Edwin M. Hydeman of 145 Central Park West, who distributed the tickets among 200 institutions and provided transportation where necessary.
Four persons were temporarily blinded yesterday at 3:20 P.M., when a gas bomb was set off in the Star Burlesque Theatre, 389 Jay Street, near Fulton Street, Brooklyn.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- The Bronxville Field Club will be the scene on Thursday night of a barn dance, preceded by a dinner. There will he a special entertainment.

TO those who delight in the society pages of newspapers this one-day fictional history of a fashionable London wedding, with its kaleidoscopic pictures of the principals, the members of their families and the more important guests, should prove entirely acceptable.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP). -- The delayed advance of Italian troops in Ethiopia is purely psychological and is intended to show the natives Premier Mussolini is unwilling to kill unless necessary, General Ezio Garibaldi said today.

Women interested in the work of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's mission in Labrador have arranged a card party and sale of Labrador handicraft for Tuesday afternoon at the Barbizon. The useful articles were made by women and disabled fishermen along the bleak coasts of Newfoundland and Labrador.

THERE is, it seems, more than one kind of African adventure. There is the kind that goes on as a preface to imperialism, or as imperialism itself, and there is the kind that Mrs. Wharton's "dear Vivienne" had and which she has described under a beautiful title from the book of Job.

BELFAST, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press). -- On a rain-sodden pitch and in a driving windstorm England today won its opening encounter in the international soccer series, defeating Ireland 3 -- 1 before a crowd of 40,000 spectators.

For the first time in the four-year history of the George H. Townsend Medal a young professional driver, Fred Jacoby Jr. of North Bergen, N.J., has won the country's highest ranking in outboard motor boat racing, according to the tabulation announced yesterday by George W. Sutton Jr., president and statistician of the American Power Boat Association.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 19. -- From the eroded wastes of San Juan Basin in New Mexico, the Rev. Dr. T. Emmett Reynolds, the "desert priest," has dug four skulls which he believes are remains of the earliest form of mammal so far discovered by scientists.

BOISE, Oct. 19. -- Here, in his home cowtown, Senator Borah is cooking up poison broth alike for the New Deal and the Old Guard in the Republican party while he ponders the supreme personal problem that a perverse destiny has reserved for this twilight time in his political career.

INTRIGUED by the success of an interesting experiment, the cinema may look to the stage as an experimental laboratory in which plays and jests are tested before being immortalized in celluloid. For years D.A. Doran, Broadway producer, has argued with studios over the wisdom of trying out plays in New York, ironing out their, bumps, building their weak portions and, through trial and error, creating a photoplay correct in every phase of structure.

Champion Milson O'Boy, Mrs. Cheever Porter's chestnut red Irish setter, was named best in show again as the twenty-first annual Bronx County Kennel Club exhibition ended last night at the 105th Field Artillery Armory. A record number of 564 dogs was benched for this highly interesting one-day program.

Adults who have observed the younger children gazing wistfully at "Smoky" will gladly welcome this volume, which has all the interest and authenticity of the longer books by Will James and which is, at the same time, simple enough for 9-year-olds to read to themselves.
WARSAW, Oct. 18. -- The Cabinet of Premier Marjan Koscialkowski is the fifteenth since the Pilsudski regime was established in Poland on May 19, 1926.

Cooperation between piece goods buyers and manufacturers in presenting the newest developments in fabrics and patterns was suggested as necessary to animate sales in piece goods departments at this time by T.L. Blanke, manager of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Although welcomed as phrenetically as a Roman Emperor at a triumph, Paul Robeson, the celebrated Negro baritone, did himself a great injustice in attempting to give his recital at the Town Hall last night. For he was obviously incapacitated by a severe cold, which he bravely but never successfully fought against from the start.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Supreme Court of the United States is again preparing to survey the constitutionality of the New Deal.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 16 (delayed) (AP). -- Although scoffing at reports of Ethiopian scouting flights, strict precautions are being taken in Asmara against air raids. Street lights are extinguished every night.

SELFRIDGE FIELD, Mich., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Captain Karl E. Gimmler of Milwaukee, driving his tiny pursuit plane perilously close to the pylons in a gusty wind, defeated nine other top-flight army pilots today to win the Mitchell Trophy race before a cheering crowd of 60,000 spectators.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 19. -- Hitting a fast pace in the second period and maintaining it until the end Exeter today recorded a 12-to-0 victory over Tilton School in the first football contest ever played between the two New Hampshire prep schools.

MINEAPOLIS, Oct. 19. -- Tulane's Green Wave was only a ripple today as Minnesota's powerful dreadnaught sank the boys from New Orleans under a score of 20 to 0. A crowd of 35,000 witnessed the intersectional gridiron battle, in which only the generous use of reserves by Coach Bernie Bierman prevented a greater score.

Reports of resistance to price advances are receiving more attention. At first confined to objections to higher meat prices, the reaction against increases was said last week to be spreading to a number of staple items of merchandise. In the wholesale markets, it was added, there has been some resistance by buyers against shirt price increases, with manufacturers reported as unable to get advances on finished merchandise commensurate with the rise in shirtings and denims.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Rutgers University alumni from all parts of the East are expected at the annual homecoming-day celebration on Saturday, Oct. 26, the program for which was announced today by Ernest E. McMahon, alumni secretary.

To a generation of theatregoers Maude Adams, as Peter Pan, Juliet, L'Aiglon, Lady Babbie in "Little Minister" and the woman in "What Every Woman Knows," was unsurpassed. She was first carried on the stage in child parts by her mother; she retired in 1918. Once, in 1931, she returned to the footlights to re-create Shakespeare's Portia, but that production of "The Merchant of Venice" did not reach New York from the road.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Governor Earle's appeal to "all decent Philadelphians" to help "destroy the stone wall" of the Republican machine in this State by electing John B. Kelly, Democrat, as Mayor next month has been greeted with mixed emotions.

ALTAMONTE SPRINGS, Fla., Oct. 18. -- Differences of opinion are responsible for an unusual situation in Florida, where engineering forces recently began construction of the proposed Gulf-Atlantic sea-level ship canal.

HIGH on the Allegheny Plateau in Warren County, Northwestern Pennsylvania, are a few thousand acres of the forest primeval -- as it was before the white man came with fire and ax. There in the wild Tionesta area are hemlock trees, 500 or 600 years old, among the stands now being acquired for the Allegheny National Forest.

Hundreds of members of women's college groups in New Jersey will answer the roll-call this week armed with notebooks and pencils for their study courses and brimful of new ideas for swelling their scholarship and fellowship funds.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Riding windward rails in a puffy northwest wind, yachtsmen from all along the coast opened the Winter sailing dinghy racing season today at the Thames Yacht Club, where the national championships were held last Spring.

GENEVA, Oct. 18. -- Will the experiment in the new kind of law-enforcing machinery that mankind is beginning here succeed? Will sanctions work? More particularly, will non-military sanctions stop a war?

THE publishers of this book call Martin Johnson "Adventurer Extraordinary." By the medium of motion and sound pictures he has made the wild life of Africa familiar to audiences all over the world. His wife Osa shares his distinction.

MAYSIE GREIG is a sympathetic purveyor of romance to the working girl in fiction. In her latest novel, pretty, dark Cara Rini works as model and shop assistant in hats. Her millinery ambitions aim at a hat shop of her own in Bond Street.

William Dillon, 27 years old, of 28 West Eighty-eighth Street, Manhattan, became so excited during the final quarter of the Manhattan-Holy Cross football game at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon that he jumped out of a lower box in the left field stands into the field, fourteen feet below, suffering a broken right leg, cuts on the lips and nose and the loss of two teeth.

MRS. RAWSON will be happily remembered by many readers who found pleasure and information in her previous books -- "Country Auction," "Sing, Old House!" "From Here to Yender," and others -- wherein with fondly dwelling interest she told of the things she had learned by much and careful inquiry into the habitations, customs, travels, vehicles and other trappings of the long-ago past.

SINCE the opening of "Porgy and Bess" I have been asked frequently why it is called a folk opera. The explanation is a simple one. "Porgy and Bess" is a folk tale. Its people naturally would sing folk music. When first began work on the music I decided against the use of original folk material because I wanted the music to be all of one piece.

Veterans of Cantigny, Soissons, Meuse-Argonne and Montdidier-Noyon joined yesterday with regular army soldiers who were only small boys when the "vets" were fighting in France in '17 and '18, to honor their outfit, the First Division. The occasion was the First Division's "home-coming day" at Fort Hamilton.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19. -- Talks by Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education in Teachers College at Columbia University, and Dr. Philip W.L. Cox, Professor of Education in the School of Education, New York University, were features of the sessions of the Bucknell University tenth annual Conference on Education, which closed today.

A 70-year-old woman, who made her living by selling her own homemade preserves and Christmas cards to neighbors, was murdered late yesterday by a mysterious intruder who entered her flat on the ground floor of 231 East Fiftieth Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

SYDNEY, Australia. THE government of New South Wales has recently approved the widespread use of shark nets to guard unwary bathers on the State's many beaches, but at Port Stephens sharks are regarded in a different light.

ROME, Oct. 19. -- A feeling of optimism continues to reign in Rome but it is more subdued than the outburst of joyful anticipation that greeted yesterday's announcement of the resumption of direct contacts between Premier Benito Mussolini and Sir Eric Drummond, the British Ambassador.

IMMEDIATE construction in a Brooklyn park of the first large museum building in the world especially designed for children's use is being urged by New York City upon Works Progress Administration officials in Washington. Plans for a two-story structure in modern style, with exhibition halls, children's "project rooms," library, roof playground and an auditorium seating 1,000, have been approved by the Municipal Art Commission and the Park Department.

IN youth, most people confidently expect that their own lives will prove exceptional; in middle age, they recognize the fact that fame and fortune and high adventure are not for them, recognize it perhaps with bitterness and rebellion, perhaps with that tranquility which was finally achieved by the heroine of Barbara B. Stevens's first novel, "Walk Humbly."

An Oriental pearl necklace belonging to the late Mary Strong Shattuck, daughter of former Mayor William L. Strong, brought $10,500 at auction yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. Her collection of French furniture, silver, porcelain, tapestries and other objects in the three days of sale netted $84,687.

The various contacts which I have had with representative business and industrial leaders in recent months have convinced me that there is an earnest desire the continue the fundamental principles involved in the National Industrial Recovery Act.

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Pushing over two touchdowns late in the fourth quarter, Loomis School's hard-fighting eleven downed a plucky Berkshire School team on Loomis Field today in their fifteenth annual battle. The score was 13 to 0.

AFILTRABLE virus consists of germs which are too small to be seen in a microscope -- so small in fact that they can pass through the finest porcelain filter. That influenza is caused by such a virus there can be no doubt after the work done at the Rockefeller Institute by Drs. Thomas Francis Jr. and Thomas P. Magill.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Penn's frustrated football forces, twice kept from victories by last-half letdowns, unleashed the full fury of their pent-up power on hapless Columbia today in subjecting the Lions to their most crushing defeat in half a decade.

So many new things are being crowded into our lives -- new inventions and discoveries, new ideas and sensations -- that it is obvious a great deal of what most of us have valued highly in the past will soon have to be thrown overboard in these moving times.

A WALK in Athens while shadows creep from behind Mount Hymettus, cautiously climb the Acropolis and then plunge headlong into Salamis Bay, starts a train of thought concerning the perennial problems of Greece.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press). -- With a narrow 1-0 decision over Grimsby Town, Huddersfield retained leadership of the English Soccer League today. The Yorkshire Club, however, failed to widen its margin over its closest rivals. Sunderland and Derby County both won, the Roker Park outfit scoring by 4 -- 3 at Wolverhampton while Derby County tallied the only goal of the match against Blackburn Rovers.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19. -- Paced by the brilliant all-around playing of Dave Smukler, Pop Warner's Temple University Owls defeated Carnegie Tech, 13 to 0, at Pitt Stadium today.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 19. -- Utilizing a brilliant passing attack, the Hill School football team conquered the Yale second freshmen, 14 -- 0, on Dell Field today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- Retail trade continued to hold a fairly good gain over the like period of 1934, although sales of coats and other heavy apparel were affected by warm weather, the temperature during the week running as high as 80 degrees.

TESTIMONIAL: To a luncheon at the Hotel Astor last week went 2,000 representatives of 300 trade organizations and 100,000 business houses in the city to honor one of their champions. Grover A. Whalen. "Who's Who" describes Mr. Whalen as a "merchant": his mercantile and trade connections number a score or so.

THIS story, by the author of "Dawn After Danger," of the struggle of a daughter of the pre-war era to find the life which eludes her is singularly inconclusive, whether intentionally or not it is hard to judge. In its outline it is definite enough.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Senator Borah has added to Republican complications by renewing his attack on Old Guard Republican leadership and demanding that the party make "trust busting" a chief issue in 1936. He defined his views in a letter last week to Colonel The odore Roosevelt.
Income statements of subsidiaries of the National Power and Light Company for September and twelve months follow:

At the Albany Crime Conference, Judge Alfred J. Talley challenged American parenthood by stressing the view that crime-prevention is a matter of influencing the souls of individuals. The parents, he indicated, are the real educators; their chief duty is the soul-enlarging, character-shaping and mind-enriching of their children during the wonderful habit-forming years between birth and the age of 7 or 8.

ANY lingering doubts that the art season in New York was to be an active one might well have been dispelled last week when more than thirty exhibitions opened in local galleries. Group and one-man shows, water- colors and sculpture. American and foreign artists, antiques and the work of fledglings, old masters and color reproductions were all available for the visitor.

IT is sixty years since the Victorians on both sides of the sea acclaimed the musical comedies which were produced by D'Oyly Carte at the Savoy Theatre in London. Today the Savoyards of the second and third generation are legion, and this is a book that offers them a rare treat.

With Harry Newman, who came out of retirement last week, In their starting line-up, the football Giants will take the field this afternoon at the Polo Grounds to battle the Boston Redskins. The return of the former all-American quarterback from Michigan came about as a result of the injury suffered by Dale Burnett in the Brooklyn game last Sunday.

The Sugarplum Family live in a doll's house, and a very engaging one it is. So closely, however, do the experiences of Mr. and Mrs. Sugarplum and their three children parallel the doings of everyday people that 5, 6 and 7-year-olds will hardly stop to think whether they are reading about toys or real characters.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 19. -- War Minister Ras Mulougheta's forces have been dispatched on different routes and in small parties, which will make the march to Dessye slow. Representatives of the Ethiopian Press Bureau will leave here next week to prepare a radio office for the Emperor's visit to Dessye.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 19. -- A five-point program favoring legislation to prohibit liquor in the District of Columbia and liquor advertisements in press, magazine or radio programs was adopted today by 500 delegates to the sixty-first annual State convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union.

Warm weather hampered the expansion of Fall retail trade in the metropolitan area last week. Increases over a year ago were smaller than in recent weeks and were not general among the leading department stores although several were credited with gains ranging from 5 to 8 per cent.

Business conditions were spotty in most sections of the country last week, with the rising level of retail distributive totals being checked to some extent by the mild weather, according to reports from the various Federal Reserve districts. With few exceptions, retail sales were under those of the previous week, although the survey shows the volume of purchasing ahead of last year in most sections.

Ann Frances, the most recent addition to that long line of delightful and very much alive little girls for whom Eliza Orne White is responsible, comes nearest in age to the heroine of Miss White's first story, "When Molly Was Six," published many years ago.

Here is a little book that is fresh and original. The fifty poems and nursery jingles, which remind us of our own Mother Goose, have been chosen and well translated from the folk rhymes of eighteen different countries. They have the music of rhyme and rhythm so important in verses for young children, they have also the dramatic quality and humor that give folk rhymes their universal appeal.

THUS sang the Mock Turtle in Lewis Carroll's verse. And now that Autumn is here, the song has a special timeliness. Even in Summer soup is an important part of the well-rounded meal; in cold weather, when one needs to fortify one's self against chill winds, it is an essential.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19. -- That Moscow is not going to permit the most recent Soviet-Manchurian border dispute to grow cold in Tokyo's Foreign Office is evidenced by a communique issued by the Soviet Foreign Office at 11:30 o'clock tonight.

Leading American film producers are protesting the French Government's proposed decree to restrict the showing of Hollywood-made motion pictures in France and assume control of film rentals. Although spokesmen for American film interests are inclined to discount reports from Paris that the decree will be passed, they admit its enactment would be a severe blow to the industry here.

A plan to provide 300 additional policemen for the city parks by having them drawn from the Police Department eligible civil list, and paid at the rate of $1,650 a year each by the Park Department, has been proposed to Commissioner Valentine and Mayor La Guardia, it was learned at police headquarters yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Bitter personal animosities engendered by the rivalry between industrial and craft unionists broke out on the floor of the American Federation of Labor Convention today, resulting in a fist fight between John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and William S. Hutcheson, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America.

An appeal to teachers to adapt to themselves the role of "substitute parent" in an effort to offset and possibly correct the mental, physical and spiritual damage caused by the home life of some children was made yesterday by Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, assistant director of the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education.

Like a spinning top that is dying down, the earth wabbles on its axis. A single wabble -- " gyration" in more seemly terminology -- is completed in 25,700 years. In this "Great Year," as it is sometimes called, Mr. H.P. GILLETTE, a former assistant engineer of the State of New York, discovers thirteen weather cycles.

A window cleaners' strike last week drew New York's excavation-watchers from the better 'oles for a bit of skygazing. Idly they began to wonder what a pane-swabber thinks about. An inquiry made for them revealed that wool-gathering is not for the man they see at work high against the sky-line with chamois and squeegee.

Prominent women of Bronxville are working toward the success of an annual exhibition and sale of handicraft made by refugee women of the Near East, to be held next Friday at the home of Mrs. Howard M. Erskine, 11 Fordal Road. The objects for sale will include a variety of useful and unusual articles, as well as a collection of antique hand-woven silver jewelry from Damascus.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19. -- Port operations here moved along at a fast pace this week, barring a few minor labor disputes, as every registered gang of longshoremen was reported assigned, and waterfront employers said that on certain days every ship in the harbor was being worked by more than 3,000 longshoremen.

Calling of bonds for redemption before their maturity was more active last week than in the preceding week. Redemptions of joint stock land bank bonds stood out in the announcements, which included also several large foreign and domestic issues.

Finishing with a burst of speed in the last fifty yards, Leonard Dauenbauer, national interscholastic champion from Syracuse Central High, scored a sensational triumph in a field of 350 runners in the thirteenth annual Manhattan College invitation cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday morning.

THERE have been many success stories in American history. The Lees of Virginia offer one of the more remarkable in that, starting with an obscure immigrant -- Richard Lee, who appeared in Virginia in 1640 -- they quickly developed an influence that for five generations the Old Dominion could not ignore.

Answering a call by the Communist party in Friday's issue of The Daily Worker, about 350 of its members paraded yesterday to Pier 58, at the foot of Sixteenth Street and the North River, to make a demonstration against Mussolini and Fascism at the noon sailing of the Italian liner Rex for Naples.
With the Fall semester in full swing, the various publication activities of Hunter College ones more are completely staffed.

ACCORDING to this booklet a situation has developed in the Old South, growing out of the dominance of King Cotton, that is quite as bad economically, ethically, and in its results and influences upon both individuals and society as was the regime of slavery.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Caught in a rooming house here last night by local police on suspicion of burglary, Edward Covey, 21, alias McKeg, a former enlisted man in the army, and John C. Margulslis, 22, alias Macuirles and Mitchell, both of Amsterdam, N.Y., confessed today to several robberies and admitted a running gun fight with police in Northern New York State.

THE Commonwealth of Pennsylvania is contemplating the construction of an all-weather highway through the Blue Ridge and Alleghany Mountains by utilizing nine tunnels which were dug for the old South Penn Railroad between 1883 and 1885, during the last great railroad war waged by William H. Vanderbilt.

CHANGED in appearance but without material engine alterations, the 1936 Fords are presented in thirteen body styles, including standard and de luxe models. It was put on display in dealers' showrooms yesterday.

For the interest which the theatre- going public has displayed in REINHARDT'S production of Midsummer- Night's Dream on the moving-picture screen, one reason doubtless was the knowledge that for the forest background, against which most of the action of the play occurs, the screen has advantages which the legitimate stage cannot attain.

Reports of ill-treatment of enlisted personnel in the United States Army's Panama Department and of alleged malfeasance by army officers there were branded as "entirely incorrect" by Colonel James V. Heidt, until recently commander of Fort Clayton in the Canal Zone, in an interview yesterday at Fort Hamilton, where he is spending a short leave of absence.

HONOLULU, Oct. 19. -- Representative Ernest Lundeen, Minnesota Farmer Laborite and a member of the House subcommittee on Territories, which concluded on Friday its inquiry into the fitness of Hawaii to become a State, indicated today that he felt conditions here warranted such a step.

GIBRALTAR. -- While outwardly the town and dockyards at the base of this famous rock are calm and peaceful, there is nothing but dust and hustle beneath the surface, especially in regard to the navy, the officers of which believe that war is certain.

ALTHOUGH the Metropolitan Opera is maintaining silence on questions of repertoire, it is rumored that the opening night opera has been chosen and that it will be "Traviata." Nothing very unusual, but opening nights do not call for exceptional presentations.

A successful end run by Mikulka following Wasserman's touchdown for the extra point in the final quarter gave the Stuyvesant High School eleven a victory as it topped the High School of Commerce team, 7 -- 6, yesterday at the Catholic Protectory Oval.

Salvage Shop, a subsidiary of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, opened officially about ten days ago in its new headquarters in the Federation Building, 69 West Forty-seventh Street, represents a unique venture in the reclamation of discarded articles and their sale for charitable purposes.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 19 (AP). -- An inspired Auburn line rose to great heights today to smash Kentucky's vaunted offense as fleet Plainsman backs scampered down the field to win, 23 to 0, and crush the hopes of the Wildcats in their bid for a Southeastern Conference title.

THE thin sheaf of verses held between the covers of this thin book presents to the reader something very delicate indeed. Also something as rare as it is precious -- the breath and delicate accent of true poetry.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin assured the Italian Government and people today with all the bluntness for which he is famous that hatred of fascism had nothing whatever to do with Great Britain's strong stand against Italy during the last few weeks.

WORRIED steamship men are trying to peer through the fog of political disturbances to make plans for their long Winter cruises. Although the waters of the Mediterranean, a tourist paradise with its numberless peaceful byways steeped in historical lore, are now troubled, most of the cruises originally scheduled for Winter remain on the calendar.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 19. -- Notre Dame's football team came from behind to smite down the Panthers of Pittsburgh, 9 to 6, before 51,000 spectators today. It was the largest crowd to watch a Notre Dame home game in the last four years.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 19. -- The sturdy, knickered figure of Gene Sarazen, the Connecticut farmer, faded out of the P.G.A. national tournament picture today before the steady play of Alvin (Butch) Krueger of Beloit, Wis. Krueger eliminated the tournament favorite, 2 and 1, in a thrilling 18-hole, second-round match.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Harvard's literary bi-monthly undergraduate publication, The Harvard Advocate, was banned from Cambridge news stands today after an anonymous letter had denounced two of its articles for "indecency" and "the smuttiest of vulgarity."

There is evidence of sharp division of opinion among the public utility officials whether the companies should recognize grudgingly the authority of the Securities Exchange Commission conferred by the Public Utility Act by complying with the early regulations, with express reservations as to their rights, or whether they should withhold recognition of any sort and thereby incur the maximum penalty of a severe fine, as well as the serious risk of the SEC's displeasure.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES AT ADOWA, Ethiopia, Monday, Oct., 14 (By Air Mail to Rome) (AP). -- The military strategy of Napoleon was summoned for the capture of Adowa, General Nino Viliasanta, commander of the Gavinana Division, said today.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- With the Republican Assembly caravan ending a trip of more than 1,400 miles tonight, Irving M. Ives, minority leader, speaking for all his colleagues, put forth a ten-point legislative program in a speech at the Broadway Theatre here.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17. -- When Governor Martin L. Davey last week issued a statement concerning football at Ohio State University he unloosed a flood of talk that ran mightily for three days, and then subsided quickly.

LIKE all people who are overtaken by legend, Katherine Anne Porter has a hard test to meet. "Flowering Judas" was originally published in 1930 in a small limited edition. It won immediately extravagant praise, but comparatively few readers had access to it and it has since become a collector's item.

Democracy, the individualist, is fighting today for her very life, not against the autocracy of kings but to preserve herself from strangulation by collectivism -- an enemy variously disguised by bolshevism, fascism, or racism.

In the opening pages of "Thirteen Sailed Home" the reader finds the four-masted barque Glorianne lying listless in the South Atlantic doldrums near the Line. Misfortune has followed her from Iquique, Chile, round the Horn (where three men were washed overboard) and up to just south of the Equator, where she has lain becalmed for twelve days.

OAKDALE, L.I., Oct. 19. -- St. John's Prep of Brooklyn attacked through the air to remove the La Salle Military Academy football team from the ranks of the unbeaten today, the Red and White winning by a 13-0 count.

The 113th annual meeting of the Synod of New Jersey of the Presbyterian Church will start tomorrow in Atlantic City, N.J., with an attendance of ministers and elders representing a membership of more than 175,000.

From the almost intolerable tension created in Europe by the events of the past week there has now come a welcome respite. Steps are being taken to assure Britain that Italian troops in Libya do not constitute a threat to Egypt and to assure Italy that she need not fear independent action by the British fleet in the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Assertions that the American Liberty League, through its committee of lawyers, has approached members of the judiciary in an effort to enlist them in its attack on the constitutionality of New Deal laws were made today by Charles Michelson, publicity director of the Democratic National Committee, who quoted from a reply to such a request sent by Justice Carew of the New York Supreme Court.

Believing "patriotism should be built up on a higher level," Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of Schools in charge of high schools, declared yesterday that the national anthem of the United States, "The Star-Spangled Banner," is "too militaristic to be sung by high school students."

Heavy week-end hedge selling from the South dominated the operation yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. The offerings were taken by a continued good trade demand on a scale-down, but prices lost the advances of Friday on most positions, the December closing at 10.83c a pound.

PROBABLY for some little time to come there will be those who deeply desire to say their say about "Pop" Hart. Like myself, they doubtless said much while he was living. Unlike myself, many of them have found his personality more interesting than his art.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 19. -- More than 12,000 persons turned out for the final day of the seventy-sixth annual Rose Tree Hunt Club meet today, Cedar Run, entry of Edward M. Cheston, just nosed out Lassitude II for the Media Plate in a six-furlong race.

Stores in this country can now learn a great deal from their contemporaries abroad, according to H. Gordon Selfridge, the merchandising pioneer who introduced the American department store in England and who, during the twenty- five years of the existence of Self-ridge Co., Ltd., in London has seen it grow into one of the largest establishments in the world.

THE Mississippi River now boasts a new bridge, which is one of the finest of the twenty-nine spanning the Father of Waters. Located a mile and a half above New Orleans, and named the "Huey P. Long Bridge," it extends 3,524 feet across the river and with its approaches is 4.4 miles long.

PARIS. DETAILS in all ages, though for different reasons, have been of supreme importance in composing the fashionable ensemble. In those early Nineteen Hundred days that have had such a strong influence on contemporary fashions, correct details were the sign of the "perfect lady."

FLOR 1936 Pontiac brings out three lines -- a straight Eight, a Six and a de luxe Six. A large number of improvements is said to be incorporated in the new cars, but there are no radical mechanical changes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17. -- This city's two magnificent new bridges spanning the bay and the Golden Gate have reached stages of completion that leave only the less spectacular parts of the work unfinished, and already give to bay region residents the full architectural effect of the great towers.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 19. -- Andy Kerr's record of never having lost two games in succession in seven years at Colgate was never in danger today as the Red Raiders swarmed over Lafayette to tally 52 points while holding the Maroons scoreless.

TEXTURE, pattern and color are the important features of floor coverings in the well-decorated room, as this season's displays of model interiors and the work of leading decorators attest. Significant in a revival of greater interest in floor effects is the more modest cost of artistic and serviceable products.

INVENTED, exploited and perfected by Americans, the film in America has made little esthetic progress and -- excepting Disney -- none since Griffith. It was Griffith who established the "flickers" as an industry and art, subsequently to be consumed by the mongrel he had created.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A tract of 500 acres of virgin timberland, part of a 15,000-acre plot situated in Graham County, N.C., and tentatively approved for purchase by the Forest Service, probably will be set aside as the Joyce Kilmer National Memorial Park.

The clang of iron rang out on Washington Heights yesterday afternoon as contestants from a wide area strove for the metropolitan horseshoe pitching championship, which was held on the courts of the Fort George Horseshoe Club, West 196th Street and Fort George Avenue.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- By winning its fourteenth straight victory, with a 13-to-6 triumph against Hobart this afternoon, Trinity was content tonight to concede the first invasion of its goal line this season.

COLLEGE education should be reserved exclusively for the intellectual elite among our youth, for those who are potential leaders, Dr. Bernard I. Bell argued on this page last week in a debate with Chancellor Chase of New York University.

The description of the fourth race at Rivermont Park is coming over the radio to the penthouse apartment of Professor Garden. The professor is not a follower of the gee-gees, but his son Floyd is, and so is his nephew Woody Swift, and both of them have bets on this race.

THE rich, active life of a woman is presented in the beautifully illustrated book which Werner Milch has brought out, "Sophie La Roche -- Die Grossmutter der Brentanos" (Societaetsverlag, Frankfurt - a. - M.).

Attorney General David Wilentz of New Jersey closed his case against Bruno Richard Hauptmann, who now awaits death in the electric chair at Trenton for the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., with a mass of expert evidence still unpresented.

In lieu of subtler qualities in its plot to keep the story moving, this adventure novel substitutes a medley of simple but crudely effective clashes between the fugitive hero and his Chekist pursuers, from whom he barely escapes alive. At the end, however, he proves himself sufficiently master of the situation to dictate the terms accepted by his adversaries.

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- Against determined opposition led by delegates from New Jersey, but with support behind the scenes from Governor Lehman, the Interstate Conference on Labor Compacts today called for adoption of the forty-hour-week by the States as "a practical possibility."

TONIGHT will bring to a close the third season of Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe in New York. Though as these lines are written several of its scheduled novelties, including "Choreartium," Massine's controversial "interpretation" of Brahms's Fourth symphony, have not been presented, it is safe to say that the present season has marked a distinct advance in several directions over those which have preceded it.

The James Monroe and Evander Childs High School football teams, both of which had been unbeaten, met yesterday at Monroe Field and when the important contest was over Evander had been dropped from the select circle. A crowd of 8,000, equally divided in support, saw the Crimson and Gold triumph by 9 -- 7, in a bitterly waged battle between Bronx rivals.

ROBERT HENDERSON has written an unusual and interesting book -- which happens to be a first novel -- about Donnie Trevett's senior year in college. It is full of the exuberance of youth, but for all that shows a fine sense of balance.

WHEN the shades of night begin their Winter specialty of failing fast, it well behooves the male involved in nocturnal divertissements of a social nature to appear in white tie and tails -- "full dress suit" to the Golden Nineties.

WHEN Mr. George Gershwin's "folk opera," "Porgy and Bess," after the play of the DuBose Heywards, was given its New York premiere, the critics had a high time, and Mr. Gershwin a double press. For critics of both drama and opera had a go at the piece.

The Italian Ministry of Communications announced yesterday through American representatives of the Italian Federation of Tourism that the country's military activities between the Mediterranean and East Africa had not impaired its merchant marine facilities in the least.

IN a rather tart foreword to this volume Katherine Fullerton Gerould defends the claims of Mr. Dobie as opposed to those of present-day fictional experimenters. Since the dawn of history, she says, man's main requirement of the story-teller has been plot -- embellished if possible with "blood-thirsty and amorous detail."
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 18. -- The political situation in Egypt is becoming aggravated and well-informed circles believe there is strong probability of political disturbances here.

Through the pages of "Wait for William" a circus parade rolls along with all the romance and magnificence that such a procession holds for youthful observers. In addition, a pleasant individual touch is supplied by William, the youngest of the three children whom we see starting so gayly down to Main Street, in the of Pleasantville, to see the circus parade.

WHEN Haile Selassie I. Negus Negasti of Ethiopia, mounted upon his royal mule and surrounded by thousands of his followers, not long ago descended the rugged slopes of Mount Entoto from the church which surmounts the mountain, whither he had gone at early dawn to pray for peace, he was met at the entrance of his palace with the ominous sound of the Ethiopian war drums within his Guibi.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 19. -- A radical change in the method of financing scholarship aid is under way at Vassar College. It aims to put scholarships on a pay-as-received basis rather than drawing upon current funds to aid needy students.

Last Summer at the Lewisohn Stadium, Lerey Anspach, a young Philadelphia pianist, slight in figure, appeared as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and created a favorable impression with his playing of the Liszt piano concerto in E flat.
The antiquity of English customs has often been commented on in the United States and perhaps your readers would be interested in the strange story of the Tichborne Dole.

The method of computing State aid for education was seen yesterday as the underlying factor in the "undue pressure" for school attendance which led to charges last week that children were punished for absences caused by illness.

The withdrawal of the Federal Government from the administration of direct relief has brought about confusion as to the responsibility for relief among the welfare agencies throughout the country, according to reports made at the annual meeting yesterday of the board of directors of the Family Welfare Association of America, at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

In "The Wilderness Trail" THE TIMES discussed very fully the recent celebration in Kentucky relating to what is known as the Transylvania Company. Also, a few weeks ago, you wrote of a celebration of the Fort Stanwick treaty with the Indians.

Having declined moderately for three consecutive sessions, the stock market was in a strategic position yesterday to rebound quickly on news of the easing of the "Mediterranean crisis." The rise was accompanied by a rapid expansion in trading activity.

Paul Stagg's well-drilled Moravian College eleven defeated Brooklyn College yesterday on the Abraham Lincoln High School field, 21 to 0. The Bethlehem team's forward and lateral passes carried them to victory.

AGAINST the Communists, Socialists, national planners, Stuart Chasers, and more-abundant-lifers, Mr. Hock directs a powerful counterblast. He is opposed to the State, lock, stock and barrel, at all times, in every country, under any party or group.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 19. -- Combining speed with accuracy, the Long Island Field Hockey Association marred the debut of the New York University women's team by defeating the Violet, 3 -- 1, at the Hempstead Lake State Park today.

WHEN English doctors need expert guidance for particular problems they may now consult films to see how specialists treat similar cases. A cine-medical library, recently established in London, has collected camera records made in hospital operating rooms and laboratories during treatment of diseases, and keeps them on file for the use of qualified medical men.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, today announced revised methods of liquidating and rehabilitating forty-six defunct banks, building and loan associations and insurance companies in New Jersey through centralized management, instead of through localized activity for each company.

NEW YORK CITY'S school officials are seeking a solution to the problem presented by the growth of the high school lunchrooms, which at the present time are doing a gross business of nearly $2,000,000 a year, and the profits from which help to make possible the school system's athletic and extracurricular activity program.

Peace in the local motion-picture field virtually was established yesterday when representatives of Loew's, Inc., signed and representative of RKO prepared to sign tomorrow a seven-year wage contract with Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union.

Cheers and laurels are too infrequently heard or tossed when an organization of women confounds its critics by some particularly fine program or piece of work, but even the most ardent cheerer couldn't keep up with the recent pace of the feminine groups. The calendar teems with neatly planned and energetically executed projects.

In September 227 cases of mendicancy and vagrancy, the lowest for any month of the year, were referred to the Mendicancy Service of the Emergency Relief Bureau, 376 Lafayette Street, it was announced yesterday by the bureau.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Coast Guard, which for years has felt the pinch of inadequate Congressional appropriations to keep its seagoing equipment abreast of smugglers, is now started on an $18,446,000 construction program intended to modernize the fleet by January, 1937.

A NATIONAL guide book on which more than 6,000 writers will collaborate is planned by the WPA with funds appropriated for subsidizing literature and the arts. To be published in five regional volumes, this new United States handbook will be at once gazetteer, tourist guide and key to the country's social, political and cultural life.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- When this is read in New York next Sunday Germany will be clear of the League of Nations. It will be the second anniversary of her notice of withdrawal. In recent weeks she has paid up at some hardship 4,000,000 marks for dues in arrears -- and where the money came from is just one of those mysteries.

ALBANY. Oct. 19. -- Representatives of thirty-five counties today went on record as favoring a tax of 2 per cent on real estate, except in eases where it becomes necessary to increase such a levy to meet old indebtedness. At the meeting, called by the Real Estate Association of the State, mortgage interests, property owners, loan institutions, granges and civic organizations were represented.
The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday a series of recommendations to the Board of Estimate to reduce by $15,307,698 the city's 1936 budget, now tentatively set at $545,551,157.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Upon getting possession of the ball for the first time, Choate School's hard plunging, well-drilled eleven marched 55 yards for a touchdown today and conquered a stubborn fighting Deerfield Academy team for its tenth straight football victory since late in the 1933 season.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18. -- The question of industrial versus craft unionism shook the fifty-fifth convention of the American Federation of Labor to its depths and established a landmark in the history of that organization.
A campaign to drive peddlers out of the Times Square area was started by the police last night, with mass arrests that taxed the facilities of the West Forty-seventh Street station.

An heiress to millions should presumably have small difficulty in settling the affairs of her penniless half-sisters and brother. But Clarissa Morton found the Morton minors a pampered, impractical and unmanageable lot, with a cousin and a friend included in their indigent orphanage.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 19. -- With estimates mounting rapidly as surveys of earthquake damage proceeded, Montana's capital city tonight counted its losses at possibly $3,000,000, with two dead, nine seriously hurt and scores with superficial injuries.

AT least eight important books, originally scheduled for publication this Fall, have been postponed until the Spring of 1936. Lion Feuchtwager's new historical novel, The Jew of Rome," is to be held over until Jan. 2 in order to start the new year off properly for Viking Press.

TO the oft-repeated assertion that the great mass of the American working class will never take spontaneously to a proletarian theatre -- that "workers want to forget their troubles when they go to see a show" -- the conscientious Theatre Union, which for the past two seasons has been offering plays of a strictly social character at the Civic Repertory Theatre, believes that it has a sufficient answer.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 19. -- Boston College today scored one of the major upsets of the year when it handed previously undefeated Michigan State College an 18-6 setback in the first intersectional football game ever played at University Heights.

EVERY YEAR one is able to observe the strange, striking difference between Mr. O'Brien's two anthologies. Marked as it is, that difference is hard to define, but roughly speaking it boils down to this: the British stories are very much more polished; the American ones show a keener awareness of the tumult of contemporary life.

ATHENS, Oct. 19. -- A German hairdresser here takes credit for the disappearance of Adolf Hitler's wandering lock of hair several months ago. He has not worked in Germany for sixteen years, but was sufficiently interested in the Fuehrer's appearance to write him.

Victor F. Ridder's accession as head of the WPA here last week marked the beginning of what many hope will prove the third and final phase of the Federal Government's re-employment drive. General Hugh S. Johnson, first head of the local WPA, federalized work relief and more than doubled its payroll in ten weeks.

JOHN O'HARA'S pedigree as a writer might be set down as approximately by Ernest Hemingway out of Scott Fitzgerald. He writes about the generation after Fitzgerald's with even more freedom of speech than Hemingway has permitted himself.

Adrian Acton was a blackmailer, but he was a clever one, and not too ambitious. Not until after he was murdered did any one, even his charming sister, know what his business had been. He was supposed to have been interested in stock speculations, a somewhat profligate youth, and always poor.

THIS new novel by Sinclair Lewis, so the story goes, was written at white heat. In six weeks of furious typing he set down this flaming chronicle of the coming of a Fascist dictatorship to the United States. It reads, for the most part, as easily as it was written.

WITH the addition of two British-made cars, the list of passenger vehicles to be exhibited at the National Automobile Show, which will open in Grand Central Palace Nov. 2, has grown to twenty-eight. The newly added makes are the Standard Swallow, entered by British Motors, Ltd., and the M.G., to be shown by W.C.R. Auto, Inc.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Army, after forty years of waiting for victory over Harvard on a West Point football field, gained its goal today.

TWELVE years ago Mr. Untermeyer compiled "This Singing World," which ever since has been a favorite anthology with boys and girls. "Rainbow in the Sky" is designed for younger children, and with the exception of three poems nothing in this new collection appears in the earlier one.

Steady activity featured nearly all departments last week, with increased interest noted in Christmas holiday gift merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., Inc. Home furnishings continued active, with deliveries hard to obtain promptly on a variety of items.

Mr. Downes's article on Schoenberg last Sunday brings up many points of interest. There is a vast chasm between the material written on a piece of music paper, in supposedly equal temperament, and the music resulting therefrom, except on keyboard instruments, where the performer has no control over pitch.
IT was just after "Anything Goes and "The Great Waltz" had been triumphantly launched last Fall that Cole Porter and Moss Hart met one night and decided, tentatively, to write musical together.

C.C.N.Y.'s superior weight in the line, amounting to approximately 15 pounds per man, proved the deciding factor yesterday as the Beavers defeated the Lowell Textile eleven, 19 -- 0, at Lewisohn Stadium.
ETHIOPIA fills the stage of British broadcasting at the moment. Or perhaps one should say that Ethiopia fills the stage, with the safety curtain down.

Logan Billingsley, real estate agent at 62 West Forty-fifth Street, appeared yesterday morning before Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter in the Federal Building, to fight removal proceedings to Reno, Nev., where he is charged in an indictment with having conspired with others to use the mails in a scheme to defraud.

JUST at a time when his prestige is not what it used to be, James Branch Cabell has received the handsomest of compliments. A young woman using the assumed name of Spotswood has written, in flattering imitation of the master, a feminine counterpart of "Jurgen."
Gains in earnings and employment among automobile factory workers for this year were reported yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association, based on calculations for the first ten months.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 19. -- Standing like the Rock of Gibraltar in front of its goal line, Nebraska's Huskers today held a fighting Kansas State eleven to a scoreless tie and complicated the Big Six title race. Twice the Wildcats were inside the Husker 10-yard line, but could not muster the strength to push over the counter.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 19. -- Dartmouth buried Brown in an avalanche of touchdowns in a 41-0 triumph today for the second highest score of the 41-year-old series.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 19. -- An invincible Penn State eleven defeated Lehigh, 26 -- 0, before an alumni homecoming crowd of 10,000 today. Playing with methodical and earnest workmanship, the Nittany Lions took command at the opening whistle.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Government aid has increased the average grower's income 100 per cent in the past three years, but cotton growing still is classed here as one of the poorest paid forms of endeavor in the United States.
WARSAW, Oct. 19. -- Poland withdrew today the exequaturs of two Czech consuls in Poland in retaliation for the withdrawal of the exequatur of a Polish consul in Czechoslovakia yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 10, 1935. A SHORT season of opera at Covent Garden has added to the musical amenities of London this Autumn. The present company has Sir Thomas Beecham as artistic director and means, later on, to tour the provinces, fulfilling thus the promise made by Sir Thomas when he founded the League of Opera some years ago.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 19. -- The Long Beach City Council, at a special meeting today, accepted the offer of the United States Government for a loan and grant of $1,730,500 for a complete beach reclamation program.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The Tiger never forgets, apparently. Back in 1869, a Rutgers team defeated Princeton in the first intercollegiate game ever played in America.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Amherst's football team, Little Three champions, had plenty of anxious moments this afternoon before it defeated the University of Rochester eleven, 12 to 0.

CHARLES G. NORRIS has often stated that the sole purpose of his writing is to make people think. This purpose, in itself, is certainly not unlike that of most novelists. The difference lies in what Mr. Norris would have people think about.

Fear that war developments abroad may result in seriously curtailing or shutting off entirely shipments of food products from Italy caused the widest demand last week for all types of supplies from that country that has been witnessed in the wholesale markets here in many years.

Sterling, responding to the movement of capital from London in consequence of the war scare, rallied yesterday as developments abroad pointed to the prospects of a peaceful settlement of the Italo-British dispute. Gold engagements abroad also declined in comparison with the levels of recent days, but this was due, in part, to the reluctance of banks to engage gold at the week end.

Mayor La Guardia and former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, scheduled to debate the proposed municipal power plant tomorrow night at the American Woman's Association, will be honored with a dinner preceding the event in the members' dining room at the club.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Louis Waldman, chairman of the Socialist Party of New York State, commenting on adoption of the Communist amendment to the A. F. of L. constitution, said today:

Revision of the plans of the State Department of Insurance to prevent a loss of from $4,000,000 to $5,000,000 to hundreds of owners of defaulted mortgage certificates of the closed Lawyers Mortgage Company was sought in a petition fried yesterday with Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler on behalf of Brentmore Estates, Inc., representing a group of certificate holders in this company.

If it were not for the gusty "Taming of the Shrew," which is now filling the Guild Theatre with guffaws, votaries of Shakespeare might be down with despair. Shakespeare is heavy company when he is indifferently performed.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 19. -- Williams turned back the undefeated Bowdoin team, 27 to 6, this afternoon before a crowd of 7,000 at Weston Field, when Eddie Stanley led the Purple's remarkable aerial attack. Nick Holmes and Mike Latvis also contributed touchdowns, the latter scoring in the final five minutes of play.

ONE of the new-style European armies has just gone into action with the latest devices for terrorizing civilian populations from the air. It is true that the victims are "only Africans" and that Mussolini regards his war in Ethiopia as just an innocent little colonial adventure.

HIGH-LOW -- that seems to be the most apt word for the new hat tendency. No question about it, there's an uprising among crowns. They point skyward on a forward or a backward slant, and yet they mount from a low molded headline.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Vannie Albanese's line plunging and Ray Reckmack's great passing carried Syracuse through to victory today, 18 to 10, in a second-half rally against a rugged Ohio Wesleyan eleven.

WITH a successful meet at the Big Meadows site in the Shenandoah National Park just closed, the Soaring Society of America is now awaiting the result on ballots for officers for the ensuing year. Under the presidency of Lieut. Commander Ralph Barnaby, the society has had a very encouraging season and seems assured of Federal funds to greatly improve the terrain and facilities at Elmira, where its annual soaring contests are held.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- A charge that "imported gunmen from the underworld of New York" were in this city to help elect John B. Kelly, the Democratic Mayoralty nominee, and the rest of that party's ticket was made today by Wilhelm F. Knauer, former Deputy Attorney General.

THIS new addition, the seventeenth, to the Century Series of expert psychological studies and investigations contains the detailed record and discussion of experimental studies in the development of infants carried on during two years in the Neurological Institute of Columbia Medical Centre, New York City.

PROFESSORS who revel in a study of the unknown have the listening habits of the unseen radio audience as something comparatively new to analyze. If 10,000,000 people are eavesdropping, or even 1,000,000, how they react at the loud-speakers is a real problem beyond the realm of mathematics.

LOUISVILLE. Ky., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Washington and Lee today smashed the 14-year-old jinx held by the Praying-Colonels of Centre College, winning, 14 to 7, before a rainy day crowd of 4,000 at du Pont Stadium.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- Ohio State University hurdled the first obstacle today in the path it hopes will lead to the Western Conference championship, by upsetting a surprisingly rugged Northwestern eleven, 28 to 7. A crowd of 43,000 saw the game.

MELBOURNE. THE reported discovery of a "new" race of people in the Papuan interior of New Guinea has piqued the interest of anthropologists. Although Assistant Resident Magistrate H.G. Hides has presented a 30,000-word report to the Australian Government regarding the eight-month expedition in which the find was made, scientists are eager for still more details and for photographs on which to base a judgment.

The organization of regional committees throughout the country for the Will Rogers Memorial Fund campaign will be undertaken by seven business men, who were scheduled to leave the city by airplane yesterday and today. An eighth man, C.J. Mason, will organize a committee in Greater New York.

MARGARET BRITTON has prepared, as a practical guide to the comparative study of painting, "A Parallel Chronology, of Painters," which is published by Harold H. Laskey in Chicago. The material is conveniently arranged in the form of a chart, which lists in parallel columns the names of important or relatively important artists belonging to the Florentine, Sienese, Venetian, Veronese, Umbro-Roman, North Italian, Flemish, German, Spanish, French, Dutch, English and American schools.

THE poetry of Winifred Welles is precise and antique and patrician. It is very much like a sampler very well done. All the characters in the four narratives that fill this book are figures belonging properly to the theocratic tradition of New England's past.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Members of society from all sections of the metropolitan district attended the annual Tuxedo Autumn bail tonight. More than 500 were present. Almost every house in the park is filled with guests over the week-end.
SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 19. -- Louisiana State University was forced to stage a last half rush to defeat the University of Arkansas 13 to 7 in their annual game.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 19. -- Possibility of the government of Ontario investigating the proposed sale of assets of the Great Lakes Paper Company to a "United States interest," consisting of publishers of newspapers in that country, has greatly perturbed holders of bonds of the company, who having foreclosed their mortgage, have agreed on a method of continuing the business.

One of the war photographs from Ethiopia shows a line of native soldiers near Harar fleeing from a trench under the fire of Italian airplanes. The picture was taken by a cameraman on the spot and sent by native runner to Diredawa.

Still three weeks in traveling time behind the girl for whom he was supposed to have flown an ocean and braved the hazards of a three-continent, inter-hemisphere flight, Juan Ignacio Pombo arrived breathless and indignant at Newark Airport at 6:02 A.M. yesterday.

THE Mission of San Juan Capistrano snuggles in a picturesque little valley half way between Los Angeles and San Diego. It is three miles off the main coast highway that carries roaring traffic between the cities, but many a tourist drives that way to "Oh!" and "Ah!" at the picturesque ruins and perhaps to bend a knee or whisper a prayer at the shrine of the Blessed Virgin.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 7 there appeared an account of the theft from a church in Mount Vernon, N.Y., of a painting valued in money at $5,000 and in sentiment at vastly more. According to report, the article said, "the painting, 'The Death of St. Joseph,' was done by Schiavonne, an Italian artist, in 1573."

An Adirondack camp -- one of those luxurious affairs to which rich city people resort when they feel the call of the wild -- is the scene of this new Trevor Dene story. Dene is an English detective, a Scotland Yard man making a vacation visit to the United States.

Eighty-five hospitals will benefit from the United Hospital Campaign Committee's drive to raise a minimum of $2,000,000 to help save the city's voluntary hospitals from operating insolvency, it was announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the committee.

JUDGE FRANCOIS XAVIER MARTIN, the "Father of Louisiana Jurisprudence," was a mean, avaricious, parsimonious old man. At the age of 20 he was a pauper, alone in a strange land. But he had a strong will and an iron constitution, unlimited energy, and faith in himself.

THIS admirable account of the present status of knowledge concerning our solar system by Henry Norris Russell. Professor of Astronomy at Princeton University, director of its observatory and research associate of Mount Wilson Observatory, was originally given last year as a series of lectures at the University of Virginia.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- A Federal club would be held over the head of every farmer in the country if the present policies of "planned economy" were carried to the conclusion aimed at by the planners themselves, Representative James W. Wadsworth of New York asserted here tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Economy in the Cook County local government has relaxed its vigilance, and the old "squander" days are coming back, according to John Rees, director of the Citizens Committee on Public Expenditure.

A Manhattan football team which refused to concede defeat wiped out a two-touchdown deficit in a desperate late-period drive to gain a gratifying 13-to-13 tie with a heavily favored Holy Cross eleven at Ebbets Field yesterday.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Employing a brilliant aerial attack in the first half, Michigan ran up three touchdowns which proved too great a handicap for Wisconsin to overcome today, and they gave the Badgers their fourth successive defeat, 20-12.

DENVER, Oct. 19. -- The Pacific Coast and Rocky Mountain States are slowly but surely climbing out of the depression. Virtually every index, urban and rural, confirms this statement, but, to one who toured this same region extensively a year ago, the visible evidences of improvement are even more convincing.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 19. -- The Ethiopian Government asserted today Italian air bombs killed a child at Ambaalaje, Tigre Province, on the northern front, infuriating the populace.

Many reservations have been made for the performance of "On Stage," a new play with Osgood Perkins and Selena Royle, on the night of Oct. 31 at the Mansfield Theatre, which has been taken over by persons interested in the work of the Vocational Service for Juniors to raise funds for that organization.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19. -- It is becoming more apparent day by day that the League of Nations can expect little cooperation from its South American members in applying sanctions against Italy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Designed to provide "the capstone of Princeton's plan of individual study, and as such to be an important contribution to American educational theory and practice," detailed plans of the new library of Princeton University, for the construction and endowment of which a fund of $4,000,000 is now being raised, were made known today by President Harold Willis Dodds.

MARGARET BRITTON has prepared, as a practical guide to the comparative study of painting, "A Parallel Chronology, of Painters," which is published by Harold H. Laskey in Chicago. The material is conveniently arranged in the form of a chart, which lists in parallel columns the names of important or relatively important artists belonging to the Florentine, Sienese, Venetian, Veronese, Umbro-Roman, North Italian, Flemish, German, Spanish, French, Dutch, English and American schools.

THE poetry of Winifred Welles is precise and antique and patrician. It is very much like a sampler very well done. All the characters in the four narratives that fill this book are figures belonging properly to the theocratic tradition of New England's past.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Members of society from all sections of the metropolitan district attended the annual Tuxedo Autumn bail tonight. More than 500 were present. Almost every house in the park is filled with guests over the week-end.
SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 19. -- Louisiana State University was forced to stage a last half rush to defeat the University of Arkansas 13 to 7 in their annual game.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 19. -- Possibility of the government of Ontario investigating the proposed sale of assets of the Great Lakes Paper Company to a "United States interest," consisting of publishers of newspapers in that country, has greatly perturbed holders of bonds of the company, who having foreclosed their mortgage, have agreed on a method of continuing the business.
