One of the war photographs from Ethiopia shows a line of native soldiers near Harar fleeing from a trench under the fire of Italian airplanes. The picture was taken by a cameraman on the spot and sent by native runner to Diredawa.

Still three weeks in traveling time behind the girl for whom he was supposed to have flown an ocean and braved the hazards of a three-continent, inter-hemisphere flight, Juan Ignacio Pombo arrived breathless and indignant at Newark Airport at 6:02 A.M. yesterday.

THE three hundred veterans of the "Rancho" outfit, tanned like Ethiops, trekked home the other day, with oxcarts, motor-lorries, an exhausted tropilla of mount animals, and the Summer's work packed in a half dozen flat cans.
ONEONTA, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, said today that an aroused public is "calling for the political heads" of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.

Many reservations have been made for the performance of "On Stage," a new play with Osgood Perkins and Selena Royle, on the night of Oct. 31 at the Mansfield Theatre, which has been taken over by persons interested in the work of the Vocational Service for Juniors to raise funds for that organization.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19. -- It is becoming more apparent day by day that the League of Nations can expect little cooperation from its South American members in applying sanctions against Italy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Designed to provide "the capstone of Princeton's plan of individual study, and as such to be an important contribution to American educational theory and practice," detailed plans of the new library of Princeton University, for the construction and endowment of which a fund of $4,000,000 is now being raised, were made known today by President Harold Willis Dodds.

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- After several years of dismal post-mortems, Massachusetts Republicans are now so cheered by their victory in the Essex by-election on Tuesday that candidacies for Governor and Senator are being announced as excitedly as if the election were next month instead of next year.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 19. -- Eight earth shocks of moderate intensity jolted Helena in rapid succession early tonight and the City Council immediately declared that a "State of emergency exists," placing the entire populace under direct orders of civic authorities.

The library of the late Appellate Judge Willis Vickery of Cleveland, together with first editions and autographs comprising the final portion of the collection of the late Jahu Dewitt Miller of Washington, D.C., and the collection of Miss Ida Cushman of Philadelphia, and other properties will be auctioned at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons.

While theoretically the policy of cutting prices to broaden volume, as advocated by the Brookings Institution, is entirely sound and commendable, its practical application in most lines of industry is beset by innumerable difficulties, business executives, accountants and engineers declared yesterday.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Haverford outplayed the Wesleyan eleven today, but it was not until the final quarter that the Quaker forward-passing machine made two touchdowns to win, 13 to 7.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 (AP). -- A rugged defense that checked five Indiana goal-line thrusts in the second half, and the long distance punting of big London Gant, Negro back, gave the University of Cincinnati Bearcats a 7 -- 0 victory over the Big Ten eleven from Bloomington today.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- Countess of Dalkeith, sister-in-law of Lady Alice Scott, has ordered a Schiaparelli evening gown for the royal wedding festivities. It is of reversible gold lame, appropriately patterned with pale blue crowns, and simply made with a loose full back panel.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, formed recently by the United States Steel Corporation to consolidate the activities of its two principal subsidiaries, the Illinois Steel and the Carnegie Steel Companies, has purchased or leased the properties of Illinois Steel, the latter company has informed the New York Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- The lame and the halt, Cecil Isbell and John Drake, shook off their miseries long enough today to lead Purdue's Boilermakers to a 19 to 0 triumph over Chicago's brave little band today before 25,000 spectators at Stagg Field.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Stand Pat, gallant chestnut son of John P. Grier, flying the black and yellow silks of the Canadian stable of E.F. Seagram, triumphed in record-breaking time today in the Massachusetts Handicap, $5,000 added feature of the final program at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 30,000.

LONDON is growing quiet, and can boast this week of but two openings. Both are on Tuesday. At the Duke of York's Frank Vosper will appear in an adaptation of Langkervist's, "The Hangman," which is a fine hit in Sweden. At the Old Vic, "Julius Caesar" will suffer revival, with Cecil Trouncer, Ion Swinley and William Devlin in the company.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- The Boerse was inclined today to take a more hopeful view of the international situation and the tendency of stocks at the close of the week was toward firmness. Trading was fairly active, and gains of a point featured early operations.

FLYING the fastest airplanes now in regular service in the United States Army, ten crack pilots, members of the First Pursuit Group stationed out at Selfridge Field, Mount Clemens, Mich., will compete today in the annual speed dash for the John L. Mitchell Trophy.

Recommendations for a "yes" vote on the $55,000,000 relief bond issue and the three proposed constitutional amendments to be found on the ballot Nov. 5 were made public yesterday by the Citizens Union.

FOR the light verse of David McCord we give hosannahs to the Lord. His metrical candescence shines like Parker's and like Hoffenstein's. He can be almost as brash as the ineluctable Nash. Or leave his limpid numbers lay as flawlessly as F.P.A.

Who killed Gregor Wilchenski, internationally famous pianist, in the New York home of his wife from whom he had been separated for years? Not that anybody cares much, aside from the police and a few devoted music lovers, for Gregor was not a nice person.

VALETTA, Malta, Oct. 19. -- The possibility of a grave shortage as a result of the sanctions on macaroni and olive oil, two staple foodstuffs of the Mediterranean peoples and exclusively Italian products, is causing considerable alarm among the quarter of a million inhabitants of these small islands.

WHILE waiting to hear from the committee of scientists appointed last Spring at the request of Secretary of the Navy Swanson to inquire into the whole lighter-than-air question, certain observers were interested this week to learn something of the history of commercial transport in airships in the last ten years.

COBURG, Oct. 19. -- Without the aid of motor cars, airplanes and loud-speakers National Socialism could not have conquered Germany, Chancellor Hitler confessed to a gathering of leaders of the Nazi Motor Corps here today. The party's whirlwind campaigns, Hitler explained, had been made possible by the exploitation of these three means of reaching the masses.

The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the Lehigh Power Securities Corporation, which is controlled by the National Power and Light Company, reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, gross operating revenues of $34,606,742, which is 2 per cent more than the $33,846,683 received in the preceding twelve months.

Mrs. Ticklefeather lives on the top of a high building, owns a puffin and loves sunflowers. In providing his mistress with a sunflower, the puffin is lost, but is found and brought back by a policeman, along with a strange collection of articles, such as a Teddy Bear, a pillow, a magnesia bottle, a pair of rubbers and a frog, that are picked up by the policeman during his search.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Six ships were speeding tonight to the assistance of the British steamer Vardulia, which had radioed "now abandoning ship" 420 miles northwest of the Hebrides Islands in the North Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Complaints against sixty-four defendants for alleged participation in a disturbance at the plant of the Consumers Research, Inc., at Bowerstown, near here, last Tuesday were filed today with Recorder Clarence Fisher of Huntington and Justice of the Peace David Kennedy of Phillipsburg.

IN hundreds of cities of Europe today children are marching. Straightening thin shoulders under black shirts or brown, they step out importantly behind banner and drum, with songs on their lips and warm nationalistic dogma in their hearts.

FLEMINGGTON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The thirteenth annual reunion of the Rockefeller Association was held here today. Seventy or more members of the American and Canadian branches of the family attended and tonight re-elected officers at a dinner held in the Union Hotel.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 19. -- Showing a return to his sensational form of the Arlington Futurity, the Bowmar Stable's Grand Slam gave a fine performance today to win the fifteenth renewal of the Kentucky Jockey Club's Stakes before a crowd of 12,000 at Churchill Downs.

WE have no right to complain of overpopulation and no need to fear it in the future," wrote Peter Kropotkin in "Fields, Factories and Workshops," first published in 1898. "Our means of obtaining from the soil whatever we want, under any climate and upon any soil, have lately been improved at such a rate that we cannot foresee yet what is the limit of productivity of a few acres of land.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Federal Reserve Board is working on regulations to give a better control of the use of bank credit in the financing of security transactions on national security exchanges under authority given to the board in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Barringer scored a 13-to-7 triumph over Weequahic High today in a thrilling game.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 19. -- A revamped Peddie team defeated the Poly Prep eleven, 18 -- 0. for its first victory of the season today.

THE creator of Mr. Reginald Fortune is one of the best living writers of detective stories: any tale by H.C. Bailey is bound to be original, well-written and absorbingly interesting; and the reader knows, moreover, that this author will follow the rules of the detective-story game without losing touch with reality in character or plot.

The New York Aggies, trailing at the half, tallied a touchdown in each of the last two periods to beat Wagner College, 14 to 7, yesterday at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S.I. The Aggies' rally started when Frank Slezak intercepted a pass and ran 51 yards to the Wagner 4-yard line. The victory was the Farmingdale, L.I., eleven's third straight.

Representatives of eleven major feminine organizations participating in the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War will convene tomorrow at the Y.W.C.A. Building, 600 Lexington Avenue, to make reports and to plan for the program of the national conference in Washington in January.

NEWARK, Del., Oct. 19. -- Randolph Macon, scoring two touchdowns in the second period, one in the third and one in the final defeated University of Delaware 26 to 0 today. The Yellow Jackets won their victory by playing more aggressive football.

The swiftly moving diplomatic action in Europe caused by Great Britain's effort to halt Mussolini's war of conquest in Eastern Africa develops with a kaleidoscopic appearance. The League of Nations, pushed by London, continues to work out the system of sanctions to be applied against Italy, having just voted a recommendation that all League members cut off all purchases from her. There sprang up during the week a new tension between Rome and London.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 19. -- Henry Tung had a birthday last night, his first, and it almost caused a panic, stopped traffic, brought out a movie star, an orchestra, a "Miss New Orleans," carvings from China and a hundred and fifty appetites.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A statement that geographers may often play an important role in preserving peace was made today by Summer Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, in an address before the Pan-American Institute of Geography and History.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Senator Norris, leader of the Progressive Republican group, announced today his support of President Roosevelt for re-election. He joined Senators La Follette and Johnson when he said that the Republicans would not nominate a man for President he could support.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- After being buffeted about Long Island Sound for twenty-two hours without food or drink in a leaking auxiliary fishing boat. Henry Fownes, retired broker, formerly of Pittsburgh, and William Ballows, a writer, of Southport, Conn., were rescued today off Smithtown, L.I.
The Columbia freshmen opened their season yesterday by trouncing the Rutgers' yearlings, 44 -- 0, at Baker Field.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 19. -- Biff Jones's University of Oklahoma squad walked away with a 16-to-0 victory over Iowa State today in a Big Six game. The game, a feature of the annual Dad's Day on the campus, was attended by 6,000 fans.

RICH bloom in late shrubs is highly prized by garden color enthusiasts; hence the unusual appeal of the Bluebeard or Blue-spireas (Caryopteris). Flowering in late September and October, these shrubs are admirably suited to small gardens, terraces and other intimate areas which call for restraint in the planting scheme, and provide colorful specimens for close-range enjoyment.
MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 19. -- The Mercersburg Academy eleven conquered Massanutten M.A. by 13 -- 6 today.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 19. -- A thousand Monmouth County farmers and their families were luncheon guests today of the Monmouth County Hunt, featuring the tenth annual Monmouth County race meet staged by the hunt on the Amory L. Haskell estate at Middletown near here.

A complete study and analysis of the manner in which the price-filing system, set up under the electrical industry's code, operated under NRA is one of forty-six projects outlined for next year in the program of activities mapped out yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

A GREAT many American actors are out of work, so many indeed that the government here has been compelled to make elaborate plans to relieve their distress. Yet at this very time I can bring over a company from England to play my "Eden End" on Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The increase in prison terms for violations of the liquor tax law, narcotics traffic, counterfeiting and motor vehicle thefts -- and the anticrime offensive of the Department of Justice -- brought the Federal prison population to an all-time high this year.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Clinton prison at Dannemora, where the State sends its hardened criminals and chronic trouble makers, is being transformed into a "model" institution.

THESE nine pamphlets have been prepared with the aim in view of presenting for general readers, and especially for adult education and workers' groups, discussions of questions of immediate and crucial interest in economics, politics and sociology.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 19. -- Henry Tung had a birthday last night, his first, and it almost caused a panic, stopped traffic, brought out a movie star, an orchestra, a "Miss New Orleans," carvings from China and a hundred and fifty appetites.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A statement that geographers may often play an important role in preserving peace was made today by Summer Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, in an address before the Pan-American Institute of Geography and History.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Senator Norris, leader of the Progressive Republican group, announced today his support of President Roosevelt for re-election. He joined Senators La Follette and Johnson when he said that the Republicans would not nominate a man for President he could support.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- After being buffeted about Long Island Sound for twenty-two hours without food or drink in a leaking auxiliary fishing boat. Henry Fownes, retired broker, formerly of Pittsburgh, and William Ballows, a writer, of Southport, Conn., were rescued today off Smithtown, L.I.

Staving off its rival's desperate bid in the last half, the Grover Cleveland High School football team remained unbeaten and untied in three starts by vanquishing Flushing High, 14 -- 12, before 7,000 persons at Memorial Field, Flushing, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 16, which included only five business days in most of the reporting cities, aggregated $7,697,000,000, or 7 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 17 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included only five business days in most of the reporting cities.
The Columbia freshmen opened their season yesterday by trouncing the Rutgers' yearlings, 44 -- 0, at Baker Field.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 19. -- Biff Jones's University of Oklahoma squad walked away with a 16-to-0 victory over Iowa State today in a Big Six game. The game, a feature of the annual Dad's Day on the campus, was attended by 6,000 fans.

THIS IS WHISKY: Last month the Federal Alcohol Administration started a school for its inspectors in the theory and practice of brewing, distilling and rectifying. That was an idea of Administrator Franklin C. Hoyt, for twenty-five years a judge in New York City and a grandson of Salmon P. Chase, once Chief Justice of the United States.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 10 (by mail). -- Psychiatrists of the world have begun a campaign against the surrender of civilization to the insanity of war. That the people of the world may be headed for a "war psychosis" is the warning contained in a document signed by 339 psychiatrists from thirty nations.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Rutgers University is in immediate need of new buildings and additions which would cost nearly $2,000,000, it was said here today in the annual report of Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the university.
There has been an encouraging subscription for the performance of "Jumbo," the new musical circus, to be given on the night of Oct. 30 at the Hippodrome in aid of the Maternity Centre Association.

Tallying the only touchdown Pittsburgh made against Notre Dame on Saturday, Frank Patrick, Panther fullback, retained first place in the Eastern intercollegiate scoring. He has made six touchdowns, five points after touchdowns and two field goals for a total of 47 points and leads Ed Stanley, Williams halfback, by 4.

An appeal for citizen support of the bond issue for unemployment relief, which comes before the voters election day, was issued yesterday by Homer Folks, secretary of the State Charities Aid Association.
Realty activity in the city over the week-end was dominated by the selling and leasing of housing properties.

Putnams report that indications now are that Admiral Richard E. Byrd's new book, "Discovery," will have an advance sale of more than 40,000 copies. Originally scheduled for publication on Oct. 25, the book has now been put over until Armistice Day, Nov. 11, because the final revision of the last three chapters was held up by Admiral Byrd's heavy lecture schedule.

The action of the Board of Aldermen in voting a reduction of water rates makes more imperative than ever the need for administrative economies to bring about a substantial cut in the tentative budget of $545,356,833 for 1936, William Church Osborn, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.

The names of thirty-five State Governors who have accepted honorary chairmanships in the Will Rogers memorial campaign opening Nov. 4--the fifty-sixth anniversary of the humorist's birth--and ending on Thanksgiving eve, were announced yesterday by Captain Eddie Riekenbacker, director of the memorial movement.

Polly Korchien and Dean Goodelle gave their first dance recital in New York since their debut two seasons ago last night at the Guild Theatre in a program consisting entirely of new compositions. Because of the excellent impression made by their previous appearance, considerably more was to be expected of them than the performance had to offer.

Midseason arrived for most of the East's prep school football teams during the past week-end, bringing not only a number of impressive triumphant performances, but also some alarming upsets that in several instances reduced the ranks of the unbeaten.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 20. -- As an aftermath of the convention of the American Federation of Labor which closed last night, proponents of a constitutional amendment permitting Congress to enact social and economic Welfare legislation were at work today formulating the wording of such an act.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP). -- A spokesman for the American Bakers Association laid the blame today for increased bread prices in some sections of the nation on the doorstep of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

The ubiquitous hot dog was officially recognized yesterday afternoon by the Gourmets Society, although in a decidedly left-handed fashion, at the first of the society's Fall gatherings, a dinner attended by forty epicures whose president, J. George Frederick, reported that the territory west of the Hudson River, was, figuratively, a "culinary Sahara."

Anticipating the allocation of Federal funds, for which application has been made, the Transit Commission has approved an estimated expenditure of $1,800,000 for the elimination of the West Seventy-ninth Street grade crossing on the New York Central tracks abutting Riverside Drive.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Considering the reluctance of several members of the League of Nations to uphold the covenant, opinion in financial London regards the problem of sanctions as another overseas trade obstacle. Observers are even doubtful whether the experiment is desirable in the interests of European peace.
GENEVA, Oct. 20 (AP).--The death of Arthur Henderson brought forth a general expression of sorrow in Geneva.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 52 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week. The highest monthly average in the year so far was 52.28 per cent, in February, while the lowest was 39.44 per dent, in July.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 20. -- Central Manitoba Mines, Ltd., has reported for the year ended on April 30 a net operating loss of $54,807, against one of $65,763 for the preceding year. In addition, William Hurst, president, presented a supplementary report to the end of August, which showed a further loss of $29,831, making a total deficit of $84,638 for sixteen months.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 19. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85.5, which compares with 85.8 the week before, 85.6 two weeks before, 85.5 three weeks before and 85.2 four weeks before.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The steady reduction of Italy's gold re- serve since she began preparations for the invasion of Ethiopia was graphically shown today in the monthly bulletin of the Federal Reserve Board.
From Sixtieth Street up Fifth Avenue the sidewalk is edged at intervals with poor, wretched trees, which through the Summer have tried to exist encased in hard, flinty-looking earth.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 20. -- A determined monkey, trapped in a cellar after his depredations cost Pasquale Schinto of Greenwich more than $50 in two weeks, is resisting the combined efforts of twenty men to bag him and put him in a crate.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week, dictated by the war news, developed a firm tone on Saturday in response to the halt in the crisis initiated by England's offer to withdraw part of her naval armament'. A similar measure of cooperation on the part of Italy is expected to finally dissipate the tension which has hovered over international markets for several months now.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 20. -- For the fourth successive year, the Piping Rock Club's strong aggregation carried off the premier honors in the annual interclub invitation golf tournament today at the readow Brook Club.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 (AP). -- New York State labor and the Works Progress Administration plan a "showdown" tomorrow on the WPA security wage scale, which is opposed by labor as opening the way for private industry to cut wages.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Farmers are marketing their livestock in a liberal way, as indicated by receipts here last week. Receipts of hogs were 64,900 head, the second largest number for a week since April 6. A year ago they were 129,544 head.

While there were fewer retail buyers in the wholesale markets here last week, mail orders continued heavy in almost all divisions. Women's apparel was in active demand, although wholesalers reported a falling off in the call for street dresses. Substantial orders were placed for afternoon and bar dresses, and the more formal types, however.

In your issue of Oct. 16 William E. Sweet, speaking of Senator Borah's letter to Colonel Roosevelt on monopoly, says: "The fight against monopoly began when Senator Borah wore short trousers, and if his advice is followed this matter is a long, long way from being ended."

Motion picture producers have responded to the demand for "clean productions" and the public which made the demand should now support the results, the Rev. James F. Cunningham declared yesterday in a sermon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street.

An open protest against communism and "any system that denies God" was voiced yesterday by Amadeus J. Ward, president of the Bronx division of the Archdiocesan Union of Holy Name Societies, before 10,000 men gathered on the grounds of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, University and Boscobel Avenues, the Bronx, for their annual rally.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of member banks in leading cities increased by $179,000,000 to $3,299,000,000, while leans on real estate at $955,000,000 showed an increase of $6,000,000 during the eight weeks from July 31 to Sept. 25, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in a survey in its current bulletin.

The fourteenth annual British Harvest Festival, the English counterpart of Thanksgiving Day, was held yesterday afternoon for the British citizens of New York and this vicinity in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street.

Adoption by New York City of a long-range, comprehensive, lowcost housing program to wipe out it slums was recommended to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Nathan Straus, the Mayor's Special Housing Commissioner.

A call to action for organization of the Catholic youth of the world against the enemies of the church was the keynote of addresses delivered before an audience of more than 450 persons yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Cenacle Giuditta Guild, an organization of young women of Italian descent, at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Repeating his protest against participation by the United States in the Berlin Olympic Games next year, the Rev. Charles S. MacFarland, who has been an annual visitor to Germany for the last quarter-century and who recently wrote a book on the church conflict there, answered today the recent statement made by Dr. Theodor Lewald, German chairman of the Olympic organization committee.

Continuing his course of ten lectures on "The Invention and Development of the Opera," Paul Bekker, music critic, will be heard tonight at 7 o'clock at the Cecilia Music School, Madonna House, 84 Market Street, in a talk on the period from Monteverdi to Haendel.

Jerome Goldman left Bellevue Hospital yesterday whistling "Fare Thee Well, Annabelle." No vague pun was intended; Mrs. Dorothy Rider, the nurse who helped Jerry through his eight weeks' siege of infantile paralysis, taught him the tune because she knew it and he liked it.
Industrial properties in Hoboken and Newark and a theatre in the latter city passed to new control in New Jersey deals over the week-end. A Harrison plot was leased for an oil plant.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Although Newark's new Federal Postoffice and Courts Building will not open until February a controversy already has developed around the "New Deal's" idea of art.

The Soldiers and Sailors Club will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show tomorrow in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Young women of society who will act as manikins in the fashion show are Mrs. David I. Mackie Jr., Mrs. Alfred J. Yardley, Mrs. Samuel Sloan, Mrs. Milton Davis, Mrs. Alan Jackson and Miss Mimi Richardson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- A.W. Miller, head of the Packers and Stockyards Division of the Bureau of Animal Industry, said that investigations of poultry handling are under way in other cities. He indicated that the government will look closely into the marketing of chickens in Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, Cincinnati, St. Louis and San Francisco.

The years soften memories into a melody of life, and time, in retrospection, offers a pattern of existence, the Rev. Dr. William H. Kephart said yesterday morning in a sermon commemorative of the thirty-ninth anniversary of his pastorship of the North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street near Willis Avenue, the Bronx.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 20. -- The Ethiopian Government's satisfaction over the way everything in the northern sector is going according to plan is certainly justified if Ras Seyoum has managed to lure the Italians toward Makale without becoming engaged in a serious action.

The De Basil Ballet Russe last night brought to a close its twelve-day season at the Metropolitan Opera House with a program which was something in the nature of a gala. Instead of the customary three ballets, a fourth was added for this occasion and comprised the novelty of the evening.

Election of at least eighty Republican Assemblymen out of 150 was predicted yesterday by Assemblyman Irving M. Ives of Norwich, minority leader, on his return from the two-week tour of the Republican Assembly Caravan through the State. In an interview at the Commodore Hotel, Mr. Ives said the revolt against the New Deal policies of President Roosevelt up-State was overwhelming and that this would be shown by the results on election day.

Registration has risen sharply throughout the State this year, as compared with figures for last year and the year before, returns from a selected list of up-State cities, towns and villages showed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Buying of grains, particularly wheat, in the world's markets, based on Italy's war in Ethiopia, is said by grain traders to have lost its bullish influence and the liquidation that took place last week carried prices down as fast as they had advanced previously.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 20. -- To raise funds with which to purchase an artificial right leg and pay for hospital treatment for a partly paralyzed right arm, James Horning, 32 years old, of Medford, a professional parachute jumper, made a spectacular leap in a chute from an airplane 2,000 feet over the Great South Bay this afternoon.

A letter asking Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, American member of the International Olympic Committee, to support a movement for the withdrawal of American athletes from the Olympic Games to be held in Germany next Spring will be delivered to him when he arrives on the Normandie today.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- A special session of the State Legislature to consider repeal of the New Jersey sales tax, which has been widely attacked since it went into effect last July 1, was called tonight by Governor Harold G. Hoffman.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 21. -- Eight ships were searching the tumbling waters of the Atlantic early today for thirty-seven missing seamen, the crew of the foundered Donaldson Line steamer Vardulia, who took to their boats in stormy seas twenty-eight hours ago as the vessel sank 400 miles off the Scottish coast.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The text of the Securities and Exchange Commission's rules for registration of unissued securities and for trading in them on a when-issued basis follows:

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- A swimming team from the Lake Shore Swimming Club of Chicago met the German provisional Olympic Games swimming team here this afternoon and an American, Adolph Kiefer, son of German-born parents, broke the world's record for the 100-meter backstroke.

HARAR, Oct. 20. -- Persistent scouting by Italian planes from the north supports the belief here that Italy's activity on the Eritrean front is a prelude for a thrust toward Ethiopia's central plateau from the edge of the Danakil desert.
DESSYE, Ethiopia, Oct. 20 (Reuters). -- Horsemen arriving here today said between 500 and 700 Italians had been cut off from communication with the main Italian forces by Danakil desert warriors.

The president of the New York Stock Exchange has begun to make addresses in various parts of the country explaining the work and attitude of that institution. If his other speeches are as thoughtful as the one he delivered at Springfield, Ill., his tour should do much to develop a better understanding between Wall Street and the rest of the country--including the Administration.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 (AP). -- The New York State Conservation Department tonight reported that forty-seven forest fires, three of them out of control, were roaring through forests of the State, and blamed the fires on the "carelessness of hunters."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- The Federal Government may learn from the Supreme Court tomorrow whether it must defend a New Deal law against the first constitutional challenge by a sovereign State.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 20 (AP). -- The battered body of a woman who apparently had been beaten and then run over by an automobile was identified tonight as that of Mrs. Evelyn Sliwinsky, aged 24, of Louisville. The body was found on a highway near here early today.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion candidate for District Attorney in Kings County and District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan, Democratic candidate for re-election, engaged in a radio debate yesterday afternoon on the issues of the campaign over Station WOR.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch today defied a rebellion of the National Parliament which voted against him and demanded that he resign.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, replied yesterday to the recent reassurances of Dr. Theodor Lewald, president of the German Olympic Committee. Mr. Mahoney, in a letter to Dr. Lewald, said that an investigation authorized by the union had established the charges of racial and religious discrimination against German sportsmen.

TRIPOLI, Oct. 19. -- Air Marshal Italo Balbo, Governor General of Libya, has given me his reasons why Italy is diverting so many troops into Italian North Africa and why he has found it necessary to reinforce the Egyptian-Libyan frontier.

Difficulties arising from Germany's use of blocked funds in her Latin-American trade are being reduced by the action of the nations themselves, Harry Tipper, executive vice president of the American Manufacturers Export Association, said yesterday in commenting upon a survey of exchange conditions conducted by his group.

The gridiron at the Polo Grounds was hot yesterday and the New York Giants professional football team struck accordingly, with the result that they led the Boston Redskins by 10 -- 0 within two minutes of play and coasted to a 17-6 victory.

Credit and collections conditions in Latin America held the gains registered earlier in the year, according to the quarterly survey of twenty-one South and Central American countries completed yesterday by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 20. -- The Kryl Symphony Orchestra appeared in the Greenbrier auditorium tonight for the benefit of the Hospital Trust Fund and the local chapter of the Needlework Guild of America. Among those attending were:

The International Mining Corporation has reported net assets of $8,604,733 as of Sept. 30 after effecting write-offs of furniture, fixtures and field equipment and providing for additional reserve of $272,970 for losses in mining ventures set up on the books since that date.

A new issue of $5,500,000 fifteen-year 4 per cent sinking-fund bonds of Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., will be offered today to the public by a syndicate headed by Paine, Webber Co., and including Hayden, Stone Co. and W.C. Langley Co.

EL PASO, Texas, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Two men were killed and thirty-four wounded, four seriously, today as friction between two rival political parties in Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico, came to a violent climax in the streets of La Chavena, South Juarez suburb.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, THE ITALIAN ARMIES IN NORTHERN ETHIOPIA, Oct. 19 (Delayed).--Slight advances along the left and right sectors strengthened the Italian armies' front line today, laying the groundwork for a new major advance that may start in forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Federal regulation of the live poultry industry in New York City and Jersey City was ordered today by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace. On and after Nov. 25 dealers and handlers of live poultry in these areas must be licensed by the Department of Agriculture.

Italy's aims in Ethiopia were defended yesterday by Corrado Zoli, former Governor of Eritrea, in an address broadcast from Rome and rebroadcast here over the WABC Columbia network. He accused the League of Nations of presenting Italy falsely in the light of an aggressor.

VIENNA, Oct. 20. -- Friedrich Scheu, defending counsel for Ladislaus Benes, editor of the American-European Press Service, who was sentenced yesterday to five days' rigorous imprisonment by an Austrian court on a charge (based on a denunciation by a police spy whose name the secret police have refused to divulge) of "publishing untrue rumors dangerous to the Austrian State," will enter an appeal tomorrow on the ground of misinterpretation of the law by the judge.

It is reported from Washington that State Department officials are mystified by former Secretary of State Stimson's letter urging more thoroughgoing support by the United States Government of the covenant and the pact of Paris. How, officials are quoted as replying, can the President use his executive powers further without violating the recent neutrality legislation?

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- Premier Pierre Laval was elected Senator today in both departments where he had presented his candidacies -- the Seine and Puy-de-Dome. He also in both cases was far at the head of the polls.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Arthur Henderson, president of the World Disarmament Conference and former British Foreign Secretary, died at a nursing home tonight after a long, wasting illness at the age of 72.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- The Chicago Bears took the lead in the Western Division of the National Football League today with a 24-to-14 victory over the Brooklyn Dodgers. The game was the first of their home season for the victors.

To the Masque this evening comes "Eden End," by that now established transatlantic playwright J.B. Priestley. Milton Shubert presents it (with Gilbert Miller he offered Mr. Priestley's "Laburnum Grove" last season) and Estelle Winwood is the featured player.

With coffee prices at the lowest level of the current movement, quotations in the commodity futures markets here were mixed last week. A new high mark was established by silk in the cash markets, with dairy products and rubber moving up and losses being recorded by the grains, coffee, cocoa, raw sugar and tin.

Prices in the cotton markets moved in a narrow range last week and at the close on Saturday on the New York Cotton Exchange they were from 1 point higher to 10 points lower than at the close of the previous week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Purchases of grain futures, particularly wheat, on the Board of Trade here last week were large, but not so heavy as in the previous week. They exceeded last year's transactions in wheat, while there were decreases in corn, oats and rye.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The crisis of the past week has shaken Britain's reliance on friendship on the Continent of Europe, with results that may change the course of her policy in the next few years. It has forced her to speed up the process of rearmament and has caused her to think of withdrawing into armed and alert isolation.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- A brilliant performance by Chancefield Flush of Earlsmoor, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel NIilbank of New York City, brought the 20-months old liver and white Springer a noteworthy victory in the members' all-age stake today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The administration was called upon to abandon its "spendthrift policies" and reduce expenditures drastically, in an analysis of the budget prospects of the Federal Government, issued tonight by the American Liberty League.

Steel operations declined 1 point last week to 51 per cent of capacity as a result of an easing in the demand from railroads and consumers of tin plate and structural steel, according to the weekly summary of the magazine Steel. The review continues:

Samuel Parker Hinckley, 85 years old, a retired real estate dealer, died of a heart attack at 2:10 P.M. yesterday at 35 East Sixty-fourth Street. Mr. Hinckley, who had lived at the University Club form twenty-five years, had just visited his secretary, Miss Ruth O'Brien.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Snow and increasing cold harassed this city today as earth tremors, which have killed two persons and injured scores, continued for the eighth successive day. Widespread suffering was feared should temperatures continue to fall.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The government's Division of Geographical Names said today that records gave these pronunciations for the names of cities figuring in the Ethiopian news:

Faced with increasingly aggressive competition from Europe, all American international air mail, passenger and express service to Latin America will be put on new high-speed schedules, averaging nearly 150 miles an hour, on Nov. 1, Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, disclosed yesterday.
"FASCISM," said Sinclair Lewis a year ago, "can't happen to America. We're too democratic here."

A departure from the conventional sermon style was used by the Rev. Raymond E. Finehout at the Lutheran Church of the Messiah, 165th Street and Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, who preached yesterday morning what he described as a "scenario sermon."

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 20. -- Miss Virginia Redding, left inner, drove a hard shot into the centre of the net in the last minute to break a 2-2 tie and give the latineoocks a 3-2 victory over the Meracocks in an interclub battle of the Long Island Field Hockey Association at Hempstead Lake State Park today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,180,355,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
LONDON, Oct. 20. -- One of the worst storms in recent years had stopped virtually all shipping in the North and Baltic Seas tonight.

The joint communique issued at Rome, respecting the call of the British Ambassador upon MUSSOLINI, said that certain "assurances" were given by Sir ERIC DRUMMOND. What these were was more explicitly stated by Prime Minister BALDWIN in his speech on Saturday. Great Britain has not the slightest thought of interfering in Italy's domestic affairs.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Herbert D. Allman, president of the National Farm School, advocated a back-to-the-land movement today and pointed to the possibilities of farming as a "creative, independent career."

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Otto Dingfield of Jersey City led the police with a score of 280 in New Jersey's first police and civilian pistol match, which finished today over the national match course here. In the civilian group, Don Marshall of East Orange finished high in the .22-calibre division, with a score of 279, and Fred Truslow of Summit led with 276 in the .38-calibre class.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Ridden to perfection by Miss Fay Griffin of White Plains, Sir Anthony, aged bay gelding owned by Humphrey J. Lynch, jumped to two victories and missed another in a jump-off in the Bronxville Riding Club's fall horse show today.

Dr. William N. Guthrie celebrated the beginning of his twenty-fifth year as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church, St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, yesterday in a service developed by the rector as a means of transmitting the message of God to the people through the media of art and beauty.

News was received here yesterday of the death of Kurtis (Kurt) Brownell, a young tenor known in music circles as a singer of great talent and promise, who was injured fatally in an automobile accident on Saturday near Oklahoma City, Okla.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20. -- Fist fights and a near-riot flared up today at Forbes Field as the Pittsburgh Pirates registered one of the National Football League's biggest upsets in beating Chicago's Cardinals, 17 to 13.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Postal inspectors received orders today to "crack down" on booksellers who offer obscene literature to boys and girls throughout the country.

The Citizens Union, making public yesterday a report on the candidates for the Board of Aldermen in Manhattan and the Bronx, endorsed three Republican members of the board and picked out three Democrats as "qualified and preferred."

Government officials, directly and indirectly concerned with the administration of relief, joined in a symposium made public yesterday on the eve of the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs, by Gerard Swope, chairman, to insist upon a renewed emphasis on private charity.

Duck hunters of this area are not over-optimistic as they await the opening of the season tomorrow. A survey of the South Shore of Long Island by veteran gunners showed that, while the black ducks are present in fair numbers, the broadbills and teal are unusually scarce.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20. -- Studies of human brains reveal no basis for the frequently encountered theory that there are higher and lower races, according to the Bekhteroff Institute of the Brain in Leningrad, which has made examinations of more than 500 brains.

County Judge Charles Colden of Queens was a speaker last night in the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island, at the first part of the two-day testimonial dinner arranged for Frank Pisani, Brooklyn barber-shop owner, who is under indictment on charges of conspiracy and coercion.

I read with interest your editorial "The Opera Guild." It is truly so that the radio broadcasts of the opera during the last few Winters have made the Metropolitan a national institution, and I have heard of several people who, until three years ago, had never wanted to see an opera traveling many miles just for that purpose.

Former Mayor James J. Walker will not be a candidate for Mayor of New York, or for any other public office, after his return to this country, according to a letter from Mr. Walker made public here yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The number of British merchant steamers rusting for want of cargoes at their anchor chains in sheltered waters around the coast was reduced from 327 to 215 in the past twelve months, according to a Chamber of Shipping announcement tonight.
The text of former Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney's letter to Dr. Theodor Lewald, charging discrimination by Germans against non-Nazi athletes to be proved follows:

At the annual Fall meeting of the { executive committee of the UnitedI States Figure Skating Association, i held yeaterdy at the r Association, it was announced that tlle national senior championships, which wiU constitute Olympic team try-outs, will be held in New York just before Christmas.

ROME, Oct. 20. -- The news from East Africa today shows a resumption of warlike activities on the Ethiopian side. There are signs that the Somaliland front may soon come into prominence, for it appears Emperor Haile Selassie is planning an offensive against the Italian forces there to counterbalance the Italians' gain in the north.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 20 (AP). -- The government weather bureau here reported tonight that a late-season tropical storm with winds of hurricane force near its centre was moving northeastward through the Caribbean Sea near the course of the cruiser Houston, with President Roosevelt aboard.

WOODBURY, N.J., Oct. 20. -- One man was killed and three injured today when an automobile in which they were riding skidded off the road at Hessian Road and Crown Point Road, Verga, near here, and crashed into a pole. All were from Philadelphia.

Praising the work of the Federal Hospital for Lepers at Carville, La., the Rev. Dr. William Danner, general secretary of the American Leper Mission, revealed in his sermon yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street, that of the 750 lepers admitted to the hospital since 1921 a total of 171 have been paroled as "symptom free."
BERLIN, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Hans Kerrl, Minister of Church Affairs, ordered a halt today on all police action on "church politics to bring about peace in church affairs."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 20. -- A census of the population of Turkey was carried out today under the supervision of Mr. Bruchweiler, chief of statistics of Switzerland. The whole population had to stay indoors from dawn until 3 P.M. while special officials visited every dwelling place and registered the answers of every inhabitant to sixteen questions.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Sidney Smith, The Chicago Tribune comic strip artist and creator of "The Gumps," was killed early this morning in an automobile collision near the limits of Harvard, an Illinois city near the Wisconsin line.
The improvement in the cotton-manufacturing industry in this country and in England that began early in August, is continuing, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Miss Josephine Deubler's brown mare Huntley Glen triumphed in the open jumping competition, the feature of the semi-annual Princeton Horse Show that was staged on the estate of Captain and Mrs. C.B. Kellogg today.

ADIGRAT, Ethiopia, Oct. 19 (Delayed). -- The Italian army's forward movements are obviously continuing along the now classic line, which is to occupy a strategic spot, consolidate it, thoroughly establish the necessary supply lines and build roads, and only then move forward. This is what is being done at Adigrat.

Net income of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for the third quarter of this year amounted to $6,154,725 after provision for income and other taxes, interest, depreciation and other charges. The earnings are equivalent to 69 cents a share on 9,000,743 shares outstanding.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Discussing trading in corn and the action of the market, a trader who long has followed the conditions surrounding the corn trade said today that "one must be absolutely right and have all the leading factors in his favor to make big profits in corn."

Chains, mail order houses and jobbers placed a huge volume of business last week on men's swimming trunks and two-piece slide-fastener bathing suits, because of the likelihood that present low prices will not prevail much longer, selling agents reported yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- Developments in the Italo-Ethiopian situation this week were the principal market preoccupation. Some recovery occurred at the opening when it seemed that military sanctions were definitely out of the picture and it was hoped that Premier Laval's negotiations, even if they did not succeed in obtaining an immediate amicable arrangement, would, at least, cause a lifting of the tension between England and Italy.
Jews in America need have no fear for their freedom, Rabbi Louis I. Newman said yesterday in a sermon at the Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- No attempt will be made here to change existing machinery for getting the needy on work-relief jobs, although with the Nov. 1 goal set by President Roosevelt but ten working days off, the program is over 2,000,000 jobs short of its goal.

Young women, headed by Miss Reva Marie Tonnele, are taking an active interest in the luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, which will be held tomorrow in the Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Ten persons were injured, four seriously, in a strange automobile accident here early this morning in which one car, driverless, plunged on for a block after a crash, breaking through a hardware store window, while five girls in the back seat of the other were pinned so tightly by the impact that fire apparatus had to be called to pry them out.

What region or subregion of the United States is without its Republican convention, conference, conventicle? These meetings of "delegates," somewhat mysteriously selected or appointed, are precious for edification: likewise for re-edification, reorganization, rejuvenation, revival.
Football reached about its halfway mark in the season with the games of the past Saturday, and by way of celebrating this produced full and complete fireworks all over the country.

Religious groups and institutions must "renovate" themselves before they can gain the confidence and support of youth, Algernon D. Black, leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, declared yesterday in an address at the meeting house of the society, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

Greater devotion to the Virgin Mary by all Christians, regardless of creed, was urged by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and Vicar General of the Archdiocese, in a sermon yesterday afternoon at the blessing of a statue of the Blessed Virgin at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, 424 West Thirty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- During September gold shipments received in the United Kingdom totaled 13,000,000, with South Africa sending 5,250,000 and India 4,750,000. Exports of the metal were 20,365,732, the United States taking 15,984,083, France 1,500,000, Sweden 1,000,000, Holland 92,104 and Switzerland 885,724.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- Despite favorable developments in business in Germany, including increased profits in the steel industry and the Reich's substantial surplus of exports in September, financial and industrial circles in Berlin continued this week to show a reserve in their outlook and quotations on the Boerse sagged further.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 19 (Delayed). -- As the days pass it is becoming more than obvious that Aksum will assume great importance in the near future. Many indications point to its resurrection by the Italians to its ancient grandeur as a religious and historic centre.

Senator NORRIS of Nebraska announces that, as a good nominal Republican, he expects to support President ROOSEVELT for re-election next year. The Republican party might win him back if it would nominate Senator BORAH. But he sees no likelihood of that.
A record high temperature turned Indian Summer into Summer yesterday and brought a Fall revival of resort activities and the Sunday traffic problem.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct, 20. -- Dapper Paul Runyan, the defending champion, unperturbed by alternate wind, rain and sunshine, played well-nigh perfect golf today as he led the way into the quarterfinals of the National P.G.A. tournament.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Trading on the Stock Exchanges in warrants and rights and securities subject to rights on a when-issued basis, which was terminated by the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, may be resumed under regulations announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, surrounded, however, with restrictions which the commission believes will prevent any of the abuses which formerly had been charged.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 20 -- Despite the abundant rainfalls last week throughout the cereal belt, the present outlook is that Argentina will have little or no wheat to export. While the bounteous rains give hope that the quality of the grains will be better than had been expected, they were too late to produce much difference in the area already sown Nevertheless, both the spot and futures grain markets closed very weak yesterday.

ITALIAN ARMY FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Northern Ethiopia, Oct. 19 (Delayed). -- General Emilio de Bono, commander-in-chief of Fascist forces in East Africa, who has freed the slaves of Tigre Province, was called upon today to solve the problems arising from their liberation.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, is among those due to arrive on the French liner Normandie, which is making her last trip for this year from Havre via Plymouth. Also on board are the Maharanee of Kapurthala, the Duke of Sutherland, Brig. Gen. Charles H. Merrill, Mr. and Mrs. Whitney Warren and William Nelson Cromwell. Others are:

An instantly favorable impression was registered by Maurice Ames, the possessor of an admirably pure mezzo-soprano voice, which was heard for the first time hereabouts at the Town Hall last night. Comely of person, sincere and direct in her approach to the work in hand, the young Boston society matron, in private life Mrs. Frederick. L. Ames, achieved some noteworthy singing during the course of the evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Hank Greenberg, the Bronx boy who went West to become the batting star of the world-champion Tigers, today was designated the most valuable American League player of 1935.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. A. Newbold Morris have joined Mrs. Newbold Morris at Brookhurst, Lenox, and she had a dinner party for them tonight. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Charles Astor Bristed, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease, Mr. and Mrs. Owen Johnson, Mr. and Mrs. Hayden Channing, Harris Fahnestock and Giraud Foster.

In trade and on the markets, there was no interruption last week to the spirit of conservative cheerfulness. For production and distribution, mid-October reaches traditionally the high mark of the year, but it is not the date for largest retail buying.

In accordance with the revised methods for liquidating and rehabilitating defunct banks, loan associations and insurance companies in New Jersey through a centralized management, Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, has announced that the institutions to be included in the banking section for liquidation are:

Bert L. Todd, general secretary of the United Licensed Officers Association, announced yesterday that a new wage scale and set of working conditions had been received from the United States Shipping Board, superseding the last scale issued in 1929.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Rolland B. Steele, 24, of Eutaw, Ala., was stabbed fatally in an unexplained encounter in the old French quarter of New Orleans early today.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 20. -- An experiment in speed of the 11-foot 6-inch dinghies of the North American Dinghy Association and the 14-foot ones of British international recognition was tried here today at the regatta of the Thames Yacht Club.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 20. -- A brilliant exhibition of place-kicking by Tar Schwammel, former Oregon State tackle, featured the Green Bay Packers' 13-to-9 victory over the Detroit Lions in a National Football League game today before a crowd of 8,000.

The statement in your columns by Thomas W. Lamont that bankers and business men did not draw this country into the World War would be more convincing if he would explain the cable sent by Ambassador Waiter Hines Page to President Wilson on March 5, 1917, which read in part as follows:
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20. -- Twenty-three billion elbows bent and 23,000,000,000 beers went down 23,000,000,000 throats in the United States during the last year, C.D. Williams stated today.

The Long Island Lighting Company, in a condensed statement of earnings for the year ended on Sept. 30, released for publication today, reported gross revenues of $11,356,267 from all sources, compared with $11,224,841 for the preceding year. Net income after all charges, including retirement expenses and taxes, was $2,508,306, compared with $2,417,333.

A statistic-buttressed reply to Chancellor Hitler's recent charge that Jewish elements predominated in the Communist movement in Germany was made public here last night by Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the American Jewish Committee; Alfred Cohen, president of the B'nai B'rith, and B.C. Vladeck, chairman of the Jewish Labor Committee.

Nothing could be more timely than ex-Senator STRAUS'S report on European housing. The sharp curtailment and demonstrated weaknesses of the Federal program have forced a reconsideration of American policy. When Congress reassembles there is certain to be renewed agitation for the adoption of some such long-range policy as that embodied in the Wagner bill.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- The legal battle between the city of Mount Vernon and deacons of St. Paul's Episcopal Church at Eastchester, over the question whether Potter's Field, adjoining the church property, is overcrowder with graves, may be settled this week when the city will seek a special order to take possession of a "Queen Anne's parcel" of land.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Oct. 20. -- A campaign to stop alleged Philadelphia residents from voting in Ocean County, N.J., was started here today with the arrest of six persons who have Summer homes in the County, on charges of driving automobiles with Pennsylvania license plates.

ROME, Oct. 20. -- Persons passing the Palazzo Venezia and the Palazzo Chigi, seats respectively of the offices of government and the Foreign Ministry, saw them ablaze with lights up to a late hour tonight. It is obvious that the whole staff of the Foreign Ministry is working overtime and that negotiations among London, Rome and Paris for a solution of the European deadlock arising out of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict are being actively continued.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- France's Premier, Pierre Laval, scored a double-I barreled personal victory today in the Senatorial elections, which sawi the country slightly drifting to the l Left. Laval won two seats in the Senate in what was regarded as a virtual plebiscite both on his careful Italo-Ethiopian policy and his drastic moves to maintain economic stability at home.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 20. -- The weather in Hot Springs has made the Autumn colony the most active in years. During the day the trails, tennis courts and golf courses are thronged, and the evenings are devoted to entertaining. There were many parties over the week-end.

Dernell Every, veteran swordsman of the New York Athletic Club, surprised a large gallery at the Fencers Club yesterday as he topped a field of twenty-five candidates in the first of a series of Olympic foils team tryouts. The former intercollegiate titleholder's conquest was his first in his comeback to foils fencing.

Several more galleries will reopen this week and a number of group exhibitions also are on the calendar. The Museum of Modern Art, moreover, will initiate with a reception on Thursday evening an exhibition of models and photographs of the work of Le Corbusier, the French architect and designer.

Plastic surgeons in particular must have rejoiced in the good week-end news from the Mediterranean. The number of faces that were saved is truly impressive. England's face was saved because she consented to withdraw her heavy cruisers only after MUSSOLINI agreed to cut down his forces in Libya.

Max Reinhardt's next production for Warner Brothers will be a film of William Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night," in which Marion Davies is to be starred. Mr. Reinhardt now is in Hollywood but is due in New York soon to produce "The Road to Promise" as a stage spectacle, after which he will return to the Coast to direct his second screen venture.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Rockefeller trustees announced today a generous conditional offer to aid the National Hospital, the world's leading centre for the treatment and study of nervous diseases.

Declaring the action of Chicago's Mayor to be "high-handed," Sam H. Grisman, co-owner with Jack Kirkland of "Tobacco Road," said yesterday at his offices here that "we will fight it if we have to go to the highest court in Illinois."

Former Mayor James J. Walker and Mrs. Walker are now expected to sail for New York this week aboard the Manhattan of the United States Lines. The Manhattan leaves Hamburg tomorrow, and touches at Southampton and Havre on Thursday. Mr. and Mrs. Walker are expected to come aboard at Havre.

The original Frazier-Lemke measure was declared unconstitutional in a unanimous opinion by the Supreme Court on the grounds that private property could not be taken for public use without just compensation. The decision, handed down May 27 in the Radford case, was given the same day the court declared the NIRA invalid.

At the battle of Antietam A.W. GREELY -- then a private, later a major general -- was shot in the face. Struggling to his feet, he was struck by another bullet in the left thigh. Outside the door of the field hospital to which he found his way the next day amputated arms and legs were piled up "like cordwood."

Mayor La Guardia and former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, counsel to the Consolidated Gas system, in debating last night the merits or demerits of a municipal yardstick power plant for New York, raised two points which hitherto had not figured in the dispute.

James Malcolm Robertson Jr., 25 years old, of 581 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, a former Duke University athlete, according to the police, was held last night on charges of assault and robbery, at the Parkville police station, Brooklyn.

George 3.. Miltenberger of Yonkers took over under foreclosure the two-story brick] clubhouse on plot 65x100 at the southwest { corner of Hutton St. and Cambridge Av.. 1 Jersey CitY. The parcel, owned by Arlon] of Jersey City, was sold under foreclosure of a mortgage on which $7,145 was due.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- The sudden explosion of high-powered fuel intended for propelling rockets on flights into the stratosphere caused injuries to a woman spectator yesterday during a series of tests on a vacant lot in the Crestwood section of this city.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Ethiopian Legation issued a statement today challenging the denial of the Italian Ambassador to London that the Italians were using poison gas and dum dum and explosive bullets in their African warfare.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 21. -- Italian officials announced today that the Fascist Southern Army in Ethiopia was pushing northward in an attempt to capture Gorahai, in Ogaden Province.
ON BOARD THE HOUSTON En Route to Charleston, S.C., Oct. 21.--President Roosevelt's cruiser bucked high seas today to keep well in front of a tropical hurricane sweeping up out of the Carribean Sea.

From last place to first is the story of Old Story's victory in the featured High Noon Purse at Empire City yesterday, where the final week of the metropolitan racing season began. Jack Westrope, apprentice sensation of a few seasons ago, had the leg up on the son of Pennant and had him home half a length in front of Malbrouk.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The Treasury has arranged for $200,000,0000 in short-term bills to mature on March 16 and is planning to redeem them in cash out of greatly increased income tax payments which are expected on that date, Acting Secretary T.J. Coolidge disclosed today.

Opposition by the parents' organization of Public School 44, 176th Street and Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, to the conversion of the institution into a junior high school led Joachim R. Scoppa, principal of the school, to disband the group and establish a new organization, the officers of which he designated himself, Mrs. Robert V. Russell, president of the United Parents Associations, declared yesterday.
A mortgage for $15,000 on 238 East 30th St. was asisned by Lewis A. Ebling to the Mastan Co., Inc. The Central Savings Bank assigned to William D. Whelen a, mortgage for $8,000 on 428 1st Av.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Investigation of weather conditions in the upper air, important for regular forecasting and for safe air transport, will be speeded up and facilitated by an instrument called a radio-meteorograph, recently perfected at the Blue Hill meteorological observatory of Harvard University.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The right of the Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey to proceed against, the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen of Philadelphia, fundamentalist leader who refused to obey a mandate of the General Assembly to resign from the Independent Board for Presbyterian Missions, was challenged here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor in conference here today disapproved a resolution which would have put it on record as opposing the Social Security Act and as supporting the Lundeen "workers' unemployment and social insurance" bill.

Mr. Priestley, the pawky Yorkshireman who wrote "The Good Companions" and made every one feel better, has turned up here with another play, "Eden End," which was acted by an English cast at the Masque last evening. It would be pleasant to be able to enjoy it.

A program of piano music by composers who are household words was played last night in the Town Hall by Marjorie Garrigue. This program contained music of such astonishing originality, freshness, variety of statement and of form as to emphasize the extreme probability that the great period of music for the keyed instrument has come and gone.

VIENNA, Oct. 21. -- A sensation was created by the publication today of the memoirs of former Crown Princess Stephanie, now Countess Lonyay, widow of Crown Prince Rudolf, who committed suicide at Mayerling in 1889. The Vienna police confiscated the book this evening.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau was quoted on his arrival here yesterday on the Normandie as having declared that the flow of gold to the United States was not being drawn from European central banks; that "we are not even absorbing the world's output of newly mined gold."

The continued absence of William (Daddy) Kelton, protege of the Times Square Mission, at 104 West Forty-third Street, who disappeared on Saturday, had reduced that institution to a state that bordered on mourning yesterday. A melancholy notice descriptive of the lost "pianist, soloist and penman" was put in its windows; the police had been informed, but the mission authorities kept hoping against hope.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Fairbanks, Morse Co., century-old machinery makers, submitted today to stockholders a plan of recapitalization designed to wipe out arrears of dividends on the preferred stock and place holders of the common shares in a position to participate in profits of the company at an earlier date than is possible in the present circumstances.

GENEVA, Oct. 21. -- The death of Arthur Henderson caused genuine sorrow here. Of all the statesmen Geneva has known there is probably none except the late Aristide Briand who aroused such respect, trust and affection as Mr. Henderson. Geneva has a better chance, perhaps, to compare the world's statesmen than other cities.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that beginning on Nov. 1 he would enforce the use of new safety cans for kerosene which will cost householders from $3 to $3.50, depending upon the size of the container.

Armistice Day is but a few weeks off, and already plans are being made for its observance. We shall see detachments of the army and navy parade our streets and a very impressive and stirring sight the uniformed men will make.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 21. -- Registering his first triumph since August, J.U. Grattan's 2-year-old Grog captured the $2,500 Woonsocket Claiming Stakes by a half length over B. Blume's Silver Fleece today. A crowd of 8,000 attended the opening of Narragansett Park's third meeting of the season.

Your editorial "Governor Hoffman's Issue" in THE TIMES of Oct. 8 shattered an illusion. It was as though Jove had discarded his robes and his thunderbolts and had descended, attired in rompers, to shoot small firecrackers in some earthly kindergarten.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- While shadowy "peace proposals" continued to be discussed in Rome and Paris today, the British Government unexpectedly announced a policy of neutrality that may hamper Italy seriously in conducting the Ethiopian war.

PARIS, Oct. 21.--The Bourse today buoyantly mirrored the improvement in the international outlook as clarified over the week-end Trading, especially in the early part of the session, was more active than in several weeks, and the entire market responded to the pace set by the rentes, which registered considerable advances.

Fred Sabella, 24 years old, slayer of a plainclothes patrolman in an apartment hold-up in November, 1933, tried to change his plea of guilty to a charge of second-degree murder to not guilty in General Sessions yesterday when he heard Judge Koenig's sentence of twenty-five years to life imprisonment in Sing Sing.

Louis Ware has been elected president of the United Electric Coal Companies, it was announced yesterday. He and Samuel F. Phillips have been made directors, bringing the membership of the board up to eleven.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 21. -- Although he was able to prolong the contest through another long sitting, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, was defeated by Dr. Max Euwe today in the eighth game of their series for the title.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 21 (AP). -- L.E. Komorous's Albert D. scored a handy victory in the Henderson Purse, today's feature at Churchill Downs.

Engagements of gold abroad for shipment here and reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York were confined to $3,000,000, taken in France. This reduced flow of the metal to the United States coincided with a further rise of 1/8 point in the franc to 6.59 3/8 cents, which put the French monetary unit above the gold-import point.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The probability that a formal naval conference will be held in London within six weeks was disclosed by high authoritative sources today. The conference would be held among the United States, Britain, Japan, France and Italy.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 21. -- Frank V. Miller, a vice president and director of the Thomas H. Hall Corporation, 180 Madison Avenue, New York City, manufacturers of cloth fabrics, committed suicide at 6:30 A.M. today at his home here, 66 Litchfield Road, by shooting himself after placing a pistol barrel in his mouth.

HAVANA, Oct. 21. -- A tropical hurricane roared northeastward into the Windward Passage between Cuba and Haiti tonight, after high winds and rain had heavily damaged Jamaica's banana crop during the day. Residents of two Cuban towns fled inland from the fury of rising seas.
ROME, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini, pressing on with his war in Ethiopia, went out today after the money needed to finance his campaign.

James Howell of the Salem-Crescent A.C., New York State title-holder, outpointed Paul J. Hoft of Philadelphia in the heavyweight special of the intercity amateur boxing bouts at the New York Athletic Club last night. The victor led throughout, scoring heavily with body punches.
FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 21. -- An Indian Summer sun cast its mellow warmth over the marshes of lower Great South Bay today.

Plans of a three-story office and storage building for 104-08 John Street, running through to 7-13 Platt Street, were filed with the Manhattan Department of Buildings yesterday. The estimated cost is $150,000. M.J. Harrison, architect, designed the structure for the 108 John Street Corporation of 90 John Street.

ALBANY, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Organized labor warned New York State's Works Progress Administration officials today that it would advocate Statewide strikes on WPA projects unless labor's demand for the prevailing rate of wages on such work is granted.

A resolution commending President Roosevelt for his efforts to safeguard American neutrality during the Italo-Ethiopian conflict was adopted yesterday by the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War. The committee held its annual Autumn meeting at the headquarters of the Young Women's Christian Association, 600 Lexington Avenue.

The Central Park Casino, opened in 1864 as the "Ladies' Refreshment Saloon" and now operated as a restaurant and night club, will be torn down if the city wins its long legal battle to oust the corporation, Park Commissioner Moses declared yesterday.

I read with great interest in THE NEW YORK TIMES an article "New Cotton Roads to Start Tuesday," and would like to draw your attention and of those specially interested that similar tests were made in Austria during 1931 and to a greater extent during 1934 and 1935.

Angelo Herndon, 22-year-old Negro Communist, who starts tomorrow for Georgia to serve a sentence of eighteen to twenty years for inciting to violence, was the principal speaker at a meeting yesterday in Union Square called by the International Labor Defense to protest the refusal of the United States Supreme Court to intervene in his case.
ROME, Oct. 21. -- The fighting at Dagnerrei was described in an official Italian communique today as follows:

Under hedging pressure that equaled any this season, prices on the Cotton Exchange yielded 5 to 13 points yesterday and closed at the bottom. Selling appeared to be centred mainly in the January and March positions, which declined to the lowest quotations since Oct. 2, prior to the upward movement following developments in Africa.

The "economic interpretation of history," a doctrine once confined largely to Marxian Communists, has become fashionable in much wider circles. People talk as if wars would never be started if it were not for the sinister schemes of munitions makers, or at least if they were not undertaken for trade expansion, colonial exploitation, the "needs" of a growing home population, or some other basically economic end.

Currency stabilization is no closer than it was last Spring, but America is ready for it when the foreign countries are ready, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, said yesterday. The United States "can still deflate the dollar further should conditions abroad require it," he added.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 21. -- Ferenc Molnar's latest play, "The Great Love," a three-act comedy, had a world premiere at Vigszinhaz here on Saturday. It was a great success. The play is considered by Hungarian critics, almost unanimously, as one of the writer's best works.

Price movements were erratic trading in the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Silk continues its advance and copper reacted sharply. On the cash markets, silk made a new high price and corn, flour and rubber also advanced. Cotton, wheat and tin declined.
