Officials of the Works Progress Administration and the office of the Borough President of Manhattan announced yesterday that they hoped to complete by Thanksgiving Day the paving of the last section of Madison Avenue, between Fifty-ninth and Eighty-second Streets.

GENEVA, Oct. 21.--The League of Nations delivered to non-member nations today a documentation of all its actions in the Italo-Ethiopian war, beginning with its judgment of Oct. 7 declaring the Italian Government had violated the League Covenant and the Kellogg-Briand anti-war pact by resorting to war.

Ready for drilling despite a rough voyage, the eight jumpers which will carry the hopes of the Irish Free State's Army Horse Show team in the National Horse Show, Nov. 6 to 12, arrived here yesterday on the United States Line's American Importer.

Speedier competition in motor boating and more of it seems forecast for 1936 regattas on the basis of a new liberality and latitude in the sport which officials adopted last night at the Hotel Lexington on the first of four days of rule-making.

The new Erdmann Auditorium of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, named in honor of Dr. John F. Erdmann, former director of surgery of the institution, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon in the presence of a distinguished gathering of surgeons and physicians.

Accompanied by many gifts from various Japanese cities to the City of New York, Mr. and Mrs. America, the two life-size wax dolls sent to Japan on May 28 by Mayor La Guardia returned to the Mayor's office in City Hall yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 21. -- With a sensational 67, six strokes under par, Al Ciuci, Fresh Meadow professional, and Lester Rice of Lido annexed first honors in today's pro-amateur event held by the Long Island Golf Association over the Lakeville club course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- A tentative draft of regulations for the control of bank loans for purchasing or carrying equity securities will be in the hands of the Federal Reserve Board before the end of this week, experts indicated today. The board is expected to submit the proposals to the SEC, member banks, Stock Exchanges and other interested parties for comment and criticism before they are promulgated as regulations.

Late October leases in Manhattan apartment buildings were reported yesterday as being numerous. A feature of the rentals was the large number of Park Avenue suites taken. Among those who have just rented large ones in that district are Mrs. Henry W. Banks, Barron Collier Jr. and Robert W. McLaughlin.

After a public hearing conducted on the demands of the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies, the Emergency Relief Bureau announced yesterday that it would reconsider its decision to dismiss part of the ERB staff and would reveal its findings tomorrow.

Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, American member of the International Olympic Committee, declined emphatically yesterday to support a movement for the withdrawal of American athletes from the 1936 Olympic Games, to be held in Germany.

United States Government issues held the limelight in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as domestic corporation bonds stayed within narrow limits, with closing prices mixed. The day's sales amounted to $9,701,000, compared with $10.328,000 on Friday.

A compromise agreement under which Fred W.I. Lundy is to pay $655.35 in settlement to the government resulted yesterday in the withdrawal by the government of its civil suit to confiscate Lundy's restaurant at 1,901 Emmons Avenue, Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. The suit was pending in the Federal Court.

Before the Labor party had been so named ARTHUR HENDERSON was a Labor representative in the House of Commons. To his shrewdness, judgment and remarkable gift for organization the party owed much of its growth and success, though it never had a majority in the House.

Although the manuscript of Virginia Woolf's new novel has not yet been received here, Harcourt, Brace, who intend to publish the book in the Spring, have now learned the title. The novel will be called "The Years."

Women were hailed as pioneers in philanthropic work by Mrs. Oliver Harriman yesterday in an address at the first report luncheon of campaign workers of the women's division of the Federation for Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at the Hotel Commodore.

How to police the parks properly is a problem that has vexed the city authorities for many years. Under the present administration cooperation between the Police Department and the Park Department has brought about some improvement, but conditions are still unsatisfactory.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- In a new publication entitled "Totalitarian War," General Erich Ludendorff demands immediate appointment of a general as new supreme war lord in command not only of the armed forces but also of politics and economics in order that in peace he may prepare the nation for war and in war employ all its physical and moral resources for defeat of the enemy.

It would appear that just as Nero fiddled while Rome burned, so, today, the responsible citizen is little concerned in the appalling poverty which is evidenced by more than ten millions of unemployed, over twenty millions of families upon relief with prevailing wages and salaries only a fraction of what they should normally be, a direct result of our schools and colleges having neglected instruction in that most important of all sciences, political economy.

The improvement in general business activity, developing during the last three months, continued through September and the first half of October, according to the regular monthly survey of business conditions released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Representative James W. Wadsworth opened the National Economy League's new drive for a balanced budget at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday at which he declared that to "weather this storm" the next administration at Washington must be prepared to say "no to an infinite variety of unsound proposals," and "tread on the toes of a great many people who have come to the belief that the government owes them a living."

Samuel Glickman, 43 years old, a beer pipe cleaner, of 990 Leggett Avenue, the Bronx, was burned to death in an automobile he was driving when the gasoline tank exploded following a collision with another machine in Fifth Avenue north of Seventy-first Street at 3:50 A.M. yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Fifty corporation executives and bankers visited the research laboratories and works of the General Electric Company today under the auspices of the National Research Council's division of engineering and industrial research, and learned how research is conducted and what new discoveries have been made and developed in these lean years of the depression.
" Harmony Lane," featuring Douglass Montgomery and Evelyn Venable, opens with a preview tonight at the Astor after the last screening of "Little America."

The Supreme Court yesterday gave the Federal Government three weeks in which to show why Georgia should not be allowed to file suit against the Bankhead Cotton Control Act. Permission to take such action has been sought on behalf of Governor TALMADGE.

The Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, provide at the moment an excellent opportunity to compare the various stages of Claude Monet's development as the pontifex maximus of French impressionism. This show, composed of thirteen canvases, opened yesterday and will continue until Nov. 9.

Under the leadership of Miss Alice Olson, senior president, the Barnard College Athletic Association yesterday inaugurated its annual Sport Week. The main event of the afternoon was an informal swimming meet in which Miss Irene Lacey of the junior class won the diving contest and several dozen students participated in novelty tandem and spoon races.

By modifying provisions which had governed the processing of sugar since March 16, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration over the week-end in effect made refiners independent both of the spot sugar market and 1935 sugar futures contracts, under certain conditions.

This evening's contribution to the life along Times Square will be the William Jourdan Rapp-Leonardo Bercovici play called "Substitute for Murder." It will open at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, with Francis Lister, Jessie Royce Landis, Myron McCormick, Tucker McGuire, Robert Sloane and Ruth Gates in the cast.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 21. -- Adhering to the precedent of previous Emperors, Emperor Haile Selassie has decided to have in his company when he goes to battle a dummy official who will be almost his double.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 21. -- Enterprise, the America's Cup defender five years ago, which Harold S. Vanderbilt called the "white ghost of the western ocean," has gone to an ignominious end in a junk heap.

MUSSOLINI has abolished free elections in Italy, but his vanity might be stirred by the obvious fact that he is a powerful influence in the elections of other countries. This is not exactly a tribute to him.

Extensions of the city's 2 per cent sales tax, 3 per cent utility tax and one-tenth of 1 per cent business tax through the first half of 1936 to raise an estimated $33,500,000 for relief are being prepared by Corporation Counsel Paul Windels and officials of the Finance Department, it was learned yesterday.

A twelve-story apartment house at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street has been sold by the 550 Park Avenue Corporation to a group represented by M. Carl Levine, attorney. The structure, which contains sixty suites of six to nine rooms, is on a plot 100 by 164 feet.

Harry Dublinsky, Chicago welter-weight, and Izzy Jannazzo, sturdy east sider, who battled to a draw recently, repeated their act last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, where they fought again on even terms in an exciting ten-rounder.

The report of Nathan Straus, the Mayor's Special Housing Commissioner, urging the adoption of a long-range housing program with Federal grants to wipe out New York's slums, inspired mixed comment yesterday from realty men and other interests.

Louis Waldman of 302 Broadway issued a statement yesterday challenging Colonel James V. Heidt to join him in requesting President Roosevelt to order "a thorough and impartial investigation" of conditions at Fort Clayton in the Panama Canal Zone.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Fears grew tonight that all thirty-seven men aboard the freighter Vardulia had been lost after entering their lifeboats 400 miles west of the Hebrides Islands in the storm-tossed. Atlantic, as more than fifty hours passed without word of their fate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Trinity Church scored a victory in the Supreme Court today when that tribunal refused to interfere with a lower court decision holding the church entitled to the valuable parcel of land roughly bounded on the north by Christopher Street, on the east by an irregular line just west of Broadway, on the south by Charlton Street, and on the west by the Hudson River.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday net assets of $62,657,248 on Sept. 30, consisting of securities valued at market quotations at $60,630,968 and cash and receivable items amounting to $2,026,280. The net assets were equivalent to $21.66 a share of the trust's stock.

Thomas W. Lamont's letter in THE TIMES under the heading "A World War Myth" is so admirable in substance and in form, takes up so many aspects of the subject and deals so effectively with each of them that any attempt to add to its force would be like painting the lily.

Aided by favorable news here and abroad, the stock market rose to the highest level in more than four years yesterday. With public participation in the trading at a new high level for this year, the turnover on the Stock Exchange totaled 2,872,000 shares, the heaviest for any day since July 26, 1934.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Most Rev. Cosmo Gordon Lang, Archbishop of Canterbury, revealed at a Canterbury diocesan conference today that he had already approached Pope Pius XI in an appeal for peace among the churches of Europe.

ISIDOR SCHNEIDER'S "From the Kingdom of Necessity" (Putnam, $2.50) follows, for some of its course, the usual path of the "melting pot" novel. But because the story is about a singularly warm-hearted, intense individual who cannot spin out of himself a protective shell of irony or reach a decision to confront a materialistic world on its own competitive terms, the flavor is sui generis.

Local, State and Federal officials hailed the $8,000,000 Brooklyn Beach Gardens apartment project at Cropsey and Twenty-first Avenues as a "great enterprise" at ceremonies yesterday marking the beginning of the work. A huge dredge was put in operation in Gravesend Bay to make part of the land now under water available for building purposes.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- A long scrimmage between the second and third string varsity players and a scrub eleven featured Princeton's workout on University Field today. Coach Fritz Crisler also had his regulars in uniform, sending them through a long signal drill.

TOKYO, Oct. 21. -- The hitherto unproductive conferences between officials representing Manchukuo and Outer Mongolia, at Manchuli, which have been going on intermittently since June, are approaching a decisive stage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The Supreme Court today refused to review the efforts of The Washington Evening Star to deduct contributions to the community chest when computing its taxable net income.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 21. -- Taking the narrow defeat by Yale only as a spur to greater efforts against Notre Dame in Baltimore Saturday, the Navy squad began special preparations today for the contest with the Ramblers. Not only is a much stronger Notre Dame team than that of the past two seasons expected by Navy, but also one which is determined to prevent the scoring of three successive victories against it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Oct. 16, issued by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows decreases for the week of $76,000,000 in total loans and investments and, $88,000,000 in government deposits and increases of $20,000,000 (including government deposits) in net demand deposits, $9,000,000 in time deposits and $167,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Oct. 22. -- A distinct atmosphere of appeasement became apparent in Chino-Japanese relations yesterday as the series of conferences between Japanese diplomatic, army and navy officials in China and special envoys from Tokyo were ended.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Yale being next on Army's schedule, the Cadets began today their preparations for that contest. Coach Gar Davidson sent them through a long practice session on the plains, following a blackboard lecture. Defense against the Elis' attack was stressed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 21. -- An Italian commercial mission arrived today on the liner Conte Grande, Headed by Albert Asquini, sub-secretary of Corporations, and four others, the mission will first visit Buenos Aires and then return here. According to Mr. Asquini, the mission is strictly commercial.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- An issue of $60,000,000 of short-term notes of New York State bearing interest at the rate of 30-100 of 1 per cent was awarded today by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, who stated they would mature on June 22, 1936.

Raiding a manufacturing furrier's shop on the sixteenth floor of the loft building at 245 West Twenty-ninth Street at 4:40 P.M. yesterday, two youthful robbers swiftly selected $30,000 worth of the finest furs in the place and escaped after locking five employes in a storage vault.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Foreign trade in September increased over the same month a year ago, the Department of Commerce said today in its monthly summary. Exports increased 4 per cent in value and imports 23 per cent. Compared with August, exports were up 15 per cent, about the normal seasonal increase, while imports declined 4 per cent, which was more than the usual seasonal decline.

Barent W. Van Kleeck, 67 years old, insurance broker who was socially prominent in Philadelphia, was killed shortly before 7 P.M. last night when he fell or jumped from an upper floor of the Hotel Shelton, 525 Lexington Avenue, at Forty-ninth Street.

The announcement of Secretary of Agriculture Wallace that after Nov. 25 the live poultry industry in New York City and in Jersey City would be under Federal regulation met a mixed reception here yesterday. Dealers and public officials expressed the opinion that the licensing plan would go far toward eliminating unwholesome conditions in the $30,000,000 industry.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade fluctuated today within a range of a little more than a cent a bushel. Outside trade was relatively light and local sentiment was mixed. There was a recession of around 1/2 cent early in sympathy with prices in Winnipeg, but the loss was more than recovered on buying induced by an unexpected decrease in the domestic visible supply.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- The Boerse was quiet but firm today. The heavy industrials registered an average rise of one-quarter to one-half point. Potashes were almost without move but Salzdetfurth gained 2 points on the last quotation, which was on Oct. 18.

A resolution adopted by the American Federation of Labor against taking part in the Olympic Games to be held in Berlin next year is only one more sign of a sentiment which has been visibly growing in this country. It will be strengthened by the letter of ex-Judge MAHONEY published in THE TIMES yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- While the Pennsylvania football squad rested today after its victory over Columbia, the 1933 Red and Blue schedule was announced by H. Jamison Swarts, director of athletics.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Declaring that the country has reached a period of "partial recovery," Dr. George F. Warren of Cornell University, financial expert and former adviser to President Roosevelt, told 1,300 delegates to the Grange League Federation Exchange today that better times can be expected in the future.

The disclosure that rings of loan sharks have been operating in the WPA and victimizing many workers employed on WPA projects was made yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, who announced his determination to put a stop to these activities.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- With a brilliant exhibition of sub-par golf, Dick Chapman of Winged Foot and Mike Turnesa of Fairview romped off with the honors in the final one-day Westchester P.G.A. best-ball tournament of the season today over the difficult Suningdale Country Club course.

One of the longest seasons in its history will be conducted by the National Hockey League in the campaign that gets under way next month. The official schedule, released yesterday by President Frank Calder, reveals that competition will start on Nov. 7, and continue regularly until March 22.

VIENNA, Oct. 21. -- Ladislaus Benes, editor of the American-European Press Service, was released tonight after his completion of a sentence of five days' rigorous imprisonment for having communicated to Anglo-American journalists in Vienna current rumors that were adjudged "alarming, incorrect and damaging to the State."

The first year's operation of a nation-wide system of distribution for works by contemporary American artists organized as the Associated American Artists has resulted in the establishment of outlets in seventy-seven cities and receipts of $16,275, according to announcement yesterday at the headquarters of the organization at 366 Madison Avenue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Jim Maser, who started at right tackle against Holy Cross and Army, will be lost to the Harvard football team for Saturday's game against Dartmouth, it was announced today.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Miss Ruth Nichols, noted flier, was seriously injured and severely burned here today when a giant airliner crashed near the Troy airport. Her pilot, Captain Harry Hublitz of New York City, was fatally injured. He died in the Samaritan Hospital here at 11:55 tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- The Pan American Airways Company offered the only bid received by the Postoffice Department today for carrying airmail across the Pacific to China.

The estate of Augustus van Wyck, former Supreme Court Justice, who died June 8, 1922, was appraised yesterday at $1,006,908 gross and $910,023 net. He owned securities worth $423,554, while his interest in the estate of his brother, former Mayor Robert A. van Wyck, was valued at $336,677. He had debts of $47,271.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The formation of a nation-wide organization, under the supervision of the investment bankers conference committee, to cooperate with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the enforcement of fair practices and in the control of the over-the-counter markets was assured today when Frank L. Scheffey, director of the committee, announced that a sufficient number of bankers and dealers had signified their intention of joining such a plan to make certain its success.
It was only a nine-line notice, mailed Saturday afternoon, when its writer shut his office for the day and went to the N.Y.U. football game at the Yankee Stadium. It read:

Unable to agree after seven hours' deliberation whether or not Eugene Simson, a gold refiner, had attempted to bribe a government agent to cover up purchases of gold from unlicensed dealers, a jury before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson was discharged at 10:20 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The Supreme Court today gave the government until Nov. 11 to show cause why Georgia should not proceed with her legal attack upon the constitutionality of the Bankhead Cotton Control Law.

Reorders received by mail in the markets here yesterday reflected the retarding effect of unseasonably warm weather in many parts of the country last week. Volume was of fair proportions, but did not feature the increases which marked the two preceding weeks.

Stocks resumed their advance yesterday where they had left off on Saturday. Aided by favorable news from many fields, prices rose to the highest level of the year. Trading was the most active since July 26, 1934. Bonds shared in the upturn, but wheat was irregular and cotton was lower.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 21. -- Mrs. Louise Mattei Farry, formerly of New Jersey and Connecticut, was married here to State Senator J. Dryden Kuser of Bernardsville, N.J., this afternoon at the home of Judge Clyde D. Souter, former New Jersey jurist. The Rev. William Moll Case performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception and later by a dinner at a night club.

Settling down from the excitement of the past week-end, football continues its steady procession. The dull moments will be few and far between from now on. This Saturday the service elevens again march into the spotlight of full attention from more than their specialized following, but there are plenty of other games of more than passing interest.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 21. -- Ras Seyoum, northern commander, in establishing telephone communication with Emperor Haile Selassie today for the first time since his departure from Addis Ababa for the front, expressed horror at the desertion of Haile Selassie Gugsa. the Emperor's son-in-law. Ras Seyoum said the traitor's vassal chiefs were joining the loyal forces.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 21. -- Theodore S. Ryan gave a party in the Homestead Club this evening for Otto Madlener and his brother, William C. Madlener, and Miss Frances Miller. The Madlener brothers afterward entertained the party at dinner in the Colonial Room.

By an agreement between the Appellate Divisions of the four judicial departments of New York State, the presiding justices have amended the court rules so that poor persons may have lawyers assigned to them to conduct litigation. Counsel will be assigned only when a litigant can swear that he is not worth $300 in cash or available property, besides wearing apparel and furniture necessary for himself and family.
Sponsors of the 1939-40 world's fair at Flushing Meadows Park were assured yesterday of the active support of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

A jury in Supreme Court brought in a verdict of $25,000 damages against Maude Adams, stage star, yesterday in the $200,000 suit brought against her and the Erlanger interests by John D. Williams, former stage director. Justice Daniel V. McNamee reserved decision on a motion by R. Randolph Hicks, counsel for Miss Adams, to set the verdict aside as excessive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- The National Youth Administration uncovered plans today for giving a large slice of its funds to local governments, with directions for putting 94,000 young people to work at a variety of tasks.

PEORIA, Oct. 21. -- The amended Frazier-Lemke Farm Debt Relief Law was declared unconstitutional in the Federal District Court here today by Judges J. Earl Major and Charles G. Briggle. It was enacted last Spring, after the original law had been invalidated in the Supreme Court.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 21. -- A straight-shooting Westerner, Al Zimmerman of Portland, Ore., sent Paul Runyan's Professional Golf Association crown spinning from his head today, and tomorrow he will join Tommy Armour, Al Watrous and Johnny Revolta in the semi-final scramble for it.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 21. -- Poison taken because of despondency over ill health killed O.B. English, a former manufacturer, and his wife, each 60 years old, in their home here today. Two notes were found on a dressing table in the bedroom where the bodies were.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP). -- The American Bakers Association charged the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today with trying to create the "erroneous and unfair" impression that the bakers' convention was "assembled here to raise the price of bread 1 cent."

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Aunt Flor, Mrs. S. Orr's 4-year-old chestnut filly, was hard pressed from gate to wire today while taking the featured six-furlongs sprint from Antarctic by a nose at Agawam Park.
LAKE CHARLES, La., Oct. 21 (AP). -- The Port of Lake Charles, shut for ten days by strikers, was opened for business today under the machine guns of seveney-five special guards.
The clerk at the advertising counter popped out his eyes, sparred for time and looked it over again. But it read the second time just as it had the first:

Columbia's varsity football players had a day of rest yesterday, a rare occasion on Morningside Heights. Coach Lou Little wanted to give them an extra day in which to recover from the effects of their battle with Penn before starting them in quest of victory against Michigan at Baker Field on Saturday.

With the disappointing trade on Columbus Day a major factor, department-store sales in the metropolitan area showed a decline of 0.3 per cent for the first half of October, in comparison with the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the local Federal Reserve Bank.

James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, wore a sad smile at his press conference yesterday. He had a mystery to report. Mr. Lyons has reported mysteries before -- such as, who stole his hat at City Hall? And what became of the key to the detention pen in the county court house?

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Soon Over, a 4-year-old chestnut colt from the Greentree Stable, won the featured sixth race at Laurel today starting in front and maintaining a length lead throughout the mile and sixteenth.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21. -- Head Coach Ducky Pond today began preparing Yale's football squad for next Saturday's Army game in the Bowl. The varsity players, all of whom lost much weight in defeating Navy, were dismissed after an hour in which they listened to coaches' comments, ran through a few conditioning exercises under Major Frank Wandle, and passed and punted.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 21. -- Formation of a new party uniting all dry voters in a drive to outlaw the liquor traffic was urged in a resolution adopted here today by the convention of the New York State Women's Christian Temperance Union.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 21. -- A slow but forceful movement of the Italian armies into the interior of Ethiopia was seen by Ethiopians tonight as Premier Bonito Mussolini's plan of campaign, as reports from all fronts indicated general quiet.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- The heaviest receipts of hogs since Feb. 11 met a good demand today from packers and shippers, and while some early sales were regarded as off 25 cents a hundredweight from Friday's levels, the general trade was about steady to 15 cents lower.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Mayor Edward H. Kelly today revoked the license of the Selwyn Theatre in order to close the play "Tobacco Road."

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 21. -- Although the Ethiopians are watching the course of France in the current negotiations with anxious uncertainty, wondering also whether Great Britain is tending toward a less firm position, the present waiting period probably is more favorable to Ethiopia than to Italy, from the military standpoint.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 21. -- A slow but forceful movement of the Italian armies into the interior of Ethiopia was seen by Ethiopians tonight as Premier Bonito Mussolini's plan of campaign, as reports from all fronts indicated general quiet.

The report of the General Foods Corporation and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday, showed net earnings of $8,770,437, after provision for income taxes and all charges. This is equivalent to $1.67 a share on 5,251,440 shares of no-par common stock outstanding.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Mayor Edward H. Kelly today revoked the license of the Selwyn Theatre in order to close the play "Tobacco Road."

County Judge Charles S. Colden of Queens said yesterday he had been misinformed when invited to attend the dinner Sunday night to Frank Pisani at the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island. Pisani, owner of a barber shop in Brooklyn, is under indictment on charges of conspiracy and coercion for trade organization activities.

MADRID, Oct. 21. -- Several Opposition Deputies today indicated their intention to interpellate the government during the session of the Cortes tomorrow on the formal accusation made last week to Premier Joaquin Chapaprieta by Daniel Straus, a Mexican citizen, who claims to have bribed a Cabinet Minister, Deputies and other public officials in order to obtain a gambling concession in Spain.

The story of AMUNDSEN'S last journey, which has been published in Oslo, tells of his relief attempt which was a noble epilogue to a life of heroic adventure. The review in the Royal Geographical Society Journal begins with the bare record:

The administrations of President Roosevelt at Washington and of Governor Lehman at Albany were arraigned last night at a dinner given by the Republican Business Women to members of their advisory committee in the clubhouse of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. About 150 attended.

A concerted raid by members of Board of Estimate yesterday reduced a Japanese good-will offering of works of art and handicraft, which were placed on exhibition Monday in Mayor La Guardia's reception room at City Hall, to a collection of odds and ends.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today sliced up the biggest world series player melon in the history of baseball, giving each of the world's champion Tigers a cut worth $6,544.76, but he withheld the losers' shares belonging to the Cubs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated in September at 93.9 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 76.4 per cent in the previous month and 54.3 per cent in September last year.

Mayor La Guardia's order to officeholders under him to resign all party positions has caused intense resentment in the Republican organization, it was revealed yesterday. Interest has centred, it was said, in James A. Hatch, Deputy Dock Commissioner and a Republican leader of the Tenth Manhattan Assembly District.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 22 (AP). -- Miss Ruth Nichols, who is lying gravely injured in a Troy hospital, and Captain Harry Hublitz, 41, who died from burns last midnight, fought desperately to save their huge airplane before it crashed at Troy Airport yesterday, one of the four other occupants of the plane testified at an inquest today.
President Roosevelt's social-security program has whole-hearted support from most of the clergymen in the United States, the National Conference of Jews and Christians said yesterday.

At Geneva Italy's small neighbors are seeking a guarantee of aid in case economic sanctions are put into effect next week. Rumania, Yugoslavia and Greece have pointed out that from one-tenth to one-fifth of their exports go to Italy and that the plan to prohibit the sale to her of all "key war materials" will deprive them of a profitable market for such goods.
Something that left a trail like a comet streaked across the northwestern sky at about 5:10 P.M. yesterday to be lost after brief moments of brilliance in the gathering darkness.

After many years of determined opposition Edward Henry Carson achieved his main political object of preventing the domination of Protestant Ulster by the Roman Catholic majority of the South and West.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 22. -Two camps for women will open Nov. 1 at Camp Alan Johnston and James H. Palmer Lodge, recently vacated by World War veterans sent there to prevent another bonus march on Washington.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that its representatives would appear on Friday before the Board of Army Engineers at the Army Building on Whitehall Street to oppose erection of the proposed bridge over the Hudson River between Nyack and Tarrytown.

Abandonment of the existing wholesale price lines in order to enable manufacturers immediately to reflect increased costs in a rising market was endorsed yesterday at a meeting of the Council of Apparel Trade Executives at the offices of the National Blouse and Skirt Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- Charles (Gabby) Hartnett, veteran catcher of the pennant-winning Chicago Cubs, was voted the most valuable player in the National League for 1935 today by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

Because the only way a racket can be stopped is by exposure, I should like to bring to the attention of your readers a racket of which I was made the victim a few days ago when T was run into on the Boston Post Road by a negligent driver going in the opposite direction, who apparently lose control of his car.

Asserting that recuperative forces were straining at the brakes which governmental policies were clamping down, former Governor Nathan L. Miller declared last night that a radical change from the present policies of the Roosevelt administration was needed to assure a substantial economic recovery.

The French modern architect who calls himself LE CORBUSIER designs houses which lack something esthetically, but his ideas always stimulate the imagination. Arriving here, he finds that our skyscrapers are much too small, though there are too many of them.

Between 500 and 600 persons on WPA jobs have been resigning daily for the past few days to return to private industry, it was revealed yesterday at the office of Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator. This is four to five times the daily number of resignations in the ten weeks previous.

The meeting of the directors of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, to be held today, promises to be one of the most important in the history of the company. With no more banking aid available and the Interstate Commerce Commission having refused to approve another loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the New Haven has now no recourse except the Pennsylvania Railroad.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Recent mysterious stone-throwing at commuters' trains running on the Nyack branch of the Erie Railroad culminated yesterday in a rifle shot which crashed through a window of the Nyack Bankers' Flyer, wounding Edward J. Bullwinkel, 42 years old, New York stock broker who lives in Upper Nyack.

VINELAND, N.J., Oct. 22. -George J. Duggan, local coal dealer and prominent wag, finished reading his mail this morning and announced to his five employes that he might be able to give them each a six-month holiday with pay.

Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, American member of the International Olympic Committee, was denounced yesterday as anti-Semitic and un-American by organizations and individuals who are urging American athletes to boycott the Olympic Games in Berlin next year.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 22. -- The fifty industrial executives and bankers who are making a tour of research laboratories under the auspices of the National Research Council's division of engineering and industrial research listened today to an epigrammatic address by Dr. C.E.K. Mees on the manner in which research should be conducted in the light of his experience.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., yesterday reported for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $40,154,667. This was equivalent, after dividends on the debenture stock, to $3.22 a share on 11,051,343 shares of common stock, the average number outstanding for the period.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- Measures to prevent further arming and retention of arms by members of France's various political leagues are being taken by the Minister of Justice, Leon Berard, and the Minister of the Interior, Joseph Paganon, who tomorrow will submit their proposals to the Cabinet for approval.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 22. -- The Navy players went through a hard practice session today in preparation for the clash with Notre Dame in Baltimore Saturday. They engaged in a defensive scrimmage against Squad B and a session in running back kicks, a department in which there was much weakness against Yale.

Export orders originating in the Mediterranean area have not been affected, as concerns New York firms, by President Roosevelt's neutrality policy, 150 exporters, importers and shippers agreed yesterday at a round-table discussion of "war zone" problems, sponsored by the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Public offering of a new issue of $5,200,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1965, of Pennsylvania Telephone Corporation will be made today by an underwriting group composed of Bonbright Co., Inc., Paine, Weber Co. and Mitchum, Tully Co.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 22. -- After a day of deadlocked ballots in which hope of agreement was almost given up, a special convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark elected this evening the Rev. Dr. Theodore R. Ludlow, rector of the Church of the Holy Communion in South Orange, to the post of Suffragan Bishop of the Diocese.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- No material pressure appeared in wheat on the Board of Trade today, and while old-crop futures dropped about 1 cent early from selling induced by weakness in Liverpool, the loss was largely recovered later on scattered buying, with the finish 3/8 cent lower on the December and May and unchanged on the July.

ROME, Oct. 22. -- The speech of Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare in the House of Commons has confirmed and strengthened optimistic forecasts here for a solution of the Anglo-Italian and Italo-Ethiopian controversies. The Italians are impressed not so much by any change in the British Government's official attitude, for Sir Samuel in substance merely restated things that had repeatedly been said in Britain, as by the change in tone of his utterances.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The cure for crime lies in more intelligent use of society's weapons for coping with it, Dr. Sheldon Glueck, Professor of Criminology at Harvard, declared here today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22. -- The execution at Sevastopol of a White Guard officer for treason committed in 1920 and the arrest of twenty workers at the Kharkov railway station on sabotage charges, were announced by the Soviet press today. The man executed was said to have hidden his past successfully for fifteen years while serving as a Red Army commander.

Thomas W. Lamont's letter published in THE TIMES seems to me to misinterpret certain "general utterances" made in my review of Nicolson's "Dwight Morrow," to which Mr. Lamont very courteously took exception.
E. Robert Schmitz, pianist, will be heard in the first of three recitals tonight at the New Jersey College for Women.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The Federal Communications Commission authorized today the establishment of direct wireless service between New York and Addis Ababa by Press Wireless, Inc., a radio news service owned by seven American newspapers, including THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The best joke of the past week was the announcement by some eminent Republican women that they would wage war on the President on the ground that his policies have increased the cost of living.

Professor Albert Einstein and former Governor Alfred E. Smith followed each other as after-dinner speaker at the Town Hall Club last night. Together with Ewart Edmund Turner, former pastor of the American Church in Berlin, they appealed for funds to relieve political and "non-Aryan" Christian refugees from Germany now facing starvation in various parts of the world.

BERLIN, Oct. 22. -- A shortage of butter recurred in Berlin yesterday. In several sections of the city it was impossible to purchase butter. In other districts the small supply that was available was put aside by dealers for favored customers.

Business failures increased in all of the trade groups during the five business days ended Oct. 17, as compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

The City of New York won an important tax reduction suit yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Rosenman upheld the assessment on the seventeen-story apartment house at 420-430 Park Avenue. The property was assessed at $2,600,000 in 1933 and at $2,400,000 for 1934.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The blockade of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program has finally been broken, Aubrey Williams, Acting WPA Administrator, stated today. WPA projects totaling $1,500,000,000 have been approved by Controller General McCarl, Mr. Williams said, and $700,000,000 in cash is now available to WPA State administrators.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- A suit in equity to recover alleged undistributed net earnings of The Philadelphia Inquirer exceeding $5,000,000 was filed in Common Pleas Court here today by John Green of Huntington, L.I., brother-in-law of the late Eleanor Mayo Elverson, widow of Colonel James Elverson Jr.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22. -- In the effort to get his Harvard team's offense really moving, Coach Dick Harlow today drove his first land second varsities for nearly an hour and a half in straight scrimmage, first against each other and then against two scrub elevens.

The astonishing family of ten Siamese kittens, including the one that died, that Sikura Jane gave birth to sometime in the small hours on Monday, in a bathroom at 62 Washington Square, will have to do without a "foster mother," it appeared yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Colonel Jacob Ruppert was here for a brewers' convention today, but he was more willing to talk about baseball.

Charles D. Halsey, president of the board of trustees of New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital, was elected president of Fifth Avenue Hospital yesterday, succeeding H.E. Manville, who resigned. It was the first meeting of the board of Fifth Avenue Hospital since the merging last Wednesday of its activities with Flower Hospital.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22. -- Yale expects a line attack by the driving Army backs next Saturday, so today the scrubs, who were taught the West Point formations by Coach and Scout Stew Scott, demonstrated them in dummy drill against the regulars and later in a lively scrimmage against the varsity reserves.

ATLANTIC CITY. Oct. 22. -- The success of the risk-rating system worked out by the Federal Housing Administration indicates that lending policies are under control and better homes, neighborhoods and cities are assured, according to Frederick M. Babcock of Washington, chief of the underwriting section of the FHA.

Head Coach Mal Stevens gave the New York University varsity football squad a three-hour workout as preparations were begun yesterday at Ohio Field for the contest with Georgetown University Saturday at the Yankee Stadium. The session was the first for the Violet since its victory over Pennsylvania Military College last Saturday.

Less hedging pressure, combined with predictions of frost in Western Oklahoma and Northern Texas, had a steadying influence on prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and final quotations showed gains of 2 to 11 points. The previous day's persistent selling from producing regions was lacking and spot firms executed fewer orders, while demand appeared from both domestic and foreign trade interests.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22. --William Randolph Hearst, in a letter to be published tomorrow, says he was compelled to close his California places and "live almost entirely in New York" because of the California income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The Emergency Conservation Administration announced today that 129 CCC camps would be operated in New York this Winter, an increase of twenty-four over the number on Aug. 31.

With Lebanon Valley to oppose on Saturday and Pittsburgh in the offing a week later, the Fordham football squad staged a hard drill at Fordham Field yesterday. The session was divided with the squad preparing for the Flying Dutchmen about two hours and spending the final hour working on plays to be used against the Panthers.

A revival of interest in domestic corporation bonds was the highlight of trading in the listed bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Reflecting the recent speculative enthusiasm which has gripped the stock market, a considerable number of the fixed-interest-bearing issues was bid up briskly under the leadership of the second-grade and more speculative loans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- The heaviest receipts of hogs here for a Tuesday since last February today sent prices off 10 to 25 cents a hundred-weight. Most of the offerings were new-crop hogs, averaging 175 to 240 pounds.

It is as a great advocate, a deadly cross-examiner, that Sir EDWARD CARSON, to give him his best known title, must long be remembered by his profession. His success was early. In Ireland he had impressed Mr. BALFOUR, whom he resembled in courage though not in imperturbability.

TORONTO, Oct. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Proclamation of Ontario's legislation canceling the Province's contracts for the purchase of power from four electric companies in Quebec was deferred late today, pending a conference between representatives of the companies and the engineers of the Ontario Hydroelectric Power Commission.

Enthusiastic and optimistic prophecies were made about America's fastest growing and most popular motor boat racing class -- the 225 cubic inch division -- last night when several score of drivers, mechanics, boat and engine builders gathered at the Hotel Lexington to overhaul and amend the racing rules.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Imports of farm products this year have been near record proportions, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The Duke of Sutherland, chairman of the English committee that arrived in New York on Monday to award the blue ribbon trophy to the French liner Normandie, is returning on that ship to England today with the other members of the committee. Among these is Harold K. Hales, M.P., accompanied by the donor, Mrs. Hales.

New York University, in cooperation with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will erect a three-story building at University Avenue and 180th Street, the Bronx, to house part of the university's College of Engineering, Dean Collins P. Bliss announced last night.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 22. -- Recovering from his defeat of yesterday, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, world chess champion, came back strongly in the ninth game of his match for the title with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam at the Military Casino tonight.
The two big questions of the Yale-Army meeting at New Haven this week will concern themselves with the physical and metaphysical.
ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- Following is the text of the opinion of Judge Irving G. Hubbs of the Court of Appeals on the New York City power referendum:

BOSTON, Oct. 22. -- Directors of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston voted today to recommend the issue of 89,146 new shares of capital stock, to be offered to present stockholders at $140 a share and in the ratio of one new share to each six now outstanding.

The prediction that immunity serum will play an increasingly important part in the treatment of pneumonia in children was made last night by Dr. Charles Hendee Smith, Professor of Pediatrics at the New York University College of Medicine, in a paper presented before the eighth annual graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

General LUDENDORFF now says that nations live only for war and should therefore be ruled in peace as in war by a military overlord. His scheme calls for a national religion on the model of Shintoism in Japan to put iron into a nation's make-up in place of the debilitating Christian faith notoriously of suspect Jewish origin.

Three judges testified for the State yesterday in the General Sessions trial of two former attaches of the Central Branch Municipal Court on an indictment charging forgery and damaging the court records to conceal alleged defalcations of $828 in litigants' fees.

The opening tonight is that of "Crime Marches On," the melodrama by Bertrand Robinson and Maxwell Hawkins, which is to test the water at the Morosco Theatre. Mary Rogers, daughter of the late Will Rogers, is in the cast; so are Elisha Cook Jr., Charles D. Brown and Charles Halton.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Army continued its intensive drive for the Yale game today. The Cadets again stressed defensive play, chiefly against the Blue's running attack, and later rehearsed their own offensive briefly. It rained throughout the drill and the players had plenty of opportunity to handle the wet ball.

A new scheme for the revival of the theatre was launched yesterday at a luncheon at the Plaza given by Mrs. Julius Sylvester Walsh, who heads a committee of Founders of the Playgoers, Inc., one of the units of the plan's organization.

GENEVA, Oct. 22. -- The League of Nations has raised far-reaching questions for the United States, it is deemed here, in notifying Washington officially of the judgment it has rendered and the steps it is taking to uphold that judgment in the case of Ethiopia against Italy for violation of the League covenant and the Briand-Kellogg pact by resorting to war.
Rene Clair's latest French film production, "Le Dernier Milliardaire," with Max Dearly, will have its American premiere on Tuesday at the Cinema de Paris.

After advancing during the morning, the stock market ran into profit-taking yesterday. Industrial shares at the close were moderately lower, but rails and public utility stocks which scarcely participated in the recent rise showed good gains.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, Oct. 23. -- Incomplete results of yesterday's general election for the Danish Folketing, or lower house, show that the Stauning Socialist government gained ground at the expensee of the Liberals.

Twenty-five crippled pupils were carried out and 225 others were led to safety yesterday when a fire was discovered in an unoccupied classroom on the third floor of Public School 2, Third Avenue and 169th Street, five minutes after the rest of the 1,700 pupils had been dismissed for the noon recess.

A perfect realization of all the concomitants that in their aggregate make up what is known as the eighteenth century style of piano playing marked the interpretations of the effusions of that period put forward by Arthur Loesser last night at his Town Hall recital, the first of his series of three concerts on as many centuries of music for the instrument.
LONDON, Oct. 22. -- Following is the text of the salient passages in the address by Sir Samuel Hoare, Foreign Secretary, on the Ethiopian situation in the House of Commons today:
A collection booth to raise funds and medicinal supplies in behalf of Ethiopian wounded has been set up in the student concourse of City College by the student council.

Increases such as marked the earlier New York meetings have been reported for the recent session of the Queens County Jockey Club at Aqueduct, according to an announcement yesterday from the State Racing Commission. The gains were the most substantial of any meeting this year, and led, Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope to the conclusion that the sport is more than ever on the upgrade.

The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week. However, the total showed a gain over the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 872, as against 1,083 in the previous week and 768 in the same week last year.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Former Premier Ismail Sidky Pasha, one of the leading statesmen in the Near East, in an interview today drew a contrast between British attacks upon Italian policy and the way the British Government "is treating Egypt."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- A request of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for a $5,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was rejected today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, and the road, according to informed circles, was started on the road to trusteeship and financial reorganization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- A $16,000,000 slash in the $147,000,000 work-relief allotment for river and harbor projects today backed the Roosevelt administration half way out of its immediate efforts to convert ocean tides into electric current.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Reporting 55,000,000 trees set out in the Middle Western shelter belt this year, the Forestry Service today shaped plans for setting as many more millions next year. Two million dollars was set aside for the work this year in semi-arid areas.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Coach Fritz Crisler sent the Princeton football squad through a long defensive drill on University Field today. The Nassau mentor worked especially on perfecting a defense for the off-tackle plays that Cornell teams habitually use.

As was customary and fitting, the British Foreign Secretary opened the full-dress debate on international affairs in the House of Commons yesterday. Sir SAMUEL HOARE made a speech second in significance only to the one which he delivered at Geneva when the Council met.

Favored horses did well at Empire City yesterday, with the most popular victory coming in the featured Shamrock Handicap, in which the Arden Farms' Quel Jeu ran one of his best races to score by four lengths at 9 to 5. Although only four started, there was sharp action in the betting ring, with each of the starters being substantially backed.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad estimates its operating revenues at $40,634,000 and its net loss at $1,917,000 in 1935, according to exhibits filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. These would compare with operating revenues of $39,866,000 and net loss of $1,891,000 in 1934.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens, who has been investigating the deaths of two patients during September at Creedmoor State Hospital, began an additional inquiry yesterday into a third death. The case was that of Silvia Heyman, 18 years old, of 409 Avenue C. Brooklyn, who died at the hospital Sunday from burns.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 22. -- The Pennsylvania State College Collegian, student newspaper, praised the Athletic Board of Control editorially today for deciding to give members of the football team two meals daily at training table.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 22. -- Early today Emperor Haile Selassie gave final instructions to Minister of War Ras Mulugeta, who then left for Dessye, about 175 miles northeast of Addis Ababa, to command a great concentration of troops there. The troops are expected to move to the northern front after the Emperor goes to Dessye next week.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 22. -Charging the elisor grand jury, empaneled here today to consider complaints resulting from the fatal shooting of Mrs. Sophie Crempa at her Scotch Plains farm Sept. 26, Supreme Court Justice Clarence E. Case said that if the deputy sheriffs detailed to arrest the woman's husband, John Crempa Sr., had warrants they were not trespassers.

A Mississippi steamboat race with variations loomed as a new attraction in the city's annual sport program in a suggestion yesterday by the New York Chapter of the Railway and Locomotive Historical Society.
The Rev. Julius Sathmary's telephone rang intermittently yesterday and with a persistence that he had not dreamed of when he advertised on Monday his intention of buying a church.

LAKE CHARLES, La., Oct. 22 (AP). -- Machine-gun, rifle and pistol fire raked the Lake Charles docks section late today in the International Longshoremen's Association strike and fatally wounded two men. Eight other, wounded, were in a hospital for emergency treatment.
ROME, Oct. 22 (AP). -- All quiet on the Ethiopian war fronts was reported today by General Emilio de Bono, commander-in-chief of the Italian armies in East Africa.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22. -Resignations of five editorial officers of The Harvard Advocate, a scorching arraignment by Frank G. Volpe, Assistant District Attorney, for "dishing up dirt," and destruction of all available copies of the September issue were the major penalties laid down tonight for the printing of two articles declared by Chief of Police Leahy to be obscene.

Six characters are in search of a comedy in "Substitute for Murder," which was crisply acted at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. No one need be a prophet to realize that the search is largely in vain. Although William Jourdan Rapp and Leonardo Bercovici have an impish sense of humor, they are traveling light, and "Substitute for Murder" gives short weight in entertainment.

" To him who in the love of nature holds communion with her visible forms," there is a kind of solace in the midst of these alarms of war in the calm certitude with which the birds pursue their customary paths of autumnal migration.

IF readers of Sinclair Lewis's "It Can't Happen Here" were left wondering about an intellectually valid economic and political program to insure the victory of Jeffersonian democracy over Fascism, Communism and the garden variety of present-day Hamiltonian plutocracy, let them hie themselves to the book stores and buy Herbert Agar's "Land of the Free" (Houghton Mifflin, $3.50).

MADRID, Oct. 22. -- Opposition Deputies sought today to force the Chapaprieta government to defend in the Cortes several Cabinet members against charges of having accepted bribes from Daniel Straus, Mexican, who wanted gambling legalized in Spain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The Social Security Board's skeleton organization was completed today with the appointment of four men to posts technically under Labor Department direction, but with duties dovetailing with the Federal security program.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 22. -- Paraguay is preparing a diplomatic protest accusing Argentina of advancing into Paraguayan territory and occupying fourteen Chaco forts. The area which is said to have been occupied varies between fifteen and twenty-five miles in width and runs about 125 miles along the Pilcomayo River.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The WPA set out today with a squad of its own sleuths, known here as the "W-men," in an effort to track down work relief grafters.

The New York world's fair of 1939 and 1940, pledged by its prominent sponsors to be the largest exposition ever held, became a legal fact yesterday with the filing in Albany of formal incorporation papers after Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins in this city had approved the certificate of incorporation.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 . -- An opera season for Philadelphia became a possibility today after a conference between Metropolitan Opera Association officials and local music patrons.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22. -- The groundwork for the first Supreme Court test of the Wagner-Connery Industrial Disputes Act was laid today when five discharged employes of the Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines, Inc., subsidiary of the Pennsylvania Railroad system, testified they were dismissed for joining Local No. 1,063 of the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railroad and Motor Coach Employes of America.
The sketches for murals of five artists working in the WPA Art Work for Public Buildings Project have received the preliminary approval of the Art Commission of New York City.

British investors have bought heavily of United States securities in the market in London in the past few months, Dean K. Worcester, executive vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, reported yesterday upon his return from a five-week stay in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- A restatement of the United States policy of neutrality in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict and of the government's purpose to maintain that policy by use of the methods embodied in the Neutrality Resolution passed by Congress is expected to follow shortly upon the return of President Roosevelt to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Applications of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission have passed 5,000 and are still being received. Registration must become effective by Jan. 1, and the commission has warned that applications must be received some time before then so that they may be examined and passed upon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The open market committee of the Federal Reserve System met today and adjourned without taking any action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration acted today on appeals of members of Congress from the cotton producing States that the ginning tax on cotton under the Bankhead Act be fixed at a rate which will be comparable to the average quotations in the ten designated spot cotton markets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- A public hearing will be held on Oct. 30 to examine the work of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., of which J. Reuben Clark, former Under-Secretary of State, is president; the American Council of Foreign Bondholders, Inc., headed by Max Winkler; the Latin-American Foreign Bondholders Association, Inc., and the protective committees for holders of bonds of the Republic of Cuba, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
BERLIN, Oct. 22. -- The Boerse was slightly weaker today and, as usual, was virtually inactive. Heavy industrial issues were mixed and unstable although changes were not significant.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 22. -The vessel bearing President Roosevelt homeward from a three-week fishing trip slipped up Charleston harbor and anchored below the Cooper River Bridge shortly before midnight.

The Health Department reported yesterday 1,428 deaths from all causes last week, an increase of 116 over the preceding week. The general death rate per 1,000 population was 9.79, compared to an average rate of 9.85 for the same week over the past six years.

MADERA, Calif., Oct. 22. -- The existence of two F.B. Fanchers was blamed by Madera officials today for the error by which three AAA cotton-control checks totaling $110 were received by Frederick B. Fancher, 80, of Los Angeles, former Republican Governor of North Dakota.
Short shots about hunting and hunters:

ALBANY, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, Works Progress Administrator, today ordered a 10 per cent wage increase for WPA laborers on up-State projects and a reduction in the total hours of work per month.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- There is a strong expectation in parliamentary and British Government circles tonight that there will be a meeting next week of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary; Premier Pierre Level of France and Premier Benito Mussolini in another attempt to negotiate a settlement of the war in Ethiopia without enforcing the sanctions against Italy that have already been agreed upon in Geneva.

Coach Lou Little continued to search among the second and third-stringers yesterday at Baker Field for players who might plug the weak points for Columbia in its meeting with Michigan here on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Financial assistance for 100,532 needy students in 1,514 colleges and universities in forty-six States and Puerto Rico will be provided by the National Youth Administration at a monthly cost of $1,503,795, Aubrey Williams, executive director, stated today.

ROME, Oct. 22. -- The London Daily Telegraph was barred from Italy today. The Ministry of Press and Propaganda admitted that the sale of the paper has been prohibited, but no official reason was given.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, urged a gathering of Barnard College girls yesterday to divest themselves of any "self-righteous feeling of superiority" with a view to "knowing the truth about our people and other peoples the world over."

I have read, with much sympathy and also indignation, of the new regulation of the Fire Department with regard to the storage of kerosene in safety cans in old-law tenements. The authorities have no right to impose such an ordinance upon people so poor that they cannot afford to pay the rent of comparatively safe dwellings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Imposition of countervailing tariff duties on imports of rye and rye flour from Poland was ordered today by Secretary Morgenthau after the customs service had determined that Poland pays a bounty on rye exports.

ARCOLA, N.J., Oct. 22. -- So satisfied were the representatives of the New Jersey clubs with the work of their golf association officials during the past season that at the annual meeting, held at the Arcola Country Club today, they re-elected the entire 1935 executive committee.
PARIS, Oct. 22. -- Defending his deflation decrees and the government's whole financial policy, Premier Pierre Laval made a special point today of repeating his determined stand against devaluation.

Proposed court rules designed to prevent lawyers and judges from disseminating or countenancing improper publicity in civil and criminal cases have been recommended by the State Judicial Council to the justices of the Appellate Division for adoption, it was announced yesterday by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals, who is chairman of the council.

The Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, held a dinner last night celebrating the sesquicentennial anniversary of its founding. The Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, addressed 200 persons on "The Church as the Nucleus of Brotherhood."
Housing deals featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- Business increased today on the London Stock Exchange largely because the overnight news from Wall Street helped sentiment. Most groups were firm in tendency. British funds improved when investment buying was resumed after early dullness.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Uncertain whether Willie Saunders had returned to Louisville for questioning in the death of Mrs. Evelyn Sliwinski, Baltimore officers made every effort today to locate the jockey of Kentucky Derby and Preakness fame.

Charges of disorderly conduct against nine men and women who picketed the offices of the Amsterdam News, a Harlem weekly, last Friday afternoon, were withdrawn yesterday, when five attorneys reprecenting the defendants agreed that their clients would not picket the place in such numbers as to obstruct the sidewalk.

The Book-of-the-Month Club choice for December will be General de Caulaincourt's "With Napoleon in Russia." This book was taken from the memoirs of the general, who was constantly with Napoleon through the campaign of 1812 -- his only companion when Napoleon fled incognito across a hostile Europe to Paris.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Asserting that President Roosevelt cannot be re-elected without Republican votes, Senator Borah says, in a letter made public here today, that "the Republican party is out of power because those who have dominated its policies and shaped its administration have not met the issues which deeply concern the people and which are in the interest of the public welfare."

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- Former Mayor James J. Walker, who had planned to return to the United States this week, may be prevented from doing so at once as a result of the accidental burning of his mother-in-law's house in England yesterday. The former Mayor and Mrs. Walker had been in Paris for some days on their return from Vichy and had made arrangements to sail on the Manhattan on Thursday.
I question whether many persons fully realize the skill displayed in the management of the city's finances.

Mayor LA GUARDIA referred the other day to the desirability of completing the Thirty-eighth Street Tunnel under the East River "in time for the World's Fair." It is his idea that the tunnel can use the visitors just as the visitors can use the tunnel, to their mutual advantage.

BOSTON, Oct. 22. -- Freddie Miller of Cincinnati, recognized by the National Boxing Association as the world's featherweight champion, retained his title by earning the decision over Vernon Cormier of Worcester in a nip-and-tuck fifteen-round battle at the Boston Garden tonight.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The Presbyterian Synod of New York at its opening meeting here today adopted a report of the Committee on Social Service supporting President Roosevelt's New Deal. The action was preceded by a discussion marked by spirited opposition to "a program which would involve the church in political issues."

The United States Shipping Board opened hearings at the government building at 45 Broadway yesterday to take testimony on the contract rate system of the Gulf-Intercoastal Conference, which some shippers wish to have ruled out of the conference regulations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 22. -- The Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey in annual session here declined today to pass on the constitutionality of the General Assembly mandate ordering members of the Independent Board of Presbyterian Foreign Missions to resign.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- Some profit-taking after yesterday's quick recovery slowed down trading on the Bourse this morning, but the final results of the day were satisfactory. The closing quotations were not the best of the session, but no significance was attached to that fact.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Directors of operating utility companies who are members of the boards of more than one such organization or who have official connections with investment banking houses which are interested in utilities were warned today by the Federal Power Commission that they would retrain such positions unlawfully unless application for authority to continue them was made to it by Friday.

I earnestly hope that all citizens who care for justice will vote in the coming election to amend the New York Constitution to give to a jury the power to render a verdict with a five-sixths majority, in case a unanimous opinion does not exist.

The heavy movement of gold to this country was resumed yesterday, when $14,617,000 of the metal was taken in Great Britain for shipment here. It was the only engagement reported for the day but the amount was the largest so far taken in that market in one day in the present movement for accounts here.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that four Brooklyn detectives, one a lieutenant, will have to stand departmental trial in connection with their investigation of the murder, last March, of Samuel Druckman, at 121 Moore Street, Brooklyn.

Daily average production of gross crude oil in the United States last week was 2,782,800 barrels, compared with 2,781,750 in the preceding week, an increase of 1,050, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 11,350 barrels in Oklahoma and a gain of 4,000 in California were the principal changes.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 22. -- Emperor Haile Selassie flatly denied today reports published abroad that the Italian Army had used either poison gas or dum-dum bullets in its invasion of his kingdom.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions' and wholesale prices in New York.

The Park Association of New York City, Inc., made public yesterday a letter to Mayor La Guardia urging him to give serious consideration to the plan proposed by Park Commissioner Robert Moses for providing more police for the city's parks.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 22. -- With a four-day Eucharistic Congress opening here tomorrow morning the Plaza dos de Mayo, a square in the heart of the city, has been converted into a huge open-air cathedral nave, the transepts being formed by three of the busiest thoroughfares.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 22. -- In an eighteen-page opinion which criticized the part played by counsel for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in the case pending in Federal District Court here, Judge William Clark struck out today the affidavit of bias and prejudice filed by the racketeer's counsel and denied the application to disqualify the court from hearing the case.

Manhattan's football team thoroughly rehearsed its offensive plays in a lengthy scrimmage at Innisfail Park yesterday in preparation for the intersectional battle with Hunk Anderson's North Carolina State eleven at Ebbets Field Saturday.

In the Commerce Department's report on this country's September foreign trade, the month's gold imports are set down as $156,805,000. These large receipts, following as they did two months of negligible gold import, are still widely ascribed to last month's "European war scare."

ITALIAN FIELD HEADQUARTERS IN NORTHERN ETHIOPIA, Oct. 21 (Delayed) (AP). -- General Emilio de Bono, commander-in-chief of Italy's armies in Africa, said today that his goal was the complete submission of all Ethiopia.

Paulino Uzcudun, the Basque woodchopper, will be the next opponent of Joe Louis, the Brown Bomber of Detroit. They will meet in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden Dec. 13 under the joint auspices of the Garden Corporation and Mike Jacobs, who holds a contract on Louis, for the benefit of the New York American and Evening Journal Christmas Fund.

After a two-year absence from the exhibition field, the New York Society of Painters is making its reappearance at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. There was a varnishing reception yesterday afternoon, and today the exhibition (the society's seventeenth) will open to the public, remaining current through Nov. 5.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. John H.P. Gould had a dinner party tonight at Mahkeenac Farm, Lenox, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. George K. Livermore, Mr. and Mrs. D. Percy Morgan and Mr. and Mrs. George H. Cabot of New York.

WELL, sir, there General Hugh S. Johnson, the former blocking back for the NRA, hauling off and putting the blast on the football system in vogue at his old alma mater, the United States Military Academy and asking, among other things, what excuse there is for a West Point team ever losing games.
Numerous leases by manufacturers and retailers in the midtown area of Manhattan were included in the business rentals reported yesterday, as follows:
ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today against Mayor La Guardia's local law authorizing a referendum on a municipal power plant at the November election.

NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, Africa, Oct. 22. -- The tragic figure of Lij Yasu, former Emperor of Ethiopia, who has lived in chains since his deposition eighteen years ago, has reappeared in the limelight for a fleeting moment, but only to change his cell without casting off his fetters.

Miss Stella Walsh, Polish Olympic sprint champion who returned yesterday on the Gdynia-American line's Pilsudski from a Summer of track competition in Central Europe, declared that the athletic situation in respect to Jews in Germany was "very bad indeed."

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- On the basis of Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's speech in the British House of Commons today and a French Cabinet discussion of recent dealings with Britain, the French have come to the conclusion that the British have renounced the idea of any single-handed action against Italy.

Supreme Court Justice Rosenman reserved decision yesterday on an application to dismiss two suits by John G. Lonsdale and James M. Kurn, trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, to recover more than $11,500,000 alleged to have been lost by the railroad through the purchase of two blocks of stock.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 22. -- Many luncheons were given on the Casino terrace today between rounds of golf. Mr. and Mrs. W.C. Fitken and Dr. Edmund LeRoy Dow played a three-some. Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Hance, Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd P. Phillips, F.A. Countway and Miss Landra Countway, and Rudolph Leitner, counselor of the German Embassy in Washington, were among those playing.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 22. -- Tommy Armour of Medinah, Ill., the veteran campaigner who has won virtually every major golf tournament there is to win, and Johnny Revolta, 24-year-old marksman from Milwaukee, Wis., shot their way through mist and chilling winds today to the final round of the P.G.A. national championship.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, B.W.I., Oct. 22 (AP). -- Rioting Negro strikers, disdaining martial law, tonight blocked Kingstown off from the rest of the island to climax two days of disorders in which three of their number were shot to death.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 22. -- The possibilities of an Ethiopian counter-attack in the north are being systematically examined. The object of such an attack, now that the Italians have retired from before Makale, would be to hold all the Italian troops in Eritrea by continual action and thus prevent the dispatching of reinforcements to Bender Kassim, Italian Somaliland.

Prices of most commodity futures were lower on the local markets yesterday. Hides, copper and wool tops advanced, but profit-taking in rubber and silk and further liquidation of December sugar featured the trading. In the cash markets cotton, corn and tin advanced, while wheat, rye, oats, rubber and silk eased.
East Side apartments, including several penthouses, made up the bulk of the rental activity reported yesterday, as follows:

HAVANA, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Restored communication lines from Eastern Cuba, hit by a tropical hurricane, brought news tonight of a death toll of from one to four and damage less extensive than had at first been feared.

A powerful electric amplifier designed to convert an infinitesimal amount of light into electricity, heralded as "another big boost in putting television on its way," was demonstrated last night by Dr. V. K. Zworykin, television research expert of the RCA-Victor Company, at the Institute of Radio Engineers.
