PARIS, Oct. 23. -- Following the speeches of Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare and Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin in England, it is being officially proclaimed in Paris that complete agreement exists between the British and French Governments with regard to the policy to be followed in the treatment of Italy.

LOS ANGELES. Oct. 23. -- A brush fire roared out of control tonight near the Malibu Summer homes of several movie stars -- one of a series in five Southern California counties that caused damages of $4,000,000, according to unofficial figures.

Goaded by the growing threat of the 225s to take their place as motor beating's blue ribbon class, drivers of the mile-a-minute Gold Cup craft last night protected their regattas for 1936 by unprecedentedly fixing an engine minimum.
New Jersey's game management policy, inaugurated last year on nine public hunting and fishing grounds, already has produced practical benefits, according to the State commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The Columbia Pictures Corporation of New York filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of 75,000 shares of no-par value, $2.75 cumulative dividend, convertible preferred stock to be offered at $50 a share, or an aggregate of $3,750,000, and 135,000 shares of no-par value common stock.

George Ziniti, 56 years old, former clerk in the defunct City Trust Company and a principal witness for the State several years ago in the trial in which Frank H. Warder, State Superintendent of Banks, was sent to Sing Sing for extortion, was indicted yesterday on a grand larceny charge.
The Park Department's $2,000,000 program for rehabilitating and improving Central Park is now in full swing, a survey yesterday revealed.

Classes in public speaking to train leaders for the 1936 Presidential campaign were begun yesterday under the auspices of the Women's National Republican Club. About 100 members attended the morning and evening sessions, which were held at the clubhouse of the organization, 2 West Fifty-first Street.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- James J. Walker, former New York Mayor, was still hoping tonight to sail for New York tomorrow on the liner Manhattan, but his plans depend on whether his mother-in-law, Mrs. Frederick Compton, can settle her business affairs in time to catch the motorship.

ROME, Oct. 23. -- It is believed here that a definite Anglo-Italian agreement has been reached to lessen the dangerous tension in the Mediterranean by reducing the warlike preparations made by both countries.

More than 100 guests prominent in shipping and transportation circles here, attended a luncheon at noon yesterday on board the French liner Normandie moored at the foot of West Forty-eight Street, when the transfer of the Harold Keates Hales Trophy, won by the Rex in 1934 for the speed record across the Atlantic Ocean, was made to the Normandie.

HAILIE SELASSIE denies that the Italian invaders are using poison gas and dumdum bullets. This confirms a longstanding impression that the Ethiopian monarch knows what is going on in the world or else has the benefit of some very competent advice on the subject.

MADRID, Oct. 23. -- The Foreign Ministry warned the Paramount Pictures Corporation agency here today that if the film "The Devil Is a Woman" is not withdrawn from exhibition throughout the world all Paramount films will be barred from Spain.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 23. -- J. B. Partridge's Prince Abbot today accounted for his third consecutive triumph when he raced to a twoand-a-half-length victory over J. U. Gratton's Allen Z in the Wampanoag Claiming Stakes before 10,000 at Narragansett Park.

At least four new men will be in Columbia's starting line-up against Michigan at Baker Field on Saturday. After three days of searching among the reserves for players to stop the gaps in the Lions' offense and defense, Coach Lou Little yesterday relied on an entire new side of the line and a sophomore fullback.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23. -Because it was disclosed at the weighing-in today that the members of the Yale eleven had regained the 108 pounds lost in the Navy game last Saturday, Head Coach Ducky Pond departed from his plan of no contact work this week.

The volume of bankers acceptances rose $6,026,906 in September to $327,834,317 at the end of that month, according to the monthly report of the American Acceptance Council, published yesterday. The total was $211,586,069 smaller than that reported for Sept. 30, 1934.

GENEVA, Oct. 23. -- The governing body of the International Labor Organization decided today to give Canada the seat left vacant by Germany's withdrawal from the League of Nations and the Labor Organization, which became effective Monday.

Rain failed to curtail the New York University football squad's preparations at Ohio Field yesterday, Coach Mal Stevens sending the Violet varsity through a two and a half hour session. N.Y.U. meets Georgetown University at the Yankee Stadium Saturday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23. -Its application for financial assistance in the amount of $5,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation having been blocked yesterday in Washington by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, through William W. Meyer, its assistant general counsel, filed at noon today with the clerk of the Federal Court here a petition for reorganization of the railroad system under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- More than 4,000 graduate students are being helped by Federal funds in their seeking of master's and doctor's degrees in 136 colleges and universities, Audrey Williams, executive director of the National Youth Administration, stated today.

Loft, Inc., candy manufacturers, announced yesterday, that Charles C. Guth Sr. had been succeeded as president of the $10,000,000 corporation by J. W. Carkner, vice president in charge of sales. Mr. Guth, it was said, had sold his interest in the company and resigned the presidency.

Unshaken by the news that Jim Whalen, 160-pound ball-carrying star, may not be available for duty against North Carolina State at Ebbets Field Saturday, Manhattan's football team drilled for two hours at Innisfail Park yesterday in preparation for the invasion of Hunk Anderson's powerful Wolf-pack squad.
MOSCOW, Oct. 23. -- Joseph Stalin as a model son -- a warm, generous, merry-hearted companion of his

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23.-- The United States Government will be prepared to send a delegation to London for a naval limitation conference on Dec. 2 or 3 or on any other date for which the British Government issues invitations. It is assumed here that the date will be early in December, and that the exact date will depend on the time when Japanese representatives can reach London.

CAMBRIDGE, Mas., Oct. 23. -Coach Dick Harlow again drove most of his Harvard varsity players through another hour of rugged offensive scrimmaging today. This time it was the second freshman eleven that had to battle the regulars, who were on the offensive all of the time.

The Board of Elections ruled out yesterday as invalid due to insufficient signatures the petitions nominating five City Fusion party candidates in the Bronx. The candidates were Thomas A. De Bellis and Morris Schaeffer, running for municipal court justice in the First district, where there are two vacancies; Joseph C. Lee and Louis Longarzo, Assembly candidates in thc Sixth and Eighth districts, and Louis Goldrich, Aldermanic candidate in the Twenty-sixth district.

To an inquiring citizen of our New York Rome Mr. BORAH, most Roman of Senators, has given answers, valuable no doubt, but perhaps confusing to the public. "Why," the questioner asks the oracle, "start a fight with the Old Guard?" The right, the perfect nominee, will be "straightforward Republican."

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Joseph A. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, arrived in London today and had a long conversation tonight with Sir Robert Vansittart, Under-Secretary of State, concerning the League and the East African dispute.

The Federal inquiry into practices of steamship lines in the Gulf and Pacific Coast trade was completed yesterday after M. G. de Quevedo, examiner for the United States Shipping Board Bureau had heard shippers and steamship operators present arguments for and against the contract rate system used by the Gulf-Intercoastal Conference.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 23. -- President Lazaro Cardenas outlined today for the first time the policy of his government toward foreign capital considering investments in Mexico. He said that just as foreign capital was necessary for the industrial upbuilding of the United States, it was required for the successful completion of the Mexican six-year plan, aimed among other things at effecting industrial expansion in Mexico.

President Roosevelt's proclamation listing articles that may not be exported to Italy or to Ethiopia "is likely to do more harm than good," Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, declared last night in a radio address broadcast by the Columbia network.
From Shakespeare we learn that Mark Antony invoked the favor of the Roman people by telling them that Caesar, quoting his will,

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, known throughout Protestant Germany as the "submarine pastor" because he commanded a U-boat in the war, has informed his parishioners in the suburb of Dahlem that Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, formally requested Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller to resign.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 23. (AP) -- Walter Schaeffer, race track exercise boy, was formally charged with murder by police tonight, at the request of Louisville authorities, in connection with the death of Mrs. Sliwinski. He waived extradition.

Details of the "get-rich-quick" scheme of William F. Peterson, 52year-old securities dealer now under indictment for grand larceny, were disclosed yesterday when the State Attorney General's office obtained from Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins a Martin act order temporarily restraining Peterson, his wife, Hilda M. Peterson, and others associated with them from selling securities in the State or disposing of property derived from fraudulent practices.
When I saw the English crown jewels,in the Wakefield turret of the Tower ofLondon, I had to look at them betweeniron bars while watchful guards scannedevery visitor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The sweeping investigation by the Federal Communications Commission into the affairs of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is not expected to reach the stage of public hearings until early in January.
Police officials turned a deaf ear yesterday to complaints that parking regulations now virtually prohibit the use of a private automobile in the city.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- While he characterized the social security program of the Washington administration as "complex rather than complete," I. M. Rubinow of Cincinnati, secretary of B'nai B'rith, tonight asked 1,500 social workers in convention here to look on the legislation as the beginning of a program which a democratic people must continue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- In line with the policy that it has pursued with respect to maturing Federal railroad loans, the Interstate Commerce Commission granted today a three-year extension of the maturity dates on $12,119,310 of Reconstruction Finance Corporation advances to the Erie Railroad.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 23 (AP). -- Governor O. K. Allen stirred State politicians today by disclosing that he had secretly qualified himself as a candidate for United States Senator and one of his political associates, Louis L. Morgan, general counsel for the Louisiana Highway Commission, for Governor in the January Democratic primary.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 23. -- Protests were filed with the Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey at the closing session of its annual meeting here today against its earlier action rejecting two complaints against the Presbytery of West Jersey.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 23 (AP). -Murder charges in the slaying of Mrs. Evelyn Sliwinski, which climaxed a wild party here last Saturday night, were placed tonight against Willie Saunders, nationally famous jockey, and Walter Schaeffer, an exercise boy for the Headley stable.

Surrogate Albert C. Henderson reserved decision and allowed attorneys for Mrs. Virginia Clayton Willys de Landa until Friday to submit further affidavits in support of their application for the appointment of an administrator to conserve that part of the estate of her father, the late John North Willys, automobile manufacturer, which is located here.
Milan Creighton, player-coach of the Chicago Cardinals, expects his team to be in excellent condition for the game Sunday against the Giants at the Polo Grounds.

Gold engagements abroad for shipment here again were in a reduced amount yesterday. Of only $2,548,000 that was taken, $1,985,000 was in England and $563,000 in France. It compared with engagements of $14,617,000 in England on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The New York Stock Exchange has been authorized to send to fiscal agents of foreign governments a letter embodying views of the general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission with regard to the registration of foreign securities on Form 108, the SEC announced today.

MADISON, Minn., Oct. 23 (AP). -- A charge that Secretary Wallace was attempting to "steal" tho forthcoming corn-hog referendum was followed quickly today by a demand from the Minnesota Farm Holiday Association that he be ousted forthwith from office.

TRENTON, Oct. 23. -- Although refusing to take jurisdiction because the proper legal course had not been followed, the Supreme Court severely criticized today candidates for public office who vote in the primary of the opposing party.

Warnings to retailers were again issued yesterday by some of the buying offices that it is essential to anticipate holiday needs on a number of merchandise items, particularly lingerie and silk underwear. The point was made that stores should not permit the present temporary slowing-up in trade to interfere with necessary forward orders on holiday lines.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23. -- Testimony to show that the Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines, Inc., met the problem presented by the unionization of some of its employes by intimidation, threats, discharges, wage rises and favoritism to company union members was presented to the National Labor Relations Board today.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 23. -- Misgivings in Ethiopian official circles over Britain's stand changed today to the undisguised feeling that she had let them down as the contents of the speech by Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons yesterday became known.

The match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine and Dr. Max Euwe for the chess championship of the world has been noteworthy for the small percentage of drawn games. Of the nine encounters in The Netherlands thus far, five were won by Dr. Alekhine, two by Dr. Euwe and only two were drawn.

A few more days of freedom remain for Angelo Herndon, 22-yearold Negro Communist who is at liberty in $15,000 bail pending execution of an eighteen to twenty year sentence imposed on him in Atlanta, Ga., on a charge of insurrection.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The Federal Government today asked the Supreme Court to hasten its hearing on the Hoosac Mills case, first test of the constitutionality of the processing taxes, because uncertainty over the legality of the taxes threatened to upset the government's financial program.

BASLE, Switzerland, Oct. 23. -The Bank of Italy's statement showing a loss of nearly a quarter billion lire in the first ten days of October is considered in the Bank for International Settlements as evidence that Italy, even without any imposition of sanctions against her, was having to pay increasingly in gold.

WASHIHGTON, Oct. 23 (AP). -Mounting exports of materials useful for war were reported today by the government. Italy was shown in Commerce Department figures to have received large shares of several items in September, the latest month summarized.

A plan to consolidate eight corporations in the United Founders group, working control of which is held by the Equity Corporation, was approved yesterday by the boards of directors of the companies. In line with the program for the simplification of the EquityUnited Founders corporate structure, the plan calls for the formation of a new company, American General, Corporation, with combined assets of $48,000,000.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed last night that he intended to ask the State Legislature in January for an extension of the city's emergency taxing power for the whole of next year so that about $67,000,000 in relief taxes might be raised in 1936.

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- The Reich Government has been formally notified of the economic sanctions against Italy by the coordinating committee of the League of Nations, the notification reaching Wilhelmstrasse Monday, the day following the expiration of Germany's membership in the League.

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- Two Catholic priests, who stand high in the German hierarchy, were sentenced today to five and four and a half years' imprisonment, respectively. Each was also ordered to pay a 150,000-marks fine, for which German Catholic charitable organizations were made responsible.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP). -- The number of public utility executives applying to the Federal Power Commission for permission to hold office in more than one company rose to fifty-four today.
LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's speech on foreign affairs in the House of Commons today:
" A Feather in Her Hat," a film version of I. A. R. Wylie's novel, starring Pauline Lord, will be presented by Columbia today at the Radio City Music Hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Dr. Edward C. Wente of New York received tonight the new Progress Medal, which is to be awarded annually by the Society of Motion Picture Engineers in recognition of leading inventions in motion-picture technology.

Defending administration moves through which price levels have been raised in the last two and a half years, John Dickinson, Assistant United States Attorney General, speaking before the opening session of a two-day marketing conference of the American Management Association in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria, contended yesterday that industry had raised its own income abundantly as a result of the burden it was forced to bear in helping provide larger incomes for workers and farmers.

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- The French Cabinet adopted a decree law this morning increasing the "Mobile Republican Guard" from 15,000 to 20,000 men as a measure of precaution for maintenance of public order in the present excited political atmosphere.

Net profit of the Phillips Petroleum Company in the first nine months of this year amounted to $9,850,428 after taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges. This is equivalent to $2.37 a share on 4,153,234 no-par shares of capital stock.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 23. -- Peacock, Anderson Fowler's durable chestnut gelding, romped to victory in the Froh-Heim Chase, the featured event on the opening day's program of the Essex Fox Hounds twentieth annual hunts meeting today on the estate of Evander B. Schley.

Your Albany correspondent stated that the Correction Hospital on Welfare Island was the subject of a critical report to the Commission on Correction. The 80-year-old building was described as being "inadequate to house the number of prisoners, insecure to hold dangerous men and, because of its age, not easy to keep clean."

The city's drama reviewers, operating under the collective title of the New York Drama Critics Circle, will offer an annual prize -starting this Spring -- for the best new play by an American playwright to be shown in New York each year.

Women owners left only small parts of the purse to the representatives of two of the best-known racing men in America when Seabiscuit won the featured Ardsley Handicap at Empire City yesterday by three lengths, with Neap second.

OTTAWA, Oct. 23. -- William Lyon Mackenzie King took over the reins of office as Prime Minister today from Richard B. Bennett and tonight his new Cabinet, the third he has formed during his career, was sworn in.

TOKYO, Oct. 23. -- Though Eiji Amau, Foreign Office spokesman, states the government will decide its attitude at the London naval conference after the British invitation is received, it is virtually settled that Japan will attend. Tsuneo Matsudaira, Ambassador to London, is unable to return at present, so Naotake Sato, Ambassador to Paris, will be the chief representative.

Indications that Rockwell Kent's new book, "Salamina," will have the largest sale of any Kent book are reported by Harcourt, Brace. A first edition of 15,000 copies has already been sold and a second edition of 10,000 copies has been ordered.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 23. -- General Rodolfo Graziani's long-expected thrust is beginning on the southern front, where the Italian forces have already occupied several villages in Ogaden Province.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The burst of speed which has marked the disbursement of Federal work relief funds in the last few days continued today, with the addition in the last twenty-four hours of about $60,000,000 in actual money for the undertaking of projects in forty-one States.

When Cornell started its season this year with two defeats that were surprising upsets, all of the groaning was not confined to Cornell or to Cornell men. One of the largest groans came from the lips of Fritz Crisler, Princeton's coach.
BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- The Boerse weakened again today. The Financial Press reported that the "inactivity and lack of business could hardly have been more extreme."

The Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $6,513,458 applicable to the common stock after all charges, including preferred dividends. This was equivalent to $4.05 a share.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The early days of the old NRA in 1933, when the Blue Eagle was soaring all over the United States and hundreds of codes for the government of industry were in the making, were recalled today when the new NRA -- a skeleton of the old organization -- called public hearings on the labor provisions in "voluntary agreements" affecting wholesale tobacco, specialty paper products and candle industries.

New Yorkers who were startled by the sight of what various witnesses described as "a huge blazing meteor," "a streaking comet" and "a falling airplane" late Tuesday afternoon probably viewed the fall of a meteor, or so-called shooting star, which had approached unusually close to the surface of the earth, Dr. Clyde Fisher, in charge of the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, explained yesterday.

Temperatures of 8 degrees above zero in Rocky Mountain States brought predictions of killing frosts in western parts of the Cotton Belt, and prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday advanced sharply more than a dollar a bale. Owing to late planting, fears that a frost now would cut down the total yield stimulated trade and speculative activity and final quotations were 17 to 25 points higher than on Tuesday.

I feel compelled to correct an impression produced by reading THE TIMES editorial "By Water to the Fair." The piece says, with regard to the East River: "Completion of the Wards Island sewage disposal plant should greatly moderate the existing pollution, making the waters to the east fit for bathing and those to the south at least fit for pleasant navigation."

If any further demonstration were required to invalidate the fundamental theory on which the major railroads bought "key lines" in the heyday that ended in 1929, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad provided it yesterday by moving for reorganization.

The tendency of policemen on crossing duty to permit vehicles to continue moving against a red light has given motorists the impulse to do so where there are no policemen. Beating the lights endangers the life of the conscientious pedestrian who assumes that the lights in his favor mean safety.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- Receipts of hogs here today were again above trade estimates, and the belief that the normal Fall movement of the new crop is now under way and will continue relatively free caused prices to drop 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- The wheat market developed an easier undertone today, and while one small upturn resulted from sympathy with corn, cotton and rye, the advance brought increased pressure. A break of about 2 cents from the high point followed with the finish on the old crop futures 1 to 1 1/8 cents net lower, while the July lost 5/8 cent.

About a thousand bakers, drivers and inside employes of bakeries and garages of Cushman's Sons, Inc., went on strike at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon at four plants in Manhattan, two in Brooklyn, one in Queens and one in Westchester for union recognition and contracts limiting working hours and raising pay.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 23. -Wafted along by a putter touched with magic, young Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee soared to the golfing heights today and won the national P.G.A. championship with a stunning 5-and-4 triumph over graying Tommy Armour of Medinah, Ill., at the Twin Hills course.

Further details of the plan of the Ludlum Steel Company to acquire the Wallingford Steel Company were disclosed yesterday with the listing of 50,692 additional shares of Ludlum's $1-par common stock on the New York Stock Exchange. The application was one of eight approved by the board of governors of the Exchange.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 23. -Mr. and Mrs. Hays R. Browning gave a party in the Homestead Club this evening for Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Parke, Miss Frances Miller, Miss Frances Budlong, William C. Madlener, Otto Madlener, Theodore S. Ryan, Mrs. Brazier Grasselli, Mrs. Frank E. Rutan and G. Paul Seabrease.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Further evidence that the British Government is hoping that some settlement of the Ethiopian war will be reached before sanctions are actually enforced against Italy was given today when the foreign affairs debate in the House of Commons was resumed.

Less than ninety minutes after the shooting of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in Newark last night, Martin Krompier, 33year-old lieutenant of the Bronx gangster, was shot and probably fatally wounded in the Hollywood Barber Shop, 1,570 Broadway, at Forty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- A thorough discussion of the question whether complete segregation of the functions of dealer and broker should be sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission will be the order of business at the meeting of the Associated Stock Exchanges in Chicago on Monday.

The plangent sonorities with which Clifford Herzer made the Town Hall resound at his debut recital last night proved but a futile expenditure of energy during the larger part of his struggles with the Bach-Busoni "Chaconne" and the Beethoven sonata, Op. 2, No. 3, in C major, the most searching compositions attempted by this pianist in the course of the evening.

A "foster-mother" discovered too belatedly to be of use to the family of ten kittens born on Monday to Sikura Jane, an aristocratic Siamese cat at 62 Washington Square South, last night was carried back to Astoria, Queens, and to her own little conservative brood of three.

" Mulatto," by Langston Hughes, is tonight's arrival, postponed from last Monday evening. It comes to the Vanderbilt by way of a tryout at Dobbs Ferry, where its frank treatment of the race question created something of a stir last Summer.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23. -Football relations will be renewed between the United States Military Academy and Princeton in 1938, after a lapse of thirty years, according to an announcement made tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the University Council on Athletics.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 23. -- On the third day of the tour of laboratories organized by the division of engineering and industrial research of the National Research Council, the fifty-six participating corporation and banking executives visited the plant of the B.F. Goodrich Company and learned from its chemists, physicists and engineers what research has recently accomplished in improving old rubber processes and creating new products.

Directors of the American Power and Light Company declared a dividend of 75 cents on the $6 preferred and 62 1/2 cents on the $5 preferred stock. On April 1, this year, payments of 37 1/2 cents on the $6 preferred and 31 1/4 cents on the $5 preferred stocks were made.

The engagement of Dusolina Giannini, American soprano, and the plan to revive several old operas for the coming Metropolitan Opera season were made public yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager, at one of his press conferences.

" Crime Marches On," which was acted at the Morosco last evening, raises a cosmic question. What is fun? To Bertrand Robinson and Maxwell Hawkins, who wrote what they describe as a melodramatic farce, and Edward Clarke Lilley, who staged it, fun is an ear-splitting fandango in the booby-hatch, mixing good satiric lines with police court horror.

It is not too much to say that -unless peace tenders between Italy and Ethiopia intervene -- the reply which the American Government will make to the letter from the chairman of the coordinating committee of the League of Nations may decide how effective will be the sanctions which the League has voted to apply to Italy.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 23. -- Ethiopian warriors are massing in the mountain passes that lie between the Ogaden Desert in the south and the empire's only railroad for a desperate stand against the armies of General Rodolfo Graziani, one of Emperor Haile Selassie's principal war lords reported today.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 23. -Returning from a three-week holiday at sea, which gave him a deep coat of tan and renewed vigor, President Roosevelt reaffirmed today with emphasis his determination to keep the United States "free and unentangled" from foreign wars.

Fumes accumulating underground in Thirty-ninth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues exploded shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, short circuited several direct electric current "feeders," startled thousands of persons, and left hundreds several stories above the street in stalled elevators.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- The fortysixth annual exhibition of American paintings and sculpture will open tomorrow at the Art Institute of Chicago, and prize awards will be made to the seven artists whose work has been chosen from the 3,000 paintings entered by contestants throughout the United States.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of the Amateur Athletic Union, who opposes the holding of next year's Olympic Games in Nazi Germany, clashed directly yesterday with Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, American member of the International Olympic Committee and advocate of American participation in the games.

C. Adolph Glassgold will deliver a lecture at the New School for Social Research at 4:20 o'clock this afternoon on "Art Agencies and the Public's Interest in Art: What the Public Likes, What It Gets and How It Gets It."

Two goals within a span of three minutes midway in the final quarter gave Brooklyn College, unbeaten since 1933, a 2-to-0 victory over St. John's University in a Metropolitan Intercollegiate Soccer Conference game at Betsy Head Park in Brooklyn yesterday.

As one of that vast group of young people, between the ages of 15 and 21, who toil in overcrowded schools and offices, I sought a form of recreation which would not only afford entertainment but also supply the very necessary exercise for my growing body. I and others have found this in roller skating.

Mad with fear that they might betray him for the killing of a policeman in a hold-up a year and a half ago, and other crimes, a 21year-old gunman named Al Stern or Stein has killed seven of his former underworld allies and wounded two others within the last two months, a high police official charged yesterday.

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 23. -- Premier Theodor A. M. Stauning's SocialistRadical government increased its majority in the lower chamber in yesterday's elections and now holds sixty-eight seats, an increase of six. The Radicals kept their fourteen seats.

Smartly dressed women and hoboes mingled at a festive buffet luncheon yesterday at the Bowery's diamond market, the largest in the world, expanded to even greater prosperity with the benediction of Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen.

Action by the Federal Government to take care of 13,000 homeless transients in this city who by order of the FERA will no longer be eligible for relief after Nov. 1 was demanded yesterday by the Welfare Council's Coordinating Committee on Unemployment after hearing testimony from representatives of eighty-one public and private welfare agencies.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 23. -- The Navy squad today went through its last hard practice for the game with Notre Dame in Baltimore Saturday, concluding the session with an offensive scrimmage against Squad B.

Lashing out at Federal interference in business and the theory that the government can remedy all economic ills, Thomas I. Parkinson, president off the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, yesterday urged 200 members of the Cotton Textile Institute, in annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore, to recapture the influence in shaping national legislation which they originally had.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 23. -- The signal for the opening of the major Italian campaign on the Somaliland front is thought to have been given last night by the Italian wireless which announced an attack by tanks and airplanes in the Webbe Shibeli River region.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP). -- Joseph Slamey, tobacco merchant, fell dead today as revenue agents, rounding up thirty men in connection with huge alleged bootleg tobacco operations, entered his place of business. He was pronounced dead, probably of a heart attack, on reaching a hospital.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar of the common stock of the Consolidated Gas Utilities Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The proposed investment bankers' conference committee has no desire to take over or render unnecessary such organizations as the Investment Bankers Association, the New York Security Dealers Association and other organizations of a similar character, but it hopes to cooperate closely with them, according to a statement issued today by B. Howell Griswold, chairman of the conference committee.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 23. -Army finished its heavy work today in preparation for the Yale game. The reserves and the B squad had a scrimmage, the latter using the Eli plays with varying success. Rain fell throughout the drill, and there was some difficulty in handling the ball.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 23 (AP). -- A. J. Sackett's Tabitha, 3-year-old chestnut filly, outgalloped Norman Church's Riskulus to win the featured fifth race at Laurel today in a blanket finish.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The continued firm tendency on the London Stock Exchange today reflected the satisfaction in financial circles over the speech of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary. The strength in British funds stood out in the trading, with the war loan receiving good support.

While the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club wrested the championship of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association from the Brooklyn Cricket Club during the campaign just closed the individual batting honors went to R. G. Ormsby of Staten Island, who, thanks to three centuries, finished the season far ahead in the averages.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23.-- An intimation that President Roosevelt's urgency in placing an arms embargo against Italy was due to a desire to placate the British with the hope of obtaining aid against Japan in the Far East is given in Izvestia, the official organ of the Soviet Government.

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- Deputies said Premier Pierre Laval today told the Chamber Foreign Affairs Committee that he had warned Premier Benito Mussolini, after the conference of Great Britain, France and Italy at Stresa, that France would have to oppose him if he violated the League of Nations covenant by invading Ethiopia.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 23 (AP). -- The special train bearing President Roosevelt to Washington stopped today for a sailfish.

Frederick I. Daniels, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, revealed yesterday that a report on the activities of Communist and other agitators at work in the relief organization in this city had been submitted to the Federal Relief Administration in Washington.

Gangland bullets felled Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, notorious former beer-runner, and three companions in a Newark (N.J.) tavern last night, precipitating warfare between racketeering gangs that led to the shooting about an hour and a half later of a Schultz henchman and a companion in this city.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP). -- Forty-two final acceptors for the Cambridgeshire Stakes, to be run at Newmarket next Wednesday, were announced today. The list included only one American-owned thoroughbred, Ralph Beaver Strassburger's Boethius.
Price movements of futures were mixed in quiet trading in the commodity markets here yesterday. In the cash markets, cotton and rubber were higher, with grains irregular and lard lower.

Beginning on Armistice Day and continuing through Thanksgiving Day, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross will conduct its yearly roll-call, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of that organization at 315 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that in the week ended last Saturday twenty-two offering sheets of various oil interests had been filed. The filing does not give to the security the approval of the commission or indicate that the commission had passed on the merits of the issue or that the material filed was correct.

Twelve of the defendants named in the government's anti-trust proceedings against persons and corporations engaged in the freshwater fish industry at Peck Slip entered pleas of guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack.
Mayor La Guardia handled critics of the new budget in tart fashion yesterday as the Board of Estimate held its first session on reductions in the estimates for 1936.

Joseph A. Ruddy, noted swimmer, water polo player and handball champion, was suspended yesterday as physical director of the Municipal Civil Service Commission after formal removal charges had been filed against him.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23 (AP). -Abraham Lazard Shushan, 42-yearold New Orleans merchant who scaled Louisiana's political ladder with Huey P. Long, was acquitted of income tax evasion tonight by a Federal court jury.

United States and Foreign Securities Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $31,885,606 as of Sept. 30. This calculation was based on market quotations or on the nominal value of $1 if market quotations were not available. In addition, the investment in the second preferred and common stocks of United States and International Securities Corporation was calculated at $1, although the common stock is listed on the New York Curb Exchange.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP). -- The City Council today approved Mayor Kelly's action in closing the stage show "Tobacco Road."

Ruling against "vicarious generosity" with stockholders' money and against payments to a "multiplicity" of lawyers and committees, Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe drastically reduced yesterday nearly all claims for services and expenses in the receivership and reorganization of the Paramount-Publix Corporation, now known as Paramount Pictures, Inc.

Second-grade railroad bonds continued to advance yesterday on the Stock Exchange in the face of the action of the New Haven road's directors in filing a reorganization petition. That the New Haven situation had been widely discounted marketwise was reflected in the market's complete isolation of the bonds of that carrier and the failure of the news to disturb the advances elsewhere in the railroad group.

To any one fully conversant with the chain of known events which brought the United States into war with Germany in 1917, Mr. LAMONT'S reasoned disclaimer, last Friday, of the myth that our Government took that step because our international bankers forced it to do so, should have been superfluous.

In the unanimous decision of the venerable State Court of Appeals rejecting his proposed municipal power plant referendum Mayor LA GUARDIA, as the saying is, "got what was coming to him." The law was clear. As the court remarked, a "mere reading" of the statute under which he sought to act would serve to reveal both its purpose and the means whereby cities could embark on such ventures if they chose to do so.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 23.-President Roosevelt in his speech at The Citadel said:

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- Ambassador Vittorio Cerutti of Italy is understood to have told Premier Pierre Laval tonight that Premier Mussolini had requested that the application of sanctions by the League of Nations be postponed beyond Oct. 31, the date fixed at present.

Two new offensive plays to be used against Pittsburgh and a revision in the first-string back field featured the workout of the Fordham football forces yesterday as the Rams drilled for about three hours on the soggy ground of Fordham Field.

Commissioner of Police Lewis J. Valentine's warning a month ago that he had ordered a thorough investigation of the work of men in the detective division, with a view to increasing the efficiency of the bureau, bore its first fruit yesterday, when 104 men were affected by special orders resulting in promotions, demotions and transfers.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 23. -If it be true that the United States is spending more money in preparation for war than any other country in the world, as Senator Nye charged last month in his address before the national convention of the W.C.T.U. at Atlantic City, the task which the Civilian Conservation Corps has undertaken on the vast military reservation seven miles north of this city may be considered both significant and premonitory.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 23. -If it be true that the United States is spending more money in preparation for war than any other country in the world, as Senator Nye charged last month in his address before the national convention of the W.C.T.U. at Atlantic City, the task which the Civilian Conservation Corps has undertaken on the vast military reservation seven miles north of this city may be considered both significant and premonitory.

ROME, Oct. 23. -- The favorable impression made yesterday by the first incomplete accounts of the speech of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, were confirmed today when the full text of his remarks was received.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Mrs. Garnet McCabe, 47 years old, of New York and Daytona Beach, Fla., applied to Justice Bleakley in Supreme Court here today for release from Matteawan State Asylum for the Criminally Insane, to which she was committed two years ago for the fatal shooting of her husband, Evert, vice president of the United Parcel Service, in their New York apartment Jan. 11, 1933.

With its fourth test of the season, the annual battle with Georgetown University, set for tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium, the New York University varsity football team went through two hours of intensive drilling yesterday at Ohio Field.

A spurt in the December sugar featured trading in futures on the commodity markets here yesterday. Price movements of other staples were mixed. Rye, tin and silk advanced in the cash market, while wheat, corn, oats, cocoa and cotton declined.

Heinz Schuengel, director of the North Atlantic service of the North German Lloyd, and Victor Neumann, director of the North Atlantic service of the Hamburg-American Line, were guests of honor yesterday at a luncheon given by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, New York's most notorious underworld denizen, and three of his henchmen are dead and another is near death from bullet wounds received in the new outbreak of gang warfare for control of the usury, policy and other rackets which has flared up in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Newark, N.J., in the last forty-eight hours.

Police Captain Richard McHale of the Flushing precinct in Queens was shot and killed at about 8 o'clock last night in his office on the ground floor of the station house. His slayer, a patrolman attached to his command who had been declared unfit for duty because of drunkenness, was shot down a moment later by a fellow-policeman and killed instantly.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24. -- Yale will face Army Saturday with the line-up that was used against Navy last week, with the possible exception of Al Hessberg, whose place at left halfback may be taken by Bernie Rankin, it was announced today.
ERNEST HEMINGWAY went to Africa to shoot the bounding kudu and the ungainly rhinoceros and to reply to his critics. The result is "Green Hills of Africa" (Scribner's, $2.75).

Proposals ranging from radical changes in the traffic laws to psychiatric examination of drivers, visual tests before licensing and placing of governors on automobiles to keep down speed were among topics discussed at the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators, which began yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.
The general notion seems to be that Michigan has the punt and the pass and Columbia only the prayer in tomorrow's meeting at Baker Field between the Wolverines and Lions.

WITH THE ITALIAN FORCES IN ETHIOPIA, AMBA AUGHER, Oct. 22 (By Courier to Asmara). -- At this historic spot, from which General Barattieri, Italian commander-in-chief in the war in 1896, started on his fatal march to Adowa and where native Askaris carrying forward the Italian centre met with their only resistance a few weeks ago, all is now peaceful.

Having officially determined that Poland is paying a bounty on the exportation of rye, the Treasury has ordered the imposition of countervailing tariff duties on Polish rye and rye flour sufficient to offset the amount of the bounty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--The Federal Reserve System's open market committee concluded a three-day meeting today without making any major shift in the system's credit policy.
Various housing and business property purchases and an industrial building project in ll'ew Jersey were reported yesterday.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Elias F. Applegate, 58 years old, of 18 De Hart Place, Elizabeth, died tonight in the South Amboy Hospital of injuries suffered yesterday when he was crushed against his own automobile on Victory Bridge, over the Raritan River, between South and Perth Amboys.

The Wine and Food Society, a non-commercial organization and an off-shoot of the British Wine and Food Society, the members of which make a serious hobby of good wines and good meals, held its first "tasting" of the season yesterday afternoon.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Florida today sent an invitation to William Randolph Hearst to move his residence from California to this State.

Sawmills will be established by the Park Department in each of the boroughs this Winter so that dead trees and old lumber may be cut up and made available to the needy for fuel, it became known yesterday.

A horse which runs so fast that he can hardly make the turns triumphed at Empire City yesterday when the Geneseo Stable's Patriotic captured the featured Hilltop Handicap by the easy margin of five lengths. Backed almost to the exclusion of all else, Patriotic was the choice at 6 to 5 and was the fourth consecutive favorite to prevail.

Department store sales during the first half of October registered a nation-wide increase of 12 per cent, as compared with the same period a year ago, according to the results of a survey issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Raymond Bauman, pianist, will give a recital tonight at the Bronx Women's Club. The recital is the first of a series of musical events to be given by the club.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- Election victories for Socialist and Democratic Lefts in such highly "Nordic" countries as Denmark, Norway and Sweden have aroused visible uneasiness in authoritarian Germany, and attempts are being made to minimize their significance.
Regarding the international situation I venture one prediction -- that whatever happens it will all be Uncle Sam's fault.

Martin Krompier, 33-year-old aide of Dutch Schultz, lay close to death last night in Polyclinic Hospital after three blood transfusions. A delicate operation failed to locate a bullet that entered his abdomen when he was shot at midnight Wednesday with Samuel Gold, 35, Broadway handbook maker, in a basement barber shop at 1,570 Broadway at Forty-seventh Street.
The following are the records of Schultz's henchmen, and of Samuel Gold, who apparently has no connection with the gang, as released yesterday at Police Headquarters:

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- Heavy receipts of hogs here again today dropped prices 25 to 35 cents a hundredweight to the lowest level since early in July, and they showed losses of $2.25 to $2.50 from the best figures of the season, paid six weeks ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Mrs. Barbara S. Loew of Briarcliff applied to Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley today for alimony of $3,000 a month and initial counsel and investigation fees of $17,500 in a separation suit against her husband, Arthur M. Loew, first vice president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Less than a block apart, in Fifty-seventh Street, there are at the moment two fascinating exhibitions devoted to the arts of needlework and weaving. Centuries, to be sure, separate them in point of time; but in a fundamental sense this work is so to speak, all of a piece.

An experiment to determine the advisability of extending its price limits to include merchandise items retailing at 35 to 40 cents is being conducted by the F.W. Woolworth Company in a number of its 150 Canadian stores, officials of the company stated yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24. -- The Argentine Government persists in maintaining its policy of discrimination against the United States in the import trade despite the continued heavy increase in American purchases of Argentine products. The monthly foreign trade statistics just given out show that exports to the United States in nine months of this year were more than double those of the corresponding period of last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Eight directors and officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were prohibited today by the Federal Communications Commission from holding interlocking positions in Bell System operating companies.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York forwarded to officials in Washington yesterday a resolution protesting against cessation of Coast and Geodetic Survey projects along American seaboards as a result of the exhaustion of Public Works funds appropriated for this purpose.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The long-heralded invitations to the nations signatory to the Washington and London naval treaties to attend a new conference this year were sent by the British Government today to the United States, Japanese, French and Italian Embassies.

Frank Merlin and Brian Marlow have gone behind the scenes at a murder trial, invaded the hotel where the jury is confined and emerged with a new play, "Good Men and True." The' latter, in turn, emerges tonight at the Biltmore in a production by Mr. Merlin and with a cast which includes Eliot Cabot, Martha Sleeper, Vera Marshe, John Gallaudet, Dodson Mitchell and Percy Helton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Charles P. Cooper sought to hold additional posts as director of the Southern New England Telephone, New York Telephone, New Jersey Bell Telephone, Bell Telephone of Pennsylvania, Diamond State Telephone, Ohio Bell Telephone, Indiana Bell Telephone, Mountain State Telephone and Telegraph, Pacific Telephone and Telegraph and Cuban-American Telephone Companies.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Army finished preparations for the Yale game with a light practice on the Plains today. The players passed and kicked the ball about, went through a few calisthenics and ended the practice with a brief signal drill.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 24. -- The threatened breach between Premier Mohammed Tewfik Nessim Pasha and the Wafd (Nationalist party) has now been averted. Mustafa Pasha Nahas and Makram Ebeid, leaders of moderate sections of the ward, evidently impressed by the restlessness of their more militant colleagues, have been steadily urging Nessim Pasha to obtain British consent for new treaty negotiations and to reintroduce constitutional government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The lines of Washington's reply to the League of Nations inquiry as to the position of the United States on sanctions in the Italo-Ethiopian war were charted by President Roosevelt at a luncheon conference with Secretary of State Cordell Hull today.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- The Radical Socialist party congress, the decisions of which may exert the greatest influence on the fate of the Laval government, was opened with an appeal for unity by its president, Edouard Herriot. Mr. Herriot is evidently anxious to prevent a split in France's largest party, which threatens to break its power and turn a large part of its more radical elements over to an alliance with the Socialist-Communist Common Front.

In the latest numbers of the long serial story of murder for business there is nothing new. The strain of competition among racketeers, the professional hired murderer, the rivals trying to invade and break down a too successful monopoly, are familiar. In AMBERG of Brooklyn, last and busiest of three brothers on whom violent deeds brought violent ends, was a certain originality.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Friday, Oct. 25.--Former Mayor James J. Walker of New York boarded the liner Manhattan early this morning when the ship arrived from Germany, several hours late on account of fog. The Manhattan was further held up to load bullion here and was scheduled to sail at 10 A.M. (5 A.M., New York time).

Harold S. Glendening, lawyer and former Rhodes scholar, resigned the first job he had after their marriage in 1922 because he "didn't like to ride downtown in the subway every morning," his former wife, Mrs. Alicia Maddox Glendening Llewellyn, testified before Supreme Court Referee Edward J. Gavegan yesterday.

The ancient racket of usury, refurbished with the strong-arm methods of modern gangsters, was said yesterday to have been an important contributing factor in the underworld feud which brought about the shooting of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 24. -- Operation of the motor bus industry under the new Motor Carrier Act was the principal topic of discussion at opening sessions of the National Association of Motor Bus Operators hero today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Princeton finished its hard work for the Cornell game with a dummy scrimmage today. The squad, thirty-five strong, will entrain tomorrow morning and reach Ithaca in time for a workout in the afternoon.

Members of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, attended a preview last night of an exhibition of the work of Le Corbusier, modern French architect, which was opened with a lecture by the architect himself.
LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange strengthened further today as a result of the better outlook for international affairs.

ROME, Friday, Oct. 25. -- The first tangible conciliatory gesture aimed at lessening Anglo-Italian tension in the Mediterranean was made today by Premier Benito Mussolini in ordering the withdrawal of an army division, numbering 15,000 men, from Libya.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Emphasizing the necessity for continued support and development of private educational institutions, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, warned at the Autumn meeting of the board of trustees today that "education must not become a State monopoly."

Mixed movements in the foreign exchange market yesterday, combined with continued small engagements of gold abroad for shipment here, indicated that European exchanges were breaking away from the hitherto dominant influence of the flight of capital induced by the fear of war.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York Bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

Wednesday's declaration of insolvency by the New Haven Railroad, and its petition to the court for the effecting of financial reorganization under the amended Bankruptcy Act, was not entirely unexpected. The railway had been particularly hard hit by the shrinkage of earnings in the depression period; its total net revenue, even in 1934, was far below that of 1933 or 1932, and less than one-half what it was in 1931.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- In a characteristically brief statement of forty-six words Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today revealed that fines of $200 each had been assessed against American League Umpire George Moriarty and four Chicago Cubs, among them Manager Charlie Grimm, as a result of their verbal blasts and arguments during the 1935 world series.

After a season dedicated chiefly to trash it is a sobering sensation to sit in the presence of a playwright who is trying his best to tell what he has on his mind. In "Mulatto," which was acted at the Vanderbilt last evening, Langston Hughes, the Negro poet, is attempting to describe the tragic confusion of the people whose blood is half black and half white.

With the arrest of Austin H. Montgomery in Rochester on Tuesday, Federal, State and New York City authorities believe that they have broken up a mail fraud ring that has been operating throughout New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 24. -- Lively recollections of what happened two years ago just before the Notre Dame game have caused precautions to be taken to guard Bill, the Navy goat, in a hiding place so that no partisan of the Ramblers will get a chance to paint him green another time.

The hoard of directors of the Cities Service Company announced yesterday the redemption of the entire issue of 1,000,000 shares of 5 per cent non-cumulative stock sold to Henry L. Doherty Co. in April, 1929. The stock was redeemed at $1 a share, the price at which it was sold, in accordance with the charter provision.

Bank clearings at the nation's twenty-two leading cities in the week ended on Wednesday increased 27.5 per cent to $5,649,897,000, compared with $4,430,487,000 a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In the preceding week they gained 20.6 per cent.

Retail package deliveries for the week ended Oct. 19 showed a rise of 8 per cent, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. Reflecting the effects of warm weather upon trade here, the figure showed a decrease under the gain of 11 per cent noted for the preceding week.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Lady Mary Crewe-Milnes, 20-year-old daughter of the Marquess and Marchioness of Crewe, became the youngest duchess in England today when she was married in historic Westminster Abbey to the 22-year-old Duke of Roxburghe, whose mother is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Goelet of Newport and New York.

Apparently because of a tendency on the part of the bullishly inclined to mark time, rather than because of a pressure of offerings, stocks failed yesterday to retain their early firmness and closed irregularly lower; the tone at the last was steady. The setback was the first since Friday.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 (AP). -- New York State's Works Progress Administration, long delayed by lack of funds, prepared tonight to put "thousands of men" to work with $15,086,733 In Federal money which Lester W. Herzog, State Administrator, announced he had received from the Federal Government.

One of the most interesting orchestral programs heard here in late seasons was given by Otto Klemperer and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. This program did not depend for effect upon a "novelty'' or "revival," or composition of some sensational sort; its suggestive and highly illuminating nature was due solely to the fortunate choice and arrangement of the material.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--Federal revenue collections are "encouraging," but President Roosevelt's estimate of a $670,000,000 increase this year will not be fulfilled without a resumption of full processing tax collections, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

The Druckman murder case controversy, which has become a major political issue in Brooklyn and the subject of a departmental inquiry by the police, will be threshed out in open court before County Judge Algeron I. Nova in Brooklyn this morning.

Fielding Yost, director of athletics at Michigan, addressed an interested group of eighty former football players, giving many of his views of the game, at the Touchdown Club's luncheon at the Yale Club yesterday.

New York's professional theatre critics may be congratulated on an exceedingly happy thought. They have decided to choose every year a best play for themselves instead of leaving the field wholly to the Pulitzer awards.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

United States Government obligations ran counter to the general trend of steadiness in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and, with but three exceptions, all of the Federal issues registered losses for the day. Other groups held steady throughout the session, with railroads and utilities moving up sharply.

ALBANY, Oct. 24. -- Declaring that the fight for reform of county government was at a crucial point, with opposition "strong and determined," Governor Lehman in a radio speech tonight urged voters of the State, irrespective of party, to vote yes on the proposed amendment No. 1.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Changing winds whipped the Malibu Hills brush fire out of control again tonight, destroying at least three additional expensive homes, while Southern California counted its two-day fire and gale loss at $8,000,000.

Sharp criticism of the $8,000,000 Brooklyn Beach Gardens apartment project at Cropsey and Twenty-first Avenues, Brooklyn, was expressed last night by Charles Abrams, general consultant to the New York City Housing Authority, in a speech at the Williamsburg Public Housing Conference at 523 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

The directors of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 75 cent a share on the common stock, payable on Jan. 2 to stock of record Dec. 1, compared with $1.25 previously paid quarterly.

President Roosevelt carried us back to the horse and buggy days in arms and ammunition when he issued his proclamation based on the neutrality resolution of Congress. By that instrument he decreed that rifles shooting a cartridge with a projectile three-tenths of an inch in diameter or larger were prohibited from export to Italy or Ethiopia, but no mention was made of rifles using smaller projectiles.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Dismissal of a court test of constitutionality of the Utility Holding Company Act was asked by the government today in a brief charging "collusive" cooperation between some persons interested in the case.

The Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway may report a small net income for 1935, the first for any year since 1931, according to a statement on file with the Interstate Commerce Commission. The company estimates its net income for September was $17,144 and its net loss for the first nine months of the year $6,065,000.

The election of Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, director of the bureau of foreign and domestic commerce of the Department of Commerce, to the presidency of the Cotton-Textile Institute, was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 23, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,485,000.000, a decrease of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week, and an' increase of $25,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

A definite shift in the first-string line-up of the Fordham football team was effected yesterday following the announcement by Coach Jim Crowley that three of his star athletes will not be used In the game with Lebanon Valley at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- A prediction that the Federal dole of direct relief would be ended during November and more than 2,000,000 persons now on relief rolls would be transferred to work relief payrolls by Dec. 1 was made tonight by President Roosevelt.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24. -- Through interoffice correspondence of the Pennsylvania-Greyhound Lines, counsel for the National Labor Relations Board today read into the record evidence aiming to prove that the company had imposed a company union on its employes.

William Dinsmore Barrows, 28 years old, of 1,017 Madison Avenue, was killed instantly about 8:30 o'clock last night when he jumped or fell from the window of a seventh-floor apartment at 105 East Fifty-third Street. According to the police, the young man was employed by Whaley-Eaton Service of 67 Broad Street, a firm of economists.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter year ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $3,882,914 after all charges, provision for Federal income tax and reserves for depreciation, depletion and intangible development expenditures.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- What he called "the most momentous occasion in my life," was experienced tonight by Dr. Francis E. Townsend, 68-year-old Long Beach, Calif., physician, as he rose to address a big first convention of his "$200-a-month" clubs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Exports of chemicals and allied products in September were more than 10 per cent greater in value than a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today, and were only slightly less than the value for August.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 24 (London Times Dispatch). -- The expected decision of the Italian Government to withdraw one of three divisions recently sent to Libya may be due as much to the inconvenience of maintaining the troops there as to political considerations.
BERLIN, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Subway construction in Berlin endangers the huge Bluecher Palace, which the United States intended to use as its embassy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Industrial employment in September reached the highest level since November, 1930, Secretary Perkins said today, showing figures to indicate that 350,000 had returned to work last month. Based on 1923-25 averages, the month's index was 83.6, as compared to 81.8 in August and to 75.9 a year ago.

The United Founders group of investment trusts which are to be merged into a new company, the American General Corporation, in accordance with a plan of simplification proposed to stockholders, reported yesterday their earnings for the nine months ended on Aug. 31.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- What to do with the stubborn Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller is a question that is becoming a nightmare for Hanns Kerrl, Minister of Church Affairs, who invited the Bishop to his office this afternoon.

The "New York World's Fair, 1939" has got off to a good start. Its published list of incorporators is, indeed, as Mr. McANENY describes it, a "cross-section of representative New Yorkers." It includes men of note in most of the trades and professions and in the various walks of city life.

Sales of housing properties featured realty activity in this city yesterday. Trading, which was light, was widely scattered over Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn. Plans for remodeling some of the properties were announced.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 24. -- Outclassing the University of South Carolina in every department of the game, Clemson College triumphed, 44 to 0, today at the State Fair Grounds. It was the most overwhelming defeat South Carolina has suffered at the hands of its ancient State rival in many years.
ATHENS, Oct. 24. -- The Official Gazette today published a decree signed by the Regent, General George Kondylis, in the King's name, wherein the Cabinet disposes of the enemies of the present regime.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Political circles in London are showing intense interest in news just received through an extremely reliable channel of information from Berlin that Chancellor Adolf Hitler's foreign policy is about to undergo a sudden sensational change.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- Governmental interference with the nation's business set-up was condemned by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, at a luncheon of the Boston Chamber of Commerce today.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 24. -- For the last twenty-four hours rumors have been afloat regarding what now proves to have been one of the most important encounters in recent times between Federal troops and a large number of insurgents in the State of Jalisco.

In the early days of the Emergency Relief Bureau members of its staff worked under disheartening conditions. Between the investigator's report of a needy case and the actual grant of relief there was often a great gulf fixed, filled to the brim with red tape. Generally the investigator had to serve also as messenger boy and typewriter.

ALBANY, Oct. 24. -- The Mack Utility Investigating Committee brought to the surface today practices of the Associated Gas and Electric system which hitherto had not been revealed, and which the State Public Service Commission has been endeavoring, without success, to investigate for the past three years.

An application for authorization to pay an initial dividend of 5 per cent to creditors and debenture holders of the International Match Corporation has been filed by the Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for the company, with Oscar W. Ehrhorn. referee in bankruptcy for the United States District Court.
No change was apparent in any section of the money market. Business remained small at prevailing quotations.
BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- "Bootleg butter'' is being smuggled over the Polish frontier into Germany as a result of the shortage of fats.

Following as an aftermath to the gatherings of motor boat contest boards on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday which forecast with enthusiastic optimism the coming year of 1936, yesterday's conclave of drivers and officials at the Hotel Lexington was the annual meeting of the American Power Boat Association to hear and approve reports and generally to take a stock inventory of the season just passed.

Fewer than 3,500, or about 17 per cent, of the 18,000 employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau answered the stoppage call of the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies yesterday, according to Miss Charlotte Carr, director of the bureau.

Mayor La Guardia made public a list last night showing the distribution of 60 per cent of his collection of Japanese gifts, after some of his colleagues on the Board of Estimate and their assistants had accounted for the other 40 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Problems faced by the investment bankers as underwriters of securities were discussed today with James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, by Benjamin J. Buttenweiser of Kuhn, Loeb Co., John Cutler of Edward B. Smith Co. and Alan M. Pope of the First Boston Corporation, all of New York.

Manhattan's football squad, in its final hard session before the engagement with North Carolina State at Ebbets Field tomorrow, was put through a lengthy rehearsal of its plays at Innisfail Park yesterday.

Award of the John Fritz Gold Medal for 1936 has been made to William Frederick Durand, Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Stanford University, it was announced yesterday by the John Fritz Medal Board of Award. The announcement termed the medal the "highest of American engineering honors."

Typewritten instructions to the victim of a robbery, to prevent conversation during the commission of a crime, which police allege were found in a bag owned by James Bampton Little, 45 years old, when he was arrested yesterday, solved, detectives say, the theft of $12,000 from a New York, New Haven Hartford ticket cage in Grand Central Station on Sept. 17, 1934.

The odor of powder smoke permeated the usually peaceful quarters of the superintendent of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday afternoon when he was ejected temporarily from his office, which was converted into a pistol range for the seventh annual pistol competition between the day and night guards of the museum.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion nominee for the Kings County District Attorneyship, told political audiences last night that "dead gangsters get more attention than live ones."
The Bank of England bought 96,500 in bar gold.

Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, called upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday to make a "public apology" for an assertion at Wednesday's meeting of the Board of Estimate that a statement of Dr. Tildsley's was that of an "ignoramus."

ROME, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Two armies in Ethiopia were said today to be ready for a march on Harar. Planes will clear the way for 300,000 men to attempt to take a broad band of Western Ethiopia, connecting Italy's colonies, Eritrea and Italian Somaliland.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The British Government tried to give an impression of firmness in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis today so that neither Premier Mussolini nor the Opposition parties in this country should think that it was "running away from the League."

Babe Ruth has received a proposal from persons interested in the promotion of baseball in England to go there and act as coach or instructor to teams which are being formed in an effort to establish the American national game.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Oct. 25 (AP). -- The Japanese Embassy here announced today that two United States sailors were involved in an alleged insult to the Japanese flag at Tsingtao yesterday and that the two men had narrowly escaped falling into the hands of a mob of Japanese.

GENEVA, Oct. 24. -- The International Labor Office's governing body opening its seventy-third session today voted, seventeen to six, to put before the June Conference the question of drafting a convention establishing a minimum forty-hour week in the textile industry.

A decline of 0.7 point in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices carried the index to 129.1 on Tuesday from 129.8 (revised) on the preceding Tuesday and a five-year high of 130.2 on the Tuesday before that.

Angered by the tone of criticism used yesterday by Joseph Goldsmith on the 1936 budget, Mayor La Guardia ordered Mr. Goldsmith evicted from the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hail, where the board was holding its last public hearing on budget reductions.

The body of Louis (Pretty) Amberg was claimed at the Kings County Morgue yesterday afternoon by I.J. Morris, an undertaker of 296 sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, who said that he acted for the Amberg family. The body was taken immediately to Montefiore Cemetery in Springfield, Queens, where it was buried without any ceremony.
U.S. Department of Agriculture.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Criticism of the policies of the Federal administration was expressed by Governor Hoffman off New Jersey and Dr. Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, in speeches before the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24.--Sportsmen of America will not tolerate the use of athletics as a means of transporting Old World hatreds to this country, Avery Brundage of Chicago, President of the American Olympic Association and chairman of the American Olympic Committee, declared today.
Until Nov. 1 the Lincoln Gallery, in the Abraham Lincoln High School, in Brooklyn, is showing color prints of work by modern masters of painting, by arrangement with the F.A.R. Gallery.

The present Duke of Roxburghe, through his mother, the former Miss May Goelet, is half-American. He is a grandson of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Goelet, whose home for many years was at 608 Fifth Avenue, now occupied by a commercial building, and a grandnephew of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt. who went to London for the wedding.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24. -- The "battle of the century" will be between the people who are paying for relief and those who are receiving it, declared William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare of New York City, in an address tonight at a general session of the New York State Conference of Social Workers.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP).--Mayor Edward J. Kelly and his police were swept out of the way of the return of "Tobacco Road" to the Chicago stage by Federal court order today.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- In the one notable speech on the third and final day of the Parliamentary debate on the Ethiopian war, Winston Churchill declared today that even now Germany was the chief menace in Europe. Italy's aggression in Ethiopia and France's hesitancy of recent weeks he attributed to the danger of a heavily rearmed Reich.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Another $50,000,000 issue of bills for maturity on March 16 was announced today by the Treasury, running up to $250,000,000 the bills that will be redeemed on that date. All these bills will be paid with money the Treasury expects to receive then from income tax payments.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- The Boerse was firmer in the early trading today, although the activity was as limited as usual and considerable weakness appeared later. Few changes of more than 1/4 point were recorded, and the market closed completely stagnant.
LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- Local operations continued today to dominate the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and while moderate strength was shown early the upturn was not maintained in the face of commission-house selling. Operators here who bought at the start on strong cable messages from Liverpool started to go out of their lines and found little demand until prices had receded around 1 1/2c a bushel from the high point.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Francis Lane, figured on as a regular halfBack at Harvard early in the Fall, turned in his uniform today and is out of football for the remainder of the year. The knee which Lane injured in the Springfield game has not improved, and he will soon undergo an operation.

PELHAM, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Launching a powerful aerial attack in the second half for three touchdowns, the Pelham High football squad removed Eastchester High from the unbeaten ranks by conquering the visitors, 21 -- 19, today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 24. -- Four persons were killed and a police corporal and several others were wounded in an armed clash between alleged Nationalists and the police today in the heart of the university town of Rio Piedras.
