The city of Seattle, Wash., will enter the investment market on next Monday with two new issues aggregating $5,500,000. Officials announced yesterday that the new issue of $600,000 municipal light and power bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1935, and maturing from 1943 to 1949, which had been scheduled for sale on Nov. 1, will be sold next Monday instead, together with a new issue of $4.900,000 light and power bonds, dated Nov. 15, 1935.

The continued influx of gold from abroad lifted the reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System another $41,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve's weekly report, issued yesterday. The reserve requirements of the banks rose about $21,000,000 in the week with the result that $20,000,000 was added to their excess reserves, carrying them to a record high of $2,930.000,000.

In a recent address before the Barnard students, Mrs. Roosevelt is quoted as saying: "I have received many, many letters which say 'My forebears came over in the Mayflower.' How all the people who came to this country in the Mayflower were contained in the Mayflower I don't know."

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- With extreme secrecy and to the accompaniment of many denials, negotiations have been begun again by Premier Pierre Laval with Britain on one side and Italy on the other in an effort to find some way of settling the Italo-Ethiopian quarrel and preventing its developing into a direct quarrel between Britain and Italy.
PARIS, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
DETROIT, Oct. 24. -- Community fund campaigns in about 400 cities of the country began this evening with a radio program which had Detroit as the key city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The decision of the five large bituminous coal companies to defy the Guffey Coal Law is part of a concerted attack on New Deal policies by "financially entrenched" interests, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, said today.
REPORTS have been received from a couple of good scouts who wandered away from the Eastern gridirons to have a view of football in other territory. Taking leave to print:

Christ Divaris, 32 years old, foreman for the Eastern Painting Company in its contract to decorate the new penitentiary on Rikers Island, was found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of forcing painters under him to "kick back" $10 weekly of their $45 wages.

A rise in commutation rates is the only source from which the Long Island Railroad can obtain the additional revenues needed to avert a $1,000,000 deficit for 1935 and an even larger one for 1936, according to testimony given yesterday by George Le Boutillier, vice president of the road.
PARIS, Oct. 24.--Magnificent private homes with burial vaults in their cellars have been discovered by a French archeological mission at Ras Shamra in Northern Syria.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 24. -- Careful study by Ethiopians said to be in close touch with the Emperor confirms the mingled satisfaction and disappointment, the latter predominating, over the speech of Sir Samuel Hoare.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24. -- Stabilization of the bituminous coal industry as envisaged under the Guffey Coal Control Law was imperiled today when it became known that five of the country's principal coal corporations would not sign the "miniature NRA Coal Code."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The meeting in Chicago on next Monday called by the executive committee of the Associated Stock Exchanges to discuss with officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission the advisability, of complete segregation of the functions of broker and dealer will bring together the largest number of Stock Exchange executives ever assembled at such a conference, Eugene E. Thompson, executive vice president of the committee, announced today.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- The names of Jews who fell in the World War fighting for Germany are not to appear in the future on German war monuments. This application of the Third Reich's racial principles is indicated in instructions issued by the Propaganda Ministry which declare it is forbidden to "specify" on public monuments the names of Jews.

Commissioner Lithgow Osborne believes the licensed sportsmen of New York should be apprised of the cooperation accorded to the Conservation Department by various State and municipal agencies in the management and improvement of wild life resources.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24. -- The Gulf Refining Company has erected at Harmarville, Pa., during the years of depression a group of modern buildings to house the geologists, geophysicists, chemists and engineers who conduct research to improve the methods of obtaining refining and utilizing petroleum and its derivatives.

Brokers announced several leases of large apartments in buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues yesterday. Some of the large suites were rented furnished. A maisonette apartment of fifteen rooms and six baths in 775 Park Avenue was leased furnished to Charles E. Sampson by Douglas L. Elliman Co.

The spectacular end to the spectacular career of Dutch Schultz fulfilled the tradition that a gangster chieftain never dies of old age. They seldom ever reach even middle age. Few of the notorious racketeers and gunmen shot down in a spectacular manner in the last ten years have been over 40.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 24. -- The feeling of the Ethiopian Government, including Emperor Halle Selassie, is downcast and disappointed over the British attitude as expressed by Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare and Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin. It is hoped the new British attitude is assumed mainly for election, purposes.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- The German press greets with enthusiasm the presentation of the Nobel Prize for Medicine to a German, Professor Hans Spemann of Freiburg. It points out that half the prizes granted to date in physics and chemistry have gone to Germans, as well as seven prizes in medicine.

Reorganization of the larger issues of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates and administration of the properties to put them on a dividend-paying basis for the investors made further progress yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler appointed three trustees for the Series Q issue of $10,315,089.66 sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Republican spokesmen condemned the New Deal from AAA to TVA at a State campaign rally here tonight. John Hamilton of Kansas, counsel to the Republican National Committee; Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the State committee, and Mrs. George Simmons of Missouri joined in attacking the Roosevelt program with characterizations which ranged from "balminess" to communism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Although the Federal Power Commission received today applications from about 140 officers and directors of operating utility companies for permission to serve on boards or as officers of more than one such organization, it appeared probable that only a small percentage of those which had been expected would be filed by the deadline, tomorrow midnight.

Behind the deserted stands of Baker Field, which tomorrow will hold the thousands gathered to see one of New York's major intersectional games, Columbia yesterday put the finishing touches on its attempted comeback.

Circulars distributed by brokers to their clients show a mixed attitude toward the stock market. Some brokers feel that the advance, having lasted seven months, is in its last phase; others believe that, while there may be minor interruptions, the trend is still upward and that prices still have a long way to go before they "top off."

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, killed by gunmen in Newark, was just an unambitious, sloppy flat-burglar and package thief in the Bronx until he was caught up on the big beer wave during prohibition and lifted to great power in New York's criminal empire.

GOUDA, the Netherlands, Oct. 24. -- Winning the tenth game tonight, Dr. Max Euwe, the Netherlands' outstanding chess master and challenger for the world championship, gained his third victory at the expense of Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the titleholder, who now leads by a score of 6 -- 4.

The greatest attempt ever made by the government to draw a true picture of conditions in American distribution will be represented in the 1935 business census to be launched Jan. 2, Dr. Vergil D. Reed, chief of the wholesale and retail trade bureau of the census,

In Monday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES William Floyd, who I understand to be director of the organization styled Peace Patriots, asks me to explain a Woodrow Wilson speech and some Ambassador Page references which Mr. Floyd cites in support of the thesis that bankers and business men drew this country into the World War.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Walter Schaeffer, a race track exercise boy, was charged with murder, and Willie Saunders, a jockey, with accessory to murder here today by the grand jury that investigated the death of Mrs. Evelyn Sliwinski.

Although the threatened frost in western sections of the Cotton Belt did not develop, and many contracts bought on fears of crop damage came back on the market, prices on the Cotton Exchange displayed steadiness yesterday and closed at losses of 3 to 8 points.

Canada and the United States have a common duty and a common opportunity today in upholding the soundness of the lesson of democracy which they have taught the world, the Prime Minister of the Province of Nova Scotia, Angus Lewis Macdonald, said last night in his address at the Maple Leaf dinner of the Canadian Society of New York at the Hotel Biltmore.

Although brokers' loans increased $14,000,000, following a decline of $7,000,000 a week ago, the total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City fell $46,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks, published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Arguments in support of the petition of the Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle, in New York City, for better broadcasting facilities on its station, WLWL, were presented today at the reopening of the hearing begun in June with the presentation of the petition to the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The general level of wholesale prices remained unchanged during the week ended on Oct. 19, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on 1926 averages, was 80.7.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Informed sources said tonight that a French journalist who has acted in the past for Premier Pierre Laval had attempted without success to draw out Chancellor Adolf Hitler on some of the complications facing Europe as a result of the Italo-Ethiopian War.

H.A. Calahan, expert on yachting, who has just written a sequel to Robert Louis Stevenson's "Treasure Island," which Vanguard will publish next month, contends that Stevenson left "plants" for a sequel, apparently intending to write one himself.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Ninety-two players teed off at the Westchester Country Club today in the final one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's season and Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, the metropolitan titleholder, turned in a card of 82 to win low gross for the third straight time.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- President Roosevelt's radio speech tonight in connection with the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs was as follows:

Prince Juan of Bourbon, youngest son of the former King Alfonso of Spain, arrived on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday with his bride of two weeks, the former Princess Maria de la Esperanza of Bourbon-Siciles. The young Prince and his bride, who is also his cousin, are making a world tour and plan to spend several weeks in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The belief that the consumer has any real choice in buying milk is an "absolute fiction" which results only in higher prices, Walton H. Hamilton, director of the Consumers Division of the NRA, said today in a report on the beginning of his study of the milk industry's price structure.

There is an unmistakable pause in the Ethiopian dispute while the chief European Powers grope for a solution. That Britain and France are considering a compromise which would grant so large a part of what Italy wants that its terms would have to be imposed by force on Ethiopia is unlikely.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The invitation extended by Great Britain to a naval limitation conference in London Dec. 2 was promptly accepted by the United States Government tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The old isolation of the United States is dead, Professor Arthur Newell of Boston, first holder of the Bryce Fellowship for promoting Anglo-American understanding, declared before the American Chamber of Commerce here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.(AP) -- President Roosevelt returned to the White House this morning after an absence of four weeks and resumed work at once with a series of conferences which put him again in touch with the important questions facing his administration.

The curtailment of prices by business rather than by "the intrusions of government" will help to increase national production and lead to a new era of prosperity, according to Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, who outlined current trends in this field yesterday at a luncheon of the Rotary Club in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- WPA workers who wish to do so may go on strike, but they will have their pay cut off the moment they cease work, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, declared today upon his return to Washington with President Roosevelt.

That Menachem Rubin's adaptation of Sholom Aleichem's "Tevye the Dairyman," which was added to the repertoire of the Public Theatre last night, is not very cogent drama is not important. That it goes along at its own sweet will, that it arbitrarily breaks into song, is also not important.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 25. -- The army has just completed successful operations against a section of Yezidis, or devil-worshipers, in the Jebel-Sinjar area, eighty miles west of Mosul.
This is one for the psychologists.
" Bad Boy," Twentieth Century Fox film of Vina Delmar's novel, featuring James Dunn, will begin a week's showing at the Globe tonight.

If Red Badgro is unable to assume his place in the New York Giants line-up against the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, Ray Flaherty will be drafted from his job as assistant coach to play end. Flaherty, an all-league wing two years ago, has been working with the squad all season and is in shape to play.

The second concert in the series of five one-man programs, featuring American contemporary music, was given last night at the New School for Social Research. The compositions of Roy Harris made up the program.

In recent years there has been a remarkable increase in the number of picture books for adults. Commenting on the latest of these, "The Story of America in Pictures," which presents the highlights of our history from the beginning to the present, The Nation remarks that the shift, in about the middle of the book, from reproduced paintings or drawings to reproduced photographs suggests a significant fact.

Charging that District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan's office is guilty of laxity in the prosecution of well-known criminals for major crimes, Joseph D. McGoldrick, the Republican-Fusion nominee, made public yesterday the details of a murder case involving Abe Reles, notorious Brownsville gangster, in which an assistant district attorney agreed to a "not guilty" verdict.

After deciding that Howard C. Hopson must testify before trial in a stockholder suit by Henry I. Gilbert to compel him and other officers and directors of the Associated Gas and Electric Company to account for alleged losses of $20,000,000, due to their acts, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins recalled the decision and after a reargument handed down an opinion yesterday refusing to grant the examination.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Alleged fraudulent practices in the sale of Trusteed Diversified Royalty trust certificates and Davis-Stinnett units, oil land trust certificates, were placed under a restraint by Judge William Clark in Federal court today on application of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- New fields of discovery were opened to chemists this afternoon when the American Chemical Society held its annual intersectional meeting at the Union College chemical laboratory and heard noted colleagues report on the results of their researches during the past year.

Importers suing to test the government's right to collect a special tax of $2 a gallon on imported liquor lost their case yesterday when the Third Division United States Customs Court ruled that the impost was constitutional.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP). -- A committee for holders of bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad system asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reject, without public hearings, a plan of reorganization proposed by the management of the road.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 25. -A 13-year-old boy, alleged to have fired the shot which wounded Edward J. Bullwinkel, New York stock broker, near here while he was riding on the Nyack "Bankers Flyer" of the Erie Railroad, was questioned late today with four other boys about recent damages to commuters trains.

GLENCOVE, L.I., Oct. 25. -- Another year of competitive squash racquets was officially inaugurated this evening as a field of twentyfour of the metropolitan area's leading players took part in the Nassau Country Club's annual handicap tourney.
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The essential parts of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's broadcast from Chequers tonight follow:

Prices were irregular in light trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Rubber futures were strong and active. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, lard, tin and rubber advanced and oats, flour, coffee and silk declined.

For many gunners of the metropolitan area who are unable to spare the time for trips to the good grouse areas in the northern part of the State the hunting season will begin next Monday and end on Nov. 9.

DUBLIN, Oct. 25. -- The Irish Free State Army's crack jumping team embarked on the liner Manhattan at Cobh today bound for New York, taking with it the unique, beautiful trophy presented by President de Valera to the National Horse Show Association of America as the Irish Army challenge trophy.

Annual Church Day of the Girl Scouts of America will be observed tomorrow with special services for their respective faiths. About 900 Catholic Girl Scouts of Manhattan Council will receive holy communion at the 9 A.M. mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor spent $1,830,000 In the fiscal year ended Oct. 1 last on needed welfare and relief work for which no public provision was made. This was announced yesterday in a report issued by Bailey B. Burritt, general director of the association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- To eliminate the necessity for repetition of much of the material already filed by corporations, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of a new form, 8-A, for the registration on national securities exchanges of securities issued exclusively to holders of other securities of the corporation, which are already registered on the same exchange.
TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 25 (AP). -Kansas Republicans presented Governor Alf M. Landon to the nation tonight as their candidate for the Presidential nomination in 1936.
In your paper today a letter from C. J. C. on the subject of "Police Conversations" attracted my sympathetic notice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Spruille Braden, New York business man and veteran of Pan-American conferences, will sail from New York tomorrow on the liner Western World for Buenos Aires to become second delegate of the United States to the peace conference which is attempting to achieve a permanent settlement of the Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay.

A spectacular five-alarm fire which lighted up part of the Brooklyn waterfront and could be seen for miles, destroyed the George Douglass Lumber Company at Oak and Calyer Streets, in Greenpoint, last night. The fire spreading rapidly, blazed for three hours.

The revival of the cotillion, in which many debutantes of this season danced the graceful steps popular in their grandmothers' days, and a parade of jewel gowns were among the striking features of the Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillion held last night at the WaldorfAstoria.

For the first time since he became Mayor, Mr. La Guardia made a public apology yesterday tc an official whom he had criticized as an ignoramus at a budget hearing before the Board of Estimate last Wednesday.

Reaching the midway mark in its current drive, the Fordham football team will engage Lebanon Valley at the Polo Grounds starting at 2:30 this afternoon. A crowd of 15,000 persons is expected to be on hand at the kick-off.

ROCKWELL KENT may be a dawn man of the Brave New World, or he may be merely a left-over Cellini. But at least there is nothing of the little man, troubled about what is to happen now, about him. He cuts his own patterns. Loving the wilderness and Bohemia too, he goes to almost deserted gray spots on the map and creates his own Bohemia.

Eliot Buffinton, 36 years old, a former member of the Stock Exchange firm of Harriman Keech, 11 Broadway, was found dead at 10 A.M. yesterday in the bathroom of a suite on the eleventh floor at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza, Sixth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP). -Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Oct. 18 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 6,589,799 running bales, compared with 6,743,904 a year ago and 8,608,090 two year ago. Round bales, counted as half bales, included in the total numbered 103,603, compared with 121,613 a year ago and 327,418 two years ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 25. -John Charles Thomas, baritone, opened the sixth season of Mrs. Julian Olney's musical presentations at the County Centre tonight. About 2,500 persons attended. The recital was warmly applauded.

New York University's array of freshman backs, led by Henry Mazzei and Harry Shorten, rushed through the stubborn-fighting Milford School eleven in impressive fashion at Ohio Field yesterday to give the Violet yearlings a 20-to-6 triumph in their opening football game.

The General Motors Corporation in a preliminary statement of earnings for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president, put net earnings at $30,753,088, equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to 66 cents a share on the average number of common shares outstanding in the period.

The Moscow Cathedral' Choir, conducted by Nicholas Afonsky, who founded it eleven years ago in Paris, promptly enthralled its many hearers in Town Hall last night, where it made its initial New York bow. By the end of the first number of its opening group, devoted to sacred choruses, there was already sturdy applause, and by the time its second effusion was brought to a termination cries of "Bravo" rang through the auditorium.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 25. -- Plans for a campaign to raise "not less than $10,000,000" for the University of Pennsylvania were announced tonight by President Thomas S. Gates at a banquet here of the Associated Pensylvania Clubs, representing alumni groups throughout the country.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Displaying a powerful attack, the Horace Mann School football team crushed Iona School, 33 -- 0, today for its twelfth straight victory since midway in 1933. The triumph was the third this season for the winners, who scored in every period but the third.

ROME, Oct. 25. -- The conciliatory gesture that Premier Benito Mussolini made yesterday by ordering the withdrawal of an Italian division from Libya has remained without official reply from the British side, causing considerable disappointment in Italy.

Plans for today's peace parade in which 50,000 persons are expected to march from lower Harlem along Central Park West to Sixty-first Street were completed yesterday, but the protests against use of the thoroughfare that began when the parade was conceived grew more bitter.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 25.--Members of the WestchesterCounty Federation of Women'sClubs, at a meeting held here todayat the Contemporary Club, passedan amendment to change its nameto the Westchester County Federation of Women.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S fresh pledge of loyalty to AAA is doubtless timed for today's balloting: more than four million farmers have been invited to go to the polls this morning to vote on an important point in the Administration's farm program. The President wishes to assure them that he regards AAA as much more than "a mere emergency operation" and by no means "a static agency."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings bank in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during September, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compares as follows with a month ago and the corresponding period of 1934. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods, re-exported.

ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- New York State's Works Progress Administration made ready tonight to put 60,000 men at work Monday on WPA projects, backed by a $20,000,000 fund on hand and the added impetus of another $26,000,000 released by Federal officials at Washington.

The New York Clearing House Association yesterday adopted a change in its constitution raising the minimum fee to be charged by its member banks to out-of-town banks for placing or servicing security loans from one-quarter to one-half of 1 per cent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade fluctuated today in the same erratic manner as in the last few days, with outside interest restricted and much business professional in character. A small advance early in sympathy with Liverpool was followed by a decline when Winnipeg eased, but the close was at the top, with shorts good buyers on the way up.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 25. -- Clear, mild weather, an assemblage of more than 60,000, including many fans from New York and other cities, a big delegation from official Washington headed by Secretary of the Navy Swanson and the 2,000 Middies make up the bright setting for tomorrow's game between Navy and Notre Dame.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The note which the State Department will send to the League of Nations in response to its inquiry as to the position of the United States with regard to sanctions in the war between Italy and Ethiopia was discussed by President Roosevelt with his Cabinet this afternoon, and the lines previously charted by the President and Secretary of State Cordell Hull were approved in substance.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Demands for a "newer deal" -- the Townsend plan -- were raised today by a battery of speakers before the first national convention of the Townsend clubs.
Isaac Elliott, white-haired, smiling and a bit mystified, found himself last night for once the central figure at the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 25. -The Long Island Professional Golfers Association staged its first amateur-pro best-ball tournament at the Garden City Country Club today, with T. Suffern Taller, former metropolitan amateur champion, figuring in two of the four ties that marked the competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Orders have been issued by the Army Corps of Engineers that no contracts for construction of the $36,000,000 Passamaquoddy tidal power project are to be let until Governor Brann of Maine calls a special session of the Legislature to create an authority for marketing the power.
BERLIN, Oct. 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The population of this city was increased temporarily today by about 7,500 persons as school teachers of the southeastern zone of the New York State Teachers Association flocked here for their ninetieth annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Denial that Congress illegally delegated power in its passage of the Utilities Holding Company Act was made by the government today in the second part of a brief filed in Federal District Court here as an answer to a suit in which the law was attacked as unconstitutional.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 25. -- In the present circumstances it is impossible to see any basis for peace between Italy and Ethiopia. Emperor Haile Selassie still refuses to make an official statement, for three reasons.

Settlement of a suit brought by a minority stockholder and the transfer of 100,000 common shares of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., to the corporation by Harry M. Warner, president; Albert Warner, vice president and treasurer; Jack L. Warner, vice president, and Renraw, Inc., was announced yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25. -State Director Thomas J. Dodd today announced at National Youth Administration headquarters here that undergraduates in other Connecticut colleges and graduate students at Yale would this year receive funds from the student aid program.

Foreign currencies weakened again yesterday in terms of the dollar, and the flow of gold here from other countries increased slightly, indicating a renewed bulge in the flight of capital to this country. Gold engaged for shipment here amounted to $6,613,000, of which $4,122,000 was taken in France, $1,594,000 in India and $897,000 in England.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- The monopoly issue was raised tonight by Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, who warned members of the Commercial Club in an address that America faced an immediate decision whether free enterprise under democracy was to survive or would be supplanted by a planned economy under a coercive government.

On the fourth anniversary of the opening of George Washington Bridge plans were revealed yesterday to place atop its New York tower, 650 feet above ground, an airway beacon to be named in memory of Wiley Post and Will Rogers.
ROME, Saturday, Oct. 26. -- The first tank operations along the southern Ethiopian front, in which many prisoners were taken, were reported by Italian war correspondents to their newspapers today.

The return of Summer temperatures checked temporarily the spread of consumer buying this week and in some parts of the country merchandise moved out at the slowest rate for any period in nearly two months, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Contests involving undefeated teams and games with a traditional flavor stand out in every division of today's scholastic football program. Topping New York City's card is the contest between the unbeaten elevens of St. John's Prep and Grover Cleveland High, while the thirtieth Lawrenceville-Hill encounter at Lawrenceville, N.J., is the highlight of the Eastern prep school schedule.

Control of the United Cigar Stores Company of America, which operates more than 500 retail tobacco stores throughout the nation and since 1932 has been in bankruptcy, has passed from control of interests headed by George K. Morrow, chairman of the company's board of directors, to a group of five, it was said authoritatively last night.

For several months the multiplying signs of business recovery have been regarded by some observers with skepticism because of the small reduction in the unemployment estimates. The record of September, now published by the Department of Labor and cited by the President, must dissipate some of these doubts.

Complete exoneration of Patrolma Edward Hayes of the Flushing Precinct, who shot and killed Patrolman Walter A. Miller Thursday night after Miller had mortally wounded Captain Richard McHale, his commanding officer, was assured yesterday by both the Queens County District Attorney and Police Commissioner Valentine.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Changes in Federal and State tax methods to promote realty ownership and adoption of a new Federal policy on housing were urged here today by the National Association of Real Estate Boards at the closing sessions of its annual convention.

MADRID, Oct. 25. -- A registered letter addressed to the President of the Spanish Republic by Daniel Straus, a Mexican citizen who claims to have bribed Deputies and even higher public officials in order to obtain gambling concessions in this country, was expected tonight to cause the resignation of the Chapaprieta Cabinet when the Cortes convenes in special session Monday.

The second of Empire City's $5,000 added stakes will be run at the Yonkers course today, with representatives of three of the country's greatest racing strings among the seven which have been named. The Yorktown Handicap is at a mile and a furlong and Roustabout, Good Harvest and Vicaress loom as about equal pre-race choices.

Clark G. Kuney, 50 years old, who said he lived at the Montclair Hotel, and Edward A. Sauter, 53, of 382 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, former officers of the Commonwealth Bond Corporation at 74 Trinity Place, which failed last January, were arrested in District Attorney Dodge's office late yesterday afternoon, charged with grand larceny.

The State Judicial Council has recommended to the Appellate Division a series of proposed rules designed to prevent the broadcasting of proceedings in any court room in this State. This is in line With the resolution adopted earlier in the year by the New York County Lawyers Association, on the ground that broadcasting "tends to diminish the solemnity and decorum which should attend all such proceedings."

TRENTON, Oct. 25. -- New Jersey's retail sales tax, in force since last July 1, was repealed at 8:24 o'clock tonight when Governor Hoffman signed the bill passed late this afternoon by the Legislature meeting in special session.

Statements made by Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer were taken down by a Newark police stenographer, F. J. Lang. The notes covered the period from about 4 o'clock Thursday afternoon until Schultz died. During that period he was delirious most of the time, but lucid at intervals.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- Tomorrow morning the coffin containing the remains of Marshal Hubert Gonzague Lyautey will be taken from the crypt of the cathedral at Nancy to be transported with all honors to a tomb near Rabat, Morocco, where he will be buried as a conqueror.

MONTREAL, Oct. 25. -- Destructive competition is seen as a result of the Gefaell plan for reorganization of the Great Lakes Paper Company in a statement issued by Charles Vining, president of the Newsprint Export Manufacturers' Association of Canada.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, called on the corn-hog farmers of the nation today to answer critics of the AAA with a "huge vote" in tomorrow's referendum.
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The text of King George's speech from the throne at the closing of Parliament today, read by Viscount Hailsham, Lord High Chancellor, is as follows:

VIENNA, Oct. 25. -- When the new Cabinet presented itself yesterday to the non-elective Federal Diet -whose members are nominated on Fascist lines -- to give its budget declaration the document was read not by the man who prepared it, former Finance Minister Karl Buresch, but by the man to whom he had yielded his place, Dr. Ludwig Draxler.

The Jury system has come in for a good deal of drubbing since the first set of "Good Men and True" was locked up in a hotel room to ponder an outside destiny. It has been accused of all the crimes from heredity on down, and justice has ruled that jurymen should be liquidated instead of encouraged.
Joseph P. Day hit back sharply yesterday at attacks on the $8,000,000 Brooklyn Beach Gardens apartment project made by Charles Abrams, general consultant to the New York City Housing Authority.

Manhattan's football team will face its third successive major opponent and its second intersectional foe this afternoon at Ebbets Field when it meets Hunk Anderson's rugged North Carolina State eleven. A crowd of more than 15,000 is expected to witness the battle, which will get under way at 2:30 o'clock.

GENEVA, Oct. 25. -- The governing body of the International Labor Office decided today by 15 to 13 to give immediate attention to the question of establishing by convention a forty-hour week in the textile industry. This allows the convention to be adopted at the coming conference in June if the necessary two-thirds majority should bo found then, instead of having to walt until the 1937 conference for its second reading.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 25. -- Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court here announced today the signing of an order authorizing the New York, New Haven Hartford to continue the payment of pensions to 1,400 retired employes.

It is about time Harry Hopkins, master mind of the various alphabetical organizations of the government, issued a statement in his own defense. Unless he does this, all the political power and diplomacy of Jim Farley cannot save the Democratic party from a loss of thousands of farmer votes in Texas.

Two of the prominent elevens of the Middle West are in the East today to furnish a part of the fireworks which on each succeeding Saturday from now until December will be set off in football. One is visiting New York and the other Baltimore, and both are regarded as favorites.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25.-With every man on the squad in prime shape, Yale's valiant little band of giant-killers engages one of its most formidable foes of the season tomorrow in the thirty-fifth meeting with Army.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The Cornell and Princeton football squads staged light practices on Schoellkopf Field today before meeting for the twenty-fourth time tomorrow. Princeton leads in the series with sixteen victories. One game ended in a tie.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 25. -- Weighted down under 138 pounds, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's sensational 4year-old colt Discovery will go to the post tomorrow in the $10,000 added Washington Handicap with a chance to boost his year's earnings beyond the $112,000 mark.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- A story of expensive temporary financing of municipal debt occasioned largely by waterfront developments that later were the subject of "glaring iniquities" in rentals and productive of a leasing system that became a political football was laid before the Securities and Exchange Commission today as the history of the promotion of Asbury Park, N.J.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, defending champion, won its opening match as the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis tourney got under way yesterday, defeating the City A.C., 3 -- 2, on its home courts.

Full public disclosure of the secret grand jury minutes of the Druckman murder case was sought by District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn yesterday when he unexpectedly consented to Police Commissioner Valentine's application for a private inspection of the 180 page record.
Apartment houses in Manhattan and the Bronx were purchased by investors yesterday, which proved to be another day of mild activity.

After advancing steadily during most of the day, the share market encountered yesterday a flurry of profit-taking in the last hour that reduced somewhat the net gains on the day. At the closing, prices were up from fractions to 3 points, a few issues doing even better.

Richard Lundy, reputed job "fixer," who gave his address as 461 State Street, Brooklyn, was arraigned in General Sessions yesterday on indictments charging conspiracy and grand larceny involving $300 he was alleged to have obtained from a would-be city fireman under pretense he would have him appointed despite the man's physical handicaps.

AMHERST vs. Wesleyan -- When in doubt, consult the largest dictionary in the vicinity. Amherst -Amherst -- well, fancy that! A section of lower Burma about thirty miles southwest of the old Moulmein pagoda mentioned by Mr. Kipling. Shipping somewhere east of Suez, one vote for Amherst.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- President Roosevelt today accepted an invitation to speak at Armistice Day services in Arlington National Cemetery under the auspices of the American Legion. He will lay a wreath on the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 25 (AP). -- Pinkie Kandell, who ran a small bank-note into a racing stable, scored another triumph today when his 5-year-old mare Hut won the fifth race, feature on today's card at Narragansett Park.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (AP). -Residents of the Malibu Lake resort region were ordered tonight to be ready for evacuation within five hours, if necessary, as a brush fire roared out of control.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25. -- With the exception of Alva Nye at right end in place of Jack Neill, Pennsylvania plans to start the same line-up against Lafayette tomorrow that vanquished Columbia a week ago. Gene Gisburne, veteran left tackle, may give way early to Bill Gunnis, however.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- As the Securities and Exchange Commission called hearings today for the consideration of applications by two utilities companies for exemption under the Holding Company Act of 1935, Philip H. Gadsen, chairman of the Committee of Public Utilities Executives, announced that the committee would open headquarters here about Nov. 1 and proposed to continue its efforts to "protect the interests of the investor in public utilities securities."

No evidence of manipulation or tool operations in securities of the local traction companies has been found, the business conduct committee of the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday after a six-week investigation provoked by the charges of City Chamberlain Adolf A. Berle Jr., that the market for these issues had been "rigged."

Ex-Mayor WALKER has sailed from England for his natal shores on the liner Manhattan, and it seems at first eminently fitting that the Manhattan should have left port several hours late. But on further thought it is also disquieting.

OTTAWA, Oct. 25. -- A revised but still not complete summary of the popular vote in the Canadian general election on Oct. 14 indicates that it was by an increase in thirdparty votes, rather than by any overwhelming addition to Liberal voting strength, that the Conservative government was defeated.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were irregular today, largely from weekend profit-taking, although yesterday's confident tone was well maintained. The strong investment buying of British funds continued, although the demand reacted somewhat in the afternoon.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- President Roosevelt declared the administration's intention today "to pass from the purely emergency phases" of agricultural policy embraced in the Agricultural Adjustment Act "to a long-time, more permanent plan," based upon the AAA.
The police and Federal agents familiar with the activities of Schultz and the members of his gang scanned his statements yesterday with interest.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin intimated for the first time tonight that the British fleet, acting alone, might be compelled to blockade an aggressor nation in carrying out sanctions under the League of Nations covenant.
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The 1931-35 Parliament was dissolved today by King George. The decks are now clear for the election of a new House of Commons on Nov. 14. The session had lasted only four days.

ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Increases of 8.3 per cent in employment and 6.4 per cent in payrolls were registered for September by 12,000 retail trade firms throughout New York State, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported tonight.
Three hundred pupils of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled last night attended the second annual Hallowe'en dance of the institute in the building it occupies at 400 First Avenue.

A room in a midtown hotel which yielded evidence that may lead to the solution of the recent outbreak of gangland murders has been discovered by the police, Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday.
Apartment rentals reported yesterday included a penthouse at 400 East Fifty-second Street taken by Max Reinhardt, theatrical producer. F. Ann Kutner was the broker. Other lessees were as follows:

Corporation bonds continued to advance in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday under the leadership of the secondary railroad and lower-priced utility bonds. A fairly active pace was maintained with total transactions amounting to $14,473,300, compared with $14,874,800 on Thursday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The counter charges of cruelty and inhuman treatment by Mr. and Mrs. Edward F., Reilly in their actions against each other for separation were submitted in briefs today to Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief, who was asked by Mrs. Reilly to grant her $500 a week temporary alimony and $10,000 counsel fees.
ABOARD THE S.S. MANHATTAN, AT SEA, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Former Mayor James J. Walker came out of seclusion today to exercise his two dogs on his first day out en route to New York.

Dr. James T. Shotwell of Columbia University was heckled, Charles Solomon of the Socialist party was hissed, and the audience was accused of prejudice, in a stirring session of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor yesterday afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25. -A large section of New Hampshire's football followers will accompany the Dartmouth Indians to the Harvard Stadium tomorrow. Harvard's officials estimate that between 45,000 and 50,000 persons will see the game, the forty-second in a series starting more than fifty years ago.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 25. -- A blocked punt on Duke's 23-yard line in the first quarter of today's game spelled victory for the charging Plainsmen from Auburn over Wallace Wade's Blue Devils. Patterson place-kicked for the extra point to give the Alabama warriors a 7-0 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP). -- A warning that Federal control will be enforced vigorously went from the government today to soft coal "interests" which it charged with seeking "to stampede", producers against regulation.

While the Emergency Relief Bureau planned yesterday to meet on Monday to consider finally its punitive action, through loss of seniority, against the 3,500 ERB workers who participated in the three-hour stoppage on Thursday, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator for the city, announced that he would absorb on WPA whitecollar projects the 900 members of the ERB staff who have received dismissal notices.

With Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and Louis (Pretty) Amberg killed and their gangs demoralized, a new group of outlaw leaders took over control of all the major rackets in New York. Brooklyn and Newark, N.J., yesterday in complete defiance of police efforts to solve the week's gang murders and break up the new combination.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- A sharp falling off in receipts of hogs today enabled receivers to check the downward tendency in the market, and while some early sales appeared 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight lower the general market was quoted as steady.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25. -- The long series of irritating incidents between the Soviet Union and Japan was extended yesterday when the Soviet press declared a number of Soviet citizens had been arrested, beaten and otherwise maltreated by Japanese in Manchuria.

A symposium on compulsory automobile insurance, discussion of the drunken driver and the offering of an 8-point program to reduce highway accidents marked the closing session of the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Dewey H. Palmer, physicist and a former director of Consumers' Research, Inc., was jailed here today in default of $300 bail as a result of the disorder on Oct. 15 at the Consumers' Research plant near Washington, N.J., between striking employes and constables employed by the company.
STRASSBURG, France, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Two German spies were sent back to their homeland today in exchange for three French spies, in a transfer carried out on a bridge over the Rhine.
Purchase of two Union City flats for investment was included in the New Jersey real estate turnover reported yesterday.

In the future all transactions of the Federal Government in the cotton futures market here will be handled by Paine, Webber Co., who will distribute the business to members of the Cotton Exchange Clearing Association. The government heretofore had placed its cotton future orders with six local firms and one New Orleans concern.
The twenty-fourth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America opens today at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

The Fieldston School eleven marked up its third victory in as many starts by conquering Columbia Grammar, 13 -- 0, yesterday at the Fieldston Field. Numerous substitutions were made by Coach Hirzler of the winners, who started his second-string line-up.
I agree with the letters from Ralph N. Taylor and C. J. C., published in THE TIMES, having reference to traffic regulations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP). -Turning to the work-relief drive for musicians, WPA today added an advisory committee of twenty-five, composed of widely known leaders in the field, to help provide jobs.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- Under the emotional inspiration of Edouard Herriot's oratory, the French Radical Socialist Congress rose for a moment far above its internal quarrels and rivalries this afternoon to what can only be described as passionate approval of the ideals for which the League of Nations was founded.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- Dr. TheodorLewald, president of the GermanOlympic Committee, issued a publicreply to criticisms of GermanOlympic policy expressed by FormerSupreme Court Justice JeremiahT. Mahoney, president of theAmerican Amateur Athletic Union.

Cooler weather caused a pickupin retail trade in the metropolitanarea toward the end of the week,F but unsatisfactory sales during theI forepart pulled dollar sales volumel of leading departmer, t stores downil to 2 per cent as compared withthe same period last year.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc,:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Authority to refinance obligations now outstanding was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission for the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation and the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company as follows:

The Federal Government struck out yesterday at the so-called "kick-back" racket, which, according to investigators, is becoming more and more widespread throughout the city, and has even invaded fields of labor financed by the Works Progress Administration.

The third of the Sunday night openings isn't to be just yet. "The Body Beautiful," which announced itself for tomorrow at the Plymouth Theatre, found it couldn't get into its scenic clothes, and so postponed its premiere to next Thursday. Tonight's preview will go on just the same....
Sidney Schachter, pianist, will give a recital tomorrow afternoon at the Y.M.C.A. branch at 215 West Twenty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's statement to the farm problem:

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 25. -- A protest against the idea that liberal culture is a "thing of the past" was voiced by Dr. George E. Vincent, former head of the Rockefeller Foundation, in an address before 150 alumnae, students and faculty of Rosemary Hall School, at the opening of the forty-fifth anniversary of the institution tilts afternoon. He went on:

And still they continue to come! In spite of the law of supply and demand, those ever-hopeful purveyors of nocturnal entertainment persist in flashing new bright spots before the latest has even begun to pall. With the flow of joy-thirsty patrons limited, after all, by certain bounds, the one thought dancing through the heads of the confident bonifaces seems to be, "If the other fellow can do it, why can't I?"

BOONTON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Mrs. F. B. Ryan of Baltusrol, prominent in metropolitan golf circles a few years ago, won the one-day tournament held by the Women's New Jersey Golf Association over the Knoll links today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25. -- Officers of the Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines, Inc., told the National Labor Relations Board today that the nine men discharged or furloughed by them had been severed from the company's employ for cause and not for union activity.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Mrs. Blanche S. Weed showed that the bulk of her net estate, $538,965, went to charity principally in Canada. Mrs. Weed who died Sept. 12, 1934, was a resident of Stamford, Conn., and the widow of Dr. Albert Gallatin Weed.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 25. -- Ras Nasibu, Governor of Harar, dispatched the main body of Harar regulars to the southern front from this walled city today and predicted that Jijiga, fifty miles east of here, would be a bulwark of Ethiopia's defense.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25. -- The Autumn Fete held annually by the members of Hannah Penn House will be given next Wednesday at West Thorpe Farm, the home of Mrs. Charles M. Lea of Devon. The fete, which Mrs. Curtis C. Eves of 1,910 Spruce Street is chairman, will include a benefit bridge, fashion show and tea.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25. -Harvard won both individual and team honors in a triangular crosscountry meet with Dartmouth and New Hampshire today.

Determined opposition to the proposed construction of a Hudson River bridge between Nyack and Tarrytown was expressed yesterday at a public hearing before Lieut. Col. John W. N. Schulz, army district engineer, at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, from 10:30 A.M. to 1 P.M.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25. -The Princeton cross-country team had little difficulty downing the Columbia harriers, 18 to 37, over a four-mile course today.

WARSAW, Oct. 25. -- A program for Poland's economic rehabilitation was outlined yesterday by Premier Marian Zyndram Koscialskowski in the Sejm when he asked Parliament for emergency powers for three months to issue decrees with the force of law.

Indian totem poles and a hornet's nest rubbed shoulders with models of airplanes and clipper ships yesterday at the opening of a handicraft exhibit conducted by the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.

Colonel Ralph Key Harvey of London gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate his seventieth birthday. His guests were Miss Amy V. Aspegren and Bruce F. E. Harvey, son of the host, who will be married Tuesday; Mrs. John Aspegren, mother of the bride-elect; Mrs. Geoffrey ThistletonSmith, Mrs. John E. Berwind, aunt of the bridegroom-elect; Mrs. Rogers C. Dunn, George A. Legg and Hamilton H. Durand.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- There was a rush of applications today by officers and directors of operating utility companies to obtain authorization from the Federal Power Commission to continue to hold similar posts in more than one company, or with a bank.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 25. -- Walter Liggett, editor of a crusading weekly, was attacked and badly beaten by several men in a cafe here early today. He suffered a battered head, with one ear almost torn off. and also suffered chest bruises.

The Anglo-South American Bank, Ltd., reported net profits of 37,019 for the year ended on June 30, at its annual meeting on Wednesday, according to the local office of the bank. Bad and doubtful debts were met from the contingency account. Of the net profits, 7,792 was applied to legal reserves in Chile and Ecuador and 29,226 to contingencies.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- Increasing hints in British parliamentary speeches and in the British press, suggesting to Germany the possibility of the revision of the territorial provisions of the Versailles treaty and the League of Nations, find enthusiastic welcome in Germany.
FREIBURG, Baden, Germany, Oct. 25. -- Hans Spemann wants to know what a man can do with $42,000, especially when he has everything he wants and is in love with his work.

The New York University football team, undefeated and untied in its three games this season, will take on its fourth opponent this afternoon when it meets the Georgetown University eleven at the Yankee Stadium. A crowd of 15,000 is expected to be on hand for the opening kick-off, which is scheduled for 2:30 o'clock.

OTTAWA, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of Canada, issued today for the week ended on Wednesday, showed Dominion government deposits down more than $3,800,000 and those of chartered banks up more than $4,600,000.

Influenced by the strength in other markets and the largest spinners' takings since November, 1931, prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range yesterday and ended at a gain of 3 to a loss of 5 points.

A diversified list of ninety State and municipal bond and note issues totaling $21,871,462 is scheduled for offering to the public next week. This compares with a revised total of $17,506,486 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $25,097,778.

The action of the Stock Exchange yesterday in reporting to the Securities and Exchange Commission, as a part of its inquiry into the alleged "rigging" of the market for traction securities, the "wash sale" of nine bonds surprised some in Wall Street who had predicted that the report would consist entirely of whitewash.

The University of Michigan will make its first football appearance in New York at 2:30 P.M. today when it meets Columbia at Baker Field. A capacity crowd of 35,000. a large part of which will be made up of Wolverine supporters, is expected to attend.

The Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street, reopened for the season this week with a small group exhibition containing work by Alexander Brook, Nicolai Cikovsky, Ernest Fiene, Anne Goldthwaite, Bernard Karfiol, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, John Marin, Georgia O'Keeffe, Charles Sheeler, Robert Laurent and William Zorach.

The concurrent public hearings before the Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission on the Long Island Railroad's recent application for increases of from 15 to 20 per cent in commutation rates were adjourned yesterday until Dec. 18.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- A heavy vote, possibly the closest of AAA history, was expected by farm administration officials tonight in to morrow's national-corn hog referendum.

Booth Tarkington, whose thirtyninth book is soon to be published by Doubleday, Doran, bought a room recently in Philadelphia because he liked the atmosphere. He had the room moved to Kennebunkport, Me., had a new stone wing added to his house and built the room, which is about thirty-five feet long and thirty feet wide, into it.

The Republic Steel Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $507,731 for the three months ended on Sept. 30, after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and guaranteed preferred dividends of the Trumbull-Cliffs Company, and including $177,000 loss on the sale of securities held in the investment account.

Mr. WINSTON CHURCHILL has held so many posts in Governments, Liberal, Conservative, Coalition, that he might almost be called a walking Cabinet. In the last few years as an independent Conservative he has been free to censure a Government that made the mistake of finding no room for him, and to chaff his old chief, friend and and enemy, LLOYD GEORGE.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Harold Schilz of Washington, Special Assistant Attorney General, was fined $25 for contempt of court here today during arguments in the government's conspiracy case against Warner Brothers and two other moving picture concerns.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $2,769,841, excluding $633,319 of revenues held in suspense and interest accrued on them. This was equal to $3.72 a share on 744,600 no-par capital shares.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The death of Dutch Schultz has not erased his liability to the State, Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, said today. Any real estate owned by Schultz cannot be transferred without the Tax Commission's consent, nor can any deposits be withdrawn or any safe deposit boxes be opened without similar authority.

A visit to the Bell Telephone Laboratories wound up yesterday the five-day tour that was organized by the Division of Engineering and Industrial Research of the National Research Council for the benefit of fifty-six corporation executives and financiers who wanted to find out how science is helping to create new industries and revivify old ones.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that bonds of eleven companies, which, since their issuance, have been assumed by other corporations would be suspended from dealings on Nov. 5 for failure of the issuers to furnish additional information to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ON THE ITALIAN FRONT IN NORTHERN ETHIOPIA, Entiscio, Oct. 23 (By Courier to Asmara.) -The road to this place was completed today for the visit of inspection by Marshal Pietro Bagdolio, Italian chief of staff, so that it is now possible to drive by automobile to the three advance positions of the front line.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Certificates of deposit or new securities need not be registered under the Securities Act of 1933 if they are issued under a type of deposit agreement by the terms of which deposits of mortgage bonds have been solicited continuously prior to May 27, 1933, when registration requirements of the act became effective, John J. Burns, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The government's drive to end the dole by Dec. 1 was spurred today through the approval by Controller General McCarl of $137,711,099 worth of additional WPA projects for twenty-five States and New York City.

Through the use of newly developed serums, the death rate from pneumonia has taken a drop of about 50 per cent within recent years and probably will continue to decline, it was brought out yesterday by physicians attending the eighth annual graduate fortnight at the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

Architects filed plans for a wide variety of building construction in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens yesterday. The projects include dwellings, flats, store and business buildings and a factory.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25. -William Barrett Schallek, a Harvard freshman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max L. Schallek, 21 East Eightyseventh Street, New York City, was critically injured when he fell four stories through the ventilator shaft of Matthews Hall, his dormitory.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- Prices on the Boerse were slightly weaker today. Heavy industrial shares fell somewhat, Rheinstahl losing 5/8 point. Machine issues showed slight gains, although Berlin Karlsruhe declined 1/4 point. Chemical stocks recorded changes that were not significant.

The movement to transfer the Olympic Games from Germany is not a political issue but a question of "humanity and Christianity," former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of the Amateur Athletic Union, declared last night in reply to the statement by Avery Brundage, head of the American Olympic Committee.
New bond financing this week, although less than last week, amounted to $61,782,088. The total last week was $134,724,000. A year ago this week, issues for $60,605,000 were marketed.

At the meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound last night in the Yale Club, Van S. Merle-Smith, president, expressed a hope for a challenge for the Twelve-Meter International Cup of the North American Yacht Racing Union in a contest next year.

While I for one do not like to see the agricultural policies of this nation made the subject of partisan debate, it is becoming apparent that each party or candidate will have to put forward a farm program. And if I understand the thinking of the agricultural producers of the nation, that program will have to be reasonably definite and clear in order to draw farm support.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Williston Academy won its third successive football game today, defeating Westminster 18 -- 13. Stepczyk and Wilson scored for Williston. Moran and Howell scored for visitors.

RICHMOND, Oct. 26. -- Strength shown by wholesale lines in the Fifth Federal Reserve District is exceeding expectations, as the con tinued rise in retail trade is being passed on to jobbers. Of five reporting lines, shoes alone in September failed to do as well as in that month a year ago, while others gained from 2.2 per cent for drugs to 18.6 per cent for hardware.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 26. -- Police today absolved leaders Blumenfield (Kid Cann) and Mrs. Annette Fawcett, divorced wife of W.H. (Captain Billy) Fawcett of any part in the assault on Walter Liggett, crusading weekly-newspaper editor, who was beaten in a cafe early Friday.

AS the Belmonte of his own hunting cuadrilla Ernest Hemingway has produced a fine book on death in the African afternoon. Incidentally, it is the best-written story of big-game hunting anywhere I have read. And more than that.

The Feast of Christ the King will be observed today and it will be made the occasion for prayers to the Prince of Peace for peace among all nations. Sermons will also be in preparation for All Saints Day, which is Friday. Lutherans will observe today as "Reformation Sunday."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- The all-conquering march of one of the pluckiest and most brilliantly armed football teams to wear the Blue ran head on into one of the great lines of the season today and Yale's high hopes for an unbeaten campaign were dashed to earth with its fourth successive defeat by Army. The score was 14 -- 8.

Delegates to the annual Fall conference of the sixth district of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs will convene Thursday for an all-day session in Westminster Hall of the First Presbyterian Church in Passaic. Hostess clubs will be the Monday Afternoon Club and the Passaic Woman's Club, of which Mrs. George Gordon Dobson was recently elected president.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens want to the Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens yesterday and took charge of the investigation that is being made into certain deaths that have occurred at that institution since Sept. 1 last.

A THEATRE is emerging here and there throughout the country that is neither a part of the Road, nor an imitation of Broadway, a trying-out ground for the professional theatre nor an extension of Summer stock; and it is not a mere outgrowth of what is known as "amateur dramatics."

Forty-one industrial, business and professional divisions have been organized by Mrs. David Challinor, volunteer director, and Mrs. L.M. Fish, associate director, of the annual membership roll-call of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, it was said yesterday by Peter S. Duryee, roll-call chairman.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 26. -- Iowa's football forces, undefeated and previously thrice victorious this season, turned their full fury on Illinois today, crushing the Illini, 19 to 0.

NOW when the world is beginning to tremble in the grip of martial ecstasy, we can depend on the cinema to whip the masses into an appropriately orgiastic mood of war hysteria. Last week on Broadway screens three films from three different nations, armed with no more perceptible artistic impulse than that embodied in recruiting posters, were busily exhorting their audiences to lyric pride in the mailed fist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The following is the text of Secretary of State Hull's note to the president of the committee of coordination of the League of Nations on the policy of the United States with reference to the Italo-Ethiopian controversy:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Behind the efficient blocking of his team-mates Vannie Albanese personally accounted for Syracuse's three touchdowns as the Orange downed a vastly improved Brown team today, 19 to 0. A crowd of 9,000 attended.
A campaign against fraudulent charity racket organizations that hold benefits and collect funds for mythical charitable purposes was announced yesterday by License Commissioner Paul Moss.

WHEN the unpleasantness in Ethiopia started there was a hunt for books on this little known country which would give some impression of who were these strange people who had defied Mussolini and rejected his offer to civilize them, and books were exceedingly scarce.

Trading was mixed and only moderately active on the commodity futures markets here yesterday. Coffee futures sold off, while hides and rubber advanced in most deliveries. The undertone in all staples was firm. On the cash markets, all the grains and cocoa were lower, and the other commodities were unchanged.

The League for Political Education will open its forty-second season at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, next Thursday night with a discussion of "Which Road to World Peace?" Among those who will take part in the discussion are Dorothy Thompson, author, journalist and wife of Sinclair Lewis, and Dr. Clark M. Eichelberger, national director of the League of Nations Association.

FROM Forbes Watson has just been received a report covering the results of the government competitions initiated by the Treasury Department's Section of Painting and Sculpture in pursuit of art wanted for the Post-office and Justice Department Buildings in Washington, D.C.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 26. -- Minnesota's great football line tamed the Northwestern Wildcats today while fleet-footed Gopher backs combed the flying fur of the invaders for three touchdowns and a 21-to-13 triumph before a home-coming throng of 54,000.

Manhattan was strong enough to check all orthodox attempts to gain along the ground and through the air by a rugged North Carolina State team at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the Jaspers were caught flatfooted when the speedy Wolf-pack backs abandoned team play and took matters into their own hands.

More than the usual interest attached to the French Senatorial elections which took place a week ago. Factions of the Left, which have been banding in opposition to the drastic economy decrees enacted by Premier Laval's government, hoped that through the success of certain of their candidates they would be able to show a drift of opinion against the government.

It is customary for the Pulitzer Prizes to be announced early in May. It is customary also for the town's dramatic critics to dedicate their columns, the Sunday after the announcement, to the proposition that the wrong play was chosen, that the prize should have gone to --.

Lafayette College has obtained in Henry W. Clark one of the most popular figures of intercollegiate sport for its new athletic director. Clark, since 1928 the assistant director to Bill Bingham at Harvard, was one of the best centres at Harvard in modern years and a competitor in track.

SELF-SUPPORTING: At the general meeting of the Society of Friends, held last week at Richmond, Ind., there was read a report showing that throughout the country not one Quaker has been on the relief rolls during the depression.

PLENTY of people run away from civilization, but few of them to such good purpose as does Rockwell Kent. He can write, he can draw and paint, and he can look back at our benighted civilization through the small end of a telescope without losing his sense of proportion.
VIENNA, Oct. 26. -- The Austrian Army received today from President Wilhelm Miklas's hand flags of the Imperial Army, following a solemn military ceremony in the court of the former Imperial Palace.

WITH THE ITALIAN SOUTHERN ARMY IN ETHIOPIA, Oct. 26 (Exchange Telegraph). -- The story of how the wily old Sultan Olol Dinle, who deserted to the Italian side, duped his countrymen into defeat in the "battle of the mountain monkeys" was revealed in dispatches received here today.

Mrs. Robert L. Bacon, vice chairman of the State Republican committee and chairman of the Nassau County Federation of Republican Women, will be hostess for the October tea of the latter organization, to be held Thursday afternoon in her home, Arlough, Old Westbury.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 26. -- E.L. Bowsher, State Director of Education, took the responsibility today for the deletion of scenes from the current edition of The March of Time, which theatres in the State began showing yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The latest and finest edition of the Bible, in a format of which only one issue has been or will be made, was put on exhibition today in the Rare Book Room of the Library of Congress.

With the steady improvement in sales volume during the second half of the year, dry goods wholesalers in general will wind up 1935 with total business slightly ahead of 1934, Flint Garrison, director general of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, reported here yesterday.

" LESS bread! More taxes!" was the way the cheering sounded to Sylvie and Bruno in Lewis Carroll's classic. "Some were shouting 'Bread!' and some 'Taxes!' but no one seemed to know what it was they really wanted."

IT appears by the latest decision of Landis, J., that the rule of thumb in baseball has been definitely amended for the benefit of the weak side. It used to be that an umpire could do no wrong, but when Landis, J., assessed a fine of $200 on George Moriarty for strong language poured over some Chicago players in the late world series, it was third down and no gain for the umpires.

Several dinners will precede the preview of "Jumbo," the new musical circus, on Wednesday night at the Hippodrome, which has been taken over by the directors of the Maternity Centre Association to raise funds for carrying on the work of that organization.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Oct. 26 (AP). -- President Roosevelt was acclaimed today by a crowd of 3,000 as he paused here briefly for dedication of the $1,400,000 Choptank River Bridge, constructed as a PWA project.
THE TIMES published recently a letter from Dr. Fritz Wittels commenting on the recent publication by Dr. Alexis Carrel, "Man the Unknown."

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 26. -- On the sodden turf of Sanford Stadium, with dusk creeping over the field and the score deadlocked, Alabama rallied spectacularly to old-time form today and stopped Georgia's unconquered Bulldogs, 17 -- 7, before 25,000 fans.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer bought a degree of immunity for the operation of his policy racket in New York by payments to politicians and police, it was shown yesterday by the data belonging to him which were seized in the Newark restaurant where he was shot and the hotel apartment he occupied in that city.

OXFORD, Ohio, Oct. 26. -- Improvement in economic conditions in every section of the country is indicated by reports received from forty-four State universities and land grant colleges, showing an increase of 8.3 per cent in the total student enrolment this Fall over 1934, according to Dr. A.H. Upham, president of Miami University, Oxford, Ohio, and secretary of the National Association of State Universities.

At one point in this story the great Ludovic Travels is about to confess defeat and to give up attemping to find out who murdered old Hubert Greeve, not because there are no clues, but because there are too many. The place is simply littered with clues, and by following them up Travers acquires a great deal of interesting information which leads him precisely nowhere.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The Rockwood Hall Country Club here was the scene tonight of a costume dance, in celebration of hallowe'en. The event was preceded by a dinner. Among the hosts were Dr. and Mrs. A.J. Raggi, Mrs. Arthur Williams, E.L. Smith, Paul D. Markell, Dr. and Mrs. A.E. Corby, Miss Agnes Wheeler, Judge and Mrs. David H. Kincheloe and William Schongalla.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The intention of the United States to continue exerting her moral influence for peace within the limitations of policies previously defined but to avoid foreign entanglements and involvement in war was asserted by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in his note replying to the inquiry of the League of Nations as to our attitude in the Italo-Ethiopian War.

AN almost threadbare discussion deals with the question of whether women dress for themselves, for other women, or for men. At last it can be said that, at least in one phase of their dressing, they will attire themselves especially to please the men.

SOME fifty-five years ago a young Baltimore woman in search of knowledge asked permission to attend a seminar at Johns Hopkins University, hitherto open only to men. The authorities were abashed but gallant. She might come, they said, if she would listen silently behind a screen.

ON rare occasions a book is written so unusually well that ordinary canons of criticism when applied to it seem hopelessly inadequate. "The Asiatics" is such a book. Some will call it a novel, others a book of travel, others, again, an autobiography.

Were we insincere in our many peace projects? I am unwilling to admit it. But it does seem clear that we have made some mistakes. Our first mistake was, of course, in not joining the League which our own President founded. As a result we find ourselves automatically on the seamy side.

Although a number of New York City's scholastic football teams will remain idle this week, merely marking time while awaiting traditional election day contests, nevertheless there will be several important schoolboy encounters on local fields on Saturday as the gridiron campaign enters its final month.

Fordham encountered little Lebanon Valley yesterday at the Polo Grounds in what was to be a tune-up for the Maroon's major clash with Pittsburgh next week. Instead the Rams had to keep tuned to a high degree of efficiency to turn back the Pennsylvanians, 15 -- 0, before 8,000 spectators.
WE live, if you stop to consider, under a crazy form of party government -- a democracy which utterly blinds its official eyes to the facts of life.
