The Borg-Warner Corporation, one of the first large auto-parts companies to report for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, showed a net profit of $4,213,008 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. The earnings are equivalent after dividend requirements on the preferred stock to $3.51 a share on 1,150,938 shares of $10 par common stock, excluding 79,925 shares held in the treasury.

INWOOD, L.I., Oct. 26. -- Baldwin High's football squad maintained its perfect record today by sweeping to a 27-6 victory over Lawrence, a Nassau County rival. The triumph was the fourth in as many times out for the winners, who were unbeaten in eight starts last year.

Henry Ware Allen's letter to THE TIMES makes a serious charge against the responsible citizen for his little concern over the economic distress of millions of his fellow-citizens. According to Mr. Allen, the American churches are still more culpable.

Dean Archibald L. Bouton of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and Dean Collins P. Bliss announced yesterday that 106 students have been pledged to the university fraternities at University Heights.

CONTINUING the adventures of that Tros of Samothrace who, with gold band on brow and purple cloak about him, came sailing his great trireme into the first chapter of "Queen Cleopatra," Talbot Mundy's new novel rings with the clash of arms.

NEWSPAPER headlines a week ago read something like this, "Yale Against Navy Tops Football Program," yet the game was not broadcast. Numerous telephone calls inquired why the broadcasters neglected the topnotch New Haven contest.

Harold Keates Hales, M.P., who sailed back to England after the Blue Ribbon Trophy he gave to the Rex a year ago had been transferred to the Normandie on Wednesday for beating the record made across the Atlantic by the Italian steamship, said that England was the only maritime nation in Europe that did not have a sailing vessel for the training of officers for the merchant marine.

For a beautiful specimen of the 1799 large copper United States cent $310 was paid yesterday at the sale of the John G. Townsend and other collections by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street. It was the finest copy of that date that has been offered at auction for several years.

WHEN the newly organized Smith College Archives recently inaugurated its series of annual publications of old and rare music with the printing of Francesco Geminiani's "XII Sonate a Violino, Violone e Cembalo" as edited into modern notation by Ross Lee Finney, the initial step was taken in a valuable undertaking which should prove of unusual interest to all serious students of the art.

A VERY mixed pickle week in the galleries has produced for current consumption group shows in a variety of media; pictures in fabric under glass; some very intangible but highly interesting experiments in color and light. Several new galleries have opened and work by artists already familiar to New York show places is not lacking.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- The Yale freshmen today subdued Worcester Academy, recent conqueror of the Harvard cubs, 13 -- 6. All the scoring occurred in a hectic first quarter and the remainder of the game was played almost exclusively in midfield.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- New York painters and sculptors carried off nearly all the honors in the competitions held by the Section of Painting and Sculpture of the Treasury Department to select artists to execute twelve statues and eight murals for the Postoffice Building and three murals for the Department of Justice in Washington.

AMOY, China, Oct. 24. -- Even a most cursory investigation of the situation in Fukien Province, adjacent to Kwangtung, discloses that any efforts regarding a revival of the anti-Japanese policy in Fukien are already doomed to failure.

Arguments for the development of a strong merchant marine to support the United States Navy were made at a Navy Day dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night sponsored by the Young Men's Council of Use United States.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The fate of democracy in the United States, in the opinion of Dr. Glenn Frank, lies in the decisions to be made by the American people in the forthcoming Presidential campaign.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Oct. 26. -- A new move to contest the will of John N. Willys was made in Probate Court here today when Mrs. Virginia Clayton Willys de Landa, daughter of the auto manufacturer, filed a series of objections which included charges that her stepmother, Florence E. Dolan Willys, "unduly influenced" the preparation of the will and also alienated Mr. Willys' affections from his daughter.

The role of dub and hero, all within the space of one minute, fell to Captain Nat Machlowitz in a tense gridiron drama enacted on the turf of the Yankee Stadium yesterday as he led the New York University varsity football team from the brink of an astounding upset to a nerve-tingling 7-6 triumph over Georgetown University.

Despite the depression, the enrolment at Fordham University is continuing the upward trend it has maintained for several years. Of the eight schools in the university, five show an increase this term sufficient to offset the losses of the rest.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- Junior members of the Plays and Players Club in Delancey Street, who recently have been organized as associates of the club, have announced plans for a Halloween costume party next Saturday at the club's little theatre.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 26. -- A fortnight's comedy of errors revolving about Count Luigi Orazio Vinci-Gigliucci, the Italian Minister, was finished, as far as Addis Ababa is concerned, today when he and Colonel Calderini, the military attache, entrained for Jibuti.

Even though the old wheeze that warns against counting chickens before they are hatched is just as applicable to motor boating as anything else, especially in the off-season when talk is cheap and usually harmless, there was an unmistakable undercurrent of genuine enthusiasm about international racing for 1936 at last week's powwows of officials and drivers at the Hotel Lexington.

MODEL SON: Around the turn of the century a 19-year-old youth was expelled "for revolutionary activities" from a school in the Caucasus district of Czarist Russia. His name was Joseph Vissarionovitch, to which he later added Stalin -- Russian for "steel."

Complaints that private ambulances in the city have been chartered for "joy rides" and that in other instances the vehicles have been driven about the streets, their sirens blaring, merely to advertise the merits of the machines, prompted Mayor La Guardia yesterday to order a police investigation.

THE Ethiopian army, as it waits in the hills and valleys of the highland empire for the oncoming Italians, is almost unreal in its anachronistic place among the world's fighting forces. Tribal chieftains decorated with lions' manes; dark-skinned warriors waving spears or guns and bounding barefooted over rocks -- surely this is a reversion to Zulu campaigns, to the dervishes of the Sudan, a figment of Haggard and Kipling come to life.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- High temperatures prevailing most of this week interfered somewhat with the volume of retail trade, but in specially advertised lines there has been a good market.

ATHENS, Oct. 26. -- Twenty-one guns at all the garrisons in Greece saluted today the twenty-third anniversary of the liberation of Saloniki from Turkish rule. All ranks received for their caps badges consisting of a crown topped by the cross of the Orthodox Church, but the oath to the King was postponed pending George's arrival.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- Yale University will invite a qualified scholar to open and study a sealed contract which dates from the thirty-sixth year of the reign of Hammurabi in Babylonia, about 3,900 years ago. The unopened envelope, unusually large and well preserved, has just been placed on exhibition in the Sterling Memorial Library.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Nebraska's Cornhuskers beat their way back into a favored spot in the Big Six conference football championship race by scoring in each of the first three quarters and nipping a late Oklahoma rally to win from the Sooners, 19 to 0, today.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Climaxing a full day's campaigning in admirable style, Ch. Vigow of Romanoff, stately Russian wolfhound owned and shown by Louis J. Murr of Spring Valley, N.Y., received the best in show trophy from Governor Harold G. Hoffman as the fourteenth annual dog show of the Paterson Kennel Club came to a close tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Increases in sales ranging from 15 to 200 per cent were reported here today by Newark businessmen, who laid the business spurt to the repeal last night of New Jersey's sales tax.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 26. -- Upsets marked the second and quarter final round matches today in the seventh annual invitation handicap squash racquets tourney at the Nassau Country Club. Three former national champions, all of whom have gained legs on the handsome J.L. Luckenbach Trophy, were ejected from the picture.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- No discrimination in favor of the athlete, either in academic requirements or in financial assistance, is the keynote of Rutgers University's intercollegiate athletic policy as outlined today by Robert C. Clothier, president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Continued business improvement in September was noted today by the Federal Reserve Board in its monthly summary of general business and financial conditions. While this gain was attributed, in part, to seasonal influences, the board's statement pointed out that in certain industries the increased activity was more than seasonal.

W.B. MAXWELL, the distinguished novelist and publisher, has written to The Times to plead that every book should carry its birth certificate; or, in other words, that all books should contain a notice giving the date of first publication.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 26. -- The end of the first week of the legal action brought against the Chilean Electric Light, Power and Traction Company by the government for alleged breach of the laws which concern the purchase and movements of foreign currencies has not yet marked a clear course, it was admitted today by well-informed sources reviewing recent developments.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend's pension plan followers today conferred on him and his principal aide authority to place their votes in the next Congressional and Presidential elections wherever they wish.
PANAMA, R. P. -- There are very few authentic Communists in Latin America, but there are comparatively few countries where the term is used more frequently or with less justification.

CHICAGO, Oat. 26. -- Merchandising continued to improve, retail sales for the week being augmented by a better demand for cold weather articles and by several basement clearance sales which brought out good crowds of shoppers.

The share market moved higher during the brief trading period yesterday, closing at or near the best levels of the day with net gains ranging up to 3 points despite the opportunity to claim profits that existed after the substantial gains made during the week.

Aksum, the "holy city" of Ethiopia, now in possession of the Italian troops, was once the political and cultural as well as the religious capital of the kingdom. Situated in the heart of the ancient kingdom of Aksum, to which it gave its name, the city is known to have been in existence since long before Christian times.
The staffs of six undergraduate publications at City College were announced yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Mrs. James Chesney's Professor Paul outclassed seven other 2-year-olds at Agawam Park today to win the $5,000 added Suffield Handicap over the mile route. Two and a half lengths behind the winner was C.V. Whitney's Bright Plumage.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 26. -- Ceremonies will be held at the University of Cincinnati, Thursday, to mark the presentation to the university of one of the finest collections of Stephen Collins Foster material in the country.

MUCH is said these days about the "succession of bloom" in gardens. Flower lovers spend long hours over planting plans in order to make sure that one period of bloom will follow another in swift succession throughout the Summer.

BALBOA, C.Z., Oct. 26. -- A Canal Zone jury returned a verdict of guilty last night against Ellis M. Stevens, an American employe of the Panama Railroad, who was charged with burglary of machine guns, automatic rifles and ammunition valued at $4,000 from the United States Army.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Unable to continue its unscored- upon record, the St. John's Prep eleven of Brooklyn nevertheless stayed in the undefeated division by overpowering a heavier Grover Cleveland High School squad, which had won its three previous games, at Dexter Park yesterday.

A tea will be given tomorrow in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for the junior committee of the fourth annual Miami Biltmore fashion show and supper dance to be held at the hotel on Nov. 22 for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Centre.

Announcement last week that the F.W. Woolworth Company is experimenting with price limits up to 40 cents in its Canadian units, with possible adoption here if the move is successful, centred attention on what other chains in the variety field are doing.

THIS is a novel of pioneer life unlike any yet written. It is in no respect another brave story of the hardy frontiersman who wrestled with life, building his cabin, clearing his land, facing privation with courage and fortitude.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- New national prosperity, set forth as the result of New Deal recovery acts, and continuance of the essentials of the AAA as a permanent farm policy will form the chief appeal of President Roosevelt for re-election in 1936, according to his advisers.
FOUR new lines of cars, comprising a number of novel features, are introduced under the Chrysler name for 1936. The latest Chryslers will go on display here in the near future.

ATLANTA, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Commenting that "special days and weeks" suggest "a kind of a racket," Governor Talmadge has refused to proclaim Monday as Navy Day and Oct. 27 as Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Day.

HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., Oct. 21. DURING the past few seasons Helen Hayes, Katharine Cornell and George Cohan have more or less rediscovered the "road" of yesteryear and the fact that Ethel Barrymore under the direction of S.E. Cochran is going over this same territory, plus a great deal more she discovered herself when a mere girl, has nothing of the headline quality about it except for this significant fact.

THE far-flung area of the city destined to lie in the shadow of the Triborough Bridge is already clearly revealing the shape of things to come. From Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx and 125th Street in Manhattan to Flushing Meadows in Queens the manifold paths of the $43,000,000 structure are outlined in skeleton steel or rows of concrete piers.

BARCELONA. -- This city, which seems to be a happy hunting ground for swindlers, is at the moment reading about the activities of two different gangs which victimized many innocent purchasers through the sale of base metal for gold. The first gang, which was under the leadership of a man known as Pepe the Cuban, specialized in the sale of "gold first communion medals."

The progress of business in general was retarded to some extent last week in most sections of the country, as retail buying of heavy clothing and other lines continued to lag under the influence of unseasonably mild weather. While retailers failed to maintain recent gains in many centres, buying generally was ahead of last year's volume.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Twenty-six officers of the Navy Dental Corps have been approved by President Roosevelt today for promotion, on recommendation of a selection board. They included nine lieutenants for promotion to lieutenant commander, and seventeen lieutenants (junior grade) to lieutenants.

The sale of the second part of Hyman Kaufman's collection of American furniture at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries brought $62,787.50, it was announced yesterday afternoon at the close of the two-day auction. Mr. Kaufman retired from the antique business in Boston a few years ago and the first part of his collection was auctioned in April, 1934.

Is it advantageous to an early-mentioned candidate to have too much conspicuity shed upon him? Governor LANDON of Kansas has been talked and written about for some time. While he is politely hospitable to interviewers, in theory he knows nothing about the glory anticipated for him.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 24. -- Shaken by the first major earthquake in its history, Helena, capital of Montana, has started to plan its rebuilding with an eye to the future and the possibility of other earthquakes in the years ahead.

IF there is any letter combination with the electrifying effect of an SOS in the electrical acropolis, Radio City, it is "DS." In the pioneer days of wireless those two letters -- dash, two dots and three more dots -- sputtered as the personal signature of a young Marconi operator named David Sarnoff.

DALLAS, Oct. 26. -- With the first touch of Winter in the Southwest, business conditions throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District have shown continued improvement. The recent cool period was accompanied by a considerable wave of buying.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 26. -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and one of the members substantially responsible for the new American neutrality formula, issued a statement today explaining his opposition to cooperation in League of Nations sanctions. He said:

For the benefit of publicity chairmen of various organizations, a press conference has been arranged for Tuesday under the joint auspices of the Woman's Club of Ridgewood and The Ridgewood Herald. The program, to be given at the Woman's Club, will include talks by Miss Monica Barry Walsh, director of club relations of The New York Herald-Tribune and Harry King Tootle, director of personnel of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

An operating rate of at least 55 per cent of capacity should be attained by the steel industry this Fall, and further gains should be made next year, T.M. Girdler, chairman and president of the Republic Steel Corporation, predicted here last week.

Every one of the seventy-three projects on the city's PWA list will be under way by Dec. 15, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday. The Mayor made the prediction in making public a report to the Board of Estimate on progress of the PWA program here.

IN 1807 Prussia signed the peace of Tilsit, which dismembered her and reduced her army to 40,000 men. Six years later she put in the field her biggest army and helped defeat Napoleon at Leipzig and Waterloo.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Navy Day will find more than 200 pieces of fighting craft, some of theme great old warriors of a day long past, tied up at government docks throughout the country.

IF not perfection, which is indeed too much to expect, the one-volume encyclopedia which has just been published under the auspices of Columbia University is a notable newcomer in the field of reference books. Prepared under the general supervision of Dr. Clarke F. Ansley, editor of the Columbia University Press, it has manifestly aimed at a high degree of accuracy and comprehensiveness.

BEN Hecht and Charles MacArthur, the Puck and Pan of North Astoria, have reformed. Gone are the radiant neckties, the backgammon board and the three-sheet whimsies they used to hang on the studio gates.

Members of the entering class at the Cooper Union Institute of Technology are predominately wage-earners, according to statistics made public yesterday by Dean George F. Bateman. Sixty-one per cent of the freshmen have found jobs to relieve economic conditions at home.

THE recent report of the United Parents Association condemning the overemphasis on attendance and the indiscriminate punishment of pupils for absence in the New York public schools has focused attention upon a subject which has long been of interest to the physician engaged in the care and treatment of children.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The New York State Northeastern Regional Junior Chambers of Commerce today put themselves unanimously behind the proposal that the government should formulate a national policy of neutrality which would remedy the inadequacies of our neutrality policy as revealed by the World War and would by effective measures subordinate any individual desire for private gain to the national will for peace through neutrality.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26. -- One of the great teams of the country came out of the West today and defeated a Navy eleven that had a courage as solid as the armor plate of one of its battleships -- and had to have in order to hold the score down to 14 to 0. That was the count by which Notre Dame downed the Middies in the Municipal Stadium before a howling crowd of 63,000.

HERE is a first-rate piece of swift-moving and dramatic story-telling in restrained and effective modern American prose. Most men and some women will get the thrill of recognition and the catharsis of vicarious experience out it.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- The greatest number of Philadelphians ever enrolled for any election, local or national, is eligible to vote in the Mayoralty contest on Nov. 5, it was shown tonight at the close of the last of the special registration days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A new transpacific air-mail postage stamp of 25-cent denomination, authorized today by Postmaster General Farley in connection with the early start of air-mail service to Hawaii, Guam and the Philippine Islands, will be put on first-day sale at Washington and San Francisco Nov. 8. It will be on general sale the following day.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for the week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

Ultimate development of a third major party in the United States was predicted yesterday by Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin in an interview at the Roosevelt Hotel. Governor La Follette, although regarding the formation of a nation-wide third party as certain, said that only future events could determine the exact time of its development.

ON Oct. 12 the Princeton University Press observed the thirtieth anniversary of its founding and the completion of twenty-five years of active publishing. At the Press building in Princeton a portrait of Charles Scribner by Wilford Seymour Conrow was unveiled; Mr. Scribner, a member of the Princeton class of 1875, and for many years the head of Charles Scribner's Sons, was the founder and benefactor of the Press.

One disadvantage of the two-party system in the United States would seem to be that party names may remain long after the reasons for assuming them have been forgotten or lost in the melee of changing issues.

With the death yesterday of Ralph R. McKee, vice president of the Board of Education, control of the board and of the city's school system passed into the hands of Mayor La Guardia and the Fusion administration.

PERHAPS the striking thing about this collection of crumbs from the abundant board set by John Galsworthy is the proof of the degree to which this paramount delineator of persons and manners lived with and among the characters of his creation.

ROME, Oct. 26. -- Italy thrust her military forces further into Northern Ethiopia today. Italian correspondents with the invaders reported tonight, as native Eritrean troops captured two villages in a determined drive southward toward Makale.

LAST Sunday in an article on William Blake in The New York Times Magazine I tried to provide something of a background for further discussion of the series of reproductions of his "Illustrations of the Book of Job" and their variations, about to be issued by the Pierpont Morgan Library.

It seems to me that Admiral Sims, in the statement quoted by Charles Warren, and you in your editorial comment thereon, miss the principal objection to the American doctrine of the freedom of the seas.

The collection of first editions, other books and autographs formed by B. George Ulizio of Pine Valley, N.J., will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons.

Fraternity members from Manhattan, Brooklyn, Westchester and Long Island will attend the opening tea of the New York City Panhellenic this afternoon at Beekman Tower Hotel honoring two women composers, Gena Branscombe and her daughter, Gena Tenney, and Miss Josephine Paddock, artist, Members of the board of governors, headed by Miss Mary Thaye Worthen, and Mrs. William Henry Purdy, president of Kappa Kappa Gamma, will receive.

GENEVA, Oct. 25. -- Hopes of members of the League of Nations for cooperation of non-members in upholding Geneva's judgment against Premier Mussolini of Italy are overwhelmingly centred in the United States. These hopes are for both moral and material support.
A school for brides will open Nov. 5 under the direction of Scientific Housekeeping, Inc., of which Mrs. Richard M. Boardman of 829 Park Avenue is president.

The National Democratic Club had a profit of $24,082 for the first nine months of 1935, Thomas J. McMahon, its president, announced yesterday. Mr. McMahon interpreted the club's showing as an encouraging sign of a return to better times.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The automobile accident in which two sons of the President were involved here recently had an acrimonious sequel today with Frank A. Goodwin, State Motor Vehicles Registrar, advising a daughter of Senator Henry Cabot Lodge to mind her own business.
SRINIGAR, Kashmir, Sept. 24. -- After weeks of negotiation the Kashmir Government gave me permission to excavate a site which has proved to be the oldest human monument as yet found in the Himalayas.

Senior high school swimmers shattered one record and equaled another at the opening series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond team championship of the P.S.A.L., conducted yesterday in the 75-foot pool of the De Witt Clinton High School.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., Oct 26 (AP). The Virginia Polytechnic Institute Gobblers outplayed and out-manoeuvred their ancient foe, the Washington and Lee Generals, to score a convincing 15 to 0 victory today before 6,000 fans in the Bluefield Municipal Stadium.

IT isn't the occasion of "Porgy and Bess" alone which indicated that American opera, in the nationally significant sense of the word, will evolve from our popular theatre rather than from our more august homes of the lyric drama.
ALBANY, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Eighty towns in the State will vote Nov. 5 on the question of licensing the sale of alcoholic beverages.

Two wide-sweeping brush fires on Staten Island became so menacing for a time yesterday that it was necessary to send in four alarms for the first and two alarms for the second and to enlist the aid of ten pieces of Fire Department apparatus from lower Manhattan.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 25. -- Entrance of Governor O.K. Allen in the Louisiana Senatorial race and of Lewis L. Morgan, State Highway Commission Attorney, in the race for Governor shows the powerful political machine left by the late Senator Huey P. Long still rent by internal strife.

A philosophy of education brought to Hunter College by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan when he became president two years ago has begun to materialize in the form of a reorganized curriculum which emphasizes individual guidance and culminates in vocational placement.

The American Liberty Leaguers demand rigid economy. If they can make rigid economy popular, with no favorites being played, may God bless them! Even President Roosevelt, admitting that he likes to spend as extravagantly as they say he does, would start a second economy drive like the abortive one in his first year, if he saw that the country demanded or would stand for it.

ROUND-the-clock short-wave listening was a pleasure during the past week, with static noises at times reaching unusually low values. Program after program seemed literally to bound from the loud-speaker as the dial pointer passed the important international channels.

Frustrated for two periods, the unbeaten Monroe High School football team staged a spirited rally in the last half to overpower Theodore Roosevelt, a Bronx rival, 16 -- 6, yesterday at Monroe Field. A crowd of 9,000 watched the battle.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Princeton established a new high in its twenty-four-game series with Cornell by scoring almost at will today against the ill-fated Red team. While 10,000 looked on from the crescent stand at Schoellkopf Field, the Tigers registered eight touchdowns and converted for six additional points, making the final score 54 to 0.

JAY N. DARLING is a versatile chap. Known to millions for his striking cartoons of public men and events, he has made a hobby of wild animals, feathered, furred, finned and horned. He happens at present to be chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, by appointment of President ROOSEVELT.

Invitations ware sent out recently to prospective subscribers to the annual Beaux-Arts Ball, which will be held on Dec. 6 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The ball this season is taking place two months earlier than the recent custom of a late January party.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- The Mayor was shocked. That is the only explanation assignable to his sudden action in closing "Tobacco Road," the drama of things as they are among the Georgia share-croppers and which opened in Chicago-seven weeks ago, playing to capacity houses of respectable townsfolk.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The debate in the House of Commons this week which served to enlighten British voters regarding foreign policy on the eve of an election proved reassuring both for the Italians, who were disturbed by British naval mobilization, and for those in Great Britain who feared too vigorous League of Nations action might lead to war.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Finishing going away and with plenty to spare the Northwood Stables' Indigo was an easy winner in the $1,500 added New Jersey Hunt Cup race, which featured the final program of the twentieth annual Essex Fox Hounds Hunts meeting today on the rolling Froh-Heim estate of Evander B. Schley.

The laughter of fate may, presumably, take the form of coincidence. In this combined mystery-and-adventure story, the arm of coincidence is not only very long but very frequent. Jim Flower, just home from Australia, out of work and penniless, finds a double in the person of Lord Wantage just before a murder is committed, and willy-nilly he is drawn into the investigation of the mystery.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 26. -- Belated reports that hundreds of persons were drowned in floods accompanying a hurricane last week-end caused officials today to fear that as many as 1,000 lives might have been lost.

With the machinery for the enforcement of the National Labor Relations Act, also known as the Wagner-Connery act, completed, the twenty-one Regional Labor Boards throughout the country have started their work of investigating charges of unfair labor practices submitted to them.

NO artist ever loved his work more passionately or received less material reward for it than Vincent van Gogh, the first comprehensive American exhibition of whose paintings and drawings will open at the Museum of Modern Art on Nov. 6.

In the British House of Commons last Wednesday Prime Minister Baldwin made a speech every member had been anxious to hear. He put an end to conjecture by announcing formally that a general election (by which a new Commons will be chosen) would be held Nov. 14.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 26. -- The Manhattan Indians really sold the island twice to the early white settlers, Reginald Pelham Bolton of New York said here today in an address to the Archaeological Society of New Jersey.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Williams subdued Tufts, 20 to 0, in a home-coming game at Tufts' Oval this afternoon. Nick Holmes made the first score on a 20-yard run. The second touchdown was made by Ed Stanley on a 12-yard sprint and the final on a lateral pass from P. Stearns to Bill Colman.

I was very interested in J.B. Priestley's article In your Sunday TIMES today, Oct. 20. He says, "Yet at this very time I can bring over a company from England to play my 'Eden End' on Broadway. Is this fair, is this decent or right? Ought my players to be barred the country until more American actors are in work?"

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 26. -- The Investment Bankers Association of America has taken definite steps to bring changes in the Securities Act of 1933 and in rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission pertaining to the syndication and marketing of securities, it was revealed today at the first open forum of the association's convention.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 26. -- Bowdoin won its first Maine State series victory in five years today, defeating Colby, 20 -- 0.

Mrs. Sarah Jacobs, 69 years old, was killed shortly after noon yesterday when she fell from the seventh floor window of an apartment occupied by her daughter, Mrs. Joseph Lewis, at 45 Gramercy Park. Mrs. Jacobs, who lived with her son, Mark Jacobs, at 233 West Seventy-seventh Street, had been subject to nervous disorders and fainting spells for the last year, members of the family reported.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26. -- Corporation executives in the steel, rubber and automobile industries are apprehensive lest the movement now under way to link up individual plant company unions into national company unions sound the death-knell of the company-dominated employe representation plan.

An analysis of the effect of the Federal Government's social security taxes on earnings of sixty-four industrial corporations has been prepared by a large New York financial institution. Estimates of 1935 sales, payrolls and common stock earnings were used as a basis for the study.

May I, as one who has given my best energies for half a century to promote friendship between the churches, international friendship, and especially friendship between your great nation and the British Commonwealth of Nations, protest against the opinions expressed for years by my friend Dr. C.C. Morrison in that exceedingly able paper The Christian Century?
NATURE took Raymond Walburn, gave him a pudgy nose, a pink complexion, a set of bewildered eyes, and the movies polished him off.

The Naval Conference which Great Britain has called to meet in London Dec. 2 cannot, by any stretch of the imagination, be called a disarmament conference. Its brightest prospects lie in the hope of its being a limitation conference.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- Colonel Franz yon Papen, German Minister to Austria and former Vice Chancellor, is here in Berlin for a week-end visit. Officially the Minister is on a hunting trip. There have been many such recently in Central Europe and it is admitted that Colonel von Papen while hunting in Berlin and elsewhere may talk politics with this and that person.

A new city ordinance requiring all sellers of tickets for public amusements to show purchasers the exact location of seats will be introduced in the Board of Aldermen next Tuesday by Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx.

With a splendid entry, a high-class judging staff and $6,000 in prize money, the second annual show of the revived Kennel Club of Philadelphia will be given this week in Convention Hall, Philadelphia, on Friday and Saturday.

VIENNA, Oct. 25. -- Last week's dramatic Cabinet reconstruction served several purposes, not the least important of which was to give Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and Vice Chancellor Ernst von Starhemberg a freer hand in the direction of policy.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 26 (AP). -- An Ethiopian chieftain whom Italians are reported to have once planned to kidnap in order to make him a puppet ruler in part of Ethiopia is a virtual prisoner in a mountain monastery by order of Emperor Haile Selassie.

THE earth like all else in nature has written its own history." The structure and chemistry of rocks, the form of hills and valleys, the drainage patterns of rivers and their tributaries, the movements and composition of air and water and ice, the fossil relics of living creatures -- these are the words and sentences of the autobiography of earth.
DUBLIN, Oct. 25. -- To outside observers the Irish Free State today, after three years of rule by the Fianna Fail party, appears free of any acute economic distress or internal turmoil.

Three Connecticut business men who started out from Stamford before dawn yesterday to fish in Long Island Sound narrowly escaped death off Stamford Light when their thirty-foot cabin cruiser caught fire and forced them to jump into the cold water.

New York City triumphed easily over Westchester County in horseshoe pitching yesterday afternoon as Vito Fileccia of 112 Central Avenue, Brooklyn, won his contest with Dominick Sharkey of 22 State Street, New Rochelle, by three straight games at the Heckscher Playground in Central Park.

On the whole, judges while not dishonest are steeped in mammonism. As lawyers, they have served rich clients. The taint clings to them on the bench. Such is the accepted "liberal" view. Professor HAROLD LASKI treats us to a bit of this moth-eaten gospel in the November Harpers:

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- With the State sales tax repealed less than four months after it went into effect, New Jersey again is confronted with the problem of finding another way, more satisfactory to the electorate, of financing relief expenditures.

In its efforts to minimize the effects of the depression on Hunter College students, the Bureau of Occupations, one of the most vital and integral parts of the college, had succeeded in placing more than 1,700 girls during the last Summer. Many students who otherwise might have been forced out of school by existing conditions have been able to continue their education through the cooperation of the bureau.

ON a quiet street in Quincy, Mass., stands the cottage in which John Adams was born on Oct. 30, 200 years ago. It is one of a unique pair, standing together, each the birthplace of a President of the United States.

ABOARD THE S.S. PRESIDENT GRANT, at Sea, Oct. 26. -- Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota expressed today "emphatic opposition" to United States cooperation in League of Nations sanctions against Italy.

SHANGHAI. -- Hereafter the sufferings of criminals condemned to death in China will be mitigated in the use of ether, chloroform "or other chemicals of the same nature" before they are executed by strangulation or by firing squads.

Miss Helene Mayer, women's Olympic fencing champion in 1928, confirmed yesterday her acceptance of an invitation to join the German team in the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin. The German-Jewish star, who won the national title in this country in 1934 and 1935 while teaching at Mills College in California, disclosed her action through authorities of the Oakland institution.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25. -- The newly vinted Soviet puritanism received fresh impetus today in an article in Izvestia by En. Izgoyev, a leading Russian sociologist. He urged a law punishing "libertines," that is men who accost women on the streets.
Textile, De Witt Clinton, Curtis, John Adams and Manual Training were crowned borough champions by triumphing in the annual P.S. A.L. borough cross-country runs at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

It was one of Minnesota's colder days, thirty below zero, and game was scarce. Armed with an air-rifle, Ivar and Waino, two Finnish boys, were returning to the village, discussing in detail just how they would have shot a moose if they could have found one.

ELIZABETH COATSWORTH'S story of Colonial Virginia is more than the "small tale of green adventure," which she modestly calls it; it is a portrait of a gallant daughter of two races, in which the dim and lovely colors of the past are freshened to a new glow by a poet's imagination and sense of beauty.

ALTHOUGH the reader is never in doubt as to the outcome of the divorce between Margot and Kent Marshall, he is interested in watching the slow dawn of recognition in the wife who thinks she does not love her husband, but who finds no pleasure in her long-sought and finally won freedom.

IN a brief announcement in the current Air Corps News Letter the story of the "Great Swap" is told. The War Department And the Navy Department have joined in a transaction in real estate that reads somewhat like a record of deals during the boom days at Montauk Point, when everybody going to and coming from Europe was planning to use Montauk as his port of entry here.

With the demand for United States Government obligations almost at a standstill, the volume of trading in other issues spurted yesterday beyond the usual figure for the short Saturday session total. Prices generally were mixed, while the market was featureless.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 26. -- Displaying a powerful and varied offensive, with an aerial game that kept the Yellow Jackets baffled, the University of North Carolina's Tar Heels turned back Georgia Tech today, 19 to 0, to keep their standing as one of the nation's unbeaten football teams.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Out of the air with rifling passes and on the ground from savage thrusts. California's Golden Bears snatched a great 21-7 victory today from Southern California's Trojans in one of the classic battles of their 20-year-old football rivalry.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Louisiana State eliminated a fighting Vanderbilt University eleven from the Southeastern Conference football race today, scoring the game's lone touchdown in the third period to win, 7 to 2. A crowd of 10,000 attended.

WITH the premiere a Billy Rose's gargantuan spectacle, "Jumbo," deferred one week (the show is now scheduled to open the night of Nov. 2 at the Hippodrome), there are evidences on all sides of several shattered precedents.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 26. -- A celebration of the seventy-seventh anniversary tomorrow of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt was held today at the grave of the late President after a pilgrimage to the national shrine here in which 6,000 Boy Scouts took part.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Britain prepared today for economic and financial sanctions against Italy and announced that an embargo on arms, munitions and other war material had been effective since yesterday.

THE way the American Art Anderson Galleries got off to its seasonal start this month was heartening to those who witnessed the phenomenon. Prices were excellent, on the whole, in what we may choose to regard as the keynote sale.

THE San Francisco exposition, which will mark the completion of the Golden Gate Bridge, at the entrance of the bay, and the double-deck Bay Bridge -- a Titan of steel that wades across five watery miles from San Francisco to the Oakland shoreline -- is scheduled to open in 1938.

REGARDING Don Quixote and Sancho, Salvador de Madariaga very justly remarks that in "the very wealth of their spirit, which stimulates the thought of commentators, Cervantes's two characters tend to become obscure and to disappear beneath the intellectual luxuriance which they have been feeding with their own vitality."

BARNARD COLLEGE is not yet fifty years old, a mere infant in comparison with the venerable institution beneath whose protecting wing it lives and works. But notwithstanding its youth in years, in experience it is hoary, for it has lived through so significant a change in the status of women that Barnard's "beginnings" were like the first fruits of a social revolution.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 26 (AP). -- The Morning Advocate said today the Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools has opened an inquiry into the effects of politics on schools of this State.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Eight men and one woman, all striking employes of the Consumers Research plant at Washington, N.J., went on a hunger strike here today in the Warren County jail, where they are being held in default of bail for the grand jury on charges of unlawful assembly and malicious mischief.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- There are two reasons why the British Government has after many delays and rebuffs called a naval conference in London for Dec. 2. One of them is obvious. It is that the Washington and London treaties both contain clauses providing for a conference this year to decide what will supersede them when they expire at the end of 1936.

HOME decorators now realize at the introduction of a piece of marble, bronze or terra cotta sculpture brings in a new note which the furnishings must enhance. A color similar to that of the sculpture may be used in a chair covering, curtain or rug, and a decorative contrast achieved by means of the texture of other furnishings.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Michigan State College roared back into the winning column today with a versatile attack which downed Washington University of St. Louis, 47 to 13, before 8,000 football fans.

THERE have been good biographies written this year, and "Joan of Arc" Stands out among them as a beautiful piece of work. It is almost everything that a biography should be; put together with assiduous regard for the niceties of history, archaeology and psychological research, its subject's peculiar personality and character are so perfectly realized as to score a minor artistic triumph for the author.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP). -- A great defensive team turned on its offensive today as undefeated University of California at Los Angeles won from Oregon, 33 to 6, before a crowd of 35,000. The winners showed dazzling speed to count in every period, with two touchdowns in the second, and kept the visitors scoreless until the final period.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The old-fashioned "rough-house" Halloween, with gates decorating the Town Hall steeple and refuse cans mysteriously appearing on the front steps, will be combated with cider and doughnuts here the night of Oct. 31.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- During this week-end France's biggest political party, the Radical Socialist, is holding its annual congress in Paris. Its leaders are divided and its members are divided. To superficial observers it presents the spectacle that all France often presents of a group of extremely argumentative and completely divided persons all ready to leap at one another's throats.

Whether the grand jury minutes in the Druckman murder case are to be made available to the public will be decided tomorrow by Kings County Judge Algernon I. Nova. The case has developed into a major issue in the Brooklyn campaign for the post of District Attorney.

IN "Mottke the Thief" Sholem Asch has done what may sound he like a contradiction in terms: he has written a picaresque novel which yet remains fixed within a milieu. His Mottke, roaming through Poland on a career of makeshifts and vagabondage, roams always among struggling Jews and inhabits a close-knit racial world.
ABOARD THE S.S. MANHATTAN, At Sea, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Whatever James J. Walker does when he gets back to New York, he said today, he will not try to take the place of the late Will Rogers.

SUNDAY performances on the legitimate stage, made legal by the Legislature and made difficult by Equity and the unions, will be given their first thorough test by the Theatre Union next month at the Civic Repertory Theatre.
The American Ballet, which returned to New York three days ago after an interrupted tour, was busy yesterday considering plans for the next few weeks.

A BOOK dealer in San Francisco was thumbing through a pile of dog-eared magazines that he had just purchased when suddenly he pounced, with a cry of joy, upon one of the most uninteresting looking of all. It was a National C. Geographic dated 1888, and worth, he declared, at least $100, possibly $200.

Michael J. Meehan replying to action against him by the Securities and Exchange Commission, issued a statement last night at the offices of M.J. Meehan Co., 30 Broad Street, after earlier attempts to reach him had failed.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- Pennsylvania ran roughshod over the Lafayette eleven on Franklin Field today, scoring ten touchdowns and seven extra points to submerge the Leopards under a 67-0 count.

VIENNA, Oct. 26. -- Institution by the Fatherland Front of a political "star chamber" to punish persons whose political leanings are suspect, to operate without the trouble of collecting evidence which would satisfy a court of law, is announced. There are too many persons, the announcement states, who wear the Fatherland Front badge, although perhaps being Nazi at heart.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- Settlement of labor difficulties in the automobile business in San Francisco resulted in resumption of plans for an automobile show in November. Striking mechanics were responsible for cancellation of the show two weeks ago.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The United States has overtaken France and zoomed into the lead in the world's aviation honors race, an unofficial compilation of records disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24. -- William Randolph Hearst's announcement that he will leave California to escape the State income tax, and his prediction that other rich men and the motion-picture industry would follow, have aroused fear and resentment in business circles where the State's power of attracting wealthy men and their money is still seen as a major asset.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- Notable accessories featured in Worth's midseason collection are wide belts and narrow standing collars, made of numerous rows of stiff gold braid or cord. They are shown with both wool street and silk afternoon frocks.

MEXICO'S experiment in "socialistic education," opposed by church authorities and inaugurated somewhat disastrously last January, now seems to be winning support. School attendance, which by way of protest in the early months of 1985 dropped to 10 or 15 per cent of normal, is today not merely normal but twice as great as in 1930, according to Rafael Molina Betancourt, administrative director in the Ministry of Education.

WIRELESS became voluble fifteen years ago this week. On Nov. 2, 1920, a radiophone station in Pittsburgh using the call letters KDKA broadcast the Harding-Cox election returns. That day is quite generally looked upon as the beginning of broadcasting, although Marconi contraptions previous to that date chattered a bit and tried to sing a few songs.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25. -- The ever-recurring clashes between the hard-riding Mongol descendants of Genghis Khan and the sturdy little Japanese troopers of the Manchukuoan army on the Outer Mongolian-Manchurian border are being watched with the gravest concern by the foreign offices of Moscow and Tokyo.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- A rugged band of C.C.N.Y. football players possessing a powerful line and a fine attack defeated Drexel Institute, 14 -- 0, today. It was the Dragons' first setback this season.

NEW lines of six and eight-cylinder Hudson automobiles are now on display at dealers' show rooms in the metropolitan district. Different in appearance from last season's models, the new cars also include a number of basic mechanical changes.
CROWDED and important are the cable's adjectives for London's forthcoming week in the theatre, which runs like this:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 26. -- An estate of about $25,000 is involved in the dispute over the admission of the forty-three-word will of George C. Hanson, former Consul General at Moscow, who committed suicide Sept. 2 on the liner President Polk en route from Saloniki to the United States.

Mr. N. Lindsay Norden's letter to you, published in THE TIMES on Sunday, Oct. 20, by way of commentary on your article about the atonalists which appeared the previous Sunday, is a timely and proper one. Any reminder of the physical ignorance (and concomitant bliss) in which we may write, perform or enjoy music is probably beneficial.

SALES of radio sets give indication that this year may surpass the all-time peak established in 1929. Sales for some months of the current year have been double those of the like months last year and production has ranged from 25 to 40 per cent more than a year ago in units, while the gain in dollar volume has been less, according to a survey by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

M.J. FARRELL (the pseudonym of a woman novelist) has deserted her Irish foxhunting and fishing for satirical characterization blended with a psychopathic and exceedingly sympathetic study of inherited insanity.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Malibu Hills conflagration, one of the most disastrous ever to strike Southern California, was checked apparently on all fronts tonight alter marching nearly to the doorfronts of pretentious movie colony Summer homes.

AMONG the depression sufferers in the United States are some 500,000 children whose situation is beyond the reach of any present collective effort at rescue. This newly discovered fact inspires the campaign opened here this month by the Child Welfare League of America.
Under the pendant potted palms of the south garden at the Hotel Astor, animal heroes of the last six months received rewards yesterday. They barked, meowed and cheeped their appreciation.

LEWISTON, Idaho, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Senator Borah's silence amid recurring reports that he would be a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination perplexed Idaho observers tonight. He left Lewiston for an unannounced destination today without acknowledging the latest "Borah for President" talk and still insisting that his current tour of Northern Idaho had nothing to do with politics.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 26. -- Putting on a drive that netted two touchdowns in the second half, the Princeton freshmen eleven today downed the Columbia yearlings, 13 -- 7, on University Field.
Rambling around the outdoor circuit:

Practically all lines of trade are experiencing an improved volume of distribution, commodity prices are firm and employment slightly improved, compared with the previous month, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday in its summary of current business conditions.

I CONSIDER the matter of money and the sale of [your] pictures as non-existing, or rather as though it existed merely as a kind of illness." Thus Theo van Gogh, the artist's brother, in one of his letters, published recently in Holland by the Wereld-bibliotheek (World Library), summarizes incisively their relationship.

Dr. William E. Grady, Associate Superintendent of the city's public schools, has been appointed by Governor Lehman to represent the State at the thirty-second annual convention of the National Conference of Juvenile Agencies in Atlanta, which begins today and continues through Thursday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The Association of National Advertisers will hold its twenty-sixth annual meeting at the Hotel Ambassador here for four days, beginning tomorrow.

Plans for the participation of the Garden Club of New Jersey in the forthcoming International Flower Show at the Grand Central Palace will be made on Thursday, when the first meeting of the new executive committee is held at the home of Mrs. William Holliday at Plainfield, N.J.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Surrounded by nearly 100 representatives of institutions of higher education and an audience that filled Park Church to its capacity, Dr. William Sumner Appleton Pott was inaugurated today as president of Elmira College.

Eric Hatch tries his hand at the butler brand of comedy. The result is a humorous, gaga yarn suitable for whiling away the feverish convalescence of a flu sufferer. It is amusing without achieving the sheer lunacy of some of the earlier Hatch stories.

IN this book -- frankly a personal record -- is very little that is not true. Very little in it is really important, even if true. But neither importance nor just perspective is the measure of human interest. And here we have vividly human material.

Greater flexibility in retail price lines came in for a larger degree of attention last week, due both to the upward pressure of rising wholesale prices and the declaration of trade groups in the women's apparel field in favor of abandoning fixed wholesale price ranges.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Even though he cannot see the hurdles, Senator Schall of Minnesota has worked out a way to take a horse over them.
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Was Britain too slow in warning Italy against war on Ethiopia? Did the British lead Premier Benito Mussolini to think he could go ahead without interference?

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 26. -- Arnaud C. Marts, president of Marts Lundy, Inc., of New York City, was elected acting president of Bucknell University at a special meeting of the trustees today. He succeeds Dr. Homer P. Rainey, who has become head of the new American Youth Commission of the American Council on Education.

Mrs. James Roosevelt heads the list of prominent women serving as patronesses of the second series of Criterion Society morning musicals, which opens Friday in the ballroom of the Hotel Plaza. The recitals, organized last Winter to raise funds for the society's foundation and to introduce talented but unknown artists to a local audience, proved so popular they were scheduled for the first Friday of each month from November to April, inclusive.

Opportunity knocked not once but twice for Michigan yesterday and the Wolverines, operating under a system of always welcoming opportunity's commands, jammed over two touchdowns in the first five minutes of play to turn back Columbia at Baker Field.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 26 (AP). -- The move to recall Charles W. Bryan as Mayor of Lincoln was interrupted but not stopped by official and other developments today.

PARIS. LOVELY and unusual color schemes are featured in Molyneux's new showing, which, as usual, is presented well in advance of other midseason collections and, also as usual, is specially dedicated to his smart private clientele.

Sixteen-year-old Jacques Margolies, who made his debut in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon as a concert violinist, manifested definite potentialities and promise which in time should make for real virtuoso playing.

The New York, New Haven Hartford's filing on Wednesday of a petition for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act was viewed later in the week in Wall Street as in large part the effect of unprofitable non-railroad investments which constituted a burden which the company's earnings could not support.

SCIENCE, bent on prodding nature to "hurry up," has devised an accelerator. Impatient with the slow growth of roots in the soil, experimenters have now developed synthetic means of producing roots in a few days -- and, furthermore, producing them wherever they want them, even at the top of a plant.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The annual Homecoming Day of Rutgers University was celebrated today by about 1,000 alumni. Features of the day were an intercollegiate football game with Lehigh University in the afternoon and the homecoming dinner in the gymnasium tonight.

MAUDIE, the irrespressible sub-deb of "Men Are Like Street Cars" and "Stag Line," is now definitely and delightfully grown up. Looking in the mirror one morning, she realizes that she has matured overnight, "just like a bond."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Investigation of the income tax return in 1930 of James E. Watson, former Senator from Indiana and Republican leader of the Senate in the Hoover administration, was revealed today. The government inquiry, which has been going on for two years, is based on the allegation that Mr. Watson failed to report $73,000 of his income in his returns.

The permanent existence of a modified form of the AAA for the economic good of the nation is urged by Thomas D. Campbell, Montana agricultural engineer and the reputed largest individual grower of wheat in the world, who came here after surveying agricultural conditions in the West and Middle West.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Chagrined at having been scored upon for the first time this season, the Hill School's football team waged a desperate battle against Lawrenceville in the second half today, and in the final minute gained a 7-7 tie in the thirtieth gridiron meeting between the traditional rivals.

A concerted attack upon the Lewis bill, under which a foreign trade board would coordinate governmental policies on international commerce, was started here last week by exporters, who charged the bill was "revolutionary in its provisions."
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26. -- Generally satisfactory business conditions prevailed in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week.
AMHERST, Oct. 26. -- Amherst successfully opened its defense of the Little Three championship today, crushing Wesleyan, 26 -- 0, with a powerful second-half drive.

Josef Lhevinne, who played yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, commenced with a series of Intermezzi and Capriccii by Brahms, which are not effective for the opening group of a piano recital. Moreover, Mr. Lhevinne was somewhat diffident, or unaroused, when he began. He did not take fire till later in the afternoon.

ONE of the islands of the Mediterranean about which have gathered the threatening shapes of war vessels is Rhodes. But the ships of peace also go to Rhodes, which is the most easterly of the Aegean Islands.

SPECIAL coins perforated in the centre so that the natives can string them together and carry them as a necklace are being issued for use in New Guinea. Australian currency has been in use in New Guinea since Australia received a mandate over the territory, which was a German possession until the World War.

PEOPLE go to see two football teams play because they want to see the game -- and for an amazing variety of other reasons. They go because their room-mate at Vassar's brother asked them; or because they want to see their old classmates; or because they have a wad of money up on the outcome; or because they enjoy al fresco drinking in the Autumn air; or because it's a dramatic and entertaining American festival.

A collection of paintings largely of the American and French nineteenth century schools but including two works by Gainsborough will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday evening.

A REVIEW of forthcoming 1936 cars was presented before the Detroit Section, Society of Automotive Engineers here last week. It was presented by Harold F. Blanchard, technical editor of the publication Motor and chairman of the technical committee of the American Automobile Association's contest board.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 24 (Delayed) (AP). -Northeastern Ethiopia i seems a terrible country for an army to cross, and from the air it i looks like a terrible country for remunerative developments.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The Hamilton College board of trustees, at the regular Fall meeting today, elected four new members to the board to replace trustees who died last year.

Several young women headed by Miss Carol Barnes are active in arrangements for the luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital occupational committee of the New York City Visiting Committee to be held Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

Many reservations have been made for the Halloween dinner dance and carnival in behalf of the Women's Aid Society for the Relief of Widows and Orphans to be held on Wednesday in the new ballroom of the Astor. Proceeds will be used in purchasing necessities during the coming Winter for the destitute widows and orphans cared for by the organization.

APPARENTLY satisfied that their experiments have gone far enough for the time being, and having started introducing new versions of old favorites, Victor seems to be settling down to release high-fidelity re-recordings of the Philadelphia Orchestra's earlier successes.

ROME, Oct. 26. -- War, even colonial war, is an expensive luxury and one not lightly to be indulged in by a relatively poor country such as Italy, which is already burdened with a very large national debt and whose taxation, by admission of Premier Mussolini himself, has long since reached the bearable limit.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Dissolution of Parliament was announced formally in a special issue of the official London Gazette in the following age-old terms:

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 26. -- A scrappy band of Tartans from Carnegie Tech, overcoming the odds against them with a sparkling, accurate aerial attack, came out of the East today to whip the Purdue Boilermakers, 7 to 0, and stun the homecoming crowd of 17,000.

GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Despondency and the love of a 50-year-old man for a high school girl were blamed by State police tonight for the slaying of the girl, Ruth Clark, and the suicide of the man today.
BIG PRAIRIE, Ohio, Oct. 26. -- The thrifty village of Big Prairie stood out today as possibly the only town in America where the depression is just a rumor.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 26. -- A poll of the Republican county chairmen of California conducted by The Santa Barbara Morning Press disclosed today that Senator Borah of Idaho headed the list as first choice for President and Governor Merriam of California for Vice President.
MOGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 26. -- Temple's Owls scored to a 19-6 victory today over West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The hopes of low-income families in the national capital rose with the recent announcement of the government's newest resettlement project -- Tugwelltown. The Resettlement Administration announced it would build this town, consisting of 1,000 low-cost four-room and six-room houses, at Berwyn Heights, Md. -- ten miles from Washington -- to rent for $20 to $30 a month.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Oct. 27. -- Bulging majorities in favor of an AAA corn-hog control program in 1936 were shown in returns early today from yesterday's national referendum. With fragments of the total balloting counted from sixteen States the latest tabulation was 173,853 for and 21,929 against a new adjustment plan.

Despite the fact that the security markets made considerable progress during the week just completed, it is true nevertheless that in professional circles a note of caution is manifest. In the heaviest trading since the week ended on Feb. 10, 1934, stocks rose to new high records for the year, many to the best levels since 1931 and even 1930; domestic corporation bonds gained moderately.

The Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement, which provides care of the sick in their homes for thousands of needy families in the city, will be the beneficiary of a dinner and supper dance on Nov. 7 at the formal opening of the new Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- A survey of rapid transit facilities in New York, Philadelphia and Boston shows a definite trend toward speeding up the mass movement of passengers over the last twenty years. Chicago is the only other city with rapid transit lines.
BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The Nazi flag flew from the towers of all Protestant churches in Germany today in honor of the memory of the Nazi district leader of Brunswick-Dessau, who was buried in Dessau.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A necessity for increasing the strength of the navy "to a degree commensurate with the country's needs, interests and responsibilities" was asserted by President Roosevelt tonight to Secretary Swanson on the occasion of Navy Day, which is to be observed throughout the country tomorrow and Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- If administration followers should take a breathing spell from their rejoicing over the general improvement in economic conditions throughout the country, they might find time to complain of the poor sportsmanship of some of President's Roosevelt's critics for seizing upon his remarks at Charleston to magnify the ills that still remain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The favorable trend of business activity continued in the week ended on Oct. 19, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of the domestic situation.

THIS, under the thinnest and most artless of disguises, is an account of Sigrid Undset's earliest years. She has gone back to her childhood as though it all happened yesterday, reclaiming it with humor and ease, piecing it together out of a powerful but not infallible memory.

Only in the formation of a strong labor party have workers any remaining hope of getting a "square deal" and the country a properly balanced economy, Francis J. Gorman, vice president of the United Textile Workers of America, told representatives of forty-five New York City trade unions yesterday at the thirteenth annual conference for women trade unionists, called by the New York Women's Trade Union League.

Like Britain's Ramsay MacDonald, Pierre Laval, France's Premier, started his political career as a Socialist and later moved over toward the centre; unlike Mr. MacDonald, the French statesman still retains a large political following. Last Sunday he was re-elected Senator by a ringing vote in two departments where he had presented his candidacies -- the Seine and Puy-de-Dome.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26. -- In reply to testimony of a Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines official who denied that a Federal conciliator had ever laid before him specific charges of violating the Wagner Labor Disputes Law, Clinton Golden, director of the Pittsburgh Regional Board, read into the record of today's hearing before the National Labor Relations Board the official report he prepared of the conversation at which he was present.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25. -- Pennsylvania's "marrying squires" have assumed long faces, tightened their belts a couple of holes and are looking around for some genteel work "on the aide."

WHEN Autumn days come with crisp mornings, and before the frost gets too deep into the ground, then is the high season of the horse that carries a man on his back. Not that there isn't a lot of riding in Summer, at dude ranches and young folks' camps and on the polo fields, on bridle paths in and out of the city and at the neighborhood horse shows.

WITH forty changes in design, the new Plymouths are presented in three regular and seven de luxe models on 113-inch wheelbase. The new cars are now on display at dealers' showrooms throughout the country.

RESTLESS Europe has lately confronted Britain and her empire with a succession of dangers of the first order -- Germany's rearmament, Italy's violently asserted colonial claims, the unexpectedly acute problem of the defense of British lines of imperial communication in the Mediterranean, the whole position of naval power as altered by the rapid growth of air fleets.

WITH workmen putting the finishing touches on the Huey P. Long Bridge across the Mississippi River at New Orleans, travelers over United States Highway 90 -- Old Spanish Trail -- will soon have an unbroken ribbon of concrete from St. Augustine to San Antonio, 1,375 miles, and then another 1,492 miles into San Diego.

After twenty years of residence in the West Indies, the Right Rev. Hiram R. Hulse, Episcopal Bishop of Cuba, has returned to his native State for a brief visit, and will be the speaker on Tuesday before the Manor Club of Pelham Manor. Mrs. Charles Chenery, president of the organization, will preside at a luncheon honoring the prelate, prior to his address.
CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 26. -- The Dickinson College team overwhelmed Haverford College by 45 -- 0, on Biddle Field this afternoon in the annual dad's day game before 2,500 fans.

DUBLIN, Oct. 4. THE Fall season of drama has begun in Dublin, and both the Abbey and the Gate Theatres hold out promise of worthy programs. During the Summer months efforts were made to amalgamate both places under a Joint directorate, but the negotiations were not successful, and the theatres continue their independent existence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Department of Justice agents and police sought today to determine who broke into the House Rules Committee in the Capitol building recently and ransacked files used in the utilities lobbying investigation.

Impressive ceremonies will mark the fifteenth annual Armistice Ball, to be given at the Astor on Nov. 11 under the auspices of the British Great War Veterans of America, of which Major C.R. Redgrave is president.

A tramp steamer is no place for a woman, especially when murder becomes almost an everyday occurrence, as it bids fair to do aboard the Sari-Bahr. One officer after another is struck down for no reason that is apparent to the survivors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Edwin H. Barker, chairman of the Asbury Park bondholders committee of New York, testified before the Securities and Exchange Commission today that the committee's agreement with its depositors of bonds permitted it to borrow money on the bonds in its trust in order to pay the compensation of the three members of the committee.

LONDON, Oct. 3. AN unusual and dangerous controversy is springing up in the London theatre. It arises from what may, for the sake of politeness, be called the quest of new talent by certain managers. Actresses are continually appearing in leading parts of whom the English stage has previously known nothing.

IT was no less a person than a Prime Minister who discovered Mary Webb, and even then she did not become a celebrity until after her death. She was born in Shropshire and all her young life was spent in that lovely countryside. Here she absorbed, almost without realizing it, a deep, instinctive understanding of its people and their lives.

PARIS, Oct. 2. WE have had one new play by Sacha Guitry, and week we are to have another. In the second he himself is to take the principal part, and that is almost equivalent to saying that it will be the better.

The body of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer remained unclaimed yesterday at the undertaking establishment of Daniel F. Coughlin Brother, 888 Tenth Avenue. No visitors were permitted to view the body.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26. -- A fighting Penn State eleven held Pittsburgh scoreless for nearly three periods, but succumbed to the superior power of the Panthers, 9 to 0, in a renewal of an ancient rivalry at Pitt Stadium today before 18,000 fans.

In THE TIMES'S recent article, "Italy Outlawed," under the subtitle "Why They Are Friends," I read the statement: "Hungary's friendship for the Rome government is based solidly on the circumstance that since the World War Hungary's one desire has been to expand; in that desire Italy has sympathized with her, has championed her repeatedly at Geneva."

Any one who likes his romantic fiction served up with the piquant sauce of a mysterious background, will find the old Teale mansion an ideally sinister setting. Darkly foreboding, it stood in dilapidated dignity at the end of a long driveway between tall trees and wild underbrush.

As their first entertainment of the new season, members of the Society of Stoopnocracy will give a barn dance on Nov. 8 in the "hayloft" of the Biltmore. Overalls and ginghams are stipulated as costumes and a special entertainment, to follow a buffet dinner, will include features of a county fair.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Archie H. Cohen, referee in bankruptcy, has recommended that Avery Brundage, chairman of the H.O. Stone Company bondholders committee, and four other members be removed "because they have shown themselves unworthy of their trust."

A fire that they thought had been extinguished killed two of five children at play yesterday at 673 Tenth Street, Brooklyn, and caused serious injuries to a third who jumped from an upper window to escape the flames.

The Ethiopian will quickly realize that his best auxiliary against Italy is time and his best weapon is his soil. His best auxiliary is time, because for five months tropical rains inundate the country. And his country is so difficult to traverse that there are only a few routes by which it can be successfully invaded.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 26. -- The largest freshman class in the history of Bowdoin College is being held to the observance of the usual freshman rules this year by a senior-sophomore organization, new to the campus, which began operations this week in place of the traditional all-sophomore society, Phi Chi, abolished last year after an existence dating from 1864.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- Several thousand surgeons from all parts of the United States and Canada, including many of the world's most eminent surgeons, are gathering for the opening here Monday of the twenty-fifth annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

TANGIER, Morocco. -- Admiral Sir Guy Gaunt, retired, who was head of the British Secret Service in New York from August, 1914, until the United States entered the World War, has been living in Morocco for several years and is one of the most popular foreign residents in Tangier.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 26. -- The first air-conditioned automobile and plans for air-conditioning buses to compete with cooled railroad coaches were announced yesterday at a meeting of the National Association of Motor Bus Operators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Michael J. Meehan, one of the most widely known speculators in Wall Street, and head of the brokerage firm of M.J. Meehan Co., was ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission today to show cause why he should not be suspended from trading on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges and in the wheat pit at Chicago.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Miss Nancy Cook, who will make her formal debut in December, was introduced to friends of her family by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herman John Cook, at a large tea in their home here today. Miss Jane Mitchell Cook, a debutante of two seasons ago, assisted her mother and her sister in the receiving.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Rice Institute staged a brilliant comeback today by toppling a fighting University of Texas team, 28 to 19, in a Southwest Conference game that kept 30,000 frenzied fans on their feet.

THE Oldsmobile models for 1936, offered in a series of Sixes in the low-price field and of Eights in the medium-price range, went on display throughout the country last week. While some changes have been made in design, the body style introduced last year is retained in general.

IN the last three years a great number of airplanes have been equipped with de-icers, which are based on the mechanical principle of breaking the ice formed on the wings and tail surfaces by inflating and deflating a number of rubber tubes held tight to the required surfaces by an elastic sheet of rubber.
BUFFALO, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Senator Wagner praised his party's record of social and labor legislation at a Democratic rally here tonight, declaring that the Republican party was without a single issue.

BESS STREETER ALDRICH prefaces this excellent and honest novel by remarking that "in the telling of a story the narrator takes a bit from life as definitely and completely as one would cut out a paper doll, trimming away all of the flimsy sheet excepting the figure.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The Winnipeg wheat market went into a nose dive today, and the decline was not checked until the December had dropped 3 cents a bushel, the limit permitted for one day under regulations of the Canadian exchange.
