BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 26 (AP). -- For five astonishing, almost unbelievable minutes Ohio State's famed "Scarlet Scourge" of football was shackled and licked by Indiana today, but it broke away with its old relentless force and crushed the valiant Hoosiers, 28 to 6, under an avalanche of second-half touchdowns.

WHEN Raul Haakon, in nautical togs, climbs down nightly from the Winter Garden flies on Vincente Minelli's decorative ratlines and breaks into a dance that no Basque sailor ever dreamt of being able to do, all ground is swept from under the feet of those balletomanes who believe that good dancing is inseparable from patronymics in -ovitch and -ovna.

TRAVELERS in Poland will find this place on the Russian border, the ancestral seat of the Radziwells, the most fascinating in the country. In Nieswiez, a huge medieval castle surrounded by a wide moat, an atmosphere of a glamorous past clings about every architectural or decorative feature the visitor observes from the moment he enters the foyer with its black eagle coat-of-arms, "Bog Nam Radzi."

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Before a record crowd of 22,000 Holy Cross today continued in the undefeated class when it turned back the pre-game favored Colgate eleven by 3 to 0. The Red Raiders outrushed the Crusaders and threatened all through the game, but bogged down when a score was in the making.

This is a season of the year when drought -- that insidious foe of the amateur gardener -- can sneak up without warning and inflict a great deal of damage. Often the results do not appear until later, sometimes not until the following Spring, when their cause will be unsuspected.

Following suggestions made by both. President Roosevelt and Secretary of Commerce Roper that the American Merchant Marine Conference in New York next month could render inestimable service to the nation by crystallizing sentiment on the question of shipping legislation, the conference has sent out questionnaires asking for written opinions on this subject.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Rutgers defeated Lehigh in a Middle Three championship game before a home-coming day crowd of 8,500 persons today, 27 to 6. The home team displayed a powerful and varied attack, but the Engineers completed eight forward passes for a total gain of ninety-seven yards and twice threatened the Scarlet goal via the air route.

The title page of this book informs us that it deals with "the mystery of a death that was neither murder, suicide, nor natural death." All of which is quite true, only there are two mysterious deaths, and the description does not apply to both, so the reader is not cheated of the murder that he has a right to expect in a novel issued by the Crime Club.

CROCKETT, Texas, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Joe Bailey Humphreys, one-time leader in the Young Democrats of Texas Club, declared against the renomination of President Roosevelt today in behalf of his rebel colleagues, the "States' Rights Democrats."

THE year 1935 has been celebrated as the sesquicentennial of the birth of John James Audubon, the great American artist-naturalist, and an appropriate monument in his honor, the Audubon Memorial Park at Henderson, Ky., is now nearing completion.

WHEN the National Safety Congress met at Louisville recently, up rose Dr. David J. Price of the United States Department of Agriculture to tell the assembled multitude -- some were firemen -- something about dust explosions.

HOLLYWOOD. IT has been said than any normal person over the age of twelve will, at the drop of anybody's hat, proclaim just what is wrong with the cinema. But as Shirley Temple undoubtedly has a number of reforms she would like to institute, even the restriction of age has been removed, so that, from the cradle to the grave, picking flaws in Hollywood is America's leading avocation.

WASHINGTON, Oct 25. -- The situation that confronts the consumer has been pushed to the fore by recent price developments and particularly by the exchange of correspondence this week between Donlad E. Montgomery, consumers' counsel for the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, and Henry Stude, president of the American Bakers Association, over increased bread prices.

The schools of the country, which were fashioned after European institutions 150 years ago, were seen emerging into "a truly American education system" yesterday by Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the Advanced School of Education, Teachers College, Columbia.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- More than 8,000 union silk workers will be called out on strike at midnight Wednesday in an effort to stabilize wages and to obtain a contract similar to that in effect in 1933. The walk-out was voted here late today by a strike committee of the Paterson branch of the American Federation of Silk Workers.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- Further consultations took place today between Premier Pierre Laval and the British Ambassador, Sir George Clerk, on the subject of the Italian proposals for settlement of their claims against Ethiopia and the possibility of reassembling the League of Nations Committee of Five for their discussion.

THE hundredth anniversary of the birth of Andrew Carnegie and the opening of Carnegie Hall on May 5, 1891, will be observed on Nov. 25 in the hall with a concert at which the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and the Oratorio Society will take part.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 26. -- Blocking two punts in the third quarter and converting both into touchdowns, the Swarthmore College eleven downed Johns Hopkins, 19 to 6, today for the first victory of the season.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 26. -- Although Anglo-Italian relations have been improved, there has been no change in the British military, naval and air precautionary measures in Egypt. In the last forty-eight hours another brigade of British troops arrived at Alexandria from England.

TOWARD the close of the week retail trade recovered somewhat from its dragging tendency. However, the results for the period continued disappointing. In this area sales were reported as 1 or 2 per cent under a year ago and other centres still told of receding gains.

Hidden deep in the heart of the Great Smoky Mountains is Ata-Ga-Hi, the enchanted mountain, where, according to the Indians, the animals live in harmony, unmolested by man since time began. There Black Bear is chief, dispensing justice to the mischief-makers with a kindly paw, and there it was that many of the animals acquired certain of their individual traits.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- President Roosevelt's ability to change the psychological coloring of situations from deep indigo to happy pink was demonstrated this week by the manner in which he handled the work-relief problem upon his return to Washington.

THE cult of the Chaplin genius has gone around the world any number of times, where, as a matter of fact, Chaplin's contribution to the craft of film making has been negligible. (He always works on a loose, intuitive, when-the-spirit-moves-him plan, changing his mind from one day to the next.)

The faith of the average American in so-called "big executives" was characterized last night by Dr. John L. Elliott, senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, as an intellectual hangover from a child's belief in Santa Claus.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26. -- An increase of spots on the sun, with resultant odd effects on the earth, was noted by scientists this week. If the scientists are right, it was a good week for sun bathers but not quite up to par for radio reception.

OMAHA, Oct. 24. -- Take it from the farmer, if retail food prices are exorbitant, it is not because farm prices are too high for the cost of producing them, and that opinion goes, too, pretty generally for nearly every one else who has any direct connection with the grower or knowledge of the industry on which the bulk of the living of these States is based.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 26. -- Rafael Martinez Nadal, president of the Puerto Rican Senate and leader of the Coalition party, said today he would ask a legislative inquiry into "subversive political thought at the University of Puerto Rico." He was moved by the death of four Nationalists and a spectator Thursday in a clash between Nationalists and policemen in the university town of Rio Piedras.

The Federal and State public employment services are prepared to work on a twenty-four-hour basis to supply the quota of classified relief workers needed by the up-State WPA to start on Nov. 1 the projects for which Controller McCarl has released Federal funds, it was announced yesterday by William H. Lange, State reemployment director.
SEATTLE, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The Stanford Cardinals, lead by James (Monk) Moscrip and all-America Bobby Grayson, upset the University of Washington eleven today, 6 to 0, before 37,000 spectators.

NEWLY-WEDS, faced with the problem of paring a budget, are inclined to postpone buying beautiful table silver until their prosperity increases. This self-denial seems unnecessary to one silversmith in Manhattan.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The motion picture, the radio and the depression's economic upheaval are the three principal reasons why "the nervous child" question has become so vital for teachers, Dr. William J. Dougherty, director of the Yonkers Neurological Institute, stated today at a conference of teachers of the New York Catholic Archdiocese of the auditorium of St. Patrick's School here.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Dartmouth remains among the nation's gridiron elect, following its first real test of the season.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- New England has reacted to the confessed bankruptcy of its principal railroad with a sigh of relief. Probably when the New Haven's reorganization gets under way and stockholders and bondholders find out how much they are going to lose, there will be tears and recriminations.
BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- Trading on the Boerse today was still stagnant, but no further losses occurred, while some scattered minor signs of strength appeared.

Writing under the title "Italy Unjustly Dealt With," in the Herald Tribune, Frank W. Simonds seems to disregard and completely ignore certain salient facts at issue. He deplores the League of Nations' efforts to maintain the peace of Europe through the threat of any sanctions which will interfere with the imperialistic designs of Italy.

ATHENS, Oct. 25. -- Whether the restoration of King George has been brought nearer or thrust further away by the revolutionary regency created by Marshal George Kondylis is the question that is disquieting Greeks today.

IT is a hundred years since Mark Twain was born, fifty years since his masterpiece was published, twenty-five years since he died. For at least half of the century now closing literary criticism has wrangled about his work. At first, when academic critics governed opinion, Mark's books were usually condemned in the light of the genteel tradition as buffoonery -- powerful perhaps and frequently enjoyable, but funny.

If ever Jockey Sammy Renick won a race by dint of keen intelligence and powerful driving, it was in the Yorktown Handicap at Empire City yesterday when he got home first with Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Good Harvest. Another big crowd of 12,000 saw a thrilling finish, with Good Harvest outlasting Spanish Way by a head.

ROME, Oct. 26. -- For several weeks Premier Benito Mussolini has remained completely silent following a period of unwonted loquacity at the beginning of the present serious Anglo-Italian crisis when he delivered speeches and granted interviews right and left.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- The presence of the Ambassador always gives a fillip to the social activity of the American colony. Jesse I. Straus and his wife, who arrived on the Manhattan, again are occupying their official residence in the Avenue d'Iena, which is well fitted for large-scale entertaining.

The gunman believed by the New York police to have killed Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Louis (Pretty) Amberg and ten of their gang members recently was found dead in a cheap Newark (N. J.) lodging house yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A flood of applications to the Federal Power Commission today brought the number of officials of operating utility companies seeking to continue as directors of more than one such company to more than 700. This was cited by the commission as indicative of a cooperative spirit within the industry.

National Girl Scout Week, opening this morning according to the tradition established for it in Scout circles, will have as one of its major features special religious services in churches of every denomination. In New York the largest single group of Scouts will attend 9 o'clock mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, and breakfast later at the Cathedral High School, Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

Billy Hogan, 140 1/4, Orangeburg, N.Y., repeated his triumph of a fortnight ago over Jimmy Murray, 140, Williamsburg, in the feature eight-round bout at the Ridgewood Grove S.C. last night before 3,500. Hogan led all the way to gain the decision.
NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Using three elevens Boston College followed up last week's victory over Michigan State by beating the University of New Hampshire, 19 to 6, today.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Abraham L. Shushan, acquitted last Wednesday night of charges of attempting to evade Federal income taxes, left his high command in the political machine of Senator Long today with an announcement that he was retiring from politics.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area was aided by cooler weather toward the close of the week, but volume for the entire period was adversely affected by the unseasonably high temperatures at the start. Estimates yesterday indicated the average sales volume of department stores here showed a decrease of from 1 to 2 per cent under the corresponding week a year ago.

ALTHOUGH traditional Hebrew music of the synagogue has been drawn upon to a certain extent for the score of "The Road of Promise," the elaborate Jewish morality play scheduled to be presented here by Max Reinhardt in December, modernism will be rampant in the tonal investiture given the spectacle by Kurt Weill, the modernist German opera composer.

Carrying red banners and vivid placards, more than 15,000 members of organizations ranging from churches to Communist groups paraded in a demonstration against war yesterday afternoon from lower Harlem to Central Park West and Sixty-third Street, where they held a mass meeting under the windows of residents who had protested against the parade.

Few people would, at first glance, take issue with Governor Hoffman over his proposal to amend the Constitution so as to subject Federal legislation to an immediate review by the Supreme Court on questions of constitutionality. On the surface there appears to be nothing more than a quickening of the judicial procedure.

IN "The Stranger Within," Matthew Trill has undertaken more than he can wield. He has worked to create atmosphere, but his setting is lifeless. He has tried to portray the inner workings of his characters, to draw one person whose spirituality lights up he lives of others, and he has succeeded in black and white characterizations, a complete villain and a greater-love-hath-no-man hero.

A slow but steady improvement in advertising volume in 1936, amounting to about 5 to 10 per cent over that of the current year, was forecast yesterday by advertising executives, following analyses of budgets now being drawn up.

Between 50 and 80 per cent of the ward and clinic patients of private hospitals are on government relief, it is estimated in an article entitled "Medicine Plus," in the forthcoming issue of Federation Illustrated, published by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 26. -The fourth annual College Day presented by the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs brought high school girls from all sections of the State to the campus of New Jersey College for Women i today as guests of clubwomen from their own towns.

THE familiar matter of an East Side Jewish adolescence is loosely and lengthily developed in "Unquiet." Its value is in what appears to be autobiographical sincerity and it relies above all on a sympathetic understanding of the author's alter ego, the fictional David Levitt.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith heads a list of distinguished speakers scheduled to participate in an all-day conference on modern trends in welfare and social work at the Hotel Commodore tomorrow. His topic is "What It Means to Be Poor."

The first twenty-six railroads to report for September had a net operating income of $29,361,000, compared with $19,244,000 in the same month last year, an increase of 52.5 per cent. In September, 1933, these carriers had a net operating income of $28,965,000, while in August this year they had a net operating income of $20,119,000.

DOZENS of front yards raked clean, truckloads of leaves and debris carted away and burned, hundreds of eager school boys and girls given an evening of fun -- this is the accounting Oberlin, Kan., a town of 1,700, has given of its Halloween activities each year for eight years.

THE Federal Communications Commission will take no steps nor issue any regulations to require broadcasting stations to observe neutrality during the Italo-Ethiopian War, according to Chairman Anning S. Prall.

Destiny does some long-distance hauling to get the four principal characters of this novel together for a thrilling episode at the Chateau Brillant in Switzerland. Priscilla, a pretty, unsophisticated spinster of 45, met romance at last on the way from England to a holiday in the Alps.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Riding, which showed a marked increase in popularity at Smith College last year, is growing even more popular. Last Fall there were 755 riding hours in October, and this year there were 546 riding hours in the first fifteen days of the college year, and 815 hours up to today.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 15 (Delayed) (AP). -- Lessons learned sixty-seven years ago by an extraordinary British expedition into Ethiopia, which resulted in the death of Emperor Theodore, are being carefully followed by the Italians in the 1935 campaign.

Leo Y. Chertok, industrial broker, announced yesterday that he would sail for London within ten days to post $1,250,000 which, he claims, will entitle him to begin exploiting 15,000 square miles of the "richest gold, silver and platinum lands in the world" in Wallega Province, Ethiopia.

MADRID, Oct. 26. -- The special Parliamentary commission appointed to investigate charges that high public officials were bribed by a foreigner seeking gambling concessions in Spain today reported that sufficient evidence had been found to justify court action against eight prominent members of the Radical Centre party, headed by Alejandro Lerroux, who is the Foreign Minister of the Cabinet now in office.

THE first issue of Race, a quarterly devoted to political, economic and social equality, is scheduled to make its appearance on Nov. 1. The editors of the magazine are Martha Gruening, Francis A. Henson, Loren Miller, Henry Lee Moon, Sterling D. Spero, George Streator and Bertram D. Wolfe.

HERE is a kind of Rex Beach story under the post-Hemingway influence. It is the deepening story of a man named Blue who was once an All-America fullback, collegiate heavyweight wrestling champion, Olympic javelin thrower and discus hurler, but who, after leaving college, finds himself with a game leg, cabined. cribbed and confined in his dad's shoe business while a coldly beautiful, socially prominent, ambitious and refined wife tries to tame him at home.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange held again within a narrow range yesterday, to end at a gain of 1 to a loss of 5 points.

The general elections to be held in this State a week from next Tuesday will have special interest for the banking community. The voters will decide whether a provision of the State Constitution imposing "double liability" upon holders of bank stock shall be repealed after having been in effect about ninety years.
Miss Stella Walsh, on her return last week from a Summer of track competition and study in Poland and Central Europe, had many interesting things to say.

St. Francis College scored its initial victory of the season by defeating its borough rival, Brooklyn College, at Lincoln Field yesterday. The score was 19 -- 0. With a set of fast-driving backs and a heavy, hard-driving line the Terriers outplayed the Kingsmen.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Out of a medley of fumbles and intercepted forward passes, the Chicago Maroons fashioned their first victory of the Western Conference season today over Wisconsin's battling Badgers, 13 to 7, in a wildly exciting struggle at Stagg Field before a crowd of 20,000.

IF Marco Polo should carry back to his countrymen tales of the American musical show they would call him a liar. When he returned from Cathay with yarns about the luxury of the court of Kubla Khan they called him a liar in self-defense, his news was so improbable.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Gifts and bequests totaling $569,104 were received by Princeton University during the academic year which ended last June, according to the report issued today by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- The waterfront labor unrest here is apparently receding. A number of lines withdrew their deep-water carriers from the port pending more settled conditions. The trend to restoration of operations is now expanding.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 26 (AP). -- A fighting University of Detroit eleven blasted Villanova from the ranks of the nation's undefeated teams in a bitterly fought intersectional battle, 19 to 15, today before 15,000 spectators.

MONET'S name is not a very galvanizing one nowadays. And yet the Monet show at Durand-Ruel's turns out to be one of the most remunerative of the current attractions. It throws light upon the whole impressionist development and is particularly helpful in dramatizing for us the career of an artist who, with unrivaled concentration, strove, up to the very last, to explore the ultimate mystery of this "science."
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 26 (AP). -- J. Shakespeare's Mucho Gusto defeated the Rosedale Stable's Silk Mask by a nose in the feature at Churchill Downs today. M. J. Conley's My Blaze was third.

HAVING tasted of culture and found it gratifying, the cinema is contemplating further and richer feasts. There are indications that grand opera, dabbled in only gingerly to date, will provide the next banquet. Most pronounced is the threat of Metro to abandon all half portions and produce complete operatic films.

SHOULD Dr. Priestley ever lose his interest in difficult crime problems it will be just too bad for Inspector Hanslet of Scotland Yard, for the Inspector has never, so far as John Rhode's records show, solved a mystery without Priestley's help.

A NEW chief of staff of the United States Army is always the object of scrutiny by the entire military establishment, for no other man in the service has such opportunity to leave upon it the imprint of his own personality and technical ability.

Signor MUSSOLINI, preparing for tomorrow's anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome, has declared another war -- this one against the economic sanctions about to be imposed against Italy by the League. He has issued a warning that his people will distinguish as friend from foe those nations which, by action or inaction, move to nullify the sanctions of the Powers which were co-signers of the Covenant Italy has broken in attacking Ethiopia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The text of the SEC order for hearing in the case of M.J. Meehan follows:

ARTISTS and musicians really are more temperamental than the average person, but they have also marked practical abilities for which they seldom receive credit. Such, at least, are the conclusions to be drawn from psychological tests of some 300 art, music and college students made by Dr. Alice I. Bryan of Pratt Institute and Dr. Ruth Perl of Columbia University.

Signor MUSSOLINI, preparing for tomorrow's anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome, has declared another war -- this one against the economic sanctions about to be imposed against Italy by the League. He has issued a warning that his people will distinguish as friend from foe those nations which, by action or inaction, move to nullify the sanctions of the Powers which were co-signers of the Covenant Italy has broken in attacking Ethiopia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The text of the SEC order for hearing in the case of M.J. Meehan follows:

ARTISTS and musicians really are more temperamental than the average person, but they have also marked practical abilities for which they seldom receive credit. Such, at least, are the conclusions to be drawn from psychological tests of some 300 art, music and college students made by Dr. Alice I. Bryan of Pratt Institute and Dr. Ruth Perl of Columbia University.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26. -- One hundred and thirty-eight pounds weighed heavily on Discovery today, and the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt star went down to defeat in the $10,000 Added Washington Handicap -- in fourth place, more than five lengths back of the winner.

For years Governor SMITH and other public men have advocated the reform of county government. Governor LEHMAN has now summed up the arguments for the change. Existing forms are antiquated, dating from Colonial times. There are too many elective officials, with no responsible head.

DETROIT, Oct. 26. -- Henry Ford was characteristically informal when I talked with him this week. It was not easy to think of him as the man who has built the biggest single enterprise in industrial history, one of the two or three richest men on earth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- With the release today by Controller General McCarl of $28,824,883 more for work-relief projects in twenty-two States, the amount of money actually put to work through the WPA rose close to the billion-dollar mark. A total of $983,922,446 in Treasury warrants has actually been countersigned by Mr. McCarl's office.

Launching a series of campaign luncheon rallies that will be held on the first Friday of each month throughout the season, the National Affairs Committee of the Women's National Republican Club will hear Dr. James L. MeConaughy this week.
DALLAS. -- Although reports from cotton-raising counties vary, those dealing with other branches of agriculture are almost unanimously optimistic all over the Southwest.

Toward the end of the week retail trade responded to the lower temperatures and sales volume snapped back to the levels established earlier in the month, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

Six years ago this Sunday the nation was having its day of rest from the big stock market crash. On the afternoon of Wednesday, Oct. 23, 1929, stocks had tumbled 5 to 96 points, THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial average going down 31 points; next day it had gone down another 12.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 26. -- An experiment in making film copies of books, manuscripts and rare items for the John Hay Library at Brown University last year brought such satisfactory results that the plan will be continued and expanded, Dr. Henry B. Van Hoesen, university librarian, said in his annual report today to the university corporation.

Alice put down the paper and said she could not help feeling rather disappointed in Mr. STANLEY BALDWIN, the Prime Minister. What did he mean by saying he expected a lull of a few weeks in foreign affairs?

This is a romantic story in Western style with a setting in the sheep country in New Zealand. For adventure there cattle rustling, buried treasure, hidden fortune and seduction. For information Miss Rees gives pleasantly enthusiastic descriptions of New Zealand climate, scenery and sheep farming.

Gang warfare, sometimes dormant but never dead, flames anew with a bitterness unequaled since repeal. Internecine strife has claimed the lives of nearly a dozen gangsters and resulted in the wounding of a dozen others in the last two months.

THE thirty-sixth annual Automobile Show, again a national exposition of the industry, will open at 2 o'clock next Saturday afternoon in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

Alice put down the paper and said she could not help feeling rather disappointed in Mr. STANLEY BALDWIN, the Prime Minister. What did he mean by saying he expected a lull of a few weeks in foreign affairs?

This is a romantic story in Western style with a setting in the sheep country in New Zealand. For adventure there cattle rustling, buried treasure, hidden fortune and seduction. For information Miss Rees gives pleasantly enthusiastic descriptions of New Zealand climate, scenery and sheep farming.

Gang warfare, sometimes dormant but never dead, flames anew with a bitterness unequaled since repeal. Internecine strife has claimed the lives of nearly a dozen gangsters and resulted in the wounding of a dozen others in the last two months.

THE thirty-sixth annual Automobile Show, again a national exposition of the industry, will open at 2 o'clock next Saturday afternoon in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Charging a conspiracy to fix prices of lobsters obtained from Canadian and American waters and shipped to dealers throughout the United States, the Federal Trade Commission today summoned the Associated Lobster Dealers of Massachusetts and several individual dealers to show cause on Friday, Nov. 29, why a cease and desist order should not be issued.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- A scenario entitled "Red Rhumba," which deals with a Communist movement in Cuba, has been chosen for the annual production of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania.
DUBLIN, Oct. 26. -- Trade conditions of the Irish Free State show a marked improvement, according to statistics just issued by the Department of Industry and Commerce here.

New Utrecht High School's powerful machine kept its unbeaten and untied record intact when it swept to a 20-0 victory over Erasmus Hail High School yesterday at Erasmus Field. A crowd of 2,500 saw the victors, after being held scoreless for the first two quarters, come back with a punishing drive in the last half to roll up all its points.

ITALIAN ARMY FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Northern Ethiopia, Oct. 25 (delayed in transmission) (AP). -- The Italian southern army under General Rodolfo Graziani may soon threaten Harar, important centre of Eastern Ethiopia, it was learned today.

SEVEN new films are reasonably certain to reach the local cinema sector during the new week. The first arrival will be "Le Dernier Milliardaire," a French contribution directed by Rene Clair, which is to have its premiere on Tuesday at the Cinema de Paris.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 26. -- Stanley W. Church, Democratic candidate for Mayor of New Rochelle, was given a police guard today after he expressed fear that he might be subjected to violence by "outside Communists." Since the death of Mayor Crandell, who was his Republican opponent, the only other candidate in the field is Antonio Lombardo, Communist.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Hurricane winds, rain storms and floods, with accompanying damage to banana crops, were reported today from the central zone. Details were lacking because of interrupted lines of communications.

MR. ELIOT'S play was written expressly to fit into the annual week of music and drama at Canterbury; it opened there in the Chapter House last June under the supervision of Martin Browne, the scenarist of "The Rock."

AUTUMN'S chilling breezes have caused automobile license tags from all over the United States to become conspicuously numerous on the highways of Florida during the last two weeks. There is ample evidence that the annual influx of tourists is well under way, and the number of daily arrivals probably will increase steadily until about the middle of February.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- A superior forward line and a back field that had the speed to move up for the attack and quickly return for a well-integrated defense, gave the newly organized 1935 Vassar College varsity field hockey team its first victory of the season today by a 7-1 margin over the Long Island Association team.

IT is commonly assumed by the trend-finders that the citizens of our Republic climbed down off the Great American Bandwagon in 1929, donned sackcloth and ashes, took to reading proletarian novels and economic statistics, and foreswore daffiness and goofiness forever. But the assumption is an illusion, probably created by the retirement of H. L. Mencken to Baltimore and Old Testament exegesis.

Trapped without warning as they were digging a cave in the steep cliff in Riverside Park below 121st Street late yesterday afternoon, two small boys were overwhelmed by a sandslide which completely buried one and pinioned the other almost neck deep.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27. -- The cotton market here was only moderately active last week so far as futures were concerned, but it was extremely brisk in spot operations. Heavy demand for the spot staple caused an increase in the volume of hedge selling, but these sales were offset in large measure by a fair volume of trade buying.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Mrs. Rose London, attractive young red-haired housewife of San Diego, Cal., was near death tonight in County Hospital here as police sought a man who beat her with a gas pipe as she slept, robbed her of $38, and left her unconscious in a room of the Lorraine Hotel early today.

Skipper John A. Paradine shuttled the little steamer Hook Mountain from Battery Landing to Bedloe's Island all day yesterday without giving much thought to the fact that the Statue of Liberty was on the eve of a birthday.

Although a fair volume of reorders were received in some departments, the slower movement of merchandise at retail was reflected in the wholesale markets here last week. The demand for popularprice dresses, including afternoon, dinner and evening gowns, was more pronounced, but only a moderate demand was noted for the higher-priced lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Navy Day, annually observed for the past fourteen years on the birthday of President Theodore Roosevelt, was celebrated today as part of a twoday observance because of the Sunday holiday.

The new United States liner which officials of the International Mercantile -- Marine Company are planning to run with the cabin liners Manhattan and Washington may be registered at 45,000 gross tons about 15,000 tons larger than originally planned.

The corn and hog raisers have voted overwhelmingly, in a ratio of six to one, for a continuance of the corn-hog "adjustment" program. AAA officials, who had affected to believe before the vote that it might be very close, are elated. The rest of us will wonder what other result could possibly have been expected.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- The gold that left the Bank of France last week all went to New York. The British Equalization Fund, which had sent much gold here in previous weeks, found it no longer necessary to intervene in the market in defense of the pound sterling and the outflow of gold to the United States was offset only slightly by some arrivals from other European countries.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Official sources estimated tonight that at least 2,000 persons are dead or missing as a result of the hurricane that swept over the southern peninsula last week-end.
Louis Wolchonok, painter and etcher, will lecture on fresco painting this evening at 7 o'clock at the Central Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue, and on sculpture at the same hour the following Monday.

The rejuvenated Brooklyn Museum, settling down from radical physical improvements and rearrangements, is very much in the art spotlight of the week, with exhibitions opening, current or about to close. The large exhibition of Spanish painting is still on (through Thursday), and a show of paintings and drawings of natural history subjects in the Gallery of Living Art will continue through Nov. 17.

The Musicians Emergency Fund during the last four years has saved thousands of musicians from becoming dependent upon public charity, and in doing so has not only saved the taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars but incidentally has enriched the community by the skills that have thus been saved.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Resettlement Administration, headed by Rexford G. Tugwell, will assume responsibility by next Friday for 175,000 more farm families throughout the United States under its rehabilitation program, with preference to be given to families in agricultural areas in extreme need of food, clothing and medical care.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27. -- Public apathy toward physical welfare was blamed today by Dr. C. Jeff Miller, Tulane University gynecologist, for unnecessary suffering and premature death among Americans.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,231,215,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

According to surveys by leaders of both major parties, the contest for control of the New York State Assembly, now Democratic by a narrow margin, promises to be close. In the present Assembly, the Democrats hold seventy-six seats, one more than a majority necessary for the passage of bills, and the Republicans seventy-three, while there is one vacancy in the normally Democratic Twentieth Manhattan district caused by the death of Louis A. CuvilIier.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 27 (AP). -- Judge Grubb, who had attracted national attention during the past year in two decisions against aspects of the New Deal, had not been in good health for many months. He remained active on the bench, and only yesterday had presided in a case involving the Guffey act, creating a little NRA for the coal industry.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 27 (AP). -- First reports of the hurricane toll in Honduras reached this city today, bringing news of the death of three native women in the mining settlement of San Juancito.

A poll by the New York State Economic Council throughout the State shows a ten-to-one opposition against the proposed $55,000,000 relief bond issue, Merwin K. Hart, its president, announced yesterday. The proposal will be submitted to the voters on Election Day as Proposition No. 1.
Obscene literature, valued at $25,000, was reported seized by detectives yesterday in a raid on an apartment in 1,454 University Avenue, the Bronx, in which three men were arrested.

ATHENS, Oct. 27. -- Thousands of Attican farmers waving olive branches streamed into this capital today to hear an address by Regent Kondylis. He spoke before 60,000 people crammed into Constitution Square.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend closed the first national convention of his disciples today with a plea for the enactment of his plan to provide $200 a month pensions to citizens of 60 and over.

May I express my commendation to the Brookings Institution for its decision to send its president, Harold C. Moulton, on a speaking tour of the country in which he will spread the gospel of a low price-scale for attaining a higher standard of living, which will in turn restore normal profits to industry?

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Mrs. Mary Palmer Livingston, 43 years old, widow of Supervisor William H. Livingston, who died last Wednesday, was nominated today by the Republican Committee of the First Ward of this city to fill the vacancy caused by the death of her husband, who was a candidate for re-election.

An army of small boys surprisingly backed up by a company of stalwart policemen invaded lower Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon and took Washington Square by storm, while the gentle, gray-beard ghost of Mark Twain, in whose honor the parade was staged, might or might not have looked on from his old home at 21 Fifth Avenue, puffing a complacent, albeit ghostly, cigar.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Two young giants who learned to play football at Duquesne University gave the Boston Redskins and a crowd of 12,000 fans a lesson in kicking the pigskin today while the Pittsburgh Pirates were beating the invaders, 6 to 0.

Any celebration of the return of former Mayor Walker "is to repudiate newly born civic idealism and burn incense once more before the Gods of 'smart alecism' if not, as many suspicion, outright corruption," the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, the pastor, said last night in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.
Eighteen vampire bats from a subterranean lair in Costa Rica share the nature news today with a family of scorpions and two Florida alligators who promply fell asleep at their debut in the Aquarium.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stosks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

New York State and its localities must continue to provide direct relief monthly for more than 200,000 needy unemployed families and non-family persons not absorbed by WPA projects, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration asserted yesterday in its annual report to the Governor and legislative leaders and its accounting to the public.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 26 (Delayed). -- Italy's Eritrean Army, driving southward toward the Ethiopian stronghold of Makale, was reported in official dispatches today to have won its way to water and an important new foothold in its advance into Ethiopia.

Women who are interested in the relief work of the tuberculosis division of Bellevue Hospital are active in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Pride and Prejudice" the night of Nov. 13 at the Music Box Theatre, which has been taken over for that night to raise funds for the organization.

Most people are commonplace or worse. Observe the people in the subways or street cars. They look sad, disconsolate and uninteresting. Many seem to have no taste in dress. Colors mean nothing in their scheme of life.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85.3, which compares with 85.5 the week before, 85.8 two weeks before, 85.6 three weeks before and 85.5 four weeks before.

Could the Perole String Quartet but have summoned up a more voluminous and trenchant tone and more telling differentiation of mood in their playing at Town Hall yesterday evening, all would have been well during their professional debut.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 27 (AP). -- America's spreading wings for foreign commerce will this week move South American trade marts two days nearer the United States.

ATLANTA, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing sharply criticized today the activities of psychiatrists, whose part in the present-day prison system he described as presenting "a most troublesome question," in an address at the opening of the congress of the American Prison Association.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Financial circles here believe that as the European situation becomes less tense politically gold shipments to the United States are likely to decrease. The week's exports to Oct. 21 were 6,781,479. most of the metal crossing the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Slowly mounting returns in the national referendum on a 1936 corn-hog program indicated tonight a favorable vote of nearly six to one. In none of the States in the tabulation thus far was the preliminary tally close.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 27. -The first junior hunt trials in the history of the Fairfield and Westchester Drag Hunt took place today on the Sterling estate at Quaker Ridge. The five classes were witnessed by a large society gallery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Further experimentation with AAA marketing agreements and license activities under the Secretary of Agriculture was recommended today by the Brookings Institution in a report which indicated a belief that this portion of the Agricultural Adjustment program was legally valid.

Trading in commodity futures on exchanges here was mixed last week, with rubber, silk, hides and wool tops firmer and comestible staples generally lower. In the cash markets, gains appeared in corn, rye, family beef, tin, cotton, silk, wool tops and rubber, while wheat, oats, coffee, cocoa, lard and antimony eased.

New designs showing an educational trend in the $200,000,000 annual output of playthings for children will be in evidence today. They will be displayed at a pre-view of offerings for the Christmas season, which will open at the Fifth Avenue Building, 500 Fifth Avenue, under the auspices of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 27. -Playing over its home layout today, the Deepdale Club golf team gained a leg on the Walter P. Chrysler Trophy in the first annual Autumn triangular matches with the Piping Rock and Meadow Brook Clubs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn.. Oct. 27. -Purchase by the Resettlement Administration of 14,000 acres in Southern Maine, a region of scenic beauty, to be developed and made accessible for public enjoyment and recreation, was announced today by A. W. Manchester, regional director of Land Utilization.
GENEVA, Oct. 27. -- The League of Nations received today messages from all three of the great democracies regarding the Italo-Ethiopian war, which one of them said "adversely affects every country."

IT was a somewhat staid Saturday on the gridiron. Most of the teams ran true to form. Yale dropped out of the undefeated class, but old Eli was wrestling with a strong Army team and a close battle was expected and delivered. Monk Meyer was just a trifle too much for Yale to tie down. His performances against Harvard and Yale will leave him a marked man for the remainder of the Army schedule.

The vicissitudes of the life of a foreign missionary have been greatly overemphasized and the missionary himself is content in his chosen vocation, the Most Rev. Francis X. Ford, Bishop of Kaying, China, declared in a sermon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventyfirst Street, east of Broadway.

Citing in detail the records of crime and escapes from punishment of four Brooklyn gangsters, former Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion candidate for District Attorney of Kings County, continued last night his attack upon the administration of the District Attorney's office by William F. X. Geoghan, Democratic candidate for re-election.

The Rev. George Arthur Clarke, pastor of the Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn, since 1927, last night received a call to the pastorate of the First Baptist Church, Malden, Mass., in the Boston metropolitan area.
The Literary Guild choice for December will be 'A Kipling Pageant," an omnibus of some of Rudyard Kipling's most notable work. Doubleday, Doran will publish this book on Nov. 29.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- A profit to the government of $2,520,567 as a result of sales of bonds by the PWA was reported today to Administrator Ickes by Philip M. Benton, director of finance of the PWA.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 27. -- The Coalition majority party and Dr. Ernest Gruening, director of the division of territories and insular possessions, United States Interior Department, came to grips this evening. The Coalition flayed Dr. Gruening as administrator of Puerto Rican reconstruction in a fifty-six-page manifesto broadcast from a local station.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Domestic trade is maintaining its activity and Lancashire's cotton mills are at their busiest in some time filling orders formerly supplied through Italian sources, while spinners of American coarse and medium yarns are requesting eight or nine weeks for delivery.

Fluctuations in the foreign exchanges last week covered a narrow range with final prices showing an irregular mixture of advances and declines. These variations were slight, however. Business was small, the little activity noted being confined to the forenoon to coincide with the open markets abroad. Bankers attributed the steady market to the progress which is being made toward an amicable settlement of the African crisis.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The AAA corn-hog program will be continued next year with new voluntary contracts changed in some particulars from the present ones.

George W. Klein, 53 years old, a former town clerk of Guttenberg, N.J., was found last night with a bullet wound in his right temple in front of a building adjoining his home at 71 Park Avenue, Guttenberg.

The winners of Colonel W. T. Johnson's tenth annual World Series Rodeo came riding into the spotlight in Madison Square Garden last night and into $40,000 in prize money. They were steer wrestlers, bronco riders and calf ropers, and they were riding on prize saddles given to them by the ranch boss at the close of the 1935 season.

I read with interest in THE TIMES of Oct. 20 an article, "New City Speedways," by R. L. Duffus. This article was most interesting and informative, but in that section devoted to parkways and highways outside the city limits I was disappointed to note that no mention was made of the Eastern State Parkway, or as it is popularly known, the Taconic Parkway.
CAIRO, Oct. 27. -- Increased uneasiness is being felt in Egyptian political circles at what are considered to be unsatisfactory relations with Britain.

I TOKYO, Oct. 27.--Since John i.I Garner, now en route here with theCongressional party that will attendthe inauguration of the first Philippine President, is the first UnitedStates Vice President to visitJapan, the government would likea fuller opportunity to entertainhim than his short stop-over permits.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 27.-Cooperatives for marketing, creditand production provide the farmer's best solution for democracy inagrioulture, Milburn L. Wilson,Assistant Secretary of Agriculture,told the opening sessions of theNational Catholic Rural Life Conference and National Confraternityjot Christian Doctrine here today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- December corn is causing much uneasiness in the trade. A liberal holding by Eastern interests is reported; also a few Eastern houses are short, while cash handlers are long.

Fewer bonds were called last week for redemption before maturity than in the previous week. The calls were principally public utility and railroad liens for future months, only a small lot of municipal notes being added for October. This month's redemptions now total $370,101,000, compared with $350,611,000 in September and $48,723,000 for October, 1934, in corresponding weeks.

With ten members of the 1932 Olympic team in its line-up, a picked aggregation from the Westchester and Philadelphia Field Hockey Clubs vanquished the Metropolitan Field Hockey League eleven, 5 -- 3, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Man cannot serve both God and mammon, Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area said yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University. Only those who are free from impurity and are considerate of others can hope to see God, he said.

Memoranda culled from the personal effects of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and the three underlings who were killed with him in a Newark tavern last week engaged the attention last night of New York and Newark detectives who are trying to find the murderers.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 27. -- In a Girl Scout Week message, Mrs. Herbert Hoover urged America's younger generation today to be "good neighbors."
YOKOHAMA, Japan, Monday, Oct. 28. -- For the first time a Vice President of the United States entered Japan today and he received a welcome befitting such an occasion.
Deals in the city reported over the week-end included sales and leases in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

Dan O'Mahoney, world's heavyweight wrestling champion, will risk his crown against Ed (Don) George in Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout will be the third meeting between the pair, but their first in this city.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Striking with dramatic suddenness in the closing minutes, the Arnie Herber-to-Don Hutson-forward-passing combination scored two touchdowns today to give the Green Bay Packers a 17-to-14 triumph over the Chicago Bears in a thrilling National Football League battle before 30,000 spectators at Wrigley Field.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct, 27.Pleasant weather lured many to theBerkshire Hills for the week-end,and there was much entertaining.

ADOWA, Oct. 26 (via Courier). -This city, famed for the defeat of the Italians in 1896 and their victory three weeks ago, is now a peaceful, commercial town with a thriving market where the native Adowans this morning gratefully sold fruit, eggs and chickens to the Italian soldiers.

MOUNT CARMEL, Pa., Oct. 27. -- Death dissolved the independent coal-mining partnership of Pete Baxter and his "buddy," John Stankowski, started because they were turned down physically for employment in the mines of anthracite companies.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., Oct. 27 (Canadian Press). -- Flashing lights and detonations failed tonight to frighten weary geese, estimated to number 10,000, sufficiently to make them leave the Niagara River where, for twenty-four hours they have been alternately swimming and rising in the air.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 27. -- Strenuous efforts will be made to bring about amendment of the Municipal Bankruptcy Act in the next session of Congress so that a municipality may file a petition in bankruptcy without the consent of its creditors, David M. Wood of Thomson, Wood Hoffman of New York, municipal attorneys, predicted today in an address before the forum on municipal bonds at the Investment Bankers Association's convention here.

Officials of the Southern New York Fish and Game Asociation, whose activities are centred in the counties of Westchester and Putnam, believe that pheasant hunters will find good sport when the twelve-day season opens today.

Overshadowing all other occurrences in the scholastic football ranks during the past week-end, particularly from the standpoint of thrills, was the Hill School's lastminute rally for a 7-all tie with its traditional rival, Lawrenceville.

The immediate outlook for business from a purely economic standpoint is "fairly favorable," according to the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, the monthly publication of the Guaranty Trust Company.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 27. -Walter F. Eberhardt, 44-year-old fiction and scenario writer and a New York publicity man, committed suicide here today in the garage adjoining his home at 46 Walbrooke Road by inhaling carbon monoxide fumes from the exhaust of his automobile.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- The ranges of prices of grain futures on the Board of Trade last week were as follows:

A suggestion to young scholars that the discovery of a copy of the Freeman's Oath would be "a nobler way of winning one's spurs than writing a doctoral dissertation," is made by Randolph G. Adams in The Colophon, New Series No. 2, a Quarterly for Bookmen, which appears today.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- On this peaceful Sunday an army with banners paraded through London streets in one of the largest demonstrations that have yet been held in England against the Nazi regime in Germany.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 27 (AP). -Valued by its present owner at $250,000 to $500,000, the famous Bible of the Rev. Thomas Hooker, founder of Hartford, may soon be for sale.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- Relaxation of the tension between England and Italy has greatly improved financial sentiment and the relief that is felt after the grave anxiety that recently prevailed has manifested itself in a general recovery on the Bourse.

A Brooklyn eleven that seemed perfectly content to dawdle along to a 3-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles at Ebbets Field yesterday, awakened shortly after the start of the third period to find the Eagles ahead, 6 to 3. So to the complete delight of a crowd of 20,000 the Dodgers came to in time to vanquish their rivals, 17 to 6.

Ministers who only preach sermons about economic and lay subjects and who habitually ignore the Bible were chided yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Joseph A. Vance of Detroit, Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, in his sermon at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, which yesterday concluded its celebration of the 150th anniversary of the founding of the parish.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The thirty-five members of the Mountain Lakes Boy Scout troop will hold their weekly meeting here tomorrow night dressed in heavy overcoats and in the open beside a bonfire -- if the police allow the fire -- because the local Board of Education refuses to allow them $5 credit.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Oct. 27. -Thousands thronged the huge hangar at the Lakehurst Naval Air Station here today when Commander Charles E. Rosendahl and the official and enlisted personnel held "open house" in advance of the Navy Day "at home" today.

The Italian Government, being highly realistic, was not slow to understand that the reply sent to the League for the United States by Secretary of State HULL serves as an "influence to nullify "the importance of world solidarity "against Italy" with respect to the economic sanctions about to be imposed by the League.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27. -- New surgical operations which correct abnormal personalities in women suffering from disorders of the outer layer of the adrenal gland were described here today by Professor Frank Hinman on the eve of the opening of the clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

VIENNA, Oct. 27. -- A curious accident enabled this correspondent yesterday afternoon to witness a parade of a new battalion of Austria's secret anti-Fascist army, the Republican Defense League, which was supposed to have been broken up and disbanded after the Socialist rising in February, 1934; hear a revolutionary address by a nameless commander-in-chief, see the battalion receive colors presented by workers' wives and hear the singing of the "Internationale."

LONDON, Oct., 27. -- Arthur Greenwood, Labor party leader, today accused the British Government of seeking re-election only so it can "pursue its policy of increased armaments." In an address at Wakefield he declared the statements at Geneva of Anthony Eden, Minister for League of Nations Affairs, were in conflict with those of men at home who advocate vastly increased armaments.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 27. -- Messages received from Ras Seyoum, commander of the northern Ethiopian Army, in the last two days suggest that the Italian attack on the northern front will be renewed early this week. Ras Seyoum believes the attack will begin tomorrow, the anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome, because the consolidation of the line from Aksum to Adigrat seems finished and reconnaissance in front of the Italian lines has begun.

The first families to occupy apartments in a New York City Housing Authority development have been selected from 4,000 applicants, Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post, chairman of the municipal housing organization, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 27. -- All talk of the "weakness" of the British Navy is nothing but a political scare intended to frighten voters, Labor party leaders declared today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The administration's experimentations were denounced as "dangerous" and as based on "half-baked theories" by the American Liberty League tonight in a pamphlet which analyzed ten phases of the government's activities and called for an end of these efforts.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The value of Germany's industrial production in the first half of 1935 is officially estimated at 28,000,000,000 marks compared with 24,000,000,000 marks in the first half of 1934. Consumption of electricity was 13 per cent greater than in 1934, but the heavy industries are less active than a year ago, and, in certain branches of consumption, goods industries employes have been discharged.

What the feminists lack is a sense of proportion. While taking to themselves all the credit for the improved status of womankind, they consistently ignore most of the real boons that have accrued to them in recent years, such, for instance, as increased safety in childbirth.

BREMERTON, Wash., Oct. 27 (AP). -- A new type destroyer neared completion today, the seventy-first anniversary of the exploit in which her namesake, Lieutenant William Barker Cushing, joined the navy's immortals by destroying the Confederate ram Albemarle with a torpedo.

President Roosevelt was charged yesterday with failing to keep a promise to make a "public statement" setting forth the attitude of the United States toward alleged religious persecution by the Mexican Government. The charge was made in a letter sent to him by the supreme board of directors of the Knights of Columbus and which was made public here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- The presidents of twenty-two stock exchanges will meet at the Union League Club tomorrow with Chairman James M. Landis of the Securities and Exchange Commission to discuss the segregation of the functions of dealers and brokers in the securities markets.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- The delay in Italy's offensive, which has been interpreted as a sign of vacillation, and the mild tone taken by Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare and Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin in the British Parliament when dealing with the subject of sanctions have convinced financial and commercial circles here that no settlement of the Ethiopian question is in sight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Prices of wheat in all leading markets of the world declined last week, largely because of the subsidence of fear that the Italo-Ethiopian War would involve Europe. Traders in the leading markets in North America and other parts of the world who were excited two weeks ago were more friendly to the selling side, and the liquidation was sufficient to depress prices.

That John Charles Thomas, the long-popular baritone, is a wizard at arranging a program, as well as a necromancer who transmutes all that he touches into pure gold, was demonstrated by the unconventionally but cannily juxtaposed concatenation of lyrics and arias which he promulgated in regal style at his initial recital of the season at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

Patrolman John Donahue and his wife, Helen, were hosts at a housewarming which continued merrily into the early morning hours yesterday in their new six-room bungalow at 158-42 Elkhorn Street, Howard Beach. Among their seven guests were two long-standing friends, Patrolman Alvaro Flynn, and his young wife, Margaret.

The German Jews are the victims of "the supreme tragedy of our day," which is more horrible than anything that happened during the war, John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, said yesterday morning at the Free Synagogue. Carnegie Hall, Mr. Holmes and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise exchanged pulpits for the occasion.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27. -A 3-year-old boy, Allen Edward Devlin, of 26 McKay Avenue, East Orange, was severely bitten here tonight by a police dog which knocked him down in a back yard near his home. The child was bitten nineteen times.

One of the best known missionary Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church, the Most Rev. Amandus Bahlmann, Bishop-Prelate of Santarem do Para, in Northern Brazil, is on a visit to New York. He is at the rectory of St. Francis of Assisi Church, 141 West Thirty-first Street.

Recalling her part in the ox-cart pioneer days, when Indians and "bad men" made travel for a woman dangerous, Mrs. Flora Spiegelberg brought back visions of the untamed West yesterday in an account of her experiences as a bride on the Santa Fe Trail.

NEWPORT, 1. I., Oct. 27.--Mrs.Drexel Dahlgren, who for the lasttwo Summers leased her BellevueAvenue home, Champ Soleil, to Mr.and Mrs. Nathaniel P. Hill, willarrive tomorrow to open it for alate-season stay. Miss Eva Dahl-!gren arrived yesterday to spend theweek-end at the La Forge.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The Reichsbank will enter November with a new expansion of its outstanding credits inasmuch as the September month-end credits have not been fully repaid. The bank's new loss of 1,000,000 marks of gold was mainly from its deposits in foreign central banks.

Mankind today is the victim of so much splendid of gesturing on all sides that it is a pleasure to take note of a really fine gesture. This was the action of Count LUIGI VINCI-GIUGLICCI, the Italian Minister at Addis Ababa, who has at last departed for home, sixteen days after the Ethiopian Government handed him his passports.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 27. -- Setting a blistering pace throughout, F. B. Alexander of the University Club today vanquished a clubmate, H. J. Lancaster in the final round of the seventh annual invitation handicap squash racquets tourney at the Nassau Country Club.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 27. -Frostbite sailing for the Winter was inaugurated today at the Larchmont Yacht Club and Corny Shields and Walter Rowe led the processions of dinghies around a triangular course in the harbor.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 27. -Cabo Gracias a Dios and other smaller towns along the Wanks River have been wiped out by wind and floods.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Two branch offices of the First Wisconsin National Bank were dynamited tonight, with extensive property damage. No one was injured, although scores of pedestrians and motorists were imperiled.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 16 it was reported that the American Nurses Association had decided to take steps to abolish the "chaotic state" in the nursing profession, a situation formerly adjusted by wars and epidemics.

Lawrence Tibbett will be the principal speaker at a luncheon for members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild at the Hotel Pierre on Wednesday afternoon. He will discuss "What the Metropolitan Means to American Artists and What Radio Broadcasts Mean to Music in America."

The city of Detroit, Mich., will sell on Monday, Nov. 4, $11,000,000 of 4 per cent sewage disposal system bonds maturing from 1939 to 1965. The cost of the system will be $20,000,000, of which $9,000,000 will be met by a direct grant from the United States Government.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71.5 on Oct. 23. This compares with 71.2 a fortnight before, 69.9 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The church can no longer be accused, as it was fifty years ago, of neglecting the economic problems of the day, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East Twentyninth Street.

Virtually no sentiment in favor of new legislation to supplant the defunct NRA exists among manufacturers, large or small, it was announced yesterday by Clinton L. Bardo, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, who based his statement on information coming to him.

An admission scale of 25 to 50 cents will prevail for all theatrical productions of which he is in charge, it was said yesterday by Elmer Rice, head of the New York program of the WPA theatre project.
Arthur W. Machen of Ruxton, Md., called the Rev. Dr. Samuel G. Craig of Princeton, N.J., editor of Christianity Today, a coward in an open letter printed in yesterday's issue of that publication.

TORONTO, Oct. 26. -- Ontario's thirty-five producing gold mines have reported for September an aggregate output of 175,445 ounces of gold and 35,235 ounces of silver, valued at $5,644,636 in Canadian funds, against a production valued at $6,627,242 in August, according to the monthly bulletin issued by the Ontario Department of Mines.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes of Montclair gave a dinner in the Colonnades Room at the Greenbrier tonight in honor of their daughter, Miss Nancy Noyes, debutante of this season. Mr. and Mrs. Ogden L. Mills entertained there in honor of Mrs. Louis C. Clark and T. Chesley Richardson.
PARIS, Oct. 27. -- Air Ministry officials reported tonight that the Berre naval air base -- France's "eye on the Mediterranean" -- will be kept at full strength.

Although certain things in the Christian faith -- the Bible, the cross, Christ and God -- are permanent, it is the function of the Protestant churches to find new interpretations in presenting them, the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, pastor of the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, said in a Reformation Day sermon yesterday morning.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Here to attend the twenty-sixth annual convention of the Association of National Advertisers, Joseph M. Kraus, advertising manager of the Paris Garter Company, said tonight that the nation's newspapers offer the advertiser a most powerful, effective and economical medium for speedily reaching the millions of families of prospective buyers.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 27 (AP). -- Ruth Nichols, famous flier, smiled from her hospital bed today and remarked, "Wherever the air trail leads to, I shall be there with bells on."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 54 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the two weeks preceding. In ten weeks the rate has varied only slightly, the average being 51 to 52 per cent, but the underlying trend has been upward.

George Gordon Battle, chairman of the Committee on Fair Play in Sports, made public yesterday a letter to General Charles H. Sherrill of the International Olympic Committee in which he challenged General Sherrill's belief that an American boycott on the Berlin Olympic games might give impetus to anti-Semitism in this country.

Two thousand relatives and friends jammed the auditorium of Stuyvesant High School yesterday to applaud the presentation of 521 gold, silver and bronze medals to honor pupils in the city's Jewish religious schools.

BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- While the world's attention at this time is centred upon the Italian attack on Ethiopia and the efforts of the League of Nations to halt it, there should be no forgetting the fact that a European situation exists beside which the Ethiopian affair, save for its repercussions elsewhere, is an exceedingly small potato.

As the Federal Government approaches the end of October its budgetary position grows increasingly unfavorable. In round numbers, the deficit at this point is $400,000,000 larger than was the case a year ago. At this rate, the end of the fiscal year next June would find it topping by a small margin the deficit for 1933-34, which was the largest for any peacetime year in the country's history.

Count me an ardent booster of races between rival ferryboats as proposed by Thomas Tabor. Enlarging upon his suggestion, may I submit the following list of vessels which I believe would make a racing card that would hold the interest of all nautically inclined folk around these parts'

The attempt to establish a national theatre movement through the use of the newly formed $20,000,000 cultural program of the WPA was characterized as "the wrong method" last night by Eva Le Gallienne, founder and director of the Civic Repertory Theatre.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 27. -- A normal transition from the present large-scale refunding program to a market for new capital is the next logical development in the investment market, according to Ralph T. Crane, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, which is meeting here.

READING, Pa., Oct. 27. -- The Reading Keys defeated the New Rochelle Bulldogs' football team today, 16 -- 0. More than 3,000 fans witnessed the game, which was featured by the fine play of Alabama Pitts for the losers.

Cotton futures moved over a wider range last week than in the previous week, but they ended with small net changes. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange on Saturday were 9 to 12 points higher than a week before.

A new date was blazoned in the local history of the dance last night when Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their concert groups in their performance at the Guild Theatre deliberately turned their backs upon the usual recital procedure with its succession of unrelated little numbers, and devoted themselves exclusively to the presentations of compositions in extended form.

In 1926 Knute Rockne sent his team Eastward to Pittsburgh to go through the formality of wiping up Carnegie Tech while he hied himself Westward to Chicago to enjoy the Army-Navy game and scout the Middies, who were to appear on Notre Dame's schedule in 1927.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 27. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the filing of ten additional registration statements under the Securities Act for issues totaling $7,165,016.15.

ROME, Oct. 27. -- While diplomatic negotiations for a solution of the Italo-Ethiopian crisis are hanging fire and it seems nothing can now prevent the application of sanctions against Italy, Italian troops are again on the march in Ethiopian territory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Daring riders of the Chilean Army today clinched the international military jumping championship, feature of the inter-American horse show, by outscoring the American cavalry aces for the second successive day.

REEDSVILLE, W. Va., Oct. 27. -The final contingent of homesteaders will move this week into the original rehabilitation settlement planned by the government for persons who have lost their means of livelihood and have been stranded in communities.

Commemorating the seventyseventh anniversary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt, the Roosevelt Medal for 1935 was bestowed upon Dr. William Hallock Park, director of the Bureau of Laboratories of the Health Department, last night at the annual dinner of the trustees of the Roosevelt Memorial Association at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 27. -- A small wild cherry tree, stubbornly growing on a rocky fourteen-inch ledge twenty-five feet below the top of the Palisades at Englewood Cliff, saved the life of Ernst Schultz, 14-year-old Boy Scout, of 148 East 115th Street, New York, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. The fact that cities cannot supply adequate recreational facilities because of high population densities and because of the failure to set aside suitable areas during their earlier growth makes recreation a State problem, on which the employment of personnel would help take up unemployment slack, State planning organizations stated in a report to the National Resources Committee made public today.

Last week presented again a picture of progressive industrial recovery. Loadings of railway freight ran 14 per cent above last year, rising for the fifth week well above the 700,000-car mark, which had not been reached in any other week of the past four years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- A rush of hogs to market last week, with a run of 93,400 head here, compared with 69,052 in the preceding week, demoralized the market and packers had the advantage of naming prices. Extreme declines for the week ranged from 75 cents to $1 a hundredweight on new-crop hogs and 35 to 60 cents on packing sows.

BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- In a programmatic speech delivered before a festive National Socialist rally at Breslau tonight General Hermann Goering, Air Minister, addressed to all the divergent elements of the German people an energetic call to order, discipline and absolute obedience to Chancellor Hitler in order to enable Germany to meet any threat to its peace.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "On Stage," with Selena Royle and Osgood Perkins in the leading roles, Thursday night at the Mansfield Theatre, which has been taken over by persons interested in the work of the Vocational Service for Juniors to raise funds for that organization.

HALIFAX, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press). -- Sixteen seamen who abandoned the British freighter Berwindlea on Deadman Island, one of the Magdalen group in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, were safe tonight aboard the Halifax salvage tug Foundation Franklin, bound for North Sydney.

In THE TIMES of Oct. 12 there was a short article concerning the exhibition of the Bowie art works. The item pointed out that the late Henry P. Bowie was "believed to be the only foreigner whose spirit was deified by the Shintoists."

Scoring all his team's points for the second week in a row, Frank Patrick, Pittsburgh fullback, increased his lead in the race for individual scoring honors in Eastern intercollegiate football. His field goal and touchdown against Penn State brought his total number of points to 56, seven more than his nearest rival, Ed Stanley, Williams halfback.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 27. -- The publication today for the first time of the text of the charge lodged against the Chilean Electric Light and Power Company by the government for alleged breach of the laws controlling the purchase of foreign currencies has aroused the country.

The Emergency Relief Bureau will meet today to take final action on the order it has projected, but not applied, for punitive loss of seniority rights by about 3,500 members of its staff who took part in the three-hour stoppage last Thursday. The stoppage was in protest against the reduction of the home relief staff by 900 members due to the shift of 100,000 relief clients to WPA payrolls.

A Pulitzer Prize winner, Sidney Kingsley, essays Broadway again this evening for the first time since that garland was accorded him two seasons ago for "Men in White." Tonight his play is "Dead End," and the talk goes that it is a distinctly realistic study of life on the East Side, complete with sound effects.

Last January the students in theAbraham Lincoln High School (morethan six thousand in number) gave amajority of their votes to Dr. WILLIAMH. PARKS as "the outstanding citizen"of New York in his service of the"largest interests of the community."Forty-three names were on the Hst ofthose discussed for this distinction, butthat he received more votes than allthe rest added together gave him aclear title, from this constituency atleast, to the first place.

In the last two years a marked improvement in the financial position of the City of New York has been brought about, according to a comprehensive survey of the fiscal position and financial problems of the city just completed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and R. W. Pressprich Co., with the cooperation of Frank J. Taylor, city Controller.

Formation of a new group of members of the bar in New Jersey, to be limited to banking attorneys, is being effected by a committee headed by J. Fisher Anderson of Jersey City. A preliminary meeting of banking attorneys, at which the committee was named, was held on Friday in the Chamber of Commerce Building in Newark.

ALBANY. Oct. 27. -- Lester W. Herzog, State Works Progress Administrator, today told WPA Job holders that "we expect an honest day's work" and announced that he hoped to have 134,000 unemployed at work by Nov. 15.

Although not rated a regular due to his erratic base running, Gerald Walker swung a potent bat in the pinches for the world champion Tigers to show the way to the pinch hitters in the American League during the past season, The Associated Press reports.
