Three women and two men were the only mourners in Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne yesterday when the body of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, last of New York's powerful pre-repeal gang leaders, was lowered into a grave.

The Park Department has assigned one-seventh of its army of 70,000 WPA workers to its Fall planting program in an effort to get trees and shrubs in the ground before frost, it was disclosed yesterday.
" Le Dernier Milliardaire," a French film directed by Rene Clair, starts an engagement today at the Cinema de Paris.

With one yachting season just about ended and preparations for next year's soon to get under way, nearly one hundred designers, dealers, shipyard executives, boat and engine men gathered last night at the Yale Club for the annual high jinks of the Yacht Architects and Brokers Association, Inc.

Offensive honors in the National Football League are shared by the New York Giants and the Chicago Bears. The Giants lead in points, with 109, while the Bears have made the most yardage, 1,856. The squads will clash at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, who in a startling broadcast Friday night gave an impression that a naval blockade of Italy might be imminent, corrected that impression today in a party campaign speech at Wolverhampton.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of an issue of $2,000,000 of Commonwealth of Massachusetts notes at 0.22 per cent, plus a premium of $15. The notes are dated Nov. 1, 1935, and will be due on Oct. 16, 1936.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The government of the Mongolian Peoples Republic rejected today a demand by Japanese-Manchukuoan authorities that a Manchukuoan Government agent be permitted to reside permanently in the capital, Urga.

Governor JOHNSTON of South Carolina is pre-eminently a man of the people. He is rich in energy. Now he is showing an originality of action that entitles him to an honored place in the Hall of Spirited Executives. The State Highway Department consists of fourteen members.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week that ended on Oct. 19 totaled 302,649,000 barrels according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines of the Department of the Interior.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 28. -Thousands of geese which man had been unable to frighten out of a natural death trap in the swift waters above Niagara Falls suddenly flew away this afternoon, and tonight only a few hundred were chancing a deadly ride over the Falls.

Starting a series of radio broadcasts which will continue each evening until the eve of election, Governor Herbert H. Lehman appealed last night for the election of Democratic candidates for the Assembly who "sincerely and enthusiastically endorse the progressive and humane principles of the Democratic party of the State of New York."

While Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion candidate, was disclosing the workings of the alleged paint racket in Brooklyn to political audiences last night as proof of the laxity of the District Attorney's staff, William F.X. Geoghan, his Democratic adversary, was charging that "high Fusion officials had prostituted their positions for the advancement of a man utterly unfit to be District Attorney" by their court move to get the grand jury minutes in the Druckman murder mystery.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, moved yesterday to meet the last-week drive of the Democratic State organization to retain control of the Assembly by charging that the $15,000,000 State PWA program was an attempt of the "Farley-Dailey-O'Connell machine" to trade jobs for votes and by arranging for a radio speech by Henry P. Fletcher, Republican National Chairman, tomorrow night at 10:45 from Station WEAF.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The effort of a mother to solve the mystery of her son's disappearance last Christmas Eve and the finding of his body in March led the Massachusetts Attorney General's office today to reopen the case of Robert Mythen, 18-year-old Winthrop high school senior.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 28. -- Although it was said by the censor last night that Emperor Haile Selassie would fly to Dessye tomorrow, returning in the afternoon, it is not believed by those closely connected with the Emperor's movements that he will go to that place by road until at least the middle of next week.

This year's Navy Day is, in one particular, different from any in recent recollection. There is at present no fear of the fleet being neglected. Congress has authorized a large program of replacement and new building, while the President has announced his firm intention of keeping the American Navy up to its full quota of strength.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- An open break between the administration and Governor Brann's Democratic organization in Maine was threatened today, due to a reported inclination by President Roosevelt to back army engineers in their determination not to start heavy construction on the $36,000,000 Passamaquoddy tidal power project until the State creates an authority for disposing of the hydro-electric power produced by the development.

OSHAWA, Ont., Oct. 28 (Canadian Press). -- The New York Americans and Rochester Red Wings battled to a 1-1 tie in an exhibition hockey game tonight. Both scores came in the second period when the teams displayed the best hockey of the night.

Dodd, Mead completed arrangements by cable yesterday for a commercial tie-up with Sanseido Company of Tokyo, Japan, for the publication here of Sanseido's books in English. The first to be published here under this plan will be "A Handbook of Japanese Art," which will contain 345 illustrations, many of them in color.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Two new warships were launched here today and the keel of a third was laid, giving 30,000 Navy Day visitors at the Philadelphia Navy Yard graphic evidence of the increased industrial activity growing out of the nation's new naval-expansion program.
Money market was dull and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

Inspector M.W. Donnelly of the Tenement House Department was suspended yesterday by Commissioner Langdon W. Post pending an investigation into charges that he had made improper inspections of the building at 673 Tenth Street, Brooklyn, where two children lost their lives in a fire last Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Woodlawn Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago appealed today to the District of Columbia Supreme Court to compel James A. Farley, Henry Morgenthau Jr. and Homer S. Cummings, as trustees of the Postal Savings System, to return collateral posted by the bank which has been closed, to secure the full payment of the system funds deposited there.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation announced yesterday that it had purchased the controlling interest in the United Cigar Stores Company of America from George K. Morrow and companies with which Mr. Morrow is identified.

Net income of the Commercial Credit Company and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year was reported yesterday as $5,523,724 after interest, Federal taxes, provision for reserves for all losses and doubtful items and other charges.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- Coach Dick Harlow today rested the Harvard players who faced Dartmouth on Saturday, using only substitute centre Greeley in the hour's scrimmage with the scrubs as work started for the Brown game.

Business recovery in the United States will continue in the future until the country is fully out of the depression. Dr. Marcus Nadler, director of research of the Institute of International Finance and Professor of Finance at New York University, said last night in an address at the annual Fall conference of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Regulations prescribing the submission of detailed information by protective committees or others soliciting proxies or authority to represent shareholders in railroad reorganizations and receiverships were issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University, declared in his annual report to the university council yesterday that two of the chief difficulties confronting American universities were the tendency of government taxation to suppress private benevolence and the increasing disposition of pressure groups to harass higher education.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The State Department made public tonight a report on the possibility that Paul Redfern, American aviator who disappeared in 1927 on a flight to Rio de Janeiro, is alive and disabled in the interior of Dutch Guiana.

Nick Wall, young rider who has gained a following at the Empire City course, scored a consecutive triple at the Hilltop yesterday, winning for favorite players in the Broadview Handicap, where G.S. Preece's Isaiah was the even-money choice.
Late October rentals have served to give more Manhattan apartment buildings a record of 100 per cent occupancy for the coming year, according to reports received from brokers yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- In the midst of the general election campaign, Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, is going to Geneva on Thursday, it was officially announced today. He will stay until Sunday, attending the meetings of the sanctions and coordination committees of the League of Nations.

Somewhat bruised after the rigors of three successive major contests, Manhattan's football squad yesterday began preparations for its traditional battle with City College at Ebbets Field Saturday. While the regulars were excused from contact work Coach Chick Meehan sent the Jasper reserves through a stiff scrimmage against a freshman team using Beaver plays.

Marshall Moss, violinist, a scholarship winner at an early age at the Peabody Institute, a graduate of the Juilliard Musical School and a winner of the Naumburg Musical Foundation prize, which bestows a free debut recital in Town Hall, made his appearance there yesterday.
Eddie Zivic, Pittsburgh lightweight, and Honey Mellody of Boston battled to a draw in the feature eight-round bout before 3,500 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Police opinion wavers sadly on the life and death of the late ALBERT STEIN. Some picture him as one of the great murder machines of history, a hired killer who single-handed wiped out the Dutch SCHULTZ gang, including its chieftain.
ROME, Oct. 28. -- All Italy celebrated today the dawn of the fourteenth year of the Fascist regime with undiminished faith in the future, despite the dark storm clouds gathering on the horizon.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 28. -Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau marked for probate today the will of Colonel Henry H. Rogers after he had been informed by attorneys for Henry H. Rogers Jr. that he had decided not to file objections.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28. -- Smoking before breakfast is one of the quickest ways to risk ulcer of the stomach, the American College of Surgeons was informed tonight in the findings of one of the most extensive investigations ever made of this common affliction.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Cycle, consistent 4-year-old gelding from Deering Howe's barns, returned to the winner's circle today when he led five other sprinters to the wire in the six-furlong feature at Laurel.

Three fishermen of Manasquan, N.J., narrowly escaped drowning early yesterday morning when their seven-ton auxiliary boat, Barracuda, anchored twelve miles north of Barnegat Light, was rammed and sunk by the northbound Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania.

GENEVA, Oct. 28. -- Although League of Nations members had been asked in Proposal 3, which would forbid imports from Italy, to inform Geneva "not later than Oct. 28 of the date on which they will be ready to bring these measures into operation," the "sanctions scoreboard" in the League press room showed tonight that only ten governments had replied accepting the proposal.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 29. -- Vice President John N. Garner was received in a formal audience this morning by Emperor Hirohito. He was accompanied by Joseph W. Byrns, Speaker of the House of Representatives.
VIENNA, Oct. 28. -- Great damage was done here and over the countryside today by a tornado which attained a speed of sixty-eight miles an hour.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Rexford G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, declared tonight before a Democratic meeting that the Roosevelt administration could satisfy every humanitarian demand and still balance the budget in 1938.
Notre Dame and Ohio State meet at Columbus on Saturday and weeks ago every seat had been snatched before any one knew whether the two teams would come together unbeaten.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Modification of the "legal list requirements" of various State laws restricting investments by banks, insurance companies and other institutional investors so as to give special consideration to municipal bonds defaulted since 1929 was urged before the Securities and Exchange Commission today by two experts on municipal credit.

A brief, recommending the establishment of a new department of State government designed to protect marriage and conserve the family, has been drawn up by a committee of prominent clergymen, educators and social service officials, and was recently presented to Governor Herbert H. Lehman at his request, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- In a fifteen-minute session today the Supreme Court issued some thirty formal orders, one of which, for the third time, carried a refusal to interfere with the progress of Thomas J. Mooney's case in the California courts, where the prisoner is demanding a writ of habeas corpus.

The National Labor Relations Board has taken its first two actions under the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act passed at the last session. One of these is against the United Fruit Company, the other against the Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines, Inc. It will be noticed that both of these companies are engaged in interstate transportation, the one by ships, the other by buses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 91 leading cities on Oct. 23, issued by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows increases for the week of $14,000,000 in total loans and investments, $55,000,000 in net demand deposits (which item includes government deposits), $40,000,000 in time deposits, and $83,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, a decrease of $83,000,000 in government deposits.
Mailing of 10,000,000 ballots in a nation-wide poll by The Literary Digest to ascertain the present popularity of the New Deal will begin today, the publishers of the magazine announced yesterday.

Failure to provide adequate financial aid for private charity in this city would necessitate a higher tax rate and an "indefinitely greater burden not only on the poor but on every one else," former Governor Alfred E. Smith told 750 persons yesterday at an all-day conference of the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at the Hotel Commodore.

William J. Pedrick, William J. Schmitt and Alexander Pfeiffer, trustees of the certificated group of mortgages known as Series F. sold and guaranteed by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, presented yesterday their accounting for the period to Dec. 31, 1935, to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- An agreement merging the University of Newark with Dana College and the affiliated New Jersey Law School and Seth Boyden School of Business was signed today by the boards of trustees of the two institutions, meeting at the Downtown Club.

Despite the numerous upsets of October football, an imposing list of major and minor college teams still display spotless records. The first Associated Press round-uD disclosed thirty-seven undefeated and untied teams -- about half of them major colleges -- and even a few that had not been scored on.

Two bandits attempted to hold up the Level Luggage Shop at 2,128 Broadway, between Seventy-fourth and Seventy-fifth Streets, shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. They were surprised by a policeman, however, and after an exchange of shots and a short chase both were captured.

TESCHEN, Czechoslovakia [Ciszyn, Poland], Oct. 28. -- Ten thousand Czechoslovaks, soldiers and members of military and sporting organizations arrived here today in special trains from all over the country and marched along the River Olza, which divides Czechoslovakia and Poland, in full view of Polish crowds gathered on a hilltop across the river.
Just what, besides the privilege of paying, is the salaried employe supposed to receive in return for his contribution and that of his employer on his behalf to the so-called social security plan?

The roaring of exhausts, screaming of brakes and racing of motors under 'the open windows of Washington Heights Court yesterday spurred Magistrate Harris to start a one-man anti-noise campaign. The magistrate went to a window and tried unsuccessfully to jot down the license numbers of offending cars.

Partly in sympathy with a further decline in wheat and partly because of hedging pressure, particularly by cooperative associations, prices on the Cotton Exchange worked slightly lower yesterday, ending with net changes ranging from a gain of 2 points to a loss of 8 points.
ROSLYN, L.I., Oct. 28. -- Honors in the year's final pro-amateur tournament of the Long Island Golf Association went today to Henry Ciuci of Fresh Meadow and Herbert (Buzzie) Scheftel of Sands Point.

A fortune of more than $122,000 left by a $40-a-week bookkeeper was made the subject of two Supreme Court actions yesterday when his employers charged that the money must have been misappropriated from them.
Every one who has given the matter consideration agrees that reorganization of county government in such manner that duplication may be eliminated and the cost lessened is an end much to be desired.

Reports were current yesterday in Wall Street that Michael J. Meehan, who was cited on Saturday by the Securities and Exchange Commission to show cause on Nov. 12 why he should not be suspended from the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges and the Chicago Board of Trade, would contest the constitutionality of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Mail orders and reorders received in the market here yesterday were described as fair. Orders for accessory and holiday merchandise made a better showing than reorders on outer apparel lines. While some gain has been noted in the dressy coat demand, it is still running substantially under expectations for this period, due to the warm weather which has prevailed.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 28. -- The stage is now set for major military operations in Ethiopia by the Italians, following the departure from Addis Ababa of Count Luigi Vinci-Gigliucci, the Italian Minister.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 28 (AP). -Belated stories of how whole towns vanished under flood waters tended tonight to confirm estimates that as many as 2,000 persons had perished or were missing in the hurricane that whipped Haiti's southern peninsula last week.

An American boys' choir, with headquarters in Steubenville, Ohio, gave its first New York concert at Town Hall last night. In recent years there have been visits by boys' ensembles from Vienna, Dresden and Paris; it was perhaps time for a native group to take the field.

Straddling the kidneys are the suprarenals or adrenals -- two triangular glands about as big as peas. The adrenalin and cortin that they secrete have become the subject of a literature so voluminous and romantic that even the general public is familiar with their extraordinary properties.
VATICAN CITY, Oct. 28 (AP).--Pope Pius and Premier Benito Mussolini are in conflict over the question of holidays, it was disclosed today.
ARMONK, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The Westchester countryside reverberated to shotgun fire today as hunters in unprecedented numbers turned out for the opening of the pheasant season.

LIMA, Oct. 28. -- Lima lived through five days of the most intense religious fervor ever known in her 400 years' history during the first National Eucharistic Congress. The spectacle on Friday of 100,000 women taking communion was surpassed by a mass procession of men Saturday night, followed by a midnight mass which lasted more than two hours, owing to the number of communicants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The project for settling non-Russian Jews from Europe in the Jewish autonomous territory of Birobidjan, in Eastern Siberia, was the subject of a lengthy discussion today between Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador, and former Representative William W. Cohn and Sol Low.

An examination of the toys which were placed on exhibit yesterday at 200 Fifth Avenue reveals that the manufacturer this year has taken more thought than ever to provide for the toy-loving parent. This crying need, one competent to judge asserted last night after viewing the toys, has at least been met.

A five-year Sing Sing sentence was imposed by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday on Harold J. Samurian, 42 years old, an ex-convict who posed as a capitalist to victimize persons to whom he offered loans. Samurian was convicted by a jury last Oct. 17 of defrauding Morris Pickar of $300 last June.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Army resumed gridiron practice today. Although the Cadets have emerged from two tough battles in which they downed Harvard and Yale on successive Saturdays, their physical condition is excellent.
CATSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 28.--Four robbers bound and gagged a mail truck driver and station agent here tonight and escaped with two bags of mail.

IF Barry Benefield had applied to the Guggenheim Foundation for money to finish "Valiant Is the Word for Carrie" (Reynal Hitchcock, $2), this is the sort of project-outline he would have been compelled to submit:

The first annual Metropolitan Contract Bridge championships, sponsored by the American Bridge League, started last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania with 116 pairs competing for the Oswald Jacoby Trophy.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 28. -- L.S. Prevatt, deputy United States marshal, was shot down and killed early today in the "badlands" section here. He had been working with Federal agents in a campaign to stop the flow of untaxed whisky in Steubenville and recently his life had been threatened.

ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Prison officials of the nation meeting here today in the American Prison Association Congress heard the views of men behind the bars on how they and the courts should do their jobs.

DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 28. -- At 72, when most men have retired from active responsibility, Henry Ford is striking into a car field he has never entered, and doing it with an automobile said to embody advanced conceptions of appearance and engineering design.

Ralph J. Cutten, described in the office of the Collector of Internal Revenue as one of the heaviest grain operators in North America; E.L. Chudleigh, a business associate, and Cutten Company, Ltd., were made defendants yesterday in an income-tax action filed by the Federal Government.

MADRID, Oct. 28. -- An extraordinary session of the Cortes today heard a report from the special commission appointed to investigate charges that eight high public officials, including a former member of the Cabinet, had accepted bribes from Daniel Straus, a Mexican citizen, seeking gambling concessions in this country.

By adding a little thought and art to considerable accurate observation. Sidney Kingsley has compiled an enormously stirring drama about life in New York City. "Dead End," which was produced at the Belasco last evening. Somewhere along the East River a raffish dead-end street meets the rear entrance to a fashionable apartment house where private yachts have a slip of their own.

ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The $3,000,000 Arlington Downs plant opened its twentyone-day Fall meeting today with an outsider, Mrs. A.M. Creech's Sound Advice, winning the $2,500 added inaugural handicap over the Waggoner course in 1:12 2-5. This course is 150 feet less than six furlongs.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28. -- Sale of the Richfield Oil Company of California and the Pan-American Petroleum Company on Jan. 31, 1936, was ordered today by Judge James of the United States District Court here. The companies have been in receivership for almost four years.

The cost of unemployment relief in this State for the year ended Aug. 31 was $352,620,419, according to the annual report submitted by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration to Governor Lehman and the Legislature and made public yesterday.

What with professional followers of the share market exercising caution in the making of new commitments and an inclination in some quarters to claim profits, prices moved irregularly throughout yesterday, save for the first few minutes of trading, when quotations were firm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- A 1935 farm income of $6,800,000,000, including rental and benefit payments, the largest total in five years and $413,000,000 more than last year, was predicted today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. This is $100,000,000 more than earlier estimates by the bureau.

Handing down decisions at the rate of about two a minute, three city magistrates disposed of a top-heavy week-end calendar of 1,010 traffic offenses in Traffic Court, 301 Mort Street, yesterday, sending seven offenders to jail in default of fines levied, and collecting $783 from others.

HONOLULU, Oct. 28. -- Advance base operations which will send forty-eight naval patrol planes as far west over the Pacific as Midway Island were announced by Rear Admiral Frederick J. Horne upon his arrival today aboard the Tender Wright. The planes will leave Pearl Harbor Nov. 9 and remain away from the base at least ten days.
Fordham's football team worked defensively against Pittsburgh plays yesterday and found them hard to handle.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 (AP). -- New York State's Works Progress Administration worked feverishly tonight to get its job program in full operation, announcing meanwhile that 419 projects employing 23,526 workers were "under way" up-State.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- For the first time since he took on the task of trying to prevent Premier Bonito Mussolini's action against Ethiopia from developing into more than a "colonial war," Premier Pierre Laval has begun to lose that optimism that has carried him along that a settlement could still be reached. He is not going to give up the struggle, but events have discouraged him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Subscriptions of $332,193,000 were received for the combined offering of $50,000,000 of 138-day Treasury bills and a similar amount of 273-day bills, bids on which were opened today at the Federal Reserve Banks, and $100,371,000 was accepted, Secretary Morgenthau announced.

The campaign of 1936 still lies some distance in the future, but our Washington Bureau notes a growing tendency in Administration circles to make prosperity the chief issue. Certainly the President's own recent addresses have pointed strongly in this direction.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 28. -- An airplane from Makale, where the Ethiopian general headquarters on the northern front are situated, brought the first Italian spy arrested in the north to Addis Ababa today. He is an Ethiopian native of Tigre Province and is supposed to be one of several native couriers used to carry Ethiopian information to Asmara in Eritrea from the headquarters of Ras Seyoum and Ras Kassa south of Adigrat.

PHILADELPHIA, Out. 28. -- Judge Raymond MacNeille ordered a grand jury today to investigate allegations that City Controller S. Davis Wilson, the Republican nominee for Mayor, was using for political purposes a $65,000 fund appropriated to him for revaluation of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company.

The customary schedule of forty-two games was announced for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League for the 1935-36 season yesterday by Ellwood W. Kemp Jr., secretary-treasurer of the circuit, through The Associated Press. The usual round-robin of home-and-home engagements will be played by Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Pennsylvania, Columbia, Cornell and Dartmouth.

The request by real estate interests to continue sub-metering of electric current after Nov. 1 has been rejected by the Public Service Commission, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner George R. Van Namee. The commission approved the ban, effective Nov. 1, when it accepted the $7,000,000 rate reduction filed by the Consolidated Gas system effective Aug. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- More than 100,000 persons crowded into the Washington Navy Yard today to watch units of the nation's first line of defense put on a show in observance of Navy Day.

A denial was issued here yesterday by Arthur T. Kemp, president of the American Hospital of Paris, of the report that the French Government was about to take over the hospital and that American physicians no longer would be allowed to practice there.
BERLIN, Oct. 28.--Hanns Kerrl, head of the Reich Church Ministry, has issued the following statement:...

New York City's gigantic usury racket, grown to an enterprise reaching millions of dollars a year in profits and emboldened to strong-arm tactics, was mashed yesterday when a series of raids, many of them simultaneous, dragged twenty-seven prisoners into custody.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Nov. 29 was set by President Roosevelt today for his speech in Atlanta, the decision determining the date of the "homecoming" celebration being arranged in his honor by the citizens of that city.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Oct. 29 (AP). -- A decision within forty-eight hours on the amount of the government loan on the 1935 corn crop was considered likely yesterday as AAA officials studied the question.

ATHENS, Oct. 28. -- Alexander Papanastassiou, former Minister of Economy, was arrested at his club tonight, charged with circulating a pamphlet inciting to revolution. The government is undecided whether to send him to an Aegean island.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 28. -- Contrary to expectations, both here and at the front, no hostilities in the north had been reported by 6 o'clock this evening. Ras Seyoum, commander of the Northern Army, said in a telephoned message this morning that the Italians had not moved from their position and that he was remaining north of Makale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Iowa Southern Utilities Company of Delaware, Centerville, Iowa, filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance, under the Securities Act of 1933, of $5,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 5 1/2 per cent bonds, Series of 1935, due on July 1, 1950, further swelling the total of issues which the commission hopes soon will be followed by large-scale financing for new capital.

Miss Elsie Lee Goadby, a debutante of the season, gave a luncheon party yesterday at the Pierre for a group of friends, also debutantes. Her guests included the Misses Rosalie Williams, Elizabeth Alexandre, Helen McPherson, Joan Belmont, Patricia Pittman, Florence Sullivan, Elizabeth Sillcocks, Alice Ballantine, Adelaide Hardenbergh, Margaret Sillcocks, Faith Locke, i Alix de Saint Phalle, Elizabeth Mitchell and Jacqueline Godwin.

Tonight's premiere will be at the Mansfield, where Benjamin Kaye's comedy, "On Stage," will arrive with Osgood Perkins and Selena Royle prominent in the cast. It was shown last year out in Cleveland and during the Summer in a couple of Massachusetts watering places.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 (AP). -- General Hugh S. Johnson attacked the New Deal in an address delivered here tonight for "amazing blunders and failures," but called for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

Naval establishments in New York City held open house yesterday in observance of national Navy Day. The chief point of interest was the navy yard in Brooklyn, where more than 25,000 visitors passed the gates, normally closed to civilians except employes.

GENEVA, Oct. 28. -- Japan took the position before the Mandates Commission in a private session today that her rights as regards mandates have not been changed in any way by her withdrawal from the League of Nations. This was accompanied by what seemed to some observers to be a veiled threat that her continued cooperation with the commission depended on the League's admitting this position, at least privately.

ADOWA, Oct. 27 (Delayed). -- Pneumonia is one of the dangers confronting Italian soldiers here. There is a great difference in the temperature between day and night and the altitude puts a strain on the heart. At Adowa, for instance, there is a 70-degree difference between the hottest part of the day and the coldest part of the night.

An official peace demonstration to be held in the Great Hall will be City College's contribution to the nation-wide peace assemblies Nov. 8, President Frederick B. Robinson announced yesterday. Dr. Robinson, with the consent of the board of trustees, has called off all classes between 11 and 12 o'clock on that day.

ADOWA, Ethiopia, Tuesday, Oct. 29. -- After an advance officially declared to have taken them twenty miles, Italian troops are encamped in the Fetes Mai region, Ethiopia's "valley of milk and honey," Black Shirts and native troops made the push without apparently finding anything to push against.
The Mary Fisher Home will be the beneficiary of a card party to be held Saturday at the Biltmore. Mrs. David E. Lurch heads the group making arrangements for the benefit.

A two-story bathhouse to be built in Colonial Park will cost $1,050,000, according to plans filed for the Park Department yesterday by Aymar Embury 2d, the architect. The site, about 420 by 40 feet, is on the west side of Bradhurst Avenue, opposite 146th and 147th Streets.

Sugar, coffee, cocoa and silk futures advanced briskly in the local commodity futures markets yesterday, while the remainder of the list was erratic. The cash market losses occurred in all the grains, cotton, lard, silk, rubber and tin.

TIENTSIN, China, Tuesday, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Japan submitted a formal note today to Chinese officials of North China demanding "prompt and decisive measures to eradicate various anti-Japanese and anti-Manchukuoan organizations existing in North China.

The grand jury minutes of the Druckman murder case will be turned over to Police Commissioner Valentine on Nov. 6, after election day, but will not be made public, County Judge Algeron I. Nova ruled in Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Attorney General Cummings said tonight that "our great American underworld is armed to the teeth," partly with 2,047 firearms and 273,326 rounds of ammunition stolen from National Guard armories since Jan. 1, 1933.

A plan for the transfer of the control of Schoellkopf, Hutton Pomeroy, Inc., of Buffalo, N.Y., an investment banking firm, from the Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland to the holders of the Class B common stock of the latter concern has been approved by the directors of Niagara Share, it was announced yesterday by J.F. Schoellkopf Jr., president.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Liquidation by tired longs in wheat continued unabated today, all markets dropping to new low levels on the current downturn. Uncertainty as to the policy of the new Canadian Government on export sales again dominated sentiment.

Due to the split-up in Coca-Cola, there has been a revision in the list of stocks used in THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial average. Brooklyn Union Gas, Coca-Cola, Corn Products, First National Stores and Peoples Gas have been dropped, and Beech Nut, Chrysler, Columbian Carbon, McKeesport Tin Plate and Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing substituted. The parity of the average has been preserved.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Orange and Rockland Electric Company of Monroe, N.Y., has registered as a holding company with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the first to take that step under the Public Utilities Act of 1935, the commission announced today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28. -- A broad study of radio as an advertising medium will be started at once by a committee representing companies that advertise on a national scale, large advertising agencies and radio broadcasting companies, it was announced today at the convention of the Association of National Advertisers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The market for hogs was weak to 10 cents a hundred weight lower in the early trading here today, but the demand became more aggressive later in sympathy with the strength in cattle and lambs and at the close prices were about in line with those at the finish on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The government has decided to reduce drastically the November direct relief allotment for New York State, and as a result New York City will be faced within a few days with the possibility of having to care for all its unemployables without Federal aid.

The Consolidated Gas Company of New York and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 80 a consolidated net income of $34,503,291 after all deductions excepting minority interests. This was equal, after these requirements and preferred dividends, to $2.07 a share on 11,476,527 common shares.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The stock-markets opened generally firm today, but later became irregular, the weakening being ascribed to the influence of the coming general election. Business on the markets was restricted. The setback in prices, however, was due mostly to profit taking.

The Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, reopened for the season with a private view yesterday afternoon. "Cezanne and the Impressionists" is the title given to the exhibition, which may be visited by the public beginning today. It will be on through November.

The children of the nation are rapidly becoming the "stanchest" supports of wild life conservation, it was reported yesterday at the opening session of the two-day meeting of the thirty-first annual convention of the National Association of Audubon Societies at the American Museum of Natural History.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28. -- A plea for some form of health insurance to enable the voluntary hospitals of the country to survive the depression was made today at the opening of the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons by Sister John Gabriel, hospital consultant and educational director of the Sisters of Charity in the Northwest.
Following is the text of Governor Lehman's radio address last night:

With the Democratic majority in the Board of Education shattered for the first tame since 1918, Fusion members began yesterday to consider slashes in the pay of some high-salaried school bureau heads and administrators.

A warning against excessive optimism over the progress made to date in the conquest of tuberculosis was sounded last night by Dr. Arnold Rice Rich of the Johns Hopkins Medical School in an address before the eighth annual graduate fortnight symposium of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Public offering will be made today of 235,225 shares of preferred stock, $4.50 series, of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, through an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co. The shares are priced at $102.75 plus accrued dividends from Oct. 1 to date of delivery.

Dan O'Mahoney made short work of Ed Don George at Madison Square Garden last night. The Irish wrestler, defending his world's championship against the North Java (N.Y.) challenger for the third time, needed only 5 minutes and 8 seconds to register the triumph.

The overcrowding problem in the city's schools is growing more acute yearly, the delegate assembly of the United Parents Associations was informed by a special committee in a report submitted to the group last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Upon what meat doth this our Duce feed that he has grown so great? More arbitrary and grandiose than ever does MUSSOLINI become as difficulties thicken round his head. His latest utterances are to the effect that the application of sanctions will mean war, not immediately and against all of the members of the League at once, but later and terribly.

At least some of the 3,500 employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau who took part in last week's stoppage in protest against the announced laying off of 10 per cent of the ERB staff may escape the penalty of losing their seniority rights announced by the ERB on the day of the stoppage.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 28. -- Militia rule was used by Governor Olin D. Johnston today to seize control of a hostile State Highway Department which he declared was in a "state of insurrection."

Deals involving apartment properties in the Bronx featured real estate trading in the metropolitan district yesterday. Multi-family houses on Plimpton and Tinton Avenues, Minford Place and in 136th and 137th Streets changed hands.

The total number of unemployed workers in September was 9,466,000, according to the regular monthly estimate of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public yesterday. This is a decrease of 386,000, or 3.9 per cent, from the preceding month, and a decrease of 927,000, or 8.9 per cent, from September, 1934.

Your correspondent, "Experienced," slates that I am in error in supposing that the British Government is analogous to our Federal Government, because, in his opinion, the British Government is more nearly analogous to the government of the State of New York. The opinion that the government which rules an empire is more closely analogous to one of our State governments than it is to the government at Washington seems hardly worthy of refutation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Rounding into form for the first time in the three-day Inter-American Horse Show, the United States Army team today scored a somewhat hollow victory over the Chilean Army aggregation in the final event of the international team jumping contest which was clinched Sunday by the South Americans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The largest assemblage of officials of the nation's Stock Exchanges ever to be brought together wrestled here all day today with the problem whether or not functions of security dealers and brokers should be separated. After a full day of it, they decided to extend their "off the record" round-table sessions through tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The first legal battle over the constitutionality of four New Deal laws will start in the Supreme Court Dec. 9. An order issued by the court today set that date for hearing arguments in the Hoosac Mills attack against the processing taxes of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Improvements in other forms of transportation tend automatically to increase the volume of passenger traffic on the sea, John E. Ryan of San Francisco, general passenger manager of the Matson Navigation Company, said yesterday. Mr. Ryan said air-conditioned trains had been responsible in part for increased Summer travel on the Pacific.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28. -- In the 1935 survey of hospitals in the United States and Canada by the American College of Surgeons, 3,565 hospitals were inspected and 2,523 were fully or provisionally approved. "Provisionally approved" means that hospitals so designated have accepted the minimum requirements for hospitals laid down by the college, but for lack of time or other acceptable reasons have not yet been able to carry them out in every' detail.
JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Oct. 26 (Delayed).--The Italian southern army was reported here tonight to have established a "front" of more than 400 miles across southeastern Ethiopia.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS W.Va., Oct. 28 (AP). -- A private, off-the-record forum discussion following Mr. Burns's address brought out a sharp conflict between the viewpoint of the commission and that of several leading Wall Street lawyers as to what certain circles regard as the dangers of doing business under the Federal security laws.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 28. -- Cardinal Schuster of Milan today wished "peace and protection" for Italy's armies, which are opening "the doors of Ethiopia to the Catholic faith and the civilization of Rome."

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28. -- The Chaco Peace Conference adopted a resolution this afternoon formally declaring the Chaco war terminated. The declaration was made in accordance with Article III of the protocol of June 12, which authorized the conference to declare the war at an end as soon as the armies had demobilized and other guarantees against a renewal of hostilities had been carried out.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- William R. Fetzer, 62, former Municipal Judge, was shot dead and two attorneys were seriously wounded today by a gunman who invaded the judge's law offices in a Loop building.

Ten Manhattan properties and three in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The Manhattan holdings included a nine-story apartment house at 144 East Thirty-sixth Street, a seven-story loft structure at 252 West Twenty-ninth Street, two five-story flats at 1,398 Second Avenue and various smaller structures.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- More than 1,500 bituminous coal producers have accepted the Bituminous Coal Code and acceptances are coming in at the rate of about 200 a day, the National Bituminous Coal Commission stated tonight. The production tonnage of these acceptances has not been determined, but it is expected that acceptances for the entire country will exceed 15,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $104,679,000 in three separate issues of bonds nominally outstanding in this country was asked by the government of Denmark in an application filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- John Da Grosa, president of the American Football Institute, asserted today that some of the country's leading football coaches unwittingly are promoting a gambling mania which threatens to undermine the foundation of the game.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Fritz Crisler paused for a moment today at the half-way mark in his season and took a glance back. On the whole, he was pretty well satisfied with what he saw. His team was still unbeaten and had found its scoring punch last Saturday, as Cornell will testify after the 54 -- 0 rout.

Football activities at Baker Field were practically at a standstill yesterday as Columbia reflected on its performance against Michigan last Saturday and looked ahead to its meeting with Cornell at Ithaca.

Steel operations this week will average 51.9 per cent of capacity, an increase of .1 point over last week's rate of 51.8 per cent, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. This is the highest rate since the beginning of February.

Opposition of the Newsprint Export Manufacturers Association of Canada to the plan for reorganization of the Great Lakes Paper Company, which includes leasing of the company's property for a period of years to a group of publishers in the United States, is not justified, according to John E. Gefaell, who was instrumental in working out the plan of reorganization.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Ruling on a phase of activities of the State Mortgage Commission not previously passed upon by other courts. Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley today upheld the constitutionality of the act creating the commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--President Roosevelt today took up the task of formulating policies to govern the emergency budget for the fiscal year of 1937, beginning next July 1.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Prices of hogs resumed their downward trend today declining 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight to the lowest level since July as the result of the largest arrivals for a Tuesday since last March. In addition to the increase in receipts there was a rather sharp decline in wholesale fresh pork prices, loins here being off 1/2 to 1 1/2 cents a pound, with 20 cents taking the best.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Harvard's football coaches found some encouragement today in an hour's scrimmage between the varsity and an eleven composed mainly of first-team substitutes. Scoring three touchdowns and just failing to make another, the regulars showed a greatly improved attack.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- All in one hour, Mayor La Guardia came to Port Jervis, addressed 5,000 at Orange Square, received a three-foot key of the city from Mayor Phillips, hurried to Mechanics Hall to address a firemen's convention and started back to New York City. This all happened between 7 and 8 o'clock this evening.

BERLIN, Oct. 29.--A Protestant Church amnesty decree was issued tonight by the church directorate formed by Hanns Kerrl, head of the Reich Church Ministry. It provides that all pastors expelled from their pulpits during the regime of Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller shall be reinstalled, all disciplinary proceedings against pastors suspended, all fines levied on churchmen returned, and all fines not yet paid canceled.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Mrs. Mary Dougherty, 50 years old, will move from the back porch of her home on Bayard Street, here, tomorrow morning. The move, however, will take her only to the open park in Court House Square, where, she announced, she will make her "home."

Benjamin M. Kaye, of the Abingdon Square Kayes, writes as well as Pirandello, who won the Nobel Prize. In fact, it has been suggested that on the evidence of "On Stage," which was put on at the Mansfield last evening, he writes better than Pirandello because he and his actors have managed to make themselves understood.

ATLANTA, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Strengthening of every link in the chain of criminal justice is the answer to America's crime problem, Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction for New York City, told the Congress of American Prison Associations tonight.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 29. -- Dartmouth used a white football in working under the are lights as preparations were launched for Yale today.

DENVER, Oct. 29. -- The Denver Post published a statement today calling the report that $350,000 was paid in 1927 to influence the editorial policy of the newspaper "palpably insufficient and inherently improbable and utterly devoid of factual or circumstantial value."

GENEVA, Oct. 29. -- A recommendation that the League of Nations continue its help toward Chinese reconstruction along the main lines so far followed is made in the annual report of Robert Haas, secretary of the Council's China Committee, just issued.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The protective committee for $34,548,000 of thirty-year 4 per cent bonds of the St. Louis, Iron Mountain Southern Railway, Gulf division, added its voice today to the mounting protest against the management's plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 29.--The world premiere of George White's "Scandals" here last night drew probably the biggest gross ever paid for a dress rehearsal, but, although the show badly needed editing, enough material was indicated for the production to survive, in the opinion of spokesmen for the 4,900 persons who saw the first of four performances.

Twenty-three properties, divided about equally between Manhattan and the Bronx, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The Manhattan holdings included the twelve-story Hotel Alcazar at 43 West Thirty-second Street, a ten-story business building at 296 Broadway and various apartment houses.

President ROOSEVELT has begun work on the new budget which will go to Congress as soon as it convenes. The budget is for the fiscal year 1936-37: that is, for the twelve-month period beginning July 1 of next year and running through the national election into the first few months of the next Administration.
Christmas Club savings accounts this year are much fatter than they were last year.

An earnest collection of contract bridge enthusiasts from the man duplicate clubs throughout the metropolitan area contended last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania against a relative handful of leading experts for final round positions in the contest for the Oswald Jacoby Trophy, signifying the metropolitan pair championship of the American Bridge League.

Not all of the stunts that present generation college students like to believe belong among the ancient past when sophistication was still a word in the dictionary for college men are completely abandoned. For the past couple of years each Dartmouth expedition to the Yale Bowl has been accompanied by unidentified custodians of pots of green paint.

General Hugh S. Johnson has been asked to become the "czar" of the dress industry by the United Dress Manufacturers Association, representing more than 2,000 dress contractors who produce 80 to 85 per cent of the output of dresses in the metropolitan area, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Oxhorn, president of the association.

Football has taken a greater toll of lives in the first six weeks of this season than during the corresponding period a year ago, it was revealed yesterday, in a survey prepared by Floyd H. Eastwood, a New York University instructor in education.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 29. -- By winning the twelfth game in the series for the chess championship of the world tonight, Dr. Max Euwe of this city reduced the lead of Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the titleholder, to 6 1/2 -- 5 1/2. Play lasted thirty-five moves.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The vote in favor of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's corn-hog control program was belittled tonight by Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, as failing to present a clear-cut issue.

Savings deposits of the country, including time deposits and postal savings deposited in commercial banks, rose $899,979,000 in the year ended on June 29, last, to a total of $22,652,489,000, according to reports received by the Savings Division of the American Bankers Association.

A disastrous freight rate war on the North Atlantic was threatened yesterday as the Black Diamond Steamship Company peremptorily resigned from the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference in protest of alleged discriminatory practices of the German Government and two German steamship lines in making possible rebates to American exporters who use German ships.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The late Arnold Bennett's hitherto virtually unknown play, "Flora," recovered from the files of a literary agency where it had long been forgotten, was presented tonight by the Covent Garden Club, a new play-producing society, of which the American, Ruth Putnam Mason, is one of the organizers.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 29.--Preparing for the Princeton game Saturday, Navy brushed up its attack today, with special attention given to passing, which has been a weak spot in the Middies' playing.

City officials, educational leaders and 2,000 upper-class pupils of the Washington Irving High School took part in the rededication yesterday of a bronze bust of Washington Irving outside the school building on Irving Place between Sixteenth and Seventeenth Streets.

Earnings for the third quarter of this year as reported by 184 industrial corporations have shown a gain of 36.3 per cent over the comparable figures of last year, according to The Associated Press. The net income of the group totaled $177,769,141, against $130,380,428 in 1934.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 29 (By Wireless). -- Indications are plain now that the Italian advance into Ethiopia is designed to follow British and French methods in dealing with subject nations -- namely, to seize the strong points, announce that the country has been conquered, and then spend years in subjugating the die-hards in the interior.

When Annie Edson Taylor announced that she was going over Niagara Falls in a barrel friends exclaimed: "You're a goose!" Years later Bobby Leach did the same stunt and proved the truth of the expression, "what's sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander."

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- Britain and France will jointly, probably within the next twenty-four hours, question Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy through diplomatic channels on the terms of his claims against Ethiopia.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Henry J. Fernekes, 39-year-old "midget" killer, took his own life today with poison.

The telephones in the office of the athletic director of Fordham were jingling furiously and imperatively, with Jack Coffey and Jimmy Crowley hurriedly grabbing receivers the instant they hung them up and promising to do the best they could about getting choice reservations.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29. -- A board of ten psychologists will be formed to help the Association of National Advertisers take the guesswork out of evaluating methods used in testing the effectiveness of advertising copy, it was decided here today at the annual convention of the association.

The Fator brothers, Laverne and Elmer, the former once a star rider for the Rancocas Stable and Elmer still in the saddle, brought off a victory at Empire City with Dasher yesterday which was the result of good horsemanship and the patience one must take with some horses.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Troops seized $1,871,352 in State highway funds at three banks here today under Governor Olin D. Johnson's edict changing the road administration. The banks had halted payments on State highway checks upon opening this morning, following the Governor's ousting of the highway board for "insurrection" yesterday.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Oct. 29. -- Military advices received here from the Southern front admit that the Italian Army advancing up the Webbe Shibeli River has been taking village after village, but it is explained that this advance fits in with the Ethiopian plans.

Mr. and Mrs. Douglas R. Coleman gave a dinner last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for the Viscountess de Sibour of Paris. The other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Michler, Mrs. Benjamin Holt, John W. Garrett and A.D. Knox.

Josef Pollack of Max Pollack Co., Inc., has been elected president of the Cotton Thread Institute, it was announced here yesterday. Mr. Pollack, who had been first vice president, had been for ten years president of the Cotton Thread Association, which the present institute succeeded.

Four bent residents of a home for the aged went to the law offices of Senator Robert F. Wagner at 120 Broadway yesterday to express the gratitude of the 382 persons in their institution for the Senator's efforts in behalf of old-age security.
TOKYO, Oct. 29. -- Cordiality of unprecedented proportions was displayed today toward Vice President John M. Garner and Speaker Joseph W. Byrns by the Japanese nation.

Charging that his adversary had been conducting a campaign of misrepresentation, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan, Democrat, asserted last night that the residents of Brooklyn were disgusted with the tactics of Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion nominee.

MANILA, Oct. 29. -- What is apparently a minor matter may develop, some believe, into the largest issue of the relation of American sovereignty in respect to the Philippines, it was disclosed today as the formal program of the inauguration of the new Commonwealth became public.

G.B. Stern has signed a contract with Macmillan for her new work. She has written an autobiographical narrative which will be called, "King Charles Head." She will arrive here today on the Berengaria.

Columbia, taking no chances on having Cornell spring an unexpected aerial attack at Ithaca Saturday, bolstered its defense against passes yesterday at Baker Field in the first intensive drill since the Michigan game.
ATLANTA, Oct. 29. -- William S. Cox of New York, executive secretary of the Osborne Association, took issue tonight with Governor Talmadge's advocacy of the chain gang and the whipping post.

The New York County grand jury handed up yesterday to General Sessions Judge Bohan first and second degree assault indictments against Edward Drolette, 34 years old, a seaman, charging an attack on Detective Matthew Solomon of the Alien Squad last July 26 in the riot on the North German Lloyd pier at the foot of West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Seven air mail pilots whose heroic action in danger saved the lives of passengers or mail received from President Roosevelt today the Air Mail Flier's Medal of Honor, authorized by Congress in 1931.

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered less than in the preceding week but were well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week totaled 809, which compared with 872 in the previous week and 696 in the same period last year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- A heavily oversold condition was disclosed in the wheat market today when shorts started to cover on indefinite war talk. Liquidation early had carried prices off about a cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here and 2 cents in Winnipeg, but when the buying movement started a lack of pressure was apparent and all markets rallied rapidly, with the close about the top.

A State-wide inquiry into the quality and cost of public education will be made by a special committee headed by Owen D. Young, who also announced yesterday a $500,000 grant from the General Education Board, a Rockefeller foundation, to carry out the survey.

Irregular price movements occurred yesterday on the Cotton Exchange after covering had advanced December contracts eleven points, in contrast with a ten-point decline in the October. Following the closing of the two deliveries at about the same price on Monday, the December went yesterday to a 20-point premium above the October, the spread widening sharply in the last hour.

A banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Dillon, Read Co. will offer publicly today an issue of $26,000,000 of the Columbus Railway, Power and Light Company first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, 4 per cent series, due in 1965.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A group of European health officers who are to study health problems in leading American cities under the auspices of the League of Nations will arrive in New York tomorrow on the steamship Manhattan, Dr. W.F. Draper, acting surgeon general of the Public Health Service, stated today.

ADOWA, Oct. 29 (Reuters). -- On a hill commanding a magnificent view of Aksum, with its round thatched huts and stone churches, your correspondent talked today with General Luigi Gubeddy, bluff, ruddy-faced commander of the native brigade who is responsible for the administration of Aksum pending installation of the Italian civil government.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--A new attack upon the constitutionality of the Agricultural Adjustment Act was begun here today by 108 business concerns of Eastern and North Central Pennsylvania which are affected by processing taxes.

Mrs. Mina Miller Edison, widow of Thomas Alva Edison, the inventor, will be married today at Chautauqua, N.Y., to Edward E. Hughes, lawyer and business man of Franklin, Pa., and a friend of long standing, it became known here yesterday.
That not all work relief is boondoggling is shown in the annual report submitted to Governor Lehman and the Legislature by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.
MACON, Ga., Oct. 29. -- Judge Bascom S. Deaver in Federal court refused today to dismiss on government motion 120 injunctions granted to complainants in AAA processing tax suits in this State.
Gleanings from mailbag and notebook:

The United Jewish Appeal, which has raised nearly $4,000,000 in the last two years to aid Jews in Germany and other lands and to permit their settlement in Palestine, will be discontinued next year and in its place the participating organizations in the appeal, the Joint Distribution Committee and the American Palestine Campaign, will conduct independent fund-raising drives.

HELEN WOODWARD, wife of W.E. Woodward, the biographer of Grant and Washington, grew up on New York's East Side when penniless German and Bohemian and Polish and Jewish immigrants were arriving with every ship. Which means that the atmosphere about her was that of a score of novels about life below the poverty line in the slum districts of a generation ago.
A new film version of "Way Down East" opens today at the Center Theatre in Radio City. Its cast is headed by Henry Fonda, Rochelle Hudson, Slim Summerville and Margaret Hamilton.

The evolution is both striking and symptomatic. Lewis Morris was one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence. Gouverneur Morris was American Ambassador its France at the time of the French Revolution. And now George L.K. Morris, a descendant of theirs, is painting abstractions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- The Securities and Exchange Commission closed today its investigation into practices of municipal bondholders' committees preparatory to formulating a report to Congress suggesting legislation to standardize refinancing procedure for cities in default.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The customary proclamation setting aside Nov. 11 for the observance of Armistice Day was issued by President Roosevelt today. He already has agreed to speak at services at Arlington National Cemetery on that date.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Birmingham University has decided to establish an academic assistance fund to be used to create temporary research fellowships for scholars of any nationality displaced from their universities by reason of race, religion or politics.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,797,950 barrels, compared with 2,782,800 in the previous week, a gain of 15,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The increase was due almost entirely to a jump of 13,500 barrels in the daily average output of California.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 29. -- Democratic defeat in the Assembly elections would start national repudiation of the New Deal, Senator George R. Fearon declared here tonight. This movement would spread over the country like "wildfire."

While business failures in the retail and manufacturing divisions increased in the week ended Oct. 24, as compared with the five business days in the previous week, the wholesale branch registered a decline, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church has present assets of $32,060,547, including $1,511,668 cash in hand, William Fellowes Morgan, president of the fund, reported yesterday at a meeting of the trustees and directors at the offices of the fund, 20 Exchange Place. J.P. Morgan is treasurer of the fund.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A revolving fund for a continuing low-cost housing and slum-clearance program was proposed today by Secretary Ickes in speaking at a press conference. He declared that proper housing within the reach of the lowest income groups could be constructed only by government subsidy.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank of New York, today urged that the Federal Reserve Board "move vigorously" toward eliminating the addition to excess reserves that has been made during the last year and a half.

Charles P. Barry, Bronx representative on the Board of Higher Education, was elected secretary of the board at its regular meeting last night. Mr. Barry succeeds Philip J. Sinnott, who resigned yesterday to become official referee of the Appellate Division.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- All day today and well into the night Premier Pierre Laval and his Cabinet were hard at work framing the texts of some 150 decree laws to be submitted for the signature of President Albert Lebrun tomorrow. These decrees constitute the final series projected under the full powers granted the Premier by Parliament and intended to correct and supplement the deflation program he has been trying to put into operation.

A surprise party was held in the offices of Postmaster Albert Goldman yesterday for William P. McKeon, assistant superintendent of mails, who has completed fifty years of service as an employe of the New York Postoffice.

The two-day conference in Chicago between officials of the nation's securities exchanges and the Securities and Exchange Commission apparently developed, as Wall Street had expected, nothing of a conclusive nature. The meeting seems to have served only as a geographically central sound-board for the protests of brokers against the segregation of broker-dealer functions, on which the SEC must report to Congress on Jan. 3.

The official rate for Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1/4, but one trust company announced that its renewal rate was 3/4, the first break and upward revision since April 18. Fixed period quotations also moved out of the pegged area which has prevailed since mid- April.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Mrs. Rosamond Batchelder Hedges, widow of John K. Hedges, a New York stock broker, leaped to her death from her seventh floor room in the Washington Hotel today. Mrs. Hedges, who was 38, made her home at 1,040 Park Avenue, New York City.
Manhattan's first eleven, returning to action after a day of rest, had its first taste of defensive work against City College plays yesterday.

Two small calibre bullets which left so little trace that an ambulance physician at first thought the victim was merely suffering from a severe beating ended the life yesterday of Theodore Plona, 26 years old, a meat cutter who had recently been employed as a WPA laborer, according to the police.

Mr. DEWEY and his aides have earned the gratitude of the city for the speed and thoroughness with which they prepared their case against the usury racketeers, and for the efficiency with which they rounded them up. With so many investigators involved, and with evidence taken from more than a thousand witnesses, it is little short of amazing that no important "leak" developed.

Tonight will bring Times Square its first double-header of the season. Two shows, one about a pianist and the other about a fiddler, will find their paths to Broadway and will set up shop about like this.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Allotments for up-State Works Progress Administration projects were swelled to $7,467,775.67 today as Lester W. Herzog, administrator, announced that $2,471,745.12 had been released in the WPA drive to put 130,000 men to work in the area within two weeks.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 29 (AP). -- H.H. Brown's Barnsley had to challenge twice today before capturing the Coventry Mile, defeating E.M. Duffy's Sir Jim James by two and a half lengths in the feature at Narragansett Park.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $1,305,205, after all charges, for the three months ended on Sept. 30, the smallest loss that it has incurred for such a period since 1931. In the corresponding quarter of last year the net loss was $9,826,767, and in the second quarter of this year, seasonally a more active period, the net loss was $762,493.

The New York University varsity squad began preparations at Ohio Field yesterday for its meeting with Bucknell's team at the Yankee Stadium Saturday. The undefeated and untied Violet eleven worked for more than two hours in the first session since its victory over the Georgetown eleven.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- After opening in a better atmosphere than yesterday, the Bourse reacted somewhat nervously today to the internal political situation. As the date for reopening the Parliamentary session approaches the political activity developed strength.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--By failing to comply with the Public Utilities Act's provisions for registration with the Federal Power Commission, hundreds of executives of operating companies faced the prospect tonight of enforced resignations from dual directorships in operating companies and utility-banking connections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Demands for the expulsion and disbarment of the fifty-eight lawyers of the American Liberty League who recently declared that the Wagner Labor Relations Act was unconstitutional will be considered by the American Bar Association at a meeting of its committee on complaints and grievances in Columbus Nov. 17, according to apparently reliable reports here.

ROME, Oct. 29. -- The start of the fourteenth year of fascism finds the Italians less concerned with the past accomplishments of the regime than the prospects for the future. The year fourteen of the Fascist era starts today, the date on which Premier Benito Mussolini assumed power.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. -- A simple method which enables a physician to determine in advance whether an individual is likely to develop high blood pressure, and means for its prevention and control in such susceptible persons through the practice of self-discipline, were described tonight before the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons in a symposium on hypertension.
BERLIN, Oct. 29. -The Boerse was quiet and weak today. Heavy [industrial issues showed insignificant changes. The machine list was totally inactive. AEG lost [ point as electrical shares weakened.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- The Court of Appeals at Albany will be asked tomorrow by the Republicans of New Rochelle to block the Mayoralty election scheduled for Nov. 5. A decision is expected before Thursday night.
Housing deals in three boroughs featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

At the corner of Kings Highway and East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, a young Communist was entreating a handful of listeners last Friday night to assemble the following day and march in protest against a threatening European war.

Calling it "bargain counter justice," Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion nominee for the Kings County District Attorneyship, told three Brooklyn audiences last night that his check-up of the cases that passed through the Kings County Court for the first six months this year indicated that nineteen out of twenty defendants have successfully bargained with District Attorney Geoghan's office for a plea to a lesser offense.

Various changes in sinking fund and collateral are planned by Ulen Co., who direct the construction of public works, because the company's board of directors believes "favorable opportunities will soon present themselves for renewed activity" in that field, both here and abroad.

Smoldering unrest within the ranks of the Actors Equity Association caused by friction between its administration and an internal group known as the Actors Forum came to a dramatic climax yesterday when Frank Gillmore, president of the association, and Paul Dullzell, executive secretary and treasurer, threatened to resign their offices unless they received a vote of confidence by the full membership.

John N. Dallon, vegetable oil broker, who opened his own office in the Whitehall Building last Wednesday after having been employed for some time by a firm at the same address, was killed at about 11 A.M. yesterday when he fell or jumped from a washroom on the seventeenth floor to an extension on the first floor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Our position in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, particularly the further steps this government might take in exerting its moral influence for an early peace, was understood to have been discussed at length this afternoon by President Roosevelt, Secretary Hull and Under-Secretary Phillips.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- The midseason changes in the Paris fashion showings are noticeable rather in the wear than in the general outline, materials used for day and evening, although there is a decided tendency toward accentuated slenderness and height for evening.

The fifth anniversary of the Lots for Little, Inc., a thrift shop which donates its proceeds to five Catholic charities, was marked yesterday by a visit of Cardinal Hayes to the store at 902 Third Avenue.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 29. -- The Canadian Government notified Geneva today that it was taking steps to prohibit the exportation from the Dominion of arms and munitions to Italy and to prevent the issue to her of loans or credits.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Labor Department, according to report, was told today that the International Longshoremen's Association would put into effect on Friday an embargo on all goods shipped to Atlantic ports from Gulf ports where strikes of union longshoremen are now under way.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, in a broadcast tonight upbraided the government for being "too late" at Geneva and breaking its pledges at home.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary, is going to Geneva to insure that nothing happens to wreck irrevocably the prospects for the Italo-Ethiopian peace settlement that Britain, with France, has now decided to promote with the object of freeing Europe from the menace of a catastrophic upheaval.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 29. -- Chinese officialdom is dismayed, according to dispatches from Peiping, by the blunt demand made by Japan today that all "anti-Japanese" activities in North China be suppressed lest vigorous steps toward that end be taken by the Japanese.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29. -- Arousing the Yale team from its tackling and punting troubles, Ducky Pond, Earle Neale, Denny Myers and Ivan Williamson, the board of football strategy, today spent nearly three hours in an effort to avert a repetition of Saturday's Army disaster when Dartmouth visits the Bowl Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The award by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of thirty-two separate municipal bond issues aggregating $3,833,300 that had been pledged as security for loans from the Public Works Administration was announced tonight by Jesse H. Jones, chairman.

With one motion yesterday Coach Steve Owen closed the gates at the Polo Grounds and opened the Giants' bag of tricks in the first practice for Sunday's game with the Chicago Bears. Safe from the prying eyes of enemy scouts, the New Yorkers revealed a dazzling attack in a dummy scrimmage.

The Bellevue Hospital occupational committee of the New York City Visiting Committee was the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show held yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Acting as manikins in the showing of costumes for Autumn and Winter sports wear were Mrs. Alfred J. Yardley, Mrs. David I. Mackie Jr., Miss Barbara Davis, Mrs. Alan Jackson, Miss Aurelie Murchison and Miss Carol Barnes.

Election of a Republican Assembly as the first step toward electing a Republican President next year by letting the country know that the Roosevelt New Deal policies were repudiated in the President's home State was urged last night by Representative James W. Wadsworth in a speech at Flushing High School.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company announced tonight that it plans to build 10,000 new freight cars and remodel 1,000 of its present freight cars, at a total cost of approximately $30,000,000.
MADRID, Oct. 29. -- The Spanish Cabinet was reshuffled today as a result of the bribery charges made by a foreigner seeking gambling concessions in this country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A farm price index of 109 on Oct. 15, compared with 107 on Sept. 15 and 102 on Oct. 15, 1934, was reported today by the Bureau of Agriculture Economics.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Livingston Mills gave a dinner at the Greenbrier tonight, honoring Mrs. Mills's daughter, Miss Dorothy R.
