Fell, and her guest, Miss Whitney Bourne. Others present were Mrs. Louis C. Clark, T. Chesley Richardson and Harvey W. Shaffer. Mr. and Mrs. Cloud Wampler gave a dinner in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Alden H. Little.

A new issue of $5,500,000 City of Seattle (Wash.) municipal light and power 4 per cent bonds was awarded yesterday to a banking syndicate headed by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation at a price of 96.25. The issue consists of $4,900,000 of refunding bonds to be used to refund certain 4 1/2 and 4 3/4 per cent bonds that are callable on Dec. 1 and $600,000 of construction fund bonds.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. L. du Pont Irving entertained several guests in the Homestead Club this evening, among them Mr. and Mrs. John W. Cross.
ALBANY, Oct. 29. -- Grand jury action and indictments loomed as possibilities tonight as the State pressed a broad investigation into alleged racketeering at the Saratoga Springs race track.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- American "cooperation" in the League's moral and economic blockade of Italy as outlined by Secretary Hull suggests in German press opinion a conciliatory approach to the League's policy without, however, surrendering the basic principles of neutrality as conceived and promulgated by President Roosevelt.
SEATTLE, Oct. 29. -- The coldest October weather in years gripped the Pacific Northwest tonight, sending high winds and rain south to California and frigid temperatures to many interior areas.

Sanctions have not yet been applied to Italy, though they are almost due. But in anticipation she has been put on a restricted diet by order of MUSSOLINI. This is in line with one of his earlier predictions, which he later withdrew, but has now apparently reaffirmed, that Italians would not go to war with a nation enforcing sanctions, but would meet them with the heroic Fascist discipline.

Harold Edmonston, 26 years old, of 2,170 Amsterdam Avenue, and his wife, Jean, 25, were killed last night when an automobile he was driving struck a tree in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. Miss Mary Muscatella, 20, of 448 West 167th Street, a passenger, suffered a fractured leg and was taken to Fordham Hospital.

The Park Department will hold a series of Halloween parties in playgrounds throughout the city tomorrow, culminating in a Halloween show and roller skating carnival on the Central Park Mall at 8 P.M. Witches, hobgoblins and other eerie manifestations are promised in abundance.

SINAIA, Rumania, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Queen Marie of Rumania began the celebration of her sixtieth birthday today by riding through new-fallen snow on a thoroughbred horse, a birthday present from V.P. Sassu, Minister of Agriculture.

HONOLULU, Oct. 29. -- The South Seas scientific cruise of Captain Eric Bisschop and Joseph Tatibouet, both said to be members of the French Geographical Society, came to an end Saturday night when their 40-foot sailing vessel Fou-Po II grounded on a reef off Kalaupapa, on the island of Molokai.

GLOUCESTER, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Five hundred students of Gloucester High School, impelled by the urge for the more abundant scholastic life as expressed in terms of touchdowns rather than Latin and algebra, went on strike today to enforce a demand for a shorter school day.
More than 6,000 persons, the police estimated, took part last night in a meeting called by employes of the Consolidated Gas Company to protest against Mayor La Guardia's utilities program.

Of the thirty-four States which have industrial safety regulations, twenty-seven have adopted some of the thirty-four American Standard industrial safety codes "as is" or "as a basis" for their own rules, according to answers to a nationwide survey, it was announced yesterday by the American Standards Association.

The United States liner Manhattan, with former Mayor James J. Walker and Mrs. Walker aboard, will arrive at Quarantine about 11:30 A.M. tomorrow, several hours ahead of schedule, the line was advised yesterday by the ship's commander, Commodore A.B. Randall.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- An appeal to all Germans to save, to enable the National Socialist regime to finance a program of "liberty and bread," was broadcast over the entire German radio system tonight by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank and Economics Minister.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 29. -- The statement that public utility interests spent more than $400,000 in 1927 to bring newspaper and other influence to bear on the voters of Denver to approve a rate ordinance covering natural gas distribution in that city was made in a report which the Federal Trade Commission published today.

The Allegheny Steel Company declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock and a regular quarterly dividend of $1.75 on the preferred shares. Similar dividends were declared on the common stock in the first two quarters of 1935, compared with 30 cents in 1934 and none in 1933.

American business today faces the possibility of the greatest degree of regulation and supervision in its history, Henry P. Fowler, assistant manager of the research department of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, warned fifty members of the New York Trade Association Executives at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- Philadelphia football coaches expressed divergent views today on a statement by John Da Grosa, president of the American Football Institute, that "football coaches unwittingly are promoting a gambling mania which threatens to undermine the foundations of the game."

SECAUCUS, N.J., Oct. 29. -- An 11-year-old school girl, who described her religion as "undenominational," caused a special meeting to be held tonight of the Secaucus Board of Education to discuss her refusal, on religious grounds, to salute or pledge allegiance to the American flag.

Slumped sullenly in their chairs against a courtroom wall, twenty-one men who professed to be furriers, store owners and, always, devotees of family life, heard themselves excoriated yesterday as loan sharks and sinister criminals who extorted exorbitant sums from low-paid workers to whom they had lent amounts small in themselves but difficult to repay.

A plan to eliminate the expense of foreclosure proceedings and take direct title to property on which the city holds a mortgage has been worked out by the Controller's office and adopted in resolution form by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- The Reich citizenship law, decreed in Nuremberg, which divides the inhabitants of Germany into "State members" without political rights and "Reich citizens" appointed by the National Socialist regime, also will have important economic consequences for those debarred from citizenship.

The first of the Eastman School American Composers' concerts will be held tonight in the Eastman Theatre, Rochester, N.Y. The concert marks the first appearance of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, under Howard Hanson.

While agreeing ardently with your correspondents who blame the enormous number of large and empty taxis that clutter the streets of the city. I would like to ask whether they have ever considered the appalling imbecility of the traffic lights.

An agreement between Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, and ten private hospitals whereby sirens would be removed from their ambulances in furtherance of Mayor La Guardia's anti-noise campaign, was disclosed yesterday following the death of Mrs. Henrietta Thode, 69-year-old victim of a hit-and-run automobile driver.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- With a great show of spirit and determination, the Princeton football team went through a long offensive drill against Navy defensive formations put on by the scrub eleven in practice on University Field today.

Credit is due THE TIMES for its sensible editorial policy in the present world crisis. The temptation to advocate peace at any price is great, especially in a city having a large Italian population, many of whom seem to wish America to condone Mussolini.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Governor Lehman's plea for the election of a Democratic Assembly on the party's record was answered yesterday by Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman. Mr. Eaton disputed the Governor's claim of administrative efficiency and pledges fulfilled and asserted that the good in the legislative record, such as the development of a system of good roads and a park system, was made possible only by cooperation.

A reorganization plan for Burns Brothers under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act, filed on Monday night before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson, was referred yesterday to Special Master John E. Joyce.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Financial sanctions against Italy became operative here today with some confusion but with scarcely a ripple of dissent anywhere in the money markets of London.

Citing an 84 per cent depletion of the nation's timber land as an example of the vast losses in natural resources suffered by this country, conservation leaders last night urged national planning for wild life preservation at the closing session of the thirty-first annual convention of the National Association of Audubon Societies at the American Museum of Natural History.

The State Mortgage Commission is anxious to get the State out of the real estate business by rehabilitating as quickly as possible the properties it controls, and does not intend to compete with private enterprise in this field, Louis S. Posner, a member of the commission, declared yesterday.
Keen's English Chop House, at 72 West Thirty-sixth Street, served its 1,000,000th mutton chop last night with a colorful ceremony.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Financial sanctions against Italy became operative here today with some confusion but with scarcely a ripple of dissent anywhere in the money markets of London.

Citing an 84 per cent depletion of the nation's timber land as an example of the vast losses in natural resources suffered by this country, conservation leaders last night urged national planning for wild life preservation at the closing session of the thirty-first annual convention of the National Association of Audubon Societies at the American Museum of Natural History.

Movements of prices in the share market yesterday were again inconclusive. Sentiment (professional, at least) continued mildly reactionary, influenced a little, perhaps, by the efforts of the banks to raise money rates, and somewhat by the slackening of expansion in some lines (mostly seasonal); there was, however, a brisk but short-lived rally in stocks at the start of the final hour of trading on the Stock Exchange.

In the days when Bryant Park was in a dismantled state -- which means before its rehabilitation under the direction of Commissioner MOSES -- the bust of WASHINGTON IRVING stood on a shabby pedestal of wood looking across Fortieth Street at the tall buildings which shut away all that he in life loved of Manhattan. Of it IRVING wrote:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. -- A miracle of brain surgery, by which portions of the skull are removed, cured of their ills outside, and restored safely to the head hours or even weeks later, was described before the American College of Surgeons here today.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, announced last night that New York's allotment of 220,000 workers on WPA jobs was reached yesterday and that from now on it would be his purpose to facilitate the return of as many persons as possible to jobs in private industry rather than maintain the city's relief job quota.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Galmica, a gelded son of Galetian from the Chicago-owned Shandon Farm, came through with his second victory of the year today as he took the measure of five other 2-year-olds in the mile and 70 yard feature.

Consolidated net income of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Sept. 30 was reported yesterday as $30,030,990, which was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.13 a share on the common stock. It compared with $31,517,631, or $1.19 a share, in the preceding year.
ROME, Oct. 29.--While the League of Nations prepared to apply economic sanctions against Italy, the Italian Government today adopted its first defensive measures.

Ezra Rachlin, a pianist who is still this side of 20, gave a recital at the Town Hall last night that stamped him as one of the biggest talents to appear here in many days. It is indeed a rarity for a young artist to play with the authority, sweep, brilliance and rightness of form, color and tone that Mr. Rachlin revealed.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 29. -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Dr. Carl E. Parry, chief of the division of security loans of the Federal Reserve Board, returned today to Washington after listening to a cross-section of opinion given by leading Stock Exchange officials of the country in regard to their business under the present Federal regulation.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, will arrive today from London on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others coming on the ship from Southampton via Cherbourg include several film players, among them Merle Oberon, Charles Boyer, C. Aubrey Smith and Eugene Pallette.

GENEVA, Oct. 29. -- Acceptances of sanctions against the Italian Government poured in on Geneva today, the only disappointment being the Swiss refusal to accept fully the boycott of Italian goods stipulated in Proposal 3.

The freighter Exarch of the American Export Lines, which sailed from New York for Constantinople last Friday with nine passengers and a crew of forty-six officers and men, was reported to be on fire at 9 A.M. yesterday about 700 miles southeast of Ambrose Lightship.

Mayor La Guardia has ordered Police Commissioner Valentine to break up the connections of racketeers with police officials and politicians as shown by "business" papers found after the murder of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and Louis (Pretty) Amberg last week, it was learned yesterday.
Four men were convicted last night in Federal Court in Brooklyn of making false reports to the government concerning sales of 1,500,000 pounds of sugar.

Two women employed by the Classy Form Brassiere Company of 125 East Twenty-third Street were slugged and the concern's designer was persuaded to go to the headquarters of the Corset and Brassiere Workers Union shortly before 9 A.M. yesterday in an attempt by union organizers to induce the company's employes to join the union.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 29. -- The Berkshire Inn, Great Barrington, will give a Halloween ball Thursday night for the benefit of Fairview Hospital in that town.

Three new plays, especially designed for use in the Manhattan College game on Saturday at Ebbets Field, were assigned to the City College football team by Coach Benny Friedman in a long drill at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. In all, nine plays have been planned for special use against the Jaspers.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 29. -- The Berkshire Inn, Great Barrington, will give a Halloween ball Thursday night for the benefit of Fairview Hospital in that town.

Three new plays, especially designed for use in the Manhattan College game on Saturday at Ebbets Field, were assigned to the City College football team by Coach Benny Friedman in a long drill at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. In all, nine plays have been planned for special use against the Jaspers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- A denunciation and a defense of the Guffey Coal Act marked the opening today of legal proceedings in District of Columbia Supreme Court to test the constitutionality of the law.
In the last few weeks your editorial page has encouraged the view that the United States Government should impose the same sanctions against Italy as have been agreed upon by the League of Nations.

Not only a "breathing spell" but a "rest cure" for business in New York State, so far as legislation is concerned, was promised last evening by Irving M. Ives, minority leader of the Assembly, if the Republicans regain control of the lower house of the Legislature.

"Proposed Amendment No. 3" relieving bank and other corporate shareholders of the provision in the State Constitution imposing double liability to the amount of the shares held for the debts and liabilities of the corporation should be vetoed by bank depositors and other creditors, for no argument presents convincing testimony that the provision is, at worst, more than ineffective, while it still affords depositors some protection.

The expected move on the part of the big Wall Street banks to raise money market rates above their current unremunerative levels got under way yesterday when the Manufacturers Trust Company announced that it had lifted its charge for Stock Exchange call loans from one-quarter to three-quarters of 1 per cent.

Weakness developed again yesterday in most commodities on the local futures markets. The volume of trading was light, although silk was active as prices declined. On the cash markets wheat, oats and cotton advanced, while corn sold at a new low level and lard and silk eased.

Real estate tax collections this year show a substantial improvement over collections for 1934, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. The improvement was attributed to better general business conditions.

"Building a Profitable Store -Better Selling, Better Buying, Better Management" will be the theme of the convention marking the silver anniversary of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania from Jan. 20 to 24, it was announced yesterday.

A determined, organized effort to transfer as many persons as possible from the WPA payroll to jobs in private industry was begun yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator. Mr. Ridder declared that a substantial reduction in the WPA relief work army by mass transfers of workers to regular employment would be one of his main objectives.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30. -The promotion of David Griffith Colwell to replace Al Hessberg as left halfback of the Yale football eleven and that of Fred Peterson to succeed Henry Wright at left tackle today indicated a changing policy of preparedness for the Dartmouth encounter Saturday.

Calling his adversary "a political acrobat," William F. X. Geoghan, District Attorney of Brooklyn, in a series of speeches last night dared Joseph D. MeGoldrick, the Republican-Fusion nominee, to endorse the Republican Assembly candidates.

PARIS, Oct. 30. -- The suggestions for a settlement of the Ethiopian situation elaborated here by the French and British experts, Count Rene Doynel de Saint Quentin and Maurice Peterson, have been communicated to Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy.

Conservationists were agreed yesterday that J. N. Darling's speech before the National Association of Aubudon Societies at the American Museum of Natural History on Tuesday night was a significant step in the movement to reconcile divergent wildlife interests and obtain a united front in the struggle for a national wildlife restoration program.

GENEVA, Oct. 30. -- The League Mandates Commission has decided to refer to the Council without discussion or comment the statement made before the commission by Japan, in which she took the position that her withdrawal from the League had changed in no way her rights as regards League mandates.

Four Bandits who shot a customer of a Brooklyn bar and grill when he protested at being held up were sentenced by County Judge Fitzgerald in Brooklyn yesterday to die in the electric chair on Dec. 19.

In response to appeals from "many disinterested persons," the Emergency Relief Bureau, at a meeting last night, lifted the penalty of loss of seniority rights, tantamount to dismissal, against the 3,500 employes of the bureau who participated in last week's stoppage staged in protest of layoffs of staff employes.

A list of fifty books recommended most often by the faculties of fiftyfive colleges and fifty books chosen by 1,638 students in fifty-three colleges was made public yesterday by Dr. Atwood H. Townsend, Assistant Professor of English in the New York University College of Engineering.

Lawrence Tibbett, the Metropolitan Opera baritone, declarel yesterday that if the opera is to live, it must not only have the support of the upper strata of society but also of the average person. Mr. Tibbett was guest speaker at the Mettropolitan Opera Guild at its first report luncheon at the Hotel Pierre.

Shih I. Hsiung, who is known as the "Chinese Shakespeare" for his translations of the bard into Chinese, arrived here yesterday on the Berengaria for his first visit to this country. Pie was accompanied by his wife.

Sixty-four contract bridge pairs competed last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania for sixteen finalist positions in the contest for the Oswald Jacoby Trophy, emblematic of the metropolitan pair championship of the American Bridge League.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Gifts of securities aggregating about $811,560 were made in September by officers, directors or principal stockholders of corporations, according to a summary by the Securities and Exchange Commission of monthly equity security transactions, issued today.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Germany announced a nation-wide "motor muster" today, indicating the possibility that her soldiers might some day go to the front in a duplicate of the French World War "taxicab army."

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins rejected yesterday an application by Joseph Lewis, president of the Free Thinkers of America, to strike out the answers of the Board of Education upholding the use of the Bible in the public schools, and defending both hymn singing and the use of public school buildings by religious and racial organizations.

Tony Beckman, American sprint star, well known as a six-day bicycle race champion and also holding the world's one-mile bicycle championship, is now teaching music for a living, it became known yesterday.

The development of a large-scale low-cost housing program in this country offers the key to economic recovery, H. Gordon Selfridge, the London merchant, told 400 retail executives yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor by the Association of Buying Offices and the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- With the time for registratin on with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Holding Company Act of 1935 set as Dec. 1, the filing of registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 by three large utility companies for the issuance of bonds and debentures aggregating $104,463,500 was announced today.
"The Three Musketeers," based on the book by Alexandre Dumas and acted by Moroni Olsen, Paul Lukas, Onslow Stevens and Walter Abel, opens today at the Radio City Music Hall.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 30. -Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State and co-author of the Kellogg-Briand Pact, declared tonight that "the United States in common with other countries can and should designate Italy as the aggressor in its flagrant violation of the sovereignty of another nation."
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 30. -- The fundamental basis for national recovery lies in the development of an integrated housing industry, properly organized for the production of homes, to make the advantages of lowcost mass production available to the people, Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, told members of the Investment Bankers Association at the final session of their convention here today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 30. -- The tendency toward a relaxation, even unconsciously, in certain standards of sound investment banking as a result of the unusually keen competition among houses of issue for new industrial bond business was sharply criticized in the report of the industrial securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America presented here today by Sidney J. Weinberg, chairman of the committee.

ATLANTA, Oct. 30 (AP). -- The American Federation of Labor urged today that future proposals for prison labor laws be worked out by a joint committee of the trades union movement and the American Prison Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- President Roosevelt appointed today the members of the Railroad Retirement Board who will administer a fund of from $130,000,000 to $140,000,000 a year, to be collected for paying pensions to those of the 1,250,000 railroad employes who reach the age of 65 and who retire from active service.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Headquarters of the Nordic pagan German Faith Movement have been opened in a building in the Wilhelmstrasse next to quarters used by the high command of the Hitler Special Guards. It is perhaps significant or perhaps a coincidence that the Special Guards are the most enthusiastic supporters in the Nazi party of Dr. Alfred Rosenberg's anti-Christian ideas.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Weakness in the market for fresh pork with the price of loins off 1/2 to 1 cent wholesale here at 16 to 19 cents a pound, the outside figure showing a drop of 5 cents in a week, is having a depressing effect on the market for hogs.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 30. -- The Trunk Line Association of New York, in a letter today to Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein, announced it had decided at a meeting in New York yesterday to grant to the Port of Newark free loading and unloading privileges and free storage allowances similar to those allowed in other parts of the New York Harbor.

MANNINGTON, Ky., Oct. 30 (AP). -- Armed against another threatened "invasion" of pickets, the Williams Coal Mine, scene of a bloody clash between union labor sympathizers and mine guards, operated as usual today with a force of 200 non-union workers.

It has been a good many years since football could show so few unbeaten teams midway in the season as have survived the decimation of the current campaign, and it is with a feeling of trepidation that most of the handful of unscathed leaders approach Saturday's pitfalls.

Walter Neusel and Primo Carnera yesterday completed hard training for their ten-round fight at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. Both fighters will arrive in town tomorrow to weigh in at the offices of the State Athletic Commission.

Stating that the experimental stage in New York racing is over and that future changes would be of administrative detail rather than of basic policy, Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, yesterday issued the following statement upon the conclusion of the New York turf season:

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 30. -- Emperor Haile Selassie today ordered all buried arms dating from the time of his uncle, Emperor Menelik, unearthed for distribution to reserve troops. Thousands of American Winchesters are included in the caches.

ROME, Oct. 30. -- Swiftly following the meat restrictions approved yesterday came an announcement today that the Fascist party had entrusted to provincial committees, composed of mothers and widows of men killed in the World War, the task of making a house-to-house canvass to organize retaliation against League of Nations sanctions.
A paper ballot with space for a "write-in" vote will be used instead of voting machines in electing a Mayor for New Rochelle next week.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 30. -- Despite official statements that reports of an impending change in the Ethiopian War Ministry are "pure speculation at this time," it is unquestionably growing clearer that there is a real basis for the assumption that Ras Mulugeta, the War Minister, will be superseded.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Foreign markets gave no encouragement today to holders of wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade, and prices sagged early until the distant deliveries showed 1 3/5 cents under Tuesday's finish. War talk was not in evidence and short covering caused a good upturn at one time.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney continued his campaign against American participation in the Berlin Olympics in a speech last night in which he assailed "some who went to Germany with the intention of keeping their eyes closed."

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, expressed the opinion yesterday that there was "infinitely greater possibility of peace than there was a month ago." He returned on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria from a two-month vacation.

The second movement of last evening's symphony was the slow one, played on muted strings and before a restless audience. Call it "Play, Genius, Play!" and say that the uneasy suspicion did get around that it was carpentered to the blueprints of the screen.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Davis gave a farewell dinner last night at their home, 115 Central Park West, for Mme. Alfredo Zayas, widow of the former President of Cuba, who is at the Plaza before going to Florida and thence to her home in Cuba. The other guests were:

GENEVA, Oct. 30. -- High League of Nations quarters expect the session of the Coordination Committee opening tomorrow to be short and confined mainly to taking two decisions -first, setting a date for economic sanctions against Italy to take effect, probably Nov. 15, and second, establishing machinery for following up in a general way how these sanctions will work and providing for the mutual support in case of losses, required by Proposal 5.

Last night I had the pleasure of listening, at a meeting of professional men, to an Italian leader but lately an anti-Fancist, who, though still an exile from his country, has been won to the support of Mussolini by Italy's entry into the African war.

The Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad announced yesterday that it would file tomorrow an application for reorganization under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The announcement was made exactly a week after the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad had filed a similar petition.

The Kreiner String Quartet still has a long road to travel before it arrives at distinction in its difficult field. Last night's weather might be blamed for the faulty intonation and crude tone that prevailed throughout the great quartet in E flat, Opus 127, of Beethoven, in the quartet's recital in Town Hall, and nervousness could well account for the lack of precision which also characterized the vain struggle of the group with this masterpiece.

An appeal for the election of a Democratic Assembly next Tuesday was made last night in a radio address by Speaker Irwin Steingut of the Assembly, over Station WJZ and a State-wide network, at 6:15 P.M.

A well-dressed boy of 16, without showing any concern, heard his 12year-old sister testify in General Sessions yesterday that the youth had beaten and kicked their 3-yearold brother so brutally last May 9 that the child died seventeen days later without medical care in their home at 75 East 106th Street.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 30. -- The continued silence of the northern front, despite the news from abroad that Italian patrols were half-way to Makale, is explained here by the fact that the telephone line extends only a little way north of Makale to a point much south of Ras Seyoum's headquarters.

Smoking before breakfast, say the surgeons in San Francisco, is likely to bring on ulcers of the stomach. This reminds one that most activities before breakfast are rather a nuisance than otherwise. By far the best thing before breakfast is breakfast.

The effort of the banking community to inject a little "planned economy" into the money market, in place of the ruthless law of supply and demand, got off to a favorable start yesterday when all important banks, bankers and banking agencies put a price of three-quarters of 1 per cent on Stock Exchange call loans, in place of the one-quarter of 1 per cent figure that had obtained since the middle of last April.

ABOARD THE S.S. PRESIDENT GRANT, at Sea, Thursday, Oct. 31. -- With memories of sitting on floors, going unshod in restaurants and eating with chopsticks, of lavish fetes and of visits to monasteries and shrines, Vice President John N. Garner and the Congressional delegation to the Philippine inauguration were sailing on the Inland Sea this morning, bound for China.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 30 (AP). -This city, the scene in the last two years of a series of industrial disturbances which brought four deaths, was chosen today as the opening battle ground in a drive by the American Federation of Labor to "purge" labor organizations of "radical communistic groups."
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 30 (AP). -National Guardsmen ejected a process server today bearing a State Supreme Court injunction against Governor Johnston's militia-made highway administration.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The Boerse observed "National Savings Day" by marking up prices in most fixed interest securities, especially in government loans, in today's operations. This strength was communicated also to the stock market, with gains of fractions predominating.

LOND0N, Oct. 30. -- Philip J. Noel Baker, secretary to the late Arthur Henderson, president of the Disarmament Conference, told the Arms Commission today that British embassies and legations gave greater support to agents of armament firms than to those of other businesses.

After almost two months of virtually unchanged operations, the rate of steel ingot production has advanced 1 point to 53 1/2 per cent of capacity, the highest rate since the second week of February, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by Iron Age.

Many public adjusters in the insurance business are little better than racketeers. Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, charged last night in an address at the tenth annual dinner of the General Brokers Association of the Metropolitan District, Inc., an organization of insurance brokers, at the Hotel Astor.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 30. -- A moral revolution of spiritual force "to build up a system based on an agricultural foundation and widely distributed private property" was advocated today by Michael Williams of New York, editor of The Commonweal.

In Los Angeles Under-Secretary TUGWELL, an angel of agriculture, has been cultivating the political garden. He comforted a Democratic meeting. What was all this talk about the backbreaking burden of debt that the Administration was handing on to posterity?

SHANGHAI, Oct. 30. -- "If the situation becomes serious the Japanese and Manchukuoan armies may move on their own initiative against Chinese Communists, but that time is not yet here, nor is the time ripe for Japan to cooperate with China against the Communists.

From every point of view the turn for the better in what has been the fierce religious controversy in Germany is to be welcomed. Both Catholics and Protestants who have stood up valiantly for their faith and their rights within the community are now to be accorded at least a large measure of that liberty and self-direction which their churches long enjoyed and which they have been steadfastly demanding.
Rain fell on Fordham Field yesterday, but it failed to cramp the Maroon eleven's style.

The aerial attack, which has been So successful for the New York Football Giants thus far, is expected to play a prominent part in Sunday's game at the Polo Grounds, where the Giants will oppose the Chicago Bears, holders of the Western championship.

The advancing, by several of the largest city banks, of their rates for loans on security collateral can hardly be considered as an effort to restrain stock speculation. An advance from one-quarter of 1 per cent (the rate which has prevailed on Wall Street call loans since April) to three-fourths of 1 per cent still leaves the charge normally low.

Sterling Securities Corporation, an investment trust controlled by the Atlas Corporation, declared yesterday a dividend of $3 a share on its ocnvertible first preferred stock on account of accumulations, payable Nov. 15 to stockholders of record on Nov. 12.
Teams from three foreign countries that will be represented in the international jumping contests of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden next week will reach New York today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30. -Following the third lengthy scrimmage of the week between teams A and B, Coach Dick Harlow tonight intimated that there may be a severe shake-up in the Harvard varsity football team for the Brown game Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP). -- A brief opposing extension of Federal power through a licensing system was submitted today to the Supreme Court by a group of lawyers, including James M. Beck, former Solicitor General.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 30. -The Army plebe eleven won its second straight game by defeating Williamsport Dickinson Seminary 14 to 0 today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30. -The old question "Is there life on Mars?" has been definitely decided in the negative by recent observational evidence, said Dr. Loring B. Andrews of the Harvard Observatory staff, in a lecture at the observatory tonight.

Alexander Tarsaidze, who heads the general committee for the Russian naval ball, to be held Nov. 15, gave a reception with dancing yesterday afternoon in the Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for Miss Lucy T. Saunders, chairman of the debutante committee for the ball.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 30. -- Declaring the American capitalistic system faces destruction at the hands of "politicians and demagogues." Malcolm Muir, former Divisional NRA Administrator for heavy industries in Washington and president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, called upon advertisers here today to lead in fight by all business against governmental regimentation.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 30. -Three 16-year-old Montclair High School boys, who exercised their mechanical ingenuity to repair an old motorcycle and make it run, but went so far as to use 1933 license plates on which the date had been changed to 1935, will begin washing cars in the Montclair Police Department garage on Saturday as a punishment for their offense.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 30 (Canadian Press). -- Severe storms moved eastward into Manitoba tonight, leaving behind it piled snowdrifts in Saskatchewan and Alberta and heavy damage to shipping and crops on the Pacific Coast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Two preliminary decisions in litigation designed to test the constitutionality of the Guffy Coal Control Act setting up "the little NRA" of the bituminous mining industry, were divided evenly today by government and plaintiff in the District of Columbia Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Rome, Geneva and Addis Ababa understand, and American exporters may as well realize it, that the President and the Secretary of State do not comment idly, in the present state of world affairs, on trading with belligerents. A big stick to use on recalcitrant exporters to Italy is now in plain sight under the White House chair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The administration began today a concerted effort to stimulate home construction and modernization. President Roosevelt announced that he had appointed Peter Grimm, the New York realty expert who was called to Washington last July by Secretary Morgenthau to serve as an assistant and study the housing and mortgage finance situations, to be assistant director of the National Emergency Council.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The Nazification of German universities, which has been marked by the dissolution of all non-Nazi student organizations and the dismissal, retirement or relegation of scores of professors, was carried a step further today when Wolfgang Windelband, Professor of History in Berlin University, was removed to the University of Halle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The first definite step toward a network of publicly owned airports throughout the country and, eventually, the nation's territorial possessions, was revealed today by the Assistant Secretary of Commerce, T. Munroe Johnson, with the announcement that $18,390,553.41 had been approved for expenditure by the Works Progress Administration for improvements on 313 airports.
CEDARHURST, L.I., Oct. 30. -The first women's Class A team matches of the squash racquets season were held today, with the Junior League defeating the Rockaway Hunting Club, the home team, 4 to 1.

Election of a District Attorney dwarfs all other issues in Brooklyn. The present incumbent of that office, Mr. GEOGHAN, was renominated in the Democratic primary, and his re-election was thought to be certain until Professor McGOLDRICK took the field against him.

Testimony intended to show that many of the bondholders' committees organized in the depression to protect owners of defaulted mortgage issues actually were set up without the knowledge of bondholders and frequently by interests inimical to them, was presented yesterday at the first public hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Bonholders, Stockholders and Creditors Committees.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 30. -Four airmen were Killed tonight when a giant test airplane of the United Air Lines crashed during a snowstorm into a low knoll six miles south of here.

The contract for construction of the first section of the Sixth Avenue subway was awarded by the Board of Transportation yesterday to the Rosoff-Brader Construction Corporation. The award is subject to approval by the Board of Estimate.

More than a score of civic, social welfare and professional organizations voiced approval yesterday of the plan of Park Commissioner Moses to provide adequate policing for the city's parks at a meeting sponsored by the Park Association of New York, Inc., in the Russell Sage Foundation Building.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 30. -- The strike of broadsilk workers in Paterson and vicinity will get under way tomorrow morning. Officially the strike call was set for midnight tonight, but inasmuch as there are no shifts working between midnight and 7 o'clock tomorrow morning the first workers to be affected will be those who would ordinarily report for work at 7 A. M.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP). -- New York State's sweeping investigation into racetrack tipster services concentrated today in Saratoga County, as Law Department officials sought at least five indictments before the grand jury.

An increased volume of apartment rentals was reported yesterday, with the larger part of the activity listed for the East Side. The upper West Side also was a favored area. Tenancies ranged northward from the Greenwich Village and Gramercy Park sections.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise went to Brooklyn last night to urge the election of Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion nominee for the Kings County District Attorneyship. He said Mr. McGoldrick had been tried in public office and had not been found wanting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30. -- One thousand milligrams of a pure, crystalline derivative of vitamin E, the fertility vitamin without which human and all other mammalian life would vanish from the earth, was shown here today for the first time before the American College of Surgeons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The United States in September increased its exports to all grand divisions except southern North America, South America, Asia and Africa, compared with the corresponding month of 1934, while imports into the United States were higher from all regions except southern North America, the monthly survey of the Commerce Department showed today.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Strong approval of the United States's attitude on sanctions is expressed by the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, semi-official publication of the Foreign Office. Such warm praise, taken in conjunction with hints in the press, indicates that Germany is likely to follow Washington's example when her turn comes to reply to the League.

The status of the investigation by the American Bar Association of a complaint against the activities of the committee of lawyers sponsored by the American Liberty League in fighting New Deal legislation was clarified here yesterday by statements from William L. Ransom, president of the association, and Raoul E. Desvernine, chairman of the lawyers' committee.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Oct. 30 (AP). -- J. B. Partridge's much-improved gelding, Prince Abbot, made it four in a row today when he won the Viking Claiming Stakes, a mile and one furlong event.

PRAGUE, Oct. 30. -- The recent death of Bohumil Bradac, president of the Czechoslovak Chamber of Deputies, is having important internal political consequences. This afternoon Premier Malypetr visited President Masaryk at Lana Castle and presented a plan of the Czech Agrarian party for Cabinet reconstruction, which is said to have been approved by the government coalition.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 (AP). -- United States District Judge Edwin S. Thomas upheld today a previous ruling by a special master rejecting a New York lease held by the Cheney Brothers of Manchester, silk manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- A means of stepping up private employment and payroll indices to the level of current industrial production being actively sought by President Roosevelt, he indicated today, through a series of individual conferences with industrial leaders.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, Works Progress Administrator, released funds for a new group of projects tonight, allocating $3,470,563 to up-State district, while jobless in many sections marked time on work halted by drenching rains.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 30 (AP). -Five seaplanes and seven subchasers searched Chesapeake Bay here today for Lieutenant M. M. Marple, navy flier, after a plane, believed to have been his, plunged into the bay during a heavy fog. The search was halted at dark, but will be resumed tomorrow.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 30. -- G. R. C. Foster's Commander III, an outsider, today won the ninety-sixth running of the Cambridgeshire Stakes.
Prices fluctuated irregularly on the Cotton Exchange again yesterday, to end a point higher to 7 points lower than on Tuesday.

VIENNA, Oct. 30. -- A leaflet well printed on good paper, many thousand copies of which were circulated in Austria yesterday, suggests that the government has suffered a serious defection among its Catholic employes. These workers once saw in the late Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss and in Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg their champions.

A Halloween dinner dance and carnival in behalf of the Women's Aid Society for the Relief of Widows and Orphans took place last night In the new Belvedere Ballroom of the Astor. The funds will be used to help the destitute widows and orphans cared for by the organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- After clearing his desk of immediate business and holding a long series of conferences on foreign and domestic affairs, President Roosevelt left tonight for Hyde Park, where he planned to remain until after election day.

Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican lightweight, became one of the leading contenders for Tony Canzoneri's crown when he scored a decisive victory over Phil Rafferty last night at the New Lenox Sporting Club before 3,000 fans. Montanez weighed 135 3/4, Rafferty 140 3/4.

"The Body Beautiful," which is a comedy and has to do with a burlesque dancer who aspires to a truer -- or Carnegie Hall -- art, is, by all accounts, opening this evening at the Plymouth Theatre. Robert Rossen wrote it and Polly Walters has the leading role.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Business on the London Stock Exchange was small again today, but prices held firm and the undertone generally was good as a result of more favorable reports from abroad. Fresh support came to British funds. European securities improved after a dull opening in the foreign section of the market.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Johnny Torrio and Charles (Lucky) Luciana, notorious gangsters wanted for questioning in the murders of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Louis (Pretty) Amberg and others, have been located in Miami, Fla., but the authorities are powerless to bring them back to New York, according to a statement yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The official beginning of the "ever normal granary" plan heralded by Secretary Wallace as the one sure medium of bringing about a balanced production in agriculture, was seen by AAA officials today in an announcement that new loans of 45 cents a bushel would be made by the Commodity Credit Corporation on the 1935-36 corn supply.

Slightly more than half of the $111,700 sought for equipment and operating costs of Irvington House, which cares for cardiac children, has been raised, it was made known yesterday at a luncheon of the institution's fifteenth anniversary progress committee at the Midday Club, 25 Broad Street.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, tried to make the flesh of voters creep today by picturing the horrors that, he said, would befall Great Britain if the Labor party with its "revolutionary platform should be allowed to come to power."

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 29 (delayed). -- The Italian Army is gradually creeping closer to Makale No concerted movement has occurred, but all sectors -- the first corps in Adigrat, the native corps in Entiscio and the second corps in Adowa -- have been stretching soutHward, consolidating their positions as they go along, building roads, extending telephone lines and moving up supplies.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 30. -- A proposal that the Federal Reserve authorities take steps eliminate about onehalf or two-thirds of the $3,000,000,000 of excess bank reserves was advanced here today by Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, in an address before the convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America.
It was with interest that I read an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Oct. 25 under the caption "Our Wines Tested By Expert Taster."

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 30. -- A Bennington College campus romance between a college policeman and a student member of a Brookline family, is resulting in the marriage here next Tuesday of Miss Elizabeth D. Alford to William E. Mattison of Bennington, Vt.

Although the Actors Equity Association will not decide until a special council meeting tomorrow what it will do about the WPA theatre projects, plans for the theatres are progressing. Elmer Rice, regional director for the New York district, announced yesterday that Eddie Dowling, who will direct the division of musical comedy, circus and vaudeville, would begin casting for productions tomorrow.
The Columbia Club, winner of the 1934-35 championship among Class A teams in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League, bowed to the New York A.C. as this season's competition opened last night.

Paris, Oct. 30. -- At the moment of completing his deflation program by the issuance of an additional 300 decrees, Premier Pierre Laval today came into open conflict with the finance commission of the Chamber of Deputies over their application.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 30. -- Former Solicitor General James M. Beck, Republican State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton and Mrs. George B. Simmons, "grass rooter," called upon a county-wide rally here tonight to register militant protest against the Roosevelt Administration in the New York State election next Tuesday.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York would press for speedy trials for the twenty-two alleged loan sharks taken in his drive against the usury racket last Monday. He hopes to begin the trials in the Court of Special Sessions a week from today.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 (AP). -- The Lions, scoring touchdowns in the first and last periods, had little trouble beating the Boston Red-skins in a National Football League game tonight, 14-0. About 14,000 saw the contest.

In a gray, sullen setting of dripping skies, Columbia ran through it next to last practice in the city yesterday before leaving for Ithaca and the game there Saturday with Cornell. When the Ithaca sleeper leaves tonight at 11:30, the Blue and White squad will be aboard and this afternoon's session will be the last real one before the meeting with the up-State eleven.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP). -- A legal manoeuvre by City Counsel blocked "Tobacco Road" from presentation in Chicago tonight just as the stage was being made ready for resumption of the play which Mayor Kelly regards as obscene.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Two high officers of the French Navy, Admiral Decoux and Commandant Deleuze, arrived here tonight to work out detailed plans for helping the British fleet in the Mediterranean Sea in the event of an unprovoked attack by Italy.

George Herman Ruth yesterday issued his ultimatum to major league baseball owners. The most famous of all ball players said he would attend the Winter meetings of the major circuits in Chicago in December, when he would give the magnates their last chance to offer him a job.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 30 (AP). -- Freshmen, equipped with Ohio State plays as given to them by scouts, scored two quick touchdowns on the Notre Dame varsity today and picked up such large chunks of ground during an hour's scrimmage that the Rambler coaches were plainly worried.
Adoption by the voters of the proposed county rule amendment to the State Constitution is urged by William Church Osborn, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission.

Miss Jane Gray heads a group of debutantes interested in arrangements for the Halloween Ball in behalf of the Young Women's Committee of the Women's National Republican Club which will take place tonight at the clubhouse of the organization, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Surgeon General Hugh S. Cumming, head of the United States Public Health Service, will arrive today from Europe on the Manhattan of the United States Lines, accompanied by Mrs. Cummings. Also on the ship are Otto Wadsted, Danish Minister in Washington, and:

Henry P. Fletcher, Republican National Chairman, stressed the New Deal in a radio address last night as the issue in the campaign for the control of the New York State Assembly. Speaking over station WEAF and a State-wide network, Mr. Fletcher declared:

The Lehman committee for holders of Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation bends yesterday addressed a letter to them, setting forth its opinion as to the weakness of their position if they relied solely on the prospects of a merger to solve the company's difficulties.
ADIGRAT, Ethiopia, Oct. 29. (delayed). -- Two columns of Italian troops moved forward toward Makale in Northern Ethiopia today without encountering resistance.

Former Mayor James J. Walker, returning to New York aboard the United States liner Manhattan today after a three-year absence abroad, will be met at Quarantine by more than one hundred friends who "knew him when."
SEATTLE, Oct. 30. -- The Arctic blew a cold breath on the Far West again today, spreading unseasonable weather over wide areas.

A new issue of $5,500,000 city of Seattle (Wash.) municipal light and power 4 per cent bonds is being offered by a banking group headed by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation at prices to yield 2.50 to 4.10 per cent, according to maturity.

TOKYO, Oct. 30. -- Well-informed observers believe the correct interpretation of Japan's coordinated Chinese policy is now clear. With Europe engrossed in the Ethiopian problem the international situation is favorable for a showdown with China.
Plaintiffs bought in eleven properties in Manhattan at auction sales yesterday. Tenements and loft buildings comprised most of the properties foreclosed. The results follow:

The metropolitan racing season on Jockey Club tracks came to an end yesterday at Empire City as rain swept an enthusiastic crowd which saw the curtain fall and the victory of Warren Wright's Some Pomp in the $3,200 New Rochelle Handicap.

As announced yesterday, a thoroughgoing State-wide inquiry into the character and cost of public education is to be made under the direction of the Board of Regents of the State of New York, with Mr. OWEN D. YOUNG as its chairman. While this should be an investigation especially valuable to the State of New York, it should be of hardly less value to the school systems throughout the United States.

A hearing on the plea of the Consolidated Gas System for abolition of all submetering of electric current will be held by the Public Service Commission on Thursday, Nov. 7, Commissioner George R. Van Namee announced yesterday. Real estate interests and other opponents of the proposal will offer their testimony and cross-examine the Consolidated's witnesses.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30. --A driving rain that lasted all afternoon did not dampen the spirits of the Princeton football squad as it went through a varied and spirited two-hour drill on University Field in preparation for the meeting with Navy here Saturday.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- An official communique announced today that the German Ambassador to Great Britain had been ordered to protest an article by Winston Churchill in The Strand Magazine of London, on the ground that it attacks Chancellor Hitler in "malicious fashion."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Controller General McCarl has approved payment of another $4,000,000 for Works Progress Administration projects in six States, it was stated today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 30. -More than 100 employes of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation have been laid off, the company announced today, on the heels of a Securities and Exchange Commission order for Michael J. Meehan to show cause why he should not be suspended from the New York and other Stock Exchanges on allegations of manipulating the company's stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The Federal Power Commission sided today with Mayor La Guardia and against former Justice Joseph M. Proskauer in their dispute over the practicability from the consumer standpoint of the proposed municipal "yardstick" power plant for New York City.

Non-fiction had an easy lead over fiction in sales during the early Fall season, Baker Taylor, wholesale booksellers, report. Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "North to the Orient" has been comfortably ahead of all other books in sales, with T. E. Lawrence's "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" second.

Results of a poll of 360 members of the freshman class by The Columbia Spectator show that 260 first-year men would rather win a Phi Beta Kappa key than a varsity letter. Sixty-nine prefer the athletic award and fifteen said they expected to win both.
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The Royal London Yacht Club, through which Charles R. Fairey, commodore of the club, recently challenged for the America's Cup, today received a reply from the United States.
C. Adolph Glassgold will speak at the New School for Social Research at 4:20 o'clock this afternoon on "The Artist and the Public."

Sterling Products, Inc., reported for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, a net profit of $6,628,301, equivalent to $3.78 a share on the basis of 1,750,700 shares of stock. This compares with a net profit of $6,529,450, or $3.73 a share, for the corresponding period of last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The influence of the United States for an early peace in East Africa was thrown onto the scales today through strongly worded statements by President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull that were considered tantamount to declaring for the cessation of all American trade with Italy.
Flats and dwellings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn formed the bulk of realty sold and leased in the city yesterday.

Irregular price movements were in evidence on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Rubber, which was strong and active, was an exception. In the cash markets wheat, corn, flour, lard, tin and silk declined, Rubber and rye advanced.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 30. -- Orrin G. Wood of Estabrook Co. of Boston, was installed today as president of the Investment Bankers Association of America for 1935-36, succeeding Ralph T. Crane of Brown Harriman Co. of New York.

DAYTON, Oct. 30. -- America's biggest bombing plane crashed to earth and burst into flames today, injuring fatally Major P. P. Hill, chief of the flying branch at Wright Field, who was one of the five men it carried. The other four men were injured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- A protest against the two-year agreement concluded with Japan on Oct. 12 governing exports of cotton textiles to the Philippines was carried to Secretary Hull today by Representative Fish of New York, who contended that it was unfair to this country.

The report of the Industrial Securities Committee of the I.B.A., made public at the convention yesterday at White Sulphur Springs, touched on a subject now foremost in discussions between investment houses and those companies for which they act as bankers: namely, the offering price of a new issue and the lack of provision for an adequate sinking fund.

Mayor La Guardia and Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, joined yesterday in declaring untrue reports that the belated arrival of an ambulance from My Immaculate Hospital, in Queens, partly had been responsible for the death on Monday night of Mrs. Henrietta Thode, victim of a hitand-run driver.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Governor Lehman corrected today an error which he said he made in an address on Oct. 24 in support of the proposed constitutional amendment for reform of county and local government.

IT'S hard to break away from old habits. Even at the luncheon table Benny Friedman was doing somo kicking and making some passes. It wasn't the Michigan victory over Columbia that brought the former All-America quarterback for Michigan on a tackle slant for the table. He had something else on his mind. His first attempt was a kick from placement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The White House will be a safer place to live in, as well as a better place in which to work, when the reconstruction now in progress in the kitchen and servants' quarters is complete, Mrs. Roosevelt said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company has been cited to defend itself against a charge that it "conspired and arranged" with one of its employes to represent himself as an independent broker of meats and meat products, contrary to the Fuckers and Stockyards Act, the Agriculture Department announced today.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 30. -The Plainfield Country Club won its initial match of the Class A squash racquets division by defeating the Montclair A. C. today, 3 to 2.

Although the characters of "There's Wisdom in Women" are children of the music world they fit cozily into the theatre's ageless scheme of things. To women, one man and a faithful friend loitering hopefully around the corner, a few smashing bars of concerto music, some reasonably bawdy conversation, and there you have the pattern of a comedy by Joseph O. Kesselring, which opened at the Cort last evening.

A new move in German finance which has reduced tonnage on American ships coming out of Germany by 50 per cent was disclosed yesterday by American steamship officials who declared that Germany was trying to regulate shipping of the entire world.

One of the largest realty deals in many months in Suffolk County, involving the transfer of ownership of the well-known Sayville Golf and Country Club to a manufacturer who will develop the property into a residential centre, was reported yesterday.

The trend of stock prices was irregularly lower yesterday, save for a flurry in utility shares, notably in the lower-priced issues, during the morning. Attention was drawn to utility stocks by the record showing of the weekly electric power output figures and by the attack made on the Public Utilities Act of 1935 at the Investment Bankers Association's convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Representative Chester C. Bolton of Cleveland, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, will be designated by the Ohio State Republican Committee, meeting next week, as the State's "favorite son" for the national convention next year.

With special attention paid to protection against forward and lateral passes, Manhattan's defense was given a thorough overhauling by Coach Chick Meehan at Innisfail Park yesterday in preparation for the traditional battle with City College at Ebbets Field Saturday.

GILBERT was wrong. The policeman's lot is a happy one -- if he happens to be a member of the force which patrols the Port Authority's tunnel and bridges. People are all the time writing in to say what an admirable chap he is, so gentle, so courteous, so helpful. Listen to Mr. W. L. HARRINGTON of 11 Ridgewood Terrace, Maplewood, gratitude oozing from every pore:

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 30. -- Returning from Harar, where there is feverish activity in preparation for the expected onslaught of Premier Mussolini's modern legions, this correspondent found the Ethiopian capital basking tranquilly under brilliant skies on plateau heights remote from the war zones.

The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday that its net profit for the first nine months of this year was equivalent to $5.35 a share on its capital stock, compared with $2.17 a share in the corresponding period of last year, and declared a dividend of 75 cents a share.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The world's wheat markets developed a much stronger undertone today as the result of decreasing Argentine and Russian exports, reduced estimates on the new Argentine crop and war talk. General buying developed here and abroad, with Liverpool gaining 2 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel in American funds, while the local market and that in the Winnipeg showed at the extreme around 2 cents above yesterday's finish.

NANKING, Friday, Nov. 1 (AP). -- This correspondent witnessed the attempted assassination of Premier Wang Ching-wei today, and it will live in his memory as a scene of wildest confusion punctuated by the sharp rattle of pistol fire, which left four high officials of the Chinese Government wounded.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

DETROIT, Friday, Nov. 1. -- A series of earth tremors shook Detroit soon after 1 A.M. Telephone calls to newspapers at Grand Rapids, Escanaba and Marquette indicated the shocks were felt as far west as Lake Michigan and into the upper northern peninsula.
One came away from New York University's football practice at Ohio Field yesterday feeling that here was a group of boys who really liked to play football.

Two benefit bridge, mah-jong and backgammon parties will be given at 3 P.M., Nov. 20, by the auxiliary of Wiawaka Holiday House on Lake George, a vacation house for self-supporting women open throughout the year. One party will be at the home of Mrs. Walter B. James at 7 East Seventieth Street and the other will be at the home of Mrs. Stephen C. Clark at 40 East Seventieth Street.

Controller Frank J. Taylor issued a statement last night pointing out that the legality of reducing the bankers' reserve in the 1936 budget from $17,000,000 to $10,500,000 might be questioned, after the Board of Estimate had adopted the budget earlier in the day at a total of $545,541,842.56.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Responsibility for inspiring an inquiry by the American Bar Association into activities of the Lawyers Committee of the American Liberty League was claimed tonight by the National Support Roosevelt League, through its general counsel, Joseph L. Kaplan.

Taxes paid to the State by racing thus far this year exceed by $3,516 the total turned over by the sport for the entire racing year of 1934. This was disclosed yesterday when the Metropolitan Jockey Club reported to the State Racing Commission a tax payment of $19,000 for its Autumn meeting at Jamaica, thus increasing the 1935 total derived from racing to $288,391.

Columbia University will soon begin experiments with a new type of vaccine which may be truly effective in immunizing human beings against the common cold, Dr. Alphonse R. Dochez of the university's department of medicine announced last night at the eighth annual graduate fortnight of the Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

Analyzing another case that had passed through the office of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan, Joseph D. McGoldrick, the Republican-Fusion nominee, charged last night that a group of policy racketeers was freed because Mr. Geoghan's office had prosecuted the case under the wrong section of the Penal Law.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

An increase of more than 50 per cent in total payrolls and average weekly earnings of employes in the steel industry over September of last year was recorded last month, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. The gain was due largely to improved operations, which caused an increase in man-hours of work.
Bank clearings for the last week of October were smaller than in the preceding week, but continued above the 1934 level for the sixteenth consecutive week.

One of the last surviving examples of the old "handle-bar" mustache that used to grace the upper lips of army recruiting sergeants in the Nineties was mustered out of the service yesterday when Sargeant John A. Johanson was honorably retired on pension after his prescribed thirty years with the colors.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP). -- A fresh appeal for the United States to join the League of Nations was made today by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin.

ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas, Oct. 31 (AP). -- In the lead from the barrier to the finish line, L. Beydas's My Auntie swept to victory today in the $800 allowance race for 2-year-olds by going the five and a half furlongs in 1:08 1-5 over a slow track.

BOSTON, Friday, Nov. 1. -- A sharp earth tremor, composed of several shocks lasting more than a quarter of a minute, shook Boston this morning starting at 1:08 A.M. No damage was reported immediately, but the shocks were of sufficient force to awaken hundreds of sleeping residents, sway hanging fixtures, jar bric-a-brac loose, and within a few minutes Boston newspaper offices, police and fire officials were flooded with calls from thoroughly frightened citizens.

The novelty of the concert given by Dr. Otto Klemperer and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was Roy Harris's overture, based upon the sturdy tune, "When Johnny Comes Marching Home." The composer was present, and after the performance he bowed his acknowledgments from the stage.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Winter weather, widespread in the Far West, brought freezing temperatures into Midwest areas tonight as the cold wave rolled swiftly eastward.

On Oct. 17, in noon-time traffic on the Boston Post Road here, two automobiles came together with considerable damage to both cars and more to the feelings of the respective drivers, one a woman and the other a man, both of New York. Bernard Isaacson, the driver of one car, assumed full responsibility for the accident and put his case in the hands of the company handling his liability insurance.

New Yorkers will not need topcoats today to protect themselves from frigid temperatures moving eastward from the Far West, but they probably will need their raincoats, according to the forecast of the Weather Bureau. Cold weather is expected within the next few days, but the immediate forecast is for warmer weather, with continuing rain.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 30 (Delayed). -- The main Italian positions at Aksum, Adowa and Adigrat are unchanged, but sufficient forces are continually being advanced to protect engineers constructing new roads and to guarantee the ground occupied.

Quotations for Stock Exchange day loans and maturity money were maintained without change from the levels set on Wednesday and which broke the pegged rates in effect since last April. Call money was 3/4, all day, and time funds were offered at 1 per cent, without a bid.

Only seventeen years after the armistice, how would the people of Europe rather spend their money -- on homes or guns? The question is prompted by Mr. GORDON SELFRIDGE'S statement on housing in England, and the answer is not easy to frame.

Declaring that "America, in fact, has at last turned the corner," Major L.L.B. Angas, British economist and author and adviser to the Brookmire Economic Service, predicted yesterday that even fears of elections and foreign wars could not check "the tidal wave of recovery and prosperity," now sweeping the country.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31. -- After three days of driving scrimmages Harvard's varsity football forces today experienced an easy session. A complete rehearsal of plays, many of which will be shown for the first time against Brown, featured the workout.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Possibilities that New York State's investigation into racetrack racketeering might lead the way to similar inquiries throughout the nation were seen tonight as Attorney General Bennett said that evidence already found indicated that abuses were "national in scope."

The long period of record low money rates came to an end in October, when quotations for both call and time loans were advanced. On the New York Stock Exchange the call rate was raised from one-quarter of 1 per cent, a charge which had been in effect continually since April 18, to three-quarters of 1 per cent on Oct. 30, at which level it closed the month.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- President Roosevelt returned again to his mother's home here today for the primary purpose of voting in person in the elections next Tuesday for members of the Assembly and local officials.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The dismissal of 1,200 additional employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau was decided upon yesterday in line with the bureau's policy to reduce its administrative personnel because of the 40 per cent diminution in the home relief load through the transfer of 100,000 relief clients to WPA jobs since Aug. 1.

Doubt that any instrument existing today can prevent a new European war was expressed last night by speakers at the meeting at Town Hall, which opened the forty-second season of forums of the League for Political Education.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 31. -- Florida State College for Women today conferred on Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, America's first woman diplomat, the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws. It was the first honorary degree granted by the college in its thirty years' history.
BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- Seven prison sentences today brought home to Germans the danger that lurks in the loud-speaker when it is tuned in on Moscow.

ATLANTA, Oct. 31. -- The American Prison Association at the closing session of its annual congress here today unanimously adopted a resolution condemning the chain-gang system of Georgia and some other States as "utterly inconsistent with dictates of humanity."

An invitation Halloween supper dance was held last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis. Arrangements for the event were under the direction of Prince Serge Obolensky, Milton Holden, William Rhinelander Stewart and Lytle Hull.

Predictions of freezing weather in parts of Oklahoma and Northern Texas steadied prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. An active demand for December as mills fixed prices on raw material advanced near months, and the list ended with changes ranging from a gain of 7 to a loss of 5 points on the day.
Primo Carnera will return to the ring wars tonight.

Observing that "we must show that the law is alive and alert," Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck dismissed yesterday writs of habeas corpus that had been obtained on behalf of four of the twenty-two alleged loan sharks taken last Monday in the drive of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, against the usury racket.
BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- Operations on the Boerse were very quiet today, and prices ended slightly weaker. All transactions of any importance continued to be carried on in the outside markets.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet today, influenced by tomorrow's closing of the Paris market and the end of the account here. The undertone, though, was generally firm. Little was doing in British funds, which were irregular.

James Lacarus, 46 years old, who gave the address 230 Riverside Drive at the time of his indictment, was sentenced to a five-year Sing Sing term by General Sessions Judge Freschi yesterday for defrauding two women of a total of $17,000 under promise to marry them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today served notice that in the future it will not ratify appointments of trustees in railroad reorganizations which would give majority representation to the managements of the roads.

WARSAW, Oct. 31. -- The dissolution of the Pilsudski party, or non-party bloc in cooperation with the government, as it was officially called, was announced yesterday by its president and creator, former Premier Walery Slawek, in a farewell speech to the provincial secretaries of the organization.

With its first month showing good results, the city's campaign for less noise gets under way in earnest this morning with the police instructed to warn noise offenders during the twenty-four hours of the day.
The successful effort of Special Prosecutor Dewey in obtaining indictments against rapacious money lenders is to be commended.

The one-hour parking rule applies even in uncongested residential sections of the city; theatre zone regulations will be continued in effect, and parking laws in general are being enforced "in a practical, intelligent way," with some pressure but without "persecution."

Completing its heavy preparations for the traditional battle with City College at Ebbets Field tomorrow, Manhattan's football team went through a long defensive session against Beaver formations in rain and mud at Innisfail Park yesterday.

Former Mayor James J. Walker and his wife returned to New York yesterday aboard the United States liner Manhattan and received a welcome from several thousand old friends and admirers down the bay and at the dock.

While upholding a verdict against the city in a case arising from the Harlem riot on March 30, Justice Benjamin Shalleck in Municipal Court warned yesterday that the law permitting suits for damages caused by mobs must be modified to prevent abuses.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Head Coach Ducky Pond extended Yale's practice to a full-length scrimmage today after the coaches had planned a decided let-down from the terrific scrimmages of the last two days. It was the last contact work before the Dartmouth game Saturday.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31. -- The St. Louis Grand Opera Company opened its Autumn season here tonight with a production of Puccini's "Turandot" in the new convention hall of the Municipal Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission gave its approval today to an extension of a $203,419 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway Company, due on Nov. 4, until May 28, 1936.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- For the first time the British dominions are to be directly represented by their own spokesmen in a conference of great naval powers. It is officially announced that Australia, New Zealand and South Africa have expressed a desire to be represented by their own high commissioners at the forthcoming naval conference in London.
