WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Duties collected on imports from Cuba under the reciprocal trade agreement jumped 40.3 per cent in the first year after the agreement was put into effect, despite the fact that tariff rates were reduced by the pact, the Bureau of Customs Announced today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 31. -- Mrs. Edward Browning gave a luncheon on the Casino lawn today honoring Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Fish and Mrs. G. Edward Atherton. In other luncheon groups were Franklin U. Gregory and John K. Kenna.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- What the Archbishop of Canterbury characterized as a "remarkable demonstration of national unity" on the Italo-Ethiopian war was evidenced tonight at a mass meeting of the League of Nations Union in Albert Hall, which was addressed by Sir Austen Chamberlain, Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, the Archbishop and others.

The way was cleared for early advancement of the city's 1939 world's fair project yesterday when Vernon S. Moon, acting chief engineer of the Board of Estimate, submitted a report conditionally recommending the proposed condemnation of 392 acres of park and parkway lands in the Flushing Meadows, Queens, for the fair site.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 31. -- An earthquake again cracked and toppled buildings here today, driving the people into the streets in terror, causing the evacuation of hospitals where many injured in the earthquake of Oct. 18 were patients, and with two more men crushed to death brought to seven the toll of fatalities in the series of more than 550 shocks since Oct. 12.
New issues of securities offered publicly here in October were more numerous than in September but their face values, in the aggregate, was smaller.

While New York gunners were jubilant yesterday over the slight rainfall, which came on the eve of the opening of the deer season today in the southern counties and the start of the upland shooting in Long Island, Connecticut's nimrods were experiencing pangs of bitter disappointment as the ban on hunting remained in force.

" Stick in the Mud" can be jotted down for Monday, Nov. 25, at a theatre to be announced later, and Betty Lancaster, Clare Woodbury and Geoffrey Bryant have been added to its cast.... B. Franklin Kamsler is expected to arrive next Tuesday from London.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- A medically authenticated case of paternity at the age of 94 years was reported today by The Journal of the American Medical Association, but another authority stated that it was far from setting a record.

Justices Thomas J. Nolan and James J. McInerney in Special Sessions yesterday, with Presiding Justice Frederick L. Hackenburg dissenting, declared Jim Tully's book "Ladies of the Parlor" objectionable, and fined Greenberg Publisher, Inc., of 449 Fourth Avenue, $50 for printing it.

Captain Liddell Hart, British commentator on military affairs, has sent to Dodd, Mead the final section to be added to his "Colonel Lawrence: The Man Behind the Legend," in which he tells what is described by the publishers as the "actual" story of Lawrence's death, and attempts an appraisal of his position among British leaders.

By his exchange of letters with Vice Chairman MANLY of the Federal Power Commission Mayor LA GUARDIA may have inadvertently done the utilities a good turn. In the course of his debate the other night on the "yardstick" power plant with ex-Justice PROSKAUER he had received about the rudest shock an earnest advocate of Government ownership could suffer.

PARIS, Oct. 31. -- The services of almost every department of the government and a large emergency staff at the office of the Journal Officiel worked at top speed all day preparing the greatest single avalanche of legislation to which any country has ever yet been subjected.

Sylvester Lancaric, 17 years old, a six-foot-tall former altar boy, testified yesterday in his own defense at his trial in General Sessions on a second-degree manslaughter indictment. He is accused of having caused the death of his 3- year-old brother, John, on May 26, by a beating seventeen days before in their home at 75 East 106th Street.

An important deal involving a change in ownership of a large hotel in the Times Square district was a feature of the real estate market news yesterday. A syndicate of investors represented by Max Dorff was reported to have taken the twenty-six-story Hotel Piccadilly, at 227 West Forty-fifth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

The program of Sergei Rachmaninoff'a piano recital at Carnegie Hall tomorrow afternoon, not announced hitherto, includes Beethoven's thirty-two variations in C minor and compositions by Scarlatti, Chopin, Schumann, Schubert-Rachmaninoff, Mendelssohn-Rachmantnoff, Rachmantnoff, Wagner-Liszt and Wagner-Brassin.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Broadsilk workers quit the mills here today in answer to the strike call of the American Federation of Silk Workers and with very little disorder tied up the plain goods branch of the industry. The only estimates as to the number who had gone out were those provided at union headquarters.

The criminal usurer has always been held in general contempt and has been prosecuted when possible, but only a few people familiar with compound interest and geometric progression realize what a parasite he is and can be.

Contending that the question of trade with Italy at present is largely an academic one for the majority exporters, men engaged in foreign trade here withheld formal comment yesterday on President Roosevelt's request for cessation of all trade with Italy and Ethiopia.

The chairs which have stood in the balcony and family circle of the Metropolitan Opera House for more than half a century will go on sale this morning to the highest bidder. New seats are to be installed next week, and the renovators have contrived to realize a little money from the old chairs.
HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, charged tonight that the New Deal's "excessive taxes cannot help but strike serious blows at industry."
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31 (AP). -- John Henry Lewis, Phoenix, Ariz., Negro, outpointed champion Bob Olin, New York, to win the world's light heavyweight title tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Reports were transmitted by the Treasury to the State Department today showing considerable increases in American exports of cotton and oil to Italy this month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Wholesale prices declined slightly during the week ended on Oct. 26, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 averages, dropped from 80.7 on Oct. 19 to 80.3 A year ago it was 76.2.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 31. -- An attempt to obtain a Supreme Court order blocking government collection tomorrow of the 15 per cent mine tax on coal failed today when an application to Chief Justice Hughes for an immediate temporary restraining order went over to the full court. It cannot now be heard before Nov. 11.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation sold bonds of the Tennessee Publishing Company to Paul Davis, president of the American National Bank of Nashville, and brother of Norman Davis, the administration's Ambassador at Large, because he offered $50,000 more than James Hammond, publisher of the Memphis Commercial Appeal, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, said today.

Maintaining a steady tone throughout the day, the share market completed yesterday its seventh consecutive month of advancing prices and one wherein the gain was the widest since July. Although trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange dropped below the 2,000,000-share mark, the market at times was called upon to absorb not a little profit-taking and did so without much variation in prices.

Bonds held steady to firm on the New York Stock Exchange in another listless trading session yesterday. Only a few individual issues broke out of the narrow price range. Transactions amounted to $9,020,700, as compared with $9,413,000 on Wednesday.

Dr. Irving N. Rattner, reported to be the author of an eight-point program designed to rid City College of radicals and Communists, has denied that the City College Post of the American Legion intends to start a Legion club in the college to fight communism, President Frederick B. Robinson said yesterday.

A nation-wide tendency among schools and colleges to diagnose the needs of students and then to fit education to their individual abilities was noted yesterday in addresses at a conference of educators in the Hotel Roosevelt.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 31. -- Many dinner parties marked Halloween at the annual dinner dance tonight in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier. Corn stalks and Autumn leaves covered the Georgian columns and ceiling and pumpkins lined the dance floor.

Westchester and the Bronx are the scenes of final preparations today for one of the most interestling games New York has had this season, the visit to the Polo Grounds of Pittsburgh for its battle with Fordham. The Panthers will remain in Westchester until just before game time tomorrow, staying at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, where so many visiting football teams have made their quarters in recent years.

The New York Giants and Chicago Bears are going to be turned loose against each other at the Polo Grounds Sunday, and the prospect is that the largest local crowd of the professional season will rally around for as wide open a game of football as will be on view in town all Fall.

PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Nov. 1. -- Two earth shocks, varying from one to four minutes in duration, were felt in parts of Eastern Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware early today. The first came about 1:05 o'clock and the second five minutes later.
The memory of Mark Twain will be honored today throughout the country in celebrations commemorating the 100th anniversary of his birth.

All Saints' Day will be widely observed today, especially in the Roman Catholic and Protestant Episcopal Churches. All Souls' Day will he observed tomorrow. Although this is Friday there will be neither fast nor abstinence for Catholics as it is a holy day of obligation. Yesterday, the vigil of the Feast of All Saints, was a fast day.

Assertions that Trinity Church is selling "phoney cards" which garble a letter of George Washington making it appear to be a prayer were made before the Appellate Division yesterday by the Free Thinkers Society of America in its appeal from a decision by Supreme Court Justice Shientag, who dismissed its suit for an injunction to restrain the church from selling the cards at 10 cents each.

TIENTSIN, China, Friday, Nov. 1. -- Although a formal reply from the Chinese authorities is expected within a few days by the Japanese consular and military leaders in North China to the demands made by them Tuesday for suppression of anti-Japanese activities, a considerable time is likely to elapse before North China becomes quiet.

Bids will be considered on Nov. 20 by officials of Grand Forks, N.D., for a new issue of $331,000 municipal light and power bonds dated Nov. 1, 1935, and maturing serially from 1937 to 1954. Bidders are asked to name an interest rate not exceeding 4 per cent.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 31. -- Today's war news places an entirely new face on the Italian strategy. The Ethiopian General Staff is now facing the necessity of formulating new plans to meet the exigency indicated in reports that the Italians will advance across the terrible Danakil Desert.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The Royal London Yacht Club today answered the New York Yacht Club's reply to the former's challenge on behalf of its commodore, C.R. Fairey, for an America's Cup series with Class K craft.

The city's hotels reported the arrival yesterday of large numbers of visitors from out of town for the annual automobile show, which will open at Grand Central Palace tomorrow afternoon. Several special trains and airplanes will bring more travelers today.

A deal in the midtown section near Fifth Avenue yesterday involved the twelve-story loft and office building at 1 West Thirty-seventh Street which was sold by the Riverside Drive Corporation, controlled by Max Rosenfeld, Joseph Schwartz and Isadore B. Geller, operators.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 31. -- An elisor grand Jury of Union County investigating the fatal shooting last Sept. 26 of Mrs. Sophie Crempa in a raid on her Scotch Plains farm by deputy sheriffs trying to serve a contempt of court order on the Crempas returned six indictments to Judge McGrath in Quarter Sessions Court here today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 31. -- A "constructive punishment" imposed on three 16-year-old high school boys for violation of the motor vehicle laws was rescinded today by Recorder Thomas B. Kaveny. He sentenced the youths last Monday to attend automobile mechanics classes in the Essex County Vocational School at Bloomfield twice weekly for a year, and to work on the cars in the Montclair police garage every Saturday afternoon for a year.

Broadway's devotion to the philosophy of art has produced the second of the season's dramas about the strip artistes of the burlesque stage, "The Body Beautiful," which was acted at the Plymouth last evening. In comparison with "Strip Girl," the new research work into hanky-panky is practically literate, for Robert Rossen has indulged himself in a funny idea.
Columbia brought its Fall rowing season to a close yesterday with the annual regatta for the Bangs Cup on the Harlem.
PARIS, Oct. 31 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 31 (AP). -- The Brookmeade Stable's Special Agent, a well thought of horse in 1934, finally won a race this season when he led an inferior lot of routers in the fifth event today at Narragansett Park.
" Hands Across the Table," with Carole Lombard and Fred MacMurray, will open today at the Paramount.

John Sloan, one of the three members of the New York State Racing Commission, last night challenged the chairman, Herbert Bayard Swope, on future policies and declared the turf public needed more protection from gangsters or other objectionable elements frequenting the race tracks.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocks for which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

Reflecting the eagerness of Democratic leaders for their party's continued control of the Assembly in President Roosevelt's home State, Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic national and State committees, is sending out 284,000 letters to voters in all parts of New York State, it became known yesterday.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- The women's squash racquets team of the Ardsley Country Club swept seven contests in short order on its home courts today, defeating the Greenwich Country Club in the first of the Westchester Class A interclub series.
Earth tremors lasting from a few seconds to several minutes shook a vast section of the North American Continent at 1:05 o'clock this morning, alarming millions of persons.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- While the campaign guesses of a political opponent cannot be taken as authoritative a charge made tonight by H.B. Lees-Smith concerning the government's secret naval policy has an uncanny resemblance to what many leading Conservatives want to achieve in this line after getting an election mandate for another four years of power.

Detailed plans for an overhead approach rising above the new elevated tracks of the New York Central Railroad at Thirty-fourth Street to connect with the West Side Elevated Highway have been presented to Borough President Levy by the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association with the backing of many merchants and property owners in that districts, it was learned yesterday.

By the statement that it is no longer possible to assume without question a rosy future for higher education in America, Chancellor CHASE of New York University prepares his annual readers for the serious problems which universities and colleges are facing in these times both in finance and freedom.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 31. -- Although a pawn ahead at the time of adjournment tonight in the thirteenth game of the chess championship match at the Hotel Carlton, Dr. Max Euwe of this city, challenger for the title held by Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, was not certain that this slight material advantage will eventually lead to a victory.

The Works Progress Administration circus opened last night at the 212th Armory, Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue, just a few minutes late. Mayor La Guardia had intended to be present and so Andre Dumont, black-mustached, silk-hatted master of ceremonies, waited for him.

Dr. Simon Flexner of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research believes that no adequate evidence exists to support the claim that vaccines developed by Dr. John A. Kolmer of Temple University and by Dr. Maurice Brodie of New York University and Dr. William H. Park of the New York City Department of Health are effective agents against infantile paralysis.

Conditions are ripe for good business in this country for a long time to come, provided the public's confidence is maintained, Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday in issuing the company's quarterly report.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October was the heaviest of any month since February, 1934, when sales amounted to 56, 834,010 shares. The heaviest day's trading of the year, and since July 26, 1934, occurred on Oct. 21, when the total was 2,872,108 shares.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 30, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,477,000,000, a decrease of $8,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $22,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Has a private citizen the right to express disagreement with a decision of the Supreme Court? Has he the right to say whether, in his opinion, a law is constitutional or unconstitutional? If he has either of these rights, does he lose them if he becomes either an officeholder or a lawyer?

The Class A teams of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League opened their campaign last night, with the Princeton, Harvard, Downtown and University Clubs winning the inaugural matches, each by the same margin of 4 to 1.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Flood waters from the Chenango Valley poured into the Susquehanna River here tonight, leaving in their wake damaged highways and considerable property loss in Norwich and Oxford.

Although the New York police say they lack sufficient evidence to extradite Charles (Lucky) Luciana from Miami for questioning about the killing of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and Louis (Pretty) Amberg, District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx announced yesterday that he had information linking Schultz's gangland rival to three other murders in the policy racket.

In a pamphlet printed in blue on white paper decorated with a red and blue shield, the American Olympic Committee set forth yesterday a number of reasons for participating in the Olympics in Germany this year.
Following is the complete statement issued last night by John Sloan, member of the New York Racing Commission.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- Objection by Miss Ruth Nichols to "embellishing this story with hospital pictures" today prompted Coroner Walter E. Healey to postpone a public inquest into the recent plane crash in which she was gravely injured and Captain Harry Hublitz, pilot, was killed.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 31. -- Controller Morris S. Tremaine told a Democratic meeting here tonight that the State budget would soon be balanced without need of additional taxes.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP). -- A current reduction in the nation's traffic death toll was credited today by the National Safety Council to the efforts of municipal governments and newspapers.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System surpassed $3,000,000,000 this week for the first time on record. The weekly report of the system as of last Wednesday, issued yesterday, showed member-bank reserve balances at a new high level of $5,653,000,000, up $78,000,000 in the last week, and said that of this amount $3,010,000,000 was in excess of legal requirements. This compared with an excess of $2,930,000,000 the week before.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Two Federal courts have decided in effect that they have no business interfering with business when business is good.

The Engineers Public Service Company reported yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $1,065,705, after all prior deductions, against $865,617 in the preceding year. Gross earnings were $44,615,385, against $43,162,331, and net earnings were $18,203,188, against $17,962,027.

DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 31. -- This afternoon, as Henry Ford and Edsel Ford, president of the Ford Motor Company, looked on, a black sedan came down the assembly line. It looked like all other cars of its model. But under its hood was engine No. 2,336,770. It was the 1,000,000th Ford unit made in the United States since Jan. 1, this year.

The last time New York and environs were shaken by an earthquake was April 30, 1925, when at 9:23 1/2 P.M. a widely felt tremor rocked furniture, shook pictures from walls and generally caused citizens considerable worry for a time. There was no damage. An earth tremor, barely perceptible, was recorded Nov. 18, 1929.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Like a fever that goes up and down, Anglo-Italian tension, which had subsided recently, was rising again tonight because of the stiff conditions that Britain continues to lay down for the withdrawal of any of her warships from the Mediterranean.

If it only were workable, the suggestion of Miss 'Elizabeth F. O'Neal. to prohibit By law the manufacture of automobiles that can run faster than a stated speed would be a fine way to reduce accidents. However, the enforcement of such a prohibition would mean another set of officials to be paid and also would invite ingenuity in getting around such a provision.

Net income of the Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the three months ended on Sept. 30 was reported yesterday as $2,435,106 after expenses, intangible development costs, depletion and lease amortization, depreciation, interest, estimated provision for Federal and State income taxes and minority interest. This was equivalent to 51 cents a share on 4,738,593 shares of $5 par capital stock outstanding.

The Rev. Joseph Lynch, director of the Earthquake Laboratory at Fordham University, said last night a preliminary examination of the seismograph there showed that this city had had two instantaneous shocks. The first occurred at 1:05:50 A.M. and the second at 1:06:46 A.M.
The third successive week of decline carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices down to 128.3 on Tuesday from 129.1 the Tuesday previous.

Neither Woodmere Academy nor unfavorable playing conditions could keep the unbeaten football team of the Barnard School for Boys from extending its winning streak at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday and the Long Islanders consequently went down to defeat by a 12-to-0 count.

Central Park's new formal flower garden on the site of the old green-houses at 105th Street and Fifth Avenue is beginning to fake shape, and if the weather is sufficiently mild to permit work to continue through most of the Winter the Park Department expects to open it early next Summer.

The Cunard White Sar Line announced the sailing date of the new superliner Queen Mary yesterday. The liner, now being outfitted in the Clyde, will leave Southampton on May 27 on her maiden voyage and reach New York on June 1, remaining in port until June 5, when she sails on her first eastward passage.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 31. -- An Italian mixed force of 15,000 Italians and Askaris are advancing westward from their old positions south of Mussa Ali, near the French Somaliland border, with extra tanks and field artillery drawn from Monghella.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- Dr. Walter B. Coffey and Dr. John D. Humber, San Francisco physicians, presented before a clinical conference of the American College of Surgeons today a review of the first five years of their research into the effect of an adrenal gland substance in the treatment of cancer.
GENEVA, Oct. 31. -- The Coordination Committee of the League of Nations resumed its sessions here tonight with sails set for applying sanctions against the Italian Government by mid-November.

The State Insurance Department has requested the Attorney General to seek from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court a determination of the right of the Investors Syndicate Title and Guaranty Company to sell a new form of mortgage certificate containing a repurchase agreement, Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP). -- Secretary Ickes released today $1,800,000 in PWA funds for a New Orleans sewerage project previously held up by a controversy over a State law which he held gave the State jurisdiction over some PWA projects.

Increased returns to shareholders, in the forms of extra disbursements and payments against accumulated arrearages, swelled the total of dividends declared in October to the highest figure for that month since 1931. Directors ordered $166,625,453 in dividends for stockholders in 757 companies last month, compared with $148,083,806 for 624 corporations in October, 1934.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Bitter municipal election campaigns in 365 cities and towns of England and Wales reach a vote tomorrow. The result is expected to provide a pointer to the outcome of the general elections of Nov. 14.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31. -- Threatening to become a political issue of nation-wide significance, the lawsuit brought against the Chilean Electric Company by the Fiscal Defense Council on behalf of the government for alleged non-compliance with the laws regulating purchase and exportation of foreign currencies is agitating Congress sessions, party assemblies and public meetings.

The first action to be brought in this district under the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act got under way yesterday in the United States Customs Court, 201 Varick Street, when Dean Charles E. Clark of the Yale University Law School, sitting as a special master for the National Labor Relations Board, began to take testimony on charges involving the United Fruit Company.
Firm changes in several financial organizations were announced yesterday by the following companies:
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 31. -- The first Federal slum clearance and housing project in New Jersey got under way on the north side here this afternoon with a premature blast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Fears that a wide rate war, precipitated by the reported acceptance of certain steamship lines of the German "aski" marks and the resignation of the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation from the North Atlantic Continental freight conference, were felt here today, following receipt of the resignation at the offices of the Shipping Board Bureau.

Subject to the approval of the Controller General of the United States, all new business in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange for the account of the manager of the government's cotton pool will be given to Paine, Webber Co. for distribution among the members of the New York Cotton Exchange Clearing Association, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Robert J. Woods of Paine, Webber Co.

After going through a workout yesterday at Baker Field, Columbia's football squad entrained last night for Ithaca, where it will meet Cornell tomorrow in the twenty-third contest between the institutions since 1889.

War rations in Italy are not the only evidence that the Italian Government finds its position in the foreign exchange market increasingly difficult. Other recent developments have pointed in the same direction. Italian newspapers have been restricted to six pages, plainly in order to conserve for the purchase of essential war materials foreign exchange which would otherwise be spent for newsprint.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The budget is a sensitive subject at the White House, and now that it draws nearer as a campaign issue the President is showing even greater determination than in previous years not to exchange quidnuncs about the budget with the press.

William F.X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, told Brooklyn audiences last night of the break-up of a borough arson ring through the conviction of twenty-six persons by members of his staff. He said the drive had resulted in the saving of more than $5,000,000 in fire losses in the last two years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Two actions connected with the move of the New York, New Haven Hartford to reorganize itself under the Federal Bankruptcy Act were taken today in the United States District Court here.

Large bank depositors, such as States and municipalities, are showing a tendency to hold part of their funds in the form of cash, rather than in deposits, in view of the fact that they no longer obtain interest on demand deposits and are unable to arrange for the acceptance of the funds as time deposits, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in its current monthly review, issued yesterday.

The City of Detroit will redeem $74,000 of 4 1/2 per cent and 5 1/2 per cent water refunding bonds through the Bankers Trust Company here and the National Bank of Detroit and the City Treasurer of Detroit.

This evening at 8:30 the Brooklyn Museum will open, with a reception and private view, two new exhibitions, both of which may be seen by the public beginning tomorrow. They will be current through November.

The Hamburg-American liner New York will arrive today from Hamburg, Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg. Among the passengers is Shepard Morgan, vice president of the Chase National Bank, and Mrs. Morgan, and Rear Admiral Robert Witthoeft, German Naval Attache at the Embassy in Washington. Others on the New York's list are:
NANKING, China, Friday, Nov. 1. -- A Chinese assassin shot Premier Wang Ching-wei and three other officials today and was shot and killed a few moments later in the resulting confusion.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Assailing the spending policies of the administration, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt charged tonight before a Republican rally here that President Roosevelt was trying to fool the American people into thinking that they would not have to "pay the bill."

Notwithstanding the upswing in the main body of stocks, several less fortunate issues continue in a bear market. New low prices for the purpose of margin computation were reached by thirty such issues on the Stock Exchange in October, compared with twenty-six in September and the same number in August.

Price movements of commodity futures were irregular and dull in the local Exchanges yesterday. In the cash markets, gains occurred in wheat, corn, rye, dairy products, tin and cocoa, while oats, flour, silk and rubber were easier.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- For the second day in a row, Princeton's football squad worked out in a driving rain, running through a two-hour varied drill in preparation for Saturday's encounter with Navy. Despite the inclement weather, the players showed great enthusiasm.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31 (AP). -- The condition of Frank Foster, elderly, diminutive janitor of an exclusive Harvard dormitory, who was beaten Saturday night when he tried to quiet unruly students, continued precarious tonight.

Oscar W. Ehrhorn, who was appointed a special master to hear testimony in bankruptcy proceedings brought against Bertram Coles Neidecker and his brother, George W. Neidecker, Paris bankers of American birth, filed a report yesterday in Federal court.

ROME, Oct. 31. -- Following a speech by Premier Benito Mussolini at the inauguration of Rome University's new centre this morning, in which he again affirmed in forceful terms Italy's determination to resist international pressure by all means in her power, the growing public sentiment against Great Britain for the leading part she has played in the application of sanctions at last boiled over.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The demand for British steel has been so insistent lately that actual shortage is in prospect, according to The Financial News. The position is clearly indicated, it says, by the fact, hitherto undisclosed, that in addition to amounts permitted to enter Britain under cartel arrangements the British Iron and Steel Federation has just purchased a large quantity of semi-finished foreign steel, presumably from Belgium.

Senator Guglielmo Marconi, the father of radio, last evening broadcast an address to the United States on "The Italo-Ethiopian Conflict." He spoke over a National Broadcasting Company network by a short-wave relay from Rome.

PARIS, Oct. 31 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- At the peace conference at Versailles, Dr. Levi, representing French Jewry on the committee of Jewish delegations, took a vigorous stand against Palestine as a Jewish national home.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 31. -- Lowering skies, and a feature riddled by scratches, flailed to dim the Maryland Jockey Club's opening today at Pimlico, where many society folk turned out with thousands of racing followers to see the victory of Mrs. T.E. Proctor II's Chatmoss in the inaugural running of the Timonium Stakes.

In an address at a luncheon at the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue, yesterday, Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, American member of the International Olympic Committee, condemned opposition to participation in the games by the United States and expressed surprise at the reception of his own attitude toward the games.
On the threshold of its first climax game of the season, Fordham's eleven put the finishing touches on its defense yesterday for the invasion of Pitt warriors at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.
Twenty contract bridge teams-of-four started play at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night for the Sir Derrick Wernher Trophy for the metropolitan team championship of the American Bridge League.

Mrs. Alfred E. Ommen gave a luncheon yesterday in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Stanley Buck of Philadelphia, Mrs. Howard Spencer, Mrs. John Cochran, Mrs. Leonard Hill, Mrs. Frederick Dallard, Mrs. Alfred Snedeker, Mrs. Hallett Caldwell, Mrs. Howard Albro, Mrs. Florence Mulford, Mrs. George R. Westerfield, Mrs. Alfred Haustetter, Mrs. Justin Uffinger and Miss Blanche Spadone.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Securities issued by the same foreign issuer for or resulting from a modification of any shares of capital stock now registered temporarily on national Securities Exchanges, will have until March 1, 1936, to obtain permanent registration, the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Prices of hogs continued on the downgrade here today. Some sales were off 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday and as much as $3 below the high point of the season in August.
Three foreign teams entered in the international jumping competitions at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden next week arrived in New York yesterday in three different ships.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 31. -- Ethiopian military circles discussed today unofficial and wholly unsubstantiated reports of a fierce and bloody battle yesterday near Makale. These reports said Ethiopians attacked in the darkness, annihilating several thousand Italians and that the Ethiopians suffered 3,000 casualties.

Brokers and renting agents added new names to the tenant rosters of apartment houses on the East and West Sides yesterday. Other apartment leasing activity extended to Greenwich Village, the Chelsea section and the upper West Side.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- A recital of the efforts of Albert F. Coyle of the Cuban Bondholders Protective Committee, organized in July, 1934, to collect $40,000,000 of Cuban bonds held by American investors and now in default, to bring United States Senators into its operating organization was a feature of today's foreign bond hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Under the stress of continued alarms for the safety of the currency, the Chinese exchanges declined again yesterday. The Shanghai dollar dropped 30 points to a new low for the year of 31.50 cents and the Hongkong dollar declined 1.40 cents to 44.70 cents.

The east unit of the twenty-two-story Victoria Hotel, at the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-first, is to be operated as a self-contained transient hotel, according to plans filed yesterday by Robert T. Lyons, architect, for the State Mortgage Commission.

An award of $1,095,000 was made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin to the owners of property condemned by the city for the erection of a group of model low rental apartment buildings in Harlem. The owners asked $2,284,753 while the city experts put a value of $678,600 on the four blocks of land bounded by West 153d Street, Seventh Avenue, West 152d Street, McComb's Place and the Harlem River.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- The Propaganda Ministry issued an official statement today denying it had decreed the removal of the names of Jewish dead from war monuments and memorial tablets. Intimations to that effect in the foreign press are denounced as lies.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York.

Miss Ida Louise Tobey, dibutante daughter of Mrs. H. Carlton Tobel,. gave a dinner last night at Sherry's for iss Audrey Thomas of Providence, R. I., who will be introduced to society next month. The other guests were fiss Jean Erb, liss Julia Booth, Robert I7. Gardner, Edward Wilson, Frederick Post, George Malcolm and Edward Post.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- The recent abrupt drop here in prices for hogs resulted in farmers curtailing loading and with much smaller offerings today prices advanced 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight. However, the demand was not aggressive, most of the receipts being taken by smaller packers, the large operators holding off in anticipation of heavy arrivals and lower prices next week.

While freezing weather failed to penetrate the Cotton Belt, temperatures in the 20s were predicted for last night, and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended unchanged to 6 points lower yesterday after holding within the narrowest range in some time.
BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Nov. 1 (AP). -- New York State's Anti-Racket Bureau and the State Racing Commission joined today in mapping a vigorous campaign to rid race tracks of racketeering.

Frederick I. Daniels, newly appointed head of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, will confer with Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, in Washington, D.C., the middle of next week on the possible continuance of direct relief by the Federal Government if the WPA should not absorb its quota of 396,000 relief workers in this State.

A net income of $511,987 was earned by the Radio Corporation of America for the third quarter of 1935, according to a statement issued yesterday by David Sarnoff, president. This is equal to 10.5 cents a share on 767,275 Class B preferred shares after Class A preferred dividends for the period, and compares with $406.190, or 82 cents a share on 495,597 Class A preferred shares, in the 1934 period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Registration statements for issuance of securities valued at $399,705,270 were filed in October under the Securities Act of 1933, bringing the total for the first nine months of the year to $2,619,689,389, a compilation by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.

MELTON MOWBRAY, England, Nov. 1 (AP). -- James Cameron Clark, millionaire American sportsman, was injured seriously while hunting with the Quorn near Wysall, Nottinghamshire, today. Mr. Clark, heir to a thread fortune, was thrown heavily when his horse struck the top bar of a timber fence.

The football spotlight radiates around the country today, with sectional titles hanging in the balance in important games on almost every front and the thin line of unbeaten teams drawn up against bristling opposition that threatens to make heavy inroads in their depleted ranks.

SECAUCUS, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Alma Hering, 11 years old, and her 7-year-old sister, Vivian, were expelled from Lincoln School here tonight by the Board of Education as the result of their refusal, on religious grounds, to salute the American flag.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 1. -- The Pennsylvania and Michigan football teams both are ready for tomorrow's game, with Penn having one of the best teams it has had in several years. Coach Harvey Harman is considerably concerned, however, over the psychology resulting from the fact that his team is to meet a Big Ten rival, above all, Michigan.
Primo Carnera weighed 268 pounds and Walter Neusel 201 for the bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Arthur Donovan was the referee and Bill Healy and Billy Joh the judges.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP). -- The Princeton Alumni Weekly, in an editorial in its current issue, today unloosed a blast at the university athletic authorities for scheduling football games with Army for 1938 and 1940 as well as arranging other "big-time" games.

Manhattan and City College, traditional metropolitan football rivals, will meet for the eleventh time at Ebbets Field this afternoon. While the Jaspers hold the edge in the series, which began in 1925, with five victories to two, three games having ended in ties, all the contests have been hard fought and interesting.

The financial district, or rather that section of it that has been interested in local transit securities for many years, was inclined yesterday to regard the plan for inclusion of Interborough and Manhattan Railway properties in general unification as fairly good.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer paid $9,000 a month for protection from police interference with his rackets during the three months preceding his death in Newark last week, it was reported there yesterday. Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld of Essex County, who began the presentation of evidence in the Schultz murder to the grand jury yesterday, refused to affirm or deny that he would lay information about these payments before the grand jury.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Monroe County can start national repudiation of the New Deal, F. Trubee Davison told Republicans at a rally here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- The October grand jury, in a special presentment tonight, accused City Controller S. Davis Wilson, Republican nominee for Mayor, of employing "for political purposes" part of a fund of $65,000 appropriated to him for use in conducting a revaluation survey of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company properties.

The big adventure of Charles G. Barnes, 15 years old, and Lawrence Van Doren, 14, intrepid wanderers from Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, N.H., since Oct. 25, ended yesterday in New York and Newark, respectively, as they again came under family jurisdiction.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- Confusion as to whether the Nazi party means to enlist in its Foreign Section foreign citizens of German origin or only German citizens living abroad reappeared yesterday in a short-wave broadcast by Dr. Ehrich, "personal counselor" of the leader of the party's foreign section, Dr. Ernst Wilhelm Boble.

Striking with a fury along the ground and in the air, the undefeated Fordham Prep football machine crushed McBurney School under a barrage of touchdowns in recording a 53-6 triumph yesterday on its home gridiron. Although half of the contest was played during intermittent showers, the winners displayed a smooth working eleven.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Another step in the drive by the Department of Agriculture on racketeering in the live poultry markets was taken today when Secretary Wallace designated Newark a live poultry market subject to Federal supervision and thus required all dealers and handlers of live poultry in interstate commerce there to be licensed by the department under the Packers and Stockyards Act.
Among the prominent persons leaving today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte Di Savoia are:
Operators and investors were active yesterday in the selling and buying of housing properties in Manhattan. Plans for remodeling were announced in connection with some of the deals.

In your editorial of Oct. 26, 1935, entitled "Neutrality in Reverse," you say "the failure to embargo the raw materials for war-making -- food, cotton, chemicals, metals and oils -- will certainly strengthen Italy to pursue the war"; and you further state that the President has power to impose such an embargo under the recent Neutrality Act as to "implements of war."

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The London Stock Exchange broke with tradition today by opening on All Saints Day, but the members did not find much to occupy their time apart from preliminary arrangements for the carry-over to Monday. The undertone, however, remained generally firm.

Purchase of the combined rapid transit properties of the B.M.T., the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company by the city for a gross price of $430,751,000 and a net cost of $416,861,000 was recommended in a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate yesterday by Samuel Seabury and A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- T.S. Eliot's drama of Thomas a Becket, "Murder in the Cathedral," first presented at the Canterbury Chapter House last Summer, has now been produced by Ashley Dukes in his tiny Mercury Theatre. The Times of London reviewer writes as follows:

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- German formally resumed her place as one of the world's biggest military powers today when the first class of recruits drafted under her new universal conscription law reported to the colors.

With the numerous restrictions placed on the shooting of migratory waterfowl this year, it was to be expected that gunners would find some of the regulations confusing. The expectations were more than realized, for the offices of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey were deluged with inquiries from all parts of the country.

A total of $46,756,000 in new bond issues was offered to the public this week, reflecting a moderate decrease in activity in the new issue market from last week, when an aggregate of $61,782,088 reached the market. This week's bond financing, however, maintained a substantial margin over the corresponding period of last year, when a total of $25,963,000 was offered.

Mayor La Guardia extended the city's welcome yesterday to a group of European physicians who arrived Thursday to study public health in the United States under the auspices of the League of Nations. In addressing the six physicians the Mayor praised their mission in high terms.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

HARAR, Nov. 1. -- The Ethiopian war spirit, combined with ancient Christianity and a deep African superstition, is generating miraculous legends reminding one of the Angel of Mons and similar marvels of the World War. Two visions are vouched for by the troops hurrying past here toward the expected battle in the south.

A painting by the French artist Jean Jacques Henner led the bidding last night at an auction sale of American and French paintings at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., and finally was knocked down at the evening's highest price of $4,600.

Next Tuesday's elections to the Board of Aldermen will be the most important in many years. It is not merely a question of sending anti-Tammany men to City Hall in sufficient numbers to give effective support to Mayor LA GUARDIA and the Fusion administration, though that is highly important.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Princeton's undefeated football team will oppose the Navy in Palmer Stadium tomorrow afternoon in a crucial midseason contest. Smarting from successive defeats at the hands of Yale and Notre Dame, Navy will enter the contest determined to knock the Tigers out of the select group of the nation's undefeated teams.

When Joe Allen, alleged loan shark, went into Special Sessions yesterday for arraignment his hope was that a plea of poverty would induce a reduction from his bail of $2,500 so that he could leave the Tombs. By the time the court had acted, however, Allen's hope was shattered and his bail was increased to $7,500.

The two pamphlets prepared by the information department of the Royal Institute of International Affairs and issued by the Oxford University Press soon will be followed by a third, which will be called "Sanctions." The first of the pamphlets, "Abyssinia and Italy," already is in its third printing.

New York University's undefeated and untied football team will encounter its fifth opponent of the season this afternoon in the Yankee Stadium when it meets the Bucknell University eleven. A crowd of 20,000 fans is expected to be present for the opening kick-off, which is scheduled for 2 o'clock.

Following the advance in crude oil prices in California yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of California, the leading gasoline marketers there increased the retail prices of premium and regular grades of gasoline 3 1/2 cents a gallon and the third grade 3 cents, according to reports received here from Los Angeles.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Nov. 2. -- Tragedy dimmed the Chinese official welcome to Vice President John N. Garner and his party of Congressmen and newspaper executives today, as it arrived a few hours after the shooting of Premier Wang Ching-wei.

Next Tuesday the voters of this State will vote on Proposition No. 1 to increase the State bonded debt by $55,000,000 for relief. Everybody is in favor of all necessary relief to those unemployed through no fault of their own. There is no difference of opinion on this point.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 2. -- Sharp gains for the Conservatives were shown in returns from more than a quarter of the boroughs in the municipal elections held throughout Great Britain today. The count has been slow and most of the results will not be known until later today.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 1. -- Founders' Day exercises, commemorating the 104th anniversary of the establishment of Lafayette College, were held in Colton Memorial Chapel today and were followed by festivities concluding with the banquet of the Easton Alumni Association this evening.
The recently enacted "Fair Trade" Law in this State, which permits manufacturers and retailers to regulate prices, was upheld in its first test in the Supreme Court yesterday.

The Railway and Light Securities Company reported yesterday that its asset value on Sept. 30 was equivalent to $241.86 for each $100 of collateral trust bonds, to $265.11 a share on the preferred stock and to $21.39 a share on the common stock.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- With both teams primed for a hard game, Columbia and Cornell took things easy in their final workouts today. Tomorrow they will meet for the twenty-third time on Schoellkopf Field, with the Lions favored to triumph.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Lack of speculative interest was regarded as largely responsible for an early upturn and a later decline in wheat today on the Board of Trade here. Trade was the smallest in some time.

The first of a series of week-end film programs selected or approved for children by the Schools Motion Picture Committee is announced by Mrs. Alonzo Klaw of Friends Seminary, head of the group. The pictures and the houses at which they will be shown are as follows:
Investors played a prominent part in Bronx realty trading yesterday with the purchase of multi-family buildings from banks.

TIENTSIN, China, Nov. 1. -- "Three problems are disturbing peace in North China -- terrific taxation, including the dishonest squeeze by officials; exorbitant levies for useless armies, and anti-Japanese activities," declared Major General Hayao Tada, commandant of the Japanese garrison here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- A temporary suspension of action on all applications for Federal Power Commission approval of mergers, consolidations, sales or other disposition of public utility facilities, as well as requests for approval of utility security acquisitions, was announced by that agency today.

An initial step to enable the Great Northern Railway to meet the maturity of $107,000,000 of Series A 7 per cent general mortgage bonds on next July 1 was taken yesterday when the directors of the company called a stockholders' meeting for about Dec. 20 to approve an issue of convertible bonds to refinance the obligation.

General JOHNSON now says there is nothing to the story that he has been asked to become czar of the dressmaking industry. It seems a great pity. Consider, for one thing, what a fresh note the General could strike in the style world if he applied the Neanderthal touch to evening gowns.

The emblem of the New York City Cancer Committee, fighting in this sector under the command of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, is a sword carrying as a battle cry the legend "Fight Cancer With Knowledge." It fights the superstition that cancer can never be cured.

The board of directors of the Timken Roller Bearing Company voted yesterday to declare an extra dividend of $1 a share on its stock. In addition, a quarterly dividend of 50 cents was declared, placing the stock on a $2 annual basis, against $1 previously.

Real estate tax collections for the second half of the current year are running more than $13,000,000 above collections for the same period a year ago, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. Late mail returns may increase the total for the current year, now set at $156,717,131, by another $10,000,000, the controller predicted.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Bruce F. E. Harvey of New York arrived today at the Greenbrier on their wedding trip. Mrs. Harvey is the former Miss Amy Aspegren. ir. and Mrs. Willam A. Battle Jr. of New York and Mr. and Mrs. .idney Kent were in a luncheon party on the Casino Terrace today, later playing a foursome on the old White course.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- The Penn Junior Varsity football team defeated Princeton Jayvees in the mud at Franklin Field today, 12 to 6.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- Appealing to every citizen, regardless of party affiliation, Governor Lehman in a radio address tonight urged voters to cast an affirmative vote on Tuesday for the $55,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief. Terming imperative that all citizens locate Proposition No. 1 on the voting machine or paper ballot, he said:

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- Prices of securities on the Boerse became weaker again today. Changes among the heavy industrials were without significance. Quotations in the machine list were irregular, Schwarzkopf and Schubert-Salzer not being recorded in the day's transactions.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The Anglo-Italian atmosphere was not improved today by a report that at next month's naval conference the Italian delegation would demand the demilitarization and internationalization of the Straits of Gibraltar.

The text of the memorandum of understanding between the representatives of the Board of Estimate and committees for the various classes of securities of the Inter-borough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company follows:

James J. Walker talked philosophically yesterday about being Mayor of New York City and about several other things, including a pension, at an interview in his suite in the Hotel Chatham. He felt he was entitled to a pension but he said he would not do anything undignified to qualify for it, such as taking an assistant district attorneyship.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1. -- How 150 Crimean mountain girls from 5 to 16 years old in a village in the neighborhood of Alushta have been allotted to bridegrooms according to an old village custom was revealed today in the newspaper Pravda, which demands that such "savage customs" be abandoned.

A motion to dismiss a complaint against the United Fruit Company under the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act was denied yesterday afternoon by Dean Charles E. Clark of the Yale University Law School, sitting as special master for the National Labor Relations Board in the United States Customs Court, 201 Varick Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1. -- The American Liberty League will take an active part in the coming elections in an effort to elect Federal officials favorable to the league's views, it was disclosed here tonight by Henry P. DuBois, director of the New York regional office of the league.

Retail distribution improved slightly this week, with the broadest trend apparent in manufacturing districts, despite the adverse influence of continued unfavorable weather in some parts of the country, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- The undefeated teams of Ohio State University and the University of Notre Dame will meet here tomorrow afternoon in the country's outstanding football contest of the day, a game that may decide the national champion for 1935.

A woman was slain and four other persons were wounded last night when a former policeman attacked relatives in Jersey City. The former policeman, George De Forge, 58 years old, of 40 Bartholdi Avenue, Jersey City, first shot and killed his estranged wife, Mrs. Marie De Forge, 58, wounded his son and then raced to the near-by home of his daughter, where he shot her, her husband and a friend.
The money market was dull. Quotations for all classifications were unchanged. Traders are apparently accepting the new rates with the same routine that governed the lower charges.

Four acting captains were promoted to full captaincies and seven patrolmen were raised to sergeantcies by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in a ceremony at police headquarters yesterday morning. It was the first series of promotions made in the department since last July.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The Sort Room of the WaldorfAstoria, redecorated except for its huge murals by Jos. Maria Serf, was formally opened last night for its season. The opening was arranged as a benefit for the Opportunity Shop, a permanent thrift shop which donates its receipts to the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The Federal Trade Commission has disapproved trade practice conference rules for retail automobile dealers because four of the six rules proposed embodied an illegal price-fixing arrangement and would tend unreasonably to restrain trade in violation of the anti-trust laws.

About 300 men and women stage performers were interviewed yesterday morning at the St. James Theatre for jobs in the musical comedy, vaudeville and circus units to be cast soon under the supervision of the Federal theatre project of the WPA.

While industrial shares made yesterday their best showing in nearly a fortnight, under the leadership of the automotive, copper and steel issues, with resultant gains for many of fractions to 3 points, the market was tempered by the cautious attitude of a large section of the professional following.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 1. -- The Princeton 150-pound football team defeated Lafayette's lightweights, 8 -- 0, on Fisher Field today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov, 1. -- The earth tremors experienced in New England and eleven other Northeastern States today may be repeated soon, although it is doubtful if the new tremors will be felt in New England, two prominent Harvard geologists declared today as they attributed this morning's quake to a shifting of the earth's crust in response to the lifting of glacier pressure 35,000 years ago.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 1 (AP). -- Division of the $30,000,000 estate of Zachary Smith Reynolds of Winston-Salem, as proposed by his brother and two sisters, was approved by the State Supreme Court today.

Wherever there are towering mountain masses, there earthquakes occur. The earth is not finished yet. Mountains are being pushed up, a process accompanied by much "faulting" or rearrangement of rocks and by violent shocks. Hence the frequent and sometimes disastrous upheavals in Japan and along the western coast of North and South America.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Armaments, as a check on war, are much more effective than the League of Nations, Admiral Sir Reginald Bacon, commander of the World War Dover Patrol, told the Arms Commission yesterday.

Irregular price movements prevailed again yesterday on the local commodity future markets, with strength in sugar the feature of the trading. In the cash markets advances were made by wheat, rye, oats, eggs, tin, and wool tops. The latter sold at a new high level.
EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Nov. 1. -- Jimmy Hines, holder of the Long Island open crown, scored a double today in the one-day tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- The reorganization plan for the Davison Chemical Company and its subsidiaries, the Davison Realty Company and the Eastern Cotton Oil Company, was presented to Judge W. Calvin Chestnut in the Federal court today.

More gold was received here in October than in any other month since March, 1934. The receipts of $297,702,000 followed imports of $151,975,800 in September and nearly completed the shipments of gold arranged abroad since Sept. 9, when the movement started.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Control of the munitions business by the government is prerequisite to world peace, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told an audience in opening the Blackstone Lecture series tonight. Mrs. Roosevelt, speaking on "The Way to Peace," called upon the young generation to influence their elders.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- Butter dealers in Berlin began to issue ration cards to their customers today. The government itself, sensitive about its prestige, has refrained from issuing such cards, but it must be assumed that the dealers adopted the rationing system with the knowledge and permission of the authorities.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The earthquake which ran lightly over the Eastern seaboard early this morning shook Hyde Park House sufficiently to awaken President Roosevelt and his household, he stated at a press conference today as he described his reaction to the experience.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Designation by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, of W.L. Hutcheson, out-spoken anti-New Dealer, and head of the Hoover Labor Committee in the last campaign, as labor delegate to the forthcoming International Labor Organization Conference in Chile in December is "offensive to President Roosevelt" and "shocking" to Secretary Perkins, it was learned today.

The Government imposed an excise tax of 15 per cent yesterday on the sale price of soft coal at the mine, this tax to be paid by the producers. In so doing it was acting in accordance with the "Bituminous Coal Conservation Act of 1935," adopted at the last session of Congress.

The Gustavus Adolphus Swedish Lutheran Church, 151 East Twenty-second Street, tomorrow will begin a three weeks' celebration of the seventieth anniversary of the congregation and the forty-fifth anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. Dr. Mauritz Stolpe.

With the publication of the latest report of Judge SEABURY and Chamberlain BERLE to the Board of Estimate, unification of all the city's rapid transit lines is brought hopefully close to final consummation. A tentative agreement on price as well as plan was reached with the B.M.T. last February.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Although the aggressor virtually all the way, the Horace Mann School for Boys football team had to wait until the final quarter to down Montclair Academy, 13 to 0, today and thereby record its thirteenth straight triumph since the midway mark of the 1933 season.

The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company (Ill.) reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net loss of $622,284, in contrast with a net income of $38,974, or 5 cents a share, in the corresponding three months of last year.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1. -- The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission today awarded hero medals to Mildred E. Nightingale of 7 Pine Street, Binghamton, N.Y.; Willwayne Dare Frazier of Falconer, N.Y.; George Willis Gardner of 32 Early Street, Wellsville, N.Y.; James M. Cunningham Jr. of 823 Union Avenue, Hillside, N.J., and Donald J. Mallon of 1,036 Anna Street, Elizabeth, N.J.

GENEVA, Nov. 1. -Pierre A. [ Tlxier, chief of the International] Labor Organization's social insur-] anee section, has been invited by[ John G. Winant, formerly one of the organization's assistant directors and now chairman of the United States Social Security Board, to advise him in setting up machinery for administering the new Social Security Law.

GENEVA, Nov. 1.--Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, and Premier Pierre Laval of France agreed today on their immediate League of Nations sanctions and peace program. It is understood Mr. Laval will make a statement at tomorrow's public meeting of the coordinating committee, proposing that economic sanctions take effect Nov. 15.
Bizet's "Carmen" in concert form, with an English libretto, condensed to two acts, will be presented, under the direction of Jacob Schwartzdorf, this afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum.

The need for a definite philosophy of American life to guide the energies of youth and give it a sense of security was emphasized in an address last night by Dr. Robert D. Leigh, president of Bennington College, at a dinner attended by 300 educators in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith went before 3,000 persons in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night and called upon them and all the residents of the State to return a Democratic majority to the Assembly to uphold the hand of Governor Lehman.
Architects filed plans yesterday for an apartment house and several dwellings in Brooklyn and Queens. Manhattan projects were confined to alterations of existing structures.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 1. -- New Deal Democrats in Kentucky are fighting desperately, but they believe successfully, to bring about the election of a Democratic Governor next Tuesday and thus avoid the possibility of the Blue Grass State being added to the Republican list of "signs of the times."

Almost two-thirds of the municipal financing scheduled for next week, totaling $18,368,414, is accounted for by the offering of $11,000,000 of 4 per cent sewerage disposal system bonds by the city of Detroit, Mich., on Monday. The revised total for this week was $57,969.462.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1. -- Medicine must face the challenge of wider distribution of its services and the equalization of the costs thereof, President Robert Gordon Sproul of the University of California told the American College of Surgeons here tonight in the course of his fellowship address delivered during the colorful convocation ceremonies which closed the annual clinical congress of the college.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The British Museum publicly admitted today that it had harbored a forgery for sixty-two years -- the so-called Cervetrie Sarcophagus, long one of the most prominent and incidentally one of the most popular exhibits in the Greek and Roman galleries of the museum.

Football will begin to recede from the 1935 scholastic sports picture today, for Lawrenceville will close its season by meeting the strong Choate eleven. However, the tapering-off process will not be concluded for several more weeks, because a majority of the metropolitan high school squads will continue playing late this month.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1. -- With the surrender of Bennett Y. Ryan, a second Harvard student charged with assault on Frank Foster, 67, Dunster House janitor, Chief Inspector John J. Canney of the Cambridge police stated tonight there would in all probability be more arrests.
Primo Carnera took his first step along the comeback trail last night by knocking out Walter Neusel, the Blond Tiger of Germany, at Madison Square Garden.

QUEBEC, Nov. 1.--From remote mountain villages along isolated stretches of the old Canadian National Railways transcontinental line through Northern Quebec word trickled into Quebec tonight over a heavily burdened dispatchers' wire to tell intimate stories of an earthquake that jarred the entire northern area and terrified a widely scattered populace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Much of the history of the soft-coal industry was paraded today as the government began its defense in the District of Columbia Supreme Court against the attack on the Guffey Coal Control Law made by James W. Carter, president of the Carter Coal Company.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1. -- The Argentine Fascists have published full-page advertisements attacking the government as an agent of the existing political parties and demanding the establishment of a new State in which the government would be conducted by representatives of all branches of national activities instead of by politicians.

General Evangeline Booth of the Salvation Army was greeted enthusiastically by 2,000 Army members last night at the opening of the fourth annual series of Friday evening services at the Centennial Memorial Temple, at 120 West Fourteenth Street.
The thirty-sixth annual automobile show will open at the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Street, at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The earthquake that trembled across the Eastern States early today was attributed by a Coast and Geodetic Survey expert to the earth shifting its surface load -- disturbance "of the isostatic balance."

Six defendants who violated city regulations against unnecessary noise were fined in West Side Court yesterday by Magistrate Alexander Brough, who said he was in full sympathy with Mayor La Guardia's campaign for less noise.

The Princeton Club team, swinging into action for the first time this season in the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis race, scored a victory over the Columbia University Club players on the latter's court last night. Princeton won by the narrow margin of 3 to 2.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1. -- Dartmouth's nineteenth attempt to break the jinx that is said to prevent it from winning a football game from Yale will be made in the Bowl tomorrow before about 45,000 spectators, if threatened rain allows a generous ticket sale.

LA TOUR, Mo., Nov. 1 (AP). -- Charles F. McClure, school superintendent whose plans to halt a Halloween prank brought death to one of his students, sobbed out a heartbroken story tonight as a charge of manslaughter was filed against him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The North American Company, one of the large public utility holding companies, took steps today by the filing of a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 to divest itself of control of the Washington Railway and Electric Company, which, with its subsidiaries, furnishes electric energy and transportion to the nation's capital and a restricted area in Virginia and Maryland.

An obvious bid for the juvenile trade, the new Wheeler and Woolsey comedy, "The Rainmakers," at the Palace, merits no more than a note for the record. This would be that their current film is considerably less than hilarious and must be listed as another victim of the fallacy that runaway locomotives, laden with dynamite, are screamingly funny.

Double Korean chrysanthemums were among the hundreds of rare Australian, pompon, single, anemone and greenhouse exhibition blooms shown yesterday at the first annual chrysanthemum show in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. The show will continue through Sunday, and is open to the public without charge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1. -- Regardless of Harvard's three defeats and the four beatings sustained by Brown, more than 25,000 will troop to the stadium tomorrow to see these rivals meet in a time-honored series.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Fearful for the safety of millions of pounds of British money invested in Chinese Government, railway and other loans, which it is alleged have been unsettled, among other causes, by the United States' silver-buying program, the Bank of England tonight announced the appointment of a strong committee of British financial experts who "will be available in case of need" to negotiate in behalf of bondholders.

The first of the monthly index numbers of average commodity prices, published yesterday by Dun's Review, is the highest of any monthly number since that of April 1, 1930. The increase in the average during October was six-tenths of 1 per cent.
ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas, Nov. 1 (AP). -- W.C. Stroube's 4-year-old Croon, a campaigner on many tracks, raced to victory today in the Crusades, $1,000 event for 4-year-olds and up.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 1. -- A plea that work, "an opportunity to earn a living," be provided for every employable person was made by Governor La Follette of Wisconsin in an address before 6,000 teachers of the Central Western zone, New York State Teachers Association, in general session here today.
ALBANY, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The State Allocations Board released $5,721,439.49 today for WPA projects to be taken up as soon as district directors can get the work under way.
Three hold-ups, in one of which the alleged bandits were captured after a gun battle with the police, netted gunmen $5,292 yesterday in Northern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The reciprocal trade agreement with Sweden which became effective on Aug. 5 has resulted in large increases in trade, according to a report received by the State Department today from Laurence A. Steinhardt, Minister to Sweden.

Declaring that the Republican party had foolishly injected national issues into the State campaign as a smoke screen because it was barren of State issues, Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, declared last night that there was no reason why any one should vote anything but a straight Democratic ticket next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.--Seasoned corporations formed as the successors to other companies may use the modified Form A-2 for the registration of securities under the Securities Act of 1933, if property acquired from the promoters "consisted principally of one or more going businesses, or of securities representing directly or indirectly more than 50 per cent of the rotting power controlling such businesses," the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today.

Indicating strong opposition to any plan which is aimed at establishing a government bureau patterned on NRA, Herbert Gutterson, president of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers, yesterday accepted the invitation of George L. Berry, coordinator for industrial cooperation, to participate in conferences between government officials and business men to discuss means for speeding recovery.

WORCESTER Mass., Nov. 1. -- The second biennial exhibition of American painting opened in the galleries of the Worcester Art Museum with a private view this evening. Beginning tomorrow the pictures will be shown to the public until Dec. 15.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- With the temperature dropping 42 degrees within eight hours, Chicago was shivering tonight as the cold wave moving eastward from the Far West swept into Illinois.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 1. -- Notwithstanding desperate efforts to turn his advantage of a pawn plus into a victory, Dr. Max Euwe of this city failed to force the resignation of Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris in the thirteenth game of their world championship match, which was played to a conclusion at the Hotel Carlton today.
GENEVA, Nov. 1. -- A spokesman for Italy said today regarding the League's peace efforts:

"AFTER a miserable night and an indifferent breakfast, I went to the Observation Car to examine the Texas of Romance, the Texas of the Rangers, of the cattle-trails, of incredible feats with pistol and lasso, of skirmishes with Indians and wild pursuits of Mexicans -- of all, in fact, that made life for a child in a London suburb worth living.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Nov. 2. -- Definite establishment of the fact that the murderous attack upon Premier Wang Ching-wei was inspired solely by opposition to China's policies toward Japan probably will serve further to complicate Chino-Japanese relations and almost certainly will delay the rapprochement that Tokyo insists upon.
The Panthers of Pittsburgh arrived in New York yesterday and began counting the hours before they will take the field against Fordham at the Polo Grounds today.

AMHERST vs. Mass. State -- The ancients used to consult the stars on difficult problems. Here's the Handbook of the Heavens (Whittlesey House, $1) just out with the benison of the American Museum of Natural History in the hope that readers will know which way to look on entering the new Hayden Planetarium. Taking a quick look up, one vote for Amherst.

TOKYO, Nov. 1. -- Primeval Shinto ceremonies, in which imperialist and religious sentiments were inextricably mingled, attracted 500,000 persons to Nagoya tonight while simultaneously Emperor Hirohito in his palace in Tokyo performed responsive rites before the imperial sanctuary.
ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- Registration figures released today at the office of Secretary of State Flynn show a total of 4,699,536, with two counties, Delaware and Westchester, missing.

HELENA, Mont., Nov. 1. -- Scores huddled around campfires outside Helena tonight, afraid to return to their homes in the quake-shaken city as Winter pressed down from the sky and the earth still trembled.

A plan of recapitalization for McKesson Robbins, Inc., drug manufacturers and distributors, designed to eliminate accrued dividends of $5,969,600 on the company's $3.50 preferred stock, has been approved by the directors and will be submitted to the stockholders at a special meeting early next month, it was announced yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 1. -- Tenseness gripped this city today with the prospect of an Italian advance upon Makale, the next major objective of the Fascisti.
The text of the report of Samuel Seabury, special counsel, and A.A. Berle Jr., Chamberlain, to the Board of Estimate follows:

Fourteen tenants of Knickerbocker Village won a temporary victory yesterday in their fight to set aside dispossess orders issued against them in the Municipal Court, ordering them to move immediately. The Appellate Term found that the papers had been made returnable on the same day on which they were issued, and that the tenants had not received the five or ten day notice provided by law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- A national tax-exempt sales allotment of 226,600,000 bushels of potatoes from the 1936 crop was established today by Secretary Wallace. This number of bushels may be sold free from the 45 cents a bushel levy provided by the Warren Potato Control Law, passed at the last session of Congress.

In a setting as dramatic as it was tense, William F.X. Geoghan and Joseph D. McGoldrick, rival candidates for the Kings County District Attorneyship, met in the privacy of the prosecutor's office yesterday afternoon and an angry encounter ensued over the issues of the campaign.
