OTTAWA, Nov. 1. -- The Hon. Charles A. Dunning, Finance Minister in the new Mackenzie King Cabinet, announced a $75,000,000 domestic loan tonight, and at the same time announced the government's determination to balance the budget.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- Nearly 900 dogs were benched today in Convention Hall for the opening sessions of the sixteenth all-breed exhibition of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia, which will be concluded tomorrow evening with the award of best in show by Governor George H. Earle.

Book renters who deposited $1 or more as security with Womrath's chain of stores are to be repaid on the basis of fifteen cents to the dollar when and if the money is available, in accordance with a reorganization plan which was approved yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

Eleven contract bridge teams remained in competition for the Sir Derrick Wernher trophy for the metropolitan team championship of the American Bridge League at the close of the semi-final round of play early this morning at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was marooned in a haze of contradictions today when it sought to prove that a representative of the Cuban Bondholders Protective Committee, of which Senator Nye is chairman and Senator Wheeler an associate counsel, had submitted to a Cabinet committee of the Mendieta government an "insufferable" plan for payment of $40,000,000 of defaulted Cuban public works bonds held in this country.

Time and again one has to wonder if any other tribe is as superstitious as the politicians are. Mr. ROOSEVELT is in Hyde Park, waiting to vote. Wherever he is there is more than enough business to attend to. He must be amused if the fact comes to his notice that the Democratic leaders of the vicinage attribute to him a sort of protective influence and power.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 1. -- It is evident that the drive on Makale from Adigrat is drawing near. Militarily no trouble is expected in the advance.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- Eight colts and one filly were named today for the $55,930 Pimlico Futurity, which will be revived tomorrow after a lapse since 1932. It is estimated that at least 20,000 persons will watch the mile and a sixteenth run, the longest distance 2-year-olds have been asked to go so far this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- An operating profit of $110,000,000, more than sufficient to offset probable losses from uncollectable loans, was claimed for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman. Of the $5,700,000,000 of non-Federal loan disbursements through loans and investments, 64 per cent has been repaid, he said.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Imperial Airways was planning a number of experimental Atlantic flights in 1936 as the first step in establishment of regular transatlantic air service, Sir Eric Geddes, the chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller, who has lost the last remnants of his authority and even his office apace since the Reich and Prussian Church directorates moved into his former administrative headquarters, is reported to be negotiating with the National Church party in Thuringia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.--The difficulties of the Tennessee Publishing Company, publisher of The Nashville Tennessean, will be inquired into by the special House committee investigating defaults of real estate and other bonds.

Depositions will be taken from seventeen witnesses in support of the government's suit to compel ten Clearing House banks in this city to make good losses of depositors in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, it was learned yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- The ranks of the broadsilk strikers were swelled today when several hundred men and women joined the American Federation of Silk Workers' walkout in response to entreaties of picketers, according to figures based on reports made at today's mass meeting of strikers.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 1. -- It is estimated that 10,000 Indians, a majority of those in the Coco River Valley, extending thirty miles on both sides and 200 miles along the river from its mouth, are destitute as a result of the recent hurricane and floods.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area during the week was disappointing. Due to adverse weather conditions which hampered the sale of heavier Winter apparel, department store volume sagged under last year's figures by from 3 to 5 per cent.

Sylvester Lancaric, 17 years old, tried in General Sessions on a second-degree manslaughter indictment, was found guilty yesterday of assault in the second degree. The conviction was based on the beating he administered last May 9 in their home at 75 East 106th Street to his 3-year-old brother, John, who died seventeen days later without medical care.

MUSSOLINI boasted of the magnificent Fascist "discipline" with which the application of sanctions to Italy would be met. But he himself, a few days later, flew into a violent passion of uncontrolled fury when he denounced the proceedings of the League, under British leadership, as the "vilest and meanest" known to history.

The earthquake that shook the Eastern section of the United States and Canada spreading fear, property damage and indirectly causing one death, was really a trifling lifting of the earth's surface that centred somewhere about the Doucet region of Quebec.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- District Administrator John B. Bryan of the Work Progress Administration dismissed 532 Westchester workers at Bear Mountain today when they went on strike for shorter hours.

Admission by Lewis H. Pounds, chairman of the independent bondholders' committee organized in February, 1933, to take over defaulted issues of S.W. Straus Co., that he did not keep track of "details" of reorganizing the issues provoked sharp criticism yesterday from Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, chairman of the joint legislative committee to investigate bondholders', stockholders' and creditors' committees, at the committee's second public hearing in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

There is little doubt that Mussolini is wrong in nearly all he has done, that he is wrong in whatever he is doing now in Italy, in Ethiopia and elsewhere, and that he is driving Italy to disaster and the world to tragic alternatives.

ROME, Nov. 1. -- Anti-British demonstrations spread from Rome into the provinces today. In every city, town and village down to the smallest hamlet crowds met taking advantage of the holiday to protest against sanctions and the part played by Britain in the application of them.

All the movie companies are getting into the Broadway swim, apparently, the latest being Twentieth Century-Fox. Blandly it revealed yesterday that it had formed a concern, in fact, a special incorporated concern, for the production of plays; the lead-off item to be Margaret Kennedy's "Autumn."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1. -- Sharp criticism of comely women defendants who dazzle juries with their good looks was voiced today by Superior Judge Joseph Vickers in sentencing Lora M. Hewitt to serve one to twenty years in prison on conviction of attempted murder.

Postmaster General James A. Farley's action in mailing letters to voters in this State urging the election of a Democratic Assembly was criticized last night by Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the New York Republican State Committee.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Gas from a running automobile engine took the lives of a family of three persons today in what Coroner A. J. Pearse said was "double murder and suicide."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The works relief drive passed tonight the original deadline for ending the dole, far behind schedule, but with plans shaping to chop off Federal contributions to relief in a score more States within a fortnight.

NANKING, China, Nov. 1. -- The critical wounding of Premier Wang Ching-wei by an assassin today was ascribed by the police to a "well-organized plot by Chinese Communists." Eleven suspects are held in the assassination attempt, including a girl Communist.

Adoption of a general policy that trading on the New York Stock Exchange shall be "flat" in all bonds or other direct obligations of corporations which are in process of reorganization under Sections 77 and 77b of the Bankruptcy Act was announced yesterday by the Exchange's committee on securities.

BEYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 1. -- With Elizabethan banners flying from the towers of Rockefeller and Pembroke Halls and animated groups of alumnae reminiscing at Owl Gate and along Senior Row, Bryn Mawr College today went back through half a century of history to pay tribute to its founders and recall the status of women's education in the Eighties.

ROME, Nov. 1. -- Anti-British demonstrations spread from Rome into the provinces today. In every city, town and village down to the smallest hamlet crowds met taking advantage of the holiday to protest against sanctions and the part played by Britain in the application of them.

All the movie companies are getting into the Broadway swim, apparently, the latest being Twentieth Century-Fox. Blandly it revealed yesterday that it had formed a concern, in fact, a special incorporated concern, for the production of plays; the lead-off item to be Margaret Kennedy's "Autumn."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1. -- Sharp criticism of comely women defendants who dazzle juries with their good looks was voiced today by Superior Judge Joseph Vickers in sentencing Lora M. Hewitt to serve one to twenty years in prison on conviction of attempted murder.

Admission by Lewis H. Pounds, chairman of the independent bondholders' committee organized in February, 1933, to take over defaulted issues of S.W. Straus Co., that he did not keep track of "details" of reorganizing the issues provoked sharp criticism yesterday from Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, chairman of the joint legislative committee to investigate bondholders', stockholders' and creditors' committees, at the committee's second public hearing in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

There is little doubt that Mussolini is wrong in nearly all he has done, that he is wrong in whatever he is doing now in Italy, in Ethiopia and elsewhere, and that he is driving Italy to disaster and the world to tragic alternatives.

Defeat of the $55,000,000 State bond issue for unemployment relief and reduction in government relief expenditures are urged in a statement by the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
WITH signal lights now set at "go" in the automobile parts and equipment field, every indication points to probably the most active Fall and Winter season in the history of the industry.

WHEN a company of dancers belonging to the modern movement devotes itself entirely to the presentation of works in extended forms in place of the usual evening of divertissements, that is news. There can be little doubt that last Sunday's performance by Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their groups at the Guild Theatre marks the beginning of a new phase of the dance hereabout.

Mr. McGreevy is worth knowing better. An Irish nationalist, it appears from his poems, a Catholic, a friend of Joyce and Yeats, undoubtedly influenced by Eliot, he shows an interesting sense of form, a sophisticated phrasing and a mind ready for adventurous ideas.

ROME, Nov. 2. -- Today's proceedings at Geneva were entirely in accord with Italian expectations. Two principal conclusions are drawn from them: First, that sanctions will be in full swing before the end of the month, and secondly, that there is no possibility for the present of a solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy by negotiation.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Governor George H. Earle tonight presented the handsome trophy which signified victory in the final award of the nearly 900 dogs in the sixteenth annual exhibition of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia.

THE automobile is probably one of the greatest factors in American life today. The trend of the country's business can be traced and gauged by statistics of the automotive industry. The increased registration of cars is an indication that business is improving and that better times are arriving.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 2. -- With a line-up sprinkled with reserves, Holy Cross had little trouble in defeating St. Anselm's this afternoon, 34 to 0. The Crusaders outplayed the Blue Jays, registering seventeen first downs against six and totaling 379 yards in rushing, as against the Blue Jays' 70.

Just how the United States is to accommodate its actions in relation to League of Nations sanctions against Italy has not been worked out in detail. But President Roosevelt has made it clear that the administration does not intend for this country to appear as a war profiteer among the nations of the world.

LAST week a committee of the United Parents Associations of New York City charged that school overcrowding here is so serious that even the new school-building program, to be financed largely with Federal funds, will be unable to relieve it.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2. -- The Argentine and Chilean Foreign Offices have given out statements making it clear that neither country will apply the boycott against Italian imports. These formal statements confirm earlier unofficial reports that the League of Nations sanctions will not be applied in such a manner as adversely to affect trade with Italy.

VERY often in developing a small place one of the most stubborn problems to be encountered is a wet, low spot, perhaps sometimes flooded, or for one reason or another almost a swamp at certain seasons.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Ted Sharretts, running around left end when he could find no receiver for a forward, scored a touchdown to give Andover a 6-to-0 decision over the New Hampshire freshmen today, the first victory for the academy eleven this year.

Charging that the Brooklyn Democratic organization was run by Postmaster General James A. Farley, Samuel Seabury endorsed yesterday the candidacy of Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion nominee for Kings County District Attorney. The endorsement was made public at an "anti-crime meeting" last night in Brooklyn.

In "Lona of Hollybush Creek" Genevieve Fox continues to write of the Kentucky hill folk with perspective and naturalness, and again succeeds in holding the reader's interest without straining probabilities, or overdrawing her characters.

Current and impending developments lead well-posted retail executives to believe that the spurt this season in home-furnishings lines is destined to be more than a "flash in the pan." The belief was expressed yesterday that the gains of 15 to 40 per cent or more which have been experienced this Fall in home furnishings and allied merchandise are the forerunner of much heavier increases to come in this field.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, of New Rochelle, well-known advocate of world peace, will address members of the Contemporary Club of White Plains at an open meeting on Wednesday afternoon, She has announced as her topic, "Lies for War -- Allies for Peace."

BECAUSE there is no conventional chassis in the new Lincoln-Zephyr, the Lincoln and Ford manufacturing units, which cooperate in building this automobile, have had to modify the process of putting the body and running gear together.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Dartmouth finally reached the end of the long trail in the Yale Bowl today. For the first time in nineteen games the Green triumphed over the Blue and before the contest ended Dartmouth started its celebration.

WEATHER conditions again proved a handicap to trade in the week, and the month closed with results well under what retailers had expected. In this area the week's decline was from 3 to 5 per cent under a year ago, and the drop for October was estimated around the same figures.
THE automobile, first introduced with curved dash and buggy-whip socket, has emerged in its evolution to aspire to a more ethereal stratum.

The share market had yesterday its busiest Saturday since Sept. 7, with sales on the Stock Exchange aggregating 1,264,000 shares. Following a generally higher opening (transit issues were an exception) the market edged higher until the usual week-end profit-taking manifested itself shortly before the closing; final prices were irregular.

In Madison Square Garden on Wednesday afternoon the National Horse Show Association will open its fifty-second annual exhibition. America's premier equine event will continue a full week, with afternoon and evening sessions each week day through Tuesday, Nov. 12.

QUEBEC, Nov. 2. -- At Wolfe's Cove, named for the English general who gave his life to conquer Canada for the British Crown nearly 200 years ago, John Buchan, Baron Tweedsmuir, novelist, historian, parliamentarian and recent peer, was sworn in tonight as Governor General of the Dominion.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- For the first time there is some open indication today that the new Franco-British partnership with its correlatives of consultations, cooperation and mutual assistance between partners in military, naval, aerial and diplomatic departments is getting under the German skin.
It certainly does seem as if most of the great writers have dealt with the war topic -- and, so far as the records show, they see unanimously against it.

The Chinese currencies were unsettled further yesterday by continued rumors of some decisive action with respect to the Shanghai dollar. The latter rallied 18 points to 31.30 cents, following losses earlier in the week, but the Hongkong dollar fell 1.50 cents to 42.90 cents.
The campaign for next Tuesday's election of a State Assembly resolved itself last week into a Democratic defense of the State administration and a Republican attack on the national administration.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will put on display this morning a restored Roman copy of an ancient Greek scultpured relief considered by museum officials a work of "remarkable interest."
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Not in twenty-five years has Westchester's Republican tranquillity been disturbed by so many pre-election developments as have appeared in the present campaign.

THE "Voice of England" is, of course, English literature, of which in this fascinating book Professor Osgood retells the story, in the way that, contrary to the modest disclaimer in his preface, it very much needs retelling at the present time.

The work of W.W. Gibson is well known and this volume is an extension of familiar material. Of the Georgian poets he has the severest social conscience, but his Tennysonian verse has not pulled its weight. Scenes from a miner's life are here, and from city tenements and trawlers and schooners, the simple and preferably pathetic annals of the poor.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 2. -- Bowdoin moved closer to a State championship by defeating the heavier and favored Bates team, 14 -- 0, today, as Colby, a team which Bowdoin has already defeated, won from Maine, 12 -- 0.

NEWARK, Del., Nov. 2. -- After being tied twice during the came, St. Joseph's of Philadelphia came through .in the final five minutes of play with a touchdown on a forward pass from Hartman to Fleming to defeat the University of Delaware, 19 to 13, today.

Tabulation of mailed payments of real estate taxes for the second half of the current year, postmarked before midnight on Oct. 31, the deadline for payment without penalty, brought total collections to $167,766,690, or 71.44 of the tax levy, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.

Bred to the horn-and-hounds tradition of racketeer investigation, New York was puzzled until last Monday by the silent procedure of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, who undertook last June the gigantic job of ridding the community of organized crime.

THE trucking industry has reached that stage of its development comparable to a boy with his first pair of long pants. For ten years the tailors have been trying to slip our young, strong legs into trousers that wouldn't fit us -- trousers generally patterned after those made for our older brother in the transportation field, the railroad. Now we have a pair of pants that we think will fit.

THE League of Composers, which has been a pioneer in producing twentieth century music in this country, has just published a booklet which reviews its work during the last twelve years. The society, organized in 1923, began its work by giving three concerts in New York City.

Mr. and Mrs. John Hall Forbes of 1,160 Fifth Avenue entertained at a large dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Their guests included:

The American edition under this title uses some poems from Mr. Pudney's first book (this is his second). Since the morality play of "Joseph" is also included, it is possible to exercise some judgment on Mr. Pudney's claims to be a contemporary of Auden and Spender -- two poets who, as it seems to us, have established their position.

A DUFF COOPER cannot complain of any lack of public attention to the first volume of his long-awaited biography of Field Marshal Haig. Though it appeared on a day of the week when most papers publish no reviews, it was immediately greeted everywhere with long notices.

ROME, Nov. 2 (AP). -- General Emilio de Bono, commanding the Italian troops in Northern Ethiopia, and General Rodolfo Graziani, leader of the southern army, were moving for further conquest on the thirty-first day of their campaign.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 2. -- Randolph-Macon's unbeaten eleven kept its record clear at Haverford's expense, winning, 27 -- 6, today on the losers' field. Jimmy Bair, high scorer, added a pair of touchdowns for the Ashland squad.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Nov. 2. -- After trailing until the last minute and a half of play, Villanova rallied to defeat the University of Detroit today, 13 to 7, to avenge last week's setback by the Titans on their home field. A big home-coming day crowd saw the game.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2. -- The University of California displayed a rugged defense and took advantage of the breaks today to score two touchdowns and remain in the undefeated class by vanquishing the hitherto unbeaten University of California at Los Angeles, 14 to 2, before 80,000.

MOST of Kathleen Norris's novels are written to the same formula and make use of pretty much the same subject-matter -- naturally enough, since no novelist could be expected to find fresh material and a new formula for each of half a hundred romances.
BALANCED engineering, that favorite study of the automotive engineer, will be more than ever in evidence in the automobiles of 1936.

Establishment of a work-placement unit in the Emergency Relief Bureau to cooperate with the Federal Re-employment Service in finding jobs for employable persons on home relief was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 2. -- The scope of dramatics has been broadened at Connecticut College with the introduction of a program of one-act plays to be presented at intervals by the various dormitories. The plays will be produced under the auspices of the college Dramatic Club before small audiences of invited guests.

NEW YORK STATE did not build as many miles of new highway this year as it has in previous years because no new work was started until September. The only work accomplished during the year was the closing up of various contracts awarded in 1934 which had not been finished when the season for road work closed late last November.

TURIN, Sept. 30, 1935. NEWS from Perugia tells of the success that attended the illustrated lecture course on Italian eighteenth-century music held this Fall at the Royal Italian University for Foreigners, under the direction of Maestro Guido Visconti di Modrone, the eminent musicologist and champion of Italy's musical glories of the past, who has achieved international prominence for similar courses and revivals in previous years.

DUBLIN -- The Irish Free State has just passed through one of its recurrent excitements over the Irish Hospitals Sweeps -- its third largest industry in point of direct employment. To the outside world the "roll of the drum" in Dublin's historic Mansion House means a pleasant gamble.

Vigorous offensives launched by women's organizations on both national and State fronts to correct abuses in government will concentrate attention of the feminine contingent this week on election results of Tuesday.
The Socialist party, according to its custom, will hold its final big meeting of the campaign tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
MOSCOW, Nov. 1. -- The Soviet Union faces the armed camps of Europe, as this third year of the second Five-Year Plan draws to a close, with ever-increasing confidence in its economic strength.

It is only when we resort to comparison with other periods that we begin to realize how extraordinary an economic phenomenon is the present inpour of foreign gold into the United States. The Federal Reserve's summary puts the import at New York, between the beginning of the Autumn movement in September and the end of October, at $449,600,000.

THE theory that Stanley Walker is a burning Communist, at heart dedicated to the exposure of capitalism's howlers, may yet turn out to be true. But one doubts it. Unlike the urchin in the rhyme, he only does it to enjoy because he knows it pleases.

At the second in a series of musical and artistic benefits for the Town Hall Endowment Fund on the night of Nov. 16 at the Town Hall, the artist will be La Argentina, Spanish dancer. Subsequent recitals and concerts in the series will be given by Arthur Schnabel, pianist, and Andres Segovia, Spanish guitarist; Harold Bauer and members of the Manhattan String Quartet; Efrem Zimbalist, Kirsten Flagstad of the Metropolitan Opera and Emanuel Feuerman.

PROFITING by the parking and traffic experiences of the past Summer, when, according to police estimates, the largest number of motorists since 1928 visited resorts within the metropolitan area, organizations functioning in these communities took steps to eliminate the difficulties encountered.

Police Commissioner Valentine revealed yesterday that Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer's "business" papers showed that he took in nearly $1,000,000 in seven weeks before his death from race track, policy and other rackets.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2. -- Captain Barney Mintz, playing the greatest game of his career and treating a crowd of 20,000 spectators to as fine an exhibition of all-round playing as ever was seen here, led his Tulane Green Wave to a 14-to-6 victory over Colgate at the Tulane Stadium today.

STRANGE it seems indeed to receive in 1935 the first English translation of a book firmly established with all students of European history for thirty-eight years as a classic of historical research and historical writing.

UNLESS excessive "cramming" of radio programs ceases, the listening public is threatened with "aerial indigestion," according to Jascha Heifetz, noted violinist, who will be heard as soloist during WEAF's symphony concert tonight at 10 o'clock.

In the Haverstraw Cemetery at Haverstraw, N.Y., is the grave of a forgotten man. It lies high on a green slope overlooking the Hudson, beneath a birch tree that was planted when its occupant was buried. He was Leonidas Hubbard, writer and explorer, who lost his life in the wilds of Labrador a little more than thirty Years ago.
Field hockey is fast moving along toward that point where an increasing number of interassociation and college varsity matches presage sectional tournaments and the end of the season.

PARIS, Oct. 25. THE second Sacha Guitry play this time with himself in the chief part, has now been produced, and, as I predicted last week, it turns out to be more in the Sacha Guitry Vein than the other. It is also more to the taste of the public and shows signs of being in for a good run, while the first has found so little favor that its last performances are already announced.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 31. -- Not since the days of the Darlington riots in 1894 has the State been thrown into such turmoil as has been occasioned by the action of Governor Olin De Witt Talmadge Johnston in ordering out a machinegun unit to take charge of the Highway Department.

The Financial Press of New York announces the publication of a book of "Interest Cost Tables" computed by George Holzman of the Chase National Bank and James R. Bartholomew of Hallgarten Co. This new table, for the use of i municipal bond dealers and financial officers of municipalities, makes it possible to determine the true interest rate on split coupon bids at rates from 1/2 to 6 per cent, in tenths, eighths and quarters.

WHAT is said by its builders to be one of the finest high schools in the country will be dedicated by Wilmington, Del., Nov. 7 as the climax of a school program that in fourteen years has raised Delaware from almost the bottom to close to top rank among American States in educational rating.

Claudette Colbert and Marlene Dietrich, for example, have functioned with eclat as representatives of a dozen racial types, from Greco-Egyptian to Slav.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Scoring in three of the four periods, a powerful Bloomfield High School eleven kept its season's slate clean by defeating Garfield High, 25 to 0, today. The victory avenged the only setback the Bengals have suffered in their last thirty contests.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Downtrodden Indiana, thrice beaten, rose up from the Big Ten football cellar like a post-Halloween ghost today to haunt Iowa's hopes for a Conference title by holding the Hawkeyes to a 6-to-6 tie before 20,000 rain-soaked spectators.

Congratulations are due Francis Moore for demonstrating conclusively last night three important facts at his treasurable piano recital in Town Hall. The absorbed attention of his audience attested to the value of them.
INCREASING recognition of the advantages inherent in motor truck transportation is reflected in the 1935 production figures of American meter truck manufacturers.

OTTAWA, Oct. 31. -- How clean the new broom which the Canadian electorate presented to Prime Minister Mackenzie King on Oct. 14 is going to sweep is still to be shown, but it has undoubtedly begun its sweeping early.

NO buyer appeared for the world's rarest and highest-priced stamp when it was offered to collectors at auction in London last week. The stamp, a British Guiana one-cent now owned by Mrs. Costa Scala of Utica, N.Y., cost Mrs. Scala's former husband (the late Arthur Hinds, whose hobby was notable stamps) 7,343, or $35,643; and the upset price at last week's auction was placed at 7,500, or about 37,500, at current exchange.
A thorough overhauling of the city's public school system is urged by the Socialist party in a fourteen-point educational program released yesterday as the third of a series of campaign pamphlets.

THE day is past when the product of any studio can be identified by the players in the pictures. There was a time when stars were as much the property of a producer and as easily recognizable as Metro's lion, Radio's beacon or Paramount's volcano.

LONDON, Oct. 10. I FANCY that in "Distinguished Gathering" the Embassy, a small experimental theatre in the suburb of Hampstead, has discovered yet another play likely to prosper on the West End stage. It may be classed with "Ten-Minute Alibi," but as a piece of theatrical mechanism it is at some points superior to Anthony Armstrong's popular "thriller."

Considerable discussion was aroused among the spectators and fans who listened to the broadcast over the officials' ruling on an unusual play which occurred in the last period of the Notre Dame-Ohio State game.

THOMAS WOLFE, whose new volume of short novels and stories, "From Death to Morning," will be published on Nov. 14 by Charles Scribner's Sons, is now working on a book which grew out of his recent trans-continental trip and which he calls tentatively "The Hound of Darkness."

UNCOUNTED refinements in design characterize nearly all the chassis to be seen at the Automobile Show this year. Outstanding changes of a basic nature are less numerous than in some years, but are not lacking by any means.

Voters throughout the State will pass upon three amendments to the State Constitution and upon one proposition for a State bond issue for relief at Tuesday's election. Originally, city voters also would have been asked to approve or reject Mayor La Guardia's city power plant project, but this question was thrown off the ballots by the courts.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Despite the appeals of business men and politicians for the election of a Republican Mayor to aid the party in the Presidential campaign, independent Republicans are in revolt against S. Davis Wilson, the party's nominee for Mayor, accused yesterday by a grand jury of employing city funds for political purposes.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Carl A. Babcock, technical adviser of the Ohio Liquor Department, ordered shelves of the State liquor stores cleared of National Distillers Corporation products today in the midst of a heated controversy between Governor Davey and a chain of Ohio newspapers.

Convinced that all divisions of the food industry will be singled out for broad investigations when Congress reconvenes, as the result of disclosures brought out during the last session, representatives of leading groups of manufacturers and distributers of grocery products opened the way last week for an extensive study of trade practices with a view to curbing abuses.

Scientists in university geologic and seismographic laboratories through the Eastern section of the United States and Canada were busy yesterday with their studies of the earthquake of Friday, one of them finding in it proof that the moon exerts a contributing influence on subsurface adjustments of the earth.

FORECASTING the new week's screen attractions becomes increasingly difficult. What with unexpected holdovers, hasty departures, shifts of program and last-minute cancellations, the departmental booking office refuses to be held responsible for its list.

Ye Olde English Faire, a three-day bazaar held annually under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women, will take place on Nov. 20, 21 and 22 at the Biltmore.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2. -- A Soviet analysis of the first month of the Italo-Ethiopian war, published in the Izvestia, doubts a speedy Italian victory and declares that modern machines of warfare have failed in East Africa.

ISTANBUL, Oct. 31. -- As the trial of the men held in the recent unsuccessful plot against the life of President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk draws near, details of it and of the background of the accused men are being made known to an indignant Turkish public.

In comparison with the New York City poliomyelitis outbreaks in 1916 and 1931, that of this year was considerably less virulent, according to a preliminary report published in the Nov. 1 issue of the Quarterly Bulletin of the City Health Department.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- Because he failed to fly the swastika flag from the tower of his church during a Nazi district leader's funeral in Dessau, Father Albert Coppenrath of Berlin was fined fifty marks today in the Berlin Criminal Court.

DESPITE a big production and sales year in 1935 the automobile industry still faces the largest replacement market in its history. It will produce and sell approximately 3,500,000 new cars and trucks this year, but it hasn't even touched the vast replacement demand built up during the depression.

Political idealism may be defined as the attempt on the part of rulers and governments to increase the welfare of the citizens or subjects living under them. Since it is difficult, if not impossible, to know the real motives of human beings, we may take for granted that the professed intentions of political idealists are their real intentions.

For several decades Senator William H. Borah and the Idaho potato have contributed to and shared the fame and glory of their rugged State. Idaho baked potatoes have graced the menus of fashionable hotels and smart restaurants, while the distinguished silver-tongued orator's name has decorated the front-page headlines of our national press.

UNUSUAL efforts will be made this Winter to insure the comfort and trip progress of its passengers by TWA through a new system of "flight control" announced last week by Jack Frye, president of the Lindbergh Line. Experienced pilots as flight control officers will be stationed at each division point.

THIS is a rare tale of that order in winch philosophy through fantasy plays over reality, opening new yet intimate little vistas on the seas of our reflections. And it has been clothed by its translators in English prose that rivals the best of David Garnett.

Nearly 200 groups have been organized among industrial, business and professional leaders to conduct the annual membership roll call of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, Peter S. Duryee, general chairman, announced yesterday. The drive will start Armistice Day, Nov. 11, and end Thanksgiving Day, Nov. 28.

This is a welcome volume, containing as it does material not to be found elsewhere except on an adult level. The book begins with an account of the origin of the oceans. This is followed by chapters explaining ocean currents, the action of the waves, tides and the composition of sea water.

Even if the reader did not know Mary Gould Davis as an accomplished story-teller who holds spellbound large audiences of boys and girls, he would be quite sure on reading "Sandy's Kingdom" that she thoughly understands children. Here is just such a dog story as 7 to 10-year-olds enjoy.

THE Spanish exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum has closed, but several new shows are now current, among them a diverse group of work by Matisse (concerning which there is comment elsewhere on this page), Czechoslovakian craftwork, together with paintings and graphic art, and paintings and drawings of natural history subjects displayed in the Gallery for Living Artists.

ATLANTA, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Intercepting a pass and racing 67 yards for a touchdown, Willie Geny, Vanderbilt captain and end, made possible the victory margin as the Commodores downed Georgia Tech, 14 to 13, in a fierce struggle today before 10,000 fans.

Ever since Italy first announced her intention of occupying Ethiopia her plea has been that she needed room for expansion of her surplus population, as well as a region from which she might obtain foodstuffs and raw materials for industry and commerce which cannot be grown at home.

Adverse weather conditions took toll of retail trade during the week and department store sales volume on the average ran from 3 to 5 per cent under the corresponding period a year ago. Heavier types of Fall and Winter apparel were chiefly affected, with volume in home furnishings fairly well maintained.

ONE does not have to be either a fisherman or a hunter to enjoy and profit by this widely informed, heartily written, wholesome book that comes straight from the heart of a man whose deepest interests are in the cherishing, preserving and developing of our wild life.

THE stream of motor touring which ebbed considerably during the worst of the depression suddenly swelled into flood proportions during the year 1935, with the result that the number of travelers and the amount of their expenditures were greater than ever before in travel history.

On reading Dr. Carleton Sprague Smith's letter in your issue of Oct. 13, I was reminded that many in this country persist in calling the violin mute a "sordino." Our composers, with few exceptions, write con sordino, or the plural, con sordini, and the editorial departments of our best music publishers permit it to pass.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 31. -- Because the Texas cotton industry is divided into three distinct economic groups, the farmer, the share cropper and the cotton broker, there is no unanimity of opinion in this State as to the advisability of the President's proposal that the AAA should be considered a permanent agency rather than a temporary expedient.

PETER LORRE is of Napoleonic size, if not of feature, and there has been fear in many quarters that he met his Waterloo when he went to Hollywood sixteen months ago. The evidence certainly pointed in that direction.

Qualifies of style would naturally be as apparent in one as in any. Generalizations as to the literary value of the type of story can only be fairly made when each has been considered and analyzed separately and in relation to the rest.

Charging that his adversary had created the impression that he had let criminals walk out of court, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan, in a statement last night, listed thirty-three felony convictions his office had obtained this week.

The recent tour of the bankers and corporation executives through some of the more widely known centres of industrial research laboratories, the interesting daily reports of Mr. Kaempffert and your editorial of Oct. 27 suggest comment on phases which might well be emphasized.

The 1935 session of the Legislature under the leadership of Governor Lehman and the Democratic majorities in the two houses was praised for enacting the most constructive social welfare legislative program in the State's history in the thirty-first annual report of the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union, made public yesterday.

Whatever may be the private opinions of individual bankers regarding the New Deal, the various committee reports delivered last week at the twenty-fourth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association reveal an apparent change in the attitude toward some of the most widely criticized regulatory acts of the Roosevelt administration.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 2. -- The budgets of about thirty undergraduate organizations at Pembroke College in Brown University will be the special concern of a newly reorganized finance committee working under the Student Government Association.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 2 (AP). -- The University of North Carolina continued its victory march by routing North Carolina State, 35 to 6, today before a crowd of 18,000 which overflowed Riddick Field's stands.

WILL ROGERS described himself as "just an ordinary Oklahoma cowpuncher who spins the rope a Little and reads the papers." He was an entertainer, he said, and modestly let it go at that. The world has the last word, however.

AFTER sixty years of discussion and negotiation the final plans for the construction of a tunnel under Mont Blanc are now under consideration by the French Government. Promoters of the scheme estimate that the work could be completed in three or four years and that receipts from the traffic through the tunnel would be as great, in proportion to capital expenditures, as those from the Suez Canal.

An aggressive campaign to encourage wider use by industry of the "natural business year" will be launched by accountants, bankers, credit men and representatives of management associations, as a result of plans drawn up at a meeting here last week, in conjunction with the executive committee of the American Institute of Accountants.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- California has lived with the Townsend Plan long enough to get over its surprise at the strength of this movement which would cure all our economic troubles by giving every person past 60 $200 a month and requiring him to spend it.

SPEAKING in terms of subject-matter, the days just past might well have been grouped under the title "Geography Week in the Galleries." New York, Provincetown, Panama, Moscow, Seattle, Mexico, China, Bali, Venice, Spain, London, the Atlantic and that nameless realm inhabited by decorative abstractions were all represented.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- One of the greatest last-ditch rallies in football history toppled the dreaded Scarlet Scourge of Ohio State from its lofty pinnacle today as 81,000 dumbfounded spectators saw Notre Dame score three touchdowns in less than fifteen minutes to gain almost miraculous 18-13 victory in the jammed Buckeye Stadium.

TRENTON, Nov. 2. -- Although a so-called "off year," because no major State-wide offices are to be filled, the general election in New Jersey next Tuesday will be watched with particular interest by political observers for a possible indication as to public sentiment toward the New Deal policies of President Roosevelt.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Mercersburg defeated Peddie by 26 -- 0 today on rain-soaked Annenberg Field. The Pennsylvania team scored in every period to preserve the record of never having been beaten by Peddie in the yearly contest.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., Nov. 2. -- Vermont scored a 6-0 victory over the Norwich eleven on Sabine Field today in a State series game that now leaves the race for the Green Mountain championship between Middlebury and Vermont.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 2. -- Rutgers used two complete teams to advantage in running through Lafayette for five touchdowns while holding the Maroon to a single score on Fisher Field today. Only one extra point was registered in six placement attempts and the final score was 31 -- 6.

THERE is no lack of published biographies of Benjamin Thompson, born in Woburn, Mass., of six generations of American farmers, who so contrived his life as to spend nearly all of it in Europe. There he picked up an unassorted lot of honors, emoluments, decorations and titles, the top of the heap being that of Count Rumford, by which for more than 130 years he has been generally known.

SINCE a year ago motoring conditions in Europe have undergone a considerable change. On the whole, it can be regarded as a change for the better. The automobile is everywhere recognized as the main method of transport and, particularly in Germany and Italy, road conditions are being made to suit really fast traffic.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2. -- The increasing number of trade inquiries received by the St. Louis Chamber of Commerce and similar organizations in other large cities of the Eighth Federal Reserve District indicate the steady quickening of business.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Vassar College has its own problem of Nazi recognition. Each Summer the German Government offers scholarships to selected students and in the past they have been unquestionably accepted. But in view of the present situation, efforts were made this week to learn whether the faculty approved acceptance of the opportunities for foreign study.

TURNING back the pages of automobile history to the dawn of the century, we find that some of the early motor-car designers came nearer to achieving ideal weight distribution than did some of the engineers in the Twenties and early Thirties, but perhaps the early engineers, like some of the engineers of later years, were to a great extent followers of precedent.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Failing to capitalize on a couple of scoring opportunities in the third quarter, but able to stage several efficient stands against the opposition, Lawrenceville came to the end of its 1935 football trail today by playing to a scoreless tie with Choate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Again delayed by construction work, the White House social program of official entertainments will open later than usual this year but earlier by a week than last year, when it was held up for a month.

PAWTUCKET, R.I. 24 Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Psychic Bid won the Fall River Handicap, $5,000 added feature, by a length from J.W.Y, Martin's Dark Hope before 20,000 at Narragansett Park today. The event was run at a mile and a sixteenth.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- City Controller S. Davis Wilson, Republican nominee for Mayor, stated tonight that he was investigating the activities of the grand jury which last night criticized his use of a $65,000 fund appropriated to him for a Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company revaluation survey.
WHEN it came time for that effulgent dictator Louis Quatorze, to sign his last will and testament, he sighed, with sardonic shrewdness: "As soon as I am dead it will be disregarded."

Mayor La Guardia assailed District Attorney Geoghan yesterday for his reference to Dr. Stephen S. Wise and the latter's daughter, Justine Wise Tulin, a member of the Domestic Relations bench, during a heated argument Friday with his Republican-Fusion adversary, Joseph D. McGoldrick.

WITH "Jubilee" in flower at the Imperial and "First Lady" and "Room Service" (lately "Sing Before Breakfast") in rehearsal, Sam H. Harris is letting his eye roam further along his schedule to item No. 4. This is quite likely, even quite certain, to be "As We Forgive Our Debtors," by Tillman Breiseth.

ALL signs point to 1935 as a peak year for the bus industry. With two months yet to go, it is estimated that approximately 375,000,000 passengers; have patronized intercity buses since the first of this year, almost as many as rode during the entire 12 months of 1934.

PETER CHAMBERLAIN is a young English writer whose work has been published by Story and reprinted by Edward J. O'Brien. His stories are striking, other reasons apart, because in tone they are much more American than British.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 2. -- Alumnae of Bryn Mawr College assured their Alma Mater today, at a fiftieth anniversary celebration, that the institution's dream of new educational facilities to provide for its 400 women students "bushels of straw to make bricks with" was about to come true.

READERS, and they must run well up into the high thousands, are likely to ask why anything more should be done on the subject of H.M.S. Bounty after the thrilling trilogy, "Mutiny on the Bounty," "Men Against the Sea" and "Pitcairn Island," by James Norman Hall and Charles Nordhoff.

Twenty-seven hospitals in Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk and Rockland Counties are listed as fully approved in the 1935 survey by the American College of Surgeons. The results of the survey, which embraced 3,565 hospitals in the United States and Canada, were made public last week at the college's convention in San Francisco.

The Ford Motor Company opened yesterday afternoon in Hotel Astor a special exhibit of its 1936 cars. Neither the Ford nor the Lincoln cars are being displayed at the national show in Grand Central Palace.

Trading was at the usual short- session pace in the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with the exception of sugar, which hit the previous top prices before selling off. Wheat advanced in the cash markets, with losses registered by corn, cotton, lard and rubber.

The Manhattan String Quartet which practiced the idea of performing ensemble works from memory here a few seasons back, has been receiving flattering notices from the foreign press during its present tour of Europe, on a schedule including appearances in London, Stockholm, Copenhagen, Amsterdam, The Hague, Paris, Geneva, Montreux, Zurich, Budapest and Rome.

Winston Leonard Spencer Churchill -- author, statesman, orator, adventurer, war correspondent, soldier -- is one of the most colorful and versatile men in Great Britain. Throughout his career Mr. Churchill has never shirked a fight; he has never failed to speak his mind.

ROME, Sunday, Nov. 3. -- An Italian advance on the northern front in Ethiopia, scheduled to begin at dawn, started just after midnight, Italian war correspondents reported early today to the Popolo di Roma.

IN AN enterprise so vast as the automobile industry, with its far-reaching influence on all commercial welfare, a continuous rate of change and progress is inevitable. Yet, with all its contributions to progress in design, research, employment and manufacturing efficiency, this industry makes its greatest 1936 contribution to national progress in the elements it builds into its cars which make them safer in the hands of their owners.

THE story of Joseph Smith, the prophet of Mormonism, is almost fool-proof. There is no need to pay much attention to defamers and vilifiers, the hundreds of early pamphleteering anti-Mormons. The mere bald narrative of the characters and events of the story of early Mormonism; taken wholly from Mormon sources and@ unprejudiced observers, transcends the most fevered dreams of the imagination.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Nov. 2. -- The voters of Suffolk County will go to the polls Tuesday to elect ten Supervisors in the ten townships, as well as town clerks, superintendents of highways, receivers of taxes, assessors and school directors.

More than 100 members of the New York Chapter of the Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians picketed the headquarters of the local WPA in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, yesterday morning, protesting the alleged "frame-up" of Jules Korchien, president of the chapter, and his ultimate dismissal from WPA payrolls for alleged organization activities.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- The gains which department store sales made in the First Federal Reserve District in September were not maintained in October. Last month's retail business was at about the same level as a year ago. Protracted warm weather was an important factor in holding down the retail demand for both men's and women's Winter clothing.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Gorton High's football team met with an unexpected defeat at the hands of Mamaroneck in their Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association contest today, dropping a 7-0 decision to the home squad.

ATHENS, Nov. 1. -- Under conditions of military dictatorship, male citizens of Greece are invited by Regent-Premier Kondylis to choose in Sunday's plebiscite between restoring King George as a ratification of the "crowned republic" founded as a result of the Kondylis revolution of Oct. 10 and authorizing General Kondylis to revive the "uncrowned republic" which the revolution upset.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told voters in a nation-wide broadcast tonight that the government has decided to embark on a five-year road program costing 100,000,000 [the pound currently is quoted at $4.91].

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, in discussing international problems yesterday said that the world today is witnessing a conflict between economic aspiration and political principle.

FOR the reader who likes to have a book lying handy wherein he may always find a page or two of pleasant chat, Cecil Roberts has provided "Gone Rambling." Some times his easy conversation is filled with information to be found -- according to him and probably he is right -- in no other book.

I was interested in the letter which appeared on the music page of THE TIMES of Oct. 20 from N. Lindsay Norden calling attention to the inaccuracies made necessary in the playing of most Western music since the times of Werckmeister, J.S. Bach and others by the imposition on it of the arbitrary tempered scales.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Among the blue-tailed skinks, spiny lizards, electric catfish and "small red rodents" donated to the National Zoological Park of the Smithsonian Institution during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1934, was an alligator, presented by Eleanor and Curtis Dall, familiarly known as "Sistie" and "Buzzie."

Coming from behind with a sensational sprint in the last fifty yards, Richard Slade of Nott Terrace High, Schenectady, defeated Leonard Dauenhauer, national inter-scholastic champion, by three yards to win the individual honors in the twenty-third annual Columbia University interscholastic cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 31. -- With Wisconsin Republicans intensely anti-Roosevelt, some influential members of the party, including large contributors to campaign funds, nevertheless are advocating a coalition in the 1936 campaign in which Republican support would be thrown to the Democratic nominee for Governor.
I read with considerable interest PAl Kelemen's letter under the heading "Hungarian Claims."

AMERICAN business has every reason to be optimistic concerning the outlook for the coming year, having reached such satisfactory levels during 1935. From all quarters comes undeniable evidence that a good measure of recovery has been attained during the past year.

As the Federal Government, through it Works Progress Administration, nears its goal of finding jobs for nearly 400,000 of New York State's unemployed, the State and local committees face the task of caring for more than 200,000 families, including between 700,000 and 1,000,000 individuals, who have neither jobs nor the means for self-support.

I AM against the stressing of high speeds in automobile advertising. It is only natural that, when the high speed of his car is brought constantly to an owner's attention, and when speed rivalry is made a point of public issue by various automobile manufacturers, the ordinary driver cannot resist the temptation to use this necessary but dangerous element on every possible occasion.

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- All over Paris this week big posters have been stuck up proclaiming that French Freemasonry wants war with Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and that in consequence Freemasonry, as represented by such men as Edouard Herriot and Camille Chautemps, must be crushed.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 2. -- Moises Poblete, delegate to the International Labor Office at Geneva, who presided today at a meeting of the committee preparing the Pan-American Labor Conference to be held here next month, outlined many problems that the Geneva office has recommended for consideration by the conference.

William Penn, founder Pennsylvania; Simon Newcomb, mathematician and astronomer, and Grover Cleveland, twice President of the United States, were elected to the Hall of Fame on the campus of New York University in the eighth quinquennial election, just closed. Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, director, announced yesterday.

THE fascination of sheer horror holds one's eyes glued to the pages of this book about the experiences of a white woman in the jungle of Sumatra. Tense emotions relax for hardly a moment from beginning to end as its incidents race past, shocking, amazing, revolting, horrifying.

It is hard to say whether little girls who live in the city or little girls who live in the country will enjoy Miss Phillips's story of Marty's visit to New York. Marty's home is on a farm, but for a whole Winter, while she visits her uncle and aunt, she exchanges a pleasant farmhouse for a New York apartment and the little white village school for a city school house five stories high.

New York University's versatile band of football players toyed with a bewildered Bucknell University eleven, punched over a pair of touchdowns with comparative ease and beat the Bisons, 14 to 0, at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. A crowd of 15,000 saw the local aggregation roll on to its fifth consecutive victory, the score of which hardly indicates the measure of superiority displayed, to remain among the nation's undefeated and untied combinations.

Unemployment and relief will be discussed at a luncheon-meeting Wednesday of the New Jersey League of Women Voters under auspices of the Women in Industry Committee at the L. Bamberger Co. restaurant in Newark.
MEXICO, D.F. HOLLYWOOD'S practical withdrawal from the production of Spanish dialogue pictures -- only one company being currently engaged in this pastime -- has been Mexico's opportunity.

LIKE G.K. Chesterton (who is mentioned only once in this book, but might appropriately have been mentioned much oftener), Mr. Agar is moved by an "ideal of personal liberty as expressed in private property." The idea is certainly not new, but it is here attractively presented as an alternative to the grim choice between fascism and communism, with which, as Mr. Agar says, our left-wing writers continually present us.

MINISTER of the People's Church of Chicago, Mr. Bradley preaches to large audiences there and to still larger ones over the radio. And to all this he now hopes to add a wider audience of readers for his understanding and inspiring discussion of fear, its causes, the devastation it works upon all the human race, and the methods by which the individual can free himself from its terrors and its serious, consequences.

With his friend Vice President John N. Garner acting as chairman, with more than 15,000 banks ready to serve as depositories and with the official sanction of the Governors of forty-seven States, the campaign to raise funds for a memorial to perpetuate the name of Will Rogers will get under way formally tomorrow, the fifty-sixth anniversary of the birth of the cowboy humorist.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The United States Department of Labor, through Colonel Frank P. Douglass of the Textile Labor Relations Board, today took steps to end the broadsilk strike. Colonel Douglass, after arriving here this morning, visited the offices of Mayor John V. Hinchliffe and later conferred with a delegation of strikers headed by Alexander Williams, general manager here for the American Federation of Silk Workers.

SOME three years after "Abie's Irish Rose" was what Broadway calls "in the money" the author of the play, Anne Nichols, considered the many appeals to change the last line of her gimcrack, which had to do with an orthodox Jewish father, who, to make everything even, remarked: 'Give me a piece of ham with mustard."

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Don Heap, a blond youth who used to give Evanston police a merry chase when they tried to keep him from getting into Dyche Stadium without a ticket, made good as a football player today with a 43-yard touchdown dash that gave Northwestern a 10-to-3 triumph over Illinois.

Miss Stella Peskowitz, 29 years old, a milliner, was found dead with three bullet wounds in her back about 6 P.M. yesterday in the kitchen of her home at 850 East 170th Street, the Bronx. Her stepbrother, Julius Greenspan, returning home at that time, discovered the body.

THE United States has become a magnet for gold. In the last few weeks more than $200,000,000 of bullion has streamed into the country, borne on the wings of fear -- Europe's fear of war and currency disorders.

NANKING, Sunday, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Reports of Chino-Russian negotiations for a pact to offset growing Japanese influence on the Asiatic mainland evoked the comment from a North China spokesman today that China eventually might have to decide between friendship with Moscow or Tokyo.

ON Feb. 9, 1937, Russia -- both Soviet and emigre Russia -- will commemorate the 100th anniversary of the tragic death of Alexander Sergeyevich Pushkin. Preparations for this event long since have been under way in Moscow as well as in all foreign capitals where the "exiled Russia" lives; they are carried on with exceptional zeal and solemnity.
Record totals for an off-year election here are expected to be shattered Tuesday, advance predictions indicating that upward of 1,750,000 voters will exercise their franchise at the polls.

Manhattan College buried the City College eleven under an avalanche of touchdowns at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Jasper machine scored almost as it pleased against a game but outclassed Lavender aggregation to run up a 65-to-0 victory while a crowd of 10,000 persons looked on.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Scoring once in each of the first three periods and twice in the final quarter, an improved Harvard team trounced Brown today in the Harvard Stadium, 33-0, under adverse weather conditions before 5,000 persons.

IMPERIAL AIRWAYS is preparing a startling experiment as a part of her contribution toward a transatlantic airplane line. The big British company has already made arrangements to share a seaplane base at Bermuda with Pan American Airways.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Resorting to an aerial attack, the Purple Tigers of Louisiana State University scored a touchdown in the last two minutes of play today to beat Auburn's defensively powerful and doggedly fighting Plainsmen, 6 to 0.

THE Duke of Gloucester's approaching marriage serves as a reminder that one of the King's sons still persists in remaining a bachelor. The King has five surviving children. His only daughter was married in 1922. His second son, the Duke of York. was married in 1923.

With the convention of the American Bankers Association at New Orleans only one week away, three candidates for the position of second vice president, carrying with it succession to the presidency two years hence, appear to local members of the association to be deadlocked.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace called upon agriculture and industry today to start a program of balanced production to handle "a moderate improvement in such a way that it does not later lead to another destruction."

IN the opinion of C.H. Bliss, vice president and director of sales of the Nash Motors Company, "economy, safety, comfort, appearance and performance are the yardsticks by which the motoring public will determine its choice of the new 1936 ears making their debut at the automobile shows this year."

THE automobile industry is closing its biggest year since 1929. It has been a year that has seen this great industry put on an epochal battle for the better economical well-being of not only itself but of the whole country, and a successful fight, too.

THE introduction of new ear models in the Fall is a double boon to the export sales manager. For the first time it enables us to enter the Southern Hemisphere markets with new models at the beginning of their major-selling season.

WOMEN, who might be termed the managing editors of the nation's family budgets, and the most vigilant guardians of national health and well-being, are likely to be more of a factor in automobile buying during 1936 than ever before.

The New York Giants will try to score their first victory against a Western rival when they meet the Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds this afternoon in a National Fotball League game. This will be the first league contest between the two teams since the Giants emerged victorious in their play-off for the league crown last year.

EITHER this department is in the pay of the Hays office or the Broadway cinema during the last two months has provided an uncommon sum of entertainment. Searching the records for September and October, I find that a score of the forty-odd films I looked at during that period delighted me in one way or another.

Aldermanic and Assemblyman candidates of the three major political parties in the Fifteenth district will be heard by members and friends of the American Woman's Association tomorrow night, at a pre-election forum in the ballroom of the clubhouse.

THOSE of us who live in "sky-scratchers," as an Italian friend insisted upon calling tall buildings, have forgotten that just as many Indian fights and scalping parties took place in New York as in any other State in the Union.

AN assignment to move the Empire State Building to the Chicago lake front would not appear a more difficult task to the layman than herding three thousand reindeer a thousand miles through the frozen wastes of the Arctic zone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to dismiss a request of the Washburn-Crosby Mill ing Company of Kansas for a review of a case involving farm processing taxes.

A heavy turnover in local traction issues at irregularly lower prices was the feature of an otherwise narrow and listless bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Interpretations of the tentative agreement in unification published in the morning caused a mixed tone in the traction group in initial dealings, which culminated in a rather sharp break in certain of the Interborough issues.
