PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- An Autumn ball will be given by the Jephtha Abbott Chapter, D.A.R., of Ardmore, for the benefit of the Tamassee D.A.R. School in the mountains of South Carolina, at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel on Nov. 15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- The government closed its books today on the first four months of the fiscal year to find that it had received only 47 cents for every dollar paid out. Receipts through Oct. 31, amounted to $1,233,000,000, while expenditures were $2,627,000,000.

In Horticultural Hall, Boston, next week the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England will hold its fourteenth annual specialty show, the spectacular feature of which will be the judging of the $1,000 Big Four Novice Stake.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 2 (AP). -- For the first time in four years, Marquette University's returning old grads celebrated a home-coming victory tonight, after the Golden Avalanche had stilled the Iowa State Cyclones, 28 to 12, before 15,000 spectators.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 2 (AP). -- On an accurately booted field goal after a spectacular 77-yard ground drive engineered by Fullback Bobby Grayson. Stanford's Indians defeated the University of Santa Clara's Broncos, 9 to 6, today as 15,000 persons looked on.

ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas Nov. 2 (AP). -- Prince Torch, carrying the yellow and cerise silks of Frank Abbate of Chicago, won the Arlington Downs Fall Handicap today over a mile and one sixteenth course. The gelding scored by a head over Bold Lover.

THE promotion of owner satisfaction, through elimination of delays in the replacement of parts for cars and trucks, is the announced objective of the expansion which the Chevrolet Parts Department has just completed, under the direction of M.D. Douglas, parts and accessories merchandising manager.

A TRUE analysis of existing conditions in the automobile retailing trade necessarily must include the experience gained under the Motor Vehicle Retailing Code when it was in effect. Contrary to general opinion, all the benefits to both the trade and the public derived from that experience did not end when the United States Supreme Court decreed NRA unconstitutional.

Rumors that the 600,000 hales of spot cotton remaining in the producers' pool may be made available to consumers later in the month helped to ease the near positions on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices ended unchanged to 7 points lower than on Friday.

WHEN the history of the automobile business is written, 1936 will probably go down in the Book as the "style year." Every indication is that in the next year, more than ever before, manufacturers will put emphasis on beauty of line, comfort and appointment.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- Good enough to stand a roughing at the top of the stretch and still come on and win was the home-bred colt Hollyrood, which won the Pimlico Futurity for Kentucky's Hal Price Headley today. A crowd of 20,000, including many distinguished visitors, saw the son of High Cloud victor by a length and a half in the first running of Maryland's greatest produce stake since 1932.

ONE of the most important motoring developments of recent years has occurred in the State of New Jersey. It is not the usual thing -- neither the completion of a magnificent highway nor a new advancement in automotive design. Instead, it is a highly intelligent effort to solve the human equation in the problem of modern motoring.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 2. -- A Frank Merriwell finish in which Vannie Albanese, Syracuse fullback, scored a touchdown with a minute to play brought Syracuse a 7-to-3 victory today over Penn State before 12,000 fans.

For Damon Runyon fans, a new volume of stories by the author of "Guys and Dolls" and "Blue Plate Special" is as welcome as "Money From Home." These stories, which have appeared previously in magazines, run true to form. They are told in picturesque, authentic Broadway jargon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Temple University, unbeaten on its home field since 1933, toppled before a fighting Michigan State team in the last period today, losing, 12 to 7, in one of the most sensational finishes ever seen at the Owls' Stadium.

HOLLYWOOD. FOUR yards of a steamship whistle are for sale. Seven and a half feet of "In the Gloaming" ending with a five-foot fanfare can be purchased at $2.50 a foot. Or, if your leanings are toward 350 feet of cowboys chasing Indians, with a 500-foot climax of a saloon brawl, you can be satisfied

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- J. Ramsay MacDonald, Lord President of the Council, and his Laborite opponent in the present electoral fight, Emanuel Shinwell, have declared a truce for the forenoon of Nov. 11. Both had speaking dates for that morning in the coal mining villages of the Seaham constituency, but they agreed to cancel them when their attention was called to the fact that it was Armistice Day.

Criticizing the Emergency Relief Bureau's methods of determining eligibility for work relief, the Lawyers Security League, at a meeting yesterday at the New York County Lawyers Association, 14 Vesey Street, voted to join other groups of professional persons and white collar workers in a protest meeting at Madison Square Garden Nov. 20.

STREET and highway safety depends upon three factors: the car, the road and the driver. The cars produced this year by the automobile industry have more inherent safety than ever before. The industry has pledged itself never to produce cars less safe than human ingenuity and engineering skill can contrive.
The editorials in your paper on the present Italo-Ethiopian war and the attitude of the administration concerning it are deserving of high commendation.

ALTHOUGH New York is one of the great cities of the world, let us not forget that it is also an island and a river town. The Hudson River, which becomes the North River when it eddies around the steamship piers, the East River and the Harlem River separate it from North America.

Beginning tomorrow and lasting until Thanksgiving Day the collection of funds for a Will Rogers memorial, or memorials, will be undertaken. A good deal of preliminary work has been done by the Will Rogers Memorial Commission. It has enlisted official and private aid in almost all the States.

While mail orders received during the week were somewhat lighter in a number of merchandise departments, market activity on the whole maintained a steady tone, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 2. -- Duke, paced by speedy Elmore Hackney, marched back into the victory column in convincing manner today by outplaying Tennessee to win, 19 to 6, before a home-coming day crowd of 16,000.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Wesleyan stopped Trinity's winning streak this afternoon on Andrus Field, 9 to 7.

A tent of red-and-white-striped canvas will envelop the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the annual Beaux-Arts Ball, "Quat'z' Arts Night in India," to be given on Dec. 6 under the auspices of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects. Cleon Throckmorton has designed the ballroom decoration for the fete, which this year is to portray a brilliant Oriental circus entertainment given by the "Maharajah of Ragput" for his honored guest, the Viceroy of India.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1. -- The Chaco peace conference formally declared this week that the war between Bolivia and Paraguay had terminated. This declaration frees peace negotiations from the military atmosphere which ruined former attempts to arrange a settlement but does not mean peace is any nearer than before the declaration was issued.

A further expansion program by the General Motors Corporation involving an expenditure of $60,000,000 which aims to "better stabilize employment" and "to make possible increased annual earnings for automobile workers," was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president.

MOTORING safety probably never has been as much in the public mind as it is today. Manufacturer, dealer, civic authorities, the motorist himself -- all have constantly in mind the reduction of accidents.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2. -- Duquesne defeated Carnegie Tech, 7 to 0, in a thrilling intracity struggle before 20,000 spectators at Pitt Stadium today. It was Duquesne's first victory over a Pittsburgh rival and at the end of the contest the Dukes' rooters, in a frenzy of joy, attempted to uproot the goal posts. The plan was foiled by Pittsburgh police.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Aggressive buying of December wheat on the Board of Trade here today by a house with Eastern connections, following an early dip, disclosed a heavily oversold pit condition and started short covering that continued until the close.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Gangsters, seeking to evade the new national crime laws and the power these statutes give to Federal prosecutors, are attacking the constitutionality of the Kidnapping and Firearms Registration Acts, the Department of Justice disclosed today.

RECENTLY a blind student of Manhattan College was elected to Epsilon Sigma Pi, highest honor scholastic fraternity of that college. Like him, sightless students in New York City keep smartly up in classes with the aid of brailled study courses.

NORTHERN FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Italian Army in Ethiopia, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Tractors hauled field artillery into position tonight and supply wagons brought up other war materials, as the Italian northern army prepared for its second important advance into Ethiopia, to start at dawn.

Generously illustrated, told in the form of letters, telegrams, newspaper clippings and cables, "The 'Charm' Girl" looks to be rather naughty, lightly humorous reading. It tries very hard to be just that. Its chief comedy prop is a dumb and beautiful girl whose innocent idiocy gets her into trouble, but also gets her out of it, and incidentally lands her in the money.

A YEAR of unparalleled highway construction has brought the metropolitan area closer than ever before to its destined position as centre of a great express highway system. Primed by Federal funds, road builders have been advancing along, over and beneath the ground to give New Yorkers easy exits from the crowded city and to give visitors equally facile entrances.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 2 -- Celebrating its first visit to Taylor Stadium since it returned home with a 14-to-0 victory. Gettysburg came back today to win again, defeating Lehigh by 21 to 14.

THE New York branch of the British Wine and Food Society gathered recently to taste thirty-seven types of American wines. Good food as an accompaniment of good wine is a primary concern of the parent society, a strictly non-commercial group organized in 1933, with its foremost object "to raise the standard of cooking as a means to better health and contentment."

IN the contest between Mussolini and the League of Nations an ancient way of life challenged a new aspiration. It has been the way of war against the way of peace. The rule that he shall take who has the power came to grips with the ideal of justice and law in a cooperative world.

The stirring days of the War of 1812 provide the background for Miss Crownfield's latest historical romance. On the Eastern Shore of Maryland life was comfortable and gay, and stout-hearted patriots were resolved to defend their homes against raids by the British.
Tamiris and her group made their season's bow last night in a dance recital at the Venice Theatre under the auspices of the New Dance League and New Theatre Magazine.

Plans for rapid advancement of the $416,861,000 transit unification plan recommended by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. will be discussed with the Board of Estimate tomorrow by Mayor La Guardia, who will also take up the question of early demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated line, as provided in the tentative agreement with the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 1. -- If ever the Italians tried and failed it was in the attempt, at no little cost, by Rome's representatives here to spread pro-Italian and anti-British propaganda in Egypt. Never have funds spent for such purposes been so wasted.

GENEVA, Nov. 2. -- The actual experience of the past week with the League's machinery for the enforcement of the covenant has shown on the one hand that it can work better than had generally been deemed possible, but on the other hand the problem it faces is even more difficult than was at first believed. So doubts remained whether its best would prove good enough.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 2. -- Hopes for an all-university peace organization are rapidly rising at Syracuse University with the authorization by the Men's and Women's Student Senates for hearings on plans for the formation of such a group. The hearings would be conducted by the student-faculty executive committee.

THOUGH Charles Gates Dawes has been prominently in public life all of this century and some of the last, America did not really discover him until 1921. In the course of a seven-hour speech before the grave and reverend seigniors of Congress who were investigating the A.E.F. the Director of the Budget said "Hell and Maria!"

Andre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador; Michael MacWhite, Minister of the Irish Free State, and several other men of distinction representing embassies and legations at Washington, as well as officers of high rank in various branches of the service will be among the guests of honor at the Horse Show men's dinner to be held on Tuesday in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE automotive industry can look forward with confidence to substantially higher commercial vehicle sales of its 1936 line, in the opinion of W.E. Fish, Chevrolet truck sales manager, under whose supervision the Chevrolet truck department have had its most successful year since 1929.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 2. -- Twenty-eight persons were arrested by the police tonight in what they called the rounding up of a spy ring working for Germany. The suspects were charged with "military high treason" for allegedly selling secrets to the Reich.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Henry Frederickson of Emerson High, Union City, staged a Garrison finish today to win the New Jersey high school cross-country championship at Branch Brook Park.
HELENA, Mont., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Tumbling temperature and new earth tremors caused relief forces to marshal every available worker tonight to care for quake-stricken Helena's growing list of homeless.

GRONINGEN, Netherlands, Nov. 2. -- Another victory for Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, challenger for the world championship at chess, resulted today in the fourteenth game of his match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, holder of the title.

AMERICA is in a mood for spending. Whether you take your index from charts of car loadings and blast-furnace production or by talking to the man in the street, you find that the upward swing of the business cycle, which started slowly nearly three years ago, has so gained in momentum that the average American now feels that the rainy day for which he has hoarded and saved has come and gone.

THIS pleasant book is a series of eight sketches and stories of the trotting circuit, of the horses themselves and the men who train and tend them. The racing of trotters, so popular thirty or forty yearn ago, has had its ups and downs, but the stables still follow the round of the county fairs, beginning in the South with the coming of Spring and ending in New England in the late Fall.

Debutantes, headed by the Misses Helen Wilmerding and Wendy Iglehart, are taking an active interest in the plans for the dinner dance in aid of the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement which will be held Thursday at the formal opening in the new Trianon Room of the Ambassador.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Decisive scoring thrusts in the first and third periods gave Amherst a 13-0 victory over Massachusetts State today in the annual town championship game.

Whenever the earth has shaken down buildings and blotted out life in Chile, Tokyo, Formosa or California, geologists have assured New York City that it is seismically safe. Yet early last Friday morning a goodly part of the region covering a thousand square miles and including the Middle Atlantic States and southern Canada was subjected to a series of shocks that made pictures swing on their hooks and glasses slide on tables.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The present generation of undergraduates is more serious than its predecessors, according to Professor Christian Gauss, Dean of the College in Princeton University, who submitted his annual report to President Harold W. Dodds today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Paul Whiteman has given to Williams College his life-long collection of scripts, arrangements, records and instruments tracing the development of music in America since the Colonial period. His gift was revealed in today's issue of The Alumni Review, which also made public plans of the trustees to give music a more prominent role in Williams's liberal arts curriculum.

HERE is a plot involving two men and two women, one of them dead. Dale Farwell's mother, Elaine, died soon after his birth, and her memory and the child were cherished alike by her widower. Throughout his childhood the boy reveled in Arthurian legend, and grew to think of his mother as Elaine, the lily maid, an image to which his father added life and color.
NEW evidence of the automobile industry's capacity for industrial leadership was revealed Saturday when the doors of Grand Central Palace swung open for the 1936 National Automobile Show.
PARIS, Oct. 31. -- In the few midseason collections which have taken place the shorter skirts and lower waistlines inaugurated last season are emphasized. On daytime dresses uneven hems are notable.

When will our Broadway drama critics wake up? Your reviewer's languid review of "Eden End" would seem to imply that Mr. Priestley's play is a virtual failure to be enjoyed only by a few old fogies. He politely wishes that he could have enjoyed it better, but he is awfully sorry the people were "dull," and Mr. Priestley "has only a modest talent for the theatre," and his "drama models are fairly outmoded."

For the first time since 1926, a Brooklyn Prep football team demonstrated superiority over a Poly Prep eleven, the Crown Heights representatives turning back their traditional rivals from Dyker Heights in the fourteenth meeting between the teams at Boys High Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

The movement between colleges and secondary schools to eliminate absolute standards and adopt an educational treatment appropriate to the individual student has spread to virtually all the institutions of higher learning in the country.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in a letter to Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, which was made public yesterday defended its recommendations for a $24,930,627 cut in the 1936 city budget, which Mr. Deutsch had criticized.

Here is another and especially pleasing volume in this attractive series of "Picture Tales" from many different lands. Mr. Hart has collected nineteen Dutch folk tales, including the story of St. Nicholas and a description of the way his festival is celebrated.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Within the closely guarded precincts of his mother's estate, President Roosevelt today gave himself almost a complete holiday, allotting only the minimum amount of time to work necessary to keep abreast of important correspondence.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- With the Stock Exchange closed today, money over the week-end was plentiful at one-half of 1 per cent. It was estimated that at least 26,000,000 was disbursed in interest and dividend payments for the first of the month, thus accounting for the unusual abundance of money today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Six awards were announced tonight in connection with the opening, with a private viewing, of the annual water-color and miniature exhibition at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. The show will be open to the public from tomorrow until Dec. 8.

TRAFFIC accidents and congestion had a good year in 1935 in spite of the fact that much was done about it. Quite recently this topic has been presented to the public by methods which, in merchandising terms, would be called "shock advertising." As serious as the problem is, however, most thinking people recognize the "blood and thunder" approach merely represents a stage similar to that through which the advertising industry has but recently passed.

MUNICH, Nov. 2. -- Rudolph Selz, a British Jew who had been in the Munich prison for a fortnight, was released this afternoon. No condition was attached to his release, but his passport was retained by the police.

A NEWS item of the last week: "PERRY, Fla. -- A 57-year-old author is in a serious condition in a hotel here following a highway accident last night. A motorist, blinded by the lights of an oncoming truck, struck his bicycle from the rear."

Automobile accidents and injuries caused by them were reduced substantially last month as a result of the city's anti-noise campaign coupled with the police safety drive, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

ANY discussion of the problem of so-called "Winter suits" for men must be tempered with a realization of the fact that most men have adopted the habit of wearing the same weight clothing all year round. There is probably some sound hygienic reason for this but actually it is the result of a clearer perspective of the main purpose of most clothes, which is to' make the wearer look well and feel comfortable.

WITH the approach of Winter, hobbyists are moving their wares indoors. For the gardener, a small glass herbarium in a wide-base bottle takes the place of his plot of flowers, a book on plantings of the plantings themselves.

WITH the presentation of its new 1936 models," says N. F. Hadley, chief engineer of the Plymouth Motor Corporation, the automobile industry is completing an important cycle in engineering. For ten years it has been advancing over definite engineering terrain, adding performance, comfort, safety, economy and style with the succeeding new models.

THE record of motor vehicle accidents in the United States for a ten-year period shows 293,860 fatalities and 10,300,000 persons injured. In 1925, there were 21,926 persons killed in such accidents; in 1934 the fatalities totaled 34,000.

After a study of the power situation in the State of Maine last Summer, during which I visited Eastport, the centre of the Passamaquoddy project, it is easy to understand why the State of Maine might hesitate to establish a power authority for the marketing of Quoddy power.

An exhaustive study of the behavior of 300 English, German, Austrian, Russian, Dutch and American prices during twenty periods of boom and crisis in business activity between 1845 and 1914, just published by the Austrian Institute for Trade Cycle Research in cooperation with the London School of Economics, concludes that there is no basis in fact for the theory that booms are becoming more intense and depressions worse and longer.

The appearance of talented pianists at the Town Hall continued yesterday afternoon with the recital of Gari Shelton, an artist not lacking in maturity, and who has studied with Ernest Hutcheson and Artur Schnabel. The pianist is not unfamiliar with the concert stage, having scored successes with prominent orchestras in this country.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 2. -- The fruits of the Summer labors of two Dartmouth undergraduates were put on display this week at the college museum, and a tale of exploration came to light.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- No form of clairvoyance is so popular in this country as reading the result of a distant national election in preliminary, local polls. That is why hordes of professional and amateur soothsayers are impatiently awaiting next Tuesday night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- A steep rise in the price of necessities in Italy is reported by the Commerce Department.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- New England is filled with rumors that the $36,000,000 hydroelectric power project at Passamaquoddy Bay, on which the Roosevelt Administration began work so cheerfully last May, will never be completed.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 2. -- Charging Newark, N.J., police broke a pledge of secrecy, Safety Director Andrew J. Kavanaugh tonight said Charles (Lucky) Luciana and five henchmen fled Miami Beach last Tuesday after confidential information had been made public by the New Jersey authorities.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 2. -- Undefeated in sixteen contests since 1933, the Nassau Collegiate Center eleven turned back the Brooklyn College football team, 12 -- 6, before 2,000 at Freeport Municipal Stadium today. It was the first time the victors were scored upon in the four games played this season.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 2. -- Hebron Academy upset Exeter today, 7 -- 0. scoring in the opening period when four forward passes in a row gained half the length of the field. The last, Tardiff to Dunlevey, resulted in the touchdown.

LAURENCE WHISTLER a young man of 23, from Oxford, has been awarded the King's Medal for his "Four Walls"; the first award of the medal, the second book to come from Mr. Whistler. The judges were John Masefield, Laurence Binyon, Walter de la Mare, Gilbert Murray and I.A. Richards.

There is nothing spectacular about the methods of Mr. Propper's pet sleuth, Tommy Rankin. He does not deal in miracles, nor does he rely on brilliant flashes of genius. He is just a hard-working detective who sticks to his job un til it is finished and is not too greatly discouraged when his theories prove to be wrong.

FLYING seems to be a far more general enthusiasm on the West Coast than in the East. So it seems fitting that Ruth Comfort Mitchell's light romance of a girl who was a born flier should have its setting in a small town overlooking the Santa Clara Valley.

A determined George Washington High School football team put up a stubborn battle before succumbing to the unbeaten and untied Curtis High eleven yesterday at Washington Stadium before 4,500 persons. Receiving unexpected opposition, the Staten Islanders rushed across a pair of touchdowns in the last period to triumph by a 20-12 score.

PRINCETON. A CHAIN of circumstances which began with the increased use of steel in burial vaults has led to the development, by Philip Kissam, Assistant Professor of Civil Engineering at Princeton University, of a method for improving the navigation of airplanes.

THERE is every indication that automobiles will be sold in larger volume during 1936 and that cars above the lowest-price brackets will receive a bigger percentage of the total business than has been the experience of the past four years.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 2. -- Minnesota's Galloping Gophers, still in tune with the victory march, wrote another score of triumph today over Purdue's Boilermakers with a 29-7 conquest that gave last year's national champions an unbeaten string in twenty-one gridiron battles.

AS a newcomer to New York," said Mel H. Hewins, newly appointed zone manager of the Studebaker factory organization in the metropolitan district, "I can better understand several of the striking contrasts of this biggest city.

EVERYTHING that Serge de Diaghileff did had to be done more sumptuously than it had ever been done before. Everything must make a big splash. Everything must be done, moreover, in accordance with Diaghileff's wishes Money? That would come. Men? They would obey -- or, to use the customary euphemism, they would "cooperate."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- A powerful, fast-moving Mississippi State eleven toppled a proud Army team into the ranks of beaten squads today by a score of 13 to 7. Twenty thousand spectators watched the Cadets go down to defeat after one of the hardest fought football games ever played in Michie Stadium.

Two rugged lines of granite mold battled each other to a standstill yesterday, checked offensive gestures at their very inception and finished sixty minutes of bruising, punishing football on even terms as Fordham and Pittsburgh played a scoreless tie.

To assist the Lenox Hill Settlement House in its plan of rehousing Yorkville, the social service committee of Hunter College has organized the Tenants' League. Volunteer members will devote their free time to addressing clubs and to canvassing the neighborhood for tenants' signatures in favor of rehousing.

AUTOMOBILE show time, whether it comes in January or in November, brings with if the perennial query: What are the prospects for the coming year? The answer, so far as my own company's outlook is concerned, has already been given in Chevrolet's announcement lust month that it had completed a plant expansion program on which we expended $25,000,000 in order to increase our production capacity by 25 per cent.

Skilled workers on WPA projects are threatening a State-wide strike to enforce organized labor's demands for the prevailing rate of wages, it was disclosed yesterday by spokesmen for the bricklayers and affiliated trade unions.

NEW YORK'S Domestic Relations Court, that ambitious social tribunal formed two years ago, apparently will have to go through the coming year with only a small portion of the increase in appropriation which it sought to enable it to broaden its work of social reclamation.

NOW, if ever, steady hands are needed on the industrial and financial reins of this country to consolidate the gains already made in our return to better times. In my opinion, there is nothing in today's general economic conditions, nor in the outlook for tomorrow, that should slow down the inspiring industrial march that has marked the past eight months of this year.

PARIS. MOVEMENT is the outstanding characteristic of the hats for midwinter and early Spring shown in Paris midseason millinery openings. Whereas last year the movement was aerodynamic, this season it is positively aerial.

A private investigator named Warren Bayne is summoned to Thor Castle in Hollywood to guard its owner, Rufus Thorne, against an unknown danger. Mysterious threats have been received, and several of the fierce dogs which guard the place have died suddenly and without apparent cause.

Coming as a surprise to steamship operators and to Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, longshoremen working coastwise ships went on strike suddenly yesterday for two reasons. They struck in sympathy with dock workers in the South, as they have been threatening to do for two weeks, and they also demanded a shorter working week.

IT HAS been my business for many years to sell automobiles," said William B. Hurlburt, vice president in charge of sales of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation. "As a result I have had to study the public to find out why it buys, what the motivating influences are that lead to the selection of a car.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Two perfectly executed plays, one by land and the other by air, left Columbia and Cornell locked in a 7-7 tie today on Schoellkopf Field.

THE new cars on display this year emphasize more strikingly than ever before the almost incredible strides which the automotive industry has taken since the day when the motor car's survival was a highly debatable question -- with more voices raised on the negative than on the affirmative end of the debate.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 2. -- The developments on the frontier of the Danakil desert are being watched with the greatest interest by the Ethiopian general staff and the Emperor. They believe the best policy in that sector is to let the savage Danakil tribes, unhampered by modern ideas of strategy, harass and cut up the Italian troops.

An elderly woman returning home from church was fatally injured yesterday morning at Grand Concourse and 200th Street, the Bronx the police said, by a young hit-and-run driver who was captured by two citizens after a short chase.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Sullivan County, here in the foothills of the Catskills, today resembled an armed camp, with regiments of red-capped and red-coated huntsmen deployed over 12,000 square miles of what is probably the finest deer country in the State of New York.

A GARDEN in the sunroom is the natural consequence of adding a sunroom to a house. Such a garden may be only a single-window whimsy or one of luxuriant tropical growth. A tinkling wall fountain or a fern-bordered pool graced by a tender water lily is quite within the possibilities offered by sunroom gardening.

THE citizen of the French Republic who is known as Le Corbusier -- he was born Jeanneret and his given name is Charles-Edouard -- is just now paying his first visit to America and has had his first eyeful of the man-made miracle which is New York.

Counsel for the United Fruit Company called nine witnesses yesterday at the final session of a three-day hearing at the United States Customs Court, 201 Varick Street, during which Dean Charles E. Clark of the Yale University Law School, sitting as special master for the National Labor Relations Board, heard testimony in a case involving an alleged violation of the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act.

The collection of tapestries, rugs, silver, furniture and other art objects' auctioned yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries realized $27,137.50. It was made up of pieces from the collections of Mrs. Paul Verdier, wife of the owner of a department store in San Francisco; Charles A. Stonehill of Chicago, Mrs. Evelyn Cohn and Mrs. Charles Amory of New York and others.
A hotly contested battle for control of the next Assembly will be fought at the polls in New York State on Tuesday, election day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The War Department assigned Captain John Meade today as military attache in Addis Ababa to serve as observer with the native troops. He will be our first military attache to Ethiopia. Colonel Pedro Del Valle of the marine corps, however, has been in Ethiopia as an observer for a month.

PLANS for the Rachmaninoff Festival to be held at Sheffield, England, next October, include the performance of his favorite and most ambitious composition, "The Bells," based on Poe's poem of that name.

TWO conflicting views have lately been expressed about our future trade relations with the rest of the world. One view is that because of our sad experience with foreign investments, and because of our unwillingness to accept sufficient imports of goods and services, it may be only a few years until the United States is again a debtor nation.

THE thirty-sixth annual automobile show opened yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, and will continue daily through this week, including Election Day, from 10:30 A.M. to 11 P.M., except that today it will be closed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Import duty collections on wines and liquors were higher in September than in any previous month since prohibition repeal, according to figures made public today by the Treasury Department. Total collections were $3,416,206, as compared with $2,437,326 in the preceding month and $3,031,828 in the corresponding month of last year.

The piano recital given by Sergei Rachmaninoff yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was a brilliant occasion. The atmosphere was that of pre-depression enthusiasm and festivity. The audience was dotted with celebrities of music, and students were everywhere, come to listen to an acknowledged master.

ABOUT five years ago the Columbia faculty authorized students to obtain prerequisite credit for any college course by passing an achievement examination on the more elementary course. If for any reason a student wishes to anticipate a course he may make application to take one of these tests.

DR. FINER, who holds the Chair of Reader in Public Administration in the University of London, announces in his introduction that his book "is intended to be a work of impartial recognition and explanation." It is possible that Dr. Finer has a different conception of impartiality than that usually held, but the method of his book is not likely to impress the average reader as judicial.

CLOSELY intertwined with the history and development of our country is the Federal style, beloved alike by the home decorator and the antique collector. In this fashion, which began with the Revolution and lasted well into the second decade of the nineteenth century, were furnished such homes as Washington's Mount Vernon and Jefferson's Monticello.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Under the executive direction of Charles W. Eliot 2d, grandson of the late Harvard president, the National Resources Committee has blueprints on hand for the future development and use of land, water and other national resources.

A year from today America's political Olympic games will reach their quadrennial climax and the country will learn which of the two existing major parties will govern it during the next four years. At this stage a third-party victory seems impossible and a third-party vote in the Electoral College improbable.

With adverse weather conditions continuing to check retail distribution, trade conditions were spotty in many sections of the country last week. Reports from several Federal Reserve District, however, indicated an improvement in industrial operations and slight gains in unemployment were noted.

THE eighth annual contract bridge tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup will begin on Wednesday afternoon at 3 o'clock at the Park Lane Hotel. The tournament is for teams of four, and entrants must be "invited," though the entries of players not on the invitation list are rarely, if ever, rejected.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Williams, with a brilliant array of backs, routed Union, 43 -- 6, today to register its fifth victory of the season.

THE country is being honored, these Saturday afternoons, with a look around that fabulous corner so grimly sought by the economists. The view is good. For far beyond the petty figures of carloadings, the dull graphs of backlog, ear-markings, unfilled orders and Seasonal Trends, lies the fact that once again the ball is on the 40-yard line.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Research on the mechanics of lubrication, taking in a far-reaching field that extends from wrist watches to ocean liners, will be started within a few days at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2. -- The discovery that a warm current from the Atlantic Ocean penetrates Arctic regions as far east as Wrangel Island, only 500 miles from Bering Strait, was announced today after investigations by Soviet scientists abroad the icebreaker Krassin.

DESCRIPTIONS of the new cars for 1936 are given in alphabetical order below. All the passenger cars listed are on exhibition at the show in Grand Central Palace, except the Ford and Lincoln, which are on display at the Hotel Astor, at the Park Lane and at the company's headquarters, 1,710 Broadway, at Fifty-fourth Street.

A small drinking fountain for birds was dedicated yesterday morning on the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the cathedral. The fountain is a memorial to James Herman Aldrich, the late philanthropist.

A survey of New York City candidates for the Assembly made by letter, telegram and "otherwise" has disclosed that 111 of them are in favor of amending present laws so as to permit Mayor La Guardia to construct a municipal "yardstick" power plant without pledging city credit, the Consumers Public Power Plant Committee announced yesterday.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 31. -What the President's statement of future farm policy means to the Corn Belt farmer depends upon which of its two propositions is under consideration -- the promise of AAA permanency or the design to effect a considerable change in the manner of its application.
THE introduction of the new Cord front drive car at the Show involves considerably more than bringing out a new model. It is the contribution of an independent manufacturer to a great industry.

Jobs for New York actors are an immediate result of the recently announced WPA arts program, which will expend $27,000,000 in nation-wide re-employment in painting, sculpture, music and literature, as well as in the theatre.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 2 (AP). -- The Nebraska football team wallowed through puddles today to a 19-to-6 victory over Missouri in a Big Size Conference game which brought the favored Cornhuskers within one step of the championship.

IT is midnight and New York's theatre crowd, save for the late diners and dancers in the all-night spots, is moving toward home. Over on the North River a giant transatlantic liner, with a dozen or more tugs shoving and hauling, is moving slowly and with infinite labor out into the stream for the earthed passage.

Less than three weeks ago shipping men in New York expressed anxiety over the outcome of Mediterranean cruises scheduled for the Winter, and since that time five of the most important of these have been either canceled outright or altered to suit the disturbed ports of the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- At least $6,000,000 will be spent by Rexford G. Tugwell's Resettlement Administration in constructing the proposed "satellite" city just thirty minutes from Times Square in the "greenbelt" district at Bound Brook, N.J.

Preparations are under way for the fifteenth annual Christmas sale and tea for the benefit of Hope Farm, a community in Dutchess County, N.Y., which cares for and educates more than 200 boys and girls, and prepares them to be self-supporting after leaving the institution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The work-relief program is nearly 2,000,000 jobs short of its goal of 3,500,000 employed, official figures revealed today, although only ten days remain in which to redeem the pledge of Harry L. Hopkins, WPA administrator, that the objective will be substantially reached by Nov. 12.

EXCEPT for cigarettes and strong liquor, gasoline is probably the most heavily taxed commodity in America. Most of this fuel is consumed in transporting goods and passengers for non-pleasure purposes, yet gasoline taxation continues, and is rising, not only because it is a convenient and vast source of income, but also because the public submits docilely to the mythical theory, disproved even twenty-five years ago, that motor vehicles are mainly operated for pleasure.

NOT every garden can have its quota of hotbeds or even cold-frames, but no garden is so small, or run on a budget so modest, that at least a simple board frame cannot be added to its equipment. Even if such a "frame" is no more than two parallel boards set on edge and held in place by short stakes driven into the soil, it will serve many useful purposes.

RADIO seems to prove that drama stripped of visuality can be successful; no longer is it considered as a freak outcrop of the stage and screen. This season finds more plays being electrified for broadcasting. Some are adaptations. Others are original.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 2. -- Westchester County voters, deeply concerned in county government reform, are awaiting with interest the vote on the State Constitution at next Tuesday's election. The amendment has been hailed by leaders in the movement for county reform as a sort of Magna Charta for New York State counties.

The sixty-first annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which will be opened a week from tomorrow in New Orleans, will provide a test of the banking community's response to the far-reaching changes brought about by the Banking Act of 1935 and the regulations affecting banking practice incident to that legislation.

Edward Vaca of Textile for the second time this Fall cracked the P.S.A.L. record for 75 yards breast stroke at the weekly series of dual swimming meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high championship, conducted in the 75-foot pool of De Witt Clinton High School yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- After a prolonged pause, caused, apparently, by the nee to consolidate positions in the North and by the interference of rains in the South, the Italian invasion of Ethiopia has made further progress in both extremities.

WITH the demand for motor cars still strong and general business conditions distinctly better, the industry's contribution to employment stabilization in the form of an earlier show date has every chance of meeting with public approval.

In the belief that the trend of legislation justifies intervention in behalf of railroad credit, executives of important savings banks and insurance companies have organized to present their views to legislative bodies. The increase in railroad bankruptcies in recent months has been a factor in this decision.

For the first nine months of this year the Murray Corporation of America and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $1.129.200 after depreciation, interest, subsidiary preferred dividends, Federal taxes and other charges. The profit is equal to $1.47 a share, based on 768,732 shares of $10 par common stock which were outstanding on June 30

FOR the first time in twenty years, White trucks are being exhibited at the New York Automobile Show. The purpose is to display the company's streamlined trucks introduced a short time ago. They were designed by Count Alexis de Sakhnoffsky, motor vehicle stylist and winner of the Grand Prix in Paris for six consecutive years.

ATHENS, Nov. 2. -- Seventy-five to eighty per cent of the votes in the plebiscite tomorrow will be announced as in favor of the restoration of former King George II by the royalist officials in charge of the tabulation of the ballots, it is reported here on the eve of the poll.

While the wedding bells were pealing at a fashionable marriage the best man had his first glimpse of the maid of honor and fell in love instantly. As they marched down the aisle together he told her he loved her and asked her to marry him. Very fast work.

METRO'S film of "Mutiny on the Bounty" has the distinction, enviable or otherwise, of being the most expensive production to come from Hollywood this year. Two years in the making and involving film expeditions to Pitcairn's Island and Tahiti -- not to mention prolonged location trips to Catalina -- the picture is reported to have cost between $1,800,000 and $2,000,000.

The November meeting of the Association of Assistants to Principal in Charge will be held at the George Washington Hotel, Lenox Avenue and Twenty-third Street, on Wednesday starting at 4 P.M. Assistant Superintendent John K. Bolen will be the guest speaker and will discuss "In-Service Training of Teachers."

IN several previous volumes, "When Ships Go Down," "SOS" and others, Mr. Masters has proved his extensive knowledge of ships and the dangers that encompass them at sea and also his ability to write most interestingly about them and their disasters.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- The semi-official Diplomatische Korrespondenz, mouthpiece of the Foreign Office, replies to Stanley Baldwin's recent speech, in which the British Prime Minister expressed regret over Germany's departure from the League of Nations.

As a result of the bankruptcy action of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company passed its preferred and common dividends yesterday, for the first time since 1907. The utility is controlled by the United Gas Improvement Company.

MODELS of the new Ford V-8 trucks and commercial cars are on display at the Hotel Astor and at the Ford Motor Company's salesrooms, 1,710 Broadway. They reveal a number of refinements in design but no radical change.

Passage of a remodeled Recovery Act at the next session of Congress will depend chiefly on the substantiation organized labor will be able to give to its claims that widespread lengthening of hours and cutting of wages have followed collapse of the codes, according to association executives and business men yesterday.

Will the Chinese laundry man who called Mrs. H.M. Cunningham of 201 West Seventy-eighth Street yesterday about a "speaking pigeon" please communicate with her immediately? Such is the appeal carried in a classified advertisement in THE NEW YORK TIMES today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. MAX GORDON has brought two productions in this week and filled Philadelphia's theatrical cup full to its glittering rim. When his "The Great Waltz" opened the huge Metropolitan Opera House Tuesday night it not only restored to theatricals a theatre that has not known them for lo, these many years, but it put electric lights ablaze upon the sixth legitimate theatre in Philadelphia to feel their beneficent warmth this week.

ROME, Nov. 1. -- Sanctions have been the favorite subject of even the most casual conversations among Italians for many months. Yet now that they are actually here they come as something almost unexpected to the majority of people.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Yale University and Canton, China, will join next week in commemorating the centennial of the founding of the Ophthalmic Hospital in Canton by Dr. Peter Parker, who later became American Commissioner and Minister to that country.

Basil Manly, vice chairman of the Federal Power Commission, was attempting to obscure the real issue in his recent letter to Mayor La Guardia in which he assailed figures tending to show that electric rates here were lower than the average charged by municipal plants in the State, according to a statement made by Joseph M. Proskauer, counsel for the Consolidated Gas Company.

The National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association joined yesterday the protest of industrial and business groups against the enactment of any legislation to supplant the defunct NRA. The National Association of Manufacturers and the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers voiced last week their protest and cited the gains made by industry since the invalidation of the NRA.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- A British ambulance unit for service in Ethiopia is ready to start for the war zone. The ambulances will be shipped next Thursday and the remainder of the unit will leave about Nov. 15 for Harar via Aden and Berbera. Headed by Andre Melly, 37-year-old London surgeon, the personnel includes Captain Townshend Stephens as adjutant and Doctors Macphee, Montgomery, Bevan and Backhuus.

DALLAS, Nov. 2. -- Cooler weather has resulted in a sharp upturn in retail sales throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, with increasing business activity generally. Marketing of the cotton crop with ready sales for all kinds of livestock, has released considerable cash in Texas and retail merchants report this increased buying power is reflected in higher sales.

JAPANESE broadcasters are having better luck this season than earlier in the year, when atmospherics dimmed their programs by the time the waves overspread the New York area. Recently, JVN, near Tokyo, has been clear on the 10,660 kilocycle channel from 6 until after 7 A.M., Eastern standard time.

NEW ORLEANS. CHALMETTE BATTLEFIELD, just below New Orleans on the winding Mississippi River, where, on Jan. 8, 1815, Andrew Jackson and his little army of Tennessee squirrel hunters and swashbuckling Barataria pirates put a decisive end to the War of 1812 by defeating General Pakenham and his veterans of Waterloo, is being transformed into a national park.

THE impending collision between the New York Giants and the Chicago Bears of the post-graduate or professional gridiron group recalls the story of the stranger in a country town who came upon a circle of citizens surrounding a bulldog that was turning on its own axis, frothing at the mouth and every now and then giving little leaps and yaps of anguish.

CITATION: Retiring from the army after thirty years' service, Sergeant John A. Johanson, Governors Island, New York, received last week congratulations not only on his record but also on his mustache. Said the official order:

THE winners in the MacDowell Club young artists' contest have been selected. The successful candidates who will be presented in recital at the club are Thomas Richner, pianist, Fort Marian, Pa.; Sidney Schachter, pianist, Winnipeg; Frederick Dvonch, violinist, Hempstead, L.I.; Renee Norton, mezzo-soprano, New York; Kempton Searle, bass, Westfield, N.J., and Anna Steck, colorature soprano.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Leaving no doubt of its intention to conserve railroad revenues wherever possible, the Interstate Commerce Commission reaffirmed today a ruling that reduced from $15,000 to $8,000 a claim of Ernest S. Ballard for legal work in the Dixie train litigation on behalf of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway.

The contract bridge team of Robert Chatkin, Jay T. Feigus, Alexander Schultz and Al Brodsky, representing the Long Island Bridge League, won the Sir Derrick Wernher Trophy, signifying the metropolitan team championship of the American Bridge League, at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

AT the outset of its 1936 campaign the automobile industry is not unlike a football team that has captured the ball under the shadow of its own goalposts and, by the successful execution of three series of plays, has carried it back up the field well into the opponent's territory.

THIS is a prep school story about a boy who is a special case. Whether or not that case will interest you will likely depend on what sort of boy you would like to have been or would like your son to be. For the novel has no special merit as a story or a picture of modern school life or as a study in education.

NO one views the mounting toll of traffic mishaps with greater concern than the car manufacturer. I call them traffic mishaps rather than automobile accidents because they are due much more to the exigencies of traffic than to machinery designed to move only in strict obedience to the will of an operator.

AN airplane design, dated 1799 and engraved upon a silver disk, has been discovered in England and is being placed on exhibition in the London Science Museum. It was identified as the work of Sir George Cayley, who was one of the earliest followers of Leonardo da Vinci in planning flying machines heavier than air.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1. -- The Western Pennsylvania district made its start this week under the Guffey-Snyder national bituminous coal control system -- the "little NRA" -- with the largest commercial soft-coal concern of the country, the Pittsburgh Coal Company, and several other sizable corporations holding back from signing the code.

Their living-room mantelpieces already sagging under the load of regatta prizes for firsts, seconds and thirds that were picked up during the racing season from May to October, the nation's leading outboard drivers during the coming week will make room for the really large trophies of gold and silver which are awarded on the basis of the season's point scoring.

TO the thirty-odd surveys made of New York City's schools in the past twenty years, a special committee, headed by Owen D. Young, now proposes to add another -- presumably a survey to end surveys. City schools in this instance, to be sure, will be investigated only as a part of the general State educational problem.

N attempting to evaluate the car of the future, one might ask three simple questions in this probable order: What will it look like, how will it perform and how will it be built? The American automobile industry is on the qui vive with its eye to the future and much which is now behind the curtain of the experimental laboratory and the proving ground will form the basis of this car of the future.

GENEVA, Nov. 2. -- With kind, conciliatory words for the Italian nation, the coordinating committee of the League of Nations tonight fixed Nov. 18 as the day when the League world shall cut off all credits to and purchases from Italy and all exports to Italy of a score of key war materials.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday commended Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, for his preliminary investigation of a case which has resulted in a conviction in connection with the "kick-back" racket.

ERNEST WEEKLEY needs no introduction to American readers who know any of his previous books, which ought all to be well known to every one for whom words have an inherent fascination or for whom they are important tools that demand skill in their use.

MANY authorities now contend that the best time to plant hedges is in the Fall as soon as the plants become dormant. The expectation of killing frosts before long means that planting time will soon be here. In the meantime the ground can be prepared and the type of planting material to be used selected.

Some time ago the dramatic critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES advanced the bold proposition that perhaps it is all right for the theatre to try to be theatrical. Mr. ATKINSON'S suggestion reaches out in many fields. Today, for instance, in the anniversary month of MARK TWAIN'S centennial, you find yourself wondering if the fame of a great humorist might not be primarily due to the fact that he was humorous.

Because yesterday was All Souls' Day and Friday was All Saints' Day, the observance will be continued in many churches today, including Masonic services this afternoon or tonight when lodges will attend in a body their annual church services.

These poems make the second book of a 33-year-old Communist from Chicago, and the first book in "a projected series which will present the work of proletarian poets." The edition, however, is not expected to reach the masses: it is limited to a thousand copies.

IF you have never read anything by Rex Stout, "O Careless Love!" should prove an enticing introduction. This seems a thoroughly safe prediction to a reviewer who has just read the book with enthusiasm and exhilaration.

THE mystery of the disappearing golf ball, which long has vexed players of the Darwin course near Sydney, Australia, has been solved. The culprit is a large species of land crab which infests the mangroves along the fairways. It steals the balls.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 3. -- A completely equipped hobby room was opened at Brown University this week to provide new and varied ways for students to use their leisure for developing handicraft and other interests.

THERE'S a thrill about having clothes made to order that is indescribable. Perhaps it is the personal attention one receives, certainly it is the excitement of feeling that one is going to give expression to one's own taste.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 2. -- The age-old question of prohibition will be a major issue when Kentuckians go to the polls in Tuesday's election.

In all the flood of contradictory news about the Ethiopian war, and in the diverse discussions of it, the ordinary man may find it hard to keep his eyes unclouded. He is told of diplomatic scheming and of plots, by one nation or another, to make use of the League for its own selfish interests.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- A sharp drop in temperatures early Friday started November retail trade off in good shape, with several cut price sales of heavy apparel drawing big crowds. The week as a whole, however, was somewhat unsatisfactory, due to the unseasonably warm weather.

FLAGS on Lexington Avenue, sleek and shining bodies-in exhibition halls and hotel lobbies, the Automobile Show in town two months ahead of time. As a social event, a thing to go to, it attracts all types and all classes. As an earnest of prosperity it lightens the gloom of the bitterest pessimist.

The opening of the new Automobile Show finds the motor-car industry in the most favorable position it has occupied in recent years. Sales in the domestic market have been larger in 1935 than in any other year since 1930. Sales abroad have also been rising, and will top the 1930 figure by a small margin if exports continue at their present rate.

No immediate prospect of widening the broadcasting band to 2,000 kilocycles is indicated by Federal Communication Commission officials. In reply to the possibilities of such expansion they ask several questions:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- An enviable decoration conferred by the King of the Belgians upon Captain Edward Darlington Jones of the Coast Guard brought a hard problem to some Treasury sub-officials today as they strove to reconcile such signal recognition by a foreign government with direct legal difficulties in the way of its acceptance.

Prices on home furnishings will average 10 per cent higher when Spring lines are opened, a canvass of the major lines revealed here yesterday. Included in the list of product for which advances are in prospect are furniture, floor coverings, curtains and drapes, upholstery fabrics, metal hollowware of all types, electrical appliances, lamps and glassware.

TOKYO, Nov. 2. -- A War Office report issued tonight giving the result of the preliminary examination of Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa, who killed Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata on Aug. 12, admits for the first time that the army has been racked by internal dissension, due to the efforts of one faction to effect what is called a "national renovation."

THE Chrysanthemum Show and Autumn Exhibition of the New York Horticultural Society, largest and most important Fall flower show in the metropolitan area, will be held in the Museum of Natural History next Friday and Saturday from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. and on Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M.

Mrs. Paul Conkling, chairman of the art department of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, will be the guest speaker tomorrow afternoon at a meeting of the Athena Club of Freeport in the parish house of the Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 2. -- Captain Marvin Jones's successful placement kick for the extra point gave Geneva College a 7-6 victory over Washington and Jefferson today, the Covenanters' first triumph over the Presidents since 1918, and their fifth in twenty-seven games.

THERE was no mistaking the objective. From as far north on Sixth Avenue as Radio City, those two mammoth new red signs were visible, extending from the six-storied roof of the Hippodrome down the corners of that venerable building and proclaiming in letters six feet high that the famous old house of wonders had acquired for itself a new tenant.

About 10,000 children have received the vaccine originated by Dr. William H. Park of the Health Department and himself and not a single child so treated has had infantile paralysis, Dr. Maurice Brodie of New York University said in taking note of statements by Dr. Simon Flexner of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research that "no adequate evidence" exists to prove that any vaccine is an effective agent against the disease.

LATE last Summer when Hallie Flanagan was struggling with the decision of whether or not she wished to undertake the central direction of the Federal theatre projects as conceived in Washington, one of the first questions to arise was what could be done under Federal sponsorship and the WPA set-up as far as the theatre was concerned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A broadened complaint including charges against additional concerns has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission against the Building Material Dealers' Alliance of Pittsburgh and Cleveland. It charges formation of a combination to compel distribution of building materials through "recognized" dealers affiliated with the organization and fixing prices by agreement.

THE English Bible has been singled out for exhibition in so many quarters lately that for any one interested in its early history there will be little opportunity to remain in ignorance. The occasion for all the celebration is the fourth centenary of the publication of the first complete Bible in the English language.

Dr. Richard Gottheil, Professor of Semitic Languages at Columbia University and the only teacher of Ethiopic languages in the United States, points out that the African country which the Italians are invading is, historically speaking, Abyssinia rather than Ethiopia.

FOR many years Boy Scout leaders have been troubled by the problem of the older Scout. The situation stands somewhat like this: scouting as it is appeals satisfactorily to boys up to the age of 15; then, in many instances, interest in the program dwindles and there is a tendency to drift away.

AS it contemplates the beginning of a new automotive year America's motor car industry can gain encouragement by looking back upon the first ten months of 1935. It can readily be said that the optimism which radiated from the Grand Central Palace last January has been completely justified by the results to date.
THE automobile industry takes pardonable pride this week in presenting to the public the results of another year's preparation -- the 1936 models.

THE approach of a general election is giving Britain an Autumn more active politically than any since 1924. In a period of international crises, when the pressure on the Prime Minister is heavy, Stanley Baldwin must find time to appear on the political platform.

TOKYO, Nov. 2. -- A War Office report issued tonight giving the result of the preliminary examination of Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa, who killed Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata on Aug. 12, admits for the first time that the army has been racked by internal dissension, due to the efforts of one faction to effect what is called a "national renovation."

It can readily be said that the optimism which radiated from the Grand Central Palace last January has been completely justified by the results to date.
THE automobile industry takes pardonable pride this week in presenting to the public the results of another year's preparation -- the 1936 models.

THE approach of a general election is giving Britain an Autumn more active politically than any since 1924. In a period of international crises, when the pressure on the Prime Minister is heavy, Stanley Baldwin must find time to appear on the political platform.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 2. -- The general election in Nassau County next Tuesday is being conceded to the Republicans as usual, although it is expected that a number of the Democratic candidates will make a favorable showing as a result of an active campaign for independent votes.

A SURVEY of modern poetry; based on some scheme indicative of the schools of thought represented by the poets of the twentieth century has long been needed. Studies of separate poets, anthologies, critical essays on a few poets we have had.

In these depression years the back-to-the-farm movement holds a wide appeal. Miss Widdemer capitalizes the idea in attractive and successful style in "Eve's Orchard." Her heroine, Eve Mannersfield, has a good job, a devoted lover and the prospect of a round-the-world honeymoon.
A review of the problem of the agunah -- the deserted wife -- was issued yesterday by the Rabbinical Assembly of America -- comprised of leaders of conservative Jewry.

A young crime reporter from New York is visiting his uncle, Amos Fenton, in the Midwestern town of Pleasant Valley when he becomes aware of a strange situation existing next door, where Mrs. Emily Ross is living with her adopted daughter Naomi.

The Poetry Ball on Nov. 20 at the Waldorf-Astoria has enlisted the interest and active support of many persons of prominence in society and the artistic world. It will be given under the auspices of the Academy of American Poets as a factor of a project to raise sufficient funds to encourage and foster the work of American poets and to seek out new talent in verse among native writers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2. -- Retail sales were slower during the week, but compared satisfactorily with those of the corresponding week last year. A wave of exceptionally cold weather for this area probably caused the smaller volume.
CURRENT models of Chevrolet trucks, embodying numerous improvements added from time to time during the year, are on display at the automobile show.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 2 (AP). -- A hard-charging Alabama line spiked Kentucky's big guns before 14,500 fans today, and the Crimson Tide beat the invaders, 13 to 0.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Governor Curley, back from a month's vacation in Honolulu, indicated that he probably would run for re-election next year rather than for United States Senator. He expressed confidence that 1936 would see another Democratic landslide and declared that President Roosevelt was as strong as he was three years ago.

THE first two programs of the newly formed Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Music Orchestra, which will offer a series of five concerts at the Town Hall, under the direction of Hans Lange, this season, will be devoted to the little-known literature for small instrumental ensembles of the sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

Dollar balances built up here by foreigners through this country's increased purchases of merchandise, gold and silver are being used for capital transactions and not for the purchase of American products. George N. Peek, chairman of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, charges in a pamphlet to be published in the near future.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Lucrative, owned and ridden by Cornelius M. Bliss of Cold Spring Harbor, who is a member of the Meadow Brook Hounds, Long Island, won the championship in the tenth annual hunter trials of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds today on the estate of the late John W. Sterling at Quaker Ridge.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Many members of the Westchester Smith College Club will open their homes on Wendesday for the first of a series of bridge parties, the proceeds of which will be used to give scholarships to Westchester students.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Political interest in the outcome of Rockland County's election next Tuesday has sharpened considerably in the closing weeks of the campaign because of the fact that the New Deal has become the sole issue and the Democrats, under the personal leadership of Postmaster General James A. Farley, are making a determined drive to win.

THE nation is three years out of the bottom of the depression and recovery is gaining momentum, in the opinion of William R. Tracy, vice president in charge of sales of the Hudson Motor Car Company. Offering evidence of his statement, Mr. Tracy said: ...

I am writing you in behalf of the Artef Theatre group, which is now in its second season at the After Theatre, West Forty-eighth Street. After ten years of operating as a thoroughly cooperative, non-profit-making group, it is launching a campaign for a reserve production fund which would assure it of a thoroughly professional standing.

William Allan Neilson, president of Smith College, will be the speaker Wednesday night before the Northern Valley branch of the American Association of University Women, who will be entertained at the home of Mrs. Dwight Whitney Morrow at Englewood, N.J. Mrs. J.A. Garretson of Englewood is president of the branch and will preside at the meeting.

IN general this work seems to have a twofold purpose: to sing a tender paean of praise of early American mission workers and to erect a private monument in glowing memory of Chloe Aurelia Clarke, who, though delicately reared in New England, stood beside her husband and helped create in the wilderness of nineteenth-century Oregon, per John Wesley, a sturdy new generation imbued with the ideals of knowledge, love and truth.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Inefficiency, indifference and ignorance were blamed for the deaths of more than 200 World War veterans in the Florida last Labor Day, in a report of an American Legion investigating committee adopted by the national executive committee and made public here tonight.
I read with much interest the letter from Governor Hoffman of New Jersey which appeared in THE TIMES of Oct. 22.

ROME, Nov. 2. -- Following the student demonstrations against Great Britain that caused a temporary closing of some British shops, reprisals against "sanctionist" countries were extended today to newspapers and other types of publications.

IN refutation of the charge, sometimes made, that men more than 40 years old have no place in the automobile industry, I.H. Long, personnel director of the Pontiac Motor Company, reports that, of the 5,500 workers employed by Pontiac when in full production, approximately 2,000 are more than 40, that a number are over 70, and that the average age is better than 34.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A denial of charges made by Representative Snell of New York that he had publicily advocated changing the Constitution so as to divest the Supreme Court of authority to pass on the validity of acts of Congress was issued today by R. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State and former Representative from Virginia.

Representatives of Protestant, Catholic and Jewish religious groups when asked to define a "present-day good neighbor," sent in definitions that were identical in substance, despite the fact that they did not compare notes, it was said yesterday by Gerard Swope, chairman of the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs.

LONDON. -- Just when Europe has attained a measure of recovery, though limited and tentative, from the economic depression, the war in Ethiopia has injected new elements of uncertainty. Wars, though stimulating some trades, are disturbing to trade in general, as the movements of the Stock Exchanges have shown.

Over the rain-soaked intercollegiate course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, cross-country teams from Cornell and Army trudged to victory in dual meets, the Ithacans defeating Yale, 25 to 35, and the West Point harriers turning back Columbia, 18 to 39.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2. -- The governments of both Argentina and Bolivia have begun official investigations of charges that the Standard Oil Company has constructed a secret pipe line across the Argentine-Bolivian frontier, through which it is alleged to have shipped 9,000,000 barrels of Bolivian petroleum to its refineries in Argentina.

Another stage in the political transformation of the Far East appears to be approaching climax and conclusion. Though overshadowed by the more dramatic properties of the conflict in Africa and the diplomatic duel in Europe, it may have more lasting results.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 2. -- With the Egyptian Cabinet's decision backing in principle the applications of sanctions as urged by Britain, Egypt finds herself in a dilemma. Probably no nation called upon to consider sanctions has a more difficult problem than that faced by Egypt.

APPROVES: The King should be a "permanent under-secretary to successive Premiers." That was how Victor Emmanuel III of Italy once de fined his position; and his reign of thirty-five years has been described as the reign of the perfect constitutional monarch, devoted to the well-being of his subjects yet scrupulous in avoiding politics.
THE designing and building of balance into a motor car is not easy to achieve. It requires endless weighing of values and compromises between many opposing factors.

In addition to being the President of the United States and the Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy, Franklin D. Roosevelt was last week the nation's most distressed householder. The White House swarmed with workmen; saws sang and hammers pounded; nowhere could a man find peace.

The corn and hog raisers having voted overwhelmingly for a continuance of loans and checks from the Government, it is announced that the Government through the Commodity Credit Corporation will lend 45 cents a bushel on the 1935-36 corn supply, and will begin putting the plan for an "ever-normal granary" to its first real test.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A live1y inquiry into the costs and profits of bread bakers is under' way here. Government officials point out that the retail price of bread has gone up a penny when the cost of all ingredients has risen only half a cent in recent months. Some costs, reply the bakers, have gone up more than 100 per cent in the last two years.

Thousands of persons yesterday afternoon and evening visited the General Motors special show on the third floor of the Waldorf-Astoria, which is being held coincidentally with the National Automobile Show at the Grand Central Palace.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2. -- A ten-year prison sentence has been imposed on Mrs. N. Barlit, the wife of a Red Army commander, on her conviction by a court at Rostov-on-Don of killing her three adopted infant girls through neglect. Today's Izvestia, which prints this news, calls on authorities to punish also the children's home that farmed out the children to the irresponsible woman.

The Society for the Prevention of Crime made public yesterday a list of twenty-six recommendations that it has forwarded to Governor Lehman for new legislation and other action to strengthen the war against crime.
THERE is one sure way to tell how a business man feels about the future. That is to check up on the amount of money he is spending and how he is spending it.

IN 1936 there will be decidedly new trends in the purchase of automobiles. Evidences of these trends have been apparent in 1935. An ever-increasing percentage of new car buyers have been making their selections from the higher price brackets.

Elephants to stalk the streets, sandwich-man fashion, are in heavy demand these days in New York and other cities. Stand on a corner in Times Square in thought and a vast gray shadow may loom along the curb. The pachyderms not only promote shows and theatres but advertise all sorts of wares from shoes to sealing wax.
THE presentation of new model automobiles in November this year, instead of January, represents the sincere desire of the nation's largest industry to help stabilize employment.

IN AUTUMN many a beautiful late afternoon in the garden is cut short by the creeping chill which, toward sundown, makes it too cold to stay out in comfort. Extended use of the garden at this season is achieved by some home owners by the simple expedient of constructing an outdoor fireplace.

THERE are two schools of thought in almost every automobile manufacturing company. The first is the broad school that deals with general design, power plants, chassis, types of bodies and the big things that go into motor cars.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 2 (AP). -- A storm which was born in Northern waters proceeded along an uninterrupted path 300 miles off the Florida coast tonight, moving south-southwestward.

MR. HUSING is known especially for his ability as a sports announcer, and he gives a good deal of space to the beginnings and development of this factor of broadcasting, with much breezy, inside, descriptive matter about events at which he has officiated -- football, tennis, horse races, baseball, track sports, the Olympic Games of 1932 and others.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- Injunctions against proposed amendments to the charter of the American Founders Corporation, an investment trust, and against the proposed consolidation of that company with the United Founders Corporation and other concerns in the Founders-Equity group were asked in proceedings instituted today in Circuit Court 2 by Mary W. Williams, holder of first preferred stock of American Founders.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Benjamin W. Sangor and Anthony M. Then, officials of the closed Toms River Trust Company, were sentenced to from one to three years in prison and fined $1,000 each tonight on charges of embezzlement after being convicted in Ocean County Common Pleas Court.
