PARLOR games are expected to have a vogue this Winter. Diversions that were forgotten during the worst of the depression are preparing for a comeback. Mah-jong -- masquerading under the name of mandarin -- is one dark horse that may prove popular again.

Three of the four surviving victims of the attack late Friday by former Policeman George DeForge, 61 years old, on members of his family and a friend were in critical condition last night in Medical Centre, Jersey City.

WITH every important land, water and air speed record held by supercharged engines, the supercharger has acquired a glamorous reputation as a mechanical magician. Actually, there is no mystery about superchargers that cannot be explained in every-day language.
THE path of the 25,000,000 motor vehicles in the United States is undergoing a billion-dollar treatment, an unprecedented program of highway improvement financed by the Federal Government.

Public offering will be made tomorrow by a banking group headed by W. C. Langley Co. of two new issues of bonds of the Monongahela West Penn Public Service Company aggregating $29,500,000. The offering consists of $22,000,000 first and general-mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1960 and $7,500,000 of 6 per cent debentures due in 1965.

The city's noise-abatement campaign swung into its second phase last week when the decree outlawing unnecessary night noises, in effect during October, was extended to cover the full twenty-four hours of each day. Hereafter the redundant decibel will be pursued as relentlessly by daylight as in the dark.

EMPHATICALLY denying reports that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has abandoned the plan of installing a television line between New York and Philadelphia, Dr. Frank B. Jewett said "the idea has never been out of our minds."

The Samuel J. Tilden High School eleven furnished one of the biggest upsets of the current schoolboy football season when it held the vaunted New Utrecht High machine to a scoreless tie yesterday at Commercial Field. A crowd of 4,000, equally divided in sentiment, saw the Green and White eleven, previously unbeaten and untied in five starts, held in check by the strong defensive presented by Tilden.

WITH the take-off from Alameda this month of a huge four-engined clipper ship of the air, Manila bound, in the opening of Pan American Airways' transpacific service, only the North Atlantic will remain bare of air-transport scheduled wings.

LOLA, "darling, incredible Lola," mistress to half the great figures of nineteenth-century romanticism and symbolic thence-after of all the naughty deeds, would seem to be interpreter-proof. William Bolitho's truculence tarnished her not, and Mr. Harre's lurid editorializing (with those wickedly suggestive dots after every love-scene) leaves her trailing clouds of glory.

AFTER passing through a period of doldrums that extended over four months of the first half of the year, the automobile tire industry has recovered its balance and is approaching 1936 confident that it holds roseate possibilities.

The Equity Corporation, investment trust, reported yesterday that its consolidated net assets totaled $21,869,943 on Sept. 30, an increase of $9,647,766 over the $12,222,177 reported for June 30. Much of the increase grew out of the merger of three subsidiaries into the Equity Corporation in the third quarter of the year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Assaults on women have been so frequent in Chicago for the past two months that a virtual reign of terror exists in many residential neighborhoods. Women fear to be on the streets after dusk without men escorts and in multitudes of homes extra precautions have been taken to prevent the entrance of strangers.

NEW, unusual and exceptionally useful, the 1936 accessories are certain to take their place along with the cars they will adorn and safeguard as another important contribution to the comfort and security of personal transportation.

BOB DAVIS had early and intimate contact with genius. The genius was his brother, Bill. Bill supplied Bob with the nickname used as the title of this book when Bill was 7 and Bob was 5. Certain facts relating to the protective coloring of tree toads connected up in Bill's mind and grew into a theory.

DESPITE the fact that the year 1935 probably will establish an all-time high for automobile casualties, it is unlikely that insuring motorists will be penalized by increased rates. Undoubtedly there will be some readjustments in territories where experience for the past twelve months justifies increases or decreases, but, at this writing, there is no reason to believe that the changes will be particularly interesting to the premium payers.
THE public's preference in the matter of automobile colors is definitely influenced by the general condition of business, according to W.A. Lindberg, color engineer of the Chrysler Corporation.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- By the margin of a point after touchdown that connected, to one that didn't, the Detroit Lions conquered the Chicago Cardinals, 7 to 6, today in rain and mud at Wrigley Field.

Last Tuesday, following a renewed command from Mayor LA GUARDIA to break up the gangs that have been warring on each other and the public in this city, Commissioner VALENTINE gave orders for every detective to be "on the lookout" for JOHNNY TORRIO, "Lucky" LUCIANA and other alleged gang leaders, to bring in any of them they could find, and to "muss them up."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3. -- Strenuous campaigns by the Republicans, based on opposition to New Deal policies, seem doomed to failure Tuesday in the biennial municipal elections in Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport, Connecticut's largest cities.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican-Fusion candidate for Kings County District Attorney, said last night in a radio speech over Station WOR that if Brooklyn's reputation has been blackened during the present political campaign it is not because of him but because of the inefficiency of the District Attorney, William F.X. Geoghan.

PARIS, Nov. 3. -- France, the country of origin of the "cause celebre," is going to be introduced to a new form of judicial spectacle when the long-postponed Stavisky case comes up in court here tomorrow. Throughout the press it is being announced as a "monster trial" and it certainly promises to break records in the history of French jurisprudence in many ways.

The voting records of Irving M. Ives, minority leader of the Assembly, and George R. Fearon, minority leader of the State Senate, on public utility and social and labor legislation were cited last night by Governor Herbert H. Lehman in a radio appeal for the election of a Democratic Assembly instead of a Republican Assembly with reactionary leadership.

A proposal for immediate condemnation and demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated line, at a cost estimated by his transit experts at not more than $15,000,000, will be placed before the Board of Estimate today by Mayor La Guardia.

From a military base somewhere between Cristobal and Balboa, via recruiting headquarters and the United States Army Information Service at 39 Whitehall Street, came yesterday an expression of need steeped in restraint.
How completely beyond recognition the world has changed in the last twenty years, let us say, we only realize by taking a good look at Broadway, both legitimate and movie.

Scoring four touchdowns in his team's victory over Union on Saturday, Ed Stanley, Williams halfback, went far into the lead in the race for individual scoring honors in Eastern intercollegiate football circles. He has made twelve touchdowns and two conversions for a total of 74 points, 18 more than his nearest rival, Frank Patrick of Pittsburgh.

PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- The Manhasset Bay frostbite dinghy sailors held their first regatta of the season today. Dan Rugg, sailing Ice, had the best score in Class A, while in the Class B one-design competition Dr. Gabriel Giannini, sailing Blue Nose, and Howard Kraus, at the helm of R.W. Fraser's Hot Spot, divided honors with 25 points each.

Allowing for seasonal fluctuations, cotton-mill activity in the United States is about on a par with the average from 1922 to 1927, appreciably less cloth business in the Exchange Service. In that period consumption of all cotton averaged about 6,500,000 bales a season, compared with 5,362,000 last season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Gradually rebuilding its trade practice agreements which were displaced by NRA code regulation of industry, the Federal Trade Commission made public today practice rules proposed by the $500,000,000 cotton converting industry and asked for criticism of the rules.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- With the packers and the government at odds over the processing taxes and the former depositing millions of dollars in escrow, pending legal determination of the propriety of the levy under the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, farmers were forced last week to accept the lowest prices for hogs that they had received in four months, losses ranging from $1 to $3 under the prices received in August.

The dissipation of the Exempt Firemen's Benevolent Fund by the old pensioners who managed it will bring an additional burden upon the Fire Department Relief Fund, active pension system of the department, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott said yesterday.

William F.X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, promised yesterday to donate $1,000 to any charity if his Republican-Fusion adversary, Joseph D. McGoldrick, could name one case that the District Attorney had tried and lost since he became prosecutor.
The nation-wide drive to raise funds for a memorial to perpetuate the name of Will Rogers begins today, the fifty-sixth anniversary of the birth of the cowboy humorist.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Nov. 4. -- The Chinese dollar opened weak at 29 13-16 cents against the United States dollar today as bankers and speculators waited to gauge the effects of the government's new monetary program, announced last night.

BUFFALO, Nov. 3. -- If all incomes in this country were limited to $5,000 a year and the excess re-distributed, the average income would be increased by just $100. This was the assertion of Dr. Ralph C. Epstein, Dean of the University of Buffalo School of Business Administration, in a radio talk this afternoon.

Pork prices dropped last week for the first time in more than a year, it was said yesterday by The Food Guide issued by the Department of Public Markets. Veal and beef also were cheaper. Vegetable prices were normal for this season and slightly lower than during the previous week.

LONDON, Nov. 1.--A critical position is reported to be developing in the British steel industry, due to intense activity and a shortage of supplies. As a result an early rise in steel prices is considered inevitable unless the government raises the steel import quota.

Scoreless ties figured prominently in causing a sharp realignment of the leaders in the scholastic football world during the past weekend. Of course, there were the usual few casualties in the select circle as some elevens finally met their masters, but more startling was the fact that several highly regarded unbeaten teams had to be content with deadlocks and thereby dropped from the "won all" division.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 3. -- The cotton market here last week was rather sluggish so far as future contracts were concerned, but it was extremely active in the spot department. Owing to the slackness in speculative interest, the volume of trading in contracts was moderate, although there was a fair volume of hedge selling to the large turnover in spots, the usual amount of scalping for short turns land some trade buying.

Esther Junger, who has been dancing in revues for the past two or three seasons, celebrated her return to the concert field with a program at the Guild Theatre last night which proved to be a most impressive one.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 3. -- The Ethiopian oil concession, relinquished by United States holders at the suggestion of Secretary of State Cordell Hull, is far from dead, Emperor Haile Selassie declared today.

GENEVA, Nov. 3. -- One feature of the League of Nations' treatment of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute has caused much speculation since the meeting of the Committee of Fifty-two yesterday. It is the Belgian suggestion, informally adopted, that further peace efforts should be conducted by Britain and France.

Christians who face threatening situations in a hostile world must "accept their glorious destiny of merely holding on and waiting" and allow the world "to stew in its own juices," the Very Rev. Jacob A. Glasier, dean of St. Luke's Cathedral of Portland, Me., said in a sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The Affiliated Building Trades of Long Island went ahead yesterday with its plans for a strike of skilled workers on all WPA projects in Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Wednesday to enforce union labor's demands for the prevailing wage on work relief projects.

Religion today lacks and needs the fervor and enthusiasm that is accorded to many other things, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Frederick Mabon, said in a sermon yesterday at the Hamilton Grange Reformed Church, Convent Avenue and 149th Street.

The Republicans of New York State, headed by State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton, by making the New Deal the issue in their campaign for the election of a Republican Assembly in the balloting tomorrow, have placed themselves "on a spot," in the opinion of Postmaster General James A. Farley and other leaders of the Democratic State organization.

ATHENS, Nov. 3. -Greece voted today to bring King George T[ back to the throne he quit by request twelve years ago. Overwhelming majorities were reported in Athens and in the provinces -- even in Crete, revolt hot-bed of other days -- for the monarchy.

Amid colorful surroundings and impressive services, recalling memories of the glory and power that was the Russian Church, Nicholas Kedroff, archpriest and administrator of St. Nicholas Cathedral, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street, received his consecration as Bishop yesterday in the presence of high-ranking priests and Bishops, in addition to several hundred visitors.

The last of the families to occupy apartments in Boulevard Gardens, the Queens housing development financed by the PWA, will move in this week, when all the suites in the 900-family project will have been taken. Ground for the houses was broken in January, 1934, and the first units were completed on June 15.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 3 (AP). -- Notre Dame became the West's public choice No. 1 for the Rose Bowl bid today as it led the nation's list of diminishing undefeated elevens through a week-end of stirring encounters.

Broadway, which has its own way of celebrating civic occasions, will summon the electorate to twelve special matinees tomorrow. On the reasonable assumption that it does not take all day to cast one vote, the managers have arranged a ballot of their own for the electorate's attention during the afternoon. The line-up:...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP). -- The drastic monetary reforms decreed today by the Chinese Government were explained by some silver experts here as a direct outcome of the sharp rise in the world price of silver under the influence of heavy American purchases.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Nov. 3. -- At the end of the trail, where the prairies come abruptly to the Great Divide, work has begun on a memorial to Will Rogers. On a promontory of Cheyenne Mountain, near here, a 120-foot native pink-gray granite tower will be a perpetual shrine to the philosopher.

LOUISVILLE. Nov. 3. -- A victory for Lieut.-Governor A.H. Chandler, New Deal standard-bearer in Kentucky's hard-fought Gubernatorial contest, was confidently predicted tonight by Democratic leaders who added that the party's majority would run anywhere from 30,000 to 100,000 in Tuesday's balloting.

ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 3.--Minister of the Interior Schinas stated tonight that the vote in Greece as a whole today was 98 per cent for the monarchy, and in Athens itself 99 per cent. The plebiscite silences those who have opposed the return of King George II to the throne and relegates the republic to Greece's turbulent past.

The time of year has arrived when activities of industrial production and distribution, after having in the middle of October reached the season's traditional high mark, begin to slacken. To what extent this will be the course of affairs this coming month, is yet to be determined.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 3. -- Ethiopian troop movements around Mussa Ali continue. Great activity is reported in the Immimi marshes, where it is said the Danakil tribesmen are continually harassing the Italian positions at night.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Eino Pentti of the Millrose A.A. today repeated his performance of a year ago in covering the second annual La Rabida Council, K. of C., road run in the best time, but the distinction of showing the way to the pack went to a runner making his first start in three years.

HOT SPRINGS Va., Nov. 3. -- Dr. Paul Schwarz of New York, former German Consul there, and Mrs. Schwarz arrived at the Homestead this morning. Among other arrivals are Dr. and Mrs. James P. Hennessy, Mrs. L. Halstead Moore, Mrs. William C. Shanlay and Miss Lois Shanlay of New York; Mr. and Mrs. Vance Lauderdale of Short Hills, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Harold Forday of Riverside, Conn.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3. -- Hollyrood, the colt with which Trainer Duvall Headley required only a month to make into a prospective favorite for the 1936 Kentucky Derby, will race no more this year, the young Kentuckian said today on the eve of his departure for the Bluegrass State with the Pimlico Futurity winner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the filing of additional registration statements under the Securities Act. The total involved is $126,093,148.65.

After three years of failure the Long Island Field Hockey Association finally came through with a 2 -- 1 victory over New York at Prospect Park, Brooklyn yesterday. Brilliant work by Miss Lillian Schuster, goalie, in the second half, and the well-coordinated team play of the victors featured.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 3. -- Hurricane winds slashed through Hopetown, small settlement on Great Abaco Island, tonight as a tropical disturbance moved southward through the Bahamas Islands toward Nassau.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- While active members of the Hyde Park Volunteer Fire Department stood at attention in the driveway to his home, President Roosevelt received today a badge commemorating twenty-five years of membership in the organization.

Admission to the Hall of Fame is a modern way of repeating the august enconium in the Book of Ecclesiasticus: "Let us now praise famous men" -- with a widening of the range of choice. In the ancient catalogue they were included who had given counsel in understanding, leaders of the people, rich men furnished with ability, and such as had sought out musical tunes and set forth verses in writing.

In view of the publicity being given the accident and death toll of automobiles, it is remarkable that no one has put his finger on the real cause -- the self-centred egoism of us Americans that makes about 80 per cent of us firmly believe that we, personally, are justly entitled to shove in ahead of anybody else that we can push out of our way.

It is possible for a woman in New York City to keep well nourished and healthy on a food allowance of $2.25 a week, it was declared yesterday by the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. Although the organization does not consider that sum a satisfactory weekly food budget, it asserted that health can be maintained upon it.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 3 (AP). -- George Olmsted, National Young Republican chairman, said today that the Republican National Committee had adopted a "hands off" attitude toward the national meeting of Young Republican leaders here Nov. 9, 10 and 11.

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- The principal worry to financial circles here this week has been domestic politics, The Congress of the Radical party did not call upon Edouard Herriot and other Radical Ministers to quit the Cabinet, but the party expressly decided to come to an understanding with the Socialists and Communists.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 (AP).--The slaying of Vivian Chase accounted for all but one of the eight persons linked by Federal investigators with the kidnapping of August Luer.

While the average freshman entering City College this Fall is younger than his predecessors of the last five years, his intelligence quotient is just as high, a report from Dr. Arthur Frank Payne, head of the Personnel Bureau, to President Frederick B. Robinson revealed.

A college degree is virtually worthless today because universities have glorified mass education to the extent that individual students are neglected, Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.

The auction of the contents and equipment of the 46,000-ton liner Olympic will commence tomorrow at Jarrow-on-Tyne, England, where the former Atlantic favorite of the White Star Line was taken recently to be scrapped.
I have read with considerable interest the letter from "Experience" published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 26.

Philip L. Coffin of East Orange, N.J., paired with Mrs. Courtlandt Smith of Glen Ridge, N.J., won the metropolitan contract bridge mixed pair championship of the American Bridge League last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania, outplaying a field of fifty-five other finalist pairs.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3. -- The Brooklyn Dodgers gained a 13-to-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in a National Football League game at Forbes Field today.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 2. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85, which compares with 85.3 the week before, 85.5 two weeks before, 85.8 three weeks before and 85.6 four weeks before.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3. -- Leonard J. Buck's Champion Torehill Trader, intriguing black cocker spaniel which has won his way into the hearts of thousands of dog show enthusiasts, tonight once more demonstrated his superiority in a great all-breed show.

ON BOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Antarctica, Nov. 3. -- (By Wireless) -- The Wyatt Earp, carrying the third Ellsworth trans-Antarctic flight expedition, is nestled once again in familiar pack ice. We are held up about ten miles northwest of Deception Island and, fortunately, are sheltered by Snow Island from the heavy westerly swell in which we have wallowed for three days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- In passing soon upon applications by a group of the small Stock Exchanges for exemption from registration as National Securities Exchanges, the Securities and Exchange Commission, in instances where the privilege is granted, it is understood, will make it conditional upon the observance of some of the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, including the anti-manipulation section 9(a), intended to protect the investors.

DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, opening a new series of radio addresses, declared today that "the slogan 'Roosevelt or ruin' must be altered to read 'Roosevelt and ruin'" unless by the next election public opinion has removed members of Congress "who have lost sight of their duty as representatives of the American people."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Ion Mihalache, leader of the National Peasant party, today defied Premier George Tatarescu, who had requested a delay of the peasant demonstration against Mrs. Magda Lupescu, King Carol's intimate friend, scheduled for Nov. 14.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Coach Francis A. Schmidt of Ohio State's football team surveyed with a heavy heart the wreckage of a national championship dream today, but remained convinced the Buckeyes are one of the greatest teams in the country.

HARAR, Nov. 3. -- This region is under unusual tension as reports seemingly originating in the south have convinced most of the population that the expected Ethiopian counter-attack against the Italians in Ogaden will be unloosed at any moment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3.--Donald R. Richberg, one-time general counsel and later successor to General Johnson as head of the National Recovery Administration, will, in a forthcoming book, "The Rainbow," oppose the idea of a constitutional amendment to offset the Supreme Court's decision on the NRA, it was announced here today.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 3. -- The bullet-pierced body of a red-haired woman identified by police as Vivian Chase, 34, suspect in the 1933 kidnapping of August Luer, 77-year-old banker of Alton, Ill., was found here today in a motor car at the rear of St. Luke's Hospital.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- City officials of New Rochelle were busy today borrowing ballot boxes from Mount Vernon and Yonkers. This was made necessary by the decision of the Appellate Division that there must be a write-in of the candidates for Mayor on paper ballots, owing to the sudden death of Mayor Paul Crandell, Republican nominee.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3. -- Dr. David M. Robinson, Professor of Archaeology at Johns Hopkins University, declared today from 40 to 50 per cent of the Etruscan art in the Carnegie Museum in Pittsburgh is fraudulent.

Appeals for an affirmative vote tomorrow on Proposition No. 1, the proposed $55,000,000 relief bond issue, were issued yesterday by Wendell E. Phillips, president of the State Conference of Mayors; George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, and the Welfare Council of New York City.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. John R. Fell gave a dinner in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier tonight for Miss Dorothy Fell, Miss Whitney Bourne, Edward J. Reeves and Bradley Dresser.

Interest in the cotton futures market last week was centred largely in changes in the differences between prices for the various future deliveries rather than in the general-price level. On the New York Cotton Exchange, December closed the week at an advance of 3 points, while the distant October delivery was down 19 points.

The puddle-scarred stretches of Marie Curie Avenue, skirting the East River between Sixty-third and Seventieth Streets, will be converted by the city into a shaded promenade and drive for residents of the populous middle East Side, it was announced yesterday.

"Christians are in the position of defending a tradition much older than Christianity, but the great danger is that we may defend the wrong thing." said the Rev. Canon James S. Bezzant of Liverpool Cathedral, England, in his sermon yesterday morning in the St. James Chapel of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

Limited fluctuations were the rule in the foreign exchange market last week. The turnover also showed contraction due in part to the holiday in some of the European countries on Friday, and to the disposition of bankers to rest their commitments beyond the routine to possible developments in the war area.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- Prices of wheat in all leading markets were irregular last week. The finish was at losses of 1/3 to 1 cent a bushel in Minneapolis. In Kansas City the May lost 5/8 cent, while the July gained 1 1/8. In Duluth, December durum lost 3/4 cent, while May gained 1/4.
Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, asserted in his sermon yesterday morning that the time had come for the church to go beyond modernism.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3. -- An 8-year-old girl rescued her infant sister by dropping her from a window into the arms of two men passers-by here tonight during a fire which resulted in the fatal burning of the child's mother and another sister.

BOSTON, Nov. 3. -- A 55-yard forward pass early in the second period from Ed Storm to Ed Manske and a fluky point after touchdown by Hank Reese gave the Philadelphia Eagles a thrilling 7-to-6 victory over the Boston Redskins in a National Football League contest at Fenway Park today.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- The international situation continued this week to have no influence on German finance and industry, and, although the Boerse was inert, prices of stocks were maintained, and bonds were firm.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the pre-opening performance of "Jumbo," the new musical circus, Wednesday night at the Hippodrome, which has been taken over by the directors of the Maternity Centre Association to raise funds for carrying on the many philanthropic activities of that organization.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,795,638,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest bearing discount bills.

Communion services commemorating the tenth anniversary of the dedication of St. Margaret's Protestant Episcopal Church, Dawson and East l56th Streets, the Bronx, were conducted yesterday morning by Bishop William T. Manning. The bishop had officiated at the dedication of the church.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Archbishop John T. McNicholas, in a diocesan letter, declared today that "if in our Congress there had been during the past years two or three hundred men who had Mexican blood in their veins, our government would long ago have found some commendable means to deal with the intolerable situation in Mexico,"

Onto the stage of the Provincetown Theatre, hallowed of old by trial and error, the new Greenwich Village Music Guild tossed its Sunday hat last night. The name of the hat is "The Provincetown Follies," and it is not what you would call a new hat. The trial-and-error method continues, though. The error would have to be called the event itself.

Paul Garrett, dean of American wine growers, who will celebrate his seventy-second birthday today, urged yesterday the classification of table wine as a food, as a means of developing the wine industry in the United States.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Nov. 3. -- More than 500 troop-carrying bombing airplanes are now in Libya at the disposal of Marshal Italo Balbo, the Governor General, who led the great massed flight of Italian aircraft across the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- December corn on the Board of Trade was under pressure last week from sellers because of increased receipts of new corn from Illinois and a sharp reduction in the cash premiums. The price dropped 3 1/8 cents a bushel from the top and finished within 1/2 cent of the week's low price, and at a loss of 2 5/3 cents for the week.

Strengthening of prices in sugar featured trading last week in commodity futures here. Wheat, cocoa dairy products, cotton and wool tops advanced in the cash markets while flour, lard, silk, rubber and hides moved lower, with corn at a new low price.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The suicide of a Newark woman by illuminating gas in an uptown apartment here early today was the forerunner of a gas explosion which wrecked the apartment in which she was staying, causing considerable damage to the building.

The thirty-sixth annual automobile show, which opened Saturday afternoon to an unusually large crowd of first-day visitors, was closed yesterday, but will reopen this morning at 10:30 o'clock and continue daily through the week from the same time until 11 P.M.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- St. Thomas College of Scranton, staged a third-period rally today to defeat La Salle College at the Phillies ball park, 14 to 13, before a crowd of 8,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Rain and snow pelted the Middle West today while abnormal cold formed the rule in the Northwest.

May I express the gratification with which I have read your editorials on the League of Nations and its effort to curb the mad course of Mussolini. Perhaps this is because I feel like the old farmer who, on returning a volume of Plato that had been loaned him by his pastor, said: "That feller has stated my idees exactly."

There would be fewer crimes, fewer suicides, fewer domestic difficulties if there were greater friendship among human beings, said the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell in the sermon delivered at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Religion could overcome one of its major weaknesses by emulating the forthright confidence and resolute strength which characterize the spirit of science, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at Eightieth Street, declared in a sermon yesterday morning.
SHANGHAI, Nov. 3. -- When the banks in China reopen tomorrow morning the country will no longer be on a silver basis. It will have a managed paper currency.

VALETTA, Malta, Nov. 3. -- The British Mediterrahean fleet is unlikely to be anywhere near Malta until after Christmas, in the opinion of officers who have returned here with the battleship Resolution. The Resolution is now bound for England after lengthy service at Alexandria and in the Eastern Mediterranean.

S. Sloan Colt, president of the New York State Bankers Association, announced yesterday the receipt of statements from former Governor Alfred E. Smith and George W. Egbert, State Superintendent of Banks, urging the repeal at tomorrow's election of that section of the State Constitution requiring double liability on bank stocks.

The lively political battle between District Attorney, William F.X. Geoghan and Joseph D. McGoldrick in Brooklyn was characterized as a "sham battle" by Louis Waldman, Socialist leader of New York State, in a speech last night at a final rally of the Socialists at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
The Bronx and Manhattan were centres of realty activity reported over the week-end.

VIENNA, Nov. 3. -- The Austrian press has been forbidden to mention the fact that Dr. Otto Juch, former Minister of Finance, accompanied by Dr. Rizzi of the Ministry of Finance, left Vienna this morning for London to persuade creditors of the Creditanstalt [Austrian bank that collapsed in 1931] once again to postpone their claims for a settlement of the affairs of this concern.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 3. -- Another Summer-like Sunday attracted many to the Berkshires and there was considerable entertaining.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 3. -- Hugh Frank (Idzy) Rutkowski, 20, believed by the police to have been the terrorist bomber responsible for five bombings here in the past week, was blown to bits today as he experimented with thirty-eight sticks of stolen dynamite.

Advances in the prices of semi-finished steel and finished steel products impend, following the increase of $1 a ton in pig iron that now is in effect in virtually all districts, while a further enlargement of demand for iron and steel is indicated, according to the magazine Steel.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The continuation of the upswing in domestic trade is regarded here as an indication that the international crisis is not exerting any adverse influence. It is impossible, however, to estimate the loss in trade due directly to the imposition of economic sanctions, but it must be remembered that even without sanctions, commercial operations with Italy would decline owing to her inability to meet the cost of imports through orthodox channels.

The apparel and other divisions of the wholesale markets last week continued to feel the effects of the recent slowing up in retail buying, although purchases of holiday merchandise stimulated activity in some departments. The volume of reorders declined and some cancellations were received.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- A surprising discovery made by many gunners from the metropolitan district who come up to this section, 100 miles from New York City, is that the desirable hunting grounds are almost as thoroughly posted as are those of Long Island, Westchester and Putnam Counties.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3. -Under the heading "Sport -- Not Politics" The Yale Daily News will say editorially tomorrow that the attitude of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of the United States Amateur Athletic Union, in urging that this country withdraw from participation in the Olympic Games in Germany, is absurd.

Rearing up in all their might after remaining strangely quiescent for the first half of the game, the Chicago Bears manhandled and overpowered the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday to gain 20-3 victory that kept them strongly in the running for Western divisional honors in the National Football League.

Though it be a strange thing to say following the wild doings of the past Saturday on various gridirons of the country, football this morning is in more or less a normal state, perhaps more so than at any other time during the current season. This statement cannot be taken as any underestimation of the character of various upsets of the day.

When the silver-purchasing scheme was being debated in Congress one of the principal arguments for it was that it would "restore the purchasing power of the Orient." When we had done this good deed the "silver-using" countries would bring back prosperity here by increasing their purchases from the United States.

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- The Bourse, i which was open only four days this week because of the All Saints holii day, showed little animation, it i was hardly influenced by the Ethioplan question, which has passed into the background since it seemed to become a certainty that there would be no military sanctions.

MADRID, Nov. 3. -- While the signature of a new Spanish-American trade treaty is reported, both here and in Washington, to be imminent, the French government is intensiflying its efforts to break the year-old deadlock in its commercial relations with this country.

Susanne Fisher, American soprano, and Enid Szantho, Hungarian contralto, will appear with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Otto Klemperer, as soloists in Mahler's Second Symphony on Dec. 12, 13 and 15 at Carnegie Halt, it was announced yesterday.

The American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries have reported for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $10,302,537 after interest and taxes, property retirement, depletion reserves and preferred dividends, against $6,587,067 for the same period in 1934.

TWO touchdowns ahead of Notre Dame in the last quarter. Just a breeze for Ohio State. That's what it was until the cyclone struck. Three roaring whirls and Columbus, Ohio, was a dazed and desolate city. Such a sweet dream the citizens had been having! And what a rude awakening! Dreadful, simply dreadful. Let a veil of charity be drawn over the scene.
The cause of New York City charter revision was linked with the fate of the county government reform amendment in a radio address made last night by former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation has made an offer to holders of the 8 per cent preferred stock to exchange their shares into an issue carrying dividends of $5 a share annually, provided such exchanges are effected before Dec. 7, according to a letter to stockholders signed by H.F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee.

College professors and others are committing assault, battery and mayhem upon "The Star-Spangled Banner." It is, they say, too militaristic, too belligerent, too brutal. But above all, it is too high and too difficult.

Paul Marras, 37 years old, a garage worker, who was taken into custody by the police after the body of Stella Peskowitz, 29, had been found in the kitchen of an apartment at 853 East 170th Street, the Bronx, Sunday evening, was formally charged with her death yesterday.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 3. -- The redoubtable Philadelphia field hockey eleven invaded the Greenwich Academy field today to defeat the strong but not yet smooth Stuyvesant team, 3 -- 1.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 3. -Cornelius Shields, who makes habit of sailing a boat for all there is in it, went around the harbor today showing other sailors how it could be done in the Larchmont Yacht Club's second cold-weather dinghy regatta.

BERLIN, Nov. 3. -- At Neuwied, near Coblenz, where 2,000 years ago, Julius Caesar crossed the Rhine for a conquest of Germania, Aviation Minister Hermann Goering today cut with a sword a ribbon stretched across a new bridge bearing his name.
ROME, Nov. 1. -- Italian markets were firm and satisfactory both for stocks and State securities in the last week.

ON THE MARCH WITH THE ITALIAN TROOPS IN NORTHERN ETHIOPIA, Nov. 3. -- General Alessandro Pirzio-Biroli's Askaris, pushing on toward Makale in the second great Italian advance of the Ethiopian war, this noon occupied Ends Abbamas, having met no resistance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The Federal Housing Administration is responsible in a large measure for construction of new houses in New Jersey, the FHA revealed today, reporting that in the month of August mortgages accepted for insurance in that State totaled 64 per cent of the building permits issued for one and two-family dwellings in cities over 10,000 population.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 3. -- Hellegrini Ghigi, Italian Minister to Egypt, called on Premier Nessim Pasha today to protest the Egyptian government's decision to apply sanctions. The protest took the form of a friendly conversation.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 3 (AP). -- Brenton Root, 32, a contract investigator for a wholesale concern here and son of a clergyman, was shot to death at his home early today.

The average of weekly earnings in domestic industry showed a further increase in September, although man-hours worked and total payrolls showed small declines from the month before, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday in its monthly survey of twenty-five manufacturing categories.

In one of the most active weeks in several months, numerous entire issues of bonds were called for redemption before maturity last week. The issues, excepting two public utility loans, which were called for payment in November, were principally for later months.
The text of the radio address by Governor Herbert H. Lehman last night follows:

All day yesterday Newark detectives questioned Michael (Mickey) Marks of 2,023 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, former chauffeur for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who was shot fatally with three of his aides the night of Oct. 23 in a Newark tavern.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 3. -- Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., reported this week for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, a net profit of $506,395, the largest in its history, compared with $334,522 in the previous quarter and $190,048 in the third quarter of 1934.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- Grain men who had looked for a large volume of speculative business as a result of the war between Italy and Ethiopia have been disappointed. They have seen also that the speculative trade that was looked for when the privilege market here was reopened several weeks ago has not developed.

General JOHNSON may have been exaggerating a little when he referred to the WPA-PWA program of made work as "an obvious and fantastic flop," yet the difficulties of the program on all sides can no longer be concealed. An obvious recent failure was the passing of the Nov. 1 "deadline" with the work-relief scheme still nearly 2,000,000 jobs short of the original goal of 3,500,000.

Flames set by a pyromaniac swirled up the hallway of an old-law five-story tenement house at 406 East 121st Street at 4:40 A.M. yesterday and took the lives of a mother and her five children who had been trapped in their dingy railroad fiat on the fourth floor.
The Bank of the Manhattan Company has been appointed transfer agent for the capital stock of the Union Bag and Paper Company.
The Bank of the Manhattan Company has been appointed transfer agent for the capital stock of the Union Bag and Paper Company.

WALTER DUBANTY'S "I Write as I Please" (Simon Schuster, $3) is the "inside story" of a Moscow newspaper assignment covering some fifteen years. Readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES are, of course, abundantly familiar with Mr. Duranty's gift for lucid explanation and with his flair for spotting the kernel of human interest that often lies buried under mountains of Soviet statistics relating to tractors, say, or to the strength of the Red army.

The tomb of an ancient Egyptian family, three generations of which died between 1520 and 1460 B.C. and were buried in a single sepulchre, has helped Metropolitan Museum archaeologists to gain "invaluable information on the type of burial prevalent among the ordinary, well-to-do citizenry" of the first half of the Eighteenth Dynasty.

Mathilde McKinney was the third pianist to appear in recital at the Town Hall yesterday. In a season that has been heavily freighetd with keyboard soloists thus far, Miss McKinney's program last night had elements of diversity. The two main works were Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 10, No. 3, and the Griffes sonata, neither of them frequently heard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Beginning their climb out of the depression, corporations in the United States cut their aggregate operating loss by 75 per cent in 1933, the Treasury Department disclosed today after an analysis of income-tax returns.

Steadily gaining momentum, the local art season swings into November with approximately twoscore exhibitions opening over the weekend or during the next few days. Heading the imposing list are several important shows in the museums; but unusual gallery attractions are not far behind.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 3. -- Dedjasmatch Ayelu, of Walkait Province, has sent a messenger by air to Emperor Haile Selassie, asking that no more troops be sent to assist him in the defense of the Northwestern frontier.

From the manifestoes of the Republican and the Democratic State Chairmen the light of truth, present and prophetic, dazzles the reader's eyes. Combining the information given by the two, even the stranger within our gates knows what will happen tomorrow and the condition of the two opposing parties today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Nov. 3. -- Paul D. Cravath, president of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was host this afternoon at Still House, his country home in the Piping Rock Colony, at a musicale and tea in aid of the Nassau Philharmonic Society, of which he is a patron.

ROME, Nov. 1. -- Imposition of sanctions against Italy is expected to be only partially effective because of three major nations and several minor ones not being members of the League of Nations. It is felt that they will insure that all necessary supplies will reach Italy. Purchases abroad of almost all articles will disappear completely.

MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Nov. 3. -- When the alert roving centre of the Middlefield Air Cadets snares an enemy pass and starts purposefully toward the opponents' goal line the followers of this junior team yell: "Atta girl! Burnham!"

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Resumption of gold purchases by the Bank of England has no significance except to strengthen the reserve before the Christmas heavy note circulation expansion. Under the statute, the Bank still pays 84s 10 1/2d an ounce, the spread from the market value being debited temporarily to the exchange fund from which the gold is bought, while the amount paid for gold is credited to funds in the banking account.

MONTREAL, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press). -- Confidence that problems of distribution would be solved under the capitalistic system was expressed here tonight by James Roosevelt, son of the President of the United States, speaking before the Peoples' Forum.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Mrs. O.D. Oliphant of Trenton, N.J., described Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as "the No. 1 pacifist in this country" at the opening session today of a two-day conference of American Legion Auxiliary department officers.

DETROIT, Nov. 3. -- William Dix, 27-year-old medical student, gave up his downtown corner news stand today to go to Harvard for his medical degree with a fortune of $71,000 left to him by a Cincinnati uncle.

A promising debut was made by Paulina Ruvinska, pianist, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The program was fortunately contrived. It offered, not only solo performers, but two concertos with the accompaniment of a small orchestra. It would be very good if other debuts could be made under similar circumstances.

From Rome comes the report that the Italians are much surprised at the action of the League in voting to begin a boycott of Italy's foreign trade on Nov. 18. Italian diplomacy had apparently hoped to be able to make a break in the solidarity of the League. Particularly had it striven to keep France from joining the others.

The executive board of the Employes Welfare Association, representing a majority of the Emergency Relief Bureau's staff employes who did not walk out in the recent three-hour stoppage staged by some 3,500 workers, issued a formal statement yesterday repudiating the stoppage as "un-American" and asking for public confidence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, tonight denied that any politics or reprisals in the labor union world were connected with the appointment of William L. Hutcheson, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, as labor; delegate to the international labor conference at Santiago, Chile, next month.

Acquisition of control of Super-Corporations of America Trust Shares, Series A, B, AA, BB, C and D, a fixed trust organized in 1930, through purchase of the depositor corporation, was announced yesterday by Lord, Abbett Co., Inc.

S.S. PRESIDENT GRANT, at Sea, Nov. 3. -- As Premier Wang Ching-wei's condition improved yesterday after the attack by an assassin, Chinese officials in Shanghai went ahead with a crowded day and night of entertainment for the United States Congressional and newspaper delegation headed by Vice President John N. Garner.
Paul Runyan's victory in the Louisville open tournament last month enabled the 1934 professional champion to move into the leadership of the nation's low-scoring pro golfers.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- The German wheat market is dull. Farmers can deliver only the quantities that were declared compulsory after the failure of the crop in 1934, but the demand is small. The price of wheat in Berlin is now 204 marks a metric ton.

BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 3. -- Senator William E. Borah hurled defiance at former President Hoover and the Republican Old Guard in an interview today. Bosses who had dominated the party for decades failed when in power to protect the masses of the people from exploitation, he asserted, and should never be entrusted with power again.

BERLIN, Nov. 3. -- Germany has very little chance of making a really good showing in the coming Olympic Games and America is certain to win them if its team competes, unless all present calculations prove false.
Paul Runyan's victory in the Louisville open tournament last month enabled the 1934 professional champion to move into the leadership of the nation's low-scoring pro golfers.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- The German wheat market is dull. Farmers can deliver only the quantities that were declared compulsory after the failure of the crop in 1934, but the demand is small. The price of wheat in Berlin is now 204 marks a metric ton.

Bosses who had dominated the party for decades failed when in power to protect the masses of the people from exploitation, he asserted, and should never be entrusted with power again.

BERLIN, Nov. 3. -- Germany has very little chance of making a really good showing in the coming Olympic Games and America is certain to win them if its team competes, unless all present calculations prove false.

If the politicians who are elected to Congress are to become puppets of the people, as members of the Townsend Club assert, the people themselves will have to acquire a capacity for thorough thinking in order to direct befitting policies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Oct. 30, issued by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows increases for the week of $46,000,000 in total loans and investments, $136,000,000 in net demand deposits and $63,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and a decline of $67,000,000 in time deposits.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4. -An unprecedented number of court fights and legal tangles are expected to mark the municipal elections tomorrow in the four cities of Westchester County.

The interposition of a holiday today in New York and in certain other States for elections probably accounted for the general lack of trading interest in stocks yesterday. Price movements were indecisive and the volume of business done on the Stock Exchange amounted to 1,748,000 shares, compared with the last full day's business, on Friday, of 2,039,000; the closing was steady and mixed.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- After some months of negotiation the government has just concluded an agreement with the four main line British railways which will enable them, on a grant of necessary powers by Parliament, to undertake an extensive program of reconstruction and improvement costing 30,000,000.

With cheers, loud applause and Fascist salutes, more than 3,000 persons celebrated last night the Italian World War Armistice in Carnegie Hall. The armistice on Nov. 4, 1918 followed the defeat of the Austrians at Vittorio Veneto.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 4. -The body of a man believed to be a victim of New York gangsters was found in an abandoned barn off the Hurleyville-Monticello road tonight, the head crushed with axe blows and portions of the feet destroyed by quantities of quicklime.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- A salary of $13,300 a year which President Harding was to have received for writing for his former newspaper, The Marion Star, after retirement from the White House, figured in an income tax case lost today by the present owners of the paper, the Brush-Moore Newspapers, Inc.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 4. -- The announced establishment in a few days of regular air service for passengers, mails and cargo between Santiago and Magallanes on the Straits of Magellan, the southernmost city in the world is considered here to be one of the most important moves of the present administration to link the entire territory with a network of air lines.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 4. -- Rain-soaked Italian troops today poured into the last of a vast northern region from the old Ethiopian frontier to the Takkaze River.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Recent talk of blockades is not the result of longing on the part of any country in the present international situation but in accordance with resolutions adopted by world powers, including Italy, as early as 1921, it was said here tonight by Dr. Carl Joachim Hambro, principal Norwegian delegate to the League of Nations.

Speaking over the radio on Sunday, the Dean of the University of Buffalo School of Business Administration stuck another pin in grandiose "sharethe-wealth" programs. Analyzing the 1931 income-tax returns, he pointed out that even if the Government had seized for that year all income in excess of $5,000 for every individual, it would have got just $4,000,000,000.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 4. -- Miss Ashton Wilson of New York gave a tea at Fenton, her place here, this afternoon in honor of her sister, Mrs. Hiram Smith. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Perceval Reniers, Mr. and Mrs. Ruck Williams, Major Gen. John L. Hines, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Hines, Mr. and Mrs. Latimer Tuke and Mrs. William B. Hines.

Yesterday's pre-holiday session caused a slackness in trading on the bond market with prices mixed and holding to narrow limits. Sales for the session totaled $9,399,400 as compared with $11,870,200 on Friday.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine ordered an intensive drive yesterday to weed policemen who drink to intoxication out of the department. At the same time he directed a speeding up of the drive on gangsters and racketeers.

A general alarm was sent out by the police early yesterday afternoon for a bold ex-convict who had escaped from the penway leading to the West Side Court a few minutes before he was to have been arraigned on a charge of burglary. The escape was discovered within a minute of its occurrence, but no sign of the fugitive could be found nor a clue to the method of his getaway.

GENEVA, Nov. 4. -- The economic sanctions committee of the League of Nations adopted in principle today the Canadian proposal that petroleum and its derivatives, coal, pig iron, cast iron and steel be added to the raw material embargo against Italy, with the proviso that it will not come into force "until conditions for rendering it effective appear to be realized."

The Orchestrette Classique, a chamber orchestra of twenty-four young women directed by Miss Frederique Joanne Petrides, opened its third season at Aeolian Hall last night. Without subsidy or endowment and without fanfare of publicity, this ensemble has attended to its business of making music.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- S. Davis Wilson, City Controller and Republican nominee for Mayor, requested Judge Raymond MacNeille late today in a formal petition to investigate reports that two members of the October grand jury, which accused the Controller of using public funds "for political purposes," were Democratic political workers.

Improved business conditions and a revived demand for quality goods are reflected in the substantial sales increase recorded by Rogers Peet Company in recent months, according to executives of that organization yesterday. Following an increase of 15 per cent in the March to August period, gains over the previous year spurted to 35 per cent in September.

The National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace, closed over Sunday, reopened yesterday morning. Among the thousands who thronged the aisles of the exhibition hall were many foreigners who had gathered in the city for International Day.

THE huddle was at full strength when somebody near the door shouted: "Company, atten-shun! Officer of the day!" In came Major Ralph Sasse, Professor of Military Science and Tactics at Mississippi State who drills the R.O.T.C. group that took West Point last Saturday. Major Sasse was accompanied by Captain Archie McKechnie of his military and football staff.

Several card parties will be held in the near future for the benefit of various charitable organizations. Women interested in the work of the Silver Cross Day Nursery, which cares for children whose mothers are employed during the day, have arranged a party in behalf of that organization to be held the afternoon of Nov. 12 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Mayor La Guardia formally opened the exhibition of North American Children's Painting in the mezzanine gallery of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center last night.

The surgeons met last week at San Francisco and reported on the progress they had made in readjusting and repairing the human machine when it gets out of order. We were properly astonished to learn that it is now possible to convert bearded ladies into gentle Clarissas, to saw bits of tumorous bone from the skull, sterilize them and put them back, and to cut sympathetic nerves and thus relieve high blood pressure.

The trifling matter of next Saturday's game with the giants from St. Mary's did not bulk so forebodingly for Fordham's happy football forces yesterday as the Rams started preparations for the now traditional encounter with the Galloping Gaels.

Apparently Jose Echaniz, who gave a piano recital last night in Town Hall, is a brilliant executant rather than an interpreter of marked musicianship or depth of understanding. He captured his audience, when he was three-quarters through his program, with three short Preludes by Shostakovich and the "Suggestion diabolique" of Prokofieff.

Continued laboratory research, rather than the "cures" announced periodically, sometimes by practicing physicians, offers the greatest hope of ultimate victory in the fight against cancer, Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Crocker Institute of Cancer Research, said yesterday.
ROME, Nov. 4. -- There was a recrudescence throughout Italy today of demonstrations against sanctions, and more especially against Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The Guffey Act was assailed in the court hearing today as "just fighting the Civil War over again." Mr. Whitney, lawyer for Carter, said that it was "a scheme" to protect Northern coal producers from the inroads of Southern competitors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Officers and directors of public utility companies are not required to obtain the permission of the Federal Power Commission to hold similar positions in national banks under the supervision of the Controller of the Currency or in banks which are members of the Federal Reserve Board, it was revealed today.
PALM BEACH, Nov. 4. -- The first detailed description of the hurricane which struck Miami this afternoon was brought here tonight by R.J. Smith, a customs inspector.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 4. -- Although extensive preparations are going on in expectation that Emperor Haile Selassie will soon depart for the front, probably for Dessye, those best informed here find it difficult to believe the trip will be carried out.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The stock markets here were cheerful today on a wave of fresh buying following the municipal elections, good trade reports and a further reduction in unemployment. British funds improved under the lead of war loans. Chinese issues were higher in the foreign market, following the currency news.

New York University's undefeated and untied football squad rested yesterday following its 14 to 0 triumph over Bucknell last Saturday. This was the fifth straight victory for the Violet. Coach Mal Stevens and his staff will begin practice this morning in preparation for the contest with City College next Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.

Henry T. Bouchier, 45 years old, a vice president of the Mortzon Corporation of 120 Wall Street, leaped or fell to his death yesterday from the twelfth floor window of his room in the Hotel Montclair, Forty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 4 (AP). -As a tide of congratulatory messages all but flooded Coach Elmer Layden, Notre Dame today counted up the cost of its thrilling football triumph over Ohio State and found it high enough to cause considerable worry over Northwestern's invasion Saturday.

Hopeful of wresting the Eastern leadership from the Giants in the National Football League, the Dodgers are looking forward to their games with the Eagles at Philadelphia tonight and with the Pittsburgh Pirates at Ebbets Field Sunday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- A list of further WPA projects for New York State totaling $1,411,739, and another for New Jersey totaling $809,311, were approved today by Controller General McCarl.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 4. -- Mrs. E. Marshall Field, who has a newly completed estate at Brookville, won the Mrs. Percy Chubb Memorial prize with twenty-three roses grown in her greenhouses in the first day's judging at the thirtieth annual chrysanthemum show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which opened this afternoon in the main building on the Pratt estate.

TRENTON, Nov. 4. -- Everett Colby of West Orange, former State Senator, was named by Governor Hoffman today as chairman of the New Jersey Committee of the Will Rogers Memorial Commission. The Governor said the commission would seek funds for a memorial to Rogers and called attention to the proclamation of Governor Marland of Oklahoma declaring today "Will Rogers Day."

Adding two more to the long list of rackets he had said existed in Brooklyn, Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican -- Fusion candidate for District Attorney of Kings County, in a series of radio broadcasts yesterday and last night, summed up his reasons for expecting the voters to support him at the polls today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4 (AP). -The National Distillers Corporation rescinded its order withdrawing $50,000 a month in advertising from thirty-one newspapers today and in a brief statement said that a "misunderstanding" had been cleared up.
The football fields of the nation are strewn with the recumbent forms of teams undefeated until last week-end.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- "Don't forget to run up to our place for the stag jamboree," Al Boesel told the writer in New York last week, when he heard we were coming up here for the deer opening.

Michael (Mickey) Marks of 2,023 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, picked up by the police on Saturday for questioning in the murder of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and three Schultz retainers, admitted yesterday, after twenty-six hours of almost steady examination, that he was in the Newark tavern the night of the shooting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Electrification of 4,247 farms was provided for today when the Rural Electrification Administration announced loans totaling $1,274,084 to six public entities and one small private company for constructing 1,125 miles of distributing lines.

A performance of Verdi's "Traviata" will be presented in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, Dec. 3, in observance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the beginning of the career of Max Rabinoff, impresario, it was announced yesterday. The opera will be presented on a stage that has recently been re-equipped for full performances.

More than 200 foreign consuls and overseas visitors, here to attend the automobile show, were guests yesterday of the Automobile Manufacturers Association's export committee at an International Day luncheon in the Hotel Ambassador.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The official Marine Gazette announced today that Germany was building sixteen submarines in addition to the twelve designated as "U-1" through "U-12."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Two new applications for merges of affiliated subsidiaries of large holding company systems were filed with the Federal Power Commission today. All action on such applications has been suspended by Frank R. McNinch, chairman, pending the working out of a system of cooperation between the commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission for enforcement of the Public Utilities Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Out of disbursements of $5,693,931,729 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to railroads, mortgage and loan associations and other borrowers, $3,076,847,659, or about 54 per cent, has been repaid, according to a survey issued today.

This evening it is' Max Gordon who again has the floor, tenderly setting on the stage of the Music Box Helen Jerome's dramatization of "Pride and Prejudice." The play comes from a Philadelphia visit and they thought it was all right down there, too.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Consumer buying-power and the rate of industrial activity, the trend of both now being upward, will probably continue to increase through the next two or three years, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics declared today in its report, the Agricultural Outlook for 1935-36."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Removal of all restrictions on the production of hogs, and a proportional increase in the acreage to be planted to corn for the next two years, was announced late today by Secretary Wallace, after he had conferred behind closed doors with about twenty-five farmers engaged in the problem of producing more meat under agreement with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Automobiles caused the death of twenty-one persons in New York City last week. Throughout the country 113 persons lost their lives in automobile accidents over the week-end alone, according to an incomplete tabulation compiled by The Associated Press.

THE TIMES index of business activity -- a figure based on production of steel, electric power, automobiles, cotton cloth and lumber, together with freight carloadings -- has advanced to 91 per cent of an estimated normal. At this point it is at the highest level reached at any time during the last five years, except for a brief period in the Summer of 1933 -- lasting from mid-June to late July.

Officials of the Chicago (Ill.) Sanitary District will entertain bids on Nov. 14 on a new issue of $20,718,890 of 4 per cent refunding bonds of the district maturing on Jan. 1, 1959, and optional on Jan. 1, 1945. The bonds are dated, all this year, as follows: $18,256,890 on April 1, $540,000 on May 1, $135,000 on April 25, $225,000 on June 1 and $1,562,000 on July 1.
HELENA, Mont., Nov. 4 (AP). -Another exodus took place today, scores fleeing as new earth tremors shook Helena.
A continued decline in earnings was reported yesterday by the Chesapeake Corporation. The company is the link through which the Alleghany Corporation controls the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.

Under a compromise arrangement with the powers of this world, twenty-five dwellers in the spiritual "kingdom" of Father Major J. Divine, who is openly addressed as God by his Harlem followers, were qualified yesterday to vote in today's election through a special registration board in West 115th Street, which is the life-line of the kingdom.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -Princeton University freshmen vote Republican, prefer a Phi Beta Kappa key to a varsity letter, think the chairmanship of The Daily Princetonian the most coveted campus honor and say the "ideal girl" is a combination of Ginger Rogers, Jean Harlow and Claudette Colbert, according to a survey of the tastes of the class of '39 conducted by The Daily Princetonian, the results of which were announced today.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4. -- Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King announced tonight that he would leave here Wednesday for Washington and, on President Roosevelt's invitation, spend Friday night in the White House.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 4 (AP). -- On the basis of a shred from a blue zipper jacket, police investigators said tonight that another terrorist shared the dynamite death of H.F. Rutkowski, bomber, and an innocent child yesterday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4. -- The first death sentence has been imposed by a Soviet court in connection with the Stakhanoff movement, a district engineer, S. Poltnikov, a former Communist party member, having been condemned today to be shot for sabotage.

On the front page, "Girl Bandit No. 1" is found slain in an automobile. On the next prominent page some one calls Mrs. ROOSEVELT our No. 1 pacifist. Thus it is once more shown how a word, a phrase or a slogan can invade these United States and sweep everything before it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4. -Seven of the Yale players who saw service against Dartmouth on Saturday, Roscoe, Colwell, Peterson, Love, Curtin, Hessberg and Gallagher, were on today's makeshift varsity which battled the scrubs for an hour and a half.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The Independent Petroleum Association of America was told today that President Roosevelt wishes the nation's oil resources to be conserved and that if the industry itself fails in the job, the government must step in with necessary legislation.
Directors of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. This will bring payments for 1935 to 75 cents a share.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- When Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin addressed a campaign meeting in Liverpool tonight he was already a legally qualified Member of the next Parliament, which is to be elected Nov. 14. He had been a Member since 3 o'clock this afternoon, the hour at which nominations closed, because no candidate had appeared up to that time as an opponent in his Bewdley Division of Worcestershire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The War Department has been authorized to buy new clothing and equipment for the CCC valued at about $10,000,000, Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work, announced today.

Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler, tax-dodging racketeer and leading beer-runner of prohibition days, gave "potent evidence of his guilt" by high living and by running away when his tax was questioned, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

MIAMI, Nov. 4. -- A hurricane which struck this city this afternoon cut a path across Southern Florida and blew out into the Gulf of Mexico near Everglades City tonight, leaving a trail of death and destruction.

DECEPTION ISLAND, Antarctica, Nov. 4 (By Wireless). -- The motorship Wyatt Earp is at Deception Island once again, on the third Ellsworth transantarctic flight expedition, and preparations are being made to assemble the airplane Polar Star on the deck.

Officers of the six teams here to compete in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show, which starts tomorrow in Madison Square Garden, were honored at a dinner last night at Squadron A and will also be the guests of honor at luncheon and dinner again today.

Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, conferred with a group of physicians yesterday afternoon on plans for a coordinated drive to raise health standards of the lower West Side. This area, which houses about 250,000 persons of more than thirty-five nationalities, has the highest death rate in the city, Dr. Rice declared.

A survey to discover those points in the city most vulnerable to earthquake is being conducted by the geology department of City College, it was announced yesterday. The study, under the direction of Dr. Daniel T. O'Connell, will be based on observations of New Yorkers during the earthquake early Friday morning.
ALBANY, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The State Allocation Board released $3,925,184.94 today for additional WPA projects in New York State. These allocations brought the total to date to $36,746,340.75.

The engineers who design and build automobiles were hosts to presidents and sales executives of car and parts manufacturing companies who attended the annual dinner of the Society of Automotive Engineers in the Hotel Commodore last night.

The Board of Estimate took the first step yesterday looking toward the demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated structure when it requested the Transit Commission to resume the hearings on that project which were started, and then dropped, five years ago.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 4. -Almost all broadsilk workers who did not answer the strike call of last week did so today and the walkout is practically 100 par cent effective, it was said tonight by Alexander Williams, manager of the local union of the American Federation of Silk Workers.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Essex County will be the centre of interest tomorrow in the New Jersey elections since the vote there will decide control of the new Assembly.

Awaited with impatience, the van Gogh exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art opened privately last evening. Beginning today, and until Jan. 5, the pictures, assembled from a large number of European and American collections, will be on public view.

WHITE BLUFF, Tenn., Nov. 4 (AP). -- A small band of white men lynched a Negro near here today after wresting him from officers on a busy downtown street. The man was accused of slapping a white woman.

ATHENS, Nov. 4. -- Marshal George Kondylis, Regent and Premier, announced today after the Cabinet had taken an oath of loyalty to the returning monarchy that he would remain in power as Premier after the return of King George. He said it was his duty to remain to bring economic reconstruction of the country and reorganize the army.
BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, as Reich and Prussian Minister of Economics, issued the following order to the Reich Economic Chamber today:
Controller Frank J. Taylor issued yesterday a pamphlet showing that the constitutional debt-incurring power of the city stood at $317,169,137 on Oct. 1.

The American agency of the Compangnie Maritime Belge announced in New York yesterday that the Belgian Line, as it is popularly called, would hand in its resignation from the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference as the result of German manipulations of Reichsmarks which give American shippers on German vessels a lower rate than they can obtain elsewhere.

Senator BORAH is now sitting in his home capital instead of Washington, his more usual site. Is it to divert the anger of the Idaho potato raisers that he jumps once more on the Old Guard? What is the peculiar wickedness of the Old Guard? It is the Republican organization, the machine.

The Eastern Women's Headwear Association announced last night that it had set next Friday at 4:30 P.M. for a lockout in 600 millinery factories affecting 25,000 millinery workers directly and about 15,000 indirectly -- a total of 40,000 workers.

Charges of fraudulent Democratic registrations in Putnam County were made yesterday by Lafayette B. Gleason, secretary of the Republican State Committee after a check of registrants showed that 102 persons who had registered for today's election in New York also had been enrolled there.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 4. -- There were four known dead in the Florida hurricane area tonight.
HAVANA, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The hurricane which struck the East Coast of Florida today was nature's latest contribution to the 1935 bumper crop of southern storms.
ALBANY, Nov. 4 (AP). -- An increase of 136,450 in the total number of factory employes in New York State in three years was reported today by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The editors and other citizens in this country who assert that the welfare of the United States cannot possibly be affected by a little bush war in Africa are more numerous than those who make the same remarks about the domestic consequences of the internal economic distress of Germany.
Five Manhattan properties and three in the Bronx were taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. One scheduled Bronx sale was adjourned. The results were as follows:

A 67-year-old grandmother and her five married daughters, and another woman and her three married daughters, are enrolled in a class in home-making and cooking offered to adults in Public School 75, Faile Street and Whitlock Avenue, the Bronx.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -With the Navy game safely under its belt by a 26-0 count, the undefeated Princeton football team turned its attention today to the meeting with Harvard here on Saturday.

The market value of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2,522,713,489 in October to a total of $43,002,018,069, according to a monthly compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price per share of all listed stocks on Nov. 1 was $32.90, which compared with $30.97 at the beginning of October.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 4. -Today was the lightest Monday the Harvard football squad has had this year. There was a total absence of contact work, but there was, nevertheless, a determined start for the game at Princeton. One of the scrub teams came over to the varsity gridiron to demonstrate the Tigers' offensive, simply walking through the plays, and there is likely to be a somewhat harder session tomorrow.

Insisting that Joseph D. McGoldrick had been nominated for District Attorney to make certain that the Republicans won one Assembly seat in Brooklyn, John J. Curtin, campaign manager for the Kings County Democratic organization, made a final plea over Station WOR last night for the election of the entire county ticket headed by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan.

In the event of a serious earthquake, New York's tallest "most triumphant" buildings would suffer worst, in the opinion of Frank Lloyd Wright, pioneer modern architect, who spoke last night before the Decorators Club at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street.
