Warning the Manhattan squad against overconfidence following its 65 to 0 rout of City College, Coach Chick Meehan worked the Jasper eleven at full speed yesterday at Innisfail Park in preparation for Saturday's game with La Salle College of Philadelphia at Ebbets Field.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange at a special meeting yesterday approved the listing of securities of the H.L. Green Company, Inc.; the Coca-Cola Company and the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Speculative interest in the wheat market was at a minimum today, both here and abroad, and prices declined more because of lack of support than aggressive selling. Buying against bids helped to check the decline, however, and closing quotations on the Board of Trade here were only 1/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel lower than on Saturday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Although court action has been instituted here to block it, the proposed merger of the American Founders Corporation with other holding and investment companies was brought nearer today when two of the companies voted here for virtual consolidation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Legal action to block the proposed financing of the Southwestern Gas Electric Company involving $20,500,000 is to be instituted in the Federal court here tomorrow morning by Halsey, Stuart Co., officers of the Chicago investment house announced tonight.

If anybody tells you that he knows all about party politics in Westchester County, don't believe him. He is only trying to impose upon your own ignorance. This year, more than is usually the case, the Westchester confusion seems to rank partisan divisions there with the "devil's incomprehensibles," as JOHN ADAMS described all New York politics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- A special investigating organization has been set up by the Federal Housing Administration for detecting and prosecuting fraud and racketeering in violation of the terms of the National Housing Act, FHA officials announced today.

A class of 190 young attorneys was inducted into practice yesterday by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court with a warning against dishonesty and communistic acts, and a demand that they "support and defend the Constitution of the United States because the Constitution is the keystone of our government."

Frederick A. Tuttle, former Assistant Chief Inspector of Immigration at Ellis Island and an employe of the immigration service for thirty-three years, was sentenced yesterday to serve two years in the Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., on charges of aiding aliens to evade the immigration laws.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The requirements of Form A-2 regarding financial statements, as applied to bank holding companies registering under the Securities Act of 1933, have been amended by the Securities and Exchange Commission to simplify the procedure of filing and at the same time to call for a complete picture of conditions which the commission believes is necessary for the full protection of the investors.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4 (AP). -Thomas S. Rhea, long a power in Kentucky politics, announced late today, on the eve of Kentucky's election, that he would support the Republican nominee for Governor instead of Lieut. Gov. A.B. Chandler, Democrat, who beat Mr. Rhea for the nomination.

There was no rest for Columbia's football team yesterday at Baker Field. The usual Monday of leisure was turned into an afternoon of hard scrimmaging as Coach Lou Little started preparations for the invasion by the undefeated Syracuse eleven on Saturday.

Arrangements have been made for the purchase of the General Motors Corporation's 13 per cent interest in Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., by Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, and the Atlas Corporation, an investment trust, it was announced yesterday by John D. Hertz, a partner in Lehman Brothers.

May I refute the criticism of Mrs. Helen S.K. Wilcox concerning my approval of the program outlined by the Brookings Institution in which it hopes to convince our citizens of the benefits to be derived by a lower scale of prices?

Mrs. John Williams Morgan gave a luncheon yesterday in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for a group of women who are organizing a card party and tea to be held Nov. 19 in the roof garden of the hotel for the benefit of charitable enterprises of the Penland board of the woman's auxiliary of the Church of the Ascension.

Decision was reserved in Jersey City yesterday by Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder on the application of three stockholders of the American Hide and Leather Company for an injunction to restrain the organization from acting further on its plan for financial reorganization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- George W. Wickersham, John Godfrey Saxe and Robert C. Morris of New York City, have been appointed members of the American Bar Association's new Resolutions Committee, which is expected to play an important part at the annual meeting in Boston next August.
Plans for deflating the Works Progress Administration, which is expected to complete its program by June 30, 1936, were announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator for New York City.

With standout teams from all sections of the country meeting the pick of local quintets, a schedule of ten college basketball double-headers has been arranged for Madison Square Garden for the 1935-36 season, it was announced yesterday by Promoter Ned Irish.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The okapi, or "living fossil," the rarest animal in the London Zoo and one of only four in captivity anywhere in the world, died suddenly in its enclosure at Regents Park today.

The directors of the Coca-Cola Company voted yesterday at a meeting in Wilmington, Del., to distribute on Dec. 10 to stock of record on Nov. 15 the additional 3,000,000 shares of common stock recently authorized by stockholders, thereby increasing the number of common shares to 4,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- With bidders present from leading cities of the East and Middle West, jewelry from the estate of the late Mrs. Sydney E. Hutchinson, daughter of Edward T. Stotesbury, was sold at auction here today for $157,787.50.

Trial of two actions to recover $1,273 from William Fox, motion picture producer, was started yesterday before Municipal Court Justice Joseph S. Rosalsky and a jury. Mrs. Alice Fox, divorced wife of Aaron Fox, the defendant's brother, is plaintiff in the suits.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Although President Roosevelt studied with keen interest advance surveys of the elections to take place tomorrow, he refrained on the eve of them, as throughout the recent past, from taking any action that might even be remotely construed as active participation.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Foreign exchange transactions opened steady today, as silver export was virtually embargoed because of China's new monetary program. Raising of the equalization fee brought the silver export duty to 65 per cent.

W. Ward Smith, campaign director of the Consumers Public Power Plant Committee, declared in a statement yesterday that the Consolidated Gas system contributed, in 1933 and 1934, $23,395.99 to six New York civic associations whose representatives are members of the group organizing a citizens committee to fight the power plant.

In observance of election day, all banks, security and commodity Exchanges in this city will be closed today. Business will be resumed as usual tomorrow. All other major security markets in the country will be closed today, except the Chicago Stock and Curb Exchanges, the St. Louis, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Baltimore and Salt Lake City Stock Exchanges.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- Marie Tempest, making her first appearance on the stage since her gala jubilee matinee last Spring, was hailed tonight in a new comedy, "Short Story," by a newcomer, Robert Morley. It was presented at the Queens Theatre.

Mayor La Guardia pledged his support for the forthcoming United Hospital campaign in a letter read yesterday afternoon before the volunteer speakers for the drive, meeting in the United Hospital Fund offices at 370 Lexington Avenue.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- By a vote of the City Council today, Chicago's more than 3,000,000 residents will regulate their lives and habits by Eastern standard time, effective March 1 at 2 A.M. On that day the city's clocks will be officially advanced one hour.

BASLE, Nov. 4. -- The monthly statement of the Bank for International Settlements, issued today, shbwed deposits increased 8;O0O,O0O Swiss francs, of which the bank immediately put 7,000,000 into gold bars. This made its total gold-bar assets a2,230,000 francs, exceeding the previous peak of April, 1934, by 4.000,0o0.

Today's news article in THE TIMES regarding the relocation of the Irving statue, supplemented by your editorial, will indeed have served an excellent purpose if either or both of them shall succeed in turning the mental gaze of the present generation back, not alone to the history of our city but likewise of our country.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4. -- Canada's capital today extended its warmest greeting to John Buchan, Baron Tweedsmuir, the new Governor General, and Lady Tweedsmuir. Citizens turned out by thousands to give them an enthusiastic welcome.

TORONTO, Nov. 4. -- Jewelry valued at nearly $8,000 was stolen today from the Vice-Regal suite of Don Juan de Bourbon, Prince of Asturias and heir presumptive to the Spanish crown, and his bride Princess Maria Mercedes Bourbon-Sicilie.

WARSAW, Nov. 4. -- A Polish-German treaty terminating ten years of tariff war and replacing the agreement concluded a year ago was signed tonight by Count Szendek, acting Polish Foreign Minister, and Hans Adolf von Moltke, German Ambassador. This treaty is the first normal convention regulating commercial relations between Poland and Germany.

The engagement abroad of more gold in the amount of $4,864,000 for shipment here was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this, $4,500,000 was taken in France and $364,000 in India. The total engaged since Sept. 9, when the current movement started, now amounts to $474,500,000, of which $446,100,000 has been received to date.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Ina Claire returned to Philadelphia tonight as a co-star with Dennis King in the premiere of "Love Is Not So Simple," a comedy presented by the Theatre Guild. Local critics, in a more or less restrained manner, suggested that the play, adapted by Philip Moeller from the Hungarian of Ladislas Fodor, was hardly worthy of Miss Claire's talents.

Italians may be excused for seeing more than a coincidence in the fact that the boycott of their foreign trade is to begin four days after the British general election. The policy of the British Government will be submitted to the voters on Nov. 14. Should it win overwhelming approval, and something like a positive mandate be given to Prime Minister BALDWIN by the people, his position would be greatly strengthened.

Although the Cotton Belt escaped the predicted low temperatures over Sunday, the Weather Bureau again forecast a freeze in parts of Oklahoma and North Texas for last night. With today's market closed and a steady trade demand in evidence, operators yesterday showed no disposition to supply contracts and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended 2 points higher to 5 points lower than on Saturday after holding within a narrow range throughout the session.

The curtain will fall today on New York's 1935 racing season when the United Hunts Racing Association's one-day Fall meeting is held at Belmont Park. This annual event draws turf devotees from all sections and all classes.

TOKYO, Nov. 4. -- Officials and bankers here are skeptical of the practicability of the currency reforms decreed in China yesterday. They are particularly doubtful of the value of nationalizing silver.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 4. -The Norwegian freighter Sneland, which earlier had reported it was being driven toward shore off the Florida East Coast near Fort Lauderdale, wirelessed Coast Guard headquarters here tonight it was no longer in any danger.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4. -The Westchester Board of Supervisors protested to the Federal Government today against the discontinuance of Camp Elmsford, maintained at Elmsford for transients by the TERA.

A young Eskimo husky named Chapka and two mountain lion cubs, newly arrived from Arizona and as a result christened 'Arry and Zona, were made cage mates yesterday at the Central Park Zoo, but their reluctant association did not last long.

There are many times more reckless pedestrians than drivers and they are seldom punished by the courts, Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, declared in a radio address over WOR last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- An assertion that the bituminous mining industry was on the way to destruction when it was saved by the Guffey Coal Control Act was made by a mining operator today before Justice Jesse C. Adkins of the District of Columbia Supreme Court in defending the constitutionality of the act.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- In a packed courtroom at the Palais de Justice, nineteen men and one woman who had been in one way or another associates, if not accomplices, of the gambler and swindler Alexandre Stavisky, went on trial today.

John E. Cowdin, president of the Queens County Jockey Club, which conducts racing at Aqueduct, yesterday made public his views concerning a recent statement by John Sloan, a member of the State Racing Commission, as follows:

The letter of William McFee criticizing the alternating traffic lights on the avenues in New York is based upon a misapprehension of the facts as to the present course of the lights and refers to a situation which occurs only occasionally.
P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, will arrive this evening from London on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, accompanied by Mrs. Franklin.
A decrease in the general and infant mortality rates in the city last week as compared with the preceding seven days and the same week in 1934 was reported yesterday by the Department of Health.
No change was noted in any section of the money market, quotations being maintained for all classifications on a modest volume of business.

This Saturday, for the first time in ten years -- which is two generations and a half where college life is concerned -- Harvard appears in the Palmer Stadium at Princeton. None of the Harvard undergraduates making the trip will have ever been there before in their official cheering status, since the game marks the completion of the resumption of relations between the two colleges.

The Board of Estimate, in a special meeting at City Hall yesterday, authorized the expenditure of $14,800,000 for relief in November and December and set the city's share at $5,550,000 for the two-month period.

Police Commissioner Valentine summoned the high command of the department to Police Headquarters yesterday and issued final instructions in an effort to achieve an orderly election today. The Commissioner revealed that the plans contained two innovations.

Excellent as was Bernard De Vote article on Mark Twain in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, the column devoted to the same subject in today's "Topics of The Times" supplies a must needed addition to Mr. De Vote analysis.

THE stories bearing on the settlement of the western slope of the Mississippi Valley have been many, ranging from Hamlin Garland's monochromatic studies in poverty to Willa Cather's more glowing canvases, but it is safe to say that nothing of the flavor of Mari Sandoz's biography of her crusty pioneer father, "Old Jules" (Little, Brown, $3), has ever been published before.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- Whatever else the past week-end's talks at Geneva may have done, they appeared today to have improved the Anglo-Italian atmosphere.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- Although Germany is doing her best to stay neutral in the Anglo-Italian controversy pending further developments, nevertheless the war in Ethiopia is beginning to subject the National Socialist regime to a new strain which tends to produce in Germany some of the same results as in war-embroiled Italy.

Postmaster General James A. Farley sang, spoke and sold the first stamps yesterday morning at 9 o'clock, when the new postoffice branch -- Station No. 82 -- was officially opened in Bloomingdale's department store, Lexington Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street.
An important deal in the East Side residential centre was reported yesterday, involving a change of ownership for the sixteen-story apartment building at 400 East Fifty-ninth Street.

A detective stenographer testified for the State in General Sessions yesterday at the trial of Nicholas (Nick) Montana, indicted for compulsory prostitution. His testimony was based on ninety-six pages of notes he said he had made over a period of a month last year on telephone conversations between the defendant and others, including physicians, relating to vice in the city.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- Earl Beatty, who faced the guns at Jutland without flinching, underwent a new kind of ordeal tonight when Laborites heckled him mercilessly at an election meeting.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 4. -- Back home from the glorious funeral of a Yale jinx that haunted them for fifty years, the Dartmouth Indians examined the reservation's football records today and, much to their dismay, discovered that the unlamented corpse was survived by a 21-year-old brother.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- The feathery impost of ninety-eight pounds, of which Jockey Nick Wall took the greatest advantage, had a large part in accounting for the victory of Breckenridge Long's Legume in the Monacacy Handicap, feature at Pimlico today. Legume led from end to end, and Wall put up one of his best rides, outsmarting even the redoubtable Silvio Coucci, leading rider of the meeting, who scored another double.

J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, whose activities have been the subject of an investigation conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, lost a point yesterday in his fight to prevent the SEC from hampering his sale of stock.

Unless cotton exports recover, the country is likely to have to find employment for almost 2,000,000 persons engaged in producing or handling of this staple, according to the agricultural commission of the American Bankers Association.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 4. -- While Italian reports state that four army corps are advancing upon Makale and that Hauzien, on the southward road from Adigrat and Tokule, twenty-five miles southwest of Adowa, has been captured, the authorities at Makale this morning reported they were unaware of any unusual military activity in the area.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4. -- A warning to Japan that she cannot escape responsibility for recent clashes on the Manchurian border is contained in a new note from Soviet Russia, which was made public here tonight.

Price movements were mixed on the local commodity markets yesterday, but the changes were small and the volume light in anticipation of today's holiday. On the cash markets dairy products, tin and silk advanced and all the grains were lower.

TORONTO, Nov. 4. -- With the exception of the Gatineau Power Company, from which a limited amount of electric current will be taken, power from Quebec has been discontinued by the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario, it was made known today at the Ontario Legislature and by the power companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- A request that the Van Sweringen plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company be declared prima facie impracticable and unsatisfactory was transmitted today to Oliver E. Sweet, director of the Interstate Commerce Commission's Bureau of Finance, by Edward C. Delafield, chairman of the bondholders' protective committee for the road's general 4 per cent gold bonds due in 1975.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Coinage by American mints in the first ten months of this year was larger than in any full year in the previous decade, the Treasury Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Despite prospects for an exportable supply of American wheat again, the Agriculture Department's outlook report redicted today that prices would not go as low as the 1931-33 period.

The General Motors Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents. These dividends, totaling $1 a share on the 42,879,894 shares in the hands of the public on Sept. 30, represent the largest distribution made at one time by the corporation since January, 1930.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Henry Hathaway of Bronxvilie gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mrs. Hathaway's brother, Harold Shantz, first secretary of the United States Embassy in Moscow. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Ray T. Wilken, Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Mills, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Stewart, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Reid, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Winters and Miss Vera Shantz.

The wheels of justice were geared for speed in Traffic Court yesterday as two magistrates mowed through a week-end calendar of 840 cases, most of them involving parking offenses. The final gavel fell shortly before 3 P.M., with $865 in fines collected, four persons sent to jail for a day in default of payment, one sentenced to ten days' imprisonment for driving while intoxicated and another to thirty days for reckless driving.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 4. -The Long Island pros and their amateur partners today gave the terrifying Lido Country Club course such a shaking up as it has seldom received at the hands of niblick-wielders.

A letter from Seldon Rodman, Yale alumnus and editor of Common Sense, condemning the stand taken by The Yale Daily News in favor of United States participation in the Olympic Games in Germany, was made public yesterday by the Committee on Fair Play in Sports of 20 Vesey Street.

Coming back from Columbus Saturday night, Dr. Maurice Keady and Joe Byrne, the Damon and Pythias of Notre Dame alumni, held open house at the rear of the club car, while William Nieman, who calls off all banking conferences with his vice presidents when his adopted Ramblers take the field, went through the Pullman to lead the passengers in refrain and cheers.

The footnote this morning must be one of gentle reproof, for the Fifth Avenue Theatre is up to its old tricks again. It does not grow gracefully into the years. It clung to the drama as long as it decently could before the restless witch shook it off and headed north toward Times Square.

The Stock Exchange compiles each month the market valuation of all listed shares, obtained through multiplying the number of shares listed for each stock by that stock's month-end quoted price. Computed on this basis, it makes October's increase in total valuation $2,522,713,000 and the increase since the first of April $12,065,918,000.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 5. -Jasper McLevy, 57-year-old roofer, was re-elected Socialist Mayor of Bridgeport today by a record-breaking plurality of 13,904 votes.
ALBANY, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Democrats and Republicans divided the honors tonight as scattered returns were counted in the election of twelve Supreme Court justices.

TORONTO, Nov. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Quotations in the mining market on the Toronto Stock Exchange moved upward today, supported by heavier buying orders, particularly among the gold shares. The holiday in New York apparently had no dampening effect on operations.
A wide republican sweep in up-State cities where there were Mayoralty contests resulted in many Democratic upsets yesterday, according to returns available last midnight.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 5. -Arthur Knapp got his Class B onedesign dinghy Four Deuces going today and led in the competition at the Larchmont Yacht Club. He ran up 59 points to 54 for Bill Griffin in his boat B'rrr. Only a point each separated the second, third and fourth craft at the end of four contests, so close was the sailing.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5. -- A revival of mining activity in Honduras, attributed largely to the increase in gold and silver prices, is sending a steady stream of foreign capital into that Central American republic and at the same time is creating one of the finest airline systems in the world, J. Joaquin Alvarado said here today.
A general air of quiet satisfaction with the election results in this city pervaded Tammany Hall last night.

New York University's varsity cross-country team scored its third victory of the season yesterday when it defeated the City College harriers, 24 to 31, over the new in-! tercollegiate five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park. This was the first setback for the Beavers in three starts this year.

READING, Pa., Nov. 5 (AP). -- Socialist candidates apparently swept the city by large majorities for all city and school board offices on the face of returns from twenty-five out of seventy-five precincts late tonight.

HARTFORD, Nov. 5. -- Bands blared and red fire flared on Hart ford streets tonight to celebrate the return of the city administration to Democraic control. Mayor Joseph W. Beach, grandson of James G. Batterson, founder of the Travelers Insurance Company, was defeated for re-election by John A. Pilgard, 69-year-old grocery merchant, who came here a Danish immigrant fifty years ago.
BUENOS AI_ES, Nov. 5.--Thelfortnightly statement of the Cen-itral Bank of Argentina for Oct. 31shows the following changes inpaper pesos:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5. -- Although the game with Princeton still is a few days away, the Harvard coaches today mustered what will be close to the starting line-up against the Tigers and drove it hard in a twenty-minute scrimmage against the substitutes.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- A friendly, laughing crowd of several hundred local Democrats led by a fife and drum corps marched tonight to Hyde Park House to celebrate with the President the first Democratic victory in Hyde Park Township in forty years.

Bootleg coal, stolen from the anthracite fields of Pennsylvania and brought by truck to the New York market, is making serious inroads into the legitimate coal business here, according to the Bronx Board of Trade, which appealed yesterday to Mayor La Guardia and to Governor Earle of Pennsylvania to take steps to halt this "illegal and unfair competition."

J. Spencer Weed, president of the National Horse Show Association, presided last night at the annual stag dinner given to the officers of the international military teams in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. A distinguished company attended the event.

A new producing firm will make its bow this evening when Albert Bein and Jack Goldsmith offer -over the footlights of the Broadhurst -- the former's "Let Freedom Ring." It is a dramatization of Grace Lumpkin's novel, "To Make My Bread," and in it will be Norma Chambers, Shepperd Strudwick, Robert Williams, William Geer and Rose Keane.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- That legislation for a permanent NRA would be a major issue in the next session of Congress was indicated today when George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, revealed that the much-advertised conference of industry and labor, which will meet here next month, would have such legislation as a principal topic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Election straws today in New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New England showed that a wind is blowing across the East against the New Deal. If Kentucky, where the counting cannot legally begin until tomorrow, should point in the same direction.

ATHENS, NOV. 5. -- King George II today sent messages to the Cabinet and the nation accepting Sunday's plebiscite as an expression of a general desire for his return and pledged all his energies to the nation's service.

PATERSON, N.J., Wednesday, Nov. 6. -- A clear-cut Republican victory was registered in Passaic County last night as the entire ticket was swept into office in the first test of the reorganized Republican county forces.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5. -- Voters throughout the State flocked to the polls in record-breaking numbers today, indicating that the total vote would approach 1,100,000 in the election of a Governor, State and legislative officers, decision on repeal of the Prohibition Amendment and enactment of an Old-Age Pension Law.

TOKYO, Nov. 5. -- Since China's new monetary reform program has proved her "insincerity" toward Japan, the Japanese Army is ready to act alone in China to protect Manchuria from "the Communist menace," War Minister Yoshiyuki Kawashima asserted tonight as he departed for the annual military manoeuvres.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Answering the call of the Controller of the Currency for statements of condition at the close of business on Nov. 1, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the First National Bank and a few others reported decreases in loans and discounts, but most institutions showed some expansion.
GENEVA, Nov. 5 (AP). -- No trade quota punishment will be meted out to so-called "deserter League States" in the general boycott of Italy, a League of Nations subcommittee on sanctions decided today.

ally average gross production ofcrude oil in the United States lastweek was 2,798,350 barrels, comparcel with 2,797,950 in the previousweek, an increase of 00 barrels, according to the American PetroleumInstitute. California and Louisianashowed moderate increases from thepreceding period, but they were offset partly by 'a decrease in the ifields east of /alifornia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- A lease to private interests of a "dry ice" well in Carbon County, Utah, has been made by Secretary Ickes. The lessee intends to ship the carbon dioxide gas, which emerges almost pure from the Utah well, for commercial use either in liquid or solid form.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Under a rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, foreign issuers who obtain permanent registration of their securities on United States Exchanges by March 31 will continue to have exemption from Section 16 of the Securities Exchange Act which covers trading by officers, directors and principal stockholders and Section 14 (a), dealing with the solicitation of proxies and consents.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 5. -- Trial of the lawsuit brought against the Chilean Electric Company by the Government for alleged violation of exchange control legislation and demanding payment of nearly 200,000,000 pesos continued today in the presence of a huge crowd, following with intense interest the attack on electric concerns operating locally with American capital.

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., Nov. 5. -- The Arctic regions yielded up another of their secrets today in the form of six islands, presence of which in the centre of the Kara Sea heretofore had been unsuspected.
Our Police Commissioner, excellent as he is, should realize that he is not the law, but an administrator of that law.
NOGALES, Ariz., Nov. 5 (AP). -Reports of a battle between Mexican troops and rebels apparently equipped with American weapons and American money reached the border today.

Anna Hamlin, soprano, and Floyd Townsley, tenor, appeared in joint recital at the Town Hall last night. The singers began the program with two duet-cantatas by Bach. Mr. Townsley followed with a Brahms group and Miss Hamlin concluded the first half with songs by Schubert.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Wednesday, Nov. 6. -- The Republican candidates won every place contested for in Union County by average pluralities of 7,000 votes, it appeared this morning on the basis of incomplete returns.

With military jumping teams entered from six nations and representatives of America's leading stables named in the various competitions, the National Horse Show Association today will open its annual exhibition in Madison Square Garden, to continue through next Tuesday night.

Joseph E. Widener's Bushranger, one of the leading jumpers of the country, scored a decisive victory yesterday in winning the Whitney Gold Trophy over a mile and a half on the flat in the feature at Belmont Park.

Over night, folk or "provincial" art in abundance has become available at two New York galleries the Marie Harriman, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, and the American Folk Art Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street. Both shows opened yesterday, the former to continue until Nov. 23, the latter indefinitely.

York money market closedfor holiday. Monday's closing ratefor Stock Exchange call loans,of1 per cent; for sixty-day time loans,1 per cent; for prime commercialpaper, three to four months,ofi per cent.London Market.Money unchanged atof 1 percent. Short and three months' billsunchanged at 9-16 to % of 1 per[ cent.

Assessed valuations of real estate holdings of fifteen local public utilities have been increased $203,000,000 in line with Mayor La Guardia's determination to set utility real estate values at the same figures for taxation as the companies use for rate-making purposes.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week and in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 680, as against 809 in the previous week and 732 in the same period last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that in the week ended on Nov. 2 twenty offering sheets of various oil interests had been received.

PRAGUE, Nov. 5. -- Severe measures have been taken by Czechoslovak authorities in Tesin district on the Polish border to prevent acts of violence and hostile demonstrations by the Polish minority living in the area, which is claimed by Poland because of its overwhelmingly Polish population.

The police made their customary arrangements last night for preserving order in Times Square, where, as old-timers may recall, crowds were wont to gather on past election nights to shout approval or disapproval of the returns.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- With almost no pageantry and with the simplest of ceremonial, the Duke of Gloucester, soldier son of King George and Queen Mary, will marry his childhood friend, Lady Alice MontaguDouglas-Scott, at Buckingham Palace tomorrow.
" Each year you must submit to some recital on the events of Nov. 4, 1918; it's a great story and a true one."

A heavy vote was cast early in New York City yesterday, with a few arrests and so little disorder that representatives of both major political parties joined the Honest Ballot Association in praising the "disinterested alertness and efficiency" of the Police Department.

A group of four election board inspectors and two policemen arose before dawn yesterday morning to prepare for the polling in the Fortieth Election district of the Tenth Assembly district in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Registration statements for issues aggregating $37,000,000 under the Securities Act of 1933 by two corporations, the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas Company, and the International Cement Corporation of New York, were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The Government took a step forward today in its drive to end all direct relief payment by Dec. 1 when Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, announced that three States, Maryland, Delaware and South Dakota would receive no further money for "dole" purposes.

A report opposing the establishment of a free foreign trade zone in the port of New York will be acted on tomorrow at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the chamber, made public the joint committee report yesterday.

Assailing the rubber companies and "the lobby in Washington" for what they consider inimical treatment, independent tire dealers at their annual convention in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday agreed to take steps to preserve their business.

Election Day brought one of the largest crowds on record to the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace yesterday. Somewhat light in the morning, the throng swelled to impressive figures early in the afternoon.

A fire, believed to have been started by boys in search of wood for election night bonfires swept an unoccupied tenement at 335 West Seventeenth Street last night. It was discovered at 9:30 P.M. and two alarms were turned in. Fire apparatus in the command of Battalion Chief Edward O'Connor answered the alarm.
Fordham's football squad forgot that yesterday was a holiday and spent the morning in one of the most active sessions it has had since the beginning of last week.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 5 (AP). -- A kindly, gray-haired minister today offered a home and the affection of a father to the woman accused of killing his only son.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- A saving of $38,481,686 to the citizens of the nation through the efforts of its Bureau of Investigation was reported today by the Department of Justice in a survey of the bureau's work. The cost was $4,626,518, including the pay of agents, fingerprint experts and scientists.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 5. -- The Argentine Government has established a tight censorship to prevent news from getting out regarding Sunday's elections in the provinces of Buenos Aires and Cordoba. The Buenos Aires newspapers received here describe the elections as the most fraudulent, scandalous and violent in the country's history.

A banking group composed of Kuhn, Loeb Co., Field, Glore Co., Hayden, Stone Co. and Lehman Brothers will offer today an issue of $5,500,000 Republic Steel Corporation purchase-money firstmortgage convertible 5 1/2 per cent bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1954, at 106 and accrued interest.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- Republicans took an edge tonight in Ohio's municipal elections.

WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Nov. 5 (AP). -- Harold Gropper, 16-year-old Memorial High School student, was arrested today as the maker of a bomb which exploded in another boy's hand during a football victory celebration.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 5. -- Strict enforcement of the Mexican laws regulating religious worship and curbing religious education was promised by President Lazaro Cardenas today in a declaration refusing the recent plea of Roman Catholic prelates for modification of these laws.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- National and State banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System were called on today to submit reports of their condition as of Nov. 1.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 5. -- Officials of the Nassau-Suffolk County division of the Works Progress Administration professed ignorance to day of the plans announced by the Affiliated Building Trades of Long Island to call a strike today of skilled workers on all WPA projects to enforce organized labor's demands for the prevailing rate of wages.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 5 (AP). -Democrats overwhelmed their Republican opponents for legislative seats in seven districts to report complete returns tonight from the general election.

The Democratic organizations in New York City swept through to victory in yesterday's election, with the result that William F. X. Geoghan was re-elected District Attorney of Kings County, the Republican representation in the Board of Aldermen was reduced from sixteen to three, and the Democratic county office-holders received pluralities that rivaled those of the days preceding the Seabury investigation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- An extension until Feb. 1 of exemption from registration on the Exchanges for issues secured by property owned or leased by a person other than the original issuer was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with the adoption of an amendment to its Rule AN 9.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Four Arctic fliers circled their planes over the rugged Alaskan terrain today, searching for a passenger ship, missing with its five Klondike passengers since it took off from Dawson Saturday.

TAPPAN, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- Assemblyman Laurens M. Hamilton of Sterlington was re-elected to the Assembly from Rockland County today on the Republican ticket by 2,800 votes. Considerable interest was focused on the result here as Postmaster General James A. Farley had made a personal campaign in his home county to defeat Mr. Hamilton on a strictly New Deal issue.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- Two years after authorizing Sunday baseball and football games, Philadelphia "liberals" today made another successful attack upon the Pennsylvania "Blue Law" of 1794 by voting to permit the exhibition of movies after 2 P.M. every Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Fleets of cargo ships and tankers leaving Gulf ports with cotton and oil for Italy, despite President Roosevelt's warning against shipment of such materials to belligerents, threaten the League of Nations' boycott of Italy, intended to halt the ItaloEthiopian conflict.

IT was Farmer Bill Brown of the Boxing Commission, on his way back to Garrison to split a bale of hay for his Guernsey herd, who said with sorrow that the recent Garden heavyweight show didn't include any young fellow who might come forward or any old fellow who might come back and give Joe Louis even a good workout. As his auto rolled northward, he went over the card.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- Army held a heavy workout today in preparation for the Pittsburgh game with disastrous results as Whitey Grove, veteran right halfback, received an injured arm and was taken to the hospital. It is doubtful if he will be able to make the trip to Pittsburgh.

On a certain occasion, not long ago, Leopold Stokowski conducted a performance of Bach's B minor mass with the aid of the instrumental forces of the Philadelphia Orchestra, which then, as yesterday evening, performed under his direction in Carnegie Hall.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5. -Yale's first and second varsity elevens scrimmaged more than an hour today in their first meeting since the squad left Gales Ferry. The practice did not close until long after the floodlights had poured their illumination over the white helmeted warriors struggling over a white ball.

CORK, Nov. 5. -- The salvage ship Ophir, which since July has been searching for the hull of the Lusitania, sunk by a German submarine off Old Head of Kinsale in 1915, will hold a memorial service tomorrow over a large wreck, ten miles southwest of Old Head, which, from the size, is believed to be the sunken Cunarder.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. (AP) -- An immediate investigation of the need for Federal control of soft coal production was reported as assured today by C. E. Smith, a member of the National Bituminous Coal Commission. The inquiry would cost $100,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Determined to keep Princeton's offensive drive at the pitch displayed last Saturday against Navy, Coach Fritz Crisler sent the Tigers through a session devoted to perfecting all phases of their attack today on University Field.

Greater cooperation between retail liquor dealers against the "fakers" and "price wreckers" who ruin the profits of other dealers as well as their own was urged yesterday by William Denmark, chairman of the Council of Metropolitan Liquor Package Stores Associations, at the second annual mass meeting of the council in the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- Conditions iwere cheerfuI again today on theILondon Stock Exchange, although]trading was less active than yesterday. A fresh upward movement occurred in British funds as a result of renewed investment buying.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Colonel R. R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, announced tonight that several members of freedom of the press committees of two newspaper associations had voted support for The Philadelphia Inquirer against the criminal libel charge brought against it by Pennsylvania's Attorney General

New York State voted overwhelmingly yesterday in favor of Amendment 1, providing for county home rule and opening the way to reform and modernize county governments by amending the State Constitution.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 5. -- The new statement of the Mexican Government's policy toward the church was addressed to Archbishops Pascual Diaz and other Catholic leaders. Informing them of the refusal of President Cardenas to accept their petition for modification of the religious laws, it upheld especially the recent decree providing for confiscation of homes and buildings in which worship is held.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The Resettlement Administration is building four of its major low-cost housing communities on plans intended to make pedestrians safe from automobiles.

Recovery, which began in 1933, experienced a setback later in that year, and resumed in 1934, has "advanced from its low point in quite substantial fashion," Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, said last night in a radio address.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 5. -- Although the Ethiopian Government has received no word officially regarding the recent European diplomatic negotiations concerning Ethiopia, the Foreign Office, at Emperor Haile Selassie's orders, is seeking settlement terms acceptable to the Ethiopian chiefs as well as to Geneva.

Clarence Eugene Rogers Bigelow, 70-year-old cousin of the late Will Rogers, who modestly claims credit for having persuaded the cowboy humorist that he "might get some place" if he would combine "a little talk with that fancy rope stuff you do," arrived in New York yesterday from Grand Rapids, Mich., to make his contribution to the Will Rogers Memorial Fund.
ATLANTA, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Governor Eugene Talmadge's Presidential "boom" received a start today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 5. -- The faculty of Williams College filed through the red, white and blue bunting-festooned door of Griffin Hall here late this afternoon to take the oath of allegiance to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the United States while more than 300 undergraduates milled about outside, laughing, cheering and catcalling over the disputed Dorgan act and the ceremony celebrating its observance.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- The Wachter twins put Herman Wolf, a Judge of elections, in a dilemma today.

Mischka, the mischievous Indian sun bear at the Central Park Zoo, went on the loose again yesterday, but this time she did not enjoy herself as much as in previous escapades. She made the mistake of getting into the polar bear's den, and it was only her agility and the quick action of zoo officials that kept her from joining her forebears up near the Little Dipper.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- J. Ramsay MacDonald, Lord President of the Council, had tonight an opportunity to make a speech without being howled down by jeering Labor voters. He was alone in a soundproof room broadcasting from Newcastle.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 6. -- The Democratic party, under New Deal leadership, was repulsed yesterday in its strongest bid in more than a half-century for the Mayor's office of Philadelphia, traditionally the nation's first Republican city.

Murtha Lawrence, 18-year-old Brooklyn Prep senior, led a field of ninety-eight harriers from eight schools yesterday to capture individual honors in the eighth annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park.

While New York detectives identified the body of Charles (Chink) Sherman yesterday from fingerprints sent from Monticello, N. Y., another body was found in Knauth Mill Pond, near Spring Valley, only twenty-six miles south of Monticello.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Persistent selling of wheat futures by commission houses in leading markets kept what prices steadily on the downgrade today, with the lowest levels made just before the close. Scattered short covering brought about a minor upturn from the inside levels, and support came from holders also, but the close on the Chicago Board of Trade was at losses of 5/8 to 3/4C.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 6 (Wednesday). -- Republican candidates in Bergen County were swept into office yesterday by a 2-to-1 majority, according to partial returns early this morning. At 2:45 A.M. returns in 190 election districts out of 358 gave the Republicans a lead of 39,024 to 20,408.
New Yorkers shed top coats and furs yesterday as the temperature rose to 71.6 degrees at 3:20 P.M., a record for the date. Despite overcast skies, the weather was ideal for election day.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 5. -- J. P. Morgan, with 40 points, won the sweepstakes award today in the annual chrysanthemum show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which closed tonight in the main building of the Pratt estate. Mr. Morgan added to his points of yesterday two first prizes this afternoon in the decorative section.

Led by Edward Beckmann, who tallied 26 points, the football team of the Barnard School for Boys vanquished the Fieldston School eleven, 32 -- 13, at the loser's field yesterday. The victors scored in every period, while Fieldston pushed over two touchdowns in the final quarter.

MIAMI, Nov. 5 (AP). -- After a survey which showed seven dead, 137 injured and possibly $3,000,000 property and crop damage in this county from the freak hurricane yesterday, Mayor A. D. II. Fossey today asked aid from State and Federal officials.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 5. -- Republican candidates in Nassau County were swept into office today by a majority of more than 2 to 1. Out of a registration of 171,206, about 120,000 voters went to the polls.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Patrick Morrison, 95, of 4 Monroe Street, Morris Township, who has voted a straight Democratic ticket since 1862 and who voted against Lincoln in 1864, kept his record intact today by going to the polls in the Collinsville section of this town to place a line of crosses down the Democratic side of the ballot.
AT THE FRONT WITH THE ITALIAN ARMY, Nov. 5. -- A fourpointed drive by more than 125,000 Italian soldiers upon the strategic Ethiopian city of Makale was halted today by heavy rains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- At a brief hearing today the Connecticut Power Company of Hartford, which is seeking exemption from registration as a holding company under the Public Utilities Act of 1935, placed its case before the Securities and Exchange Commission, contending that its activities were intrastate and that it did not own as much as 10 per cent of any company operating in other territory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Requests for more than 200 corporations that certain information including remuneration of officers and directors supplied in seeking permanent registration of securities on the Stock Exchange be held confidential have been reviewed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, and it is understood that, in most instances, the requests have been either withdrawn or denied.

The Central Park Zoo is to go right ahead with its plan to bring up together Chapka, an Eskimo husky, and two mountain lion cubs named Arry and Zona, Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout, director of the zoo, said yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Thirteen men were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in connection with the embezzlement of $226,000 from the National Central Bank there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- At a press conference last Friday Administrator Harry Hopkins sharply criticized the relief and budgetary record of Governor Alf Landon of Kansas. Since many Republicans believe that Mr. Landon is their most available Presidential material next year, the attack quickly became celebrated.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 5. -- For the second time in two years, residents of Camden voted today in favor of constructing a municipal light and power plant. Their first vote, on a referendum held in 1933, had no effect because the courts subsequently held that the petitions placing the question on the ballots were not legal.

Announcement of a new plan for financing time-payment sales and the prediction of an increase of 75 per cent in the company's production next year were features of the annual show luncheon of NashLaFayette distributers and dealers at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -Complaining that consumers were misunderstanding the AAA, Secretary Wallace asserted today that it is "necessary that neither farmer nor consumer be led astray by wild stories spread by interested parties who have little concern for consumer-farmer welfare."

Why do the coup d'etat boys go to the trouble of staging plebiscites? Hypocrisy has been called the compliment which vice pays to virtue. Isn't there danger that a plebiscite might be interpreted as a compliment paid by dictatorship to free government?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 5. -A Republican landslide today in Westchester County, interpreted by Charles H. Griffiths, county leader, as a protest against the New Deal, was featured by the victory of Harry Scott, Republican write-in candidate for Mayor of New Rochelle.

Massachusetts is asking for an extension of the duck hunting season to make up for the days lost when the fire hazard caused a ban on shooting, and Eastern sportsmen are awaiting developments with unusual interest.

The result of the Assembly election was an upset for both the New Deal and Postmaster General Farley, Representative Hamilton Fish declared in a statement issued last night at Republican State headquarters. Mr. Fish said:

Fordham University's freshman football team displayed too much power for the New York University yearlings and defeated the Violet, 18 to 6, at Ohio Field yesterday. A crowd of almost 7,000 persons saw the two elevens clash for the first time since 1930.

ROME, Nov. 5. -- Direct AngloItalian negotiations for a solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy were resumed this afternoon in a long conference between Sir Eric Drummond, British Ambassador to Rome, and Premier Benito Mussolini, to which great importance is attributed in political and diplomatic circles.

Engineering awards last month, totaling $182,631,000, were the largest since October, 1931. The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday. Private awards were held to be increasingly responsible for the improvement.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 5. -- Carlos Steer Lafonte, 19-year-old naturalized son of an Englishman, who assassinated Dr. Antonio Miro Quesada, for thirty-five years editor-in-chief of the newspaper Comercio, and his wife on May 15, was sentenced to twenty-five years' imprisonment by a court-martial last midnight.

WHAT would have happened to the Western word if there had been no sudden interruption of international peace by the guns of 1914? This is the question that broods over George Dangerfield's brilliantly written "The Strange Death of Liberal England" (Smith Haas, $3). Paradoxically enough, the question gives Mr. Dangerfield's book a meaning for 1935, for the World War, of course, only served to postpone the asking of certain vital questions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Close scrutiny by the Senate Munitions Committee of shipments of raw materials to warring Italy and Ethiopia injected a new note today in the neutrality stand taken by the United States.

It was extremely refreshing to note in THE TIMES that at least one member of the New York State Racing Commission keeps his eyes open when he attends the races. It's plainly apparent even to a casual racegoer like myself that there is something very disreputable about our metropolitan race courses.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Medical testimony today to the effect that it was unlikely that any one could view a day-old infant and then identify the child two months later, further confused the contest between two reputed mothers for custody of 11-week-old Ernest Ludwig Muench.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5. -- The cotton market here was comparatively quiet today, the holiday observed on the New York Cotton Exchange checking the interchanges between the markets. Absence of stimulating developments limited trading to moderate proportions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Receipts of hogs here today were the largest for a Tuesday so far this season, and prices dropped 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight early in consequence, but there was a marked broadening in the demand from smaller packers who operate largely on fresh pork, and part of the loss was recovered before the close.
A close contest in Paterson, with conflicting claims by rival headquarters as the last returns filtered in, was the most interesting of scores of mayoralty elections throughout New Jersey yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 5. -- Republicans in Suffolk County won a smashing victory in the polls today. The Board of Supervisors was reclaimed after two years of Democratic control. Only one town, Smithtown went Democratic.

President ROOSEVELT will have as his guest in the White House Friday evening the new Canadian Prime Minister, Mr. MACKENZIE KING, and it is suggested that the occasion will serve for an informal discussion of the possibility of a new reciprocal trade agreement between Canada and the United States.
SEATTLE, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Seattle faced a virtual potato famine and rising fruit and vegetable prices tonight as the Northwest noted mounting crop losses in the continuing cold weather.

Dean Ralph C. Epstein of the University of Buffalo School of Business is quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES under the heading, "$5,000 Income Limit Means $100 Rise in Average Wealth," and no more. The dean concludes: "For a plentiful distribution of wealth and income we need first to have enough to distribute."
MONTREAL, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Disappearance of 10-year-old Helene Kernan became an international matter today as the child telephoned from some town across the border to her mother.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Formal registration papers for the new investment banking house of Harris, Hall Co. were filed today in Washington, D.C., it was announced by Julien H. Collins, vice president of the organization.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- Complete returns from the eighty-three election districts of Yonkers showed that the Democrats re-elected their Mayor and retained control of the Board of Estimate, while losing control of the Common Council in today's election.

Despite the handicap of warm weather, election-day trade in local department stores was good, retail executives here reported yesterday. Increases ranging from 5 to 10 per cent over the same day last year were noted, with the coat departments a leading centre of shopping interest and the main floor accessory departments playing a slightly smaller role.

A spanking northerly breeze, whipping the basin of the New York Motor Boat Club off West 147th Street yesterday morning, caused a 34-foot yawl anchored there to curvet and plunge like a show-horse at the end of a firm tether.

HOUSTON, Nov. 5. -- Seventy-eight Episcopal Bishops from all parts of the United States and from many foreign countries were in Houston today to attend their annual convention, opening tomorrow at the Palmer Memorial Chapel and continuing through Friday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- New difficulties arose today in the path of PWA allotments for highway construction. The Bureau of Public Roads informed the PWA that fifteen projects, for which $1,764,585 had been allotted, were on Federal highway systems and therefore at least temporarily held up by action of J. R. McCarl, Controller General.

Mayor La Guardia accepted membership on the United Hospital Fund Campaign Committee and endorsed its efforts in behalf of New York's voluntary, non-profit hospitals, in a letter received yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Discussions which W. L. Mackenzie King, n-w Prime Minister of Canada, will have here with United States officials this week are expected to shape the terms of the reciprocal trade agreement now under negotiation, by clearing up uncertainties on important tariff schedules.

The Democrats, history records, won the New York Assembly once in twenty years. The State is gerrymandered so as to insure that only on the occasion of landslide elections can the Democrats gain a majority in that branch of the Legislature.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 6. -- Judge Jesse E.B. Cunningham, who campaigned for reelection as a critic of the New Deal, apparently defeated his Democratic opponent, Deputy Attorney General Robert L. Myers Jr. yesterday for the Superior Court judgeship, the only State-wide contest involved in yesterday's Pennsylvania election.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 5. -Credit for the fact that this country is still a constitutional democracy was given to its judges by Rainbridge Colby, Secretary of State under President Wilson, in an address tonight at a dinner held by the Sacramento County Bar Association in honor of the California judiciary.

Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State of the State of New York, departing for the maritime conference at Geneva; Captain A. T. Beauregard, United States naval attache at Paris; Jascha Heifetz, violinist, and J. Webb Benton, secretary of the United States Legation at Prague, are among the notables due to sail today for the Channel ports on the Manhattan of the United States Lines.

More adept in the art of completing timely forward passes, Manual Training High's football team topped its traditional foe, Erasmus Hall, to the tune of 27 to 13 before 12,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday in the twenty-eighth edition of their annual election day scholastic classic.

Last week twenty-one persons in New York City were killed in automobile accidents. This was an increase of a third over the corresponding week a year ago. The increase in deaths occurred in spite of sharp decreases in the total number of accidents and of injured.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- Humble British homes provided some of the gifts today for Lady Alice MontagueDouglas-Scott. One of the first gifts to be received was a cushion, worked by a miner's wife, in the traditional hand-quilting design of the period when quilting was used by chain mail-clad British warriors for undergarments.

A seasoned pair of bridge veterans who date back to the whist days, Jules G. Wetzlar, secretary of the Cavendish Club, and L. Roy Slater, Staten Island real estate man, won the metropolitan contract bridge championship of the American Bridge League last night at the Algonquin Club, 65 West Fortyfourth Street.

The Seas Shipping Company, which operates the Robin Line between New York and South African ports, announced yesterday that all available space for unboxed automobiles for South African ports on ships sailing in the next month was completely filled and that the company had sent a telegram to the Department of Commerce asking for allocation of a Shipping Board freighter to take surplus cargo.

WOODMERE, L.I., Nov. 5. -Everett Ruskay tallied three touchdowns and Dave Seidman went across for two as the Woodmere Academy football team turned back the Columbia Grammar School eleven, 39 to 0, today. Tom Vogel was responsible for the other Woodmere six-pointer.

Many of those who voted against the $55,000,000 bond issue for relief yesterday may have done so because they were doubtful as to the continuing need for State expenditure on such a scale for this purpose now that the Federal program is under-way. But that program is directed only at the employables, and it is already evident that it will not be able to absorb anything like all of them.

Governor Lehman said last night that he was not surprised by the Republican capture of the Assembly and he emphasized that the Democratic aggregate vote for Assemblymen exceeded that of the Republicans.

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- A slim little comedy, "Katy Did: So What?" written, directed and starred in by Mary Young, received what was virtually a world premiere at the Copley Theatre tonight before a large audience. It was tried out at the Wharf Theatre in Provincetown under the title of "Mrs. Tarquin," and then rewritten.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- Albert F. McCormack, 31 years old, a former special policeman in a New Jersey theatre, was drowned in the Hudson River early this morning when he drove his sedan off the steamship dock near Hook Mountain into twelve feet of water.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hattersley gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino to celebrate Mr. Hattersley's birthday. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Alfred V. Leaman, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kelley, Mr. and Mrs. John Durant, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Rice, Mrs. Potter Ayer, Henry Fleitmann, Harold Barker Jr. and John Claiborne.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The number of corporations making a net profit increased by almost 33 per cent during 1933, and their aggregate profits were 31 per cent larger than those reported in 1932, the Treasury Department announced today after making an analysis of corporation income tax returns for 1933.

PARIS, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The first defendant cross-examined in the Stavisky pawnshop scandal trial asserted today that the swindler's threat of suicide forced him (the defendant) to join illegal dealings lest "the body be found in my office."

Returns in the New Jersey election indicated early this morning that the Republican party had increased its present majority in the Assembly by gaining nine seats and losing one, while the Democratic minority in the State Senate had gained two seats.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 5 (AP). -A dazzling burst of speed uncorked at the far turn and continuing to the wire brought victory to W. C. Weant's Prince Fox in the six-furlong Millwood Handicap, feature of today's card at Narragansett Park.

With its shifty, fast left halfback, Captain Hal McCullough, going over for all the touchdowns, Boys High School's eleven routed its time-honored foe, Alexander Hamilton High, in the twenty-ninth struggle of their series at Boys High Field in Brooklyn yesterday.
Election day was a holiday for many persons in the city yesterday but not for the members of Lou Little's squad of Columbia gridiron workers up at Baker Field.

The results of the Assembly contest in this State clearly show the trend away from the New Deal. The Assembly was recaptured by the Republican party despite the efforts of the New Deal administration and the Democratic State Chairman to hold the Republican tide through the use of patronage and money.

DES MOINES, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Governor Hoffman of New Jersey fired a broadside at the New Deal today in a message to the National Young Republicans expressing regret that he would not attend their convention here Saturday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 5. -- Harold H. Burton, independent Republican, was elected Mayor of Cleveland today in a decisive victory over former Mayor Ray T. Miller, the Democratic candidate. The vote was interpreted also as a repudiation of the Democratic organization led by W. B. Gongwer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5.A crisisin the United States silverbuyingprogram has been precipitated bythe Chinese monetary decrees promulgated Sunday, it was admittedunofficially here today.

That Professor MCGOLDRICK'S stirring fight in Brooklyn would end in his defeat was pretty clearly indicated before the actual polling. As a candidate for District Attorney of Kings County he made his campaign almost wholly on the charge that the conduct of that office had been marked by great laxity, constant inefficiency and occasional traces of scandal or corruption.

Badly outplayed in the first half, the De Witt Clinton High School eleven rallied in the last two quarters to register a 28-0 victory over Stuyvesant yesterday in a renewal of their time-honored series at the Polo Grounds.
Housing deals featured the Manhattan and Bronx realty trading reported yesterday.

ATHENS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- Five hundred representatives of leading American universities, colleges and learned societies will participate with prominent State officials, alumni, faculty and 2,600 undergraduate students in the inauguration Nov. 15 of Dr. Herman Gerlach James as president of Ohio University.

Up-State New York returned to its Republican allegiance at the election yesterday, enabling the Republicans to recapture the Assembly and bringing about a result which the Republicans said can be interpreted only as a repudiation of the New Deal in the President's home State.

Jane Austen was a wit and Jane Austen is a wit if we can believe our ears at "Pride and Prejudice," which was put on at the Music Box last evening. Perhaps she was not quite the irrepressible wit Helen Jerome has represented her as being in this stage version of a wise, crisp novel, for skillfully written novels often look machine-hemmed on the stage.

The Autumn meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association yesterday at Belmont Park, the final event of the season in New York, drew a large crowd of society members from the North Shore and many who have closed country homes and are in the city.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 5 (AP). -- A drastic shake-up of the State administration's plans fo fill the Senate seat of the late Huey P. Long was announced tonight after prolonged conference of administration leaders.
The New York Civic Orchestra, under Modeste Alloo, will give a concert this afternoon at the American Museum of Natural History.

Mayor Frank Hague's Democratic organization had the greatest victory in the political history of Hudson County, N.J., yesterday, with its leading candidate, Surrogate John H. Gavin, running for re-election, receiving more than 167,145 votes on incomplete returns.

Resumption of large-scale road building in many countries should bring about greatly increased sales of American cars abroad, B. C. Budd, vice president of the Packard Motors Export Corporation and member of the export committee of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, asserted yesterday.

James J. Dooling and Kenneth Simpson, county chairmen respectively of the Democratic and Republican parties, by arising at the crack of dawn managed to cast ballot No. 1 yesterday in their respective polling places. The Tammany leader hazarded no prediction on the outcome of the balloting, but Mr. Simpson said it was "a strictly Republican day."

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Late tonight the Republican party was leading in Essex County by nearly three to one in one of the most intensive political battles in recent years. The Democrats made strenuous last-minute efforts to defeat the Clean Government Republican candidates for the State Assembly and Senate.

pARIS, Nov. 5.--A sudden satisfactory recovery in prices tookplace today on the Bourse, whereit appears to be realized ri.ow thatall fears of the last two weeks hadbeen somevehat premature if notexaggerated.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5. -- Theheated governorship contest today' between A. /. Chandler, Demo-Democrat, and King Swope, le-publican, and many local contestsended with two men killed and twoothers wounded in shooting andcutting affrays.
Several sales and leases of properties in suburban districts were reported by brokers yesterday. Sites were purchased at Scarsdale and at Candlewood Lake for the erection of new homes.

The attention of the board of directors of the New York State Nurses Association has been called to an article which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 18. Reference was made to the discussion of a tentative bill to amend the present Nurse Practice Act. Because some misapprehension was apparent over the proposed measure, it was voted to discuss the bill further in each of the fourteen district associations of the State.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith wore a pearl gray fedora hat instead of a brown derby yesterday when he voted at noon in a stationery store at 743 Madison Avenue, because, he explained it was an "off year" politically. While declaring it was an off year for him, too, he declined to express his own opinion of the New Deal.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5. -- The Lucullite colt, Only One, returned to the scene of his Spring victory in the Dixie Handicap to stop the rush of George D. Widener's heavily weighted Sation in a nose finish at Pimlico today with the main purse in the Baltimore Handicap as the prize.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- Ralph Kercheval's talented toe lifted the Brooklyn Dodgers into a first-place tie with the Giants in the Eastern division of the National Football League when he kicked a field goal that beat the Philadelphia Eagles at the Phillies ball park tonight, 3 to 0.

A vote that was characterized as "gratifying" by leaders of the party was cast in yesterday's election for candidates of the Socialist party. For pride in actual triumphs, however, the local Socialists found it necessary to speak of results outside of the city and outside of the State elections.

BACON'S tobacco shop, almost as famous as all but the most famous colleges of the University of Cambridge, is open again. The only breach in the continuity of its life of 130 years came in the last twelvemonth as the result of collegiate rebuilding plans. DARWIN as an undergraduate roomed over BACON'S.

P. A. S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania from a month's business trip to London, in connection with $12,500,000 owed to his company for the sale of the White Star fleet.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 5. -President Roosevelt will visit Chicago on Dec. 9 to address the annual convention of the American Farm Bureau Federation, he announced today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 5. -- Disapproval of Federal competition with private utility companies was voted by the Southeastern divisional meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States at the closing session here today and the Knoxville delegation in a body walked out in protest.

As the first step in his effort to "deflate" the WPA here, Administrator Victor F. Ridder announced yesterday that relief workers leaving the WPA rolls to accept private jobs would receive certificates entitling them to preferential re-employment in the event that their new jobs proved impermanent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- Elected Mayor in yesterday's Republican sweep after the bitterest campaign in the city's recent history, Controller S. Davis Wilson announced today that he would "press for a thorough investigation" of the grand jury which accused him last week of using for "political purposes" part of a fund voted to him for a rapid-transit revaluation survey.

Ernie Caddel of the Detroit Lions not only continued his leadership as the leading ground gainer of the National Football League during the past week, but also advanced to a tie with Don Hutson of Green Bay for high-scoring honors with 36 points each.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6. -Harvard's varsity football squad was given another stiff defensive drill against the Princeton attack today, at the conclusion of which Coach Dick Harlow named the squad that will make the trip to Princeton.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 6. -Army's plebes defeated the Rutgers freshmen, 24 to 7, today in a game that was featured by a 104-yard touchdown run by Mullen, right end of the Rutgers eleven.

A warning to exporters that, if President Roosevelt "cracks down" further by prohibiting all trade with belligerents, even irrevocable letters of credit opened here by Italians cannot be paid, was sounded by banking representatives who attended a discussion of export credit problems conducted at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men.

Evidence of the public's cooperation in the new program, suggested by President Roosevelt, to advance the automobile merchandising season became apparent yesterday at the Grand Central Palace, where the National Automobile Show is being held.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The belief that Premier King intends using his visit to Washington for a supreme effort to gain additional trade for the Dominion through a reciprocal trade agreement was heightened here today as State Department officials studied his record, particularly his recent election campaign.

A "static-less" radio system invented by Major Edwin H. Armstrong, Professor of Electrical Engineering at Columbia University, was demonstrated last night for the first time before the Institute of Radio Engineers. Major Armstrong contends that his system, if applied to broadcasting, especially on shortwave bands, would usher in a new era in reception and make it possible to send and receive as many as four programs simultaneously on one wave.

AT THE FRONT WITH THE ITALIAN NORTHERN ARMIES, Nov. 6. -- Natives of this occupied territory told The Associated Press correspondent tonight that vast armies of Ethiopians -- "so many they can't be ceunted" -- were massing for pitched battle at Alaji [forty miles south of Makale].

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Names of public utility executives and directors who contributed $468,900 to Republican campaign funds and $120,100 to Democratic funds in 1924, 1928 and 1932 were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission in connection with its investigation of gas companies.

PIMLICO, Md., Nov. 6. -- The first disqualification of the Pimlico meeting occurred today at the expense of Alfred Gwynna Vanderbilt and those smitten form players who made Scotch Bun one of the best-played favorites of the session. The gelded son of Colin came home first by two lengths, only to be set back.

ROME, Nov. 6. -- Newspapers are full of reports that scouting parties from the army in Ethiopia have advanced beyond Makale, but the attention of most thoughtful Italians is again turned toward the Mediterranean, which has occupied the centre of the political stage since the meeting yesterday between Sir Eric Drummond, British Ambassador to Italy, and Premier Mussolini.

Plaintiffs bought in seventeen Manhattan properties at auction sales yesterday. Ten of the holdings were acquired by bidders representing savings banks. Most of the auctioned realty consisted of tenement houses.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Thursday, Nov. 7. -- Urging Americans to search their consciences and associate themselves with economic sanctions against Italy, Emperor Haile Selassie in a radio address to the United States tonight launched a personal campaign to line up nonmember States in support of the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The State Department is now in direct, independent communication with Addis Ababa through the shortwave navy wireless station which was taken to the Ethiopian capital by four expert radio enlisted men of the navy when hostilities were imminent.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6. -- The eighteenth anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution will be celebrated throughout the Soviet Union tomorrow. This holiday, which is not only the Russian Fourth of July but can also be compared to Christmas -- for gifts of rooms, automobiles, money, food and clothing are given to outstanding workers -- was officially launched tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Secretary Hull in a radio address tonight said it was not enough to embargo arms and adopt other negative measures to keep the United States out of war but that this country should take more positive steps to cooperate with other governments for peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Whether China will revalue silver at $1.29 an ounce or will permanently abandon a silver standard was a question much in the minds of United States officials as they awaited today formal notice of the new Chinese monetary decrees.

Awed but not inarticulate, a little Camp Fire Girl in white middy blouse, navy skirt and scarlet tie sat and answered questions from the wife of the President on her ideas about vocational guidance.
