Both had just arrived at Camp Fire Girls headquarters at 41 Union Square -- Mrs. Roosevelt, the interviewer, from Hyde Park, and Geraldine Hartman, the interviewed, from Reading, Pa. Geraldine is 15.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The recent improvement in Anglo-Italian relations was carried slightly further by yesterday's talk in Rome between Sir Eric Drummond and Premier Mussolini.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 30 Charles Warren expresses the view that under the Neutrality Law provision directing the President to enumerate the arms, ammunition and implements of war which may not be shipped to belligerents, the President does not have power to extend his present list to include food, cotton, chemicals, metals and oils.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Coming visit of Premier Mackenzie King to Washington is being watched with some anxiety by the British Government, especially since it is understood that one of the chief subjects of discussion is to be the problem of Canada's huge wheat reserves.

The secret grand jury minutes of the Druckman murder case were turned over to Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday by District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn, who had been directed in a court order to deliver them the day after election.

William W. Bodine, president of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company, said in a letter to stockholders yesterday that the company had retained counsel to take any necessary action to protect the company's interests in any reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company and the Connecticut Company.
New York admirers of Will Rogers were asked yesterday to send in suggestions for a suitable memorial along with their contributions to the Will Rogers Memorial Fund.

Two members of the American delegation to the maritime conference to be held late this month in Geneva sailed yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan. The third member, Samuel Aitken, vice president of Moore McCormack, Inc., steamship operators, received his appointment yesterday and will sail next Wednesday on the President Harding to represent the steamship owners on the delegation.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 6. -Racing in the colors of Mrs. L. H. Nimkoff for the first time, the 5-year-old gelding Beefsteak raced to a new track record for a mile and seventy yards today in winning the sixth race at Narragansett Park.

A drop in temperature, interrupted only by a slight upward swing in the afternoon, brought an end yesterday to the warm weather, abnormal for this period of the year, which prevailed in the city during recent days.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., successfully opened defense of his world's threecushion billiard championship tonight by conquering the foreign threat, Kinrey Matsuyama, Japanese titleholder, 50 to 35, in fifty innings.
Monkeyshines and high jinks set the pace in Central Park yesterday afternoon as the Park Department put on the first performance of its new Playground Traveling Troupe.

By winning their respective matches yesterday the New York A.C., Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club and the City A.C. moved into a three-way tie for first place in the Class A, Metropolitan Squash Tennis League, each with two triumphs in as many starts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- State Chairman Farley knows that, whatever was the Democratic popular majority in the contests for the New York Assembly, the recapture of Assembly control by the Republicans is hurtful to Democratic national prospects next year.

ATHENS, Nov. 6. -- King George II has yet to assume the crown in Greece, but the future of the kingdom is tied up with the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, and its effect upon Greece's strategic position in the Eastern Mediterranean is being watched.

The incorporators of the New York 1939 World's Fair Corporation met yesterday at the State Chamber of Commerce and elected a permanent board of directors. The board, which will have charge of the development and conduct of the fair, consists of the following twentyone members:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6, -- The Charge d'Affaires of Poland and Mme. Sokolowska gave a luncheon today at the Embassy for Mrs. William Brown Meloney of New York, who has been honored by the Polish Government with the Order of Polonia Restituta in recognition of her services to science and to Poland, through gifts of radium to Mme. Curie.

About forty articles of fine sewing or carving, all made by persons handicapped by incurable diseases, were displayed in an exhibit called "Forty Days of Occupational Therapy," in the Beth Abraham Home for Incurables at Bronx Park East and Allerton Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday.

Yesterday the Junior League squash racquets team lost the second match of its 1935 schedule. Victorious over all other teams in the metropolitan area for the past three years, the Junior League players gradually have been acquiring an aura of invincibility, but yesterday they were unable to salvage even one point, as the Cosmopolitan Club won four contests in a row and gained the fifth by default.

BAARN, The Netherlands, Nov. 6. -- Another draw, the fifth of the series, was recorded tonight in the fifteenth game of the world chess championship match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam. Consequently, the tie, with the score at 7 1/2 to 7 1/2, remains unbroken.

With the members of his family as the only mourners, the body of Charles (Chink) Sherman, latest victim of the gang war, was buried yesterday in Washington Cemetery in Brooklyn. The body was in a simple pine box and the ceremony was brief and devoid of the usual gangster color.

Emperor HAILE SELASSIE was guilty of a grave tactical error when he permitted his American financial adviser to cut the price of beef in Addis Ababa to 3 cents a pound and eggs to 2 cents a dozen. It may please the inhabitants of the capital, but it will have the opposite effect on popular Ethiopian sentiment in the outlying provinces along the line of Italian advance.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 6. -- Ten persons were injured today when a derailed observation car on the Empire State express sidewiped a locomotive here this afternoon. The car narrowly escaped plunging thirty feet to Central Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The public hearing called for next Tuesday, at which Michael J. Meehan of New York was ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission to show cause why he should not be suspended from the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges because of trading activities in stock of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation, was postponed late today until Dec. 11 at the request of Edward J. Flynn, counsel for Mr. Meehan.

Selma Kramer, who made her debut at the Town Hall last night, is a genuinely gifted young pianist. She possesses not only the virtuoso instinct but the intelligence and feeling of a musician. In a season which has had thus far a preponderance of pianists, Miss Kramer is one of the ablest of the newcomers.

Dr. Heinrich Bruening, Chancellor of Germany from April, 1980, to June, 1932, has just returned to Europe after a visit here of several weeks, it was learned yesterday. His presence and his movements were carefully guarded by his friends and not even the date or boat on which he sailed was made known.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- An inquiry into rises in bread prices in nine cities was begun today by Donald E. Montgomery, consumers' counsel of the AAA.

Plans for a more equitable method of dealing with traffic violators, with small fixed fines for first of fenders and stricter handling of "repeaters," were discussed yesterday by Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., chief city magistrate. He spoke before 250 persons at a luncheon of the traffic committee of the Association of Grand Jurors of New York County in the Hotel Ambassador.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
Expression of newspapers throughout the country on Tuesday's elections obtained by THE NEW YORK TIMES are as follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Among the grade-crossing projects in New York State which will be helped by the President's approval of the State's Public Works Department program are the following:

ALBANY, Nov. 6. -- The Republicans will press for three proposals in the 1936 Assembly: relief for agriculture; a balanced budget with a fair tax, and a permanent relief plan, said Irving M. Ives, Assembly leader, today, as he sat in his office and received hundreds of telegrams and telephone calls from over the State.
A one-man show of paintings by the American artist, Abraham Rattner, has opened at the Julien Levy Gallery, 602 Madison Avenue. It will be current until Nov. 19.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, declared yesterday that, had President Roosevelt been running for re-election in Tuesday's election, he would have carried New York State by a large plurality.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack, acting yesterday at the request of counsel for creditors who seek reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and of attorneys for that $600,000,000 utility group, granted an adjournment of further hearings before him until Dec. 4 at 2 P.M.

In his answer to your editorial "Italy on War Rations" Arturo Sergio repeats the old story that the Western world owes a great debt of gratitude to fascism, since "it was Mussolini and fascism that bombed bolshevism from Central Europe back to the land whence it came."

A resolution calling for a tradingup policy in garments was adopted yesterday by the council of apparel trade executives at a meeting at the offices of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association. The resolution urged emphasis upon quality merchandise "to meet an expenditure on the part of the public for such garments of from 25 to 35 per cent more for the coming Spring season than for Spring, 1934."

James Hilton, English author of "The Lost Horizon," "Good-bye Mr. Chips" and other novels, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain on his first trip to America. Mrs. Hilton accompanied him. They will be the guests in New York of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont.

The automobile industry is committed to a policy of endeavoring to spread employment and smooth out the production curve. William S. Knudsen, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, told a crowded luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York at its clubhouse, 23 Park Avenue, yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Relative strength in Liverpool and Buenos Aires brought in sufficient short covering in North American markets to lift wheat prices moderately. General outside trade was lacking, however, and according to pit observers on the Board of Trade here, the upturn there was largely at the expense of the technical position.

Practically complete unofficial returns from the New Jersey election Tuesday showed a plurality in the State of 27,294 for the Republican Assembly candidates, despite the record Democratic plurality of 170,000 produced in Hudson County by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic State leader.

Evidence of a quickening flight of capital from France to this country was provided yesterday by a fall of the franc in the foreign exchange market and the disclosure that $17,076,000 of gold had been engaged in Paris in the last two days for shipment here.

A Congressional investigation of the rubber industry was called for yesterday in a resolution adopted unanimously at a meeting of independent tire dealers in the Hotel New Yorker, About 150 members attended the meeting of the National Tire Dealers Association, at which alleged injustices of the "big companies" against independent retailers were bitterly discussed.

Litigation in the courts of Colombia over an "imperial crown" made of gold and containing 296 emeralds, in which the Archbishop of Popayan, Colombia, is the plaintiff and Manuel Jose Olano is the defendant, reached the Supreme Court in New York yesterday when Justice Wasservogel named Philip B. Thurston of counsel for the Colombian consulate as commissioner here to try to find Olano and examine him as to what he knows about the crown.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- Whether to try to upset the phenomenal write-in election of Harry Scott, Republican, as Mayor of this city through an appeal to the court was the principal subject of debate today among Democrats of this city.

Mayor John V. Hinchcliffe of Paterson, seeking re-election for a fifth term, was successful over a Republican opponent in one of the closest contests in the city's political history, it developed yesterday with the filing of final returns in communities throughout New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Regulations governing the labeling and advertising of wine will be the subject of a hearing here on Nov. 22, Franklin C. Hoyt, Alcohol Administrator, announced today, Changes in the existing rules are forced by the new Alcohol Control Act.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 6 (AP). -- Warning that a tropical storm, moving through the Gulf of Mexico after scourging Southern Florida, will probably turn inland again tomorrow was given tonight by weather observers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Following is the text of the address on "Our Foreign Policy With Respect to Neutrality," prepared by Secretary of State Hull and, in his absence from the capital, read for him tonight by William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, over the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System:

Mayor La Guardia, in discussing the defeat of Joseph D. McGoldrick, suggested yesterday that the Kings County Republican organization had "knifed" the Republican Fusion candidate for District Attorney.

Superb horsemanship, exhilarating competition and stirring spectacles received unstinted applause last night from one of the most appreciative gatherings that has ever crowded Madison Square Garden for the first evening session of the National Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Preparations for assuming a closer supervision of the over-the-counter markets were made today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with the appointment of Sherlock Davis as assistant director of the trading and exchange division to administer the activities of the commission in the regulation of these markets and of investment banking.
Investment buying of apartment houses continued yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx, with the latter borough an active centre. Some of the buildings will be altered by the new owners.

Cooler weather yesterday imparted additional life to retail trade, with the heavier apparel sections continuing the improvement which started on election day. Retail executives here are looking forward to exceptionally heavy shopping at the week-end, particularly if lower temperatures are experienced.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- A complete dearth of new arguments and a rising tide of recriminations by all parties now characterize the British political campaign, which will and in the general election a week from tomorrow. But even the bitterness is not sufficient to draw big crowds to the hundreds of meetings being held throughout the British Isles.

Charley Zielinski, the biggest man on the Columbia football squad, probably will start at tackle against Syracuse on Saturday in place of Tony Mareski. Zielinski went through a long session yesterday and excelled at stopping the Orange plays as put on by the rugged freshman team.

PARIS, Nov. 6 (AP). -- The names of two leading figures in the current war crisis, Premier Pierre Laval of France and Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, were mentioned today in the trial of twenty defendants accused of aiding the late Alexandre Stavisky to swindle the French public out of many millions.

Net income of the American Cyanamid Company and subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year was reported yesterday as $2,533,969 after depreciation, depletion, research and process development expenses, interest, Federal taxes, minority interest and other charges.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -Pointing ahead to the Harvard and Princeton games, Coach Ducky Pond today sent the Yale varsity through its third scrimmage in a row. He said that Yale's hope in achieving victory in the climax contests of the season hinges in surmounting the blocking and tackling problems which stood out acutely against Dartmouth last Saturday.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- British bankers have flatly rejected an appeal by Austria for at least a year's extension of the 80,000 Creditanstalt agreement, which is due to expire soon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -Howard S. Palmer, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, was named by Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks as a reorganization trustee of that company at today's hearing. The appointment of James Lee Loomis, president of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford, was taken under consideration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Approval of an application of the New York Triborough Bridge Authority for the construction of a bridge across Little Hell Gate, just west of the New York Connecting Railroad Bridge between Ward's Island and Randall's Island, was given today by the War Department.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP). -- To keep the complement space with its growing fleet, Secretary Swanson disclosed today that the navy wants more men.

GENEVA, Nov. 6. -- The League of Nations learned today that the German Government plans to reduce considerably the great German leak in economic sanctions against Italy. How much is not clear, but at worst this unexpected help, with all its political implications, is deemed of high importance here.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Andre Laboulaye, French Ambassador, and Mrs. Laboulaye, were among the 1,600 guests yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art at the opening of the loan exhibition of French eighteenth century art.

An expression of friendship toward the United States is contained in a cablegram sent by the Prince of Wales, as president of the English-Speaking Union of the British Empire, to John W. Davis, president of the American branch of the union.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 6. -- Confronting the task of raising funds to overcome possible deficits in the missionary budget, the House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church opened its annual meeting today. Seventy Bishops from all parts of the United States and several foreign countries were present.

Pig iron production in October, according to The Iron Age was 1,978,411 tons, or 63,820 tons a day, compared with 1,776,476 tons, or 59,216 tons daily in September. The gain, in terms of daily rate, was 7.8 per cent. Furnaces in blast Nov. 1 numbered 116 as against 104 on Oct. 1.

After a brief hearing yesterday, Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy for the United States District Court, reserved decision on an application by the Irving Trust Company, trustee for the International Match Corporation, to pay a dividend of 5 per cent, or about $5,000,000, to holders of debentures in the bankrupt estate.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 6. -- It is evident that the twenty foreign banks operating in China under extraterritoriality are reluctant to hand over their silver coins and bullion to the government-owned banks, and unless all agree to do so, none will.

TRENTON, Nov. 6. -- Accused of causing death with an automobile, theft of an automobile, driving without a license and being a hitand-run driver, Joseph Di Natale, 12 years old, of 775 Hunt Avenue, Hamilton Township, was awaiting arraignment today before Judge James S. Turp of the Mercer County Juvenile Court.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- Early tomorrow morning the entire personnel of the new German Army and Navy will assemble at barracks and other posts when the first German conscripts since the World War will take an oath of personal loyalty to Fuehrer Adolf Hitler and salute the new German war flag, designed by Hitler, which will be displayed for the first time.

Queen Mab, one of the best-known racing schooner yachts along the coast, may be the next flagship of the New York Yacht Club. She was sold, it was learned yesterday, by Horace Binney to W. A. W. Stewart, vice commodore of the New York Club, who is in official line to succeed Commodore Junius S. Morgan next month.
Continuance of an active and broad stock market was without corresponding effect upon the money market, where the demand for funds was small. Quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

The nominating committee of the Stock Exchange held yesterday the first of a series of three meetings at which it will receive suggestions from members regarding the personnel of the committee for 1936. The old committee is to put up twenty-one nominees from whom the membership will elect seven on the second Monday in January.

LOUISVILLE., Ky., Thursday, Nov. 7. -- Lieut. Gov. A. B. Chandler, a Roosevelt Democrat, early today apparently had won a smashing victory over his Republican opponent, Judge King Swope, in their race for Governor of Kentucky.

Holders of common and preferred stocks of L. C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc., will vote on Nov. 15 on a plan of recapitalization proposed by the directors to eliminate $654,500 of accumulated dividends on the $100 par 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock and pave the way for resumption of dividends on the common shares.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The first complete performance of William Walton's first symphony by the British Broadcasting Corporation Orchestra under the baton of Sir Hamilton Harty at Queens Hall tonight brought a chorus of praise for the most ambitious work thus far of Britain's rising composer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- To hasten completion of the Inter-American Highway which is already in use from the Rio Grande to Mexico City, President Roosevelt approved today a gift of funds for the construction of three bridges in Panama, Honduras and Guatemala.

The city of Detroit, Mich., announced yesterday that bids would be received on Nov. 15 for an issue of $4,643,000 of non-callable refunding bonds, Series D, to be dated Dec. 1, 1935, and to mature from Dec. 1, 1936, to 1961. Bidders are requested to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 3/4 per cent.

THE Rose Bowl nominating or invitation committee is in Something of a dither, not knowing whom to invite for the big garden party at Pasadena and fearing that logical contenders may be knocked flat this coming Saturday or the stand-up teams may be the kind that are not allowed to accept transcontinental travel as part of the curriculum.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 6. -- Bob Antrim and Charley Reimann, stalwart Middies from Indiana and recruited from the plebe squad of last season, may be the answer to the Navy's cry for a better passing game. Both are booked to see action against Pennsylvania.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- As President Roosevelt studied the returns in yesterday's elections today he revealed to intimate friends a deep satisfaction based on his belief that the count showed a continuance of a trend which he dates as having begun in 1930.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- A comprehensive investigation of investment trusts and investment companies, authorized by Section 30 of the Public Utility Act of 1935, will be undertaken immediately under the general supervision of Commissioner Robert E. Healy, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

TOKYO, Nov. 6. -- Assurances that Britain desires to cooperate with Japan in measures for helping China and that London has not acted individually were given today to Mamoru Shigemitsu, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, by Sir Robert Henry Clive, the British Ambassador.

Leo Spitz of Chicago, a lawyer, will become president of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation, succeeding Merlin B. Aylesworth, who is to become chairman of the board. Selection of Mr. Spitz to head the motion-picture company was announced by Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, which, with the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers, purchased control of R.-K.-O. last month from the Radio Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Agreement on the manner in which New York State will take over the care of its own unemployables and how Federal "dole" payments to the State will be ended was reached today by Governor Lehman and Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, at a two-hour conference.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued firm today as business increased, particularly among the industrials, wherein a shortage of shares resulted in some sharp gains. British funds rallied after a dull opening. European securities were firm in the foreign section.

Joe Kiernan, one of the main cogs in the wheels of Dartmouth's undefeated football machine, is a glittering example of the old proverb about perseverance. Back in his high school days in Washington, Joe couldn't make the grade as a regular on the Central High School team.

TAPPAN, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- Postmaster General James A. Farley conducted a personal campaign in Rockland County yesterday in an effort to elect his brother Supervisor of Haverstraw, an office he once held, and to defeat Laurens M. Hamilton, Republican Assemblyman.

Temperatures fell below the freezing point over a large area of Oklahoma and Northern Texas on Tuesday, halting maturity of lateplanted cotton, and prices on the Cotton Exchange here advanced about $1 a bale at one time yesterday.

Mr. BERRY, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, seems determined to revive the NRA. He has sent out 5,000 invitations for a meeting in Washington on Dec. 9 of representatives of industry and labor for "round-table discussions "looking to the furtherance of the best "means of accelerating industrial recovery, "eliminating unemployment "and maintaining business and labor "standards."

Miss Agnes M. Craig, Bronx lawyer and former school teacher, and now the first woman to be elected to the Municipal Court bench, is a "fine cook but helpless when it comes to doing anything else around the house." She was the victor in Tuesday's election in the second district in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Republican leaders expressed jubilation today as they studied later returns on Eastern elections, in which the New Deal was more or less of an issue, and viewed the results as showing a loss in Democratic prestige, indicating a trend to sweep the East into the Republican column in 1936.

The county home rule amendment so overwhelmingly approved on Tuesday makes one explicit and immediate change in county government within the confines of this city. Hereafter the County Clerk in each county, instead of being elected by popular vote as in the past, is to be appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 6. -A suit to test the constitutionality of a new State law which makes it illegal for a retailer to sell goods at prices less than those which may be set in any contract which may exist between a manufacturer and a retailer was challenged today in a test case laid before the Supreme Court here.

The first night performance of the National Horse Show presented a scene of brilliant pageantry in Madison Square Garden last night. The action and color of the spectacular events in the ring were augmented by a notable assembly of society and distinguished guests in the boxes.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler has promised Count Henri Baillet-Latour, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, that during the Olympic games next year anti-Semitic placards will be taken down in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, the scene of the Winter Olympics, and Berlin, the scene of the Summer Olympics.

The need for a third party was debated in the weekly radio broadcast of the National Student Federation yesterday over station WABC. Alfred M. Bingham, secretary of the Commonwealth Federation and son of former United States Senator Hiram Bingham of Connecticut, said he favored the formation of one.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- Gene Gisburne of East Orange, Pennsylvania's veteran left tackle, will not be able to play against the Navy in the annual game here this weekend. This was learned today when the team physician announced his leg injury had failed to respond to treatment.

DETROIT, Nov. 6. -- John Erskine, the New York author and lecturer, was severely injured and narrowly escaped death today when the automobile in which he was riding with Mr. and Mrs. Edgar H. Clark was hit by a truck. Mr. Clark was seriously injured.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- An extension for five years of $7,778,000 of loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation due on Dec. 7 was requested today by the Illinois Central Railroad in an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission.
OTTAWA, Nov. 6. -- A Liberal Prime Minister left Ottawa for Washington today on a tariff mission approved by organs of Conservative as well as Liberal opinion.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- The Rev. William A. (Billy) Sunday, one of the most noted evangelists of the old "sawdust trail," died suddenly tonight of a heart attack in the home of his brother-in-law, William J. Thompson, a florist. He had been in poor health since February, 1933, but had remained moderately active until last night when he went to bed complaining of "queer pains."

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today tentatively approved the plans submitted by security holders and creditors for reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company, which was the centre of the former Insull utility system.

ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Zuni, from the B. Hernandez Stable, carrying 113 pounds with L. Turner up, raced to an easy victory today in the $2,000 added West Texas Handicap on a slippery track.

READING, Pa., Nov. 6. -- Polling nearly 21,000 votes, almost exactly as many as his older parties' rival candidates combined, J. Henry Stump, Socialist former Mayor, was declared elected Mayor today for a four-year term. With him will go into office Socialists named to every important City Hall and School Board seat on the November ballot, Republicans and Democrats failing to capture a single seat.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Determined to keep the Harvard offense in check Saturday, Coach Fritz Crisler sent his Tiger squad through a thorough defensive drill against Crimson formations as portrayed by a scrub eleven in practice on University Field today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

With non-fiction book sales having led all lists during most of theFall season, Cosmopolitan Magazinenow a,mounces that it will publishcondensed versions of outstandingnon-fiction books in future singleissues. Condensed versions of novels have for some time been published in single issues of magazinesand book retailers have complainedthat this practice is damaging totheir interests.

Debate is still raging about the proper understanding and application of Article XVI of the Covenant of the League. Spokesmen for Italy have violently protested at Geneva that the League, in its decisions against the Italian Government, has departed from the real intent of Article XVI and has exceeded its own powers.

Motorbus service will begin on Eighth and Ninth Avenues shortly before noon next Tuesday, replacing the existing surface car transportation, Hugh J. Sheeran, president of the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation, announced yesterday.

Sixteen teams which survived this morning the first two qualifying sessions of the eighth annual tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup, the oldest of the contract bridge team-of-four events, will resume play tonight at the Hotel Park Lane.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 (AP). -Pennsylvania's "Blue Law" forbidding Sunday movies went to the scrap heap in ninety-five communities and received a pledge of support from 101 other cities and towns in a referendum which drew more than 5,000,000 citizens to the polls yesterday.
"Peter Ibbetson," a Paramount film adaptation of the novel by George duMaurier, will open today at the Radio City Music Hall. Gary Cooper and Ann Harding are featured.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Following are comments on the election results:

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 6. -- Italian native troops reconnoitring under Gerasmatch Zagaye, an Eritrean commander, entered Makale last evening. They were lured on by the Ethiopian garrison, which had evacuated the town in accordance with its daily practice but had not returned at sundown, as usual.

Replying to a newspaper correspondent's question, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator HOPKINS burst into an unexpected attack upon the State of Kansas and its Governor. He was wrong as to the facts. Even if he had been right, the decencies of his post should have kept him from an incursion into partisan politics.

Walter Willis and William Schaaf, co-managers of the fishing information Bureau of the Long Island Railroad, reported yesterday that the codfish have started to bite again at Montauk, following the three-day northeaster.

ROME, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Although the main body of General Emilio de Bono's army in Northern Ethiopia has been held up by the rains, advance patrols continued penetration movements today, according to an official communique, which quoted the following message from General de Bono;

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, and other leaders of the party became increasingly certain yesterday that the outcome of Tuesday's election, which resulted in a Republican Assembly, cleared the way for carrying the State next year.

A decision by the Interstate Commerce Commission ordering a decrease in passenger fares in the East would result in an increase in net income for the railroads, Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, predicted yesterday. He said railway traffic generally had improved lately.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Continued strength in fresh pork, with loins advancing 1 cent a pound to 16 1/2 to 22 cents, wholesale, and 3 to 3 1/2 cents above the close of last week, brought an aggressive demand for choice hogs here today from smaller packers who operate largely on pork and lifted prices as much as 10 cents a hundredweight in the early trading.

WARSAW, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Poland did not celebrate the seventy-fifth birthday today of one of her most distinguished sons, Ignace Jan Paderewski, because such a proposal was "extremely unpleasant" to the pianist-statesman.
The New York Stock Exchange admitted to the list yesterday Republic Steel Corporation first mortgage convertible 5 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1954.

Head Coach Mal Stevens sent the New York University varsity football squad through a brisk two-hour session at Ohio Field yesterday in preparation for the City College game at the Yankee Stadium. Expecting to use his full squad on Saturday, the Violet mentor tried various varsity combinations.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Count Henri Baillet-Latour, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, entered the pre-Olympic lists today to combat an American movement aimed at transfer of the 1936 games to some country other than Germany.

Dean Ackerman in attacking the present semester-hour basis of college education states that "the point system * * * resulting in a degree after four years of work, does not occupy the student's time and does not engage or retain his interest."

Greater cooperation by manufacturers of homewares in developing and standardizing new merchandise was urged by Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale Bros., Inc., at a meeting of the Housewares Club of New York held at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $3,083,660 after all deductions, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.08 a share on 1,741,008 common shares, compared with $3,057,038, or $1.06 a share, on 1,748,473 common shares, the year before.
The individual receipts of city taxicabs are higher this year than last, but fewer cabs are on the street, officials of large operating companies said yesterday.

Constructive operations characterized bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Led by industrial loans, which were bid up sharply on an increased turnover, the improvement spread over a broad list of domestic corporation bonds.

"Drama of the 'lint heads'" is the program description of "Let Freedom Ring," which was put on at the Broadhurst last evening. "American folk drama" would be quite as accurate a rubric and more intelligible to the untutored theatregoer.

The fact that the Federal appropriation of $5,500,000 for the erection of the new Brooklyn College buildings is threatened because the injunction suit by the Community Councils of New York still stands of record was made known in the Supreme Court yesterday when the Corporation Counsel's office, through Philip W. Haberman Jr., an assistant, asked Justice Callahan to throw the suit out of court.

With an optimistic eye fixed on the turnstiles in anticipation of another prosperous season, the National Professional Hockey League will open its nineteenth campaign tonight in Chicago, where the Loop's Black Hawks engage the New York Americans in the premiere.
BERLIN, Nov. 6.--Trading on the Boerse today was very quiet and prices were slightly firmer. Heavy industrials lacked activity, but Klockner gained 1/4 point. Potash issues were passive.

Seeking to avert a threatened lookout in the millinery industry, Mayor La Guardia sent invitations yesterday to employers and employes asking them to send committees to City Hall at 12:30 today in an attempt to reach an agreement which would end the dispute.
"The Stranger," Jacob Gordin's Yiddish version of the Enoch Arden theme, was revived last night at the downtown National Theatre with Joseph Shoengold in the leading role.

News of Republican gains in Tuesday's State and municipal elections was followed by a sharp rise in the stock market yesterday. Gains in leading issues ranged from 1 to 5 points. The turnover on the Stock Exchange totaled 3,075,000 shares, the largest volume for any session since July 26, 1934.

Most commodity futures were lower in rather quiet trading on the local markets yesterday. On the cash markets, cotton, rubber, tin and butter advanced and new high prices were set by iron No. 2 Philadelphia foundry, quicksilver and wool tops.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- The Nazi government has broken its armistice with the Protestant church. Both independent theological seminaries established by the Confessional Synods have been seized by the secret political police, the professors and students have been expelled and the buildings have been locked and sealed.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 6. -- The State Court of Criminal Appeals in a decision today upheld the freedom of the press and specifically declared that newspapers had a right to report a public trial. The case was in the nature of habeas corpus proceedings involving six Houston newspaper men.

Mayor La Guardia, former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, joined yesterday in urging public support for the $2,000,000 drive of the United Hospital Campaign Committee, which opens Nov. 18.
LUCRETIUS in his "De Rerum Natura" wrote of an ancient "sire of science" that which might in our own day be written of HENRY FAIRFIELD OSBORN, the "doctrines of whose godlike mind"

Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Richardson gave a dinner last night at their home, 156 East Seventy-ninth Street, and later took their guests to the Persian Room of the Plaza for supper and dancing. In their party were Mr. and Mrs. J. Gould Remick, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic A. Cammann, Mr. and Mrs. George E. Werlemann and Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6. -- A plea that common sense be substituted for experiment in dealing with the country's economic problems was made by Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas in an address here tonight before the Ohio Chamber of Commerce.

In a brief talk before several hundred members of the League for Political Education at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, yesterday morning, Mayor La Guardia vigorously attacked political machines of whatever party, praised nonpartisan government and declared that as long as he was Mayor he would never build up a personal machine in his own interest.

In London it was "The Old Ladies," but in its American premiere this evening at the Booth it is "Night in the House." By any title whatever it is Rodney Ackland's dramatization of the Hugh Walpole novel, and Helen Arthur presents it with a cast of four -Nance O'Neil, Josephine Hull, Mildred Natwick and Ellen Hall (plus some off-stage voices).

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- Not only the present tension in the Mediterranean but the whole question of the future of that area appears to have entered into the Anglo-French talks which have opened here as a result of Geneva's commissioning of France and Great Britain to seek a solution of the Ethiopian conflict.

With Democratic leaders convinced yesterday that their party was on its way back to power in New York City, Mayor La Guardia stanchly insisted that the defeat of thirteen Fusion Aldermen was no rebuke to his administration.

In your issue of Nov. 4 the excerpts from sermons include the one preached at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by Dean Glasier of Portland, Me. You correctly report the dean as declaring that there are periods of history when all the church can do is to hold on to its own righteousness and let the world go its way.

Although production of steel ingots declined 1 point this week to 52 1/2 per cent of capacity, the recession cannot be considered significant in view of the accumulating evidences of expanding demand, according to yesterday's weekly summary of The Iron Age.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -Allotment of $300,000 for buying 30,000 acres of "poor" land in the Finger Lakes region of New York State was announced today by the Resettlement Administration in starting its land adjustment program for New York State.

Two seeded teams which survived the qualifying rounds in the eighth annual contest for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup for contract bridge teams of four went down to defeat last night when play was resumed at the Hotel Park Lane. They were eliminated from the competition, as were six other teams, thus leaving eight teams in the field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Striking back at critics, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA administrator, declared today that Federal administration of relief was too serious an under taking to be identified with politics. He expressed surprise that his recent remarks on Governor Landon's handling of the Kansas relief situation had been interpreted as having "political significance."

HENRY FAIRFIELD OSBORN, the most eminent of American students of evolution, shared the obituary pages yesterday with the Rev. WILLIAM A. SUNDAY. The coincidence of their death on the same day comes as a reminder that it is unsafe to generalize concerning these times, these United States or this imperial city of ours.

Trading in commodity futures here was quiet yesterday with prices generally steady. Cotton, rubber and wool tops were higher in the cash markets, with quick-silver at a new high price. All the grains, tin and silk were lower, with corn and lard at the lowest price of the year.

Elaborate costumes, with a dazzling display of jewels and the soft colors of orchids, marked last night's session of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. The boxes and arena seats were filled with brilliantly attired women.

Operations of the American Rolling Mill Company in the first nine months of this year resulted in a net income of $3,011,140 after Federal taxes, depreciation, interest and other charges, it was announced yesterday. The income was equivalent, after dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, to $1.71 a share on 1,710,776 shares of $25-par common stock.

Gold to the value of $4,222,000 was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment to this country, bringing to $495,?00,000 the total of engagements since Sept. 9, when the movement began. Of yesterday's engagements, $2,475,000 was taken in France, $891,000 in England and $856,000 in India.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Rare orchids and choice fruits shared honors with chrysanthemums and other flowers at the annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York which opened last night at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.
Tempted by Spring-like rains and continuing warm Fall weather, an apple tree bloomed yesterday on a penthouse terrace between the skyscrapers of midtown Manhattan and the downtown financial area.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- While official comment on United States foreign policy was carefully avoided, there was intense interest here today in Secretary Hull's radio speech of yesterday, in which he said the United States should use its influence to prevent and shorten wars and warned that transactions between Americans and belligerents might cause difficulties.

Gilbert Colgate, former president and chairman of the board of Colgate Co., who died Jan. 5, 1933, left an estate appraised yesterday at $3,916,666 gross and $2,980,871 net, of which $3,100,317 was in securities. Mr. Colgate had debts of $816,745, which included $56,968 as the Federal income tax for 1932.

CAIRO, Egypt. Nov. 7. -- An official communique issued here states that Great Britain has given Egypt assurances that the British Government has never thought of profiting from the presence of its fleet in near-by waters to modify the status of Egypt as a virtual protectorate and particularly has never entertained the idea of establishing a naval base at Alexandria.

HOUSTON, Texas. Nov. 7. -- The three-day annual convention of the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church came to a close here this afternoon with the election of two new Bishops and the adoption of a resolution strongly condemning the Italo-Ethiopian War.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 7. -- The Nassau and Suffolk Building Trades Council issued a strike order this morning on all WPA projects in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The action, it was said, was a protest against the prevailing low scale of wages paid to skilled and unskilled workers on Long Island public works projects.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Whole sale prices declined slightly in the week ended on Nov. 2, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 7. -- After losing three games in the last six and drawing the others, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, has good prospects of at last scoring a victory when the sixteenth game of his match with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, adjourned tonight, is played to a finish tomorrow.

The Department of Labor reported yesterday that the cost of living had advanced another notch, and due note of the fact will doubtless be taken by good party strategists. It is apparent that Democratic leaders are increasingly concerned over the higher prices asked by the butcher and the baker, while Republicans sense a golden opportunity to make good use of the slaughter of the little pigs and the wheat fields turned to pasture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- A plan for a complete revamping of the country's broadcasting structure is being studied by the Federal Communication Commission, it was disclosed today in connection with a move designed to eliminate duplication in chain-station programs.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Ruth Nichols, commenting on the resignation of Helen Richey as an airline pilot, said today that in heavy weather the strength of two men is sometimes needed to control a large transport plane.

To begin with an old story, "Jumbo" is postponed again. It will not open tomorrow night at the Hippodrome. One date being probably as good as another, it is now announced for a week from tomorrow night (Nov. 16). For the apologies and soul-disturbances of its producer, Billy Rose, see an advertisement in the vicinity of this column.

ALBANY, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Peter G. Ten Eyck, State Agriculture Commissioner, announced appointment today of fourteen-member milk advisory committee to aid in the regulation of New York State's milk industry until next March.

Discouraged because he was behind his class in school and some of his schoolmates chided him about it, George Meisner, 16-year-old orphan, hanged himself yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Bertha T. Lutz of 103-36 177th Street, Jamaica, where he had been boarded out by the Gould Foundation for Children, Inc., of the Bronx several months ago with his brother, Herman, 18, and sister, Emma, 12.

A consolidated net income of $4,117,525 for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 was reported yesterday by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its subsidiaries after all prior deductions. This was equal to 47 cents a share on 8,738,728 common shares.

Executives of the major public utility holding companies were elated upon learning of the Baltimore decision declaring the Public Utility Act as unconstitutional, asserting that they would have been surprised if any other position had been taken by the Federal court.

The 1,483 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $42,298,955,051 par value on Nov. 1, had a total market value of $38,170,537,291, according to a compilation issued by the Exchange yesterday. On Oct. 1 there were 1,485 issues, aggregating $42,671,487,291 par value, which had a total market value of $38,374,693,665.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Rain and fog failed to interrupt Fritz Crisler's preparations for the Harvard game as he sent his Princeton squad through another long defensive drill on University Field today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 6, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,482,000,000, an increase of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and $25,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

A banking group headed by John Nuveen Co., and including A.C. Allyn Co. and C.W. McNear Co.; Stifel, Nicolaus Co., Inc., and Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., is offering a new issue of $1,325,000 East Side Levee and Sanitary District, St. Clair and Madison Counties, Ill., 4 per cent bonds, maturing from 1939 to 1954, at prices to yield from 2.50 to 3.70 per cent, according to maturity.

Three graduates of Yale University, two of whom were honor students; forty-nine other individuals, including a New York attorney and a woman, and twenty corporations -- all accused of taking part in a $4,500,000 swindle -- were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury in the largest mail-fraud prosecution ever undertaken in any judicial district.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The Laclede Power and Light Company of St. Louis filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $6,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series A, and 30,000 shares of no par value preferred stock, Series A.

Tributes to Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of the Amateur Athletic Union, for his stand against American participation in the Berlin Olympic Games were given last night at a dinner in his honor attended by more than 1,200 persons at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Additional WPA projects for New York State, totaling $16,298,410, were approved today by Controller General McCarl, and as a result Lester W. Herzog, State WPA Administrator, now has funds on hand exceeding the quota set for the WPA program outside New York City.

The Department of Justice announced yesterday the arrest of Edward Schiffert, 26 years old, of 131-18 Newtown Avenue, Astoria, Queens, on a charge of attempting to extort $10,000 from Miss Thelma Todd, screen comedienne.

PARIS, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Fear of the great power of the late Alexandre Stavisky was said today by a defendant in the trial of his twenty alleged accomplices to have been his reason for joining their operations.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- The German Government issued an official communique today denying reports abroad that the German consul in Geneva had made a demarche at the League of Nations of such a character that sections of the foreign press hailed it as virtual participation by Germany in sanctions against Italy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Feminists of the national capital joined Amelia Earhart today in championing Helen Richey, first woman airlines pilot, who would not be just a "fair weather flier" and so quit.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 7. -- Judge Coleman's summary of his opinion in the Public Utility Holding Company case reads as follows:

President Roosevelt visited the city last night for about seven hours to take part in the ceremony raising two of his sons, James and Franklin Jr. to the third degree of the Masonic Order. Several prominent city officials, including Mayor La Guardia also were present.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Laurence Stephenson, chief of the Customs Patrol Inspection at Niagara Falls, has been suspended and charges of misconduct have been filed against him, Secretary Morgenthau said today. Five charges have been made against Stephenson, and he has five days in which to reply before action is taken.

The discovery by Dr. W.R. Valentiner, director of the Detroit Institute of Arts, of a portrait by Raphael and its purchase by the institute were announced yesterday. It was acquired through the E. A. Silberman Galleries, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, and comes from a royal European collection the identity of which was not disclosed.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is prepared to furnish $47,130,000 of the $58,380,000 required for the construction of a vehicular tunnel under the East River between Manhattan and Queens, Jesse Jones, chairman of the government loan agency, said yesterday following a meeting with the tunnel commissioners.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- Amid the thunder of twenty-one saluting guns, the pealing of church bells and the blare of military bands, the new German war flag with the swastika cross designed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler himself was unfurled for the first time at 8 o'clock this morning over all army, navy and air-force buildings and training grounds throughout the land and on all German warships in port or on the high seas.
LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The London-South African air service is expected to be reduced to four days, as Sir Eric Geddes, chairman of Imperial Airways, foreshadowed last week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- A continued good distributing demand for fresh pork was more than offset in the hog market here today by the second largest receipts for a Thursday this season. Prices were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower in the early trading but there was an active demand on the decline and part of the loss was recovered.

After a brief ownership the Gortham Estates, Inc., Isadore Lorber, president, resold the six-story elevator apartment building at 6,672 St. Nicholas Avenue to the Bervan Management Corporation for investment. The sellers acquired the realty recently from Workmen's Circle, Inc., and resold it for cash over a first mortgage of $168,400 at 4 per cent.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 7. -- A black horse scudding through fleecy mist and driving rain gave Mrs. M.D.P. Somerville her third consecutive victory in the Masters of Foxhounds Steeplechase over the Pimlico course today. Hunt club followers from as far south as the Carolinas rallied in tweeds and mackintoshes to see Wild Son, by Son-in-Law from Wild Mint, toy with a field of nine others and triumph easily by six lengths.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Looking over market reports showing sharp price increases for potatoes during thirty days, AAA officials said today they believed the proposed Federal subsidy program to increase 1935 crop prices would be unnecessary.

VIENNA, Nov. 7. -- Major Emil Fey was appointed today president of the first Austrian Danubian Steamship Company. At the same time Major Fey resigned the post of commander of the Viennese Heimwehr, a position that gave him considerable power in Austrian politics during the last four years.

The Touchdown Club went on record yesterday as opposing any meeting between college and professional football teams. At the weekly luncheon at the Hotel Martinique action was deferred on a blanket resolution presented by Al Wittmer of Princeton expressing disapproval of any contest between amateurs and professionals, even between all-star groups, but sentiment was unanimously against a game between a particular college team and a professional eleven.

The potency of melody, sincerity and genius was strikingly manifested at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert conducted by Otto Klemperer last night in Carnegie Hall. It triumphed over the inherent patchiness of an overture which is nevertheless a living and pulsing thing -- Weber's overture to "Euryanthe" -- and this in spite of a performance that was noisy and theatrical.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Amelia Earhart and Helen Richey agreed today that the latter lost out in commercial aviation because she was a woman.

Paintings by American and European artists, together with thirty-five bronzes by Antoine Louis Barye, all from the collection of the late James G. Shepherd, brought a total of $77,820 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

A repertoire of thirty-six operas and a personnel of seventy-nine singers have been arranged for the coming Metropolitan Opera season, according to the prospectus made public yesterday. The Opera House will embark on the fifty-third year of its existence under new supervision, with Edward Johnson as general manager.

AT THE FRONT WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES, Overlooking Makale, Nov. 7. -- Italy's central columns bivouacked tonight on a mountain rim in easy sight of Makale, ready to push into and past that city in a dawn drive -- with scattered battles likely.

High school students must pledge allegiance to the government before they can qualify for a diploma, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, insisted yesterday after the Board of Superintendents had made public a decision upholding the "loyalty oath."

Captain Earl F. Thomson and Captain Cornelius C. Jadwin of the United States Army equestrian team last night won the international military jumping event for pairs at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden with the remarkable score of one-half a fault.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is trustee for $2,600,000 reorganization bonds of the Mayfair House, 60 East 65 Street Corporation.

Further losses in livestock and meats and lower prices for wheat and corn carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale prices 1 point downward to 127.4 on Tuesday from 128.4 (revised) on the Tuesday previous. Part of the loss in corn was due to the use for the first time this week of new-crop quotations, which are sharply below those for the short old crop.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, criticized high city taxes in a statement read last night at a dinner in the Ritz-Carlton attended by representative business men and trustees of the Citizens Budget Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Discussions on the proposed reciprocal tariff agreement between the United States and Canada will begin at the White House tomorrow night between President Roosevelt and W.L. Mackenzie King, Canada's new Premier.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7. -- Trading, the like of which has not been seen in local markets since the wild days of 1929, returned to the San Francisco Stock and Curb Exchanges today as news of the Baltimore decision on the Utilities Holding Company Act reached financial circles here.

Victories by the Princeton, Harvard and University Clubs last night kept the teams in a triple tie for first place in the Class A championship race of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League. All three won by four matches to one.

Dates for three of the major events sponsored by the United States Golf Association, the open, amateur and Walker Cup matches, were announced yesterday by Frank M. Hardt, secretary of the national body.
BINGHAMTON, Nov. 7. -- Deposit Village went back to horse and buggy days today, re-enacting the start of construction of the Erie Railroad a hundred years ago.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- Leaders of the confessional synods have hurriedly assembled in Berlin to discuss the crisis caused by the secret police suppression of the synod's independent theological seminaries. The Prussian Brotherhood Council met today, and the Reich Brotherhood Council will go into session tomorrow.

The statement issued on Wednesday by Secretary HULL outlined the victory of the doctrine of neutrality in time of war. It was of slow growth. The United States, as the Secretary of State remarks, contributed a great deal to its development. But that was largely in the way of defining and defending neutral rights and the freedom of the seas.

Opposition to Major Berry's proposed conferences on industrial and labor problems was reiterated here yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association, while the Machinery and Allied Products Institute also went on record against the meetings.

Increased sales have been reported by seventeen chain store and mail order houses. Decreases are shown by only two of the nineteen concerns that have announced sales for October, and each drop was just 2.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Branding as "partisan" charges that his work relief policies and press conference references to New Deal opponents were in the interest of President Roosevelt's re-election, Mr. Hopkins said today:

MOSCOW, Nov. 7. -- Over the golden, sanded cobbles of Red Square thundered the Red Army's mightiest tank demonstration today -- 420 land battleships -- to mark the eighteenth anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution.

Dr. Marvin A. Stevens, who has had a full share of football at Yale and now at N.Y.U., looked out through the rose-colored panes of his office at the Heights yesterday and expatiated with his characteristic frankness on the football situation at his alma mater and in his own camp.
Sir HERBERT SAMUEL'S name is first among signers of the manifesto of the Liberal party, one of the disject members of an organization once so great.
Federal control over the sale of proprietary medicines rather than local control was proposed to representatives of the drug industry at City Hall yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Bernard M. Baruch, economist and statesman who served as chairman of the War Industries Board during the World War, declared last night that the citizens of this country must "firmly and unalterably" stay out of war "by creating a state of mind that shall be closed and immovable."

The widow beaver of the Bronx Zoo and her two fatherless babies have been found. After wandering for two months about the zoological park, "the little devils," as a voice from the zoo said over the telephone yesterday, are due to go back to their own pond today.

For the "dressy" hat this Winter velvet will predominate if the women of the land follow the lead of the First Lady, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt went shopping rather early yesterday morning and bought two hats after trying on four.
Widespread trading in apartment house properties in the Bronx yesterday was featured by resales. Principals involved in the activity included operators, investors and savings banks.

William J. McDermott, 54 years old, a former Deputy State Attorney General, who had been sought since last week on an $18,000 theft indictment, surrendered at District Attorney Dodge's office yesterday. He gave his address as 509 West 112th Street.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 7. -- Mrs. Doris Melanson's Happy Knot, a 5-year-old mare, won the fifth race today at Narragansett Park, to continue her record of finishing in the money.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 7. -- Six robbers, armed with sub-machine guns, automatic pistols and sawed-off shotguns, held up and robbed an Erie mail train when it stopped at Garrettsville, Ohio, this afternoon and took pouches containing at least $34,000 in currency and $12,450 in securities.
LONDON, Nov. 7. -- C.F. Pike, Conservative member from Sheffield in the last Parliament and now a candidate for re-election, finished tonight a journey to reach his constituency that breaks records.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 7. -- The military ball, one of the three major formal dances of the year at the University of Vermont, will be held tomorrow evening.

The promise of lower-priced seats in New York City's legitimate theatres as the result of the projected building code was held out last night at a meeting of producers, architects, designers and representatives of acting groups. The meeting took place in the offices of the Theatre Arts Monthly, 40 East Forty-ninth Street.

Three men, emphasizing their brusqueness with aimed pistols, handcuffed two employes of Pickslay Co., jewelers, in its little shop on the ground floor of 338 Park Avenue, at Fifty-first Street, at 10:30 A.M. yesterday and escaped with jewelry valued at about $15,000.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Operations were restricted today in the London Stock Exchange because of final arrangements being made for the settlement and the approach of the general election. Profit-taking followed the recent sharp gains and prices became irregular.

MANILA, P.I., Friday, Nov. 8. -- Philippine leaders today submerged all economic and defense problems connected with the islands' forthcoming independence to unite in acclaim of the delegation from the Congress that granted that freedom and of the representatives of more than twenty American newspapers and press associations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Frank P. Parish testified today that stock of his Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company crumbled in a market "raid" forty-eight hours after he had refused to sell out at cost to Standard Oil and Cities Service.

Efforts will be made to continue the works-relief program until next June instead of stopping earlier, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator here, said yesterday. He made the announcement before leaving for Washington, where he hopes to obtain the $74,000,000 allocated to New York City for its work-relief program.

The total bed capacity of Harlem Hospital, seriously overcrowded for years, will be increased from 325 to 677 with the opening of the institution's new women's building on Jan. 2, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, announced yesterday.

A city-wide search was started for Tim Sullivan, an Irish terrier, after an alarm was sent out at 10:07 o'clock last night over the police teletype system to all precincts and detective divisions. The dog is the property of James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, who has been living at the Hotel Chatham, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, with his wife since their return from England about a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- A careful examination of the RFC's present financial relation to the newspaper business leads to the belief that Colonel McCormick, Mr. Hearst and the other vigilantes of a free press need not call out the constitutional posse on this particular job.

A resolution vigorously opposing a proposed Federal regulation which would require all advertisers to reveal the alcoholic formulae of their products was adopted yesterday morning by the National Wholesale Wine and Liquor Dealers Association, which is holding a three-day convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

In a radio broadcast over Station WABC yesterday at 1:15 P.M., Alfred H. Swayne, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, answered a number of questions pertaining to automobiles and the automobile show put to him by the station's announcer.

NAPLES, Nov. 7. -- The war is closer to Naples than to any other Italian city. The gateway to the African front, the most exposed point of the home front, the first place to feel the pressure of the new war of sanctions, Naples has the atmosphere of a beleaguered town.

More than 400 women attended a tea yesterday afternoon in the roof garden of the Hotel St. Regis, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, and heard plans outlined for the raising of a fund of at least $2,000,000 for the United Hospital Campaign.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Head Coach Ducky Pond said tonight that he plans to keep Captain Kim Whitehead, Jerry Roscoe and Clint Frank out of action Saturday when Yale meets Brown. Pond kept all three backs on the bench today, but denied that any of them is suffering from injuries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Various foreign reactions to Secretary Hull's radio speech on neutrality last night elicited the comment from the State Department today that the speech spoke for itself. Officials declined to elaborate it.

I have just read Mrs. Thomas D. Griffiths's letter with a great deal of interest and much surprise. Is a government "socialistic or communistic" if it provides for its citizens -- even if only for those who are aged and infirm? If so, very many of us have been Socialists and Communists these many years and have not known it.

The request of PADEREWSKI that the people of Poland should not be "bothered" to commemorate his birthday will not prevent hundreds of thousands in all parts of the world from sending their grateful thoughts toward him, even if these do not get into printed, written or spoken words.

A plea for support of President Roosevelt's naval policy, including opposition to "all subversive influences tending to destroy the national defense," was made yesterday by Admiral William H. Standley, chief of naval operations, in an address before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Julia Hoyt was married at 5 o'clock this afternoon at Briarcliff Lodge to Aquila C. Giles by Justice of the Peace John M. Haviland of New Castle.

Representatives of employers and employes in the millinery industry moved yesterday to avert a threatened lockout when they agreed at City Hall to discuss their differences immediately with a view toward settling them amicably.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- A pair of second-string tackles, a new centre and a substitute right halfback will probably be in the Pennsylvania line-up at the kick-off against the Navy. Coach Harvey Harman has been obliged to make the changes due to injuries in his squad.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 7. -- Crown Prince Asfavu-Quossen arrived from Dessye by airplane this afternoon and was received by Emperor Haile Selassie, who advised him about the conduct of the government here while the Emperor is at the front.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7. -- The Public Utility Holding Company Act passed by Congress to give the government power to make a sweeping reorganization of the utility industry was declared unconstitutional "in its entirety" in a ruling today by Judge William C. Coleman in the Federal District Court.
William Randolph Hearst, publisher, returning here yesterday because of California income taxes, urged a "permanent breathing spell" for business.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The Italian advance has been resumed after a further short delay to improve communications which were deteriorated by unexpected rainstorms. The advancing troops have gone forward to a ridge north of Makale and Dolo, but a fresh storm is reported to have imposed a further check.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares its follows. Quotations are in cents:

Perhaps the day before the St. Mary's game is no time to be discussing Fordham's 1936 prospects, but the completion of the Ram freshman season on Tuesday makes the subject rather pertinent. To begin with, Sleepy Jim Crowley has been using two full teams and of those twenty-two young men he loses by graduation only four -- none of them being exactly irreplaceable.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Nov. 7. -- W.K. Kellogg ordered the six-hour day, 36-hour week made permanent in his cereal plant here today, and increased the average pay rates by 12.5 per cent, thus bringing the wage scale to a level of that which prevailed under the eight-hour day prior to Dec. 1, 1930.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Railroads must unite to solve the transportation problem. Dr. W.T. Jackman of the University of Toronto said tonight, if they are to avoid either government ownership or their collapse.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Striking at a variety of frauds in connection with transactions of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, the corporation's criminal investigation section reported today it had recovered $472,000 for HOLC borrowers and applicants for loans.

Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week, according to the reports wired especially to THE TIMES yesterday by the regional associations. The adjusted index, which is a component of THE NEW YORK TIMES business index, declined to 75.4 from 75.8 in the previous week and compared with 53.3 for the week ended Nov. 3, 1934.
Loew's, Inc., declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock.

Holders of the 7 per cent first mortgage debentures of the Anglo-Chilean Nitrate Corporation have approved amendments to the trust deed providing for readjustment of the indebtedness of the company, Medley C.B. Whelpley, president, announced yesterday.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 7. -- Internationally known specialists condemned tonight at a clinical meeting the "mercy killing" of "incurable" patients. They took the position that no doctor has the right to take a patient's life, since he has no way of being certain a case is incurable.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- All ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society were represented tonight in the capacity audience which welcomed Roman Totenberg, young Polish violinist, who made his United States debut at the first evening concert given this season by the National Symphony Orchestra in Constitution Hall.

In a lecture delivered before the Royal Institution, Sir JAMES JEANS presented what must have been a harrowing prediction of the moon's fate. The catastrophe foretold was a popularization of the fine mathematical study of the tides for which astronomers will ever thank the late Sir GEORGE H. DARWIN.

Plans for formation of a large and aggressive national wholesale liquor dealers' association, in which State jobber groups of the country will hold membership, will be perfected today by a special committee meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

Your correspondent Louis Griffin, who questioned the correctness of the headline which appeared in your issue of Oct. 26, reading "Pneumonia Deaths Cut 50 Per Cent by Serums," is entirely warranted in doing so, as the body of the article itself reveals that a reduction in the mortality rate by the use of serums was claimed only for the pneumonias caused by the germs of types one, seven and eight.
Executives of the major automobile companies were guests of the Merchants Association of New York at a luncheon given as a tribute to the industry in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

The world of science and medicine and many lay groups observe today the sixty-eighth anniversary of the birth of Marie Sklodowska Curie, Polish scientist and co-discoverer of radium, who died a martyr to her great work last year.

Tenement houses formed the bulk of realty put up for bidding at auctioneers' stands yesterday. The properties offered at foreclosures consisted of seven parcels in Manhattan and eight in the Bronx. One scheduled sale in the latter borough was adjourned.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- With the declaration, "No more Mdivanis!" Pola Negri disclosed today that she was going to marry "a middle-aged British statesman" some time before Christmas. She kept secret her new fiance's identity, however, saying:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will proceed with administration of the Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 regardless of the decision of Judge Coleman at Baltimore, in the American States Public Service Company case, although admittedly it will complicate the situation, especially if utility holding companies fail to register by Dec. 1, the deadline set by the act.

The Republican party in New York State will utilize its new control of the Assembly to push a program which it is hoped will attract the voters of the State toward the Republican banner in the 1936 Presidential election, it learned yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- Red Dutton's New York Americans, outplayed but never outfought, bowed to the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 3 to 1, in the opening match of the National Hockey League season.
The twelve-day open season on pheasants will come to a close at nightfall tomorrow throughout New York State, with the exception of Long Island, where the ringnecks are legal quarry until Dec. 31.

TOKYO, Nov. 7 (AP). -- A Japanese national news agency, the subject of three years of negotiation, came into being officially today. The government delivered to Tokichi Tanaka, former Ambassador to Moscow and publisher of the newspaper Chugai Shogyo, as chairman of the organizing newspaper representatives, a charter for the Domei Tsushun Sha -- which can be translated as the "Alliance News Association."

E.M. Durham, senior vice president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, is to succeed James E. Gorman as head of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway, Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, disclosed yesterday in a discussion of the railroad situation. Both roads are in bankruptcy pending reorganization.

With 500,000 traffic cases a year to dispose of, it is little wonder that city magistrates toss in their sleep, dreaming of dragons whose eyes flash alternately red and green. Crossing against the lights and parking against the rules are the two chief offenses, accounting for more than a third of all the business of the courts.

A decline in the total of member-bank excess reserves from the high record of $3,010,000,000, reached last week, to $2,990,000,000 as of last Wednesday was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve System. This decline took place in the face of a further rise of $18,000,000 in the total of member-bank reserves, carrying that figure to a new high mark at $5,671,000,000.

The first conviction as the result of a police investigation of a system in which taxicab drivers are forced to pay tribute to racketeers for the privilege of standing at hotels, restaurants and other public places was obtained in Special Sessions yesterday.

State and municipal financing for October reached $65,599,933, compared with a revised total of $115,207,812 for September of this year and with $69,748,006 for October, 1934, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The State of New York was taken to task in The Journal of the American Medical Association today for advertising milk as a "patent medicine."

Production of steel ingots last month amounted to 3,116,184 gross tons, an increase of 110 per cent over the total for October, 1934, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The output was the largest for any month since May, 1934, and the largest for any October since 1929.

The awarding of gold medals to five Boy Scouts who saved the lives of others "at great risk to their own" was announced yesterday by the National Court of Honor of the Boy Scouts of America. The Court also announced the award of certificates for heroism to four other scouts who made rescues where the element of risk was less great.

ROME, Nov. 7. -- As the fateful 18th of November approaches.
