Italians are watching ever more closely the countries that, either because they do not belong to the League of Nations or because they have refused to give their adherence to sanctions, will soon become Italy's only sources of the materials and supplies necessary for carrying on the military campaign in East Africa.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Harold E. Scarborough, American newspaper man and author, who until recently had been chief European correspondent of The New York Herald Tribune, was lost overboard from the liner Berengaria today shortly before the vessel's arrival at Southampton from New York.

Since Hugh Walpole invented them, the creeps in "Night in the House" have a genuine artistic flavor. He invented them in a shadowy novel entitled "The Old Ladies," which Rodney Ackland has transformed into a diabolical play that opened at the Booth last evening.

Within a week or two after receiving the city's request for such action the Transit Commission is prepared to resume public hearings on the proposed condemnation and removal of the Sixth Avenue elevated line, it was indicated yesterday.

Hosiery shipments during September amounted to 10,816,410 dozen pairs, an increase of 17 per cent over the preceding month and of 34 per cent over September of last year, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- An effort to show that United States holders of defaulted Brazilian bonds were treated less favorably than British investors in the negotiations of 1933-34, and that Speyer Co. of New York worked in the interest of British and French capital rather than American, was made today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the course of its hearing on the activities of various bondholders' protective committees and houses of issue.

While bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange lost much of the buoyancy that characterized Wednesday's session, prices among the higher grade issues maintained a firm undertone. Pronounced weakness was confined to a few isolated groups, noticeably the local traction list where pressure became somewhat heavy during the afternoon.

HARRISON, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Republican leaders conferred here today on whether to challenge the election of Raymond J. Funkhouser, who was chosen Supervisor of this town, and C.C. Pettijohn, who was selected a Councilman, on the ground neither owned property here on election day. Both Mr. Funkhouser and Mr. Pettijohn are Democrats.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 7. -- President Arturo Alessandri signed a decree this morning forbidding the formation and public appearance of organizations wearing distinctive insignia and having a military or semi-military character. The Boy Scouts are excused, but must obtain permits for public demonstrations.

OTTAWA, Nov. 7 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday decreased $3,448,082 from the previous week, said the bank's statement today. Deposits by chartered banks increased $7,427,370.

THE card the boy brought in read: "El Schacht, Toreador, Good-Will Ambassador from Mexico." The advice to the boy was: "Show him up." A minute later in came Senor Schacht in person, and not a picture.

Adoption of a three-point program to curb unfair price competition and advertising was urged yesterday by Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, in an address at the luncheon meeting of the National Notion Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The first of a series of Thursday Dutch Treat dinner dances was held last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Among those who gave dinners were Mr. and Mrs. Arnall P. Hodges, whose guests included:
ALBANY, Nov. 7. -- Next week was proclaimed today by Governor Lehman as American Education Week, when people should visit the schools and participate in special programs.

Bank clearings in the five-day week ended on Wednesday were 20.5 per cent above those in the corresponding week last year. The total for the twenty-two principal cities throughout the nation totaled $4,987,404,000, against $4,138,643,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

The seventeenth annual collection of O. Henry Memorial Award Prize Stories, under the editorship of Harry Hansen, is published today by Doubleday, Doran. The judges this year -- Tess Slesinger, Clifton Fadiman and Joseph Henry Jackson-awarded the first prize to Kay Boyle for "The White Horses of Vienna," published in Harper's Magazine.

Four changes in the Manhattan eleven's line-up for its game with La Salle College of Philadelphia at Ebbets Field tomorrow were made definite yesterday with the announcement of the starting order by Coach Chick Meehan at the conclusion of a brief workout at Innisfail Park.

Marking the first decrease since May 25, retail package deliveries in metropolitan and suburban areas declined 1 per cent for the week ended Nov. 2, as compared with the same week a year ago, it was announced yesterday by the United Parcel Service.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7. -- Argentina has 26,272,000 bushels of wheat for export, according to an official estimate by the Ministry of Agriculture issued tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- Willie Hoppe, New York, defeated Arthur Thurnblad of Chicago, 50 to 41, in forty-four innings tonight in the play for the world's three-cushion championship. Hoppe had a high run of 5.
RYE, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- California climate decidedly did not prevail here today, but the Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's found this no obstacle.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7. -- The hastily rearranged football team which will start Saturday for Harvard at Princeton today polished its plays and held a short defensive workout against the junior varsity, which demonstrated Tiger plays in a dummy scrimmage.

Joseph Loguidice, a 15-year-old youth who lives at 162 East 103d Street, was shot in the back yesterday by a patrolman as he fled from the scene of an accident in which the car he was driving had been involved. The youth escaped but later admitted his part in the accident when his father brought him to Mount Sinai Hospital for treatment about 9 o'clock last night.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Governor Oscar K. Allen is considering resigning to assume the Senate seat vacated by the death of Huey P. Long.

There is big talk coming out of Washington about spending billions to keep men occupied on work, some of which seems to be quite unnecessary. But there is profound silence regarding the thousands of experienced men who have been thrown out of work through the operations of some of the many unusual New Deal inventions introduced for the purpose of restoring prosperity.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Election betting on the London Stock Exchange today indicated increasing skepticism concerning the size of the Conservative government's majority in the Parliament which will be chosen next Thursday.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that applications to list the following securities are pending before the committee on stock list:

The American Radio Telegraphists Association announced yesterday that protests had been sent to President Roosevelt, Secretary of Commerce Roper, and James Craig Peacock, chairman of the United States Shipping Board, over a shipping board order reducing the average wage scale of radio operators on forty-seven government-owned vessels being operated by private concerns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Developments in the Chinese monetary situation are being closely studied, but they have not yet brought any change in the United States silver-buying program, Secretary of the Treasury Henry W. Morgenthau Jr. said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- A warning that if the railroads do not act in carrying out suggestions for effecting economies through consolidation of terminal facilities he may be forced to take the matter in hand and issue some orders was given today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, in a talk before the Association of American Railroads at the Stevens Hotel.

Classes in Teachers College, Columbia University, will be suspended between 11 A.M. and noon today to "permit the participation of students and faculty" in an anti-war meeting in Horace Mann auditorium, 120th Street and Broadway, it was announced yesterday by Clarence Linton, secretary of the college.

Prices of gasoline were marked up yesterday a quarter cent a gallon in Eastern New York State and New England by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company. It was the first widespread advance in the section since May. No announcement was made by the other major refiners in the territory, but it was expected that they would change their prices to conform with those of Socony-Vacuum.
Rowland B. Haines, Columbia Club star, was among the winners last night as the annual Princeton Club squash tennis tournament got under way at the club's courts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The government will not inject into the first Supreme Court test of the Agricultural Adjustment Act the amendments to the law which were passed at the last session of Congress, the Department of Justice stated today.

A healthy distrust of common sense that is predicated upon past experience and the use of outworn symbols was urged last night by Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of the Johns Hopkins University, in an address before a joint meeting of Johns Hopkins alumni of New York and New Jersey, at the Fraternity Clubs Building, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

Every member of the Columbia football squad, from Captain Al Barabas to the last substitute for the third-string team, was sent through heavy-duty practice yesterday at Baker Field. It was the final intensive workout before the Blue and White faces Syracuse tomorrow.

That the share market's professional following, at least, is not of a mind to attempt to draw too definite conclusions from the welter of political comment that has followed the elections on Tuesday, was evidenced yesterday when, after early strength, prices softened under profit-taking to close irregularly.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Stuart Symington 3d gave a supper party last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Byron C. Foy. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, Mr. and Mrs. T. Reed Vreeland, Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius V. Whitney, Mrs. Warren Leslie Jr., Miss Miriam Hopkins, Miss Elizabeth Allen, Rouben Mamoulian and John McClain.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward again yesterday, influenced by the buoyant stock market and by a further advance in Liverpool. After an opening gain of several points, foreign and domestic trade orders, with more commission house interest, absorbed hedges and closed the list around the day's top figures at 7 to 12 points higher.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- A campaign to establish "the right of persons suffering from incurable disease to die" was announced today after a British doctor was reported to have admitted five "mercy slayings." A "kindly faced elderly family doctor," according to The Daily Mail, made the "confession."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- An intimation that the Associated Gas and Electric Company was preparing to adjust its affairs as a prelude to regulation under the Holding Company Act of 1935, by providing for mutualization of servicing for operating subsidiaries was contained in a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Metropolitan Edison Company, a member of the Associated System, for the issuance of $11,700,000 in bonds to redeem other issues.
The "stern authority" which Miss M.E. Merington and Miss Ida L. Rayner once exercised over the schoolboys of Harlem had resolved last night into an attitude of admiration for their former pupils.
PARIS, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The continued efforts of the stock list committee of the New York Stock Exchange to inform investors of intra-company changes which might affect security values is beginning to cause the Exchange to issue a variety of news items. Yesterday it reported the death of an official of one company, the election of officers by another, the sale of a piece of property by a third and a shift in collateral by a fourth.

ALBANY, Nov. 7 (AP). -- New York State's campaign to "sell milk as a medicine" and not "for its food value" drew sharp criticism from two medical men today, one of them the State Commissioner of Health.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- A heavy undertone developed today in North American wheat markets immediately after a fractionally higher opening. Lack of speculative interest was again a material influence.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7. -- As Soviet Russia celebrated its anniversary today the government claimed a great improvement in its financial and trade situation.

GENEVA, Nov. 7. -- Brazil informed the League of Nations today that it would not participate in sanctions against the Italian Government. Except for the usual formalities, the text of the answer was as follows:

In spite of yesterday's rain, the afternoon and evening attendance at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace was as large as on any day since the opening last Saturday, and a canvass of salesmen indicated that it was the best day for business so far reported.

The resignations of all thirteen members of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference were in the hands of James Sinclair, secretary, yesterday afternoon after a final meeting at which attempts to keep the conference intact were unavailing.

The first public airing of the charge that a $100,000 bribe was offered to "throw" the Druckman murder case will start today when four police detectives will be served formally with departmental charges.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Va., Nov. 7 (AP). -- An airplane pilot and one of his two passengers were killed and the other passenger was seriously injured in the crash of their Florida-bound plane fifteen miles south of this place today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 7. -- While the Supreme Court sat today to consider the appeal of the Chilean Electric Company against the government's orders of arrest against the concern's directors and managers on charges that they violated the exchange control laws, the company's street cars continued to run all day in defiance of a boycott proclaimed by workers.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Nov. 7 (AP). -- New York State prepared tonight for swift prosecution if the Saratoga County grand jury hands down indictments next week in connection with the investigation into fake race track tipster services.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 7. -- While the Supreme Court sat today to consider the appeal of the Chilean Electric Company against the government's orders of arrest against the concern's directors and managers on charges that they violated the exchange control laws, the company's street cars continued to run all day in defiance of a boycott proclaimed by workers.

September cash farm income was reported at $636,000,000 by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, The Annalist reports, against $547,000,000 in August and $626,000,000 a year ago, or with AAA payments at $692,000,000, against $592,000,000 and $699,000,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The most important collection of Renaissance paintings of the Veronese school in America has been presented to the Museum of Historic Art of Princeton University by Henry W. Cannon Jr. of the class of 1910, it was announced here today by Dr. Frank Jewett Mather, director of the museum.
BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- The Boerse was very quiet today, although it showed some signs of firmness.
Suburban real estate transactions reported yesterday took a fresh spurt and included a variety of holdings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- "Yellow-dog" contracts, which are said to have led to the mine strikes of 1927, were recalled in the District Supreme Court today during the hearing of the petition of James V. Carter, president of the Carter Coal Company, for a permanent injunction to restrain application of the Guffey-Snyder Coal Control Act to his company.

The influence that the automobile has had upon American life in a relatively short time was stressed yesterday by W.C. Cowling, general sales manager of the Ford Motor Company, who spoke over the radio.

The influence that the automobile has had upon American life in a relatively short time was stressed yesterday by W.C. Cowling, general sales manager of the Ford Motor Company, who spoke over the radio.

ALBANY, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The Niagara Gorge Railroad Corporation, from whose cars countless thousands of honeymooners and tourists have viewed the Niagara cataracts and rapids, petitioned the Public Service Commission today for permission to dissolve and scrap its equipment.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Chosen Governor of Kentucky by a Democratic landslide, Lieut. Gov. A.B. Chandler reiterated today his promises to repeal the State Sales Tax, cut governmental costs and "uphold the hands" of President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Gold and silver imports once more pushed the total of United States monetary stocks up to a new high level in October, the Treasury Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- With his interest centred on foreign affairs, President Roosevelt returned to Washington today from an eight-day vacation at his home in Hyde Park and a visit of a few hours in New York City last night.

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- The National Socialist Frontfighters' League, better known as the Stahlhelm or Steelhelmet league of war veterans, which Nazi local rulers had already suppressed in most parts of the country, was formally dissolved by Chancellor Adolf Hitler under a decree dated Nov. 7 -- the day on which the new swastika war flag was hoisted by all army and navy units.

With the prospect of enjoying more seasonable weather than has fallen to the lot of hunters in New York and Connecticut, where earlier opening dates are in force, New Jersey's licensed sportsmen await the start of upland game shooting on Monday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 8. -- America has "smoked economic hashish and seen economic visions, beautiful but wholly without substance," according to Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Depositors in closed national banks which were liquidated in the last year received about 59 cents on the dollar, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, reported.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 8 (AP). -- Overtures for cooperation and harmony between the young Republican organization and the party's national committee came from two sources tonight, the eve of the national meeting of youthful groups' leaders tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The Peruvian Bondholders Protective Committee, organized in August, 1932, by H.N. Blaustein, a Baltimore lawyer, and of which former Senator A. Owsley Stanley of Kentucky is chairman, and Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity for New York City, is one of the counsel, faced the fire of the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

BOSTON, Nov. 8. -- Five hundred Boston University students, in the olive drab uniform and the martial formation of their R.O.T.C. unit, were surprised attendants today at a mass student peace demonstration on the Mall of Boston Common.

The city will no longer provide for transients under a new policy announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at the Board of Estimate meeting in City Hall. The Mayor made his announcement after a conference yesterday morning with TERA officials, which delayed the start of the Board of Estimate meeting for about half an hour.

The Harvard and Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Clubs continued undefeated in yesterday's Class B squash tennis play in the Metropolitan league and are tied for first place with two victories each. Harvard downed the City A.C., 3 to 2, while the Crescents gave Columbia its third straight setback, 4 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- President Roosevelt and Premier W.L. Mackenzie King broached today the broadest possible reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Canada, the President indicating that he confidently expected a pact would soon result from Mr. King's visit to Washington.

About 20,000 college students in the city mobilized for peace yesterday. With classes suspended for an hour they gathered in auditoriums and on campus grounds to hear discussions of war. In contrast to similar demonstrations of previous years, in which the student attitude was rowdy and lighthearted, the meetings had an atmosphere of seriousness and order.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 8 (AP). -Senator George W. Norris, Republican independent, announced today that he was retiring from the Senate -- but friends from Nebraska to Washington voiced belief or hope that he would run again.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8. -- Barely able to beat Penn State and held to a standstill by Fordham in its last two gridiron battles, which had been figured as easy games, a puzzled Pitt Panther must brave the flying heels of the old Army mule in the feature game of the local college football season at the stadium tomorrow.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Atkinson gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Lady Kempton of London, Mrs. William Merrill, Raymond Hines and John Brantley. Another dinner there was given by Mr. and Mrs. C. Haskell Bliss for Mr. and Mrs. Cyril J. Edwards, Mrs. Charles F. Kettering, Harry Mitchell and William Hutton.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 8. -- Colonel Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, the stormiest petrel in the Ethiopian Army, allowed it to become known today that he had settled his serious differences with Emperor Haile Selassie.
The fifth edition of that melodramatic thriller in New York's repertory of football attractions, the Fordham-St. Mary's game, will be offered at the Polo Grounds today.

The Bronten Corporation, acting for the Manufacturers Trust Company, plaintiff, yesterday bought in the six-story apartment house at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 109th Street where Mayor La Guardia lives. The bid was $5,000 over a mortgage of $232,000.

The trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday displayed little of the enthusiasm that developed on the curb market and in over-the-counter dealings by the decision on the Public Utilities Act. Utility bonds were buoyant at the start but turned irregular and reactionary in subsequent dealings with the result that the price average for the group showed a small decline on the day.
District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn called on Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday for cooperation in stamping out the pin game racket in Brooklyn.
I read with interest the editorial "Knights of the Crossing," and was pleased that our much-misunderstood traffic "cops" had a champion who knows that they are human and have hearts.

The Most Rev. James DeWolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, will make an episcopal visitation in the Southwest following the annual meeting of the House of Bishops, at which he presided in Houston, Texas, this week.

Spurred by the decision of the Federal District Court in Baltimore holding the Public Utility Act of 1935 unconstitutional, the Stock Exchange yesterday enjoyed its heaviest trading session since February, 1934, while the Curb Exchange saw its first million share day since July, 1933.
Another ring engagement was arranged for Joe Louis yesterday when a contract was signed for him to fighth Isadoro Gastanaga, Spanish heavyweight, at Tropical Park, Havana, Cuba, Dec. 29.
ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- Irving M. Ives, minority leader of the Assembly, was invited by Governor Lehman today to attend the budget hearings now being conducted by the budget director, Abraham S. Weber.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Syracuse, undefeated and untied in its five games this Fall, will meet Columbia at 2 o'clock this afternoon at Baker Field before an expected throng of 25,000 fans. The Orange squad, accompanied by several thousand supporters, arrived in New York last night and established headquarters at the Biltmore Hotel.
ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- People of New York State were asked by Governor Lehman today to enroll in the American Red Cross annual roll-call.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. -- Manhattan College crews won three out of four races from Pennsylvania eights on the Schuylkill River today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 (AP). -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks signed an order today appointing Professor W.M. Daniels of Yale and James Lee Loomis of Granby, president of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, as additional trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

Most commodity futures were slightly lower on the local markets yesterday. Trading was light. In the cash markets, however, rubber alone cased; gains appeared in cotton, all the grains, silk, and tin, and zinc, wooltops and gasoline sold at new high levels.

GENEVA, Nov. 8. -- Miss Sarah Wambaugh of Boston, technical adviser and deputy member of the Saar Plebiscite Commission, received here tonight an honorary degree of Doctor of Social Sciences from Geneva University. It was presented as she concluded a series of lectures on the plebiscite at the university's Institute of Higher International Studies.

The Associated Gas and Electric System announced yesterday the formation of Utilities Mutual Management Association, Inc., all stock of which is to be owned by operating companies in the system, and gave out also the servicing companies to be owned by the new company and placed on a non-profit basis.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- The Boerse was weak and inactive today. In the decline of the heavy industries list Mannesmann lost a point. Potash shares were mixed, with evidence of weakness predominant.

PRAGUE, Nov. 8. -- The criminal court here started today the trial of nine persons accused of espionage in behalf of Germany. The principal defendant is the 24-year-old Anna Dienel of Eger, charged with the organization of a spy net in Northwestern Czechoslovakia among young Germans.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 8 (AP). -The toll of the Fall hurricane which swept the Northern Bahamas and Southern Florida mounted to nineteen today with belated reports of eleven persons drowned at Great Abaco Island.

Progress was made in conciliating differences between the National Wholesale Wine and Liquor Dealers Association and the Institute of Wine and Spirit Distributors, Inc., a New York State organization, at a closed meeting yesterday afternoon in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

Miss Tatiana Sanzewitch is a serious-minded young artist. The recitalist, who made her first appearance at the Town Hall in a piano recital last night, was well rewarded for her four years of earnest study with Josef Hofmann at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia; and who as a child was a pupil of Alfred Cortot in Paris.

Trenton, N.J., will enter the market on Nov. 15 with a new issue of $500,000 of tax-revenue notes, dated Nov. 4, 1935, and due on Nov. 3, 1936. Bidders are requested to name an interest rate not exceeding 1 1/2 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Liquidation by holders of December wheat contracts again today dropped the near-by delivery to around 1/2 cent a bushel under the May, the widest discount so far. Houses with Eastern connections bought the May heavily on the early dip, which had carried prices about a cent under yesterday's finish and into the bids.

Special arrangements of cut flowers and foliage for luncheon table decorations and other household purposes received awards yesterday on the second day of the annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York held in the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

A preliminary announcement of a new serum against the form of bacteria known as streptococcus, certain types of which cause fatal infections, was made last night by Dr. Edward R. Weidlein, director of the Mellon Institute for Industrial Research, Pittsburgh, before a joint meeting of the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry and the New York Section of the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The PWA slum-clearance program is running fifteen days ahead of schedule, officials said today. All land has been put under option or purchased for fifty projects in thirty-five cities. The program is being undertaken with $100,000,000 of work-relief funds and $29,000,000 from the original PWA funds.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES AT MAKALE, Ethiopia, Nov. 8. -- Italy's legions took Makale in their military stride today without a struggle and pushed on south and west into the rugged approaches to Lake Tana, lifeblood of the British Sudan.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- For the first time since 1925, ten full years, the Crimson feather of Harvard appeared on the sleepy old streets of Princeton today.

The Corporation Counsel's office is studying whether the agreement leasing the Central Park Casino to the Dieppe Corporation until 1939 cannot be broken immediately, in view of the fact that Sidney Solomon has sold his interest in the business, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- A cotton crop of 11,141,000 bales for 1935 was forecast today by the Crop Reporting Board of the Agriculture Department, based on conditions on Nov. 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Colonel W. De Basil's Ballet Russe attracted tonight to the County Centre the largest audience seen there in three years. The ballet was presented as the second attraction in the annual recital series arranged by Mrs. Julian Olney.

It may be inferred that Turkey is wishing to bring herself still more closely into association with the West and its ways by bridging the Bosporus -- though another interpretation is possible. In any event, it was inevitable that hurrying humanity in the contracting planet would be insisting upon swifter passage between the continents that here are separated by only half the distance that Leander swam in his love for Hero.
The Symons Galleries, Inc., open today the eighth of their series of exhibitions devoted to the decorative arts. Chippendale, showing the Chinese, French and Gothic influences, will be featured.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by sixty-seven municipalities amounts to $36,687,840, compared with a revised total of $18,933,414 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $25,692,608.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Both industrial production and employment are now at their highest level since the Autumn of 1930, according to the monthly business survey made public today by the Department of Commerce. President Roosevelt recently made it known that he was studying, in cooperation with leading industrialists, the lag in employment and payrolls behind the production indices, and the figures given out today tended to emphasize this problem.

In the course of a charity performance given last night by the Society of Illustrators at the Heckscher Theatre, 104th Street and Fifth Avenue, police mounted the stage and stopped the show to the amazement of the audience of more than 800 men in evening dress. Five women performers were arrested.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

After deliberation with the American Olympic Committee the United States Figure Skating Association has announced Dec. 27, 28, 29 and 30 as the dates for the national championships and Olympic trials.
Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to the people of New York City to contribute to the Will Rogers Memorial Fund.

Three loan sharks were sentenced yesterday to thirty days in the workhouse by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Harlem Court. The magistrate said that he was taking it upon himself, in the circumstances, to broaden the meaning of Section 887, Subdivision 1, of the Criminal Code applying to vagrancy.

The Hon. James Moncrieff Balfour is sailing tonight for London on the North German Lloyd liner Europa with Mrs. Balfour. Others leaving on the ship for the Channel Ports are Marquis Gabriel de Mun and the Marquise, Heinz Schuengel, North German Lloyd official, and:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8 (AP). -Kentucky continued to go Democratic by a landslide, while majorities piled up for prohibition repeal and in favor of old-age pensions as tabulation of the huge vote cast in Tuesday's election neared completion tonight.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 8 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- The Senate of the Hebrew University today elected Professor Hugo Bergmann to fill the newly created post of rector. The post was created by the university's board of governors at its last annual meeting in Lucerne, Sept. 11, to take over some of the duties of the chancellorship when Dr. Judah L. Magnes relinquished that position to become president of the university.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- The constitutionality of the Railroad Retirement Act and Pension Laws will be contested by the Association of American Railroads and member roads, it was announced here today by John J. Pelley, president of the association, at the conclusion of the organization's first annual meeting.

In quest of its fifth victory of the season, Manhattan's football team will meet a strong La Salle College of Philadelphia eleven at Ebbets Field today, starting at 2 o'clock. The contest will mark the first meeting of the institutions on the gridiron.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 8. -Shakespeare and Longfellow will meet tomorrow -- not to trade verses, but to play all the football they know as Notre Dame and Northwestern stage their annual struggle.

MONTREAL, Que., Nov. 8. -- According to information reaching here from Toronto this evening, the latest development in the Gefaell-Great Lakes Paper situation is the resignation by the National Trust Company as receiver for the Great Lakes Paper Company as a member of the Newsprint Export Manufacturers Association of Canada.

The Anchor Corporation and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended on Sept. 30 earned a net profit of $469,198 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other deductions. This was equal after dividend requirements on $6.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock, to 98 cents a share on 273,698 shares of common stock, excluding 3,000 shares held in treasury.

Detectives of the bomb squad seized yesterday afternoon an alleged blackmailer accused of threatening the life of Herbert L. Bodman, president of Milmine, Bodman Co., grain exporters. The arrest was made in the postoffice in the Custom House, where letters had ordered the money be left.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- Finance Minister Marcel Regnier, speaking before the American Club of Paris, painted a picture of the French economic and financial situation that was encouraging without being optimistic.

A glittering array of fashion and jewels featured the parade of society at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. With no counter-attractions, many social notables attended the event for the first time prior to leaving for their country places for the week-end.

How the Fisher interests of Detroit were called upon to buy securities in the open market to aid a $12,000,000 refunding plan which the Baldwin Locomotive Works effected in 1933 was described by George H. Houston, president of Baldwin, at a hearing yesterday before Edwin P. Kohl, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The letter signed O.B.H. in your issue of today is very much to the point. But why confine it to jay-drivers and jay-walkers? More important is "jayorders."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8. -The adaptation of the geophone in exploring the ocean has opened to science new possibilities in geologic procedure, according to Professor Richard M. Field of the Princeton University Department of Geology.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Nov. 8. -Charley Shirley skirted left end fifteen yards in the last quarter for the touchdown that gave Pelham High School's football squad a 6-0 decision over Tuckahoe in a stirring battle today. Shirley's run terminated an 83-yard march by the winners, who were on the defensive for most of the contest.
OTTAWA, Nov. 8. -- Anxious to retain their advantage in the Canadian market, representatives of Welsh coal interests today urged upon the government that the duty on hard coal entering Canada from

Personified by a big and powerful St. John's Prep team, thirteen lived up to its hoodoo reputation on Horace Mann Field yesterday as the unbeaten Brooklyn eleven plowed and passed its way to a 20-to-0 football victory over Horace Mann School for Boys, thereby ending the latter's long winning streak in decisive fashion.

Over the protest of American steel producers, the engineering department of the Triborough Bridge has approved the use of imported German sheet steel piling for the Queens approach of the bridge. The order calling for the use of the steel was held up yesterday, however, on the instructions of the Public Works Administration at Washington, which is financing the construction of the bridge.

AMHERST vs. Swarthmore -- In this connection the class will now take up the case of the late Vincent van Gogh, Dutch painter, who was just as crazy as any one who tries to guess football results in advance. He was the founder -- so the art critics say -- of an advanced school of painting. This school had no football team, but that wasn't the reason why he shot himself.

Henry Gordon, 40 years old, of 242 South Second Street, Brooklyn, who described himself as a "genealogist," was committed to the Tombs in default of $10,000 bail in Special Sessions yesterday on a charge of illegally practicing law in the so-called "lost heirs" racket in the Surrogates' courts.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. -- Pennsylvania and Navy, both fighting to redeem three early season defeats, will meet on Franklin Field tomorrow in the twentieth game of their series. The crowd will probably reach 70,000, the biggest of the season in Philadelphia, with the entire regiment of 2,200 Midshipmen attending.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8. -Charley Ewart tonight was chosen by Head Coach Ducky Pond as field general of the Yale eleven against Brown tomorrow, succeeding the veteran Jerry Roscoe. Ewart, whose 68-yard run gave Yale its only score against Dartmouth last Saturday, is, like Albie Booth, a product of a local school team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- While he declared that he was not issuing any appeal or warning, Chairman Landis of the Securities and Exchange Commission declared today that the time had come when stockholders of public utility holding companies should be informed of dangers that lie ahead should the companies fail to register with the commission under the Holding Company Act of 1935.

Loans made last month by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to banks, railways and other private borrowers were the smallest in its history. In round numbers they amounted only to $30,000,000, compared with $50,000,000 received during the same month in repayment of earlier advances.

HOT SULPHUR SPRINGS, Col., Nov. 8. -- A special train carrying students of the University of Colorado and followers of the university football team from Denver to Salt Lake City jumped the tracks west of here tonight, causing minor injuries to about 150 passengers.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- William F. Seber, 48 years old, president of the Manufacturers National Bank and president of the Troy Board of Education, was shot and killed shortly after noon today in his office at the bank. John E. Healey Jr., 60 years old, principal of School No. 5 of Troy, was held as the slayer.

A downward revision of 323,000 bales in the government crop estimate was more than traders had expected, and prices on the Cotton Exchange here advanced more than $1 a bale yesterday, to end with gains of 15 to 17 points.
A letter to THE TIMES from H.S. Hammond merits commendation by all motorists.

PROSPECT PARK, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Robbers invaded the Prospect Park National Bank this morning and escaped with $18,000 in cash as pistol shots, shouts, a clanging burglar alarm and the shriek of sirens turned the business street of this Paterson suburb into turmoil.

Leaders of the women's division in the campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies reviewed the needs of that organization yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Lecture Group Committee at the Hotel Plaza.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is not bound by the decision of Judge Coleman in Baltimore, according to counsel to utility companies here, because the SEC, as a body, was not a party at interest in the case, its counsel having appeared only as friend of the court.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 8 (AP). -- Paul Smith of Rutgers paced his team to victory over Lafayette and Lehigh in a triangular cross-country meet today, shattering the record for the five-mile course. He covered the distance in 26 minutes 11 seconds, bettering the previous mark by 29 seconds, to finish nearly 200 yards in front of Williamson of Lafayette, who was second.

SINGAPORE, Saturday, Nov. 9. -- Two giant British Air Force flying boats and a squadron of bombers have thus far searched the Bay of Bengal without avail for Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith, who at the time of cabling this dispatch [6 A.M. Saturday, London time] has been missing for twenty-eight hours on his flight with Tom Pethybridge from Allahabad in an attempt to break the England-to-Australia record.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- A cheerful air continued today on the London Stock Exchange, the spirit of profit-taking having proved short-lived, and a fresh inflow of buying following. British funds were again supported as a result of the news that the banks have been adding lately to their holdings.

A Bronx building operation will be undertaken by the Derlow Estates, Samuel Derfner, president. The latter bought from Elise Levy a plot adjoining the southeast corner of Mosholu Parkway South and East 204th Street, which had been in the seller's family for about twenty-five years.

A large luncheon and fashion show were given yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Working Girls' Vacation Society. Several debutantes of the season acted as manikins in the style pageant.

Next Monday will be Armistice Day, the seventeenth anniversary of the cessation of World War hostilities: The day will be widely observed here. Pre-Armistice Day celebrations will take place today and tomorrow.
Children shrieked with laughter in the auditorium of Ward G 6, Bellevue Hospital, yesterday afternoon as they watched Salt Pork, the clown, swaying on a rickety chair atop an equally rickety table.

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP). -- Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee today ruled excessive the $25,000 awarded to John D. Williams, a former stage director and publicity man, in a breach of contract suit against Maude Adams.

Interrputed by the holiday on Tuesday, activity in bond flotations slackened somewhat this week, a total of $37,950,000 in new issues being placed on the market, compared with $46,756,000 last week. This week's financing, however, maintained a substantial margin over the corresponding period of last year when new bond offerings amounted to only $11,723,000.

Traffic experts of several leading automobile companies contradicted yesterday the statement of W.H. Chandler, traffic bureau manager of the Merchants Association, that the congestion of outbound automobile shipments in New York was temporary.

William Morrow Co. are paring down and only partly filling orders they receive for copies of "U.S. Camera -- 1935" and expect to be out of stock on this book within a few days. More than 12,000 copies have been sold, 10,000 in the first three weeks of publication.

DUBLIN, Nov. 8. -- The Dail Eireann, acting as a sovereign legislative assembly, has passed a bill enforcing financial, commercial and other sanctions against Italy in accordance with its obligations as a member of the League of Nations.

DETROIT, Nov. 8. -- Further testimony concerning participation in union affairs of J.N. Martin, a Pinkerton Detective Agency operative, was described before the National Labor Relations Board today by members of the local American Federation of Labor union formed at the Fruehauf Trailer Company plant, which is charged with violating the Wagner-Connery Act.

MUNICH, Nov. 8. -- The German National Socialist revolution, proclaimed twelve years ago tonight, which lasted then for less than a day but attained a nation-wide triumph ten years later, is again being celebrated here at the scene of its temporary defeat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP). -- Scoring three touchdowns and tossing passes for two others, Alphonse (Tuffy) Leemans led George Washington University to a 53-to-7 football victory over Davis and Elkins tonight before 7,000 fans.

Further apprehension over the impending political and financial crisis in France carried the franc lower in the foreign exchange market here yesterday. At the same time the flow of gold from Paris to this country was increased by $8,925,000.

In one of the most thrilling international military competitions ever staged at the National Horse Show, the United States Army team last night snatched victory from the Chilean Army officers in the final event of the high-score competition.

Bank exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country rose last month to the highest level since January, 1932. The total was $26,356,037,027, being also the largest turnover for October since 1931.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine will swear in 102 members of the Park Department as special police officers next Wednesday morning, it was learned yesterday. The step was said to be in line with the efforts of the Police and Park Departments to render the parks safer and enforce park ordinances more strictly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The CCC awarded contracts during October for the purchase of 226 trucks, twenty-two tractors, 208 air compressors, ninety snow plows and a considerable quantity of other materials needed for the Winter, Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work, announced today.

ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas, Nov. 8 (AP). -- Flashing to the front, near the finish line, G.W. Ogle's Drombo ran six furlongs in 1:17 2-5 over a heavy track today to capture the Athens race for an $800 purse. The event was for 3-year-olds and up.

Frank J. McGowan and thirty other physicians filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday demanding the removal of Maurice C. O'Shea, son of William J. O'Shea, former Superintendent of Schools; Dr. Louis L. Shapiro and Dr. Emeline P. Hayward from their temporary positions as medical examiners of the Board of Education.

Sales of General Motors cars last month reflected the introduction of new models two months earlier than last year. Sales to dealers gained sharply as stocks of new models were built up. Sales to consumers fell off slightly, however, as the 1936 Chevrolet was not introduced until this month and the Pontiac, Oldsmobile and Cadillac were not formally shown until late in October.

Control of the Blue Ridge Corporation, held by the Atlas Corporation for several years, is being sold to a group of purchasers under a transaction completed early yesterday, it was announced by Floyd B. Odium, president of the Atlas Corporation.

VIENNA, Nov. 8. -- Maxwell Anderson's "Elizabeth and Essex" was produced in the Vienna Burgteater tonight as the contribution of the United States to the international series called "Voices of Folk in Drama," which this theatre has been presenting for some time.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Burnham North Dell of Princeton gave a large dance this evening at the Present Day Club here to introduce their daughter, Miss Florence Burnham Dell, to society. Miss Dell attended Miss Fine's School in Princeton and was graduated from the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, Pa., last June.

William Terror, 21-year-old undergraduate at Teachers College, Columbia University, and three alleged accomplices charged with holding up an elderly woman on Thursday night were arraigned yesterday in West Side Court.
The Palace Chop House at 12 East Park Street, Newark, where Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and three other men were wounded fatally the night of Oct. 23, lost its liquor license yesterday.

Demonstrating that a year of retirement has cost them little in the way of card cunning, the Four Aces contract bridge team rolled up a margin of 9,550 points last night to win their way into the semi-final round of play for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup for teams of four at the Park Lane Hotel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Johnny Layton, Sedalia, Mo., veteran seeking his twelfth world three-cushion championship, defeated Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia, 50 to 34, in fifty-three innings tonight for his second straight victory. Layton's high run was 8, Reiselt's best was 7.
HONOLULU, Nov. 8. -- The first of a series of naval flights to stretch United States defenses westward and northward in the Pacific will get under way tomorrow.

The annual football dance of the senior class of Columbia College will be held this evening in John Jay Hall on the campus from 9:30 until 2. More than 100 couples will attend, according to Randolph L. Titus of Kent, Conn., general chairman of the arrangements committee.

While trade during the week was aided by the uneven gains noted on election day, sales volume for the entire week has not been especially gratifying, retail executives here reported yesterday. Department store sales on the average are estimated to be about even with a year ago, although several establishments have achieved good gains despite the handicap of adverse weather conditions.

New York's thirty-sixth annual automobile show will close tonight at 11 o'clock. It has been called one of the most successful in a number of years. Every one connected with the exhibition agrees that it has succeeded. The attendance yesterday was undiminished, and exhibitors continued to report sales far in advance of those recorded at the show here last January.

When the Banking Bill was debated in Congress, the chief rallying cry of its sponsors was that the "money power" must be taken out of the hands of Wall Street and placed under the control of Washington. That demand has been paralleled by similar agitation in other countries.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 8. -- A strong Hill School eleven swept to a 20-7 victory over a light, fast Hotchkiss team in the thirtieth battle between the traditional rivals on Dell Field today. The game was marked by frequent blocked kicks and fumbles, which aided in Hill's triumph.
The twenty-eight battle flags of the Seventy-seventh Division were taken to City Hall yesterday and massed before Mayor La Guardia in the opening ceremony of the division's Armistice Day celebration.

The drop in temperature in most parts of the country this week enabled retail sales to recover definitely from the lull in buying that developed during the latter part of October, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CHICKASHA, Okla., Nov. 8. -- Dr. Howard Taylor, dean of the Oklahoma College for Women, was "kidnapped" before dawn today by four students clamoring for a holiday, and capitulated with a smile after being bound and gagged in the country.

ROME, Nov. 8. -- A reliable source disclosed tonight the Fascist high command had ordered anti-foreign demonstrations halted, and said the order reflected progress in peace negotiations between Italy and Great Britain, and France.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 8. -- Waste rather than conservation of human and economic resources has been the dominating force in our society, and the ignorance and indifference of the citizenry to public affairs have been "largely responsible for our social disaster," Miss Josephine Roche, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, told a Mount Holyoke College audience crowding Mary Lyon Chapel this morning to celebrate the ninety-eighth anniversary of the founding of the institution.

After getting off to a slow start, Edward G. McLaughlin of the Columbia University Club, and fourth ranking player in the tournament, gained the third round in the Princeton Club's annual invitation squash tennis competition last night.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- The problem of post-doctoral fellowships was dissected at a public session of the Association of American Universities at Cornell University today, with Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of Stanford University, asserting that an "increase in training time is required if men with research capacity are to be given an adequate trying-out and development period."

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- Franz Seldte, who inaugurated the Stahlhelm veterans' league at Magdeburg Nov. 13, 1918, just after the World War armistice, submitted meekly to Chancellor Hitler's order dissolving it.

Senator NORRIS of Nebraska has once more intimated, more positively than ever yesterday, that he will not be a candidate for re-election next year. It will be hard to imagine the Senate without him. He is no doubt sincere in feeling that the burden of years is getting too heavy upon him, and that younger men ought to carry on the work which he has been trying to do.

A general exodus from the current gridiron wars by Eastern prep school elevens will take place today and the program includes several traditional battles, which will serve as the season's closing games for most of the participating teams. Principally in that category are the Mercersburg-Kiskiminetas, Pedd-e-Blair and Kent-Choate contests.

FOR some years women haven't had much trouble keeping up with their husbands. During the depression depths it was the tongue-scorched husbands who were worrying that they had married above themselves -- not the wives. So maybe "Edna His Wife" (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50), by that practiced public pulse-taker, Margaret Ayer Barnes, is a bluebird sign.
The Bronx Symphony Orchestra, under Eugene Plotnikoff, will give a concert this afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum. Herma Menth, pianist, will be guest artist, playing the Liszt E flat concerto.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 8. -- The Exchange Telegraph correspondent here reported to London that C.J. Melrose, flying from England to Australia, said that Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith and his flying companion, Tom Pethybridge, were battling a raging monsoon.

Your editorial citing twenty-one deaths in New York City last week alone seems almost incredible. And yet the Police Department continues to do almost nothing about those most reckless drivers who practically ignore the red lights. It seems to be about time for some definite safety campaign to take form based on the slogan "Red lights mean stop!"

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 8. -- By winning the sixteenth game of his match with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, adjourned from last night, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, tonight regained the lead and now is showing the way with the totals at 8 1/2 -- 7 1/2.

Three regulars will be missing from the New York University varsity football squad today when the Violet encounters City College at the Yankee Stadium. This will be the sixth contest on the schedule for the undefeated and untied N.Y.U. eleven, and in spite of the absence of Ed Smith, Bob Hersh and Joe Mandell it will enter the fray an overwhelming favorite to keep its record clean.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 8. -- In the second race ever run at a mile and a half over the Narragansett Park track, the Saddle Spur Stable's Sandwrack today clipped seven and one-fifth seconds from the track record when he captured the endurance event in 2:33 1-5.

Rolling up one of the largest scores in metropolitan schoolboy circles for the current campaign, the Xavier High School football machine ran roughshod over McBurney yesterday at Recreation Park, Long Island City. With its attack gaining momentum as play progressed, the victors scored at least once in every period to triumph 51 -- 6.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Buying of hogs was stimulated here today by reports of higher prices for fresh pork in the East with a good demand, and the general market advanced 10 cents a hundredweight. Some of the lighter kinds were up 15 to 25 cents, with shippers finding it hard to fill the demand for weights under 180 pounds, and some orders went over unfilled because of small supplies.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- The Chicago Tribune will publish tomorrow morning a report of an interview by Arthur Sears Henning with former President Hoover. The dispatch, dated at San Francisco, is in part as follows:

The differences between the trustee of the St. Louis Gas and Coke Corporation and the bondholders' committee are almost ironed out as the result of a hearing before Special Master Edward P. Allen in Quincy, Ill., last week, it was learned here yesterday.

Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, who wrote the loyalty oath requirement in 1919 as a prerequisite to a high school diploma, expressed a change in his views yesterday, and in so doing supported the United Parents Associations in challenging the legality of the requirement.

A special dividend of 50 cents and a quarterly dividend of 50 cents were declared yesterday by Sears, Roebuck Co. The quarterly dividend places the stock on a $2 annual basis. On May 1 a special dividend of 75 cents was paid, the first dividend since May 2, 1932.

Team captains and members of the women's division of the United Hospital Campaign committee held their first meeting on the St. Regis Hotel roof yesterday. Mrs. William Woodward, the women's division chairman, said that 134 teams of women had been formed with 1,250 workers.
ROME, Nov. 8. -- The European situation continues to be a source of much apprehension to Italians.

There is always something hearty and often something surprising in Kentucky elections. The heartiness if not the surprise was shown this week. Lieut. Gov. "Happy" CHANDLER was chosen Governor by an unnecessarily fat majority, still growing. The bolt of Governor LAFFOON and his candidate, beaten in the run-off primary, Mr. RHEA, was no thunderbolt but a fizzle.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan heard arguments yesterday and reserved decision on the petition of the Standard Gas Light Company, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas Company, for an order directing Controller Frank J. Taylor to deduct the sums paid by the company under the relief excise tax law from the utility franchise tax.
May I add my approval and endorsement to that of the Rev. Arthur J. Brown, writing under the caption "Ourselves and the League," for your comment upon the League of Nations activities?

United States Senator Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware questioned yesterday unsuccessfully the right of the Congressional committee investigating real estate bondholders' reorganizations to inquire into the proposed reorganization plan for General Theatres Equipment, Inc.

The crowned heads of the unbeaten will continue to serve as shining targets today as football makes ready for another Saturday of tense expectancy. The ever thinning ranks of the mighty are likely to be further trimmed by nightfall as all wonder just where that dangling sword of Damocles is going to fall.

Apathy would be a mild word to describe the state of mind of the British electorate if it is true that radio is ousting the heckler. WILL ROGERS once commented on the striking difference between English public meetings and our own.
Three police detectives were served formally yesterday with departmental charges of negligence in connection with the Druckman murder case, and were demoted and transferred to new stations.

With everything quiet along the front of the WPA theatre project, the drama turned yesterday for its excitement to the old battle between actors and managers about salaries. This time the argument is over Sunday performances, legalized by the State and City of New York but snagged since then by various economic situations.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 8. -- Walter M. Jeffords's Firethorn, leading 3-year-old in training and victorious in the Lawrence Realization and Jockey Club Gold Cup, will be tested again tomorrow when he goes to the post for the mile and three-sixteenths of the Riggs Handicap, feature at Pimlico, under top weight of 122 pounds.

The Appellate Division upheld yesterday the decision of Surrogate James A. Foley admitting to probate the will of Mrs. Florence Adelaide Pratt, daughter of Isaac Singer, one of the founders of the sewing machine company. Mrs. Pratt, who lived abroad for many years, and died Oct. 30, 1932, in France at the age of 75, left much of her $5,000,000 estate to a former Scotland Yard man and two Parisian saleswomen, and disregarded two sisters.

A permanent youth service in the Federal structure, founded on governmental experiences in the CCC, the NYA and other units, was proposed last night by John A. Lang, member of the United States Bureau of Education and former president of the National Student Federation, at the ninth annual meeting of the New York State Association of Deans in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Somerset Maugham, British novelist and playwright, arrived yesterday from London on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after an absence of eight years. He brought with him the manuscript of his autobiography for which he has not yet found a title.
Mayor La Guardia entered Mount Sinai Hospital, Fifth Avenue and 100th Street, late yesterday afternoon for a stay of about a week to undergo treatment for rheumatism and sciatica.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Justice Branson in the King's Bench Division of the High Court today dismissed a petition of right that raised the question of the direct gold clause in a twenty-year 5 1/2 per cent coupon gold bond issued by the British Government in 1917.

The safety of passengers on the Brooklyn crosstown line of the city's Independent subway system may be jeopardized if the city persists in its policy of recognizing jurisdictional claims of Local 3 of the Electrical Workers Union in connection with signal work to be done on the line, the Board of Transportation was told at a public hearing yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- A temporary and limited exemption from certain provisions of the Holding Company Act of 1935 to holding company subsidiaries engaged in the general business of a broker or dealer in securities was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Brokers completed yesterday the assembling of a plot in lower Manhattan or a new building.

For more than a decade, Roland Hayes, Negro tenor, has held undisputed sway as the foremost song interpreter of his race. Last night at Carnegie Hall he soon made it evident that if his voice no longer is what it was in earlier days, he is still a past master of the art of elucidating the innermost meaning of a song.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 8. -- The news that Makale has been captured is received here with incredulity, as there is no official news from either front.

Major Gen. Sir James H. MacBrien, Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, revealed yesterday that liquor in considerable quantities has been and is being smuggled into Canada from the United States since repeal. The Federal, provincial and municipal police of the Dominion are thus faced with a new and somewhat intricate problem, he said.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 8. -- Oscar Nelson of Charleston and Lewlsburg, W. Vs., president of the United Carbon Company, and Mrs. Nelson will entertain 525 guests at separate dinners tomorrow night at the Greenbrier. The guests w/ll arrive in special trains, 125 coming from New York and New Jersey.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP). -- Acquisition of a recently restored painting by Hans Holbein, the younger, famous painter in the court of King Henry VIII of England, by the Museum of Fine Arts was announced today by Director George Harold Edgell.

RUMSON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Warrants charging illegal voting and perjury were issued here tonight for Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Dominick Stout of New York City. Mr. Stout is a stock broker and a member of the firm of Jacquelin De Coppet.

The New York Stock Exchange's special committee on customers' men, appointed two years ago yesterday, has rendered a final report to the governing board of the Exchange, which may vote at its meeting next Wednesday upon the committee's recommendations in the form of amendments to the constitution of the Exchange.

ROME, Nov. 8. -- With the bloodless occupation of Makale, over which the Italian flag has been flying since 9 o'clock this morning, General Emilio de Bono has concluded the second stage of his advance into Ethiopia. The first was the capture of positions extending from Adigrat through Adowa to Aksum.

Gold continued its flight from France to the United States yesterday and with increasing intensity as Paris manifested alarm over impending political developments. The loss of gold by France is now reaching proportions that are causing concern, and whether or not the amounts leaving Paris for New York, London and Amsterdam are being offset partly by receipts from Italy is problematical.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The British Ambassador and Lady Lindsay gave a dinner tonight at the embassy for twenty-four guests, including the French Ambassador and Mme. the Laboulaye, the Hungarian Minister and Mme. Pelenyi and Demetrios Sicilianos, Minister of Greece.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The $200,000,000 Federal program for elimination of hazards at railway grade crossings gives evidence of speeding up. Through Oct. 26 only 187 projects had been approved, totaling $14,013,050, and only seventy-four contracts had actually been awarded, for a total of $4.278,666, and the program was lagging far behind the general advance of the PWA.

MOSCOW, Nov. 8. -- Faced with the problem of industrializing an admittedly backward country in the shortest possible period, the Soviet Government has turned to specialization as the key to rapid and efficient production.

HARAR, Nov. 9. -- The exodus of disappointed "war correspondents" and camera men from Ethiopia is now well under way after one of the greatest and most expensive flops in journalistic and newsreel history. A dozen already have departed, as many more have "stand-by" orders to leave for home and the majority of the rest are hoping to be recalled.

interest in the old house called Ravensdale: these, together with servants and detectives are the persons who play their parts in the drama of murder and greed that is enacted at Ravensdale. Th .tory! is far too long and not absorbing enough to hold the reader's interest throughout its 405 pages.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Fourteen years after the United States buried its Unknown Soldier, and seventeen years since 4,000,000 American soldiers under arms ceased firing on that eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month in 1918, President Roosevelt and the American Legion prepared to ask the American people Monday for a ban by civilization on war, and for peace and good will among all peoples of the world.

TOKYO, Nov. 9. -- The Japanese War and Foreign Offices indicated today their displeasure with China for having promulgated her currency reform plan without previously consulting Japan and obtaining her approval.

It was with a great deal of pleasure and interest I found such an ominent critic as Barrett Clark recognizing the non-professional theatre and its work. I have spent the last six years close to just such groups and have felt that their problems and work deserved better consideration than our bigger brethren of Broadway were willing to concede to their poor relations.

Members of the board of directors of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Church of the Ascension have arranged a card party and tea for the afternoon of Nov. 19 in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis to raise funds for the dispensary of the Appalachian School in Penland, N.C.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9. -- For two periods today Tuss McLaughry's oft-beaten Brown eleven threatened to register one of season's greatest upsets. The Bruins threatened to hold Yale to a scoreless tie and they staged one goal-line stand that amazed the 12,000 onlookers.

A NUMBER of provocative selections infrequently heard and several important novelties are scheduled on the programs of the series of twelve concerts being given Wednesday evenings by the B.B.C. Symphony Orchestra in London.

PARIS, Nov. 9. -- The Ethiopian conflict has taken a back seat for the moment in the talks that have been started here for its settlement. At least with all hope of immediate discussion in abeyance during the British election campaign, European Foreign Offices are concentrating upon the far wider problems that this dispute has brought into the limelight.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The Governor of Iowa is going to deliver personally the pig he lost to the Governor of Minnesota on the Iowa Minnesota football game today.

IT was not possible, at the time it opened, to write in much detail about the Carnegie International at Pittsburgh. Nor will there today be room for more than a bit of critical comment on the American section.

George Hiram Mann, the resurgent Republican, who in September won a 25-year fight to get Congress to pay overtime wages to 1,377 Navy Yard workers, to whom they had been due for more than fifty years, came out yesterday with a new idea.

ROME, Nov. 9. -- As the northern Italian Army in Ethiopia consolidated its position at Makale, military experts here predicted tonight the Fascist troops might meet their first serious resistance at Amba Alaji, forty miles south of Makale.

Bids totaling more than $1,000,000 for grading and paving in the Grand Central Parkway Extension, which forms the western border of the projected World's Fair site on the Flushing meadows, were opened yesterday by the State Department of Labor.

Village life in the early Nineteen Hundreds is as remote from today, measured in the familiar terms of everyday living, as that of the Victorian years. The idea of an automobile ride being given as a special treat would be received with a slight sense of shock, if not as a farcical joke, by the average child of the Nineteen Thirties, but such a treat was the climax to the celebration of Edith's seventh birthday.

Congress cannot be permitted to give "blank checks" representing the delegation of its authority to the President of the United States, according to a statement by W.T. Halliday, president of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio.

IT is the seventeenth memorial of the first day of Armistice which brought peace to a warring world. Once again in a two minutes' silence millions of men and women -- hundreds of million -- will remember their dead and all the agony and the ruin of those war years.

MASSAWA, Eritrea. -- The Italian troopship Gange left Naples at 7 in the evening with the comparatively light contingent of about 1,200 men and 110 officers. At Messina, the next day, some 800 more men and fifty more officers were taken aboard, not to mention three mules, a half dozen tanks and a supply of other material.

After some twenty-odd years of participation in the doings of the street called Broadway, I left five years ago for the so-called pastures of Hollywood. I returned, after those five years, hungry for the theatre, starved for the word spoken on the stage.

CONSTRUCTION of the giant Bonneville Dam has made necessary difficult and far-reaching changes in one of the nation's most spectacular avenues of automobile travel -- the Columbia River Highway in Oregon. The New Deal's vast power and navigation project, now being built in the heart of the Columbia River gorge, will raise the water level of the swift-surging stream.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9. -- A Pittsburgh machine that has been backfiring and spluttering badly for the last three weeks was in perfect running order today and, as a result, the Army eleven, unbeaten until a week ago, was steam-rollered in the Pitt Stadium.

MORRIS MARKEY could easily qualify as New York's No. 1 guide. For more than ten years it has been his job to report on the town for The New Yorker. Most of the Reporter at Large pieces in that magazine have been his.

Archbishop Leopoldo Ruiz y Flores, Apostolic Delegate to Mexico, in a letter received here yesterday, said that President Lazaro Cardenas had "lost a new chance for restoring peace in Mexico." The letter, mailed from San Antonio, Texas, where the Apostolic Delegate is in exile, was released through The Associated Press here.

THE long chronicle, rich and detailed, suits Mrs. Barnes's particular talents. In many respects "Edna His Wife" is the best of her books -- better, certainly, than its immediate forerunners; as good as "Years of Grace," if distinctly less glamorous.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 9. -- The degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred this morning by the trustees of Amherst College upon Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Dr. Laurens H. Seelye, '11, new president of St. Lawrence University.

HOW long can Italy hold out? With sanctions or without, how soon will she reach the end of her fast-diminishing resources? Months before the League of Nations moved to impose a boycott on Italian exports and imports the outside world was mystified as to how a nation poor in money and raw materials, drained by vast expenditures for public works undertaken to fight depression, could possibly meet the cost of a war of expansion.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH a revival in independent production, the leasing lots -- institutions unknown to the outside world -- are experiencing the most gratifying boom since the wild, glad days of early sound. Again the "million-dollar front" is in demand.

The Evander Childs and St. Francis Prep football teams were victorious in the schoolboy doubleheader played before 3,000 yesterday at Dyckman Oval. The former was hard pressed before downing Seward Park, 18 -- 7, in the opener, while St. Francis conquered Theodore Roosevelt, 6 -- 0, in the hard fought afterpiece.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Alert to capitalize on every break, Princeton today crushed Harvard by supplementing its own destructive power along the ground with a dazzling pass attack and forcing the Crimson into damaging errors.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- While Britain and Italy remain in a state of armed watchfulness in the Mediterranean, unable to agree on a mutual reduction of their naval and military forces, the impression grows in Italy that Premier Benito Mussolini's most formidable adversary is neither the Ethiopian Army nor Ethiopian terrain, but Britain.

PRAGUE, Nov. 9. -- The case of an unemployed Viennese, Alfred Joellinger, is cited by the Austrian Social Democrats' foreign bureau here as an example of the extreme powers of punishment conferred on the police by the Austrian dictatorship and of the fact that a man can now be punished five times for one offense.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, tonight pledged himself and his government -- as impressively as in his speech at Geneva in September -- "to carry out our obligations, wherever they exist, and to strive for peace, wherever peace is threatened."

ROME, Nov. 9. -- There is a widespread impression throughout Italy that Britain is putting up a show of very great intransigence at the present moment, not because she has any real hope of keeping the Italians out of Ethiopia but because she is planning to use the East African situation as a lever to wrest concessions from Italy in the Mediterranean.

STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 9. -- Alton T. Peterson, 27, of Hampden, Neb., a cadet at the Army Flying School at Langley Field, died of injuries in Bridgeport Hospital tonight after an army pursuit plane he was flying crashed in the Paradise Green section near the centre of this town this afternoon.

WE are always being told that the golden age of conversation lies far behind us, that the salon belongs to history, that the impact of literary, artistic, critical minds upon each other has descended to mere log-rolling in our day.

THE brooding and mysterious East infuses the richly glowing still-lifes of Hovsep Pushman, who is having his first show in several years at the Grand Central Fifth Avenue. Galleries (through Nov. 16). If his subject matter changes little from year to year, there is no monotony in these beautiful arrangements of orientalia -- figurines, jade, brocade.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (AP). -- A long, daring pass, thrown in desperation as a gray dusk settled over the gridiron and covered waning hopes, sailed over the goal line into the arms of a substitute here today and brought Indiana a 13-to-7 inter-sectional football victory over Maryland.
RECENT rains having moistened the soil, which is still warm, gardeners are taking advantage of unusually favorable conditions for late planting. A great variety of plants may still be set out.

Red Cross flags fluttered from hotels, office buildings, churches and other structures in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday in anticipation of the New York Chapter's annual roll-call which starts tomorrow and continues until Thanksgiving. Efforts will be made to raise $400,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 9. -- Pupils of the Indiana State School for the Blind in the near future will explore -- by touch -- the mysteries of botany in what school officials believe may be one of the first, if not the first, Braille garden in the country. Inscriptions in Braille will mark each plant.

GATES W. McGARRAH is known in Wall Street as a stern fighter and a man whose reputation is above reproach. He is a banker of the old school which dealt in commercial paper and not in the underwriting of securities.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 9 (AP). -- The body of Corinna Loring, 26, who vanished Monday, two days before the day set for her wedding, was found today in a clump of pines and grass about five blocks from her home at Mount Rainier, Md.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- An optimistic report on the condition of farmers, based on excellent showings in the repayment of borrowings from government agencies, was given to President Roosevelt today by W.I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Nov. 9. -- Via perhaps as thrilling a rally as has been staged on any prep school gridiron this Fall, Mercersburg Academy's well-drilled and wide-awake football team closed its campaign in a blaze of glory today with a well earned 14-13 triumph over Kiskiminetas.

American Education Week will be observed on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday throughout the country. Locally, the observance is known as Open School Week and its purpose is to acquaint the public with the work of the schools, their ideals achievements and needs.

According to a custom of the last several years the Montclair Junior League will present a play for children at Mount Hebron School auditorium on Saturday morning. This year's entertainment, "The Magic Sword," was written by a league member, Mrs. Kerby Fisk, who is also chairman of the production, with Miss Esther Mount as assistant chairman and stage manager.

London, Oct. 17. IT has been a week of tolerably good entertainment and indifferent art.
