James Bridie began it with "The Black Eye," which he calls "a novelette in dialogue," a highly immoral tale of a young hero who would not be bothered to pass his examinations but saved his family from bankruptcy by playing roulette with a professional rogue and putting the capital thus acquired on a rank outsider.

ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 9. -- In discussions intended to determine whether Greece's government under King George is to be affected by British or Italian interests in the Mediterranean, the Ministers of both powers are conferring with chief royalist leaders in advance of the King's arrival.

ANNIVERSARIES: In a bitter moment, seventeen years ago today, the Emperor of Germany slipped across his country's border into Holland. On the following day came the Armistice. For the vast majority of the defeated Germans Kaiser Wilhelm II had died with his flight; his glib postures, his pomposity, his vanity, were memories of the past.

MILLIONS of men and women play contract bridge, but only a few hundred qualify as "experts" and compete regularly in national tournaments. Many of this small group play as much as eight hours a day, and one wonders where, or if, they find the time to earn a livelihood.

With the formal abandonment of the silver standard by China last week the silver policy of the United States reached a climax. The episode gives promise of becoming a unique example of poetic justice in the world of international monetary affairs.

BOSTON. TWO new overpasses to cost $1,000,000, authorized by the State Department of Public Works, will be constructed next Spring at Brookline Village and at the Arborway and Huntington Avenue to bring the Worcester super-highway directly into the city without interference from local traffic.

A large committee of debutantes has just been organized for the Tropical Ball to be given on Dec. 12 in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House, one of the city's oldest philanthropic institutions.
SCHENECTADY. N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Union College, in a series of effective aerial plays, defeated Rochester University today, 13 to 12, in the thirty-second game of the t6-year- old rivalry.

Herein the indefatigable William Colt MacDonald chronicles another amazing exploit (the sixth in the series, if memory does not falter) of his celebrated "Three Mesquiteers," Tucson Smith, Stony Brooke and Lullaby Joslin -- that trio of irrepressible, fast-drawing trouble-shooters of the Southwest border country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The first group of applications filed by motor truck and bus companies under the amended Transportation Act was received today from fourteen companies at the offices of the Interstate Commerce Commission. The addresses of the applicants and the character of the service they perform follow:

RETAIL trade continued to suffer from unseasonably warm weather in many sections of the country last week. The Midwest apparently overcame this handicap to some extent under the influence of higher employment in industrial centres.

AFTER many years of close interest in the hubbub of Broadway, Hollywood has begun this Autumn to finance plays on a large scale. "Movie money" has stood hopefully back of about a third of the new productions of the current season.

EINDHOVEN, The Netherlands, Nov. 9. -- Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, titleholder, and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, challenger, today played the seventeenth game of their match for the chess championship of the world at the Philips Chess Club in this city.

American youth, although faced with unemployment and uncertainty, "neither understands nor desires" sympathy from an older generation and is better able to meet present conditions than its elders, in the opinion of Henry P. Van Dusen, dean of students at Union Theological Seminary.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Seven of this city's better-known night, clubs were raided simultaneously early today by State Liquor Board and Federal agents, who arrested 124 persons.

The New Jersey Zinc Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $3,342,216 after taxes, depreciation, depletion, contingencies and other charges. This profit is equivalent to $1.70 a share on 1,963,264 shares of $25-par stock.

A full roster of 200 subscribers for the season's program of the Montclair Member Society of the Chamber Music Society of America is forecast by the committee handling the subscriptions, just prior to the opening event on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- In a vigorous defense of its crop control policies, under fire because of recent advances in food prices, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today called attention to the fact that most major articles of food were selling in September for considerably less than in September, 1929, before the stock market crash.

SAN FRANCISCO. THE lowest death toll from automobile and traffic accidents in seven years! San Francisco points proudly to this record for the fiscal year ended July 1, and has now set about to better this achievement for the coming year.

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- A 54-yard march early in the fourth period, which culminated in Bob Grossman scoring from the 6-yard line gave Rutgers University a 12-to-6 decision over Boston University at Fenway Park today. A crowd of 5,000 saw the hard-fought battle.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 9. -- The cost of an education has been reduced to a minimum for a select group of co-eds at Ohio State University this year.

The thirty-sixth national automobile show, which has been running at Grand Central Palace since Nov. 2, closed last night at 11 o'clock, and those most closely associated with its management expressed themselves as more than satisfied with the venture of advancing the date from the customary January to November.

LIKE a butterfly brilliantly bursting from its cocoon, the social season is breaking forth from the somber restraints of the past years in a rhapsody of warm colors and rich fabrics. Restaurants, night clubs, theatres are filled with women who are more than well-dressed; who, indeed, are wearing exceptionally handsome clothes.

Over on Lexington Avenue there is a good deal of magic and legerdemain being put to practice in the office and blue-plint room of Ira Hand, secretary these many years of the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers and general manager of the National Motor Boat Show.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Two powerful lines pounded away at each other throughout four strenuous periods of hard, straight football and in the end were content to limp off the field on even terms as Peddie and Blair battled to a 6-6 tie today.
Curtis High School's undefeated and untied football team maintained its proud record by scoring an impressive 21-7 victory yesterday over New Utrecht High at Thompson's Stadium, S.I.

IN addition to its fascinating qualities as entertainment, "The New Gulliver" should forever end the popular American belief that the Russians are somber fellows, whose merriment takes the form of sardonic laughter over the ironies of life.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A swift series of dramatic episodes, portraying the various fields of relief work accomplished by the American Red Cross, was broadcast by radio tonight over a nation-wide network as part of the annual Red Cross roll-call.

The Harlem Market, at First Avenue and 107th Street, constitutes a dangerous fire hazard, Fire Commissioner McElligott reported yesterday to Mayor La Guardia. The report followed an investigation of the market which revealed violations in many of the buildings, some of them old-law tenements, which house the 111 mercantile establishments in the market.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 9. -- An im portant aggressive movement by Ethiopian troops was reported tonight. Ethiopian troops were stated to have attempted enveloping operations on the western end of the northern front, planning to invade Eritrea through the Walkait district in Northern Ethiopia.

THE fine, enduring qualities of oak furniture are best appreciated in settings decoratively in accord with early Jacobean days, when craftsmanship in oak reached its highest point. During that era paneled oak walls, leaded glass casements, plaster-ornamented ceilings and tapestry hangings all furnished a background of elegance which both softened and enhanced the sturdiness of well-made oak pieces.

For the second successive time Manhattan's improving football team enjoyed a touchdown parade yesterday. Supplementing a powerful running game with a dazzling aerial attack, the Jaspers rolled up eight touchdowns and six extra points against La Salle College at Ebbets Field in registering a 54-to-13 victory.

A greatly accelerated trend toward private brands and the production of merchandise on exclusive specifications and prices mutually agreed upon between retailer and manufacturer was predicted in retail circles yesterday should legislation be enacted by the next session of Congress along the lines of the bill sponsored by Representative Patman to control large-scale purchasing.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 9. -- A nose on the post decided the Riggs Handicap before 15,000 persons at Pimlico today as Selby L. Burch became the first double winner of the stake when his Mars gelding, Thursday, just got up to triumph.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 9. -- Notre Dame's new wonder team of football, perched on the highest peak since the days of its immortal Knute Rockne, fell into the ruin of an almost unbelievable 14-to-7 defeat today.

JANE AUSTEN, spinster of Steventon and anonymous author of half a dozen novels, did not care overmuch for the theatre. Her infrequent visits, recorded in letters to her sister and nieces, left her somewhat less than overwhelmed by the surge and ebb of the drama.

ATHENS, Nov. 8. -- The forcible change from a republic to a monarchy, engineered by Marshal George Kondylis against the will of a large percentage of the Greek people, has awakened general misgiving, complicated by the unofficial alliance with Great Britain to which it binds Greece at this time of Mediterranean unrest.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Nov. 9. -- The dismissal of a Finnish-born Bolshevist leader, Edward Gylling, from the post of Premier of the Karelian Autonomous Soviet Republic after a tenure of eleven years and his subsequent deportation have attracted much attention in Northern European countries.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 9 (AP). -- A fake spinner worked a score of times, mixed with well-placed passes, gave the University of Georgia Bulldogs a 26-to-13 victory over Tulane's Green Wave today before a crowd of 12,000 fans.

Members of the younger set, headed by Miss Beatrice Butler, will assist at the annual Christmas sale for the benefit of Hope Farm which will take place on Wednesday and Thursday at the Savoy-Plaza. Tea will be served both afternoons by Mrs. Henry R. Labouisse Jr. and Miss Susan V. Ord.

TWO hundred thousand feet of film, much of it specked by age or buckled from disuse, has been stored safely somewhere in the Bronx as the celluloid five-foot shelf of the Museum of Modern Art Film Library. The imposing pile -- it already fills one vault -- represents the first four months' work of the museum's curator and staff.

There is a story about a befuddled judge who, intending to sentence a convicted man to "not less than three nor more than five" years in prison, inadvertently sentenced him to "not less than five nor more than three." In effect that is what has been happening in New York State for some time.

A three-hour argument over details connected with the sale of a window-cleaning business ended abruptly last night in a lawyer's office in the Brownsville district of Brooklyn when four young gunmen invaded the office, took from four of the lawyer's clients $2,261, including half the down payment of the window-cleaning business, and escaped after cutting the telephone wires.

MADRID, Nov. 8. -- A coalition of Liberal, Centre and Conservative Right forces, necessary for a strong Parliamentary majority, has just survived what is known as a gambling scandal, and thereby once more a dissolution of the Spanish Cortes, so ardently desired by the government's opposition, has been avoided.
RUTLAND, Vt., Nov. 9. -- To consider paramount issues in the nation today, 600 Young Republicans of New England opened a two-day conference here today.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Mrs. R. Clifford Black of this place will open her home on Thursday for a reception and tea sponsored by the Pelham committee of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Miss Susanne Fisher, soprano, who will make her debut at the Metropolitan Opera this season, will sing.

A field goal by Captain Bill Hutchinson enabled the James Monroe High football team to preserve its unbeaten record against George Washington, a traditional rival, in their eleventh annual meeting yesterday at Monroe Field. A crowd of 11,000 saw the Crimson and Gold squad register a 9-to-7 victory to gain an edge in the series, 6 -- 5.

WHILE the Metropolitan Opera management has announced a number of revivals -- "Norma" with Flagstad, "Carmen" with Ponselle, "Rondine" with Bori, "Gianni Schicchi" with Tibbett, in English; and "La Juive" with Martinelli and Rethberg or Lawrence -- no definite date has been set for any of them.

The forty-sixth annual exhibition of American paintings and sculpture at the Art Institute of Chicago will remain on view until Dec. 8. The exhibition contains 235 paintings and 49 pieces of sculpture.

Although election day trade showed improved consumer response, sales volume for the week in the metropolitan area continued to be adversely affected by weather conditions. Estimates indicated that, on the average, department-store trade in the metropolitan area is running about even with the same period a year ago, although several establishments are achieving comparative increases.

ONE first sees Beany-eye on a bitterly cold evening. He is working in a gravel pit. The thin shirt sticks to his muscles and the sweat trickles from beneath his black bowler. He stabs the hill of gravel with a shovel as if he were fighting with a bayonet.

Custom plays an important part in the development of business procedure. The tendency to do what the majority does, in the conduct of business, sometimes obscures substantial benefits which could be obtained by a departure from the customary.

Informed observers see the lines forming for a contest of strength between the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Van Sweringen interests as a result of the situation created by the Midamerica Corporation buying control of the Alleghany Corporation at a creditors' sale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Ending of high prices for pork to the consumer was made an aim of the administration's farm policy today in the first of a series of modifications in AAA crop programs, designed to lower the cost of foods. The farm administration announced its intention to accept recommendations from its corn-hog program conference intended to bring this result.

IN view of the fact that Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, advocated in an address on national planning a through transcontinental highway, members of the Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce, which first uged the construction of such a road, have not despaired that it may still be placed upon the public works program.

THIS book by the Associate Professor of English in the University of Oregon purposes to show whoever studies it how to make himself master of a wide vocabulary and how to keep that vocabulary under ready and sure command. Examination of the work makes evident Mr. Smith's excellent equipment for the task he has set himself.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Navy took advantage of two golden opportunities today, converted them into touchdowns, and defeated the strong Pennsylvania eleven, 13 to 0.

I read with interest the article, "The Old Spanish Trail," by James P. Welsh, in your issue of Oct. 27, but found some discrepancies. Writing of his visit to Mobile, Ala., Mr. Welsh refers to "its Magnolia Cemetery, in which Braxton Bragg and Father Abraham Ryan sleep side by side, the rippling Stars and Bars above them."

BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- With German unemployment figures rising again, Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, the Finance Minister, in a speech at Frankfort yesterday, sounded a new appeal to the world to open its doors to German exports and to allot to Germany some colonies which could provide her needed raw materials.

Austin H. Montgomery, former stock broker and ex-convict who was arrested two weeks ago in Rochester, will be arraigned on Tuesday in the Federal Court here before Judge Francis G. Caffey to plead to an indictment charging use of the mails to defraud.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Nov. 10.'Nearly 2,000 Japanese marines marched into the demilitarized part of Shanghai today after the slaying of one of their comrades. Bayonets fixed, a battalion was mobilized from three Japanese warships in the harbor and hurriedly sent into the native qtarter where the slaying took place.

An address by Raymond Moley, editor of the magazine Today, will feature the second of a planned series of monthly luncheons to be held under the auspices of the Association of Buying Offices and New York retailers on Tuesday, Nov. 26, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Passage of Federal legislation for the control of the sale of drugs and cosmetics at the coming session of Congress appeared more likely yesterday as manufacturers and distributers here decided to throw their weight behind such a law in an effort to avoid local control.

By quick and forceful action Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, expects within a short time to banish from New York County an evil which has been increasing greatly not only here but throughout the country -- the making of small personal loans at usurious rates of interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Considerable interest has been aroused by the fact that the St. Louis Southwestern Railroad (Cotton Belt) has asked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a ninety-day extension of its $17,882,250 loan, falling due on Dec. 1, especially since such indulgence has been requested for interest as well as principal.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 9. -- The Swarthmore program of faculty-directed extracurricular work in creative activities has gained added impetus, with five groups reporting membership lists totaling 328 names this Fall. Although this includes some duplication, such a turnout is considered notable in a student body of 650.

Encouraged by the exceptionally good demand experienced at earlier trade events, manufacturers displaying new Spring lines at the furniture trade show opening here tomorrow will impose price advances averaging 5 per cent on practically all types of furniture.

To young John Thomas Kennedy of Brooklyn, Ireland is a very nice country indeed, but he frankly prefers living in the United States, even after passing several full weeks in Dublin and other Irish cities as a feted guest. He said so yesterday when he returned on the United States liner President Harding and went back home to 266 Forty-ninth Street.

A fickle fate that handed St. Mary's the game early in the second period intervened to save Fordham's embattled football team from defeat through a goal-line fumble in the closing quarter yesterday as the intersectional rivals battled to a 7-7 tie before 45,000 wrought-up spectators at the Polo Grounds.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 9 (AP). -- Wisconsin's victory starved Badgers shook off the memory of five straight defeats to register an 8 to 0 decision over Purdue today in one of the major upsets of the Western Conference football season.

The net results of the American silver policy so far have been something like this: (1) American silver producers are much better off, at least for the present. (2) Foreign holders of silver have been able to unload their stocks on an obliging American Government at prices more than twice as high as they were able to get before our Government's buying policy began.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra, headed by Hans Lange, and the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Antonia Brico, begin their seasons this week. The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Klemperer, will present Bruckner's Eighth symphony.

THIS is not merely a book that grips the attention. It is a book of the moment. The Italian mind is inspired by that peculiar mesmerism by ultimates which we call genius. Mazzini was a genius as patriot. He is the mirror in which we can envisage another genius of patriotism, Mussolini -- the other way round.
BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- Retail trade in the First Federal Reserve District continues to be affected adversely by unseasonably warm weather, although the week's performance was better than the week before.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 9. -- Holding the University of Baltimore scoreless while tallying four touchdowns, Herb McCracken's Lafayette eleven registered its second victory of the season today by the score of 26 -- 0. Tommy Bennett, a junior of Dumont, N.J., led the scoring with a pair of touchdowns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- With the administration still short of the half-way mark in its drive to provide 3,500,000 jobs, figures made public today showed it must double its recently accelerated work relief pace to meet the Dec. 1 goal.

MANILA, -- With the inauguration on Nov. 15 of the Philippine Commonwealth Government the United States carries one step further its experiment in controlled autonomy for the Filipinos. The fanfare of trumpets planned for this ceremony has led many persons to the belief that this marks the inauguration of Philippine independence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- It is a wise saying, applicable to more things than storms and storm tracks, that the average is something that rarely happens. In books on meteorology one finds descriptions of the "typical" West India hurricane and charts showing the "typical" tracks of these disturbances.

With Vice Admiral Sir Mathew Best, commander of the British West Indies Squadron, and Lady Best as their guests of honor, the British Great War Veterans of America will give their fifteenth annual Armistice Ball tomorrow night at the Hotel Astor.

An infrequently exploited, scarcely glorious epoch in American history -- the Mexican War and our simultaneous conquest of vast territory in the Southwest -- provides the plot, action and characters of this picturesque tale with a plentitude of strenuous things to do.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, Sunday, Nov. 10 -- An Indian Ocean monsoon was feared tonight to have brought death to Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith, noted Australian aviator, and his co-pilot, Tom Pethybridge. Nearly two days have passed since their plane disappeared.

Efforts on the part of manufacturers in two branches of the coat-and-suit industry to avert destructive competition during the coming Spring, through adoption of definite programs of intensive collaboration, will take tangible form this week, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., reported yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- There is no longer the slightest doubt that Princeton has one of the best football teams of the year.

THE reorganization of Twentieth Century-Fox has been completed. The captains and the kings of the old concern have departed, the new group is functioning in machine-like fashion and the studio has settled down to the exciting routine of making pictures.

PHILADELPHIA. LACK of municipal funds and unwillingness of city officials to borrow from the Federal Government have prevented the adoption of an extensive measures this year to improve the traffic situation.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 9. -- A Williams juggernaut that scored almost at will rolled over Wesleyan today, 41 to 0. The Eplimen, using straight line plays, gained a total of 262 yards.

Concerts to be given by symphony orchestras, bands and chamber music and choral groups for 118 community centres in Greater New York under the Federal Music Project will be restricted to members of such centres, according to an announcement yesterday by George Crandall, head of the concert division of the project.

TORONTO, Nov. 8. -- Canadian Malartic Gold Mines, Ltd., reports a profit of $50,398 for the three months ended on Sept. 30, before allowing for taxes, depreciation or deferred development, against a profit for the first three full months of operation, May, June and July, of $30,535.

The second Russian naval ball under the auspices of the Association of Former Imperial Naval Officers will be held on Friday night at the Plaza. The event will be in commemoration of the ball given here sixty-four years ago for the Grand Duke Alexis and his retinue during his visit to the United States.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- One-third of the members of the undergraduate body of Princeton University were registered with the Bureau of Student Employment and attempted to earn part or all of their college expenses during the last academic year, according to the annual report issued here today by Richard W. Warfield, director of the bureau.

IT would be misleading and unfair not to distinguish between Mr. Schneider's autobiographical novel, for all its second-rate quality, and many another novel, infinitely more finished and bearing all the usual niceties, but trivial and furnished with secondhand feelings and ideas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A subpoena was issued today by the Board of Tax Appeals for Mrs. Martin L. Davey, wife of the Governor of Ohio, to appear at a hearing Wednesday before the board in the tax case of the Davey Tree Expert Company of Kent, Ohio.

DETROIT. LACK of sufficient funds has necessitated deferring to another year some of the many projects considered earlier in the year toward the improvement of traffic and accident conditions in Detroit and vicinity.

LOWELL, Mass., Nov, 9. -- Filling the air with passes in one of the most spectacular exhibitions ever witnessed on the Textile gridiron, Lowell Textile today defeated Brooklyn College, 25 to 7. Athanas and Cavaney starred as a scoring combination, the former registering three touchdowns and his teammate one.

HOW many of the hundreds of thousands of American students who gathered last Friday in an impressive "mobilization" for peace would really "refuse to support the Government of the United States in any war it might undertake" as suggested in the call to the assembly?

A BURNING building yields swift drama, full of sound and fury. The fireman becomes the man of the moment. Quiet streets succumb suddenly to the crescendo of screaming sirens, the staccato of gongs, the rapid thudding of booted feet, the shouts and murmurs of an excited throng gathering quickly from nowhere.

Pianism highly commendable for its thoughtfulness and intelligent approach was displayed by Henriette Michelson at her Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. Miss Michelson, a member of the faculty of the Institute of Musical Art, played with the assurance and conviction gained from previous appearances here, the last of which was made a season ago in an all-Beethoven program.

It will be sixty-eight years next month since Charles T. Harvey, wearing a silk hat, a beard and an expression of invincible determination, climbed to the top of the half-mile stretch of elevated railroad he had built in lower Greenwich Street, took his seat in a kind of glorified hand-car, hooked the car to a running cable and made the first successful demonstration of rapid transit in New York City.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9. -- Clear, frosty weather in California during the past week has stimulated retail trade, particularly in Winter wearing apparel. A noticeable increase in home appliances, such as heating units, was also reported.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 9. -- Amherst defeated Swarthmore, 40 -- 6, this afternoon before 4,000, which included many alumni back for the fraternity initiation week-end festivities.

This week's program for the Garden City-Hempstead Community Club schedules meetings for four days, beginning with that of the garden department tomorrow afternoon in the Casino, when Mrs. Stephen Pell will give an illustrated talk on Kings Garden and Fort Ticonderoga.

A record-breaking performance by Thomas McDermott, all-around swimming star of George Washington High, was the highlight of the third series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior team championship of the P.S.A.L., conducted yesterday in the 75-foot pool of De Witt Clinton High School.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 9. -- Minnesota's mighty football force, stalled for thirty minutes by a furious Iowa offensive, let loose a crushing countercharge in the second half today to whip the Hawkeyes, 13 to 6, in their battle for the Western Conference leadership.

MANILA, Nov. 9. -- The question of what exactly remains of American sovereignty over the Philippines is still unsolved, since Secretary of War George H. Dern is vigorously noncommittal. The bigger issue at the moment, curiously, centres upon what ostensibly is the most minor matter -- namely, what salute should be given Manuel Quezon, President-elect, upon his inauguration.

IT seems a long time ago that, after considerable advance talk about Finnish governmental subsidies, dickering with the composer, his insistence that the late Dr. Kajanus be employed and a bo@t of other petty detail, arrangements to make the first recordings of the symphonies of Sibelius were completed and Columbia finally issued the First and Second played by an anonymous orchestra.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 8. -- With the presentation to President Roosevelt by Amine Youssef on Oct. 29 of letters of credence as the Minister of Egypt to the United States there was opened what promises to be a new chapter in the relations of the two countries, owing to the vigorous personality and progressive views of the new envoy, who, in practical ways, intends to cultivate closer and more extensive ties than have hitherto existed.
Another active session on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried all months above the 11-cent level, prices ending at net gains of 7 to 10 points.

OUT here in India things are beginning to take shape for the production of "Elephant Boy." It has been a good number of weeks since Alexander Korda sent us off from London, but the delay in getting started was, I think, well worth it.

NOW that the "peace garden" established upon the boundary line between Canada and the United States has progressed to a point where much of the actual construction has been accomplished, it is receiving an ever growing amount of attention.

Murtha Lawrence of Brooklyn Prep outran a starting field of 140 schoolboy harriers to win premier honors, while his school took the team title for the second straight year in the annual private schools' cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

BREMEN, Nov. 9. -- While the sixteen dead of the National Socialist putsch of 1923 were being honored in Munich today a State funeral was held here for Sergeant August Sahlbusch, described as a member of the irregular corps "who in Germany's dire distress fought for Germany's honor and freedom."

Commodity futures declined slightly on the local Exchanges yesterday in a small volume of trading. Numerous staples were entirely inactive during the half-day session. On the cash markets there was an advance in cotton but no other changes.

GRADUALLY the campaigns of local travel companies, aided in recent months by the frowns across European frontiers, are turning the American tourist to the Americas. Here, indeed, lie treasures not only of physical beauty but of spiritual loveliness.

MILAN, Oct. 15, 1935. THE publication of the full bill now promises a more interesting season at La Scala than was at first feared. Besides the absolute novelty of Wolf-Ferrari's opera "Il Campiello," there will be the Italian premiere of Strauss's "Silent Woman," and as local novelties, Pizzetti's "Orseole," Allegra's "Ave Maria" and Zandonai's "Farsa Amorosa."

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Nov. 10. -- Shanghai was plunged suddenly into a state of tension last night comparable to that immediately preceding the outbreak of hostilities in January, 1932. By midnight the borders of the International Settlement and Chapei were ominously guarded by armed forces of the international police and Japanese marines on one side and Chinese police and gendarmes on the other.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 8 -- Only two years ago at this time the AAA, with the cooperation of its farm belt advisers, had just completed the purchase and premature slaughter of 6,000,000 little pigs, mostly for tankage, and was devising a control contract to pay the farmer a premium for breeding fewer hogs.

NORWOOD, Mass., Nov. 9 (AP). -- Eleven persons, including three Brooklyn (N.Y.) women, were injured as four automobiles collided here today. The Brooklyn women, suffering serious injuries, and three others were taken to Norwood Hospital.

Veteran army balloon officers of the World War took steps last night at their annual meeting and dinner at the Hotel Montclair to make their experience in aerial observation available to the general staff and the Air Corps. They adopted resolutions, proposed by Captain Ashley B. McKinley, president of their association and photographer with the first Byrd Antarctic Expedition, to this end.

In furtherance of a campaign to standardize styles and steps, to the end that ballroom partners may avoid the awkwardness of trying to dance together in different modes, the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at its meeting in the Hotel Astor this morning will hold a forum for the discussion of ballroom dancing as seen in the metropolitan district.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The Bucknell eleven was routed by the overhead and running attack of the University of Detroit today, 53 to 0, before a homecoming day crowd of 12,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 8. -- The Potato Control Act goes into effect on Dec. 1, and at a conference here this week attended by potato growers from all New England and some adjacent States, the triple A representatives from Washington discussed certain modifications of the act which will be sought at the next session of Congress.

Undisclosed British interests have obtained the sanction of the British Exchequer for the repatriation of all, or the greater part of, the holdings of Radio Corporation of America in Electric and Musical Industries Company, Ltd., according to foreign dispatches yesterday.

GRADUATE managers are leaning back contentedly these Autumn days -- football is drawing the old crowds. Hundreds of thousands of men, women, children -- especially students and alumni -- are jammed together around the gridirons these Saturday afternoons; gate receipts are improving.

In a striking setting of yellow and black -- colors of the National Horse Show Association -- the annual Horse Show Ball will be held tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. FOLLOWING the close of the National Automobile Show in New York, which signaled the opening of numerous shows in other cities, leaders of the industry are putting forth cooperative efforts to divert at least a portion of the nation's buying power from Spring to the Autumn and Winter seasons.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, Sunday, Nov. 10. -- Royal Air Force flying boats operating from Victoria Point searched all yesterday afternoon for Air Commodore Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith and Tom Pethybridge, who disappeared while flying over the Indian Ocean Friday in an attempt to set a new England-Australia record.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP). -- A thoroughgoing study of all applications for Federal aid in setting up municipal power plants was being pursued today by officials of the Public Works Administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public a further list of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities markets who have registered.

ATLANTA, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Controller of the Currency J.F.T. O'Connor said today the "man on the street" was entitled to the protection afforded by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

A tea dance will he given on Friday at the Delmonico for members of the junior and debutante committees of the fourth annual Miami Biltmore fashion show and supper dance which will be held on Nov. 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The young women in these groups will be among the manikins appearing in the elaborate fashion show to feature the dance.

Emphasizing the development of new uses and products this year, the paper industry is now running about 15 per cent ahead of last year and production has rebounded to 75 per cent of capacity, according to a survey here yesterday. When it is considered that the peak of 84 per cent was reached in 1920 and that the 1929 figure was only 82 per cent, the current showing is regarded as very encouraging.

OTTAWA, Nov. 8. -- High-tariff Canadians and that now over-whelming majority of the Dominion's citizens who would like to return to lower duties alike will await with unfeigned interest the outcome of Prime Minister King's conversation with President Roosevelt.

CARLISLE, Pa., Nov. 9. -- "During thirty active years in the financial district of New York, I haven't been able to pick out the college men," said Paul Appenzellar of Bronxville, N.Y., former member of the New York Stock Exchange, in an address before the Homecoming Assembly of Dickinson College this morning.

Directors of the Chicago Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 60 cents on accumulations and a quarterly dividend of 40 cents on the preferred stock. WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 9. -- Holy Cross, unbeaten this season, kept its record clean today by defeating the Carnegie Tech eleven, 7 to 0. It was the first meeting of the institutions on the football field.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 9 (AP). -- The fighting Illini wrecked whatever Western Conference gridiron title hopes Michigan may have entertained by whipping the Wolverines, 3 to 0, in rain-swept Memorial Stadium today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9. -- Yale University aided 1,205 students in the past year by $612,223 in fellowships, scholarships and loans, exclusive of grants for research to holders of advanced degrees, according to the annual report of Albert B. Crawford, director of the department of personnel study.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 9. -- The University of Nebraska regained the Big Six Conference football championship today, defeating Kansas, 19 to 13, in a dizzy, delirious game which had 29,000 spectators on edge from start to finish.

ST. LOUIS. AN ambitious safety program has been in effect here for several months with a view to decreasing traffic accidents and promoting safety, enhanced by a sustained drive by St. Louis police against intoxicated drivers and speeders which has resulted in the arrest of thousands in the past few months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The Public Works Administration said today it had received no protests against the use of German sheet steel piling for the Queens approach to the Triborough Bridge in New York City.

BALTIMORE. NEARLY $5,000,000 is being spent by Baltimore and the State of Maryland for the elimination of traffic hazards and improved roads contiguous to the city. Some of the work is being done with the aid of Federal funds, but most of the financial cost is being underwritten by the city and State governments.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 9. -- Although the Ethiopian Government is without direct word from the fronts as yet, the highest government spokesmen readily admit that Makale and Gorahai probably are in the hands of the Italians. KENT, Conn., Nov. 9. -- Striking back with a fiery attack in the second half after being outrushed in the opening portion of the game, Kent School's plucky football team handed Choate School a 7-0 setback in the twenty-sixth annual clash between the traditional foes on Alumni Field today.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 8. -- Political interest in Kansas during the last week has centred around the attitude of relief agencies in Washington toward the Republican administration in this State and the possible connection between the blossoming candidacy of Governor AIf M. Landon for the Republican Presidential nomination and a scathing attack which Harry L. Hopkins, national Emergency Relief Administrator, has made on the Landon record.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. -- Crow is on the table in Philadelphia this week after the Mayoralty election, but jubilant Republicans are having a hard time forcing the Democrats to eat it. Democratic leaders refuse to admit that this city rebuked the New Deal by electing City Controller S. Davis Wilson, Republican, to the Mayoralty instead of John B. Kelly, Democrat.

Missenden, manager of Docks and Marine at Southampton, who sailed for England yesterday morning in the Cunard-White Star liner Aquitania after making a 7,000-mile inspection tour by rail through the United States.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 9. -- The Smith College Museum of Art has added several works to its permanent collection. The acquisitions, which have been on exhibit at the Tryon Art Gallery throughout the Fall, include a landscape by Eilshemius, a colage or abstraction by Cesar Domela, a marble by Lachaise, an Aztec head of a death god, and a portrait of E. The local WPA will be able to continue its work relief projects until April 1 with the additional $33,800,108 allotted to New York City by the Federal Government Friday, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator for New York City.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9. -- Continued improvement in the Pacific Coast freight and charter market was noted during the past thirty days. Berth lines were running with capacity cargoes and space in many trades was at a premium. Inquiry for tramp vessels to load full cargoes was strong, but business was retarded due to owners' rapidly advancing ideas of freight rates.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Mrs. Samuel Woodward is arranging the musical program to be given tomorrow night at 8:30 at the Plays and Players clubhouse. Assisting Mrs. Woodward are:

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 9. -- The University of Mexico gave Louisiana College a surprisingly hard battle today but was beaten, the score being 27 to 7. Williams, an exchange student from Arkansas who is attending the university here, ran seventy yards for a touchdown to provide the feature of the game.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 9 (AP). -- Marquette's brilliant Golden Avalanche swept to a bitterly fought 13-to-7 victory over the Michigan State College Spartans today to keep its undefeated record intact, and mar the homecoming of 20,000 fans who braved a threatening day to attend.

PARIS, Oct. 22. THERE are few literary men now living with an international reputation so great as that of Maurice Maeterlinck. It is difficult therefore to break the brutal truth that he has written a bad play.

OLD Jules was a D'Artagnan in Nebraska -- a D'Artagnan reduced by circumstance to peasant status. His knees were out through his britches and he was dirtier than most. Cleanliness and a willingness to labor he considered feminine virtues, and he was rather easily mistaken for a tramp.

Basing his story upon what has happened in Italy and in Germany, the author attempts to depict what might happen in the United States. In the opening chapter we find the friends of the Ideal Order advancing upon the Capitol to demand the passage of an act which shall turn over all public utilities to the government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A 1,250-pound cheese was on its way to President Roosevelt from Wisconsin today, but it does not set a record for size.

The magic that HITLER has seemed to work for Germany is expressed in an industrial boom and an increase of employment. Our correspondent in Berlin, Mr. BIRCHALL, examines the facade of this prosperity wrought by National Socialism and, writing in the Review Section of THE TIMES today, finds flaws in it.

While routing two armed thugs with only billiard balls and cues as weapons, two men were seriously wounded at about 9 o'clock last night in the clubrooms of the New Arkeos Social Club, an Armenian organization, on the second floor of 511 East 173d Street, the Bronx.

Chain-store sales last month were 12.8 per cent more than in October, 1934, according to a compilation by Hammons Co., Inc., and Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc. The rise, the second largest this year, would probably have been greater if the unusually mild weather in the last fortnight had not retarded business, it was said.
RADIO, now widely recognized as "equipment" of 'a modern! motor car, is celebrating the opening of the 1935-36 automobile season.

An exchange of more than a dozen shots between three gangsters in a sedan and a rival on the sidewalk endangered more than a score of children playing in a vacant lot on West Seventeenth Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues shortly after noon yesterday.

A MURDER committed in England and discovered in Ireland makes the polices procedure a bit complicated. The body of Mr. Harden, first mate of the steamship Bayne, is discovered when the ship, a collier, reached an Irish port. It is buried under a good part of a cargo of coal shipped at Sunderland in England.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- King George of Greece will receive tomorrow addresses on behalf of the government and people pleading for his return to the throne, Peter Mavromichelis, Minister of Transport; General Papagos, Minister of War, and President Valanos of the National Assembly arrived in London tonight to escort the King back to Greece.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9. -- Extra dividends declared by the International Shoe Company and a large department store in the last week are accepted as indications of general business advances in the Eighth Federal Reserve District. Plans are being speeded for the employment of more than 10,000 men on civic and county projects, with government aid, and throughout the district projects are also being speeded up to relieve aid rolls.

ATLANTA, Nov. 9 (AP). -- In a wild afternoon of football, marked by a conglomeration of passes -- forwards, laterals and double laterals -- Auburn crushed Georgia Tech today before 14,000 fans. The score was 33 to 7.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- London's latest "Dick Whittington," Sir Percy Vincent, who as a country boy of 13 years came from Norfolk fifty-six years ago to be a dry goods apprentice, was installed today as Lord Mayor with all the traditional pomp and panoply.

WHEN the hard young stranger showed up Colonel Pete Loring promptly put him on his payroll, and at better than top wages. For Colonel Pete was having a hard time of it, notwithstanding that he worked hard, that he knew cattle, that the range out there in the mountains was excellent.

LIKE Barbellon's "Journal of a Disappointed Man," this anonymous book tells the story of a man who considers himself a failure. It is an honest and credible story, apparently sincere, both in its self-searching and in its commentaries along the way on people and events.

The most startling news item of the week, if not indeed of the year, the generation and the century, has been allowed to pass practically without comment. It concerns Chicago and her decision last week to move out of Central time and into Eastern time.

HONOLULU, Nov. 9. -- Forty-one planes of the United States Navy arrived at French Frigate Shoals, 759 miles northwest of Honolulu, completing the trip from the Pearl Harbor air base in six hours and ten minutes. The first squadron of planes arrived at 2:55 P.M. (8:25 P.M., E.S.T.). An hour later the entire air armada had arrived.

A father was killed and five members of his family were injured seriously last night when all were struck by an automobile on East 177th Street, near Philip Avenue, the Bronx. The car was driven by Patrolman George Short of the Highbridge police station.

Debutantes of this season, comprising a committee headed by Miss Hope Gatins and several of their older friends in society, are arranging a bicycle breakfast to be held in the morning and early afternoon of Dec. 1 at Le Coq Rouge. A portion of the proceeds will be donated to the Children's Welfare Federation, which is composed of several organizations devoted to the welfare of infants, young children and mothers.

WHEN the British democracy goes to the polls in the general election next Thursday to cast some 25,000,000 ballots for the choice of a new Parliament it will be as though the shadow of two Continental dictators were darkening every village voting booth from the Orkney Islands to Land's End.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 8. -- As the unconfirmed report circulated here today that the Italian Government was attempting to purchase 50,000,000 barrels of East Texas crude oil for delivery over a period of two years, local petroleum interests commenced active discussions of the potentialities contained in the present Italo-Ethiopian conflict.

DALLAS, Nov. 9. -- With rain and Cold weather during the early part of the week, followed by fair weather for the last three days, retail trade in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District for the week will reflect weather conditions. On the whole, the trade trend continues upward.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- This week the voice of the people was heard in the land. It came through the loud-speaker of local elections. Part of the message seemed clear to the experts. On the meaning of part of it they differed.

A lean, slight and bright-eyed youth of 13 years 5 months, sitting erect but at ease in a chair in the apartment of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Freedman, on the twenty-first floor of 211 Central Park West, explained the secret of easy and early achievement of scholastic honors.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 9. -- Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, in his annual report to the board of trustees, came to the defense of the privately endowed independent college.

The macadam of Central Park's centre drive resounded with the rhythmic clatter of speeding roller skates yesterday afternoon as more than twoscore children, finalists from contests in the five boroughs, competed for city championships.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The annual Charter Day dinner to commemorate the 169th anniversary of the granting of a royal charter by King George III to Queens College, now Rutgers University, will be given by the Rutgers Club of New Brunswick in the Hotel Woodrow Wilson tomorrow.

Those who have followed the exploits of the great Fu Manchu may be disappointed to learn that he does not appear in this new book. Mr. Rohmer has turned from the mysterious lore of China to that of ancient Egypt and has created a new superman to take the place of Fu Manchu.

For sheer quantity of news of women's organizations and for the zest indicated in events slated, the present week promises to establish something of a record. Larger, more important gatherings are impending than for any previous seven days of the current season.

The people of Italy are beginning to tighten their belts. The economic sanctions threatened by the League are already being translated into terms of food, fuel and light. From restrictions decreed recently by Il Duce Italians are now learning that war is something more than cheering soldiers who march away to the battlefields.

AS we strive to fit together the pieces and see the man whole, Vincent Van Gogh's short life may seem to us to have been a field in which was waged an almost unremitting conflict between God and the devil; between the spirit that aspired to all things great and good, and stubbornly recalcitrant flesh that at every step essayed to negative achievement.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The last of six eggs laid by one of the black swans of Montclair's Memorial Park were hatched late this afternoon before several hundred persons from many parts of New Jersey and New York.

ONE of the marvels of radio is that so many services can he squeezed into the air without interference with each other. The broadcast listener, in a little world of his own along the dial, eavesdrops on the symphonies, jazz and drama, little realizing that just across the ethereal frontier to the left are ships busily flashing messages, and to the right voices are "calling all cars."

THE London cable gets down to business and, without delay, lists the current week's benign expectations in the following calendar order. Sometimes things happen to change schedules, but late last week these were the plans:
Toys designed for the education and amusement of young scientists and engineers were featured as the Christmas corral of Abercrombie Fitch opened yesterday.

Ratification of the proposal for an amendment to the State Constitution limiting taxes on real estate to 2 per cent of the assesesd valuation would prove "disastrous" to free public education here, Dr. John S. Roberts, Associate Superintendent of Schools, told 500 persons yesterday at a luncheon of the United Parents Associations at the Pennsylvania.

SALISBURY PLAINS. L.I., Nov. 9. -- Carding a 74, one stroke above the regulation figures, Charley Lacey, long-hitting pro from the Lakeville Club at Great Neck, became the first chaimpion of the newly organized Long Island P.G. A. today.

WITH the eighteenth century at the Metropolitan Museum talking pure Parisian French -- if there is such a thing -- it was a happy idea on the part of the Knoedler Galleries to stage a loan exhibition of eighteenth-century English with Hogarth ruling in the centre for "L'etat."

PARIS, Nov. 7. -- The midseason openings demonstrate a trend away from picturesque fashions toward a more youthful modern tailored mode. The majority of the couturiers are sponsoring a super-pencil daytime silhouette.
TULSA, Okla., Nov. 9 (AP). -- Two rival parades, one to "honor the colors" and one "without flag-waving," will feature Tulsa's Armistice Day program.

Reorders slowed up during the week and the wholesale markets are rapidly catching up with deliveries, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. More attention, however, is being directed to purchases for January sales and retailers are being advised to place orders now for sheets, pillowcases, blankets and similar goods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- On the ground that their operations were entirely of an intrastate character, the Long Island Lighting Company of New York and the Pacific Lighting Corporation, together with their subsidiaries, requested today of the Securities and Exchange Commission exemption from the provisions of the Public Utilities Act.

A NEW publishing house, Basic Books, Inc., has just brought out its first book, "The Earth Among the Stars," an introduction to astronomy by Marian Lockwood and Arthur L. Draper, assistant curators of the Hayden Planetarium in New York.

NOW that the maples have dropped their rosy leaves and deep, early mists rise on the still air, the fox-hunting folk are assembling in Virginia. New York stockbrokers, Chicago bankers, sportsmen from Long Island, Boston and Pittsburgh, the red clay farmers from Virginia, polo players, steeplechase riders, writers, horse traders, occasional army officers and straight-backed ladies, are gathering in the meadows where the hounds meet.

BLOOD spurts on the first page of this book and on the last That is appropriate. It's a hearty odyssey of tales told by the Mexican ranchers and soothsayers and cowhands in a land that knows blood and sand. Any one who enjoys reading books about Mexico will find entertainment in Mr. Dobie's account of his wanderings through the northern deserts.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Thomas C. Gardner, 51 years old, general manager of The Peekskill Daily Union, oldest daily newspaper in Northern Westchester County, died today of a heart attack while hunting with his son, Thomas F. Gardner.

WAYCROSS, Ga., Nov. 9. -- The men who hew the trees and split the rails, and timber land owners, turpentine operators and scientists will gather here in the land of the "Suwanee River" Monday for a "Forest Festival," believed to be the only celebration of its kind in the United States.
LONDON. -- In this city on Nov. 12 many notable persons will attend a dinner in honor of the 900th anniversary of the death of King Canute.

OF all the pages of modern history few contain a story so utterly fantastic and incredible as that of Alexander Obrenovitch, King of Serbia. His country had been in the grip of the Turks for centuries when there arose two men, both determined to liberate it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Tatsuko Yamanoto today was the wife of Frank Huggins of Orillia, Canada, son of a former American consular officer in Japan. They were married by an Elkton, Md., justice of the peace after an elopement and came to a Washington hotel.

The Brooklyn Dodgers will endeavor to gain undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern division of the National Football League this afternoon, when they oppose the Pittsburgh Pirates at Ebbets Field. The Dodgers are now tied for the lead with the New York Giants, who are not listed to compete in a league contest today.
The Police Department's drive against unnecessary noises "will now be doubly intensified," Police Commissioner Valentine announced last night.

ORDINARILY, the Boy Scout is pictured as a lively, robust lad, and his activities bear out this picture. His merit badge program includes life-saving, swimming, canoeing, athletics, hiking, camping, physical development and a score of other energetic tests.

Six thousand persons, including public and parochial school students, soldiers, representatives of veterans' organizations, Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts, marched yesterday afternoon along Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn in a safety parade under the auspices of the Police Department and the Boys' Club of Bay Ridge.

ARCHIPENKO, the celebrated Russian sculptor, is one up on his fellow-hierarchs in modernism, Braque, Picasso and Brancusi. It shall be recorded of him that he has visited a movie atelier and they haven't. We had the pleasure the other morning to function as his auditor on a long prowl, incognito, through the Paramount studios.

ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- When the 1936 Legislature convenes in January the Assembly, which will be Republican by 82 to 68, will have its program all ready for action, Irving M. Ives of Chenango, majority leader, declared today. This marks the opening of the campaign to elect a Republican Governor in 1936 and at the same time to attempt to make the Senate Republican.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee will issue a call soon for a meeting here of the national committee to select a time and place for the national convention and to discuss campaign policies, so far they can be considered in advance of drafting the platform.
The news that came from Shanghai last week had been anticipated for some time: China formally went off the silver standard and will resort to a managed paper currency.

THIS sequel to Miss McKee's first Hawaiian novel, "The Lord's Anointed," raises an interesting question as to her intention. One of the women in the story told Hal Carrington, the hero, that if she knew half he did about the place and its people she would "do a Forsyte Saga on Hawaii."

The "Boswell Papers" will be discussed by their owner, Colonel Ralph Heyward Isham of England, at the opening meeting of the Bronxville Women's Club on Tuesday afternoon. The speaker was educated at Cornell and Yale Universities, where he developed his interest in collecting books and manuscripts.

On his way into Los Pinos young Dan Clifford, mule skinner, played the Good Samaritan to three orphans -- sixteen-year-old Milly Sutherland and her younger brother and sister, whose father had died on the road. Asked what she aimed to do in Los Pinos, Milly said she could wash clothes.

Armistice Day will be observed today as "Remembrance Sunday." Today will likewise be observed as "Red Cross Sunday," and appeals will be made in churches of Manhattan and the Bronx -- 127 Protestant and 124 Roman Catholic edifices.

Many visitors from other clues will attend the twentieth Fail assembly of the Eastern Federation of Delphian Chapters on Tuesday at the Hotel Barclay, at which 200 members are expected to be present. Mrs. Charles J. Snyder, president, will preside at the luncheon, which will be the main feature of the program.

Lotte Lehmann, Metropolitan soprano, who has not sung in Germany for the last two seasons, said yesterday she had been informed by the various local managers in Germany that "they had received formal notice that my professional appearances were 'undesired' in Germany," although no official notification had been made to her.

MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The reconstruction of Communist Youth organizations in nations outside Russia to include members of religious and political groups heretofore barred was recommended in a resolution adopted by the Sixth International Communist Youth Congress.

A FEW weeks ago there were great doings in Billingham, England. The old town was decked out in flags. Bands played. Dignitaries representing the army, the navy, the coal-mining companies and the government were on hand.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 9. -- A hotel, two country clubs, a large estate and an office building were among Long Island properties sold by Suffolk County at a tax sale here today. The charges against the properties totaled about $350,000, of which the county had to bid in about $50,000 worth.

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- One of the most popular Nazi propaganda films stresses as an illustration of the suffering brought upon the German people by "Marxist treason" long queues of housewives standing before grocer shops to obtain meager supplies of foodstuffs.

All the statesmen of Europe have their eyes on the British parliamentary elections which take place next Thursday. The Conservative Government has gone to the people on a nationalist program of greater national defense, calling for important increases in the naval and air forces of the country.

LADIES AND HEELS: Description of women's heels, by Dr. Dudley J. Morton, Professor of Anatomy at the Columbia University Medical School: "A powerful and vicious factor in the development of foot disorder when worn during working hours." If women wore tall heels only in the evening they would suffer much less from foot disorders, the professor said in a published paper.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 9 (AP). -- A field goal by Jim (Monk) Moscrip in the last forty seconds of play enabled Stanford to defeat Southern California, 3 to 0, today before 40,000 spectators, including former President Hoover, a Stanford graduate.

Assassinations, devaluations of currency, international loan manoeuvres, the shooting of a Japanese marine, diplomatic challenges over border clashes -- all things conspire to hasten the climax in the Far East. It is as if Japan, already chafing to go forward, had forces gathering behind it to push it in the direction it wants to go.

WERE it only for its illustrations this would be a distinguished volume. Massive beasts charge full tilt across the pages, a war elephant tosses his painted trunk to heaven a bedizened royal elephant of India minces along in ceremonial trappings, and a few pages later a group of circus elephants clown and pose with comic grace.

VERY betimes up, and to my office, and all day there hard at my stint, and Mr. Adams the Book Editor come staggering in under the load of two colossal volumes called "The Diary of Our Own Samuel Pepys," saying. "If the Cettysburg Address was good these must be half a million times as good, metric scale dominating."

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 9. -- Paced by Don Jackson, who galloped to two touchdowns and passed to a position for two others while playing only 10 minutes, North Carolina's flying Tar Heels romped over Virginia Military Institute, 56 -- 0, to annex their seventh straight victory today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- The first official run of the season for the Radnor Hunt, of which M. Roy Jackson is M.F.H., will be held near Malvern on Nov. 16.

Hospitals of every description lead the list of suggestions made the nation over by contributors to the Will Rogers Fund as to the form which the proposed memorial should take, it was learned yesterday as the first week of the campaign neared its close.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 9 (AP). -- Mixing a powerful running attack with passes, Louisiana State University today tallied four touchdowns in the first half to beat Mississippi State, the conqueror of Army, 28 to 13, before a crowd of 25,000.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 9. -- William Yenser, 28-year-old trooper of the New Jersey State Police, was killed early this morning by a sawed-off shotgun charge fired full in his face from a speeding coupe that he and Trooper John Matey had chased twelve miles along Route 25 into Avenel, a section of Woodbridge, near here.

IN obscure corners of the town you can find a few old-time gangsters of the hob-nail and raw-knuckles period mumbling their scorn of current racketeer bosses who sit at mahogeny desks and push electric buttons instead of getting out on the firing line with their hoodlums as orthodox leaders did twenty years ago.

THE long French perspective, attention to which was called in these columns last week, continues to add to the resources now at our disposal about town. The seventeenth and eighteenth century developments have already been discussed, along with a few of the later aspects currently illustrated in New York galleries.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The possibilities of government management of railroads were discussed today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, but he expressed doubt that such a step would be necessary.

AN intriguing achievement marks this addition to Mrs. Deland's long list of books. It is not every one -- it is, indeed, a rare person, whether author or not, who can view his own childhood with the objective attitude and the judicial spirit with which she looks back upon the small Maggie who was to become the distinguished novelist, Margaret Deland.

When old Len Daybright, owner of the Ragged O Ranch, died there was nobody to succeed him as Home Valley's leader but his orphaned granddaughter Janet, called Jan by everybody but her cowboys, who affectionately dubbed her "Sprig." Len had been the pioneer.

THIS is the open season for esses as to which announcer will be awarded the American Aeademy of Arts and Letters medal for good diction on the radio. The prize for 1935 will be presented on Thursday at 3:30 o'clock during a broadcast over WJZ.

SINCE 1928, the British programs on Armistice Day have included a relay from Whitehall of the service held annually before the Cenotaph, generally in the presence of His Majesty the King and members of the royal family.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Great Britain needs to spend at least 150,000,000 on naval building, in the opinion of Admiral Earl Beatty, before she can keep her command of the seas and play her part in enforcing world peace.

Three women were rescued from apartments in the four-story dwelling at 308 West 103d Street, between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive, after a fire which started in the cellar at 5:10 o'clock yesterday afternoon had spread up an elevator shaft and swept through the first floor.

A strong contract bridge team composed of Louis H. Watson, Edward Hymes Jr., Sam Fry Jr. and M.D. Maier eliminated the team of Harold S. Vanderbilt, Waldemar von Zedtwitz, B. Jay Becker and Theodore A. Lightner early this morning in the semi-final round of play for the Vanderbilt Cup at the Park Lane Hotel.

The furniture, bronzes and other objects of art from the collection of the late Mrs. Emma Rockefeller McAlpin, widow of David H. McAlpin, and the collections of John R. Thompson of Chicago and others brought $59,540 at auction yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

CHICAGO. THIS year in Chicago a vigorous program of traffic accident prevention has been carried on. The effects of this program may be found in the fact that during the first eight months of the year 485 persons were killed in automobile accidents as compared with 637 traffic deaths for the same period of 1934.

IT is an old truth that a sincere autobiography, or the confessions, of any human being is a thing of interest. All the more is it so when the author of the confessions possesses an unusually original personality, when he has an uncommonly interesting career to narrate and when he narrates it not only with a winning audacity but also with a remarkable literary talent.

Veterans of the Seventy-seventh Division and their guests turned out in large numbers for the Armistice Ball held last night at the Hotel Roosevelt under the auspices of the Seventy-seventh Division Association. Nearly 3,000 attended and it was estimated that about $5,000 would be realized to help needy veterans and to build a clinic in the association's memorial building at 28 East Thirty-ninth Street.

At 3:10 o'clock on the afternoon of Aug. 26 there was a happy ceremony in the White House. Surrounded by a group of Congressional leaders who had made the ceremony possible, the President signed the Public Utility Bill; he used several pens in the signing and, in accordance with custom, distributed them among his guests.

Delving further into the scope of financial operations of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, lawyers for the Securities and Exchange Commission obtained yesterday an admission that the trustees for one of the company's note issues had permitted violations of the trust indenture.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 9. -- Reports from Magallanes indicate that Lincoln Ellsworth and the members of his expedition are putting the finishing touches on their equipment for a 3,000-mile flight over Antarctica in their small low-winged monoplane in order to survey unmapped regions.

Adult education neglects the "unorganized majority" at the expense of educators who wish to obtain more education, Edward A. Richards, associate director of Columbia University Extension in charge of home study, declared in his annual report to the trustees made public yesterday.

The University of Pennsylvania freshman eleven defeated the Columbia yearlings, 10 -- 6, yesterday morning at Baker Field. The Red and Blue capitalized on two Lion fumbles to register a field goal and a touchdown.
THREE weeks returned from England, I was shuffling notes on several contemplated plays, when the preceding letter arrived accompanied by a few clippings.

SUMMER TIME ENDS" is like reading half a dozen novels in a kaleidoscope, snippets of each alternating line by line, and still seen altogether. There is a Love on the Dole novel in it, a Lady Swingletree's Lover, an Industrial Crisis, a Novelist's Novel, and so on -- more than half a dozen.

PERHAPS it is well that the publication in English of Gide's "Si le grain ne meurt" has been delayed until now. For one thing, the public is no longer so horrified by disclosures of homosexuality that it need regard the book -- as it might have regarded it ten years ago -- as something sensational.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A gangster's offer to serve time to win the freedom of his woman companion was rejected today by the Department of Justice. The offer was made by William Weaver, a kidnap suspect, who proposed to trade a "guilty" plea for the liberty of Myrtle Eaton.
Results of the annual class elections of the Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University were announced yesterday by Dean William Payson Richardson.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 9 (AP). -- Fourteen persons were injured, six of them seriously, when a railing on top of the east bleachers at Whitnall Athletic Field collapsed this afternoon, hurling about thirty persons to the ground, twenty feet below, during the Colgate-Syracuse freshman football game.
While the sense of loss of a great man and a great citizen is fresh in our minds, may I call the public attention to a matter very dear to his heart?

CAIRO, Nov. 9. -- An official note was handed by Pelligrini Ghigi, the Italian Minister to Egypt, to Premier Tewfik Nessim Pasha today protesting vigorously against the Egyptian Government's decision in principle to apply sanctions against Italy.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- Once more an orgy of mud-raking and mud-slinging has broken out in France with the opening of the trial of nineteen men and one woman who were Alexandre Stavisky's associates or accomplices.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 9 (AP). -- California's dreams of an undefeated season and the bid to represent the West in the Rose Bowl came a step closer to reality today. The mightest Golden Bear eleven in years scored a 14-to-0 victory over the University of Washington's Huskies.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 9. -- Trinity resumed its winning streak today against the University of Vermont eleven, finishing the season before a record crowd with a 7-to-0 triumph. The winners made fifteen first downs as against three for Vermont.

Despite substantial increases in worsted yarn quotations, many women's bathing suit styles for 1936 were officially shown by selling agents yesterday, with prices substantially unchanged from those prevailing in the latter part of the 1935 season.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9. -- Speaking before 400 Connecticut Democrats, including practically all the party's State officeholders, Postmaster General Farley tonight declared that an organized effort was being made by employers of the State to coerce their employes, through letters, and influence them against the New Deal. Such letters, he said, had come to his attention.

THIS is a disturbing book by a new author. Its theme is the battered, time-worn old triangle of an artist, his wife and the other girl, painstakingly padded in matters of sex and soul. We might dismiss it with a shrug, had not Hubert Nicholson succeeded in vivifying the emotional torment of his characters and, in his microscopic probing, stirred our lethargy.

Dr. John Haynes Holmes undertakes to interpret an editorial on "Motor Fatalities" by adding his own assumption that alcohol ranks first in contributing factors in automobile accidents. Of course Dr. Holmes's guess on this matter is as good as any one's, but it must necessarily be only a guess.
Drastic staff cuts and other economy moves will be made Jan. 1 by the Cunard White Star Line in its British and Continental offices, according to word received yesterday from London.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- The Irvington House for Cardiac Children here will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance to be held Saturday evening at the Westchester Country Club, Rye. Mrs. George W. Whiteside, Mrs. Graver A. Whalen, Mrs. Messmore Kendall, Mrs. Reed Albee and Mrs. Charles H. Smith head the committee in charge of the event.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Efforts to bring about a reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company, key holding unit in the old Insull system, met a new obstacle today when attorneys for holders of the company's $40,000,000 of outstanding notes made formal objection in the Federal court here to revisions in the plan suggested by Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson.
District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn admitted yesterday that "there is some truth" in reports that his staff will be shaken up when he begins his new term on Jan. 1.

MUNICH, Nov. 9. -- In a long, impressive ceremony the remains of the sixteen Nazi dead in the putsch of 1923 were laid at rest today in their stone coffins in two open temples fronting the great square which is to be the forum of German National Socialism, there to constitute an "Eternal Watch" over party destinies.

THOUGH it is light enough in manner, and presumably in intention, this story is fundamentally and essentially a novel of character. Only Anthony Gibbs's dexterity at weaving a plot around his central figure and his skill in the application of certain useful literary tricks has kept "The Dramatist" from seeming more like a character sketch than a novel at all.

PARIS, Nov. 9. -- The Bourse opened today for the first time on a Saturday this season, and the session was dull and irregular. Both public and professional traders are observing the strictest caution pending the outcome of Premier Pierre Laval's meeting on Tuesday with the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

THE series of volumes, of which this is the twelfth, that is being published by the Commission of Inquiry on Public Service Personnel afford another of the very useful fruits of the activities of the Social Science Research Counsel, by which the commission was appointed two years ago, with the approval of President Roosevelt.

Nazi Germany is looking expectantly to the East, according to statements made last week in French newspapers. Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Reich Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, is alleged to have disclosed to French and British bankers Berlin's desire for expansion in the Baltic and in the Soviet Ukraine.

A rush for reservations for the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at Syracuse tomorrow has been interpreted as indicating an attendance beyond the ordinary. The largest delegation will leave tomorrow morning, with smaller groups departing on later trains.

Athletically speaking, Mount Holyoke has one of the liveliest of the college campuses. Especially advanced are the undergraduate riding requirements. Ever since Mrs. Henry Beaumont took charge of the riding classes in 1932, there has been an increasing emphasis on the desirability of truly expert horsemanship among the college riders.

The promotion and appointment of 102 students enrolled in the advanced courses of the City College R.O.T.C. unit were announced yesterday by Colonel Oliver P. Robinson, head of the Department of Military Science. Edward M. Kinney, '36, has been named colonel, the highest cadet rank in the division.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Gasoline buyers were advised by the NRA Consumers Division today "to be wary of paying any significant differential in price because the pump has a familiar trademark blazoned conspicuously on it."

Columbia's reign of football supremacy over Syracuse ended yesterday before 25,000 spectators at Baker Field as the Orange eleven defeated the Lions, 14 -- 2. The first half was of decidedly Columbia hue; the second all to the advantage of the up-State outfit.

In the days when river traffic flourished in the Mississippi Basin a boy's life was incomplete until he had taken a steamboat trip. Billy was particularly fortunate, as his uncle was owner of the Senator Ordway, a packet boat on the upper Ohio, so Billy learned all about steamboats from the texas deck to the boiler room at firsthand.

IN view of the general excellence of Esther Junger's performance at the Guild Theatre last Sunday, it is difficult to realize that this was only her third New York recital. She is to be sure, a more experienced dancer than that would seem to indicate, as a glance at her background clearly reveals.

THIRTEEN years ago a fiery little Filipino dropped a bombshell among a group of American business men and government employes by declaring in a burst of passion: "I would rather live under a government run like hell by Filipinos than one run like heaven by Americans."

DESPITE the fact that H.G. Wells or his publishers seem strangely reluctant to call this book a scenario, preferring that more hopeful designation, "a film," it seems safe to declare that "Things to Come" is the playing script of a movie that will open shortly, and consequently is a scenario.
