Several of the Dodecanese islands, at present Italian, are mentioned in an Athens cable as the tentative price asked by Turkey in return for armed support of Britain in the event of a conflict with Italy. These islands are accustomed to being handed about. Settled by Greeks, they were for 400 years Roman.

Hijackers who kidnapped a truck driver and his helper made off yesterday afternoon with a truck and its load of furs, the value of which the police said may amount to between $50,000 and $60,000. The truck later was abandoned at Fifty-eighth Street and Tenth Avenue.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Frederick W. Drinkwater of Elizabeth, cousin of John Drinkwater, English playwright and author, was struck and killed by an automobile here today. Mr. Drinkwater, who was 34 years old, was a sales manager in the northern district of New Jersey for the Tidewater Oil Company.

Business activity improved in many of the leading centres of the country last week, although mild weather continued to retard retail purchases of heavy apparel and other seasonable merchandise in some districts. Spotty conditions prevailed in most of the wholesale markets, as retailers are fairly well covered for the present as the result of the backward season.

One of the five known autograph manuscript copies of "The Star-Spangled Banner" by Francis Scott Key recorded in Oscar G.T. Sonneck's Library of Congress reports on "The Star-Spangled Banner," will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., in a sale of rare books and autographs on Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 (AP). -- A suit for divorce was filed today by Barbara Stanwyck, screen star, against Frank Fay, stage and screen actor. She charged her husband harassed her about trivial matters.

THE American people maintain their wholesome appetite. To be sure, they pulled in their belts during the depression but it takes thirty-two pounds more of food to satisfy the individual appetite than it did fifteen years ago.

A brilliant assembly of social and sports notables filled the boxes at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. The entire program was a pageant of dashing military mounts, flashing harness horses and superb hunters, enlivened near the close with "the Gay Nineties."

AT the time of his death Edwin Arlington Robinson left the completed poem "King Jasper," which is now posthumously published with an introduction by Robert Frost. But Mr. Frost, although he writes admirably of Robinson, even if somewhat briefly, has been general and not specific, so that his words have only indirect application here.

EXCITING textile novelty satins are printed in a new process, a well-known automobile paint being used to produce luminous color effects. These come in huge floral patterns; many houses show luscious evening gowns of these novelty fabrics.

On the estate of R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont in Bedminster, N.J., on Wednesday and Thursday will be held the fifth field trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club. Labrador, golden, flat-coated and curly coated retrievers are eligible.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The government was urged tonight to adopt a "hands-off" policy toward business in resolutions of a divisional meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP). -- George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, specifically asked industry today to be ready to tell him Dec. 9 what steps should be taken to accelerate recovery and to eliminate unemployment.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 9. -- The Brazilian press applauds the stand taken by Brazil in refusing to collaborate with the League of Nations sanctions. The press holds that Brazil should keep aloof and maintain strict neutrality by selling products to either belligerent.

IT is almost fifty years since Mark Hopkins died and, although his influence still lives and the impression he made upon his own time is not yet wholly forgotten, the younger generations know very little about him. As Mr. Denison remarks with gentle irony, it is well to let this generation know that he "was not the builder of the Union Pacific, who is so well known in California."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Bankers of the nation, concerned with new Federal legislation affecting their business, will devote much of their discussions to that subject when they gather here on Monday for the annual meeting of the American Bankers Association.

THE sign "Public Works Project" at many points on the roadside often catches the eye of the tourist this Fall. Emblem of the Federal job-making drive, the PWA sign connotes not only sweeping changes in the physical contour of the land but, for the motorist on the road, some real benefits.

When the gavel raps to attention the assembly in the Hotel Astor ballroom on Tuesday evening, under auspices of the New York City League of Women Voters, one of the biggest jobs of the year for that unit of the national organization will have been brought to fruition.

The life of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference was extended for six days at an eleventh-hour meeting at 80 Broad Street yesterday. The thirteen members had resigned from the conference, effective next Wednesday, as a result of a protest by an American member that two other lines were profiting in discriminatory manipulation of discounted marks by Germany.
In efforts to safeguard the health of school children, officials of the Board of Education are recognizing a growing need for a more extensive program to remedy hearing defects.
KAGOSHIMA, Japan, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The Japanese Army launched its annual grand manoeuvres today, with Emperor Hirohito unable to join his troops in the field because of a cold.
Since the attack on the Washington prayer has been renewed and concentrated on Old St. Paul's of Trinity Parish, it may be opportune to set forth the facts about the prayer.

OWNERS of trailers and semi-trailers must have a factory or serial number on each vehicle before they can register them during the 1936 period, it is announced by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. Serial numbers may be obtained from any issuing office of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, and an owner will be allowed ten days, following the beginning of the registration period, to have the number stamped on his vehicle.

NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 9. -- Western Maryland staged an upset at Alumni Field this afternoon, beating Boston College, 12 to 6, before 8,000. The visitors used only two substitutes during a hard-fought game, and both of these were needed to replace injured players.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- "Complete agreement" on the objectives of Canada and the United States in the tariff negotiations which have been going on between the two governments and "substantial progress" toward realization of those objectives were announced tonight in a joint communique issued by President Roosevelt and Premier W.L. Mackenzie King.

WHEN President Roosevelt, checking up on the coming issue of transpacific air service stamps, discovered that a Yankee clipper ship was shown with two masts instead of three and had the error rectified, he prevented the sale of a stamp that might, in time, have had great value.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Trends in last Tuesday's election, indicative of an anti-New Deal sentiment in the conservative East, have strengthened the hopes of Republicans for success in 1936 and intensified the activities of potential and avowed candidates for the Republican nomination for President.

Mayor La Guardia passed a quiet day yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, where he was sent Friday for a combined rest cure and treatment for arthritis. His physician, Dr. George Baehr of 110 East Eightieth Street, said yesterday that arthritis is the only complaint from which the Mayor is suffering.

Supplying an extracurricular outlet for the cultural, religious and departmental interests of Hunter College students, forty-three clubs under the supervision of the Student Council have elected more than 250 officers to guide their programs for the current semester.

DETROIT, Nov. 8. -- With testimony on its records in the first case it has heard involving manufacturing, the National Labor Relations Board has taken the initial step toward a Supreme Court decision on the constitutionality of the Wagner-Connery National Labor Relations Act.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Foreigners appear indifferent to upturns in North American markets, and the failure of Liverpool to respond to the rise on this side late yesterday caused Board of Trade operators to turn to the selling side today, lowering prices at the extreme to more than a cent under yesterday's close.

THE "Conquering Seas" of the title are those stormy wastes of the sub-Arctic stretching from the Faroes to Iceland. There lie the rock shelves where are to be found the teeming cod and haddock and there go the British trawlers from the port of Hestern.

ASIDE from the authentic account this story gives of the unparalleled Sioux uprising in Minnesota during 1862, and of the widespread massacre to which the hapless settlers were subjected by the rampant savages, there seems to be little in the book which should interest readers fond of novels merging historic events with purely imaginative narrative.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 9. -- An anti-New Deal youth movement was started here today as the Young Republicans of thirty States opened a three-day convention here. About 200 delegates have the two-fold purpose of expressing the viewpoint of the younger generation on national affairs and stimulating the organization of younger Republican voters for the national campaign.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 9. -- Dartmouth's football team was hard pressed during the first half by a fighting William and Mary eleven today, but five brilliant scoring thrusts enabled the Big Green to win, 34-0.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- War as a means of settling international disputes was denounced today by Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, retired marine officer, with a pledge that never again would he bear arms except on his native soil in defense of his country.

We believe that the great majority of thinking American citizens, regardless of their politics or their opinion of specific items in the Nebraskan's platform, would like to see Norris remain in the Senate.

The sharp rise in raw material prices has given large manufacturers a decided advantage over their small competitors, and in the last two months particularly has enabled them to take a substantial volume of business away from the smaller units, according to opinions expressed yesterday by executives here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The volume of industrial activity continues to hold at the level of recent weeks, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly summary of domestic business.

TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Sunday, Nov. 10. -- A "holy war" plot to overthrow Bolshevist rule in two of the Soviet republics in Central Asia and to set up a Mussulman State was charged by authorities today at the trial of thirty-two persons.

IN "Selina" Sheila Kaye-Smith again explores that sheltered world of comfortable middleclass childhood which has for the English a definite and charming pattern. Selina and Moira South, the children of "Summer Holiday," are a little older.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- On March 1 next, by order of the City Council, this city will break step with the State and the whole Middle West. It will push its clocks an hour ahead and go on Eastern time as an all-the-year-around program. In the Winter months it will be in step with New York.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 7. -- Much to the surprise of almost everybody in Missouri, the famous "milk bottle caps" with which citizens of the State started paying a 1 per cent sales tax last Aug. 27 have brought in a revenue of more than $800,000 for the only month yet totaled.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, director of the United States Mint, pleaded today in an address before the eighty-first annual convention of the New Jersey State Teachers Association for a strengthening of the American resolve to remain neutral in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Industrial unionism, which was opposed by craft unions at the recent American Federation of Labor convention, will be pushed by an organization formed here today by representatives of seven international labor unions.
BERLIN, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Willie Hoppe, former balkline king, played brilliantly in the afternoon session of the world's three-cushion billiard championship tournament today to defeat Kinrey Katsuyama, the Japanese expert, 50 to 35, in thirty-five innings.

On behalf of the Wine Institute, the members of which produce approximately 80 per cent of the total American wine production, I wish to correct certain statements contained in THE NEW YORK TIMES report of the Wine and Food Society's public tasting of American wines.

On the roof of the Jung Hotel in New Orleans this afternoon the Association of Bank Women will celebrate the opening of its thirteenth annual convention by giving a tea for the outstanding business and professional women of New Orleans.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9. -- A fund to continue research on slums and housing policy in New York City has been awarded to Professor James Ford of the Harvard Department of Sociology by the committee on research in the social sciences at Harvard University.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Pickets trying to win a union dispute at a real estate development on Knollwood Road, Greenburgh, were accused today in Supreme Court of attempting to wreck automobiles, endanger lives and damage twenty new buildings.
All the student organizations at Barnard College have begun their Fall activities and installed their officers for the year. Officers who have been elected or appointed are as follows:

GENEVA, Nov. 8. -- The League of Nations now is applying arms embargo sanctions against the Italian Government and in a week three other forms of sanctions go into effect among fifty of the League's members -- a credit blockade, a boycott of all Italian goods and an embargo on a score of key war materials such as rubber, nickel and tin, the production of which they control.

KENNETH ROBERTS is possessed of a lively style. He has the ability to make something of an adventure of almost anything on earth. "For Authors Only" is addressed, in good part, to writers or to would-be writers, but it contains essays for almost every one who has, at some period in his life, accepted an enthusiasm as a cure for all evil.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 9. -- Held to a single touchdown in the first half, Lehigh put on its big offensive in the third quarter to defeat Muhlenberg before a crowd of 8,000 spectators in Taylor Stadium today by a wore of 26 to 6.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8. -- These points stand out in the overwhelming victory of Lieut. Governor A.B. (Happy) Chandler, Democrat, in his race for the governorship:

TO the naked eye it is impossible to see that the fixed stars are in continual motion. Yet they are moving, for the astronomers tell us so. In somewhat the same manner, although we may fail to see it, we are assured that the rarest of rare books and manuscripts are disappearing down the one-way street that leads to the permanent asylum.

IMPORTANT timeliness attends the publication of this work, since the indications are that the approaching Presidential campaign will bring much discussion of the Constitution and of whether or not its future life and usefulness are being endangered.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- There will be two ballotings in Great Britain next week -- one of the entire electorate to choose a new Parliament, the other by miners to determine whether to strike for higher wages. The result of the miners' vote bids fair to provide the first major industrial difficulty to plague Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's government after it is returned to power by next Thursday's election.

A pre-holiday atmosphere dominated trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, prices generally holding within a narrow range on a light turnover. Total sales amounted to $5,577,000, as compared with $5,590,000 on Saturday of last week.
BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- So-called "Rome-Free" Catholics met in Essen yesterday to discuss plans for separating German Catholics from the Roman church and creating a national church.

UNTIL a short time ago it was quite a simple matter to get a divorce in Soviet Russia. Being bored with your mate, you dropped in at the Bureau of Vital Statistics and said you wanted to be free. Three rubles was the charge, and on payment of the fee a postcard was sent to notify your erstwhile spouse.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 8. -- Whether Father Charles E. Coughlin's first broadcast of the season, delivered last Sunday, was a success, he alone can tell -- and he is keeping his secret. Nor is he disclosing what his new campaign will cover.

FRIEDRICH SCHORR, baritone, of the Metropolitan Opera; Ruggiero Riccl, violinist, and Sascha Gorodnitzki, pianist, will share the program to be given at Carnegie Hall, Sunday evening, Dec. 1, for the benefit of the Jewish National Fund of America.

LONDON. -- As a municipal housekeeper, Europe can teach the United States many things. In disposing of garbage and sewage, in purifying adjacent waters and in cleansing the air European cities are economical and efficient, eager to learn and quick to apply the best of knowledge gained anywhere.

Despite the fact that it was an off-year election (a circumstance which caused Alfred E. Smith to wear a pearl gray fedora instead of the traditional brown derby when he went to his polling place), New Yorkers east a powerful lot of votes on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Retail trade averaged well ahead of last year during the first week of November, despite the effect of mild temperatures on the Winter apparel lines. State Street stores experienced a good general volume of sales, while results from one neighborhood sales event were the best since 1929.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Red Cross said today that it had answered more calls for help in the last year than in any twelve-month period in its history.

NORTON, Mass., Nov. 9. -- Wheaton College will hold a brief peace demonstration on Armistice Day, Monday, objecting to the militaristic atmosphere which surrounds many peace demonstrations, and Wheaton students have planned a gathering to be notable mainly for its simplicity and quiet.

A SERIES of concerts which represent by far the most interesting feature of a season that has started in a dull and mediocre manner begins tomorrow night in Town Hall. The programs of these concerts will steer clear of the hackneyed repertory.

The problem of finding employment for from 5,000,000 to 8,000,000 youths between the ages of 16 and 25 only can be solved through reforms in the nation's industrial structure, according to Aubrey Williams, executive director of the National Youth Administration, who was one of four speakers yesterday at a luncheon discussion in the Hotel Astor.

AFTER having been jealously guarded for nearly forty years, the entire correspondence between Tchaikovsky and his mysterious patroness, Nadejda Filaretovna von Meck, is now coming out in Moscow. These letters, of which the first two volumes cover the period from 1876 to 1881, have a rather romantic history.

A NEW extension of the possibilities of flying mail by means of rockets is to be attempted late this month. At that time a rocket airplane is scheduled to be sent from Greenwood Lake, N.Y., to Hewitt, N.J., an airline distance of about six miles.

Harry Hanss, 36 years old, no home, appeared in the police lineup yesterday after being brought here from Wilmington, Del., to face a charge of having taken $25,000 worth of rugs and antiques in a burglary of the Interstate Warehouse, Inc., 605 West Fifty-first Street, in March, 1933.

City College's outweighed football team witnessed another touchdown parade over its goal line yesterday, this one being staged by the undefeated and untied New York University eleven on the Yankee Stadium gridiron before a crowd of about 6,000 spectators.

New York City's busy tide of activity will halt at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning as the city observes a two-minute period of silence on the seventeenth anniversary of the cessation of hostilities in the World War. Workers in industry, in offices and in stores will pause; all subway trains will stop as the power is shut off, and in the streets traffic will cease moving.

BY not too strange a set of circumstances this could turn out to be Helen Jerome's year. There is her "Pride and Prejudice," acclaimed last Tuesday night at the Music Box. On the same evening, Elsie Ferguson arrived on the Aquitania, still very keen about "That Enchanting Hussy," and at once went into conference about it with Adrienne Morrison.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 9. -- The second annual military ball of the North Shore of Long Island Chapter, Reserve Officers Association, was held here tonight at the Knickerbocker Yacht Club. Many delegations and individuals from American military units and patriotic societies and national and foreign veterans' groups were present in the assemblage of 500.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Ten additional packing companies were charged today by the Agricultural Department with violations of the Packers and Stockyards Act and were called to appear before Secretary Wallace at future dates for hearings.

Last Tuesday's elections were only a curtain raiser for 1936. Yet they foreshadow, not necessarily the result, but the method, of the next Presidential election. It will be, that is to say, the free expression of the judgment and the will of a free people. With us this has long been a commonplace. But it is becoming a much rarer thing in the rest of the world than it used to be.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Ten additional packing companies were charged today by the Agricultural Department with violations of the Packers and Stockyards Act and were called to appear before Secretary Wallace at future dates for hearings.

Last Tuesday's elections were only a curtain raiser for 1936. Yet they foreshadow, not necessarily the result, but the method, of the next Presidential election. It will be, that is to say, the free expression of the judgment and the will of a free people. With us this has long been a commonplace. But it is becoming a much rarer thing in the rest of the world than it used to be.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 9. -- Revival of interest in the square meal as a national institution was cited as another evidence of returning prosperity here today by George R. Le Sauvage, assistant to the president of the F.G. Shattuck Company, in an address to 100 members of the New Jersey Home Economics Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Ever since tobacco, a commodity called basic in the Agricultural Adjustment Act, was restored to its pre-depression price status the question has been asked with increasing frequency: In what direction is the AAA headed and how long will it last?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A small piece of paper, bearing a sailorman's scrawl, arrived at the Navy Hydrographic Office today after a 6,500-mile trip in a bottle around the fringes of the North Atlantic which took five years to complete.

TORONTO, Nov. 9. -- Sweeney Schriner was too much for even the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight and the New York Americans tied the National League champions, 5 -- 5, in the opening local game of the major hockey league season.
LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Conservative party organizers have threatened tonight to adopt Fascist strong-arm tactics in the last few days of the election campaign if rowdyism at meetings is not ended.

FLORENCE. -- So far there is very little sign in Tuscany of wartime conditions. An exception is the rise in price of bread, flour, butter, oil, meat, wool, This means great difficulty and distress among those classes which until now have just managed to get along.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9 (AP). -- The lowest level of taxes in seven years, an increase of nearly 200 per cent in favorable balance of county funds, and greatly increased general efficiency are some of the advantages claimed for the county manager form of government by its proponents after nearly four years of experimentation in Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Carrying President Roosevelt's personal formula for a Canadian-United States reciprocal trade treaty, Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King left here for Ottawa today to put it up to his Cabinet.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- The Chicago Cardinals came to life in the final period of a National Football League game today to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles, 12 to 3, in slippery going at Wrigley Field before 6,000 spectators.

Whether the country's leading public-utility systems and allied investing companies intend to resist the control over them conferred on the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Public Utilities Act of 1935, many of them have already taken steps which either put them in line with the requirements of the act or which will put them in the corporate sense beyond its powers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -Confidence is felt that increased business activity will give the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad system an improved net income, but adjustment of present acute conditions could not be accomplished without recourse to the reorganization requested under court appeal, according to a statement Howard S. Palmer, president, issued to stockholders of the system tonight.

Pipe Major Hugh Grant of the Fourth and Fifth Seaforth Highlanders and bagpiper at Skibo Castle for the last twenty-one years, arrived from Scotland yesterday on the Anchor liner Caledonia. He was met at the pier by Roswell Miller, son-in-law of the late Andrew Carnegie, with whom he will stay for six weeks at 9 East Ninetieth Street.

A fire that was burning at least half an hour before it was discovered by an auto driver drove twenty-four families into yesterday's dawn from two four-story tenements at Third Avenue and 173d Street, the Bronx.

In answer to Emma Glasser's letter to THE TIMES, I venture to say that the competent regisitered nurse need not fear forced idleness. She has at least four or five fields of endeavor from which to carve out a career for herself. There is general hospital duty or supervisory, special hospital duty and private duty.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Speculative trading in corn was largely among local interests last week, neither side, however, making much headway on the long or short side. Wet weather in certain parts of the Corn Belt has delayed husking and marketing, while elsewhere, where harvesting conditions were favorable, the movement marketward was light.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Organized business is expressing emphatic disapproval of "recent trends in Federal legislation" in a referendum conducted by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- A deficit for July and August, first two months of the current fiscal year, was reported today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration. With the number of court attacks on the legality of the processing taxes mounting daily, the farm administration blamed temporary injunction proceedings for the lag in revenues.

TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Nov. 10 -- The Mohammedan priest, Pir Ishan Abdul Mutalieff, and three of his aides were ordered shot after their conviction of plotting a "holy war" against the Soviet Union, publication of the court decision disclosed tonight.

ROME, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Ita]y will honor the sixty-sixth birthday of a warrior King tomorrow as her contribution to a celebration known elsewhere in the world as Armistice Day. The celebration will catch King Victor Emmanuel III in the midst of the fourth war he has seen as sovereign.

PEIPING, Nov. 10. -- Although it is impossible to confirm Tientsin reports that Major Gen. Kenji Doihara, Japanese military representative in North China, had advised General Sung Cheh-yuan, commander of the Peiping-Tientsin garrison, that the time had arrived to declare North China's independence, bankers and municipal authorities of Peiping and Tientsin today joined in a formal defiance of Nanking's order nationalizing silver.

Mary McKiernan, 2 years old, of 3,000 Randall Avenue, the Bronx, who was injured in an automobile accident Saturday night with five other members of her family, died yesterday morning at Fordham Hospital, eight hours after the death of her father.

France wrested the honors from the United States in the $1,000 international military sweepstakes, the featured event of the gala performance of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 10. -- Mrs. Lafayette B. Mendel, wife of the Sterling Professor of Physiological Chemistry at Yale University, died in a hotel here this afternoon from an overdose of a drug which she had used under a doctor's prescription to induce sleep.

Big posters in Italy proclaim that fascism has molded a generation of "few words and many deeds." But it must also be a generation in whom the sense of humor has been completely molded out. No other kind of generation could maintain a straight face to hear itself described as one of few words.

With stores holding fairly substantial stocks as a result of the slowing up in sales activity, reorders were lighter in the wholesale markets here last week. There was a good demand for holiday merchandise, particularly in the lingerie and accessories departments, and supplies were also sought for January promotions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- President Roosevelt has approved a suggestion that his fifty-fourth birthday, Jan. 30, 1936, be again used as the occasion for a nation-wide birthday ball, whereby large sums of money may be raised to fight infantile paralysis, of which the Chief Executive was himself a victim fourteen years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71 on Nov. 6, compared with 71.5 a fortnight before, 71.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

GALLABAT, North Ethiopia, Nov. 10. -- After complete investigations, which were difficult owing to the lack of communications, it is now possible to give a reliable account of the present situation on the northern front. Ras Seyoum, who is staying near Makale with 18,000 warriors, has orders from Emperor Haile Selassie to harass the enemy.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 10. -- Armistice Day always is the darkest day of the year for Tom Little, veteran custodian of the property room at a major Hollywood movie studio.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The New York Giants, champions of the National Football League, today defeated the Paterson Panthers, 24 to 6, in an exhibition contest before a capacity crowd of 13,000 in Hinchcliffe Stadium.

A crowded house greeted Martha Graham with cheers at the first of two dance recitals at the Guild Theatre last night. The program contained two novelties in the form of solo dances, entitled respectively "Formal Dance" and "Imperial Gesture," but they did not constitute the real feature of the evening.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The currency plans of China are regarded here as having been inevitable and as the outcome of the silver policy of the United States. Therefore, it is reasoned, the Chinese steps are a reply to President Roosevelt's artificial price-raising movement, which could bring only chaos to the silver-using countries.

Breaking 96 out of 100 targets, T. H. Lawrence took the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He also won the scratch shoot at 155 targets, carding 142.

ESSEX, Conn., Nov. 10. -- With a stiff southeast breeze whipping the Connecticut River today, forty dinghies sailed through the continued regatta of the Essex Yacht Club. Mrs. Helen Hill of Larchmont, N. Y., had her name inscribed on the Roosevelt Trophy by leading in Class A, while W. L. Inslee of Montclair, N. J., apparently took permanent possession of the Essex Cup, the Class B prize.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 10. -- The annual battle between the independent fishermen or baymen of Great South Bay and trap fishermen began today as the former prepared to fight against the wholesale trapping of eels where the method is prohibited.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 10 (By Wireless) -- The advance of the Italian armies in the last few days on the northern and southern fronts has caused no dismay among the leaders of Ethiopia, least of all Emperor Haile Selassie.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- The Eastern season will enter its final session of the year when racing shifts to Bowie on Friday, but the eyes of turf followers tomorrow will be fixed on Pimlico, where the Walden Handicap is down for decision. This last rich test for juveniles offered by the Maryland Jockey Club has attracted seventeen of the most formidable youngsters left in training.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- More concerns in the field of banking and finance failed to show any net income on their 1933 income tax returns than in any industrial group, the Treasury Department reported today. Out of 446,842 active corporations filing returns, 337,056, or 75.4 per cent, reported no net income, and of the latter number, 99,314 were classified in the finance and banking group.

Two minutes of silence will hush the city's din at 11 o'clock this morning as the thoughts of millions of New Yorkers go back seventeen years to the hour when the roar of the guns died away along the western front.

The forward movement of last week's stock market, with more than 3,000,000 shares changing hands on Wednesday -- the largest business of any day in fifteen months -- was by Wall Street commonly ascribed to results of Tuesday's voting.

An ambulance, transporting a patient to Bellevue Hospital early yesterday morning was in a head-on collision with an automobile at Third Avenue and Twenty-third Street. Although the ambulance was overturned, none of the occupants was injured seriously.

Tenement inspection work as a "career" for young men in the Tenement House Department is suggested by the Charity Organization Society as one means of combating socially bad housing in this city. The suggestion was contained in letters addressed by Stanley P. Davies, general director of the society, to representative citizens asking them to help in a movement to increase the effectiveness of the Tenement House Department.

A bitter protest against the cruelty and futility of war is revealed in an exhibition of etchings by Kerr Eby, war veteran and noted artist, timed to open today at the galleries of Frederick Keppel Co., 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, coincident with the celebration of Armistice Day.

Boys hunting for a ball in the sewer at the southwest corner of Second Avenue and 128th Street in Harlem at 1:30 P.M. yesterday discovered two corrugated boxes containing parts of a man's body. Dr. Thomas Gonzales, chief medical examiner, judged from a superficial examination that the man had been between 25 and 30 years old, weighed between 180 and 190 pounds and had been powerfully built.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Breaking a precedent of twenty years, the so-called rank-and-file group of the New Jersey State Teachers Association introduced an opposition slate of nominees at the evening session today of the eightyfirst annual convention of the association, in the convention hall here.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 10 (AP) -John Godfrey Saxe, president of the New York State Bar Association, tonight announced the appointment of three committees to assist in framing the State's far flung anti-crime program.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85, which compares with 85 the week before, 85.3 two weeks before, 85.5 three weeks before and 85.8 four weeks before.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- An overwhelming sentiment among daily newspaper editors of the United States in favor of an immediate balancing of the budget was reported today by the National Economy League on the basis of straw vote returns from 377 inquiries.
A proclamation was issued yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in behalf of the annual membership roll-call of the Red Cross, which opens today and continues until Thanksgiving. The proclamation follows:

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 10. -- Although the Italian invasion on the northern and southern fronts seems to be well under way. Ethiopian officials here maintain the closest secrecy as to what has happened. No official statement on the progress of the war has been issued for five days and officials profess to be without any information about Makale or the situation at Gorahai.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- From a military viewpoint the Italians' capture of Gorahai in the South would seem to have more significance than their occupation of Makale in the North.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 10. -For the second time in a week a Philadelphia field hockey eleven invaded local fields today to administer defeat to a metropolitan team. Following the example of the Philadelphia first team, which gained a victory over Stuyvesant last week-end, a team from the Saturday Morning Club defeated the Long Island Association aggregation today, 4 goals to 0.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 10. -Young Republicans late tonight pledged full cooperation to the Republican National Committee and put forth a declaration of principles of the anti-New Deal youth movement.

Subsequent Sunday night benefits this season had better look to their laurels to achieve the high mark reached by last evening's second annual entertainment in aid of the American Federation of Actors at the Majestic Theatre.

The Rev. Dr. John Gass was instituted yesterday morning as the seventh rector of the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street. The service of institution was conducted by Bishop William T. Manning and he preached the sermon.

Steelworks operations have declined 1 1/2 points to 53 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly summary of the magazine Steel. The decline reflects a drop in consumer demand. As yet, the article says, there have been few speculative purchases of steel, despite the recent rise in prices of semi-finished steel, and the likelihood that finished steel prices soon will be increased.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,845,883,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest bearing discount bills.

The annual hunter trials of the Meadow Brook Hounds will be held today on the estate of Mrs. Middleton F. Burrell and Daniel S. Underhill in Jericho, L. I. About 100 horses are entered for the various competitions, which will be Judged by Mrs. Guy Carey, C. Wadsworth Howard and F. S. Von Stade.

MOUNT RAINIER, Md., Nov. 10 (AP). -- Police tonight arrested a man they said was Aubrey Hampton, 30, for questioning in connection with the slaying of Miss Corinna Loring two days before she was to be married. Police said that he was a former suitor of the girl.

A closely integrated fight by Protestants, Catholics and Jews to regain religious liberty in Germany, Russia and Mexico, where it has been curtailed by governmental action, and to preserve it in this country, where it is threatened by liberals, was urged yesterday morning by speakers of the three faiths at a meeting of the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall.

Still another Republican meeting is under way, this time at Des Moines, Iowa, where a Young Republican Club has for some time been emitting political thoughts. This gathering is to cover three days of speech-making. Apparently it is called a "rally," much as we say that a patient in a hospital has "rallied" after at severe relapse.

The world today was described as a congested road in which each nation drives according to its own rules, unwilling to make traffic rules for the good of all, by the Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street, in his sermon on the causes of war yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- The new commercial treaty with Poland and the progress toward placing Russia's 200,000,000-mark order have had a favorable effect on industry here. The barter agreement of 1934 with Poland, which has been replaced by the new treaty, worked unsatisfactorily for the Germans because the Poles exported without taking an offsetting volume of German goods, las the agreement required.
Most of the New York City Democratic members of the State Senate received some praise from the Citizens Union, in a report issued yesterday, on their records at the last session of the Legislature.

PARIS. Nov. 9 -- A decrease of 173,000,000 francs in the gold reserves of the Bank of France, the ratio falling from 74.92 to 74.36 percent, was shown in the return for Oct. 30. A remarkable feature of the present situation is the great amplitude and the frequency of international gold movements.

Pledging anew their fealty to the nation and its flag, more than eighty military, patriotic and civic organizations took part yesterday in the fourteenth annual observance of the Massing of the Colors, the picturesque ceremony designed to show that loyalty to the flag is still a living virtue among New Yorkers.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 10 (AP). -- The Green Bay Packers defeated the Detroit Lions in a National Football League game today, 31 to 7, scoring twenty-one points with a sensational second-half forward passing attack.

MANILA, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Philippine officialdom, playing host to a large group of distinguished Americans, plunged tonight into an ambitious round of inauguration week social activity as the prelude to the birth of the new Commonwealth on Friday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10. -- Joseph Stalin, Russia's dictator, had to borrow money from War Commissar Klementi E. Voroshiloff when a 12-year-old girl who had been his guest at a parade in Red Square asked for carfare home.

ROME, Monday, Nov. 11. -- Italy's invading forces occupied new outposts early today in advance of the main armies on both Northern and Southern Ethiopian fronts, Italian press dispatches from East Africa announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -October "was the nation's biggest home-building month in four years," with contracts for urban home construction totaling $55,100,000 in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

William M. Kingsley, New York University treasurer, announced yesterday that the university showed an operating surplus for the fifth successive year, in his annual report to the university council, which covered the operation of the treasurer's office for the fiscal year ended June 30.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- An effort is being made by the packers to keep prices of hogs in line with those of the dressed product. Pork loin prices have advanced $2 a hundred pounds from the recent low level, but are still $5 under the year's high price.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Nearly fivescore street repairing and sidewalk and curb projects in Jersey City, which would involve an expenditure of about $8,349,000, were the most numerous items listed by the WPA today in an announcement that a Treasury warrant would permit State Administrator Ely to initiate work on selected projects in New Jersey from a program which totals $12,685,529.

OTTAWA, Nov. 10. -- An arrangement looking toward increased reciprocal trade between Canada and the United States was believed close to realization today when Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King, postponing his Southern holiday, hurried from Washington back to Ottawa to put latest developments before his Cabinet.

The proposal by the La Guardia administration to move for immediate condemnation and removal of the Sixth Avenue elevated line is based upon an estimated cost of $12,551,000, it was indicated yesterday.

WARSAW, Nov. 10. -- Yesterday's anti-Semitic outbreaks in Warsaw colleges -- completely ignored by the government press -- were hailed by Nationalists today as "a splendid manifestation of the patriotic feeling of most Polish students."

Mayor La Guardia replied yesterday to a recent statement by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, that the number of city employes could be cut by 20 or 25 per cent. The Mayor, in a letter, said that the statement, was inaccurate and untrue and that Dr. Butler must have been deceived "by some willful person."

The firm of Robinson Smith and Frederick W. Ayer launches its career tonight with "Parnell," a new play by the late Elsie Schauffler, based on the tumultuous career of the Irish patriot. George Curzon takes the title role, Margaret Rawlings plays Katie O'Shea and others in the cast include Effie Shannon, John Emery, Ruth Matteson, Alexander Frank, Edward J. McNamara and Barry Macollum.
A smaller volume of bonds was called last week for redemption before maturity than in the preceding period. The recession was attributed partly to the election day holiday.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Nov. 10 (AP). -- In a case in which Senator Byrd of Virginia, Democratic critic of many New Deal measures, joined with other creditors in attacking the law, Judge John Paul, in United States District Court here, held the amended FrazierLemke Farm Mortgage Act unconstitutional.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 11. -- Japanese newspaper correspondents in North China warn their, readers that a declaration of North China's autonomy is imminent. Shantung, Chahar and Hopei Provinces will participate in the secession, it is said.

Gifts suitable for the holiday season will be offered for sale at a card party in behalf of the Silver Cross Day Nursery to be held tomorrow afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The funds realized will further the work of the nursery, which cares for and trains children whose mothers are employed during the day.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 10. -- The American Bankers Association will open tomorrow its sixty-first annual convention here with an attendance that promises to exceed 3,000.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10. -- National production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 53 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the rate in the two preceding weeks, but 1 point above that of two weeks before. In twelve weeks only small variations have occurred, in contrast with wide swings since 1932, when production was fairly steady, at the lowest rate in the depression.

A recent article referring to the children's division of the Domestic Relations Court conveys an erroneous impression of the intelligence of the delinquent children arraigned. Delinquent children are not bright on the average.

The World War cut short the preparations making for a premiere in English of Alfred Capus's four-act comedy -- comedy because like Dante's it has a happy ending -'The Adventurer," which had allowed the author to write "of the French Academy" after his name.

Declines took place last week on he commodity futures markets here in sugar, coffee, cocoa, hides and copper, while other staples were generally stronger. Trading was moderate throughout the week. In the cash markets, all the grains, raw sugar and lard eased, but gains were made by cotton, dairy products, zinc, tin, silk, gasoline and rubber.

ROME, Nov. 10. -- The southern or Somaliland front suddenly leaped into prominence today when news was received of the capture by General Rodolfo Graziani's forces of the important town of Sase Baneh, which lies considerably more than half way to Harar from Mustahil at the Italian Somaliland frontier.

Broadway's Sunday show question being what it is, which is to say uncertain, Catharine A. Bamman launched the fourth season and the seventh edition of her "Sunday Nights at 9" last evening at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre. Even when and if Broadway is knee-deep in Sabbath entertainments, full of actors getting double pay, Miss Bamman will probably keep on with her "Sunday Nights at 9."

It was surprising and exciting to enter Town Hall last night as Erica Morini, violinist, began the finale of Mozart's A major concerto. As a young girl Miss Morini had made herself known in this city as a performer of exceptional but uneven equipment.

For seventeen years Armistice Day has come and passed and most of us have given its observance a cursory and oblique thought at best. But those of us who have year by year sensed its significance have seen it as a twofold one. In the first place, it is the day upon which we commemorate the sacrifice of those who died in the last war.

The overwhelming victory of the Brooklyn Democratic organization, headed by Frank V. Kelly, in last week's election has revived talk of the possibility of picking a Brooklyn man for the Democratic nominee for Mayor in 1937, it was learned yesterday.

Gains of 40 to 47 points were registered last week on the New York Cotton Exchange, a contributing cause being a belief, later confirmed by the November crop report issued on Friday, that the current crop was smaller than the government estimate of a month ago.

Cincinnati is as a city set on a hill: good government has made it illustrious. For more than ten years its affairs have been conducted by a council elected by proportional representation and dominated by the so-called Charter group of practical reformers. The city boasts a city manager, the substitution of the merit system for spoils politics, a low tax rate and the highest credit rating of any American municipality.

By way of starting a company devoted to intimate revue, members of the Vilna Troupe, which made Yiddish theatrical history a dozen years ago, presented sample performances at the New School for Social Research on Saturday night and last night.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 10 (AP). -- A navy at least equal to that of any other nation and a "small but highly efficient army" were advocated for the United States tonight by General Malin D. Craig in his first public address since he became army chief of staff.

A 1,800,000-candlepower airway beacon, of the two-color type capable of penetrating space to an altitude of three miles and visible for sixty-four miles around, will be installed as a memorial to the late Will Rogers on one of the two Manhattan towers of the George Washington Bridge by the New York State Aviation Commission, it was announced yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Nov. 10. -- Many dinners were given in the Colonnades tonight, marking tomorrow's starting of the hunting season. Mr. and Mrs. John W. Davin entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Marlin G. Geiger and Marlin Geiger Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Johnson, Venable Johnson, F. W. Seymour and L. C. Percival.

WEST YARMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 10. -- Cape Cod raised its collective voice today in apparently unanimous resentment at the proposed removal from this historic section, by Henry Ford, of America's oldest windmill.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- In an address before 3,000 members of Episcopal parishes in Westchester County who attended the annual "Bishops' meeting" at the Westchester County Centre here this afternoon. Bishop William T. Manning said pagan influences which are strong in many colleges and universities must be driven out by Christian influence.

HONOLULU, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Ten thousand square miles of ocean was blocked off today as a testing area for the United States Navy's midPacific air fleet, operating from French Frigate Shoals, 759 miles northwest of here.

Four newcomers were amonll thesuccessful candidates for 13ositionson the N~w York Field Hockey Association first team, it was announced by Miss Ann.e Toomey,chairman of the selection committee, after a four-hour practice ofthc aspirants at Prospect Park.Brooklyn. yesterday.They are the Misses KathleenMarvin, Denise O'Brlen, MaryCoghlan, all of the Carroll Club,and Miss Irene Mahsr of Greenfield.Those who retained positions onthe varsity which will see action inthe Northeast tournament on theAdelphi College grounds in Garden

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Secretary Ickes, Ogden Mills, Governor La Follette of Wisconsin and Mayor La Guardia are among the speakers listed for this Winter's program of the Town Hall of Washington, announced today by Mrs. Richard V. Oulahan, director.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Open interest in wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade was 780,000 bushels larger at the close last week than the previous week, while in corn the gain was only 210,000 bushels, and in rye there was a gain of 64,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Ostensibly for the sake of economy and efficiency, but actually to lessen the tension that has existed in the headquarters of the American Legion "lobby" here for several years, Edward McElhiney Lewis, legislative officer of the Legion for the last fourteen years, was summarily dismissed yesterday.

Hugh Alessandroni former national titleholder, gave a rare exhibition of foils technique in a field which included most of the nation's best swordsmen yesterday to sweep through fifteen of his sixteen bouts and capture the competition staged by the Amateur Fencers League of America on the Fencers Club strips.

Gridiron togs will be stored away at many Eastern prep schools within the next few days because a number of leading teams closed their seasons during the past week-end. However, King Football will reign in domineering fashion for another three weeks, for high school squads in this vicinity will keep going strongly until the end of the month and, moreover, some prep school combinations will continue playing for another week or two.

Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Harlem court yesterday prescribed very drastic measures to curb the habit of Anthony Grolick, 52 years old, who said he had no home, of turning in false alarms of fire.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- With numerous influences at work in the world's grain markets, even the betterinformed operators, who usually are able to commit themselves correctly, are freely admitting that they are not in a position to plot their operations, with the result that the volume of business, considered from a pit standpoint, is not large.

Attendance records were broken at the twenty-eighth annual Fall exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, which closed last night at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West. The show was more successful from every standpoint than any the society had ever put on before.

In issuing the pamphlet report of the Oeneral Motors Corporation for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president, dedeclared that the public's support of the corporation's effort to stabilize employment was essential to insure success of the earlier introduction of new models of automobiles this year.
Several of the foreign currencies last week broke out of the narrow trading area which has characterized the markets of the last month. Special factors were responsible for these movements.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Quiet financial markets are considered likely here until after the elections on Thursday, but confidence has not abated and a victory by the National party, with a working majority of at least 100, would cause an upswing of prices.
WINCHESTER, Mass., Nov. 10. -Even as Lotta Crabtree, actress and philanthropist, savored the bittersweet of life before she died, so did her once-favored bay mare, Lotta.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Slight increases in New York State employment and payrolls for October were reported today by Industrial Commissioner Andrews.
Home sites and dwellings in Westchester, New Jersey and on Long Island were sold in brisk suburban activity reported over the week-end.

There existed at Armant until 1861 an extremely interesting temple built by Cleopatra the Great in honor of the birth of her son, Caesarion. This was completely demolished between 1861 and 1863 and the materials were used in the construction of a sugar factory; but prior to that date it had been visited and described by many travelers, and fortunately a number of drawings, plans and photographs of it were taken by them.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- More than 4,000 persons gathered tonight at the Westchester County Centre in a county-wide Armistice Day celebration, in which seventyseven Westchester patriotic organizations participated. A feature was the massing of colors by the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- After almost twelve years in exile, King George II of Greece, the eldest son of the unhappy King Constantine of the war years, agreed today to return to the throne that he held for only fifteen uneasy months in 1922-23.
May I suggest that a special session of Congress be called forthwith to empower the government to deal adequately with the crisis the world faces at this moment?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -The United States Marine Corps today celebrated its one hundred and sixtieth birthday. A radio program in which the high command participated marked ceremonies on ship and shore wherever detachments were stationed.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Tomorrow, seventeen years after the guns of the World War ceased firing, the great silence associated with Armistice Day will again fall upon Britain at 11 o'clock in the morning.
DETROIT, Nov. 10. -- Detroit's Red Wings and the New York Rangers opened their schedules and the National Hockey League season here tonight with a 1-1 overtime tie.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Nov. 11. -- A stream of fear-stricken refugees poured into the International Settlement last night and today from adjacent Chapel following widespread rumors that Japanese military action was impending in retribution for the unsolved slaying of a Japanese marine Saturday night.

Ed Stanley, Williams halfback, retained first place in the race for individual scoring honors in Eastern intercollegiate football by tallying two touchdowns against Wesleyan on Saturday and brought his total points for the season to 86. He has made fourteen touchdowns and two conversions.

A pageant in which 1,129 children and adults took part, all in costumes either of their nationality or of the organization to which they belonged, was given yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral in celebration of the silver jubilee of the Sisters of Our Lady of Christian Doctrine.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Boston Redskins displayed marked improvement today although they dropped their seventh straight National League game to the spectacular Chicago Bears, 30 -- 14, before a crowd of 16,000 at Fenway Park.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- Basing the prediction on records of the first nine months of 1935, the State Department of Health declared today that, barring unexpected developments, the birth and death rates of the State for the year would reach a new minimum.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- In October 1,515 stock corporations were formed in the State, according to records compiled by the division of corporations of the Secretary of State's office. This brings the ten months' total up to 15,546, which is forty-six less than in the ten months of 1934.

The problems confronting the maintainance of world peace were discussed last night by four speakers at the first meeting of the Alexander Forum Foundation, held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Nearly 500 attended the meeting.

THE THE NEW YORK TIMES printed recently an assertion by Dr. Ralph C. Epstein that if all incomes were limited to $5,000, and the excess redistributed, the average income would be increased by just $100.

KUALA LUMPUR, Federated Malay States, Nov. 10. -- The search for Sir Charles Kingford-Smith and Tom Pethybridge, missing with their plane on a flight from England to Australia, is still unsuccessful. Two flying boats of the Royal Air Force from Singapore, which searched between Singapore and Victoria Point yesterday, left Victoria Point this morning to survey the area to Rangoon.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Nov. 10 (Havas). -- With 5,000 warriors who have joined him in deserting the Ethiopian army, Mohammed Jahio, Sultan of Aussa, was on his way tonight to join the Italian Army.

MAKALE, Ethiopia, Friday, Nov. 8 (Delayed). -- Marching with General Ruggero Santini's column in the advance upon this city, officers had to form a vanguard to turn back over-eager troops who on Nov. 5 wanted to make one straight jump from Adowa to Makale.

Plans for a commercial mission to Latin America, in which representatives of leading American exporters will make a four-month tour of Central and South America for the purpose of stimulating business with the United States, were announced yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Armistice Day is celebrated this year with mixed emotions. We in this country have not forgotten the quickened and united national spirit with which we entered the war, nor the sense of relief and hope which animated us all when we saw it end. There have since been many disappointments and disillusions, but the things for which we stood a score of years ago are still fundamental in our convictions.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Nov. 10. -- Sergeant George E. Layman completed a routine cross-country flight from Middletown, N.Y., to this post at 5:40 o'clock tonight. Making the flight with him was Corporal H. W. Fisher. Although Layman had not stopped on the way, he landed here without his passenger.
DUBLIN, Nov. 10. -- Nineteen Irish harvesters returning from work in Scotland to their homes in the Aran Islands off the Donegal coast lost their lives in a boat disaster this week-end.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Nov. 10. -Captains Albert W. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson of the Army Air Corps will start at dawn tomorrow on a National Geographic-Army stratosphere flight, using the 3,700,000 cubic foot helium-filled balloon Explorer 2d, the largest free balloon ever constructed.

The New York art season continues its pace this week, variety perhaps setting the key of the attraction. Folk art having come to the fore again, the Whitney Museum opens tomorrow afternoon an exhibition of handicraft work indicative of the level of culture of the old Shaker communities of the United States, with special emphasis on the period 1839-1859.

Leaving his brother, Max, alone in his office at 135 Prospect Park Southwest, Brooklyn, shortly before 1 P.M. yesterday, Dr. Morris F. Wiener left by automobile for Manhattan, where he had an appointment to meet a friend at First Avenue and Fifty-second Street.

Mrs. Gordon Knox Bell and Mrs. Herbert L. Satterlee head a group of prominent women interested in the work of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York who have subscribed to the performance of "Pride and Prejudice" the night of Nov. 21 at the Music Box Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the institute.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Purchases of grain futures here last week were as follows:

The annual bazaar under the auspices of the Helpers, a philanthropic organization that maintains a settlement house at 113 East Eighty-fifth Street and relief enterprises for the poor, will take place on Wednesday in the small ballroom of the Plaza. A feature of the benefit will be a tea room where luncheon and tea will be served.

The Department of Labor waves a magic wand, and presto! -- the retail price of food, which had previously been above "normal," falls below it. This is the consequence of shifting the period on which the department's index of retail prices is based. For this purpose average prices in the year 1913 have hitherto been used.

General John J. Pershing urged that American youth should be trained for peace by the development of a spirit of sportsmanship and good will toward all nations, in a message broadcast yesterday over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

An attitude of preparedness and a firm stand against Socialism and Communism was urged yesterday by Governor Harold G. Hoffmann of New Jersey in an address at the annual Armistice Day services of the Trinity Bible Class of Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church of West New Brighton, S.I. More than 2,000 attended the services, which were held at 9 A.M. at the Ritz Theatre on Richmond Avenue, Port Richmond.

The history of the church is engraved on "the living hearts" of its members, Cardinal Hayes declared yesterday at the diamond jubilee celebration of the Church of St. Joseph of the Holy Family, 125th Street and Morningside Avenue.

MONTREAL, Nov. 10 (Canadian Press). -- Overwhelmed by racing flames, which rapidly turned a wing of St. Jean de Dieu Mental Hospital into a raging inferno last night, four violent male patients were burned to death. A fifth inmate died of heart failure induced by shock.

The Brooklyn Dodgers rushed over a touchdown on the Pittsburgh Pirates in the opening minutes of their game at Ebbets Field yesterday and poised themselves for a jump into undisputed possession of the Eastern Division lead in the National Football League.

Every once in a while some one wistfully portrays a utopia in which people crowd to libraries and concerts and picture galleries as they now do to prizefights and football games. But Americans do better in this respect than they are commonly credited with doing.
BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- The Reich Food Estate, the only "estate" thus far organized in the projected but still belated "State of estates," opened its third annual "Reich peasant day" in Goslar today.

PORT. WASHINGTON, L. I,, Nov. 10. -- The old Class A dinghies, innocent of frills and refinements, showed signs of a revival on Manhasset Bay today when seven of them turned out for the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's second regatta.

Our classic American phrase "All is over hut the shouting" describes aptly enough the British election campaign, not only in these its last days but from its beginning; and most of the shouting comes through the loud-speaker. The general result being admitted, the only crumbs of uncertainty to be picked up by the bettors are speculations on the number of seats that the Laborites will gain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- A program calling for $1,638,945 aid monthly to 104,501 needy undergraduates in 1,602 colleges and universities and for 4,500 graduate students in 177 colleges and universities throughout the nation was announced tonight by Aubrey W. Williams, executive director of the National Youth Administration.

Hans Lange will direct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on Nov. 20, 22, 23 and 24 in place of Otto Klemperer, who will rest during that week, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Klemperer has been conducting the orchestra since the opening of the season in the first week of October.

All reports this year regarding financial recovery in Great Britain have laid stress on what was described as the British "housing boom." Analyzing the nature and causes of this largely unexpected phenomenon, The London Economist in a special editorial article begins by emphasizing the magnitude of the boom.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Liberal fluctuations were made in lard futures here last week because of the prices on hogs, which declined early and had a good rally later. The volume of business was not large, and it is said that brokers for some of the large commission houses have been without orders at times, either to buy or sell.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- While President Roosevelt devoted part of today to preparation of his Armistice Day speech to be delivered at Arlington National Cemetery tomorrow morning at the hour when hostilities ceased in Europe seventeen years ago, the nation paid homage to the war dead today in exercises that will be continued throughout tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- A streamlined turkey is the goal of a new series of experiments by Agriculture Department scientists, one official saying:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -Conspiracies to fix prices and obstruct commerce in the wholesale distribution of candy were charged today against two New York associations and their affiliates and members by the Federal Trade Commission.
BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- Important negotiations between Italy and Germany are being carried on in Munich, where Baron Pompeo Aloisi, Italian delegate to the League of Nations, arrived incognito yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- Despite the impression here that the international situation has improved, in the sense that prospects for a direct Anglo-Italian conflict are diminished, business circles this week expressed anxiety, and even favorable reports of corporation meetings failed to check a decline on the Boerse.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., suffered his first defeat in defense of his title as world's three-cushion billiard champion today.

Millions of football fans the country over experienced their most poignant disappointment of the season late in the afternoon of last Saturday when the telegraph wires out of South Bend flashed the news of Notre Dame's defeat by Northwestern.

Mayor La Guardia's dispute with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler over the latter's statement that city payrolls could be cut 25 per cent was clarified yesterday when the Citizens Budget Commission disclosed that it had prepared the figures used by Dr. Butler.

BASLE, Nov. 11. -- Europe's leading central bankers seem to welcome China's shift from silver to the pound sterling as possibly important in helping to stabilize the world monetary situation eventually. They attribute it fundamentally to the United States silver policy and tend to believe its success depends on Washington's continuing to buy silver.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton, physicist, was "interested" in the report that the stratosphere balloon had apparently attained a new world altitude mark, but more so over its crew's statement that cosmic rays at a rate of 150 per minute had been counted near the flight zenith.

The National Municipal League announced yesterday the program of its forty-first annual conference on government, to be held on Nov. 25 and 26 in the Hotel Biltmore, Providence, R.I. The delegates will be greeted by Governor Theodore Francis Greene of Rhode Island and by Mayor James E. Dunne of Providence.

JERICHO, L.I., NOV, 11. -- A low, gray sky that contributed alternating drizzle and fog failed to mar the hunter trials of the Meadow Brook Hounds today on the estates of Daniel Underhill and Mrs. Middleton S. Burrill. The crowd in attendance was held down a bit, but there were nearly a hundred horses in competition and a full day of sport.

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- Armistice Day, of which no mention can be found in German newspapers and which apparently is not even remembered by the German public, came around at a time when interesting although somewhat nebulous diplomatic activities were going on.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- A reduction of 3 per cent in the Crop Reporting Board's estimate of the 1935 potato crop over the Oct. 1 prediction, coming with rapidly advancing potato prices, today appeared to assure abandonment of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's plans to raise the prices by spending $5,000,000 for diversion of potatoes from food to industrial uses.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- William Bradford, who came from England late in the seventeenth century to set up a printing press in Philadelphia and later became royal printer of New York at a salary of 40 a year, was hailed at exercises here tonight as "the greatest name in American printing."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Although depression losses to business are put at $26,631,000,000, sharp decreases in such losses in 1933 and 1934 brought the line of income produced on the national chart closer to the line of income paid out, Robert R. Nathan, chief of the Income Section of the Division of Economic Research writes in the Monthly Survey of Current Business of the Department of Commerce.

Harvey Shapiro, 'cellist, winner of a Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation prize, which means a New York recital, all expenses paid, gave the recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. His program included Strauss's Sonata in F, Op. 6; Sammartini's Sonata in G, Emanuel Moor's Rhapsodie, Op. 78; Saint-Saens's Concerto in A minor, Op. 33, and shorter items by Bloch, Gustav Saenger, Granados and Saint-Saens.

F.A. Cauchois and Z.G. Simmons tied for the high scratch cup in the handicap event shot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each gunner finished the regular shoot by breaking 97 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off, Cauchois broke 25 straight targets, and won the trophy. Simmons had 24.

CLINTON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Phalanxes of khaki-clad gunners swept across the 900 acres of the Clinton public hunting grounds, nine miles west of here, in a misty, gray dawn today and ushered in the New Jersey upland game season with a bombardment that rocked the peaceful countryside.

Seven residents of the lower East Side were in Bellevue Hospital last night suffering from food poisoning. Another returned to his home after emergency treatment. The police reported that all had eaten cream puffs about three hours before they became ill.

Count Robert van den Straten- Ponthoz, Belgian Ambassador to the United States; Princess Miguel de Braganca and Sir Frederick and Lady Williams-Taylor are among the prominent persons due today from Europe on the French liner Ile de France. Others coming on the ship from Havre via Southampton include:

A telephone call to the police at 2:35 o'clock this morning revealed the death by shooting of a man listed as Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, about 40 years old, in a room on the twenty-first floor of the Beckman Towers Apartments at 3 Mitchell Place, at First Avenue near Forty-ninth Street.
The people of New York City, who seventeen years ago greeted the armistice with a wild and impromptu carnival, observed its anniversary yesterday with solemnity and reverence.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 12. -- The tone of telegrams from China and the official attitude here suggest that the Japanese authorities, naval and diplomatic, desire to prevent the development of another Shanghai incident. The suggestion that the killing of a Japanese marine in Shanghai Saturday may have been the work of Communists, trying to stir up trouble between Japan and China, is helping to restrain nationalist excitement.

Retail trade here yesterday was active, the holiday serving to swell customer attendance in most establishments to a considerable degree. Despite warm weather during a good part of the day, sales increases ranging from 5 to 8 per cent over the sharp gains of the corresponding day last year were noted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The question whether any of the great utility holding companies will register with the Securities and Exchange Commission remained in the balance today as the commission continued preparing regulations for administration of the act.

The Greater New York Federation of Churches will discuss at its next meeting Nov. 21 the recent edict of the Sinking Fund Commission calling upon churches throughout the city to pay all bills issued to them by the Department of Finance for local assessable public improvements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- New Deal forces were heartened today when the Supreme Court refused to pass upon cases involving the validity of the amended Agricultural Adjustment Act's processing taxes and the Guffey Coal Control Law.

The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday that it had spent $12,679,775 in 1934, and at the same time made public the totals granted for specific divisions of its program, as embodied in its annual report.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the extension until Aug. 1, 1939, of the $31,610,400 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad which was due on Nov. 21.
WILLARD, Kan., Nov. 11. -- This Kansas community of a hundred residents was probably saved from destruction today through the use of a machine gun to puncture a flame-surrounded gasoline tank.

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- Prices on the Boerse weakened again today. As usual, financial commentators here attributed little significance to the developments on the market in view of the fact that all transactions of any importance are now being carried on independently of the Boerse and as privately as possible.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Nov. 11. -- Flights into the stratosphere in three balloons have been made on ten occasions. Three of these expeditions ended in accidents, and in two of them men lost their lives. In each flight the object was scientific research, including cosmic ray, meteorological, zoological and electrical studies.
"Crime et Chatiment," based on Dostoevski's "Crime and Punishment," begins an engagement today at the Cinema de Paris.

A demand for better merchandise, an appreciation of values and a new sense of discrimination on the part of the buying public have manifested themselves in the department store field within recent weeks, representing one of the most encouraging aspects of the upturn in business, according to Nell Petree, president of James HcCreery Co.

WEST YARMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 11. -- Apparently undisturbed by protests of native Cape Codders and scores of Summer residents over his sale for removal to Dearborn, Mich., of a 300-year-old windmill, oldest in America, Dr. Edward F. Gleason, surgeon, declared today that "it's a shame the news got out so soon," because the windmill was to be a surprise present to Henry Ford by the Ford Dealers Association of America.
Captain Al Barabas, Columbia's star halfback, was in uniform yesterday at Baker Field, but he did not participate in the heavy work given to other members of the squad by Coach Lou Little.

MANILA, Tuesday, Nov. 12. -- Trucks rumbling from the Governor General's palace this morning with Governor Frank Murphy's possessions, which are being scattered in temporary and inadequate quarters in preparing the palace for Manuel Quezon, the President-elect of the new Philippine Commonwealth, symbolize the confused and indeterminate state in which Mr. Murphy's future powers as High Commissioner have been left.

Mrs. Rose Engle of 70 Albany Street, Manhattan, keeper of a dry-goods shop in Far Rockaway, lost her handbag containing jewelry valued at $1,800 and $1.97 in cash on the subway yesterday morning, but it was returned to her by the police half an hour later.

The Second Annual Marine Exhibition held under the auspices of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York will open today at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street. It will continue for nine days, ending Nov. 20, and according to officials in charge, will be the largest exhibit of its kind ever held here, particularly as several other associations and societies allied to shipping have arranged their meetings concurrently.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 11. -- Prime Minister Mackenzie King announced today that the reciprocal trade agreement concluded between Canada and the United States had been approved by his Cabinet and would become operative in a few days.

It cannot be said that the President's Armistice Day address was pitched on a note of high hope and expectancy. Feeling it necessary to be entirely straightforward with the country, he drew a rather dark picture of world affairs. The war to end war has not done it.
