Since the "tasting" of American wines held by the Wine and Food Society on Oct. 24, several communications have appeared in your columns relative to the conduct of this affair and its attendant newspaper reports. I have been empowered by the executive council to make this reply:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Forty-four issues of municipal securities pledged with the Public Works Administration for Federal loans were offered for sale today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The aggregate principal of the securities is $5,339,500.

Night workers coming out of the Fourth Avenue subway at President Street in Brooklyn at 3:15 A.M. yesterday stumbled over a man's body. It lay on the glistening wet pavement, one bullet wound in the right temple, four in the body.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- With an estimated 2,225,000 on work relief jobs today, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, ordered fifteen more States dropped from the list of those receiving "dole" funds, thus leaving but twenty States.

Speed Kills Most. The week-end brought its usual grisly harvest of automobile killings, into which, no doubt, a variety of causes entered. But if the present nation-wide protest against slaughter by gasoline is to have effect we must not lose ourselves in refinements of analysis.

Tonight's arrival, this one at the Fifty-eighth Street Theatre, is "Mother Sings" (once called "Heritage"), by Hugh Stange. Mr. Stange is believed also to be the "William Crosby, Inc.," who presents it, and it is conceded that he staged it.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Walter P. Chrysler, American automobile manufacturer, was denounced today by Justice Sir Cyril Atkinson in King's Bench Court in delivering judgment in a conspiracy case which has lasted sixty-two days and entailed legal costs estimated at $200,000.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The Harvard varsity and freshman harriers were victors in the annual cross-country meet among the Crimson, Yale and Princeton today.
The Pius X School of Liturgical Music of the College of the Sacred Heart will be the beneficiary of a card party, fashion show and tea the afternoon of Dec. 2 at the Plaza.

Women interested in the work of the New York Committee of Mothers' Health Centres, of which Mrs. Frederic Cromwell is chairman, have taken over a pre-opening performance of "Abide With Me," the night of Nov. 19 at the Ritz Theatre. Proceeds will further the health program of the committee.

WEIMAR, Germany, Nov. 11. -- Fuehrer Adolf Hitler attended here today the funeral of the philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche's sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Foerster, who died at the age of 89 years, having devoted the latter part of her life to her brother's archives.

HARAR, Nov. 11 (by Wireless). -- Wounded Ethiopian soldiers are beginning to arrive in Harar from Gorahai, Sasa Baneh and other sectors of the southern front, where the Italians under General Rodolfo Graziani are rapidly pushing their way toward Harar and the Addis Ababa-Jibuti railway.

Five 1935 fellows of the American Academy in Rome are joint exhibitors at the Grand Central Vanderbilt Avenue Galleries this week. They are Robert Amendola, sculptor; Daniel Boza, painter; Robert Johnson McKnight, sculptor; James Owen Mahoney, painter, and Morris Early Trotter Jr., landscape architect.

Replies to questionnaires and referendums on opinion are sometimes illuminating, but they cease to be so when the questions beg the point, or even when they are of a highly general nature. Do you prefer peace to war? Do you favor fewer automobile accidents?

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11. -- The nation's bankers were urged here today to place an "embargo" upon the flow of credit to the Federal Government in order to force the administration to come to terms on a program of rigid economy, budget balancing and sane taxation.

Democratic members of the 1936 New Jersey General Assembly, meeting yesterday in caucus at the Hotel Plaza, Jersey City, elected Thomas Glynn Walker of Kearny as legislative minority leader and chairman of the caucus.

Surviving members of the War Industries Board, Woodrow Wilson's "right arm and right eye" in the World War, met yesterday at the Hotel Savoy Plaza together with some 150 associates and agreed that, come what may, the United States must not be involved in another European war.

The new buses will come to Eighth and Ninth Avenues today as a boon and a blessing. Here, as elsewhere in Manhattan, the ancient surface cars were long ago outmoded. They clanged and jolted their way up and down the avenues to the discomfort of passengers, the danger of pedestrians and the despair of neighboring storekeepers, making the whole neighborhood look more down-at-the-heel.
With realty sales activity comparatively light over the holiday week-end, interest was centred largely in the reports of new leases of business space.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 11. -- Dr. Vladimir Matchek, whose popularity in Croatia now almost outstrips that of the late Stefan Raditch, summed up the uncompromising Croat program to your correspondent today as "back to 1918" and "recognition by Belgrade of the Croats' full national sovereignty."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11. -- The American Bankers Association opened its annual convention here today with a series of divisional meetings devoted largely to technical subjects, but carrying, threaded through the technicalities, the underlying theme that recovery is definitely in progress and that the banking problems of the moment are those of a recovery period rather than, as in the case of problems discussed at recent conventions, those of crisis and reform.

OTTAWA, Nov. 11 (Canadian Press). -- A solemn national service of remembrance on Parliament Hill today gave expression to Canada's respect for and gratitude to the 60,000 Canadians who lost their lives in the World War.

A glittering array of fashion and the presence of many distinguished guests marked the large attendance at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. Many women in the boxes were dressed for the annual Horse Show Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria, their gowns and jewels adding to the brilliance of the night performance.

ROME, Nov. 11. -- Troops are already descending from the Eritrean high plateau on their way to Massaua, where they will embark for Mogadiscio to reinforce the army of General Rodolfo Graziani, whose series of remarkable successes on the Somaliland front have carried the Italian threat to the very heart of the Ethiopian Empire.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Dr. Leon N. Neulen, Superintendent of Schools of Camden, was elected president of the New Jersey State Teachers Association at the close of its eighty-first annual convention in the Convention Hall here this afternoons.

WHITE LAKE, S.D., Nov. 11. -- A gentle landing by the world's largest balloon in a field near here late today successfully ended man's most sensational venture into the heights of the stratosphere -- to an unofficially recorded altitude of fourteen miles.

Joe Murphy of Manhattan College lost twenty pounds in weight and found new speed afoot between cross-country seasons with the net result that he won the metropolitan intercollegiate championship over a five-mile Van Cortlandt Park course yesterday.

Urging that the people of this country rededicate themselves to the principles set up by those who gave their lives in the cause of peace during the World War, Governor Harold F. Hoffman, addressing the annual veterans Armistice Day gathering at the foot of the Lincoln Statue in Lincoln Park, Jersey City, yesterday, said that 50,000 American soldiers died in the cause of peace and safety for this country.
ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 11. -- The Ethiopian Foreign Office and military authorities assert that in the past week they have ferreted out virtually all Italian spy activities centring in Addis Ababa.

President ROOSEVELT spoke encouragingly yesterday of the outlook for a new reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Canada. There is one influence particularly favorable to such an agreement. This is Canada's proximity to our markets. Our Government is committed by numerous treaties to the most-favored-nation tariff system, under which concessions granted to one country must automatically be granted to all others.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 11. -- About 400 port directors from the four corners of the nation and Canada attended the opening session today of the annual convention of the American Association of Port Authorities.
The New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico conducting, will open its new season with a concert at Carnegie Hall tonight. Grete Stueckgold will be soloist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Martin H. Carmody, Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus, said in a letter made public here tonight that there was "nothing partisan or personal" in the letter recently sent to President Roosevelt criticizing his silence on Mexican religious matters.
Captains Stevens and Anderson, soon after landing last night on the open prairie near White Lake, S. D., spoke briefly over the National Broadcasting Company's network. Captain Stevens said:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 11. -- One of the largest parade crowds in the history of the city lined the sidewalks of Broad Street today to watch the annual Armistice Day march here. More than 100 organizations participated and the police estimated 8,000 were in the line of march.

Champion Ledgelands' Tuff Fei, striking red-coated entry belonging to Mrs. David Wagstaff's Ledgelands' Kennels of Tuxedo Park and shown by the veteran handler Ernest Wells, was adjudged the best chow at the fifteenth annual specialty show of the Chow Chow Club on the roof garden of the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 11. -- Commenting on current reports of a possibility of a new effort to reach a more tolerable relationship between France and Germany, tonight's Temps says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Completion of a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Canada was announced simultaneously in both countries today by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Mackenzie King. It was hailed by the President in his Armistice Day address at the Tomb of America's Unknown Soldier as another tie of friendship between two friendly neighbors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Pledging his determination to keep the United States out of future wars, and reiterating the administration's "good neighbor" policy, President Roosevelt, addressing nearly 5,000 veterans gathered in the Arlington National Cemetery and millions of others who listened at the radio, today challenged other nations to reduce armaments and promised that the United States would quickly follow such a course.

While the Chicago Bears maintained their big lead in ground gaining and scoring in the National Football League during the past week, Green Bay, won-and-lost leader of the Western Division, made a considerable advance, statistics released yesterday show. The Packers moved into second place in ground gaining and scoring.

In addition to gaining eight up-State Assembly seats and thereby recapturing control of the lower house of the Legislature, the Republicans wrested control of the Boards of Supervisors in a number of up-State counties, it was learned yesterday from reports received at Republican State headquarters.

Automobile accidents cost the lives of 122 persons throughout the nation over the week-end, according to an incomplete compilation made by The Associated Press yesterday. This total was nine greater than that of the preceding week-end and twenty greater than that of two weeks ago.

Harpers say they believe they have another best seller for the Christmas book trade in "Prophets and Poets," by Andr lVaurois. which they will publish on Dec. 1. They are pushing it to repeat the sales history of "Only Yesterday," by Frederick Lew/s Allen, which had a record Christmas sale when it was published.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The address of President Roosevelt in the amphitheatre at Arlington National Cemetery today was as follows:
RAPID CITY, S.D., Nov. 11. -- Explorer II, the world's largest balloon, took off today at 7 A.M. (Mountain time) on its long-awaited journey into the stratosphere for scientific exploration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Edsel Ford, president of the Ford Motor Company, rejected today the government's invitation to participate in a business-labor conference on needs for a new NRA.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 11. -- Fifty thousand, one of the largest crowds in Narragansett Park's two-year history, saw F.A. Carreaud's Ajaccio defeat Warren Wright's Crossbow II today after racing almost head and head during most of the $3,500 added Worcester Handicap.

The first annual solemn high requiem mass to be observed on Armistice Day by the Catholic War Veterans since its recent organization was celebrated yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. E. J. Higglns, founder and national chaplain.
Apartment rental reports show about equal activity on the East and West Sides of Manhattan, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The government lost today in the Supreme Court in its protest against returning $29,497 of Federal taxes to Samuel Untermyer, New York lawyer. The court refused to review a ruling by the Second Circuit Court of Appeals which held that Mr. Untermyer was entitled to the refund in taxes for 1918 and 1919.

The menace of a new world war arising from the international crisis caused by the Italo-Ethiopian clash was emphasized yesterday in a radio broadcast celebrating Armistice Day in which speakers representing six nations participated.

Defending their title for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup for contract bridge teams-of-four, the Four Aces got off to a lead of 4,220 points in the first thirty-six boards of their final match last night against quartet headed by Louis H. Watson at the Park Lane Hotel.
Provided contractual regulations are complied with, the Triborough Bridge Authority will make no effort to prevent the purchase of German sheet steel piling for the Queens approach to the bridge.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Stocks of unconsumed goods -- especially raw materials -- were reported at encouragingly low levels today by compilers of official figures.

Charley Jamin's field goal from the 25-yard stripe in the early minutes of the final quarter was the determining factor in St. Peter's Prop's triumph over Brooklyn Prep's eleven yesterday at Boys High Field, Brooklyn. A crowd of about 500 students saw the Jersey City team win, 9 to 7.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov, 11. -- Wounded Ethiopians brought here from Gorahai, the first to arrive, declare an appalling battle raged daily and nightly for four days at that town.

New York money market closed for holiday. Saturday's closing rate for Stock Exchange call loans, 3/4 of 1 per cent; for sixty-day time loans, 1 per cent; for prime commercial paper, three to four months, 3/4 of 1 per cent.
ADDIS ABABA. Nov. 11. -- Emperor Haile Selassie tonight ordered 40,000 troops rushed from the capital to Jijiga in a supreme effort to hold that key town against an Italian assault from the south.

The stars as they shone on Flanders Field on the night of Nov. 10, 1918 -- the last night of the World War -- shone again yesterday for 6,000 men, women and children who flocked to the eighth special performances at the Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

The American Bankers Association opened its annual convention yesterday in New Orleans in an atmosphere of greater optimism than has marked its gatherings for several years. Our correspondent at the convention notes none of the tension which prevailed a year ago in Washington, when an open break with the Administration was narrowly averted and a "truce" arranged only the last moment.

PARIS, Nov. 11. -- Political fever ran high throughout today's celebrations of the anniversary of the armistice which ended the World War seventeen years ago. Officially it was the past that was remembered and those who died in the great war who were honored.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Funds making possible repairs on seventeen armories in New York City under the WPA program were made available today by J.R. McCarl, Controller General, who countersigned Treasury warrants on WPA projects for the city costing $1,638,492.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Stolen bonds bought in good faith do not have to be returned to their owner, the Supreme Court ruled today in a unanimous opinion by Justice McReynolds. The finding was in the case of Richey V. Graham of Chicago, from whose home $35,000 of Illinois highway bonds were stolen Sept. 2, 1930.

Anti-sedition legislation such as that requiring teachers to take a special oath of allegiance to the Constitution is a dangerous step toward crippling democratic ideals, according to Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, who spoke at the twentieth annual meeting of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Out of the inflamed records of a celebrated career Elsie Schauffler composed a passionate drama, "Parnell," which was beautifully acted and staged at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. The past tense is lamentably accurate, for Mrs. Schauffler died a few weeks ago, just at the moment when her play was on its way to rehearsal.

Thirty-five thousand needy high school and college students in this State are still awaiting the first of the monthly subsidy checks that the National Youth Administration was scheduled to send them six weeks ago, it became known yesterday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- A bruised and battered Army squad returned to the gridiron today and went to work in earnest for the Notre Dame game at the Yankee Stadium Saturday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- Scraping the fence with one boot, and staving off the staggering Wise Duke with the other, Jockey Wayne Wright brought Willis Sharpe Kilmer's Ned Reigh through the Pimlico stretch today to win the $11,220 Walden Handicap before 15,000 spectators.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. ll. -- Members of North Shore society and visitors from New York filled to capacity tonight the Theatre of the Four Seasons, a new playhouse remodeled from the Roslyn Neighborhood Centre by Charles Hopkins and Grant Tierney, who presented for the first time in America "The Rag Picker of Paris, or the Modest Modiste," an old French melodrama by Edward Stirling, revised by Christopher Morley.
LONDON, Nov. 11. -- The stock market here today was quieter owing to the approach of the general elections on Thursday, but trading had a firm tone.

The program of social events held this season in connection with the Horse Show was climaxed last night with a large and colorful ball at the Waldorf-Astoria. The guests of honor were the officers of the international military jumping teams who have thrilled thousands of spectators in Madison Square Garden during the past week in spectacular performances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Charges have recently been made that, just before the elections of Nov. 5, the administration for political purposes released great work-relief sums which had been deliberately held for that period. The rate was estimated at $27 a voter, for example, in Poughkeepsie ($475,000 in all) and $40 a voter in Kentucky (about 42 millions).

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Great Britain honored her million war dead today in an impressive service at the Cenotaph in Whitehall with deeper emotion than has been displayed since the armistice seventeen years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The "utmost importance" of maintaining the Red Cross as a great national relief agency was stressed today by President Roosevelt in opening the annual Red Cross roll-call, which will continue until Thanksgiving Day.

United action by the English-speaking peoples of the world to prevent future wars and the "interdependence" of the United States and Canada were urged yesterday by Colonel the Venerable Archdeacon J.M. Almond of Montreal, director of chaplains of the Canadian Corps in the World War.

Ever since Professor AUGUSTE PICCARD ascended in a hermetically sealed globular car to a height of 53,136 feet in 1932, physicists have protested that they are not interested in breaking the altitude record. They protest too much. Unless they do ascend to heights never before attained by man there is no scientific excuse for aeronautic ventures such as those sponsored by the National Geographic Society and the United States Army.

Mayor La Guardia agreed with Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday that the police who handled the Samuel Druckman murder case in Brooklyn had done all in their power to have an indictment returned by the Kings County grand jury, but both officials insisted that the case should be presented anew to a different grand jury.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- Albert E. Morton, alias Whitey Lewis, sought since Saturday for the murder of State Trooper Warren G. Yenser near Elizabeth, N.J., ended his life with gas today in a rooming house at 2,223 North Fifteenth Street here.

A four-year program of town-planning and housing studies, aided by a grant of $24,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, will be undertaken at the Columbia University School of Architecture, it was announced yesterday by Professor Leopold Arnaud, chairman of the school's committee on administration.

The Consumers Public Power Plant Committee, which is supporting Mayor La Guardia's proposal for a municipal electric plant, yesterday produced photostatic copies of reports of the Brooklyn Edison Company to the Public Service Commission to substantiate the charge that the company had paid $21,250 to the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce during 1933, 1934 and 1935.

Coincident with the beginning of bus operation on Eighth and Ninth Avenues today, replacing the trolley service, Central Park West will again become a two-way street for vehicular traffic, it became known last night.

Columbus, Ohio, on the eve and day of the Notre Dame game put on a fair imitation of a college town in the throes of football delirium, but any one who would like to imbibe the rah-rah spirit in its undiluted and unadulterated essence is advised to proceed up-State to Syracuse with his pup tent.

A full-grown, full-winged blue peacock flew over the fashionable shopping district at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street yesterday morning and started three patrolmen, three men from the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, two attendants from the Central Park Zoo and reporters and photographers on a chase that lasted three hours and ended on top of the Plaza Hotel.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Nov. 11. -- The members of the crew of the Explorer II by training and experience were well fitted for their task. Both men went into the stratosphere last year and when their balloon burst escaped death by leaping in parachutes.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 11 -- Premier Mussolini is taking a desperate gamble in his invasion of Ethiopia, but one in which he has the massed strength of the Italian nation behind him, Irving Squire, author and commentator, who returned ten days ago from Rome, told the annual convention of the State Federation of Woman's Clubs here tonight at its first session.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- Welker Cochran, San Francisco, widened his lead in the world's three cushion billiard championship tournament tonight by defeating Allen Hall, St. Louis, 50 to 41 in 47 innings. It was Cochran's fourth straight victory. Cochran had a high run of 5 and Hall, 8.

Often it is claimed that the American public, even the musically cultured public, loves a sensation above most things. Well, the concert given last night in Town Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra, Hans Lange conductor, provided a sensation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- There was an aggressive demand for hogs here today as the result of cold weather and an advance of 1/2 to 1 cent a pound in the price of fresh pork loins. The general market was quoted as 10 to 25 cents a hundred-weight higher than at the close of last week, with some light kinds up more.

DUBLIN, Nov. 11. -- Shops and residences were tightly shuttered today as the little island of Aran mourned nineteen persons, several heads of families, lost over the week-end when their boat capsized while returning from Donegal. Nine bodies have been recovered.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- "Neutrality will never end wars nor can it long be preserved by a nation as large as ours while wars are under way." The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church of New York City, told a denominational mass meeting in Trinity Church this afternoon.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11. -- Voicing determined opposition to multiple taxes on the oil industry, and diversion of State gasoline tax funds to other than highway building purposes, 3,000 leaders of the oil industry convened here today in the sixteenth annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute.

Detective John J. Callahan of the safe and loft squad, who has been assigned to make investigations with the postal authorities, was struck from behind by an unknown assailant early last evening as he was walking north on Columbia Street, near the approach to the Manhattan Bridge.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Nov. 11. -- When the Explorer II rose from the floor of the Bonanza Bar Canyon this morning, it broke several world's records. It was the largest free balloon ever built, having a capacity of 3,7000,000 cubic feet, 700,000 more than last year's stratosphere balloon.

Twenty hardy survivors of the numerous early-season football upsets stood up well against further assaults. The list of undefeated and untied teams compiled by The Associated Press lost only Notre Dame, which was upset by Northwestern, and Western Reserve, held to a tie by Ohio Wesleyan.

John G. Jackson of New York will become president of the United States Golf Association at its next annual meeting to be held early in January. Moving up from the post of vice president, he will succeed Prescott S. Bush of Greenwich, Conn., who has held the office for the past year.
Eric Seelig, former welterweight and middleweight champion of Germany, knocked out Charley Belanger, Winnipeg veteran, in the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11. -- In a letter to the National Trust Company, as receiver and manager of the Great Lakes Paper Company. Charles Vining, president of the Newsprint Export Manufacturers Association of Canada, denied today a report which has been circulated in financial circles.

James Chapin deserves a hearty welcome upon the occasion of his return to the local exhibition field after an absence of three seasons. He is having a one-man show at the Rehn Gallery, 683 Fifth Avenue. It opened yesterday and will continue through November.

Net income of the Davison Chemical Company and all of its subsidiaries, including those in receivership or trusteeship for the fiscal year ended on June 30 amounted to $901,004 before provision for depreciation and Federal income taxes, the trustee reports.
Captains Stevens and Anderson, besides going higher in the air than any other expedition, set a record yesterday by keeping up an intermittent conversation over the radio for nearly eight hours.

A sellers' market, the first of substantial proportions which furniture manufacturers have enjoyed in more than ten years, developed yesterday at the New York Furniture Exchange, where 500 manufacturers are displaying Spring lines of merchandise.

Trial of two officers of the Ward liner Morro Castle and an executive of the Cuba Mail Steamship Company will start this morning at 10:30 o'clock before Judge Murray Hulbert in the Federal court in the old Postoffice Building. The operating company also must answer to charges of negligence that resulted in the burning of the liner with the loss of 124 lives off Asbury Park, N.J., the night of Sept. 8, 1934.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. ll. -- Two youngsters, 14-year-old Bryce Kirk and 18-year-old Vic Romagna Jr., carried off the honors today in a dinghy regatta marred by calm and fog on Manhasset Bay.

Twenty-five thousand persons demonstrated their will to peace yesterday morning by gathering at the foot of the Eternal Light in Madison Square Park in the city's official tribute to those who died in the "war to end war."

PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., Nov. 11 (AP). -- William A. Rockefeller was reported by reliable sources today to be completing negotiations for the purchase of part of a huge tract of forest land at Baypool in the Northern Adirondack Mountains. The tract is one of the largest in the Adirondacks and embraces nearly 60,000 acres, mostly woodland.

IT was an extra large huddle, with Chick Meehan in the middle. Dick Harlow was on the fringe. He wasn't turning any handsprings for pure joy over the result of the Princeton-Harvard encounter. "But I will say this," remarked Mr. Harlow. "Princeton was just about as good a team as I've seen in a long while."

Bill O'Brien, the professional tennis promoter, announced yesterday that Mrs. Ethel Burkhardt Arnold of California, member of the Wightman Cup team that defeated England this year, has signed a contract to go on tour.

Despite objection by many business men and industrialists that the procedure will involve unnecessary bookkeeping and expense, the State Department of Labor plans to require employers to provide, beginning Jan. 1, unemployment insurance data for every individual employe, according to a tentative reporting plan that will be submitted to the Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council on Thursday.

More than thirty-five groups, representing the British Empire, France, Belgium, Poland and the United States, massed colors last night at the fifteenth annual ball of the British Great War Veterans of America at the Hotel Astor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- Supported by June Walker and a first-class cast, Frank Craven appeared before an appreciative audience at the Broad Street Theatre here tonight in the premiere of "For Valor," a two-act comedy by Martha Hedman and Henry Arthur House.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11. -- Efforts of the government to convict five individuals and eight corporations outstanding in the moving picture production field of violation of the anti-trust laws failed today when a jury returned a verdict of acquittal for all the defendants.

Once more in Madison Square Garden last night the strains of the "Star-Spangled Banner" echoing through the great arena proclaimed the victory of an American Army officer in an international military Jumping event at the National Horse Show.
The recent economic controversy in your columns affords an excellent illustration of the general confusion, as well as lack of realism, prevalent in that field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Italy has challenged every member of the League of Nations to accept individual responsibility for any sanctions that it may impose, and has asked every country now considering sanctions to make known its intentions.

ROME, Nov. 11. -- In an atmosphere of fervid patriotism aroused by recent news from East Africa, Italy today celebrated King Victor Emmanuel's sixty-sixth birthday with impressive military displays. The King being detained at Turin, Premier Benito Mussolini acted as his deputy in Rome and was the principal figure in a great review of the nation's armed forces.

KIMBALL, S.D., Nov. 11 (AP). -- Elated but weary, Captains Anderson and Stevens slipped into Kimball late tonight, bade several hundred well-wishers "good-night" and retired in a small hotel without announcing plans for the future. Both expressed complete satisfaction with the flight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- At today's session of the Supreme Court every one of the nine justices differed at one time or another from his colleagues in the opinions handed down. The court split in varying degrees on at least ten of its twenty-one rulings, five of which were joined in one issue.

The complaint against the five girl dancers arrested last Friday night at Heckscher Theatre, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, at the annual benefit show of the Society of Illustrators, was made public yesterday. Signed by Detective Joseph Radzik of the Sixth Division, one of the men who made the arrests, it will be presented in Harlem Court on Thursday morning, when the girls are arraigned.

The practice of "smoking out" bears has long been an American pastime, but when spectators suggested smoking out Mrs. Flynn's cat, which fell down a chimney yesterday from the roof of an apartment house at 321 East Ninety-first Street, a representative of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals vetoed the idea.

Joyce Kilmer, poet and newspaper man, who was killed in the battle of the Oureq on July 30, 1918, was eulogized yesterday at a memorial service conducted under the auspices of the Bozeman Bulger Post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and broadcast over WNYC.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Nov. 12. -- Tension increased in Chinese-Japanese relations today with reports of the stoning of a Japanese school girl while the Japanese Government formally requested the immediate arrest of perpetrators of disorders last night.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11. -- Southern Methodist University's Mustangs galloped all over the big Memorial Coliseum today to crush the University of California at Los Angeles, 21 to 0.

In the thirteenth game of the world chess championship match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine and Dr. Max Euwe, recently contested at Amsterdam, the Ruy Lopez was adopted for the first time in the series as an opening.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The systematic daily exercise taken by President Roosevelt was suggested today by Captain Ross T. McIntire, White House physician, as a good idea for all the people.
RAPID CITY, S.D., Nov. 11. -- The log, of the stratosphere flight was as follows (given in Central standard time):

In a recent issue of your paper Robert Bruce alleges: "It was approximately a century after Washington's Farewell Address, in which he counseled against foreign entanglements, that the United States entered the war with Spain, starting a policy of expansion with inevitable complications."
BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- Germany indirectly joined countries taking sanctions against Italy today by placing a blanket embargo on certain important products regardless of their destination.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- The Boerse weakened again today, but activity was much greater than it had been recently. The market was wholly under the influence of heavy outside selling of securities which was welcomed back on the Boerse even if it involved increased pressure on already falling prices.

There is much food for thought in the statement in your editorial "The Result in Kings County" that "the outcome was a triumph for party regularity and experience in office over the dashing leader of a not too compact body of followers."

Because a special panel of 100 talesmen had been exhausted when only nine jurors had been chosen, the General Sessions trial of Frederic J. Fuller, Harry A. Kahler and H. Pushae Williams, former officers of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company, had to be adjourned late yesterday afternoon until tomorrow.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 12. -- The Dartmouth football team had a long workout today in a steady downpour which made footing unsure.
Democratic members of the Board of Aldermen split yesterday and the board declined to override Mayor La Guardia's veto of the $5,900,000 cut in city water rates.

COLUMBUS, Texas, Nov. 12 (AP). -- A mob estimated at 700 persons, including several women, tonight took two Negro youths accused of the murder of Miss Geraldine Kollmann, 19, from Colorado County officers and hanged them to a tree four miles north of here.

THE TIMES editorial "Business at a Peak" says that "cotton manufacturers were rushing to lay in stocks of materials" when the first NRA codes were being written, and later you refer to this as "speculative buying to beat the gun on NRA."

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- The Chrysler Corporation of Detroit and four of its executives, including Walter P. Chrysler himself, were ordered by Justice Sir Cyril Atkinson today to pay 39,500 damages, with 5 per cent interest from March 1, 1928, in the conspiracy case which has lasted for sixty-four days.
The foreign exchange market had a mild respite yesterday from its recent activity. The change was attributed in part to the situations facing the French and Italian currencies.

The Great Northern Railway's management is considering a plan of recapitalization calling for changing its $100-par preferred stock to no-par stock in order to facilitate the refunding of $107,000,000 of 7 per cent bonds which will mature next July 1. Stockholders will vote on the financing plans on Dec. 20.

Miss Vera Stretz, 23 years old, a strikingly good-looking young woman with ash-blond hair, coolly admitted yesterday morning to a policeman that she had shot and killed Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, wealthy German economist and financier, in the doorway of his apartment at 3 Mitchell Place.

Two days before Will Rogers took off on his fatal plane trip to Alaska, he promised to send two horses to his friend, Will Hays. Mr. Hays received word here yesterday that Mrs. Rogers had sent the horses to his California ranch.
Sales of several housing properties in the Bronx and a midtown business building in Manhattan were included in the list of realty transactions reported yesterday.

For about three years a Foreign Office ban has held up the publication of George Seldes's "Sawdust Caesar" in England. This is a book on Mussolini and fascism which has been suppressed since 1932 "owing to the very friendly relations between Britain and Italy."
Lateral and trick plays near an offensive team's goal are inadvisable, John W. Heisman, veteran football coach, said yesterday at the weekly Football Forum at the Downtown Athletic Club.

Franz Werfel, the Austrian author and playwright, expressed in an interview yesterday his "deep respect for American contemporary literature," and added that he was "deeply convinced that something worthwhile will emerge from the American effort."

A warning that detrimental effects upon retail trade and consumer spending would result if production industries are successful in obtaining approval by the Federal Trade Commission of fair trade practice rules of the type now being submitted to that body was issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Association of Buying Offices.
Victory in the stratosphere is like so many other triumphs of man. It involves knowledge, skill, preparation, courage, discipline, and, in the emergency, a needle and thread or something of the sort.

To fifty members of the League of Nations MUSSOLINI has sent an identic note about sanctions as applied to Italy. Nothing will be done in retaliation at present, but Italy will cherish a grievance against each of the nations joining in the penalties, and will wait for an appropriate time of punishment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today eleven registrations under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of securities valued at $17,715,349. These are in addition to five recent registrations by utility companies for an aggregate of $169,879,000, and two issues totaling $14,809,125 by other corporations, details of which were made public at the date of filing.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 12. -- A 13-year-old boy was shot and critically wounded here tonight by an irate watchman who objected to the boy and his two companions playing in a vacant lot adjoining the factory in which he was employed.

District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn and Police Commissioner Valentine were at odds yesterday on the question as to whether the Druckman murder case should be resubmitted to a new grand jury on the basis of evidence upon which the April jury failed to take action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted as murderer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., brought his case finally to the highest court in the land when Egbert Rosecrans of the prisoner's counsel deposited with the Supreme Court today a petition demanding a review of the action of the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals in sustaining Hauptmann's conviction by the trial court at Flemington, N.J., last February.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Two scientists at Western Reserve University announced today that argon, one of the "inert" gases of the atmosphere, can be made to form a chemical compound with boron fluoride.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- A committee of 180 business men and civic leaders was named today by George W. Young, president of the Association of Commerce, to begin the drive for bringing the Republican and Democratic conventions to Chicago in 1936.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Army practiced in the fog and mud today in preparation for the Notre Dame game. The Cadets had a long period of work devoted chiefly to defensive formations against the Rambler style of attack. There was much shifting about of players as Gar Davidson drove his men through the spirited drill which lasted until after dark.

A stockholder's suit in equity seeking to recover common stock of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., to the amount of $6,500,000 which is said to have been transferred for no consideration and for an injunction restraining officers of the corporation from voting proxies approving settlement of another stockholders' suit was filed yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn.

The people of the United States have demonstrated clearly their determination to avoid participation in armed conflict, Secretary of State Cordell Hull asserted in a message read last night at a "neutrality mass meeting" of the League of Women Voters at the Hotel Astor.

The four largest shipbuilding concerns in the United States refused yesterday to offer the United States Lines a bid on specifications for a new liner planned by the company for the transatlantic run with the liners Manhattan and Washington.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 12. -- Jimmy Hines of Garden City and Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills, L.I., put together a brilliant 65 today to lead the field in the first round of the professional best-ball golf tournament for pairs.

Indignation over the ordering of $19,000 of German sheet steel piling for the $62,000,000 Triborough Bridge continued to mount yesterday. Labor officials joined American steel producers in protesting the purchase as being contrary to the spirit of PWA and unfair to American interests.

Religious organizations throughout the city began yesterday to plan a campaign to force the City Sinking Fund Commission to rescind its action of a month ago requiring churches and other institutions exempt from real estate taxation to pay assessments for improvements.

The proposed free foreign trade zone on Staten Island received both vigorous opposition and approval at the official hearing held at 45 Broadway yesterday before the Examiners Committee of the Foreign Trade Zones Board.

Births in New York City showed a decline last week from both the preceding week and the corresponding period of last year, according to the weekly report of Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records of the Department of Health. A total of 1,673 live births was reported, compared with 1,894 the week before and 1,787 last year.

Plans for a memorial for Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, who died on Nov. 6, were started yesterday by the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History at the board's Fall meeting. A memorial committee will be appointed within the next few days by F. Trubee Davison, president of the museum, it was announced.

A "marked increase" in the number of special gifts and memberships during the first two days of the present Roll Call of the New York Chapter, Red Cross, was announced yesterday by Mrs. David Challinor, roll call director. Hopeful signs that the $400,000 needed for relief and other activities of the chapter would be raised by Thanksgiving were reported.

Action of the Supreme Court in denying motions to hasten progress of test cases involving the processing tax and the Bankhead act had a stimulating effect on prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. With final decisions delayed, the outlook for continued government control of production seemed to be strengthened, and speculative activity increased.
ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 12. -- A communique issued today states:

A jury before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert was selected yesterday to decide whether William F. Warms, captain of the Ward Liner Morro Castle, had committed acts of negligence which were responsible for loss of life when that vessel burned Sept. 8, 1934.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- Jews emigrating from Germany constitute a substantial source of revenue for the National Socialist government which Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, has himself described as "anti-Jewish."

A move to bring about the construction of a city-owned yacht basin in the Hudson River off upper Manhattan was announced yesterday by representatives of boating associations and the Washington Heights Chamber of Commerce.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 12. -The Elizabeth Town and Country Club and the Plainfield Country Club won Class B matches in the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League today. The former scored decisively over the Short Hills club, 4 -- 1, at Elizabeth, but the latter subdued the Essex County Club here by only 3 -- 2.
"Thanks a Million," featuring Dick Powell, Ann Dvorak and Fred Allen, opens this morning at the Center Theatre, Radio City. Also on the program will be the latest release of "The March of Time."

Following execution of a heavy accumulation of buying orders as a result of the extended week-end, occasioning a long list of new high marks for individual issues, the share market was called upon yesterday to absorb considerable profit-taking during the late morning.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 12. -James Spillane, 28 years old, of 26 Van Nostrand Avenue, Jersey City, who led Motor Cycle Policeman Charles Nolan a two-mile chase and attained a speed of eighty-two miles an hour while intoxicated at the wheel, was fined an unprecedented amount by Recorder Daniel J. Murray in Police Court today.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Interest in the British general election has now narrowed down to the number of parliamentary seats Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's government is going to lose. The Conservative leaders are anxious, not because of fear of defeat, but because of the manner in which their greatly reduced majority in the next House of Commons may be interpreted in foreign countries, especially in France and Italy.

MOUNT RAINIER, Md., Nov. 12 (AP). -- Releasing a fiance and a former suitor of the slain church worker, Corinna Loring, police decided today to question members of her family in a search for further clues.

Stark is the polite word for Hugh Stange's "Mother Sings," which was acted at the Fifty-eighth Street Theatre last evening. So stark, in fact, that a playgoer who has just been released from gratuitous misery instinctively takes refuge in raillery. For Mr. Stange, one-time author of "Veneer," has taken the worst features of "Desire Under the Elms," "The Silver Cord" and "Tobacco Road" and combined them in psychopathic guignolism.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 12. -- Efficient transportation is the key to the country's industrial life and its defense, Major E.M. Markham, chief of engineers of the War Department at Washington, told the Association of American Port Authorities at today's convention session.

For many months the unproduced property of Jed Harris, "Ethan Frome" now belongs to Max Gordon. And Mr. Gordon, far from keeping it quiet, will present it as soon as possible. His immediate problem is one of casting. Ruth Gordon is definitely set for the company.

Frankie Madden, the Bowery Bhoy, who brought great honor and prestige to the East Side twenty-five years ago as he went from one fight club to another battering down the leading lightweights of that period, died in the alcoholic ward at Bellevue Hospital yesterday.

John Carroll gave his annual song recital at the Town Hall last night, presenting a program in which the recognized classics had little part. Mr. Carroll has a light baritone that reaches well up into the tenor range, and he chose songs of an intimate, popular character suited to the quality of the voice.

KIMBALL, S.D., Nov. 12. -- The third stratosphere balloon flight sponsored by the United States Army and the National Geographic Society, as far as Captain Albert W. Stevens and I were able to tell, was a success in every way.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 12 (AP). -- Liquidation of the Amoskeag Mills in Manchester -- largest cotton textile unit of its kind in the country -- is "no idle threat," Governor H. Styles Bridges' Textile Committee reported today.
Columbia started to tune up its passing attack yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the encounter with Navy at Annapolis on Saturday.

The Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico, conductor, which gave its first season of concerts last Winter in the Town Hall, changed last night to Carnegie. This was the first of six concerts to be given this season in that auditorium.
WHITE LAKE, S.D., Nov. 12 (AP). -- The crew of the 1935 stratosphere expedition, having added to America's air honors the unofficial world altitude mark, broke Camp for home today.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 12 (by Wireless). -- While the world observed two minutes of silence on Armistice Day, Harar also was hushed for a very special reason. Abede Wolde Johannes, beloved Amharic captain of infantry, the first casualty brought to this city from the battlefront in the south, gave his left arm in his country's cause.

ROME, Nov. 12. -- Sir Eric Drummond, British Ambassador, again called on Premier Benito Mussolini this evening and remained in conference with him more than an hour, during which, according to an official Italian communique, they once more discussed the situation of Great Britain and Italy in the Mediterranean.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12. -- Homer Spofford, who started the season as the first-string right halfback, was dropped to the third team today as Fritz Crisler sent his Princeton squad through a drill on fundamentals on University Field.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12. -- The Wafdist party decided tonight to withdraw its support from the government of Premier Tewfik Pasha Nessim.

The last link in the steelwork of the main suspension span of the Triborough Bridge was forged yesterday when a twenty-seven-ton cross-floor beam was riveted into place high over the waters of Hell Gate between Wards Island and Queens.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- The fear, or conscience, of three young boys, all about 12 years old, gave Mamaroneck detectives several hours of arduous digging today for $38 in hidden loot.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
RIPLEY, W. Ya., Nov. 12. -- The blazing body of a white man identified as J.S. Gunnoe, 50, a CCC camp foreman, was found hanging from a tree on a farm near here late tonight.

Fifteen thousand frenzied spectators in Madison Square Garden last night madly cheered the representatives of the Irish Free State team when they defeated the officers of the United States Army in a jump-off for the International Military Perpetual Challenge Trophy, the spectacular event of the closing session of the National Horse Show.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, announced last night that, for the present at least, no more persons would be put in WPA jobs because the city has exceeded its originally allotted quota of WPA placements.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- An "industrial reduction program" which "plowed millions of workers into the streets" was blamed by Secretary Wallace today for the billions of relief expenditures.

MAKALE, Ethiopia, Nov. 12. -- A big prize fell into the hands of Italy when her troops occupied Makale, because it is the principal salt market of Ethiopia. Salt is of great economic significance here, being not only the principal currency of Southern Ethiopia, but also a commodity which brings huge prices, according to the distance it is carried.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 12. -- The Harvard varsity's scrimmage against the freshmen was called off today because of first-year examinations. The varsity will have its only hard football before the New Hampshire game Saturday against its scrubs.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 12. -- A grand jury of eighteen men and four housewives, instructed by Judge W. Butler Windle to "proceed without sympathy, prejudice or regard to rumor," began an investigation today into the death Sept. 11 of Miss Evelyn Hoey, former Broadway musical comedy actress.

In a telegram yesterday to the American Bankers Association, now in convention at New Orleans, President ROOSEVELT expressed his confidence that the country's banks are in a strong position and his hope that they will act "to provide credit, when it can be done "upon a sound basis, to business and "industry and to real estate."

The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was slightly less than a week ago. However, the total was well below the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 670, as against 680 in the previous week and 795 in the same period a year ago.

Charles C. Walsey, president of the Burland Printing Company, has bought for a Summer home a furnished residence, said to represent an investment of more than $500,000, at Deal, N.J. The house, which contains thirty rooms and twelve bathrooms, was built by Jefferson Seligman of J. W. Seligman, bankers.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 12. -- Although comment generally is being withheld pending publication of the details of the Canadian trade treaty with the United States, the preliminary reaction to it in the Dominion is apparently highly favorable.

Manhattan's varsity eleven engaged in what probably was its final scrimmage of the year yesterday at Innisfail Park. Offense was stressed by Coach Chick Meehan as the Jasper first-stringers clashed with a scrub eleven until after dark in preparation for the closing game of the campaign against Georgetown at Ebbets Field Saturday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, took charge as head saleswoman yesterday morning at the opening of the annual pre-Christmas exhibition and sale of Val-Kill furniture and metal crafts objects at 732 Fifth Avenue, near Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Arguments over a Federal law 19 years old brought forth from Justices of the Supreme Court today conflicting views on New Deal principles which emphasized anew the "liberal-conservative" split in the judicial body.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Josephine Roche, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and the only woman coal operator in the country, gave unqualified support to the Guffey Coal Control Act in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today. She was a witness for the government in the suit of James W. Carter to enjoin the application of the act to the Carter Coal Company of West Virginia, of which he is president.

Luxuriously appointed bathrooms for oil tankers, with chromium fixtures and walls in green and cream tile, vied for attention with streamlined rudders at the opening yesterday of the second annual marine exhibition of the Maritime Association in the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12. -- The longest price thus far of the Maryland season, and one of the greatest in the history of the State, was returned today at Pimlico when John H.C. Forbes's Axacan triumphed and returned $340.40 for $2 in the mutuels.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Political Washington got a hint today that President Roosevelt may intervene to keep Senator Norris of Nebraska from retiring.

The discussion in the columns of TH TIMES with reference to the alleged financial and commercial causes of America's entrance into the World War justify a very frank statement from a member of President Woodrow Wilson's Cabinet.
DUBLIN, Nov. 12. -- The government here is taking an active part in plans that are afoot to establish an Atlantic air service. A statement issued by the government Information Bureau tonight says:
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 12. -- Another draw resulted from the eighteenth game of the chess match for the world's championship between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of this city tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Asserting that the work-relief plan encompassed hundreds of "utterly ridiculous and fantastic" projects, the Republican high command today disputed an administration contention that the works program is "all good solid stuff."

The twelfth annual commercial printing of the year exhibition, held under the auspices of the American Institute of Graphic Arts, opened last night at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, where it will continue through Nov. 29.

The New York public will be able to meet Mark Twain's most famous characters in sculpture embodiment next week when a large model of the Mark Twain Memorial, to be erected in Hannibal, Mo., his boyhood home, will have its first public showing in the Grand Central Art Galleries.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 12. -- Although thus far the Japanese authorities in Shanghai have not formulated any demands concerning recent anti-Japanese outbreaks here, it was authoritatively revealed this afternoon that deliberations of the gravest importance were being held.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP). -- J. Robert (Bob) Shawkey will not manage the Newark International League Baseball Club next season, a statement from the office of George Weiss, vice president and general manager, said today.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- A list of materials the export of which is now to be embargoed, except under special license, was published today in the German Official Gazette. The list is unexpectedly long. It goes into effect Saturday, two days before the League of Nations sanctions against Italy begin to operate.

The final session of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night was attended by a brilliant assembly. The pageant of fashion began early, when hundreds of notables in the social and sports world streamed into the Garden in time for the parade of international military jumping teams at 8:35 o'clock.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- Hanns Kerrl, head of the Reich Church Ministry, denied today through his press spokesman that he had ever issued a statement to the effect that Chancellor Hitler had advised Nazi party leaders he would "lead the party along the path of positive Christianity and not along the false path of anti-Christian doctrine."

Completion of tho second round in the invitation squash tennis tourney at the Princeton Club last night was featured by the matches in which Vincent Furno of the Columbia University Club and Arnold Wood Jr. of the Princeton Club emerged the victors.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Senator William E. Borah called for strict enforcement of the anti-trust laws today as a quick means of restoring prosperity. The Senator arrived here at 8:45 A.M. today from his home. At the same time another train came in bearing former President and Mrs. Hoover.

Supplementing the group of seventeenth and eighteenth century art shows already current, the College Art Association, in collaboration with the Arthur U. Newton Galleries, yesterday opened a varied and interesting exhibition of portraiture representative of those two centuries.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- With the violence that is a part of the Nazi literary style, the Voelkischer Beobachter today objects to a short dispatch that appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 20 regarding the opening of the newly formed Reich Institute for the History of the New Germany.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 12. -- All the oils, water-colors and pastels executed by Childe Hassam that were in his possession at the time of his death are bequeathed to the American Academy of Arts and Letters of Manhattan in the artist's will, filed today in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court.

Distributions by Christmas clubs throughout the United States during the next two weeks will amount to $312,000,000, with New York State heading the list with a total of $79,000,000, it was estimated yesterday by Herbert F. Rawll, president of Christmas Club.

A new divining rod for the human brain, which literally smells out the presence of brain tumors of a size that cannot be detected by the X-ray, and also determines the tumor's size and exact location, was described for the first time last night at the New York Academy of Medicine.

The Four Aces of contract bridge won the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup for teams-of-four for the second consecutive year last night, defeating an American Bridge League championship team headed by Louis H. Watson by 4,090 points in the wind-up of the final match of 100 boards played in the Park Lane Hotel.

It is the dubious pleasure of Manhattan, which has displayed quite a burst of power during the present season, to entertain this week the team which apparently takes more pleasure in upsetting expectations in New York than any other team.

A plan for a memorial in Central Park for Charles B. Stover, Park Commissioner under Mayor Gaynor, has been agreed upon by Park Commissioner Moses and the Charles B. Stover Memorial Association. This was announced last night at the second annual meeting of Friends of the University Settlement at Keen's Chop House, 72 West Thirty-sixth Street, by Jacob S. Eisinger, president of the memorial association and treasurer of the settlement group.

In the Democratic National Convention of 1932 a resolution was passed restoring the rule by which each State is represented in that body by two delegates for each Senator and Representative in Congress. At the first national convention of the party in 1832 there was one delegate for each electoral vote.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Mrs. Mary P. Livingston took her seat on the Westchester County Board of Supervisors this afternoon, the first woman ever to serve as a member of the board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A protective committee for holders of first mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds and non-cumulative income bonds of the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway Company was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in the Missouri Pacific reorganization.
LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Despite Italy's threats of reprisals, the British Government intends to proceed with sanctions as if the threats had never been made, officials declared today.

When Mayor LA GUARDIA appointed ROBERT MOSES Park Commissioner he arranged that Mr. MOSES should manage the parks in all five boroughs of the Greater City and at the same time retain his connection with the Triborough Bridge Authority and his position as head of the Long Island State Park Commission.

"Anzac eagle" an imaginative newspaper man once called Sir CHARLES KINGSFORD-SMITH, thinking only of the youth of 18 who came out of the war an ace. "Best airman in the world" is the opinion of C.W.A. SCOTT, himself one of the best. Only DIEUDONNE COSTE holds more records.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Civil Service Commission issued figures today which showed that the total of Federal employes reached a peace-time peak of 794,467 in September. There was an increase in the month of 10,434 permanent and 14,178 temporary employes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Triborough Bridge Authority was directly responsible for the purchase of German instead of domestic steel piling for use on the $62,000,000 New York structure, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and head of the Public Works Administration, charged today.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,802,250 barrels, compared with 2,798,350 in the preceding week, an increase of 3,900, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 19,500 barrels in the daily average output of California and a decline of 14,200 in Kansas were the principal changes.

With the introduction of several new plays New York University's undefeated and untied football team began preparations yesterday at Ohio Field for its seventh contest of the season Saturday, when it meets the Rutgers eleven on the University Heights gridiron.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm today, although the general election restricted business further. British funds recovered well as a result of renewed investment buying. Japanese issues improved in the foreign department and Brazilians also went higher.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 12 (AP). -- Halfback Andy Pilney and Lineman Dick Pfefferle tried out their injured legs in Notre Dame's practice session today and were ordered right back to the infirmary by Dr. John E. McMeel.

Most commodity futures were lower in light trading on local markets yesterday. In the cash markets, cotton was at a new high price for middling, and corn and tin were strong, while wheat, rye, silk, mess pork and rubber were lower.

Two patrolmen and two plainclothes men joined in a wild chase to capture a man who had pushed his way into the driver's seat of a taxicab at Central Park West and Sixty-first Street last night, shoved the driver into the street and driven off with a woman passenger.

ALBANY, Nov. 12. -- The invitation sent by Governor Lehman last week to Irving M. Ives, Republican Assembly leader, to "sit in" at the State budget hearings was declined by Mr. Ives tonight in a letter to the Governor. The Assemblyman based his refusal on the ground that neither he, nor any one else, "is in a position to represent the 1936 Assembly."

IT has been mentioned elsewhere that in the Notre Dame-Northwestern affair Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was on the winning side and William Shakespeare was on the losing side. If this is offered as an example of poetic justice, the stirring cry should be: "Appeal at once!"
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 12. -- It was learned unofficially tonight forty-nine Bolivian officers, seized during the Chaco War, have escaped from an encampment of prisoners at Paraguari, Paraguay.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 12. -- Driving an automobile identical in appearance with that of their victims, three young bandits held up two employes of P. Ballantine Sons, brewers, as they were leaving the plant at 57 Freeman Street this afternoon and escaped with $10,500 cash and checks totaling $28,000.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 12. -- While confusion seems to exist about the possession of Daggah Bur, the Ethiopian Government announces a battle has taken place at the Anale wells, about thirty miles to the south.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Underweight hogs outsold all other kinds today for the first time this season as the result of the broadest shipping demand for weights less than 180 pounds so far this season. Fresh pork loins were quoted as 1 to 1 1/2 cents higher in the various markets, with prices here lifted to 22 1/2 cents a pound for the best, or 4 cents above the level that, prevailed twelve days ago.

The International Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $21,666,535 after expenses, taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization and proportion of earnings applicable to minority interests.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- The German Ambassador, Baron Leopold von Hoesch, called at the Foreign Office today and asked why Dr. H.W. Thost, Nazi newspaper correspondent, had been refused an extension on his permit to work in England.
Further evidence of Spring in Fall appeared yesterday as warm weather continued for the eighteenth consecutive day.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- George H. Houston, president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, testifying today before the Securities and Exchange Commission, characterized as "totally unwarranted" any inference, or charge, that the corporation ever had changed its bookkeeping methods for the purpose of creating a picture which would induce holders of securities of that corporation to accept reorganization plans now pending in the courts.

A dinner was given by 160 professional, scientific and business leaders, including Professor Albert Einstein, Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Felix M. Warburg and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to Dr. Nathan Ratnoff, medical director of the Beth Israel Hospital and founder of the Jewish Maternity Hospital, which was merged with it five years ago.
A few postscripts on the opening of the New Jersey hunting season:
LONDON, Nov. 12. -- The text of the Italian note to powers considering sanctions, as received here, is as follows:

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Unemployment can be wiped out and the problem of an increasing burden on the taxpayer in the form of a thinly disguised dole can be solved only by increasing production, not by restricting it after the fashion of the Roosevelt administration policy, the Rotary Club was told today by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover.

In another column is printed a letter by NEWTON D. BAKER, which should go far toward putting an end to some current misapprehensions and actual untruths. We refer to the perverse and unfounded stories of the reasons why the United States entered the war against Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The next Democratic National Convention will be made up of 1,100 delegates, a reduction of 54 from the 1932 apportionment. The Southern and border States lose fourteen delegates, the Western and Southwestern States twenty-eight, and the New England and Middle Atlantic States twelve.

Strong opposition to the selection of Assemblyman Herbert Brownell, Jr., as majority leader of the Assembly has arisen among up-State members of the lower House of the Legislature, it was learned yesterday.

WHAT! Another book about Lord Byron? If any one had told me a week ago that Would shortly be reading one and thoroughly enjoying every page of it, I should have replied, "Nix, my friend, you overestimate the resilience of the human mind; it just can't gorge with any pretense of relish on facts that have been digested a score of times before."

SYRACUSE, Nov. 12. -- Confronted with facts and figures about the empty hands and the idle minds of the "depression generation," which has never had a chance to show what it can do, delegates to the current convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs took serious cognizance this afternoon of the dilemma of the youth of the country.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 12. -- Tom Hamilton began today a graduated course of football in preparation for the Columbia game here Saturday. The time was devoted almost entirely to the running attack, the blocking dummies being used in directing the plays and one set of backs after another was used in running them through.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- President Roosevelt was reported today to be considering a proposal made to him yesterday by Governor Lehman which would save New York State $4,000,000 a month in relief outlay. Mr. Roosevelt conferred yesterday with the Governor, Frederic I. Daniels, New York TERA Administrator, and Washington relief officials.
WASHINGTON, Nov., 12 (AP). -- Peaceful relations of the United States and a "closer fellowship" among individuals were cited by President Roosevelt today in proclaiming Nov. 28 as Thanksgiving Day.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 12. -- Recognition that the period of crisis and controversy has ended and that the period of recovery and cooperation is at hand was developed as the central theme of the sixty-first annual convention of the American Bankers Association at the general session held here today.

VIENNA, Nov. 12. -- Foreign Minister Egon Berger-Waldenegg told the budget committee of Parliament today that the Austrian delegate's recent explanation at Geneva of his country's necessity for making reservations regarding economic sanctions against Italy had been misinterpreted as a negative vote and that Austria in reality stood "strictly" behind the League of Nations.
BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- Germany has lost in Dr. Fritz Gebhardt an industrialist and financier of considerable distinction.

BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- Following spirited discussion in which President Conant of Harvard and President Marsh of Boston University backed the majority, the Association of Urban Universities voted 18 to 4 today to approve the action of its resolutions committee in killing an anti-pacifist resolution condemning "subversive activities" of the National Students League and the League for Industrial Democracy.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Peter Mavromichelis, Greek Minister of Communications and leader of the delegation sent here to escort King George II back to his restored throne, called upon Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare today. The visit was purely of a courtesy nature.

Other exhibitions opening yesterday include recent paintings by Murray Hoffman at the Reinhardt Galleries, 730 Fifth Avenue; commercial illustrations by Frederick Bradley at Arthur Kudner's; figure painting in the modern French manner by Donald Maxwell, at 137 East Forty-third Street, and rare laces from the Olga Asta Collection, Venice, at James McCreery Co.

Two trolley cars of the Eighth Avenue line left Fourteenth and 125th Streets simultaneously at 11:24 A.M. yesterday and headed for Columbus Circle. They arrived at their destination, were pointed out to onlookers as reminders of a bygone era and then clanked back to the car barns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A few yellowing sheets of parchment in the Protocol Room of the State Department, which were placed there eleven days less than sixty-four years ago, are being cited to the department as presenting an insuperable barrier until 1937 to any concerted action with the League of Nations by the United States in embargoing raw materials to Italy.

Luigi Antonini, first vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, returned yesterday on the French liner Ile de France from a six-week trip to Europe and was met at the pier by a band and an enthusiastic crowd of fellow trade unionists and anti-Fascists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- With 1,700 needy actors at work in WPA theatre projects in New York, jobs there for about 4,000 additional actors on relief are being blocked by inability to obtain contracts for five or six theatres, officials said here today.

The 16,599-share increase during October in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, raising the total to 930,219 shares, marks the resunption of a trend which was interrupted sharply in September by a decline of 85,000 shares.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Weakness abroad and the proposed reciprocity treaty with Canada were too much today for the wheat market on the Board of Trade. Prices never went as high as Saturday's finish, while the close was at the bottom at net losses of 1 1/8 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel, the December leading the decline.

Detective Hugo Harris, testifying yesterday as the last State witness in the General Sessions trial of Nicholas (Nick) Montana on a felony vice indictment, swore that last Summer Alexander R. Klahr, one of Montana's lawyers, offered to pay him $1,000 a month if he would permit Montana to operate disreputable apartments in the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Nov. 6 shows an increase for the week of $48,000,000 in total loans and investments, a decrease of $40,000,000 in demand deposits -- adjusted, and an increase of $138,000,000 in deposit balances of domestic banks.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 13. -- A toll of two dead and two missing was reported in radio flashes this morning from rescuers at the wrecked freighter Silverhazel along with word the fifty others aboard the craft had been saved after a four-day battle in raging waters in San Bernardino Straits.

David Brynley and Norman Notley, tenor and baritone, and members in previous seasons of the admirable organization known as the New English Singers, made joint appearance in an unusual form of entertainment yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall.

TRENTON, Nov. 12. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, notified Governor Hoffman today that $1,500,000 had been allotted to New Jersey for the last half of November and it would be the final direct relief grant for this State.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 12. -- Mrs. Dodge Sloane's colt, Indian Broom, showed today that, given a fair break, he can down most of the best colts on the Narragansett track.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 12 (AP). -- Aerovias Centrales (Central Airways), operating to Los Angeles and El Paso and touching all principal cities in northwestern Mexico ceased operations today as the result of an order from the government requiring employment of Mexican pilots on all planes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Formal signing of the new reciprocal trade treaty by the United States and Canada and disclosure of its details are expected by administration officials to give such an impetus to others now in negotiation that several more will be completed before Jan. 1.

Delayed announcement of details of the United States-Canadian trade treaty whetted the interest of foreign traders and domestic manufacturers to the point where they made telephone appeals to Washington, Ottawa and to local offices of Canadian banks in a vain attempt to get information yesterday about the items on which concessions have been agreed.

It is of interest to note how our public men, without apparently recognizing it themselves, are more and more accepting socialistic thought and principles. As recently reported in the press: "Grover Whalen recently said, at a dinner given in his honor, that taxation should be based on ability to pay and not on mere ease of collection."

The city of Cincinnati, Ohio, yesterday made the tentative award of a series of new general obligations bonds, aggregating $2,130,000, to a syndicate headed by the National City Bank. The price was 100.25 for $1,360,000, due from 1937 to 1976, as 2 1/4s, and $770,000, maturing from 1937 to 1961, as 2 3/4s.

Seven Manhattan parcels and eleven Bronx properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. One of the Manhattan parcels included two six-story storage warehouses at 14-16 East 133d Street. Apartment structures of six stories or less made up the bulk of the remaining offerings in the borough.

ITALIAN GENERAL HEADQUARTERS ON THE NORTHERN FRONT, Nov. 12. -- Italian scouts reported tonight that nearly a quarter of a million Ethiopian warriors would attempt to throw back the advance of Italy's armies from Northern Ethiopia.

LOS AGELES, Cal., Nov. 12. -The choice of perpetuating a competitive, private industry serving the public or of socializing industry to serve the political breadline has united the petroleum industry in opposition to Federal control, Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute, said here today in an address at the annual convention of that body.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Tiff Denton, 53-year-old star of Kansas City, turned in a brilliant performance in the world's 3-cushion billiard championship today to defeat the defending champion, Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo.

LOS AGELES, Cal., Nov. 12. -The choice of perpetuating a competitive, private industry serving the public or of socializing industry to serve the political breadline has united the petroleum industry in opposition to Federal control, Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute, said here today in an address at the annual convention of that body.
