CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Tiff Denton, 53-year-old star of Kansas City, turned in a brilliant performance in the world's 3-cushion billiard championship today to defeat the defending champion, Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo.

Lack of supervision and medical care as well as use of faulty equipment must be charged with responsibility for the majority of football deaths this season, in the opinion of leading coaches and officials.
Reporting for October, the Alton Railroad, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, showed yesterday an improvement in gross and net income. Its statement follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Plans for hastening the establishment of the proposed nation-wide organization to cooperate with and help the SEC in the regulation of transactions in the over-the-counter markets were discussed today by James 35. Landis, chairman of the SEC, and members of the drafting committee of the Investment Bankers conference committee.

ROME, Nov. 13. -- Coincident with General Emilio de Bono's entry into Makale, of which he took possession today in the name of the King of Italy, comes the news that Italian troops moving due south and southwest from Aksum have reached the Takkaze River.

Fresh produce price trends were again toward lower levels yesterday, with supplies plentiful, the City's Consumers' Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets announced. Meats were steady and seafood was generally high.

A warning to Catholic educators to beware of making the school life of children "too easy" was sounded by the Rev. Richard J. Quinlan, superintendent of schools in the Archdiocese of Boston, at the opening session yesterday of the semi-annual meeting of the superintendents' section of the National Catholic Educational Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm again today, although business remained restricted on the eve of the general election. Outstanding in the operations was the continued investment support for British funds under the lead of the war loan.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 13. -- Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, said today in an address before the Kansas City Chamber of Commerce that consolidation of the country's many railroads into a few strong systems was one solution of their problem. It also would increase both competition and efficiency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The first formal step by this government toward ratifying the reciprocal trade agreement with Canada was taken today by President Roosevelt when he assigned "full power" to Secretary Hull to sign the treaty on behalf of the United States.

Led by Mrs. Rogers Dunn and brought to a successful close by Mrs. Armitage-Crawford in the fifth encounter, the Junior League squash racquets forces yesterday won their match from the Heights Casino team, 3 -- 2.

SCOTTSBORO, Ala., Nov. 13. -- New indictments charging criminal attack were returned against the nine Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case today by a Jackson County grand jury upon which a Negro sat for the first time in sixty years.

Frau Hettie Dyhrenfurth, holder of the world's altitude record for women mountain climbers (24,500 feet), is a wife and mother who does not like mountaineering and hates record-making. In an interview yesterday Frau Dyhrenfurth, who is in this country for a lecture tour, warmly declared that she would never approach a mountain if it were not for love of her husband, Dr. Guenther O. Dyhrenfurth, noted geographer and geologist, who would rather climb than eat.
The name of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who was killed with three companions in a Newark chop house on Oct. 23, bobbed up on three fronts yesterday.

F.P.A.'s own Samuel Pepys in two big volumes begins in 1911, a date which gives the reader pause. Will he be able to make head or tail out of the book? He has read any number of new books dealing with the dead past of October, 1932.

No one, I suppose, will take issue with Representative Thomas R. Amlie when he asserts that actual production falls far short of potential production. This condition exists in spite of the fact that decade after decade our actual production has mounted higher and higher.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Captain Orvil A. Anderson and Captain Albert W. Stevens declared here today that they are willing to take another trip into the stratosphere at any time, and are confident that on the next endeavor they will surpass their record fourteen-mile ascent.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 13. -- Cooperation among ports in working out their problems was urged today as a solution to the strife which has racked waterways by speakers at the convention of the American Association of Port Authorities.

Hockey makes its bow for the season in this city tonight, when the New York Rangers tackle the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. Local fans have anxiously been awaiting the advent of the National League campaign here, and it is generally believed that a near capacity crowd of 15,000 will be on hand to see the rival sextets skate out against each other.

SOUTHBORO, Mass., Nov. 13. -- Spurred to scoring precision when its rival took a surprising one-point lead in the first half, Groton School's powerful eleven tallied twice in the fourth quarter to down St. Mark's, 19 to 7, on a slippery gridiron today.

A concept of public health work in which economic security is considered as a disease preventive was presented by Edgar Sydenstricker, scientific director of the Milbank Memorial Fund, at a luncheon yesterday of the medical social service section of the Welfare Council at the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco held the undisputed lead in the world three-cushion billiard championship tonight by defeating Augie Kieckhefer, Chicago, 50 to 25, in thirty-four innings, for his fifth straight victory. Cochran led all the way. Both had high runs of six.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- Dr. Heinrich Sahm, Mayor of Berlin, who has held that office since April, 1931, has been put on trial before a National Socialist party court on the charge of having made purchases from a Jewish-owned store in violation of a party regulation.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- The Federation of Christian Women of this city, at a bi-monthly luncheon today in the First Methodist Church, appointed a committee on World Peace and named as its chairman Mrs. E. Graham Wilson, wife of the Rev. Dr. Wilson, Executive Secretary of the Presbyterian Board of National Missions.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13. -- Orval W. Adams, banker of Salt Lake City, who is a strenuous opponent of the New Deal and who urged bankers last Monday to declare "an embargo" on government securities to force the administration to balance the Federal budget, was elected today second vice president of the American Bankers Association in a stormy and unprecedented contest on the floor of the sixty-first annual convention of the association here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A liberal interpretation of the hitherto undefined "general welfare" clause of the Constitution was asked of the Supreme Court today by government attorneys arguing the validity of a New Deal law.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of October: Total imports, 73,380,000; exports of British products, 39,860,000; re-exports, 4,730,000; total exports, 44,590,000; excess of imports, 28,790,000.
ST. PAUL, Nov. 13 (AP). -- Every one except "Big Boy Floyd of Rosedale," the Iowa hog that received a "State" reception today, knew what the Governor of Iowa said to the Governor of Minnesota.

Advancing for the third consecutive month, retail prices rose 1.2 per cent in October, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index, issued yesterday. The figure on Nov. 1 was 87.6, the highest since October, 1934. For the first time in months the index is higher than year ago, the figure for Nov. 1, 1934, being 87.4.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Nov. 13 (AP). -- A reiteration of charges that gangsters frequent the New York State race tracks enlivened a grand jury session today devoted to an investigation of bogus horse-race tipping activities.

The announcement by W.K. Kellogg of Battle Creek, Mich., of the Kellogg Company's conclusions respecting shortened hours with no reduction of wages and its relation to the unemployment program is of the first importance.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Formation of a National Advisory Council on Applied Physics, sponsored by the American Institute of Physics with the cooperation of a number of scientific societies and large corporations, was announced yesterday by Dr. Henry A. Barton, director of the institute.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Two officials of a Paterson bank, now in the process of liquidation, were named today in four indictments charging them with making loans and handling financial transactions in an illegal manner.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 13. -- Cairo was a scene of rioting today as thousands of students observed "National Independence Day" by demonstrating against Great Britain. Official reports gave the casualties as one student killed and twenty demonstrators, one police captain, one lieutenant and twenty-one policemen seriously injured.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 13 (AP). -- The University of Nebraska eleven clicked like a new clock today in the final home workout before departing for the Cornhuskers' intersectional football game with the Pitt Panthers at Pittsburgh Saturday.

I have observed recently a number of letters about careless dog owners who allow their pets to befoul the sidewalks. As a dog owner who has always tried to conform to the sanitary laws I wish to make a statement concerning the difficulties which confront any one similarly situated.

Tenders will be consided by Cuyahoga County, Ohio, on Dec. 6, for a new issue of $2,725,000 of poor relief bonds. They will be dated Dec. 1, 1935, will mature March 1, 1936 to 1944, and carry a 6 per cent interest rate.

The Bank of Manhattan Company has been appointed transfer agent for the 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Celotex Corporation, and for the preferred and common stocks of the Mutual Fruit Distributors, Inc.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- The lowest prices for wheat on the Board of Trade since early in September were recorded today as the result of general selling induced by continued weakness in Liverpool and Buenos Aires. Some uneasiness was apparent at times owing to fears that the proposed reciprocal treaty with Canada would lower the import duty, but this idea found little credence among well-informed local interests.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13. -- Head Coach Ducky Pond today rang down the curtain on practice scrimmage at Yale for the season with more than an hour's hard football in a drizzle.
Columbia evidently expects to employ an intensive passing attack against Navy at Annapolis on Saturday as the Lions yesterday continued to drill on aerials at Baker Field.

On Tuesday two judges of the Supreme Court interrupted the argument of counsel in an important ease bearing upon the licensing power of the Federal Government. Judge BRANDEIS closely questioned Mr. BECK with regard to the consequences of the constitutional doctrine which he was laying down.

Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, director of the WPA theatre program, denied reports emanating from Washington yesterday that there had been difficulties in formulating theatre projects in the New York region because of the unwillingness of producers to cooperate.

The Bank of the Netherlands reduced its discount rate from 4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent yesterday, indicating to foreign exchange observers that Holland has escaped, at least temporarily, the threat of devaluation, but despite this the guilder declined 2 points to 67.92 cents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Virtual assurance that the 1934 cotton loans of 12 cents a pound, under which the government has control of about 4,000,000 bales, will be extended when they fall due Feb. 1, was given today by Chester C. Davis, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 14. -- A critical stage has arrived in North China, according to today's Japanese press dispatches. A split has developed among the northern generals, two of whom are said to have definitely rejected Nanking's offers while a third, Shang Cheng, has sent his family to Shanghai and is removing his army from Peiping to Paoting.

Further cases against Sam Faden of 1,835 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, and others of the twenty-two men arrested as loan sharks in raids staged by Thomas E. Dewey, special racket prosecutor, will be heard in Special Sessions Court today.
Howard Chandler Christy put the final touches on his portrait of Will Rogers yesterday as he recalled the humorist's last visit to the studio.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Reduction in interest rates charged on real estate loans was urged by President Roosevelt today as essential to economic recovery.

Five minutes after the jurors hearing his case in Bronx County Court had been dismissed because they were hopelessly deadlocked Hans Albert von Wehls, on trial for the alleged extortion of $200, pleaded guilty last night before Judge Harry Stackell to attempted extortion as a felony.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Bank creditors of the Middle West Utilities Company, in an answer filed in Federal court here today, rejected the "suggestions" made by Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson for modifying the plan of reorganization now before the court.

Standing beside a four-foot model of the Ward liner Morro Castle which burned Sept. 8, 1934, off Asbury Park with a loss of 135 lives, Francis W.H. Adams, Federal Attorney, accused of negligence yesterday William F. Warms, who was acting skipper of the vessel, and Henry E. Cabaud, executive vice president of the line.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler is not the "altogether bad man" he is frequently reported to be, but, like several men who have occupied the White House, he has some poor advisers, according to Bishop R.J. Wade of Stockholm, Sweden, in an address at a reception tonight for the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which is holding its semi-annual conference here.

New York University's undefeated and untied football team increased its pace yesterday in preparation for its engagement with Rutgers. Coach Mal Stevens drilled the players for more than two hours on the soggy turf of the University Heights gridiron, with special attention being devoted to building up the forward passing attack.

Although the play "Career," which has been made from Phil Stong's novel of the same title, is expected to arrive on Broadway some time next month, the novel on which it is based is being kept out of the Christmas rush by the publishers, Harcourt, Brace, and will not appear until mid-January.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- State Department experts are of the opinion that, if the Neutrality Resolution of last August should be extended to cover such raw materials as cotton, oil and copper for embargo against the belligerents in the East Africa war, and if Italy should counter by citing the commercial treaty of 1871 between Italy and the United States, some very perplexing questions would arise.

MANILA, Nov. 13. -- Governor General Frank Murphy, who will be the United States High Commissioner in the new Philippine Commonwealth after its inauguration Friday, said today that the Filipinos were far better prepared to rule themselves than the rest of the world supposed and that insular finances were in the best condition in their history.

After thirty-two years as the head of the Detroit Tigers, Frank J. Navin experienced the thrill on Oct. 7 this year of seeing his own team win the world championship pennant in Navin Field. In those thirty-two years the Tigers won the American League pennant four times, and for winning the world title last month, Mr. Navin received the official thanks of the city of Detroit.

Wool consumption in September, amounting to 29,000,000 pounds, was 254 per cent greater than that of the corresponding month of 1934 and was the largest figure for any September since 1922, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

After a two-day respite from practice, the Fordham squad resumed work yesterday with enthusiasm. For two hours the Rams went through a passing session on Fordham Field and when rain fell, they continued the practice in the college gymnasium.

Business need no longer feel any uncertainty as to what may come in the future with respect to governmental measures, Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, assured manufacturers and distributers at the annual dinner of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

A.H. Woods's next show -- and its title has reverted from "A Gambling Chance" to "The Ragged Edge" -- will open at the Fulton on Nov. 25. A recent addition to the cast is Nancy Dover, stage and screen actress. In private life she is Mrs. Cliff Edwards. By the way, Charles Bryant and Lee Baker have withdrawn from the company.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 13. -- Citizens of the town of New Canaan invoked the aid of Governor Cross today, requesting him to take action against the Federal Government under the Ninth and Tenth Amendments of the United States Constitution in a fight against the proposed potato sales processing tax.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 13. -- The Japanese authorities in Shanghai are continuing their slow, painstaking investigation into the shooting of a Japanese marine last Saturday and other anti-Japanese activities in Shanghai and it is intimated that if responsibility, for anti-Japanese activities is traced to the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] it is likely Japan will demand that Nanking close all Kuomintang branch offices in the Yangtse Valley.

ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- Schools, city and village halls would be closed and whole municipal services would be abandoned, the State Conference of Mayors and other municipal officials warned today, if the 2 per cent over-all constitutional tax limitation amendment is enacted, as real estate interests demand. The warning was based on a study by the conference's advisory committee of the effect of the plan on the finances of cities and villages.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 (AP) -- President Roosevelt urged the United States Building and Loan League today "to lower costs of financing" as a step toward "better housing at lower cost." In a message to the league, in convention here, he said:

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 13. -- Mrs. Doris Melanson's Happy Knot, 5-year-old daughter of Happy Argo, maintained her reputation for consistency today when she won the Block Island Claiming Stakes, a $2,500 added six-furlong event at Narragansett Park.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler handed down yesterday a decision which will coat the bond and mortgage companies now in liquidation millions of dollars and will benefit the investors in defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates that much, it was estimated.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 13. -- Victor Andoga of New York, a stage director and singing instructor, who coached Evelyn Hoey) for her brief career in musical comedy, said here today he was convinced that Miss Hoey had killed herself. She was worried, he said, over a love affair with a New York theatrical man and over the fact that her voice was failing.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 13. -- Joint British and American cooperation to establish a North Atlantic air service with experimental flying to begin next year is the plan behind the conference to be held in Ottawa next week between British, Irish Free State and Canadian postal and air officials.

General John J. Pershing, chairman of the United States Battle Monuments Commission, is among the passengers returning from Europe this evening on the Washington of the United States Lines Others on the ship include H.G. Wells, British novelist; Henry J. Allen, former Senator from Kansas, and Mrs. Allen; Max Altglass, operatic tenor; Kaarle Altic, Consul General for Finland in New York, and:

TRENTON, Nov. 13. -- The Minute Women of 1936, said to be a nonpartisan group formed for the purpose of fostering a five-point program, much of which apparently is aimed at President Roosevelt's New Deal policies, has filed articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State.

In transmitting to the Bankers Convention at New Orleans the President's assurances of business recovery, Chairman JONES of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation gave on his own account a generally cheerful view of the business prospect, but spoke with some reserve of the railways.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- The stratosphere balloon that carried them nearly fourteen miles from the earth on Monday was a "flying teaketle" by the time it reached the "ceiling," Captain Stevens and captain Anderson disclosed here today.

The first dinner of the Wine and Food Society since its organization as "a non-commercial fraternity of gourmets" last Spring will be held tonight at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza, when 200 of its members will sit down to sample an ideal epicurean meal.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 13. -- The plan of reorganization for General Theatres Equipment, Inc., which is in receivership, met strong opposition today from the All Continent Corporation in a chancery court.

At the completion of the third round in the Class A tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association last night only two teams remained unbeaten, as the City A.C. met with its first setback, The teams now tied for the lead, each with three victories, are the New York A.C. and the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 13. -- A courageous finish by Gene Kunes of Philadelphia and Dick Metz of Chicago won for them first money in the professional best-ball golf tournament, completed today. They scored a 137.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Cambridge University has just agreed to sell to Soviet Russia the giant generator of magnetic fields and other scientific apparatus installed in the Mond Laboratory at a cost of 15,000 several years for the use of Professor Peter Kapitza, famous Russian physicist.

The American Iron and Steel Institute issued a reply yesterday to the statement made by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace in Washington Tuesday that "the pig iron reduction control of the big steel companies in 1933 was, in principle, one thousand times as damnable as the pig reduction campaign of 1933."

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Prices of hogs today were generally 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, despite another advance of 1/3 cent a pound in fresh pork loins to 23 cents wholesale here. Receipts of hogs were liberal and the Eastern demand was less aggressive.
BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- The Boerse was quiet today, with occasional flurries of strength. The changes recorded at the finish were not significant.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, Nov. 13. -- In an article entitled "Male Servant Girls in Jewish Kitchens," the Frankfurter Volksblatt, a local National Socialist organ, launched an indignant protest today against the employment of "Aryan" young men in Jewish households.

Condemnation of the "partisan character and evident objectives" of the recent questionnaire of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States on New Deal legislation was voiced in a resolution unanimously adopted yesterday at a meeting of the Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives at the offices of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Applications for ratification of their appointment by the Federal court as trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by Howard S. Palmer, W.M. Daniels and James L. Loomis.

While the Manhattan first team confined its activities to a brisk signal drill, the Jasper second eleven engaged in a lengthy scrimmage against the freshmen yesterday at Innisfail Park in preparation for the game with Georgetown at Ebbets Field Saturday.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- Before replying to the Italian note on the application of sanctions the powers will consult. Great Britain, it is understood, has urged a collective reply, but the French contend that separate answers should be given.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Additional WPA projects for New York State totaling $73,470,771 were finally approved today by Controller General McCarl, who made $5,685,955 available to sixteen States for carrying out approved projects totaling $117,967,549.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13. -- An average increase of 16 per cent in business during the last season was reported for resort hotels at the annual convention of the American Hotel Association here tonight.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, declared in an appeal to German theological students tonight that "the Fuehrer principle does not apply to the church." The declaration ostensibly denotes a clean break with Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller's former policy of attempting to enforce the dictatorial principle in the administration of the Protestant Church on the ground that it was National Socialist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A study of transactions in options, particularly as such activities might tend to influence buying and selling of securities in contravention of the anti-manipulative section, 9 (a), of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, is being made by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

With 10,000 new applications for relief being received weekly by the Emergency Relief Bureau, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, yesterday ordered an investigation to he made of reports that hundreds if not thousands of persons were quitting WPA jobs to return to the home-relief rolls.
LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Representatives of British aviation and post-office officials left today for Ottawa to discuss the proposed transatlantic air service between Canada and the United Kingdom.
The governors of the New York Curb Exchange yesterday elected Frank J. McCabe to fill a vacancy on the board until the next annual election in February, 1936.

PERNAMBUCO, Brazil, Nov. 13. -- New Zealand's young and adventurous girl flier, Jean Batten, stepped smiling from her airplane at Natal late today -- the first of her sex to fly alone across the South Atlantic.

Asserting our merchant marine is in a critical condition, Colonel John Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, declared yesterday that the United States must give up its prestige as a maritime nation if the merchant fleet is not promptly rehabilitated.

ROME, Nov. 13. -- General Emilio de Bono's Italian army lengthened its front in Northern Ethiopia today by moving into the Dessa region, about fifty miles east of Makale, and on the western end of the line reaching the Takkaze River.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary, indicated in an election speech tonight that the government would resume negotiations for an air pact as one of its first actions after being returned to power.
An exchange between President Roosevelt and the New York Board of Trade was disclosed yesterday at a luncheon of that organization held at the Hotel Commodore.

The nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange, of which R. Lawrence Oakley is chairman, posted yesterday on the Exchange the names of fifty-nine members who have been suggested for places on the slate of twenty-one which the committee will report on Dec. 16. From this number the membership will choose at an election on Jan. 13 seven to compose the 1936 nominating committee.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12. -- The continual difficulties which the Nitrate of Soda and Iodine Sales Corporation of Chile, controlling the country's principal industry, has had to meet in France for placement of its product notwithstanding the demand of continental consumers has moved Gustavo Ross, Minister of Finance and chairman of the directorate, to ask President Alessandri officially to approach the French Government.

BEFORE limping into the football scrimmages again there's just time to note that ice hockey is about to break out on the Garden rink tonight and twenty-four hours later a couple of tiny chaps will be engaged in trading leather in a dispute over what is recognized as the bantamweight championship in this territory.

When Pitt and Nebraska meet in Pittsburgh on Saturday it will be for the tenth time, the intersectional series having begun in 1921 when Pop Warner, now at Temple, was guiding the destinies of the Panthers and Fred Dawson was handling the Cornhuskers.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- The German Institute for Business Research issued today a survey according to which the National Socialist regime financed the "German miracle" of unemployment reduction and rearmament with a net increase of only 4,340,000,000 marks in Germany's public debt, bringing that debt's total to 29,800,000,000 marks at the end of June this year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -- Don Jackson, Harvard's 191-pound ball-carrier about whom Dick Harlow expected to build the Crimson's attack at the beginning of the season, saw action today for the first time since he was hurt in the Springfield game on Oct. 5.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 8 there appeared an editorial, "Prices as an Issue," the last two sentences of which I quote:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Enlargement of the enlisted personnel of the navy by several thousand men in the fiscal year beginning next July in order to provide crews for new warships that will be completed then is being studied by President Roosevelt in connection with the budget for that year.

COLUMBUS, Texas, Nov. 13. -- The lynching of two Negroes here last night after they had been taken from the custody of the Sheriff by a mob was condoned today by the County Attorney, O.P. Moore and by County Judge H.P. Hahn.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey listed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday 344,744 additional shares of $25-par common stock which it will pay to the Standard Oil Company of Indiana as the fifth and final instalment on the purchase of the Pan American Foreign Corporation under a contract calling for $47,910,106 cash and 1,778,973 shares of Jersey Standard common.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Decorations were awarded by Secretary Swanson today, "in the name of the President of the United States," to four members of the Second Byrd Antarctic Expedition.

The New York Giants, anxious to square accounts with the Bears, will leave for Chicago tomorrow with two newly signed players on the squad. They are Granville (Buster) Mitchell, end obtained from Detroit, and John Mackorell, former Davidson College quarterback.

The Parents Association of P.S. 135, Linden Boulevard and East Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, ended its strike yesterday, and Mrs. Betty Koplin, president, instructed all mothers to send their children to school today. Mrs. Koplin made her announcement that the strike was over after a conference with Rufus E. McGahen, director of the budget.

The first pronounced success of the season by a new artist from abroad was scored by Ria Ginster, German lyric soprano, at her debut recital in the Town Hall last night. Miss Ginster at once established herself as a singer of superior merits.
Rare books and autographs from various private collections and estates yielded $42,795 last night at the first of two auction sessions at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 13. -- Further adjustment of the purchasing power of the dollar to increase price levels was called for today by committees of the New York State Farm Bureau Federation in recommendations of policy to be pursued by the bureau.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- The breathing space in Premier Laval's clash with the Finance Commission over the 1936 budget was prolonged today until Tuesday, but the situation remains strained. Over the week-end both sides will reorganize their positions.

Public offering will be made today by a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and Coffin Burr, Inc., of a new issue of $15,600,000 of Central Maine Power Company first and general mortgage, Series G, 4 per cent bonds due in 1960. The bonds are priced at 99.
DUNDEE ISLAND, Antarctica, Nov. 13. -- Dundee Island has been, a lucky find. The Polar Star, my airplane, in which I hope to fly across Antarctica, is now resting on the solid snow above the island.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 13. -- Two prominent feminine leaders faced the State Federation of Women's Clubs in convention tonight with recommendations that such organizations narrow their field of activity for the sake of a more speedy realization of their objectives. Neither had known previously the tenor of the other's remarks.

It has given me a great deal of pleasure to forward your editorial "The Silver Rainbow" to Senator Burton K. Wheeler, with a challenge to answer it, which I am in hopes he will do, as you quote him so many times.

Castling his king in the face of an open rook's file cost Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris a valuable pawn in the recently played fourteenth game of his world championship match with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and led directly to his defeat at the hands of the challenger.

TIENTSIN, Nov. 13 (AP). -- A woman assassin killed Marshal Sun Chuan-fang today. He was a bitter opponent of the Nanking government and was often mentioned as the possible choice of Japan to lead an independence movement in North China.

WESTFIELD, Mass., Nov. 13. -- Mrs. Alice D. Burke, who made history here in the nonpartisan run-off primary yesterday by being the first woman in the city ever to be nominated for Mayor, plans an aggressive campaign through the press and pamphlets containing pertinent issues, and by making personal contacts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The possibility that President Roosevelt might be called upon to make a final decision on government policy with regard to the purchase of foreign materials for the PWA part of the work-relief program loomed tonight as a result of the purchase of German steel for two PWA projects, the Triborough Bridge in New York and the Ocean Terminal at Morehead City, N.C.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 13. -- A critical situation in the anthracite coal fields involving some 20,000 miners digging "bootleg" coal from properties of the principal companies in the southern areas is about to come to a head with a formal appeal by the combined anthracite operators to Governor Earle requesting the State authorities to take summary action against the lawbreakers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Informal orders to cut Federal expenditures under the 1937 budget by $500,000,000 less than the newly estimated total for 1936 have been issued to administrative officials by President Roosevelt, and as a result the lives of numerous Federal bureaus and agencies, including the PWA and some others of the better-known New Deal alphabetical units were reported today to be hanging precariously in the balance.

A fire on the stage of the Imperial Theatre, in Forty-fifth Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, after the matinee performance yesterday, caused the calling off of last night's performance of "Jubilee," the musical comedy hit. The fire was slight, but damage done by water to the settings of the first and final acts made the action necessary.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 13. -- When he failed to attend classes at Lakewood High School today, Joseph Russell Sperling, sixteen-year-old member of "Jehovah's Witnesses," who refused to salute the American flag, was automatically expelled by the Board of Education. The suspension is permanent.

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house to accommodate forty-five families, the plot 100 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of 207th Street and Seaman Avenue was sold yesterday by the estate of Patrick H. McNulty to the Romax Holding Corporation, builders. J.M. Felson, architect, is drawing plans for the building, which will contain apartments ranging in size from two to four rooms.

TRENTON, Nov. 13. -- Chester I. Barnard resigned today as chairman of the New Jersey State Relief Council. His action followed an announcement last night by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, that Federal grants to New Jersey for direct relief would cease Dec. 1.

The Hughes Medal of the Royal Society in London has been awarded to Dr. Clinton J. Davisson, research physicist on the staff of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, for his discovery, jointly with Dr. L.H. Germer, of electron diffraction, it was announced here yesterday.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters holds its annual meeting today and in this connection will open a large retrospective exhibition of paintings and drawings by Cecilia Beaux, N.A. The work has been installed in the gallery of the academy at 633 West 155th Street, west of Broadway.

In a move to make the parks safer for the men, women and children of the city. Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday swore in 100 employes of the Park Department, ninety-nine men and one woman, as special park patrolmen.

As the District Attorney's office disclosed yesterday that it would ask the grand jury either tomorrow or Monday to return a first-degree murder indictment against Miss Vera Stretz for the slaying of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, German financier, the young woman succeeded in continuing to keep secret her motive for the shooting.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Princeton's varsity was sent through a forty-five-minute scrimmage against the scrubs at the close of today's practice session, held in a steady downpour of rain. Chick Kaufman, playing at right half on the first-string eleven, starred, scoring once and making consistent gains.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 13. -- Andy Pilney has played his last football game for Notre Dame.

Hearings were begun yesterday in the Queens Supreme Court, Long Island City, on a test case against the Hearst Hotels Corporation which are expected to determine the outcome of a series of ten court actions by members of firemen's families for damages totaling $1,000,000.

ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- The Public Service Commission "exceeded its delegated powers and cannot be sustained," the Appellate Division, Third Department, held today in annulling the determination of the commission fixing rates for the municipal electric plant of the village of Boonville.

Directors of the Container Corporation of America declared yesterday a dividend of $19.25 a share on the preferred stock. This clears up all arrears on the issue and also provides for the current-quarter dividend.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The briefest parliamentary election campaign in modern British polities ends tonight after only three weeks of artificially fervid oratory in which nothing new has been said since the opening day in behalf of the Conservatives, Laborites or Liberals.

The movement to form a "third party" will be discussed tomorrow evening by Governor Floyd B. Olson of Minnesota, who will speak at a meeting in the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the Commonwealth Federation of New York, it is announced by Henry Pratt Fairchild, chairman. Governor Olson will speak on "A New Party -- Why, When and How?"

In one aspect of great moment it may be said that the dissolved National Government will be continued in the British elections today, whatever gains are made by Laborites or Liberals. For the application of sanctions there is practical unity among all parties. The country stands by the League of Nations, as the referendum showed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A step toward settlement of the controversy over the 1932 income tax of Edward F. Harkness of New York was taken today when his attorneys and the Internal Revenue Bureau mutually stipulated that his gifts in that year were "not less than $2,000,000" and his capital loss $1,870,563.

Mrs. Ellen Madsen, 46 years old, of 817 Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, was "run over" by a Sea Beach express train in the B.-M.T. station at Fifty-ninth Street and Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, but she suffered only a few scratches and bruises.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Low basic one-way passenger rates on Western railroads have been permanently adopted, Hugh S. Siddall, chairman of the Western Passenger Association, announced today.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn rejected yesterday three bids offered for the purchase of the Brooklyn Paramount Theatre, at Flatbush Avenue Extension and De Kalb Avenue. The theatre building is the property of the Allied Owners Corporation, which is undergoing reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws.
The essential facts in the controversy which has developed over the purchase of German steel for use in the Triborough Bridge may be set forth as follows:

Despite the continued slowness in major items of women's apparel, accessory volume has continued notably good. Retailers have had excellent results with handbags, particularly in the better price brackets, and manufacturers have a substantial order backlog for forward delivery.

Enthusiastic and loud applause answered the suggestion of Major Henry H. Curran, chairman of the Mayor's anti-noise committee, at a meeting at the Hotel Brevoort last night, when he proposed to the assembled enthusiasts for silence that each one constitute himself a vigilante in the matter of automobile horns.

District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn acted unexpectedly yesterday to reopen the Druckman murder case, which became a leading issue in the last election campaign when charges of laxity in prosecution and of police protection were made.

The stock list committee of the New York Stock Exchange has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the registration of 1,337,449 rights to subscribe to Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company 4 per cent convertible debentures which accrue to common stockholders of record of Nov. 18 which the Exchange plans to admit to dealings on a "when-issued" basis on the same date.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks and member of the Triborough Bridge Authority, said yesterday that so far as he was concerned the incident relative to the purchase of $19,000 worth of German steel to be used in the construction of the bridge was closed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A great Italian chemical and fertilizer corporation, which is also the largest producer of dynamite and gunpowder in Italy, and the Copenhagen Telephone Company have filed applications under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 for the of bond is permanent registration sues on exchanges in the United States, the first to take that step since the Securities and Exchange Commission issued new forms covering registration of foreign issues.

An increased supply of contracts in more distant positions, following the recent steady advance of about $3 a bale, created a somewhat easier range on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices ended at losses of 1 to 12 points.

Reflecting an increasing demand the rate of steel production has risen 1 1/2 points to 54 per cent of capacity, the highest rate since the first week in February, according to The Iron Age's weekly summary, issued yesterday. The price of scrap steel has moved up at both Chicago and Pittsburgh, the article adds.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 13. -- Rome reports of sensational victories on the southern front were flatly contradicted today in an Ethiopian official communique, the first issued here in weeks. Not only do the Ethiopians insist that Gorahai, Sasa Baneh and Daggah Bur are still firmly in their hands, but they also claim a smashing victory at Gorahai, in the vicinity of which bitter fighting is still apparently going on.

What was said to be the first complete liquidation of a guaranteed mortgage issue reorganized under the Schackno act was reported yesterday by the Series N-9 Corporation, of which Albert W. Fribourg is counsel, to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13. -- The French-bred Malbrouk, owned by Robert S. Clark, today exhibited all the bad temper for which he is noted, but was forgiven when he ran one of his best races to capture the Garrett Purse, feature at Pimlico.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13. -- Axtell J. Byles was re-elected president of the American Petroleum Institute at the annual election here today. Jacob France of Tulsa, Okla., president of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation, was elected vice president in charge of refining. O.D. Donnell of Findley, Ohio, president of the Ohio Oil Company, was elected treasurer.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- City Controller S. Davis Wilson, who is Mayor-elect, announced today that he would request the City Council next week to purchase, by condemnation, the entire city transit system. including the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company and its dozens of underliers, for about $100,000,000.

The recovery of industrial production in the United States continued during last year and the first eight months of this year, but is lagging behind that registered for the world as a whole, according to a study released yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research on "Production in Depression and Recovery."

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- The annual report of the Kloeckner steel corporation sets forth that its export business is based on sales abroad at a loss. The Kloeckner firm has recently been the successful low bidder on several public works projects in the United States.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

ROME, Nov. 13. -- Only two weeks ago Great Britain still turned a deaf ear to any suggestion of negotiating a compromise solution of the Italo-Ethiopian problem and rebuffed Premier Mussolini's repeated advances by saying she did not see her way clear to taking any step likely to interfere with normal League of Nations procedure.

The committee on business conduct of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday new rules governing margin requirements on "when issued" securities in order to conform to the regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The committee on business conduct of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday new rules governing margin requirements on "when issued" securities in order to conform to the regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13. -- Ernest Elmer Baker, the cowboy, evangelist and bricklayer from Menard, Texas, has at last reached his mecca -- Moscow's Kremlin -- but without his Bible. Polish border guards took the book away from him more than a year ago.

After two years of service as president of the Salt Water Anglers m of America, Mrs. Oliver Cromwell Grinnell announced her retirement from leadership of the organization at the annual meeting in the Hotel Gramercy Park on Tuesday night. She was succeeded by C. Blackburn (Kit) Miller of Yonkers, angler, hunter and contributor to outdoor publications.

CARLETON BEALS was pounding away with characteristic diligence at his "The Story of Huey Long: America's Amazing Threat to Democracy" (Lippincott, $2.50) when the assassin's bullet of Dr. Carl Weiss removed the necessity for the subtitle. The bullet must also have left Mr. Beals in something of a quandary, for he thought he was writing journalism and woke up to discover that his manuscript belonged to the ages.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $7,742,584 after charges, taxes and provision for depreciation and depletion. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 50 cents a share on the 14,584,025 common shares.

VANCOUVER, B.C. Nov. 13. -- Because it will enable Canadians to exchange goods and, without default, continue to pay their interest charges on American-held bonds, The Vancouver Sun welcomes the reciprocity pact.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sherman Haight gave a dinner last night at their home, 960 Park Avenue, for Miss Marie-Madeleine Huguenot and Guy Dal Piaz, secretary of the French Line in this country and Canada, whose marriage will take place in January. Mr. and Mrs. Haight later took their party to the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for supper.

The $5,900,000 cut in the water rate voted by the Aldermen some time ago was a matter of strategy rather than tactics. They were more interested in getting re-elected than in establishing a more equitable schedule of charges. Strategic considerations likewise doubtless dominated Tammany's recessional on Tuesday when a motion to override Mayor LA GUARDIA'S veto of the water rate cut was laid on the table by a vote of 37 to 21.

Business leasing activity reported yesterday centred in the midtown area. Philip Dincin, in the hotel and restaurant business for forty years, is leasing for ten years the store in 67-73 West Forty-fourth Street for the first link in a proposed chain of restaurants in this city. The Cross Brown Company was the broker.

MANILA, Thursday, Nov. 14 (AP). -- How survivors sang on wave-lashed rocks to keep up their spirits as they saw comrades die was told here today when the United States destroyer Peary docked with forty-three persons rescued from boiling seas 350 miles southwest of here, where the British freighter Silverhazel crashed Sunday.
VIENNA, Nov. 13. -- The question of an Austrian embargo on arms and other war material for Italy is puzzling political circles here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Transfer of control of the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation from the relief branch of the government to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration has given to the latter organization machinery for buying and selling all kinds of farm products which is even more extensive than that of the old Federal Farm Board.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 13. -- A Works Progress Administration grant of $320,124 for the development by Rutgers University of the 256-acre plot purchased last Spring was announced today by J.H. Weitzen, director of WPA District 4. The university will contribute $98,390 as its share of the project, making the total cost $418,514.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Including Sundays and legal holidays, there are only eighteen days left in which utility holding companies may register under the requirement of the new law, the law which made the last session of Congress a battlefield of the so-called "death sentence."

The proposed new railroad-rate schedule on unboxed automobiles between Michigan factories and Gulf ports for the export trade were defended as legal in the light of two previous decisions of the interstate Commerce Commission, in a brief filed yesterday with the commission by several New York trade groups.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13. -- Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court today ordered the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, which has asked permission to reorganize under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, to submit a plan for reorganization before April 23, 1936. He said in a briefly worded document, filed with the clerk of the court in this city:

MOSCOW, Nov. 13. -- Two spies, both former Russian White Guard officers, who confessed at a two-day trial before a military tribunal at Khabarovsk that they had been sent into Soviet territory by a foreign military mission on an intelligence service detail, have been sentenced to die before a firing squad.

Approval of the city's transit unification plan by stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines which the I.R.T. leases and operates, was urged yesterday by officials and attorneys for the elevated company at the annual stockholders' meeting held at 165 Broadway.

More than 40,000 letters with contributions and suggestions for a memorial have been received at the national headquarters of the Will Rogers Memorial Commission, Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, director of the campaign to perpetuate the humorist's memory, announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13. -- Bankers attending the convention of the American Bankers Association here asserted tonight that hanks were lending money much below the 6 per cent level. Some chosen at random from scattered sections made the following comments:
Gold bullion on the open London market, in terms of British currency, up 2d at 141s 6d per fine ounce. Price before British suspension of gold payments on Sept. 21, 1931, was 84s 9 3/4d.

Police Commissioner Valentine sent a letter to District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn yesterday questioning the District Attorney's sincerity in his "sudden interest" in the pin-game racket and suggesting that both officials "get back to the serious business" of performing their respective duties.
ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 13. -- Uncertainty prevails here whether Emperor Haile Selassie will visit Dessye or Hater or whether he will remain at general headquarters in the capital.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 13. -- The State Democratic executive committee elected today Governor Bibb Graves, Senators Hugo Black and John Bankhead, and John D. McQueen, its chairman, as delegates from the State at large to lead Alabama's delegation to the 1986 Democratic National Convention.
Aldermanic President Deutsch yesterday set Nov. 27 as the date for a public hearing on the city's policy regarding assessments on property of religious and charitable institutions.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- Three per cent and other French rentes fell a whole point on the Bourse today in a market that was very much depressed. Evidently an unfavorable interpretation is being given to the political situation and to the probable outcome of the conflict between the government and the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

The examiners committee of the Foreign Trade Zone Board closed its hearings at 45 Broadway yesterday on the proposed selection of Staten Island as a free foreign trade zone, or "free port," in New York.

MAKALE, Ethiopia, Nov. 13 (AP). -- As General Emilio de Bono arrived today to take formal possession of this city for Italy, wild shouts and fierce gestures of welcome greeted him from the warriors of Haile Selassie Gugsa, traitorous son-in-law of Emperor Haile Selassie.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- With the Yankee Stadium sold out to its capacity of almost 80,000 seats, Army went through a long workout under floodlights in the rain and mud today in preparation for the meeting with Notre Dame on Saturday.

Alexander R. Klahr, attorney of record for Nicholas Montana in his General Sessions trial on a vice indictment, took the stand yesterday as a defense witness and denied testimony of a detective the day before that last Summer he offered the detective $1,000 monthly to permit Montana to operate disreputable apartments in this city.

Following an up-State sleet storm which partly isolated communities near Malone, N.Y., and left several places without light or power, New York City was advised by the United States Weather Bureau that the cold snap that set in last night would continue today and tomorrow.

With President Roosevelt again raising the question of loan rates yesterday and expressing the hope that especially those on real estate loans would be lowered below 6 per cent, bankers in this city asserted that Washington apparently was not conversant with the situation here. For some time savings banks in the metropolitan area have been charging less than 6 per cent.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- Three per cent and other French rentes fell a whole point on the Bourse today in a market that was very much depressed. Evidently an unfavorable interpretation is being given to the political situation and to the probable outcome of the conflict between the government and the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The New York Stock Exchange has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the registration of 3,000,000 shares of unissued common stock of the Coca-Cola Company for "when-issued" dealing on that Exchange between the date of issuance on or about Nov. 15 and the final date of distribution of the shares to stockholders, the commission announced today.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., whose realty interests recently have been centred in the Rockefeller Center project, is planning another major building operation in the midtown district near Fifth Avenue, it was learned yesterday.

Bond prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday continued toward moderately lower levels. The trading pace was further slackened with most of the activity confined to domestic corporation bonds. Total sales were $11,352,900, against $12,257,800 on the previous day.

Prospects of a more than usually interesting season were brought forth at the Annual meeting of the Indoor Polo Association of America held last night at the Metropolitan Club. Winston Guest, the only 10-goal man in the indoor sport, was returned to the post of president.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- The prospects of a Franco-German rapprochement, which has at least reached the stage of discussion, appear to hinge more and more upon the attitude of Russia. The arrival in Paris of Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador at Large, is not yet officially announced, but his private secretary, Mr. Abetz, is here and has already conversed informally with some French authorities.

Members of the New York City Colony of the National Society of New England Women will hold their annual card party in behalf of their philanthropic projects this afternoon in the Romany Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Irregularity developed in the trading in futures on the local commodity markets yesterday. Gains were made by cottonseed oil and wool tops, while other staples were unchanged or weak. Rye, oats and butter advanced in the cash markets, and wheat, corn, cocoa, and tin declined.

GENEVA, Nov. 13. -- Only nineteen contracts of eleven countries are found to meet the conditions for exemptions from Sanction 3 --the boycott of Italian goods -- by the subcommittee on this subject, which issued its report today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14. -- The American Bankers Association concluded its annual convention here today with the official adoption of resolutions declaring that "recovery is making vigorous progress" and predicting that "1936 will be a better business year than 1935."

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 14. -In her competitive debut for the season, Mrs. Ary J. Lamme, leading woman squash racquets player of the metropolitan district, led her Apawamis Club team to a 3-2 victory over the Greenwich Country Club on the Greenwich Field Club courts today.

With the employer members dissenting, the Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council approved "in principle" yesterday by a vote of six to three plans for keeping records under the new Unemployment Insurance Act, which will require individual reports on each of the two to three million workers who will be eligible for unemployment benefits.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Four white horses dragged into the White House grounds today a large van, decorated like a sleigh, bearing a 1,250-pound cheddar cheese.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 14. -The responsibility for meeting the latest relief emergency in New Jersey lies largely now with the municipalities, Chester I. Barnard, who resigned yesterday as State relief director, told delegates to the twentyfirst annual convention of the New Jersey League of Municipalities here today.

Every conductor has his special powers and musical affinities. Last night in Carnegie Hall Otto Klemperer led the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a memorable performance of Bruckner's Eighth Symphony. In view of this interpretation, and the one given last Winter of Bruckner's Ninth, it is reasonable to believe that Mr. Klemperer has a special insight into the works of this composer.

Lou Salica, bantamweight champion of the world, will risk his title tonight when he clashes with Sixto Escobar of Puerto Rico in a fifteenround bout at Madison Square Garden. Because of the stirring battle staged by these rivals when they met last August their fight tonight is expected to draw one of the largest crowds to witness an 118pound contest in years.

The dismissal from service of Mrs. Mary C. Williams, Negro teacher of Public School 90, Manhattan, and a follower of Father Divine, Harlem religious leader, was the result of charges of falsifying records to conceal maternity, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, explained yesterday.

A contest in decorating a Thanksgiving Day dinner table ended yesterday with the honors going to a New Jersey woman who took as her keynote extreme simplicity. The event was held under the auspices of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut at Horticultural Hall in Rockefeller Center.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The Incorporated Society of British Advertisers has appealed to Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin to halt the efforts Sir Kingsley Wood, the Postmaster General, is now making to prevent British radio advertisers from using continental stations for advertising.

A damage suit for $850,000 against the City Housing Corporation, alleging false representation of costs in the construction of the one, two and three family homes in Sunnyside Gardens, Queens, was brought yesterday by 269 persons who bought 217 of the properties.

The Class A squash racquet teams of the Harvard, Princeton and University Clubs proved victorious again last night in the metropolitan league race and consequently continued to share first place in the standing.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 14. -- All the signs and portents in this unique war give vivid evidence that the Ethiopian warriors on the southern front will not fall back like those in the north before the invading Italians.

GEORGE II is on his way back to Athens to assume the crown which he lost twelve years ago. A plebiscite upset his throne and a plebiscite has restored the monarchy. The world is justly skeptical of these popular consultations and their predetermined overwhelming majorities, but as plebiscites go nowadays the recent popular vote for the return of the King was perhaps not too outrageous.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Most of the complaints of "poverty in the midst of plenty" are founded on economic misconceptions, Sir Josiah Stamp declared yesterday in the annual Norman Lockyer lecture, delivered before the British Science Guild.

The Union League Club, in its second attack on the Roosevelt administration in the last two months, charged last night that the spending policies of the government will, if continued unchecked, lead to national disaster.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Over the protests of a reluctant prosecutor, the hog-gambling charge against Governor Herring of Iowa was kept alive today until Monday at least.

PLYMOUTH, England, Friday, Nov. 15. -- Viscountess Astor was elected a member of Parliament for the Sutton division of Plymouth today for the seventh consecutive time. She rolled up 21,491 votes, to 15,394 for George Ward, Laborite railway worker, after one of the quietest campaigns in her political career.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The administration's campaign to end the Federal dole went past the halfway mark on two fronts today when Harry L. Hopkins ordered nine additional States cut off direct relief.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, delegate of the United Sea Food Workers Union, and two co-defendants, accused of having been active in the fresh-water fish racket, were found guilty last night of violating the anti-trust laws. A jury in United States District Court returned a verdict at 11 P. M. after almost seven hours of deliberation.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14. -- One clash between students and the police today broke the calm in Cairo after yesterday's violent anti-British outbursts.

A trade fair, conceived with the aim of encouraging both export and import sales, will be held here in the closing weeks of May, according to plans announced yesterday by the American Manufacturers Export Association, which is cooperating in sponsorship of the event.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Voting in the general elections today began briskly with a steady flow of voters to the polling booths this morning, the weather favoring the first voters, while later in the day it was rainy and cold.

Auctioneers offered nine properties in Manhattan at foreclosure sales yesterday. Most of the auctioned parcels were bought in by banks. The improvement consisted almost entirely of tenement houses. One scheduled sale was put over to today.

MANILA, Oct. 14. -- The inauguration of the Philippine Commonwealth government automatically takes the Philippine Islands from under the provisions of the Jones law, or Organic Act, passed in 1916, and puts into effect the newly drafted and approved Constitution of the Commonwealth.
Yesterday's statement of thetwelve Reserve Banks showed totalgold holdings for the system as awhole to be at the highest point ofthe year to date.

Ten field hockey teams representing nine different associations will start their annual three-day Northeast sectional tournament this afternoon on the fields of Adelphi College, Garden City, L. I. The smooth Adelphi grounds were used for the same tournament last year, but today the Hew York Field Hockey Association, rather than Long Island, is acting as sponsor.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 14. -Questioned for two hours before the Chester County grand jury here today, Henry H. Rogers Jr. expressed the opinion, it was reported, that Evelyn Hoey might have ended her life accidentally, not intentionally, in the bedroom of his farm home near Downingtown, two months ago.

Support for the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, which seeks to raise $400,000 by Thanksgiving in its annual roll-call, was asked yesterday in an address over Station WEAF by General James G. Harbord, chapter chairman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Pacific Lighting Company and its public utility subsidiaries, the Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation, the Southern California Gas Company, the Southern Counties Gas Company of California and the Santa Maria Gas Company, sought today to establish their claim for exemption from the Public Utility Act of 1935 at a bearing before Charles S. Lobinger, examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Budd Manufacturing Company disposed, during October, of 9,110 shares of its common stock through the exercise of an option held by Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., it was disclosed yesterday in the company's monthly report to the New York Stock Exchange on reacquired stock.

Cornell has not won a game this season, and since both Dartmouth and Penn still have to be played, the chances are that the once mighty powerhouse from Ithaca will complete the first year in its history barren of victory. And is the axe being sharpened for the long, lean neck of Gil Dobie? Not a bit of it.

Warning that American institutions will vanish if they do not adapt themselves to social changes, Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace, in a speech here last night, urged the establishment of a nonpartisan, independent Council on the General Welfare, chartered as a sort of economic supreme court, to study Federal legislation, recommend changes, and promote permanent well-being and balanced national economy.

An error of two and three-tenths miles was made by an officer of the Coast Guard cutter Tampa in estimating the position of the Ward liner Morro Castle, when that vessel was burning off Asbury Park on Sept. 8, 1934, Earl G. Rose, commander of the cutter, admitted yesterday in Federal court.

Robert C. Baldwin, receiver for the Commercial National Bank of Washington, began suit yesterday in Federal court here to restrain the Chase National Bank of New York from surrendering $997,448.33 to the government of the Philippine Islands. Mr. Baldwin contends that the sum should become part of the receivership estate and used for the benefit of all creditors.
In your editorial "Words, Words, Words" you state that physicists, like surgeons, prate meaninglessly in their discussions of the fundamentals of their science.

There have been half-hearted apologists for lynching, but it remained for Texas to furnish two out-and-out defenders of it. They happen also to be responsible for the trial and punishment of criminals in their particular county. The dispatch in yesterday's TIMES from Columbus, Texas, told of the lynching of two Negro boys who had been guilty of criminally attacking and murdering a white girl.

The Chicago Cardinals will arrive in New York tomorrow for their game with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field on Sunday. The invaders will be bent upon returning home triumphant, since they must defeat the Brooklyn eleven to remain in the race for the Western Division championship.

OTTAWA, Nov. 14. -- Announcement that a settlement of Canada's trade war with Japan would soon follow the conclusion of a trade treaty with the United States was made by Prime Minister Mackenzie King this afternoon just before he left for Washington, where he will sign the treaty at the White House tomorrow afternoon for Canada, with Secretary Hull signing for the United States.
One of the five known autograph manuscripts which Francis Scott Key wrote of "The Star-Spangled Banner" was sold last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., for $5,500.

An endowment of $100,000 for the Point Barrow Hospital in Alaska, where the bodies of Will Rogers and Wiley Post were taken after their fatal airplane accident, was among the proposals for a Rogers memorial received yesterday with contributions to the Will Rogers Memorial Fund.

One more loan shark was convicted yesterday in Special Sessions, six additional convictions were found against another and a third pleaded guilty. Of the twenty-two men accused, four await sentence on Nov. 22 on charges of lending money at interest without license and of exacting usurious rates.

A gain of $60,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, bringing the total to $3,050,000,000, a new high record, was reported yesterday in the system's statement for the week ended on Wednesday. The previous high level, established two weeks ago, was $3,010,000,000.
ROME, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The Italian high command tonight claimed a victory in which 300 Ethiopians were killed on the Somaliland front. Sharp fighting also marked operations in Northern Ethiopia.

Reassured by pronouncements from high governmental places that business need not fear uncertainty because of measures of government, and that the 1937 budget is to be pared, and by the reminders that European investment in our securities is increasing steadily and that large investors here are not disposed to part with their holdings for tax purposes, the share market yesterday gave one of its most impressive demonstrations of the year.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 14. -- Criticism of the National Youth Administration as "a misdeal far youth" featured the address of George A. Hastings, former extension director of the White House Conference on Child Health and Protection, before the annual convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs here today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14. -- As the sixty-first annual convention of the American Bankers Association came to a conclusion here tonight, Robert V. Fleming, newly elected president of the organization, summed up the sentiment of the more than 3,600 bankers who attended in the following statement:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Testifying today before the Securities and Exchange Commission, Colonel Grayson M.-P. Murphy of New York, chairman of the general advisory committee of Peruvian bondholders, blamed Congress and, to a lesser extent, the newspapers, for the chaos involving about $100,000,000 of Peruvian bonds now in default and owned by American investors.
A single lapse in defense cost the Rangers their opening hockey game at Madison Square Garden last night by a 1-0 score.

From his bed in Mount Sinai Hospital Mayor La Guardia intervened yesterday in the controversy arising from the purchase of German steel for the Triborough Bridge, taking action designed to bring about cancellation of the deal.

Stocks and bonds rose briskly yesterday in response to the overnight announcement of an economy program by President Roosevelt, and the statement by Secretary of Commerce Roper that the basic objectives of reform had been attained.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- The wheat market reversed its recent trend today and was as strong as it had recently been weak. Aggressive short covering developed as the result of a bullish construction placed here and abroad on the Canadian Government's crop estimate which was issued late yesterday and showed 16,000,000 bushels below the previous returns.

John J. Kelly, Tammany district leader, and Lamar Hardy, former Corporation Counsel, are now the leading candidates for the posts of United States Marshal and United States Attorney for the Southern District, according to information here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 13 as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,484,000,000, an increase of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week, and of $15,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Public Works Administration will change its regulations to make impossible the purchase of foreign materials for Federal or non-Federal PWA projects unless approval is first obtained from the PWA Administrator, Secretary Harold L. Ickes informed William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a letter mailed today.
To all intents and purposes, Manhattan College's football season came to a close yesterday, although it won't officially end until tomorrow.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., Nov. 14. -Competing against one of the largest and most capable fields ever to participate in a field trial for Labrador retrievers in America, Blind of Arden, fast-going entry belonging to William A. Harriman of Harriman, N.Y., captured top honors in the open all-age stake today.

CI-]XCAGO, Nov. 14.--Miss PaulinePo liner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.Potter Palmer, whoso formal presentation to Chicago society w~lltake place on tho afternoon of Dec.27 in the historic Potter Palmermansion, will leave for the Eastnext Monday to attend the YaleHarvard game at Cambridge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -Cotton consumed during October was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 552,187 bales of lint and 67,106 of linters, compared with 449,126 and 61,127 during September this year and 523,032 and 56,612 during October last year.

Employment opportunities for the youth of the country are gradually enlarging through the aid of governmental and social agencies, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Girls Service League at the Hotel Plaza.

Proposals for promotion of temperance, unification of basic Stats legislation and reduction of liquor taxes as a means for better control of the liquor industry were endorsed by the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators at the opening sessions of it second annual convention at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Triumphant after their balloon ascent to more than 73,000 feet above South Dakota Monday, Captain Albert W. Stevens and Captain Orvil A. Anderson came to the capital today to receive President Roosevelt's congratulations and to help in the immense amount of work needed to prepare their various scientific data for interpretation by experts.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden. Nov. 14. -- The Nobel Prize in physics for 1935 was awarded today to Professor James Chadwick for his discovery of the neutron while working at the Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, in 1932.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 14. -- Tension exists along the Peruvian-Ecuadorean frontier, which for generations has been a bone of contention between the two republics, because of alleged invasion of the Peruvian Province of Tumbes by Ecuadorean cavalry and police.

In an address characterized by a warning against "the uncertainties of tomorrow," Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, called upon capital and labor yesterday to aid in formulating a program for hastening recovery, eliminating unemployment and maintaining business and labor standards.

ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 14. -- King George's departure from London for Greece today intensified the struggle between Regent George Kondylis and former Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris for control of the future government, but the departure was received without visible emotion by the man in the street.

It was Mr. Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs of the baseball Giants, who edged himself up to the luncheon table, ordered a tomato juice cocktail, a chicken sandwich and a cup of coffee, and then took off as follows, generally speaking:
In an interesting communication to this column, R. C. waxes enthusiastic over "the brightest gem in the wildfowl crown -- the woodcock," and laments the absence of a good flight this season.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 (AP). -- A Federal court special lawyer counsel held today that O. P. Van Sweringen of Cleveland acted without authority in purchasing $3,438,016 in stock and bonds in the open market in 1930 and 1931 for a Missouri Pacific Railroad Company subsidiary.

Denying that the AAA program was a movement for blanket crop reduction or for raising prices through "contrived scarcity," Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, declared at a luncheon here yesterday that American agricul ture must adjust itself to a radically changed market situation, particularly a diminished export opportunity.

Mrs. Herbert Hoover visited the national headquarters of the Girl Scouts, at 570 Lexington Avenue, yesterday morning. She was recently re-elected national president of the organization. In the afternoon she was the guest of honor at a tea given by the Engineering Woman's Club, 123 East Thirty-seventh Street, of which she is a charter member.

ATLANTA, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Fitzgerald Hall, president of the Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis Railroad, has been warned that unless he ceases attacking the Roosevelt administration the road may lose the livestock business of the Southeast, estimated by The Atlanta Journal at more than $300,000 a year.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- After eleven years of exile King George II of Greece left London today on his return to the throne. He departed amid royal honors and cheers from fellow-countrymen and British friends.

A consolidated net income of $10,677,577 is reported by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended on Sept. 30, after all prior deductions, equivalent after preferred dividends to 32 cents a common share, compared with $11,365,640, or 39 cents a share, in the preceding year.
Leasing of dwellings on the East Side featured realty activities in Manhattan yesterday.

The Italian liner Rex arrived yesterday from Naples with three stowaways on board. Two of them were young Italians and the third, an Italian mother, who paid $190 for the passage of her 10-year-old son, Vincent Esposito, in the special class and then hid in his cabin until last Sunday night, when the Rex was two days out from Gibraltar.

With the first advance in five weeks, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 127.9 on Tuesday, from 127.4 on the preceding Tuesday. Advances being general, with corn, cotton, hogs and pork rising in particular.

The thirteenth annual drawing of works of art, contributed by artist members and distributed among lay members of the Grand Central Galleries, Inc., was held last night at a reception in the galleries at 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.
