Marga Waldron last night presented a program of "ballet divertissements" at the Barbizon-Plaza before an audience that filled the hall and gave every indication of enjoying itself. Not since 1929, when she gave a pair of performances at the Princess Theatre, has Miss Waldron appeared here in recital, and there has been considerable growth in her work since then.

Declaring that the main objectives of the conferences proposed by Major Berry are close to achievement in the shoe manufacturing industry, Frederick A. Miller, president of the H. C. Godman Company, and also head of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association, yesterday amplified his group's opposition to attending the suggested meetings.

A booking made some time ago, but disclosed only last night, will bring "First Lady," the Katherine Dayton-George S. Kaufman comedy dealing with the upper strata of Washington's political society, to the Music Box on Tuesday evening, Nov. 26.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has informed the Northern Baptist Church that hereafter he will not contribute to its unified budget and that his future donations to religious work will be made to "specific projects, chiefly interdenominational or non-denominational in character."

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced last night settlement of the first complaint brought by the board in this district under the National Labor Relations Act. The case, settlement of which followed hearings lasting three days, involved the United Fruit Company, charged with formation of a company union, in violation of the act.

Most futures advanced in generally more active trading on the local commodity future markets yesterday. On the cash markets, gains were made by all the grains, cotton, rubber and butter, while tin, antimony, lard and hides were lower.
Meat trade conditions and wholesaleprices in New York:

Support for President Roosevelt's policy favoring Federal aid for the merchant marine was urged yesterday by Rear Admiral George H. Rock, retired, president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, at the opening of the society's annual meeting at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas for the week ended Nov. 9 showed a rise of 6 per cent over the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. This indicates to some degree an improvement in retail trade here, inasmuch as deliveries for the preceding week showed a decline of 1 per cent under 1934.

Intensive work for its encounter with Rutgers was ended yesterday by the undefeated and untied New York University varsity football squad at Ohio Field. This afternoon the players will go through a brief drill and tomorrow they will clash with the eleven from the shores of the Raritan in the thirtythird meeting between the teams.

This week's statement of loans and investments, deposit and other liability of reporting member banks in New York City is given in more detailed form than heretofore. Brokers' loans in the week ended on Wednesday gained $16,000,000, of which $14,000,000 represented an increase in loans to New York City brokers and dealers and $2,000,000 to out-of-town brokers.

While the authorities were hastening preparations to bring her to trial for murder in the first degree early in January, Miss Vera Stretz was transferred yesterday from her cell in the Women's House of Detention at 10 Greenwich Avenue to the prison hospital.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- The Army football squad, thirty-eight strong and physically fit, arrived tonight at the Knollwood Country Club where it will remain until shortly before the game with Notre Dame at the Ya kee Stadium on Saturday.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 14. -- Private advices support the Ethiopian official view that Italian reports of advances in the south toward Jijiga and Harar are propaganda for moral effect.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- With Leopold Stokowski conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Ballet Russe -- Colonel W. de Basil's troupe presented by impresario S. Hurok -tonight gave a diversified and impressive program at the Academy of Music.

The particular British election figures which will be scanned with most interest this morning by the cognoscenti are those relating to the Lloyd George Liberals. Have the Lloyd Georgeites perhaps scored a sensational gain of 100 per cent and gone up to eight members in the New House of Commons?

SHANGHAI, Friday, Nov. 15. -The Rengo (Japanese) News Agency correspondent in Peiping reported that North China's longawaited movement for self-government apparently had been launched today when Yin Ju-keng, administrative commissioner of the demilitarized zone, issued a telegram circular demanding that the Nanking Government accord autonomy to the North China provinces.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 14. -- American education, the civilized woman and science's strides against infectious disease were discussed at academic conferences here today preliminary to induction ceremonies tomorrow for Dr. Alan C. Valentine as the fourth president of the University of Rochester.

The Alleghany Corporation, next to the top company in the Van Sweringen railroad-holding structure, reported yesterday a net loss of $20,885 in the three months ended on Sept. 30, against a net loss of $39,723, excluding a profit of $784 from the sale of securities, in the preceding quarter, and against a net loss of $260,981 in the third quarter of 1934.

Despite another short week, bank clearings continued heavy. The total for the twenty-two leading cities throughout the country was $4,741,075,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represented a gain of 23.1 per cent from the $3,860,276,000 reported a year earlier.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- Prices on the Boerse were marked up along the entire list today. Heavy industrials rose considerably, Mannesmann gaining 2 1/2 points and Vereintgtestahl 1 5/3. Textiles, machines, cables, wire works and electrics also rose 1 to 2 points.

A conviction that the novel as a medium of expression is out of gear with twentieth-century life was expressed yesterday by Thornton Wilder, author and professor of comparative literature at Chicago University, who returned on the Britannic after a six months' tour of Europe.

A special invitation concert by members of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under Dr. Henry Hadley, will be given tonight for members and guests of the American Academy of Arts and Letters at 632 West 156th Street.
LONDON. Nov. 14 (A/P). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

MOSCOW, Nov. 14. -- A death blow to the "Black Bourse" here is seen in tonight's decree by the Council of People's Commissars abolishing from Jan. 1 virtually all foreigncurrency transactions except in exchange at the new official rate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Anything like the exact figure by which the administration may be able to cut the 1937 budget in its economy drive will not be settled until a few days before President Roosevelt submits his budget message to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- A thorough investigation into the management and financing of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, the second in the road's history, was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission as a prelude to renewed demands on Congress for authority to regulate all railroad expenditures.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 15. -- The Hon. William Waldorf Astor, only 27 years old and never before in politics, became one of the outstanding heroes of the entire election today by capturing the East Fulham division, in London, from the Labor party.
POTTSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 14. -The problem of bootleg coal gives rise to anomalous situations such as these:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- The reciprocal tariff treaty with Canada, arranged by President Roosevelt and Premier Mackenzie King, was denounced by two large farm organizations meeting here today so far as it may reduce the United States' tariff on dairy imports from the Dominion.

With President Roosevelt as honorary chairman, and Nicholas Murray Butler as chairman, a Mark Twain Centennial Dinner will be held on Tuesday in the Grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Professor William Lyon Phelps will be toastmaster, and Austin Strong will introduce Tom Sawyer, Huckleberry Finn, Colonel Sellers and fourteen other characters from Mark Twain's books.
"Mary Burns, Fugitive," with Sylvia Sidney, Melvyn Douglas and Alan Baxter, will open today at the Paramount.

News that President ROOSEVELT is seeking economies in the budget for next year, together with his reported approval of Secretary ROPER'S statement that the present "breathing spell" for business "means specifically that the "basic program of reform has been "completed," will be interpreted in many quarters as "a swing to the right" on the part of the Administration.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters yesterday honored accomplishment in literature and in stage and radio diction by awarding gold medals, respectively, to Pearl S. Buck, Lynn Fontanne, and Alois Havrilla.

By far the greater number of the suggestions offered by your various correspondents for cutting down motor fatalities may fairly be likened to applying skin lotions for an organic disease. Any one with eyes to see and common sense to judge must be convinced that speeding is responsible for the vast majority of the accidents that kill and maim so many thousands of our people annually.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -Jim Salsich was promoted to the quarterback post on the second team today, as Fritz Crisler sent his undefeated and untied Princeton eleven through a lengthy session that included signals, kick blocking and individual assignments on University Field.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 14. -The director and associate director of a survey of educational methods and practices in New York State which may bring about a drastic reorganization of public education were named today at a meeting here of the New York State Board of Regents.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 14. -John A. Pilgard, Mayor-elect of Hartford, died at St. Francis Hospital at noon today, bringing about an unusual situation.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 14. -- Judge Elwood Hamilton of the Federal District Court tonight held the Guffey Coal Act constitutional. He declared that Congress has power to regulate wages and prices of any industry which Congress may conclude bears on interstate commerce and pronounced the courts powerless to review such a conclusion if any facts support it.

The Public Service Commission of New York yesterday authorized the sale of $25,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds by the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company at not less than par and interest.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Miss Lillian Bruce, 35, of Lawrence, Mass., physical education instructor in the New Rochelle elementary schools, told Troy police today that fear of loss of her job caused her to attempt suicide. She jumped sixty feet from a bridge into the Hudson River last night.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14. -- With Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Hindu Queen the probable favorite in the featured Bowie claiming stakes, the final race meeting of the Eastern season will get under way at Bowie tomorrow to run for fourteen days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- President Roosevelt is expected to make his decision as to whether he should issue a new and more emphatic appeal to American business men against trading in war supplies with Italy on the basis of a governmental report just compiled that is understood to show no general decrease during October of United States exports to Italy.
WASHINGTON, NOV. 14 (AP). -- A strong intimation came tonight from Senator Borah that he might, under certain circumstances, enter the Republican Presidential primaries for 1936.

The French Government took offielal recognition of the heavy lossof gold to New York and otherI world monetary centres in the lastfew weeks in the action of theBank of France yesterday in raising its discount rate from 3 percent to 4 per cent.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14. -- Solution of the oil industry's marketing problems must await some modification in the laws of capture and of offset drilling, and the establishment of effective control to relieve the pressure of crude oil profitseeking on the subsequent markets, Howard T. Lewis, Professor of Marketing at Harvard University, told members of the American Petroleum Institute, at its closing session today.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The strength shown in today's election by Conservative candidates -- pledged to "repair the gaps in Britain's defenses" -- should strengthen the government's hands in demanding at least twenty new cruisers at the coming naval conference.

Five smartly dressed young women made their way through the crowd and out of Harlem Magistrate's Court yesterday morning, freed of charges of participating in an indecent performance. Magistrate Aurelio had dismissed the charges on the ground that the girls were "merely actors" and therefore could not violate Section 1140A of the Penal Code.

The investment bankers' committee of which Trowbridge Callaway is chairman announced yesterday that it will send to brokers and dealers throughout the country a questionnaire on the segregation of the functions of brokers and dealers, a problem on which the Securities and Exchange Commission will report to Congress on Jan. 3, 1936.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Although the election restricted business today on the London Stock Exchange, a cheerful tone prevailed under the influence of good trade figures and of Wall Street news. The latter resulted in a sharp rise in International Nickel, which stood out in the trading in rising to the highest price in five years on the report detailing good quarterly earnings.

Jess W. Sweetser, who put the metropolitan golf district on the map in a way that had not been done since the days of Jerry Travers and the late Walter J. Travis by his victories in the American and British championships, has been nominated for the presidency of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

A special meeting of the stockholders of tho Standard Commercial Tobacco Company has been called for Nov. 25 to act on proposed changes in the certificate of incorporation, including changing the common stock from no par value to $1 par value.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The President has more time these days than at any prior period of his administration for the things he has to do. His visitors' list is rather small. Though his daily cares are mountainous in weight, and numerous enough to swamp the high-powered executives of industry, the White House pace is easier than at any time since the New Deal began.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- Sigmund Eisner of Red Bank, N.J., today received the United States Army contract, on bids opened at the Army Quartermaster's depot here yesterday, to furnish the Medical Department with 25,000 terry cloth bathrobes at $1.94, less one-tenth of 1 per cent in ten days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- A proclamation certifying the freedom of the Philippine Islands and the election of officials chosen by ballot In the islands on Sept. 17 was signed by President Roosevelt a few minutes after noon today.

Henry J. Allen, former Governor of Kansas, returned from Europe yesterday deeply impressed with Premier Mussolini's renaissance in Italy. He arrived on the United States liner Washington with Mrs. Allen after spending two months abroad gathering material for articles.

One of the briefs filed with the Supreme Court by Government attorneys begs that tribunal to make a broad definition of the "general welfare clause" of the Constitution. The obvious implication is that many things have been done under the New Deal for which it is hard to find specific constitutional warrant.

Fourteen jurors, two of them alternates, were accepted in General Sessions yesterday for the trial of three former officers of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company for an alleged false statement on its financial condition shortly before it was taken over by the State Insurance Department in 1933.

An indication that passing will play an important part in Fordham's offensive against its foes in the last two games of the season was given as the Maroon football forces went through their workout at Fordham Field yesterday.

Building projects filed in the cityyesterday included a $150,000 apartment house for the Bronx and a$140,000 theatre for Woodside,Queens. A $170,000 Welfare Islandalteration project and revised plansfor $1,414,000 Brooklyn housing alsowere filed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14.-- Government and coal-mining circles favorable to the Guffey bill received with gratification tonight the decision of Judge Hamilton that the Coal Regulation Bill was constitutional.

A defense of the Reciprocal Tariff Treaty of 1934, now in force between Cuba and the United States, but under attack in the Customs Court, was made in a statement by Pablo Suarez, Cuban Consul General, which was read yesterday at a luncheon of the National Commission for Propaganda and Defense of Havana Tobacco at the Lexington Hotel.

Retail prices of butter rose 2 cents a pound yesterday and were expected to rise another 2 cents today as a result of rising wholesale prices. The 4-cent advance in two days was attributed by observers of the produce markets to an unusually sharp Fall decrease in the production of butter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The nine justices of the Supreme Court varied their routine abruptly today by becoming, in partial effect, a coroner's jury to investigate the fatal shooting of a clerk more than four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Edison Illuminating Company of Boston has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of 89,146 additional shares of $100 par value capital stock, warrants and fractional warrants evidencing 534,875 rights to subscribe for the stock and stock subscription receipts for subscription payments on the capital stock.
The retirement of one member firm, the fomation of two new ones and the proposed transfer of two memberships were announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- The big local packers were aggressive buyers of hogs here today following a steady to weak opening and started a scramble to secure supplies on the part of all interests. As a result prices at the close showed advances of 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- Willie Hoppe, master at balkline billiards, offered convincing proof that he has mastered the three-cushion game when he conquered Augie Kieckhefer of Chicago, 50 to 39 in forty-four innings in the world championship today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- High confidence in European countries as to the success of the United States Government's policies as indicated by the large transfers of foreign balances of the United States, was reported to the President today by Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who outlined observations made on a recent trip abroad.

H. G. Wells, brimming over with amiability and enthusiasm for his incursion to the complex film world of Hollywood, arrived last night on the United States liner Washington, to learn whatever else he can about the film business, his latest love.

Meyer Luckman was arrested again yesterday in connection with the murder of Sam Druckman last March in a Brooklyn garage. A city-wide search was begun for two other suspects who, like him, escaped indictment by a Kings County grand jury last Spring under circumstances which have since been the subject of investigation by Police Commissioner Valentine.

Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, told the Academy of Political Science at its annual meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday afternoon that the Federal budget must be balanced if the country is to avoid inflation, followed by another crash and deflation.

Construction plans submitted to the State Department of Labor last month totaled $2,603,300, the largest aggregate for any month since May, 1930, when the total was $3,881,360, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 14. -Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, suffered a broken hip late last night when she fell in her house at Sagamore Hill, her estate here. Mrs. Roosevelt, who was 74 years old last Aug. 6, was taken this afternoon to North Country Community Hospital in an ambulance.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 14. -An all-claiming card was staged today at Narragansett Park, with the best class of horses running in the second and fourth races. These were both at six furlongs and were for 2-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Court of Claims has held unconstitutional the tax levied by Congress on profits made in the Spring of 1934 from sale of silver, when the silver bullion of the country was nationalized.

The prolonged factional feud between the "Old Guard" and the Left Wing in the Socialist party reached a climax yesterday when it became known that the Central Committee of the New York City organization voted by 69 to 47 to "reorganize" the party here by eliminating left wingers engaged in what the committee characterized as "disruptive" activities.

iN-EW ORLEALTS, Nov. 14.--Inspeeches of sharply divergent context before the final session of thruAmerican Bankers Association'mannual convention here today, government spending wu attacked onone side as a menace, and defendeclon the other as the saving factorof the capitalistic system.

MANILA, Friday, Nov. 15. -- With a vast display of pomp and excitement acting temporarily as an opiate for hearts filled with doubts and forebodings, the new Philippine Commonwealth was cast out into the world today by the combined forces of United States idealism and economic interests and of Filipino aspirations and politics.

The organization of an effective agency to combine all groups fighting crime into a concerted community effort to war against juvenile delinquency was urged yesterday by Dr. Bernard Sachs, former president of the New York Academy of Medicine, in presenting to the justices of the Domestic Relations Court a voluminous report covering a study of the court.

The Twentieth Century Sporting Club will be even more important in local boxing circles in the future than it has in thc past year, following the announcement made yesterday by Mike Jacobs, secretary of the organization. Jacobs revealed that he had signed four-year leases on both the Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds for the promotion of outdoors shows.

George Herman (Babe) Ruth, baseball's most famous player but just another driver in the world of motoring, was arrested at the point of a repeating rifle last night by a police squad at the Manhattan exit of the Queensboro Bridge. He had driven into a trap for a hit-and-run driver.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 14. -Orville White of Overland, Ohio, who last Winter began knocking at the door of top-notch professional golf, scored a 70 and led the field by two strokes in the first round of the thirty-six-hole tournament that started today.

The investment bankers' committee on segregation, which announced yesterday its intention to send a questionnaire to brokers and dealers throughout the country, apparently is more sanguine than the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Sylvester Lancaric, 17 years old, who beat his 3-year-old brother, John, so severely on May 9 in their home at 75 East 106th Street, that the child died two weeks later, was committed yesterday by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions to an indeterminate stay in the New York State Vocational Institution at West Coxsackie, N.Y.

PARIS, Nov. 14. -- As a measure of defense against the export of gold, the regents of the Bank of France raised today the bank's discount rate from 3 to 4 per cent, which action advances the rates on security loans from 4 to 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -Dissatisfied with its progress, Rexford G. Tugwell today signed orders for a major shake-up in personnel and organization of the Resettlement Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Wholesale prices advanced slightly during the week ended on Nov. 9, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average, was 80.1 compared with 79.8 the preceding week, and 76.6 the corresponding week last year.

The Greyhound Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 net profit of $3,800,940 after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal taxes and other charges, but before provision for management compensation plan.
MONTREAL, Nov. 14 (~P).--Na-tionalization of banks was describedby Jackson Dodds, president of theCanadian Bankers Association, to-day as "perhaps the most insidiousof the monetary nostrums."

MOULTRIE, Ga., Nov. 14 (AP). -National Guardsmen, sent here to prevent mob violence to John Henry Sloan, Negro, accused of slaying a white man, fought their way out of town with the prisoner late today soon after he had been convicted and sentenced to die Dec. 10.

ZEIST, The Netherlands, Nov. 14. -- Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, principals in the match for the chess championship of the world now in progress, entertained a large and interested crowd tonight when they contested the nineteenth game of the series at the headquarters of the Zeist Chess Club.

Intimations from government officials that the 12-cents-a-pound loan, covering 4,430,000 bales of spot cotton, would be extended beyond Feb. 1, 1936, taken in conjunction with a buoyant stock market, brought a sharp rise in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- The Sanitary District of Chicago sold at 100.05 today $20,718,890 of 4 per cent Series A refunding bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1955, to a syndicate of banks headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of this city. They are to be offered at once to investors at prices to yield 3.77 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Lawyers for utility companies today attacked the stand of the Securities and Exchange Commission that preliminary registration of those corporations with the commission would not imperil their right to contest in the courts the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act.

ADEN, Arabia, Nov. 14. -- Reports from Massaua, Eritrea, and Mogadiscio, Italian Somaliland, say that one of the greatest anxieties of the Italian military authorities is a shortage of camels on which to transport food and munitions. They are needed to go into the mountainous country into which Italian troops have advanced, for motorized units can operate there only with great difficulty.

A definite declaration favoring a return to the "fast whistle" in football was made yesterday by Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, coach of the New York University eleven, at a joint luncheon of the Touchdown Club and the Advertising Club at the latter organization's headquarters.

On Nov. 8 Senator NORRIS was said to have said to reporters in Salt Lake City that he wouldn't be a candidate for re-election. He was too old. Some younger man should get a chance. So many remonstrances reached him against the decision, suspected or declared even before his visit to Utah, that already he felt it would be more trouble not to be than to be.

The bondholders' protective committee for Eastern Cuba Sugar Corporation 7 1/2 per cent mortgage bonds, headed by Charles Hayden, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective yesterday, proposing a plan of readjustment with respect to the bonds.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 15. -Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's government has been returned to power for another five years as a result of yesterday's parliamentary election in Great Britain, in which 31,000,000 men and women were entitled to vote. Returns up to early this morning indicate that not more than 70 per cent of them availed themselves of that privilege, but the vote has had no effect whatever on the fortunes of the existing regime.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- Peter Legge, Catholic Bishop of Meissen, appeared today before a Berlin criminal court to answer a charge of having disobeyed the Reich exchange laws by buying up abroad bonds of his financially hardpressed diocese.

PARIS, Nov. 14. -- Negotiations went forward between the Finance Commission and the government today, but no solution of the budget crisis was reached. Without waiting further for a settlement, the Bank of France raised the discount rate from 3 to 4 per cent as a means of checking the gold outflow to the United States, which is daily growing in importance.

While Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, repeated his "work or starve" order yesterday with reference to WPA employes who quit their jobs to go back on home relief without good reason, Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, urged the creation of a board to handle applications for home relief of needy persons discharged from the WPA.

The Viking, a five-page weekly published by the playground children of Leiv Eiriksson Park, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, was named the best of thirty-nine newspapers entered in the Park Department playground newspaper contest by a committee of four reporters and one professor of journalism who judged the entries yesterday afternoon at the Central Park Arsenal.

While the always colorful spectacle of the Army-Notre Dame game at the Yankee Stadium overshadows everything else in this part of the football world, there are in sight for today plenty of interesting meetings throughout the country, including several traditional encounters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- A new "teachers' oath" was demanded, under a ruling issued today by Controller General McCarl, of employes of the public school system in the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Reports were current today that at least three large public utility holding companies, one of them the Associated Gas and Electric, would register under the Holding Company Act of 1935 but no definite information had been received by the Securities and Exchange Commission from any of the companies or their attorneys.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Stern enforcement of traffic laws was demanded today by President Thomas P. Henry of the American Automobile Association to cut the nation's motor vehicle death toll in half.

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Springfield -- This gets harder as it goes along. It's about as hard as corundum now. Corundum? It's the stuff that rubies are made of. And sapphires. And emery. Yes, the humble emery is a near relative to the aristocratic ruby in a mineral way. One vote for Boston College.

Virtually dominating the play throughout, Poly Prep's football team regained its winning stride yesterday by blanking an old foe, St. Paul's School of Garden City, 26 to 0, on the Poly field in Brooklyn. It was the Blue and Gray's ninth success in as many years in their rivalry, which started back in the Nineties.

French cement is being used in New York City public schools which are being constructed with funds advanced by the Public Works Administration, it became known yesterday, when American cement manufacturers protested that foreign importations were depriving American workmen of employment.
CAIRO, Nov. 15. -- Today passed without incident here after two days of disorders.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 (AP). -- A Federal Court grand jury returned indictments today against Seymour Weiss, political treasurer for the late Huey P. Long; Mike M. Moss and Joseph B. Meyers on six counts charging conspiracy to defraud and obstruct the operation of the Treasury Department.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

"Lightship," a first novel by Archie Binns, has won the Prix Femina Americain, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Jeanne Dauban, secretary of the American committee. Founded in 1931 by Mrs. Dauban under the patronage of the former French Ambassador, Paul Claudel, the Prix Femina Americain is given each year to the American work of creative imagination considered most worthy of translation into French.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Prices on the Boerse were firm again today, with the trading somewhat more active than usual. Banks again appeared to be giving the Boerse certain transactions, but much business is still carried on privately.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- With an emphasis unusual in his informal talks at White House press conferences, President Roosevelt today branded as deliberate misrepresentation reports that the administration had changed its policy on Public Works Administration purchases as a result of disclosures that German steel had been bought for use in the Triborough Bridge and a project in North Carolina.

The Association of Former Im-i perial laval Officers held their annual ball last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza in commemoration of the visit of the Grand Duke Alexis of Russia to this country in 1871. Net proceeds will aid members of the association to educate their children in schools and universities here.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 15. -- The Ethiopian southern command reported today the repulse of an Italian column yesterday at a fortified ford of the Fafan River, midway between Gorahai and Daggah Bur. The Italians were en route from Ualual, apparently to reinforce the troops in the Gorahai region.

The Appellate Division reversed yesterday the conviction of Harold Spielberg, president of the Lexington Surety and Indemnity Company, on a charge of presenting a false affidavit to the Superintendent of Insurance to obtain his approval of an increase in capital of from $250,000 to $300,000 for the surety company.

Visits to Mayor La Guardia at Mount Sinai Hospital and the children's ward in St. Vincent's Hospital featured the tour of inspection undertaken yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Gates W. McGarrah, retired international banker, in behalf of the Fall campaign of the United Hospital Fund.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Controller General McCarl has signed today a Treasury warrant releasing 598,037,280 for Works Progress Administration projects in New York State. Funds are available for only part of the complete list, but the warrant will speed transfer of men from the relief rolls to work relief.

With its diversified attack functioning flawlessly, the powerful football team of the Horace Mann School for Boys concluded its campaign by subduing the Irving School of Tarrytown, 45 -- 12, yesterday on the winners' gridiron. The home outfit finished with a record of five triumphs and one reverse, the setback coming at the hands of the unbeaten St. John's Prep eleven last week.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 15. -- The Saddle Spur Stable's Sandwrack proved his liking for distances when he captured the feature race, a mile-and-five-furlong event, at Narragansett Park today.

President Roosevelt announced yesterday in Washington the appointment of Lamar Hardy as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and John J. Kelly as United States Marshal for the same district, thereby giving James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, something less than half a loaf.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 15. -- The "ballyhoo of college athletics" and the administration of loyalty oaths to teachers were denounced here today by academic leaders gathered for the formal induction of 34 -- year- old Alan Valentine, former master of Pierson College at Yale, as fourth president of the University of Rochester.

Your discussion of high-hat plurals reminds me that sundry years ago at a meeting of the council of the Authors League Brander Matthews, always a militant champion of pure American speech, called me down for using some Latin plural in the course of a discussion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus, advocated by the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars, was asked formally of President Roosevelt today in an eight-point legislative program, personally delivered to him by James E. Van Zandt, commander of the latter organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- President Roosevelt today urged in strong terms that Senator Norris be kept a member of the Senate "as long as he lives."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The New York University freshman eleven overwhelmed the Rutgers yearlings today, 32 to 0.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Heavy buying of wheat futures, attributed to short covering for Eastern and local professional operators, a broad demand for flour in the Northwest and resultant removal of hedges by mills, swept prices of wheat upward sharply today.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Nov. 15. -- Sportsmen today must revise their ideas to conform to changing conditions, warned Thomas E. Brady of White Plains in an address before 150 members of the Ridgefield Fish and Game Club at Odd Fellows Hall last night.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 15. -- Dribbling, passing and rushing the hill up and down the Adelphi College fields in four games made snappy by the cold, raw weather which is now recognized as typical for field hockey tournaments, eight teams from New England and New York started play in the annual three-day round-robin Northeast tourney today.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Judge Charles B. Faris of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals late today disapproved contracts by which the Missouri Pacific Railroad agreed in 1930 to buy terminal properties in Kansas City and St. Joseph, Mo., from the Van Sweringen interests for approximately $20,000,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- President Roosevelt, in a message to the American Automobile Association convention meeting here today, urged an intensive and continued campaign for highway safety.

Net income of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $1,473,642 after depreciation. Federal taxes and other charges. The earnings are equivalent, after dividends paid on the $4 convertible preferred stock, to $1.74 a share on 701,749 shares of no-par common stock, excluding 26,900 shares held by the company.

MANILA, P.I., Saturday, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The first President of the Philippine Commonwealth was "at home" today in Malacanan Palace, after the retiring Governor General from the United States as his last official act freed sixty political prisoners, some of them in prison for a decade.
A new witness appeared yesterday before the Brooklyn grand jury hearing evidence In the Sam Druckman murder case, which District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan reopened suddenly on Wednesday.

The United States Attorney's office attempted yesterday in Federal Court to show a jury before Judge Hulbert that the Ward Line, operators of the Morro Castle, had violated regulations of the Department of Commerce by failing to assign every member of that vessel's crew to a station to be occupied in the event of fire.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 15. -- Another clash between Thursday and Only One, which finished a nose apart in the Riggs Handicap, is scheduled for tomorrow. The two speedsters are among the twelve named for the Prince George Autumn Handicap, mile and a sixteenth feature of the second day of the Bowie meeting.

NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, British East Africa, Nov. 15. -- Lieut. Col. John Malet Llewellyn, Tanganyika farmer, has left with sixty-three natives, mainly Somalis, three Indian sub-assistant surgeons and a European transport supervisor to join a British ambulance unit in Ethiopia.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 15. -- A virtual promise that if the anthracite operators distribute the available working time among the employes of their various collieries the union will see to it that "bootleg" operations cease has been made by the United Mine Workers of America.

A plan to broadcast auditions given to applicants for jobs with the Metropolitan Opera Company has run into a snag, it was revealed yesterday when the National Broadcasting Company applied in Federal court for an order to restrain Charles Henry Freeman Jr., booking agent of 115 West Fifty-seventh Street, from attempting to upset an arrangement it has with the Sherwin-Williams Company, prospective sponsor of the programs.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, announced yesterday that the directors had decided to sell the 1,700,000 ordinary shares of the Electric and Musical Industries, Ltd., of England which the corporation owns to British interests for $10,220,000.

Several hundred exact reproductions of telegrams filed in Buffalo for New York destinations were delivered here yesterday by Western Union following the opening of the new Buffalo-to-New York facsimile system, which went into regular operation Thursday for night traffic between the two cities.

The pupils' strike at Public School 135, Brooklyn, is happily over. The children are happy because they had enjoyed two extra holidays; the parents are elated because they had made the City Superintendent of Schools admit that "there was some justice in their complaints."

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Nov. 16. -- The ominous lull continues in Shanghai, where tension increases the longer Japan defers presenting formal demands in connection with the slaying of a Japanese marine a week ago and other anti-Japanese incidents.

While the November grand jury was indicting Miss Vera Stretz for first-degree murder yesterday for the shooting of Dr. Fritz C. Gebhardt and while the funeral of the murdered German financier was being held with semi-military honors bestowed by the New York Chapter of the German League, detectives announced new evidence which they assert proves conclusively the State's "other woman motive" against Miss Stretz.

I read recently of a commission of inquiry which proposes critically to inspect the present educational system in the schools of this State with the purpose of discovering how existing faults may be remedied.

A request that persons who were eligible for home reilef prior to Nov. 1 shall be considered eligible for placement on the Federal Theatre project without going through the Home Relief Bureau, if they are otherwise qualified, has been submitted to Harry L. Hopkins, the WPA Administrator, by Elmer Rice, regional director of the WPA theatre projects in New York.

In a report for the nine months and twelve months ended on Sept. 30, the General Telephone Corporation announced yesterday that the exercise of purchase rights by former holders of Associated Telephone Utilities Company preferred stock had resulted in the sale of 73,513 shares of preferred stock and 73,513 additional shares of common stock of the General Telephone Corporation.

The American Founders Corporation will offer at auction at 11 A.M. on next Wednesday through Howard L. Wolbert, auctioneer, at 1 Exchange Place, Jersey City, its entire holdings of 901,411 $1-par common shares of the United States Electric Power Corporation.

Secretary HULL repeated yesterday his warning to American exporters. They will do business with Italy, he said once more, at their own risk. That they understand perfectly and have been, as Secretary HULL reports that the Government has ascertained, doing a larger business than ever with Italy.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by 124 municipalities amounts to $21,070,057. This compares with a revised total of $43,892,840 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $26,088,265.

The main ballroom of the RitzCarlton was the setting last night for the first of the Friday sembUes of this season. The series of dances, for young married couples. recent dbutantes and single men. was organized in December, 1926, and the first dance was given the following November.

By proclamation of the President, the new Philippine Commonwealth has come into existence. It is a half-way house to freedom The islands are to have their own Constitution and their own Government, already duly ratified and chosen. But for ten years -- the lifetime of the Commonwealth -- certainties to the United States remain.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Light receipts of hogs and the highest prices for fresh pork wins in November in six years resulted today in advances of 15 to 30 cents a hundredweight in the prices of hogs at the stock yards. The top price of $11.95, including the processing tax of $2.25 a 100 pounds, was the highest in a November since 1926 and was 25 cents above yesterday's best figure.

Returned to Washington after communion with selected Idahoans and other progressive citizens of the West, Mr. BORAH confided to the newspapers his unremitting trust in the people. Whom do the Republican people want for President? The people's choice should be determined by the people in the people's Presidential primary.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- With returns from 600 out of 615 Parliamentary constituencies received, the Baldwin government was returned to power for five years with a clear majority in the House of Commons of 244 seats and with a majority more than 1,000,000 in yesterday's election.

Philip J. Roosevelt yesterday was elected president of the North American Yacht Racing Union, the rule body of sail racing in this country and Canada. His elevation to that office was at the annual meeting of the union, held in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, preceding a dinner.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange today reflected satisfaction over the results of the general election. The opening was strong and buying developed in all departments, with British funds prominent. While some reaction occurred in the afternoon owing to the influences for end of the account, the undertone remained very firm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP). -- A leather-cushioned chair in the centre of the Supreme Court bench was conspicuously vacant today while a middle-aged, frequently smiling attorney was showered with questions by the remaining eight justices.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- Bids were opened at the Army Quarter-master's Depot here today on proposals for 30,000 mechanics' caps, Type A-1, and 110,000 pairs of olive drab fifty-four-inch cotton tubular laces for breeches for the army, and for 225,000 towels for the army medical department.

As a means of raising money to help defray the expenses of the American Artist Congress scheduled to be held in New York this Winter, an exhibition of prints by nearly 100 artists is being held at the A.C.A. Gallery, 52 West Eighth Street.

More than 2,000 members of the Protestant Teachers Association will attend their annual luncheon today in the Hotel Astor. The principal speaker will be the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman of Brooklyn and his theme will be "The World at the Crossroads."

The 150th anniversary of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, at Barclay and Church Streets, the mother church of that faith in New York State and Eastern New Jersey, will be celebrated next week, beginning tomorrow. The occasion also is the golden jubilee of the consecration of the present edifice, which itself is ninety-nine years old.
Real estate activity centres in uptown Manhattan yesterday when brokers announced deals in the Harlem, Washington Heights and Dyckman sections.

The first major consolidation in the railway equipment manufacturing field since the depression is under discussion, it was disclosed yesterday by C.J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry Company. The proposal would unite the Ryan Car Company, the Mount Vernon Car and Manufacturing Company and the Bettendorf Company with Mr. Hardy's organization.

Mixed conditions prevailed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Some of the advances of the preceding day were lost but the price changes as a rule were minor and the volume small. On the cash markets all the grains, cotton, lard and silk advanced, while tin and rubber eased.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 15. -- Dartmouth faces its old football nemesis, Cornell, tomorrow in a game which has Green supporters on edge. Cornell has taken three straight as the underdog.

New bond financing this week amounted to $41,416,390, compared with $37,950,000 last week and with $14,881,000 a year ago. Only two major classifications were represented. Activities were somewhat curtailed by the holiday on Monday.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 15. -- While the Ethiopian Government issued official answers to the points contained in the Italian note to powers applying sanctions, Emperor Haile Selassie, in a special interview with the writer, gave his own reactions to the note.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- George Munro, well-known London newspaper man, scored a real success at the Embassy Theatre tonight with his play "Murder Gang," written in collaboration with Basil Dean, who would have produced it himself except for his increasing film activities lately.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Investment of the capital and premium funds of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has netted the corporation a sum sufficient to meet its deposit liability in closed banks, and has permitted the application of the full amount of the premium fund to the payment of insurance premiums by the banks under the new law, it was made known today.

PEIPING, Saturday, Nov. 16. -- Although travelers from northeastern points confirm the reported concentration of Japanese troops at Shanhaikwan, where they have occupied railway waiting rooms as barracks, Colonel Tan Takahashi, Japanese military attach here, disclaims any of the knowledge of the movement, saying that "that is an affair of the Kwantung army headquarters" and that the Japanese Army is always more or less on the move.

Support of the New York City free port movement, opposition to the St. Lawrence waterway project and criticism of preferential rail rates granted to New Orleans were voiced yesterday by two speakers at the Maritime Exhibition in the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- A sharp warning to American exporters against dealing in war supplies with Italy was issued by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today, with the approval of President Roosevelt, in a statement prompted by governmental reports which show a considerable increase in this business in October.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Dr. Clinton J. Davisson of the Bell Telephone Laboratories in New York was named today as recipient of the Hughes medal of the Royal Society for his discovery of the physical existence of electron waves. The discovery came after long researches on the reflection of electrons from crystal planes of nickel and other metals.

The Appellate Division announced yesterday the punishment of attorneys accused of unethical practices. The court disbarred Joseph A. Fontinelli, Jacob Grudberg, Bernard Kushner, Harry Rapport and former State Senator Michael E. Reiburn, formerly Michael E. Reitzenberg.

The most successful football season in Manhattan College history will come to a close at Ebbets Field this afternoon when the improved Jasper eleven meets a formidable Georgetown team in the third game of a series inaugurated in 1933. A crowd of 20,000 is expected to witness the contest, which will get under way at 2 o'clock.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 15. -- Maintaining a pace almost as fast as his 70 of the first day, a mark unequaled in the two days, Orville White of Overland, Ohio, today captured first money in the thirty-six-hole golf tournament which featured the mid-November professional party here.

A banking syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $4,643,000 city of Detroit, Mich., water refunding bonds. The group paid 100.011 for the 1936 to 1945 maturities as 3 1/4s, the 1946 to 1950 maturities as 3s, and the 1951 to 1956 maturities as 3 1/4s, thus taking $3,693,000 of the issue as 3 1/4s and $950,000 as 3s.
The money market was uneventful so far as rates for credit and business were concerned. Levels were maintained on a light turnover.

MAKALE, Ethiopia, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Italian pilots believed today they had bombarded yesterday Ras Seyoum, Ethiopian Governor of Tigre Province, with several hundred of his men in a triangular region marked by the Villages of Antalo, Afgol and Buia.
Directors of the Pennsylvania Water and Power Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1 on the common stock, against a previous quarterly rate of 75 cents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Officials here doubt that the Chino-Japanese difficulties in North China will develop to the point of war. Contrary to fears expressed in China, experts here do not look for fighting.

WALTER BAGEHOT thanked GOD that Englishmen were not logical as the French are. But sometimes they are at least guided by the logic of the situation if not of reasoning. That was distinctly the case in the general election on Thursday. Under the guise of seeking a national mandate, Prime Minister BALDWIN so arranged things that be held his opponents in a cleft stick.

The action of John D. Rockefeller Jr. in publicly announcing that he would no longer make regular annual gifts to the Northern Baptist Convention's unified budget, was received yesterday by Baptist leaders with regret, although they said it was not unexpected.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The Suez Canal's 100-mile channel has been deepened to accommodate vessels with a draft of thirty-four feet, as against thirty-three feet heretofore, the canal company announced today. The entire length of the canal channel has been deepened one foot.
Army and Notre Dame meet at the Yankee Stadium today before the Eastern season's record gathering of 80,000 and in an atmosphere of prosperity putting any lingering spectre of depression to rout.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Employment in the work-relief program was 2,009,339 on Nov. 9, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, announced today. This figure is almost 300,000 greater than on the preceding Saturday, and unofficial estimates of progress during the current week bring the total now employed to more than 2,500,000 persons, a million behind the administration's goal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- An open breach between the Association of American Railroads and the Interstate Commerce Commission over the latter's public investigation of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, now in trusteeship, was in prospect today as J.J. Pelley, president of the association, termed the inquiry "ridiculous'' and "shocking."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Senator Borah called about thirty-five reporters to his office this afternoon and, while he refused to admit his candidacy for the Presidency, left little doubt that he would seek the nomination.

[ MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 15.-I Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Carnpaigne gave a reception this afternoon at i their home here to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Constance Campaigne, and to celebrate I their twenty-r/fth wedding anniversary.

New York University's undefeated and untied football team meets a traditional rival this afternoon in the encounter with Rutgers at Ohio Field. The contest will be the thirty-third between the two elevens in a series which dates back to 1890. With the series even, both having won fifteen times and two engagements ending in ties, a capacity crowd of 15,000 is expected to witness the opening kick-off, which is scheduled for 2 o'clock.
PARIS, Nov. 15. -- The old distillery in which the Carthusian monks used to make their famous Chartreuse was destroyed early today by an avalanche unprecedented in the district.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP). -- A Kansas City business woman told the Federal Trade Commission today how she had acted as a rival company's spy in the offices of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company.

WINDSOR, Ont., Nov. 15 (AP). -- Announcement that consideration would be given to the placing of the common stock on a dividend basis early in 1936 was made by W.J. Hume, president of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Wortz to shareholders at the annual meeting here today.

The State began submitting preliminary testimony yesterday through two witnesses in the General Sessions trial of three officers of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company on accusations that they violated the insurance law on Jan. 13, 1933, by publishing a false statement on the company's financial status.

Whistler led all other artists in demand last night when British portraits, Barbizon and other landscapes from the collection of the late William H. Sage were offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Flying over much of the trail he covered in 1931 with the late Will Rogers as passenger, Lieut. Commander Frank Hawks has thus far met a combination of warm welcomes and cold and hazardous flying weather on his air tour in behalf of the Will Rogers Memorial Fund Commission, it was said yesterday at the headquarters of the commission at 570 Lexington Avenue.

GENEVA, Nov. 15. -- Great Britain has informed the League of Nations that after midnight Sunday it will allow no imports from Albania, Austria, Germany, Hungary or Switzerland unless they are accompanied by a certificate of origin to prove that they are not from Italy and therefore in violation of Sanction Three.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15. -- The Senate has given final approval to the Brazilian-American reciprocal trade treaty negotiated in Washington last February. The delay in ratification here was due to a campaign organized by Brazilian industrial interests, which assailed the pact in the press and through a Congressional lobby.
I am taking the liberty of submitting for the kind consideration of the members of the League of Nations, of its honorable secretary, and of all its wellwishers, the following questions:

PARIS, Nov. 15. -- Henry Berenger, former Ambassador to the United States, laid the responsibility for cessation of all debt payments flatly on former President Hoover yesterday in an address before the American Club of Paris.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The filing of a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 by Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its wholly owned subsidiary, Hiram Walker Sons Distilleries, Inc., for the issuance of $8,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/4 per cent convertible debentures due on Dec. 1, 1945, and 164,140 shares of no-par value common stock of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- Pennsylvania today enjoyed the rest cure on the eve of its thirty-fourth annual game with Penn State, only the backs reporting to Coach Harvey Harman at the training house for instructions. Penn leads in the series with twenty-two victories to eight defeats and three ties.

WESTCHESTER, Pa., Nov. 15. -- A decision to summon an "amateur detective" before the Chester County grand jury, which is investigating the fatal shooting of Evelyn Hoey, former musical comedy actress, delayed the final presentment in the case today.

Formation of a nation-wide third party in 1940, if not in 1936, was predicted last night by Governor Floyd B. Olson of Minnesota. The Farmer-Labor Executive spoke to about 1,500 persons at the first public meeting of the Commonwealth Federation of New York, which was organized recently to try to bring about the combination of radical groups to form a third party.

I would like to take issue with Clarence K. Streit when he declares in THE TIMES of Nov. 10 that "the League has no legal authority to force any member to enforce the covenant," and that "there are no sanctions in Article XVI for those who refuse to apply sanctions."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 15. -- The Little Three championship will be at stake tomorrow when Williams and Amherst clash before a record crowd of 11,000 at Weston Field in their fifty-second game. Each already has gained a one-sided victory over Wesleyan, the third member of the triumvirate.
Three seeded players emerged victorious in the opening round of the amateur squash racquets open tournament on the New York A.C. courts last night.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 15. -- Mrs. Susan Tilton Alexander, 27 years old, of Bernardsville, N.J., whose marriage to Archibald Stevens Alexander, a lawyer, was one of the events of the New York social season of 1929, killed herself here today by jumping in front of a train.

The Harvard Club yesterday won its third straight match in the Metropolitan League's Class B squash tennis tournament, to remain at the top of the standing with a clean slate. The Crimson players invaded the New York A.C. courts to triumph by 5 -- 0.

As our nation once more dedicates itself to peace, with the hallowed memories of our soldier-dead brought to our minds at Armistice Day, and because I had the honor of being a former chaplain of the 168th Infantry of Iowa, Rainbow Division, may I state my feelings about the memorial statue to the Forty-second Divisional chaplain, the Hey. Francis P. Duffy?

Let this November morning solemnly salute the double negative. For the first time in more than a month "Jumbo" has not been postponed. Unless something frenzied happens between this hour and 8:30 tonight, it will open at the Hippodrome, loosing upon the Sixth Avenue world Jimmy Durante, Arthur Sinclair, Paul Whiteman and Rosie, the elephant.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15. -- Yale and Lafayette will meet tomorrow in the Bowl in their third football game in football history. Yale won the first game in 1912 by 16 -- 0, and the second, 28 -- 0, in 1913.
Renovation of Madison Avenue between Fifty-ninth and Eighty-second Streets is being held up by the dilatory policies of the Works Progress Administration, it was said yesterday.
A national survey of social conditions resulting from existing methods of liquor control will be started shortly by the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators.

Coincidental with the Postoffice Department's appeal for early Christmas mailing. Harllee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General, announced the latest sailing dates from New York which will permit the delivery of mail in foreign countries before Christmas.

The construction of naval vessels using high pressure and superheated steam installations for propulsion machinery was criticized as an unwarranted expense in a paper submitted by Charles P. Wetherbee, consulting engineer, at the closing session yesterday of the annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.

The career of the late Henri Barbusse, French anti-war leader, was invoked as an example for American foes of war by speakers last night at an anti-war dinner arranged by the Henri Barbusse Memorial Committee. More than 600 persons at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue, heard an exposition of the dangers of war today and a call to organize to combat it.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printeloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15. -- A Harvard eleven only four members of which started against Princeton last week will meet New Hampshire tomorrow on Soldiers Field. The Durham squad will well match the Crimson for weight, but generally lacks the Crimson's power and defense, particularly in reserves.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 15. -- In eloquent phrases Governor Cross, who is editor of The Yale Review, issued a Thanksgiving Day proclamation today. It read as follows:
PARIS, Nov. 15. -- Following the action of the Bank of France yesterday in raising the discount rate to 4 per cent, the Bourse today recovered somewhat from yesterday's depressive tone.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP). -- The sale of assets to retire preferred stock of the McKinney Steel Holding Company, approved yesterday by stockholders, will give the defunct Union Trust Company of Cleveland about $2,835,000, Oscar L. Cox, liquidator, said today.

James Paul Mills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Denckla Mills of Radnor, Pa,, and this city, and Joseph Cornelius Rathborne, son of Mrs. J. Cornelius Rathborne of New York ad Westbury, L. I., gave a i combined bachelor dinner last night at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Sixto Escobar won the world's bantamweight championship last night. The doughty Puerto Rican battler pounded out a decisive victory over the courageous Lou Salica of Bath Beach at Madison Square Garden to gain the recognition of the New York State Athletic Commission and the National Boxing Association as the leading 118-pound fighter in the world.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 15. -- The Columbia and Navy elevens, which meet at Thompson Stadium tomorrow in the last home game of the local team, both practiced here today. The Lions drilled for an hour and then returned to Baltimore, where they are staying overnight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15. -- The Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in semi-annual conference here, endorsed today the proposed merger of the three Methodist denominations and the creation of the largest Protestant church in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The committee named by the Investment Bankers Conference Committee to maintain contact with the Securities and Exchange Commission held its first meeting today with the full membership of the commission to exchange points of view on problems of the over-the-counter markets and on the speeding up of plans for getting into action the nation-wide organization that the bankers plan to establish to cooperate with the SEC.
BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Two events of importance in framing the future of this new Third Reich occurred today.

Amelia Earhart, associate director of the operations committee of the Will Rogers Memorial Commission, telegraphed yesterday from Lafayette, Ind., to Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, operations head, that never, despite all her flying, had she been more frightened than when she had to speak before an audience that included the late Will Rogers.

A sharp reduction in limits of automobile liability insurance was urged yesterday at the annual meeting in the Hotel New Yorker of the Casualty Actuarial Society by Winfield W. Greene, president of the society. Mr. Greene, who is also vice president and secretary of the General Reinsurance Corporation, said cheaper insurance would mean a greater number of insured drivers.

Transient relief will continue beyond next Monday through the use of $375,000 given to the city by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch told a delegation of unemployed at City Hall yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The statements of President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull, for the United States, and of Prime Minister Mackenzie King, for Canada, at the signing of the trade agreement between the two countries, were as follows:

Those who were fortunate enough to hear Arthur Loesser's interpretation of Schumann's "Kreisleriana," at his piano recital in the Town Hall last night, listened to a truly distinguished reading of the eight sketches of that opus. The artist was in top form, here, and fully merited the big hand he received from a crowded house for his exceptionally vivid exposition of the work's romantic content.

Action by food manufacturers throughout the country to resist "unjustified attacks" charging profiteering in the industry in view of steadily rising production costs, was urged by Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at a luncheon here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco crushed Jay Bozeman, Vallejo, Calif., youngster, 50 to 20, tonight for his sixth straight victory in the world three-cushion billiard championship tournament. The San Francisco wizard needed only 33 innings in which to subdue Bozeman.

Oscar Spitalnick, president of the Federation of Kosher Butchers, announced yesterday that 40 per cent of the federation's 5,000 shops had closed during the day in a protest against the high cost of meat.

BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- The opening session of the fourteenth annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England, one of the most famous single breed fixtures in the East, was staged at Horticultural Hall today, with most of the interest being centred on the judging of the $1,000 Big Four Novice Stake.

Scholastic football's premier event, the Andover-Exeter game, tops today's big schedule, which calls for widespread activity on various fronts. Important games are listed in virtually every section of the East, but overshadowing all insofar as tradition is concerned is the fifty-sixth gridiron clash between the academies at Exeter, N.H.
ALBANY, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, Works Progress Administrator, today turned down a demand by organized labor for union wages on WPA projects up-State.
ATHENS, Ohio, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Dr. Herman G. James became Ohio University's twelfth president today in inaugural ceremonies before many educators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The reciprocal trade treaty between the United States and Canada, aiming to restore by mutual tariff concessions the commerce between the two countries, which exceeded $1,000,000,000 in pre-depression years, was signed just before 4 o'clock this afternoon by Secretary Hull on behalf of this government and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King, representing His Majesty King George V, for the Dominion of Canada.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Ramsay MacDonald, former Laborite Prime Minister and now National Labor Lord President of the Council, was swept out of Parliament yesterday by a tidal wave of anger among the pinched and undernourished coal miners of Durham.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15. -- Jean Batten, the 25-year-old New Zealand flier who set a speed record in crossing the South Atlantic Wednesday, but was reported lost yesterday while flying toward Rio de Janeiro from Natal, was found this morning after she had made a forced landing in a swamp.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- After a protracted decline which reduced the stock index below what it was a year ago, Boerse quotations have staged a strong recovery in which gains of one to two points are frequent.

Colder weather spurred retail trade toward the end of the week. However, in view of the comparatively poor showing earlier, with the exception of Armistice Day, department store executives were doubtful that sales figures for the week would run ahead of those for the same period of 1934.

The basic principles which retailers should stress in the drafting of State unemployment insurance legislation in those forty States which have not passed laws to conform with the Federal Social Security Act were outlined yesterday by the unemployment insurance committee of the store management group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in a detailed comparative analysis of State legislation which has already been enacted.
LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The new House of Commons will have only nine women members, compared with fifteen in the last Parliament.

A new system of dealing with parking violators, in which "casual" parkers will be let off with $1 fines while "habitual" ones will receive heavy penalties, was begun yesterday by Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., chief city magistrate.

The steam oil lighter Florence was lying submerged at Pier 43, North River, below the foot of Christopher Street yesterday while salvage officials of the McAllister Towing Company were endeavoring to get slings under her keel and lift her to the surface.

A long list of foreclosure sales in Manhattan kept auctioneers busy yesterday. The schedule included forced sales of a tall loft building on Eighth Avenue and an eleven- story structure at Broadway and Twelfth Street.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Princeton's undefeated and untied football team is a decided favorite to win its seventh victory of the season against Lehigh in Palmer Stadium tomorrow. The contest will be the thirty-seventh between the two ancient rivals.

CHELSEA, Mass., Nov. 15. -- Labor's first organized attempt to standardize wages in New England's shoe industry will be made tomorrow when officials of the United Shoe and Leather Workers Union meet here.

W.B. Quaintance Co., a textile import firm which has been in 440 Fourth Avenue for twenty years, will move on Dec. 1 to 240 Madison Avenue, where the eleventh floor has been leased. The firm was established forty years ago. The Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation arranged the rental.

Strange is the case of Dr. PETER KAPITZA, until a year ago engaged in the Mond Laboratory, Cambridge, in studying physical phenomena at temperatures approaching absolute zero. He returns to his native Russia for a holiday, only to find that he cannot return to England.
Harold Samuel, pianist, will give an all-Bach program tonight at the Washington Irving High School.

Answering criticisms of its $2.25 a week food budget for a single woman, the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor exhibited yesterday a sample of the food purchased for that amount, and prepared another family food budget of $8.76 for a week, or $1.75 per person for a family of five.

James D. Mooney, vice president of the General Motors Corporation in charge of overseas operations, said yesterday on his return from Europe that European nations were using loopholes in the regulations of the League of Nations to provide Italy with goods and that this and other conditions would keep the economic sanctions from being effective instruments.

After spending the past two Saturday afternoons in combat with powerful intersectional foes, the Fordham football team will meet a less formidable but highly regarded eleven at the Polo Grounds today. The Maroon will line up against Muhlenberg for the opening kickoff at 2 P.M.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exch2nge market, i based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, com-[ pares as follows. Quotations are[ in cents:

Strict adherence to the Monroe Doctrine as a vital point in the country's future foreign policy was urged last night by Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, former Ambassador to Turkey and Argentina and American member of the Olympics Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Demands that the administration clarify its intentions in the housing program were filed today by two unrelated groups in widely different ways, but with the one object of gaining for builders and property owners an elucidation of official policy.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
A Brooklyn usurer was sent to the penitentiary yesterday, three were convicted in Manhattan and another accused on similar charges was returned to Elmira Reformatory as a parole violator.

The eleventh annual Thanksgiving Day parade of R.H. Macy Co., to be held Nov. 28, will be "bigger and better than ever," with many floats, numerous huge balloons and marchers who will portray Pilgrim scenes, according to plans released yesterday.

Nobel Prizes are getting to be routine with the CURIES. Between them PIERRE and MARIE CURIE discovered radium and received the Nobel Prize for physics in 1903. MARIE CURIE on her own account won the prize in chemistry eight years later.

Establishment of any industrial control legislation by Congress would be inadvisable, as it would produce less satisfactory results than those now obtaining, Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, former head of the Foreign and Domestic Commerce Bureau of the Department of Commerce, declared yesterday, in entering into the duties if his position as president of the Cotton Textile Institute.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it had rejected bids recently submitted for the construction of the Weehawken land sections and plaza of the new Midtown Hudson Tunnel because they were greatly in excess of estimates prepared by its engineers.

Another sharp advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried December contracts to within 3 points of the 12-cent level for the first time since the middle of July. After a slight setback in the morning as the market digested hedge and profit-taking selling, prices moved upward nearly a dollar a bale to end at net gains of 6 to 13 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP). -- A pitched battle before the Supreme Court over the constitutionality of a series of New Deal laws seemed likely today to be set for December, with final decisions in January.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Harold Nicolson, biographer of Dwight W. Morrow and an expert in history and the practice of diplomacy, scored an unexpected election victory yesterday, being elected to Parliament from West Leicester. It was his second venture into party politics.

ROME, Nov. 15. -- The results of the British elections surprised the people here for the extent of the Conservative victory, which has been greater than most Italians expected. The support given to the Baldwin Cabinet is accepted, however, with complete equanimity because the Italians knew that both the Conservative and Labor parties were committed to sanctions and to upholding the League of Nations and might be expected to follow identical policies toward Italy.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15. -- Direct air mail service from San Francisco and other California cities to Mexico was halted suddenly tonight.

When James Friskin gives a piano recital, the audience may expect music eminently worth the performance and interpretations of this music which are always those of a substantially equipped pianist and a high-minded interpreter. Yesterday afternoon Mr. Friskin played a program at the Town Hall that was distinguished in every item offered the public.

AT the very heart of Ethiopia, not only geographically but emotionally as well, lives Haile Selassie I, the Lord King of Kings, Conquering Lion of Judah and bearer of other titles now familiar to the Western World.

Glancing at an article in The Quarterly Review on the books read by the Victorians, one is reminded again of those compartments of sentimentality and comedy peculiarly characteristic of the Victorian Age. It was a time of hearty laughers and as hearty weepers. "Tears flowed for the flimsiest reasons," says the Q.R. man, Mr. MORRIS DOWNING.

BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- Proposal of a plan to prevent threatened liquidation of the great Amoskeag cotton textile mills at Manchester, N.H., advanced this week by a special textile committee appointed on Aug. 9 by Governor Bridges of New Hampshire, turns the spotlight on basic conditions within the industry as a whole which are matters of grave concern for all New England.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- Department store trade showed a good gain over the preceding week and over the like week of 1934. Factors in the upturn were a better demand for cold weather apparel, particularly cheap fur coats, which were sold at clearance prices because of the mild Autumn, and a heavily advertised feature sale of a large department store as the week ended.

Dr. George W. Crile, surgeon and nerve specialist of Cleveland, sailed yesterday on the French liner Ile de France on his way to British East Africa, accompanied by Mrs. Crile. He will go first to Paris and then to London, from whence he will fly with Mrs. Crile to Nairobi to join Dr. Daniel P. Quiring of Western Reserve University and Arthur B. Fuller of the Cleveland Museum.

Samuel H. Kaufman, special assistant to the Attorney General prosecuting naturalization frauds, announced yesterday his resignation from the Federal service. He is a law partner of Representative Emanuel Celler.
