The constitutionality of that section of the Mortgage Commission Act which empowers the State commission to reorganize certificated mortgages if not more than one-third of the holders, after notice, dissent, was upheld in a decision yesterday by Justice Albert M. Cohn of the Supreme Court.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Nov. 16 (AP). -- Outrunning two other entries over a four-mile timber course today, Indigo from the Northwood Stables won the Dinwiddie, featured event of the Middleburg Racing Association's Fall meet, in 8:10 3-5.

Reports on general business conditions last week in most sections of the country were more optimistic in tone. Although the absence of seasonable temperatures continued to retard retail buying in some districts, in others where colder weather prevailed there was a steady expansion in sales activity.

A NEW type of all-steel automobile body assembled from four major units without the use of flashwelding has been developed by the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company of Philadelphia, it is reported. Described as the "Mono Roof Body," it is designed to reduce the cost of shipping, assembling and finishing, to effect a substantial saving in weight and to provide accuracy of dimensions.

Another hockey opener will be staged at Madison Square Garden tonight, when the New York Americans start their home season against the Canadiens of Montreal. Because of the optimistic reports that have seeped into New York concerning the strength of the Americans it is quite likely that a crowd as large as the gathering of 15,000 persons that saw the Rangers open their local stand will be on hand for the battle.
Gleanings from notebook and mailbag:

Miss Ratzesberger's story successfully conveys the atmosphere of modern Baghdad, with its mingling of the ancient and the new, but it also proves again that boys are much the same, whether they are playing on the banks of the Mississippi or the Tigris.

The Rev. Raymond E. Brock, for more than three years rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Riverdale Avenue and 252d Street, the Bronx, has submitted his resignation effective next June, it was disclosed yesterday.

GARDENERS who have finished their Fall planting or who are for the moment "caught up" have been taking advantage of the recent mild open weather to prepare beds, borders and plots for next Spring's sowing and planting.

On the basis of a sample cross-section check of the 1,600 local committee organizations of the Will Rogers Memorial Fund, more than 5,000,000 admirers of the cowboy humorist will contribute toward his memorial, Owen D. Young predicted yesterday at a meeting of the fund's operations committee, of which he is chairman.

ROYAL CHRISTENING: Next Wednesday the infant son of the Duke and Duchess of Kent will be christened in the private chapel of Buckingham Palace. The Archbishop of Canterbury will perform the ceremony, using water from the River Jordan and a golden fount that served at the christening of the Princess Royal, eldest daughter of Queen Victoria.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 16 (AP). -Ollie Adelman, a Milwaukee boy with swivel hips and perpetual-motion legs, escaped from the Northwestern bench today to stage an unforgetable running exhibition that gave the Wildcats a 32-to-13 triumph over Wisconsin.

Dr. Thomas Clark Chalmers was widely known as a specialist in internal medicine. He was born in New York City Jan. 3, 1868, and was licensed in 1899. He received the early part of his medical education at Bellevue Hospital Medical College and served his internship at the Blackwells Island Hospital.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 (AP). -Tulane swept to a 20-13 victory over Kentucky today behind the rifle-like passing of Troy Odom.

The Midamerica Corporation, the new holding company formed by the Van Sweringen group, has an important interest in any litigation which may be started as a result of a decision issued last week by the Federal court in St. Louis, according to counsel who have studied the situation.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- Serious and apparently unforeseen reactions to the Jewish regulations promulgated yesterday have already developed. The entire diplomatic corps is seething today about the new regulations and individual protests and possibly even a joint representation by the embassies and legations, are foreshadowed.

WHAT with Billy Rose now in command of the Hippodrome, it seems not entirely outside reason that next Spring will see Hassard Short heaving the wrestlers out of Madison Square Garden. For Mr. Short has designs for an American production of "Wild Violets," which requires, among other things, a vast ice rink.

Like the deep-throated roar of a mighty cataract, rumbling cheers of glee and dismay split the cold November air yesterday as the East's largest football crowd of the season watched Notre Dame's astounding last minute rally. Perched high above the huge gathering of 80,000 were a thousand more on the neighboring housetops, cheering, too, like an answering echo.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- The first real activity in several weeks in stock trading on the Bourse took place today, although the spurt did not extend to rentes and fixed-interest securities. The latter securities were irregular and heavy toward the closing of the session, indicating that financial circles are not yet fully convinced of the lasting of the truce in internal political conflict.

HANNIBAL, Mo., Nov. 16 (AP). -- Richard Reed, 14, of Bloomington, Ind., was announced today the winner of a nation-wide literary contest held in connection with the centennial celebration of the birth of Mark Twain.

IN this book on Byron, Shelley and Keats, Frances Winwar is less concerned with the romanticism and the rebellion in their poetry, on which perhaps too much stress is generally laid, than she is concerned with the rebellion and the romance in their lives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- While the President's key men, headed by the Secretary of the Treasury, were working busily in Washington under Mr. Roosevelt's direction to try to reduce by $500,000,000 or more the Federal budget, the American Bankers Association at New Orleans, which has been demanding an economy effort of this sort, reverted to its critical attitude toward the New Deal.

EVIDENCE that the public is settling back to normal enjoyment of life after the forced gayety of the depression is provided by travel agents, who report, with the approach of the Winter season, that "whoopee" cruises and voyages "to nowhere" are going out of style.

LYING in a French hospital during the Winter of 1924-25, half delirious from the fever and agony of a gangrenous foot, Walter Duranty resolved that "if I do get back I shall do as I please and think as I please and write as I please, without fear or favor."

If those who are now writing and talking about an amendment to the Constitution taking from the Supreme Court its supposed power to invalidate an act of Congress will read Article 3, Section 2, of the Constitution, they will get some much needed enlightenment.

The grand jury investigation of the murder of Sam Druckman will be resumed in Brooklyn tomorrow. It was predicted in the office of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan that indictments would be returned by mid-week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- WPA will have to supply almost all of the additional 1,000,000 jobs which must be provided between now and Dec. 1, or in two weeks, if the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program is to reach its goal of 3,500,000 employes by that date.

The Associate Alumni of City College, holding their fifty-fifth annual dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt last night, honored six alumni of the college for their achievements and for their service to the college.

HERE is a book about the Winter woods and all the little creatures who frequent its white silences that is almost breath-taking in its sheer loveliness. Moreover, the reader has the feeling that a hasty movement may send these chipmunks, squirrels and rabbits flying out of sight, across the soft snow, with such life-likeness has

ALOIS HAVRILLA, announcer, awarded the 1935 medal for good diction on the radio by the American Academy of Arts and Letters, could not speak a word of English until after he was 5 years old, according to the Havrilla family statistics.

ALBUQUERQUE N.M., Nov. 14. -- While enjoying the abundant life in most respects New Mexico is experiencing a unique scarcity. For payment of its sales tax the State issued fractional coins so like the Federal coinage that they appealed to tourists as curiosities.

The 1935 season of the Jaspers came to an unsuccessful close yesterday as an alert, hard-hitting group of youngsters in Georgetown's Blue and Gray, obviously relishing their role of under dogs, sent Chick Meehan's Manhattan team to stunning defeat.

AUSTIN, Texas. -- Pursuant to the approval of an amendment to the Texas Constitution last August, authorizing the State to pay old-age pensions, the Legislature after nearly two months of debate has approved a measure designed to assist the aged indigent.

Single-handed, a Scotland Yard detective undertakes to expose and break up a powerful criminal organization called the Knockers. It proves to be quite a job, one which calls for all the daring and audacity that Inspector Zachary Callinder possesses.

THE O. Henry collection is so much better these days than ever it used to be that it is now giving the O'Brien annual a run for its money. This year, moreover, all three of the usual prizes have gone to writers who really deserve them.

THIS is Arabian Nights entertainment about art dealers in general and one James Henry Duveen in particular. He is a gay raconteur, with a love of vigorous and surprising anecdote. As his name implies, Mr. Duveen is a member of the large and internationally known family of art dealers.

A style review, with manikins, will be the feature of the November meeting of the Woman's Club of Garden City, in the Casino tomorrow afternoon. In connection with the promenade of Autumn modes, a discussion of body building and correct posture will be given.

John McLean, 28 years old, of 206 Bowery, was held in $1,000 bail on a forgery charge yesterday, after he had used a letter signed by a non-existent officer of THE NEW YORK TIMES and written on the stationery of this newspaper, in appealing for aid at two Brooklyn offices of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 16. -- Practically all of the gains in October in business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District are being continued in November.

SAY one thing for Hollywood: when a studio spends $2,000,000 on a film, you can see where the money went. On those occasions when a fabulous budget is fortified by genuine skill and imagination, Hollywood can silence her critics with a picture like "Mutiny on the Bounty," which is playing to tumultuous crowds at the Capitol Theatre.

HONOLULU. -- Chartered by the Territory a group of business executives has formed the Industrial Association of Hawaii as a counter-influence against the activities of a communistic element among dock workers here.

BIBLIOGRAPHY is not likely to be exciting reading. But the history of our national anthem as treated by Joseph Muller, "the Sage of Closter," N.J., in his first book, "The Star-Spangled Banner," is so exceptional in its lively handling of its subject that the reader is carried along to the final pages of the dissertation on a high tide of interest.

HENRY ADAMS, writing of English society of the latter nineteenth century, called it "eccentric by law and for the sake of eccentricity itself." No book could more shrewdly or charmingly illustrate his point than the present novel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- It costs from $30 to many thousands of dollars to hear the Supreme Court say "No." But litigants figuratively stand in line to hear it year after year.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 16. -- With a complete display of mastery, Colgate's dashing Red Raiders toppled a hitherto unbeaten Syracuse eleven from the ranks of the mighty today, trampling all over their old rivals to win by 27 to 0 with a relentless, devastating offense.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16. -- Nebraska and Pittsburgh continued their tradition of thrilling football struggles at Pitt Stadium today, the Panthers winning, 6-0, as the fighting Cornhuskers sought vainly for their first triumph over Pitt since 1921.
This year, as part of the School Art League program, Hunter College classes in Play Production and Dramatic Interpretation will give a half dozen performances of "Costume and the Actor."

" Collective Responsibility for Peace" is the subject of the two regional conferences held each year in New Jersey by a group of fourteen cooperating organizations under the leadership of the local Committee on the Cause and Cure of War.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The continued split among factions of the Colgate University students still exists today, although during the week an attempt was made to pass a compromise plan which would allow each faction to be properly represented and enable each to elect men to offices.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- German exports, which have risen steadily ever since the 1,000,000,000-mark export subsidy scheme became effective last June, reached another high for the year during October and pulled the German trade balance out of the red for the first ten months of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Headed by George W. Wickersham and William D. Mitchell, former Attorneys General of the United States, a committee of lawyers met today at the request of the Supreme Court to formulate uniform trial rules for the Federal courts.

OTTAWA, Canada, Nov. 16. -- In connection with still more rigid and effective application of sanctions against Italy, provided for by an Order in-Council issued here today, special orders have been issued to Canadian customs officials to guard against the shipment of camouflaged Italian goods from the United States.

America's productive enterprises, including agriculture, went more than $26,000,000,000 into the red during the years 1930 to 1934 inclusive, according to a recent Department of Commerce report written by Robert R. Nathan, chief of the Income Section of the Division of Economic Research in the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Nov. 16. -- The new strategic situation of the Baltic region because of Russian and German naval rearmament is causing increasing anxiety in the smaller Baltic States. Military experts continue discussions of how Finland, Sweden, Estonia and Latvia would be able to protect their independence in a war between Germany and Russia.
Your correspondent H.I.H. asks what the employe is to get for the tax against his payroll in the "so-called social security plan."

THAT traveler is fortunate whose first glimpse of Istanbul is caught in the early morning. The buildings that stand out clear in the sunshine amaze and satisfy the senses by their beauty of line and light as much as they stir the imagination by their associations.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 . -- Tomorrow, Nov. 17, marks the second anniversary of the recognition of the Soviet Union by the United States -- which occasion probably gave rise to more optimistic predictions than any political event since the signing of the Versailles Treaty. Both countries will undoubtedly note the day with reserve.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 16 (AP). -- Crossbow II triumphed today in the $5,000 added Wannamoisett Handicap, at a mile and 70 yards for 2-year-olds at Narragansett Park.

VIENNA, Nov. 3, 1935. THERE ought to be a law against the production of Meyerbeer in any lyric theatre unable to muster at least half a dozen singers with something resembling the voice, the brio, the virtuosity, the amplitude and luxuriance of artifice that formerly lent operas like the "Huguenots" and the "Prophet" a considerable part of their justification and effect.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 15. -Publication this week of a set of Democratic resolutions, suppressed for nearly a month, calling upon the Wyoming Congressional delegation and State officers and commissions for a "purge of Federal recovery and State payrolls of persons unsympathetic and disloyal to the New Deal," caused a flurry in Wyoming politics, with accusations, explanations, denials, admissions and obvious alibis.

SHAKESPEARE'S imagery tells us of the "furniture of his mind," his characteristic habits of thought and observation, the range of his interests, his instinctive return to familiar experiences. It differentiates him from other dramatists, so that a carefully documented study of the imagery alone might decide the question of authorship in "Richard III," say, or "Pericles."

The wife and two widows of three former Presidents of the United States, Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, Mrs. William Howard Taft and Mrs. Herbert Hoover, will be the guests of honor at the Coral Jubilee Breakfast in celebration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Daughters of Ohio tomorrow at the Hotel St. Regis.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16. -- The government abolished the system of auctioning foreign exchange which has been in effect for two years. In the future the Central Bank will fix both the buying and selling rates for drafts in foreign currencies.

One of the features of the annual Miami Biltmore Fashion Show and supper dance on Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Centre will be a wedding scene in which young matrons, young women and debutantes will act as manikins.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 16. -A gathering of 4,000 shivering fans saw Holy Cross close its home season in a one-sided game against Bates winning, 79 to 0.

IN her stories of interesting personalities -- and she has never been occupied, except briefly, with anything else -- Colette has always been exquisitely delicate and sometimes subtle to a point not far removed from obscurity. But in her latest novel, impossible as it seems, she has created a refinement upon even her own ultra-microscopic technique.

HOLLYWOOD. THE recently enacted State income tax supposedly leveled at the huge salaries of the cinema has provoked considerable discussion throughout the land, far more, in fact, than it has within the industry. Seriously involving not more than two or three hundred people in a business employing 30,000, there is an understandable apathy toward the measure.

IN a satirical article, Reynaldo Hahn, French composer and critic, writing of the works by Saint-Saens being performed in Paris at the one-hundredth anniversary of the master's birth, asserts: "At last they play a bit of his music.

Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, and Miss Charlotte Carr, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, discussed plans yesterday for the creation of a board to study the problems of persons leaving WPA rolls to return to home relief.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -Variations in cosmic ray intensity, a subject of wide scientific interest, will be studied at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology this Winter with one of the seven new cosmic ray intensity meters which are to be used in a world-wide investigation of cosmic radiation under the auspices of the Carnegie Institute of Washington.

AFTER reading the English translation of this novel it is difficult to imagine upon what grounds it was awarded the Prix Goncourt in 1934. Did the French prize committee secretly glory in the fact that an ordinary, piggish, stocky, chubby-cheeked Breton draper was discovered, between 1924-18, to be a violent soldier -- a perfect daredevil of epic proportions?

MADRID, Nov. 16. -- General satisfaction is felt in Spain over modification of the Tangier international statute, just agreed upon in Paris. The Foreign Ministry indicated that Spain had agreed to a renewal of the statute until 1948 only after a number of "important advantages" had been obtained.

MRS. KING'S memoirs of her threescore and ten years of perpetual adventure in South Africa come from England sponsored by Field Marshal Viscount Allenby, friend of the author for half a century, and with Book Society and Book Guild recommendations.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 16. -- William Henry Harrison (Tippy) Dye, 142-pound reserve Ohio State quarterback, sloshed 50 yards through a broken and muddy field today to defeat Illinois, 6 to 0, and keep Ohio in the Big Ten title race. A crowd of 44,000 saw the game.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 16. -- Although Andover reeled off nine first downs to two for Exeter, the Blue's attack was checked at the crucial moments today and the alert home eleven, profiting by a fine break early in the second quarter, recorded a 7-to-0 victory in the fifty-sixth edition of this oldest prep school football rivalry.

ADRIAN STOKES has fallen in love with the ballet. His book, which has already had some success in England, is meant, he says, "to convey not so much my impression of ballet as the necessity of ballet for me, the supreme pleasure I gain from watching it," and to "indicate why at the present time one should be so liable to fall in love with ballet."

AS a basic step toward an improved individual guidance for school children, Wilkes-Barre, Pa., recently made a detailed observation of pupils' behavior. Cases studied were those that required special individual aid, such as delinquent pupils, those with academic difficulties and high school students who intended to enter college.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Elmira College students are enjoying an unusual Mark Twain exhibit which has been arranged in the college library by Dr. Dorothy Dondore, Professor of English.

The reorganization plan of the Davison Chemical Company, the Davison Realty Company and the Eastern Cotton Oil Company was finally and unconditionally confirmed by Judge Calvin Chestnut of the Maryland Federal Court yesterday, the reorganization committee announced.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- France's reply to the Italian warning on sanctions, which Premier Pierre Laval communicated to Ambassador Vittorio Cerruti tonight, declares the French Government will conform to the Geneva decisions.

EDUARDO ZAMACOIS, in "La antorcha apagada" ("The Extinguished Torch"), has produced a strange and powerful novel, and one that will arouse controversy. It may be maintained that on such a topic a novel should not have been written.
The text of former President Hoover's address last night before the Ohio Society of New York follows:

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- For a thousand years, ever since Charlemagne split up the empire of the Franks among his heirs, thereby creating the nations that later became France and Germany, European continental history has been more or less dominated by conflict between the two.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Politicians are speculating on the possibility of a contest between former President Hoover and Senator Borah over the Republican Presidential nomination and platform for 1936.

More than a hundred local leagues will be represented, it is anticipated, when the New York State League of Women Voters convenes at Albany on Wednesday for its sixteenth assembly. Mrs. Douglas M. Moffat, State chairman, will preside at the three-day session.

An unusual setting and pageant have been arranged for the Poetry Ball to be held Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many in social, artistic and literary activities are on committees for the event, which will benefit the Academy of American Poets.

THE observation has been made by travelers in Holland that the Dutch are more interested in improving the soil than they are in cultivating the plants. This comment might well be applied to good gardeners in any country, because it is the good gardener who spends his time and energy in building up his soil so that the plants naturally take good care of themselves.

NOW that the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra concerts are stimulating unusual interest in the little-known musical output of early composers in the realm of ensembles for smaller groups of instruments, It may be timely to call attention to the fact that the New York Public Library recently has issued a catalogue of the numerous works of the sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth centuries available in black line print on its shelves.

Elizabeth Mackinstry adds new luster to this oldest of fairy tales with her pictures in gorgeous colors and carefully patterned black-and-white. The jewels in the secret cave glow with Oriental richness; jovial genii, grinning broadly, build Aladdin's palace in a sapphire night, while the Fire-Bird and the Roc hover graciously on the outskirts, and in the background the Wicked Magician scowls in rage or leers in horrid triumph.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 15. -- An interesting chapter in industrial labor relations is being written in the courts of Ramsey County. In two pending cases organized employers are in court to force other members of this city's trucking industry to correct alleged grievances of their employes.
St. Francis College of Brooklyn, scoring one touchdown in each period, defeated the Wagner College eleven, 24 to 6, yesterday at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S.I., for its second victory of the season.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 15. -New indictments found this week in the Scottsboro case point to an early resumption of all the noise, bitterness, notoriety and expense that attended the earlier trials. Alabamians still are divided on the merits of the case, but of one mind in the wish to be rid of the thing for better or for worse.

DETROIT. ALTHOUGH automobile manufacturers express general enthusiasm for the current rate of sales, there is scarcely any doubt that they still remain to be convinced about the value of the Fall shows.

RECENT advices from Teheran, Iran, report that the Emperor, Rexa Shah Pahlevi, has at last assented to the proposal that women he allowed to unveil. They are not required to do so, but no hindrance may be placed in the way of those who wish to discard the age-old custom of their land.

Showings of Southern resort and cruise wear lines during the week evoked a response that exceeded that for the corresponding showings of last year by "a considerable margin," it was reported yesterday by Albert M. Post, executive director of the Fashion Originators Guild of America.

ROME, Nov. 16. -- News from Italian Somaliland today indicates that General Rodolfo Graziani has given up all thought of attacking Jijiga and Harar until he has thoroughly consolidated the positions conquered so far.
ROME, Nov. 15. -- The fatal date on which sanctions will be applied against Italy is only a few days off, and the whole country is in a fever of activity organizing to resist them.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- Addressing the council of the International Chamber of Commerce here yesterday, Commerce Minister Georges Bonnet spoke in cautious terms of France's decision to adopt a more liberal tariff policy.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16. -- The divisions of refining, marketing and production of the American Petroleum Institute elected twenty members each to their respective general committees this week as the institute terminated its sixteenth annual convention.

Several clergymen from Canada will preach in local pulpits today as part of a general exchange of some 200 pastors in the United States and its Northern neighbor arranged by the Committee on Relations with Canada of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Official figures showing precipitate declines since 1929 in virtually every category of American-Canadian commerce were scanned by observers today for hints on tariff trends in the new reciprocal trade agreement.
About 1,000 persons attended the laying of the cornerstone of the new $1,000,000 Tottenville High School at Yetman and Summit Avenues, Tottenville, S.I., yesterday afternoon.

THE perennial appeal of Chippendale derives partly from the manifold designs originated by the great English craftsman. His clever adaptations of foreign motifs to English use include Gothic patterns, Chinoiserie and "French taste" designs, and he made, of course, numerous interpretations of the native Georgian mode.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Mrs. Roosevelt today added another definition to those previously given "by request" at her press conferences.

DAVID WARK GRIFFITH has been described as the Columbus of the Cinema. Today he finds himself in much the same position as Columbus would be returning to the New World. There is one difference: Christopher would get a grand reception; David Wark is on the outside, looking in.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 16. -- President Lazaro Cardenas spent two hours this afternoon at the National Cattle Exhibition at San Jacinto, on the outskirts of this capital. He was accompanied by General Saturnino Cedillo, Minister of Agriculture, and several foreign diplomats.

HAVANA, Nov. 16. -- A plot to poison the water of Havana aqueducts was charged today by the Army Intelligence Service, which detained Andres Rey Rodriquez, a native of Corunna, Spain, charged with being the chief of the conspirators.

With a war in Ethiopia, and a new Commonwealth in the Philippines, and a new Parliament in Great Britain, and unrest in Egypt, and a new Japanese grab in North China, how much simpler it is to talk about the new buses on Central Park West.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Successful treatment of arthritis by administering drugs externally with an electric current was reported today by a St. Louis University physician.

VIENNA, Nov. 16. -- Musical circles have been stirred by simultaneous announcements of the discovery in Vienna and Prague, respectively, of an early overture by Schubert and what is called the first symphony by Dvorak, both, by a curious coincidence, in the key of C minor.

RADIO'S outstanding triumph of the week was maintaining two-way communication with the stratosphere balloon that lifted two army fliers, Captains Albert W. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson, to the highest point yet reached by man.

The Baldwin Government was faced last week with the double problem of keeping itself in power in Great Britain and of keeping Britain in power in Egypt. Ballots achieved the first end, bullets the second.

Just 150 years ago today twenty-two men met in Walter Heyer's Tavern in Pine Street, then King Street, and organized the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York. The society, with more than 300 members, investments and holdings of more than $4,400,000, and a free school serving more than 4,000 students, will celebrate its 150th anniversary tomorrow night with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, opened yesterday an exhibition commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of Samuel L. Clemens (Mark Twain), which will continue in the main exhibition room on the first floor until April 15.

As we register our gratitude that, in 1935, Johnny Crow has seen fit to enlarge his little Garden, we find ourselves wishing that for every Christmas season we might have a new Leslie Brooke picture book.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- More than 500 persons attended the dinner dance held here tonight at the Westchester Country Club to aid the Irvington House for Cardiac Children. There was an entertainment featuring Miss Colette D'Arville, Miss Ethelyne Holt, Miss Marjorie Logan and Miss Anna Maria Morales and Peter Morales.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16. -Northern California fresh fruits cleared through the State refrigeration terminal for export and intercoastal water shipment will aggregate close to 370,000 packages, as against 314,000 packages last year, it was estimated yesterday by John Bermingham, superintendent of the plan.

THERE appeared recently in the press an account of a brilliant young woman who committed suicide in London because "she could both sides of every question so forcibly that reaching any decision worried her to death."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- An investigation of the purchase of French cement for twenty-five PWA financed schools in New York City will be ordered by Secretary Ickes, a PWA spokesman said today.

In the daily presentation of news covering people and events in East Africa, scene of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, there is often used Ethiopian terminology, with no indication of the English equivalents.

Problems of the American merchant marine will be discussed by leaders in the shipping industry at a two-day national merchant marine conference tomorrow and Tuesday at the Waldorf-Astoria. About 1,500 are expected to attend the meetings and a dinner tomorrow night at which Secretary of Commerce Roper will be the principal speaker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- An assertion that the American banking system was sound under the Hoover administration and that recovery was under way in March, 1933, before the New Deal program became effective was made by the Republican National Committee today.

WEATHER conditions continued to shape retail trade in the week. In sections favored by seasonal temperatures volume increased. In others, where the warm spell persisted, sales lagged. Home furnishings business was still a feature.

HAVANA, Nov. 16. -- The Social and Economic Union of Cuba today cabled President Roosevelt petitioning for the re-establishment of railway communications between Key West, Fla., and the mainland in a gesture of sympathy and cooperation toward the small town that played so prominent a part in the Cuban struggle for independence and was a means of more closely linking Cuba with the United States.

Although it contained little more than 100 pieces, the art collection of Ira Haupt, member of the New York Stock Exchange, brought $90,755 when auctioned yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. Ten of the pieces paid were more than $3,000.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 16. -- Three of the minor stakes of the fourth annual field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club were decided today in the covers and on the lakes of the estate of Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Over-strenuous action in the rehearsal of a play resulted in the death of an actor, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reports. The actor's death was one of 108 industrial fatalities in the State during October.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Only eight States and the District of Columbia are fully prepared fort the start of the Federal unemployment-insurance system Jan. 1.

PARIS, Nov. 16 (AP). -- An oral outline of France's reply to Italy's protest note, defending the French position on sanctions, has been given to Vittorio Cerruti, Italian Ambassador to Paris, it was reliably reported today.

The wide variety of government orders scheduled to be placed shortly in the various textile markets will serve as a strong barrier against any price weakness at a time when demand from regular channels normally slackens, selling agents reported here yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 16 (AP). -The professional ethics and grievance committee of the American Bar Association will consider tomorrow a complaint that the American Liberty League offered free legal services to any one in defense of his constitutional rights.
SHANGHAI, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Chinese sources said today a "death blow" had been given to the movement to establish a separate government in North China independent of Nanking.

For the first time since 1931 the North Jersey Field Hockey Association will sponsor the Southeast sectional tournament, the annual round robin being scheduled to start on Friday at the Montclair Athletic Club, Montclair, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A double-barreled campaign program in which he combined advocacy of governmental economy with payment of the soldiers' bonus was set forth today by Colonel Frank Knox of Chicago, when he arrived here to establish a Winter home for Mrs. Knox.

ERNEST FIENE is having a one-man show at the Downtown Gallery. It will continue until the end of the month. Fiene, it seems, has been devoting himself particularly of late to the water-color medium, and sometimes with conspicuous success.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 16. -- The strong Baldwin High School football machine brought its second regular campaign to an end with an unbeaten record by conquering its perennial foe, Hempstead, today at the Municipal Stadium.

As one who has recently made some studies in the field of delinquency, I must object strongly to Clairette P. Armstrong's attempt to give scientific color to a conclusion that is far from scientific -- that "the 'clash of civilizations' is the cause of delinquency" and "the harvest is now being reaped from mass immigration of the lowest population levels of many countries."
Boys High registered its first football triumph over Erasmus Hall since 1932 by 44 -- 0 at Boys Field in Brooklyn yesterday. A crowd of 5,000 witnessed the rout.

Governor Floyd B. Olson of Minnesota made a bid to youth to join the American Commonwealth Federation, organized recently to coalesce radical groups into a third party, in a radio broadcast last night over WABC and a Columbia network.

A group of passers-by gazed from the sidewalk in amazement yesterday afternoon at a "Florodora" sextet and a half-dozen firemen dressed in gray silk toppers, stock collars and frock coats, as they went through song and dance routines of "Tell Me, Pretty Maiden" and other choral numbers from the once-famous "Florodora" in the drill yard of the Fire Department School of Instruction, 154 East Sixty-eighth Street.

MARIE STERNER has arranged at her gallery in Fifty-seventh Street a delightful exhibition to which the title "Dance, Music, Theatre" has been given. There are paintings, drawings and lithographs by just short of thirty artists; artists of several lands, some of them contemporary, some belonging to earlier days.

FOLLOW the Maine Coast from Bath to Bar Harbor, from Casco Bay to Penobscot to Eastport, and you will find the background for Mary Ellen Chase's fine romantic story of four generations of a seafaring family.

Army's players apparently came through yesterday's grueling game without any serious injury. Their dressing room, after the battle, was thronged with visitors, despite a police guard at the door, and the entire squad was receiving congratulations as enthusiastic as though there had been a victory instead of a tie.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 16. -Three Coast Guard cutters were searching the stormy waters of Great South Bay tonight for a thirty-one-foot sloop that carried three Islip men out of Islip on a fishing trip this morning and did not return at nightfall.

A YEAR has passed since Lawrence Riley stuck his head out of a hotel window and pointed with pride to his name written in lights under the legend "Personal Appearance," while his aunt, not at all impressed, demanded that he close the window and quit pointing because there was a draught in the room.
Epigrams from former President Hoover's address before the Ohio Society of New York last night follow:

PARIS. A BIRDSEYE view of the Lyons looms, at any tinge of the year, will pretty accurately forecast style trends. The great Lyons textile creators work in close collaboration with Paris couturiers in preparing the way for new modes.

WESLEY, Me., Nov. 16. -- Almost at the point of dropping from exhaustion after suffering cold and hunger, while lost nearly three days in the wilderness on a hunting trip near here, Lewis Adams, 20, of Boothbay was found just before dark tonight in an abandoned lumber camp.

Perhaps there is no movement in our country so little understood by the aver age person as the pacifist movement. Perhaps a statement of just what the pacifists believe and how they work will not be unwelcome.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Despite the fact that a processing tax case is now awaiting determination by the Supreme Court of the United States, it is possible that the legal controversy concerning the constitutionality of the AAA processing tax will not finally be adjudicated for many months.

A RETROSPECTIVE exhibition that serves to sum up the career of the widely known American artist, Cecilia Beaux, N.A., opened to the public a few days since, at the American Academy of Arts and Letters, 633 West 155th Street. It is scheduled to remain current until early next May.

Some hours after a drunken party the dead body of beautiful Marguerite School is discovered in her Greenwich Village apartment. The police immediately suspect Robert Crocker. an artist living in the same building. The evidence against him is so conclusive that he is almost sure to be convicted, but Pe ter Adams, a reporter, has his doubts about Crocker's guilt.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 16. -- For 18-year-old James Patrick Byrne, whom his friends know as "Bubber," his teammates at Notre Dame High School played inspired football yesterday but lost to bigger Central High School 7 to 6.

FORCED to resign his commission in a crack guards regiment because of an act of chivalry against the Turkish Prince Ali, nephew of the late Sultan Abdul, while visiting Britain, Captain Destine is rewarded for the sacrifice of his army career by appointment to an extremely dangerous job of espionage which bears him to Stamboul in the ostensibly innocent guise of an English tobacco merchant.

UNCHANGED in fundamental mechanical details, but redesigned for the market, the Stout Scarab, originally announced last February, is now in production in Detroit, although William B. Stout, who developed the car, has announced that his present plans call for the manufacture of only 100 units, to be sold to preselected buyers in special localities.
OTTAWA, Nov. 14. -- Premier Aberhart's political honeymoon is over.

For a variety of reasons there was much news last week about recovery and about its handmaiden, politics. The bankers held their annual meeting in a cheerful frame of mind -- so cheerful, indeed, that they unanimously approved a resolution declaring that "recovery is making vigorous progress."

John Whopper was first published in 1870. One can easily imagine him as a favorite with those who were boys and girls in the last decades of the nineteenth century and it is also safe to say that John Whopper's adventures will be read and enjoyed by many a present-day 9 and 10 year old.

Organization of a "general creditors committee" of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, "to protect the interests of investors in the liquidation of the company" and to study plans for the possible formation of a new concern out of the assets of the present company, was announced yesterday.

A sixty-four-year-old treaty between the United States and Italy was brought into the news last week. Ratified in 1871, it was originally to run for five years, but provision was made in it for its continuation automatically and indefinitely until terminated on twelve months' notice by one party or the other.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 16. -- Tropical hurricanes have taken more lives this year than the reported toll of the Italo-Ethiopian war.

Despite adverse weather conditions in several sections of the country, which have retarded retail volume in men's and women's apparel, the wholesale markets have continued unusually strong, because of the basic firmness in raw materials, according to a survey of the various fields yesterday.

Fourteen miles was the goal that Captain Albert Stevens and Captain Orvil Anderson intended to reach in the National Geographic Society's balloon Explorer II. If they failed to achieve precisely that height last Tuesday it must have been by only a very few hundred feet.
THUS debonairly did one 11-year-old ride away into the far country that books had opened out before her.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- An essential section of the new Frazier-Lemke Act, providing a three-year "moratorium" on farm mortgages, and setting up refinancing machinery, was held unconstitutional today in a unanimous opinion handed down by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Seventh District.

OLD Trinity Church, suffering from what might be called a severe curvature of the spire, has just undergone a long and delicate surgical operation. Tower and spire are still out of plumb and may always remain so. But the operation has eliminated the danger that they would crash down together across Broadway and into Wall Street opposite.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 16 (AP). -- Slippery Tom McGannon, sophomore Purdue halfback, intercepted one of Oze Simmons's long forward passes with a shoe-string catch and streaked 63 yards straight down the gridiron today to give the rejuvenated Boilermakers a 12-to-6 victory over the University of Iowa.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 16. -- Jean Batten, New Zealand aviatrix, is taking this capital by storm. The newspapers give her visit first importance, relegating Ethiopia to second place. Cable messages from many parts of the world and even overseas telephone calls are being received by her.

FOR twenty-five centuries there has been a city of great strategic importance on the shores of the Bosporus. This city was originally called Byzantium and was Greek in development. In the years A.D. 328-330, the Emperor Constantine the Great abandoned Rome as his capital and made Byzantium his metropolis.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 16. -- The approval of the Chilean-Peruvian trade treaty by the Peruvian Congress is causing general rejoicing in this country today. The pact is expected to open the way to mutual and highly beneficial commerce between the two nations.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 16. -- Minnesota's football machine, fast, powerful and bone-crushing, smeared the gridiron prestige of once powerful Michigan with a 40-to-0 rout today. It was the worst Michigan defeat in forty-three years.

CHARLIE CHAPLIN'S forthcoming picture, like every other major event, has cast its shadow before. If it is an unfamiliar shadow -- the little man blown up to threatening proportions, the flip walking stick brandished like a club -- blame it on the experts for the light they have thrown upon a picture they have not seen.

The Bronx will begin on Thursday of this week a series of events which James J. Lyons, President of the borough, hopes will help people to "think of the place as something other than the home of the cocktail and the cheer."

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- Admiration coupled with envy is expressed by the French press today because of the manner in which the British general election was conducted and because of the result. The virtual return to the two-party system and the elimination of extremists -- Fascist and Communist -- are envied.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16. -Yale scored a 55-to-0 victory over Lafayette today in their first meeting since the Bowl was opened. The visitors made only three first downs and never threatened the Yale goal line. They have yet to cross the Yale goal line in three games played.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 16. -As the result of today's play on the Adelphi College field the Boston Hockey Association must definitely hand the laurels of the Northeast section over to the Westchester players who make up the Stuyvesant team.

There can be little doubt that the day of the lone inventor, the starving genius of the garret, is over. He gave us great inventions, but he took too long about it. Discoveries and improvements made decades and even generations apart had to be assembled before we had the telegraph, the telephone, the harvester, the flying machine.

Incomplete returns from the first week in the fund-raising campaign of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, showed contributions more than $20,000 in excess of the corresponding period last year, it was said yesterday by Pater S. Duryee, the roll-call chairman.

In both appearance and content "The Good Master" is a genuinely joyous and beautiful book. The scene of the story is a farm on the great Hungarian plains, a farm where there were thousands of sheep, horses, cows and pigs, where there were chickens and ducks and geese, even donkeys, but only one boy, 10-year-old Jancsi.

At this season the great color pageant of the American Autumn draws to its close. Nature gathers in all her brighter and frailer wares -- the tropical Summer resident birds, the butterflies and moths, flowers and leaves, the voice of the cricket and the frog and the songs of the feathered host.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- About 52 per cent of the trained laborers in manufacturing plants who were unemployed in March, 1933, had regained their jobs last September and the trend of re-employment was still upward, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States reported today in declaring that new NRA legislation "would impede the continuance of gains."

XENIA, Ohio, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The possibility that Senator Borah might file in Ohio for the Republican nomination for President prompted Representative Leroy T. Marshall to declare today that such a course "would be contrary to the plans of most leaders here."

Teachers, principals and school administrators interested in progressive practices in education will meet at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Friday and Saturday for the annual New York regional conference of the Progressive Education Association. The conference is expected to attract 3,000 persons from the metropolitan area.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16. -The American premiere of T.S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral" will be given in the Yale University Theatre during the second week of December. This next major experimental production by the Yale Drama Department will be under student supervision.

This story should open up new vistas into his country's past for the boy in his early 'teens, for it presents a panorama of Indian life in Eastern America before the white man came. It is the tale of Wehinahpay, son of an Algonquin chieftain, and his heroic journey in search of his sister from his home in the Housatonic Valley to the Dakotah tribes in Minnesota, the Land of the Sky-Tinted Waters.
The loyalty oaths required of teachers were condemned yesterday by the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman as "impertinent interference with academic freedom."

MODERN methods of teaching art to children, as developed by the Works Progress Administration, will be demonstrated to public school teachers of New York and vicinity in a "clinic" to be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Nov. 23 in connection with the regional conference of the Progressive Education Association.

The last half of November finds the radio bill following a fixed pattern from week to week. The guest artists alone add variety to the spice of broadcasting, and it will not be until the holidays approach with special events and music that the routine will change.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16. -Princeton's undefeated 150-pound football team scored its third victory of the year today, downing the Yale lightweights, 26 -- 0, on University Field.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand. -In this education-conscious country, where illiteracy is virtually unknown, there are, by strange irony, thousands of children who have no chance to attend school.
NASSAU, Bahama Islands. -- More important undertakings of American origin and financing have been announced in the Bahamas during recent weeks than in any ten years in the history of the colony.

IN the realm of the small boy the Cub Scout movement grows steadily more popular. It fills a definite need in the world of the lad between 9 and 12 years of age; it gives him a taste of older Scouting besides offering a program of its own, and it is building an organization of which an increasing number of Scout leaders, teachers and parents approve.
OTTAWA, Nov. 16. -- Drastic penalties for contravention of the government's Order-in-Council providing for imposition of sanctions against Italy have been provided, it was announced today.

A pain-crazed laborer living on home relief shot and seriously wounded Dr. Ercole Fiore, 41 years old, a nose specialist, shortly after noon yesterday in a dingy flat at 242 East 109th Street, near Second Avenue.
When American folk drama takes its place more securely with the other folk dramas of the world, the material offered by the Southern mountain people will be of our best.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- J. Edgar Hoover's agents can take something from nothing.

THESE two books, of large octavo size and consisting chiefly of pictures, initiate a new series whose purpose is to further and make popular the fresh outlook, the new vision, with which, aided by the camera, mankind is now observing the new works of man and his machines and the old and everlasting works of nature.

THE new Antioch has been operating for fifteen years. The educational process we are trying to promote is significant for America, especially as it is not imposed on the students but gradually emerges, through the exercise of a large degree of freedom, and the encouragement of the innate self-respect of young people.

The Hapag Lloyd liner Deutschland carried a new master and the largest consignment of German beer to reach the country since the war when she docked Friday afternoon at Pier 86, North River. Captain Hans Kieff was on the bridge in place of Captain Heinrich Dau, her regular master, and in the hold were 900 barrels of Muenschner brew.

Sale by the Radio Corporation of America of its interest in affiliated companies in which it held less than a majority ownership has placed the directors of the company in a position to proceed soon with plans for a recapitalization that will eliminate dividend arrears on the B preferred stock.

No more French or other imported cement is to be used in the construction of twenty-five new public schools of New York City under the Public Works Administration, it was announced yesterday by Walter C. Martin, superintendent of school buildings of the Board of Education.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- This city's majority vote last week in favor of Sunday movies was another step in a slow but gradual liberalizing of Pennsylvania's "blue law" of 1794.

WASHINGTON, Nov 16. -- The government-sponsored Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, organized at the instance of the President, disclosed before the Securities and Exchange Commission the story of its prolonged, and so far unsuccessful, effort to bring about a modification of the Foreign Debt Adjustment Law passed in January by the Chilean Congress.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said today that the Federal Government must bear the brunt of providing employment for several years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The price of whisky, occasionally described in satirical circles as repeal's great disillusionment, is due for another forward bend. The bending force this time will be applied at the Canadian border.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- With deceptive reverse plays Temple University swept Marquette from the undefeated ranks today by rolling up a 26-6 victory over the Golden Avalanche at the Temple Stadium before 18,000 persons.

AS a new factor in American social life, the advent of all-season, all-purpose week-end country clubs is noted. These organizations are increasing in the vicinity of New York City and throughout the land in response to the growing zest of urban dwellers for recreational facilities.

MOTORISTS from the North, East and West may drive to New Orleans over hard-surfaced highways early next Winter, and, at the same time, the nation will have available a hard-surfaced highway across the Southern States from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

The current expansion in retail charge account and instalment selling is evidenced in the report yesterday by A.B. Buckeridge, manager of the Retail Credit Bureau of Greater New York, that the bureau last week handled the greatest number of credit applications for any like period in its history.

At a Golden Jubilee dinner in the Hotel Commodore next Thursday, in honor of her lifelong devotion and service to the welfare of her people, Mrs. Rebekah Kohut will receive $50,000 to distribute to those charities to which she has contributed for half a century.
WITH THE ITALAIN ARMY AT MAKALE, Ethiopia, Nov. 16 (AP). -Huge preparations, marked by sharp combats, were made by the Italian Army today all along the line for the next advance.

HARTFORD, Nov. 16. -- Connecticut's new marriage law was interpreted at a recent conference of bewildered State, county and local officials to mean that no marriage may be performed in the State on New Year's Day, 1936, or any subsequent day on a license issued in 1935 and that no 1936 license may be issued except after the expiration of the present five days' banns, plus a satisfactory blood test by both man and woman.

A spectacular 43-yard forward from Paul Verbitsky to Winston Stillwell in the last play of the game enabled the aggressive Curtis High School football team to defeat a capable Massanutten Military Academy aggregation, 18 -- 13, yesterday at Thompson's Stadium in Stapleton.

Few actual characters are as appealing to young readers as T.E. Lawrence is. He has the romantic charm of a legendary hero and the interest of a great contemporary figure. Thus it is a satisfaction to find him the subject of a reliable and dignified biography for young people.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16. -Princeton's first-half attack enabled the Tigers to defeat Lehigh today, 27 to 0. Scoring all of their points in the first two periods, the Tigers seemed well on the way toward rolling up their highest score of the season, but the fighting Engineers from Bethlehem braced surprisingly in the two closing chapters and succeeded in keeping the high-geared Princeton machine from again crossing their goal line.

An unprecedented number of persons visited New York City's three zoos this year, according to figures made public yesterday by the Park Department and the New York Zoological Society. The increasing "zoo consciousness" of the public was attributed primarily to the opening of the reconstructed menageries in Central and Prospect Parks.

AFTER the splurge of color in October, the sober brown of the November woods may seem dull by comparison -but there is much quiet beauty there for those who go in quest of it. And the delight that comes with the changing season.

THE fight on roadside billboards is growing. Owing to the campaign for safety on the highways, the struggle against the road signs has shifted its ground from esthetics to accident prevention. As made evident at the meeting of the National Roadside Council here last Tuesday, garden clubs, highway beautification groups and civic associations in every part of the country have redoubled their efforts to bring down distracting or view-obstructing placards.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 16 (AP). -- In the wildest exhibition of wide-open pass throwing shown by any major Pacific Coast team this year. Southern California came from behind to beat Washington State, 20 to 10, today.

A warning to business against boycotting the Dec. 9 conference of Major Berry was sounded here yesterday by Sol A. Herzog, counsel for trade associations and members of the Consumer Goods Industries Committee. Mr. Herzog added that political thinking appears to have superseded economic and business thinking, so far as the scheduled meeting is concerned.

THE appearance in 1935 of an English translation by Mark Twain of "Der Struwwelpeter," never before published, is an event, and an interesting link in the history of a remarkable book. Written and illustrated in 1844, by Dr. Heinrich Hofmann for his 3-year-old son, because Dr. Hofmann liked none of the children's books on the market, it was translated into English four years later and was promptly adopted as a favorite by English nurseries.

A news item in your columns on Nov. 12 estimated the cost of the depression years of 1930 to 1934 inclusive at $26,000,000,000, based on the figures by Robert R. Nathan, chief of the Income Section of the Division of Economic Research, Department of Commerce.

APPROPRIATELY enough, the southbound Belfast-Dublin express comes to a halt about midway between the two cities. Customs officials of the Irish Free State clamber aboard, and for passengers there begins a dreary fifteen minutes of luggage inspection.

New regulations now being formulated to govern professional improvement of teachers in the city's public schools will be made effective next September, and until then no new courses for alertness credit will be approved at the Board of Education.

ATHENS, Nov. 16. -- King George's passage through Italy and his visits to King Victor Emmanuel and Premier Benito Mussolini are being closely observed here with relation to the King's future attitude in the Anglo-Italian rivalry in the Eastern Mediterranean.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15. -- The annual convention of the American Bankers Association, possibly the most influential business organization in the country, offers occasion each year for an assay of the financial and political sentiments of the entire country concentrated for this event within the confines of one convention hall.

A survey of operating rooms in New York City's ninety-eight voluntary hospitals showed that an appendicitis operation involved the use of about eighty surgical instruments, the United Hospital Campaign Committee announced yesterday.

DANIEL CATTON RICH, in The American Magazine of Art for October, deals with the new museum at Rotterdam. Also outstanding is the first instalment of E.M. Benson's monograph on John Marin (Part I, "Marin the Man"), illustrations for which include a frontispiece in color.

A WORLD'S record for "mass mountaineering" was recently claimed by the army of the Soviet Union in Central Asia. Three hundred Red Army officers and men, on a six-day trek, conquered Mount Trapetsia, a peak rising almost 20,000 feet above sea level in the Pamirs, the mountain range bordering Tibet and known as the Roof of the World.

With automobile and home furnishings promising to be far more important factors in gift volume this year merchandising and promotional plans are now being completed by retailers in all lines for what is expected to prove a $4,500,000,000 Christmas trade.

Mary Poppins did come back! During just such a crisis in the Banks household as when she first appeared, the same tart-spoken, black-haired, blue-eyed nursemaid, who could quell and enchant the four obstreperous Banks children in one awesome glance, took charge.

ON his retirement from the sea and the command of a transport liner, Captain Barakiah Bodfish resolved to return to Cape Cod, his boyhood home. On a visit to an old friend, Hopestill Davis, now happily married and living in the little town of Winnemansett, he found himself liking the place so well that he began to feel that he himself might like to settle down there.

THE fiftieth of the Boston Symphony Orchestra's visits to New York has been signalized, among other things, by a notable tribute which William J. Henderson, the distinguished dean of American music critics, has paid this celebrated organization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco won his seventh straight match in the world's three-cushion billiard championship tonight, defeating Johnny Layton, Sedalia, Mo., in a closely contested match, 50 to 46, in 46 innings. Cochran had a high run of 8 and came from behind to gain the victory. Layton's best run was a cluster of 5.

LONDON. -- Political geography will be prominent at the naval conference which is soon to meet in London. The powers, more than ever before, will insist upon the interdependence of the quality and quantity of their armaments on one hand and their geographical positions on the other.

Who appointed Mr. Lewis Jacobs the lord-chief-supervisor of the American film? He is so cute sitting on his pasteboard clouds and hurling destructive shafts of tin-pan thunder on Chaplin, Lubitsch, Mamoulian, Vidor and others.
ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Ten thousand Ethiopian warriors, bound for the front, passed in review before Emperor Haile Selassie today.

AT the first world's fair it was architecture in the form of a glass palace that caught eyes, set tongues to chattering and stayed in men's memories. At the last one it was transportation. What will hold first place at New York's projected show is a matter only to be determined when 1939 arrives.

IT is the Alaska Peninsula to which the title of Father Hubbard's book refers. To the north of this desolate finger of land is the Bering Sea and the cold Arctic current; to the south is the Pacific Ocean and the warm Japanese current.

ESCANABA, Mich. -- Problems in the financing of local government in the forest areas of Michigan are expected to arise as a result of the removal of much land from the tax rolls through acquisition by the State and Federal agencies.

LONDON, Oct. 24. FOR once the Londoner can assure visitors that the most elaborately staged play running at a fashionable West End theatre and the one most happily representative of young English acting talent is Shakespeare's. There is general agreement that the unusual assurance is thoroughly justified by John Gielgud's presentation of "Romeo and Juliet" at the New.

BOB VAN BRUNT was a serious, liberal-minded, very up-to-date young preacher. Faith Llewellyn typed his radio sermons and did highly efficient secretarial work for him. Faith was an atheist, deeply embittered by her husband's cowardly suicide.

Stone Webster, Inc., has reported a net income of $159,419 for the year ended on Sept. 30, 1935, contrasted with a net loss of $131,661 in the preceding year. Dividends from subsidiaries were $456,341, against $250,000, and other revenues were $412,221, compared with $408,086.

BOSTON, Nov. 16. -- Showing in a brilliant manner throughout a long day of competition, My Black Model, handsome entry owned by Mrs. Joseph N. Levine of Philadelphia and William Gass of Schnectady, N.Y., was adjudged the best in breed as the fourteenth annual specialty exhibition of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England came to a close at Horticultural Hall tonight.

Dean Archibald L. Bouton of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science yesterday announced three important revisions in the curriculum of that institution in his annual report to Chancellor Harry VVoodburn Chase. The changes are:

STARTING "from scratch" is seldom the gardener's privilege. Trees, shrubs, even established borders, are often inherited from previous planters, and so garden pageants are invariably staged with something old and something new.

MR. BRAY has invented a new name for the theme which he tackles in this very serviceable book -the lore of the Mythosphere, a region which he envisages as enveloping the whole earth and concerning which he has collected the facts that hundreds of delving, searching, investigating students have discovered.

None of the pro-Army supporters were yearning more for a West Point victory than the cadet first year men, the senior class. They had gone through the academy without ever celebrating a victory over Notre Dame and did not want to be that rarity, the first generation of cadets that had never seen Army defeat the Ramblers.

THE scene of the greater part of this story is an old chateau somewhere near Orleans in France. The company gathered there includes, besides the host and his servants, several passengers from the Marseilles-Paris plane, which has been forced down by engine trouble, and several others who have met with misadventure while traveling by taxicab.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Amid the double distraction of the war in Africa and the election at home the British Government has awakened slowly this week to the fact it has received a diplomatic rebuff of the first importance in the Far East.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Catholic University scored its first victory since 1913 over the Green Terriers of Western Maryland today at Griffith Stadium, 20 to 6.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- A striking picture of the new conditions nations will have to face on the outbreak of a war was painted last night by War Minister Jean Fabry before a party congress of the Alliance Democratique at Bordeaux.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The Boerse was quiet and mixed today as tra ding closed for the week, the banks evidently having withdrawn completely from operations after the recent flurry in prices, which was believed to have been in response to a certain amount of official pressure on those who had been carrying on all their transactions independent of the official market.
