BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 16 (AP). -- Alabama's Crimson Tide swept over Georgia Tech, smothering its passing offense in a drive of power today to score a 38 -- 7 victory before 12,000 spectators.

SOME fragrance still lingers in the late Auturn garden where Jack Frost has not yet paid his first visit. Bees gather late sweets from the clumps of alyssum. But it is only a matter of weeks, perhaps days, before the last trace of fragrance as well as of color will be gone from the flower borders.
Lilliputian folk ushered in the Christmas season in a big way yesterday by entertaining thousands of youngsters at the opening of the Hearn department store's Toytown.

The Cortlandt F. Bishop collection of engravings, etchings and color prints, together with furniture, sculpture, paintings, tapestries, porcelains and other art objects, comprising furnishings from the late Mr. Bishop's town house at 15 East Sixty-seventh Street and items removed from his residence, Ananda Hall, at Lenox, Mass., will be offered at auction this week at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.
The pageantry of the Army-Notre Dame classic held sway over Broadway last night as a football-mad throng spent its way through the Roaring Forties.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The Conservative victory in the British election was interpreted in German political quarters and the press as a personal triumph for Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and approval by the British people of a strong foreign policy in keeping with the importance of the British Empire.

WERE it not for its twenty-one predecessors the latest number of The Colophon might safely be described as the most interesting group of essays on book collecting that we have seen within the covers of a single volume.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 16. -- The sentence issued yesterday by the Chilean courts, refusing to grant the plea of the acting general manager of the Chilean Electric Companies, Archer K. Jones, for a withdrawal of the embargo applied by the law courts on the company's properties, marks the commencement of another period of rapid legal proceedings brought with unusual energy against an American-owned corporation here by the government.

As a beginning to Homelands Festival Week, sponsored by the Contemporary of Newark, pastors in all Newark churches will give some place in their services today to the thought of international understanding and world peace. With the cooperation of the public schools, the Newark Library and the Newark Museum, the Contemporary has arranged entertainments, exhibits and lectures for practically every day this week.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The religious organization called the Watch Tower Movement, which developed in the United States, was termed "a dangerously subversive movement" by a British commission today.

SAN REMO. Nov. 6, 1935. A BRIEF chat with Franco Alfano about his latest creation, "Cyrano de Bergerac," the chief novelty of the coming Royal Opera season. Alfano's lyric version of Rostand's famous "comidie heroique" was conceived, and in large part composed, in this romantic, sun-kissed villa on the Italian Riviera, where the Neapolitan composer spends his vacations and every possible day of freedom from his duties as director of the Turin Conservatory.
ROME, Nov. 16. -- Orders for the Fascist fight against the League measures were delivered by Il Duce in a secret session of the prefects of Italy's ninety-six Provinces today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Not many persons have the occasion of their birth accompanied by celestial phenomenon. King Kamehameha I of the Hawaiian Islands did, according to tradition, and for that reason the bicentennial celebration of his birth planned for 1936 may be delayed some twenty years or so.

The Misses Katharine Schuyler Cammann, Margaret and Magdalene Salvage head a group of younger persons who will assist at a sale of sailors' handicraft to be held during the intermissions of the performance of "Pride and Prejudice" on Thursday night at the Music Box Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

THAT half-century has given to Mr. Alexander such simon-pure satisfaction and pleasure that they irradiate his account with a naive charm as unconscious as it is unusual in biographies. His first big Job as a youth of 21 was with the Equitable Life Assurance Society, which he entered in the Autumn of 1869 when he was 10 years old.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- The Illinois Emergency Relief Commission fears that when Dec. 1 arrives it will find itself with twice as many cases left on its direct relief rolls as it had expected. It has certified 245,000 employables to WPA, but Harry L. Hopkins has ordered that only 183,500 be assigned to jobs by the date when Federal aid for direct relief is to end.

According to Webster's Dictionary a cedilla is a small mark, similar to a comma, placed under the letter "c" to indicate that it is to be pronounced as "s." But what Mr. Derleth calls a cedilla is like a circumflex accent or a misplaced caret.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Art has driven politics over the ropes of the conversational ring in Chicago. The forty-sixth annual exhibit of American paintings and sculpture at the Art Institute has made itself the one topic upon which everybody must have an opinion.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 16. -- Duquesne University conquered West Virginia, 19 to 0, today with comparative ease, outplaying the Mountaineers both through the air and in running attack.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Emil Schroeder, a stenographer who had been making a shorthand report of the trial of Dr. Peter Legge, Catholic Bishop of Meissen, and two co-defendants on exchange law charges, was arrested yesterday by the secret political police.

PARIS, Nov. 14. -- A stunning Winter sports collection was shown recently at the Hotel Crillon by Maurice Och, of Saint Moritz, and Madeleine de Rauch. Here were launched several interesting, specially woven French fabrics and reversible jacquard tricots.

Plans to study all proposed State and Federal legislation with the view of vigorously opposing that which is found to be "dangerous and un-American" were made yesterday by the assistance committee of the General Society of Mayflower Descendants.

Speculation as to effects of criticisms of club programs voiced last week at Syracuse during the convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs is increasing. The similarity of the views of Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole and Miss Lena Madesin Phillips, both former heads of large national organizations, as to overlapping of effort and the desirability of uniting important groups for special aims inevitably jolted their audience.

ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 16 (AP). -Louisiana State University's football powerhouse, featuring a 95-yard touchdown run by lanky Jess Fatherree, conquered Georgia by 13 to 0 today as the Bulldogs repelled three goal-line thrusts in a spectacular battle before about 20,000 spectators.

Beginning tomorrow a new course will be included in the curriculum of the Police Academy here and the State Police School, dealing with the workings of the State parole system, according to an announcement yesterday by Parole Commissioner Joseph J. Canavan who said it should help in the police fight against crime.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN this week found himself in the midst of his season's program, one of his more ambitious of recent years. "Splendor" was released; "Shoot the Chutes" was scheduled to finish with Eddie Cantor shouting "Never again with Goldwyn"; "Children's Hour," which now is known as "These Three," was ready for the cameras, and preparations for "Dodsworth," in which Waiter Huston may appear, were well under way.

RADIO is likely to remain a "lost horizon" for dramatists until the broadcasters discover ways and means of making it worth while for a playwright to give the microphone a good idea to devour in one performance.

New York University's football team stands on the threshold of a record clear of defeat and tie. A crowd of 15,000 gratified supporters of the Violet saw it strike with all its latent power through the airways and over the ground to crush Rutgers, 48 to 0, for its seventh triumph of the season at Ohio Field yesterday in the thirty-third encounter between these traditional rivals.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 16. -- The chimes of Thompson Chapel rang out the tidings of a smashing victory for a superior Williams football team which regained the Little Three championship by conquering Amherst, 13 to 0, in a hard-fought battle on Weston Field today.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Undefeated Texas Christian University's juggernaut, led by Sammy Baugh, trounced the University of Texas, 28 to 0, today. Baugh riddled the Texas defense with his bullet-like passes. Seven of his fifteen flips were good, three ending in touchdowns.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 16. -- The faculty of Wesleyan University is cooperating with the CCC educational directors in offering evening courses to men at Camp Jenkins at Cobalt who are qualified to receive instruction. The work is under the direction of Professor John E. Cavelti of the Chemistry Department, but the instruction is being given by one member of the senior class and two graduate students.

THE pink pants in question have nothing to do with the intimacies of the boudoir. They were oversize football pants, made from Pipperbody's Dubblethick Pre-Shrunk Sateen to fit the charming and heroic person of Brunnehilde Downing, otherwise known as Pussy.

TRAVELERS who flee the rigors of Winter are now speeding southward along the open highway and camping at leisure in houses on wheels. The number of these folk who find pleasure in living the nomadic life for a season is increasing each year.

AIR-MAIL service across the North Atlantic should be a matter of international cooperation rather than competition, Martin Wronsky, managing director of the Deutsche Lufthansa, Germany's national and international airline system, said here last week.

THE author of this book is minister of the Second Presbyterian Church of Indianapolis, a church of many historic services and memories, of which a hundred years ago Henry Ward Beecher was pastor for almost a decade. Mr. Miller takes his title from a verse of Matthew which quotes Christ a saying: "When it is evening, ye say it will be fair weather, for the sky is red.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 16. -Warned by Governor Lehman of impending sharp increases in city relief costs, the advisory committee of the State Conference of Mayors met here today to consider problems of unemployment relief and municipal financing.

A CONCERT version of "Tristan" will be presented Thursday evening and Friday afternoon in Chicago by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, under Frederick Stock, with the assistance of seven guest artists and a male chorus. Lauritz Melchior will sing Tristan's music and Dorothee Manski that of Isolde.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Charging "banker domination" of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad through H.A. Scandrett, its president, an independent bondholders' protective committee today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission not to confirm his appointment as a trustee until it had investigated his qualifications in public hearings.

THIS new Masefield novel of the sea will be, we imagine, a delight to those who have known full-rigged ships in all their glory. And although long stretches of it are much too technical for most of us to understand them the book stands up as a hearty yarn of a half-forgotten order.

THE rags-to-riches story which is the life history of Sophie Dawes could only have been lived out in that decaying wonderland which consisted of the great estates of France just after Waterloo. Born the illegitimate daughter of a drunken English smuggler and brought up in a poorhouse, Sophie found work at the age of twenty as a servant in a Piccadilly house of call.

SUPPLEMENTARY to the exhibition of eighteenth century French paintings at the Metropolitan Museum, four rooms of eighteenth-century prints have been arranged, so that we have the insistent charm of that long dead century doubled for us during the remainder of this year.

ABOUT 48,000 communities in this country are dependent on motor trucks to handle their freight, as they are not reached by railroads, according to Motor Truck Facts, just issued by the motor truck committee of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

ROME, N. Y., Nov. 18.--Mr. Stevens, who was a son of Jamae Stevens, former Mayor, Assemblyman and State Senator, was born here on June 24, 1874. After attending l-larvard University he at one time was vice president of the Rome Merchant Iron Mills and later a director of the Kent Company and the Farmers 1National Bank and Trust Company.

THE purpose of Dr. Kugelmas all through this book is to apply what he calls "the doctrine of individuality" in aiding, molding and perfecting the growth and development of children. It is based on the principle that "whatever the level of the child's endowment, the tempo of each element can be modified in the direction of more wholesome development."

While Miss Vera Stretz, under indictment for first degree murder for the shooting of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, remained a prisoner in the women's house of detention, detectives yesterday conducted a vain search for a woman said to be a blonde and whose friendship for the murdered German financier indicated a jealousy motive for the crime.

INCREASED facilities for the playing of national games by New York City s foreign-born people are an important feature of the city's rapidly expanding park system. Italians, Scots, Irish, Germans and other groups now find ample opportunity for the amateur pursuit of their favorite pastimes in city parks and recreation centres.

WHEN Ronald Firbank died a few years ago, few candles were left burning at his shrine; he had had, and already forfeited, his little day. His small fad had resulted, in this country at least, from the larger fad of Carl Van Vechten; which was no more than right, since he had been (Continued on Page 24)

GENEVA, Nov. 15. -- There are both optimism and pessimism here on the eve of the application of the first economic sanctions. The optimism arises mainly from these facts: The world has avoided the worst -- failure of the League of Nations to function. For two months the League has taken every hurdle better than had been expected.

In a lovely prose Frances Clarke Sayers tells the story of a strange little cat, of a village that moved and changed its name, of a little boy and his grandmother who stayed behind in the deserted town of Bean Blossom. On a Winter night so cold and clear that the stars seemed to be twirling through the skies Christopher first saw the kitten, a patch of blackness against the white snow.

This is the story of the young son of an African Congo chief. In the jungle village where he lived Kintu and his brothers and sisters had many lessons to learn, Kintu more than any of the others, for he was the eldest son and to be a chief one must know many things.

THE time is coming when we are going to have traffic regulations in the air, when it will be necessary to govern landings and take-offs by a traffic control system of some sort and when in flying across country there will be special rules and regulations for the purpose of avoiding congestion in the skies."

Transfer to the city of title to a site for a park in the Maspeth-Middle Village section of Queens from the estate of Arnold Rothstein was made possible yesterday by the tentative acceptance by the Federal Government of claims against the estate for income tax arrears.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Industrial activity has tended to level off after the upward movement of September and October, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business.

The centenary of Andrew Carnegie's birthday will be widely observed in the United States during the week of Nov. 25, according to an announcement of the Carnegie Corporation of New York last night. Preparations have been made in hundreds of American communities, colleges and universities to pay tribute to the Scotch boy who came to this country, made a fortune in steel and then devoted the later years of his life to philanthropy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- Business in wheat contracted sharply today on the Board of Trade, compared with yesterday's heavy turnover, but there was further buying by houses with Eastern connections which was regarded as short covering. Prices fluctuated erratically within a range of around a cent, the December showing relative strength from buying against sales of May, attributed to changing over hedges by mills.
ANNVILLE, Pa., Nov. 16 -- Albright, with a powerful running attack, downed Lebanon Valley today, 10 to 0.

Increased activity in the stock market in the last month has ended "Scotch week," restored the 10 per cent salary cut and doubled weekly wages in many Stock Exchange houses. The granting of bonuses already has been announced by three member firms since Nov. 1.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 16. -- Mrs. W. Deering Howe's Only One captured the Prince Georges Autumn Handicap before 12,000 persons and sent his earnings for the year to $28,480, the sum of $2,650 being added today.

Buyers continued to set the pace in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in the heaviest turnover for a two-hour session since Feb. 23. Activity was concentrated on second grade domestic corporation issues, many of which were bid up to new high levels, while the higher grade investment bonds, including United States Government obligations, showed a firm undertone.

ROME, Sunday, Nov. 17. -- A summons to all Italians to unite in resistance of the economic sanctions to be imposed tomorrow by fifty-one nations was issued by the Grand Council of Fascism this morning at the conclusion of a meeting lasting nearly three hours.

THE glass panel over the main entrance of the Palazzo d'Italia, 626 Fifth Avenue, latest of the Rockefeller Center decorations to be installed, is to be followed by another over the main entrance of the six-story extension of the International Building, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, within a few months.

Echoes of the crusading anti-Tammany sermons of the late Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst will be heard in a number of churches of the city today in preparation for the launching of the movement to raise funds for the Parkhurst memorial planned in Madison Square facing the site of Dr. Parkhurst's church.

Any one who remembers his childhood efforts to visualize Kentucky as something more than the green spot on the map, or New York as the pink State, will appreciate this volume. Brilliantly colored pictorial maps of the same order which have been amusing adults for the past decade show the United States and their Territories as active, picturesque entities.

A contingent of New Yorkers will go to Waterville, Me., for the marriage there on Nov. 30 of Miss Margaret Boe Nivison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nivison of that place, to Austin Carleton Chase 2d of this city and Whitefield, N.H.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- County and city officials in Westchester County were puzzled today by appropriations reported to have been made by the Works Progress Administration for a malaria control program. There has not been a case of malaria reported in the county in years, according to the records of the Westchester County Department of Health.

AN experiment now being tried by Lovat Dickson is being watched with keen interest by other London publisher. It might also deserve the attention of any American authors who do not despise the possible increment of their royalties through English editions of their own work.

Dean Joseph W. Barker of the Columbia School of Engineering, in his annual report to the university trustees, made public yesterday, declared that State laws requiring teachers to take an oath of allegiance to the Constitution were "ineffective" and a hindrance to the "free examination of ideas which is essential to a democracy."

THE Marxian theory this year is that it's smarter to try out a picture on the old Pantages circuit than in Times Square. The theorist is Harpo Marx, the red-wigged, horn-tooting, harp-playing, knife-dropping but otherwise silent pantaloon among the brothers.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 16 (AP). -Whether there is a new fortune for the Southern farmer in "cotton roads" is a question in which the South is interested as highway engineers conduct experiments.

Beavers are fascinating wild creatures and in this book the authors and illustrators make the reader feel that he has actually been given an opportunity to watch a beaver family as they leave their home, driven out by a forest fire, and, following streams and rivers, travel on till they come to a good location for a new dam and a new beaver colony.

A brand new name for a familiar old yacht club was selected last week by the board of governors of the North Hempstead Y.C. at Port Washington, according to Commodore Martin J. Porter. Henceforth this club, which has been rapidly growing during the past two seasons and which this Fall has acquired land that it has heretofore used on a rental contract, will be known as the Nassau Y.C.

NOW that "Pride and Prejudice" is here, another rule of workshop will have to be discarded. The bigwigs have long agreed that good plays cannot be conjured out of novels unless the playwright throws the book out of the window directly he has read it and writes his play as an independent work of art.

Eight hundred women, including scores prominent in the artistic and commercial life of the city and State, will assemble tomorrow night at the A.W.A. clubhouse, at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, for the ninth annual joint "friendship dinner" of organizations of business women.

Harrel H. Good scored a 45-second knockout over Thomas J. Hall in their heavyweight special bout last night on the amateur boxing program staged under the auspices of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. in Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 2,500 attended.

EVER since the World War Manley O. Hudson, Professor of International Law in Harvard's Law School and member of the Permanent Court of Arbitration, has been among the foremost of the deplorably thin ranks of those who work for the cause of international peace.

From the Civil Service Commission came last week a report which showed that the Federal Government now has more employes than ever before in peace time. The total (for September, the latest month available) is 794,467, exclusive of the army, navy, CCC and the needy who have relief jobs.

A royal welcome awaited La Argentina when she opened her sixth New York season at the Town Hall last night before an audience that, as usual, completely filled the auditorium. Certainly in the case of such an art and such a personality as hers there is nothing dulling about repetition, and one finds her now as thoroughly enchanting as on the evening of her debut.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 16. -Charles Balough, 39 years old, of 349 West 145th Street, Manhattan, is being held by the police here on a charge of taking part in a confidence game last June in which Kalmon Kipp of 401 Twenty-third Avenue, Astoria, Queens, lost $11,000. Balough was arrested in New York Friday.

GENEVA, Nov. 15. -- During the period since the League coordination committee completed its program of five proposals for sanctions against Italy, acceptances of these sanctions have been coming into Geneva. First they came trickling in; soon the tide rose, reached a flood and then, with most of the League members accounted for, began subsiding.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 16. -One hundred and twenty-seven Brown University upperclassmen have been put on the Dean's List for the rest of the semester, as an award for high scholastic standing. A place on the Dean's List gives students unlimited absences from classes and freedom from other routine requirements.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Eight banks in New York and Chicago were made defendants in suits today growing out of the bankruptcy of two former Insull holding companies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -Yale's freshmen finished one of their most successful football season's in years when they won a hard-fought 21 to 19 decision from the Harvard yearlings today before 2,500 spectatotrs.

THE revised Americans, under the dauntless leadership of Red Dutton, will sally forth on the Garden ice tonight and attack Le Club de Hockey Canadien, otherwise known as the Habitants. The Americans are determined to win a hockey game if it takes them all Winter, which perhaps it will, although Red Dutton fervently hopes not.

The close battle between the Giants and Brooklyn Dodgers for leadership in the Eastern division of the National Football League will be continued today. The Dodgers will face the Chicago Cardinals at Ebbets Field, starting at 2:15 P.M., in an effort to overtake the Giants, who will be in Chicago meeting the Bears.

It is encouraging to note a much more general and lively discussion of the railroad situation than has been evident for some time. A recent article in The Savings Bank Journal called attention to the fact that seventy-four railroads were in process of reorganization, comprising 30 per cent of the railroad mileage of the country.

Brooklyn College and New York Agricultural College battled to a scoreless tie yesterday at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium. The Kingsmen had numerous opportunities, but were unable to produce a fruitful play when deep in Aggie territory.

IF you have an insomniac on your Christmas list, you may help to cut down his or her sleepless hours by giving a set of luxurious matching or harmonizing sheets, quilts, blankets and blanket covers. These come in any color and thus can be made to suit any bedroom decor.
LONDON is muddling along about as usual, the cable says, the events of the current week being these:

Trading again was mixed on the commodity futures markets here yesterday, with volume large for a Saturday. Cottonseed oil and copper prices were slightly firmer and other staples were steady or weaker. On the cash markets oats and lard advanced, while declines occurred in wheat, corn, rye, cotton, butter and rubber.

The corner of White and Moore Streets, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, is desolate and deserted at night. The neighborhood is one of old, mostly abandoned, factories. About 8:30 o'clock on the night of March 3 a call was received at Brooklyn Police Headquarters that there was trouble in a garage at 225 Moore Street, where dingy White Street cuts across it.

WINIFRED HOLTBY, whose untimely death was recently announced, has written a book on women that should take its place on the bookshelf next to Virginia Woolf's "A Room of One's Own." With searching analysis, lit by erudition and humor, Miss Holtby examines the subject of women's place in the world, touching lightly on early civilizations but concentrating on the past three centuries.

Laverne Fator, the former jockey, was held up and robbed of $600 by two armed men at the Jamaica Race Track shortly before 3 P.M. yesterday. The robbers fled in Fator's car, a new sedan, making him walk a quarter of a mile to a cottage on the field to notify the police.

VIENNA, Nov. 16. -- The uncertainty of Austrian mails because of secret activity by censors, even where mail is addressed to foreign newspaper men, has just been established experimentally by this correspondent.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -Pennsylvania's eleven rose to a fighting pitch against Penn State today to roll up five touchdowns for a surprising 33 to 6 triumph.

All characters, places, situations and frames used in this story are imaginary," including the name of the author. "Smoke Screen" is the first murder tale by a writer who hides his Identity under a penname, and, whether or not he is already well-known in other fields of literary work, the adjective that best applies to this story is promising.

Immediate adoption by a special session of Congress of an absolute neutrality bill to replace the present "hypocritical and ineffective legislation" was urged yesterday afternoon by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader.

In his speech explaining why there must be a general election in mid-November. Prime Minister BALDWIN gave several reasons which made the House of Commons more amused than convinced. One of them was that advantage should be taken of the "lull" in foreign affairs.

THE emergence of "Crime and Punishment" on Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall is, cinematically speaking, the outstanding event of the week. Though important in its own right, the Dostoevsky classic merits particular attention in this instance because Peter Lorre portrays the student Raskolnikov.

In the second drastic shake-up in a week Police Commissioner Valentine issued orders last night for the transfer at 8 o'clock this morning of seven police inspectors, four of whom have had charge of Brooklyn divisions.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 16. -- Gil Dobie had no chance to dry his tears today. His team went off Memorial Field in the evening chill of a near-freezing day after absorbing the most decisive beating a Cornell eleven has suffered in years at the hands of the Dartmouth Indians.

BORED with fashions? How can one be! Even when one has finished with buying new clothes there are always the accessories -- those baubles that brighten one up at all times of the day -- to be thought about.

DR. LOUIS I. NEWMAN'S "Hassidic Anthology," recently reviewed in these columns, has now a worthy companion volume in Dr. Jacob S. Minkin's "The Romance of Hassidism," which is not only a complete history of the remarkable religious movement which revolutionized the spirit of Jewry in the seventeenth century -- a movement which by no means is dead even now -- but is also a portrait gallery of the fascinating men who shaped and developed it.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- With the election safely and triumphantly over, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin pulled out his pipe, draw up in front of the fire at his country home, Chequers, and began to think seriously about the composition of the Cabinet, with which he will rule the nation for the next five years.

The resolutions adopted by the national Bankers' Convention at New Orleans dealt temperately and tactfully with the questions of public policy, concerning which the banking community and the Administration have been at odds. They had a good word to say for the Banking Act of 1935, for instance; they expressed belief in continuance of business recovery and disbelief in the theory that the recent pace of recovery means "inflation."

New York City's anti-noise campaign will be explained to officials of other cities tomorrow by Major Henry H. Curran, chairman of Mayor La Guardia's Noise Abatement Committee, in an address before the Conference of United States Mayors in Washington.

" SHARK?" queries the fish dealer. "No, no shark. But I could get it for you. Do you like shark?" He has plenty of devilfish today, however, and, nestling cozily among them, a repellent little purple object, which one does not need to have eaten to know for an octopus.

Making his second attack upon New Deal spending policies this Fall, former President Herbert Hoover proposed an eleven-point fiscal program as an alternative to those policies last night in an address before the Ohio Society of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 16. -- Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris again found himself in desperate circumstances tonight when, at the end of a session lasting five hours, the twentieth game of him match for the world chess championship with Dr. Marx Euwe of this citw was adjourned.
A charging Army defense came within a few seconds of defeating Notre Dame's football team at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

Cold weather stimulated retail trade in the metropolitan area at the week-end. Gains, however, were not sufficient to offset the decreases noted on other days of the week, with the exception of Armistice Day, and it was estimated that department store sales on the average just about equaled or fell below the 1934 figures for the period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A technical victory for Secretary Wallace and AAA officials who have opposed enforcement of the potato tax was recorded today when it was announced that Controller General McCarl had ruled that Emergency Relief funds are not available for administration of the act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Mayor Daniel W. Hoan of Milwaukee today branded as "absolutely untrue" any statements that States and cities now were in a position to take over the relief burden from the Federal Government.

Marshal Pietro Badoglio, successor of General Emilio de Bono as commander-in-chief of the Italian forces in Ethiopia, will return to a battleground with which he is familiar, because he directed the pacification of the Italian colony of Libya as military governor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16. -- A Statewide campaign for repeal of the California sales tax will be started soon by organized labor, Edward D. Vandeleur, president of the California State Federation of Labor, stated here today.

The rapid rise recently in cotton prices, which carried the December to around 12c a pound, attracted enough profit-taking and Southern selling to bring a setback of 7 to 11 points yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.
UNION, N.J., Nov. 16. -- The Panzer College eleven was defeated by Kutztown Teachers College at Tri-City Stadium today, 26 -- 0.

MR. VAN LOON is trying an experiment in this book. He says that it is "the first collection of bona fide broadcasts that has ever been printed." All other volumes, he believes, have been more or less edited before they have appeared as books.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The Baldwin government, at the beginning of a new five-year lease of power won this week by a generous vote of confidence from the British electorate, has a much freer hand in foreign policy than when it first took office in 1931.

FOR the first time in many years the United States Supreme Court is in the political spotlight. The role is not of its own choosing. It has been thrust upon it by event. The court has no alternative. In one form or another the Constitution will be an issue of the oncoming Presidential campaign -- probably a very important issue.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 16. -- A well planned but poorly executed prank, by which one of a pair of youths was to have made himself a hero in the eyes of the 13-year-old daughter of his employer, ended last night in the jailing of both youths.

GENEVA, Nov. 16. -- The successful efforts made in the last twelve years by the International Labor Office to improve conditions for Iranian child rug weavers brought it today an unusually valuable Khorassan rug.

HERE is a thrilling tale of a parson who turned pirate in order to avenge a great wrong that had been done him and who then turned parson again and tried to bury his wicked past. But the spirit of adventure had not died in him, and the past refused to remain buried.

Its store fronts festooned with bunting and banners proclaiming "Welcome, Bill Shakespeare," "We're Proud of You" and similar sentiments. Staten Island took time out last night to greet one of its sons who became a nationally known football luminary.

THIS November marks the eighteenth anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. According to Soviet law, citizens of the U.S.S.R. "come of age" on their eighteenth birthday, when they receive the right to vote.

GIRLS at the Fieldston School this year are having a chance to study the changing theories of "woman's place" throughout the ages. From primitive to modern times her role is illustrated for them by selected readings from more than 100 volumes, following a syllabus compiled through years of research by Margaret A. Koch and Elizabeth H. Day of the Fieldston history department.

MR. WEBB, one of the few genuine historians of the Southwest, has done a magnificent job in sifting the voluminous but often tedious and conflicting records of the Texas Rangers, and in writing, from the heart, the story of these tough, hard-riding, fast-shooting peace officers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Uniform legislation in the forty-eight States governing automobile drivers was urged before the American Automobile Association convention today as a measure to cut down motor accident deaths.

A CENTURY hence meteorologists will look back at our time and perhaps smile a little at our crude way of forecasting the weather. But they will also voice their gratitude for the exploration of the stratosphere that we began.

Skookum was a small but very hungry goat, with a talent for doing the wrong thing. Sandy discovered him, a wistful and lonely prisoner, pent up in a yard in the little Indian village in the Pacific Northwest, and promptly coaxed him away from the old Indian who owned him.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 16. -- In his annual report, released today, President James L. McConnaughy of Wesleyan University announced that gifts to the college for the fiscal year were $2,562,454, a sum greater than the total assets of the institution in 1900.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 16. -Brown won its first game this season by defeating Boston University today, 14 to 0.

The flaming resurgence of the Notre Dame spirit that made history at Columbus. Ohio, asserted itself again yesterday to earn the never-say-die Ramblers a 6-6 tie with Army in the closing forty-five seconds of an uproariously waged battle at the Yankee Stadium.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Old fashioned wooden paddles lustily applied to 19-year-old boys would reduce juvenile crimes, Dr. Harry R. Hoffman, director of the Cook County Behavior Clinic, said today.

More than 4,000 volunteer workers for the United Hospital campaign will begin solicitations tomorrow in an effort to raise at least $2,000,000 to help ninety-eight hospitals affiliated with the United Hospital Fund in their efforts to give free or below-cost care to the sick and injured.

MISS HARE, apparently, is not one to exhaust congenial material in a single book. Following her "Diary of a Pensionnaire," comes this new novel with an identical background, offering equal opportunities for light ironic wit.
AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Three Croats charged with complicity in the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia more than a year ago, will go on trial Monday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Work is "so much more amusing" than play to Mrs. Maude Howe Elliott, 81-year-old daughter of the late author and woman suffrage advocate, Julia Ward Howe.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 15. -- Kansas is becoming so excited over the growing boom for Governor Alf M. Landon for the Republican Presidential nomination that even Democratic leaders are beginning to pledge their support to him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Central Airlines, Inc., complained to the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the Pennsylvania Airlines and Transport Company has resorted to unfair competitive practices on the Washington-Detroit air route.

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden was the guest of honor at a luncheon given here recently by Count and Countess Costantini, the former Frieda Frasch Whiton. The other guests, numbering about thirty, included the Swedish Ambassador, Count Ehrensvard, and his wife, several members of the United States Embassy staff; Mr. and Mrs. Willing Spencer, who have just returned to Paris from the United States, and Mrs. H.H. Harjes.

THE most casual discussion of American literature has a way of becoming a serious discussion of American life. The novel for two decades, in the hands of Anderson, Lewis and Dreiser, has been variously documenting, denigrating and defying established society.

THE prospectus for the coming Metropolitan Opera season is out and one of its most interesting items is the standard repertoire from which the season operas will be selected. Thirty-six works are named, including Wagner's last nine, four by Verdi and five by Puccini.

A committee has been appointed to investigate the State rural education system. Similar committees have functioned several times within my recollection, but "the deestrick skool" seems to be an act of God and, like the weather, nothing can be done about it.

WARSAW, Nov. 15. -- This year's Polish Independence Day celebration on Nov. 11 was even more of an army show than when Marshal Josef Pilsudski lived. The army considers itself the true heir and guardian of the late dictator's ideals.

SHAKER handicrafts constitute a very interesting exhibition at the Whitney Museum, which will be on until Dec. 12. The material selected and arranged by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Deming Andrews, serves to bring to us evidence of the artistic expression of a New England religious sect; expression with which few hereabout are likely to have been previously familiar.

WITH the shortest day of the year a little more than a month away, the 50-meter wave band, because of its ability in darkness to span long distances, is becoming the stand-by for radio globe trotters.

A concert by Mme. Kirsten Flagstad, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera on the night of Dec. 11 at Carnegie Hall will benefit the National Music League, of which Mrs. Frederick Steinway is president. Proceeds will go to the opera department of the league, which furthers operatic appreciation in the schools by the frequent presentations of operas.
WHILE Cabinets and political disorders trouble France the Green Border Club of Paris strives to insure tranquillity in the home.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 16. -- Soundings made at Tarsus in Cilicia by a Joint archaeological expedition of Bryn Mawr College, the Archaeological Institute of America and Harvard University have assured the excavators of the discovery in the first season's work of "a cultural sequence beginning with about 1000 B.C. and going back we know not how far," according to a report from Miss Hetty Goldman, '03, the expedition's director.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- A demand for men to play the tunes that set soldiers and sailors to marching has arisen out of the plans to hire more fighting men for the nation.

LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 16. -- The Franklin and Marshall eleven displayed its greatest offensive strength of the season to overwhelm Dickinson today, 62 to 0, in an Eastern Pennsylvania Collegiate Conference game. Dickinson had won four straight before coming here.
GOSLAR, Germany, Nov. 16. -Side by side with the army, the Nazis are energetically building another "private" armed organization for work that the defense forces can't or won't perform.
THIS novel by the author of "Joseph and His Brethren" is, if anything, even more close to the soil. "Hester and Her Family" is indeed of the earth earthy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16. -- Gains in both retail and wholesale business, an active stock market and encouraging indications from a number of industrial sources lent much to improved sentiment throughout the Pacific Coast area.

WHATEVER its results in the field of the extension of scientific knowledge of the upper air -- and they promise to be large -all will rejoice at the perfect functioning from the aeronautic point of view of last week's balloon ascent to a record height of about fourteen miles by Captains Albert W. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson of the Air Corps.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The freighter Farnham, carrying 5,000 tons of scrap iron and steel, cleared tonight for Genoa, Italy. The Farnham is under British registry, owned by the Delta Steamship Company of London, reputedly operated with Italian capital.

AT her Carnegie Hall recital Wednesday, Dec. 11, for the National Music League, Kirsten Flagstad, Norwegian soprano, will be heard in a program including three operatic arias: "Leise, leise," from Weber's "Der Freischuetz"; Tu che la vanita conoscesti," from Verdi's "Don Carlos," and "La luce langue," from Verdi's "Macbeth."

THE police are ones more seeking to clear the Times Square area of Broadway of the peddlers and "pitchmen" who hawk fruits and candies, songbooks and workless watches, dolls and even dictionaries. Broadway's crowds usually find time to stop and listen to, if not to buy from, the fast-talking street salesmen, with a resultant blocking of traffic.

ANTWERP. -- "Look at that," said the Polish official, waving his arm across Warsaw. "Look and you will understand why we made the pact with Germany and why we have to spend upon our army so much of the money that is urgently needed for national reconstruction."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 16 (AP). -- Led by the flaming spirit and sensational performance of Captain Willie Geny, the Vanderbilt Commodores today defeated the University of Tennessee, 13 to 7, for the first time in nine years, before a crowd of 15,000 persons.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- The Drexel Institute eleven overwhelmed Delaware today, 34 -- 7.

WATER-COLORS, unusually in evidence in the early part of the present season, are again well represented in current exhibitions. Three shows by very different practitioners are on this week and deserve well at the hands of gallerygoers.
ROME, Nov. 16. -- Four American musicians were beaten by Black Shirts here, friends said today, after they laughed and failed to salute when a Fascist funeral passed by.

The prospect that the forthcoming Beaux-Arts Ball will be one of the gayest in the colorful history of these fetes is seen in plans for the episodes of pageantry and entertainment features, which have just been announced by the committee. The annual ball is to take place on Dec. 6 -- several weeks earlier than usual -- in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

SEATTLE, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Lumber operators and workers found common ground today in anxiety over a threatened increase in competition from Canadian sources as a result of the Canadian-United States trade pact.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Reports from the northern front in Ethiopia confirm the view earlier expressed that the next step following the Italian penetration to Makale would be the expansion of the front westward by bringing forward the right wing to the Takkaze River.

PARIS, Nov. 15. -- Once more, and it must be about the tenth time since the war, there is talk on both sides of the Rhine of the possibility, or at least the desirability, of getting rid of that spirit of bitterness, of fear and of rivalry between Germany and France which has so poisoned life in Europe.

THE team which won the Vanderbilt Cup last week for the second successive year has compiled an enviable two-year record. The four players who make up the team -- David Burnstine, Michael T. Gottlieb, Oswald Jacoby and Howard Schenken -have individually and as a team figured prominently in the winning of every important tournament since August, 1933.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov., 16. -- A Columbia season already made dismal by defeats at the hands of Penn, Michigan and Syracuse and no more than a tie with Cornell was rendered gloomier than ever today when the Lions had to submit to a drubbing at the hands of Navy.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The German Government emphasized anew its neutrality in the Anglo-Italian controversy today when it announced it had made representations to the British Government regarding the British demand for certificates of origin for all German exports to Britain.

The annual engagement between Evander Childs and James Monroe, traditional rivals, was the highlight of the fourth series of dual swimming meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the P.S.A.L., conducted yesterday in the 75-foot pool of De Witt Clinton High School.

ROME, Nov. 16. -- The 69-year-old General Emilio de Bono has been relieved of his command of Italian forces on the Eritrean front and recalled to Italy. His successor in command is Marshal Pietro Badoglio, chief of staff of all the Italian armed forces, who is very close to the royal family.

TATIANA TCHERNAVIN, author of "Escape From the Soviets," will arrive in this country early in January for an extended lecture tour under the management of William Feakins. Her new book, "We Soviet Women," will be published in January by E.P. Dutton Co.

Rounding out its eighth month of rising prices, the share market ended the week yesterday with an impressive demonstration of strength. In one of the busiest weeks of the year, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks reached its highest level since Sept. 8, 1931; nearly all classes of stocks participated in the advance, including such groups as the steels, foods and railway issues which had been laggard at times in recent weeks.

Striking back at critics of the reciprocal trade program, exporters will shortly announce formation of an organization known as the National Committee for Reciprocal Trade, to conduct a nation-wide campaign in support of the treaty undertaking.

Under General Gomez, Venezuela has become probably the most prosperous and forward-looking of all Latin-American countries, according to Henry E. Linam, president of the Standard Oil Company of Venezuela, who is here for a visit. Mr. Linam said Venezuela was the only Latin-American country free of foreign debts.

MARTIN MOONEY is a newspaper man in New York City who has specialized in crime reporting. His journalistic connections have been with that section of newspaperdom which exploits crime and criminals, in the belief that they furnish the news of highest consequence, which will draw the greatest number of readers and interest them the most keenly, and that, of course, has made it easy for him to develop his specialty.

A fashion show for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Association will be held on Thursday afternoon in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis. Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins. The proceeds will be used in providing vacations in the country for city children.

IN its immemorial swing, the art pendulum tempts to extremes that the wise learn to guard against. At most times we can if we will uncover, conveniently at hand, object lessons in the matter of snap or emotionally off-balance judgment.

WHEN Georges Duhamel's "Papa Pasquier" appeared in English a year ago, few knew that it was the beginning of another enormous French novel cycle, a la Proust, Rolland or Romains. But now that "The Fortunes of the Pasquiers" is before us, it seems no less natural than delightful for Duhamel to continue his full-flavored chronicle of French family life.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- Final estimates of retail trade for October put the gain over a year ago at 4 per cent and the mild weather early this month held the advance down to about 3 per cent. The lower temperature this week has turned demand to heavier and more expensive goods, which will raise the record for the first half of the current month.

A resolution opposing the holding of the 1936 Olympics in Berlin and urging the Olympic authorities to postpone or remove it was adopted yesterday at a special meeting of the German-American League for Culture.

Vv-/TJTJT, Mass., Nov. 16. -- President Tyler Dennett of Williams College and Mrs. Dennett gave a luncheon today at their home on Main Street for Dr. Stanley King, president of Amherst College, and Mrs. King. Fifty guests, including several of the Williams trustees and prominent alumni, attended.
OUR DELEGATE: In preparation for the forthcoming London Naval Conference, President Roosevelt had a conference in Washington last week with

BENEATH a sizzling sun in Africa white men and black men are rushing at each other's throats, the blue waters of the Mediterranean are dotted with the dull gray ships of Britain's navy and over the telegraph wires across Europe are speeding messages to and from the representatives of half a hundred nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -A ten-year slum clearance and low-rent public housing program, with an appropriation close to $1,000,000,000 to start it off, is under discussion in the Roosevelt Administration.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- Governor Lehman's notice to Mayors today concerning the coming increase in the home-relief burden brought the statement in official quarters that the number of persons whom the State and municipalities would have to support will be between 600,000 and 680,000.

As secretary of the British Association's Research on Climatic Changes, Moses B. Cotsworth emphasizes what many of us have previously known, that the Sahara Desert is creeping south, drying up lakes along 1,500 miles from Lake Tohad to Timbuctoo. Agricultural tribes are being driven toward the Equator.

Discussion of the relative merits of unemployment insurance and public relief will be directed by Glenn A. Bowers, director of Unemployment Insurance, New York State Department of Labor, at the Women's City Club civic luncheon on Tuesday at the clubhouse under the title, "What Price Security?"
With its offensive guns working from all ranges, Fordham defeated Muhlenberg, 45 -- 0, yesterday before 5,000 spectators at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The new reciprocal trading agreement with Canada, this country's second best customer in the markets of the world, illustrates more clearly than any of its six predecessors the meaning and scope of the foreign trade objectives which the Roosevelt Administration hopes to reach under the Trade Agreements Act it pushed through Congress in the Spring of 1933.

MR. HANSEN would be the last person to conceive of this novel of his as in any sense an important or significant work of fiction. He has read and appreciated too many books which merit that description; he has as a professional writer about books too well balanced a set of values, to be deceived by his own child.

PARIS. THE cinema season is going at full force in this town now and it is as easy to find good pictures as to fall off the proverbial log. Whatever else expatriated Americans miss in this once glamorous city they find no lack of Hollywood films.

Stocks ended the week yesterday active and strong in the heaviest trading for a half day since Feb. 10, 1934. Transactions on the Stock Exchange reached 1,639,480 shares, compared with 1,166,000 on the Saturday before. Steel shares led the advance, which, for many of the leaders, resulted in net gains of 1 to 2 3/4 points.

Under the sponsorship of the civics-education and the home economic departments of the Westchester Woman's Club of Mount Vernon, a panel discussion will be held on Wednesday night at the clubhouse on "Uprooting the Roots of War." The public is invited.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 16 (AP). A.A. Baroni's Top Row, son of Peanuts and twice conqueror of Discovery, won the third annual $15,000 added Waggoner Memorial Handicap today over a fast track. He ran the one mile and a furlong in 1:51.

General market activity last week was only fair, but there was an increased demand in various departments for special-price merchandise for promotional purposes, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Co.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 15. -- Nebraska Liberals received a severe nervous shock, followed by rapid recovery, this week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -The University of New Hampshire offered small opposition to the rushing and passing plays of Harvard's football team today, the Crimson registering six touchdowns to beat the husky but outclassed collegians from Durham, 41 to 0.

After five families had fled to the street when fire threatened a three-story building at 224 West Tenth Street last night, Miss Greta Spiro, 20 years old, a second-floor tenant, was rescued after she had been trapped by smoke in a front apartment.

OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 16. -- Bill Simon, veteran Curtis High School harrier, scored a brilliant triumph in annexing the individual honors in the eighth annual La Salle Military Academy invitation interscholastic cross-country race today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- When the trim little cutter Electra glides down the Potomac next Spring with President Roosevelt aboard it will become the fifth vessel used by Presidents for brief escapes from daily routine.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 16. -- After yesterday's calm, trouble was renewed here this morning when students of the Higher School of Arabic and Religious Studies gathered on the school grounds with the intention of staging anti-British demonstrations in the streets.

Juvenile delinquency will be the subject of an all-day conference Tuesday at the Bronx Woman's Club, 2,506 Davidson Avenue, in which fifty or more civic and welfare organizations in the borough will participate. The speakers, drawn from the legal profession and social-welfare organizations, include, for the afternoon session:

AT a confusing moment in the annals of mankind, Mr. Dangerfield has written a book that includes a missing word. "The war," he says, "hastened everything -- in politics, in economics, in behavior -- but it started nothing."
A fighting De Witt Clinton High School football team staged a gallant fourth-quarter comeback to down the James Monroe eleven, 18 -- 14, at Monroe Field yesterday.

Man never is but always to be blessed. That applies particularly to the saving of our Government and our society by the formation of a political third party steeped in radicalism. Governor OLSON of Minnesota is sure that such a party is necessary and will be created. But in his speech in this city on Friday evening he was a little indefinite about the date.

A striking example of how the symbolism and design of ancient art meet with modern decorative requirements can be seen in the unique work of two Peruvian artists, the sisters Elena and Victoria Izcue, who will exhibit their modern use of the ancient Peruvian art motif in this city next month.

I don't know what will make "the great American play." But I damn well know a good American play when I see it; and I saw it when I went to see Albert Bein's "Let Freedom Ring" at the Broadhurst last night. So far as a dozen excursions permit of Judgment, this seems to be the all around most important play on Broadway at the present time.

The jury that heard the evidence in the trial of Nick Montana, who was indicted for compulsory prostitution, after deliberating twenty-one hours reported at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon to Judge Cornelius F. Collins in the Court of General Sessions that it was hopelessly deadlocked and unable to reach a verdict.

But I damn well know a good American play when I see it; and I saw it when I went to see Albert Bein's "Let Freedom Ring" at the Broadhurst last night. So far as a dozen excursions permit of Judgment, this seems to be the all around most important play on Broadway at the present time.

The jury that heard the evidence in the trial of Nick Montana, who was indicted for compulsory prostitution, after deliberating twenty-one hours reported at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon to Judge Cornelius F. Collins in the Court of General Sessions that it was hopelessly deadlocked and unable to reach a verdict.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- New Rochelle High School's smooth-functioning football machine preserved its untarnished slate by repulsing White Plains, defending titleholder, 13-6, in a Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association contest today. The victory gave New Rochelle the undisputed lead in the league.

TORONTO, Nov. 16. -- Young Nick Metz, red-haired and a junior in amateur hockey only two seasons ago, scored two goals tonight and the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the New York Rangers, 3 -- 2, in their second engagement of the new National Hockey League season.

NEW YORK'S goal of 238 municipal playgrounds has been brought measurably closer to realization with the formal opening recently by Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Moses of twelve new play spots scattered about Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Apparently more impatient members of the Wafd, the largest party in Egypt, believe that the only way to win parliamentary government for their country is to take advantage of Great Britain's preoccupation with the delicate naval and military situation in the Eastern Mediterranean to annoy the British as much as possible in the hope of wresting the political concessions they have sought vainly in less disturbed times.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16. -- Hugh S. Gibson left for Rio de Janeiro today to resume his duties as United States Ambassador to Brazil after serving as a delegate to the Chaco peace conference here. Spruille Braden, the new United States peace delegate, arrived Wednesday and immediately assumed his duties as the United States representative at the conference.

SANTO DOMINGO. -- Just inside the San Diego gate, the ancient entrance through which almost every visitor passes from the waterfront into this historic city, there has just been painted on the old city wall a map of the Dominican Republic.

The names of 120 students of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science who have attained the honor roll by high scholastic standing were announced yesterday by Dean Archibald L. Bouton.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Lady Astor will enter the new Parliament as leader of the largest "family party" in the House of Commons. It will be a solidly Conservative party of four, with the fifth member, Viscount Astor, across the lobby in the House of Lords.

With Captain Hal Lube, veteran quarterback, scoring four touchdowns, the Flushing High School eleven overwhelmed Jamaica High, 38 to 0, in the eighteenth meeting of the traditional rivals before 4,000 persons at Memorial Field, Flushing, yesterday.

There was neither joy nor sorrow in the Notre Dame dressing room after the game, but an air of disappointment. Apparently the last-minute touchdown that tied the score was held secondary to the winning conversion that failed. The players dressed quietly and quickly, making hasty exits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Temple N. Joyce, prominent aircraft designer and builder, has resigned from the presidency of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation, at Newcastle, Del., and has become an executive of the Great Lakes Aircraft Corporation, at Cleveland, aviation authorities here have been informed.
DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 16. -- The Rose Bowl hopes of the highly touted University of North Carolina football team went a glimmering today under the smothering attack of an invincible Duke eleven.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Federal Government, as the biggest banker in the country, was disclosed today to be in a fair way toward becoming the nation's largest real estate owner and operator.

BERLIN. THE recently published book on Cromwell by Hermann Oncken, Berlin Professor of History, created a considerable sensation even among the general reading public because of its subtitle: "Four Essays on the Guidance of a Nation" (Grote, Berlin).

With the time-honored six-mile distance giving way for the first time to a five-mile route, the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. will conduct its twenty-seventh annual cross-country championships over the well-worn trails at Van Cortlandt Park this afternoon.

A sixty-four page pamphlet opposing American participation in the Olympic Games in Germany next year was issued yesterday by a Committee on Fair Play in Sports, of which George Gordon Battle and Dr. Henry Smith Leiper are co-chairmen.

The crucifixion of Christ was the one thing in His life that could have been foretold with absolute certainty, Bishop Edgar Blake of Detroit said in a sermon at the Broadway Methodist Episcopal Temple, Broadway and 174th Street, yesterday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Following a struggle of twenty years to carry on a service to homeless and friendless men in a small building in Mount Vernon, the Salvation Army dedicated this afternoon the largest rehabilitation centre in the United States on South Third Avenue and Columbus Avenue with special ceremonies in the presence of 2,000 visitors.

PARIS, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Three members of the Manhattan String Quartet, American musicians touring Europe, said today they would seek a United States protest to Italy because they had been beaten on the streets of Rome for their failure to salute a Fascist funeral procession.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 17. -- Wind and rain combined to call off the finals of the Northeast field hockey tournament on the Adelphi College fields today, it being impossible to play the four remaining association games and the traditional battle between the newly chosen Northeast and Northeast Reserve elevens.

Once again a football week-end has departed, leaving in its wake changed ideas and further indication that this has been very nearly the most unusual season of the past four or five. It leaves also the slow dawning of a belief that perhaps there are no really outstanding teams this year, just several rather good ones, with none sticking out head and shoulders above the rest.

Giosue Randazzo, 35 years old, of 30 Douglass Street, Brooklyn, kissed his wife and four children Saturday morning and went off hunting. He did not bother to go outside the city limits, heading instead for the Bay Meadows section of East New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Registration by utility holding companies with the Securities and Exchange Commission is not a mere formality but exposes the companies and their operating subsidiaries "to the possibility of drastic and destructive consequences," Philip H. Gadsden, chairman of the committee of public utility executives, said today.

The directors of the Schenley Distillers Corporation have called a special meeting of stockholders for Nov. 27 to authorize the creation of 200,000 shares of the 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of a par value of $100 a share, of which it is planned to sell 150,000 shares to bankers.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 17 (AP). -- James Patrick (Bubber) Byrne, halfback on the Notre Dame High School football team who bucked the line against death with the same courage that made him a gridiron favorite, died of blood poisoning tonight.

It is not necessary to add anything to the statements made in the excellent letters by Thomas W. Lamont and more recently by former Secretary of War Newton D. Baker in refutation of the idea that the United States entered the World War due to pressure by big business or bankers or munition makers.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17. -- National production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 54 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week and restoring the rate of two weeks before. The impressive feature of steel production is its steadiness in the last thirteen weeks, not paralleled for many years.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Allotments for 172 additional WPA projects in New Jersey, embracing twenty counties of the State and estimated to provide employment for 9,345 persons, were announced today by William H.J. Ely, Works Progress Administrator for the State.

The reciprocal trade treaty between the United States and Canada is the greatest single step toward the reduction of tariff barriers and away from economic nationalism that has been taken anywhere since the onset of the depression. As such it is not only a fine achievement in itself, but a hopeful augury of a wider restoration of international trade and sanity.

By President Roosevelt's appointment of John J. Kelly, Tammany leader of the Twenty-second Assembly District, as United States Marshal for the Southern District of New York, the Roosevelt group in this State has obtained the support of a powerful faction in Tammany regardless of the position of James J. Dooling, the leader, it was said yesterday by members of the Tammany organization.
ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, up-State Works Progress Administrator, announced today the allocation of $3,320,209 to up-State works projects.

The radio in patrol car 820 crackled at 6:05 A.M. yesterday as Patrolman Alphonse Hambsch steered through the fog and the rain past Second Avenue and Fifth Street. It was dark and the windshield wiper was working jerkily.

Opening the drive of the Parkhurst Memorial Committee, the Rev. George Drew Egbert, president of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, charged Governor Lehman in a sermon yesterday with permitting "outrageous" vice and crime conditions to flourish in Albany.

The annual memorial service for members of the Episcopal Actors Guild who died during the past year was held yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Tributes to nineteen actors were delivered by Edwin Milton Royle, playwright.

Completing his season by scoring two touchdowns against Amherst, Ed Stanley, Williams halfback, went further into the lead for individual scoring honors in Eastern intercollegiate football. Stanley has tallied sixteen touchdowns and two points after touchdowns for a total of 98 points, and leads his nearest rival, Vannie Albanese, Syracuse fullback, by 29.

GENEVA, Nov. 17. -- Fascist gratification over the United States neutrality policy continues, but the government has decided it is wiser no longer to express its pleasure, judging by secret instructions to the Italian press that are published in the Journal des Nations here.

The twentieth National Hotel Exposition will open in the Grand Central Palace at 2 P.M. today, preceded by a luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania. At 10:30 o'clock tonight, the Holy Greeters of America will give their fourth annual reception and ball at the Hotel Commodore.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The Short Hills Club remained undefeated and the Elizabeth Town and Country Club moved into second place in the New Jersey group of the metropolitan Class B Squash Tennis League as a result of today's matches.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- So many important developments have invaded the world's wheat markets recently that the trade is almost at a loss to move with assurance. Price fluctuations have been numerous and within a fair range during the week, while sentiment turned from the bear to the bull side, and Back again at the close.

THE Cadet players, spruced up in their soldier suits after the grim gridiron battle with Notre Dame, were coming out of the Yankee Stadium in the dusk and embarking in a big bus. One tall, black-haired Cadet had a grin on his face and a football half tucked under his uniform cape. That was Bill Shuler, the Army captain and left end.

Foreign exchanges were irregular last week. Changes were slight, however, since no great volume of business was involved and traders were disposed to await progress of developments in the Italo-African situation.

Thomas J. McMahon has been renominated for president of the National Democratic Club, and former Mayor James J. Walker has been renominated for member of its board of governors, according to an announcement made yesterday by George J. Atwell, chairman of the nominating committee.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17.--Rockefeller's Ace, international champion owned by W.C. Ely Jr. of Terre Haute, was named best of breed in the third annual Boston terrier specialty show today.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 17. -- Disappointment was expressed by leaders of the National Grange tonight over the trade agreement with Canada.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Trading in grain futures was larger and there was greater activity, especially in wheat, last week, while trading in corn, oats and rye decreased from the previous week. Compared with last year there was a decided gain in wheat, while in corn, oats and rye there were decided reductions. Comparisons follow:

ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 17. -- After a thirty-six-hour journey on mules, a field ambulance and army trucks, it is now possible for the first time to give a first-hand account of Brig. Gen. Oreste Mariotti's remarkable dash through the unexplored Danakil desert, of the battle of the Ende gorge and the three terrible days that followed it.

The United Air Lines Transport Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $304,566 after all charges for the quarter ended on Sept 30, equivalent to 29 cents a share on the outstanding stock. This compares with a net profit of $107,326, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter ended on June 30, and contrasts with a net loss of $426,934 in the first quarter of the year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- With lighter receipts and a better general demand, prices of hogs were on the upgrade here last week and at the close on Friday were 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds higher than a week before.

The condition of world merchant tonnage and of foreign trade were cited as an encouraging indication of recovery in statements issued yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping and the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.
GENEVA, Nov. 17. -- The League of Nations was ready tonight to begin its passive siege of Rome tomorrow.

No authorized assent of the holders of the outstanding 43,510 shares of unmodified guarantee 7 per cent stock of the Manhattan Railway Company was given to the recent tentative agreement for the city's purchase of the Interborough and Manhattan Railway rapid transit properties, according to a letter sent yesterday to the stockholders by Harold Palmer, chairman of a protective committee for that class of securities.
LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Great Britain's foreign trade in October made an extremely favorable impression, supplementing many other indications of increasing business.

AIX -EN-PROVENCE, France, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Recurrent reports of a plot to kill or kidnap three Croats before they go on trial for alleged complicity in the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia brought 1,000 policemen to guard duty here today.

High seas, borne inland by a tide estimated to be five feet higher than normal and driven by a northeast wind of fifty miles an hour, pounded the New Jersey coast yesterday from its southern tip to the Hudson River in a storm described as the worst in twenty years.

Except for cottonseed oil, wool tops and some of the metals, which advanced, and sugar, which was steady, commodities declined in price generally last week on the local futures markets. In the cash markets, corn, oats, flour, lard, butter, cotton and wool tops advanced, while the other grains, coffee, raw sugar, mess pork, eggs, antimony, quicksilver, tin, silk, rubber and hides declined.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 17 (AP). -- The Rose Bowl game pendulum swung sharply toward the Southwest today as three more teams dropped from the undefeated division yesterday on the gridiron battlefronts.

As a means of urging boys and girls of their age to make up their minds "whether they want to grow up to be useful citizens or cannon fodder," a group of 15 and 16-yearold students at Fieldston School, high school unit of the Ethical Culture Schools, has brought out a handbook about war.

With one member of her crew washed overboard, her boats smashed and pumps keeping the water below her fires, the Boston freighter Hartwelson got under way again last night after an all-day fight with the storm.

RAMSAY MACDONALD came out of the election defeated and sad, but time must show whether his hurts are enduring. "I am just completely done in," he said as he boarded the train at Seaham, the old constituency which rejected him.

According to Rinaldo Blast, the suave maitre d'hotel at the American Women's Association clubhouse, 361 West Fifty-seventh Street, the thousand or so folk who peopled the ballroom there last night and early this morning for the third annual supper dance of the Metropole Sporting Club were excellent spenders.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 18.--The Rengo (Japanese) News Agency reported from Hsinking today that Japan's powerful army in Manchuria "is prepared to use force" to prevent Chinese interference with an autonomy movement in North China.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Mayor-elect S. Davis Wilson announced tonight the appointment of five more members of his cabinet.

An unusual combination, a coloratura soprano and a chamber orchestra, gave a joint concert at the Town Hall last night. Beatrice Belkin was the singer, and the Vrionides Sinfonietta, conducted by Christos Vrionides, was the ensemble.

PARIS, Nov. 17. -- Firearms were used and fifteen people were seriously injured, some probably fatally, at Limoges last night when a clash occurred between members of the Croix de Feu and Socialist opponents.

Obligations of the United State Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,896,025,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, note and non-interest bearing discount bills.

Mr. RAMSAY MACDONALD takes the demonstration against him in Seaham more tragically than an Englishman would. He is an imaginative Celt. After all, to end in the House of Lords is neither a cruel nor an unusual punishment. No doubt his sadness will pass away just as the campaign ferocities will soon be forgotten.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 17. -- Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador, angrily rebuked representatives of an anti-Nazi student group in a press conference at the University of Wisconsin today.

Kathleen Wells, a featured radio soprano, was injured fatally at 4:45 o'clock yesterday morning when an automobile in which she was returning to her home at 285 Arlington Avenue, Jersey City, from an engagement in Jamaica, Queens, was in collision with a milk truck at Grand and Varick Streets, Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Domestic distilling interests predicted tonight that the 50 per cent cut in duty on Canadian aged whisky, announced in the new reciprocal agreement would "pull down" the price of higher quality whiskies. "The new agreement will probably have no effect on the dollar-a-pint class of whisky," said Dr. J.M. Doran, director of the Distilled Spirits Institute, "since that is about as cheap now as it ever will be."
Upton Sinclair and Norman Thomas debated the merits of the EPIC plan last night before more than 2,000 persons in Mecca Temple, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- A claim that the PWA slum clearance division "has aided in giving a new direction to the creation of housing for the American people" was advanced today as Secretary Ickes reported that 18,400 of the 19,500 projects under the old PWA program were completed or under construction.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. James E. Brady gave a dinner in the President's Suite at the Greenbrier tonight for Mr. and Mrs. William W. Luke.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 17. -- Although Egyptian authorities fear the disturbances of the past few days are only the beginning of more serious developments, no demonstrations occurred anywhere in the country today. Student feelings, however, are still running high, as was shown by an incident this morning.

In a beautiful fawn-colored coat, Hans Khoo Hansi of Merricka, the splendid pekingese owned by Mrs. Philip M. Schaffner of Merrick, L.I., was placed at the top of 149 toy dogs in the third annual exhibition of the Progressive Dog Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe will present a program of "Les Sylphides," "Scheherazade" and "Prince Igor" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The government reported today that one-sixth of the relief population comprised youths between the ages of 16 and 25.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Canada and the United States, in their trade treaty, grant to each other most-favored-nation treatment and minimum tariff rates on every commodity accorded to any country apart from components of the British Empire on the one hand and United States possessions and Cuba on the other.
