NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85, which compares with 85 the week before, 85 two weeks before, 85.8 three weeks before and 85.5 four weeks before.

The Empire Theatre reopens its distinguished doors tonight to a pair of returning veterans -- to George C. Tyler, who presents "For Valor," and to Frank Craven, who staged and plays a leading role in it (his first Broadway appearance since "Riddle Me This" in 1932).
The steamer Florida, a 3,005-ton freighter belonging to the Record Steamship Lines of 50 Broad Street, wirelessed the owners last night that she was in trouble off Norfolk.

New York Chapter of the American Red Cross yesterday began the second week of its campaign to raise $400,000 for relief and other helpful services in Manhattan and the Bronx. It will continue until Thanksgiving. Fifteen more churches associated themselves with the two hundred and sixty already active in behalf of the drive.

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- Having provided juridically for the elimination of German Jewry by every means short of actual massacre, the leaders of National Socialists are endeavoring to justify their actions to their own people by a reinterpretation of history.

The Federal Theatre Project of the WPA has been "hamstrung" by the Actors Forum, it is charged by the administration of the Actors Equity Association in the November issue of Equity Magazine, just published.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 17. -- The storm today struck with greatest force and caused most damage at the eastern end of Long Island. At a late hour more than 500 persons were stranded on Shelter Island and at Orient without means of receiving food or mail or of reaching the mainland until the storm abated.

The question of whether it is fair to withhold birth control information from families who are on relief will be discussed at a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall the evening of Dec. 2 and the public asked to decide the issue, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Birth Control League under whose auspices the meeting will be held.

Teaching that once was considered an art is now considered a science the Rev. Leonard Feeney of Boston College declared in an address to 1,500 members of Theta Phi Alpha gathered at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, for their annual communion breakfast.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17 (AP). -- High winds and tides combined tonight to damage Connecticut shore communities.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- Shipping was paralyzed, airplane traffic stilled and land transportation greatly delayed in New England today as rain, snow and sleet, swept by gales, raked the coast and angry seas tore at the coastline.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The American Bar Association's standing Committee of Professional Ethics and Grievances held today that the American Liberty League's National Lawyers' Committee violated no canon of legal ethics in offering free legal services to citizens without funds to defend their Constitutional rights.

CRACOW, Poland, Nov. 17. -- American soil from historical places in all forty-eight States and United States possessions was mingled today with Polish soil in the mound erected in Sowiniec, on the outskirts of Cracow, in memory of Marshal Josef Pilsudski.

Two days after Christmas, Doubleday, Doran will open what is generally referred to as the "Spring" publishing season, by bringing out "The Sound Wagon," a novel by T.S. Stribling, a recent Pulitzer Prize winner. Politics provide this novel's background.

Amateur hockey returned to Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, and despite a game which was marked by the hardest sort of play the result left something wanting. In an overtime period neither the New York Rovers nor the Hershey sextet was able to count, and so the fray ended in a 1-1 tie.

I have read with considerable interest the Nov. 1 issue of The Consumer, published by the consumers' division of the National Recovery Administration. By executive order it is stated that the purpose of the consumers' division is "to review public policy in so far as it relates to the consumer * * * and to promote larger and more economical production of useful goods."

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 17. -- Without making another move and recognizing the hopelessness of his plight, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, today announced his resignation in the twentieth game of his title match with Dr. Max Euwe of this city.

Real estate activity in the city over the week-end was featured by the sale of an apartment building in the Bronx, a sale and various leasehold deals in Manhattan and the purchase of two houses in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Though mourning his slain son, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Root mounted the pulpit of St. Simon's Episcopal Church today and pleaded with the world to forgive the slayer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today eleven registration statements for securities having a total value of $9,766,332. The statements, filed under the Securities Act of 1933, are described as follows:

Some were so foolish as to expect that Mr. HOOVER in his speech before the Ohio Society on Saturday evening would announce that he is a candidate for re-election. That he did not do, but made a speech which plainly indicates his determination to assert himself as titular leader of the Republican party.

A luncheon and fashion show in aid of the West Side Thrift Shop will be held tomorrow in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Guests have been requested to bring packages of useful articles suitable for sale later at the shop, at Columbus Avenue and Ninety-first Street, a permanent institution maintained for the benefit of charitable organizations.

While going through Central Park on my way to the subway this morning I noticed a group of interested spectators gathered about the outdoor cage in which several small monkeys have been kept during the recent warm weather. Inside the cage were four workmen armed with poles, on the ends of which were a species of bag or net, and with metal rods or poking sticks.

Primitive life among the Chama Indians, living on the shores of the Ucayali River in Eastern Peru, will be shown in a new model village placed on exhibition at the American Museum of National History today.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 16. -- The Dutch monetary situation shows complete recovery. Private discounts are now at 3 1/8 per cent, against 5 3/4 per cent at the end of September. Other money rates show similar trends. Considerable funds are flowing back to Holland, as illustrated by a recent loan of 4,000,000 guilders, privately and easily placed by the government at 4 per cent, and by better terms for Treasury tenders.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- A $6,000,000-a-year "business" by a murdered gang chief was cited by J. Edgar Hoover today to show how "the leech of racketeering" is draining the country's resources.

The admiration of Miss Olga Ostergard of 315 Riverside Drive for Will Rogers is expressed in her own memorial to the cowboy humorist in the form of a life of Rogers as told in newspaper and magazine stories.

With retailers placing a substantial volume of fill-in orders for apparel and other lines for immediate delivery, various branches of the wholesale markets here were fairly active last week. There was also a steady demand for all types of holiday lines as stores completed preparations for Christmas.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Rumors that Ras Ayelu Burru, Ethiopian commander of the Setit River front, is likely to come over to Italy soon coincided today with speculation over a possible change in the whole character of Italy's military operations in Northern Ethiopia under Marshal Pietro Badoglio, the new high colonial commander.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17. -- The threat that the proletarian capital will become the most expensive city in the world for foreigners after Jan. 1 as a result of the Kremlin decree fixing the ruble at 20 cents is having its effect as well on a small percentage of the Soviet population that is dependent on remittances from abroad.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- "The forgotten man" of Colgate's football squad, Harry (Pete) Ritchko of Oneonta, N.Y., hero in the conclusive 27-0 victory over Syracuse yesterday, today was the toast of students, coaches and local football fans.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Ten letters written by Napoleon and five written by Marie Louise are among the collection of the official and private papers of Prince Eugene Beauharnais which have been placed on deposit in the library of Princeton University by Andre De Coppet, '15, of New York City, James T. Gerould, university librarian, announced today.

Lieutenant Fred R. Weber of the New York Athletic Club, sixth in the nation's seeding of epee fencers. came through brilliantly yesterday in the first of the Olympic series of epee tryouts staged by the Amateur Fencers League of America on the strips of the Fencers Club.

Service to God, whether in Labrador or New York, can be found in the simple things of life and need not be sought in abstract truths, Sir Wilfred Grenfell said yesterday at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, who began to turn a mildly critical fire on the Washington scene two years ago, ran up his battle flags today as a foe of the Roosevelt administration policies.

Some of the gifts the Nantucket seamen made for their women folk a hundred years ago when Nantucket Island was one of the world's leading whaling ports are to be seen at the fourth annual exhibition of American folk arts. The exhibition is sponsored by the National Committee on Folk Arts of the United States, and it will be opened to the public today at the committee's headquarters, 673 Fifth Avenue.

The continued need for the humanitarian services provided by private charitable agencies irrespective of public relief programs was stressed at the opening dinner of the 1935 campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies last night in the Hotel Commodore.

A howling northeaster lashed the Atlantic Coast yesterday from Cape Cod to Cape Hatteras, menacing ships at sea, pounding shorefront property to splinters and causing property damage estimated in New Jersey alone at more than $1,000,000.

An effort to remove a blemish from the reputation of the American eagle and shift it to combative small boys and imaginative country news correspondents took shape yesterday in an announcement by the National Association of Audubon Societies.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17. -- The comment in Ottawa official circles tonight is that the new Canadian-American trade treaty restores the United States to the status she enjoyed in 1930 and gives Canada a number of concessions denied to her then.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- New revenues available to New York State cities and villages from sources other than taxation would be only a "drop in the bucket" in reducing local tax burdens on real estate, even if utilized to the full limit of their productiveness.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- As foreseen, the Bank of France's return for Nov. 8 shows a decrease of 667,000,000 francs in the gold reserves, and already it is considered certain that the next return will disclose a further outgo at least equal to the one just announced.

Any idea of warfare between the United States and Canada Is "something abhorrent, like a war between two brothers," the Rev. Dr. F.W. Kerr of St. Andrew's Church, of the United Church of Canada, Montreal, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Eleventh Street.

Eugene List, 17-year-old American pianist, played an audition for Otto Klemperer last week and was engaged to appear as soloist under him with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on Dec. 19, 20, 21 and 22 in the first New York performance of Dimitri Shostakovitch's piano concerto.

Interest in the Bible is currently increasing, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia University, said yesterday at the 11 A.M. service in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus. The service was in commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the printing of the first complete English Bible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The Agricultural Adjustment Administration has expended $204,156,727 to date in buying farm surpluses, a survey disclosed today. Of this sum about $187,540,089 has been or will be recovered in cash or is represented by commodities distributed to the needy and unemployed, AAA officials said.

CHICAGO. Nov. 17. -- Action of the oats market during the week was not such as to attract new business. Price changes, from day to day, were small and cereal interests furnished a large part of the trading. Price advances brought out fair liquidating sales which were readily absorbed.

James D. Mooney, president of the American Manufacturers Export Association, predicted last night a steadily growing two-way trade as a result of the new American-Canadian trade treaty, according to The Associated Press.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- Germany's export surplus of 55,000,000 marks in October entirely obliterated her import surpluses in the earlier months of the year. The export surplus in the first ten months of 1935 was 24,000,000 marks, against an import surplus of 250,000,000 marks in the same months of 1934.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Democrats were quick to retort to the views expressed by former President Hoover in his speech in New York last night.
ADOWA, Ethiopia, Nov. 17. -- Two sharp combats between a band of irregulars from General Pietro Maravigna's column and enemy forces were reported today in the vicinity of the Takkaze River.

No doubt the primary reason for last week's financial cheerfulness was the evidence, presented in the week's industrial statements, that this Autumn's forward movement was not destined, after culminating in October, to be sharply reversed. That had been the fate of each movement of the kind which occurred at other seasons during 1934 and 1933.
" Hunter Lost Three Days Is Found in Maine," was the headline in yesterday's newspaper.

With the utmost ease and outward composure, Webster Aitken gave a performance of Beethoven's "Thirty-three Variations on a Waltz by Diabelli," at his debut recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, that was uncanny in its complete comprehension of the great masterpiece for one of his years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Ken Strong, a celebrated invalid, hobbled out from the Giants' bench early in the third quarter of today's National Football League game at Wrigley Field and kicked a field goal from the 14-yard line to give the New Yorkers a 3-0 victory over the Chicago Bears.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- In the last week the Bank of England has added 1,149,382 to its gold holdings, the total of which is at the high record of 197,556,588. Since the beginning of the year the Bank has acquired 4,332,895 in gold, most of which has been bought since the middle of August.

The day, Nov. 18, set for the beginning of sanctions against Italy, finds the Italian Government in a mood both of protest and retaliation Threatened with a trade boycott, it talks about setting up a more stringent one of its own. If Italy is to be injured by having her foreign commerce throttled, the loss will also be inflicted upon others.

I have been much interested in the items in THE TIMES concerning plants found in blossom during the last few days. Here is a list compiled by the botany class at Wells College after a field trip on Nov. 11.

Government subsidization of the American merchant marine under control of the Navy Department of the Department of Commerce rather than the Post Office Department will be one of the most important considerations of the 1,500 leading steamship operators and owners now in conference at the Waldorf-Astoria.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., Nov. 17. -- With all traffic stopped by floods, Beach Haven is isolated from the outside world tonight, except for communication by boat and one remaining telephone line. As a result of high wind and abnormally high tide, water covered a seven-mile stretch between Beach Haven and Tuckerton.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Chief Executives of America's greatest metropolitan areas gathered here today to consider the grave problem of caring for the hungry and destitute.

In Mark Twain's relation of his experience as editor of a country weekly he tells of a correspondent who asked if it was true that a fish diet promoted brain growth, and, if so, how much fish he should eat. Mark's reply was: "If you are a Republican, and believe in a protective tariff, I advise you to eat a whale; one large whale or two medium-sized whales."

A mortgage for $28.000 on 88 Amsterdam i Av., held by Frederlcl W. Marks from Alma Blohm and laullne G. Hayward, has been extended to Nov. 2, 1940, at 6 per cent. A new mortgage for $500 given by Sam Klrel to the Et Side Renovating Company, Inc., has been consolidated with a prior mortgage to form one lien for $5,500 on 86 Sheriff St. and extended to lov. 1. 1940, at 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Denying that the Roosevelt administration has been responsible for improvements in general conditions and threatening to "tell the facts based on the record," Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, promised today to continue a series of articles in "Facts and Opinions," until the detailed record had been told.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- In financial circles here it was conceded that the raising of the official bank rate has had the effect of increasing the already heavy burden on the treasury, which, likewise, has had to raise from 3 to 4 per cent the interest on the bonds it issues and renews every three months to the amount of 15,000,000,000 francs to cover current requirements.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 17. -- A driving northeaster, accompanied by a torrential downpour with occasional snow flurries in the early morning, caused the postponement today of the running of the open all-age stake, the final and most important event of the fourth annual field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The Detroit Lions, with Earl (Dutch) Clark supplying the spark, stayed in the running for National Football League honors by defeating the Green Bay Packers, 20 to 10, today before a crowd of 14,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17. -- Atlantic City and three neighboring communities were entirely cut off from automobile traffic from the mainland for a time today after rising tides whipped inshore by a strong northeast wind flooded the three boulevards leading to the city.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- The New York Rangers, worn by their strenuous campaigning last week including a hard match at Toronto last night, took a 3-to-0 beating from the Chicago Black Hawks tonight before a crowd of 14,500 in the Chicago Stadium.
SHANGHAI, Nov. 17 (AP). -- A new wave of apprehension swept Northern China tonight, intensified by Japanese military movements along the Great Wall.

Viewed From several angles, the past week-end produced one of the most surprising batches of results recorded in the scholastic football world this Fall. A number of topnotchers won by large scores which exceeded expectations, a few dropped from the unbeaten ranks even after obtaining leads, but in some cases, notably those of Exeter and Curtis High, the startling element was the manner in which they achieved their successes.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 17. -- Hubert Fauntleroy Julian left this capital on the morning train today for Jibuti, French Somaliland.

Jim Browning, former heavyweight wrestling champion of the world, will oppose Chief Little Wolf of Albuquerque, N.M., in the feature exhibition at Madison Square Garden tonight. They will wrestle to a finish.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 17. -- Hubert Fauntleroy Julian left this capital on the morning train today for Jibuti, French Somaliland.

If the exhibitions in the local galleries this week are somewhat fewer than in the preceding days of the season, they make up in variety for any falling off in number. For they range from the folk art of Nantucket Island to early Hindu sculpture and the latest creations of the Ecole de Paris.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Mutual tariff concessions on commodities representing a large part of the trade between Canada and the United States, which in the economic heyday of 1928-29 ran to the billion-dollar level, were granted in the reciprocal trade agreement, whose details were made public today at Washington and Ottawa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Administration officials looked to the Supreme Court tonight for possible rulings tomorrow which may speed or retard constitutional tests of New Deal legislation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17. -- St. Mary's Galloping Gaels combined line cracking and accurate kicking today to defeat their oldest football rivals, University of Santa Clara's Broncos, 10 to 0, before 59,000, the largest crowd of the season in San Francisco.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The British Government is now obliged to consider the attitude it will take toward Soviet Russia, this question having become a major issue of foreign policy. The reasons for this are as follows:

With a special blessing received by cable from Pope Pius XI, the celebration of the 150th anniversary of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, Barclay and Church Streets, began yesterday. The edifice, a downtown landmark, is the second to stand on the same site.

Another house sold out to the last inch of standing room marked Martha Graham's second recital of the season at the Guild Theatre last night. Neither the disagreeable weather nor the fact that the program contained no novelties beyond those introduced at last week's recital had any apparent effect on the situation in respect to numbers or enthusiasm.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The outcome of the British elections, it is felt here, portends no change in the foreign policy at Westminster. If anything, it means less anti-German spirit than would be the case with a Labor administration. Also, it is reasoned, Prime Minister Baldwin is inclined to avoid precipitate measures in the Italo-Ethiopian situation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Willie Hoppe, maintaining his place as the leading contender in the play for the world's three-cushion billiard championship, tonight defeated the defending titleholder, Johnny Layton, 50 to 49, in fifty innings. Hoppe had a high run of 7 while Layton's best effort was 6. It was Hoppe's seventh triumph in eight starts.

Rapid transit lines, street railways and buses carried 2,909,600,000 passengers in the city during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1935, representing a gain of 24,600,000, or nine-tenths of 1 per cent, over the traffic for the previous fiscal year, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.

The possibility that Congress may pass a soldiers' bonus bill over the President's veto in January and print paper money to provide the necessary $2,500,000,000 was called to public attention in a "warning" issued yesterday by eighty members of the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy.

Mark Graves, president of the New York State Tax Commission, revealed yesterday that he would file this morning an assessment of $487,299 against three poultry corporations with headquarters in Hoboken but doing about 95 per cent of their business in this city.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17. -- Outlining Yale's plans for the Harvard game week, Head Coach Ducky Pond tonight ordered the entire squad to report tomorrow for the first session of a four-day program. Practice scrimmaging for the 1935 season has passed into history, and drill in timing and blocking with some individual specialties and signal rehearsals will comprise the final week's effort.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 17. -- The national Foreign Trade Convention at which leading American exporters and importers meet annually with the bankers who finance their trade and with representatives of foreign countries to discuss the problems of international business will open here tomorrow and will last through Wednesday.
President Roosevelt rejected yesterday the demand of the Knights of Columbus that his administration act to halt "persecution of religion by the Mexican Government."
ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Construction employment and payrolls showed a slight increase for October, Industrial Commissioner Andrews reported today.

The great radio audience who listened to the broadcast of the Armistice Day services must have felt that there never was a more moving occasion. The addresses appealing to the universal conscience were filled with both anxiety and hope, realizing that the sacred significance of this day was at stake in this world crisis; also that evil does not destroy evil but propagates its kind; that increase of armaments merely prepares for further conflict.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- President Roosevelt today declared that permanent advisory planning boards were a need of every unit of government from towns up to the national government. He issued his statement in making public a report on State planning submitted to him by the National Resources Committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The text of the general statement regarding the trade agreement between the United States and Canada as issued by the State Department is as follows:
The Canadiens of Montreal failed to enter into the spirit of things last night when they helped the New York Americans open their campaign on home ice at Madison Square Garden.

ROME, Monday, Nov. 18. -- Last midnight was the zero hour for economic hostilities between Italy and the "sanctionist" powers, which hostilities will rage more bloodlessly but perhaps with more far-reaching results than the warfare in East Africa.

The breach in the Socialist party between the "Old Guard" in control of the city and State organization and the left wing, led by Norman Thomas, with a majority on the national executive committee, was widened yesterday. Both sides took steps to carry the factional contest before the national convention in May.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- This city today had legalized Sunday movies for the first time in its history. About 300 theatres took advantage of the outcome of the referendum of Nov. 5, at which Philadelphia voted more than 2 1/2 to 1 in favor of permitting the exhibition of movies after 2 P.M. on Sundays.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17. -- With the Eastern racing season entering its final fortnight at Bowie tomorrow, it is safe to say that Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt will head the American list of money-winning owners, marking the first time a Maryland establishment has held that distinction in twenty years.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 17. -- The House committee will submit a majority report this week recommending ratification of the commercial treaty with the United States, it is reported by the newspaper Pais as a well-founded rumor. It is reported that the minority will oppose some phases of the treaty.

A letter sent to President Roosevelt last Friday by the Merchants Association, saying it was important for business advancement "for business to know where it stands with the government," was made public yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, president of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The text of the trade agreement between the United State and Canada, signed at Washington Nov. 15, and the text of the Canadian note on valuations handed to the Secretary of State by the Canadian Prime Minister at the signing of the agreement follow:

President Roosevelt's letter, setting forth his refusal to intervene in the Mexican church situation, will "be immediately interpreted on both sides in Mexico as permission to the persecutor to go ahead," the Rev. Wilfred Parsons, editor of the Catholic weekly America, commented yesterday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 18. -- The National Grange, by an unanimous vote of delegates, called upon the national administration tonight to rescind its new reciprocal trade treaty with Canada. Adopting a report of the legislative committee, the Grange said: ...

The new lines of resort and Summer cottons for 1936 were previewed yesterday by more than 100 department store executives, resident buyers and fashion experts at a showing held by the Cotton-Textile Institute at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Many colorful, new weaves, textures and finishes, embracing the entire ranges of dress fabrics, were displayed.

TORONTO, Nov. 18. -- Distillers, cattle exporters, lumbermen and the Canadian housewife are jubilant over the new Canada-United States trade agreement, expressions of opinion here indicate. There is a diversity of opinion in other groups.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Part of the Greek manuscript of the Gospel According to St. John, which apparently lay for centuries on a rubbish heap in Egypt, has been discovered among an old collection of papyri in the Rylands Library at Manchester.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 18. -- The Brazilian-American reciprocity trade treaty was signed today by Speaker Antonio Carlos de Andrada, thus becoming a legal instrument but still awaiting President Roosevelt's signature. It was signed by the Speaker because the new Constitution vests power exclusively in Congress to conclude commercial treaties.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18. -- Nine objections to the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board were filed with the board today by Earl F. Reed of Pittsburgh, counsel for the Wheeling Steel Corporation, when the board opened hearings here today to consider a petition for an election of collective bargaining representatives filed by five lodges of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP). -- Presentation of evidence to a Saratoga County grand jury in one phase of the State's investigation into fake racetrack tipster services is expected to be completed within twenty-four hours, officials said tonight.

The Appellate Division upheld yesterday a decision by Supreme Court Justice Black refusing to reduce a verdict of $10,000 awarded a poor woman in a suit against the Second Avenue Railroad on a plea of the railroad company that the verdict was excessive for a person of her "social class."

ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 18. -- A clash of Italian troops with the Ethiopian force under Ras Seyoum appears to be drawing near. This redoubtable chieftain is Italy's most important foeman in Northeastern Ethiopia.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18. -- The list of patronesses for the Prince-Tiger dance to be held in the Princeton University gymnasium next Friday was announced here today by Henry P. McNulty, '36, of New York, chairman of the dance committee.

ROME, Nov. 18. -- The first day of sanctions passed off here amid an almost festive mood more befitting a day of national rejoicing than one marking the start of a period that will surely entail hardship for all Italians and actual suffering and want for many.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- Having made the most of her export embargo, which has been effective for two days, Germany -- publicly at least -- assumed toward the League sanctions imposed against Italy today the attitude of an innocent bystander forced to watch a fight with brickbats which does not concern her, but which she fears might break her own windows.

Although "Outposts of Science," by Bernard Jaffe, is the Scientific Book Club choice for November, it will not be published until Nov. 25, when Simon Schuster will issue it. The book represents four years' work, much of the material having been gathered during visits to fifty research laboratories of this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Seeking an early agreement among producers and State and Federal authorities on a milk compact in which the government can legally offer its aid, the Milk Section of the AAA today assigned E.M. Harmon, one of its agents, to discuss proposals with heads of the groups in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area.

The Kings County grand jury which is investigating the Druckman murder case gave almost its entire attention yesterday to hearing the story of Detective Charles S. Corbett, who is said to have hinted several months ago that a $100,000 bribe was offered to "throw" the case.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Nov. 9 amounted to 299,722,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines of the Department of the Interior. Compared with the previous week, this total shows a decline of 1,261,000 barrels, comprising a decrease of 1,372,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude petroleum and an increase of 111,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude.

MAKALE, Ethiopia, Nov. 18. -- General Emilio de Bono today handed over his command of the Italian armies in East Africa to General Melchiade Gabba, his chief of staff, and left the front to return to Rome.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 18. -- Nassau County will soon have a traveling District Attorney's office for the investigation of crime in the "open spaces." District Attorney Martin W. Littleton received permission today from the Nassau County Board of Supervisors to purchase a truck and trailer to be sent on short notice to the scene of a crime.

TOKYO, Nov. 18. -- North China will set up an autonomous government divorced from Nanking this week, according to the unanimous testimony of Japanese correspondents in the North China capital. Five provinces are expected to sign the declaration of independence.

For "professional achievement, for public service and for personality,'' Mrs. Helen Rogers Reid, vice president of The Herald Tribune, last night received the medal of award at the Friendship dinner at the American Woman's Association clubhouse in the ninth of the series of annual affairs sponsored by organizations of business and professional women.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- With the assertion that cessation of the relief activities of the Federal Government next year was "simply unthinkable and impossible," Mayor La Guardia of New York called upon the United States Conference of Mayors today to formulate specific recommendations for relief appropriations at the next session of Congress.

Lou Tellegen, actor, who committed suicide at Los Angeles, on Oct. 24, 1934, left an estate of about $300 and no will, it became known yesterday when letters of administration were issued to his widow, Julia Thorne Tellegen of the Hotel St. Andrew.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 18. -- New Jersey's population will continue to increase more rapidly than that of the nation at large for some years to come, the New Jersey State Planning Board predicts in its first annual report, which was submitted to Governor Harold G. Hoffman here today.

The Grand Central Galleries are particularly active this week with respect to openings. At the Fifth Avenue establishment (corner of Fifty-first Street) a one-man show of paintings by Howard Chandler Christy opened with a reception yesterday afternoon, while in the Grand Central Terminal headquarters two exhibitions will open today.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- The following statement on the incident in Rome, when members of the Manhattan String Quartet were molested by Blackshirts, was made by members of the quartet at the United States Embassy here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Secretary Wallace today assured the farmers of the country that the reciprocal tariff treaty agreed upon with Canada would improve their lot in the long run. Dairymen's representatives, however, appeared to be divided on the merits of the treaty so far as that industry is concerned.
Arguments for more liberal use of buildings housing legitimate theatrical productions were presented to the Aldermanic Committee on Buildings at City Hall yesterday.

The popular conception of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer as a gangster chieftain of fabulous wealth, was reduced yesterday to the portrait of a harassed man dying a pauper's death, according to the testimony of his relatives, accountant and attorney before Deputy State Tax Commissioner Seth T. Cole.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- Declaring that the purpose of "loss leaders" is to attract customers and that it is no more destructive of competitors than are other forms of advertising, Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close held unconstitutional New York State's Fair Trade Act in a decision handed down here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- George N. Peek, chairman of the Export-Import Banks, has brought back with him from an extended vacation in the farm belt two economic platforms of eight planks, each of which graphically illustrates his divergence from the agricultural, tariff treaty, monetary and other key policies of his associates in the government.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, Nov. 18. -- The bodies of six drowned men, evidently Russians, have been discovered along the Finnish coast northwest of the Russian naval base of Kronstadt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- An inquiry covering a group of real estate bond houses will be started with public hearings here on Thursday, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. Real estate projects in New York, Chicago, San Francisco and other cities will come under scrutiny, it was indicated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Treasury tabulation of relief outlay to Oct. 31, under the Emergency Relief Appropriation Act of 1935, including approval of projects by the President, definite allocations of funds toward these projects, and actual cash disbursements, is as follows:

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, sent out yesterday invitations to the party leaders of the more populous counties of the State to a conference today at the National Republican Club to discuss the selection of leaders in the next Republican-controlled Assembly and to receive advice on a legislative program.

GOESCHENEN, Switzerland, Nov. 18. -- Traffic through the great Saint Gothard tunnel, the chief link between Germany, Switzerland and Italy, reached an all-time peak today, railway men here said as the League of Nations economic sanctions against Italy went into effect.

The headquarters of the New York City committee of the Will Rogers Memorial Fund reported yesterday that on Saturday $2,500 in small contributions had been received as the city's tribute to the cowboy humorist. This total, a record single day's receipts at the city headquarters, represented the contributions of nearly 1,000 admirers.
LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Sanctions cutting off Italian exports went quietly into effect today here and in all the far-flung colonies and dominions of the British Empire.

A dollar's return is yielded by every dollar given to a private hospital, but no such return is expected when the dollar is "publicly spent," it was declared by former Governor Alfred E. Smith in an appeal last night for the United Hospital campaign to raise a minimum of $2,000,000 for eighty-one constituent private hospitals.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 18. -- Unless railroads in the United States took immediate steps to effect slashing economies, the Federal Government would own them within a few years, Henry A. Palmer of Chicago, editor of Traffic World, said tonight in an address to the Richmond Traffic Club.
Mrs. Herbert C. Hoover and Mrs. Benjamin Harrison were among the guests of honor yesterday at the annual jubilee breakfast of the Daughters of Ohio in New York, at the St. Regis Hotel.

Sam Langford, former boxer, was injured seriously about 2:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon when he was knocked down by a taxicab while crossing Lenox Avenue at 135th Street. The Negro, who is partly blind, was taken to Harlem Hospital suffering from internal injuries.

Jersey City's mock trial of its citizens and officials for "laxity" in public health matters was prevented last night by 1,700 children who were not supposed to be present but once there, refused to give way for their elders. While Mayor Hague, judges and city officials waited, the youngsters booed all who tried to tell them that the meeting was not for children.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- For the third time since he announced that scrimmaging was over for the season, Head Coach Ducky Pond today gave the Yale varsity a fifteen-minute offensive contact drill. The wide, sweeping plays which netted eight touchdowns against Lafayette and the forward-passing play which has been the Blue's most effective ground gainer the past two seasons were employed.

Mayor LA GUARDIA told a Washington conference yesterday that the Federal Government will find it impossible to abandon its relief activities next July. He is probably right about that. Unemployment is declining as business activity expands; but there is not much chance that by next Summer it will have reached a point at which States and municipalities will be able to carry the entire burden by themselves.

Dr. Federico Pinedo, Argentine Minister of Finance, in a recent interview here, said the cash position of the Argentine Government was solid, that all her national debt services were being met and that general obligations to contractors for all public works were being discharged "faithfully and promptly."
BERLIN, Nov. 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement for Nov. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- An active demand for hogs here today from packers, both large and small, fully offset the effect of the largest receipts since last February and the market was quoted as steady to strong. The top price was unchanged at $9.70 a hundred weight and the day's average was the same as on Friday at $9.45.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

In THE TIMES last Sunday John Temple Graves 2d, your editorial correspondent of Birmingham, Ala., wrote freely, frankly and very impressively of the Scottsboro case, again acutely in the news because of a new indictment of the involved Negro youths handed up by a grand jury that included a Negro in its personnel.

Three New Jersey corporations, conducting most of their operations in this city and allegedly maintaining a monopoly of the poultry-handling business here, were served formally yesterday by Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, with assessments totaling $487,299.83.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18. -- Final hearing in the suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Whealton Company, Inc., of Philadelphia and more than thirty dealers and salesmen who are alleged to have participated in fraudulent sales of oil land trust certificates arranged by the Whealton Company, was continued today in Federal court here to an indefinite date in January.

Traffic accidents in New York City in the week ended Nov. 17 were 11 per cent fewer than in the corresponding period a year ago, according to figures made public yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine. Mr. Valentine also revealed that there were 16 per cent more accidents in the two-day weekend than during the corresponding week-end in 1934.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Weakness in wheat markets abroad and in Winnipeg had relatively little effect today on prices on the Board of Trade here, and while there was a decline of around 1 cent a bushel early, the loss was fully recovered and the December closed 1/5 cent higher than on Saturday, while the distant deliveries were unchanged.

Launching his campaign for a return meeting for the title with Danno O'Mahoney, Chief Little Wolf, Navajo Indian, defeated Jim Browning of Missouri in the feature wrestling match at Madison Square Garden last night before 3,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The crisis in North China is being watched closely here, but without any indications that active diplomatic measures or new policies are under consideration in view of Japanese plans to set up an autonomous State in North China.

Legislative changes which would add an estimated $700,000,000 of property now tax exempt to the tax rolls were recommended yesterday in a report of the Advisory Committee on Tax Exemption and Tax Inequalities, headed by Joseph Goldsmith.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP). -- Arthur Thurnblad, playing in the form that brought him the 1931 title, jolted Welker Cochran of San Francisco out of undisputed possession of first place in the world three-cushion billiards championship tournament tonight by defeating the Pacific Coast star, 50 to 37, in 45 innings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Managements of utility holding companies at this time are almost a unit in the decision not to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935, according to reports in utilities circles here today.

BOSTON, Nov. 18. -- Those in various industries who have studied the Canadian-United States tariff agreement sufficiently to comment on what effect it may have on business in New England agreed today that, to all appearances, that section stood to gain rather than lose, particularly in the cases of shipping and fishing.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18. -- Mrs. John D. Hertz's Our Reigh and Buckley M. Byers's Thorson were first in their respective divisions of the Robert Eden Handicap, feature event which was split into two sections today. By a coincidence both racers finished in the same time of 1:50 4-5 for the mile and a sixteenth, and each victor returned $8.60 for $2 to backers.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18. -- Herbert Hoover was quoted today by two officials of the Maryland Federation of Young Republicans as saying that he was not a candidate for the Republican nomination for President next year.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., were the successful bidders yesterday for a new issue of $11,379,000 of first mortgage bonds of Public Service Company of New Hampshire. The group bid 100.647 for 3 3/4 per cent bonds.

His Exalted Highness the Nizam of Hyderabad plans to present a radio set to each of his 20,000 villages in celebrating the twenty-fifth year of his reign next February, Syad Mahboob Ali, wireless director for the Hyderabad government, revealed yesterday in an interview at the Hotel New Yorker.

Since Frank Craven and June Walker are members of the cast, it would be courteous to pretend that "For Valor" in adult entertainment worth unfolding in a distinguished theatre like the Empire, where it was laboriously staged last evening. For the past three years Mr. Craven has been a renegade, banqueting in Hollywood.

Samuel Leibowitz, attorney for Vera Stretz, who is under indictment for the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, visited his client in the Women's House of Detention yesterday and later indicated the course the defense would take.

Architecture and the other arts will be emphasized in planning the 1939 World's Fair. George MeAneny, chairman of the preliminary fair committee, declared yesterday, speaking at the annual meeting of the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- After watching the Canadian-American trade negotiations with some uneasiness for the last fortnight, British exporters awoke today to find that the completed treaty had conferred unexpected benefits upon them.

Led by Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club, the national champion, the four top-seeded entrants in the invitation squash tennis tournament of the Princeton Club came through their quarterfinal tests successfully yesterday to gain places in the semi-final bracket.

MANILA, P.I., Nov. 18. -- Replacement with Filipinos of the few Americans remaining in the Philippine Government service was started today by President Manuel Quezon. He announced the reappointment of the six Filipino members of the Supreme Court, but failed to reappoint the five Americans.

Representatives of several Federal departments whose activities bring them in contact with maritime matters participated yesterday in the "Federal Day" program of the second annual Marine Exhibition at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street. The exhibition, held under the auspices of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, opened last Tuesday and will close tomorrow.

Elmer Rice, regional director of the WPA theatre project, insisted yesterday that his plans would provide employment for every actor in every unit that has been touring the CCC camps. These units were recently discontinued for the Winter.

Fairfield Osborn Jr., State Director for New York of the National Youth Administration, has resigned. In a letter which he mailed on Saturday to Aubrey Williams, national executive director, and which he made public here last night, Mr. Osborn charged that the Washington authorities had failed to provide a program and had failed to provide funds as promised for youths not attending schools or colleges.

Charles Miller, 27 years old, a truckman living at 507 East Eighty-second Street, pleaded not guilty yesterday morning before Magistrate Burke in the Traffic Court to a charge of operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated. He was released in $25 bail for a hearing tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Act, imposing processing taxes upon basic commodities, was an exercise of the constitutional power granted Congress to levy taxes for the general welfare, Attorney General Cummings contended in a brief filed with the Supreme Court late today.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The result of the elections brightened the Stock Exchange here today, as did the continued firmness in Wall Street, and there was another large turnover in international issues at rising prices. British funds were irregular, early strength giving way to profit-taking, Chinese and European issues were better in the foreign market.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Opinion was divided in Chicago today regarding the reciprocal trade treaty with Canada which is to go into effect on Jan. 1. Interests which depend largely on agriculture, particularly livestock, were not favorably inclined.

Edgar T. Appleby of New York and Edmund Soussa of Egypt will meet in a challenge match for the national Class A amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship, held by the latter, at the Metropolitan Billiard Club, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, starting tonight at 8:15 P.M.

The National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, opened its season last night in Carnegie Hall with a performance of Mendelssohn's "Italian" Symphony which could only have been surpassed in felicity and eloquence by some one of the leading orchestral bodies of this country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Expressing surprise at objection by creditors to his suggested modifications of the proposed plan for reorganizing the Middle West Utilities Company, principal holding company of the old Insull system, Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson indicated today that he will not approve any plan not in general accord with his suggestions.

This writer, a dirt farmer, doubts if laymen are giving sufficient thought to a practical, workable solution of agriculture's dilemma, providing the Supreme Court dismantles AAA in whole or part; or in case the New Deal is repudiated in 1936. Although agriculture is in the minority, the next election will certainly be decided by it.

SHREWSBURY, N.J., Nov. 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Dominick Stout of New York City and Rumson, N.J., were released in $1,000 bail each today in Shrewsbury Police Court on charges of illegal voting and perjury. Ivan Wardell of Rumson was released in $500 bail on a charge of aiding the violation of the law by driving an alleged voter to the polls on election day.

The attack on the tentative transit unification agreement between the I.R.T. and the Manhattan Railway Company and the city, made on Sunday by Harold Palmer, chairman of a protective committee of holders of unmodified guarantee 7 per cent stock of Manhattan Railway, was answered yesterday by Charles Franklin, general counsel of the Manhattan.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- A search for oil to make the British Navy independent of foreign supplies during wartime is to be commenced immediately over an area of 5,438 square miles in a dozen English counties, it was officially announced tonight.
PARIS, Nov. 18. -- All necessary steps have been taken by French authorities for the application of sanctions against Italy.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 19. -- The' declaration of an autonomous North China nation with Japanese protection may be "postponed" until Saturday while leaders of the movement study the reaction of the Chinese Government in Nanking, the Rengo News Agency announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- An order to cease price fixing and some other practices was issued against eighteen manufacturers of fire extinguishing equipment today by the Federal Trade Commission, which said that the companies consented.

Arthur S. Vernay and Suydam Cutting are returning today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria from an anthropological expedition to Tibet for the American Museum of Natural History, of which they are both trustees. They reached Lhasa on Oct. 5 and explored the great gorge 15,000 feet up in the Himalayas, where the sacred river Brahmapootra rises.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- Syracuse University announced today that it has leased one of the city's largest theatres as a home for its dramatic department, legitimate touring attractions, movies and children's theatre productions.

H.G. Wells came back to America on Thursday with the same Wellsian smile, the same calm, cheerful voice and youthful appearance. But this time he is here in a new role. It is not that of the Utopian novelist, the prolific historian or the genial appraiser of the New Deal, but as champion of the motion pictures.

Hopes of rebuilding Canadian-American trade to the $1,000,000,000 status it enjoyed before the depression were expressed here yesterday ruby exporters, who commended the administration on all phases of the reciprocal trade agreement.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- To any one familiar with present-day Germany it is quite obvious that the concerted tongue lashings administered to bolshevism in the abstract by Nazi leaders over the week-end had some other motive than a mere desire to rewrite recent German history.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 18. -- The death of Miss Evelyn Hoey, musical comedy actress who was fatally shot at the Summer home of Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d. on the night of Sept. 11, was declared a suicide today by a Chester County grand jury after a week's inquiry.

Could not those interested in the progress of the rehabilitation of Jerusalem reflect a ray of light for a "home" for Christian children there who are already in a very needy state for lack of funds? As one who has lived very close to the scenes of misery there, I can speak truthfully of this need.

Angelo Vlaco, a short man wearing horn-rimmed glasses and a wing collar, testified yesterday in Federal Court that he had been a shipping master of the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company for the last twenty-four years, although he could not read or write.

The issue of convertible bonds planned by the Great Northern Railway to retire $101,266,000 of general mortgage Series A 7 per cent bonds due on July 1 next will be offered first to stockholders, it was announced yesterday in a communication to stockholders.
Except for moderate activity in commercial paper at prevailing discounts, the demand for credit was small in other sections.

BALBOA, C.Z., Nov. 18. -- The largest flood in five years, rushing down the Chagres River into Gatun Lake and the Panama Canal at a rate of 7,200,000 cubic feet a min ute, is testing the recently completed Madden Dam, built to control such emergencies and to provide an additional storage of water during the dry season.

DUNDEE ISLAND, Antarctic Archipelago, Tuesday, Nov. 19. -- We are now completely ready for the start of the transantarctic flight. All yesterday the men hauled sled loads of material up the steep grade to almost the top of the island, and at last midnight, our time, the last of the gasoline and supplies were loaded into the airplane Polar Star.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Authority to issue and reissue $75,000,000 not to exceed 6 per cent interest promissory notes to be payable on demand, or such due date as may be specified, was requested by the New York Central Railroad Company in a petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 18. -- William G. (Billy) Evans, general manager of the Cleveland Indians for eight years, resigned today.
Harry Dublinsky, Chicago welterweight, gained the decision over Jimmy Leto of Hartford, Conn., in the ten-round feature bout last night at the St. Nicholas Palace.

ABROAD survey of the wide field shows Princeton, Dartmouth and N.Y.U. standing up in the East, Minnesota looming large in the Mid-west, Southern Methodist and Texas Christian running rampant in the Southwest and California cantering along on the Coast. All the other big teams have either been halted or thrown in "moving accident by flood or field."

Proving their contention that all that business needed was cold weather in order to push ahead, retail executives here reported brisk trade yesterday, with the turnover on Saturday generally described as notably good. Store representatives here expressed the view that the tide in local trade has now turned and that no serious setbacks are expected until the wind-up of the holiday trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Nov. 13 shows increases for the week of $64,000,000 in total loans and investments, $162,000,000 in demand deposits -- adjusted, and $112,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, Nov. 18. -- Disorder in the court room forced the suspension today of the opening session of the trial of three alleged Croatian terrorists, accused of complicity in the murder of King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Foreign Minister Louis Barthou of France in Marseilles on Oct. 9, 1934.

The possibility that Arturo Toscanini may retire as conductor and general musical director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the end of this season became known yesterday. The Italian conductor, one of the greatest musicians alive, will begin his tenth season at the head of the orchestra on Jan. 23 and end it on April 26.

Initial steps in a nationwide campaign to urge women to buy only coats and suits carrying a "consumer protection label," replacing the former NRA insignia and signifying the garments have been made under fair wage and hour standards, were taken yesterday at a luncheon meeting held under the auspices of the Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at the Women's City Club.

A campaign to keep bright the memory of operatic stars of other years by providing reduced-rate opera tickets in their names for impecunious music students and others "who have rendered honorable service in the field of music education but whose purges are too slim to stand the strain of ticket purchases at regular prices," was announced yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

Reassuring reports on the state of trade and industry -- some of them decidedly optimistic -- served yesterday to maintain active buying interest in stocks, although in the late trading profit-taking was pronounced, causing the list to close irregularly lower.

The State Conference of Mayors makes a convincing case against the flat 2 per cent over-all constitutional property tax limit advocated by real estate interests here. If applied in forty-eight cities, including New York, it would automatically create a deficiency of $147,000,000 annually.

While most of the comment heard from liquor interests was favorable to the new reciprocal tariff treaty with Canada, American liquor stock declined at the opening of the stock market yesterday on the announcement of the terms.

A purchase of industrial property for expansion featured the New Jersey trading reported yesterday. Samuel Hird Son, woolens and worsteds, bought two parcels totaling about five and one-half acres in Clifton from Louis Hammer, Inc. The property is for future expansion of a Clifton factory containing 100,000 square feet acquired from the Pennsylvania Textile Company, Inc., Louis Hammer, president, by the Hird firm, which has a plant in Garfield.

A Bronx apartment house resale by an operator was included in the urban realty transactions reported yesterday. Eight Manhattan parcels and one in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales. One Bronx building was taken over by a tenant.

Leaving behind it a coast line strewn from Cape Hatteras north-ward with the wreckage of seaside dwellings, of battered piers and boardwalks and of stranded fishing and pleasure craft, the northeaster that lashed the Atlantic Coast Sunday moved out to sea yesterday, while scores of communities began repairing damage estimated as running into millions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Organized labor put itself on record tonight against the further shipment to Italy of materials that might be used for war. President William Green of the American Federation of Labor called upon American industry to heed the warning of President Roosevelt that such shipments violated the spirit of the Neutrality Act.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18. -- Joseph Stalin, general secretary of the Communist party, closing the congress of 2,500 Stakhanoffites, smiled down upon the delegates from the speakers' platform today and said: ...

Secretary of Commerce Roper last night warned American shipping that it must be prepared to accept a compromise with the government in so far as Federal aid to the merchant marine is concerned, or witness the transfer of shipping control from private to governmental hands.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 18 (AP). -- Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared today a special dividend of one-fifty-fifth of a share of General Motors common to each share of du Pont common, payable on Dec. 27 to holders of record of Nov. 27.

Imposition of sanctions against Italy by members of the League of Nations yesterday produced only slight repercussions in the price of the lira, although the discount on the ninety-day forwards widened from 30 to 35 points. This marked the first break in the rates in several days.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- On the Bourse the week opened hesitant and irregular, with little business done. There was still considerable nervousness regarding the outcome of the difference between the government and the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies, which should be settled tomorrow.

Forced into idleness by last Sunday's rain, the Brooklyn Dodgers will oppose the Chicago Cardinals at Ebbets Field tonight in the first National Football League night game of the local season. The kick-off is scheduled for 8:30 o'clock.
Ten sandwiches may cost Earl Fairchilds, 36 years old, thirteen years in prison.

Dr. Emil Altman, chief medical examiner of the Board of Education, charged the Teachers Retirement Board yesterday with responsibility for the death last month of Edward Woticky, 55-year-old teacher at Public School 71, the Bronx. The retirement board, through its secretary, Louis Taylor, flatly denied the charge.

Arthur Krock, on Nov. 13, took issue with statements recently made by Frank Kent and George Van Slyke and others to the effect that just before election Federal moneys were sent into Kentucky in amounts equal to $40 per voter and into Poughkeepsie, N.Y., in amounts equal to $27 per voter.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator here, disclosed yesterday that WPA investigators had uncovered evidence of serious abuses in the transportation division of the WPA.

QUEBEC, Nov. 18. -- Another offer for Price Brothers Co., Ltd., bankrupt newsprint company, was reported today to be ready, with a Montreal syndicate as the prospective purchaser. Names were withheld, but it was said that O.T. Sweezy, who headed a syndicate which bid unsuccessfully for the company last year, was behind the new group.

Net profit of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation for the year ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $903,273, after Federal taxes and all charges. This is equivalent to $2.58 a share on 350,000 shares of capital stock outstanding. In the preceding fiscal year, the company showed a net profit of $463,212, or $1.32 a share.

Deputy Chief Inspector Michael A. Lyons, now in command of the uniformed force in Queens, will be elevated to the position of Third Deputy Police Commissioner on Dec. 2, it was revealed yesterday at police headquarters. He will be the departmental trial commissioner, succeeding Deputy Commissioner John A. Leach, who will retire because of age Dec. 1.
ST. PAUL, Nov. 18. -- A flood of criticism from agricultural leaders met the newly announced trade pact with Canada today, but a majority of business and industrial leaders declined to comment.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18.-- The Princeton football team, slightly disturbed by its unconvincing showing against Lehigh last week, settled down to serious work again today with a two-hour practice session in preparation for the Dartmouth test on Saturday.

Slow-motion pictures of the Army-Notre Dame football game, shown yesterday at the Pathe studios, failed to settle the argument over the play on which the Cadets were penalized for pass interference, close to the goal line, and the Ramblers thereby given their chance to score the tying touchdown in the last minute.

The city of Lancaster, Pa., awarded yesterday a new issue of $770,000 school district bonds to Gertler Co., Inc., and Stroud Co., Inc., both of Philadelphia, at a price of 101.57 for 24S, The bonds mature on Dec. 1, 1936 to 1955, and were reoffered to the public by the bankers at prices to yield from 0.40 to 2.15 per cent, according to maturity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- While nearly all of the four-billion work-relief fund appropriated by Congress has been allocated, only a fourth of that sum has been expended up to Oct. 31, the Treasury Department showed today in a review of emergency expenditures.

Making ready for its final game of the season, the traditional battle with New York University on Thanksgiving Day, the Fordham football squad learned yesterday that Nat Pierce, veteran guard, may not be able to go the route against the Violet.

Several card parties will be held this afternoon to raise funds for various charitable organizations. There has been a large subscription for the annual bridge and tea for the benefit of the philanthropic enterprises of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service to be held at the Plaza.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 18. -- Economic nationalism was strongly condemned as a fallacy, while internationalism in the fields of political and naval affairs was as strongly denounced in speeches delivered here today at the opening general session of the twenty-second annual National Foreign Trade Convention.

HAVANA, Nov. 18. -- A newly erected statue of Generalissimo Maximo Gomez, commander-in-chief of the Cuban forces during the war of independence with Spain, was unveiled here today in the presence of thousands who had gathered to pay homage to the patriot on the ninety-ninth anniversary of his birth.
OTTAWA, Nov. 18. -- Canada's reaction today to the new trade treaty with the United States was generally favorable.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin returned to 10 Downing Street today after two days of post-election rest and rumination at Chequers, flavored no doubt with a modest touch of self-congratulation on his great victory at the polls.
The New York Rangers will seek their first victory of the season on home ice tonight when they oppose the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden.
Two seeded players triumphed and two others were eliminated yesterday in second-round matches in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association amateur open tournament at the New York A.C.

The theory that football coaches require from two to three years to install their system of play appears to have been pretty well exploded this season, along with a lot of Rose Bowl hopes and reputations for invincibility.

Criticizing educational methods of most colleges and large universities, Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, president of Antioch College and chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, declared last night that these methods had left most of the people of the country at a "high school level" as far as general culture was concerned.

ATHENS, Nov. 18. -- With Rear Admiral Duriou in command, the cruiser Helle and the destroyers Psara and Hydra sailed from the naval base at Saloniki, tonight to Brindisi, Italy, with orders to bring King George II home.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 18. -- Penetration of the lower depths of the cerebral cortex, topmost layer of the brain and seat of higher intelligence, which reveals for the first time the existence of a separate electrical dynamo in each of the six individual layers of that forbidden no-man's-land of mind and matter, was reported before the National Academy of Science meeting at the University of Virginia for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- A number of trained observers and political fact-finders are already convinced that the decisive battle of the 1936 campaign will be fought on the great agricultural plain of the Midwest. If the Republicans can break the President's strength in the farming States of the Upper Mississippi Valley, these readers of the auguries feel sure Mr. Roosevelt will be defeated for re-election.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 18. -- In contradiction to Italian claims of the submission of Ethiopians in the occupied northern area, the Ethiopian Government announced today that the civilian population of the Enderta region near Makale had revolted against the invaders yesterday and were subsequently punished by an aerial bombardment.

DETROIT, Nov. 18. -- Speaking for business leaders in the Detroit area as a whole, Charles E. Boyd, secretary of the Retail Merchants' Association of the Board of Commerce, stated today that this country's reciprocal tariff agreements with Canada were particularly welcome to Detroit and Western Ontario merchants.

Faced with rising prices and a shortage of high-grade leather more than 350 buyers started to cover their initial Spring shoe requirements at the opening yesterday of the three-day style show of the Shoe Fashion Guild of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 18. -- George Ade, who is 70, told today how to be young.

An underwriting group consisting of E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., Burr Co., Inc., and Chandler Co., Inc., is offering today, at 93 3/4 plus accrued interest, $2,450,000 of first mortgage twenty-year 5 per cent bonds, series A, of Canadian Utilities, Ltd.

Sponsors of the movement to permit firms having membership in the New York Stock Exchange to incorporate, who have been more or less quiescent since last Spring, have renewed their pleas to officials of the Exchange to consider a constitutional amendment embodying this change.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- Sharp criticism of the Roosevelt administration for promoting a "philosophy of scarcity" was contained in what was described as a nonpartisan statement presented today at the annual meeting of the Methodist Board of Home Missions and Church Extension.

Moe Attel, publicity man for sports clubs, and David Gelenter, whose office was a bench in Madison Square Park, already convicted as loan sharks, were found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of additional charges of usury.
A decision of great interest to members of the wildfowling fraternity was handed down recently by Judge J. Earl Major in the United States District Court at Springfield, Ill.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York has been appointed as paying agent for principal and interest on an issue of the Village of Sloan, Erie County, N.Y., general 4 per cent bonds for the purpose of "constructing a concrete flume."

Greater New York's three major league ball clubs were preparing yesterday for the first important manoeuvres of the current off-season, the minor league convention, which opens officially tomorrow in Dayton. Ohio.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- The Court of Appeals was asked today by Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt to permit an appeal in the battle for the custody of her daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt. Papers submitted by Nathan Burkan, lawyer, cited several grounds for the appeal.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 18. -- The Italians are approaching Daggah Bur slowly along the Gorahai road, and have reached a point about thirty miles to the south, presumably, therefore, past Ane.

The Theatre Union will start its third season tonight by offering a version of Gorki's "Mother" at the old Civic Repertory Theatre. Bert Brecht based the play on the novel and Paul Peters translated it from the German into English; the music is by Harms Eisler.

Michigan State closed up the supposed wide-open championship cross-country race of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. tighter than a drum over the well-worn trails at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday as the Spartans won the twenty-seventh annual test with ridiculous ease.

Washington is already buzzing with reports that the Canadian reciprocity agreement will cut a large figure in next year's Presidential campaign. In both parties politicians are pricking up their ears about it. As the tariff is involved, Republican managers see an opportunity to make an issue again of protection.

A new issue of $40,000,000 Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation first and general-mortgage 4 per cent series bonds due in 1970 will be offered today through an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at 102 and accrued interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- A preliminary study of the Canadian trade agreement drew an opinion from Westerners in the capital today that livestock interests would not suffer from a reduction in the cattle tariff.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt praised the work of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at a rally luncheon of the women's division at the Hotel Commodore yesterday. She said that the great need today is for some one who will really study the problem of each individual.

The Warner Brothers have set back the opening of "Frisco Kid" from tomorrow to Saturday morning at the Strand. James Cagney has the principal role. Margaret Lindsay, George E. Stone and Ricardo Cortez assist.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The Boerse returned today to its normal condition of almost total inactivity and insignificance as an economic and financial barometer. Heavy industrials declined, Hoeseh and Harpener each losing 1 1/4 points. Potashes were firm, Salzdetfurth gaining 1 1/2 points.

Columbia turned its attention yesterday to its annual game with Brown here next Saturday, when the Lions will have their next to last chance to salvage a major victory from the 1935 campaign. Although the regulars had a rather easy time of it, Coach Lou Little sent the second-string team through a strenuous session in an attempt to build up reserve strength.

The old-fashioned hotel bathroom can be transformed in a few hours into a kitchenette for a modern apartment with an invisible kitchen and service pantry which utilizes the bath tub for a laundry hamper. This was demonstrated yesterday at the opening of the twentieth anniversary National Hotel Exposition in the Grand Central Palace.

ONE finishes Frederic Prokosch's "The Asiatics" (Harpers, $2.50) with a helpless tongue-tied feeling born of the fact that no critical cliches seem to fit this astonishing novel. Mr. Prokosch's prose is something like shot silk; it glints with a myriad hues that clash and blend, and the more one ponders it the more one is at a loss to decide whether the author has achieved perfect harmony or shrieking dissonance.

Most commodity futures were lower in the trading on the local markets yesterday. Cocoa and sugar were slightly firmer. On the cash markets wheat, rye and dairy products advanced, while corn, oats, silk, rubber and hides declined.

MANILA, Nov. 18. -- The United States owes and will always owe a moral obligation to the Philippines to defend them from attacks from without, Senator William H. King of Utah said tonight at a dinner given for the Congressional and newspaper delegations to the recent inauguration by the former Philippine Resident Commissioners to Washington.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18. -- Harvard's varsity football team today started preparations for its annual battle with Yale in a lengthy but not hard workout on chilly and damp Soldiers Field.

Public bodies sometimes find it difficult to decide whether to publish their reports on a calendar year or a fiscal year basis. The Transit Commission obligingly, though perhaps a trifle extravagantly, does both. The report for the fiscal year ending last June shows a slight increase in global intracity travel, elevated, underground and on the level.

A suit for $20,000 for information which is alleged to have led to the recovery of the jewels stolen from Mrs. Margaret Hawksworth Bell at the Miami-Biltmore Hotel at Coral Gables, Fla., on Jan. 26 was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Isidore Neuman.

Following is the text of the decision rendered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close in the suit of Doubleday, Doran Co., Inc., and Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Inc., against R.H. Macy Co.:

Governor LANDON has said more than once that it isn't "agreeable" to him to have his friends discuss his candidacy. The party, united if it can be, is the only thing that matters. Its counter, stocked with the right issues, is the only thing of moment. The man, the humble instrument that may be selected to lead it, is nothing.

The Yale Club, with two crack squash racquets players in its lineup, scored a sweep over the Essex Club as six of the eleven teams in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League started competition yesterday.
ROME, Tuesday, Nov. 19. -- Premier Benito Mussolini expounded war and politics for two hours last night to his Fascist Grand Council, but what he said was kept from Italy and the world.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Miss Virginia Rodgers was presented to society this afternoon at a tea given by her mother, Mrs. Philip Owen Coffin, at their home in S Street.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 18. -- Policemen prevented today's scheduled parade to the graves of student victims of recent anti-British disturbances here. Hundreds of mounted and foot police, all wearing steel helmets, guarded Opera Square, dispersing all gatherings.

GENEVA, Nov. 18. -- All was quiet here today as the economic sanctions decreed by the League of Nations against Italy went into effect. There seemed to be less instead of more activity than usual in the League building. No committees sat and the bulletin board scheduled no meetings for tomorrow.

Charles Williamson of the Police Athletic League of this city, captured a decision over Huel Goodwin from Philadelphia, in their 175-pound special intercity engagement on the card of amateur boxing staged at the New York Athletic Club last night before a capacity crowd.

Lehman Brothers and Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., will offer formally by prospectus today 38,375 of the 65,148 shares of common stock of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, at $19 a share.
