SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Nov. 19 (AP). -- An official source said today that Chinese authorities had been instructed "to be prepared for any eventuality," while rumors sped about that the Nanking Government was planning to adopt a bold front against the impending North China autonomy proclamation.

Creation of a Department of Nursing in the Columbia Medical School to direct the educational program of the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing was announced yesterday by Dean Willard C. Rappleye.

The most vivid narrative of actual fighting in Ethiopia was Mr. MATTHEWS'S account yesterday of the Italian dash across the Danakil salt desert and the battle at Ende. Not the least interesting feature in the story is the means of locomotion employed by General MARIOTTI'S flying column.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Consumers have no reason to fear that higher coal prices will follow the enforcement of the Guffey act, C.F. Hosford Jr., chairman of the Bituminous Coal Commission, declared today. He pointed out that the law vests authority in the commission to "establish minimum prices for coal in order to protect the consumer against unreasonably high prices."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19. -- What is regarded as the attitude of the steel industry toward government-supervised elections among plant employes was presented to the National Labor Relations Board today by Earl F. Reed of Pittsburgh, counsel to the Wheeling Steel Corporation.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 19. -- Two Ethiopian commanders, Fitaurari (vanguard commander) Bekele and Fitaurari Ayele, are moving south of the Italian position at Anale, according to a message received from the field wireless station in Southern Ogaden Province.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The British Government is showing more and more concern over events in the Far East, although it has not the least idea as to what the powers can do at present to prevent Japan from taking another huge slice of North China.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins was proposed as the next Democratic candidate for Mayor by Thomas J. McMahon, president of the National Democratic Club, at a beefsteak dinner for the jurist at the clubhouse, 233 Madison Avenue, last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Norman H. Davis was named today by President Roosevelt as chairman of the delegation that will represent the United States at the conference on naval limitation which will convene in London on Dec. 6.

A preponderance of sentiment among Stock Exchange member firms seems to be no less opposed to changing from partnerships to corporations than it was when the matter was last broached early this year. One of the principal objections is to the requirement that incorporated brokerage firms publish annual financial statements.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a gain over the previous week. However, the total was well below the corresponding week last year, according to the listings in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week numbered 697, as against 670 in the previous week and 745 in the same period a year ago.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin was summoned to Buckingham Palace this afternoon, presumably to be congratulated by King George on his big electoral victory and to tell the King of such few changes as may have to be made in Cabinet personnel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- The heaviest receipts of hogs for any Tuesday since last January depressed the general market 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight today, with the finish at the low point. A large part of the arrivals were new crop hogs weighing 190 to 225 pounds.

Harry F. Wolf, national amateur champion, and Rowland B. Haines, the runner-up last season, will meet again tomorrow in the final of the Princeton Club's invitation squash tennis tournament. They are scheduled to take the courts at the Princeton Club at 5:30 P.M.

Mrs. Selma Filtzer of Kew Gardens, Queens, whose husband was drowned on Sept. 8, 1934, when the Morro Castle burned off Asbury Park with a loss of 135 lives, told Federal Judge Murray Hulbert and a jury yesterday the story of a wedding trip that ended for her in tragedy.

Some Americans are heard to wonder at the resolution of the Italian people under the severe hardships which they have to endure. But this is to forget what we ourselves did in a time of national danger. War, or the threat of war, has a strange power to work changes in the whole temperament of the public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Refunding of the entire issue of outstanding first mortgage bonds at a lower rate of interest is being considered by the Virginian Railway Company, the Interstate Commerce Commission was advised today by W.T. Loyall, vice president and general solicitor.

After a considerable interval the Theatre Union has resumed activity with a play entitled "Mother," which was acted in Fourteenth Street last evening. The German playwright who signs himself plain Brecht has adapted and improvised it out of Gorky's novel of the same title.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Anglo-German relations have recently taken a course so much to Germany's liking that the occasion is deemed opportune to carry them a little further. Accordingly, a mild campaign against the inclusion of Winston Churchill in the new British Cabinet has started, obviously by a common inspiration, in the German press.

Roman Totenberg, the young Polish violinist, who came with considerable flourish of trumpets, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. His program was that of a serious and thoughtful musician. It offered three substantial compositions in a row that consumed a good hour of playing, and smaller pieces that were more than mere gew-gaws invented to win a hand from the gallery.

A sentence of three and one-half years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday on Max May, 48 years old, a former tailor, who, according to Irving W. Halpern, chief probation officer, is suspected of having been a professional setter of fires for ten years.

Early sculptures, small bronzes and paintings from India constitute an exhibition that is booked to remain at the Heermaneck Galleries, 724 Fifth Avenue, until Dec. 7, perhaps longer. It was arranged by the College Art Association and will travel about the country.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 19,. -- Canada produced 280,362 ounces of gold in September, or 35,585 ounces more than in the same month last year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics has reported. Production in the nine months ended with September amounted to 2,370,272 ounces, an increase of 8.4 per cent over the 2,193,831 ounces produced in the same period of 1934.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Pressure may be exerted on American companies through the Shipping Bureau of the Commerce Department to reduce oil shipments to Italy if it is found that the admonitions of President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull for a reduction in sales of war materials to the East African belligerents are not sufficiently observed.

A memorandum purporting to have an important bearing on the affairs of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company was read in General Sessions Court yesterday by Special Assistant District Attorney Lawrence S. Lesser.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Police guarded the banquet hall of a downtown hotel today as Dr. Hans Luther, the German Ambassador, advocated expansion of free trade between nations.

The guns of duck hunters in New York, Connecticut and other States in the northern zone were silenced at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon as the thirty-day period allotted by the Federal authorities came to an end. The season for the southern zone, which includes New Jersey, will open at 7 A.M. today and close on Dec. 19.
